title: On Protecting Life in Global Health Assistance
content:
article by Alysun Littlefield

On February 7th, the US State Department released a six-month review of the policy that Trump has dubbed “Protecting Life in Global Health Assistance.” The name might be different, but we know this policy well; originally dubbed the “Mexico City Policy” by Reagan in 1984, it is now more widely known by feminists and women’s rights advocates as the global gag rule.

So what does this policy do? While the US already banned foreign aid from being used for abortion services in 1973 (which is insane in and of itself), the global gag rule takes this further and says that any NGOs that use their own, non-US funds for providing abortion access will have their aid cut off. As the United States is the largest development aid funding country in the world, cutting off this kind of assistance can have significant impacts. These NGOs must certify they none of their funding goes to:

  • Providing abortion services
  • Counseling patients about the option of abortion or providing referrals for abortions
  • Training abortion providers
  • Advocating for the liberalization of abortion laws

Multiple studies show that this policy does not reduce the overall abortion rates, but instead just the number of unsafe abortions.

Trump’s reinstatement of this law is not surprising. Since it’s first conception, every Democrat that’s been elected has repealed it and every Republican has reinstated it, which is a huge problem for NGOs working on these issues because changing US politics can hinder any kind of growth they achieve and make long term projects hard to justify investing in. Trump’s version of this policy, however, is particularly heinous. Under previous Republican administrations, this policy rescinded around $575 million, while Trump’s more strict policy has taken away an estimated $8.8 billion as it has been applied to funding support for family planning and reproductive health, maternal and child health, nutrition, HIV/AIDS—including The President’s Plan for Emergency Relief for AIDS (PEPFAR), prevention and treatment of tuberculosis, malaria (including the President’s Malaria Initiative), infectious diseases, neglected tropical diseases, and even to water, sanitation, and hygiene programs.

The February 7th review of this policy in no way took into account the actual impact that it is having on women’s health around the world and instead focused solely on how effectively the policy has been implemented. As this policy has only been fully implemented for six months, many NGOs have not yet renewed their grants, so it’s likely that even more money will be denied to these institutions in the coming months.

So what do these impacts actually look like? If an NGO uses half of its funding for reproductive health and referrals for abortion but uses the other half for vaccinations, nutritional supplements and HIV/AIDS treatment, the group now has to choose between shutting down half of their programs or losing all of their US funding. Complications from pregnancy and childbirth are the second leading cause of death in the world for ages 15-19 and the World Health Organization estimates that at least 22,000 women die from abortion-related complications every year. Those rates will only get worse. The US provides nearly 50% of the world’s HIV/AIDS funding and this policy will impact the quality and availability of screenings and care.  Thousands of people now do not have access to care and Trump’s review doesn’t even take this into account because he doesn’t care about the lives of woman around the world. Hell, he doesn’t care about the lives of woman here. Until there’s another Democrat in office, this won’t be changing soon.

title: On USSF’s Hiring Process // Sports
content:
There’s Hardly a Reason to Criticize the Berhalter Hire, But Many to Question USSF’s Hiring Process 

article by Ben Hunter

After being rumored as the frontrunner for the vacant USMNT job for last 14 months, former USMNT defender and current Columbus Crew boss Gregg Berhalter was announced as head coach by USSF on December 2. Berhalter played collegiately at UNC and then had a lengthy playing career in Europe, featuring for the likes of Crystal Palace, 1860 Munich, Energie Cottbus, as well as three Dutch sides. He became the first American to manage in Europe when he took over Hammarby in 2011. He was fired in 2013 and took over the Crew, where he has been since.

There are several surface level reasons to criticize this hire; however, it is far more complex than the twitter warriors portray it to be. People say that he wasn’t that successful so far as a head coach and that his brother, Jay, is COO of US Soccer. It’s hard to determine the validity of this criticism for one simple reason: USSF’s hiring process had next to no transparency. It’s also hard to assign blame for this lack of transparency. Carlos Cordeiro wasn’t elected president until February, and Earnie Stewart didn’t begin his job as GM until August. This is the biggest issue from my perspective; Cordeiro and USSF needed to have a GM working sooner to finalize our head coach sooner. Bruce Arena resigned on October 13, 2017, and it made sense why we would wait to hire a head coach. Dave Sarachan could handle the job for a little while, and we could look to get a coach who may become available at the end of the club seasons or World Cup. This did not happen, and the top candidate from the list of American names was ultimately selected months later.

USSF really dropped the ball during this hiring process, leading loads of unnecessary pressure being put on Berhalter. There was a 33 person shortlist, which was trimmed down to 11, and it’s unknown how many interviewed. The only two who are confirmed to have interviewed were Berhalter and Oscar Pareja, who just moved on from FC Dallas for Tijuana. It is rumored that there was a third candidate interviewed, but no one knows for sure. By not interviewing more candidates, USSF implies that Berhalter is such an incredible candidate that it’s not worth interviewing the likes of Peter Vermes, Tab Ramos, Jesse Marsch, Juan Carlos Osorio, or Julen Lopetegui (who reached out to the federation). Another name that I wish the federation reached out to is Arsene Wenger, since I think his play style would be perfect for developing our young attacking talent, but that’s a debate for another day.

It is clear as day that Jay Berhalter’s presence impacted the decision to hire his brother, no matter how much USSF insists he was not involved in the process. It’s not possible to think that a coach who did respectably—but by no means incredibly—as an MLS head coach is such a good candidate that hardly any others need to be interviewed.

Additionally, USSF put even more unnecessary pressure on Berhalter by taking 14 months to find a new coach since the catastrophic failure to qualify. This is not his fault, but it adds even more scrutiny to his job. USSF makes it even more clear that he was the top candidate all along, as they waited for him to finish his MLS season. MLS shouldn’t take priority, period. There was a major wasted opportunity here because Berhalter should’ve been put in charge in August, so that he could prepare for the three fall international breaks. The USMNT had six friendlies, each of which was against a good team. It was good to see Sarachan playing the youngsters; however, it would’ve been even better if they were playing in the system that Berhalter wants to utilize in the foreseeable future. Also, veterans like Bradley and Altidore should’ve been re-integrated under the new coach, so that they could provide experience and mentorship to young guys, while they all adapted to a new coach and system. There are only about 10 international games per year, excluding summer tournaments, so I think the opportunity to have played 6 games against top-tier opposition would’ve been invaluable. From my perspective, the media is not talking about this opportunity that USSF wasted enough. It is especially confusing since the hiring process took so long, but its length doesn’t seem to be justified from what we know.

Despite all of these questions and criticisms of the process, Berhalter may turn out to be an excellent hire. Actually, I think he is the right man for the job. I would’ve liked to have seen Peter Vermes considered, as I think his achievements at Sporting KC are very solid, and I wish we knew more of any foreign candidates considered. Overall though, I think it is good we hired an American. With our identity severely damaged, we needed someone who understands the US Soccer system and what it means to represent your nation in a sport that may not be on top, but is rising and has the power to influence people. Additionally, Christian Pulisic said he just wants someone who has a tangible plan on how to turn around the program. Berhalter will have a plan in mind without any doubt. He served as both head coach and technical director in Columbus, and he worked with a below-average budget, so having a plan was critical. His record may not be incredible with a 74-69-50 MLS record, but when you consider the market he worked in and the fact he made four playoff and one MLS Cup appearance, it is impressive.

All things considered, Berhalter is a slightly lackluster but solid hire for USMNT head coach. Criticism has come from the media for the outlined reasons; some of it may be justified, but that doesn’t mean Berhalter doesn’t have what it takes to lead what will hopefully be a
successful USMNT period. He will certainly be prepared to coach this team in the upcoming cycle with a new plan and identity. All he has to do to silence the critics is one thing: win.

title: Latinx Punks’ Style Against Societal Norms
content:
Article by Samantha Garduno

Photographs by Karina Jaramillo and Kelvin Cerezo

In the United States, white supremacist and patriarchal ideologies create societal norms causing a struggle for survival among marginalized youth. Latinx kids from Los Angeles are currently trying to create their own space in order to openly perform their identities and ideas in an oppressive society. The punk genre is a loud and fast-paced form of music that speaks about the failures of society. Classism, Sexism, and Racism are all issues that limit the growth of marginalized youth. This genre encourages rebellious youth movements against oppressive social norms and government institutions. The punk scene is a form of spatial entitlement and sonic space among Latinx youth trying to survive in Los Angeles. The rebellious aspect of the punk scene is shown through Latinx fashion; their style is considered as nonconforming. The dark “edgy” clothes worn by these youth is critical in giving the space meaning and allows the representation of Latinx punk identities. Conservative adults look down upon Punk Latinx groups because they look intimidating and problematic. However, interacting with these Latinx Punks and hearing their stories it reveals how empowered they are by claiming a space that is rarely inclusive towards their identity.

The aggression and rebellion that is seen through Latinx Punk style is a product of marginalized kids’ creation of subcultures in order to help them survive discrimination and racism. Their styles showcase empowerment and unity among Latinx youth. They are able to separate themselves from mass culture to seek their own individuality. In the following photos, I will present some images from the OC Punk Fest of Latinx youth embodying the punk culture. At the fest, I asked them to introduce themselves, share their identities, and why the punk subculture is important to them. After hearing their stories, I learned that these Latinx punks are visionaries and want to present themselves through their fashion, ideas, and music. They are making an impact in today’s society by being themselves.

Left to Right: Jagger Age 16, Sydney Mendez Age 16, Rodrigo Hernandez Age 15, Daisy Gonzales Age 16, Andrew Hernandez Age 17 (Shot by Karina Jaramillo)

Sidney Mendez: “My name is Sidney, I’m 16 years old. I live in Placita. I’m Latina and Columbiana. Punk is something that has been a part of my life because it runs in my family. My mom was in a band when she was younger and so she taught me basically everything she knows about punk music. It’s basically something that I’ve been listening to my whole life and never got over it.  Punk music is more than just listening and liking how it sounds, it makes me feel alive because of how my adrenaline rises. It’s a contest feeling of happiness for me and it brings me and my friends closer because we share the same interest in music.”

Left to Right: Aurora Zavala Age 20, Karina Perez Age 20, Leslie Mayorga Age 19 (Shot by Karina Jaramillo)

Aurora Zavala: “My name is Aurora Zavala I’m 20 years old I’m latina. The way I dress is inspired by some of my favorite musicians from the ‘80s and of course, I incorporate my own taste into it. It’s important to me because I feel like it represents everything that I like.”
Karina Perez: “Well hi my name is Karina Perez I’m 20 years I live in South Central Los Angeles. I’m Latina. Well for me it’s a representation of who I am what I like and it’s important to me because I’m representing the punk scene in some way since we are underrepresented and not really paid attention to an extent. It also represents us female since it’s very dominated by males and shows that females do exist in the punk scene that were out here changing the scene and representing it. And also it is a part of me and my style and who I am as a person.”
Leslie Mayorga: “My name is Leslie Mayorga I’m 19 years old and I’m from Los Angeles, I identify as Hispanic. My style varies a lot it’s usually lots of black 80s-esqué garments like dresses, trousers, blazers, etc. I love jewelry too! I’ve made earrings and stuff like that. I feel like the reason I like to dress the way I do has a lot to do with how I express myself and want to physically project myself to others, a lot of times people stare at me and mad dog me and I know the reason for that is because of how I look (dress, hairstyle, makeup) and in a way making people angry or uncomfortable in that sense can be liberating because it’s obvious that if someone feels threatened it’s because they are looking at something they don’t know or even bother to understand/respect and I find it kinda funny and kinda sad how people can be so judgmental. Part of it too is that I just love putting outfits together and adding little details. Fashion and style can be very empowering.”

Far Right: Ramon Torres Age 19 (Shot by Karina Jaramillo)
Ramon Torres: “Ramon Torres (19) Hispanic. My style is a mix of 90s grunge/punk/hipster style. It’s just a combination of all the things I enjoy listening to or things I find appealing to wear. Usually set myself apart from the general population that wears the new high-end brands while I just thrift most my stuff to save money and mix it up. My style is significant to me because it gives a satisfaction that I don’t look like everyone else and it gives me confidence. This is basically saying to everyone else “This is me, I dress weird and that’s okay.” I always had a sense of style, however, my current style was influenced by OC punk scene going on right now where punk is still seen as abnormal and crazy!”

Anai Mata, Age 19 wearing a distress Black Flag Police Story shirt and a cheetah print skirt (Shot by Karina Jaramillo)
Anai Mata: “Anai Mata, age 19, born Chula Vista raised Moreno Valley, I am Mexican American, first language Spanish. My style has a lot of rock and roll roots, my dad was a metal head and I would see pictures of him; he’d talk about the music but in very little interest. When of course I was interested. He has the photo of him and his old friend and they’re both in heavy leather jackets and hightop Nikes; I thought it looked badass. Anyway, music wise I started off listening to Rage Against the Machine when I was 5 years old and from there  I built up a style, you know. My first punk bands were The Adolescents, Conflict, The Casualties, The Clash, and Circle Jerks. I always thought about the punk scene/music was revolutionary. The style itself was fucking everyone off right and it was an outcast thing. That’s goes with me. My parents didn’t let me dress myself under up to 5th grade and I would dress casual. At the age of 12 through 15, I was making my own shit(jeans, cut shirts and shit like that). I started attending backyard shows at 13 because my brother had this band, so therefore I was exposed to the Moreno valley punk/ska/indie. It was all mixed in from what I remember. Throughout high school I had my docs and patches I shaved my hair into a tri-hawk and would wear it up every day. My dad has beat me up because of the way I would dress and stuff. It wasn’t cool but it’s important because it shows the ones that want to see you “normal” or “una pinche niña adolescente” like it’s a big FUCK”

Nathan Salazar Age 15 (Shot by Kelvin Cerezo)
Nathan Salazar: “My name is Nathan Salazar.  I am 15 years old and I’m from Long Beach, California. I am Hispanic and Guatemalan. My style isn’t exactly the same as everyone else; I like to dress in my own way where I feel comfortable. I like to paint my nails black and wear docs and tuck in my shirt with cut sleeves and wear a bandana around my leg. I paint my nails and wear the bandana because I hate the fashion now and everyone looks the same and it bugs me. I just try to do the opposite like painting my nails to show that I don’t care that “painting your nails is for females. ” The scene is important to me for many reasons. I’m glad punk rock is still thriving because if it weren’t I would be one bored mf but also it gives me a reason just to go out and be with people I can call my friends because we all feel the same about things and how we think people on the outside are. I’m thankful for the scene because how it brings us together in every way not just through feeling but through the love for punk rock and without the scene I don’t even think I’ll have my own band, The Neurotics, and it encourages me and my band just go hard every time we play because we can’t look sorry. I love the people in it yeah everyone’s not perfect but the people I’ve met I’m thankful for that people are really humble.”

title: Why the Oscar’s Don’t Mean Sh*t
content:
article by Adrian Tapia

That golden statue. That 13.5 inches tall award that almost every actor wishes to be handed. That 8.5-pound gold-plated object that gets so much attention.

The Academy Awards, or the Oscars, is a prestigious night watched worldwide by millions of fans and thousands in the film industry. This special afternoon honors those working in film, congratulating them on their artistic merit and technical achievements. It is a night to celebrate all things Hollywood.

But if the Academy Awards are really meant to award cinematic accomplishments, then how did Suicide Squad beat Star Trek Beyond in Best Make-Up and Hairstyling. Was Jared Leto’s poorly designed, face-tatted, hipster looking Joker really better than Star Trek Beyond’s heavily researched, carefully molded, beautifully crafted characters?? How about Brave? Was Pixar’s generic, slow-paced Brave really a better-animated film than Laika’s stop-motion, creative, unique film Paranorman? And finally, how in god’s name did Shakespeare in Love beat Steven Spielberg’s incredibly realistic, emotionally driven Saving Private Ryan??? I’ll tell you how. Money and campaigning. I will be providing the links to where I got this information if y’all doubt me and shit.

Studios do this thing called “For your consideration campaigns.” In this tactic, studios spend millions of dollars, even up to 10 million dollars, pushing their films to Academy members through free screenings of the films, meet and greets with the actors and directors, and even smear campaigns against other films. Studios will track where Academy members live or even vacation, and throw free screenings by there. Denzel Washington even admitted to and made fun of this tactic in his acceptance speech for a Golden Globe, stating, “Freddy Fields invited me to my first Hollywood Foreign Press luncheon. He said, ‘You’re gonna take pictures with everybody, you’re gonna hold up the magazines, take the pictures, and you’re gonna win the award… I won that year.’” To put the cherry on top of this ridiculous and infamous strategy, Harvey Weinstein came up with it. Yeesshhhh.

See, receiving an Oscar doesn’t truly reflect one’s achievements. It demonstrates the amount of money the studio put in, for one to get that gold-plated statue. As the “For your consideration campaigns” get more expensive, the value and worth of the Academy Awards will go down. This way it doesn’t mean shit.

No one has said this better than the show “Adam Ruins Everything” with the line:

“Money can’t act!”

“No, but it can make voters act differently.”

title: Climate change, system change, and… education change?
content:
article by Sophia Donskoi

What do schools, climate change, and all 50 states have in common? Nothing, inherently. That’s surprising, considering the United States is one of the world’s main contributors to climate change. Fortunately, the country is beginning to adopt policies that work toward more sustainable goals, such as sourcing renewable energy and banning single-use plastics. Scientists, politicians, and both the public and private sectors recognize the unavoidable impacts of climate change, but many districts around the country refuse to teach climate science to the generations that will be most affected by it. Education is vital to the understanding of climate change, and we must arm students with the necessary knowledge to help continue the United States’ progress toward sustainability.

Education policy is under the jurisdiction of the state, not federal, governments. Various national policies such as the bipartisan No Child Left Behind Act have attempted to remedy discrepancies among varying state educational standards. Both teachers’ unions and educational reform advocates agree that these standards should be uniform to make the jobs of teachers more manageable and benefit students.

Forty-six percent of Americans believe their country’s education in science, technology, engineering, and math is “below average,” according to a Pew Report. These Americans wouldn’t be far from correct, considering 20% of American 15 year-olds had low proficiency in science, falling short of international standards. It’s unfortunate that we haven’t yet found a solution that will push students ahead in one of the most important fields of their time. Unsurprisingly, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the two fastest-growing jobs in the U.S. are both science and climate-related: solar panel installers and wind turbine technicians. Clearly, students could benefit from not just science education, but climate education in particular. 

Some states like Wyoming (the state with the most carbon emissions per capita, surprise!) refuse to mandate climate change education— likely because informing students could lead to downfalls in the states’ oil and coal industries. But a downfall in those industries is exactly what America needs. By educating all students in this country on the foundations of climate change, we can effectively prepare them for what lies ahead: a climate-conscious economy and workforce. The journey to organized climate education isn’t long or arduous, considering a team of 40 scientists has already developed a system that’s been adopted in 26 states. Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) set standards for science courses that emphasize the human contributions to climate change and its effects on the Earth.

We need a national movement toward the NGSS so we can implement standards across state borders as soon as possible. Climate change is inevitable, so why can’t climate education be? Students have a right to know what lies ahead for them and their posterity as much as they have a right to learn in school, regardless of which polluting companies monopolize their individual states. When we adopt Next Generation Science Standards nationwide, we can leave the country united against the biggest problem facing humanity.

title: On Steve Alford // Sports
content:
By Holding onto Steve Alford, UCLA is Accepting Mediocrity and Underachievement for its Legendary Basketball Program

article by Ben Hunter

Ever since the day Steve Alford was hired in Westwood, he had his critics for a fair reason. It began because of his mishandling of a sexual assault case while at Iowa, and it has continued since it has become apparent he is a mediocre coach. There was some justification for holding onto Alford after another underachieving season last year, going out in the First Four to St. Bonaventure. The reasoning hinges on the fact that Alford has been a decent recruiter, and he has steered clear of scandals that have recently plagued college basketball. Despite this, holding onto him is still not justified. 

All things considered, Alford’s successful recruiting is nothing to be applauded. His standard of recruiting should be the expectation. UCLA is a college basketball blue blood, with the most all-time championships at 11. John Wooden, one of the greatest coaches in all of sports, and legends of the game like NBA all-time scoring leader Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Bill Walton, and Reggie Miller, among others, made their names here. In addition, UCLA is located in Westwood, one of the best areas in all of Los Angeles, which is already a destination for recruits and an extremely fertile recruiting ground. Because of this prime location and esteemed culture of winning, recruiting a top-10 class every year should be the expectation, not something to be praised. 

The FBI probe has shown the dark side of college basketball over the last year or two. UCLA has kept its nose clean, which actually is something to be applauded. However, we should still be firing Alford, because almost any coach would be better than him, even if it meant eliminating preferred candidates who we can’t be sure are innocent in this investigation. Even if UCLA hired a coach who had to be fired, Alford has underachieved so much that this hypothetical program turnover would still be better, assuming the contract is properly structured so that firing a coach with cause results in no compensation to him. Following an exit from last year’s tournament to a St. Bonaventure side with significantly less talent and resources, the fact that Alford was retained essentially condones the fact that for four out of five years of Alford has led underachieving teams. Names like Nevada’s Eric Musselman and then Xavier’s Chris Mack seemed like no-brainers to be willing to come to Westwood and be more successful Alford, but Alford was held onto. 

Only in the 2014-15 has Alford’s team outperformed its projection. That actually might not be the case, as the argument can be made that they underperformed during the regular season. The team featured the likes of Kevon Looney, Norman Powell, Isaac Hamilton, and Tony Parker, so a Sweet Sixteen exit could hardly be considered an overachievement. The year before’s team featured three first-round draft picks in Jordan Adams, Kyle Anderson, and Zach LaVine, and they went out in the Sweet Sixteen. UCLA missed the tournament altogether in 2015-16, which had plane banners flying overhead saying “March Madness is not firing Steve Alford.” The much-hyped Bruins in 2016-17, featuring Lonzo Ball, TJ Leaf, Tom Welsh, Aaron Holiday, Isaac Hamilton, Bryce Alford and more went out in the Sweet Sixteen after looking for most of the year like they had championship-caliber talent. Last year, as explained, we lost to St. Bonaventure, who in no scenario, considering last year’s squad, should we have lost to. The shock of losing this match due to the name brands alone could result in a coach’s firing. 

This many years of underachievement can’t be a coincidence. It all points back to one thing: coaching. It’s also not as if we don’t witness the lack of coaching. Alford’s hesitance to call timeouts, make in-game adjustments, and his look of bewilderment during games have become jokes and “memes” among UCLA fans. Alford doesn’t call timeouts early in opposing teams’ scoring runs to stop their momentum, despite this being standard practice in the basketball world; presumably, this is because he doesn’t know how to address it during the timeout. This could be seen in Las Vegas over Thanksgiving early in the game versus Michigan State. Last night versus Notre Dame, Notre Dame switched to a 2-3 zone in the second half, and UCLA couldn’t figure out how to break it, a common theme during Alford’s tenure. The team looked bewildered, operating out of a 3-high, 2 low, look which is a common zone offense. However, instead of featuring quick ball movement, handoffs from the guards, flashes to the short corner and high post from the post players, or zone screens from the bigs, they stood around and played sluggishly. No adjustments were made, and UCLA resorted to contested jumpers, allowing Notre Dame to get back into the game. A clutch shot from Kris Wilkes won it at the horn, but that shouldn’t hide the fact that this game was close because of a lack of preparation and in-game coaching, and because it was close, this win will likely not boost our tournament resume, since Notre Dame has looked weak this year. 

UCLA should be the gold standard of college basketball, alongside Duke, UNC, Kentucky, and Kansas. Instead, UCLA is an underachieving basketball program who usually brings in some talent, fails to accomplish much, and sees that talent move onto the NBA. Our last sustained period of success occurred under Ben Howland when we made three straight final fours from 2006-2008. Howland achieved much more than Alford and was fired for much less, although his recruiting suffered towards the end of his tenure, resulting in less talented teams. Regardless, Steve Alford must be shown the door at the end of this year in Westwood, if not sooner, unless he makes a surprising run in March. This team probably has Elite 8talent on it, but the performances so far look like we’ll be lucky to win one or two games in the tournament. 

At the end of the day, winning is what matters to the fans for all sports in Westwood, especially basketball. Dan Guerrero and UCLA athletics, though, seem to be sending messages that this is not the case. There is a reason so many protest banners have flown over our beautiful campus over the last few years. Barring an impressive finish to this season, Steve Alford must be relieved of his duties, and UCLA must invest in a top-tier coach who has proven ability and is capable of restoring Bruin Basketball to its former greatness.

title: Gunz n Butter // Music News
content:
Article by Sophia Donskoi

When I saw the song “Gunz N Butter” on A$AP Rocky’s album the day of its release in May 2018, I was surprised. The title immediately took me back to my high school economics class (shout out to you, Mr. Torres), where we learned that the analogy of “guns and butter” referred to the allocation of government spending on defense (“guns”) and civilian resources (“butter”). A$AP Rocky is a famously apolitical artist, who on numerous occasions has responded to reporters’ political questions with comments such as “don’t ask me no shit like that on camera sweetheart,” and his release of a song like “Gunz N Butter” was seemingly out of character. However, Testing in itself is a more experimental, creative step out of Rocky’s comfort zone, who for a good portion of the album’s production, created music under the influence of psychedelics. The meaningful lyricism of the song cites spirituality, the current presidency, and inequity in society, but the music video takes the entirety of “Gunz N Butter” even further with its powerful visuals.

The opening shot is Rocky sitting atop an old Mercedes marked with his signature black and yellow car testing dummy symbol. The camera zooms to the windows of the car, on which videos of the dummies play. The faceless, child-sized dummies sit in a classroom, where the sounds of gunshots fire in the background as a teacher dummy “teaches”. An explosion occurs, and viewers are taken to a commercial for “Guns & Butter Lights” cigarettes which are marketed by a white man as “fresher, smoother, bolder.” This is likely Rocky’s commentary on big tobacco and big corporations taking advantage of the public.

The theme of the inherent power and evil of large corporations continues as music resumes and the video cuts to a factory farm with thousands of chickens, then a meat processing plant, then a dark cattle pen, and finally to hanging cow carcasses. A$AP Rocky portrays the meat process as unethical, disturbing, and grotesque in a matter of seconds as the cuts are paired with the dramatic sound of gunshots that are a part of the song. Rocky himself is a known vegetarian and once said, “you gotta go do research on the way they treat like f*****g chickens, man. Those chickens go through f*****g torture before they’re processed and s**t, have all sorts of f*****g steroids injected in them and everything.” Clearly, Rocky wanted to portray his beliefs and expose the cruelty with the platform that his new video, which is currently over _____ views utilizes.

The video then makes a switch to a different kind of processing: information and technology. Newspapers run across a printing press and a 3D Printer quickly prints a gun,  drawing a comparison between the availability and prevalence of news in America and the availability and prevalence of guns in America. Phone screens move down a manufacturing belt, followed by a bird’s eye of what looks to be a packaging warehouse with employees dressed in yellow. This warehouse is presumably one run by a large corporation such as Amazon that takes advantage of warehouse workers and brings up questions about the conditions of said employees. There is a quick shot to a large, Walmart-esque store with “G&B” signs and customers milling through it like they are no longer human. Through this series of shots, Rocky again pushes the agenda that large corporations are taking value from society and pushing an agenda that dehumanizes and desensitizes America.

The camera zooms out on a group of Navy sailors holding rifles through the lens of the barrel of a handgun being cleaned by a white teenage boy. The boy’s room is postered, one of which reads “The Golden Butter,” another analogy to the large “G&B” corporation. The shot is ominous as nobody knows (but everyone can assume) what the boy will do with his gun. There is a quick moment of comedic relief as the shot reveals a man and a woman holding a glass of rose quickly having sex in the kitchen. Children who are the testing dummies come-to-life smoke G&B cigarettes in a sterile room with their arms tied through straps on their jumpsuits; they are helpless, yet tough. A white man in camo, a distinctly Southern pattern, drives his adolescent son who is holding a rifle on the back of his pickup truck. The features of both of the young white men with guns in this portion of the video scream “school shooter.” According to a Mother Jones database of U.S. mass shootings since 1982, 54 percent US mass shootings have been carried out by white men.

Rocky crowd surfs through a performance during his next shot of comedic relief that includes an ad-lib from Yams day in 2018, where an altercation occurred backstage and A$AP was called by Hector Delgado to address it. Next, a young boy in a Christian household peacefully eats his cereal as outdoors a group of Ku Klux Klan members assembles. Rocky’s most political line in the song plays: “So get up off my YKK [a euphemism for Rocky’s genitalia alluding to the biggest zipper manufacturer in the world], the President a a-hole (fuck off) Prayin’ for a JFK, all we got was KKK.”  The KKK members burn a cross, and consequently, themselves. They are a self-destructive result of the society that has created them.

Some heavily tattooed, and again, white, males clean handguns nonchalantly in a kitchen. Around their neighborhood, a large squadron of snipers walks toward a large and powerful structure with the Testing symbol on it. Perhaps they were sent by the government to remove the dissenting Testing experimental thinkers while they blindly miss (or ignore) the injustices that occur in their plain sight. A$AP Rocky is seen off where he started on the Testing car which now plays American commercials on the windows, and in the last few seconds, Rocky breaks through the front windshield.

title: International Observe the Moon Night
content:
article and photographs by Sophie Taylor

Many of us have a special relationship with the moon, whether it be religious, spiritual, emotional, or professional. I grew up in awe of her soft, hazy glow, sitting for hours just to watch the moon rise, changing from a deep, earthen orange to an ethereal white as she made her way across the night sky. Flash forward to the present, where I’m lucky enough to get to work closely with the moon within the Earth Planetary and Space Sciences department here at UCLA, cataloging her cratered surface.

October 20, 2018 was International Observe the Moon Night (IOTMN), and the EPSS Department jumped at the chance to share the amazing work we do here with the general public! They set up multiple telescopes, some pointed at the moon and some pointed at Mars, for students, teachers, and families alike to gaze through. Actual lunar samples from the Apollo missions could be viewed under microscopes, and attendees had the chance to observe models of instruments aboard the spacecraft (including a lunar drill, and a cushion Apollo Lunar Lander Seat that would have been used by the Apollo astronauts!). To aid in the learning experience, lunar experts roamed around, making themselves available to answer any and all questions and explain the work done here at UCLA.


The event was a huge success–we had hundreds of people across every age range show up to celebrate the beauty and mystery that the moon embodies. My hope is that people left feeling curious, inspired, and more connected to the moon than ever before.

But why stop there? While IOTMN was a wonderful way to educate the general public, why not observe the moon every night? For all those autumn nights spent on rooftops, gazing at the moon, here are my favorite songs about the moon, for your listening pleasure.

title: Midterm Election Reflection
content:
article by Tayla Koger

The 2018 midterm elections resulted with Democratic control of the House whilst Republicans maintained their control of the Senate. The most significant result of Democrats gaining control of the House will be the power to investigate the Trump administration. With a divided Congress, the question of if there is truly a way for a bipartisan government to function currently is possible, or if oversight of the Trump administration will take precedence over passing legislation. 

The midterms were a night of historic firsts, especially for women. At least 100 women won house races, with 35 newly elected women gaining seats. In the Senate, 12 women won seats. Additionally, this election cycle offered the most diverse set of candidates in history. The first Muslim women were elected to Congress, the first openly gay Governor elect won in Colorado, the first Somali-American woman was elected to serve in Congress, and the first Palestinian woman was elected to Congress. All of these candidates reinforce the diversity of the Democratic party compared to the Republican party. Interestingly, this election cycle the Democrat party did not push left towards more progressive candidates as was predicted. Rather, more moderate Democrats who focused on the needs of their district won. 

Even a week after the midterms, citizens of Georgia and Florida are still fighting to have each vote counted. In Georgia’s governor race, Stacey Abrams has not conceded due to how close the votes were and the voter suppression that occurred. Her opponent, Brian Kemp is being accused of voter suppression while he held his position of Secretary of State in Georgia. The month before the midterms, it was reported that 53,000 voter registrations, 70% of them from Black applicants, were being held by Kemp’s office for failing to meet a match of social security and state driver records. Although Kemp has declared victory, Abrams has not conceded arguing that are still 26,000 provisional ballots that must be counted.  President Trump has called for the recounts to stop and revert to what was counted originally. Essentially, he is asking for an incomplete count of the votes to be used. In Florida, recounts are taking place for both Governor and Senate races, both of which Republicans are currently narrowly in the lead for.  In the governor race, Ron DeSantis is ahead of Democrat candidate, Andrew Gillum by merely .4%. In terms of the Senate race, Rick Scott led by only .14% over Bill Nelson. Florida counties only have until Thursday to complete all of the recounts, which many argue is too soon. 

Although the 2018 midterms led to many great historic firsts and the Democrats gaining control of the House; they also showed the work that still needs to be done regarding accessible voting and voting suppression.

title: Still EP ~ Review
content:
“You’ve got the same smile you had before. It’s just lighter and what I adore.”

Still EP is Mazzy Star’s first major release in 5 years, since their fourth studio album, Seasons of Your Day. (I say major release because they did release the single “I’m Still Here” in 2014).  The EP is an amalgamation of old and new, with a few tracks that had previously been performed live for years but were never formally released. I find the EP to be a welcome addition to Mazzy Star’s discography, as it possesses the same haunting quality that I have come to expect from them. It does not steer far from their traditional sound, but it is beautiful regardless. I, for one, am just excited that they have had an excuse to begin touring again.  “Quiet the Winter Harbor” is the only single released from Still EP; Hope Sandoval’s gorgeous vocals are layered over a gentle piano piece. I would happily listen to it in place of my nightly Headspace sessions. Hope Sandoval narrate my guided meditation please? “That Way Again” is arguably the most enjoyable of the four tracks, emotionally impactful but breezy. The vocals on “Still” resemble spoken word, to the effect that they become cutting, melancholic, and, frankly, creepy – in the best way possible. Sandoval has formerly used this vocal style on tracks like “Umbilical” and “Mary of Silence,” both equally ghostly tracks. The last song on the EP is an alternate version of “So Tonight That I Might See,” noted as the “ascension version.” It puts an emphasis on the chaotic instrumentals, but otherwise, does not excessively differ from the original track. This EP cemented my suspicion that it’s hard to ever be disappointed by Mazzy Star; any and all new music is welcomed from my end.

~ Anshu Patel

title: On Pelosi et al. // News
content:
article by Luca MacDougall

The incoming majority in the House of Representatives is an important turning point for the Democratic party. Not only does the party now have the capability to actively resist the Trump administration’s heinous method of governance, but it also needs to start preparing for the future. 

The top three Democrats in the House–Nancy Pelosi (D-CA), Jim Clyburn (D-SC), and Steny Hoyer (D-MD)–do not represent the future of the Democratic party. Pelosi and Clyburn are both 78 and Hoyer is 79. While they are all strong, historic, and important members for the left, they also epitomize the antiquity of the party and its hesitance to transform into a more progressive political force. Although they were all elected by their constituents, the midterm election was essentially a mandate for Democrats to move further left, with Representatives-elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY), Ilhan Omar (D-MN), and Ayanna Pressley (D-MA) being some of the most prominent and progressive candidates to win their seats. In the current political climate, it is essential for older Democrats to vacate their seats and begin training their replacements. 

The Republican party is older, out of touch with younger generations, and subscribes to an outdated form of politics. Currently, though, Democrats aren’t much better. As recently as the 2016 election we saw evidence of the Democratic National Committee actively suppressing Bernie Sanders (the more progressive candidate) in favor of Hillary Clinton (the established, moderate candidate) despite substantial party support, especially among younger voters. Being the incoming voter base and the future leaders of the party, it is the responsibility of the party establishment to step aside and contribute their influence in a more effective way. A prime example is former California Senator Barbara Boxer retiring in 2017, giving way to Senator Kamala Harris, one of the most passionate and outspoken Democrats in Congress. Going forward we need Harris’s energy and passion, but we also need her youth and her appeal to progressive voters.

Although the calls for powerful female Democrats like Pelosi and Feinstein to step aside are sometimes combined with misogyny, it is still necessary for them and their male colleagues to find a replacement with a longer career ahead of them. The DNC must realize that their hesitance to change what has worked before is already hurting their presidential and congressional efforts in races 10 years away. The DNC and establishment legislators at all levels need to find the Ocasio-Cortezes, the Omars, and the Pressleys, and they need to give them the training and resources they need to develop themselves. Simply put, the new Democratic majority in the House shouldn’t comfort Democrats, it should energize us.

title: Desert Daze 2014
content:
Festival Season is now in full swing, and no festival line up matched the Desert Daze lineup this year. With bands like Unknown Mortal Orchestra, Diiv, Night Beats, and Blonde Redhead, this festival was not one to miss!

The cloudy and dusty day in Mecca started off with a bang, and despite the long line of late campers and anxious festival-goers, everyone was pumped and excited to get started. The long line of cars was alleviated with free energy drinks, and everyone was friendly and clearly stoked.
After passing through security, people were eager to get to the stages.  Bands  Church of Son and LA Witch opened the show on the party stage, while Froth got the crowd going the Moon Stage with their psychedelic lo-fi set. Next came bands like Mr. Elevator along with Fever the Ghost and Night Beats. The local LA dudes from Mystic Braves then played a great set, and the sun set to the sounds of Unknown Mortal Orchestra.
Between sets festival goers could catch a bite at one of the many food trucks there, and relax by the lake. On-site shops offered festival goers small trinkets for sale, and you could grab a tie-dyed dessert daze shirt at the merch table. The VIP section was super chill and included hammocks and tee pees where you could catch a drink and relax in between sets. 
Even with all those amenities, it’s easy to get tired at an all-day festival in the desert. However, even late into the night, the slightly drunk, dusty, and happy crowd’s energy was not lost, even with Liars playing a set until 2am. After the set, desert dazers could become desert dwellers and stroll back to their snuggly campsites. Needless to say, happy festival goers probably needed all of Sunday to recuperate. Until next year, desert daze!

title: TODAY WE HAVE CHUCK D FROM PUBLIC ENEMY IN THE STATION FROM 3 - 4 PM. LISTEN IN
UCLA Rejects $3 Million Sterling Donation
content:
UCLA has to decided to reject a $3 million donation from the Donald T. Sterling Charitable Foundation amid the recent controversy surrounding the racially insensitive Clippers owner. 

This coming on the same day that NBA commissioner, Adam Silver, handed out his first major decision - hammering Sterling with a lifetime ban from the league and a $2.5 million dollar fine. 

Sterling’s foundation had previously reached an agreement with the university, and was refunded the first $425,000 that had already been donated. Following Silver’s press conference, the university released the following statement about the rejected donation.

“Mr. Sterling’s divisive and hurtful comments demonstrate that he does not share UCLA’s core values as a public university that fosters diversity, inclusion and respect.”

The university also responded to an ad taken out in Sunday’s edition of the L.A. Times in which UCLA thanked Mr. and Mrs. Sterling for their generous donation. The ad went on to state that a golden plaque would be placed in the lobby in Sterling’s honor. According to UCLA, the ad was taken out by Sterling himself, and not someone on behalf of the university. 

Sterling is still awaiting a vote by the other 29 NBA franchise owners to determine whether or not he is required to sell the Clippers. According to Forbes.com, the price tag for the team could reach over $1 billion, an impressive turnaround on his original $12.5 million investment.

title: Heisman Winner Cited for Petty Theft
content:
The 2014 Heisman trophy-winning quarterback Jameis Winston was cited for shoplifting from a Publix grocery store in Tallahassee, Fla this past Tuesday night. (Photo Cred: thekeyplay.com)

Winston walked out of the supermarket with $32.72 worth of seafood, claiming that he forgot to pay for the items. 

The freshman quarterback was reported as being cooperative with police, issued a fine, sentenced to 20 hours of community service, and suspended from his role as the closer for the Seminoles baseball team until his hours are completed.

Florida State football coach Jimbo Fisher said he “fully-supported” the decision by the school’s baseball coach, and had faith that his star quarterback would meet all obligations. 

Here is the statement Winston released through his attorney’s earlier this afternoon:

“As reported in the news, last night I received an adult civil citation for petit theft from a local supermarket. I went to the supermarket with the intent to purchase dinner but made a terrible mistake for which I’m taking full responsibility. In a moment of youthful ignorance, I walked out of the store without paying for one of my items.

I realize that I am in the public spotlight and my conduct needs to be above reproach. Over the last year I’ve learned that my accomplishments on the fields can be a wonderful thing for my school, teammates, friends, and family. At the same time, I must realize that my mistakes are magnified and can bring great embarrassment to all those who support me every day. I make no excuses for my actions and will learn and grow from this unfortunate situation. I hope and pray my friends and family will view me as the 20-year-old young man that I am, and support me through this unfortunate situation.

I am grateful to be able to participate in the adult citation program where I will complete community service.”

title: MEET THE DJS WEEK: Fall 2014
content:
An Interview with Scarlett (New Media Manager 2012-2014) by 
Priyanka V. 
1. What made you want to join UCLA radio?

I came back as a readmission student in the Winter and I literally had NO friends and knew I wanted to get involved in something to meet people. I’ve always been really into music and I really loved the vibe of the people in the station. It really became a second home over the last few years. Plus it just seemed like a really great organization and an opportunity to do some really creative, progressive things

2. How had UCLA radio affected you as a person?

UCLA radio was my college experience at UCLA. I came back after a long hiatus and a stint in a few different places and I made so many friends, more than I can even believe and even thought I would make as a returning student. I also had the chance to do a lot more than I could have done in any other organization because of all the freedom of UCLA radio. I had the chance to rise up to the management super quick and make a lot of positive changes. I haven’t even graduated yet and I miss it already so much

3. As new media manager what is the biggest difficulty you have encountered?

Definitely having patience. So much of the time applying for press means throwing out shots in the dark and not getting any response from anybody and its really frustrating.

title: South China Sea Conflict: Vietnam vs. China
content:
by Justin Duong

In the South China Sea, tensions between China and Vietnam have increased with recent developments over disputed territories called the Xisha Islands in China and Hoang Sa Islands in Vietnam. The conflict began in May when China’s state-owned oil company, the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, installed an oil-rig in territories that both Vietnam and China claim rights to. The Vietnamese consider the offending rig’s installation to be a violation of international law because it believes the territory to be theirs, while China claims the territory as part of its “continental shelf” and sees the installation of the rig as an avenue to advance its geopolitical agenda. China’s escort and installation of the rig, which was escorted by naval ships, has provoked Vietnam to move several of its own boats as buffers, creating a tense situation that has been exacerbated by the sinking of a Vietnamese fishing ship by a Chinese equivalent. On the domestic front, angry Vietnamese protestors attacked Chinese businesses in Vietnam, “smashing down gates and setting fire to businesses, attacking anything deemed to be of Chinese origin…” These developments have strained the relationship between the two countries; however, the result may very well end in China’s benefit because an armed conflict is unlikely – it is irrational for both to engage in violence – leaving the bargaining range to consist of economic affairs. China’s economy is vastly superior to that of Vietnam’s and since Vietnam relies heavily on foreign investment, Vietnam will eventually have to yield to a less-than-favorable agreement.

Further reading: CNN International

title: How Amazon Prime Air wil make pooping infinitely better
content:
by Ghazain Jamil

Amazon.com is officially going to launch it’s Prime Air service in 2015. Prime Air is a service that makes 30-minute deliveries by the use of drones. This raises many issues as delivery drones on US soil have not been licensed yet. But can they be considered the same as remote controlled airplanes? Probably not as they are autonomous drones. However, unarmed, they do pose a variety of potential threats.

Personally, I wonder how Amazon.com will implement the delivery system. Who is to say they will not be shot down mid-air? Who is to say the drones are not going to fail due to technical complications and drop on someone’s head in the middle of the street?

These are all possibilities, but let us be grounded in the realm of all that is indubitable (let’s be real.) 30-minute deliveries are probably going to be expensive, but that is still besides the point. Who needs the 30-minute deliveries? I know. It’s lazy college kids like me who sit on the can to lose a pound of fecal matter, only realizing after the deed’s been done that the toilet paper is on temporary hiatus (read: I forgot to buy more toilet paper.) For such situations, Prime Air is the only solution available to mankind.

Thanks to the mind and heart of Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and CEO, such miracles will now be possible where one will have to wait no more than 30 minutes on the loo to receive a gift from the sky that will allow them to proceed with routine life. However, Jeff Bezos has to have a greater motive than start a whole service for the sole purpose of delivering toilet paper to lazy college kids. Why? Because he is bald, and bald CEOs are evil and not to be trusted.

For your viewing pleasure: Amazon Prime Air in action!

title:
UCLA 72, University of Colorado 59
January 31, 2015
content: Avenging a six-point road loss from January 2nd, the UCLA Bruins Men’s Basketball Team defeated the University of Colorado Buffaloes by a score of 72-59 at Pauley Pavilion. Despite shooting only 25 percent from the three point line and receiving only eleven bench points, the Bruins were able to win their second conference game in a row behind Senior Norman Powell and Freshman sensation Kevon Looney. For the second game in a row, Powell scored over 20 points and paced the Bruins in scoring, contributing a full stat line of 22 points, five rebounds, five steals, and five assists while hitting 7 of 8 shots form the free-throw line. A likely lottery pick in this this years NBA Draft, Looney led the Bruins with ten rebounds, adding fourteen points for his eleventh double double of the season. Backcourt duo Bryce Alford and Isaac Hamilton each logged over 34 minutes, with Alford chipping in with eight points, five assists, and foul free defense, while Hamilton added twelve points of his own. The Bruins controlled the game from outset, turning a four-point lead at the half into a thirteen-point victory, while outrebounding, assisting, blocking, and stealing the Buffaloes, all while committing fewer fouls and turnovers. The biggest hurdle the Bruins were able to climb in this victory was the team’s continued improvement from the free throw line, following up a 75% performance against Utah by making 19 of 23 attempts on their way to an 82.6% mark. Defensively, this marked one of the Bruins stronger performances in quite some time, as they held Colorado to a 36.4% field goal percentage, while forcing 15 turnovers. Now up to sixth in the Pac-12 standings with a 5-4-conference record, the 13-9 Bruins will head to Northern California to take on conference foes Stanford and California Berkley, both of whom the Bruins defeated at home earlier in the season.

title: Artist of the week: Of Montreal
content:
With new music about to be pressed, this late 90s band is as big as ever.

By Sheehan Parker

Many well known artists and groups were birthed and developed in Athens, Georgia, but few have defined their niche in the musical community quite like Of Montreal.  The band was founded by multi-instrumentalist Kevin Barnes in 1996,  and since its creation has enlisted a wide array of artists.  Their upcoming album, Aureate Gloom, which is scheduled for release on March 3rd on Polyvinyl records, will coincide with a concert tour.

Through their nearly two decade history, Of Montreal has developed a reputation of marose oddity, characterised equally in their music and in their concert performances.  Drawing on contributions from other members of the Elephant 6 collective, a late 90’s music collective centered in Boulder and known for including such bands as Neutral Milk Hotel, Of Montreal developed quite a bit in the span of their first three albums, before being formally signed to Kindercore in 1999.  The band continued to release studio albums, and began honing their concert performances, even touring the United Kingdom in the early 00s. By the time Kindercore folded in 2004, Of Montreal had built an international name for itself, and their second release with Polyvinyl records, 2005’s the Sunlandic Twins, was a major critical success (and is printed on oddly charming red vinyl with haunting images etched on the B side.)  As the band developed with Polyvinyl, Kevin Barnes began to direct the musical development of the group’s releases more and more unilaterally; Kevin Barnes having written and recorded the entirety of Hissing Fauna, Are You the Destroyer? (2007) himself, with help in particular instances from his family and friends in Elephant 6.

Nonetheless, a group is very much required for the band’s highly regarded concert performances.  The band will use the space that they’re in with ingenuity, such as the use of video projectors coordinating with on stage props in their last tour, which I was lucky enough to catch at L.A.’s Echoplex.  More often than not, their shows give the impression of being designed for the space, exemplified by actors’ use of the catwalk at the Hollywood Bowl.  On stage, the band is accompanied by actors working in choreography that expresses or accompanies the music; examples range from a bizarre butter-knife sword fight, or as support for Kevin Barnes as he enters atop their shoulders.

No doubt, I’m equally excited for Of Montreal’s soon to be released album, Aureate Gloom, and their newest tour.  A track off of Aureat Gloom, “Bassem Sabry”, can be listened to now on SoundCloud; it underlines the tendency that Of Montreal has developed in recent albums towards a funky driving line.  At the same time, Barnes’ iconic vocals and a constant juxtaposition of the upbeat music with morose or troubling lyrics maintain the Of Montreal line which fans have come to identify with.  Soon to be entering their third decade of work, the band has released 13 accomplished albums including Aureate Gloom and shows no signs of abating.  Aureate Gloom will be available on Polyvinyl records March third, and Of Montreal will play two shows in Los Angeles on March 22nd and 23rd, at the Regent and the Largo, respectively.
tags: UCLA Radio artist of the week

title: The Coach's Son Gets It Done [No. 12 UCLA-20, Texas-17]
content:
By Jeremy Daniels (9/14/14)

In his homecoming to Texas for the Bruins game against the Longhorns, Jerry Neuheisel likely never expected to be carried off the field by his teammates. However when heisman hopeful, Brett Hundley, went down with an injury in the first quarter, the stage was set for the red shirt sophomore son of former UCLA head coach and Quarterback, Rick Neuheisel. 

“I just thought, Wow. You couldn’t write a better script than this right here,” coach Jim Mora said. “His dad was a great player here. For him to come to Texas and bringing his team from behind to get a win. It’s incredible. It’s awesome.”

Neuheisel would go on to complete 23 of 30 attempts for 178 yards and two touchdowns, including a game winning 33-yard dime to Jordan Payton with just 3 minutes to go. 

“It took until I got in the locker room and we did the fight song that it really sank in,” Neuheisel said. “Right now I’m just kind of on cloud nine and enjoying the moment.”

The Bruins had their work cut out for them in facing off against Tyrone Swoopes. The Longhorns QB showed flashes of brilliance en route to 196 yards and 2 TDs. Texas did however, give UCLA a huge break to start the game. After deferring their choice to the second half, the Bruins still received the ball first. Texas had mistakenly chosen to play defense to start, a blunder that gave UCLA a free possession.

Hundley injured his non throwing elbow at the end of an 11 yard scamper on the Bruins’ second possession of the game. The incumbent QB fell awkwardly, appearing to hyperextend his elbow while attempting to break his fall. Though Hundley wanted to get back into the game, the UCLA coaching staff decided to keep him on the sidelines. He is expected to undergo an MRI on Monday.

Down 3-10 to start the second half, Neuheisel engineered a 7 play 75 yard drive which culminated in the first touchdown pass of his career. A 25 yd field goal from Ka’imi Fairbairn later gave the Bruins their second lead of the night, before Swoopes connected with John Harris late in the contest to make it 13-17. 

A Jordan James fumble with 5 minutes left, looked like a potential dagger to the Bruins’ hopes of a story book ending. The defense stood tall though, forcing a 3 and out that led to a 58 yard punt return by Ishmael Adams. With the ball just 33 yards away from pay dirt, and a little more than 3 minutes left on the clock, Neuheisel took over. It took just one play for the backup to deliver. Neuheisel took the snap and pumped once before launching a perfect pass to Payton for the winning touchdown.

Paul Perkins was also excellent for the Bruins, rushing for 126 yards on 24 carries and adding an additional 69 yards on 5 receptions. UCLA (3-0) is back in action Sept. 25th when they face off against divisional foe, Arizona State. The Sun Devils (3-0) got the best of UCLA last season in the Rose Bowl, and a loss by USC this past saturday makes the match-up all the more significant for PAC-12 south supremacy.

title: This Week In Music: American Football's S/T LP 15th Anniversary
content:
Today, May 20th, marks the 15th anniversary of the release of the only studio album from the influential Midwestern emo band, American Football. Hailing from Champaign-Urbana, Illinois, American Football consists of Mike Kinsella, Steve Holmes, and Steve Lamos. They are known for their intricately layered guitar work and confessional lyrics.

Originally only active from 1997 to 2000, American Football has reunited to play a few shows on the east coast and released a deluxe reissue of their self-titled album along with unreleased demo tracks and photos through Polyvinyl Records, out today.

Though the members have since moved on to other projects, American Football’s influence can still be seen today 15 years later. They helped define the 90s emo scene, along with the genre of Midwestern emo.

title: Ukraine: I, Me, Mine
content:
by Sergio Garcia

On Sunday, voters in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions of eastern Ukraine asked to separate from Ukraine. Separatist leaders in those regions are asking to join Russia. Russia’s thinking about it, but in a few months’ time, I wouldn’t be surprised to see a larger Russian Federation. The EU and particularly the U.S. are freaking out. They have been doing so since Crimea voiced similar desires. The rhetoric has escalated despite the U.S., EU, and Russia all condemning violence and political aggression. Why? Specifically, why the U.S.?

This seems to be a game of I, Me, Mine. Both the EU and Russia have very real economic interests in Ukraine. The recent Ukrainian unrest began with disputes over a trade deal between the two parties months ago. The U.S., on the other hand, has a very real interest in not letting Russia get what it wants. As a citizen, especially one who never lived during the Cold War, I ask if this interest is legitimate.

I claim no expertise on the situation, but it appears to me that our actions are excessive and self-absorbed. Far too many have already died over political squabbles. The Ukranian people have a voice and a will. It is not outsiders’ position to manipulate or denounce its legitimacy simply because the conniving Russians have interests in the situation. U.S. foreign policy is not the puppet master that it used to be. Our leaders must recognize this limitation and deescalate like it’s 1991.

Further reading: Wall Street Journal

title:
Artist Of the Week: Deap Vally

DEAP VALLY: “TOO COOL FOR SHUL” by Lauren Fay
content:
lostandsoundshow:

A borderline unhealthy preteen obsession with Ben Stiller led me to purchase the book Jews Who Rock, for which I had zero regrets. I wonder, however, when the next edition comes out, because I cannot wait to see Deap Vally front cover. And perhaps a follow-up, Knitters Who Rock, would be just as appropriate.


Deap Vally’s debut 2013 album, Sistrionix, made a splash in the states, and a tidal wave in the UK. They have been known to draw in everyone from teenage girls with budding libidos and lesbian curiosities to wise, old men reliving Woodstock and dusting their instruments off from storage. For a first time listener, an unexpected encounter with Deap Vally might be likened to innocently strolling through a park at sunset when suddenly the sky turns black and a flirty skunk (a la Pepé Le Pew) marches right up to you and unashamedly sprays you in the face, flashing you a devilish smile. At first you are shocked…offended—but then, suddenly, your soul feels renewed. You feel alive. You come to love the scent, increasingly by the second. Never want to wash the smell away. 

It’s raw. It’s natural. It’s real. It’s rare. And you can’t get enough.



What’s that smell? FUNK, derived from the Latin “fumigare,” meaning, “to smoke.” These smoking ladies don’t need boots to walk all over you. The barefoot duo’s perplexing mixture of brazen and sweet allows them to zigzag from songs of poignant social commentary and resolute declaration (“Creeplife,” “Gonna Make My Own Money”) to vulnerable bare-all ballads and songs of universal empowerment (“Six Feet Under,” “End of the World”). Not purely blues-rock—though lazy critics will regurgitate that—with a gun to my head I would sandwich them between funk and punk, because it’s just as much about attitude and intent as the guitar-and-drums sound. In the early 20th Century jazz circuit, funk was slang for music that was deeply, strongly felt. Later it would come to mean “hard-driving, insistent rhythm, implying a more carnal quality…the music was identified as slow, ‘sexy,’ loose, riff-oriented and danceable.” Deap Vally fuses funk and punk to create something intoxicating and full of soul and truth.

In the words of Funkadelic, “What is soul?…soul is a ham hock in your cornflakes… soul is the ring around your bathtub… soul is a joint rolled in toilet paper… soul is you, big mama.” Capturing the sound of soul and the soul of sound can be the greatest challenge of a studio album. Sistrionix’s high fidelity recording approach triumphed in its ability to reproduce the soul of their live performance, capturing the raw energy and sex appeal that oozes from the stage. Little instrumentation, BIG SOUND. That is the magic of Deap Vally. There are only two people to focus on, and yet you cannot decide where to look. 

Lindsey Troy’s voice takes you to church while Julie Edwards’ drumming plays games with your mind.



They handle their instruments like machine guns, but snuggle kittens behind the scenes. These enigmatic women are wolves in sheep’s clothing by day, and sheep in wolves’ clothing by night (and if the thought of them as sheep makes you want to wear them as a sweater near to your heart, look out for their hand-crocheted merch).

In 2015 we will be hit with album number two. Date and label TBA, but need an amuse-bouche to hold you over? Nick Zinner of Yeah Yeah Yeahs produces it, and the trio has palpable chemistry on tracks ranging from experimental prog and kraut-rock to the heart-melter “Turn It Off” (see teaser below).


I cannot reveal the album name, but anticipate the same originality and provocation as the last. Recorded partly in El Paso and partly in Los Angeles, this diverse collection of gems defies industry pigeonholing and offers a fuller scope of their personalities. This album presented an opportunity forcomplete freedom of expression, resulting in everything from an investigationof a child beauty queen to a PSA about men insistent on making homemade porn. The album is edgy, satirical, and wise—darker and more lyrically and musically exploratory than the last, sprinkled with sassy and amusing songs that make you feel like Lindsey and Julie are personally winking at you from behind your speakers. 



The album’s climax comes in the form of a 90s throwback teen angst anthem that will make you head bang, laugh, and later, cry at the resonance of lyrics, such as 

I am not ashamed of my mental state. I am not ashamed of my body weight. I am not ashamed of my rage. I am not ashamed of my age. I am not ashamed of my sex life, though I wish it were better. I am not ashamed I am no one’s wife, though the idea does sound kinda nice.



Follow facebook.com/lostandsoundshow to stay posted about Deap Vally’s upcoming visit to UCLA Radio to DJ their favorite songs and debut new tunes. And catch Deap Vally live in your city.

title: Clippers Cruise Past Mavericks In 120-100 Statement Victory
content:
Photos and Text: Darryn Albert

Blake Griffin stuffed the stat sheet with 22 points, 7 rebounds, and 6 assists on 11 of 15 shooting from the field as the Los Angeles Clippers ran the Dallas Mavericks right out of the Staples Center on Saturday afternoon by the final of 120-100. Chris Paul added 17 points, 13 assists, and 0 turnovers for the Clippers who improved to 3-1 in 2015 with the victory as well 25-12 on the season as a whole.

Dirk Nowitzki led the Mavericks with 25 points while Monta Ellis added 23 points, 4 rebounds, and 6 assists. However, Rajon Rondo was just 1 for 11 from the field for 2 points and the Mavericks floundered after head coach Rick Carlisle was ejected from the game after picking up his second technical foul just 6 minutes into the second half. Once again, the Clippers used a massive third quarter run to put the game away. They went into the locker room at halftime nursing 56-48 lead after a back-and-forth first half played at a blistering pace that had the Staples Center feeling like a playoff atmosphere. But LAC went on a 14-2 run to kick off the 3rd frame and never looked back from there, opening up a second half lead that peaked at 26. Coach Doc Rivers credited Blake Griffin’s strong play in his post-game interview saying of Griffin that “he’s such a weapon. He makes it very difficult to trap. He is so unselfish.” Rivers also praised Griffin’s decision-making when facing double-teams down low saying “Usually, that makes you go away from the post, but it actually made us go to the post more because we knew that would create a 2-on-1 and he kept making the right decisions.”

Rivers would go on to speak highly of the entire team’s mentality saying “I love the fact that, offensively, we never turned it off. I thought we played downhill the entire game and I thought that was important.” Chris Paul would echo his head coach’s sentiments in his own post-game interview, mentioning that “We want Blake to be aggressive, to shoot, attack, all that stuff,” also speaking highly of the job Griffin did defensively on Nowitzki. Paul also credited the victory today to “pushing the tempo,” “defending a bit better,” and “playing in transition a lot more.” He would go on to applaud Spencer Hawes’ efforts in stifling Rondo in the lane (Hawes recorded 3 blocks on the afternoon).

Griffin, himself, gave kudos to the team’s offensive play: “Our offense was the biggest different today. Everyone that came on the floor played with pace. We all moved the ball and we all got easy shots. Things like that are the jolt that gets the team playing the right way.” The defensive-minded Matt Barnes chimed in saying “It starts from the defensive end. We’re a very talented team offensively. But when we have that defensive energy and get out in transition, we’re the best team in the world.” Barnes and J.J. Redick deserve a lot of recognition for the victory, combining to score 15 of the team’s first 17 points in the first quarter to really set the tone for the rest of the game. They finished with 18 and 16 points, respectively. DeAndre Jordan also posted 13 points and 15 rebounds. The Clippers shot 52% from the field today and hit 13 three-pointers. They also won the battle on the boards (47 compared to 40 for Dallas) as well as at the free throw line (21 attempts to 17 for the Mavericks).

Veteran official Joey Crawford was forced to exit the game at the 7:42 mark of the second quarter after pulling up lame. He left the floor under his own power, not to return, and the game played out with 2 officials. Coach Rivers commented on Crawford’s injury saying “I was very concerned. But it looks like a meniscus from what I hear and you don’t want to lose Joey, I can tell you that.” On the possibility of coaching his son Austin, Rivers also said that he would be open to the idea. “I think a year ago, I probably wouldn’t. But I think I would, for sure. I think this team could handle that. He’s a downhill guard, which is something we need.” Austin Rivers was traded to the Boston Celtics, the team that his father used to coach, on Saturday as a part of the Jeff Green-to-Memphis deal causing Doc to quip “I guess I shouldn’t have sold my condo.” But the Celtics seem poised to move him immediately and officials within Doc’s staff and the Clippers front office are reportedly pressuring him to deal for his son.

The Clippers improve to 25-12 with the victory and will face off against the Miami Heat on Sunday afternoon in another Staples Center matinee game (3:30 PM EST/12:30 PM PST tip-off).

The Mavericks meanwhile fall to 26-12 and will head to Sacramento for a Tuesday night matchup with the Kings (10 PM EST/7 PM PST tip-off).
