title: Bilderberg's Birthday
content:
By Sheehan Parker

No, Bilderberg is not a friend of yours that you need to rush onto facebook and congratulate after realising it’s their birthday.  Rather, Bilderberg is a top secret conference, held every year in Europe, and attended by the most powerful Western players in the fields of finance, industry, and, of course, politics.  The meeting, which convened a week ago in Copenhagen and finished on Sunday, is celebrating its sixtieth anniversary.  The corpus of attendees is comprised of influential and powerful westerners, with a total of 21 western nations being represented.  According to the BBC, roughly two thirds of the 140 or so attendees hail from European powers, the other third from the North American power(s).  What’s more, roughly a third of the attendees are from policy and political fields, while the rest represent their positions in finance and industry.

The topics up for discussion this year, as released by the Bilderberg group, include questions naturally of the upmost importance to the wealthy western industrialists: issues regarding the Ukraine, big shifts in technologies and jobs, and “Is the economic recovery sustainable?”.  It also includes loftier questions, questions ostensibly being determined by the very attendees themselves: “The future of democracy,” “Does privacy really exist?” and “How special is the relationship in intelligence sharing?”.  Perhaps most telling, is the topics of discussion which are geographically removed from the western conference.  Though there are no representatives at the conference from middle eastern nations, and China is the only represented western nation, and only marginally represented at that, the topics include “The new architecture of the Middle East,” and “China’s political and economic outlook.”  Who are the people in these discussions? And do they have the power to change the world based on the revelations the could be made at this secretive conference?

Yes, they do have the power.  The chairman of the conference, French industrialist Henri de la Croix de Castries, is himself the CEO of the largest insurance company in France.  Perhaps more telling is the presence of former director of the NSA Alexander Keith, Swedish and Spanish ministers of foreign affairs, and of course the Supreme Commander of Allied Troops in Europe Phillip Breedlove; all of whom are nestled cozily amongst representatives such as Benoit Coeure, a member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank, and George Zanias, chairman of the National Bank of Greece, among others.

I realise all this name dropping can be dizzying, and I wish I could get on to what was actually said at the conference- unfortunately, that is all secret.  The conference is closed to the press, and while members are free to discuss what was said, they are not to disclose the names or affiliations of the speakers.  When Al Jeezera asked a spokesman for the conference if it would have any tangible effects on current events, he responded that while the conference has no desired outcome, “we cannot comment on this issue.”  Well, when a room of the wealthiest and most powerful people in the world discuss current events, I don’t see how it could not have an impact on the world.  Ultimately, the Bilderberg Conference is a tangible example of the intersection between money and power which the people of the world feel every day; and it is exclusively the advice and considerations of western financiers and industrialists that the leaders of Europe and North America listened to for the past week.

title: Aiken for Congress?
content:
by Noor Gill

Most reality stars of the past fade into either the darkness of obscurity or a couple of episodes of Celebrity Rehab. However there are a select few that continue to shine bright. Clay Aiken is one of those stars, that now shine brighter than ever.

Clay Aiken, once golden boy of popular singing competition show, American Idol, has won the Democratic primaries in North Carolina for a seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. He will now face GOP Representative Renee Elmers in the general election.  And hopefully for all those Claymates out there, the final results of this election will not end in another unexpected Ruben Studdard-esque situation.

Aiken’s possible rise to political power is nothing new. Celebrities have been known to involve themselves in politics in the past, from the classic example of Schwarzenegger to the lesser-known involvements of Chuck Norris with the Republican Party. So why is this important?

When people in the media switch roles from singer of some kind of music (I don’t actually know a single Clay Aiken song) to an elected official, its only natural for us news consumers to take notice. So, am I ashamed that this is the only current event that currently comes to mind? Yeah, a bit.  

In relation to other news, the future career of season 2 American Idol runner-up is probably not all that important. But hey, it’s entertaining. Who knows where Aiken’s new political aspirations will take him? Congressman? Governor? President of the United States?

Further reading: ABC News

title:
UCLA 69- #11 Utah 59. 
Chase Madorsky, January 29, 2015
content: Led by the backcourt duo of Sophomore Bryce Alford and Senior Norman Powell, the UCLA Bruins Men’s Basketball team upset the number 11 team in the nation, the Utah Utes, by a score of 69-59. Scoring the first basket of the game, the Bruins led from start to finish, turning a 3-point, 33-30 lead at the half into a ten-point victory. Norman Powell led the team with 23 points, consistently having his way with the Utah defense in getting to the hoop, while reaching the free throw line six teams in the game. Bryce Alford contributed with 14 points and seven assists, playing tenacious defense while leading the Bruin defense in forcing 16 Utes turnovers. The crowd at Pauley Pavilion provided constant energy for the Bruins, with coach Steve Alford getting involved in the action with numerous fist pumps, hugs, and high fives directed at his team. The turning point in the game occurred in the first half, when freshman center Thomas Welsh laid down a thunderous one handed dunk en route to a seven-point performance, leading the UCLA bench. Overall, the Bruins shot 46.2% from the field, while converting on 18 of 24 free throw attempts for a 75% success rate. Across the board, the Bruins outplayed the highly ranked Utes, out-rebounding the visitors 29-27, while gaining three more assists (15-12), six more steals (8-2), and committing five fewer fouls (11-16) than their Pac-12 foe. With the victory, the Bruins break a two game losing steak and improve to 12-9 overall, while breaking the 500 mark in Pac-12 conference play with a 4-4 record. This Saturday, January 31, the Bruins will look to build on this upset when they take on the University Colorado Buffaloes at Pauley Pavilion, 7:30 pacific time tip.

title: The Fall of Troy: USC Continues the Drama this Preseason
content:
Article by: Nicole Kern (Aug 30, 2014)

USC may finally be off of NCAA probation, but the team’s misbehavior is not over. USC has survived many scandals including OJ Simpson, the returned Heisman, and the stripping of the BCS title. This past week can be added to the list. Two scandals broke this week leading to the removal of two USC players and ESPN anchor John Anderson calling the school “a clown college”.

Josh Shaw, a USC Senior Cornerback and team captain, admitted to lying about saving a drowning nephew to cover up how he actually sustained high ankle sprains and subsequently has been suspended indefinitely. Shaw said the sprain occurred this past Saturday when he jumped from a second story window of an apartment building to save his 7-year-old nephew. Only after USC received many phone calls questioning the incident did Shaw admit that he had fabricated the story. “We are extremely disappointed in Josh,” said USC head football coach Steve Sarkisian. “He let us all down.” USC touted Shaw’s heroism on its website and posted a link to the story on Twitter. Media outlets reported the account and it went viral over social media adding to the school’s embarrassment from the incident. Shaw’s attorney says the true story is that Josh fell from a balcony, but LAPD is now questioning Shaw in connection to a break in of his girlfriend’s apartment. Shaw’s fate with the team now hangs in a balance, as does USC’s football season.

This incident would be enough to derail USC’s football program as they prepared to face Saturday’s opening game against Fresno, but they also had to deal with allegations from senior cornerback Andrew Brown. Brown claims that Steve Sarkisian is a racist, which caused him to quit the team. Brown quit the team a weak ago and this past Thursday he posted on Instagram, "Sark treated me like a slave in his Office…Can’t play for a racist MAN!!!!! #Fighton.” Sarkisian was "shocked” and said these claims are “ridiculous”. The posts were later removed. According to Sarkisian Brown quit the team after he was moved from cornerback to running back. Brown has faced numerous injuries in the past two years and only played in two games last season. Many players have come out in defense of Sarkisian, including former USC quarterback Matt Leinart.

These off the field controversies leave many with numerous questions and very little answers. The biggest, how can USC play a successful season with both the team’s captain and their coach being brought into question? USC was able to win their first game against Fresno State 52-13, which has brought some optimism to USC’s situation.

title: Meet the DJs: Winter 2014 Interns
content:
Kareem. 2nd year. Psychology major, English minor. 

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I am a big fan of sharing stories and/or information over different forms of media and radio was definitely one of them. Also, I’ve interned before and really love the people here. Big fan of wearing those headphones too. 

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Sixth Street EP by Yuna. I love the soulful, jazzy type music she creates with killer lyrics to beat. I think she brings a very unique form of personality to the indie music scene, adding a little bit diversity and originality to an already convoluted genre: a very difficult thing to do. But maybe I’m bias because she is from Malaysia, and so am I.


Brenda. 2nd year. Music History major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined Radio because I thought it was a cool way to show people music because I get really joyous when I do. I also joined because I always thought the people in Radio were cool (which they are).

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
My favorite album of this past year would have to be Matangi by M.I.A. because she’s just super duper awesome. She’s such a big inspiration to me and her music is on point. The beats and powerful lyrics bring it hard

Recommended tracks:
“MATANGI”
“Come Walk With Me”
“Bad Girls”
“Double Bubble Trouble”
“Y.A.L.A.”
“Bring the Noize”.


Jimmy. 2nd year. Microbiology, Immunology, Molecular Genetics major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
Being stuck in south campus most of the time, I don’t get much social interaction outside of a few ‘Hi’s.’ Classes are competitive and seldom do people want to make friends, and if they do, most interaction revolves around schoolwork. Radio seemed like a great opportunity to get together with people who have similar interests and diversify my social circle at UCLA. 

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Oneohtrix Point Never - 'R Plus Seven.’ R Plus Seven is an absolutely lucid listening experience. Much of the album consists of eerie minimalist synth compositions that sound reminiscent of the music that backed early 90’s television bumpers or instructional videos. OPN’s use of bright, yet cold textures provides a fresh new perspective on the beginning of the digital age of consumer electronics , one that that is equally nostalgic and haunting. 

Recommended tracks:
“Inside World”
“Cryo”
“Zebra”


Alexandra. 4th year. Geography major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I used to be OBSESSED with Frasier. I thought it was the coolest thing ever that he went to work and got on the radio and talked to people all day and gave them advice on air. This was my happy place! And I listen to the radio all the time and often find myself wishing I was there to give my input. When I saw that there was UCLARadio I really hopped on board because I wanted to get involved and wanted to explore this field since I can never make up my mind about what career I might want. 

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Avicii: True. It is a super feel good album, not only good for getting pumped up but good for just driving around. 

Recommended tracks:
“Wake Me Up”
“Hey Brother”


Desiree. 1st year. Global Studies major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined radio because I like sharing my music with other people and other people sharing their music with me.Plus, who doesn’t want to be a DJ at some point in their life? 

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Favorite albums of the past year would have to be Love is the law by The Memories and Ride your heart by Bleached.

Recommended tracks:
“En Espanol” by The Memories
“Dead Boy” by Bleached


Bryce. 1st year. Undecided.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined radio because I wanted to get involved with some of the media groups on campus and radio had such a funky vibe to it. Plus, also, I knew some people already in radio and they’re real whackos so that could only bode good things.

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
My current favorite album from this past year would be The Hands That Thieve from Streetlight Manifesto. I’ve been a fan of them for so long and they don’t put out a lot of albums. I think they’ve also stopped touring…anyway it was just nice to hear something from them again. They’re ska punk but I like to think of them as really long epics with a hornline. Darker than Reel Big Fish, less spastic than Bomb the Music Industry!, and bit more punk than The Toasters. They’ve got a lot of energy and really solid ideas. 

Recommended tracks:
“Oh Me, Oh My”
“With Any Sort of Certainty”
“They Broke Him Down”


Megan. 3rd year. Comparative Literature major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I decided to join radio because I’m obsessed with making mixes and love sharing my weird songs-of-the-moment with people.

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Face album is a tie between Modern Vampires of the City and Yeezus.

Recommended tracks:
“Hannah Hunt” by Vampire Weekend
“Unbelievers” by Vampire Weekend
“Bound 2” by Kanye West
“Blood on the Leaves” by Kanye West


Eva. 1st year. History major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined radio so I could play music I love and learn about how a station works!

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
One of my favorite albums from this past year would have to be whysowhite by whysowhite. The album is fresh funk out of Chicago and in this debut album of theirs, really blends strong instrumentation with upbeat and quickly lyricism. I adore them!

Colin. 3rd year. History major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
Joined radio because I dig music and it seemed like a great way to get involved!

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
B-Room by Dr.Dog. Catchy melodies, vocal harmonies, guitar solos. It’s got everything!

Issa. First year. Political Science major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined radio because I love music and making playlists and the idea of independent radio in general.

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Time by Alex Calder. It was released almost a full year ago but I can’t stop listening to it. It’s got an odd, dreamy, disjointed feel to it that fits right into the malaise that fills me during my morning walk to class, as well as melodies that have me humming about it even after the morning grog is worn-off.

Recommended tracks:
“Suki and Me”

-by Sara Haenny and Ashley Helm

title: BRYAN'S WEEKLY ROUNDUP
content:
Welcome to UCLA Radio’s newest weekly feature ….. the Weekly Roundup!!!!! Check this space every weekend to get the scoop on what shows UCLA Radio wants to go to next week! Lovely Digital Press staffer Bryan is kicking off the series with his day-by-day recommendations for the week of January 25th! 

Monday Jan 26th

Rae Sremmurd @ The Observatory 10:30pm

Rae Sremmurd is touring for his new album. Who doesn’t want to here No Type and Flex Zone live on a Monday night?? 

Tuesday Jan 27th

Tijuana Panthers @ Troubadour 7:00pm

They’re touring for their new album Wayne Interest. This lo-fi wonder is everything you want to hear on a Tuesday night. Beach vibes tbh.

Wednesday Jan 28th

Leighton Meester w/ Dana Williams @ Hotel Café 9:30pm

Gossip Girl throwback on a Wednesday night, what else can you asks for? Her new album Heartstrings just came out and it’s great!

Thursday Jan 29th

Badfish - A tribute to Sublime @ The El Rey 7:00pm

Thursday night means listening to a Sublime cover band and singing your heart out, pretending like you’re actually at a Sublime show.

Friday Jan 30th

Airborne Toxic Event @ Troubadour

Airborne Toxic Event, who have been under the radar since 2009, are touring for their new album Chains. If you have nothing to do Friday night, check em’ out! Another throwback this week!

Saturday Jan 31st

Paul Oakenfold @ The Avalon 10pm

Paul Oakenfold just released a new song and is DJ’ing at the Avalon this Saturday. If you want to rave it up, I highly recommend it. He’s a legend in the trance scene.

Sunday February 1st 

Frequency Fest V 4.0 @ The Smell 2:00pm 

A 3 day music festival of music created by obsolete video game and computer hardware. If you’re into 8 bit I HIGHLY recommend you go. Also it’s 10 bucks so why not???

~Bryan

title: Podcast Recommendation: Not Too Deep
content:
For those who haven’t yet heard of Grace Helbig, take some time this winter break to check out her podcast from the comfort of the rock you live under. Comedian and general internet super-star Grace Helbig gained popularity from her daily comedy videos on YouTube and has ventured into books, movies, and her podcast, Not Too Deep. Not Too Deep is a refreshing, emotionally unsatisfying, upbeat and hilarious departure from whisper-y, intimate tell-all podcasts. It’s like getting to listen to the conversations of those people laughing in front of you in line, who share a love of drinking and HGTV.

Recently, Grace had friend and comedian Mamrie Hart on her show. In this episode, the chemistry is immediately obvious as Grace introduces Mamrie and offers her a Bloody Mary with unwashed celery. An hour of funny questions, quick quips, and hilarious anecdotes about gender-neutral dogs then ensues. One of many highlights: Mamrie tries to get Grace to name five Beatles songs, and in response to Mamrie’s hint, “You need this right now” (suggesting The Beatles’ “Help”), Grace responds, “Do they have a song called ‘Deodorant’?”

Check out Not Too Deep or any of Grace’s hundreds of videos on her YouTube channel, itsGrace.

title: A Female Football Fan’s Reaction to the Ray Rice Scandal
content:
By: Nicole Kern (9/11/14)

I have been a football fan since I was 8 years old when my mom explained the rules to me at a peewee football game. Since then I grew into a full-fledged fanatic. I live and die by my team. I rarely miss watching my NFL team play and I spend the entire game jumping, cursing, and sometimes, if we lose, crying. Whenever I mention my obsession people are surprised since I am a girl.

In my 12 years as a football fanatic it has been a fact that the NFL world is not female friendly. I have just grown to accept it. I love the sport and I love proving to the guys that I am just as valuable of a fan as them. I thought that this sexism came from ignorance, until this week. As anybody that follows any sort of news knows, the video of Baltimore Raven’s Ray Rice punching his fiancé Janay Palmer unconscious was released this week.

The altercation occurred in February and NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell suspended Rice for a laughable two games. The Ravens even held a press conference about the incident with Rice and his new wife. Not once did Rice apologize to Palmer. The Ravens even tweeted after that Palmer apologized for her role. After months of public outrage the NFL crafted a stricter policy against domestic violence. This seemed to placate most people and the focus shifted to the beginning of a new season. Then when Rice is preparing to play in his first game after suspension, TMZ released a video showing Rice punch Palmer and her falling to the ground unconscious and him dragging her limp body out of the elevator. Within hours Rice was cut from the Ravens and was suspended from the NFL indefinitely. Goodell claimed he had never seen this second tape and even sent a letter to all NFL coaches describing the steps he took to try to procure the tape from New Jersey Police. New Jersey Police says they did send the tape to NFL executives. Currently former FBI director Robert Mueller will investigate how the league handled the Rice affair.

I am now told I should boycott the NFL or I am a hypocrite that does not respect myself. Ray Rice’s actions and the aftermath sicken me. There is no excuse for a man to ever hit a woman, especially when that man is twice her size and is a professional athlete. There is also no excuse for the NFL and the Ravens to try to cover it up. 44% of football fans are women and it is atrocious for the league to disregard them like this. The sexism that I always tried to conquer is not just boys being ignorant, but instead is institutional. I do not want to just give up on the NFL, because it is flawed. I want to be a part of the solution. When these issues come up (and sadly they do often) I want to be there to push for changes to be made.

There is hope in the NFL. Many players and ESPN commentators have condemned Goodell, Rice, and the NFL in general for how they handled this. I do not want to abandon football instead I want to call on the NFL to fire commissioner Roger Goodell and force Steve Bisciotti, owner of the Ravens, to sell the team. This story can go from “the darkest week in the history of the league” to the opening of a dialogue on sexism in sports, domestic violence, and even player accountability. Again I am going to choose to rise above it and keep hoping that the sport I love will start meeting my expectations.

title: Tim Minchin @ the Wilshire Ebell Theatre 5/29
content:
Last Thursday I had the pleasure of seeing the fantastic musical comedian Tim Minchin, at the Wilshire Ebell Theatre.  As I approached the historical venue that blends very well into a quiet area near Koreatown, the first thing I noticed was the crowd gathered outside: a collection of middle aged pony-tailed men, punky teenagers, nerdy college students, and classy old people. An interesting bunch for an oddball artist.  There was also $1 coffee, tea, and hot cocoa, so the Ebell immediately won my love.

After the full house was seated, the show began.  His entrance onto the stage immediately sent red flags to the audience that “yes, this show is going to make you laugh extremely hard so I hoped you all used the little spectator’s room.”  Mr. Minchin, holding his glass of red wine, strode out onto the stage, wearing his usual all black attire, heavy eyeliner, and sporting mad scientist-like red hair.  He announced that it was his first live show in 2 years, and gave a disclaimer that he didn’t know what was going to happen that night.  Although he stumbled with lyrics a few times, he was always met with laughter and applause, which he responded to with “Fuck You!” in his twangy Australian accent.  
His subjects ranged from the struggles of being ginger (“Prejudice”), to atheism (“Thank You God”) to love (“If I Didn’t Have You”).  At some concerts, I tend to daze of for a bit, listening to the music but zoning out and not being truly present.  However throughout his set I clung to every word, because everything he said and sang was pure gold.  One of his last songs was “Dark Side,” a lengthy ballad which discusses how he responds when a girl tells him he’s lacking emotional depth because of his consistently happy manner.  During the song he hardcore solo’d all over the grand, improvising for about 5 minutes and even sneaking in a quick “Fur Elise” reference.  By the climax he already had us in stitches, but nearly killed everyone at the last chorus by turning on a wind machine to majestically blow his hair.
Three encores later, he bid us goodnight, and everyone filed out of the theatre with a smile on their face.

title: This Week in Music History: The Prince Edition
content:
by Megan Lent

In 1984 on May 16th, Prince released the single “When Doves Cry.” On the same date in 2000, he stopped being the Artist Formerly Known as Prince and became Prince once again. 

1984 was a big year for Prince. It’s the year he released the album Purple Rain, which would become the soundtrack to the movie of the same name. But “When Doves Cry” was also a huge hit for Prince.

What’s interesting about this artist is his ability to combine so many different genres of music. He’s impossible to classify, with a strange, alien-like style and a sound that mixes everything from jazz to folk to soul. Yeah, this makes him easy to feel uncomfortable around—I think that anyone who makes fun of Prince is really just unable to “get” him—but it also makes him incredibly exciting.

May 15th, 1985, he released “Raspberry Beret,” a date which also falls under this week. Maybe this is just Prince’s favorite week in May, or something. Or, more likely, it’s coincidence. But it’s a great excuse to turn this into a Prince Appreciation Post.

There’s really never been a performer as enigmatic and ethereal as Prince is. I’ve never seen him live, but I’ve seen him on older episodes of Saturday Night Live (and there’s, of course, Purple Rain), and he’s so addictively watchable. 

So, take this opportunity to listen to some Prince this week!

title: This is a real “oh, shit” moment. Our ice is history.
content:
by Charlotte Miller

Ice is really really important, and not just for adorable polar bears. If all of our ice were to melt suddenly, sea levels worldwide would rise by more than 200 feet. According to two new research papers (from Science and Geophysical Research Letters) some major glaciers in the West Antarctic Ice sheet are goners, and, according to the researchers (who, by the way, work for NASA so you know they’re legit) the glaciers’ collapse seems unstoppable. The researchers also believe that the collapse will probably affect adjacent glaciers as well, creating a domino effect for the majority of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet.

So what does that mean? Well, the West Antarctic Ice Sheet contains enough water to raise sea levels by 13 feet. That’s a dramatically different planet. To give you an idea, 99.5% of the population of Louisiana would be submerged and 30% of all homes in Florida would be underwater.  

The West Antarctic Ice Sheet research comes on the heels of the most recent National Climate Assessment, which concluded that climate change, once a far-off notion, is already affecting our weather patterns: extreme heat waves, droughts, and torrential rains are just some of the results of the average 2 degrees Fahrenheit increase in temperature over the last century.

The latest climate change research is simply screaming at us to pay attention, and yet, we treat the warming of our world as an afterthought.

So, to sum up, oh shit. 

Further reading: Mother Jones; New York Times

title: ICYMI: UCLA vs. Harvard Improv
content:
Last Thursday, UCLA’s resident improv team, Rapid Fire, collaborated with visiting team, The Immediate Gratification, in an on-campus performance showcasing the improv stylings of both UCLA and Harvard students.


“Hosting the Harvard improv team was awesome because they specialize in long-form improv. Rapid Fire specializes in short-form, so it was interesting to see that other side of improv,“ said Rapid Fire performer Susan Alami. "Plus it was cool to watch an improv set before we performed!”


And cool it was. The show started off with a “rap battle” between the two teams, where they picked a word and alternated forming sentences to rhyme with said word. Then Harvard launched into their renowned long-form, working together impressively to create clever scenarios from insecure superheroes to sandcastle contest corruption.


Rapid Fire followed with short games, like interviewing a fratty female director about her heartfelt classic, "My Mother, the Elk.” But the most notable moment of the night was undoubtedly a “medicine-man-recommended” four-way kiss between four Rapid Fire performers.


Last week’s event showcased the creativity, undeniable enthusiasm, and ever-present weirdness of two talented teams with different origins and specializations.

title: Podcast Recommendation: Call Chelsea Peretti
content: Chelsea Peretti, known for her blunt stand-up and her role on Brooklyn Nine-Nine, doesn’t disappoint with her podcast Call Chelsea Peretti. Relatable and casual but still satirical, the recent episode “HI AMERICA” dares to discuss race with Tchaiko Omawale and friend Ibrahim, mainly on how difficult it is for white people to talk about Ferguson without sounding stupid. Ibrahim asks why white people are so angry about Ferguson, and argues that on matters of race, they should just listen, prompting Chelsea to bring up an important point that “listening” can translate to being just a passive uninterested white person. Later in the podcast, Chelsea talks to adoring callers, successfully pulling out a range of important topics from them, like when dogs should be put down or put on Prozac, and abruptly hangs up on them. Be sure to check out more of Call Chelsea Peretti for her relevant commentary on Big Brother.

title: UCLA Soccer Sweeps Weekend
content:
by Cole Frost (11/18/2014)

UCLA Women’s Soccer kicked off a major weekend in collegiate soccer with a 5-0 drubbing of San Diego. Five different players scored as twenty-one players got valuable tournament experience for the undefeated Bruins. The Bruins’ next game is slated for Friday, November 21, as the defending national champions will take on Harvard at Drake Stadium at 8:00 p.m. 

Men’s soccer continued the weekend’s success by defeating San Diego State 2-1 on Sunday at Drake. In what can only be called an incredibly professional performance from the Bruins, the UCLA team was a class above the Aztecs for the first 89 minutes of the game. 

On a day where the team was honoring six seniors, including senior Earl Edwards, Jr., and star midfielder Leo Stolz, Leo stole the show. It became clear just how much the team would miss Leo next year when he showed incredible composure and skill on the ball nearly every time he touched it. Stolz benefited from a free-flowing formation and, despite playing a very direct San Diego State team, found ways to get the ball to his feet in space to avoid being bypassed by a team who showed no real desire to keep any possession within the midfield. The Aztecs placed 6’5” Senior Henrik Synnes up top and consistently looked to play directly to the tall target man. For a short time, it looked as though their direct strategy would work, as UCLA struggled to win the second ball. Synnes’ strike-partner hit the bar in the 22nd minute, and UCLA’s Michael Amick followed with a heroic headed save to keep the scores level.

The first thirty minutes failed to produce a real chance for UCLA, who struggled at first to cope with SDSU’s direct style of play. However, the game opened up after Leo Stolz picked a goal from very little by beating the goalie near post during the 31st minute. The goal was met with a small bit of controversy, as a few Aztec players seemed to appeal for a handball after UCLA won the ball at midfield in the move that started the goal; however, the ref appeared to make the correct call in dismissing the appeals. UCLA’s Nico Gonzalez had the best chance of the last 15 minutes of the first half to double the lead, after finding himself in alone on the keeper but being unable to round the Aztec shot-stopper. 

Freshman forward Abu Danladi started the second half, giving UCLA an extra spark. San Diego State, in need of a goal, got absolutely nothing going forward to start the second half. UCLA even struck the bar at the 63rd minute. At the 68th minute, San Diego State’s Jeff Rhodes received a yellow card for a harsh challenge on UCLA’s Felix Vobejda, who had been exploiting the left side of the Aztec defense along with fellow German Leo Stolz. Soon after, Danladi would double the lead with a cool finish off of a breakaway. 

At the 85th minute, with SDSU still posing no real threat, UCLA gave reserves a run out. A lapse in concentration gave SDSU a goal with 18 seconds left in the game, but a simple clearance from UCLA off of the kickoff ended the game and saw the Bruins clinch a 2-1 win that was never really under threat. The team were then greeted by news today that they had received the second overall seed for the Men’s NCAA tournament, which commences this week.

The Men’s team will face either San Diego or Cal State Fullerton in their first tournament game, which will take place on Sunday, November 23rd at 7:00 p.m. The Bruins, who are the tournament’s second overall seed, lost 1-0 away to San Diego earlier this year. The two UCLA soccer programs stand in a unique position, with both the Men’s and Women’s programs having a shot at titles this year, a rare feat that was mostly achieved by the University of Connecticut basketball teams in 2013-2014.

title: Clippers Ride Huge 3rd Quarter To 120-107 Victory Over Suns
content:
By Darryn Albert (11/17/2014)

Chris Paul and DeAndre Jordan led the charge at Staples Center on Saturday night as the Clippers cruised to a big victory over the Phoenix Suns by the final of 120-107.  In a back-and-forth battle between two Western Conference heavyweights that was tied at halftime, the Clippers came blazing out of the gates to start the second half, outscoring the Suns 42-20 in the 3rd quarter and never looking back from there.

The theme for the Clippers on Saturday was Paul pacing the team on the offensive end and Jordan pacing the team on the defensive end.  The former put the team on his back in the second half, scoring 23 points after the break and almost single-handedly putting the clamps on a late Suns comeback bid in the 4th quarter to finish with 32 points and 9 assists.  Meanwhile, Jordan had perhaps his best game of the season, posting 12 points, 18 rebounds, and 7 blocked shots, stifling Phoenix at the rim all night long and making his presence felt on both the offensive and the defensive glass.  

Coach Doc Rivers had high praise for both in his post-game interview.  Speaking about Paul’s aggressive mentality, Rivers mentioned that “he’s such a point guard that it’s hard for him to do it.  But when he does it, I think it makes us a very dangerous basketball team.”  When asked about Jordan’s performance, Rivers said “I thought he was the star of the game.  His energy tonight was amazing.  He was a one-man wrecking crew.”  Commenting about Jordan’s blocked shots, the Clippers coach said “It felt like he had 30 of them” and went on to call his work on Saturday, “a Picasso.”  

Elsewhere for the Clippers, Blake Griffin put up 19 points, 8 rebounds, and 4 assists, crediting “getting defensive stops” for the team’s success and mentioning how “our offense got energy from our defense.”   J.J. Redick added 14, saying “I think tonight was a step forward,” saying how “we were better spread offensively.”  Meanwhile, Spencer Hawes had his best game as a Clipper adding 14 points, 8 rebounds, and 3 blocks off the bench, mentioning how “two really good days of practice” contributed to Saturday’s big victory (though Hawes was spotted with his left foot in a walking boot in the locker room after the game).  Matt Barnes also added 12 points in his return to the starting lineup but was ejected in the 4th quarter after picking up his 2nd technical foul.  When asked for a reaction to Barnes’ ejection, Coach Rivers simply said “No comment.  I want to save my money.”

The Clippers team as a whole shot 53% from the field, hit 14 of their 23 three-point attempts, and got to the line a whopping 43 times (compared to only 23 for the Suns).  They held Phoenix to 38% shooting from the field and though they ceded 19 points each to Goran Dragic and Isaiah Thomas, 17 points and 11 rebounds to Alex Len, and 26 points to Gerald Green, the Clippers held the Morris twins to a combined 8 points, Eric Bledsoe to just 1 point, and really controlled the tempo Saturday against a team well known for playing at one of the fastest paces in the NBA.

With the victory, the Clippers improve to 5-3 on the season and from here, will conclude their homestand on Monday night as they host the Chicago Bulls at 10:30 PM EST/7:30 PM PST.  Rivers commented that he hadn’t thought about the matchup yet, saying “I’m just thinking about dinner tomorrow with Thibs that he’s gonna pay for.”  And while Griffin downplayed the matchup too saying “I don’t like to get into defining games, especially this early in the season,” he did admit that “this will be a good test for us,” and indeed it will be.

title: THROWBACK THURSDAY ALBUM REVIEWS
content:
uclaradio:

This quarter, UCLA Radio is digging deep into the archives and revisiting albums from our distant past.  This series is largely inspired by the incredibly sub-par review given to Emergency and I by the Dismemberment Plan upon its original release (stay tuned to check out this re-review). Keep your eyes peeled for all the classic (and not so classic) albums that we will be revisiting! To inaugurate, our New Media staff member, Eric A. has given another listen Elvis Costello's A Taste of Extreme Honey. 

Re-Review of Elvis Costello’s A Taste of Extreme Honey

by Eric A. 

Elvis Costello’s A Taste of Extreme Honey is a soirée of fleeting thoughts and melodies from Elvis Costello’s body, all representing “places” in his memory, a la Sherlock Holmes memory palace in BBC’s show Sherlock.

Tracklist

1. The Bridge I Burned

2. So Like Candy

3. My Dark Life

4. London’s Brilliant Parade

5. Couldn’t call it unexpected (No. 4)

Track 1, The Bridge I Burned, has a very similar feel to some of his earlier songs, and sounds like some of his combinations with Burt Bacharach such as “In the Darkest Place”. The song has a dual-modality- at times it feels like you’re listening to a sad contemplation of life, and at other times it sounds like you might have accidentally put the Friends theme song on.

So Like Candy was actually co-written by Paul McCartney and Elvis Costello. It’s their song that reflects on a relationship that went sour, and the girl has a now has a shiny new beau that is not Mr. Costello. It’s like a bitter and sad version of your typical break - up song. I’d believe it if this song were on Taylor Swift’s new album coming out.

Track 3 is a weird, weird song. It honestly sounds like a mix between “America the Beautiful” (he literally says this phrase in the song), and “We Are the Champions”, with a disproportionate amount of LSD thrown into the mix. The song doesn’t have a consistent feeling or mood throughout like most of the others- instead, it feels like we are descending into the dark depths of Elvis Costello’s thoughts as he reminisces on past victories, failures, and ephemeral thoughts.

With his 4th song, Costello recedes from the dark depths of My Dark Life and comes back into what one could call his comfort zone. This song represents one of the frequently visited places in his brain, the one that he exudes in a lot of his more fun, rambunctious songs. For Simon and Garfunkel fans, this song is reminiscent of “At the Zoo”, and uses metaphors to describe the specific place he is in at the time that he is writing this song. The victory horns provide an apt contrast to the womanless, bachelor style life which he indulges himself in.

Elvis rounds of the five song album with his song Couldn’t Call it Unexpected (Number Four). The track has myriad instruments backing up the vocals- including instruments that sound like a mandolin, a trumpet, a rolling drum beat, and even a triangle. One would think this track should actually take on the name of track four, because upon closing your eyes, it feels like you are watching the finale to a musical about a clown parade. Upon analysis of the lyrics, though, it’s clear that the song follows the same archetype of “sad songs about girls”. What I call the “parade” music in the background provides a nice juxtaposition to the dejected subtext of the lyrics.

A Taste of Extreme Honey has everything for a Costello fan- it has the classic sound of juxtaposition that long time Costello listeners can relate to, but also the ingenuity and fluctuation that, at this point, is expected from Elvis Costello’s music.
