title: Ten-Men Bruins Defeat #1 Washington
content:
By Cole Frost (10/23/14)

UCLA Men’s Soccer held off Washington despite playing most of the second half with ten men. The Bruins, who came into the game after a tough weekend in Northern California saw them lose to Berkeley and draw Stanford, kept Washington in check during the second half, securing a 2-1 win. After a first ten minutes where both teams really struggled to establish a rhythm or take hold of the game, Leo Stolz opened the scoring for UCLA with a bit of clever work at the top of the Washington box. Washington, however, would level only five minutes later with a Josh Heard goal. Heard finished in plenty of space after a well-placed cross by Huskies defender Justin Schmidt. However, it took a mere five minutes for UCLA to regain the lead as Seyi Adekoya finished off a good attack started by a quality tackle in the midfield, capping off an enthralling ten minutes that saw three goals.

Adekoya found himself at the center of attention several times throughout the game. In addition to the goal, Adekoya got the crowd on its feet with a clever turn around midfield. The Freshman forward beat his defender with a brilliantly executed dummy. However, he also put the Bruins down to ten men with two reckless tackles. The first came ten minutes into the game, when Adekoya ran through a Washington player. The second yellow card, which had some slight room for debate but was certainly within reason, came with nearly forty minutes left to play.

After this red card, the Bruins buckled down. However, Washington did not necessarily dictate the flow of play until the closing minutes. Striker Abu Danladi led the lines and kept the pressure on Washington defensively, taking some of the heat off of a solid UCLA defense. Center back Michael Amick, despite looking uncomfortable in possession at times, was solid defensively, including one goal-line clearance. Earl Edwards Jr. put in a shift in goal, coming up with six saves to maintain the conference victory for the Bruins.

The Bruins followed the victory with a 3-0 drubbing of Oregon State, in a game where Abu Danladi grabbed two goals in the first half. UCLA jumped to #2 in the nation’s RPI rankings with the weekend’s performance. The Bruins now face a trip north to take on Washington and Oregon State away.

title: The Strokes: August 24th, 2014 at FYF Fest
content:
Check out this super sweet FYF throwback review by our New Media staff member Bryan!!! 

by Bryan Villalpando 

The Strokes headlined day two of FYF Fest at Exposition Park in Los Angeles, CA and for not having a concert in Los Angeles since 2006, the crowd was definitely a bit anxious about the show: “Are they still going to be good after 3 years of not playing a single concert?!”, a fan exclaims to me and the tens of thousands of people, eagerly waiting for them to start. 10 minutes into their set time begins, still no sign of the band. The crowd begins to sing their 2001 hit, “Someday” out of sheer impatience yet excitement. Then house lights dim and a deep red light filled the stage. The crowd screamed as the shadows of Julian Casablancas (Lead Singer), Nikolai Fraiture (Bassist), Albert Hammond Jr. (Guitarist), and Fabrizio Moretti (Drums) appear. Standing stolidly for about 30 seconds, they tease the crowd with their presence. 3 half-beats of snare drum signify the beginning of their song, “Barely Legal” off of their debut album Is This It, and the beginning of their set. Released in 2001, the song brought nostalgia to the entire crowd, ranging from students just as myself—I was in elementary school when this 13-year-old song came out—to the parents of those students previously mentioned. The song finished and the crowd went wild, demanding more.

The Strokes did not let down at all. Their set consisted of 17 songs, ranging from their smash hits “Reptilia”, from the Room on Fire album, and “Last Nite”, from their Is this it album, to their new songs “One Way Trigger” and “Welcome to Japan” off of their latest album Comedown Machine. Throughout the show, the entire crowd jumped, screamed, and sang as much as their hearts let them. “We don’t want our talking to take time from our set, so we’re just going to play if that’s okay.” Julian states. 16 straight songs later, the band says their goodbyes and walk away.

The best moment was the encore of the concert. After 5 minutes of the crowd screaming, “One more song!” the band reappeared. “This one goes out to the homies in Ferguson” Julian Casablancas states as the stage lights turn a patriotic red, white, and blue. A 4 count from the drummer and the band begins to play their most controversial song “New York City Cops” from their album Is This It. Because the song was dropped from their US version of their album, only the truest fans knew the song. 

90 minutes later, the band said their goodbyes to the FYF Festival, thus ending another successful year. The show that The Strokes produced—the energy created—resonated within me for the next two weeks. I still feel nostalgia induced goose bumps when I hear a strokes song. The Strokes: a rare performer, a life changing experience.

title: Concert Alert: Julian Casablancas + the Voidz take on the Wiltern this Thursday (11/06/14)
content:
Singer-songwriter, label owner, and multi-instrumentalist Julian Casablancas is coming back to Los Angeles to play a live show with his new backing band, “the Voidz.” Julian Casablancas + the Voidz’s album Tyranny, came out late last month on Julian’s own Cult Records and has been long anticipated since playing numerous shows all across the globe for the past year. Fans of Julian can remember his month-long stint at the back in 2009 for his debut solo album Phrazes for the Young, in which Julian had a Friday-night residency in the month of November. His band then included a young Danielle Haim on drums, most notable for fronting the Los Angeles-based band Haim, along with her sisters Este and Alana.

Julian Casablancas + the Voidz are back for another show after playing the main stage at this year’s FYF Festival in Downtown LA at Exposition Park in support of Tyranny, where they played with bands such as Blood Orange, who supported the band for a secret release show at the very intimate DIY venue Shea Stadium in New York, and Mac DeMarco, who is scheduled to tour with JC + the Voidz later on in the tour.

Julian Casablancas + the Voidz play the Wiltern this Thursday with a very special guest (!!!) (11/06/14), in Santa Ana tonight at the Observatory (11/05/14) with support from Part Time, and will be on tour across North America for the rest of the month before heading to Europe for another leg of the tour.

GET YOUR TICKETS TO SEE JC + THE VOIDZ @ THE WILTERN HERE!!!

title: The Groundlings Theatre (1/27) // Improv Review
content:
Written By: Lillian Stanwick

Post Date: 2/10/17

It was 9:50 p.m. by the time I arrived at The Groundlings Theatre on the corner of Melrose and Poinsettia, and I was surprised to see a decent-sized line formed outside of the brick building. When I had previously called the theater, the staff made it clear that there would be no late seatings. True to their word, within five minutes the doors were opened, and by 10:15 everyone had taken their seats and the show had begun. Although I had never been to an improv show, I had high expectations from the star-studded list of former cast members. Backstage West, a magazine for working actors, once dubbed The Groundlings Theatre “the unofficial training ground for future players on Saturday Night Live.” Sure enough, photos of the school’s famous alumni, including Jillian Bell, Melissa McCarthy, Kristen Wiig, Maya Rudolph, and Will Ferrell, decorate the lobby.

Melissa McCarthy and Will Ferrell in The Groundlings.

The Groundlings Theatre met my high expectations. Every sketch was clever and well executed. The audience was in stitches from the first scene, about a new nail technician and his pushy girlfriend, to the last number of the night, about two background singers breaking out into a solo career. It occurred to me early on that one of the cast members looked remarkably familiar, so during the intermission, I googled his name and confirmed that I, in fact, did recognize the actor - Andrew Leeds, from his recurring role on Bones as Pelant. This discovery speaks to the theater’s ability to draw both up-and-coming as well as well-established actors to their stage.

My favorite sketch of the night featured Mr. Leeds. This scene was a musical number that followed two sports writers as they tried to find a story to save their failing sports website. The tune was very catchy, and I can assure you that it was stuck in my head for the next three days after the show. If you asked me, I could probably perform half of the dance that went along with it too. My plus one for the night preferred a different musical sketch, which featured two intellectuals critiquing their daughter’s talent show choreography, culminating in an overtly sexual and outrageous dance routine to Hailee Steinfeld’s “Starving.”

Halfway through the show, two of the cast members performed an improvised scene. An audience member was asked to read the last text message they received, which was to become the first line of the new sketch. The selected text message read, “I was planning something for after,” and the subsequent scene had a somewhat expected, suggestive theme, but it was funny nonetheless. Another standout sketch that featured audience participation commented on the ridiculous nature of fame. It opened with the entrance of two female cast members dressed in gaudy clothing who proclaimed that their job was to “seem famous.” According to them, Los Angeles is full of people like them who carry the air and appearance of being famous but are not actually famous. They then brought a rather reluctant audience member onstage with them and taught her how to “seem famous” as well, sharing tips about how to name-drop and casually mention that you’re filming a blockbuster. For me, the weak link of the night was a Liam Neeson sketch that fell short, but overall I found the show to be consistently entertaining.

I’d be remiss if I didn’t take a moment to complement the live band that played during set changes. The trio did an excellent job of maintaining the audience’s energy by playing segments from a variety of classic songs, from artists such as the Rolling Stones to newer songs by Daft Punk and Arcade Fire.

After the show, the cast members came out into the lobby and mingled with the audience members. I was very surprised to see this since it is very unusual for the staff of professional companies to interact with the public post-performance. However, I was glad that The Groundlings Theatre did this because it gave me an opportunity to talk to Andrew Leeds and tell him how I thought he was excellent in Bones, like a total noob.

As a whole, The Groundlings put on a good show, and I’d recommend that everyone take the chance to see them on a Friday night while you’re going to UCLA. As a word of advice, the earlier you show up, the better your seat will be, and if you are hoping to participate, try to sit near the aisle where you’ll be easier to reach. No matter where you end up, though, I guarantee you’ll enjoy The Groundlings Theatre’s witty comedy and silly sketches.

title: Russell Westbrook is Box Office...But
content:
Written By: James Shippy, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 12/11/16

Russell Westbrook is box office. Russell Westbrook is a spectacle we can’t turn our eyes from. But Russell Westbrook can kiss winning an NBA Championship in OKC goodbye. And last but not least, Russell Westbrook has great numbers, but it’s all fools gold at the end of the day.

Now before you throw your phone at the wall, knock your computer off the table, and contemplate sending death threats…hear me out.

First, let me give this man his props. Westbrook is doing things that 98 percent of humans are incapable of. He’s setting this league on fire and sending a message to Kevin Durant that he’s doing fine just without him. He’s playing a jilted lover left at the altar whose determination to get a revenge bod has only made him hotter - and I mean a hotter commodity. As of today he’s averaging 31.2 points, 11.3 assists, and 10.5 rebounds. He’s a fantasy basketball dream come true. We should be thankful that we get to witness this kind of dominance in a league that has become just as compelling in American sports as the No Fun League (NFL.)

Instead of tucking tail and signing with a ready made team that didn’t need him like Durant this past summer, Westbrook said the hell with that.  Westbrook doubled down and reiterated that the OKC Thunder was his team and that he was always as suspected, the alpha male on that squad.

But Westbrook and I know a little something that the rest of the basketball fan boys fail to see. Westbrook is going to be a stat machine for the rest of his prime with no jewelry to show for it. Let’s realize there’s nothing wrong with that.  People would kill to be able to play basketball for a living. We’re talking about a childhood game that you can get millions for, including endorsements and fame.  

Right now the OKC Thunder have a record of 14-5. They’re the fifth ranked team in the Western Conference, and Westbrook is averaging a triple double later in the season than anyone in NBA history besides Oscar Robertson, the only man ever to average a triple double for a whole NBA season. But we have to dig deeper. The Thunder have only defeated two teams that currently have winning records above .500. It’s still early in the season but if those numbers keep up once the season is over, Westbrook can only take OKC so far in the playoffs without a viable number two scorer.

I can see people arguing, “But Westbrook is doing what he has to do.” That is true, but do you think, given the way he dominates the ball, that a top tier free agent will want to go play with him in Oklahoma City? Do you think the Thunder will be bad enough to get a top draft pick in the next few years? The answer is no.  Westbrook’s best chance at a championship is basking in the Golden State Warriors locker room as we speak.  

If we were to compare these players, Westbrook is a like a Ferrari in a driveway of an apartment in Pacoima. Durant is a Prius in a driveway of a Beverly Hills condo. I’ll take the latter situation any day of the week.

For now, I’m going to sit back and enjoy the show like everyone else, because we’re watching individual history being made in the NBA. But unfortunately, the NBA is a team sport.

title: Excerpts from My E-Mail
content:
Written By: Aaron Peretz

Post Date: 3/2/17

The email inbox/outbox is a plenum, both un-empty and unchanging. In fact, any corpus of content is unwavering in its immediacy. Each thread samples the changing I. Inevitably, however, any thread is taken out of context, thus misrepresenting the self as positive (substantive) stagnancy. Because of public critique the self receives dynamic interpretation through its preservation in art. The private nature of e-mail fails to accurately capture the changing nature of an I. In fact, change is never captured; it is simply contacted. In offering public access to private artifacts, I hope to create a space for contact and resolve anymisconceptions about my nature.

‘Please preserve this message.

Enjoy!’

‘Hi D—,

Attached is, you guessed it, the bootleg audio from Bruce Conner’s CROSSROADS. Recorded at SFMoMA, the audio synthesizes the certainty of Patrick Gleeson and Terry Riley’s intent, with the authentic experience of the recidivistic audience. Including white noise, scruffles, and cough-coughing, the new mint stands as a reinterpretation, a standalone work of art—in this sense, my own position is related to the recording as Pierre Menard stands to QUIXOTE.

Conspiratorily yours,

[Aaron]’

‘Heidegger’s had a profound framing on subsequent studies of mine.’

‘I’ve continued to probe our discussion on God. I especially appreciate your point about contact, I think it rings true. One aspect that troubles me, or at least nags, is the question of being heard. Many people find comfort in keeping a diary, or holding a personal relationship with God. I, on the other hand, have never been able to commit to a diary (or conversations with God)—I write down the thoughts I consider important, but that rarely includes a strict recounting of my day. Part of my failure to commit is because I’m not heard. Writing down the important thoughts is a means to further elaboration and ultimately communication. Keeping a diary or “communicating” with God doesn’t satisfy the quality of being heard by people that aren’t me. 

Perhaps I’ve misunderstood the purpose of having a diary/talking with God. Maybe it lies in a distinction between meditation and therapy. Still, if writing our thoughts down is meditative (a discussion with ourself), then why do we need God? At first glance, it seems that keeping a diary, writing thoughts down, or talking to God all fulfill the same purpose of meditation. And talking with God can’t be therapy because it’s actually a conversation with another part of yourself. So why do we need to posit a make-believe God rather than just writing our thoughts down?

Hope all is well.’

‘Hey J—,

Thanks again for gifting me the SubPac! It’s been working great. I even held a de facto show ‘n’ tell with some UCLA Radio people who were pretty hyped on it.’

‘ A waiter comes over to a table full of Jewish women and asks, “Is anything alright ?” ’

‘I’ve made a lot of notes. All of my notes are important to some degree. The last one and the one starting in bold are most important for general criticism of the whole essay. I think some sentences/paragraphs need to be moved around to better preserve and highlight a structure. The historicization is pretty good, can use a little cleaning (not much). Your sociological views aren’t robust enough yet. (Don’t be racist). I talk about settling on a direction of causation. If you’re notsure what I mean ask me. Ask if you have any other questions in general.’

‘I need something by tomorrow.’

‘Hello Music Department,

As evident by the subject line, I’m petitioning that SPOILER ROOM be granted a Level 1 excusal from logging NMFs for Winter 2017. The show has taken its own form and makes its selections known to me, its servant. The show survives on a diet primarily consisting of 80s and 90s dance music with support from new wave, no wave, ambient, and a little bit of rock 'n’ roll. The music of now is never precluded, and often finds a seat on the playlist. However, the show curates a feeling, and that feeling is endangered by limitations in finding so-called "new music.”

The music played on my program is overwhelmingly niche. That is to say, for most audiences, it will be their first encounter with the content. To identify new music as just-released music is, I think, a conflation. What’s new is what’s untainted. Moreover we should say that what’s untainted is most precious. And the most precious gems are preserved under the weight of history. These gems are what SPOILER ROOM seeks to uncover. Un-leash the show, and let it dig up history.

Thank you,

[Aaron]’

‘<Subject: Username and password recovery at Chess Tactics Server>

handle: —

password: —

email: —

Please preserve this message.

Enjoy!’

title: “And Please, Jen, No Politics at the Table.”
content:
Written By: Jen Harbeck, UCLA Radio Comedy

Post Date: 12/16/16

In the days leading up to Thanksgiving, the question of whether or not politics would make an appearance at the dining room table this holiday season clouded the thoughts of my friends and all the feeds of social media. Coming from a liberal household, I did not expect my family to avoid the topic of politics when I came home, but in fact I was wrong.

“Don’t talk about the election when you are home,” my mother said as I prepared to exit the car outside my house. I was shocked with the only thoughts that ran through my head being:

1. What a strange request to come from my pro-Clinton mother.

2. Will there still be stuffing this year?

3. I’m a political science major, that’s all I know.

4. I mean I can deal with no turkey, but stuffing?

5. Does that mean someone voted for you-know-who?

6. Stuffing.

So I asked what any liberal arts college student coming home for the holidays would in a situation such as this - “Who voted for Trump?”

“No one, what, why would you ask that?” she responded, furrowing her brows at my question. “Dad just doesn’t like how upset the household gets when we talk about it.”

I furrowed my brows. She furrowed her brows even more, as if it were a competition of furrowing brows, which in this case it definitely was.

I, of course, was not done investigating the issue of discussing politics (or brow furrowing for that matter) and thus went directly to the most active member of the family group chat, my brother. If anyone knew what was going down on the frontlines of family discourse, it was him.

“Let’s talk politics.” Richard swiveled in his office chair as I entered his room after five minutes in the household, as if waiting for my arrival.

“Who voted Trump?” I responded.

“I think Dad did.”

“What?

“I said it.”

“No.”

“Yes.”

“Are you sure?”

“Not hundred percent, but…”

“Well mom said everyone voted Clinton.”

“You don’t know that.”

“But he voted Bernie in the primaries,” I responded, furrowing my brows in confusion. My father could not have voted Trump, he was my father, he was my mother’s husband, he was a huge Bernie supporter.

“He gets annoyed when we talk about the election,” my brother shrugged. “But you never know. Anyway did you hear about the recount in Wisconsin with Jill Stein? In my opinion, they should be doing it in Michigan there was a closer margin in that state….”  

I nodded as my thoughts became clouded with the idea that my house was a house truly divided by political ideology. Was this what all my friends were worrying about back on campus, about dealing with a household split by the election? Was this now my reality? Would there be stuffing? So of course I went straight to the source, my father, regarding the issue with my furrowed brow and the fear that my brother was right.

“Dad, I need to ask you a question,” I bravely stuttered as he put down his yoga mat and looked over at me. My father had picked up yoga as his drug of choice ever since retirement, and thus had acquired at least four more mats in the past two years, for what? I still do not know.

“Yes?”

“Will there be stuffing this year?” I asked nervously.

“I’m pretty sure, we always have stuffing. But no alcohol or pork, your brother’s girlfriend’s family is coming over and they are Muslim.” He responded putting away his yoga blocks. “They are a really sweet family, so best behavior. And please Jen, no politics at the table.”

title: Maple Syrup’s Vera Williams Speaks Out About Their Latest Music Video “Maybe Someday (I’ll Have a Friend)”
content:
Written By: Elizabeth Hsieh 

Post Date: 2/16/17

Currently studying at UCLA as a foreign exchange student from New Zealand, Vera Williams of Maple Syrup was quick to plunge herself into LA’s music scene by creating two new bands and playing constant house shows throughout California. For those who have not yet heard of Maple Syrup, their sound embodies that new wave of gritty, melodic punk combined with the sound of dirty guitars and momentous bass lines. Even as she is separated from the band back home, she continues to make moves in her musical career, with her band just recently releasing a music video for their single “Maybe Someday (I’ll Have a Friend)”. Check it out below.

Who is Vera? Who is Maple Syrup?

My name is Vera. I am currently a student at UCLA and I am from Wellington, New Zealand. Maple Syrup began about 4 years ago in Wellington, with myself and Jerry Ramirez making absurd folk mix tapes. We eventually got our friend from High School, Tarquin Smith, on drums and Lukas Jury on bass, and developed a much heavier sound. Since then, we’ve played shows all around New Zealand, released an EP and have recorded a soon-to-be-released record, which this single is off of.

What was the inspiration behind the video?

I remember I got the idea in the middle of the night. That’s usually when I get my best ideas. I’ve always liked one shot videos with minimal editing. Its fascinating to watch action play out sort of live in front of you, like in Radiohead’s “No Surprises” video! Our band is very much about the coming together of the sublime and the ridiculous — and I think the video is inspired by that concept.

How was the creative process of making the video? Were there any difficulties?

We spent the day after Christmas rehearsing the video from start to finish with all of the cues - from the lighting, to when each object would be thrown on me - until we had it perfect. That got pretty tedious because of how messy I ended up getting, and we had limited resources (e.g. one pack of cigarettes) and only one shot to get it perfect. Our plan was to just roll with it if something went wrong, but luckily nothing did. When I beat up Jerry at the end of the video, what you can’t see is that he is lying in a pile of squashed cigarettes mixed with maple syrup and water. 

There are weird objects being thrown at you during the video. How did you decide on what objects to include?

Each one had a different reason. Some were chosen in direct reference to the lyrics (e.g. the cigarettes and the paint brush). Others were chosen purely for visual effect (e.g. the toilet paper, the egg on the head, the bucket of water). Then of course there is the Maple Syrup reference with the pancakes! Each object also has its own symbolic purpose as well, I suppose.

Your character undergoes quite a drastic change in attitude during the video. Can you talk about some of the symbolism behind that?

My interpretation is that it’s about someone who is going through life passively, not letting anything affect her. In the song that’s expressed by the passive way I sing harsh lyrics, and in the video by my lack of a reaction to having various objects thrown at me. When I’m pushed over the edge, I finally expresses myself and assert my power by getting revenge. I’m sure everyone will read the video differently, though. There is no correct interpretation.

So would you say there is a feminist angle to the video?

Definitely. I think that, as women, we are expected to deal with a lot and be able to just get on with it and not burden others with our feelings. Our ability to do that so well is a testimony to how strong we really are. At the same time, it’s important to liberate yourself from those expectations and express who you are and how you feel. I think my character is pretty chuffed with herself once she does.

How can we stay tuned for more info about the upcoming album?

We already have two singles out which you can listen/download free on bandcamp. We update everything on Facebook and you can follow our Instagram for regular nudes @Whoismaplesyrup.
tags: maybe someday i'll have a friend

title: RIP Craig Sager: A Cancer Survivor’s Perspective
content:
Written By: Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 12/18/16

On December 15, the Turner Sports family, the NBA, and the world lost a shining light in long-time sideline reporter Craig Sager, who passed away after his two and a half year long battle with leukemia. What will never be lost, however, is Sager’s courage and compassion which touched and inspired so many. While there is much sadness in the loss of such an iconic figure, it is impossible to look back on Sager’s life and career and not feel a deep sense of gratitude for his unwavering courage in the face of true hardship, his vibrant personality, and his refusal to compromise on those things which make life worth living.

In the days since his passing, hundreds of Sager’s colleagues and fans have come out to offer their condolences to his family and share their fondest memories of the man and how he affected the lives of everyone he met. These videos and articles are out there and I highly recommend you check them out, as well as his speech at the ESPY Awards earlier this year where he was presented the Jimmy V Award for Perseverance by Vice President Joe Biden. 

While I echo all of the sentiments expressed above, this is not one of those pieces. I’m not writing this to talk about the death of a giant in the world of sports broadcasting. The reason I’m writing this piece is because I feel a deep connection to Mr. Sager. I am also writing this because, in a year when we have lost so many, Sager’s death has affected me deeply in ways I have yet to fully process. I am still trying to understand how his death, and more importantly his legacy, will impact how I will live the rest of my life.

Craig Sager was a shining example of positivity in the face of adversity. He demonstrated that you can live your life with joy no matter what circumstances you may face. Most people who know me know that I am a Golden State Warriors fan. What not all of them may know is that this fandom came on very suddenly just last year, out of the most unexpected of circumstances. Last September, just weeks before I was to begin my senior year at UCLA, I was diagnosed with Stage III Mediastinal B-Cell Lymphoma. In less than a week, my life went from going to concerts with friends and stressing over the prospect of writing my senior thesis to a seemingly endless barrage of scans, biopsies, and hospital beds.

I’m not going to lie and say I knew about Sager growing up, or even that he was influential for me going into my treatment. I only started watching basketball after I was diagnosed and found myself with lots of extra time and empty nights, looking for a sense of purpose and identity when it seemed like all others had been taken away from me. I was no longer a student or a friend or a musician - I was just a cancer patient. That was, except for a couple of nights a week, when I was a Warriors fan. Being a fan of the Warriors meant that, even if it was just for some precious hours out of the week, I was on the winning team.

One of the things that first drew me to the Warriors (what has made me such an ardent GIF-sharing, monogrammed-backpack-carrying, superstitious-lucky-cap-wearing fan) was the sense of joy with which they played every night. It was clear that they loved what they were doing, and even when the stakes were high, they would never sacrifice the fun and love of the game. As someone who has chosen to live my life pursuing my passion, this resonated with me deeply. Whatever joy the Warriors expressed on the court, Sager exemplified the same joy on the sidelines, not just in his unapologetically flamboyant and at times outrageous outfits and amiable demeanor, but in the thoughtfulness and directness of his questions and the high standard to which he held his work every night.

You can never know how you will respond to something like cancer until you’re faced with it directly. I never imagined it could happen to me and I certainly could not have predicted that if it did, I would face it with positivity and use it as an opportunity to become a stronger person. Don’t get me wrong, cancer is absolutely horrible. Chemotherapy is a long and unrelenting uphill battle designed to push your body to its absolute limits. I don’t need to go into all of that. While I was hooked up to machines in the hospital bed during one of many five-day stays to receive my chemotherapy, I knew my circumstances were unusual and objectively awful. I knew that regardless of how I felt on a given day, I was always sick. If I ever happened to forget, I had visitors coming in everyday telling me how terrible my situation was and how it was so unfair that I had to endure this.

Yet, as I sat in my bed and looked around at the family and friends by my side, and the doctors and nurses who worked tirelessly to get me well, I felt like the luckiest person in the world. Yes, I was very ill and hundreds of miles away from the friends and school I loved so dearly, but I knew all of that would still be waiting for me when I was healthy enough to go back. My fingers had gone numb as a side-effect of my chemotherapy which made playing guitar and bass quite difficult, but every time I picked up my instrument, I felt a fire inside of me that pushed me to play harder everyday. People would ask me how my treatment was going and I almost had to bite my tongue because I felt like I was doing nothing but brag about the excellent care I was receiving.

You can also never know the ways in which cancer will try to break you until you experience it firsthand. It doesn’t care if you’re young or old, rich or poor, religious or atheist. It will take from you everything it can, and in the face of that battle there is no “correct” way to cope with cancer. How you process and face your illness is as unique to the individual as your treatment plan. Whether you choose to greet the day with gratitude or with anger, everyone’s emotions are valid. When I woke up in the morning and saw before me an opportunity to seize the day and show this disease that it would not dictate how I lived my life, it wasn’t because I thought it would help me get better faster or make me less of a burden on those around me. It was simply how I saw the world. Prior to cancer, I was already aggressively optimistic and always tried to look on the bright side, not for any superficial reason, but simply because it was there.

Craig Sager was validation that I didn’t have to view cancer as a negative - that sickness didn’t have to become my identity, and that if you live life with love and passion as your core, you can overcome anything. While my age and prognosis clearly differ greatly from Mr. Sager’s, I know there is always pressure to give in and succumb to the weight and the gravity, especially when it feels like your disease is always three steps ahead and you’re struggling just to hold down a meal. I am in constant awe of the lengths to which he went to seek every experimental treatment that offered a chance at extending his life, all while continuing to work and travel to cover games, sometimes just hours after receiving chemotherapy. It’s no small feat to not only refuse to let your illness hinder your spirit and ability to pursue your passion, but also to use it as fuel to push you to chase after it like never before, whether or not optimism is your default state of mind.

When you decide to live your life following your passion, it is a choice you make every single day and a mentality that drives everything else you do in life. For Sager, letting cancer keep him from working was never an option. Taking time away from the NBA to receive treatments that required him to be in total isolation, as some doctors had suggested, would have meant that the cancer had won. No matter what the disease threw at him, he was adamant that a life in which he could not do the job he loved most was not a life worth living.

Prior to the start of the Golden State Warriors game against the New York Knicks in Oakland Thursday night, Warriors head coach Steve Kerr, who was a colleague of Sager’s at TNT prior to taking the coaching job at Golden State, spoke of Sager’s “zest for life,” and said that rather than have a moment of silence, “given the way Craig lived his life and the joy that he brought to so many people, [it would be more appropriate] to have a moment of joy instead.” The entire Oracle Arena agreed and responded with fervent applause and cheers.

It is easy to boil down Sager’s legacy to his elaborate suits or his memorable conversations with Kevin Garnett and San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich. But as a survivor, I will view Mr. Sager’s true legacy as his ongoing commitment to his job, his family and friends, and always being himself and expressing his true colors, even when the vibrancy of those colors may raise some eyebrows.

While Craig Sager’s battle with leukemia may be over, he did not lose the battle. He lived his life with courage, grace and optimism right through his final days. The fire of his spirit, kept alive for so many years by his compassionate soul and fierce tenacity, could not be doused by cancer. It still burns deep in the hearts of all who knew him and were inspired by his unrelenting determination to, as he said so eloquently in his ESPY Awards speech, “sucking the marrow out of life as life sucks the marrow out of me.”

We may have lost Craig Sager, but cancer did not win.

title: Jalen Santoy Talks Philosophy, His New EP, and Summers in LA
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp

Post Date: 2/20/17

“The sole feature that gives an action moral worth is not the outcome that is achieved by the action, but the motive that is behind the action.”

Kant’s famous philosophy echoes in the back of my mind as I try to recall his work. Kant? Kant. He’s the philosopher that caused a breakout on my roommates pore-less face during fall quarter. She cried about it and almost switched her major to chemistry. Kant’s a priori rhetoric is on the tip of my tongue, but it lingers and melts into my taste buds. I gulp. I can’t recall it exactly. It’s hot, even for an LA day in February, but Charlotte hip-hop artist, Jalen Santoy, is composed, and smiling. “Kant is my favorite philosopher. I had to take a break for a while, but he’s still my favorite. I like to test my pen.”

Santoy’s demeanor is inviting and playful. He asks genuine questions and goes out of his way to make eye contact. He visited UCLA Radio for an interview on February 4 and talked about his latest EP, Charlie Eastern, named after his late cousin who passed at the hands of a police officer. With over 13 million hits on Spotify and a thriving career ahead of him, Santoy has every reason not to be humble. But he is.

“I love all types of instruments, but I wouldn’t say jazz is my only influence. I grew up listening to a lot of Jay-Z, Tupac… but I don’t want to be compared to any of them. J Cole has done a lot for North Carolina in general and I definitely look up to him in some lights. I have respect for his craft, but I have respect for mine as well. You can’t be mad at another person’s reality… in a sense it’s all subjective,” he says.

Santoy’s most famous song, “Foreplay,” is rooted in traditional jazz sound, with the saxophone and bass drum carrying the melody from beginning to finish. Charlie Eastern depicts the story of a coming of age man, experiencing heartbreak, death, and a means to be the life of the party, especially if that means wearing a mink in the summer. The messages in each song resonate with listeners for all different reasons, and prove that Santoy has a focused vision for his life.

His relationship with his mom stands out the most. I ask him about the line, “You cannot achieve what you cannot articulate..” found in his track “Mama Loves Me.” A self-proclaimed mama’s boy, Santoy explains, “She didn’t know music was my passion… I didn’t want to give it (my music) to her, I didn’t want to give it to a lot of people until it was right. She heard it on the radio, and it was a moment for her. She cried.”

I asked about Black Lives Matter and his politicized messaging in his lyrics. “I want my music to stand for progression and social awareness.. I don’t want that all to be my music embodies, but it’s a platform I want my music to standby. A lot of dilemmas that we deal with socially… it can be solved with awareness. You can have communication about it, but once you find ways to make the awareness intentful and find ways to change things, that’s when I think things are going to change,” he says.

This thought resonates with me and I immediately question the intermingling of hip hop and politics. Two frameworks - two philosophies - all made for the same purpose? I wonder. “The most that resonate with people are what resonates within their society.. Politics isn’t as personal. In hip-hop, we don’t have the masses that politics embodies, but we have a culture and a following,” he explains.

Santoy’s music isn’t strictly political. His hit “Off the Glass” of his EP is catchy and should be remixed during college and club DJ sets. Paying ode to Jordan Belford of Wolf of Wall Street, I picture good girls rapping the chorus. “I’d rather wear a mink in the summer,” creates the perfect visual of irony and spontaneity.

In 2017, Santoy plans on developing his sound, landing some concerts, and putting out more music. He’s never spent a summer in LA. I told him, “I will buy you a mink if you wear it in the summer. On the beach. In Venice. We will make a music video.”

Summer 2017, we’re coming for you.

title: It’s Time for the Raptors to Trade for Paul Millsap
content:
Written By: Aidan Donahue, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 1/11/17

After a scorching hot start, the Hawks have come back to earth. This has left their front office looking in the mirror, forced to evaluate the moves the team made this off-season. They currently sit at 20-16, a record good enough to rank them fourth in the East. The team appears to be set for a middle playoff seed in the East, at best a first round victory. They pose no real threat to the conference leading Cavs. Their front office is now forced to ask themselves: are we good enough?

Flying north of the border to Toronto, Dwane Casey’s bunch is right on the heels of Cleveland. They stand at second in the conference with a 24-11 record, leaving them two and half games behind the Cavs. Last season, they took Cleveland to six games in the Eastern Conference Finals. The franchise’s best seasons by winning percentages are this one, and the three years previous. This core group - built around Kyle Lowry and Demar Derozan– is setting franchise records in wins. But when considering their ability to actually beat the Cavs in a playoff series, we are forced to ask ourselves: are they good enough?

There are many ways to characterize “good enough.” The owners must think about profit much more than we as fans do. Toronto fans are thrilled about the success of their team, leading to tremendous ticket sales and a collective energy around the city of Toronto. Fans are proud. The team has two all stars. They sure are good, but when is good enough?

On the other hand, the Hawks have an emerging point guard in Dennis Schroder, an all-star in Paul Millsap, and a reinvigorated hometown hero in Dwight Howard. Fourth in the conference isn’t too bad either. But if the sole goal is to win a championship, then both teams have some serious self-reflection to do.

The Hawks need to reboot and build their team with younger players. Howard and Millsap are both 31. The timetables don’t line-up between the progression of their young players and the abilities of their established hoopers. Plus Millsap has a player option for the upcoming year, and he could opt out to try to cash in on one more long term contract in today’s fountain-of-fortunes NBA. In all, it looks like their best option is trade Millsap for as much youthful talent as they can get, setting their sights on contention in three to four years.

The sell is tougher for the Raptors. They are in the midst of unprecedented success for their franchise. There is a lot at risk, a lot to lose. At the same time, most teams would kill to be in their position for one reason: opportunity. They are one player away, a couple lucky injuries away, a couple insane performances from their stars away from really competing for a title. Few teams have had an opportunity to be this close; why not put all your chips in to try to win a title?

The Raptors are limited primarily because of their defense and rebounding. While they pace the league in offensive rating (points scored per 100 possessions), they are fifteenth in defensive rating. There is little precedent for teams to win a title without a top offense and defense. Even more telling, they’re twenty third in defensive rebound percentage.

Millsap would go a long way to plugging these holes. He is the best heavy minutes defender on the Hawks, who sport the fifth best defensive rating in the league. Among rotation players on the Hawks, he has the third best defensive rating, first among players who play more than 20 minutes per game. He brings a needed agility to the power-forward spot, allowing him to chase around quicker players and unlock a faster overall defensive scheme. This would allow the Raptors to switch on more picks, which is beneficial against any team, but almost necessary against the Warriors. He is second on the team in steals, a testament to his elite hands for his position. He is eleventh in the league in defensive rebounds per game among non centers, so he would boost the Raptors in that category. He is also a great size to match up with Lebron - this is key for any team that wants to take down the Cavs.

In addition, he would make their league best offense even better. His ability to hit the three would open up more driving lanes for Derozan and Lowry. He is also a great playmaker–averaging 3.7 assists per game– which would allow for better ball movement and more off-ball Lowry.

Now the question is: can this happen? Both teams could stand to benefit from the trade, but are they willing to give up enough so that both are willing to do it? Do the Raptors have the best offer available of interested teams?

A trade of Millsap for Terrence Ross, Pascal Siakam, Jared Sullinger, and a protected first round pick could be the move that pushes both organizations in the right direction. Ross is having a career year. As the leading scorer off of their bench, he is shooting 45.8 percent from the field and 38.1 percent from deep. His efficiency in this role shows that he could be ready for a bigger one. Wings are in high demand in today’s NBA, so nabbing a budding one brings a lot of value.

Siakam offers high upside at the power forward spot. He’s athletic and plays hard on defense, showing a match of physicality and quickness that is key for modern NBA power forwards. He can dribble well too, and has an intuitive feel for the pick and roll. He offers much more upside than Poeltl, which makes him more enticing for a team looking at growth instead of instant production. Plus he plays the four instead of the five, so he could play with Howard. Based on their playing time, the Raps would probably rather give up Poetel (10.9 minutes per game) than Siakam (18.1 minutes per game). But if the Hawks are willing to accept this trade, then Masai Ujiri has got to pull the trigger. Throw in Sullinger to balance the cap, and the trade could pass through.

The Raptors have some interesting prospects. The Nuggets are rumored to be interested, and they’re stocked with a lot of good young players, yet they don’t offer a stunning amount of upside. They could be at play too, but the Raptors have more enticing individual assets. The Kings really don’t have any interesting young players to offer. The Celtics are stocked with assets, and could look to make a trade for Millsap, but they may be looking for a younger star. The Sixers are at least a couple years from contention; they really don’t have much of an incentive to trade for him. In all, the Raptors have some of the best assets to offer, and easily have the most incentive to acquire a player like Millsap.

The Raptors need to step up their defense if they want to really compete with the Cavs in the East. The Hawks need to cash in on Millsap before he becomes a free agent, netting as many young assets as possible. It’s looking clear that both teams need to make a move to get to contender status. Their paths there are increasingly looking like they will cross.

title: NBA Eastern Conference Playoffs Preview
content:
Chase Madorsky

As the regular season comes to a conclusion, playoff race in the NBA Eastern Conference is tighter than ever. At the top of the Eastern Conference are the Atlanta Hawks, who have set a new franchise record with 60 wins, as coach Mike Budenholzer has effectively utilized his four All Star starters (Kyle Korver, Jeff Teague, Paul Millsap, and Al Horford) in a Spurs inspired team system of basketball. Locked into the two seed in the east are the Cleveland Cavaliers, who’s big three of LeBron James, Kyrie Irving, and Kevin Love have combined with trade pickups J.R. Smith and Timofy Mozkov to form what may be the NBA’s most dynamic starting five. Fighting for the three seed with identical records are the 48-32 Toronto Raptors and Chicago Bulls. (Note: The Raptors own the head to head tiebreaker). Hurt by the injuries to superstars Derrick Rose, Joakim Noah, and Jimmy Butler, the Bulls have nonetheless remained in the thick of the playoff race thanks to an All-Star, bounce back year from Pau Gasol. However, one must wonder if it is to little, to late to catch the Raptors, who despite struggling through multiple five game losing streaks have rounded into form, led by the backcourt duo of Kyle Lowry and Demar Derozan. Locked into the five seed are the 45-34 Washington Wizards, who despite inconsistent play all year are always a dangerous matchup thanks to the a combination of speed, veteran leadership, and size that can be seen through point guard John Wall, future Hall of Fame forward Paul Pierce, and center Nene. At 40-40, the six seed is the surprising Milwaukee Bucks, who in Jason Kidd’s first season have used a combination of length and athleticism that has fans excited for the future.  Fueled by a midseason trade for Point Guard Isaiah Thomas and led by former Butler Coach Brad Stevens, the upstart Celtics currently hold the seven seed in the Eastern Conference with a 38-42 record, despite trading away many of their assets in what appeared to be an open rebuilding effort. Only a game behind the Celtics are the 37-43 Brooklyn Nets, who despite their sky high payroll hope to make noise in the playoffs behind a healthy Deron Williams and rejuvenated play from Brooke Lopez. On the outside looking are the Indiana Pacers, who despite the return of Paul George from injury currently sit a half game back of the Nets with a 36-43 record.

The Eastern Conference is clearly not what it once was, as evident from the fact that the bottom three playoff teams all may finish with a record below 500. However, the top of the Eastern Conference could easily bring a Larry O’Brien trophy back home with them. Look for the Conference to be decided in a seven game series between the two best teams the East has to offer, the Hawks and the Cavs. Although the Hawks have without question been a top three team in the league all season with their selfless and team style of play, at they also lack what I consider to be a truly dominant scoring presence, which I feel that every championship team needs. For this reason, LeBron James will continue his homecoming party and lead the Cavs into the NBA Finals, as his take-over ability combined with Kyrie Irving’s shooting and Kevin Love’s inside out presence will simply be to much for Atlanta to handle. Even if the Hawks starting 5 hangs in there with LeBron and company, the Cavs bench, led by Tristan Thompson, Iman Shumpert, and Mike Miller will be to much for the injury laden Hawks to handle, who will greatly miss the bench presence of Thabo Sefolosha who is out for the year with a broken leg.

title: UCLA Basketball: Don’t Lose Hope Yet
content:
Chase Madorsky

As with every great run in March Madness, the UCLA Men’s Basketball Team returned home knowing that the team that got them to the Sweet 16 for the second straight year would be drastically different the year after. Gone would be senior guard Norman Powell, who anchored the Bruins Offense with 16.4 points per game en route to a First Team All Pac-12 selection. Although expected, projected lottery pick Kevon Looney, who led all freshman in double-doubles nationally to go along with 11.6 points and 9.2 rebounds per game, declared that he to would be leaving Westwood for the greener pastures of the NBA. In an instance, a team that captivated the student body of UCLA was torn apart; gone were their leading scorer and rebounder, leaving major gaps in the Bruin’s rotation.

However, rather than dwell at the past, Bruin fans should look forward to what Coach Steve Alford’s team will have to offer next year with hope. Remaining with the Bruins are their point guard, Bryce Alford, who is coming off a season where he average 15.4 PPG and 4.9 assists per game. Yet it wasn’t until the round of 64 matchup with SMU where Bryce showed what he was capable of, where he made 9-11 three-point shots, including the game winner to send the Bruins to the Round of 32. Alford will have the benefit of having his backcourt running mate Isaac Hamilton back to play alongside him. Although Hamilton at times appeared uncomfortable overall, his play picked up substantially over the second half of the season, peaking with a career high 36 point effort in a win against USC in the Pac-12 Tournament that proved Hamilton could be trusted as a dynamic scorer. In the front court, starting center Tony Parker will return to anchor the Bruins defense, where he will aim to improve on his 2014-2015 play by cutting down on his fouls and stepping in as the primary rebounder for the Bruins. Off the bench, Thomas Welsh will attempt to solidify himself as a reliable big man off the bench with his 7 foot frame, while Gygory Goloman will continue to become integrated into the offense as a stretch four who can draw defenses away from the hoop with his outside shooting.

Yet the biggest reason for Bruin fans to look on in excitement for the 2015-2016-basketball season is another stellar Steve Alford recruiting class. Although ruled academically ineligible this past season, Jonah Bolden will make his anticipated debut with the Bruins. A 6-8 Power Forward from Australia who was a four star recruit and ranked 69th overall in the 2014 ESPN 100, Bolden will be looked upon to fill the void left by Looney in the starting five. Combined with four-star guards Prince Ali and Aaron Holiday, this trio will look to make an immediate impact for the Bruins. Even more help can be on the way, as five star recruit and number two overall recruit Jaylen Brown, number six recruit Ivan Rabb, and number 10 recruit Stephen Zimmerman have all received offers from UCLA and are considering the Bruins as National Signing Day approaches.

title: Review: Jessica Pratt @ The Echo 2/28/15 by Gabriel Brenner (DJ Lil Kid aka Pasteles aka Pastel aka Gabe for Honestly? This Goes)
content:
The first time I heard Jessica Pratt’s “Back Baby,” off of her Drag City debut On Your Own Love Again, it was as if I had been transported to her living room, Pratt cooing honeyed lyrics from the pages of her tattered diary and lovingly plucking guitar strings as the faint hum of civilization buzzed in the far distance. There’s a strong sense of intimacy and place to Pratt’s acoustic folk balladry. She rarely, if ever, rises above a whisper. The timbre of her voice falls somewhere between that of Stevie Nicks, Kath Bloom, and Vashti Bunyan, and her hushed conversational delivery of unfussy lyrics makes every tale she tells feel of the utmost importance. And then there’s the hum of her home, the constant background warmth of her lived-in space that’s a key component to all of her recordings. Listening to Pratt’s music is instant escapism; she invites you into her private world, only asking for you to lend an ear in return.

It is this striking sense of solitude that made me hesitant to see Pratt perform live. To be fair, The Echo is a relatively minuscule venue in relation to, say, the Hollywood Bowl, or even the El Rey. It can seemingly only fit about one hundred people at capacity. Nonetheless, I feared the tiny world she crafted on On Your Own Love Again, the world I found so much comfort in, would crumble under the weight of an audience greater than the fictional sole listener in Pratt’s living room. To add to this, it was uncharacteristically rainy for a February night in Southern California, and the crowd was rowdy with both delight and confusion at the prospect of precipitation.

When Pratt finally entered the stage, following charming opener Matt Kivel, the room fell silent. She nonchalantly sat down and began to talk, shocking me with the stark difference between her singing voice and speaking voice. I raised my phone to take a picture of her, but felt like I had infiltrated that sense of intimacy when we locked eyes after I snapped the shot. That was the first indicator of the dichotomy between the setting and tone of Pratt’s performance.

Pratt herself was ethereal and arresting. With just an acoustic six string and flourishes of electric guitar as her backing, she closed her eyes and dove deep within, summoning the otherworldly being that is her voice. Her performance felt deeply personal and earnest, and each word that was slowly and subtly unleashed held vast emotional weight on its shoulders. Every aspect of Pratt’s set felt immensely considered, down to the enunciation of vowels and weight with which she plucked her guitar strings. It is obvious that she truly loves what she does, and her talents are undoubtedly overflowing.

However, the venue didn’t seem to be on Pratt’s side on Saturday night. The sound was a tad muddy, and Pratt’s voice often became more of a texture than its own entity. There was an unruly fog machine that she, and every other artist performing that night, had to request to turn off during their set due to it’s loud metallic buzzing. The walls in the bathrooms must’ve been built extra thin, too, as Pratt’s set was consistently interrupted by the guttural roar of a hand dryer and slamming stall doors. The crowd quickly grew restless and chatty, making it difficult to understand what Pratt was relaying to us. At one point, during “Back Baby,” a member of the audience behind me fainted and had to be dragged to safety. Obviously, I cannot fault a concert goer for their potentially frightening health scare that they had no control over, but the list of distractions grew so numerous and impossible to ignore that the world Jessica Pratt was constructing before us crumbled apart again, and again, and again, and again.

The shortcomings of the venue is not necessarily Pratt’s issue, though, and as a performer, there was little, if any, more that I could ask from her than what she gave that night. However, I find myself repeatedly asking the same question: if Pratt’s live set can’t withstand the tiny Echo, then what venue would suffice?

But when her tour mate that accompanied her on the electric guitar left the stage for Pratt’s final song, she once again silenced the entire building and almost entirely redeemed the downfalls of The Echo. I wasn’t familiar with the song she played; perhaps it was from her self-titled debut LP, with which I am less familiar than her most recent release; perhaps it was something new. That didn’t matter; what matters is that I have zero recollection of what was happening around me during that song, and Pratt was able to recreate the intimacy of On Your Own Love Again with astonishing ease. Maybe where an artist shares their craft isn’t always important. Maybe what an artist does live will never fully live up to what they create on tape, and vice versa. What I do know, though, is that Pratt’s final song left enough of an effect on me that I’m certain she’ll be an important figure in music for many years to come. You can ask almost anyone: it’s difficult to ignore a talent as unique as hers.

title: Can UCLA Basketball make the Big Dance?
content:
By Ariq Chowdhury

The beauty of March Madness is that upsets are the normal and every school – whether it’s undefeated Kentucky or big dance rookies North Florida – believes it just might have a chance to win it all. The 2015 NCAA Men’s Basketball Tournament officially starts March 17, but Coach Alford and the UCLA Bruins have to worry about the Pac-12 Tournament before they can start dreaming.

Although Selection Sunday (March 15) is the day teams officially find out if they are one of the 68 who made the tournament and where they’re seeded, hundreds of amateur and professional bracketologists across the country have essentially calculated the NCAA selection committee’s final decisions to a science. They look at all factors of every team’s resume – win-loss records, strength of schedule, point differential, etc. –  to determine who the best teams in college basketball are and if they’re truly worthy to make it to the league’s greatest stage. UCLA actually doesn’t fare too poorly in many of these rankings (they rank 50th in RPI, which measures teams by the aforementioned factors and more), but they played in a weak conference, have few signature victories, and have ultimately looked mediocre throughout the season. Most are predicting that UCLA will just miss the cut, but the season’s not over yet and the Bruins still have a chance!

So what do they have to do to make it into the final March Madness bracket? Simple – beat USC tomorrow and then scratch out a win against Arizona, the 5th highest ranked team in the country, the very next day after. Yikes.

USC is coming off a thrilling comeback win against ASU earlier today, as it defied all odds by going on a 19-2 tear to end the game to win as the lowest seeded team in the tournament. While some might think this is a bad result for the Bruins as it eliminates the chance for a signature win against a decent ASU team, this was actually the best possible outcome for UCLA. The selection committee would not consider a victory over ASU a signature win, so the difference between beating USC rather than ASU is almost negligible for the Bruins. USC has proven to be the worst team in the conference this season and lost to UCLA in both previous meetings this season, including the final regular season game just a week ago. On top of that, the Trojans will surely be on tired legs tomorrow as they face the Bruins on the second night of a back to back. Truthfully, if the Bruins can’t get up to beat their inferior cross-town rivals, they don’t deserve to make it into the tournament. So assuming that UCLA will get a win over USC and Arizona beats Cal tomorrow, Bruins and Wildcats will get to face off in both schools’ biggest game of the year.

Arizona has already earned their place in March Madness after a fantastic 28 win season, but they’re fighting for a number one seed in March Madness. They won’t hold back at all, as a number one seed rather than a two or three means they would have an easier road to the Final Four. If the Bruins can beat a motivated Arizona team, they’ll convince this pessimistic UCLA fan that they have the fight to compete against the big boys. More importantly, they will convince the NCAA selection committee that they deserve to be in.

It will all come down to the next two days. Can the country’s most storied college basketball program beat the most dominant team in the west? Maybe not, but who knows – anyone has a chance.

title: MLB Cali Grades by Andrew Gerson
content:
With Spring Training games on the horizon, most teams are finished making their offseason moves. None of the California teams had an awful winter, but some teams look completely revamped, while others look very similar to their 2014 predecessors. Let’s hand out some grades and see who is poised to contend for the upcoming season.

Los Angeles Dodgers: The Dodgers began their offseason with a front office makeover, hiring Andrew Friedman as president of baseball operations and tabbing the popular A’s executive Farhan Zaidi as the team’s GM. The upgrade from former GM Ned Colletti cannot be understated and was arguably the Dodgers’ most important move before Spring Training. However, Friedman and Zaidi did not sit on a roster that won 94 games last year, trading for Jimmy Rollins to replace Han-Ram, as well as Howie Kendrick for Dee Gordon through a series of moves. They also got younger, acquiring several intriguing prospects from the Marlins for Gordon along with catcher Yasmani Grandal and pitcher Joe Wieland in the Matt Kemp trade. Dealing Kemp to San Diego – with a significant portion of his salary – enables Joc Pederson to compete for a starting role while lessening the team’s obligations for the future. Not only does the team have a better roster than the year before, its future looks brighter than ever. Grade: A+

San Francisco Giants: Coming off their third World Series win in five years, Giants fans expected the organization to use the extra revenue to sign a marquee free agent – if not more. Not only did they fail to resign Pablo Sandoval, but Jon Lester and James Shields also spurned the team, leaving them with little recourse to improve a weak starting rotation whose only certainty is a pitcher who threw 270 innings in 2014. Signing Nori Aoki was a prudent, cost-effective move, but the offense may struggle without the power of the aforementioned Sandoval and slugger Mike Morse. The options at 3B were limited, but one has to imagine that Casey McGehee was not the best player available on the trade market. Perhaps sticking to the formula will work, but Sabean & Co. should have done more. Grade: C-

San Diego Padres: The Pads weren’t terrible last year, going 77-85, but young GM A.J. Preller decided to try something different in the offseason. Trading most of the team’s top prospects, he acquired Justin Upton, Matt Kemp, Wil Myers, Will Middlebrooks, Derek Norris, and underrated bullpen piece Brandon Maurer. It remains to be seen how the team will survive defensively without a natural CF among their starters or a solid defensive catcher, but the Friars will certainly be an offensive presence. After inking a good deal for James Shields, the rotation looks strong with Andrew Cashner, Tyson Ross, Ian Kennedy, and Brandon Morrow joining the formal Royals’ ace. The short-term moves may cost them dearly in the future, but for now the Padres are a team to watch. Grade: B+

Los Angeles Angels: Deeply committed to Albert Pujols and Josh Hamilton, the Angels didn’t have much in the way of spending money this offseason and subsequently were somewhat inactive. However, they did improve upon their primary weakness, SP, by acquiring prospect Andrew Heaney for Howie Kendrick. If Garrett Richards and Tyler Skaggs can successfully recover from their injuries, this group could be one of the deeper rotations in the AL. Kendrick’s replacement, former Rockie Josh Rutledge, won’t have the same kind of impact but doesn’t figure to be a negative either. Losing Hamilton to February surgery certainly hurts an already righty-heavy lineup, but the offense still figures to be productive with the best player in baseball hitting in the 2 spot. Grade: C

Oakland A’s: Breaking down all of Billy Beane’s moves would be a hassle, so it’s best to just look at the final result. After collapsing down the stretch last year, the lineup is very different, featuring younger players such as Brett Lawrie and Marcus Semien, bounceback candidates Billy Butler and Ike Davis, and the always productive Ben Zobrist. If Jarrod Parker and A.J. Griffin can quickly return from TJ surgery, the rotation following Sonny Gray and Scott Kazmir will be deep thanks to the acquisition of Jesee Hahn in the Derek Norris trade. The farm has also been revitalized from trades, receiving multiple top prospects from the Blue Jays as well as other good pieces from San Diego and the White Sox. While 2015 won’t be what A’s fans had envisioned during 2014, the team is ready to continue its run of success. Grade: B
