title: UCLA Baseball Continues Near-Perfect Year, Shuts Out Sparty
content:
The Bruins stretched their win total to nine on Saturday, running past Michigan State in a 5-0 win. With the Bruins’ sole loss of the season coming to UNC, the team stands as a consensus top-10 team with their 9-1 record. Backed by strong pitching and typical UCLA small-ball, the Bruins enter an important last non-conference week on a high note.

A pair of triples led to the first two UCLA runs. A Chris Keck triple in the first inning saw Ty Moore cross the plate. In the fifth, shortstop Kevin Kramer reached on a triple on what could have been a routine fly ball if not for the uncharacteristic wind in Westwood and scored on a sacrifice fly.

The rest of the damage done by the Bruin offense came in the bottom of the seventh. After UCLA bunted two runners into scoring position for Ty Moore, who is batting .550 on the season, Michigan State intentionally walked the bases full for Chris Keck. Keck made the Spartans pay with a bases-clearing double that put UCLA up by five runs, putting the game beyond the reach of Michigan State, who struggled with the Bruins’ pitching.

Grant Dyer came into the game in the eighth and threw hard, allowing no base runners and making quick work of the bottom of the Michigan State order. Finally, former walk-on and now-elite closer David Berg closed the game out, giving up only one hit to the top of the order for the Big Ten opponents.

The shutout win comes in the second game of a three-game series with Michigan State, and less than one week away from a high-profile matchup with Vanderbilt. The Bruins will also face rivals USC in Dodger Stadium on Sunday, March 8. The Bruins will also formally start conference play on Friday, March 13 against Washington at Jackie Robinson Stadium.

title: Owa Helping His Stock at Pro Day
content:
By Josh Naftulin

       In the introductory course on logic I attended during my sophomore year of college, a massive man would sit toward the front of the classroom each day with crutches by his side.  It was Owamagbe Odighizuwa, the promising young defender who was forced to miss the entire 2013 season while recovering from right hip surgery.  Fighting hard to rehab after his surgery, Owa was able to take redshirt for medical reasons.  It was uplifting to see him return at full health to have a monster year and earn himself second-team All Pac-12 Conference honors.At the NFL Combine just last month, Owa opened the eyes of many scouts with his outstanding build and clear physical ability.  A top performer for defensive linemen in the vertical jump, broad jump, 20-yard shuttle, 60-yard shuttle, and 40-yard dash, Owa cemented himself as a definite NFL-caliber player.  Owa even said in an interview that his play in the Senior Bowl sparked more intrigue from NFL personnel, but really it was his showing at the combine that has led to the increased amount of attention he has recently received.  With Owa having only six sacks this past season, however, NFL talent evaluators were interested in seeing more of his ability to rush to passer. 

        During UCLA’s Pro Day this past Tuesday, Owa was able to perform linebacker drills for NFL team scouts.  Apparently he did well, for his name has been highlighted by various media sources since the workout as one to watch as we approach the upcoming NFL Draft.  Although us Bruin fanatics are well aware of the disrupting presence Owa brings to the field and the rare combination of speed and athleticism he possesses, it appears the pro day was what the draft candidate needed to prove himself to NFL front office members.  Now, following the pro day, Owa has placed himself into the discussion of being a possible late-first round draft pick.  A defensive team captain this year, Owa not only contains the skill to play at the next level but also the type of attitude that will allow him to excel in the pros. 

        In an interview with Mike Mayock at the pro day (which you can view here), Mora described Owa as a “specialist” who is likely best-suited as a defensive end at the next level, but also as someone who may be able to make a smooth transition to outside linebacker. 

         As we move closer to draft day, it will be imperative for Owa’s stock that NFL evaluators see him as being able to make that positional change.  For if many see him as a true defensive end, Owa will likely be plagued by a perceived lack of versatility.  It is always fun to see former Bruins continue pursuing their dreams as professional football players because in the end, they’ll always be one of our Bruins.  Having personally met him in class and witnessed his road to recovery, I’ll be excited to see him suit up for whichever NFL team lands him.  No matter where he ends up, Owa will be out to prove all his doubters wrong and Bruin supporters everywhere should be cheering for him all along the way.

title: UCLA 72, WSU 67
content:
By: Dean Rowe

Not all days are rainy here in Los Angeles, but on Sunday, March 1st, UCLA seemed to let it get to them when WSU came to Pauley to attempt to upset the Bruins. UCLA has had a very interesting year when it comes to Men’s Basketball.

They struggled very early, but have come out near the end of the season to show that they can still contend. This is exactly how the game unfolded too. Tony Parker slept in and showed up late to warm ups. Thus, he lost his starting position and was benched. From the beginning, UCLA seemed to not have it going for them. This was only truer when the halftime whistle came. WSU was up 34-32. Their 3-pointers were raining from the sky and only a 9-4 run by UCLA right before the half could get them back in the game. It all came down to the second half.

UCLA ended up outscoring WSU 40-33 in the second half to bring home the W by 5 points. Powell scored a career high of 28 points to bring the Bruins the victory. Even when losing the starting position, Parker came in to score 15 points and get 10 rebounds. Alford again had plenty of steals with 4 this game.

In the end, UCLA pulled out another second half minor comeback. Althoughthe year has been very up-and-down for UCLA basketball, there is hope and promise for the team. They rally and they comeback. Even after losing three starters in the NBA draft last year, UCLA has shown that they can compete with forces working against them. Now, with this W over WSU, they hold the fourth spot in the PAC-12 coming up on their rival game against USC. They are in position to hold a good spot in the PAC-12 tournament and while simultaneously continuing to grow. The next month and year will be very interesting with high-stakes for UCLA Basketball.

title: Clippers Stifle Spurs, Take Series Opener 107-92
content:
(Photo Credit: Darryn Albert)

Written by Darryn Albert

Batman and Robin.  Simon and Garfunkel.  Han Solo and Chewbacca.  Abbott and Costello.  John Lennon and Paul McCartney.  Peanut butter and jelly.  Now it just might be time to add Chris Paul and Blake Griffin to that list.  

The dynamic duo combined for a whopping 58 points on Sunday night at the Staples Center as the Los Angeles Clippers won their playoff opener against the San Antonio Spurs by the final of 107-92.  Hosting the defending champs in Round 1 is no walk in the park and use it as an argument for abolishing the NBA’s antiquated divisional seeding rules if you will, but the Lob City alpha males certainly came to play in Game 1.  

Paul posted a massive 32 point, 7 rebound, 6 assist line while Griffin tacked on 26 points, 12 rebounds, 6 assists, and 2 memorable poster dunks on hapless Spurs center Aron Baynes as the Clippers rode 51% shooting night against a Spurs team ranked 3rd in the league in defensive efficiency for the season to victory.  Jamal Crawford added 17 points off the bench while DeAndre Jordan had 9 points, 14 rebounds, and 4 blocked shots.  

The Clippers hit 10 three-pointers at a 56% clip on the evening and dominated the Spurs inside (46 points in the paint) as well as in transition (23 fast break points).  

But as impressive as a performance as it was on the offensive end for LAC, it was all that and more on the defensive end as well.  The team rotated crisply along the perimeter on defense, suffocating a Spurs team known for its impeccable interior passing ability to the tune of 14 forced turnovers.  Jordan was playing like his entire Defensive Player of the Year candidacy rested solely on his performance in this one game while Griffin’s instincts on the defensive end were sharp as well evidenced by his 3 steals and 3 blocks on the evening.  

The Clippers held the Spurs to just 37% from the field and though some of that can be chalked up to San Antonio simply missing good, open looks, Coach Doc Rivers’ troops certainly deserve to be commended for the defensive effort they put forth on Sunday.  

Reigning Finals MVP Kawhi Leonard led San Antonio with 18 points, 6 rebounds, and 3 assists while the legend Tim Duncan put up 11 points, 11 rebounds, and 4 assists.  But the rest of the team might as well have describe trying to solve the Clippers defense as like trying to solve a Rubik’s Cube.  Danny Green shot 2-for-11 from the field, Boris Diaw outstank him with a 2-for-12 line, Manu Ginobili was just 3-for-10, and Tony Parker (who twisted his left ankle early) didn’t fare much better with a 4-for-11 line.

It was an uncharacteristically flat performance by a San Antonio squad that shot 47% from the field in the regular season and they struggled to match the intensity and physicality that the Clippers were able to maintain over all 48 minutes.

The Clippers jumped out to a 12-point lead after the first quarter, really feeding off the energy of a raucous Staples Center crowd that was much louder than it had been all season.  The Spurs responded though with a 10-0 run to start the second quarter against LAC’s notoriously lacking second unit, eventually taking the lead and bogging down the high-octane Clipper offense by hacking DeAndre Jordan (who shot 5-for-12 from the line).  But ignited by a loose-ball scrum between Baynes and Matt Barnes as well by an increased emphasis (sparked in part by the zest of the home crowd) on pushing the pace in transition that led to some of Griffin’s highlight reel plays, the Clippers put the Spurs away for good in the third quarter, seeing their lead balloon all the way to 18, before finishing with the final cushion of 15.

The usually calm, calculated Paul played with a sense of frenetic urgency, aggressively seeking out opportunities for himself and for others on offense, and raising the intensity level of the entire team on that end of the floor, while also playing bulldog defense on Tony Parker.  Griffin as well looked in prime shape, balancing out his development as a player from the perimeter with his classic tendencies to beeline for the rim and dunk on anybody that dare stand in his path (as Baynes could twice attest to).  

(Photo Credit: Darryn Albert)

Coach Doc Rivers praised his guys in the postgame press conference while at the same time remaining cautious of a multi-championship proven team with all sorts of experience in overcoming adversity.  “We had a good defensive night,” Rivers said.  “We have a lot of confidence in our team, but you just have to stay humble and respect who you’re playing.  They’re a heck of a basketball team.  We won one game.”  He also spoke highly of Griffin’s effort (“He got to the basket…he was just attacking”) as well as that of Jordan (“He changed shots, he was fantastic…He’s just so gifted athletically, so smart defensively”).  In summing up Game 1 and looking ahead to Game 2, Rivers put it well in saying that, “My belief is that we won tonight because we just had more energy.  For us to win on Wednesday night, we’re going to have to play better, and we’re going to have to execute better defensively.”

Spurs coach Gregg Popovich went on to sum things up by saying “The game was – their defense was better than our offense.  That’s the bottom line.  Their aggressiveness, their physicality, their athleticism, really hurt us offensively.”  Duncan echoed these sentiments saying “They were physical.  Their shot blockers in the back with DeAndre especially I think affected us at the basket.  We got off a lot of pretty decent shots that we usually would make.  But all in all, we give them a lot of credit because they stuck with what they were doing, got up in us, and made us do what we didn’t want to do.”

Griffin, for his part, credited the win as a total team effort.  “We came out with great energy and made stops.  I tried to be aggressive.  I didn’t want to settle for any jump shots.  We tried to put pressure on them.”  He continued, “This was a great win but if we learned anything over the years in the Playoffs, it’d be that you have to finish it out.  This was one of four that we need, so we need to come out with the same mentality.”

The Clippers now hold a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven first round series.  Game 2 is on Wednesday night at the Staples Center (10:30 PM EST/7:30 PM PST tip-off).

title: Show Blurb: Dead Finger @ the Virgil (3/3/15)
content:
On March 3, 2015 Indie-Grunge-Rock band Dead Finger played a show at The Virgil in Hollywood. The setting seemed all too fitting for the nouveau-Nirvana rock group. Members Indio Downey, Kyle McNeil and Ralph Alexander rocked out for an hour set to close the venue’s ring of live bands on a tuesday for the evening. title: Breaking Down a Tough Weekend For Bruin Baseball
content:
By Andrew Gerson

UCLA baseball fans had high expectations for the past weekend, facing perennially talented Vanderbilt, TCU, and the infamous cross-town rivals. Unfortunately the Bruins went 0-3, and the team’s claim to the NCAA’s #6 ranking was weakened significantly. What went wrong, and will it happen again?

Facing Vanderbilt on Friday, UCLA simply could not stand up to Carson Fulmer, who earned his third victory of the season. Despite only throwing 50% of his pitches for strike, Fulmer got the Bruins to chase all night, racking up 9 strikeouts and giving up only 3 hits. UCLA did take advantage of his wildness with 5 walks, but they failed to get a big hit before Philip Pfeifer shut them down for the last 2 2/3 innings of the game. Starting for UCLA, James Kaprielian wasn’t able to stop the Vanderbilt offense despite his impressive swing-and-miss stuff.

Against TCU, the Bruins again looked outmatched at the plate, striking out 9 times in Alex Young’s 8 innings for the Horned Frogs. However, with Grant Watson and the bullpen able to keep the team in the game, the difference came on a catcher’s interference call in the 6th inning that allowed TCU’s Barzilli to double in 2 runs. UCLA had a chance to win this one, but the bats once again failed to supplement the team’s good pitching staff.

Playing USC at Dodger Stadium, the Bruins fell behind early but tied the game at 3-3 with a big 3rd inning and Christoph Bono’s first long ball of the year. This time the pitchers faltered, with Cody Poteet only lasting 3.2 innings and the subsequent relievers giving up 4 runs over the next 3.1 innings. With 11 hits to USC’s 14, the game could have had a different outcome with some more timely hitting. Ultimately, the team couldn’t stop a Trojan offense that scored in 6 of 9 innings.

Fortunately, this looks to be a minor slump for a team that has excelled so far in the young season. Grant Watson has been brilliant so far in his final season as a Bruin, and the offense has been generally productive thanks to the big start from the top of the lineup. The bullpen needs improvement, but relievers are often volatile and could experience a quick turnaround. Perhaps the most important change for the team’s long-term success would be improvement from Kaprielian, Poteet, and Griffin Canning who are all allowing about a hit per inning. It may be bad luck, but their success is critical to the pitching staff.

title:
Future Already Looking Bright for UCLA Football’s 2015 Season
By: Nicole Kern
content:
Lots of exciting news and changes are brewing in Westwood this offseason with UCLA having its most impressive signing day in recent history and the departure of the defensive coach, Jeff Ulbrich, to the NFL’s Atlanta Falcons. This week culminated with UCLA being ranked ninth in Mark Schlaback’s new Way-Too-Early predictions. On signing day UCLA signed several new players to their already impressive young roster.  Here is the scoop on the top new recruits.

Chris Clark: A four-star tight end recruit from Connecticut signed with UCLA over Michigan. Rivals.com and Scout.com ranked Clark first in the country for tight ends. Clark was originally committed to UCLA but backed out after Michigan replaced Coach Brady Hoke with Jim Harbaugh Tight end is not a position that UCLA normally utilizes so it will be interesting to see how UCLA incorporates him into the team.  Clark emphasized Jim Mora’s role in his choice claiming Mora has been like a “second dad” in the past few weeks.

Soso Jamabo: Five-star running back Soso Jamabo from Texas chose UCLA over UT and Notre Dame. The running back was a standout in Texas having 484 rushing yards and 6 touchdowns. Jamabo was so excited about signing with UCLA that he declared he would stay with the Bruins for the next four years. UCLA’s backfield is already crowded with three running backs returning to UCLA, including standout Paul Perkins. The Bruin’s second leading rusher was quarterback Brett Hundley who has entered the draft this year, which does leave a possibility for Jamabo to start this season and really make a difference in UCLA’s offense.

Josh Wariboko: A four-star offensive guard picks UCLA over Oklahoma and others and will join his cousin Soso Jamabo. The offensive line was probably UCLA’s weakest area and bringing in a top recruit can only help the line.

Cordell Broadus: Cordell Broadus may be the most talked about recruit from signing day as he is Snoop Dogg’s son and a four-star receiver.  Broadus has some competition in starting for the Bruins as both of UCLA’s top receiver’s, Thomas Duarte and Jordan Payton, will be returning next season. Snoop Dogg is an avid USC fan, but he now says he will throw away all of his USC gear and throw his full support behind the Bruins.

Keisean Lucier-South: A five-star defensive end that signed early on with UCLA. Lucier-South is considered to be a great replacement for former UCLA player Anthony Barr to ensure UCLA’s defense’s continued dominant performance.

Josh Rosen: The number 1 quarterback and a 5 star recruit from Southern California. Described as “having it all” he not only brings a lot of talent to the team on his own, but his early commitment also was a significant draw for the other top recruits. Rosen has a tough battle to becoming the starting QB with both Jerry Neuheisal and Asiantii Woolard both very much still in the running. Rosen has incredible arm strength, but is still capable of running the ball, which is a large characteristic of UCLA’s offense.

With such an impressive class the talk of National Championships has begun again. UCLA was not the only school with an impressive recruiting class. UCLA got the 2nd best recruiting class in the nation with only 1 point making the difference between them and Alabama. UCLA’s class was ranked seventh in the nation. This could strike fear in Bruins for their annual matchup with the crosstown rival.

title: I Summon You Here My Love: Spoon @ The Teragram Ballroom, 5/31/2015
content:
There comes a time in every band’s career where a decision is made about what will come next. Sometimes it’s a complete change of style, A La Radiohead. Sometimes it’s a change of scale, maybe adding a full blown orchestra, or a brass section. Maybe it’s scaling down and getting more intimate. A very rare thing for a band to do is however, to become more introverted and extroverted at the same time; to have a very clear idea of what the core of the band’s soul comes from, and still be open to add and explore new sounds. And that is the exact reason why Spoon comes forward as one of the most unique and accomplished rock bands of our time.

The Austin natives followed their performance at The Wiltern by playing the the inaugural show of the Teragram Ballroom, located just between Koreatown and Downtown Los Angeles, to an intimate and energetic crowd. The opening band, Sweet Spirit (also of Austin,TX) provided a jump start to the evening, with a thick and energetic ensemble performance, climaxing with Britt Daniel of Spoon joining them for their final song of the evening. Although they encountered sound issues at several moments, Sweet Spirit displayed the energy and spirit of a promising ensemble, one that surely convinced the audience to keep an eye out for their future works.

After a short set change allowing everyone to visit the water closet and get a refill on their IPA’s; the lights went dark, and Spoon took the stage. The electrifying stage presence of the band started to ooze out with the first few notes of Rainy Taxi from last year’s phenomenal They Want My Soul. As the band powered their way through newer cuts and classics, some things became very clear.  To begin with, getting to see a band of such a caliber in such an intimate setting was a very rare opportunity. Making his way through his third decade on the stage, Britt Daniel’s performance as a frontman is more effortless and commanding than ever. He not only gracefully plays off his band members whilst being in charge of the momentum, he also delivers the lyrics with the raw energy and skill of someone who can only be described as a true rock star. Jim Eno’s drumming is more transgressive than ever, rendering both older Spoon cuts into an unpredictable sonic area, and adding a much appreciated rhythmic backbone to their newer works. It is fascinating to watch a band with so many classic cuts that remain so gracefully timeless. 

The deeper the band moved into their setlist, playing tracks like The Ghost Of You Lingers,  Let Me Be Mine and The Beast + Dragon, Adored; making their way to a true modern masterpiece, They Want My Soul’s Inside Out. The track’s famous synth line resonated even better live, with the newest band member Alex Fischel’s keyboards swirling into a semi-loop as Jim Eno’s bass drums resonated in the ears of the audience. It is very interesting to watch the level of integration Fischel has in the core line-up of Spoon. Eno and Daniel appear to be constantly open to taking their sound to new places, exemplified by the keyboard dominant sounds from their newer works. Because of how self-aware Spoon is of their work as a band that the raw core of their work is always open to change, yet it somehow always stays familiar; which seems to be the main reason they are able to stay so relevant in their third decade as a band. An interesting metaphor for this is the one second gap they take towards the end when they play Inside Out. Always in motion, always able to stop and think; always able to stop and feel.

The rest of their set included classics like I Summon You, wherein Britt Daniel breaks out his inner Dylan and shines as the classic leading man singing a guitar driven ballad. The band wrapped up their set with tracks like The Underdog and Rent I Pay, and the crowd wandered into the night; taking pictures of the “SPOON TONITE - SOLD OUT” sign outside the Teragram Ballroom and share with their social media-verse the gospel of a group of guys from Austin we know and love as Spoon. Their performance was as much planned as it was energetic, as much a ritual as it was a bash. Spoon yet again convinced me that they are one of the finest rock bands of the planet right now, and I can’t wait to hear what’s next.

Photos & Words: Hakancan Altiner

title: Stickers of the Station - Lovedrug
content:
This tattered up sticker barely reads “LOVEDRUG” with a brown background and a flowery border surrounding it. Pretend You’re Alive is the first album released by indie rock band Lovedrug. Lovedrug was formed in Canton, Ohio in 2001. Frontman Michael Shepherd came up with the name “Lovedrug” for his band because he initially dropped music to enroll in film school, but his “first ‘love’ of the music medium ‘dragged’ him back,” thus the word “lovedrug” is a loose past participle. The ambiguous and multiple meanings of the name of the band provide an opportunity for listeners to think of their own interpretation. Upon first look at the sticker, “pretend your alive” paired with “lovedrug” most obviously seems like an implication that love is a drug that kills you. The specific song “Pretend You’re Alive” is a somewhat dark song that includes elements of nature, seasons, and spirit while talking about trying to let go and enjoy life even during a mental breakdown. The band Lovedrug recently celebrated its ten-year anniversary by re-releasing their debut LP Pretend You’re Alive along with feature demos, live recordings, and unreleased songs.

Find out more about Lovedrug at their website: http://www.lovedrugmusic.com!!

With much LOVE,

Elizabeth

title: The UCLA Student’s Drinking Guide to the 2015 NFL Draft
content:
By J.T. Osborn

There is something so intrinsically fun about watching the NFL’s annual spectacle of initiating hundreds of college athletes into legitimate football professionals.

Perhaps it’s the hope that a certain athlete or group of athletes will be the answer to your nightly prayers of an upcoming Super Bowl victory.  Or maybe it’s a perverse way to visually see what your life would be like had you not torn your ACL in high school as buddies respond with a resonated sigh and one of them boldly steps up claiming that ‘you sucked in high school anyway’.

Whatever, it’s still really the best day an NFL fan has in the wasteland of time between the ending of the Super Bowl and the Pre-season.

I understand and can acknowledge that the whole grandeur process is over-the-top and the amount of media dedication to it is unnecessary. But screw it, it’s a shitload of unnecessary viewing fun! So buy a pack of your favorite beer. Get your dusty liquor bottle off your top shelf and enjoy a ridiculously arbitrarily fun night with friends!

Here is a drinking guide to maximize your NFL draft viewing enjoyment:

Take one drink of beer if:

  • The analysts make a comparison to how different this draft is than last year because it’s in Chicago now and not New York.
  • Jon Gruden exclaims “I love (insert football players name here)”.
    • Stipulation: Chug your beer if Gruden already has a nickname for said player
  • Mel Kiper and Todd McShay disagree on the draft spot of a prospect. 
  • A UCLA player gets drafted. 
  • Someone struggles to pronounce Owamagbe Odighizuwa.
    • Added Bonus: challenge a friend to chug a beer if they are unsuccessful in spelling his name in one try.
  • A football player drafted to the Jacksonville Jaguars looks like he’d prefer to be undrafted. 

Take a  5-second chug or one shot if:

  • Roger Goodell gets cheered/applauded for.
  • Mel Kiper Jr.’s hair does not look colored in.
  • An actor comes on the analyst board to promote some awful sports movie coming up.
    • Make it a 10 second chug if an analyst at any time refers to the sad existence of a movie that was Draft Day.
  • Brett Hundley is referred to as a “developmental quarterback”
  • More USC players get drafted than UCLA players.
  • Analysts speculate when Jim Mora will leave UCLA for the NFL 
  • A punter is drafted. 
  • An analyst questions why a team would draft a punter. 
  • You see a punter. 
  • Mike Ditka makes an appearance
  • You see a Bears fan crying in the audience.

Crack open two beers, hold them above your head and pour them into your mouth if:

  • A draftee walks out to Stone Cold Steve Austin’s entrance music.
    • Make a friend chug 5 beers in a row if you can successfully ‘Stunner’ someone in the room. 

Chug a whole beer or take 3 shots if:

  • A quarterback is not taken with the first and second pick.
  • Frank Caliendo does an impersonation of any of the analysts.
  • Chris Berman mentions that ‘Nobody Circles the Wagon like the Buffalo Bills’.
  • Your favorite team drafts a player that the analysts find to be “not a value pick at that spot”.
  • Jim Mora leaves UCLA for the NFL while you watch the draft.
  • A trade happens.
  • You get bored waiting for a pick to even happen as analysts go on and on about something you’ve heard 46 times already.

title: Is the NBA Finals Already Over?
content:
By John Tyler Osborn

At 98-98 going into overtime, this Warriors vs. Cavaliers series looked like it was going to be an instant classic. With Curry’s sharp-shooting and tenacious squad against LeBron, his sidekick Kyrie and a supporting cast of trade-offs they got for pennies on the dollar.

But still, LeBron and his Team of Misfit Toys were almost able to steal Game 1 in Oakland. The 4th Quarter was a teeter-totter of scoring runs for both teams and the excitement it generated had fans like me ecstatic to watch it continue into overtime.

Boy was I completely wrong.

The overtime was all Warriors from the tip-off, LeBron went 1-10 in the 4th quarter and he scored the only basket for the Cavaliers in a superfluous layup attempt after the Warriors victory was already sealed in an envelope with Riley Curry’s stamp of approval.

The Warriors defense completely shut down the Cavaliers with their aggressive, small-ball defense able to cause turnovers and no uncontested shots for the Cavs. That’s also not the only thing the Warriors shut down though.

With two minutes left in overtime, Kyrie Irving was driving to the basket and collapsed as he tried to cut back. He grabbed his knee as he got up and hobbled to the locker room following a David Blatt timeout.

According to sources, Irving has a fractured knee cap and will be having season ending surgery, making him officially out for the playoffs now.

So, what does this all mean for the Cavs? Many analysts already predicted that the Warriors would win the series with a (somewhat) healthy Kyrie anyway. Is the series already over for the Cavs?

I’ll say this on the matter, if LeBron can somehow put the whole team on his back and slug out four wins, or if JR Smith scores 60 3-pointers in the series, or if Dellavedova KO’s Curry and Thompson in one punch, than the series is already over.

At least we’ll have a fun Riley Curry press conference at the end of it.

So that’s pretty nice.

title: Forced Rivalries and American Soccer
content:
By Cole Frost

In 2018, Major League Soccer will once again have two teams in Los Angeles. Currently, this team (often somewhat mockingly called “Los Angeles 2”) is being sort-of officially called the Los Angeles Football Club, LAFC. As of now, they are discussing with Los Angeles locals regarding the official name, colors, and crest of the club.

On Monday, May 18, however, this club took a major step towards its start in MLS by announcing that its stadium would be placed at the current site of the Los Angeles Sports Arena. The stadium is set to seat 22,000 and cost $250 million (and is privately financed). The stadium location is significant because it is so close to downtown LA (the Galaxy’s location in Carson has been criticized for being too far from downtown). The owners are clearly committed and the stadium announcement is an exciting one for the league.

However, the announcement has been accompanied by one of the more frustrating aspects of MLS as an organization: artificially manufactured rivalries. Rivalries are a great way to drum up media attention, drive viewership, and create die-hard fans. The NFL benefits rather heavily from the NFC East hatred, the MLB craves interleague rivalries, and even international soccer salivates over classic rivalries like the Old Firm between Celtic and Rangers in Scotland. These rivalries are storied and have years of history, and MLS, as a newer league, would love to have a rivalry that comes close to the level of any other significant major sports rivalry. Sometimes, there are hints that these rivalries exist: The Galaxy and San Jose hate each other (The California Clasico). Portland and Seattle both have great fan support and their rivalry is budding. DC United and New York Red Bull have a long history dating back to when Red Bull was Metrostar. However, MLS spends too much time trying to create other rivalries that simply do not exist, including ones with teams that do not yet exist.

Most of these forced rivalries are regional (LA Galaxy and LAFC or Red Bull and NYCFC). However, some of the rivalries are formed on the most trivial connections between clubs. NYCFC and Orlando were pitted as rivals simply because they are both expansion clubs who joined the league at the same time. Realistically, that type of rivalry will die out quickly and just makes the league look desperate. However, even the regional rivalries should not be forced. At some point in the future, I hope to see someone in an LA Galaxy jersey exemplify the sort of pure hatred for someone in an LAFC (or whatever they end up being called) jersey as someone in a Red Sox jersey would show for a Yankees fan or an Evertonian would show his Merseyside counterpart. But, for now, it is ridiculous to picture a nameless team with no players, crest, or even colors as a rival to the team that has won 5 of the 19 titles in MLS history.

By: Hakancan Altiner

title: Not A Ritual Of Emptiness: Sleater-Kinney at the Hollywood Palladium, 4/30/2015
content:
I’ve always felt an instinctual attraction to things that have an appeal to be both mentally stimulating and emotionally liberating at the same time. Be it a sport, a game, a film, or a band. I wasn’t born early enough to be a contemporary of the period in which Sleater-Kinney was taking colleges across North America by storm, giving the neglected a voice they connected to so naturally and effortlessly. I walked into the 75 year old Hollywood Palladium as Fred Armisen was singing his last song as his alter-ego Ian Rubbish. I wandered through the thick smell of history at the venue, a smell that was an effortless mix of worn out carpets, lukewarm beer spilled on the floors and the mild odour of a generic air freshener blowing through the central air conditioning system of the venue. An enthusiastic pair of girls volunteering for Planned Parenthood, an organisation Sleater-Kinney has been collaborating with throughout their North American tour, handed me a condom and a pamphlet to keep me informed on how to stay protected. A perfect fit for both parties involved, especially because of the resemblance in their distinct messages as a band and an organisation. Whenever I go to a venue i’ve never been to before I enjoy looking at the ventilation ducts. I look at the decay of paint around the ducts and try and imagine all the sonic energies that have echoed through the structural integrity of that building. Be it an EDM night, or a Mastodon gig; I always try and make myself believe that some sense of liberation flows through those ducts at every single event. Thankfully, that liberating stimulus flowed through me; right into those ducts at that night.

As I sipped my ice cold and overpriced beer and looked around to see who i’d have to talk to for getting into the photo pit; Kim Gordon and Bill Nace, also known as Body/Head took the stage. Having seen them a couple of times before, I was very eager to see if their small and intimate sound bath would translate to a venue of this scale, and whether it would gain what it would loses from it’s intimacy in a sense of sonic scale. As the sounds they were releasing into the room could conventionally be described as experimental or noise oriented; there was some extent of alienation oozing out of the audience; but that thankfully did no harm to the raw connection that cements the on stage power-duo relationship between Nace and Gordon. Much like the prime of Sonic Youth, Body/Head’s sounds feed on the emotional outpour of Gordon’s sonic style. She’s still the uncontrollably raw performer she always was, and it’s a great delight to see her with an on stage partner that she feels so comfortable with. As they were playing the first few notes of the third song, I was allowed into the photo pit alongside a few other people who had cameras with lenses bigger than their arms. “Self-consciousness inflicted through an inferiority complex caused by size differences, how fitting for such a sexually aware show” I thought to myself as I attempted to both let go of the feeling of inferiority and enjoy being that close to such raw energy exhuming from two performers, whilst simultaneously trying to make sure I was capturing adequate pictures to accomplish the task I was given. What a fabulous metaphor for the “music business”.

Gordon threw her guitar around the stage and crawled back to the microphone to vocalise her energy as Nace played a few last notes to round out their fourth or fifth track while me and the rest of the folk with big cameras were asked to leave the pit as we had reached the end of the time during which we were allowed to take pictures. I paid yet another 11 dollars for a beer as the sound engineer put Andy Stott’s Faith In Strangers on the sound system while the stage crew started making the final arrangements & last minute tunings for Sleater-Kinney’s set.

Then it all went dark, and Sleater-Kinney took the stage. Fuelled by the first few deep chords of their cut Price Tag from the sublime No Cities To Love, the raw energy of the trio, joined by guitarist Katie Harkin of Sky Larkin, took over the room. With their energy now more relevant than ever, they powered their way through the first two tracks before taking a minute to talk with the audience. As they started playing Turn It On, I was let inside the photo pit and was allowed to shoot them up close for 3 songs, a period that felt both unbearably short and an eternity. It is fascinating to see the clash & harmony of energies between Tucker and Brownstein, as Corin’s energy is vividly present yet so sensitive that she can easily feel disrupted by a drunken member of the audience, whereas Carrie is just a powerhouse, with an impenetrably raw style and stage presence that you can’t help but get caught up in. Janet Weiss’s drumming acts as the core of power for the band, a force that Brownstein transforms into a resonant wave of stimulus that gets passed on to Tucker’s powerful vocals and bangs on the eardrums of the audience. It was a strange feeling to be capturing pictures of such a powerful trio so close.

Only a band with the caliber of Sleater-Kinney can force it’s audience to be swept away into a stream of awareness that demands a conscious surrender; a surrender that will allow whoever feels the need to find a voice to do just that. With such a broad array of topics to protest against, Brownstein and Co. act as the ring bearers of awareness in an age where many feel like they have to kill or surrender to an idol to feel like they have a voice, or a community. The experience of being in the presence of such skilled performers caused a thrill that could be felt throughout the room. The band made their way through new and old songs like A New Wave, Rollercoaster, Surface Envy and and Jumpers before briefly exiting the stage only to come back for an encore that included their classics One More Hour and Dig Me Out, with The Woods’ Modern Girl acting as the climax and final track of a perfect set. Harkin’s strumming was a force to be reckoned with throughout the night as she added a depth and rhythm to the Sleater-Kinney sound when a trio may not have had the same effect. It was a delight to see how well she gelled in with Weiss, Tucker and Brownstein to prove that a touring member with the right energy can have a monumental effect on a band’s performance.

As I exited the Palladium and wandered into Sunset Boulevard for a walk back to my car, I had a brief chance to reflect on the magnificent show I had just seen. The reason Sleater-Kinney is more relevant as a band than ever is because the continuous disconnection in society, particularly in the youth, can turn into a serious obstacle for individuals trying to find a genuine voice for themselves, and Sleater-Kinney is up for the challenge of giving them one. They represent the minority as well as they represent the majority. Their energy, their sound and their lyrics give consistent fuel to go on for those who try and dig beneath the surface of everything in a search of true happiness. They are the reassuring pat in the back for a generation that has big problems getting knocked down. They are the supportive big sisters as much as they are the riot grrls. I wasn’t old enough to have my heart broken when they announced their split, but I am genuinely delighted they are back. Keep your guitars raised high and voices strong for all of us cause we need you now more than ever, girls.

Photos & Words: Hakancan Altıner

title: UCLA Baseball Takes Down Stanford
content:
By Dean Rowe


After coming off a shaky series with the Cal Bears, UCLA baseball traveled up to Northern California to play a series against the Stanford Cardinals this past weekend. The Bruins were feeling confident at #3 in the country, but Stanford came out in the first game with much more to play for. By beating UCLA 6-1 in the first game, the Cardinals showed that this would not just be another easy series for the Bruins. Cardinal pitcher Brett Henewich won the game for his team, while UCLA pitcher James Kaprielian struggled to even help the Bruins as he gave up a season high amount of runs. However, if you could learn anything about Bruin baseball, it is that you should not count them out. They did just as they did with Cal the week before: came out the next game with a chip on their shoulder. In game two of the series, UCLA shut out the Cardinals 10-0. Grant Watson, a senior pitcher, came in for game 2 and brought the Bruins to victory at Stanford by throwing 6 shutout innings. Now, everything came down to game 3. Both teams had something to prove, but the Bruins pulled away with the series victory by throwing in relief pitchers. Freshman pitcher Griffin Canning lasted for a little over five innings and only gave up two runs. However, senior pitcher David Berg came in for relief to bring the Bruins a 9-3 victory over Stanford in that last game. With good pitching, especially off the bench, the Bruins put out great offense and return to LA feeling good with another series victory under their belt. If one has anything to learn from the last two series for Bruins baseball, it would be that we need to balance the performance of our pitching core and see healthier, more reliable output from the offense.

title: Austin Rivers, J.J Redick Lift Clippers To Blowout Game 3 Victory Over Rockets
content:
By Darryn Albert 

(Photo Credit: Darryn Albert)

“This is one time where you can be dad and not just coach.”  So the ESPN national broadcast captured resident Point God Chris Paul telling head coach Doc Rivers on the sideline during the 3rd quarter of the Los Angeles Clippers’ 124-99 victory over the Houston Rockets in Game 3 of their 2nd round playoff series.  Paul, who had missed the first two games of the series with a strained left hamstring, was supposed to be the big story of the evening in his triumphant return to the lineup.  Instead, the night belonged to a 22-year-old kid from Duke: one Austin James Rivers.  

The younger Rivers scored a playoff career-high 25 points, including 15 in the 3rd quarter, in just 23 minutes as the Clippers took a 2-1 lead in the best-of-seven series.  It was a surreal scene at the Staples Center as the home crowd deafeningly chanted Austin Rivers’ name and gave him a standing ovation as he exited the game.  With a bevy of acrobatic layups, stepback 3s, and high degree-of-difficulty floaters, Rivers was the biggest catalyst behind an 18-0 Clipper run at the end of the 3rd that promptly turned a five-point lead into “Game over” in the span of 4 minutes.

And look how far he’s come.  Ever since being acquired in a January trade with the Boston Celtics to become the first player in NBA history to play for his father, Austin, along with the elder Rivers, Doc, was absolutely skewered, both in the media and in the inner NBA community.  Cries of nepotism ran amok.  “GM Doc” jokes abounded.  Austin became a walking punchline, a pariah that supposedly symbolized just how lousy and misguided the Clipper second unit really was.  The Internet had a field day just one game earlier when Austin Rivers lost control of the ball at a pivotal moment in the final minute of the 4th quarter in Game 2.  A turnover on a behind-the-back dribble gone awry that ended with Austin face-down on the hardwood in shame.  But some 48 hours later, a play christened by some as “the defining Austin Rivers play” had long been forgotten.  And in its place, a simple truth: the player who was once nothing more than the coach’s son has now almost singlehandedly won the team two playoff games (Friday’s Game 3 and Game 4 of the San Antonio series) and played a pivotal role in the stealing of another victory (Game 1 at Houston last Monday night).  Who would’ve thought?

“It was confidence and hard work that helped me,” Austin said in the postgame interview, the finishing touches on a well-deserved “podium game.”  “I was able to get to the basket a couple of times and then I just had it going from there.  My teammates believed in me and I was having fun out there.”  After a performance that featured an otherworldly stepback 3 on Jason Terry that spurred the younger Rivers to launch into James Harden’s “stir the pot” celebration and that had the Clippers official Twitter account singing the praises of Chef Austin Rivers and his three-cheese lasagna, it looks like he wasn’t the only one who was having fun.  

But for father and coach Doc, despite Paul’s best efforts, he always tries to treat Austin like just another one of his players instead of his son.  And that was no different after Austin’s huge Game 3 showing.  “They’re all my sons,” said Doc.  “Like if Lester [Hudson] or Matt [Barnes] had done the same thing, I would’ve been proud, because I see all of them do the work.  So good for him.  He knows the way I think, though.  We’ve got another game, and you’ve just got to be ready for the next game.”  But the Clipper coach did give Austin proper credit for his Game 3 performance saying, “But it was great.  It was needed.  He was just very aggressive and that’s what we’ve been telling him to do.  But it was important really because it allowed us to keep CP at the minutes.  That was huge for us.”  

And though Austin was the big story in Game 3, his out-of-body experience almost obscured the strong team effort that made the Houston dismantling possible.  J.J. Redick poured in a playoff career-high 31 points and Paul looked great in his return, scoring 12 points and dishing out 7 assists in just 23 minutes.  Blake Griffin added 22 points (including some earth-shattering dunks on the entire state of Texas), 14 rebounds, and 4 assists while DeAndre Jordan pulled down 15 rebounds.  

James Harden led the Rockets with 25 points and 11 assists while Dwight Howard added 14 points and 14 rebounds.  But the Clippers clamped down on Houston’s complementary players, frustrating them to the point that Jason Terry was ejected in the 4th quarter for a blindside cheap shot on Blake Griffin.  The way that the Clippers held Harden, the NBA’s regular season leader in free throw attempts, to just 5 FTAs was a big storyline as well.  Coach Rivers praised his team’s defensive effort on Harden saying “Every time he drove, you saw our guys pulling their hands back, pulling their hands back, and they had the discipline to do that.”

(Photo Credit: Darryn Albert)

For his part, Harden credited the Clipper defense saying in his postgame interview, “They’re a really good defensive team, especially when they get set.  We’ve just got to do a better job of moving the basketball and just being aggressive.”  Rockets coach Kevin McHale echoed these sentiments, saying, “We couldn’t get shots to go, and we didn’t have any flow.  Really James was the only guy that was making plays for us in the halfcourt.  We weren’t running, we weren’t getting stops.  We didn’t play very well.  In that third quarter, our team defense went to hell.”  

The game was yet another exhibit in the Clippers’ rapidly growing portfolio of strong two-way play in the postseason.  They finished the night shooting over 55% from the field and they won the rebounding battle by the total of 50-43.  

When asked about how his hamstring held up after the game, Chris Paul replied, “I got through.  This is the point of the season where nobody is 100%.  And if I could give anything to get out there and help the team, then I wanted to do it.  It was fun to get out there and be a part of the action.”  With regard to Austin’s performance, Paul remarked “Austin was unbelievable.  I was probably his biggest cheerleader there in the 3rd quarter.  He’s been working really hard and seeing him do that, it gave me a chance to rest.”  The artist known as CP3 has since remarked about his status for Game 4 saying “There’s no speculation, probable or questionable, I’m playing.”

Ultimately, Game 3 will be remembered for a lot of things.  A night where the Clippers got their floor general back.  A night where J.J. Redick canned every shot he looked at.  A night where Blake Griffin dunked on entire cosmos (well…another night).  And a night where the once-detested Austin Rivers caught fire, spread his wings, stepped on Houston throats, and finally earned the respect of the Clipper faithful.  We’ll see if Sunday’s Game 4 at the Staples Center (8:30 PM EST/5:30 PM PST tip-off) can top it.

title: FLYLO

Give Hockey a Chance; 
A Pathetic Poetic Call for Appreciation
content:
By J.T. Osborn

As the brooms swept up the hardwood floors,
Excitement fading away like Curry,
I wondered what could offer more,
Basketball had left me worried.
Where is the pressure, the guts, the clutch
That made me love the NBA so much?
These Conference Finals were a bore,
I cannot take it anymore.

That’s when it hit me,
Like a shot from Dwayne Johnson,
I’d hit Rock Bottom.

I flipped and skipped and dipped through shows,
NBC stopped me
With Hockey,
Curious?
I suppose.

The flurry, the hurry, the quickness the hits!
The stressing, the guessing, I just couldn’t sit!
I never ever ever could have guessed,
This game would have my heart beat straight out of my chest.

Lightning had struck,
Lone Ranger no more,
I fell for some Ducks,
Whom beat Blackhawks galore!

Slapshots,
Black eyes,
Jaw-dropping saves,
Fist fights,
Puck flips,
Very quick skates.

Two Game Sevens,
Everything’s on the line.
Santa has delivered gifts early this time.

Please, I beg of you.
For your own sports fulfillment,
Give Hockey a Chance.

Or I’ll hunt you down and make you watch the NBA Conference Finals again.

title: Meet the Springterns: Emi Eck (Reviewing “Who’s Gonna Get Fucked First?” by Father)
content:
Interview Questions

What do you enjoy most about being a father?

  • Eddie: Listening to Father on Mother’s Day! #meninism. I think the most enjoyable thing is just focusing on myself, and being able to focus on myself while being a dad…including shunning my family and making everything mostly about me.
  • Matteo: Changing diapers all day is really great. My favorite scent now.

What would your dad think about this album?

  • Matteo: My dad would absolutely hate this album lol
  • Eddie: My dad: “what the fuck! This isn’t the Beatles!”

If you could compare becoming a dad to any song on this album what song would it be and why?

  • Matteo: “spoil you rotten”–self-explanatory
  • Eddie: Definitely “Slow Dance” just cause I have two left feet and it’s great to hear that as a dad, I won’t be able to teach my kids to or dance with my àmour without looking like a tard!!!! Sums up the whole dad experience.

After listening to “Who’s Gonna Get Fucked First?”, Father has a place in my heart as a raunchy, twisted DILF/ father-figure. I feel like I’m babysitting at a birthday party and he’s some kid’s Dad who smokes me out in a bounce house. Overall, the album feels carefree, defiant, dark, and sexual. Its minimalist, heavy beats are like xanned-out lullabies with nursery-rhyme sounding riffs that are comforting yet destructive.

title: Not a Bad Place to End Up: Hundley Waits to Day 3 to be Selected by the Pack
content:
By Josh Naftulin     

     We all know about Brett Hundley by now around Westwood.  That is, unless you’ve been living under a rock while attending UCLA or following PAC-12 football during the past few years.  His leadership and good character were unquestionable, but as the 2015 NFL Draft approached more GMs and scouts appeared to be criticizing his ability to transition to being a starting quarterback at the next level.  I of course thought my personal prediction that Hundley wouldn’t stay undrafted past the second day of the draft was a sure thing, but I’m biased because I’ve seen him develop over his college career. And that’s why I’m overjoyed Hundley was forced to endure the pain of not being selected until the 5th round.  When the Green Bay Packers made him the No. 166 pick in the draft, I could feel a little smile find its way to my face.  I immediately saw this as the perfect situation for Brett, and after discovering that the Packers traded to move up nineteen spots to select him, I honestly think that Director of Pro Personnel Eliot Wolf was smart to move up to nab the athletic quarterback.          Being able to learn from and develop behind a guaranteed future Hall of Famer in Aaron Rodgers will allow Hundley to harness his skills at the next level while not being thrust into a starting role.  Green Bay had already addressed its more pressing needs in the draft, and made an incredibly smart move to shuffle a late 7th-round draft pick elsewhere in order to seize what might just end up the greatest mid/late-round QB steal since Tom Brady. There’s no need to address his stats or intangibles in this article.  Hundley certainly has the look of a NFL starting quarterback and the right head for the job, and that is why I think several GMs and personnel scouts throughout the league will be smacking themselves in the head years from now for letting Brett slip into Round 5.                    There’s literally no better football atmosphere to witness than the one at Lambeau Field, and I’m sure Hundley will find himself at home as the next Bruin (drafted since Johnathan Franklin) for Cheese Heads to cheer for.  While Brett will likely have to wait for a while to receive his chance to lead a NFL team, he’ll have an excellent chance to become what many doubted he can be.  With that immense chip on his shoulder from having to wait so long to receive that fateful phone call, Brett Hundley will definitely work to show the Packers front office and fan base his appreciation for their belief in him.  Knowing how hard Hundley will continue to work to prove himself now that he had so many quarterback-needy teams pass him up, I’ll certainly be cheering for Hundley at the next level and hope he’ll have a chance at some point down the road to prove himself as a starter.

title: 28 Grams - Wiz Khalifa
content:
By: Scott Gee

            When listening to Wiz Khalifa in the past, the normal question asked during every song would be “Just how high is he right now?”  28 Grams leaves the listener with quite another set of questions because it is painfully aware just how high Wiz is.  The first question I asked myself was, “How high to I have to get before I don’t hear this vocoder anymore?”  Khalifa has taken a curious turn down the autotune road of T Pain and Future in an attempt for what some might call “innovation”.  Wiz’s attempt to innovate on 28 Grams leaves a sour taste and overall is a poor attempt to add depth to a music catalog that was already very thin to begin with.

            From the opening of the mixtape, Wiz shows that his original polish and originality aren’t going to be making a full appearance.  Already known as a rapper who borders on lazy, a lackluster first track followed by a cover of Man of the Year is a clear indicator that there will be nothing groundbreaking coming.  An overall emphasis is the “trap” sound that has taken over the rap genre with the phrase “TRAP WIZ” yelled over the beat as many times as possible.  Considering that Wiz was an original propagator of the trap sound as created by Lex Luger on his prior mixtape Cabin Fever, its puzzling that this can be seen as a step forward when it realistically is a giant step backward.  The trap sound here attempts to be a more polished version than the truly raw Cabin Fever but loses its human connection in a whirlwind of computerized vocals and bass heavy beats.

            The true strength of Wiz in the past was the ability to flow on a beat and give nothingness a direction.  On 28 Grams, this shtick begins to lose steam.  For one, the mixtape is 28 songs long, a length that comes from a lot of material that frankly should never even make it to a mixtape.  On top of this, previous Wiz listeners can easily point out lines he has used in previous songs.  The nonchalant attitude of Wiz normally propels his music to a level of weightlessness that can fill hours and move through spaces easily.  Here, the bearing weight of the production and the lack of a clear direction or idea lands the music before it ever had the chance to take off.  That being said, this mixtape does have its brighter moments, they just never gain enough momentum to amount to anything.  When Wiz drops the autotune and decides to rap, there is still that flicker that could leave fans excited for his upcoming album Blacc Hollywood.  Otherwise, listen with caution.

Recommended Tracks: James Bong, Samo, The Last, The Rain

 GRADE: 3/10

title: Fall(?) of Brady
content:
By J.T. Osborn

On February 1, 2015, Tom Brady won Super Bowl XLIX and solidified himself as possibly the greatest quarterback of this generation if not ever.

On May 5, 2015, a report came out that may jeopardize that assumption. Ted Wells’ report on the Deflategate scandal stated that it’s “more probable than not” that Tom Brady was likely aware of the purposeful deflating of game balls for the AFC Championship game against Indianapolis.

Following the Championship game, officials and reports came out claiming that a vast majority of the Patriots’ game balls used were under-deflated beyond the legal playing limit as designated by the NFL. Immediately, Commissioner Goodell responded with an investigation, hiring Ted Wells to lead the investigation and find out who was responsible for the deflations.

Rumors began swirling blaming Tom Brady, locker attendant Jim McNally, and even Bill Belichick for being responsible of such treachery.

Now, it’s official…kind of. McNally is labeled to have deflated the balls and Brady is being (sort of) labeled as (more probable than not) the evil mastermind behind it all.

So what exactly does this all mean for Brady’s legacy? I’m glad I asked. Brady has never had the popularity his arch rival and friend Peyton Manning has had. Manning comes off as intelligent, witty, funny, likeable, and someone you’d want to share a beer with to both fans and media alike. Brady however, has come off as snotty, arrogant, and whiny to the pigskin population. Manning gains a lot of ground in the legacy department simply because he’s been more likeable than Brady, because let’s face it: the greatest player of this generation comes down to between these two.

It’s not entirely fair that people judge Brady the way they do and that Manning will always be seen more favorably simply because he was more likeable during his time in the NFL.

But Brady has always had two things going for him against Manning: Super Bowls and head-to-head victories: four Super Bowl victories compared to Manning’s one and an 11-5 record head-to-head.

Now, Tom Brady has another distinction: suspended (probable) cheater. To what extent do under-deflated balls help Tom Brady? I don’t know. Has Tom Brady been doing this for a while? I don’t know. Will this hurt Brady’s legacy? Yes, I do know.

It’s official that Tom Brady will be suspended for an unknown amount of time during the 2016 season. The duration of the punishment should come out next week and I’m sure Brady will appeal.

Still, the blemish will be there. The report will always be tied to his name. In the United States Justice System you may be innocent until proven guilty, but in the sports world and to the fans, it doesn’t matter. That ‘what if’ will always be there, and the Internet generation never forgets, just ask Barry Bonds.

Dammit Brady, you had it all wrapped up and you blew it.

Long live Manning, the fair-playing, savvy quarterback that will go down as the best of our generation.

title: Throwback Review: Of Montreal (3/22/15)
content:
Here at UCLA Radio, we love Of Montreal. In case you missed Eddie’s review of their show at the Regent in March, we got another throwback review for you today. Get ready to transport thyself back to the 22nd of March! 

Of Montreal played Sunday night (3/22/15) at the Regent Theatre in Los Angeles, and, without failing to be critical, it was probably the best show I’ve ever seen.  Of course, Of Montreal always puts on a phenomenal show; their recent tour, however, is especially fun and goofy.  As promised at the beginning of the show  by a masked MC who made a deal with the devil himself: if we all, collectively, have the greatest night of our lives, Of Montreal will be awarded with the power to alter reality for an hour- or as it turns out, an hour and a half.    

Musically, the band was on top as ever.  They played a 100 minute set which included their newest hits, such as those of their most recent album, Aurelate Gloom.  They also stretched back into the Of Montreal canon to play their earlier classics: hits like ‘Wraith Pinned to the Mist and Other Games’, which always induces a lovely and bouncy crowd response.  Of course, part of the beauty of a live show is how the music diverges from the records we know and love. Kevin Barnes and the band were not afraid to make those diversions, often times illiciting a huge crowd response.  When Barnes extended a note into what is normally a silent pause, for example, the crowd went wild with cheers and clapping. An Of Montreal show, however, goes well beyond the music.  As in past shows, the band was frequently joined on stage by costumed performers who would present visually stimulating scenes or use their bodies and props to augment the already interesting light show.  Masked figures use large white circles to capture picture from the projector: skulls, faces, sperm and eggs, and much more pop off the back wall and onto the stage in these placards.  As if these masked performers weren’t enough to capture the imagination- which they were- performers also came out in much more vibrant costumes.  One should mention the numerous masked brides, one of which engaged in fabulously simulated sex with the guitarist, who, although riding the brides pelvis with both legs in the air, never ceased playing. My personal favorite scene, however, involved two large breasted dogs in American flag jumpers.  They first treated to audience to a boxing match, before begining a bizarre strip tease.  The crowd going wild, the dogs finally stripped to their waists, revealing comically large foam breasts which they showed off to the audience. 

No doubt, however, the star of the show was Kevin Barnes himself.  It’s not often that the main singer and guitarist for a band finds his way off stage multiple times through out the show, but it was necessary for Barnes to manage his multiple outfit changes.  Though each outfit is worth a mention, it was what he wore to finish the show that captures best the fun, party spirit of the concert.  After called for an encore, Barnes returned to the stage wearing nothing but short white shorts and a neck scarf, flaunting his lean torso for the benefit of the audience.  Other entrances were even more spectacular, such as when, after a outfit change, Barnes was reintroduced as the center piece of an altar of sorts- a combination of actors draped in white and extraordinary projections. In a word, the concert was sublime.  Multiple other nuances of the concert going experience as well as those described in depth above came together for a truly enjoyable concert going experience.  The audience, for example, seemed light-hearted, jovial, and interested in having a good time.  The merchandise table, located on The Regent’s balconies which afford a more than acceptable view without the crowds, was selling wares which included tape cassettes and underwear, along with the usual garb.  Feathers, shot into the audience, added to the show’s relaxed yet mystical atmosphere, allowing for bizarre breaks such as the country feminist anthem played during one of Barnes’s changes.  There are more sights and sounds at an Of Montreal concert than can be put into a measly review such as this one; this critic’s advice is that when Of Montreal plays near you, you ought never to fail in attending.

Review by Sheehan and photo by Eddie

title: SHOW REVIEW: Mantzoukas And...
content:
A consistently good improv show can be hard to find. But at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre, it’s always a little easier. At UCB’s monthly show, Mantzoukas And…, Jason Mantzoukas (The League, The Dictator) is joined by a few of his fellow improvisers to perform long-form improv.

November’s guests were Lennon Parham and Jessica St. Clair. As three performers who have been honing their craft for almost 20 years, the show was a flawless (or at least just made funnier by any flaws) hour of comedians bouncing joke after joke on one another with a reparté that only comes with practice and the natural chemistry.  With the audience suggestion “unplugged”, Parham, St. Clair, and Mantzoukas launched into an hour-long scene that natural tangents aside, felt like a cohesive scene and a perfect example of long-form improv. The show then culminated in an audience Q&A, which led to the improvisers critiquing and joking about the show, something that is usually left unsaid. Mantzoukas And… is a monthly mainstay at UCB Franklin and a must-see for any improv fan. This month’s show takes place December 11 and is, sadly, sold out.

title: Stickers of the Station
content:
Check out our new Series, Stickers of the Station! On Tuesdays for the rest of the quarter, we will be posting pics, descriptions, and even investigations of the many stickers in our station. Feel free to follow along on your own blog and we always encourage submissions! 

Our new series, Stickers of the Station, is meant to further connect our listeners to UCLARadio. Our station is a physical representation of all of our DJs past and present.  This is our way to document that for you! We’ll be starting things off with this sticker for Jade Tree Records.

Jade Tree was founded in 1991 by Darren Walters and Tim Owens, who had both previously owned straight edge hardcore labels. In response to the decline of the scene, Jade Tree was born. Though the label started with many post-hardcore acts early on, their repertoire expanded as things progressed.

Much to the founders’ surprise, what had started as a small effort to help support independent music grew into a label with several well known bands. Some of the more prominent punk bands signed to Jade Tree include The Blood Brothers, Alkaline Trio, and Fucked Up. Another notable portion of their lineup was 90s emo, including such prominent bands as The Promise Ring, Texas is the Reason, and Jets to Brazil. Additionally, the label has a significant portion of Mike Kinsella’s (of American Football) project: Cap’n Jazz, Joan of Arc, and Owl. 

You can find out more about Jade Tree on their website, www.jadetree.com

by Jeremy, New Media Co-Manager

title: Stickers in the Station
content:
Check out our new Series, Stickers of the Station! On Tuesdays for the rest of the quarter, we will be posting pics, descriptions, and even investigations of the many stickers in our station. Feel free to follow along on your own blog and we always encourage submissions! 

If the raw energy of Explosions in the Sky and the ambient vibes of Tycho somehow had a child, El Ten Eleven, a post-rock/instrumental band from our very own Los Angeles, CA, would be it. Formed in 2002, they have since released 5 albums, and 2 EP’s—their most recent is For Emily.

I discovered this band during one of my weekly mindlessly-look-at-related-artists-of-a-band-I-like-as-an-excuse-to-not-do-my-homework sessions and I’ve got to say, ETE has probably left the most lasting impact. Every time I’m lounging in my dorm room writing a paper, needing what I like to call “prevent writer’s block at all cost” music, I listen to ETE because I know their vibes will get my creative juices flowing. Their debut self-titled album, El Ten Eleven, is by far my favorite of their discography and this is my go to album for whenever you need to access a stream of consciousness state. 

If you like Explosions in the Sky, Tycho, Built to Spill, or any other related artists, give this band a listen. They will relax you for sure.

~Bryan

title: Podcast Recommendation: "How Did This Get Made?"
content:
The Best Way To Hate Watch

Paul Scheer, best known for VH1’s “Best Week Ever” and sketch comedy team “Human Giant,” hosts the “How Did This Get Made” bi-weekly podcast on the Earwolf network, which offers an in depth analysis of some of the best-worst movies of the year. Scheer co-hosts with wife June Diane Raphael, star of Adult Swim series “NTSF:SD:SUV,” and friend Jason Mantzoukas of “The League” fame. The podcast also employs a cast of guests on each episode such as Amy Schumer, Chris Hardwick, Damon Lindelof, Adam Scott. In one episode the show even booked Vanilla Ice to explain just what was going on in his head when he filmed the critically panned “Cool as Ice.” The podcasts go about the task of deconstructing choice scenes and making sense of often nonsensical plot developments. On the latest full episode, Scheer and three guest star comedians, Rob Huebel, Chelsea Peretti and John Flynn debate the merits of “LOL,” a 2012 vehicle starring Miley Cyrus as a rebellious teen. The four tackle scenes in the film for almost an hour, commenting on the oddities not addressed throughout the plot. Their calling out of the strangeness of key scenes such as when Cyrus undresses and showers in the presence of her mom, played by Demi Moore, without explanation and another in which her friend fingers a raw chicken while on Chatroulette (“She is putting a camera into a raw chicken’s body cavity. That’s serial killer shit,” one comments) provide most of the fun in the podcast. Other segments include “second opinions,” in which Scheer reads out passionate five-star reviews of the films from Amazon.com users and show recommendations about whether or not to watch the movie under review. The films discussed on the “How Did This Get Made” may not be fun to watch, but the show certainly makes them fun to discuss.

title: The Looney Effect
content:
As they head into Wednesday’s game at home against UC Riverside, the men on the UCLA basketball team have a chance to refine their games a bit more and learn to play more in sync with one another. Coming off of a rather tight game with the University of San Diego, the team must establish a greater identity as before a tough home contest facing Gonzaga on Saturday and a road trip to go play Kentucky and Alabama before entering league play.

This current group of Bruins is still growing together, but the players must learn to mesh a little better before the Pac-12 games start to roll around. The plethora of talented underclassmen is exciting, but team leaders must step up and take charge. Though Norman Powell appears to be offering the young group a veteran presence, Tony Parker has failed to take on a larger role both in the locker room and on the hardwood.
With that being said, perhaps the best aspect of the team this season has been the play of True Freshman Kevon Looney. The 6’, 9” forward out of Milwaukee, Wisconsin is a double-double machine and is already a projected to be a top-15 pick in the 2015 NBA draft. While he could probably do to improve his baseline jumper and add some muscle, Looney’s incredible length and athleticism certainly make him an attractive prospect to NBA teams. Not only Looney’s body type, but also his tenacity and aggression bring to mind comparisons to a young Kevin Garnett. Of course we will have to see how the rest of the season pans out, but if Looney continues to post a steady double-double, it will be difficult for the Bruins to retain the budding Freshman.

Coming out and attacking during the second half of the last game against the Toreros, Looney finished with 18 points and 11 rebounds. His presence in the paint throughout the final period provided the Bruins an excellent change of pace to a game plan that included what had been mostly outside jump shots up to that point. Moving forward, Coach Alford should really reshape his offensive plan to include more passes to Looney on the drive or down low in the key. Looney’s 7’, 1” wingspan allows him the advantage of reaching over opponents for key offensive rebounds and put-backs. Additionally, the effort and energy Looney displays on a regular basis have already earned him more minutes, on average, than returning big man Parker. If this pattern continues, don’t be surprised to see Looney continue to be the Bruins’ first option in the frontcourt, and don’t say you weren’t warned if you see the Milwaukee product bolt to the next level after this season is over.

title: A Fan’s Farewell to the Most Important American Soccer Player Ever
content:
Leading scorer in United States Men’s National Team history. Highest assist numbers in United States Men’s National Team history. Leading scorer in MLS history. Highest assist numbers in MLS history. Five MLS titles. The face of a league, a national team, and a sport within a nation. From the golden boy in 2002 to the reassuring veteran presence in 2010. A product of a German youth academy who became the face of the San Jose Earthquakes organization before a short, unsuccessful spell at Bayern Munich. A Galaxy legend who won the hearts of Everton supporters in two successful loan spells.


Landon Donovan took American soccer to the next level. The success of 2002 and the drama of 2010 brought the game into national focus. His play at Everton was a large step in establishing the legitimacy of Major League Soccer. Landon consistently won big games for the USMNT. He was also consistently the best player in MLS. The pacey Californian, somewhat affectionally referred to as “Landycakes,” once grabbed 20 goals in 25 games in a season, a season that inspired then-Bayern coach Jürgen Klinsmann to bring Donovan in on loan. While the loan was not as successful as many would have hoped, Landon broke a huge barrier simply by being an American on the books of one of the biggest clubs in the world (Julian Green owes Landon a thank you for this).


Of course, Landon’s relationship with Jürgen was not always this good. This summer, the most famous American soccer player was left off of the World Cup roster. Soon after, he announced that he would be retiring from professional soccer. Because of this, I find myself, along with countless others, saying goodbye to the most important American soccer player ever. I hesitate to assert that he is the best, although I do think that. But there’s an argument to be made for Claudio Reyna, Clint Dempsey, Tim Howard, and several others when it comes to best. There is no argument for most important. Landon transformed the sport in this country. He is a huge reason why millions of Americans tuned in to the World Cup this summer, even if he was not in Brazil with the team. His influence is one of the reasons why saying bye to Landon should be hard for every American soccer fan.


Thank you, Landon, for everything.

~Cole Frost

title: SHOW REVIEW: Future Islands @ the Wiltern (11/20/14)
content:
Up-and-coming synth-rockers Future Islands warmed up their audience with a massive dance party at The Wiltern on a chilly Thursday night. This marked the 20th night of the month-long event hosted by Red Bull’s #30 Days in LA with its mission to showcase new musical acts throughout venues around LA. Fans were greeted with a lively ambience with numerous minibars surrounding the lobby of a majestic theatre, while the actual venue was minimally populated with somewhat dull opening bands. As soon as the two opening bands finished, fans cut their chitchatting and rushed towards the stage. One man was clearly prepared for the party as he came dressed up as “Tin Man” from Wizard of Oz – also a song by Future Islands featured in their early albums. 

As roadies began to set up for the main act, hardcore fans immediately noticed that these men were the actual band members minus singer Sam Herring who was most likely behind curtains practicing his notable dance moves. All four members finally conjoined and began their upbeat set with “Back in the Tall Grass” off from their most recent album Singles. Sam ordered everyone to stop playing towards the beginning of the song, as he was definitely not enjoying the build-up. Everyone applauded and cheered as they decided to restart their opening song with a more intensifying force. Sam finally juxtaposed his dancing along to the music as he swayed his hips and arms in a very seductive manner that drove the audience significantly wild. His dynamic style of dancing made his shirt tear apart which he did not notice after two songs. Meanwhile, Tin Man was unfortunately trapped behind the second section of the general admission area in which he later attempted to get closer, but was unluckily stopped by security.
 

The dance party continued with full force as the band played every song from their recent album. Songs such as “Doves” and “A Dream of You and Me” made the audience jump repeatedly until their utmost energy was then transformed into a surreal mosh-pit with their hit-song “Seasons (Waiting On You)”. During this song, Herring roared as if he was trapped in a sea of despair portrayed by the melancholic lyrics. Similarly, in the song “A Song For Our Grandfathers”, Herring gazes at the ceiling with an extended arm as he reminisces about his own grandfather. The audience is able to detect his sorrow and stand paralyzed until the very end music note of that song. The celebration is however brought back to life by their continued set infused with an array of synth beats and groovy bass lines - a staple of Future Islands’ music.

A sense of climax and closure finally wrapped up the band’s live performance as balloons fell from the ceiling decor of The Wiltern. A total of 14 songs were played which made fans feel satisfied and head towards the exit. The band was however not ready to leave and came back up on stage with 3-song encore that kept the party going past midnight. Future Islands left the stage after almost a two-hour set filled with non-stop dancing triggered by the electrifying beats that have caused their success to keep growing due to their spirited musicianship.

Photos & Words // Michelle Preciado

title: On Concert Etiquette
