content:
Written By: Sam Blake

Post Date: 4/19/17

Many of life’s great questions reveal themselves only through experience. So it was, that, at a Sigur Ros concert I attended some time ago in New York City, I found myself in a situation demanding an ethical response. My decision would, undoubtedly, set the standard of behavior I would need to follow for the rest of my life. For what is a man if he is not consistent?

The situation reminded me of one of my favorite moments in The Simpsons - arguably the greatest show of all time if, and only if, one considers only seasons one through twelve. Otto, the headphoned bus driver, is sitting at a concert in a stadium chair. He is eager, as one would expect, to have his face melted by his revered gods of rock. Yet, he finds himself in a most bogus situation: he cannot see the stage. “Sit down!” he yells in his gravelly voice. “You’re ruining it for us all!” Out of the entire sold-out theater, however, he is literally the only one who is not standing.

At the Sigur Ros concert, I was seated for the opening act. I was relaxed, and my view of the stage was primo: my buddy and I were in the first row of seats just behind the general admission floor. It seemed like an incredible bargain. This is how the symphony-goers watch music: just killin’ it. I figured I might as well continue this bargain bourgeoisie experience while I had it.

Then, waves of people down in the general admission area begin standing up from their floor seats. They ripple from just in front of the stage back to my row and fizzle out shortly thereafter. I can no longer see. The people just behind me, though, who are still sitting–they can. I’m trapped.

What do I do? If I keep sitting, I can hardly see the stage. If I stand, the people sitting people won’t be able to see.

Several Otto-like grumblers emerged from the crowd to my rear to yell at the people who had stood up. Unlike our beloved bus driver, though, the Madison Square Garden crowd didn’t bother pretending that they cared for anyone else’s enjoyment. Instead, they voiced their discontent in slightly more antagonistic language. The common refrain was something like, “Sit the fuck down, asshole!”

I’m teetering. I remain seated as I think it through. It’s certainly cool that a live band is playing up there, very close to me. But I didn’t come to this concert merely to have my ears titillated nor to be excited by proximity. I came to see the music being played. And I could only see if I stood.

Decision time. To sit or to stand? If I do what the Ottos behind me want and continue sitting, only they will be able to see. If I do what the Ottos do not want, only I will be able to see. But if we both do what we sort of do not want to do, well, then we will all be able to see.

So I stood. I felt, and still feel, that I made the right choice. The ethical choice. A choice that allowed us all to bask in the beauty and the intensity that is a Sigur Ros concert. And so, my friends, I hereby bequeath this experience and the accompanying wisdom to you. Let it be known: it is okay to stand, even if a bus driver behind you adamantly wishes otherwise.

title: The Crisis of Musical “Individuality”
content:
Written By: Libby Hsieh

Post Date: 3/31/17

In 2017, the muddy waters of musical homogeneity are crowded with people trying to stay afloat, and succeeding under the premise that they all scream the same words. Being a musician, I, like everyone else, have spent many hours daydreaming about performing my music as a way to make a living. Every time I think about it, I want to smash my guitar like those guys in creepy metal bands like I have some predisposition against “the man,” throw my keyboard out the window like that badass old lady in Zombieland, and proclaim an existence of silence before tying my vocal chords into a knot.

Attending small house shows, performing at them, and seeing my friends play the same game, leaves me in this place of not-so-quiet contemplation concerning one word—individuality. Certainly, a shitty college apartment or an underground warehouse—with the same lo-fi static, cut off jeans, apathetic eye rolls, and “Add us on SoundCloud!”—are places where you will find very tiny amounts of it. I don’t care how underground and experimental you think it is. It’s not.

As an influx of musicians scheme their way through exclusive DIY communities, it’s hard to distinguish true creativity. Everything becomes a bland, hackneyed line of formulaic music. Music communities originally formed on the intent of wild expression have become a basic need for musicians to receive populist validation.

It’s all overproduction. It has deformed authenticity and rugged individualism into a plastic model of what people want to listen to. Because we’re lazy.

Musicians (some, not all) know what they want to play because they know what other people want to hear. Sure, you can play guitar. Sure, you have a stellar set of pipes—but where is the creativity? Anyone can play three noisy chords. Anyone can listen to a vocal riff and copy it without a hitch.

Likewise, in the form of other genres, anyone can read an inspiring lyric and write something that mirrors it. But where is the authenticity in that? How can being a ‘creative’ be authentic when every person’s music is a derivative of something that has been done thousands of times before? You can’t keep recycling old ideas and passing them off as individuality. Everyone else is doing that. This pseudo-individuality is overdone and frankly, it’s boring.

In his essay “E Unibus Pluram,“ David Foster Wallace proposes that the next literary, or artistic, era is going to be littered with “anti-rebels,” who “treat old untrendy human troubles and emotions in U.S. life with reverence and conviction.” He goes on to say, “These anti-rebels would be outdated, of course, before they even started. Too sincere. Clearly repressed…Real Rebels, as far as I can see, risk things. Risk disapproval. The new rebels might be the ones willing to risk the yawn, the rolled eyes, the cool smile, the nudged ribs, the parody of gifted ironists, the ‘How banal.’”

But what happens when we have started producing mass sincerity, individuality, or experimentalism in order to gain a profit to the point where “sincerity” and “individualism” are things that are as common as traffic on the 405 at 3 p.m.? People like relatable artists. People like realness. What happens when realness isn’t real anymore? Sincerity has become the standard for music and has done people’s thinking for them. It makes people forget that what they are listening to is wholly intended for them and is predigested rather than a true reflection of the artist. It becomes no more than a means to an end. Why can’t sentimentality be the end?

Trying to be wholly authentic, wholly emotional, or wholly “individual” seems like it’s an effort to rally against the status quo. However, as every musician gets the wise idea of rebellion, they become a humdrum cliche. I was having this conversation with a good friend of mine and he said that for music to be considered “good,” and non-cliche essentially, it has to have a quality of inspiration and a knack for drawing people in—emotionally and also with outstanding musicianship. But in a culture where every person is producing similarity and wiping out originality, how do we differentiate between what is genuine and what is solely trying to make a profit or appeal to a larger audience?

Many of those artists, who have tried to write music solely for themselves, have been perfectly molded into these stereotypes, against all their efforts, simply because there are a million other musicians exactly like them. Any attempts at trying to break into the realm of inspiration to others is impossible when the credibility of uniqueness has become nullified. People are so used to hearing “rawness” and “realness” that their ears are used to it. They have become tuned to this song of predigested overstimulation.

Sure, you can say that this idea is elitist and only appeals to avant garde music and classical pieces—music that plays to the unreached imagination and successfully fulfills the emotional human need. But it’s not. It’s not necessarily about writing something strange. You can’t create new instruments. You can’t create new sounds.

In the current climate of political intensity, authenticity is no longer enough. Individualism is only of service to those creating it. Getting people to move is what we need. So maybe our place in the musical realm isn’t solely to be ourselves and create new things. Instead, we should pander to this collective idea—in a real positive way. In a way that incites action and creates change in a place where people often feel misguided and marginalized.

title: Served on a Silver Platter: Reviewing Salome at the LA Opera
content:
Written By: Aaron Peretz

Post Date: 3/21/17

This season of the LA Opera began its wane in conjunction with the onset of spring and the production of Richard Strauss’s Salome. Originally written at the close of the 19th century, the opera’s libretto was written by Strauss himself (following a relaxed sense of Gesamtkunstwerk in the Wagnerian tradition) after the Oscar Wilde play under the same name. The parable comes from the Bible. Its title is derived from the protagonist Salome, the daughter of stepfather King Herod (of mandates decreeing the death of male babies notoriety) and hermother Herodias. At the nascent age of 15, her beauty is already renowned throughout the kingdom, and all men find themselves snookered by her - including her stepfather. A precocious youth, she resents her controlling and lascivious parents but is aware of her beauty so that she often manipulates others to get what she wants.

During a royal banquet, Salome storms out of the hall and hears the wails of a man locked in the palace cistern. The voice belongs to the prophet John the Baptist. Rumors have spread throughout the palace regarding Herod’s fear of the prophet. Salome feels compelled to see the object of her stepfather’s fear, and convinces a guard into temporarily releasing him (after breaking his position’s oath, he kills himself.) Salome finds within John the Baptist an overwhelming purity, a chasteness of soul that she compares to her own virginity. The prophet averts his eyes from the youth and decries her advances on him. He returns to his prison warning her to visit Jesus or to expect a violent end.

Her stepfather approaches her following this interaction. Desperate for the love of Salome, he promises her anything in exchange for a dance. Salome takes up the king’s offer seeing a chance to incite the jealousy of her mother, and fulfill her passions. The following scene is accompanied by the legendary “Dance of the Seven Veils” and garnered a lot of notoriety at the production’s inaugural performance due to the suggestive nature of a teenager stripping. A satisfied Herod follows through on his promise to give anything to Salome. Moved by the shame of denial, she asks for the head of John the Baptist on a silver platter. Herod ultimately gives in to her demands.

Following the death of the prophet, Salome muses over her own executive ability. As she dances with the head, her parents silently enter the scene. The opera comes to its zenith as Salome comes through on her promise and kisses the lips of John the Baptist. Herod sentences her to death, and the curtains fall.

As a repeat opera goer, I cannot attest enough to the profundity of the music. Few operas that I’ve attended have yielded such a strong physiological response on my part, with goosebumps and palpitations and so-forth. Strauss’s music projects a noticeably more contemporary sound than its predecessors—his sound’s motifs are much closer to the character of modern film scores than, say, Mozart. The impact of Salome’s kiss remains un-betrayed despite a popular overexposure of sex and violence in 2017.

The opera considers themes of jealousy and power, but perhaps most evident is the love of the unattainable. The cadence and form of the content mirrors the phenomenon of post-coital tristesse. Both Herod and Salome ultimately achieve some minimized version of that which they most want (each a carnal desire). But the consequences for both are destructive. Herod’s love devolves to shame and anger at witnessing Salome’s kiss on the detached head of John the Baptist. Salome, in turn, is met by her death after attaining only the phantasm of her desire. Even the guard who helped Salome in the opening scene killed himself after her persuasive flirtations.

This dichotomy of that which is within and beyond our grasp is extended to the character of John the Baptist. Framed as the only spiritually pure character in the opera, he strives to move beyond the earthly realm. An initial reading of the opera may suggest a lionization of Christian asceticism, but review calls this first thought into question. To emphasize his disconnection to the earthly realm, John the Baptist is only seen in one scene while his disembodied voice haunts the palace throughout the opera. Of course, his conviction pales in comparison to the lord Jesus Christ who is never seen nor heard in Salome. This naturally calls into question the enduring faith over someone or something that may be nonexistent. However, John becomes closest of anyone to fulfilling his desire, viz. achievement of the ascetic ideal. This is represented by his death.

Strauss wrote a tone poem after Nietzsche’s treatise Thus Spoke Zarathustra, so there was an evident familiarity and respect of Nietzsche on the part of the composer. In On the Genealogy of Morality, Nietzsche calls into question the righteousness of the ascetic ideal. He discards this aspiration for being one of repression and inaction. The initial championing of John’s purity turns to contempt when considered under a Nietzschean lens. He lives his life as a slave to his morals, guided by something outside of himself—something that doesn’t exist. Instead, the apparently superficial obsession of Salome turns to sacrament. She overlooks the content of the prophet’s words, transfixed on his skin, hair, and lips, because his words convey nothing. They are the non-referring and empty utterances of a man disposed to inaction. What Salome loves in John the Baptist is the chastity she loves within herself. But chastity here is the regurgitated symbol of repression and inaction. Thus, Salome too falls slave to the unachievable nonexistent.

title: Is There a Balance Between Art and Gentrification?
content:
Written By: Sam Blake

Post Date: 3/29/17

Art and artists influence how our cities evolve. Over the last several months, I’ve been studying gentrification for my Master’s in Public Policy capstone project. My group and I have read hundreds of pages, created a survey, and administered it to over 40 small business owners, and conducted 15 interviews with economic and community development advocates, political staff members, real estate developers, and academics. The best, most truthful answer I can give to the simple question of What have you learned? is: It’s complicated. I’m writing a Master’s thesis on this stuff, so obviously there’s more to be said than what can fit in a blog post. I’ll take this opportunity, then, to focus on something my team hasn’t delved into much, but about which I’ve been thinking quite a bit.

First, I must define gentrification. It is the process wherein the “desirability” of a neighborhood grows and thereby increases demand from people to live and work there. I don’t believe that gentrification is inherently bad, and I like this definition because it doesn’t presuppose as much. What is bad about gentrification is the potential outcome of this increased demand: land values increase, rents rise, residents and sometimes businesses are displaced because they can no longer afford to pay, and the cultural and historical fabric of a neighborhood is replaced by sterile corporate franchises more beholden to their shareholders than to the communities they have entered. This is a worst-case scenario; there are many outcomes in between, some of which are highly attractive. In the life of a neighborhood, growth and development are important, and stagnation is unhealthy. Finding the right balance between growth and preservation is the challenge. The degree to which the government ought to intervene, especially on the commercial side, is unclear: one’s answer depends largely on one’s views on the proper role of government and the value one places on the free market. So, yeah: it’s complicated.

Artists are often the first movers into a downtrodden neighborhood, attracted by the low price per square foot, and perhaps by the unvarnished and therefore untarnished look and feel of the place. Someone may open a café with an affordable rent to serve these artists coffee at an affordable price. And so begins the growth of “desirability.”

In Boyle Heights, a predominantly Latino neighborhood east of downtown LA and the focus of my capstone project, an “anti-gentrification collective” called Defend Boyle Heights organized last July to protest an artist nonprofit. One might not associate an artist nonprofit as an evil gentrifier, but protesters were upset that the nonprofit did not acknowledge that it was part of the problem. They have demanded all new art galleries to leave the city and let the community decide how to use the property. “We don’t need more galleries,” they chanted, “We need higher salaries!”

Underlying this battle is another one of the ugly faces that can accompany gentrification: a colonialist, privileged kind of occupation that extends the historical threads of inequity like racist lending practices.

I love people and I love cities and I love art and I love culture. I don’t want to destroy anybody’s home and I don’t want to stifle anybody’s creativity. What is the right thing to do?

Complicated, right?

As my group finishes its work and submits our recommendations to our client, a local economic and community development nonprofit that seeks to build sustainable, resilient communities, I suppose the actual best answer I’ve arrived at is: it’s complicated, but it’s possible to find the balance between growth and preservation. It requires awareness and empathy from all sides, especially from those moving into a new place. Enter with a paint brush, an outstretched hand, and a mindset that appreciates what has come before you, and you are more likely to be met with a community willing to share its easels, shake your hand, and appreciate how you can contribute to the ongoing growth of the neighborhood, together.

title: Pod Save the World - Snowden and Surveillance // Podcast Review
content:
Written By: Bethany Rennard

Post Date: 3/23/17

Following the November presidential election, I made a promise to myself to increase my efforts to support good journalism and be more socially and politically informed. I have found in the subsequent months that one of my favorite ways to consume news is through podcasts. In my trek from my apartment to class, I can learn about anything from the sanctuary movement to the role of political satire. One of the staples in my podcast consumption is Crooked Media, a progressive independent media company started by three former staffers from the Obama White House.

Although I love all of the podcasts produced by Crooked Media, my current favorite is Pod Save the World, a foreign policy show hosted by Tommy Veitor, former National Security Spokesperson and Assistant White House Press Secretary. Each week, Veitor interviews a foreign policy expert and breaks down the core elements of their work or area of expertise in an accessible way. As someone with limited foreign policy knowledge, I have found the podcast to be a perfect balance of entertainment and education, and always look forward to the weekly release of new episodes.

The past week’s episode (released 3/15/17) was especially interesting because Veitor interviewed Glenn Greenwald, a journalist and author best known for reporting on classified documents released by Edward Snowden. Greenwald came on the show to rebuke and respond to criticisms of Snowden made by Veitor and Ben Rhodes in a previous episode. As someone actively forming my own opinions about where to draw the line between ethical and unethical surveillance, I found this episode to be especially informative – particularly because Veitor and Greenwald were often presenting strong but oppositional arguments.

One argument I found particularly compelling was Greenwald’s assertion that we should distinguish between the ethics of Snowden leaking classified information and the ethics of Snowden leaving the country. When thinking about the case in the past, I had often thought of the two decisions as integrated, assuming that Snowden’s choice to seek asylum in Russia was, at least to some degree, indicative of the morality of his motives. However, I think an argument can be made that Snowden’s choice to avoid prosecution by fleeing the country was fueled by a desire for personal preservation rather than evidence of malicious intentions.

Another point that intrigued me was Greenwald’s adversarial approach to journalism. When Vietor highlighted the fact that a number of intelligence officials have negative views of Greenwald, the journalist asserted that an independent, free press is supposed to question and antagonize the government, and therefore ensure that the country avoids excessive concentration of power. As critiques of the news and media are more prominent now than ever before, I find it fascinating to consider when (or if) journalists are intended to have positive rapport with the government.

Most of all, I loved this episode because it modeled the importance of engaging with those who are ideologically different. Although Veitor and Greenwald were aware that they held different beliefs, they were able to engage one another and critically consider views opposite to their own. In an increasingly partisan and polarizing political landscape, I think conversations such as this are vital now more than ever before.

title: “The Rickshank Redemption” - Rick and Morty // Television Review
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee

Post Date: 4/10/17

After approximately a year and a half long hiatus since the show’s season two finale, the season three premiere of Rick and Morty aired in a surprise release on Adult Swim’s website this past April Fool’s Day. The episode streamed on repeat for several hours throughout the day (Though this looped streaming stopped at the end of April Fool’s Day, currently Adult Swim is streaming every episode of Rick and Morty including the season three premiere, so “The Rickshank Redemption” can still be viewed with a little bit of careful timing.) Given the lengthy wait and cliffhanger ending from the penultimate episode, to say that the expectations for this episode were high is to understate the fervent anticipation of the show’s fan following. For fans of Rick and Morty, the expectations were exceptionally, extraordinarily high. Thus, it is all the more impressive how well “The Rickshank Redemption” lives up to its hype, delivering humor, character insight, and wild visual aesthetic without any compromise to the movement of the plot.

From this point onward, this review will contain episode spoilers. Look out!

“The Rickshank Redemption” features an escape from intergalactic prison, the toppling of an alien government colonizing Earth, and a divorce - and that’s only what happened in Universe C137, Rick and Morty’s home universe. The episode is fast-paced action, making it all the more impressive when the visual images do justice to the storyline. As Rick tumbles first through the world in his mind, then to the Council of Ricks headquarters, and finally the Galactic Federation, the audience is privy to stunning animation that bring to life each and every different world Rick and Morty has ever imagined. Accompanying these colorful illustrations is hilarious dialogue. Creators Dan Harmon and Justin Roiland incorporate acerbic criticisms of the banalities of people into the show’s characters (i.e. Jerry’s cowardice when he says, “I’m not proud to share this, but I just kept crawling and it kept working,” and Rick’s mania when he says, “I want that Mulan McNugget sauce, Morty! That’s my series arc, if it takes nine more seasons Morty!”) and the result is brilliant, and often self-deprecating, comedy. And of course, this clever dialogue is supplemented with less clever, but still rewarding humor such as references to alien dick and a planet known as ‘Butt World.’

Beneath the butt humor and slapstick jokes about insectoid aliens, one of the most engaging parts about “The Rickshank Redemption” is its real emotional depth. The episode highlights Morty and Summer’s devotion to their grandfather, which grows complicated as they grapple with Rick’s blatant disregard for other people. Viewers receive a glimpse into Beth’s dependency on her father, and how she navigates her marriage amidst fears of abandonment and her husband’s distaste for her hero Rick. And, most of all, this episode hints at the ambiguous motivations of Rick himself that simmer underneath his callous bravado. Rick consistently undermines his own random acts of compassion by claiming he did them for self-serving reasons. He manipulates his daughter and repeatedly threatens his grandson Morty. Additionally, Rick’s instances of vulnerability are juxtaposed with the show’s plethora of bawdy humor and spectacular supernatural events so that Rick’s true character remains nebulous; for example, after extensive buildup, the backstory of the death of Rick’s wife in this episode prove to be nothing more than a farcical set-up by Rick. However, hints at Rick’s self-loathing and mysterious past imply that his selfish insensitivity is not authentic, but rather a veneer he wears to mask both his affinity for his family and a deep-seated unhappiness with himself. Rick as a character cannot be immediately understood as merely a crass old man, or even as a space traveling mad scientist. Rick’s personal complexity creates a compelling emotional pull, and brings a somber yet more intriguing dimension to the show’s comedy.

In short, the season three premiere of Rick and Morty is simultaneously a giant adventure, a joke, and a subtle portrayal of the inner demons of a broken man. “The Rickshank Redemption” wraps up the season two cliff hanger virtually seamlessly and with an abundance of humor, while leaving much to explore in the following episodes. I look forward to see what the rest of season three has to offer.

title: Beware the Ides of March
content:
Written By: James Shippy

Post Date: 3/23/17

There’s a saying that it’s hard to live in the past, that people need to move on and life is about forward thinking and not backward thinking.  As we come to the middle of March, I can’t help but think about this time last year - you know, when Trump wasn’t the president of the United States.  On Super Tuesday, March 1 2016, Trump won seven out of 10 states, which included Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Vermont, and Virginia.  Fast forward to Super Tuesday III, which fell on March 15 (literally the ides of March), Trump won five more states.

There were still doubters about this fringe presidential run and naysayers that felt that the sideshow would just go away and America would come to its senses.  We were all wrong. The silent majority made their voices heard in November and we’re now about two months into what some people would call the political freak show.  Make no mistake; this politics of chaos is not the norm. This unchecked and ongoing level of corruption which is sadly turning into something new each and every day of the week it seems, is not business as usual.

Assuming that America would make a sound decision last year proves how things can change drastically from year to year. Our new president will be in office until 2020, which feels like a very very long time, unless you ask Prof. Allan Lichtman.

Looking forward, voters should realize that this time next year in March 2018, candidates will be campaigning for over 30 Senate seats up for grabs. Plus, all 435 house seats will be on the line too.Since 1934, the party of a newly elected president has suffered an average loss of 23 seats in the House in the following midterm. Those are promising numbers for the newest opposition party, the Democrats.

I know I’m throwing out a lot of numbers and dates out there but the main point is that a year goes by in a blink of an eye.  And although it can seem like an eternity until the next election, 2018 will be here before we know it. And that can be the first civic step towards deciding what kind of leadership we as voters want representing us.  For those of us eager to exercise that civic right…March can’t come soon enough.

title: Public Media Is More Than Just #SaveBigBird
content:
Written By: Alex Ivanova

Post Date: 3/24/17

I fully attribute my English fluency to Sesame Street, Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood, and the various programs that aired on PBS when I was a child. Growing up in a Russian-speaking household, television was my only real exposure to the English language until I started school. Ultimately, public broadcasting meant being able to assimilate into the culture and language of this country, even if my household was of a different one.

For many children like me, PBS and other local public stations were especially influential to our education. A major facet of public media is its commitment to early learning, as seen with the Ready to Learn initiative in the early 1990s, which was later reauthorized by the No Child Left Behind Act in 2002, and renewed in 2010 for another five years. This partnership between the U.S. Department of Education, Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and countless other public media sources meant that “high need” children (children of immigrants, children with low access to educational resources, low-income families, disadvantaged minorities, etc.) would have access to content to expand their math and literacy skills

Literacy in a nation is more than just a positive - it is necessary and vital to a nation’s economic stability. A one percent increase in literacy scores ultimately results in an eventual two and a half percent rise in labor productivity, and a one and a half percent rise in GDP per person (C.D. Howe Institute). Despite this, in 2015, only 34-percent of  eighth grade students performed at or above the proficient level, declining two percent from 2013 (National Assessment of Educational Progress).

President Trump recently proposed massive budget cuts for our domestic programs— namely cutting agency funds for the arts, humanities, and public media. White House Budget Director Mick Mulvaney defended the proposal, saying, “Can we really continue to ask a coal miner in West Virginia or a single mom in Detroit to pay for these programs? The answer was no. We can ask them to pay for defense and we will, but we can’t ask them to continue to pay for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.” Yet public media only costs approximately $1.35 per citizen, per year, according to CPB President and CEO Patricia Harrison.

The benefits of public broadcasting certainly outweigh whatever potential benefits can result from allocating those funds to increasing the defense budget yet again. Ultimately it is only a disservice to educating our children and providing information to all citizens, both in urban, rural, and disadvantaged communities. The benefits of the Ready to Learn Initiative are not unfounded. Over a fourth of the money funding the initiative went to researching its success, and ultimately, the results supported that public programming increased literacy skills when comparing a group of at-risk students who viewed various PBS shows, and control groups of students who did not.

Furthermore, the majority of viewers were children from economically disadvantaged families, the majority of which were making less than $50,000 a year. In a recent Washington Post publication entitled, “Public Broadcasting Shouldn’t Get a Handout from Taxpayers Anymore,” Howard Husock claims that minorities can “find what they are looking for” on private media and major cable outlets, claiming that “public media today looks far too much like a niche programming service for a left-leaning, upmarket urban constituency.” In some ways, his article is valid. Public media often does serve a niche market, with many viewers moving towards the private media industry to find programs that cater directly to them. It is important for public media to broaden its focus now more than ever when competing with other forms of media, especially as the internet becomes more and more influential on consumer tastes. We cannot, however, expect this to be a reality if we diminish public media’s already low funds exponentially by defunding them entirely.

Trump’s call to zero-out public media funding is frightening, especially to the vast amounts of disadvantaged communities who depend on it. However, it also serves as a wake-up call to public media outlets to adapt to growing demands as competition with private markets increases, and they cannot depend simply on their role as a public service to convince a conservative government to allocate funding to them.

title: On the Era of Fake News
content:
Written By: Sam Blake

Post Date: 3/10/17

Fake news is not new. Yellow journalism was flaunting its amarillo curls in the late 1800s and continued well into the 20th century. If you define fake news as the intentional distortion of truth - whether through omission, sensationalism, or unsubstantiated reporting - you’d even have to include on your list of perpetrators the religious institutions that managed the dissemination of printed information to the masses.

What’s new, by definition, is the present era. Information flows at a rapid pace across a global network connecting billions of people. Whereas previous generations accessed news and opinion from a relatively small variety of sources, an internet search today on any given topic yields more results from more sources than one person could ever reasonably need or want. The “democratization” of media is a nice idea, but we are so flooded by information and data and ideas that it is hard to make sense of the world. We need a filter mechanism. Enter the arbiters of information: Facebook, Google, and friends.

There’s nothing inherently wrong with a filter. We use them all the time. Heuristics - rule-of-thumb instincts that guide our reactions to external stimuli - help us avoid being overwhelmed by all the noise around us that’s constantly knocking on the doors of our mind, demanding to be processed. Still, it’s important to realize the negative implications of relying on heuristics, however sensible that reliance may be.

A heuristic is a bias. Research abounds on the unconscious biases to which we are all susceptible. Tests on our blink-of-an-eye reactions to a white person compared to a black person, for instance, have brought these biases to the light of day. To move past our biases, the first step is to become conscious of them.

Thanks to fake news, we are now conscious of the role that information filters and algorithms like Facebook and Google play in our lives. In the Presidential election, we saw how radically different people’s social media lives were depending on how their online behavior and that of their social networks fit into the on-high algorithms. And, according to some sources, we saw significant consequences from this, like the influencing of voting behavior for the leader of the world’s most powerful country.

This new era requires new rules. Rules can either be officially enshrined as law, or they can permeate from our ethical codes of conduct. I wouldn’t envy any legislator or civil servant tasked with designing a comprehensive, adaptable law governing information flows that would be effective, constructive and enforceable. I’m not sure it’s even possible. Some stop gap measures can be passed, but the way forward is through ethics. And a tricky thing about ethics is that if you dig into the reasons why a given code of conduct exists, and you keep asking why, like the Louis CK joke, you inevitably end up with an answer like… “Well because it’s the right thing to do, dude.”

The hubs that have outsize control of our digital flows of information must be ethical, and the only way to make them do it is through the power of the people. In this era, we are all responsible for holding them accountable. Each of us must practice and expect the kind of ethics we want to see in the world — this is the way that ethics are spread and upheld. We must be transparent with each other. We must respect and listen to each other. We must be the force from which the ideals we want to live by are generated.

To achieve this, it is important not to be overly cynical. Be critical, be skeptical, but don’t be cynical. Be aware of the fact that what you read may be true, tinged with fiction, or overflowing with falsehood. But don’t let that awareness keep you from seeking truth, or from believing in one another. These problems have been around for a long time, and while we’ve still got a ways to go in terms of moving our world closer to its ideal version, we’ve come a long way. To go further, it’s up to us.

title: Who is Vic Spencer?
content:
Interview by Brianna Klipp

Who is John Galt?

It was around page 340 that Ayn Rand could fully explain her liberalist philosophy. Atlas Shrugged laid the groundwork for future political agendas and is still known as one of the most circulated books whose title is acknowledged with an affirmative nod of approval whenever mentioned. And yet, people still can’t speak to its plot. To be fair, Atlas Shrugged is long. Too Long. Abstract. Multi-dimensional. But even the phonies who claimed to have read it don’t want to forget the significance, so they get t-shirts printed and overpriced bumper stickers with the phrase “Who is John Galt?”

Who is Vic Spencer?

Riddled with the he-said-she-said hearsay of the real world and skill-set that only the Grammy’s would ignore, a movement is in place. Vic Spencer, the Chicago based rapper with an affinity for honesty and White Castle burgers, visited UCLA Radio on April 19. He’s hyperactive with a smile and open arms to embrace. The way he embraces a stranger is the way he approaches life: as a good listener who doesn’t second guess his ideas or future plans. He laughs in between thoughts, and though pessimistic about where hip-hop is headed, believes in himself and the value that true artists can bring.

“Radio is what has changed the most…When I was growing up in Chicago, we had stations that would play the major artists, but we also had radio stations that catered to the underground hip hop scene. It was hosted by the Ghetto Boys, playing the low-key cats. I was surprised at the contrast, because ghetto boys was more like straight forward, slap-ya-mama type music, but then they play The Roots.. Now we just don’t have anything. XM Shouldn’t be ‘the option’ because a lot of people don’t have XM Radio. It’s kinda crazy.”

Spencer recognizes the need to adjust to the times and use app based technology like Spotify, but he explains that older generations and older fans haven’t adjusted yet. Using Twitter as a platform, Spencer has gotten involved in hip hop beef and connected with artists he’s idolized. In a world where hip hop artists are viewed as modern social justice heroes and changemakers, I question his role within society at large. “I just do what Victor does. Now that I have the legends looking up to me, that’s where the expectation is now. I do a lot of things outside the music in the Streets of Chicago, I do what I know works.”

Chicago is famous for the authenticity and unique sound of its rappers, but Spencer doesn’t believe that artists should unite just based on their similar roots. “If you’re talking about the Kanye from the beginning of his career, you can say I respect it… now, hell nah. I do respect what he’s trying to do, but just because I respect it doesn’t mean I agree with it.”

In 2016, Spencer found himself in a hip hop battle with Mick Jenkins. Spencer reflects on the idea of rap disses today: “Rap battles back in the day was a real thing. People’s feelings was hurt… Now it’s just for attention. People have diss tracks, just to do it. Like, what? Beef really happens if there’s something wrong. If someone has beef, they make a record. It’s all a promotional tool now. I wouldn’t call it beef, it’s just what I make it about. I will destroy you lyrically. When I saw (Jenkins), he didn’t say a word to me at all, but then when I made a statement on Twitter, he was one of the first people to run his mouth.”

Spencer is committed to his brand and promoting sound that makes sense to him. Instead of following what the mainstream considers “good,” Spencer’s standard is based on how the music should make you feel.

“Ghostwriters 100 percent take away the credibility of artists. Good music is the type that touches my soul. Me and conceptual songs don’t get along, like, say when people make a song about the police… No one’s listening to ‘Fight the Power’ now. I want people to be able to listen to my work at any given moment and so I just consider making that kind of music. I like stories.”

Working with a plethora of rappers, like Chance the Rapper, Spencer has seen changes happen in hip hop as commodification and money become involved and artists become more successful. “I’m disappointed in Chance the Rapper musically. He used to be a rapper. To me, he’s not. Just because he doesn’t touch my soul doesn’t mean he’s touching millions of others, though. I feel that the music that I do is not a room for opportunity in Chicago. I want to be able to have an opportunity to be a different plate on the table.”

Spencer has released hundreds of tracks over the years, and most recently collaborated to create “VicTree,” a unique vibe which is described as “soul-trap.” Spencer has big goals for the next year, including more music, merch, and collaborations. I jokingly ask when he’s moving to LA.

“I like the smell of Chicago. Sometimes it smells like gunpowder, sometimes it smells like weed. I’m immune to all of it. But LA is a different monster… I know why they call it LA LA land. I believe life is a pot of gumbo full of surprises and you don’t want to be caught up in what’s being displayed. All the things that happen on a negative level can be turned into a positive. Always. If you believe in it, you have the attribute to go after it.”

Spencer has laid the groundwork and influenced the sound of hip hop for the past 15 years. A phantom in the scene, when we ask who is Vic Spencer, the answer becomes obvious: Who is hip hop?

Visit Vertigo’s SoundCloud to here the full interview.

title: The Many Meanings of College Radio
content:
A couple musings from the manager of the UCLA Radio blog.

I joined UCLA Radio four weeks into my freshman year. I can’t reflect back on my time in college without stumbling upon memories of afternoons in the radio station, co-hosting shows with my close friends, and of course, hours and hours spent behind the mic - and I wouldn’t have it any other way. I’ve been here since the beginning of my college career and I’ll remain in the station until the day I graduate. Now, nearly two years after I first became a part of radio, I sit in a corner of the station, typing away and reflecting on my time as a DJ. The part college radio has played in my life has changed many times over, but it’s easy for me to say that regardless of what radio has meant to me, it’s been one the most meaningful experiences of my college career.

I remember the first time I stepped into the radio station, hidden in the corner of Ackerman. Inside, every square inch of the white walls, even the ceiling, was filled with band stickers and the inner musings of past DJs. The chalkboard was overflowing with the scribbles and doodles of station members. Lines and lines of CDs filled the wooden bookshelves. A large old couch in a worn black slipcover occupied one corner. Music floated from the DJ booth, where two decrepit stools in the most atrocious shade of orange I’d ever witnessed were illuminated by the glowing lights of the soundboard. Even with the mere fifteen of us interns who had come to visit the station, the small space was feeling more than cozy. The station was tiny, most everything was in need of replacement, and it was more than I could ever hope for. 

The first time I spoke on air was terrifying. It was as if I’d never heard my own voice aloud before. I became suddenly self conscious of how I sounded as I racked my brain with something significant enough to say on air, and in the end all I came up with was “Hey guys!” - which at the time felt like the most mediocre phrase ever uttered in the English language. I remember how my voice sounded so loud. I imagined my words echoing out into a void of other sound waves, hoping it reached any listeners out there far, far away. And yet the act of speaking felt so intimate, even though I couldn’t see the people I was talking to. The uniqueness of that connection was captivating.

Of course there was the music. It’s as if I’d forgotten how powerful a song could be. How unparalleled the rush of walking into the station was knowing I had a really good set for that day. There were nights when I danced alone after other DJs had long abandoned the booth before remembering the station cameras were on. There was the time I sat in front of the mic at 9 a.m., quietly digging my nails into my palm to stop myself from crying when I played “What a Wonderful World” by Louis Armstrong for my grandmother, who had died five days earlier. Hearing the songs I played on air became an entirely new way of listening to music. It’s a communal experience, the thrill of sharing with someone the music you love like it was a piece of yourself.

Radio is so many things. It’s four people crammed into one booth with not enough headphones to go around, crowding in to share a mic, poking fun at other DJs and arguing about which track to play next. It’s just you in the booth, late at night, with the music cranked up as loud as it can go to keep you company. It’s that brief silence when you turn off the mic and fade in the song you’ve been dying to play all week. Here at UCLA Radio, it’s our 200+ members and the nearly 100 unique radio shows we host. And most importantly, it’s the people who support us each year to make sure we can continue as a college radio station. Today marks the beginning of our annual Pledge Drive. As a 100 percent student run station that features original programming without advertisements on air, we depend on the support of our listeners to continue running. You are the reason we are able to see the many different meanings of radio, and we hope you can help us discover many new understandings. If you choose to donate today, maybe ask yourself, what does college radio mean to you?

title: Make Coachella Great Again
content:
Written by Gabrielle Seok 

Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival started in 1999, as a one-day festival in Indio, California. 18 years later, it is now one of the largest and most recognized festivals in the United States — and the world. How has it become what it is today?

The early seeds of Coachella were planted in 1993, when Pearl Jam refused to perform in Los Angeles as an act of defiance against Ticketmaster’s practices. Instead, the band held a concert in Indio. This location served as inspiration for Paul Tollett, who was the head of Goldenvoice at the time. He envisioned a legacy. Sparked by his fascination for European music festivals like the Glastonbury festival, Tollett wanted to bring something similar to the States. Goldenvoice, spearheaded by Tollett, took a risk and started the music festival, in spite of the negative publicity behind Woodstock ‘99, which was notorious for its problems with looting, arson and rape.

Somehow, the festival endured a few rough initial years, losing money and even skipping a season due to a lack of interest. The birth of Coachella began with raw faith and a reliance on artistry — not radio popularity. The lineups consisted of small artists. It would take years for the festival to build its impressive roster. And because of this, it earned the reputation as the “anti-Woodstock.” It billed itself as a single entity, fueled by a pure love for music and a vision of greatness. You can see why this greatly contrasts with the landscape of the festival today.

From an economic perspective, today’s Coachella is an economically ingenious event that tells an inspiring rags-to-riches story about following your dreams. For music lovers, it tells something very different. Coachella is accused of selling out and becoming a mainstream, money-making machine. And this is not unwarranted. What was once rooted in support for independent artists and a sanctuary for local artisans now has become a commercialized annual occasion with corporate sponsorships and headlining pop artists. Not only that, the culture of Coachella has changed to become somewhat of a runway show for attendees who plan their festival outfits months in advance and take hundreds of photos at the three-day long event. Attendees have been criticized for being more concerned about keeping up appearances rather than enjoying the music. Additionally, the exclusive events and after parties that take place during the festival have become a way for social media ‘influencers’ and social climbers to flaunt their arms in their colorful, sought-after wristbands. Considering this, it is not inaccurate to say that the culture of Coachella has dramatically shifted away from what it once stood for.

While it is easy to write off Coachella as a soulless capitalist endeavor, it is important to acknowledge its contribution to the music industry. The monetary value of music maintains legitimacy, as hundreds of thousands of festival-goers pay to see live performances by some of the most popular artists today. Not to mention, the festival does still showcase a variety of talented artists and musicians from across many genres of music, some more well known than others. In its relatively young history, the festival has hosted a plethora of music legends, such as Paul McCartney, Queens of The Stone Age, Dr. Dre, Outkast, Prince, Muse, Jack White and many more.

Despite these, the bitter aftertaste the festival has left in many diehard music fans’ mouths is not to be ignored, especially with the destruction of their initial values and their shifted focus towards money. In the end, it is inconceivable to see Coachella ever reverting back to its roots; however, it should serve as a cautionary tale for other festivals in the market today. Music and arts festivals must consider the sacrifices that will be made when they commercialize on such a large scale. While it may be extremely tempting due to its ridiculous profitability, the ethics behind the art of music appreciation will be compromised. The music lovers, also known as the tastemakers, the independent bloggers, and more importantly, the ones who are willing to pay for music on a smaller scale, will slowly fade away as festivals encroach on the mainstream music scene. They will search anew, leaving behind commercialized successes as one for the uncultured masses, while merely holding onto nostalgic remnants of what once satisfied their adoration of live music.

title: Spotlight Sunday: Kinda Loud on the Eastern Front (Tuesdays @ 11 AM)
content:
Spotlight Sunday is a new weekly post where we feature a rad and unique UCLA Radio show that we think people should check out.

This show is brand new, but OH MAN does it have an old sophisticated soul, and we cannot wait for you to be as excited about it as we are. Kinda Loud on the Eastern Front showcases the music of Eastern Europe and the Middle East as you’ve never heard before. Remixes of folk songs, Balkan Beats, Gypsy Punk, Turbofolk and much, much, more. DJ Sam will show you how traditional sounds from these regions have been interpreted in the modern musical landscape. But what exactly are Balkan Beats you ask? The only wikipedia page you’re going to find for it is in Dutch, so let me lay down the basics: imagine traditional eastern european folk music colliding with hip hop, electronic music, swing, etc. It’s beautiful. What sounds like the world’s most unlikely combo is just possibly the best thing you’ve ever heard.

Let’s be honest, sometimes finding new music is hard work, and finding great artists outside of your everyday genre is even harder. Let DJ Sam, who is like a ridiculously fun, charismatic knowledgeable professor, open your eyes to all the glorious sounds of Eastern Europe and the Middle East every Tuesday at 11am. You won’t regret it.

https://www.facebook.com/kindaloudontheeasternfront/

title: Ghosts of EDM
content:
Written By : Ivana-Beija Faria, UCLA Radio DJ 

Post Date : 04/28/16

Ghostwriting and ghost producing is a ubiquitous phenomena familiar to all genres of music, not excluding EDM. Some of the most distinguished and prominent DJs have been accused of unrightfully releasing tracks they are not responsible for creating. Affluent DJs, such as David Guetta, Tiesto, and Markus Schulz are speculated to have paid off “ghost-producers” to help create their hits.

DJs are this generation’s rock stars, and consumers are often well aware of ghosting in today’s celebrity branding industry. DJs feel the pressure to produce new tracks to remain relevant and in addition, the advent of social media requires that producers work at hyperspeed in order to feed the demands of attention-deficit listeners.

So what then is the problem with ghost producing anyway? This by no means a novel dilemma. Throughout history famous artists often take credit for another’s work. So long as these ghost-producers are getting compensated in some way, what’s the issue? Or should celebrity artists not be exempt from exoneration just because of their brand? What then constitutes a DJ’s authenticity if ghost-producing is considered acceptable?

In my opinion, people truly irked by the inauthenticity of ghostwriting/producing will find independent artists, while those unconcerned by this will blithely listen to their mainstream DJs, regardless if they have people working behind the scenes or not.  

There are then two stances one can take on this, as expressed by the following two insiders, both of whom have both worked anonymously for famous DJs.

“I’m just a nerd standing up to the jock who stole all the nerd’s homework.”  -Mat Zo

“Nobody cares if it’s your track or other people’s track as long as the party is good.” -Tocadisco

content:

title: Sia’s Coachella Performance // (04/17/16)
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp, UCLA Radio DJ (04/19/16)

The dust collected in the lungs of Coachella day 3 festival goers eager to catch the waves that the main stage would offer. Behind bandanas and blistered toes, it was clear that this venue contained the most diverse lineup and audience of the entire 72 hours. In a perfectly arranged spectacle, the stage cleared from the rambunctious Matt & Kim balloon-poppers to 100 BPM ravers shuffling to Major Lazer. But right as the sun was collected behind the desert landscape, the best performance of Coachella history moved the crowd to emotions they didn’t know they are capable of feeling. Sia proved that the best Coachella performances don’t arise from Vegas-Style light shows and cameos by guest artists, but instead, the raw talent that can only be delivered through in the moment scenes of vulnerability by live performance actors.

Sia’s 13-song hour set wasn’t meant to entertain or evoke good vibes. The performance opened up our childhood wounds, forcing the audiences’ hidden fears and memories to be brought to the frontal lobe and be recognized. This journey forced us to confront the thoughts we try to forget, proving that the human experience is meant to be painful and shared. Sia tells the story of childhood abuse and feeling trapped by her father, but rather than showing it through her own perspective, she shifted from the view of her father as a child experiencing a neglected upbringing to her own childhood and adult self desperately wishing for reconciliation. As the first song, “Air” belted through Sia’s lungs, the Coachella audience immediately knew that this would be the most liberating experience of pain and pleasure. In just an hour’s time, Sia was able to demonstrate the complications of a father-daughter relationship and the meaning of forgiveness.

In true Sia fashion, her face and body was covered in dark shadows, hiding behind the exaggerated sharp lines of her girly-bubble dress and rigid black-and-white short wig. This minimalist feature only heightened the entire performance as the infamous dancers who appear in her music videos- Maddie Ziegler, Paul Dano, Gaby Hoffman, and actor Kristin Wiig (who played Sia)-  were shown on the main screens in similar attire in pre-filmed videos, while the live dancers performed simultaneously in unison to the movements on the screens. Kristin’s acting range impressively left the audience speechless as she portrayed every emotional extreme of the set from bliss to devastation, where at one point she was left sobbing and shaking uncontrollably. Meanwhile, as the pre-filmed videos appeared on the big screens, the dancers took to the stage in a contortionist method of extreme flexibility and perfectly synched movements for the entire hour, portraying the notion that life moves quickly and pain can be endless.

The audience was left standing in tears as a collective body of conflicting emotion. The character development was so perfectly built during the entire performance through the shared views of Sia’s father and herself that it was painful to decide which character was the protagonist or villain, making it so that when the lights finally dimmed to the darkness on stage and the characters took their final bow- we will spend the rest of our lives deciding.

title: Spotlight Sunday : Bit.Shadow (Tuesdays @ 7 PM)
content:
Spotlight Sunday is a new weekly post where we feature a rad and unique UCLA Radio show that we think people should check out.

One of the interesting characteristics that’s consistent across all forms radio shows is it that it’s truly impossible to be certain who is sitting on the other side of mic. UCLA Radio’s stimulating and thoughtful electronic show, Bit. Shadow, brought to you by Isa, emphasizes this sense of mystery through narrating the entire show through an automated robot voice. However, the mysterious contemplative and philosophical aspect of Bit. Shadow is not limited to its narration. The episodes of Bit. Shadow follow the great fable of Powerball, the goat human. A techno hip hop mix, and ode to Homeric oral tradition, the epic of our time unfolds.


If you’re into artists like Luca Lush, Baauer, Cavalier, or Dr. Fresch, or even if you’ve never heard em but now your curiosity is peaked, tune in and experience an enchanting electronic escape from reality, guided perfectly by the ethereal and brilliant DJ Fizzy. It’s midterms, you deserve the break, and everybody likes a mini-escape. UCLARadio.com at 7 pm on Tuesdays.

title: Berlin Profiles: Homopatik Barbapatik // (03/18-19/16)
content:
Written By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio DJ (04/02/16)

Illustration by Augusto Siccardi courtesy of Homopatik

Photo courtesy of Resident Advisor

Homopatik is inarguably one of Berlin’s best and most well known nights. The gay party is held the third Friday of every month at ://About Blank in the Friedrichshain quarter of East Berlin. The party starts at 23:59 on Friday and runs until late Saturday evening. The line is often quite long, but the party is well worth it.

The walls of the entryway are covered in stickers and set the stage for the gritty feel of the space. After paying the 13-euro admission and getting stamped, most people roll up to the second story, past a disco ball and a few couches, and head to the coat check, to strip down into more appropriate clubbing attire. Back downstairs, the venue has two main indoor stages: “The Lobby” which is in a more elongated and narrow room, and the main stage. DJs playing at these two booths bump mostly techno, some house, and a bit of minimal. At the back of the venue, a covered smoking porch opens out into a large garden, at the opposite end of which is a tent with its own DJ booth. Here, DJs tend to play restorative music, more along the lines of disco, to rehabilitate attendees from the harder music inside.

The crowd left no question to the fact that Homopatik is a gay party. Shirtless men with black leather accessories were not a rarity. The venue has a policy that partygoers can turn in glasses/bottles from around the club for money to be used towards more drinks. This is genius in that it helps keep the club clean and makes it so that attendees can drink – and stay at the party – for longer.

The party was born in Bologna, Italy, and imported to Berlin a few years ago. The theme for the particular party that I got to attend was based on European cartoon Barbapapa, which played on a screen near the entryway. While I was there, I was most excited to hear Akira Hawks, Floyd Lavine, and Mr. Ties, the cult figure and resident DJ who runs Homopatik, play.

I left around 7AM, which felt quite early, as the party continued well into the following night. At the nearby Ostrkeuz S-Bahnhof station, as commuters bustled around me, I got a closer look at the Homopatik entry stamp on my wrist, which was a giant penis with wings.

title: "Not a Suggestion" - why sexism in mainstream music needs to end
content:
Written By : Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ (03/04/16)

When I heard radio was participating in See, Recognize, Hear, a movement for female empowerment on campus, I rejoiced. At first I was excited because any active effort to promote inclusivity is dope as hell, especially in a space where I live and study. Yet the more I thought about how the campaign applied specifically to music, the more angry I became with the state of the music industry and the message perpetuated by mainstream music about how we see women. The blatant bigotry that exists against women in music today shows just how important this week is in making a platform to discuss narrow-mindedness and sexism within our culture.

Just looking at the well known songs of the past year, the majority shamelessly drop sexist remarks. Nick Jonas thinks it’s perfectly acceptable to be a paranoid obsessive partner because, let’s face it, she’s just “too sexy, beautiful/​And everybody wants a taste.” Maroon 5 made the incredibly creepy metaphor of comparing women to prey and saying even if “you think that you can hide,” they will still hunt and eat you (gross). Drake preferred it when you waited at home for him like a “good girl” instead of doing things like not depending on him and controlling your own life. The Weeknd is “just tryna get you out the friend zone” because it’s not really worth it to have a relationship that doesn’t involve sex. And let’s not even get started on Meghan Trainor and “Dear Future Husband.” It seems the only functions women have in most popular songs is to either take care of their man or serve as objects of lust for the artist to fawn over.

The glaring problem with this message is that it maintains women should only be seen in relation to sex, and warps our perspective of how relationships are supposed to work and how women are supposed to be treated within them. Mainstream music loves to recycle the twisted romance tale where men continually fuck up and women are continually expected to forgive them and stay true to them because, apparently, that’s what love is. These alleged rules for relationships are reinforced again and again within the lyrics of popular music. And the more times we’re told this is how love is supposed to be, the more people will actually believe it.

The issue doesn’t end with music - it extends to the artists themselves. It’s as grossly simple as this: Chris Brown physically assaults his girlfriend and we award him the Grammy for Best R&B Album, but when Kesha tries to sever her contract with her alleged rapist, we turn up empty handed. The fact is change within the music industry is not a suggestion. It is an extreme necessity.

I’m tired of women only being seen as bitches and hos and sex objects. I’m tired of artists profiting off depictions of women as malicious, subservient, and shallow. I’m tired of the double-edged sword of promiscuity, that awards men respect but makes women only seem undesirable. In short, I’m tired of mainstream music repeatedly failing to grant women a basic amount of respect and fairness, because the truth is it’s not that fucking difficult to do. Really.

A common method of dismissing the glaring problem that popular music these days is sexist and inexcusable is to claim, “it’s just a song.” As someone who loves and values music as an important aspect of my life and a part of how I define myself, I can tell you with confidence this is not at all “just a song.” Music and the arts in general serve as a mirror, and can show us who we are and what we believe. We can either choose to let it continue down a troublesome path, or use it as a space to express the change that needs to happen within society. It’s going to take more than a week, but we can use events like See, Recognize, Hear as a starting point to mobilize for equality. Hopefully in the future, music will reflect an environment where women are adequately and honestly portrayed as individuals beyond offensive and sexual stereotypes.

title: Punks Not Dead // Pussy Riot @ Royce Hall (02/11/16)
content:
Written By: Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ (02/29/16)

On Feb. 11 Maria Alyokhina of Pussy Riot took to the stage of Royce Hall to discuss politics, performance art, and prisoners’ rights. Although she did not perform, her presence sent a powerful message - punk isn’t dead.

The punk scene, since its inception in the 1970s, has evolved rapidly, and more recently moved into more than questionable territory. With Green Day and Blink 182 ringing in our ears, many of us are wondering if the dumbed down, commercialized pop punk tracks of late have led us to a point of no return. Considering parents used to send their kids to mental institutions for sporting spiked hair and safety pins, the fact that 5 Seconds of Summer thinks they’re “punk” is rather distressing. I, myself, have had a share of modern punk experiences I’d rather forget. Growing up near 924 Gilman, considered the home of pop punk, there were many times I’d stand in the venue on a Friday night, listening to white suburban boys scream into the microphone and tell their parents to fuck off, usually while the parents were in the crowd, capturing the entire performance on a camcorder. As I watched the “You don’t get me, Dad!” declaration of teenage angst, I often wondered to myself, “What the fuck are these kids even complaining about?”  

Punk has continually served as a space over the past several decades where musicians could voice their opinions against unjust economic, political, and social climates. The Sex Pistols stood up for the overburdened working class; straight edge took on the drug epidemic of the 80s; the D.C. scene protested against racism and apartheid; Jello Biafra asserted the importance of freedom of expression; riot grrrl fought the patriarchy. Again and again, movements within the punk scene dragged different issues into the spotlight and refused to stop until everyone got a glimpse. Yet now, when there seems to be an overwhelming abundance of things wrong in the world (i.e. the refugee crisis, the NSA, police brutality, religious intolerance, income inequality, immigration, Donald Trump - need I go on?) the fact that All Time Low exists seems to show punk indeed has lost its ability to confront society and all its bullshit.

Yet right when it seemed all hope was gone, three members of the band Pussy Riot were arrested for performing a punk prayer against current Russian president Vladimir Putin in Cathedral of Christ the Savior. The group was already known for their public punk protests, but after being sentenced to two years in prison for what many considered to simply be an exercise of free speech, they became internationally known. Widespread outcry against the unjust ruling morphed into protests across the world. For what seemed like the first time in decades, people mobilized over music.

The significance behind Maria Alyokhina’s visit is that she proves there’s still a place in music to have a voice that’s punk and political. While most mainstream “punk” seems to have become apathetic, there’s many still fighting to maintain its revolutionary qualities. The fact that punk can make the president of Russia shit his pants means it still has a fighting chance to continue in the 21st century.

title: Featured Artists of The Week
content:
Every week, the UCLA Radio Music Department publishes their top picks of the week!

Check out the playlist of our choices: 

https://open.spotify.com/user/1231929428/playlist/7mXHXjyOPhSVTraWOU0ixK

Yndi Halda - Under Summer
Recommended Songs: Together Those Leaves
Genre: Post-Rock
Fuck ya! Yndi Halda is a band that has extreme emphasis on the instrumentals so to but it simply, this song is epic! I want to describe them as the rock version of Sigor Ros. “Together Those Leaves” starts off real chill and relaxing but when you get to the end of the 5 minutes, you feel like you’ve just trekked the trail of your life time. Good song to listen to on the bus/airplane and contemplate your life

Lovespeake - Tightrope (Single)
Genre: Synth Pop
Tightrope is pretty tight. Uptempo, super groovy, great hooks with a late nite feel. 80s inspired with modern flare. Solid production/mixing as well. Lovespeake is a brand new artist who’s released two other singles, “DNA” and “Dreamer.” Both are pretty decent, so if you like Tightrope I’d check em out.


Shining Bird - Helluva Lot EP
Recommended Song: River Mouth
Genre: Indie Rock
Another great band! With “River Mouth”, Shining Bird turns back to their rock roots. They play some pretty slow songs and this one is no exception. One of my favorite things about this band is how deep the vocals are. But even more than that, their music has this sense of simplicity to it that gives it such a sweet sound.


Elvis Depressedly - Holo Pleasures / California Dreamin’
Recommended Song: Slip
Genre: Lo-Fi, Pop
I’ve always loved Elvis Depressedly’s lo-fi sounds and he nails it again with his newest single “Slip”. Don’t know if his new album is being released via Orchid Tapes as well…but hopefully yes because that label is great. Anyway, listen to this song if you want to feel like an emotional artist trying to sing the feels away.

Leyya - Spanish Disco (out May 20)
Recommended Song: Butter
Genre: Dream Pop
I really enjoyed this track - it starts off dissonant, slow, and dreamlike and picks up to a catchier upbeat rhythm when the beat drops. The mix of experimental electronic and more typical pop rhythms makes this weird enough to be interesting but still easy and fun to listen to.

Ed Tullett  - Fiancé
Recommended Song: Saint
Genre: Electronica/Folk
This album is a weird mix of genres but Tullett succeeds in luring the listener into his strange haunting world. Every track is a sort of dreamy electronic soundscape supplemented by unexpectedly folk-ish vocals. Some tracks are more folky and some are more purely electronic, but the album is still cohesive and lovely. Really, really great album and definitely worth a listen.

Tacocat - Lost Time
Recommended Song: Dana Katherine Sculy
Genre: Garage Pop Punk
Tacocat remind me alot of the Go-Go’s but with more of a garage rock/pop punk sound. Their lyrics are genuine and funny and feminist (see the ode to Scully from the X-Files, “Dana Katherine Scully”, and “Men Explain Things to Me”), but there are really sweet melodies here too. This is a really fun, catchy record that Burger Records fans will probably like even though Tacocat is on Hardly Art. My other favorite tracks are 4 (“I Hate the Weekend”) and 11 (“Night Swimming”).

Cate Le Bon - Crab Day
Recommended Song: Love in Not Love
Genre: Experimental Folk/Country
The entirety of Crab Day had me questioning whether I actually enjoyed what I was listening to, yet its appealing eccentricity kept me captivated throughout the album. Cate Le Bon’s high, haunting vocals are set against a disjointed experimental country influenced sound. If Nico and Hank Williams collaborated on an album, and then that album took some weird psychedelics, Crab Day would be the result. I wouldn’t be surprised if this ends up on a future Wes Anderson soundtrack. Give if a listen if you’re looking for something delightfully weird.

title: Prototype #032: Israel Vines and Ben Klock // Saturday, April 2 & April 3rd, 10PM - 4AM
content:
Written By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff (04/18/16)

Techno powerhouse Ben Klock and veteran Israel vines graced Lot 613 on Saturday, marking the 32nd installment of Los Angeles-based promotion company Prototype. Having drawn artists like Rødhåd, Hot Chip, Four Tet, and Marcel Dettmann – among others – to Los Angeles in the past, Prototype is a massive force to be reckoned with in the city’s electronic scene. Where a large majority of LA’s electronic shows are thrown out of warehouses, Prototype operates out of the Arts District’s Lot 613. The space offers the best of both worlds in that the legal and permanent nature of the venue allows for an impressive sound system to be set up, while the energy remains that of an underground warehouse party.

The outdoor area, as expansive as the indoor space, helps contribute to this effect and provides a respite from the unrelenting techno like that which was spinning on Saturday night. The outdoor bar and food vendor were a nice contribution to the space. The venue’s geographic placement amidst a plethora of warehouses contributed to the venue’s refreshing energy of a warehouse/club hybrid. The dark club was permeated by dim light reflecting off of the disco ball and from a few light-filled balloons that ravers tossed around the crowd. The balcony at the back of the venue offered a nice perspective on the large space and was a calmer oasis for those that didn’t feel like battling the massive crowd.

Israel Vines filled up the enormous venue over two hours. His set was indicative of and influenced by the long career he’s had in electronic music, from the Detroit rave scene all the way to his contemporary collaboration with Kit Geary under the alias KGIV. The LA-based DJ and producer released Gatekeepers last month on Eye Teeth, a sub-label of Detroit’s renowned Interdimensional Transmissions.

At midnight, clad in a sleeveless grey tee shirt, Ben Klock stepped up to the booth to unleash a massive four-hour set. Klock’s phenomenal set was nothing short of the brand of techno that the Berghain resident has become so known for. The prolific artist has put out releases on Bpitch Control, Rekids, Klockworks, and Ostgut Ton. With about an hour left in the set, he mixed in his seminal track Subzero, marking his dissent into a very strong final hour that kept the venue packed until the lights came on.

Prototype brought the proper warehouse vibes and unbelievable energy all night. Catch the 33rd installment on May 14th at Lot 613.

title: Television Review: More Human: Reviewing The Leftovers
content:
When trying to qualify creative work as ‘art’ most want to evaluate form, symbolism, theme, originality; but these concepts are illusory and subjective. We value a critic who can offer the best interpretation of a work, just as we admire the artist for her creative endeavor. But, I think the most consistent measure, albeit one not necessarily present, for qualifying ‘art’, is the emotion a work evokes. This is precisely where The Leftovers flourishes.

The Leftovers is a feelings show—it’s about feelings, it makes you feel feelings. The biggest success of the show is its ability to connect you with the mood of any situation. Its plot is is posed as being completely feasible and real, despite the unbelievability of its preliminary conflict: one-fiftieth of the world’s population disappears in the blink of an eye. The story takes place in our own world, but this preternatural occurrence gives a platform for characters to reevaluate their lives and imposes the question of purpose onto the rest of the world’s players. Surely, a viewer can substitute the Happening for some post-modern advent, like the information revolution or the rise of Donald Trump; but the feelings of uncertainty and hopelessness that the search for purpose evoke feel much more important for the show than do whatever the Happening possibly symbolizes.

Why are the feelings more important than the possible symbolism? Because feelings are unifying. The Leftovers reminds us that horror is less horrible when shared. Each player involved in a horrible situation can mitigate the fear by taking on a small piece to unburden the load for everyone else. (Think: being in a large group in a haunted house maze.) This reminder is relevant for the characters of the show and similarly relevant for establishing the show as ‘art’ for it effectively evokes the same emotion across any audience.

The second season of the show finds the central family—the Garvey family—in a new locale: Jarden, Texas. The move is motivated by the family wanting to escape the problems encountered in their hometown, but they find that a new location brings its own problems, and that you can never escape your character. With two episodes left this season, viewers are in the midst of experiencing the characters confronting themselves, questioning if love can serve as a functional savior from earthly limbo.

Stellar acting and a moving score alone merit the show as being an upcoming great. However, I haven’t given due respect to the great writing. The plot is gripping and the dialogue is presented in a down-to-earth manner impelling the belief that the world in which the events take place is the same we take for granted.

If feelings are a common ingredient for humanity, then watch The Leftovers and feel more human.

Words By: Aaron Peretz

title: Book Review:  Claire Vaye Watkins’ “Gold Fame Citrus”
content:
What is California, really? And what happens when our ideas of it shift from one extreme to another? 

We are a state of respective booms: the Gold Rush; the Film Industry; the Counter-Culture movement of the 1960’s; the Tech Boom, etc.  People don’t just come to California, they pour into it.  They explode from planes, trains, automobiles and ships to converge on her shores; into her stockyards, huddle in the backrooms of bars or the human resource offices of yet another technology startup gone into the stratosphere.  Everyone here is looking for something, or is the descendant of someone who was. Whether or not they find it, invariably they put down roots and become the proverbial California graft.
