Maybe the ground shakes a little from time to time, and those who aren’t really in it for the long haul depart for places where tornados or blizzards seem like manageable risk. The rest stay. They become part of the fabric of the place, weaving in their own longing for something better. Longing for get-rich-quick schemes, for easy sex, for fresh fruit off of the tree, for stardom.  All of this passion for unrealized dreams and the co-existing brutal realities of the place amalgamates somewhere along the way into a shiny reality that seems just a little bit tainted by fantasy – equal parts gold glitter, crude oil and human blood. 

Welcome to California.  We hope you enjoy your stay.

In her first novel, Gold Fame Citrus, Claire Vaye Watkins takes a deep dive into the desert ocean that the Golden State threatens to become in dreams we don’t remember about an apocalypse we deny will ever come.  In a Los Angeles largely evacuated of inhabitants after drought has ravaged the landscape into a twisted version of what it once was, Luz and Ray eke out an existence surviving on rationed colas, too little water and whatever they can scrounge from what has been left behind by the exodus of those with the resources and/or wherewithal to escape to greener climes.  The Los Angeles of Luz and Ray has become the last outpost for those who still make their home there: the criminals, poor, outcast, forgotten and neglected.  Those who remain even with sufficient resources to perhaps buy their way out stay behind in a state of emotional paralysis.  For one reason or the other, no one left behind is moving forward, and the only movement that is taking place is that of the nascent and gargantuan desert, the Amargosa, absorbing everything that comes in its path.

Ray, an army deserter, and Luz, a model and once-was child celebrity, drift through their days without change or reckoning of time passing until one day they on impulse snatch a feral toddler from her equally feral caregivers.  Their act, given the parameters of the situation in which they find her and themselves, seems at once terrible and understandable.  Their break from inertia comes with the realization that taking responsibility for her obligates them to give her a better life.  When they leave Los Angeles heading eastward in hopes of crossing the desert, they enter a world of mirage, illusion and blindness.  An encounter with a beguiling cult leader in the desert exposes them to the extremes of rightness and wrongness in a place that glows with the same sunshine that kills those who get lost in it.  

Watkins excoriates cult and culture alike in her gentle and hypnotic attack on celebrity, consumption and the integration of blessing and curse that California represents.   In a world of unrelenting beauty that kills everyone it touches, her characters survive by breaking apart, coming together and reinventing themselves in a merciless and unforgiving dystopia that is all the more frightening given its proximity to the California we live in today.  Everyone survives at the expense of another; success is determined by how much of yourself you will abandon to become someone or something else; and hell lives just underneath the skin of paradise.

The book is prosaic in its witness of the end of it all; beautifully written, shockingly original, simple and easy to read.  Ideally it takes its place as a classic of California literature and a call to action for those of us still seeking dreams instead of nightmares in our lives here.

Reviewed by: Anastasia Gershman

title: Show of The Month: Spectral Rhomboid w/ DJ Chillbo Baggins
content:
“Spectral Rhomboid” is a unique show on UCLA Radio that showcases essential ambient and electronic tracks in weekly playlists. The show’s host, DJ Chillbo Baggins aka Hakancan Altıner, excels in curating one of UCLA Radio’s finest themed shows by using self-expression as a means to make his show as honest as it can be to his audience. 

This Fall, Hakancan’s show starts up again Wednesdays at 8pm starting next week (10/7/15) on UCLA Radio at uclaradio.com. UCLA Radio has awarded Hakancan with the station’s first ever “Show of the Month” award, and I’m very excited that I got the chance to talk with him a bit about the ever-so-brilliant mind behind Spectral Rhomboid. 


Eddie: Hakancan, you have been awarded the first ever “show of the month” commemoration. How does it feel?

Hakancan: I’m very honored because I joined UCLA Radio for a couple of reasons. One of them was to be close to people that I feel I could have similar interests and similar ideas with to express myself through my program and through my selections. Any form of appreciation for that just feels amazing and out of this world and I am very honored to be picked.

Eddie: What do you garner influence from to create such a unique show as “Spectral Rhomboid”?

Hakancan: I think the process that I use to prepare my playlists and my topics is that I don’t confine myself a period of time, like “I’m gonna do it the day before for each week’s show” so the whole week is basically like a canvas for me. I just listen to music, then I keep adding songs to my playlist. It kind of goes both ways in that both my feelings and ideas in the week shape my playlist and the stuff I listen to shape how I feel. That really interests me, like if I’m feeling moody, you can see it on the playlist, and since I keep listening to sadder songs or emotional songs, that makes me more sad as well, which makes for a very bad week but a very good show. I just feel like self-expression is a very important part of my show, both in my selections and the stuff I talk about, so I want to be as honest as I can in my selections and make the show a part of me. Not to discourage any other shows or any other DJs, but that’s how I see in my way a personal show should be.

Eddie: Do you have any advice for any shows looking for ways to improve their skills?

Hakancan: I could advise potential interns or anyone who’s in UCLA Radio and doesn’t have a show in that the self-expression value of a show is very underrated. If you give yourself into the show, it takes a lot out of your mind, it takes a lot out of your conscience and it gives you a platform to express yourself. I think that both, it’s very relieving and liberating for a person and it makes for a very good show.

Eddie: Based on what you play in your show, has ambient music been a big influence in your life or is it a recent interest?

Hakancan: It was sort of like my teen angst phase when I first got into that music. For me, ambient music was like Slipknot and Fall Out Boy. I mean it’s still with me and present in my music taste. I grew a pallet for textures and soundscapes. It had mostly to do with the fact that I used to play a lot of “Football Manager” (it’s a game) and you don’t do much in it, you just build your tactics and shit. The good thing was there was no soundtrack so you could play whatever you want in the background, so if I played “Football Manager” for fifteen hours straight, that means I could listen to music for fifteen hours straight. The stuff that I did on “Football Manager” sometimes took a lot of attention in that I would benefit from having music on that didn’t distract me from what I was doing and that’s where ambient music came into play. So this was probably when I was a Freshman in High School, and it just kind of stuck around!

Eddie: How do you feel being involved in college radio as opposed to other forms of radio, be it a local radio station, satellite radio, etc., gives you the opportunity to have the show you have?

Hakancan: I think college radio is like a safe haven for genuine music fans in that it provides a noncommercial “don’t think about the consequences, just express yourself” kind of music selection, you know? It’s like a playground. I think UCLA Radio’s diversity in the programming lineup and how distinct the shows we have on here is a good reflection of that. College radio should not be like KROQ or a Top 40 station, it doesn’t have to have just one theme or sound and follow that. The sense of community that comes from the unity of different sounds, that’s the most important aspect of college radio.

Eddie: Are you excited to start your show again this quarter or are you thinking of going a different route?

Hakancan: I am very excited! I want to build on this honor and I want to have the best show I can. I want to bring in more musicians, I want to have more themed shows, I want to get right down to the emotions and ideas I want to reflect, I want to have more performances, and I want to talk with and talk about more interesting people and more interesting topics. So, I am very excited to have this opportunity to feel appreciated and that’s motivating me to improve on the show.

Eddie: We’re glad to have you back.

~ Eddie Hernandez

title: Rock with Us: Ryan Hemsworth & Tommy Kruise @ the Observatory (6/25/15)
content:
The Just Rap Tour featuring Ryan Hemsworth and Tommy Kruise made its stop at Santa Ana on Thursday night. I walked into the Observatory and was very shocked in how intimate the whole thing was, but then thought, “hell, it’s another Ryan Hemsworth show, it’ll make for a very chill crowd.” Well, you know what, I’ve never been to a club or never have wanted to, but this show was an experience that definitely felt like it can be considered “Club Night with Ryan and Tommy” or something and it was the first time I’ve ever felt okay with wanting to stay at something that felt like a club, but I digress. Nothing beats a first impression than walking into a venue and seeing three huge pieces of cloth with spray paintings all over hovering above Tommy and Ryan’s stage setup as a backdrop. I wasn’t able to see the left, but the right and center paintings were enough to not only crack me up, but get so hyped for the night: on the right, huge spray painted versions of Ciara and T.I. stand in front of three rappers I don’t even know the names of and in the center, Tommy, Ryan, a huge wad of Canadian cash next to each of them and a blinged-out version of Bart Simpson in between them. If this wasn’t enough to get myself going for the night, I had three hours left in that venue to take more in, which I was more than excited to do but also did not know what to expect.

A good thirty minutes pass and one half of the “Just Rap Tour” duo steps up promptly at 11pm and introduces himself as “Tommy Kruise from Montreal.” Not having heard Tommy Kruise’s material before, I thought I was in for a treat regardless but then Tommy flipped the script once he said “this is JUST RAP, we’re only playing rap music tonight so rock with us.” Prior to this, I actually had no idea that the tour was called “Just Rap” for a reason. In fact, I thought it was something done jokingly based on Ryan’s sense of humor via his beautiful internet presence, but nope, this was real. This was happening. And it was amazing. Tommy began to play a whole set of rap songs I have never heard of (with the exception of a Young Thug song played in there somewhere) but in an instant, the crowd was vibing so hard. A few songs in, Tommy had the left side of the audience chanting “AYEEEE!” “AYEEEE!” until they made a party train and brought themselves over front and center and influenced the whole crowd to chime in. Playing remixes from local Montreal artists, himself, and his own friends, Tommy Kruise played a spectacular set enough to allow the crowd to get ready for what was coming next.

The one and only internet mogul Ryan Hemsworth comes onstage while Tommy plays his last song and Ryan continues to prep for his set while appreciating his tourmate’s banger choice for the night. At this point, the Observatory has already turned into one of the hottest, sweatiest venues I’ve been to and everyone is at peak hype when Ryan starts to pick his rap choices for the night. Ryan’s choices were a little different than Tommy’s in that Tommy chose the louder, heavier rap songs while Ryan’s are based off of his remixes: which are somewhat dreamy and light with the trademark xylophonic percussion rhythm used in a lot of his songs and other types of percussion similar to the sort. Over time, there would be someone crying out, “I’m so hotttt” but damn it was worth dancing through the sweat and claustrophobia. Ryan threw a ton of crowd pleasers from Fetty Wap’s “Trap Queen” to Jamie xx’s “(I Know There’s Gonna Be) Good Times” and even included one of my favorite Ryan tracks “Cream Soda,” which was a surprisingly really fun song to dance to considering the chiptune beats and video game vibe it gives off. Even Tommy poked fun at his set when he went back onstage when he told him “you didn’t even play rap tho, I thought it was supposed to be JUST RAP?!”

After a hot, sweaty, two hours with Ryan and Tommy, Tommy heads back on stage and the two begin to do an additional, collaborative 30 minute mix of rap together. On top of that, they even responded to the crowd’s “WE WANT MORE!” and played an encore which was (I believe) an alternate mix of Ryan’s single “Snow In Newark” off of his latest album Alone for the First Time. Honestly, do not take my word for it, but yes, this is the greatest club event in history and you should go now. There’s so much to grasp and so much to love at the same time that makes listening to rap through Ryan Hemsworth and Tommy Kruise DJ sets all the more fun.

Words by: Eddie Hernandez
Photos by: Ryan Kageyama

title: 4 Reasons Why Coachella Weekend 2 Is Better than Weekend 1
content:
If you’re set on going to the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival but unsure on if you want to go Weekend 1 or Weekend 2 let me help you, by presenting my…

4 Reasons Why Coachella Weekend 2 Is Better Than Weekend 1: by Jeffrey Brownell AKA Captain Neopetz on Malibu Yacht Club Saturdays 6-8pm

1. The Crowd Is Better

The number one reason anyone would want to go Weekend 1 is to see and be seen. By that I mean Weekend 1 attracts celebrities and wannabe models galore. This is the weekend that spawned the fashion blogs and so-called “coachella diets” that pop up every spring. Somewhere along the line Weekend 1 became some twisted fashion party fest. I am by no means one of those “Coachella should only be about the music” types, but Weekend 2 really caters to those that are more interested in listening to dope music and having relaxed fun, rather than the “party only because you have to” feel while beer ponging yourself to oblivion with your bros. Long story short, nobody cares what you wear or what you do during Weekend 2, and that’s the sort of environment where a genuine sort of party really lets loose. And besides, if you go Weekend 2 (because I’m sure you’re not Vanessa Hudgens or one of the Jenners) even YOU can be the queen of Coachella. That is, if I wasn’t already going of course.

2. The Music and the Experience Is Better

Practice makes perfect. It’s one of the wisest phrases in the English language, because it’s true. As far as music and performance quality Weekend 1 is a just a big dress rehearsal for Weekend 2. I would even say that most artists probably have a better time and really hit their “stride” after the clusterfuck that is Weekend 1. Artists like Outkast and Pharrell that got awful press Weekend 1of 2014 boasted drastically better performances the second time around. Of course, the music isn’t the only thing that improves with Weekend 2 though. Everything from the food, campgrounds, and security lines all get better with age, and nothing is a bigger boner kill than having to wait in line to have fun. Fortunately the security lines for getting into the grounds and the festival itself become stream-lined and shorter (Pro Tip: possibly less thorough too), as they work out the kinks come the next weekend. Basically come to Weekend 2 if you want to sneak stuff in or just see better live performances.

3. You Know What is Going to be Good and What is Going to Be Bad

Let’s just say that rule two doesn’t work out and some artists just suck no matter what weekend it is. For example, let’s say you’re torn between seeing 2 Chainz and going back to your campsite because your buzz is starting to wear off (true story throwback to 2013 me). Prior to getting to the festival you heard your friend that went to Weekend 1 said she tried to see 2 Chainz, but he showed up awfully late and only performed a very disappointing 15 minutes of his 45 minute set. Because you’re going the smarter weekend, you can bypass the disappointment, get your drink on, and set up for something that’s going to be doper, later, like Hot Chip was for me. Sure stage hopping and discovering magical musical moments on your own is a big part of music festivals, but the press that Weekend 1 gets gives you the opportunity to trim the fat and make your festival going experience better and efficient when Weekend 2 rolls around.

4. You Close Out the Festival

Nobody wants to be the first to the party. At least that’s what I always thought anyway, so it seems awfully strange to me that people really flock towards Weekend 1. My favorite thing about Weekend 2 is simply that I am the last one there. In essence, you’re shutting that motherfricker down. I couldn’t think of anything more disappointing then going to Weekend 1 and seeing Snoop and Dre and a Tupac Hologram and feeling that depressing, “it’s over feeling” only to realize that Weekend 2 is right around the corner and you’ll have to read about the hype for another week. It certainly works way better the other way around (see reason 2 and 3). Just be there when they close the door on Coachella until the next year, and you’ll know exactly what I am talking about.
So if you heed my advice, next year when Coachella 2016 is done and the nasty hangover is over, you can pick your dust induced boogers and know you went the right weekend. You’re welcome.


More info about Coachella Wristbands for 2016 can be found here: https://www.coachella.com/2016-advance-sale-faqs/

title: Mixtape Review: Drake & Future’s What a Time to be Alive by Doug Gil
content:
This summer we all learned the price you pay for defaming Drake, but in the fall, we’re finding out if an alliance with the Champagne Papí really pays off.  What a Time to Be Alive is the mixtape (though the $10 price tag really says “album”) born of the collaborative forces between Drake and Atlanta emcee, Future.

Word of this project broke out much to the excitement of hip-hop fans, especially being that both of these artists are still fresh off the trail of some of their strongest releases yet.  Despite that, a Drake/Future collaboration is no big surprise given that all three of Future’s studio albums boast a Drake feature. And much to my dismay, What a Time to Be Alive feels as if it’s exactly that: another Future LP but with even more Drizzy features added to the mix.  But that being said, the inclusion of Drake definitely makes this project much more engaging than a standalone Future release.  The Toronto-native has definitely proven himself as having a much stronger handle on melodies and hooks– assets that serve as a welcome antithesis to Future’s borderline redundant approach to his solo work.

When Drake hops on, he delivers his verses with the confidence that inevitably fills one’s spirit when your name is half the project. Future isn’t bad either; he comes forward with a distinctive personality, and his flow helps establish the aesthetic this mixtape is aiming for.  But speaking of tone, What a Time’s production is reminiscent of the minimal and spacious feel from both If You’re Reading This, It’s Too Late and DS2, without truly establishing anything of its own sadly.  This project isn’t devoid of identity per se, but I can’t help but feel as if things were played dangerously safe.  After the opener, “Digital Dash,” you basically know what you’re getting for the duration of this thing: Drake and Future exchanging lines over carefully executed, and occasionally atmospheric beats that can go hard, albeit very conservatively.  

After subsequent listens I start to get the sense that this project was a little thrown together too, and it was– What a Time was allegedly recorded during an impromptu six-day session.  The result is impressive on some levels, especially when tracks like “Diamonds Dancing” and “Jumpman” hit, but the spontaneity of the whole thing really starts to reveal itself with the amount of uninspired lyrics, or tracks such as “Jersey” that feel like throwaway cuts from DS2. 

That’s not to say that this project falls horribly short of an enjoyable listen during its forty-minute runtime, however.  Despite my complaints, nothing here is particularly awful; it’s just not filled with very many standouts either.  What you get just feels like the bare minimum from both of these artists, so I can’t help but feel like What a Time to Be Alive is just a myriad of unexplored potential.  Like I said, Drake and Future possess the chemistry necessary for a solid collaborative effort, but the execution just doesn’t reach the effort of say, another Run the Jewels at this point.

Words by: Doug Gil
tags: what a time to be alive

title: 20th Year Memorial Service for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin
content:
“We’ll fight terror like there’s no peace, and we’ll make peace like there’s no terror.” The passionate words of Yitzhak Rabin set the tone for the peaceful remembrance of his legacy and Israel’s mourning for his loss.

Actor Joshua Malina

Hosted by acclaimed Israeli – American actor Mike Burstyn, dignitaries, elected officials, philanthropists and members came together in Rabin’s honor. Mr. Jonathan Benartzi, the grandson of the late Prime Minister, traveled to Los Angeles after meeting with Bill Clinton in Israel, to commemorate his grandfather’s legacy with members of the Jewish community. An amalgamation of Jewish organizations in Los Angeles and Tel Aviv collaborated to host this evening with first-hand stories from his loved ones and moving musical arrangements by acclaimed composer Sharon Farber.

The grandeur of the Saban Theater peacefully set the tone for an evening of accolades in remembrance of Prime Minister Rabin. Rabin’s progressive global perspective can perhaps be attributed to his valiant past. Rabin rose to become Chief of Operations during Israel’s War of Independence and in 1948, began a 27-year run as a soldier in the Israel Defense Forces. In 1974, Rabin was appointed Prime Minister – a period in which he thrived through the raid on Entebbe and the signing of the Sinai Interim Agreement. Throughout the 1980s, Rabin served as Israel’s Minister of Defense until resuming his duties as Prime Minister in 1992. During his second term, Rabin prioritized a peaceful resolution between Israel and Palestine, including signing several agreements in the Oslo Accords. His efforts were recognized in 1994, when Rabin won the Nobel Peace Prize with Shimon Peres and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. On 4 November 1995, Prime Minister Rabin was assassinated while leaving a peace rally in Tel Aviv’s central square, engraining his legacy of peace and progress in the hearts of Israelites.

General Photo

The admiration in the audience was palpable, as various guests from around the world made their way to the podium to share stories of Rabin’s life. Shir Lashalom, from the Temple of the Arts, opened the event in speaking on how Rabin exemplified the strength that is Israel and strived for peace: “God will give you strength and then will give you peace.” As an outsider to this community, this gathering of Israelites, relishing in their culture, pays testament to the valiant effort the Jewish community in LA upholds towards preserving their culture in the modern day. The importance of words and languages was warmly felt. Rabbi David Baron’s national pride was echoed with applause when he held that there is no time like the present to visit Israel, regardless of its present dangers. David Siegel from the Israeli Consulate recounted hearing the news of Rabin’s death while he was serving as an Israeli diplomat in a small country in the horn of Africa: "It was like the patriarch of my own family was shot. The bullets were fired not only at this man… But at the core values of our existence.” A great friend of Rabin, singer Pat Boone, named Rabin a “great soldier who did not die in battle, but in his quest for peace,” as he told his story of cheering up soldiers in a bunker one day.

Consul General David Siegel

Unity means respect for one another, even when we are at odds in opinion. This event gave me a sense that the Jewish community is ready for a future of peace. Rabin stood for the Unity of the Jewish people and his plight towards peace was a story marked by pluralism, democracy and tolerance.

Yitzhak Rabin’s grandson, Yonatan Benartzi

Photos: Joseph Pal
Words: Brittany Hewitt

title: Never Grow Up, Never Grow Old - A Conversation with Nick Rattigan (Current Joys fka TELE/VISIONS / Surf Curse) by Eddie Hernandez
content:
(Photo via Current Joys on Facebook)

On a stupid hot July morning at Runaway Festival outside of LA’s nightclub & occasional concert venue Los Globos, I spot New York based multi-instrumentalist and the ever-so-wonderful Nick Rattigan, who presented himself to me as “Festival Staff” as he is helping the organizers set up for the day’s events.

I met Nick a few years back at the Smell in Downtown LA during various Surf Curse shows, a band comprised of himself and fellow lifelong buddy Jacob Rubeck - who helms a fantastic solo project under the name Casino Hearts - that deserves to be praised (and sure is) in LA. Nick has always focused on his new wave / pop solo project in addition to being in Surf Curse and is a genius at recording insanely catchy dance anthems that are - at the same time - carefully composed and capture such raw emotion in the efforts he makes in recording his music, using limited equipment for limitless ideas. He already has several albums released as “TELE/VISIONS”, his former moniker, and just released the beautiful Me Oh My Mirror a couple of months ago under the name “Current Joys.”

I ask Nick if it’s cool if I can chat with him for a bit in which he agreed, so we decide to find some time to do so. Nick and I reconvene a little while after Surf Curse play a lit (that shit was lit) set to a huge crowd of fans eager to dance their cares away. After watching fellow LA-based Arjuna Genome’s set, we walk out of the venue, grab a drink, and sit down to talk more about Nick’s solo project and latest release under a new name - one of my personal favorite records of 2015.

Eddie: First off i wanted to ask, hearing Me Oh My Mirror was such a different listening experience than hearing all of the TELE/VISIONS stuff and obviously Surf Curse so I was wondering how was the recording process like? Did you use the same software or did that change up too? It sounds like something different happened-

Nick: “-Yeah! you’re right, something different did happen. All my equipment broke so I had to buy new recording equipment. I had to buy a new loop pedal and I moved across the country. Yeah, a lot of these factors led to it sounding very different. I feel like I sort of wanted it to sound different, I could definitely say there was an effort on my part. With the recording and everything I bought a new interface which I’ve never had before. I’ve always done really shitty recordings - I mean - they’re shitty in their own right. I still love everything everything I record, you know, it has a sentimental part in my heart, but it’s not how people record things and have never taken a class or read up on recordings. I’ve just sort of done it in any way I can and a lot of people are like, “Oh! they sound great though!” so I’m just like “Oh! I’ll just keep doing it my way” you know? I don’t want to change anything I’m doing but in the process of moving and losing instruments, losing and getting new guitars, I feel it’s changed the way I record for one and just the person who I am. I feel like I’ve been through a lot that’s just changed the way I see music and the way I feel.“

Eddie: So how do you feel now? What do you feel are some changes you’ve noticed?

Nick: “I just feel like a really jaded person (laughs). I wish I wasn’t so jaded and I talk to people all the time about music and the culture in general right now, and sometimes I think it’s just me growing older and losing my “punkness” and how I would go and dance at shows. I talk to a lot of people and it seems that there’s really something going on in the culture, something really going on in rock music that is frightening and I don’t think a lot of people are paying attention to it. I always relate it to the end of classical music. How it had all of its time eras and at a certain point in the turn of the 20th century, people just started playing Beethoven and Bach all the time and they’re like “we’re not gonna we’re not gonna have original compositions because the greatest music has already been written.” It’s a very similar thing with rock music where we went through the birth of rock music and then the psychedelic era and punk and all this stuff. It’s reached this point where people are just recycling those genres, you have all these revival bands now, and now it’s gone into this “post“ world. It’s kinda sad and it’s kinda frightening but I’m also just trying to embrace it for what it is because it does affect me as a person and my ambitions as a musician. So I guess what I’m trying to do is just experiment. I’m not trying to change anything, but I want to make music that I wanna hear. Part of the recording process is trying to make it as raw as humanly possible and I wanna speak to people that are listening to it.”

Eddie: Do you feel there was more of an influence towards me oh my mirror than simply transitioning from "TELE/VISIONS” to “Current Joys”?

Nick: “I broke my loop pedal, which was my big thing. It had everything I used to record and then it broke. I couldn’t record anything cause I used my loop pedal to record every song. I wouldn’t even layer it - I would just do one and record over it, so I never got to play with levels on songs or anything. I bought an actual interface and that sort of beefed up the recordings a little bit and I tried my hand at mastering. That’s why it took so long to fucking record this album *laughs*. I recorded so many songs too! I must’ve recorded like 40 songs for this album and meticulously listened to it over and over to find where a song should go and how they should sound.

I fucking hate perfection because it just drives you mad, you know? Sometimes you just have to put a cap on writing a song and so I did that and put [the record].

I was listening to the record and well, I’ve always had complications with my name. I’ve always wanted to change my name. I just thought, ‘you know what? This is a good place to start for me, this is what I wanna do.’ So I changed it.”

Eddie: How is the live experience for Current Joys different from past projects, especially with owning new equipment and all?

"It’s always been a real emotional thing for me - playing my music. I don’t think it’s changed. I think just some of the sounds have changed. Before I’d always try and be "the band”. I’d have the loop pedal, the drum machine, I’d try to loop the bass track, and all that stuff. So I’m pretty much choking out what a live band would do. Whereas now I feel like I’m really embracing myself as a person and what sounds I can get out of nothing, like out of silence at some points, or actually being quiet or out of one note.“

Eddie: Yeah, I feel that ambience is really explored in that album.

Nick: “Yeah! I haven’t really played any of those live though, just the instrumentals. Those I all recorded usually super late at night around 3 or 4 in the morning just not being able to sleep and have my headphones in and loop something. you know, “the dark times of the morning” *laughs*. There’s not really words you can put into it then, it’s just how you feel.”

Eddie: How do you feel about the festival so far?

Nick: “Love it! Amazing, yeah! I’ve been really into old school LA lately. I’ve been listening to a lot of stuff on Charles Manson and so old Hollywood - the weirdness of it - like the Hollywood in the 70s and 80s. And this is an old 70s nightclub so it’s totally in line with what I’m into right now.”

Eddie: Nice! I was about to ask you what are you listening to right now?

Nick: “Oh man, I’ve been diving into the past a lot. I listen to a lot of Dennis Wilson, his solo album - one of the last solo albums he put out before he drowned is really fucking good. I listen to a lot of Beach Boys because I watched that Love and Mercy documentary. Agh, I loved it. Some people thought it was really cheesy but I cried through the credits, like this man has struggled so much *fake cries* *laughs*.

Eddie: Sweet! I’ve been wanting to watch that. Well, one last question. What’s your favorite meme on the internet?

Nick: "Aw man, I’m so not a meme person. I don’t delve into that realm very often.”

Eddie: That’s good. Really.

Nick: “I did find out I share my birthday with Elliott Smith which is pretty cool. Yours is pretty close to mine right? Do you know who you share with?”

Eddie: Yeah, I share mine with The Edge *both laugh*

Me Oh My Mirror is available for download (pay-what-you-wish) via bandcamp today.

Listen to Nick’s solo goodies here:

Current Joys: https://currentjoys.bandcamp.com/
TELE/VISIONS: https://televisionsss.bandcamp.com/
Nick Rattigan: https://thenicholasproject.bandcamp.com/

Written by: Eddie Hernandez

title: Recordings You Should Be Aware Of
content:
It may seem strange that on a blog dedicated to a radio station, one might find an article that has to do with a movie. Even stranger then that the movie in question would be a horror film, which, for the most part, is regarded in a lower tier of artistic quality than its more pretentious genre siblings like dramas, historical pieces, the classic Oscar bait films. Well if you’re looking for a reason, it is that I like horror movies. If the genre was not so filled with utterly awful films, it would probably be my favorite genre. Recently there has been a dearth of horror films, as the genre was pulled down into the pits of endless sequel nonsense, but finally a messiah has arrived in the form of the ultra-indie It Follows.  Viewing this film was among the most stressful experiences of my life, causing great anxiety for hours, even days afterward.

Now, why does any of this matter to a radio blog? Because of the score of course! The score to this film, by Disasterpeace, a relatively well known chiptune artist, is far beyond any of his previous work in both tone and complexity. It is one of the most otherworldly collection of noises to hit cinema screens, perfectly encapsulating the strangeness that permeates the film even at its calm moments.  In this way it echoes the classic horror themes of old, beginning with John Carpenter’s masterful score work on the 1979 film Halloween. Capturing a similarly eerie melody, complemented by an unrelenting rhythm underneath sets the viewer’s senses on edge from moment one. But to expand on Carpenter’s formula, almost as a way to shock jaded horror audiences out of familiarity, each piece includes notes that seem to not only be out of key, but out of place in the score as well. It perfectly emulates the situation of the characters by never allowing the audience to truly believe they have a grasp of the situation at hand. In the more pulse-pounding moments of the film, the score channels Bernard Herrmann’s iconic Psycho score, overwhelming the senses in an incomparable way. The film is a symbol of growing ingenuity in the indie horror scene, and the score itself is very much a part of that.

~ David Wright

title: Chosen Rosen Delivers in Win Over Virginia
content:
The UCLA Bruins dominated the University of Virginia Cavaliers with a final score of 34-16 in the season opener. This is the Bruins second consecutive win against the Cavaliers. There was much anticipation for this week’s game with the start of true freshman quarterback, Josh Rosen, the preseason rank at thirteenth in the nation, and a shaky performance by the Bruins in last year’s game against Virginia. 

 Josh Rosen proved that he is the right man for the starting quarterback position with his impressive performance. Rosen completed 28 of 35 passes for 351 yards and 3 touchdowns. Rosen is the first true freshman to start an opener at quarterback in UCLA history. He also established Bruins’ single-game records for a first-year freshman in completions, attempts and yards and tied the mark for touchdowns. 

Rosen showed great maturity and focus throughout the game making completions to receivers in deep coverage. One of these passes was a sixteen yard pass to senior Thomas Duarte on third-and-five, setting up the first touchdown of the game. Duarte even said, “Sometimes we would look at each other, like how did he do that?” Many fans felt the same feeling of disbelief in the freshman’s first performance with the crowd often breaking into cheers of “Chosen Rosen” many times throughout the game. 

The Bruins also showcased many new players, besides Josh Rosen. True freshman running back Soso Jamobo shined with 70 yards in seven carries. This leads many Bruin fans to feel safe in knowing that UCLA’s reign as the best college team in LA is assured for at least another few years.

UCLA’s defense rounded the impressive performance in the 3rd quarter with both Miles Jack and tackle Kenny Clark making offensive touchdowns for the Bruins. 

Up next is UCLA against UNLV in Vegas and another expected Bruin domination with the Bruins favored as 28-point favorites.  Before next week’s game UCLA is looking to focus on avoiding penalties. Against Virginia UCLA received twelve penalties for 87 yards, which is not unusual for the Bruins, but this game comprised of many aggressive penalties including two for horse collar tackles. The Bruins also must recover from the loss of defensive lineman Eddie Vanderdoes who suffered a torn ACL during the game. Bruins kickoff against the Rebels on Saturday at 7:30 pm.

title: The Beat Will Never Die: Underworld & Jungle @ Hollywood Bowl, 06/21/2015
content:
The summer solstice occurs when the tilt of a planet’s semi-axis is most inclined toward the star that it orbits. For us, the citizens of planet Earth, that date is June 21st. It is the official beginning of summer, the time of vibrancy and energy; the crescendo of the seasonal cycle, if you will. What a fitting date for a night of two performances displaying the ever so different points on the electronic music spectrum in a resoundingly similar energy.

Kicking off KRCW’s World Festival of 2015 were Jungle, one of the finest exports to come out of the UK in the recent years. As I entered the Bowl I was very curious to see if Jungle’s renowned live performance could actually live up to the standards of the venue, as both in terms of capacity and the fact that that same stage had hosted some of the greatest musicians of all time, I was anxious to see whether Jungle would be able to sustain and deliver the energy that forms the heart & soul of their band.  

The electrifying body and soul of Jungle shook the crowd to their bones. It is impossible to watch Jungle and not be mesmerized by the energy that pours out of their performance. Tom McFarland and Josh Lloyd-Watson have made the conscious decision that they want to be a band that differentiates themselves from others by their live performance, and boy do they deliver. With their funky guitar grooves reminiscent of Nile Rodgers and a dominant keyboard sound that can only be described as “what would Herbie Hancock sound like if he was born in London in the 90’s”, Jungle gave a performance that was just the right mixture of raw energy and funky sounds. The band played most of the tracks from their self titled 2014 debut, with tracks like Time, Busy Earnin’ and Julia forcing everyone from the front row to the nosebleeds off their seats to dance like they were at a rooftop in Peckham.

As the sun went down and the lights faded out, Karl Hyde, Rick Smith and Darren Price; also known as Underworld, took the stage. Touring in support of the reissue of their 1994 classic dubnobasswithmyheadman, the band kicked things off with Mmm… Skyscraper I Love You. The subtle rhythm underlying the track immediately transformed the Hollywood Bowl into an open air club. The strobe lights flickering inside and around the dome of the stage helped the vibe become even more resonant, and when Hyde’s vocals kicked in it was already apparent that the band before us was undoubtedly one of the greatest electronic music acts of all time.

Underworld made their way through classic tracks like Rez, Spoonman and Jumbo as Hyde kept on showing that even while he’s approaching his fourth decade as a performer, his energy on stage is a force to be reckoned with. The visuals were gorgeously planned to emphasize the eclectic style Hyde displays on stage, as he transformed himself into a sinister electronic music devil with his mimics and dance moves. The drums pounded ever so lightly and consistently as the crowd danced their way through the night, with glow sticks in their hands and a smile on their faces.  

As the night was approaching an end, the band rounded out their set with two of their essential cuts. “You bring light in!” echoed Hyde’s vocals as the pulsating synth lines of Two Weeks Off sonically shook the Bowl. The last tune of the night was arguably the most famous Underworld track, “She said come over come over, she smiled at you, boy.” cried Karl Hyde as the iconic Born Slippy brought the evening to an end. The word Solstice is derived from the Latin words sol (sun) and sistere (to stand still), yet ironically on the 21st of June, 2015 at the Hollywood Bowl; the sun was nowhere to be seen, and nobody was standing still.

Photo Credit: Victor Frankowski

*photo taken from http://www.underworldlive.com

~Hakancan Altiner

title: Recordings To Be Aware Of
content:
Recommended if you like: Women

Following the release of their 2011 album Public Strain, Calgary’s experimental noise rock band Women was unable to continue as a band due to the sudden passing of rhythm guitarist Chris Reimer. While music blogs and zines haven’t really given the remaining band members the attention they received during Women, the bassist’s new project Viet Cong has more recently become a popular Pitchfork favorite. While Viet Cong consists of two ex­-Women members, the band continues to move away from the experimental, noisy, droney direction that Women left off in and are more concerned with putting out “noise pop” songs. On the other hand, the lead guitarist and vocalist of Women, Pat Flegel has been working under three different monikers, all equally as abrasive and droney as the opening track off of Women’s Public Strain, “Can’t You See”. At the end of 2012, Flegel released a tape titled, “Tatlashea” under the moniker Cindy Lee consisting of eight tracks ranging from lighthearted Women-­esque Pop songs like “holding the devil’s hand” to no­wave and drone pieces like “assassination reality”. The recording quality of these songs is somewhere between that of Public Strain and 2001 Nokia flip phone recording (maybe).

The following year, a more coherent and listenable 7” was released by Flegel under the name Androgynous Mind (originally a Sonic Youth song). The 7”, titled “Nightstalker” consisted of five songs and are arranged on the record in a very tricky and confusing manner. The first side starts with “Bobbi” and “Good Friday”, which almost just plays as one song that gives the impression of a field recording of a bomb being set off in a drum store. Easily dismissable as just another pretentious noise project, the first side of the record doesn’t do much for the listener. Though a switch to the other side reveals three gems that seem more like unreleased Women recordings. “Knock On My Door” remains as a personal favorite of the course of the past two years. Though continuing in the grimy lo­fi aesthetic of previous recordings, the twangy, yet muffled 60’s pop sound Flegel creates using his Fender Telecaster induces a heavy wave of nostalgia for those who unofficially identify as Women’s cult following. The other two songs “Juanita” and “Desert Corpse”, continue in the vein of Cindy Lee’s experimental recordings in a more minimal and restrained manner. While one might dismiss the proliferation of Women-­esque recordings coming out of Calgary as alienating, pretentious and repetitive, the projects formed from the ashes of Women are a sure­fire way to satisfy one’s search for contemporary noise music.

~ Jake Stutz

title: “A broken heel at a rustic farm-to-table dinner”: Escaping today’s troubles in French memoirs
content:
Written by Moses Mascuch 

There is no way of getting around it. We are living in a dark chapter of American history. “It isn’t a good time right now,” is no longer just something you tell your friend when he calls you in the middle of your masturbation session. Instead, it has become a fitting summary of the world around us.

In times as bleak as this, we all need our personal escapes. For some, the escape comes in the form of a pill. For others, the escape comes in the form of a new hobby. For me, the escape comes in the form of memoirs of women who’ve moved to France.

I can’t recall which book first opened my eyes - was it Blossoming In Provence, or Seven Letters From France, or Picnic in Provence: A Memoir With Recipes? It doesn’t matter, as the titles are unimportant. It’s the arc of the story, the hero’s journey, as set in rural (or nonrural) France. The words slide off the page, blending into a warm, soothing bath of shoes, delicious food, and worrying about weight.

There are two types of these books. One type is the straight up memoir, simply a woman telling us what it was like to drop everything and move to France! The other is the combination book, a book that is maybe both a memoir and a cookbook, or maybe it’s Bringing Up Bebe: One American Mother Discovers the Wisdom of French Parenting: a book that is part memoir, part parenting guide. It joins the likes of French Kids Eat Everything (which claims to be “At once a memoir, a cookbook, a how-to handbook, and a delightful exploration of how the French manage to feed children without endless battles and struggles with pickiness”) and Bebe Day by Day.

But no matter whether the author has enough material to fill out a whole book, or whether she needs to pad it out with supplemental material (I’m waiting for one with a crossword), the most compelling thing about these books, the thing that makes me go to them when I need to escape, is not the tales within them. Like a written version of jazz, it’s more about what’s not written.

Moving to France is not cheap. A one way flight will run you around 600 dollars, and that’s before you check a bag, or buy one of those snack baskets with a little tupperware of grapes and some cheese. Once you’ve landed, you better have a nice nest egg with which you can find a place to live, or else you’ll be out on the street with all the mimes who never made it big.

I say all this to say that if you can move to France, you probably don’t have many real problems (at least financially or socially). A survey of these memoirs bears that out. The protagonist is inevitably a well-off white woman, for whom the height of day-to-day struggle is a broken heel at a rustic farm-to-table dinner. If that sounds trite, bear in mind it’s a real anecdote from Tout Sweet. This is what is not written in the books. What are inconveniences to us are major crises to them. The appeal, then, is to in inhabit someone for whom rock bottom is the local baker not returning your flirting glances.

I am a college student. If I can make through the next four years, I’ll be walloped with an incredible amount of debt, thrown into an economy where wealth inequality is the highest it’s been since the roaring 20′s. But that identity slips away when I sink into the first-person prose of one of these books. Instead, I’m touring France with Karen in Tout Sweet, metaphorically clutching the back of her Vespa. I cheer as she falls in love with the antiques dealer, and hiss with anger when she finds out he’s married, never wondering how she can afford to spend so much money on finding herself.

While these books are marketed as memoirs, they’re more like fantasy. Or, more accurately, it’s like if Narnia released a tourism brochure. I’ll never drop everything and move to France. I don’t have enough money to “wave good-bye to [my] glamorous city lifestyle to go it alone in a run-down house in rural Poitou-Charentes, central western France.” I’m stuck with my decidedly unglamorous city lifestyle. But when I crack the spine of Tout Sweet or Blossoming In Provence, I don’t have to be. For such an escape, $10.16 on Amazon seems like a small price to pay.

title: Meet the Team: UCLA Mens Basketball 2017-18
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman

As the basketball season is fast approaching, it is time to meet the players on this year’s team. Last year was a thrilling season for the fans in Westwood as Pauley Pavilion saw its largest crowds in the last 10 years. The optimism entering this season regarding this team is there, but now it is time to meet some of its stars.

Returning Players to Know

This year’s team is returning five key players. Although the Bruins only returned one starter from last year’s team, it did return its top two men off the bench from a year ago. With the expected starting lineup consisting of those three men paired with two freshmen, in addition to getting a huge boost from some players returning from injury, the expectations for this team are through the roof. The new starting guard this year is a familiar face to the fans. Aaron Holiday returns to the starting lineup after playing the role of sixth man a year ago. He started almost every game as freshman before he took a backseat to Lonzo Ball. Holiday is a tenacious defender, and complements that with his aggressive moves to the basket. Where he differs most from Ball is that he is a much better pure shooter, as he shot over 40 percent from three a year ago.

The next man to know is Tom Welsh. Welsh is a senior, who has seen consistent playing time ever since he got to Westwood. What some don’t know is that Welsh has changed his game this year. The nation’s best free throw shooter may also just be the nation’s best three point shooter. Welsh has adapted his game so now he can stretch the floor and start draining the three ball. He complements this ability with his rock-solid hook shot from the post, his solid rebounding, and great post defense.

The third starter will be senior G.G. Goloman. Goloman played around 15 minutes a night last year, but will be asked to do a lot more this year. He will assume the starting power forward position and will be asked to do a lot more on the offense and defensive side of the ball. Goloman is expected to run more pick and roll sets with Holiday and the other guards. In addition, he will be asked to guard more post up big men, with Ike Anigbogu having gone to the NBA draft. Everything said about Goloman from training camp has been extremely positive and the team expects him to have a breakout season.

The first man off the bench this year will be Prince Ali. Ali is a redshirt sophomore who is ready to fulfill the expectations many had when he came to campus three years ago. Ali will be asked to handle the ball a lot off the bench when leading the second unit, since the team lacks a true backup ball handler. In addition, Ali is healthy again, which means his athleticism and length will be a huge advantage for this team. He will allow the team to run a small ball lineup with four guards on the floor. Expect Ali to have a similar year to what Holiday had last year in which he will be talked about as the best sixth man in the country, as he is able to put up around 12 points a game.

The final returning member of the team in the rotation is Alec Olesinki. The redshirt sophomore is coming back from injury but is expected to have a pivotal role for the team. With a very thin depth in the front court, Coach Alford will be calling on Olesinski to play around 15-20 minutes a game. This will be a huge test for him as it will mean his defense will be constantly challenged by the physical big men around the Pac-12.

Freshmen to Know

Steve Alford has recruited a top five class again for the Bruins. Today we will highlight the two men who are starting for the Bruins from that class. At this point the statuses of LiAngelo Ball, Jalen Hill, and Cody Riley are unknown after the incident in China, so we will not discuss them.

The new stud guard coming to UCLA this year is Jaylen Hands. The best player to compare Hands to with this style of play is Zach Levine. Hands will be the primary ball handler for this team. His biggest strength is his freak athletic ability. Hands can fly people and will be putting on some wild dunks. He is also a crafty finisher in the paint, which allows him to make tough shots around the basket. He is a feisty defender as well. Him and Holiday will provide the Bruins with its best defensive duo in the last four years from the backcourt.

The next freshman was “Mr. Basketball” in Indiana last year. It is an extremely prestigious award to win, and he joins a long list of great college players who have won the award. Some of the recent winners include Greg Oden, Eric Gordon, Tyler Zeller, Cody Zeller, Gary Harris, and Caleb Swanigan. The guy who will be suiting up for UCLA is Kris Wilkes. His offensive game is a little raw right now, but he has the makings of an elite scorer with his large wingspan and ability to get to the rim. What most fans are excited about is what he brings with his size and length. Wilkes can guard every man on the floor, from the point guard to the back to the basket center. This will be a tremendous advantage for the Bruins when they go to smaller lineups, as he can switch onto any player in the pick and roll scenario.

As you can see, there is a lot to be excited about in Westwood with this basketball team as the season rolls around. The expectations are sky high for this bunch, not just this year but for the years to come.

title: Good Time // Movie Review
content:
Written by Hunter Saling 

Ben and Josh Safdie’s Good Time provides a close-up, intense view into desperation influencing action. It is tense, unforgiving, and consistently fast paced, while also possessing some necessary artistic merit that makes this film worth at least one watch.

Robert Pattinson provides what could be the best performance of his career, as Constantin “Connie” Nikas, a failed bank robber trying to get ten thousand dollars to bail his brother, Nicholas, out of jail after a robbery gone wrong. Nick, played by Ben Safdie, is mentally handicapped and has supposedly faced abuse from the brothers’ grandmother. Safdie skillfully inhabits the mind of the character, projecting the pain and confusion that Nick feels, all while just wanting to be close with his older brother, Connie. 

However, the truly shining performances in Good Time come from its supporting cast. Jennifer Jason Leigh is vicious and driven as Corey, Connie’s friend and lover who he has hold over. Leigh’s performance poignantly captures a person emotionally and financially controlled by her affection, only muddled by the very short screen time she ends up having. Newcomer Taliah Webster plays Crystal, a young girl who lives in a New York apartment that Connie finds his way into in order to get his brother away from police custody. Webster gives an incredibly natural performance that makes her character one of the most believable in the entire film. Almost as living commentary on apathetic youth, she is driven to listen to Connie out of a naive complacency that feels both neutral and rebellious, a hard middle to masterfully play, but one that Webster hits to a T. 

However it is the character of Ray, played by former-inmate-turned-actor Buddy Duress, who shines and provides the film with its steel backbone. Duress plays an inmate who Connie unknowingly sneaks out of hospital custody, mistaking him for Nick, and provides the lead with a new way of getting the money to bail out his brother – finding stashed robbery money and a bottle of LSD. The pinnacle of Duress’ performance comes during a monologue that goes through how he ended up in the hospital. The raw, “I was there” perspective on the thought process behind being involved in crime is one for the books. Duress gives a performance that is a natural, no-bullshit take on being on the other side of the law. The conflict between wanting to be the image of crime, and the harsh reality of being prosecuted and law-bound shakes the young man to his core. If anything, watch Good Time for Duress’ skillful performance.

What both makes and breaks this film is its cinematography. Much of the film features close-ups of the actors’ faces, the entire screen filled to the brim with eyes, ears, and nose. It gets the job done, as you literally cannot look away from the trauma and conflict that these characters endure when it takes up the entirety of the picture. I personally got to the point of my eyes starting to hurt from darting back and forth to see opposite ends of just one human face. Instead of this method accomplishing the effect it was meant to have, I walked away feeling as if I saw what it was trying to do, instead of feeling it work as intended.

The score, composed by Oneohtrix Point Never, is masterful. It keeps the film tense and the audience locked in, with the heavy electronic pulse that accentuates the drama and pain within the characters.

All in all, Good Time is not a bad time. While its editing and sometimes rocky pacing take away from the experience, at its core it is a raw, unforgiving film about how far people will go when they are desperate. If anything, it is worth a view to experience the tragically humanizing performances given. If any picture should make the world start to pay attention to Pattinson again, this would be it.

title: RL Grime Nova Tour Preview
content:
Written By: Jenny Tong

Photo Credit: Yimmy Yayo 

As the last stop of the Nova Tour, RL Grime will be playing for two nights in a row back in Los Angeles. The November 24 show is sold-out, but THANKFULLY a second show has been added on November 25th at the Shrine.

At the age of 26, Henry Steinway has already made a name in the trap music scene, having showcases from Coachella to international music festivals in Shanghai and Buenos Aires. Despite having only released one EP, he has sold out every show thus far, even breaking festival attendance records. He has been described by Stereogum as one of “the most colorfully inventive producers in bass music,” and praised by Pitchfork for “his ability to restructure songs without losing the drama of soaring dance melodies.”

He is best known for “Kingpin” featuring Big Sean back in 2014, the largest collaboration track in the album Void. It spearheaded more hip-hop and trap music cross-overs that are now very prevalent by the likes of others electronic dance music artists.  

Released in 2016, “Waiting,” co-produced with What So Not and Skrillex, represents each producer’s distinctive style. Beginning with more mellow vocals, the delicate synths and lush beats build up the momentum and erupt into a full-blown barrage. The song’s structure and the story behind naming the song all sync up perfectly - apparently they named the song after fans continuously commented “waiting” for its release, as the trio had started working on it in 2013. 

RL Grime’s most recent collaboration with Miguel, “Stay for It,” is another track you cannot miss. It exonerates an eager desire tampered with a softer tone, and the beats are also more mellowed down, digressing from his former “headbanger” style. It is interesting to see the evolution of his style, adding freshness to his repertoire while retaining his unique appeal. I am definitely looking forward to the sound development in his new projects under the works.

Also, a Halloween special - check out RL Grime’s Halloween Mix, with available download links before you head out in your favorite costume tonight.  

Happy Trick or Treating!

title: Web of Lies
content:
Written by Maddie Young 

Being a female on the internet can be an obstacle to navigate rather than a mere personal feature in many online communities. While I’m proud to say that I don’t make a grand effort to hide my identity online, sometimes I wish it was even possible. This was one of those instances.

I had been trying for years to find a platform to sell my crocheted crop tops, a pastime I had picked up in high school when I spent winter after San Diego winter on the beach. I had almost forgotten about my search when I stumbled upon the perfect place. It was an app called letgo that allowed one to sell within a community of one’s choosing, connecting local buyers and sellers and eliminating the need to ship. For safety, the app allowed for verification with social media accounts so that you could see who you were buying and selling from. Wary of the app still, I took it for a test before using it to sell my own things. I ventured to purchase a Levi’s acid-wash jean jacket from a woman who lived not fifteen minutes away from me. Her husband had worn it in the 80’s, and now it was mine for a mere eighteen dollars and a half hour of my time.

Feeling reassured that other women were vendors on this app and that the seller could choose the meeting location, I posted my first item for sale. It was a light blue, scalloped halter top that I’d crocheted long ago, but never worn. While experimenting with angle after angle to photograph the product lying on my wood floor, I decided it would make more sense to put it on for a modeled shot.  After all, how is anyone supposed to know what size this handmade halter was if they couldn’t see it on a person? I took a photo to show the true fit, keeping it as modest as I could and trusting that the fellow denizens of North County San Diego would respect my posting. Within just one hour of putting the item up for sale, I was ecstatic to receive an offer! The series of messages read like this:

Hi, I’m [insert buyer name here], they started.

yikes. They added in a new line of text.

You have been blocked by this user.

Confused by this string of choices and hoping to find some enlightenment, I checked their profile and saw that they had been able to sell more than ten items with the set of social skills that they possessed. Shaking off this strange encounter, I forged on with the hope that not all interactions with buyers would be so nonsensical and one-sided. Minutes later, I received another potential offer. Optimistic that this user was actually interesting in buying my item, I opened the message.

Did you make this? they asked.

Yes! I can do custom fits too, I replied industriously, proud to share my craft with people of all sizes.

Do you have lace thong or thong to go with? Used? They inquired.

I was fairly certain that this man was taken by more than just my even stitching. Curious about who this person was, I checked their profile and saw that they had somehow obtained a five star rating. I hoped that this hadn’t set some sellers at ease to meet with this man, only for him to request unsolicited and inappropriate favors in person. Fortunately for me, I knew what he was after without ever having to come face to face with him and could weigh the options on my own. While the promise of selling and hand-delivering my own used undergarments to a stranger seemed both enticing and safe, I decided against it. I promptly deleted the app, giving up on both my sales endeavour and my hope in the internet.

While I know that the app was trying to create a safe haven by allowing its users to link their social media accounts for verification, I believe that they could have done more. To start, they could extend the security check beyond essentially confirming that the user has an email address, despite how many laborious seconds it takes to obtain one. In contrast, ride-sharing app Ride Safr goes so far as to meet its drivers in person for interviews before hiring them. The app also includes an SOS button in the app if something goes awry during your ride, making incidents more traceable. Regardless of the need for improvement in preventing inappropriate behavior among users of letgo, the unfortunate moral of this story remains: if you are a woman on the internet, any photo that you post of yourself will be interpreted by some people as an invitation for harassment.

title: Roy Halladay - In Memoriam
content:
Written by Tyler Roope

Roy “Doc” Halladay tragically died on November 7, 2017 when his personal aircraft crashed into the Gulf of Mexico. He leaves behind his wife and two kids along with countless fans. Halladay pitched for the Toronto Blue Jays from 1998-2009 and the Philadelphia Phillies from 2010-2013. In his 15 year career, he had a 203-105 record with a career ERA of 3.38, and notched over 2000 strikeouts. He was an eight time all-star, two time Cy Young Award winner, led the league in wins twice, and pitched a perfect game and a postseason no hitter in the same year (2010). His impact on the field is only overshadowed by his impact off the field. During his time in Toronto, him and his wife created “Doc’s Box,” which encouraged many to donate to The Hospital for Sick Children during games. Along with this, he was often times the finalist for the Roberto Clemente Award, which highlights a player’s contributions off the field. I would like to share my story on this future Hall of Famer.

I’m a die-hard Reds fan through and through - all my life I have been. When I was in the sixth grade, the Make-A-Wish Foundation flew me and my family to Cincinnati to meet the Reds and attend a game. The point is they mean everything to me, and at that point in 2010 they had never made the postseason in my life. That year felt right though. Everything was going for them. I even became great friends with Jay Bruce! Needless to say, when he hit the walk off to clinch the division against the Astros, I flipped. I mean, I felt a little of it was because of me :)

Then I hear we were facing the Phillies. Oh boy. I knew we had a huge challenge, especially with Halladay. The day that match up came, I couldn’t sit still. I was so nervous at school, yet upset because I couldn’t watch the game there. Then I hear my principal tell me my dad was here to get me for an emergency. Naturally, I knew what was going on. I was stoked when I saw him and realized we were about to relax at home and watch the game together.

This moment in my life this was one of the most exciting things to ever happen…then the game started. We all know what happened…I imagined that the Reds might lose. I thought if that came to fruition I’d be devastated. And to be honest, until about the seventh inning, I was. But then I realized what was actually happening. I mean, oh my God, a playoff no hitter and by the Doc himself! When the game ended, of course I was sad. But I saw victory in defeat. I took a step outside of my shoes as a Reds fan and looked through the lens of a baseball fan.

Ever since that, when the Reds blow it (especially these past few years), I’m reminded of that no hitter. I look at our 90+ loss season we had (again) and I try to see the greatness that still occurred:

  • Barnhart wins gold glove over Molina and Posey
  • Six of our hitters with over 20 dinger
  • Votto MVP season 
  • Hunter Greene and other young pitchers in the system

The point of all this is that Doc taught me how to see the positive in an otherwise seemingly hopeless situation. And for that, and for him, I will always be grateful.

title: Judah Friedlander - America is The Greatest County // Stand Up Review
content:
Written by Moses Mascuch 

When Judah Friedlander takes the stage at the start of his new comedy special, America Is The Greatest Country In The United States, he looks like a man who has been living alone in a cabin for many years. His eyes are hidden behind thick glasses, which shine beneath the brim of his trucker cap. The words begin to trickle out from the guise of a mountain man, complete with long hair and a scraggly beard. Unfortunately, it’s not just Friedlander’s appearance that makes it seem like he’s been out of touch with society. It’s his jokes, too.

America Is The Greatest Country In The United States is an unorthodox comedy special that combines footage, filmed in black and white, from three separate nights. Despite the caliber of the venue, the Comedy Cellar in New York, the special has a gritty do-it-yourself vibe. Because of the Cellar’s small space, no matter where the camera is, Friedlander takes up most of the frame, giving the special an intimacy absent from those at larger venues. This intimacy is true of Friedlander’s material, too, which relies heavily on crowd work and audience suggestions. A major part of the special is Friedlander’s riffs on where various audience members are from, and his delivery and stage presence renders his remarks indistinguishable from the pre-written material. Friedlander takes a lot of risks in his special, but for the most part they pay off.

What brings the special down is ultimately that Friedlander doesn’t tread any new comedic ground. America Is The Greatest Country In The United States is, at its heart, a satire of American exceptionalism. Friedlander highlights America’s deepest flaws, and instead of decrying them, explains why they prove America is great. Why do women in America get almost no maternity leave? Because women in America care about the economy. If this kind of humor seems familiar, that’s because it is. Friedlander’s satire follows the tradition of the Colbert Report and arguably Michael Moore in ironically justifying all of America’s shortcomings. Thing A is bad, but it’s actually good for wacky reason B, cue laughter. Other than straight-up outrage, this has been comedy’s main method of critiquing America for as long as my millennial butt has been paying attention. In this way, Friedlander’s jokes are destined to fall flat, propelled as they are by such a tired style. Also, in light of our current political climate, it’s worth asking if this is still a valuable or effective method of critique. What is the purpose of ironically exposing fringe nationalists beliefs when they’re the same beliefs held by the current White House? The humor of much of Friedlander’s special relies on absurdity, he seems to say, “Imagine if someone really thought this.” Unfortunately, we don’t have to imagine anymore. The fictional deranged  nationalist Friedlander’s comedy conjures is real, and occupies the White House.

Despite his somewhat outdated subject matter, Friedlander remains an exceptional comedic performer. The deadpan comedy style that served him so well on 30 Rock is perfected here, as Friedlander is able to keep a low-key energy while still generating big laughs. At his best, Friedlander can completely blindside you with an out-of-left-field punchline delivered so matter-of-factly that it sneaks up on you. One that has stuck in my head is, “I went to China and met a five-year-old boy. His toy said ‘I made this.’” Simple, absurd, but delivered like it’s the most natural thing in the world. There are some laugh-out-loud moments in America Is The Greatest Country In The United States, especially towards the end as Friedlander drops his ironic justifications of America’s flaws, and plays more heavily on interacting with the audience.

Ultimately, the best parts of America Is The Greatest Country In The United States can be attributed to Friedlander’s personal style: his deadpan, off-the-cuff delivery, his deft control of a crowd, his absurdist outlook. Conversely, the worst aspects of the special have nothing to do with Friedlander at all. Rather, they speak to a larger failing within mainstream comedy to craft effective satire of our contemporary political climate, which is more darkly ridiculous than anyone could have expected. America Is The Greatest Country In The United States’s political commentary may be dead on arrival, but Friedlander remains a unique and valuable voice in comedy.
tags: america is the greatest country in the united states

title: Chip Kelly: Let’s Take a Look at the Hype
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman 

With Chip Kelly recently hired as the head football coach for the UCLA Bruins, let’s take a look about what all the hype about. For those who don’t know his background, he is the former head coach of the Oregon Ducks (2009-2012), Philadelphia Eagles (2013-2015), and San Francisco 49ers (2016). He is known for creating the most unique offense in the modern NFL and NCAAF, in which teams limit their time in between plays, limit the amount of substitutions, minimize time of possession, and utilize the quarterback outside of the pocket. For his system to work, he will have to recruit unique talents that fit his system. His offense will be much different than what UCLA currently has and runs.

College Record:

In four years as the coach of the Oregon Ducks, Kelly led them to one National Title game, a Fiesta Bowl, and a pair of Rose Bowls. For reference, UCLA has not been in the Rose Bowl since 1999, or any other major bowl game for that matter. In just four years, Kelly was able to take his teams there four times. In 2007, when Kelly became the offensive coordinator of Oregon, he took them from a middle of the pack offense to one of the most elite offensives in the country. His style of play led to a revolution in the college football landscape that led to almost all teams adjusting their style of play to be like him. Overall with Kelly as a head coach, Oregon went 46-7 finishing in the top five of the rankings three of the four years. This guy did everything as a college coach besides winning a national championship. He made Oregon the program of the Pac 10 and made staying up late on the East Coast for football worth it. The most prominent quarterback to come out of his system was Marcus Mariota. Under Kelly, Mariota finished in the Top 10 for the Heisman Trophy and put himself on the radar of every NFL franchise. To say Kelly is a program altering coach is an understatement.

College Recruiting:

While the head coach of Oregon, Kelly successfully recruited in California. In 2011, Kelly landed multiple marquee players from California in hot beds that used to be dominated by UCLA. To show how good he was at selling players on his system, he was able to land the two best athletes in their class to leave California and go to Oregon. Both of these kids were expected to sign with either UCLA or USC, yet they went to the Ducks under Kelly. One of these kids was De’Anthony Thomas, who quickly became the fastest player in college football during his time in college. He was an electric player who would have changed any program he went to. Even though he was from Los Angeles, he decided to go to the Ducks, which would change the landscape of the Pac 10. So now imagine Kelly being able to navigate his old recruiting grounds for a local school. As head coach, he could realistically sign Top 10 recruiting classes regularly. With our resources, new top-notch facilities, and close proximity to hot beds like the entire city of Los Angeles, Fresno, and Chino Hills, nothing could stop this man.

title: Prototype 034: Fine Time w/ Robert Hood, Mike Servito, Tahl K @ Lot 613 (05/21/16)
content:
Written By : Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio Art Manager

Post Date : 05/30/16

Fine Time’s Tahl K opened up the night at Lot 613 in the Arts District of DTLA. Tahl K has quickly built a name for himself, playing alongside the likes of Soichi Terada, Pearson Sound, Call Super, and Galcher Lustwerk all in the last year alone.

Brooklyn-based selector Mike Servito took control with the type of “upfront, dirty, deep, and bitchy” set he’s known for. Servito’s sound speaks to his roots in Detroit, the city responsible for giving birth to techno. Servito’s rise to prominence is delineated by his status as a Ghostly International DJ, position as a resident at The Bunker New York, and recent ranking on Resident Advisor’s annual taste-making DJ Poll, among other things. It would be uncouth to mention Servito without taking into consideration his contributions to the queer dance community. Recently featured in NPR’s article Reclaiming the Queer Dance Floor, Servito has been hailed as a central figure in today’s queer dance music realm.

When techno legend Robert Hood came up to bat, the energy of the room shifted. The commencement of his set commanded a sense of reverence, as he opened with the minimal techno he is known for pioneering. The Detroit native’s contributions to electronic music have been enormous, including co-founding the massively influential label Underground Resistance and independently creating labels such as M-Plant and Hard Wax. With a career spanning over three decades, Hood’s longevity can be chalked up to his drive to create timeless music and dogmatic dedication to polishing his sound, rolling with the technological changes in the industry while not succeeding to them. Hood’s masterful mixing on Saturday night was made all the more impressive given the fact that he played almost exclusively from vinyl. A self-identified Christian, Hood brings an interesting perspective to dance music, which can get a rather hedonistic rap. That said, the way his music spiritually invigorated the dance floor left even the worst sinners with a sense of divine rebirth.

title: Lightning in a Bottle 2016 Ultimate Guide
content:
Written By: Pamela Crick, UCLA Radio Promotions Manager

Post Date : 05/24/16

From the geniuses that brought you the Do-Lab at Coachella, comes Lightning in a Bottle. For those of you unfamiliar with the name, LIB is a four-day camping, arts music and yoga festival in Bradley, CA. LIB is different than most festivals you’ve been to. Not only do they host an incredible electronic line up with headliners Grimes, Cashmere Cat, Chet Faker and Mr. Carmack but also they are the most environmentally conscious festival in America! They have been awarded A Greener Festival’s Outstanding Award five years in a row, which means you can party guilt-free knowing that you are actually contributing to a more sustainable world! Tickets are now sold out, but for those of you planning on attending, check out this ultimate guide curated by our very own UCLA Radio DJs. 

WEDNESDAY:

The festival officially kicks it off tomorrow at noon with the Village Action Day. If you are interested in attending this opening ceremony, be sure to snag an Early Arrival Pass here. 

After that, be sure to check out the annual Permaculture Action Day from 1pm – 7pm hosted by the LIB headliner, the Polish Ambassador. This is a cool way to get involved and make some friends at some awesome curated events dedicated to community building, earth stewardship and purposeful fun. RSVP here! 

THURSDAY:

For everyone else, you’ll probably be heading up on Thursday. Check out the ultimate LIB packing list here for an intricate list of stuff you should bring. Parking is free if you carpool, so plan ahead!
