Thursday is a great day to get acquainted with the grounds, set up camp and check out some of the panels and events before the music starts. Take this weekend as an opportunity to try new things! LIB offers many different events that you should take advantage of. The Learning Kitchen hosts tons of interactive activities from chocolate aphrodisiacs to a culinary guide to partying harder by Chef Sarah Brewer. Or maybe head on over to the Mediation Look Out to reflect and practice mindfulness before the craziness starts. I highly recommend checking out the new “VR Galactic Gallery“ a Virtual Reality Art Gallery experience at Archival Ink Gallery by Zach Krausnick and David Starfire. See the full schedule here. 

FRIDAY:

Friday the music has officially begun. Spend your day exploring the stages, but don’t forget, fun activities and events are still happening all around you if you feel like you need a break from the music.

What NOT to miss: Grimes, Tourist, Big Gigantic, Monkey Safari

A personal favorite of UCLA Radio, Grimes is one of those artists that is going to go down in history. Do your future self a favor and go see her. Her music is innovative and edgy but still danceable and beautiful. She’s on at 1am at the Lightning Stage. 

Tourist has just released his debut album U. It’s out now on Spotify and has become a personal favorite of mine, so definitely make sure you drop by and check out his set. His music is dreamy and dancey, probably the perfect combination for this kind of festival. He’s on at 8:25pm at the Lightning Stage.

Check out Monkey Safari to satisfy your techno fix for the day. As described on their Soundcloud, “Monkey Safari bring rays of light to whatever dance floors they cast their shimmering spell on.” Do yourself a favor, and don’t miss them. They’re on at 6pm at the Woogie. 

The love child of a drummer and a saxophonist, Big Gigantic has brought their own unique twist to traditional electronic music. Their sound is funky, but still has those trap-like drops that every EDM fan knows and loves. Similar sound to Griz. Check ‘em out at 10:10pm at the Lightning Stage. 

For your consideration: Marian Hill, Lane 8, Cashmere Cat, The Polish Ambassador. 

SATURDAY:

You’re probably going to be exhausted from Friday, but don’t sleep in too long. There’s still tons of stuff to see and do! Hit the showers ($7), eat a hearty breakfast and head on out to explore the wonders of LIB again.

What NOT to miss: Jamie xx, TOKIMONSTA, Autograf, Ibeyi, Justin Jay

Another classic UCLA Radio artist, Jamie xx is probably one of our most spinned artists, and for good reason. He is my favorite electronic music producer at the moment and his live sets are a spectacular and spiritual experience. He’s closing at 12:10am at the Lightning Stage. 

TOKIMONSTA has been a prevalent force in the LA electronic scene for years now. Not only is she a female DJ succeeding in a male-dominant male music scene, but she has collaborated with huge names such as Anderson .Paak, Gavin Turek and Jonny Pierce from the Drums. She is a Do-Lab veteran, and a definite good time. She’s on at 11pm at the Thunder Stage. 

UCLA’s very own CEC and Message in a Melody will be having Autograf perform a live set tomorrow night in Ackerman! If you miss it, make sure you don’t miss him at LIB. Autograf is one of those artists who’s music does not reflect completely his live sets. He plays music from all genres to create a surreal dancing experience. He’s on at 4:15pm at the Thunder Stage. 

Parisian musical duo Ibeyi is another incredible act you shouldn’t miss. Their sound is a mold of electronic soul and Afro-Cuban roots. This will truly be a unique set, so come and get funky with them at the Lightning Stage at 7:35pm.

Dirtybird’s Justin Jay is another familiar name on the UCLA campus. Last year they opened for Anna Lunoe for Message in a Melody’s annual concert and they killed it. Justin Jay’s set is one of the most interactive I’ve ever been to. They’re upbeat and fun and sure to leave you in a good mood. They’re on pretty early at 1:30pm at the Thunder Stage. 

For your consideration: Hayden James, Lucent Dossier Experience, Haywire.

SUNDAY:

That bittersweet feeling of the Sunday of a music festival will probably hit you here. Make sure to live it up as much as possible before you’re back to reality! The Thunder Stage looks especially trappy today, so if that’s what your into, you should probably spend your whole day there. 

What NOT to miss: Mr. Carmack, Four Tet, Desert Dwellers Live Experience, Chet Faker, Lafa Taylor

One of the most innovative producers out there, Mr. Carmack is one you should plan your day around. There is no doubt in my mind that his set will be the most lit of the weekend. His live sets stand alone as some of the most expert DJing at the moment. He blends countless genres to create a futuristic and trapped out experience. This will be an extremely packed crowd, so try and get there early! He’s on at 11pm at the Thunder Stage. 

If you missed Four Tet at the Shrine a few weeks ago, now is the time to make up for that FOMO. Having dropped his incredible new album Morning/Evening (if you haven’t heard it yet - check it out), Four Tet will brings a unique sound to traditional dance music by incorporating organic and programmed sounds. Don’t miss his set at The Woogie Stage at 10pm!

I actually first heard about the Desert Dwellers Live Experience from an Uber drive on my way to an LED Presents rave during Memorial Day last year. If you’re looking for that “Burning Man” aspect that so many say LIB fosters, this is a set you will want to check out. They’re on at 6:25pm at the Thunder Stage. 

Chet Faker is an obvious addition to this list. Many don’t actually know that he is quite the musician and will blow your mind with his incredible vocals. He’s not too bad to look at either. If you want to end the night singing along to his countless hits, he’s closing the Lightning Stage at 12:30am. 

Make sure to catch rising star, Lafa Taylor, at the Lightning Stage at 2:20pm on Sunday. He crosses the spectrum of Hip Hop, R&B and electronic music and his live shows are energetic, dynamic + soulful and not to be missed.

For your consideration: Moderat, Alina Baraz, Guy Gerber, Lee Burridge, pantyraid

MONDAY:

The festival is officially over at 11am. Pack up, say good bye to all your new friends and reflect on these three days of pure bliss. Remember to leave your campsite how you found it and take all your trash with you. This is a sustainable festival, after all! Finals week is just around the corner, so you better get ready for that now ;) 

Be sure to check out our Instagram all weekend long for exclusive updates and photos! See you there!

title: Featured Artists of the Week: S16 W9
content:
Every week, UCLA Radio’s Music Department pick their favorite tracks that they find absolutely ravishing. These tracks are some of the newest tracks circulating around other radio stations and blogs, and some music they listen to are still unreleased! Check out what our DJs have to say and take a listen on the Spotify playlist.

Mutual Benefit - Skip A Sinking Stone
Genre: experimental pop/singer-songwriter
Recommended Songs: “Lost Dreamers”, “Not for Nothing”, “Getting Gone”
I’ve been listening to Mutual Benefit for years now and his music touches my heart in a very special way. I would mostly group his style with the likes of Fog Lake – most with fairly soft vocals yet beautiful composition. With his new album Skip A Sinking Stone, Mutual Benefit returns to his singer-songwriting roots to create a melodic journey that is easy to listen to. The album stays pretty consistent in this whimsical vibe that could be the soundtrack to one of those indie romance films.

The Velveteins - A Hot Second With the Velveteins
Genre: indie rock
Recommended Song: “Hanging From the Ceiling”
Easygoing garage-surf-indie from the Edmonton natives. Feels like a sunny day, whether strolling down the sidewalk or chilling in the sand. Although they draw from many styles, they’ve put their own touches on familiar sounds, which makes the album more interesting and engaging. Somewhat happy-go-lucky, but all in all, A Hot Second With the Velveteins is a solid, compact 6-song record.

Misogi - PLAYMISOGI
Genre: chill trap/electronica
Recommended Song: “Swervin’ ft. Madeaux and Manman Savage”
This whole album has a lot of ambient beats. The tone of this album is mostly a bit somber while not at all discouraging. Rather the music is a bit more confessional sounding, and is good for listening to while studying, chilling, cleaning, or a late night drive on a road that is normally so busy yielded empty by the night hours. Misogi is a producer that brings some of the core elements of what “trap” started as back to life. The beats knock harder than radio hits, but you can feel the underground vibe coming from the full sound scape of the instrumental. There’s a really strong connection between any verses that are on the tracks and the emotion that is introduced by the beat in the beginning of each of the songs. It doesn’t feel as though it is the vocalist controlling the music in this way.

Little Green Cars - Ephemera
Genre: folk rock/indie rock
Recommended Song: “Easier Day”
The vocalist in this band has a fairy-like voice and the way she sings is a nice mixture of frail but confident. The drums usually come in to build a lot of tension and then continue to set the pace one the guitarist or vocalist has laid down a mood within a song. Also, I noticed most of the guitar work in the album is pretty gentle which provides a very intimate setting for the bass guitar to carry along the vocals. The album has a strong fleeting feeling and picks up speed after the first third or so. Other great songs that I recommend on there are “The Party” and “Good Women Do” because I really love the singer; she’s a freakin’ rock star.

Tracy Bryant - Subterranean
Genre: psychedelic 50s garage rock
Recommended Song: “The Background Singer”
Subterranean is (surprise) yet another psychedelic garage rock album, but is still a solid release. Some of the album strolls down memory lane in a sappy but enjoyable tribute to 50s rock - tracks like “The Background Singer” sounds exactly like the track of a cheesy oldies band playing at prom, while “Shining” plays on old surf rock. Although it manages to incorporate a diverse amount of influences, the album sometimes feels like it’s riding the nostalgia train riding through a lot of current psychedelic and lo fi music, but it’s still very much worth a listen.

Grubby Little Hands - Garden Party
Genre: psychedelic pop
Recommended Song: “No Such Thing”
Grubby Little Hands is your basic dreamy, psychedelic pop band. Stretched out, echoing vocals layer over distorted yet colorful instrumentals in an unsurprising but satisfying album. It’s good, chill background music, but certainly nothing revolutionary.Garden Party is a well suited album for putting on your headphones and zoning out - while it’s not riveting, it does its job.

Holy Fuck - Congrats
Genre: electronic
Recommended Song: “Tom Tom”
Congrats sounds like an electronic version of a Black Keys-Thundercat hybrid. The distorted sounds sound unexpectedly gorgeous at times and sound noisy at others. “Tom Tom”’s slow vocals create a lot of beautiful tension, and “Shivering” is wonderfully theatrical. Overall the album is an interesting and wonderful mix of rock and electronic soundscapes.

L.A. Flood - Synesthesia
Genre: rock
Recommended Song: “Time In Reality”
Synesthesia is a wonderfully bright and funky rock album. Catchy grooves keep the album in motion, and each song has different influences whether it’s R&B, funk, or pop. The variety keeps it interesting and overall very upbeat and energetic music. “Time In Reality” is a perfect representation of the versatility of the album.

Def Sound - Timeless
Genre: hip hop/electronic soul
Recommended Song: “Movementation tr3s”
Timeless is a four-movement suite. Each track has a different element and different lyrical theme, but all are a rhythmic mix of electronic and organic sounds. The first movement has a loopy stream of consciousness feel, the second is autobiographical and sharply rhythmic, and the third is a lyrically potent track all about love. The fourth has no vocals and is produced by Def himself. The mood of the suite is relaxed and unhurried, and often feels like spoken word.

Rollercoasterwater - Umami Sounding Fireball
Genre: electronic/soul
Recommended Song: “Foam In My MIDI Controller”
Rollercoasterwater takes distorted electro-soul in a new direction with “Umami Sounding Fireball”. Sawtooth distortion, sweet guitar riffs, and sweet ethereal vocals combine to create an out-of-this world mixture of space and color. Very ambient, but the most powerful songs are the ones that are more immediate, showcasing the group’s unique atmospheric sound. “Ave Tare Said” and “Foam in my MIDI Controller” are highlights.

A Giant Dog - Pile
Genre: punk/mud
Recommended Song: “Sleep When Dead”
A Giant Dog is a breath of fresh punk air, combining the use of muddy textures and rebellious loud vocals with interesting panning and mixing techniques. This album delivered a dynamic quality you do not typically hear in the punk genre, which makes for a great listen. The vocals are very raw and don’t have much of an intriguing quality, but the instrumental quality more than makes up for any lyrical shortcomings. “Sleep When Dead” is a culminating statement in the project, complete with a great beat and hook. If you are fan of alternative rock or post-punk, this album is for you.

title: I Found Love on the Loudest Part of the Web
content:
Written By : Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/17/16

The following is a continuation of an account of one person’s accidental journey of finding love on the online music sharing platform Soundcloud. The story was entrusted to the author and is written from the perspective of the author’s friend. The first part of the story can be found at http://goo.gl/AyJrCT

When I clicked on his page I was shocked by what I saw: reposts of all of my tracks. Even the b-sides. Even the chopped ’n’ screwed field recordings of Cavalia’s Odysseo (which is a must see, by the way—you wouldn’t believe the kind of equine acrobatics that are possible today). I scrolled through the Swedish producer’s page now existing as an echo of my own. His latest track was titled, “For Horse Girl.” It couldn’t have been for anyone else. Overcome with a throbbing flutter of butterflies in my stomach, I hit play. A sultry female voice (think: Kučka) scatted over a lively cumbia-inspired synth—an obvious nod to my hispanic heritage. As the song crescendoed I realized that the lyrics were being played in reverse. Do the lyrics contain some sort of subliminal message? A love letter, maybe?

I found an online track reverser to begin decoding the enigma, but I didn’t realize what I had just gotten myself into. Even with the track reversed, the lyrics became no less clear: it was sung in a language not immediately familiar to me, one long unheard by the ears of the masses. The words sent chills and my hairs spiked up like a cat who has encountered a cucumber. As I looped the track, the phonemes sublimated into packages reminiscent of Hebrew. I began to trace the etymology of Hebrew, clicking from the “Semitic languages” page through “ancient Semitic speakers” to arrive at a page on “Aramaic.” A sonic sampling of the language confirmed my suspicion: the recording was in fact spoken in Aramaic. Naturally, I was entangled by questions seemingly only one person could answer.

I snapped to my computer desk and selected the “soundcloud.com” shortcut on my

Bookmarks Bar. A quick search of the Swedish producer left me haunted. His page was barren. It was stripped of all reposts, likes, and sounds; except for one. A solitary song remained: “Error 404.”

To be continued.

title: Ecochella Preview
content:
Written By : Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 05/04/16

Ecochella returns this year for their fourth time running the all bike-powered music festival. Ecochella first started in 2013, under UCLA’s E3: Ecology, Economy, Equity club. Since then, the music festival has been an annual favorite event for students and locals alike as people come together to power the festival with bikes. As always, Ecochella will be taking place at Sunset Recreation Center and the festival will be on Friday, May 6 this year.

Every year, Ecochella curates its lineup to include student groups as well as local bands. These musical acts also vary in genres, ranging from rock to dream punk to rap.

The lineup for this year includes:

ABEL

Ubiquitous Love Tribe

Westwood Village Entertainment Group

Mr. Moon

Stefan Diamond

Triangle Fire

So Many Wizards

WALLA

Furthermore, Ecochella will also have a sustainability fair, which helps promotes sustainability, clean energy, and loving the environment. There will be vendors present at the fair to sell art and other goodies, and festivities include yoga classes and more!

Come join us at Ecochella, the event runs from 3:30PM-9PM. Free admission for everyone or even better, help volunteer and sign up to help bike power the event. All the information can be found on their Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/events/849224721888234/ and also their website http://www.ecochella.org . Hope to see you there!

title: I Found Love on the Loudest Part of the Web (Part One)
content:
Written By : Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 05/01/16

The following is an account of one person’s accidental journey of finding love on the online music sharing platform Soundcloud. The story was entrusted to the author and is written from the perspective of the author’s friend. Accordingly, real names have been obscured for privacy.

Shortly after I uploaded a profile picture to my Soundcloud profile I experienced an influx of follow requests from basement producers, you know, the kind working out of their mom’s basements. Before the picture, my profile was receiving minimal traffic and my songs were getting most of their hits from friends. After awhile the updated profile had the unintentional consequence of my music’s being discovered. My songs were being played in the tens of thousands, and at this point it became unclear whether people were following me for me or for my profile picture or for my music.

One day, a Swedish House producer (wearing white designer wraparound shades in his profile picture) followed me. Minutes later I received a direct message in my Soundcloud inbox, “Hey.”

“Hey? What the heck does this boy wearing a deep v-neck want,” I thought to myself. This period of my life was marked by a succession of failures with dating. I had largely given up on looking for Mr. Right. I was dedicated to my music. I had a career to work on. But now this super-tan Swede with bleached teeth burst into my life like a water balloon filled with diet coke and Mentos. For so long I had been repulsed by the idea of finding love online—corny pick-up lines, lame attempts at small talk, the inevitable conversation of my vestigial tail. I decided I would message him back and let him down easily before he could get any more involved with a mess like me. But when I clicked on his page to respond I was shocked by what I saw…

To be continued.

title: Featured Artists of the Week: S16 W10
content:
Every week, UCLA Radio’s Music Department pick their favorite tracks that they find absolutely ravishing. These tracks are some of the newest tracks circulating around other radio stations and blogs, and some music they listen to are still unreleased! Check out what our DJs have to say and take a listen on the Spotify playlist.

Tanbark - Write Soon
Genre: alternative/country
Recommended Song: “Lady Love (Mother Nature)”
Tanbark is breaking barriers with this album. Typically you see country artists sticking to just country, or non-country artists staying away from country, but Tanbark creates a new type of sound by fusing rock music with country influence. The vocals are beautiful, and each song gives you a nice soothing feeling.

Gurus - Unconditional Surrender
Genre: alternative
Recommended Song: “Channel”
Unconditional Surrender is a musical journey from start to finish. The whole album flows well together, and it tells a great story. Definitely an album you can listen to all the way through. The instrumentation is sounds great, and the whole tempo of the album fits well with the vocals. Well put together album.

Michelle Willis - See Us Through
Genre: alternative/r&b
Recommended Song: “Home”
Vocals are amazing. From the start of the album to the finish, her vocals draw you in and don’t let you go. Great album to listen to for relaxing and chilling at home. The instrumentation is ambient at times and serves an instrument to let your mind free. I loved the album.

Yumi Zouma - Yoncalla
Genre: indie pop, synth pop
Recommended Song: “Short Truth”
Swedish band Yumi Zouma achieves the rare feat of making distinctive electropop. Almost every track here sounds like it could be a single, and the lyrics are sweet and sad at times. Chill without blending into the background, catchy without being repetitive, Yoncalla is a good record for finals week and the rest of the summer. 

Puro Instinct - Tell Me (Single)
Genre: indie pop
Recommended Song: “Tell Me”
New single off of the LA sisters’ upcoming album “Autodrama.” Super chill atmosphere, easy to melt into. Ethereal lead and backing vocals. It sort of blurs the line between indie pop and shoegaze, making it appealing to fans of either genre. Active production prevents drowsiness as you sink into the mellow melody.

Kaytranada - 99.9%
Genre: funk/electronic soul
Recommended Song: “Together ft. Alunageorge & Goldlink”
The whole new Kaytranada album, 99.9% is truly great. This single off of the album is my absolute favorite, and it’s a feature track with Alunageorge and Goldlink. Aluna Francis of Alunageorge is one of the sweetest vocalists around right now, and her voice smoothly glides over the funky beat. Goldlink, well-known for being a member of the Soulection crew, has a fast, down-to-earth verse that shuffles through the middle of the song. This clean edit allows the pure warmth to be felt, and takes a little of the grit that Goldlink raps off of the feel of the track. It does a good job of juxtaposing a very masculine energy with Aluna’s delicate melody, kinda like what Andre 3000 of Outkast does really well. Please get this album if you’re reading this!!!

Volbeat - Seal the Deal & Let’s Boogie
Genre: rock & roll/metal
Recommended Song: “Seal the Deal”
Volbeat is a Danish Metal band, and this album felt on the cusp of strong Rock & Roll with some Thrash. There are even a few tracks which dip into having elements of Rockabilly music, which was really sweet alongside many songs with some good shredding. Rob Caggiano has been with the band for a while, coming from famous Thrash metal band, “Anthrax.” Seal the Deal was familiar to me from their Coachella performance this year, and has arguably the most power in the album. Another really great song was the final track, “The Loas Crossroad,” which finishes the album on a really epic note. It even uses a dude playing the bagpipes in the last minute, I was NOT expecting that! After listening to the whole thing through and then the first track once more, it felt like music that would go along with a couple of fighting Irishmen.

BRONCHO - Double Vanity
Genre: alt rock
Recommended Song: “Fantasy Boys”
Hailing from Tulsa, Oklahoma, this alternative punk group has made some very interesting musical turns from their first 2 records to Double Vanity. What was once a purely 80’s hook-punk group has no explored blues, funk, and soul to create an in-your-face, edgy record. The lyrics are obscure and there are very funny pronunciations of words (see Fantasy Boys), but the ride is awesome.

Ladyhawke - Wild Things
Genre: synth pop
Recommended Song: “Golden Girl”
Ladyhawke takes synth pop to a new level on Wild Things. Her attention to detail is evident in the wonderful overall mixing, spiraling ethereal intros, and booming emotive hooks. Some of these songs are masterful records in the synth-pop genre, and although her voice is not stand-out on its own, she makes up for it with incredible production value. If you want to hear the masterful craftsman version of the ubiquitous pop radio songs, then you have Ladyhawke.

title: Call A Plumber: Musing on Trump, Batman, and Beyond
content:
Written By : Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/25/16

What do Ancient Rome, the USA, and Gotham City have in common?

A few months back I was struck by an acute bout of nostalgia. College and maturation has the effect of twisting your mind into knots like a kinked hose. I sought a sedative, the desire to relive the simple pleasantries of a life unaffected by the brutal realities of a disinterested world: I wanted but to un-kink the hose, if only for 23 minutes. As a kid I was an apostle of the Cartoon Network lineup, infatuated with the haunting unease of Courage the Cowardly Dog and the isolating disquiet of Samurai Jack. Batman Beyond was another favorite. I never completely lost touch with Courage, but out of my distending desire to escape the present situation I hit Netflix to re-watch Batman (don’t try finding it, Netflix took it off). I’d soon be substituting one tough reality for a tougher look at the future.

The world of Batman Beyond takes place in Gotham City (as all other Batmen do), but in a dystopian future long after Bruce Wayne has hung up his cape. The series isn’t so trite as to depict an Orwellian dictatorship, but instead paints a future polluted by capitalism run amok. The social commentary is basic situation and not thematic—each episode focuses on struggle and character. Of course, the characters are degraded like the city they call home; the theme permeates the setting. It is the theme of the future. Lurking obelisks dominate the Gotham City landscape, each tower covered in glyphs resembling Asiatic characters. Bruce Wayne, pillar of American exceptionalism and justice is old and weak. The East has supplanted the West. But the East is never depicted as the enemy. They are the natural successors to a line of greed and amorality—their ruin too, is inevitable. The cause of our collapse is internal.

                                                           ***

Today, the world spectates the rise of Donald Trump in American politics. The severity of America’s bigoted tendencies was never so apparent to me as it has been through the 2016 elections. Trump relies on a platform of fear and hate. It’s hard to speculate on the level of insecurity of a man that has never had to question his decisions. But he, like so many Americans, feels entitled. Entitled to ignorance. Ignorance as refusal of reflection: the shirking of fact and responsibility. Nonetheless, he knows who is to blame and he knows damn well who is going to pay for it. Americans love it—polls show so. We don’t want to reflect on anything. We love the displacement of responsibility. We love small words and shorter sentences. We’d love to believe that our country is in the shitter and everyone else is to blame: China, Mexico, &c.

If we want to act like children, then we should take a cue from cartoons. Batman Beyond tell us that these countries are not trying to destroy us. Some countries may be opportunists, but we our responsible for creating any kind of opportunity. The greatest irony in the rise of Trump is that his supporters who cry for the return of our country are the same malignancies responsible for degrading it. We can’t be exceptional if we’re not just, and we can’t be just without reflection. We need to take responsibility for what we want our country to be.

Answer: lead in the water.

title: Featured Artists of the Week S16 W8
content:
Every week, UCLA Radio’s Music Department pick their favorite tracks that they find absolutely ravishing. These tracks are some of the newest tracks circulating around other radio stations and blogs, and some music they listen to are still unreleased! Check out what our DJs have to say and take a listen on the Spotify playlist.

Jessy Lanza - Oh No
Genre: indie electronic
Recommended Songs: “Oh No” and “Never Enough
Emotional, diverse, effortlessly cool, Jessy Lanza’s second LP Oh No is a wonderfully produced electronic album that blends pop, R&B, techno, and "additional forms of electronic post-disco that cross four decades” (Allmusic). Sometimes upbeat and danceable, other times serenely downbeat, the album showcases Lanza’s broad electronic talents and angelic vocals. Fresh, notable, and definitely worth a listen.

Local Natives - Past Lives
Genre: indie rock
Recommended Song: “Past Lives”
It’s been three years since Local Natives released their second album Hummingbird, but the Silver Lake band is back with their newest single “Past Lives”. I think this song still reflects the nature of the band very well, especially Taylor Rice’s singing style is still very distinct on top of the Local Natives impeccable rhythm. However, the band has definitely grown – using more synths and electronic sounds in their music. Local Natives has always managed to create music with many layers of sound yet make them all sound cohesive.

LISS - First EP
Genre: synth pop/indie pop
Recommended Songs: “Without Me” and “Miles Apart”
LISS is a Danish indie pop band. Their new EP First is extremely synthy and popy. Upon my first listen, I was actually reminded of boy band music from the late 90s because of the singing styles on the song. LISS actually has a bit of the weird HOMESHAKE vibe mixed with the 90s boy band music but it actually works. It’s odd but it works.

Cate Le Bon - Crab Day
Genre: indie rock
Recommended Song: “I Was Born on the Wrong Day”
Welsh singer-songwriter Cate le Bon uses a quirky lyrical approach and a breathy falsetto in her new record to discuss curious topics. She sings about how she was born on the wrong day. Le Bon displays her versatility as a singer, featuring upbeat tracks with powerful guitar riffs as well as mellow, eerie ballads.

Misha - All We Will Become
Genre: indie pop
Recommended Song: “Limelight (Mantra)”
All We Will Become is Misha’s first record in almost ten years. Songwriter John Chao aims to merge a poppy sensibility with elements of indie, hip hop, asian and celtic music. “Limelight (Mantra)” is definitely a highlight, and the rest of the record is decent indie pop with a lush orchestral sound that stands out.

Kyle Craft - Dolls of Highland
Genre: rock n roll
Recommended Song: “Pentecost”
Dolls of Highland combines several influences from folk, glam rock, and rock and roll in a truly amazing debut album. It’s a brilliant take on old influences invigorated with new passion. Craft’s vocals convey an electric and almost erratic energy, and his use of religious metaphors in tracks like “Pentecost” and “Lady of the Ark” tells a story of raw emotion and reminiscence of growing up in rural Louisiana. Honestly one of the best debuts of 2016.

title: Featured Artists of the Week S16 W7
content:
Every week, UCLA Radio’s Music Department pick their favorite tracks that they find absolutely ravishing. These tracks are some of the newest tracks circulating around other radio stations and blogs, and some music they listen to are still unreleased! Check out what our DJs have to say and take a listen on the Spotify playlist.

The Coathangers - Nosebleed Weekend
Recommended Song: Make it Right
Genre: punk, alternative
The Coathangers hail to riot grrrl and garage rock on their newest release Nosebleed Weekend. While the album seems to start off with the rather mild track “Purfume,” songs like “Squeeki Tiki” sound like they could be bonus tracks on a Bratmobile or Le Tigre album. Definitely a good recommendation for fans of current all girl bands like Vivian Girls or Girlpool.

DTCV - Confusion Moderne
Recommended Songs: Impossible (Yeah), L'Accord Parfait
Genre: indie rock / french pop
DTCV with their fourth LP Confusion Moderne, this time with all-French vocals and more gritty, confident, rock swagger. You don’t need to know French to fall in love with the music, however. Filled with crisp, stoner-esque, classic indie melodies, and drawing from elements of french pop, garage rock, and psych-rock, Confusion Moderne strikes a delicate balance with spectacular results. Although some tracks lack focus, the album overall is infectious and as good (if not better) than any indie rock I’ve heard this year.

Gavin Turek - On The Line
Recommended Song: On The Line
Genre: funk/electronica/female vocalist
Gavin Turek is a local Los Angeles songstress who has heavily collaborated with famed producer TOKiMONSTA. Turek is making a name for herself and her newest single “On The Line” is the perfect launching point. Turek nails the balance between funk/disco with electronica. The percussions are fast on this track but Turek takes her time with her vocals, creating a beautiful dynamic. The overall composition of the track is sick and Turek kills it on the vocals.

Onsen - Peggy Lee
Recommended Song: Peggy Lee
Genre: dream pop
Onsen’s “Peggy Lee” is a dream pop track that melts all the layers of the track into this bundle of synth. On firsthand, this could be a Cascine artist with the light pop yet cosmic, spacey composition. The song itself has this sort of invincibility vibe to it that makes it seem impenetrable.

Twin Peaks - Down In Heaven
Recommended Songs: You Don’t, Keep It Together
Genre: rock n’ roll
Twin Peaks’ “Down In Heaven” showcases yet another side of the band. They started off lo-fi and scuzzy on their 2013 debut, polished up on Wild Onion, and here they’ve added more diverse instrumentation to their classic-rock/punk hybrid sound. They pay homage to their rock heroes here by including bah-bah-bah-bah’s lifted straight from the Velvet Underground’s Who Loves the Sun and riffs that sound exactly like T.Rex. Overall, this is a solid record and I really loved Holding Roses, You Don’t, Keep It Together and Walk to the One You Love.

Woods - City Sun Eater in the River of Light
Recommended Song: Can’t See At All
Genre: psychadelic folk
Using a combintation of funky, envelope-filtered bass, shakers, and dusty guitar riffs, Woods creates a beautiful and soulful LP. This project sounds like a beach party on the shore of a desert oasis, with hints of Southwestern folk elements. If you enjoy funk rhythms and psychadelic rock, you will really enjoy what Woods has to offer on this record. This LP was consistent and provided the right amount of melody, funk, and sunny vibes to be a relisten. Can’t See At All and Creature Comfort are personal favorites.

Free Cake For Every Creature - Talking Quietly of Anything With You
Recommended Song: So Much Strange to Give
Genre: indie rock
From Philly, Free Cake blends very present guitar with a beautifully soft lead vocal that sounds like whispering. This project sounds unmistakingly like it was recorded entirely in a closet of a one-bedroom apartment, with soft, consistent static and very pretty quiet vocals and simple guitar. Some of the songs teeter the edge between lo-fi and a middle school girl singing over her siblings’ guitar riffs. This being said, the project seems self aware of this and even embraces the innocence and intimacy of the style, and in doing so actually creates a somewhat fascinating sound.

title: Featured Artists of the Week:
content:
The Music Department’s top picks of the week! Check out the playlist of our picks: https://open.spotify.com/user/uclaradio/playlist/1qL63cdaN3uZXz6pvnB4Qp


Rogue Wave - Delusions of Grand Fur
Recommended Song: California Bride
Genre: Indie rock, lo-fi


This song gives me some major throwbacks (anyone else listen to “Eyes” or “Lake Michigan” by Rogue Wave?) Honestly with this song, I would not have been able to tell you that it’s Rogue Wave at all. What I like about this song is that it really gives ode to the indie rock of the early 2000s. “California Bride” still manages to capture the innocence of early indie rock and the melodies are solid.

King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard - Nonagon Infinity
Recommended Songs: People Vultures, Gamma Knife
Genre: Psychedelic


The group explores unusual time signatures and wild effects as they explore the idea of a psychedelic rock concept album. Songs bleed into one another making the album truly infinite. Influences of groups like Pink Floyd are evident in the investigation into different time signatures and new sounds.

This album is crazy, in a good way though. It’s full of high energy, and it grasps your attention with every song. You will be banging your head to this non-stop.

Grubby Little Hands - Garden Party
Recommended Song:  Dial Tone
Genre: Psych-indy-dream pop


Super dreamy. The group shows they can lay down hip hop grooves, heavy guitar riffs AND poppy, psychedelic dream fuel. Heavy reverb on vocals shifting from right to left and back again makes for a memorable, ambient feel. Cool!

Morly - EP Collection
Recommended Songs: 4. By the Polo Pond 7. And Sooner Than We Know It…
Genre: dream pop, synth pop, electronic, experimental


I am a huge, huge fan of Cascine and their artists. Morly uses a lot of heavy synths in her music to give it this lethargic feel but some of her songs still have a lightness to them that can still classify them as a dream pop songs. On EP Collection, she has songs with and without vocals, but both kinds are equally good. “By the Polo Pond” really experiments with vocals and a stripped version of dream pop. “And Sooner Than We Know It…” has no vocals but the samples that she use tell a story of their own, even without a vocal narration.

Jared Illiad
Recommended Song: Hustle or Fall
Genre: hip hop


Lyrically meaningful and deeply personal songs. Illiad has an energetic flow with a passionate voice. “Hustle or Fall” is a powerful track about perserverence and family. “Gettin That” has a relatively generic beat with an autotuned hook. Both songs show potential but there is nothing that stands out about the overall sound of the tracks. Despite differences in lyrical content, Illiad sounds a lot like The Game.

Holy Ghost! - Crime Cutz
Recommended Song: Crime Cutz
Genre: disco/funk


Disco revival! “Crime Cutz” is contagiously funky with a gradual buildup. It sustains energy and tension throughout the seven minute track. “Stereotype” and “Footsteps” are more funk, while “Crime Cutz” and “Compass Point” are more purely disco dance songs. Overall a really well-rounded collection of four tracks.

Eskimeaux - Year of the Rabbit
Recommended Song: Year of the Rabbit
Genre: indie folk-pop


“Year of the Rabbit” is a deeply intimate 6-song EP from the notable Brooklyn songwriter Gabrielle Smith. Calm and serene, Smith’s airy vocals compliment the lo-fi, minimalist indie pop instrumentation. More focused and warm than her previous work, the songs are an excellent addition to Eskmeaux’s catalog, and showcase Smith’s continually developing talents. Recommended for fans of Frankie Cosmos, Girlpool, or female indie pop in general.

PUP - The Dream Is Over
Recommended Song: “If This Tour Doesn’t Kill You, I Will”
Genre: Alt/Emo Rock


If you like Grouplove, you’d probably really appreciate this stuff. “If This Tour Doesn’t Kill You, I Will” has a super upbeat groove in it behind the hilarious lyrics. The drummer is totally on point in this, and is what makes this song the most dynamic, I think. The lyrics are funny but powerfully delivered. I could imagine listening to this as an opener at BFD up in Nor Cal or something similar.

title: Spotlight Sunday : The Poetry Beat (Wednesdays @ 7)
content:
Spotlight Sunday is a weekly post where we feature a rad and unique UCLA Radio show that we think people should check out.

One of the curses of that every college student faces is the need to feel deep, and insightful, like you have something powerful and unique to say. A voice in the masses. But we all know that takes a lot of work. So let us tell you a little secret… If you tune into The Poetry Beat on Wednesday’s at 7 pm, DJ Karl will take all the work out of looking deep, and provide everything you need to look sophisticated on your next first date or water cooler conversation.

The Poetry Beat explores the intertwined realms of poetry and music, as if both forms of art are whispering sweet sweet nothings into your ears. Each episode focuses on a single poem, which is then paired with music from an extensive and diverse library in order to reveal the hidden elements of the chosen poems deeper meaning and musicality. DJ Karl has such a subtle and smooth way of completely blowing your mind. He brings light to the muddled fog that meaning hides behind. You are bound to learn something, but in the most refreshing way. Exciting topics, epic poetry, with insight provided? What do you have to lose?

Tune in every Wednesday at 7 pm to experience the wonderful guided tour of meaning and melodic aesthetics that is The Poetry Beat.

title: Op-Ed: Anti-PC Rhetoric, “Feminism is Cancer,” and the First Amendment
content:
Written By : Zach Conner, UCLA Radio Digital Press 

Post Date : 06/02/16

(This essay reproduces explicit language.)

Protesters unravel a banner.

Tuesday’s student protest of Milo Yiannopoulos’ “Feminism is Cancer” event has been reductively charged with devaluing free speech. The issue is far more complex than that. The defense of protest is at the essay’s end, but I encourage you to consider it in its totality.

Imagine a high-level calculus lecture conducted with disregard to the rules and language of calculus. The lecturer has replaced numerals and variables with wingdings, and confuses antidifferentiation with differentiation. Or imagine an architecture lecturer pointing to a window and calling it a “glass-filled wall-hole,” and a column a “stone trunk.” And imagine an ethnographic census that groups citizens by racial epithets.

Every field of study, whether STEM or humanities, is grounded in a linguistic foundation, laboriously set by scholars and always subject to scrupulous internal revision. Gender studies and queer theory are not exempt from this; they are not trivial fads with loosely defined lexicons; they are legitimate academic endeavors centuries in the making. Undervaluations of their veracity and place have arisen largely because these fields have only recently, in the late 20th century, spread to societal consciousness, which tends to react adversely to any disruption of comfortable assumptions. The public is liable to misunderstand new theories on gender and sexuality because the complex language they employ is diluted when detached from the comprehensive totality of original texts. Moreover, the meticulous attention new theory devotes to unpacking historically narrow definitions (e.g. ‘gender’ and ‘sexuality’) is seen as obtuse nitpicking rather than a truly viable reanalysis.

Now, replace those imagined lecture scenarios with a real one, in which feminism (an academic discipline with adjacent social movements) is discussed only with vulgarities and coarsely misappropriated terms. This was the caliber of Milo Yiannopoulos’ “Feminism is Cancer” talk at UCLA on Tuesday, May 31. Its title alone implies not an academic debate but a violent eradication of ‘metastasized’ thought. Yet the event’s organizers, the Bruin Republicans, billed it as part of their commitment to “encouraging ideological diversity and promoting thoughtful debate on campus.” Should this prefatory disclaimer excuse the talk’s callous and incendiary language? For your consideration I have selected a couple Yiannopoulos quotes from the night’s hideous heap, barely paraphrased and without excision of expletives:

“The males involved in “Black Lives Matter” are all skinny, white, and cucked. All the hysterical black women in “Black Lives Matter” are fussy because they’re really lesbians.”

“Teaching is a profession that does not attract the smartest people. It is not a real job. Teachers are fucking idiots and left-wing cunts.”

But with blatant hypocrisy he accuses the left of “shaming, name-calling, silencing, bullying, and nannying.” So the “thoughtful debate” was in effect a sophist’s orgy of ad hominem complaints. Of course, this is Yiannopoulos’ platform: the absolute rejection of political correctness (PC) by absurd and provocative defiance. I recognize that many liberal and conservatives alike interpret political correctness as a tyrannical imposition on the First Amendment. People, understandably, do not like to have their values questioned and they do not like to be told what they should say. When intellectuals are the ones questioning values and pushing for progressive linguistic change, people are even less happy because they perceive it as belittling condescension. Admittedly, professional intellectuals occupy a privileged position in the United States, and so people without the most advanced (and expensive) education should never be expected to show them subservience. But political correctness is not enslaving anyone to pedants. It is better defined (and this is what I mean when I use it) as a responsible acknowledgement of historical transgressions and persisting social inequalities through word choice at the minimum. Thoroughly informed language is the first step in all progress. Rabidly anti-PC rhetoric precludes receptivity to non-normative language and thus erects an impenetrable wall of ignorance and apathy. I want to be clear that I am not criticizing it for failure to conform to some kind of social justice dogma; I am criticizing its embrace of linguistic violence and its disregard for nuanced thought. As Eve Sedgwick more elaborately states in “Queer and Now,” anti-PC rhetoric broadly attempts to

…revoke every available cognitive and institutional affordance for reflection, speculation, experimentation, contradiction, embroidery, daring, textual aggression, textual delight, double entendre, close reading, free association, wit––the family of creative activities that might, for purposes of brevity, be more simply called thought–– they yet stake their claim as the only inheritors, defenders, and dispensers of a luscious heritage of thought that most of them would allow to be read only in the dead light of its pieties and its exclusiveness.

In short, with the pretext of preventing ‘oppressive’ impositions, it reinforces myopic conventions. This is the case not only with Yiannopoulos but South Park’s characterization of “PC Principal” as the stereotypical social justice ‘bro.’ While the show may have some claim to address imperious instances of PC enforcement, it glosses over larger pertinent issues with the same blasé demeanor as Yiannopoulos. Both lionize abrasive humor as a potent critical tool. The loyal audiences are conditioned to adopt this humor in their social and political lives, and its inherent disdain for any discourse not marked by scorn and self-regard debars their potential for open mindedness. Here South Park is mild compared Yiannopoulos, whose Youtube live-feed comment section mirrors his speech more explicitly but with comparable maliciousness:

Note the similarity of these comments to the vitriol that passes for truth in the anonymous forums of 4chan. Its connection to a recent mass shooting evidences how hatred on the web may spill into reality. The violence Yiannopoulos incites has up to this point been limited to the realm of language: he is incontrovertibly a proponent of hate speech. He is an unfortunate proponent of the First Amendment, which can never be legally abused but can legally be an implement of verbal abuse (a real form of abuse). His use for legality, however, ends here. In the talk he follows his endorsement of Donald Trump with the triumphant guarantee: “you’ll be able to say, do, and feel whatever you want!” Exaggerated, but telling nonetheless. Yiannopoulos supports Trump because he wants to ‘liberate’ us from ‘compulsive’ morality.

Hopefully I have constructed a tenable argument so far; now I want to exonerate the anti-Milo protest. Two criticisms have been leveled at those involved:

  1. The protest impeded the entrance to the auditorium at which Milo Yiannopoulos was scheduled/authorized to speak, and therefore infringed on his freedom of speech and the right of his audience to peacefully assemble.
  2. The protest could have better confronted Yiannopoulos by calmly countering him in his Q&A as the Bruin Republicans asked, or by ignoring him altogether.

Regarding the second point, the organizers never intended for this event to be a “thoughtful” and “diverse” discussion, despite their assertions. Look into Yiannopoulos’ history and you will notice the pattern: he riles people up and shuts them down not with rational debate but with disparaging insults. When faced with disagreeable questions he can do nothing but laugh, shrug, and allude to vague, sensational claims. Or he does nothing at all. Accordingly, protesters did not prepare for the futile and tedious task of calm counterargument; and surely they did not expect resistance to change the minds of bigots. The gathering was a conscious refusal to be baited with promises of academic dialogue into a trap of certain hate and a reminder that the fallacy of misplaced scale elevates obvious slander to an academic level at which it cannot contribute. No more than supple compliance could disregard have made this statement; nonchalance is certainly not listed alongside ethics, excellence, work, and commitment in the True Bruin Values. The appeals for ‘respectable’ debate and casual indifference invoke a notion of dignity too disconnected from the political arena to have any real effect. Decorous responses, perhaps, but merely postured retreat, a la Yiannopoulos. It delivered these messages to him, and more importantly it questioned UCLA’s sanctioning of the event.

I understand how conflicted the administration is, obliged by the First Amendment to protect even the most puerile, apolitical platforms. But when true hate, flying under the guise of political discourse, is given an auditorium and fair consideration, it is also authorized to degrade the integrity of our academic community. On this same premise, no white supremacist group would be accepted. Yiannopoulos’ political popularity and ‘respectable’ affiliations should not be allowed to mask the patent parallels between his vile rhetoric and that of organizations with only slightly more transparent agendas of hatred. The administration has called them distinct and leaned on the excuse of legality, which we can view alternatively as a feeble crutch or infallible pillar. Neither viewpoint will alter the Constitution and, as the 80’s and 90’s have shown, we cannot legally bar hate speech from campus without winding up at the Supreme Court. Perhaps through instances like “Feminism is Cancer” the law’s shortcomings embolden us––this event has in fact generated at least latent academic discussion to reaffirm and bolster progressive movements, and importantly it has shown the full but manageable extent to which Donald Trump’s pernicious populism threatens UCLA. Hence I will not end with condemnation, bitterness, or indecision, but rather encouragement. As student protesters we proclaim our voice louder and more human by inconveniently existing in a space where the law must permit hateful assembly and speech; where the law does not immediately advocate for the virtues of language and education, we must.

title: In Studio Performance Roundup // San Holo, Avi Buffalo, HUNNY  (04/25/16 to 05/1/16)
content:
Post Date : 05/04/16

Photo by Derek Khaothong

San Holo came into the studio and played a booming live mix, which included tracks like “We Rise”, his hard-hitting remix of Outkast’s “Ms. Jackson”, and his thumping nostalgic remix of Dre’s “The Next Episode”. In addition, DJ TBD, DJ Maxatrillion, and DJ Fizzy interviewed San Holo about plans for a future full-length EP and his collabs with WhatSoNot and Yellow Claw. San Holo also talked about his unique use of “sparkle” in his songs, claiming that it was a special secret involved in his production that could not be revealed to the public. Although his New Sky Tour has come to an end, keep a look out for a full-length EP to come soon by Heroic Records.

Photo by Jonathan Hays

Avi Buffalo performed an enchanting all-acoustic set for our listeners with tracks like “How Come?” and “So What” on Dj Chai Tea’s show Pillow Talk. He recently played a set at 4th St. Vine with Whisper Kitten on 04/29/16! Avi Buffalo recently joined the new band Litronix, which is due to release their first single soon.

Photo by Regina Napolitano

HUNNY rocked out at the studio with DJ Dirty P & DJ Harry Melrose on their show The Sauce. Not only did our DJ’s interview HUNNY, but HUNNY tweeted out the in-station phone number for callers around the world to answer questions. HUNNY talked about their favorite movies and fans from all over the United States of America announced their desires for HUNNY to return to their cities for another show.They very recently played at The Troubadour at West Hollywood on 04/30/16! As they reiterated on-air, stay tuned for a new album to come soon.

title: Five Female DJs to Watch in 2018
content:
Written by Pamela Crick 

The presence of women in electronic music has typically been limited to the crowd, but times are a-changin’. While electronic music is incredibly inclusive in its fan base, women are now becoming more and more prevalent behind the decks. These five fiery females are providing unique takes on their own subgenre and are paving the way for future generations.

1. REZZ

Genre: Dubstep, Experimental

If you like: Zeds Dead, Deadmau5, Feed Me

Canadian DJ/producer REZZ has been on the scene for a few years now, and has earned herself the number one spot on this list through her unique sound and unmatched visual performances. Her music is hard to categorize, but is certainly dark and minimal with heavy dubstep influences. 2017 marked a milestone for REZZ with the release of her widely successful debut album Mass Manipulation on deadmau5’s label, mau5trap. There’s not many artists out there right now that can be compared to REZZ, and therefore it’s no surprise she’s gained a massive and exponentially growing, cult-like following known as Rezz-bians. This year, she will be performing at Coachella, Electric Forest, and likely many other big name festivals as she cements herself as a staple electronic act for festival lineups. Make sure to stop by and check her out. She’ll be easy to spot, as she will likely be wearing her iconic trippy glasses.

2. Yaeji 

Genre: Techno

If you like: Jessy Lanza, DJ Seinfeld, FKA Twigs

Newcomer Yaeji seemed to emerge overnight and is clearly on a strong upwards trajectory. 2017 was the year of Yaeji. With the release of her two impressive EPs, she has set the tone for her career, earning her the respect and praise from many well respected publications. Even though she is releasing music pretty damn quickly, nothing about her music seems rushed or unintentional. Her silky voice floats in and out of the melodic bass lines, often times switching between English and Korean. The production of her music is seamless and fluid, creating the perfect balance of dance music and darkness for the listener. Highly recommend playing her stuff when driving home in the Uber at 3am.

3. Flava D

Genre: UK Garage, Bass House

If you like: AC Slater, Preditah, Malaa

Not new by any means, but it’s time people learned of Flava D. Obviously UK Garage is not as familiar to us American listeners, but it has always been a genre I have enjoyed and followed closely for a few years. Flava D is one of the leading artists in the UK Garage scene today. She brings the heat with high energy vocal samples and powerful drops. Her style is unexpected, constantly evolving and sure to liven up any dance floor. Her collaboration project with Royal T and DJ Q, aptly named TQD, is also a necessary listen for any garage fan. Her music is great, but her mixing is even better. Check out her Mixmag In the Lab session here,

4. Hannah Wants 

Genre: House

If you like: Low Steppa, Sonny Fodera, Chris Lorenzo

Established house DJ and producer Hannah Wants has performed at club shows and festivals around the world. By no means a newcomer, with the resurgence of house music in general, it is only right to include her in this list. She is one of the only well known female DJs in the modern day house scene, producing music with jackin’ beats and deep bass lines that will be sure to get you moving. She has many collaborations with Chris Lorenzo and is also performing at Coachella this year. Make sure you check her out when she’s in town, if you’re down to get down. 

5. Whipped Cream 

Genre: Trap, Dubstep

If you like: Ekali, RL Grime, Luca Lush

Whipped Cream is a breath of fresh air in a subgenre that has gotten lazy and redundant over the past few years, relying on the same drops (*cough* Goosebumps - NGHTMRE remix *cough*) over and over again, Whipped Cream pushes the envelope with lively and goosebump inducing (irony intended) sets. Unapologetically confident and original, Whipped Cream is currently making a name for herself as she headbangs into 2018. Her style is forward thinking and unique, with hard hitting drops and stimulating samples. Any trap fan will fall in love with Whipped Cream. Keep an eye out for this LA-based artist, as she will surely be appearing at some more Brownies and Lemonade type events in the new year.

title: The “One and Done” Rule
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman 

The “one and done” rule have come under a lot of scrutiny in recent weeks. The one and done rule have been a polarizing rule ever since it was implemented by the NBA. When it was introduced, no one expected the grand effect it would have. One and done players, though, have become the primary talk of college basketball over the last decade. However, I believe that it needs to stay. What people do not realize about the one and done rule is that it offers players a unique opportunity to receive a college degree even if they leave school early. Most people would agree that the players deserve to be paid, but determining that is very difficult. The solution of the NBA eliminating the one and done rule, though, is not the right answer.

Players who have been one and done are Anthony Bennett, Greg Oden, Xavier Henry, Josh Selby, Johnny Flynn, and many more. What all of these guys have in common is that their NBA careers did not go as planned. But by going to college for that one year, they had the opportunity to go back and pursue their degree on their own terms. By creating this rule, the NBA allowed the opportunity for these men to, rather than go straight to the draft and then flop as players, go to school after their careers on a full scholarship and get degrees. By giving these men the opportunity to eventually earn degrees, a new career path is created after their playing careers. In addition, players can go whenever to finish their college degree. So, for a player like Anthony Davis, for example, once he decides to hang up his sneakers for good, he can go back to Kentucky and complete his degree. A player who flopped in the NBA but does not have this opportunity is someone like James Lang. Lang skipped a year of college and instead went straight to the NBA draft. If given the option of going to college to play basketball, it can be assumed someone like Lang would take that opportunity. By having these kids, even if it is just for a year, at college before going to the NBA, it can change their lives in the long term.

Mark Emmert,the president of the NCAA, has said he doesn’t want players to go to play college ball if they are only there just to get to the NBA. I strongly disagree with his take. The one and done player has not only improved the product, but also sometimes come back for a second year that was not originally planned. A prime example of a player who came back for a second year that no one expected to and who then improved his draft stock and took the next step is Russell Westbrook. After his freshman year, Westbrook truly needed that second year to take the next step as a player. By encouraging the one and done players, guys like Westbrook ended up staying a second year at school. The one and done rule has done more to help these players then hurt them.

I am not saying the players should not be paid. The players should be paid, and most are under the table. The NCAA has been called the most corrupt system for a reason. Eventually, they will figure it out (I hope.) But eliminating the one and done rule is not a solution to the problem, as most of the players who enter into the NBA draft flame out.

title: Best Five Musical  Acts to See at Air + Style
content:
Written by Natalie Benudiz 

Picture this: it’s March 3. Midterms are over. You’re dancing to Phoenix because you’ve just realized you actually like them. In the distance, skateboarders. I’m two months behind on this meme, but just roll with it because it’s exactly what you should be doing in two weeks at Air and Style.

Don’t show up in a flower crown, because this year’s Air and Style defies the paradigm of disappointing lineups and mainstream pop giants. Wear whatever you want, because you’re not going for the scene - you’re going for the diverse range of acts that have already proven their musical prowess. Of the 20 bands stacked on this lineup, here’s the quick and dirty guide to the five artists that need to be your priority. 

1. Phoenix

They’re the Taylor Swift of the alt-rock world, and this isn’t even a pleasure to feel guilty about. Their colorful, glossy melodies are familiar yet pleasant. It’s shimmery, it’s fruity, it’s just fun; they sound the way champagne tastes, so drink up. 

Tracks to check out before the festival: “Rome,” “Ti Amo,”and “Trying To Be Cool.”

2. Mura Masa

If you’re still bitter about missing him at Bruin Bash because CEC can’t get their shit together when it comes to ticketing systems, now is your chance! Honestly, though, I rolled my eyes at yet another electro-producer-beat-whatever. When I decided to sit down and give Mura Masa a try, I finally understood the hype. It’s undeniably dancy with just the right amount of funky, and it would be hard not to have a good time dancing around to this in a crowd of 5,000 of your best friends.

Tracks to check out before the festival: “What if I Go?” “…Girl” and “Firefly.”

3. Washed Out

 It’s summer somewhere in Europe and you’re at a kickback in a beach villa belonging to someone you’ve never met. Wait, no, you’re in the middle of DTLA at a music and snowboarding festival? In reality, you’re taking a breather in between sets from the smorgasbord of different genres. Washed Out’s chill, exotic vibes will cleanse your palate after headbanging yourself into oblivion at together PANGEA.

Tracks to check out before the festival: “Hard to Say Goodbye” and “It Feels Alright.”

4. together PANGEA

 Though they’ve been around since 2008, every time I see them it’s as if I’m listening for the first time. As artists, their strength lies in their ability to take angst and transform it into clean melodies that leave a sweet-and-sour taste in your mouth, making you beg for more catchy choruses. Their sunny garage punk vibe perfectly compliments the rambunctiousness of Twin Peaks, and I really wouldn’t be surprised if they teamed up for a song or two during the festival. 

Tracks to check out before the festival: “Badillac” (it’s a BANGER), “Money On It,” and “River.”

5. Twin Peaks

The last time Twin Peaks played on the West Coast, I was still getting A’s in my GEs. If anything, you should be going to this festival just to see boy-wonder Clay Frankel in the flesh. Otherwise, you should be going to their set to experience the madness of a Twin Peaks show. Their garage-Rolling Stones sound is a pure shot of adrenaline into your ear that you feel through your whole body. Catch me at their set crowd surfing away from all my problems. 

Tracks to check out before the festival: “Butterfly,” “Mirror of Time,” and “Flavor.”(Read what happened at the last Twin Peaks concert HERE.)

To close, let me hit you with some math, because school is in session: 

1 Air and Style ticket = $149

20 shows = 1 A+S ticket

$149 = 20 shows

1 show = $7.45

LESS THAN $10 PER PERFORMANCE IS CHEAPER THAN FAT SAL’S. Even if you failed Econ 11, Air and Style is clearly a better investment than most of the other festivals happening this season.

So, did I convince you?

title: 10 Acts You Cannot Miss at Lightning in a Bottle 2018
content:
Written by Pamela Crick

Photo courtesy of Michael Roush (@michaelroushphotography)

Lightning in a Bottle is by far the most diverse electronic music festival out there right now. If you’re headed up there this Memorial Day weekend, don’t stick to what you know. Branch out and embrace all of what LiB has to offer! Here is a list of ten performances from all types of genres that you should pencil into your schedule this year

Zhu

Let’s kick off this list with a crowd favorite, Zhu. Steven Zhu has cemented himself as one of the best and relatively new producers in the electronic music world. If you haven’t heard of him yet, get to know him. With collaborations from Ekali to Skrillex, Zhu has proved to his fans that he is as versatile as he is unique. His performances are much more than just incredible music, combining dark cinematic themes with surreal visual effects. Zhu is also one of the most popular Asian-American artists paving the way for a new generation of electronic producers, highlighting diversity and breaking free from the mold of what it means to be a DJ.

The Glitch Mob

Glitch Mob is probably the most traditional “LiB” artist on this list. They’re likely to play a closing set this year, so get ready to see people dancing on speakers, twirling neon hula-hoops and losing their minds to the distinctive sound of the one and only “Glitch Mob.” With a fantastic blend of hip hop influences and thumping electronic rhythms, the Glitch Mob will perform one unforgettable set.

NAO

Need a break from the constant pounding bass? I probably won’t, but I’m still extremely excited to catch NAO at LiB this year. You’ve probably heard the song “Firefly” by our Grammy nominated Bruin Bash alumni, Mura Masa. Well, that’s NAO’s voice on that hit song! NAO is a talented vocalist with a refreshing new take on modern RnB. Her phenomenal production value paired with her unique voice will make for one powerful performance.

MK

Martin Kinchen, professionally known as MK, has been hitting the decks since the 90’s. Even though he’s been a staple in house music for decades, he’s showing no sign of slowing down. His recent release, “17,” currently number one in the UK dance charts, proves that his sound is timeless and universal. Step back in time to experience some real house music with MK at LiB this year!

The Black Madonna

The Black Madonna is proving to the world that a DJ is a true artist. Her sets are dynamic, seamless and incredibly diverse, pulling from countless genres from disco to techno. I guarantee you will dance your a** off at the Black Madonna. Her sets are straight up parties, where you will find her fans belting along to classic house anthems or getting down to a song you’ve never heard before.

KRANE

For those who are craving some trap during their weekend at Lightning in a Bottle, head on over to KRANE’s set and get your fill. He’s actually performed at UCLA before last year at the Brownies and Lemonade event. If you missed him then, don’t miss him again! His sets are fueled with high energy remixes and hard hitting drops, so let’s get headbanging!

Sango

One of my personal favorites, Sango, combines Brazilian sounds with American trap inspired beats. His songs are layered and complex and have an impressive track record of collabs from Goldlink to TaKu. Soulection’s Sango will provide a fun yet thoughtful and unique set.

YokoO

Transport yourself to Burning Man with ethereal and atmospheric vibes from globe-trotter YokoO. Close your eyes and dance around as YokoO takes you on a musical journey through time and space. For those of you that want a taste of the desert at LiB, make sure you check out YokoO.

Walker & Royce

Coming off a recent sold-out show at Sound Nightclub, it just felt right to include Dirtybird boys Walker & Royce on this list. They are the masterminds behind the tech-house crowd favorite “Take Me To Your Leader,” and it will be impossible to stand still at Walker & Royce’s set!

Bleep Bloop

“Bleep Bloop? What kind of name is Bleep Bloop?” you might ask. At least, that’s what I asked when he performed at LiB back in 2016. The whimsical name was intriguing to me, and I was pleasantly surprised that I convinced my friends to come check him out with me. His sound is definitely not your typical electronic set, as he plays most of his own music with a heavy emphasis on computer noises. Whether you enjoy it or not, you won’t experience anything quite like Bleep Bloop!

Lightning in a Bottle 2018 might be the best lineup they’ve ever had. Besides Anderson .Paak, there are many other must-see acts that will be performing this Memorial Day weekend. Who are you most excited to see? Also, if you haven’t gotten your tickets yet, they are on sale NOW! Get them here and get stoked!

title: A Love Letter to Live Music
content:
Written by Emily Zheng 

You’re supposed to roll your hips in time

You’re supposed to see your age rewind

You’re supposed to pull me like the sun pulls the earth

I’m belting my heart out to “If You Didn’t See Me” by JR JR. I look at my beautiful friend as we dance to the tune, smiles plastered on our faces. This is our celebration of youth, our anthem for reckless abandon.

Ever since I went to my first concert two years ago, I’ve been addicted to the movement of live music, how it puts you in that late night vulnerability. I always end up swapping secrets with the friends who go with me. The collective energy of the crowd shamelessly singing off-key. The timeless magic of dancing to your favorite songs in person.

At my last concert, I remember my friend Claire grinning, “You don’t know how much I needed this.” Hearing that opening song, I realized that I did. We both sought to forget all the petty worries we normally obsess over. We wanted hair tangled, sweat sticking to our skin, boundless silliness. We wanted to dance until we were dumb.

Besides forgoing all the mundane problems, concerts are about remembering. Seeing just how booming and vibrant life can be. Live music forces me to look at all the small wonders through a magnifying glass. And then, I become the girl with this big, silly smile on her face like she’s fearless. Present. Things might not always be okay, but this moment is hers. No one can take that away.

I’m at a Capital Cities concert. I’m screaming the lyrics and dancing with an energy usually meant for solo dance parties in my room. A man approaches me: “Oh my god, I love your enthusiasm. You’re awesome,” and we high-five. I beam back at him. As I reflect on the night, I know this is what I want to be: larger than life, unapologetic, free. His words are a small token for my shamelessness, and I let myself live audaciously. I let myself take up space.

When you strip back all the expectations, who we are becomes fuzzy. I’m a passionate writer. Asian American. But I’m also a girl who likes taking pictures of her friends, eating chili lime potato chips, and writing long emails. Die-hard romantic. Concert enthusiast. Self-proclaimed philosopher of existential questions.

We spend so much timing trying to become who we should be rather than letting who we are flourish. Live music has given me the push to seek authenticity. When I’m carelessly singing to my favorite songs with my best friends, I do not have to fulfill anyone’s assumptions. I’m no longer the crazy best friend. I’m just me, with all of my contradictions and idiosyncrasies.

Sometimes, all you need is something as simple as live music to find yourself. I’m always going to overthink situations and obsess over details, but for this one night, for these few songs, I am electric. I’m filling the present with gorgeous melody and joy and spirit. I don’t know all the answers, but that’s okay, as long as I’m still asking questions.

But there is something that I do know, with all the certainty in my heart: In this moment, despite all the hurt and turbulence in the world, I am happy.

title: Lightning in a Bottle 2018 // Lineup Release
content:
Written by Pamela Crick

The highly anticipated music and arts festival Lightning in a Bottle is back! The recent release of yet another fantastic lineup boasts Bruin Bash alumni Anderson .Paak, the mysterious and electrifying Zhu and IDM innovators the Glitch Mob. Featuring an incredibly diverse mix of electronic from trap to techno, this year’s LiB is sure to attract fans from all spectrums of the EDM world. Check it out below, and stay tuned for a more in depth review of the lineup this coming week!

Join the four day celebration this Memorial Day weekend (May 23 - May 28 2018) in Bradley, CA. Only a 3 hour drive from UCLA, LiB is located at the picturesque Lake San Antonio, great for camping, enjoying yoga and dancing late into the night. Being an LiB veteran myself, I can easily say this is one of the most original and progressive music festivals out there. Party guilt-free, as LiB is known for its sustainability and social awareness, but make sure to also play your part by bringing along your own water bottle. Always unexpected and always fire, the music at LiB does not disappoint.

If you’re already headed to Coachella, check out the Do-Lab for a taste of what LiB is all about. Make sure to bring your camping gear, festival attire and good vibes!

Tickets are on sale January 18th at 10am! Prices start at $305. Festival Passes include tent camping. Get them here!

title: Five Fuckboys That’ll Make You Say “I Don’t Know, He Means Well…”
content:
Written by Tiernan O’Neill

1. Infinity Scarf Fuckboy

His name is probably something bland but spelled weird, like Will with one “L” or Jack with no “C.” He’s from Orange County, but all of his social media profiles say “LA” with the palm tree emoji. Oh yeah, and he has waaaay more Instagram followers than you and it’s probably deserved. His feed is a stunning compilation of pictures of beaches, his designer dogs, and him and his impossibly hot friends posing in front of a bevy of ~fun~ walls. He’s an ardent liberal, but probably doesn’t believe in bisexuality. You realize he’s a fuckboy when you catch your reflection in his mirror-lens Ray Bans while he takes photos of his meal at brunch. But you won’t call it off until he sincerely recommends Milk & Honey to you.

2. Joan Didion Fuckboy

You met him in your discussion for Gender Studies, you were instantly attracted to the way he waxed on about Judith Butler’s Gender Trouble. Your dates mostly comprise of going to the Hammer and Profeta. He’ll send you the soundtrack to Call Me By Your Name and say that it reminds him of you. You think this guy may be the one! Well, that is until he ghosts you two days later. If you’re reading this, text me back Reid. Please.

3. Phillips Exeter Fuckboy

You’re think you’re charmed by his prepster style, but really he’s just realizing your repressed high school obsession with Ezra Koenig. Because of this, you overlook A LOT of red flags. Like when he talks about being kinda ~edgy~ because he chose to go to a public school instead of an Ivy, or like when complains that no one knows what a clambake is here. Which, for the record, is when you cook shellfish in the fucking sand. EW! Anyways this WASPy prick will tell you two months down the line that he’s emotionally unavailable and just can’t do anything serious right now. Oh yeah, and he gave you mono.

4. THAT ONE FUCKBOY WHO ONLY GIVES ME A SMIDGE OF GUAC AT CHIPOTLE

FUCK YOU SAUL. I’M NOT PAYING $1.80 FOR A TEASPOON OF AVOCADO.

5. Plug Fuckboy

His name is Mike, or maybe Jared. You both know that you’re only in it for weed and y’all are both okay with it. He smokes you out with Blue Dream and then you watch Courtney Barnett music videos together. It’s nice, he’s nice. He might not be the fuckboy in this situation. Damn. Am I a fuckboy? …I should text Jared back.

The Person Who Wrote This Fuckboy

So I think I realized that I, myself, am a fuckboy. Maybe I should try and improve my interpersonal relationships with other people. I think I’m gonna delete Bumble, Tinder, Grindr, Scruff, Jack’d, Chappy, and Christian Mingle, and just focus on myself. Maybe I’ll go on a vacation, that’d be nice. Or maybe I’ll move to Maine, open up a nice stationary shop, and sell knick-knacks too. I’ll just be able to finally be myself, ya know?

Oh shit. Reid just texted me back!!

title: Wow! Straight Woman Can’t Stop Gushing About Call Me By Your Name, Still Feels ‘Uncomfortable’ Around Lesbian Roommate
content:
Written by Lillian Stanwick 

*WARNING: Satirical content ahead, proceed with a sense of humor.*

Straight female, Kelsey, just saw Call Me By Your Name for the first time last week, and wow! She cannot stop talking about how hot she thinks Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet are.

“Timothée’s acting was so amazing! The scene at the end definitely made me cry. Their love was just so beautiful!” she mentioned to everyone at hot yoga last Sunday.

“Definitely snubbed for the Oscar, IMO.”

When asked how her queer roommate, Jane, liked the film, Kelsey ignored the question and instead complained about how “awkward” the living situation is.

“It’s just really weird…I didn’t know she was gay when I agreed to live with her. She really should have told me!”

When asked to elaborate, Kelsey stated, first in a whisper, then in a defensive shout, that “sometimes being around her makes me feel really uncomfortable, I just don’t want her to try any of her gay stuff on me!”

Going into detail on a specific incident that made her uncomfortable, Kelsey vented about the following:

“Last week, Jane told me she liked my shirt – which totally crossed a line! I just know that means she’s constantly staring at my boobs…so creepy!”

Kelsey, who makes sure to remind Jane that she is 100 percent straight “at least four times a week, just in case,” is also convinced that Elio and Oliver would have never ended up together had she been there.

“Elio wouldn’t have even been attracted to Oliver if Marzia wasn’t such a bore. If it were me instead of her, Elio and I definitely would have ended up living together on a vineyard by the end of the film. I’m clearly much prettier and way more interesting than Marzia.”

The business/econ major, whose favorite position happens to be missionary, “mainly because it’s the only one I’ve tried,” recently posted a tweet calling the peach scene from Call Me By Your Name “an important piece of art.” Yet, she still can’t seem to wrap her head around lesbian sex.

“Like do they actually do the scissoring thing? How does that work? I mean, they definitely can’t cum from just that, right? They probably use a strap-on…”

Kelsey, who has never heard of Boys Don’t Cry and thinks Blue Is the Warmest Color is “a popular lesbian porno,” found the fellatio in Call Me By Your Name, “not weird at all.”

And yet, Kelsey still can’t stand to be in the same room as Jane and her girlfriend.
