“They’re like all over each other… and PDA is so gross. My boyfriend Chad and I NEVER kiss in front of other people. Unless we’re at a party, or a restaurant, or school, or even Whole Foods sometimes…but that’s totally different!” she insists.

When asked if Chad had seen the film, Kelsey explained that her beloved boyfriend of two and half weeks refused to go see it with her.

“Yeah, Chad said he didn’t want to watch two dudes kiss, which is totally understandable, and definitely doesn’t mean that he’s homophobic or anything…”

If anything, Chad is super cool with lesbians, Kelsey insists:

“He keeps asking to have a three way, and I’m down, just as long as I don’t have to kiss or touch the other girl because, like I keep telling Jane, I’m 100 percent straight.”

title: Outside Lands 2018 Review
content:
article and photographs by Ariana Momnoon

Golden Gate Park in San Francisco was illuminated with music, art, food, and thousands of people on Augusts 10, 11th, and 12th at this year’s Outside Lands. The eclectic music performances, interactive areas such as Grasslands, and an abundance of delicious food options dominated the park last weekend, and we are here to highlight our favorite moments from the weekend!


Music

Chicano Batman

Chicano Batman’s set at Outside Lands reminded me why this festival is such a gem. The psychedelic rock infused band from Los Angeles gave the festival a tremendously warm and energetic beginning. Songs such as “Black Lipstick” and “Magma” had the crowd dancing with one another and embracing the beauty of Outside Lands. Every moment of Chicano Batman’s set reverberated with colors and life.

Mac Demarco

I’ve seen Mac Demarco live too many times for it to be okay, but let me just say, Mac’s performance at Outside Lands on the quaint Sutro Stage reassured me that my devout attendance any time he plays a set is necessary. The crowd at Mac Demarco had to be my favorite during the whole weekend. Every fan at the stage was ready to mosh in a friendly manner, scream every lyric to “Ode to Viceroy,” and simply have a good time with the people around them. The girl next to me had come to the set alone, joined our dance squad, bought me a beer, and sang along to “Freaking Out the Neighborhood” with all her heart, and this is all due to Mac Demarco creating an atmosphere that was simply so sweet and tender.


Food

Oh my. The amount of absurdly delicious food available at Outside Lands was ridiculous. From Thai noodles to beautifully large pieces of pizza, I was in heaven. The food item that stuck out to me most was CAULIPOWER, a gluten-free pizza option with crust entirely made from cauliflower. This healthy pizza option had me hooked the moment I tried it. It was flavorful, light, and good for me, which I found to be the coolest part about this pizza. This is a pizza brand I definitely recommend for my gluten-free gals and guys


Interactive Areas

Grasslands

Outsidelands featured various spots for people to explore when they wanted to stimulate their brains in between sets. One of the newest interactive areas was Grasslands, a space dedicated to the appreciation and education of marijuana. Although the vendors at Grasslands were not sampling cannabis products, they still gave information about the benefits of such products and allowed people to try things without cannabis in them. This space was perfect when we wanted to just stroll through a Greenhouse and learn more about the benefits of using marijuana.

See more photos from Outsidelands 2018 below!

title: Jenny Hval and the Struggle to Define Art Pop
content:
Written by Clea Wurster

Art pop, as defined by none other than the reputable Wikipedia, is “a loosely defined style of pop music influenced by pop art’s integration of high and low culture, and which emphasizes the manipulation of signs, style, and gesture over personal expression.”

To me, it has always seemed like an ironically inaccessible form of music, that despite its best efforts to ground itself in the true culture of the average person, it still feels uppity in some way, possibly pretentious.

This imagined, or real, condescension is off putting for a lot of reasons and until I recognized the capacity of art pop to explore topics outside the realm of more generic, easily palatable genres, I couldn’t push past the inevitable feeling of unworthiness and distance that it can elicit in its listeners. Yes, art pop requires a bit of digging and some persistence, but it doesn’t require anyone to be intimately acquainted with the topics of exploration that often preoccupy its composition.

Plenty of artists who can be classified by this label take liberties within their music to consider broad subjects, often relating to the reality of human existence. But this form, uniquely unlimited by norms or expectations, is able to push past traditional understandings of what a piece of music should or can be and delves deeply into philosophical experiments in thought and art, all without pushing listeners too far away. Artists like Perfume Genius sometimes discuss less abstract topics, like adulthood, but in equally artful manners to artists with broader more, enigmatic concerns.

While it can be disconcerting and even distressing to hit play on a track that forces interaction between a listener and a weighty topic, the genre has incredible flexibility and power to involve its listeners in its project.

Up until very recently, over the course of the last year or so, my opinion has changed on the value of art pop. Initially, I shied away from music that might force me into a deep existential crisis, spinning out from the mention of  my mortality or human failure, but now I welcome the opportunity to splash around in topics that often require a deep dive, so deep in fact, it feels unlikely that it would be possible to resurface.

Or maybe, as I’ve immersed myself into a bastion of academia, elite condescension and inaccessibility, I’ve simply come closer to valuing that which art pop represents and upholds. But what’s important for the purpose of this article is not whether I have become a star member of the dreaded class of academic elite, but rather how I came to respect, love and explore this self-contradictory genre of music.

I came into this new understanding through the prolific work of Jenny Hval, and her 2016 album Blood Bitch. An album supposedly about vampires, as Hval states in the beginning moments of the track “The Great Undressing,” to which someone replies, “That’s so basic,” as the first lyrics come into the scene, “Late capitalism, it looks like unrequited love.” But really, the album is all about periods - no, not the punctuation marks. Vampires for Hval are a symbol for women, and display a continuation of her album’s long fixation with the female body and menstruation.

In the same vein as many albums within the genre, Blood Bitch on first listen feels surreal, and above my intellectual capabilities, but with repetition and concentration I soon came to love the album and regard the principle track, “Conceptual Romance,” as a favorite.

This high regard for the Norwegian artist meant I was ecstatic to hear news of a recent release. The single “Spells,” released on April 11, is the first hint of an album to come entitled The Long Sleep. Presumably, this album will tackle a similarly complex human issue: death. But for an album, and more specifically a single, about such a seemingly bleak topic, the music is pleasantly upbeat.

With lyrics like, “You are your own disco ball/Hovering above you like a comforting reminder/That not even you belong to you,” the song leaps into a lighter, optimistic view of mortality. Everything about the music is an open invitation for the consideration of something generally regarded as dark and dreary.

The piano is uplifting at the beginning, mixed into overwhelmingly jazzy tones with a saxophone that continues pulling you up into the music and preparing you for what’s to come.

A steady drum beat joins in with a pop-ish feel, forcing you to bop your head along. Then, the song hits its peak and Hval’s characteristic speak-singing soft voice with a high-pitch comes in to replace the saxophone and follow the piano keys. Something about it feels like an 80’s cocktail bar, but it’s a marked departure from the solemn, nearly angsty vibes that Hval generally unleashes in her music.

Her continual high pitched holds give the song a light, young feel despite the harshness of the lyrics “you will not be awake for long,” before coming to its conclusion with some light scatting - only furthering the jazz references. Her voice speaks softly in the last few lines of the song as the music fades and the saxophone returns to complete the song full-circle.

Hval has impressed yet again and pushed the edges of her style, attempting something new and wholly successful with “Spells.”

title: How UMBC Saved the PAC 12
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman

After the first day of the tournament, the talk was that the PAC 12 was the worst conference. All the PAC 12 teams didn’t even make it to the weekend. Arizona got blown out by Buffalo, UCLA looked lost against St. Bonaventure, and Arizona State couldn’t break down Syracuse’s zone. With all this being known, the committee had looked like geniuses for leaving out USC. That was the story entering the games on Friday. Now no one will ever remember that the PAC 12 was terrible in this tournament. The biggest upset in the college basketball happened this weekend, and saved the PAC 12 from all the shame it faced.

UMBC ,being the first 16 seed to win against a 1, will forever be the story of this tournament. People will wonder how it happened: was UMBC under-seeded, was UVA overseeded? All of these questions and story lines are what will be associated with this tournament. The PAC 12’s abysmal showing will forever be overshadowed by this. This tournament, no matter who wins, who makes the Final 4, and what other Cinderella stories there are, will always be about UMBC. UMBC did the impossible. I truly believed it was impossible for a 1 to lose to a 16. It just seemed so difficult. Whenever there was a great 16 seed, they would be over-hyped,and the 1 seed would just blow them out. This year, it was different.

 A team that lost by over 40 to Albany around 2 months ago beat UVA, a team that won the ACC regular-season title and then the ACC tournament. UMBC, no matter how much further it went in this tournament, will always be the biggest winner of the opening weekend. Those players will forever be remembered in the record books. They did the impossible. The David truly beat the Goliath.

As PAC 12 looks at it though, this upset saved them from all the negative media that was on the way, as UVA has taken it off their hands.

title: Attention UCLA Students: Enter To Win a Chance To Perform at LiB!
content:
Written by Pamela Crick

Are you a huge fan of Beats Antique? Are you in love with this year’s Lightning in a Bottle lineup? Have you always dreamed of performing at a music festival? Well, here’s your chance! Do LaB and Beats Antique are offering fans the chance to win a Lightning in a Bottle Festival Pass and an opportunity to perform in The Beats Antique Lighting Orchestra. All artists and performers are encouraged to submit their video audition by May 7, playing Beats Antique’s popular hit, “Beauty Beats.” This contest is an excellent chance for underexposed musicians and performers across North America to demonstrate their skills to gain real recognition at a world renowned music festival! This is just another way in which this festival goes above and beyond to become one of the most inclusive festivals in the country. Find more details on the event here.

Submissions start April 10 and will continue through May 7. Two winners total (1 musician & 1 performing artist) will be chosen by Beats Antique, Grand Artique, and Do LaB on the basis of musical ability, originality, vibe, and showmanship to perform at LIB 2018!

Submission Form

http://lightninginabottle.org/forms/view.php?id=49864

Grand Prize

  • Performing live at LIB with Beats Antique Lightning Orchestra at the Grand Artique Stage
  • 1 LIB 4-Day Festival Pass for First Place Musician  

  • 1 LIB 4-Day Festival Pass for First Place Performance Artist

Contest Qualifications

  • Submit an original video of you playing “Beats Antique - Beauty Beats”
  • Must be 18+ years of age to enter
  • Contest open to North Americans only
  • Travel & Accommodations are not included
  • Must be available to play at Lightning in a Bottle Sunday, May 27, 2:30-4am (technically Sunday but really Saturday late night set) on Grand Artique’s stage

Submissions and voting close at 11:59pm PDT on Monday, May 7. The winner will be announced on Friday, May 11 at 2pm.

title: UCLA RADIO watches LAFC vs NYCFC (5/14/2018)
content:
By Sahej Verma

This past weekend, I went to cover LAFC vs NYCFC at the brand new Banc of California Stadium. It was an amazing experience and I got to see the game from the Press Box. LAFC is a new expansion team of the Major League Soccer and this is their first season. Located at Exposition Park, the Banc of California Stadium is a site to behold.

Both sides on the day featured some major names in soccer. For LAFC, their number 10, Carlos Vela, a Mexican international was the star attraction and for NYCFC, David Villa, a World Cup winner with Spain.

The game got off to a fast start with both sides attempting to put quick moves together but it was a VAR (Video Assistant Referee) decision that won NYCFC a penalty. Veteran, David Villa stepped up to take it. The LAFC keeper, Tyler Miller dived on the correct side but Villa headed home the deflection. LAFC were back on equal terms through an own goal as the first half ended.

In the second half, LAFC took the lead through Vela. The crowd erupted and the energy was palpable. In the last 20 minutes of the game, NYCFC were attacking and LAFC were on the back foot. Ismael Tajouri-Shradi, a substitute for NYCFC, scored the equalizer. The game ended 2-2.

After the game, I had the opportunity to go to the Press Conference where Bob Bradley, the head coach of LAFC and Patrick Vieira, head coach of NYCFC shared their views from the game. In addition to the coaches, I was also in the company of professional sports writers such as LA Times writer Kevin Baxter.

NYCFC head coach Patrick Vieira

I cannot believe that LAFC has just started playing, the passionate fans, the stadium, the chants; Los Angeles has welcomed the team with open arms.

DJ Sahej himself!

title: Why the PAC 12 Network is to Blame for the PAC 12’s Failures
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman

Do any of you not have Spectrum? Have you ever just wanted to watch PAC 12 games but seen it was on PAC 12 Network, so you knew your provider does not have it? This is the life of anyone of who does not use Spectrum. PAC 12 Network can only be seen on Spectrum, so most people do not watch the games that are televised on it. All a fan is left with is following a GameCast or Box Score. You never truly get an understanding of what happens in the game. And you do not learn anything about the teams.  

What about fans along the East Coast? Even for those that have Spectrum, most do not have the PAC 12 Network. You have to pay an extra fee to get it on the East Coast, for the few fans that have interest in the Conference of Champions. It is not growing a fan base, but rather killing it.

What I am getting at is that the lack of exposure to PAC 12 Network and lack of broadcasting of PAC 12 games is what is to blame for Selection Sundays like this year’s. Most fans argued for a small school being robbed of an NCAA Tournament bid over the likes of the PAC 12 schools that got overlooked. The reason for all this? No one outside of the PAC 12 schools watch these games.

The PAC 12 Network is the worst network of all the major conferences. BIG 10 has its own channel that is on every provider, same with SEC. BIG 12 and ACC have deals with ESPN to make sure all of their games are on watchespn.com. The PAC 12 Network only has one provider producing its games, and most fans of the sport don’t even own that channel. If the PAC 12 Network was on every cable provider I guarantee teams like USC would be dancing right now. UCLA would not be traveling to Dayton. Arizona would be a top 3 seed. All of these do not happen though, because no one watches PAC 12 basketball.

As someone from the East Coast, the going joke is that PAC 12 Network is a myth. No one actually knows it exists. Every major sports bar does not have it. Every home does not have it. Every major fan of the sport does not believe it exists over there, since there is no exposure. If the PAC 12 Network would be put on Verizon, Direct TV, and Optimum, days like this year’s Selection Sunday would never happen again.

In order to regain relevance, it is simple: just release your network to all the providers and let people enjoy it.

title: Giannis is Bonkers!
content:
Written By: Aidan Donahue, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 12/10/16

On his last international trip as President of the United States, Obama spoke in Greece about democracy. He touched on ways in which we are united, highlighting the fact that we’re all cheering for Giannis Antetokounmpo.

In a time where seemingly no one can agree on anything, it seems like everyone is excited about the Greek Freak. The 6’11” power forward/point guard/center/overall basketball menace is smashing the limits of a new era pioneering positional flexibility.

Giannis serves as the young Buck’s lead guard and primary shot blocker.  He who-will-not-be-pronounced-correctly is leading the team in points (22 per game), rebounds (8.3), blocks (2.1), and steals (1.9), and is a close second in assist (6). He is the only player in the league with these averages, a testament to his elite versatility. This allows him to make plays few others are capable of.

Last week against the Magic, Giannis recorded a triple-double with 20 points, 10 rebounds, 10 assists, 3 blocks and 5 steals.  This has been done 5 times in NBA history since the NBA started recording blocks in the 1973-1974 season. The last player to do so was Andrei Kirilenko in 2007.

This versatility is most evident on plays in which he gets the block after helping on the weak side, grabs the rebound, takes it full court in 4 dribbles, and finishes with a nasty Euro step. The combination of length, athleticism, timing, and handles is rare in the league.

Giannis has taken huge steps as a playmaker this year, allowing him to exercise this versatility on offense.  Around mid-season last year, Jason Kidd made him the full time starter at the point. Matthew Dellavedova has slid into the official position after he signed with the Bucks this offseason, but that hasn’t decreased Giannis’ role. The Greek Freak leads the team in touches per game at 81.9, while Dellavedova is second at 61.6.

The offense primarily runs through Giannis, and he’s making the most of it. He’s shooting a career best 51.4 percent from the field, a testament to his ability to get into the paint and finish. This is largely due to how assertive he’s been. Out of 57 qualified players (at least 60 touches per game), he’s 39th in seconds per touch. This shows he’s getting into his moves quickly, especially considering the burden he must carry on offense. His high scoring and assist numbers show that he is beginning to produce at elite levels.

The scariest part is that his game is still unrefined; he has the potential to get a lot better. Primarily, he needs to develop a better jump shot.  He’s shooting 25 percent on catch and shoot attempts, and 24.4 percent on pull-up attempts. Defenses sag several feet off of him when he’s standing at the three-point line, which damages the Bucks’ spacing and makes his drives tougher. He and Jabari Parker have developed a great sense of timing on cuts to combat these shooting issues, but if they can start to rain jump-shots, then their potential is unthinkable.

The Bucks will be much better when they get Middleton back. Giannis and Jabari are both only 21. They have time to improve their game. Both have taken a huge step up this year, and look to keep getting better. Before long, Giannis will become such a household name that we’ll all learn how to pronounce ‘Antetokounmpo.’

title: American Political Party Prediction — 2016 Edition
content:
Written By : Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 11/21/16

Please note: there are no (explicit) value judgments expressed in this article! Although I make prescriptive claims they’re not rooted in personal moral principles. I prescribe here in the same way a weatherperson prescribes an umbrella on a rainy day.

My housemate swears there’s going to be a revolution. For the purposes of this article, I’m conjecturing something less drastic. Some feel that duress to our extant democracy means political reformation. One potential measure of reform is our party system. Here’s some loose change on the future of American political parties—

The Democratic Party will emphasize states’ rights in its ideology. Though the Republicans (and not Democrats) are historically known to champions states’ rights over federally dictated laws, I find that states’ rights is a solution to Democrats’ problems. With the president-elect purporting to erase all remnants of our dear lame duck, the future of America looks inhospitable to the progressive. Although Clinton won the popular vote, Trump won the majority of districts. The central bastions of progressives are the two coasts, CO, and so forth. These blue states will welcome strengthening of states’ rights to distance themselves from an antithetically motivated executive branch thus preserving the progressive legacy. Furthermore, Trump is known to support states’ rights himself, so the potential for sharper legal distinctions between states seems high.

The Republican Party will combine libertarian economic sense with alt-right social sentiment. The alt-right has become a favorite subject of discourse for major media outlets these last few months. Adults are always late to catch-on to the newest fad. Every ten years a local news channel plays a story about whippets five years after high schoolers have found a new aerosol to get high to. The same is true of memes. The Republican Party is criticized as being the party of old white men. But this is no longer true. Now it appears to be the party of old and young (mostly) white men. The Republicans will imitate the meme motif of the alt-right to appear relevant just like Drake did by having a campy photoshop on his latest album cover. The modern Republicans almost always support fewer business regulations. I can’t imagine that this changes because: i) Trump is a businessman, in some sense of the word; and ii) the alt-right corroborates much of Trump’s social views, but lacks any core political ideology beyond acute nationalism.

Members of the Democratic and Republican Parties will develop gills like fish to empower their new underwater lifestyles when the sea levels rise. I recognize that this level of speculation may be unsettling to some readers asking, “Why gills and not blowholes?” It is a salient question considering our mammalian cousins, the whales, have blowholes and not gills. Fish, of course, are taxonomically more distant than whales. Commuting the Lamarckian framework of evolution to American political parties subjects the dichotomy to a worldly uncertainness. Yet the biological yield is fruitful. That untapped epigenetic circulatory variegation of species homo sapiens leaves underdetermined any answer to a question “Why gills and not blowholes?” In recognizing the potential for both we diffuse the Republican-Democratic- two-party-dialectic. Fish qua humans qua Democrats qua Republicans. Vectors. The future is fishy. Moreover, I would point out that humans would look way cooler with gills than blowholes.

title: FYF 2016 Pre-fest Preview
content:
Written By : Brian Suruki, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 08/10/16

The lineup for 2016’s FYF Fest has been announced and I am excited to experience the magic all over again. This year’s headliners include Kendrick Lamar, Tame Impala, LCD Soundsystem and Grace Jones. Other acts that I am anticipated for are Beach House, Anohni, Mac DeMarco, Grimes, Kelela, Corbin (FKA Spooky Black), Hot Chip, Father John Misty, Explosions in the Sky, Rae Sremmurd, Blood Orange, Young Thug, Vince Staples, Wolf Parade, Gold Panda, and Denzel Curry. Once again FYF delivers a splendid lineup with a diverse range of top-notch artists.   

Kendrick Lamar has been one of the most prominent artists of our time. Since being discovered as Dr. Dre’s protégé, he has arguably become one of the most iconic figures in Hip-Hop. Both of his albums, good kid, m.A.A.d city, and To Pimp a Butterfly, are both platinum certified and considered classics. As Kendrick Lamar makes an appearance, FYF Fest will provide the opportunity to witness his artistic mastery.


Tame Impala is another band that will inevitably deliver a phenomenal performance. Since debuting in 2007, they have reached a great success in leading a new age of psychedelic rock. With achievements such as having back-to-back Grammy-nominated albums with Lonerism and Currents, Tame Impala will undoubtedly provide the psychedelic vibes that will make for a perfect summer.


In 2013, Rolling Stone magazine added LCD Soundsystem on their selective list of “New Immortals,” which is their title for, “current artists that will stand the test of time.” In 2011, the LCD Soundsystem announced their disbandment, which led many fans to believe that they will never have the opportunity to see them perform again. The last time LCD Soundsystem performed in Los Angeles was at the Hollywood Bowl in 2010. As the band makes their awaited return to Los Angeles, FYF Fest provides the opportunity to dance the night away with LCD Soundsystem.


 There are those who fit the mold of a star, then there’s Grace Jones who has the ability to change the mold of the star all together and transform it into something the world has never seen. Grace Jones is a living icon in both the worlds of music and fashion. Jones has influenced some of today’s biggest influencers, including Kanye West, Lady Gaga, Rihanna, and Lorde. FYF Fest will be a weekend of iconic performances as Grace Jones is added to the lineup.

Aside from the headliners, the lineup is stacked with other artists you will not want to miss. Beach House will be sure to provide beautiful festival vibes. In 2015 they released two back-to-back albums, Depression Cherry and Thank You Lucky Stars, both of which were sensational. Grimes also released one of the greatest albums of 2015 with Art Angels. Dancing away to Grimes’ unique sounds will be a one-of-a-kind experience. Dev Hynes (Blood Orange), who has been a writer for artists such as Solange, Tinashe and FKA Twigs, recently released his third studio album, Freetown Sound. Blood Orange provides a rich 80’s R&B aesthetic mixed with a modern sound, which results in a constant pleasure of timeless music. Long Beach’s Vince Staples is personally one of my favorite current rappers. Staples’ provides a combination of dark lyrics and a catchy flow that he usually laces over bass-heavy instrumentals. The combination of Vince Staples musical elements results in a very enjoyable audio experience. Atlanta’s Young Thug is another artist I am looking forward to. Young Thug will bring another dynamic to FYF that will keep the weekend interesting and full of energy. With hits such as “Lifestyle,” “About The Money,” and even working with Jamie xx on “I Know There’s Gonna Be (Good Times),” Young Thug is another artist that will bring iconic moments to the memorable weekend.

title: Hall of Fame: A Reflection
content:
Words By: Chase Madorsky, UCLA Radio DJ  1/17/2016

After electing four players last year, the Baseball Writers of America have had their votes tallied, and two players were elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame as part of their 2016 class: Mariners and Reds outfielder Ken Griffey Jr, and Dodgers and Mets catcher Mike Piazza. Prior to the voting period, over 100 sports writers were stripped of their ballots due to not having covered the game of baseball in the past ten years. As a result, many fans and analysts predicted vastly different results from 2015, as the voting body shifted towards younger, and more analytic based voters.

Elected with a record 99.3% of the vote, Ken Griffey Jr. enters the Baseball Hall of Fame on his first appearance on the ballot, where he will be enshrined in Cooperstown wearing a Mariners hat after appearing on all but three (437 out of 440) of the writers’ ballots. The son of former All Star Ken Griffey Sr., Junior became the first player to be selected as a number one overall draft pick to be elected to the Hall of Fame. A thirteen time all star, Griffey is regarded as one of the games’ premier all around players, winning ten straight Gold Glove awards in the outfield and finishing his career with 630 home runs, the sixth most all time. The greatness of Griffey can be summed up in the fact that many in the baseball world felt he had a legitimate chance to become the first unanimously voted Hall of Famer. Although he ultimately fell short of that mark, “The Kid” finished with 83.7 Wins Above Replacement, (The 57th most in baseball history) and the 1997 AL MVP Award, while widely being credited as the man who saved baseball in Seattle.

A man known for his clutch heroics such as his game-winning home run against the Braves as New York was reeling following 9/11, Mike Piazza received 83% of the electorate vote to enter the Hall of Fame. Regarded as the best hitting catcher in baseball history, Piazza finished his career with 427 home runs and a .308 career batting average despite falling all the way to the 62nd round of the 1988 amateur draft. A twelve time all star and ten time Silver Slugger award winner as the best hitting catcher in the National League, Piazza was the heart and soul of the New York Mets, leading the team into the Subway Series in 2000 and famously refusing to back down against Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens. Piazza’s election is not without controversy; although he never failed a drug test or has been directly indicted for performance enhancing drug use, there were sports writers who speculated Piazza was using steroids due to his back hair and acne. Although Piazza is an incredibly deserving Hall of Famer (one whom I find to be clean, and someone who should’ve easily slid in on his first ballot) he is also the first player to be connected to steroids to enter the Hall of Fame, which could lead to a shift in voting totals going forward for alleged steroid users such as Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.

Just missing the required 75% of the vote needed for induction were Jeff Bagwell, Tim Raines, and Trevor Hoffman, who finished with 71.6%, 69.8%, and 67.3% of the vote respectably. In his sixth year on the ballot, Bagwell’s voter percentage increased by about sixteen percent, putting him on the cusp of election next year. The 1994 NL MVP, Bagwell displayed a rare combination of power and speed for a first baseman, finishing his career with 449 home runs and 1401 runs batted in, but also 202 steals, including ten seasons with double digit totals. Raines made his fourteenth appearance on the ballot, jumping fifteen percent as he heads into his final year on the ballot in 2017. Regarded as one of the finest leadoff hitters to play the game and the National League’s answer to Rickey Henderson, Raines concluded his career with 1,571 runs scored, 2,605 hits, 1,330 walks, and 808 steals (fifth all time) all of which are the marks of a dominant table setter at the top of the order. Although there are currently only five closers in the Hall of Fame, longtime Padres closer Trevor Hoffman made a very strong debut on the ballot. One of only two players to record 600 saves in their career; Hoffman is widely thought to be one of the greatest closers of all time, saving thirty or more games thirteen times in his career. With the debate still raging on whether or not the specialized position of a closer should be represented in the Hall of Fame, it will be interesting to see if Hoffman enters Cooperstown in 2017.

Despite the younger group of voters, the results were not kind to players who have been linked to steroids throughout their retirement. Although both players jumped to the 45% vote range, all time home run king Barry Bonds and seven time Cy Young award winner Roger Clemens still fell significantly short of the votes needed to gain election. Although they are trending upwards, many speculate that Bonds and Clemens needed a larger jump in their vote tallies this year from the voter changeover in order to have any chance of gaining entrance into the Hall of Fame. Similarly, despite all hitting over 500 home runs in their career, Mark McGwire, Gary Sheffield, and Sammy Sosa all received less than 13% of the vote, casting a shadow over the probability that players linked to steroids will ever get the support they needed from the Baseball Writers of America.

Joining McGwire, a notable player whose time on the ballot has expired is former Tiger shortstop Allan Trammel, who led the Tigers to the 1984 World Series and whom many hoped would get a big push in his final appearance on the ballot. Additionally, notable players who failed to received five percent of the vote and were thus removed from the ballot included two time AL batting champion Nomar Garciaparra and Jim Edmonds, the owner of eight Gold Gloves and 393 home runs.

Looking forward to 2017, it is likely that Raines, Bagwell, and Hoffman all find themselves giving induction speeches as the logjam of strong players on the ballot continues to clear up. Notable players who will be joining the ballot include Vladimir Guerrero, Ivan Rodriguez, Manny Ramirez, and Jorge Posada, all of whom have legitimate arguments in their own right to join the Hall of Fame.

title: Mr. Ball’s Bold Prediction
content:
Written by: Ryland Towne, UCLA Radio Sports 

Post Date: 12/4/16

With finals approaching and our football team taking what seem like endless losses, it appears as if all hope is lost for UCLA. Yet there appears to be light at the end of the tunnel - with the recent 74-67 win over Texas A&M, the UCLA mens basketball team has clinched their first tournament title.  

The Wooden legacy appeared to be a breeze for the Bruins with opponents Portland, Nebraska, and eventually Texas A&M taking on the incoming 4-0 team.  Portland could not stop the onslaught of offensive power and UCLA rolled over them, outscoring Portland 99-77. During halftime, the father of superstar freshman Lonzo Ball spoke with the announcers.  Beyond analysis of his son’s game, Ball’s father made a surprising statement proclaiming that the Bruins would be winning the NCAA championship this year.

This got me thinking.  With the new additions of Lonzo Ball and T.J. Leaf, does UCLA have a chance at making a significant run in the big tournament?

In all honesty, I believe Mr. Ball would reclaim that statement if he saw how UCLA played in the next two games.  While they did dominate over Nebraska and Texas A&M, there were flaws exposed in both games. While the Bruins defeated Nebraska by double digits, the Cornhuskers stuck around for nearly the entire game.  One reason was that Nebraska’s Tai Webster and Glynn Watson Jr. were playing some of the best basketball they’ll play all year.  They combined for a total of 47 points, more than two-thirds of their entire team’s final score.

UCLA can run-and-gun offensively with nearly any team in the nation.  With Ball’s seemingly effortless scoring ability as well as a more dominant presence in the paint thanks to Leaf, UCLA appears to have a balanced offense. However, when players like Webster and Watson Jr. get hot, it will be interesting to see how UCLA reacts.  In the Nebraska game they resorted to a spread 3-2 defense, which proved effective but did not slow down Watson Jr. from launching beyond the three-point line. For the Texas A&M game, UCLA largely depended on the offensive persistence of Hamilton.  Alford went scoreless during the first half but made a resurgence in the second half, scoring 13 critical points.

The Bruins will have their hands full when they begin to face top-ranked teams. I believe they will find that while their offense is commanding, they must not depend on it. The rest of the season will serve as a true testament to whether UCLA can uphold Mr. Ball’s prediction of a 114th NCAA championship.

title:
Dancing to Emo Music With Strangers or Why You Should Go To Shows Alone:
A PWR BTTM show review
content:
Written By : Regina Napolitano, UCLA Radio Alumni

Post Date: 11/20/16

You can go to shows alone. You can go to shows alone with no explanation and no awkwardness. You can go to shows alone and not speak to a soul and have a grand time. And you can go to shows alone and make eight new friends and leave the venue with glitter all over your face and four new Instagram mutuals.

That was my Friday night on November 11th.  PWR BTTM at the Bootleg was the best show I have attended in my twenty-two years of existence. To think that I might have missed it all because of social mores! Every show you attend alone will not be like that, but I want to encourage you to attend shows alone because it will increase your chance of having that one night where you feel like you are exactly where you need to be.

PWR BTTM is a special band. They are an explicitly queer indie rock band that create songs that are both campy and vulnerable. Their shows are true performances. Liv and Ben, the band’s main members, have an unmatched onstage repartee. Ben typically slathers glitter and stickers on their face. During the show I attended they brought a person wearing a chicken wing costume onstage. I know of very few contemporary bands that seem to be having as much fun onstage as they are. Please go watch their Tiny Desk Concert and see for yourself.

Their fans often participate in the camp and the glamour. When I arrived at the venue, the glory of the PWR BTTM fan base was on full display. Lined up and down Beverly Blvd were kids and adults doused in sequins and glitter. People all across the gender spectrum were holding hands, laughing, and hanging out after a truly horrible week for queers and minorities of all kinds. One person even wore a pastel pink wig.

I mentioned that I came alone, and alone I stayed for half an hour or so. I sat down and watched the opener, Lisa Prank play her set. Lisa Prank’s aesthetic and work fit in well with PWR BTTM. She wore a sparkly gold paper crown and sung about her feelings. She shone brightest when she turned off her drum machine and played her songs with just her and her guitar.

Then I got up to use the bathroom and made friends with four teenagers in the line. It all started because one of them took out four markers and asked me if I wanted to draw on their pants. Soon we were talking about post-Halloween sales and exploring the venue together. And, the Bootleg is a great place to explore. For some unknown reason we found a collection of statues featuring barbies and trophies while wandering the halls. I also recognized rock royalty Patty Schemel (of Hole aka my favorite 90s alternative band) and Waxahatchee amongst the crowd.

We settled in to watch the Bellows set next. Bellows is a more standard, four piece indie band, complete with a bassist, guitarist, keyboardist, and drummer. Like all the music that night, their songs are emotional and leaky in a way I crave and appreciate. The group next to me started swaying and I joined them. Suddenly they were all introducing themselves to me and passing me glitter packets to apply to my face. They took a group selfie and insisted I join them.

If you try to listen to Bellows on the device of your choosing you might not think it lends itself to dancing, but not so at their live shows. Me and my new friends jumped up and down, rocked and swayed through the whole set. I have never had so much fun dancing to emo music with strangers.

By the time PWR BTTM took the stage the whole crowd was dancing. Due to the current state of our country, I could feel how much we all needed to be there. And so, everyone was going to get as much out of the show as they possibly could. After a few songs, when the vibe was higher than I have ever felt at any other show, Ben yelled, “THIS IS WHY I’M NOT AFRAID! Because there are so many of us and so few of them.”

And so PWR BTTM directly addressed the election of Donald Trump and all the fear that has come with it. And yet, the whole show was exploding with hope and creativity. The bands’ van and almost all of their gear and clothes were also stolen two days earlier in San Francisco, but there they all were, strutting and confident onstage in all of their queer, sparkly glory.

The crowd sang along to the songs they knew and rocked out to the new material the band played. The pink wig I had seen in line earlier migrated up to the stage where the bassist wore it and Ben and Liv joked about how dry it looked. It was an hour of pure magic.

I left the show high off of the kindness of strangers and the glory in the queer and the different.

The upcoming days seem dark and sometimes they scare me, but PWR BTTM and all of those lovely strangers showed me how beautiful we can be in struggle. We can sparkle and shine and even dance with new friends as we fight and suffer for a better world

The concert was like a wave washing over me, cooing, It’s all right, It’s all right, we’re all here, have some glitter, let’s dance. And then, let’s build together and let’s fight.

title: Putting the Con in Male Contraceptives
content:
Written By : Jen Harbeck, UCLA Radio Comedy Intern

Post Date : 11/3/16

(Photo: Getty Images/Science Photo Library)

As many of my closest acquaintances and most distant friends know, I have a lot of qualms with our society’s lack of birth control options for men. You may be thinking, what a specific qualm to have regarding such a particular subject. Ah yes, but if you saw the amount of Planned Parenthood propaganda I have on hand, you would understand my obsession with controlling the overpopulation of our planet through one of our main sources of human genetic material, sperm count. 


Now you may be asking, what about the womxn of our society, don’t they too have genetic material? Well, if you are asking a question like that you probably missed that one class on the history of women’s oral contraceptives, and thus should sit down and study up, kiddo.
As we are well aware, both men and women are responsible for pregnancy, yet more times than not the burden of attempting to prevent this outcome falls more on one gender than the other. For years, men’s only options for birth control revolved around the three methods of “pulling out,” which is extremely ineffective, condoms, and sterilization. Thus, the burden remained on women to take more precaution and use other forms of contraceptives to prevent pregnancy, until now. 


That’s right folks, since 2011 a trial to create a new contraceptive for men in the form of a shot has been in full swing, until the study was cut short due to adverse side effects. Now you may be thinking, What crazy side effects must have occurred to cause a complete shutdown of a study on this new revolutionary form of birth control for men? Well kiddo, as one who is extremely invested in the issue of lack of contraceptive options for men, I can give you all the sweet deets.


According to CNN.com, “Serious negative effects resulting from the shots included one case of depression and one experience of an abnormally fast and irregular heartbeat after the injections stopped,” which was probably caused by “one intentional overdose of acetaminophen” determined by researchers of the study. Other side effects include injection site pain, muscle pain, increased libido and acne. Yet researchers of the study reported that “nearly 39% of these symptoms – including one death by suicide – were unrelated to the shots.”
Wait a second, a lot of these symptoms sound very familiar, don’t they? Perhaps to the side effects of oral contraceptives for women? Which were approved by the FDA in the 1960s? I don’t know about you, but something seems a little fishy around here, and this time it’s not the vagina.
Unfortunately for now, the reality of another male birth control option does not seem to be “pulling out” anytime soon. But hey, at least we now officially know that our society is still men-centric and women’s health will always be less important in the eyes of the FDA.

title: Stay Freaky, Joshua Tree - Desert Daze 2016 in Review
content:
Written By : Isabelle Abbitt, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : (10/28/16)

This month, the Institute of Mentalphysics in Joshua Tree became the newest venue for the rapidly-growing psychedelic rock festival Desert Daze. Joshua Tree has been deemed one of the strangest places to visit in California, so it makes sense that Moon Block Party decided to move the growing “anti-coachella” festival from previous locations. The small desert city is known for it’s high desert art galleries, new-age spiritual centers, and a hip and growing music scene. The latest 420-acre venue is a meditative center built by Frank Lloyd Wright, advertised as “a portal to your inner being”, which helped provide Desert Daze with a miraculously otherworldly aesthetic. The spiritually charged atmosphere was complimented by the many interactive art installations, meditative altars tucked away from the crowd, mysterious tents filled with Reiki healers, and the trippy sound of psych-rock penetrating the air.

Day 1 

The first day of the festival was very different from the rest of the weekend, mostly because the crowd presence was much smaller. Since many people didn’t arrive until Friday night, it was particularly easy to stand next to the stages and be close to the performers without trying to squeeze past anyone. When I watched one of my favorite bands Mild High Club, who gave an amazing performance, there were only about fifty people in the audience. Gary Wilson, pictured below, performed with his band at the same small stage and it was easy to just walk up to the band and have a conversation (they became very offended when I complimented their wigs, saying, “We never wear wigs” in a harsh tone)  As the band played, Gary Wilson writhed around on the floor under a plastic tarp holding various makeup-smeared mannequin heads.This performance was Desert Daze in it’s most pure form. Later that day, many other bands such as Deerhunter, Washed Out, Toro y Moi, Suuns, and King Gizzard and The Lizard Wizard played on the other two bigger stages. Toro Y Moi played a wonderfully energetic set, but I didn’t end up seeing all of the bands that night because I decided to spend my night in the Mystic Bazaar. The Bazaar was a healing tent situated next to the camping section. The smell of sage continuously filled the air while the spiritual healers held sound baths, performed massages, Reiki healing ceremonies, and Shamanic rituals until about 3am.



Day 2

The second day was of the festival was much livelier, especially since there was a much larger and more excited crowd. Cherry Glazerr was definitely one of the crowd’s favorite sets during the day. Thee Oh Sees hit the stage early that evening and delivered a set with limitless energy, probably one of the most intense performances I’ve ever witnessed. The Black Angels (pictured), the festival’s founder’s very own band JJUJJU, and Night Beats were followed by Montreal post-rock legends Godspeed You! Black Emperor who played their highly regarded album Passover in it’s entirety. The main stages had psychedelic oil light shows projected upon strips of cut fabric blowing in the desert wind which was an incredibly breathtaking sight.


Day 3

The last day had so many incredible artists that it was really challenging to see most of the bands I wanted to see, especially since many of them did not end up starting on time. My favorite performance during the day was feminist duo Deap Vally who had about a dozen dancers wearing unicorn and monster costumes on stage while they played a catchy and politically-charged set. Overall, Foxygen (pictured below) was my favorite band of the night. Even though they took almost an entire hour to soundcheck, the band made up for it with a fun performance with the lead singers dancing and the band playing an extremely broad range of instruments. The iconic band Television was one of the last shows of the night, and ended their set playing the cult-favorite Marquee Moon. Overall, Desert Daze was a truly magical experience that I would highly recommend over more commercialized festivals such as Coachella. Even though there were many legendary groups, it still kept a low-key and relaxing vibe which made the experience that much more special. Rumor has it the next location of the festival will be in Arizona, looks like I’ll be taking a road trip this time next year!

title: Top 5 Most Surprising Acts at ArcTanGent
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 09/12/16

When gearing up for a major festival, you can do all the research and Spotify playlists that you want. But often times some of the bands that stick out for you the most are the ones you just happen upon while waiting in line at a food truck for your third serving of the greatest pad thai on the planet. This is a list of some of the not-so-hidden gems I stumbled upon throughout my weekend at ArcTanGent Festival in Bristol, UK (August 18-20).

5) Vasudeva
I wasn’t surprised that Vasudeva absolutely killed their set. I’d seen them play a house show in Los Angeles about a year ago and knew they were an undeniably sick act. But from such an intimate environment, I never could have predicted how well their sound would carry from the main stage of a festival. The lyrical guitar lines and heavy reverb filled the space beautifully without ever straying from the tightest of pockets. Their highly technical yet groove-able tunes were a perfect opener for the day and it was a wonderful harbinger to those in the crowd that if this was the quality of music we’d be receiving at 11:30am, the rest of the day was bound to be incredible.

4) The Brackish
I caught The Brackish’s set immediately after Vasudeva’s and while I had listened to them prior to the festival and was intrigued by their sound, I have to be honest and say that the reason I rushed to their stage was because it had started raining heavily and their stage was less than a kilometer from the main stage (I’m assuming. I still haven’t quite figured out the metric system). I’m sure I wasn’t alone in this reasoning but by the 3rd song, I had forgotten the rain and was totally engrossed and rocking along to their hybrid of tight math rock and free flowing jam-band grooves. While still keeping with the cerebral nature of the genre, they managed to produce a set that was almost nostalgic of the free love and psychedelia festivals of decades past.

3) Space Blood
While several bands throughout the weekend could be noted for their grand displays of showmanship, I have to give the crown to Space Blood. I had listened to the band’s most recent album, Can’t Stop Seeing Creed, which featured Dan Wild-Beesly of Cleft playing guitar on the title track and I was eager to see the song replicated in a live setting. But when the bass and drums duo took the stage wearing masks and blasting confetti cannons into the audience, I knew I was in for something bigger. At a festival where many bands favor a raw, stripped down aesthetic, Space Blood took a more heavily conceptualized approach. In lieu of typical stage banter, all the dialogue in between songs came from a computerized voice who dished out plenty of tongue-in-cheek social commentary (sarcastically praising the “Non-United Kingdom” on their recent Brexit) and space-puns. When Dan entered the stage, he had donned a blonde wig as Boris Johnson and was tasked with several trials including correctly distinguishing a cookie from a biscuit, doing an impression of the Queen, and being successfully “Malort-ed” with the band’s special edition of the infamous Chicago wormwood-tinged liquor. Finally, it was with the powers granted to him by drinking the Malort that he was able to strap on his guitar and join the band in their thumping interstellar space rock. From the heavy jams, to just the right amount of wackiness, to the band’s ability to break the fourth wall at all the right moments, it was clear from the audience reaction that the brainwashing mission was a huge success.

2) Godspeed You! Black Emperor
Friday night’s headliner was the heavily billed Godspeed You! Black Emperor, a highly influential band in the progressive rock genre whose sets are known for their elaborate production and visual component. As one of the most talked about acts of the festival, nothing about Godspeed’s act should have come as a surprise to me. But after months of hearing so much about how astonishing their live performance was, I made the decision not to explore their music prior to the festival so I could go in with fresh eyes and ears to take it all in. This approach ended up working out perfectly. Their set was a beautiful presentation of stunning graphics paired with vast soundscapes, the audio and visual mediums continuously feeding into one another without one ever overshadowing the other. Their 8-piece arrangement was the perfect musical centerpiece and matched the cinematic scale of the epic displays on the stage. Going back now and exploring the albums on their own continues to deepen my respect for the band and the high level of artistry they put into everything they do, for as different an experience it is to hear the music without the accompanying film, it is obvious that the music and its story are not dependent on visuals and can easily stand alone as a true work of art.

1) Plini 

In a way, my experience with Plini’s set encompassed the entire ArcTanGent experience. For as breathtaking as GY!BE’s performance was, when a Facebook-acquaintance-turned-concert-buddy suggested we leave halfway through to catch Plini, I decided to join her. Since I’d assumed that I would be spending the entire evening glued to the main stage, I hadn’t researched Plini at all so once again I was going in with zero context or expectations. And once again, it paid off big time. Right away, seeing Plini and his bassist both walk out with Strandberg headless guitars was an indicator that this would be a performance unlike anything else I had witnessed at the festival thus far. When the music first began, I was immediately blown away by the purity of his guitar sound. Just as beautiful as the melodies he was playing was the thick, shining tone by which the melodies were being carried. Equally exciting for me was the crunchy yet bright tone of his bassist, who also thrilled throughout the set by exhibiting many virtuosic displays of tapping on his own 5-string Strandberg. The music was an excellent demonstration of math-jazz fusion in its truest form. Aside from some crucial swells and several moments of insane time-bending drumming, the music wasn’t aggressive. Whether it was through his melodic lines, his phrasing, or just his stance at center stage, Plini was never without his swagger. The set as a whole was magnetic and he seemed a bit shocked at times by the energy and depth of his audience, even reminding the crowd at one point that the headliner was performing at the other end of the festival. But, as I’m sure every person at that stage had realized, there was no such thing as bad bands at ArcTanGent and literally any band at any time of day could blow you away if you just stop and take a listen.

title: Title-Time in Chicago
content:
Words By: Chase Madorsky, UCLA Radio DJ 1/16/2016

1908. In the year 1908, Teddy Roosevelt was President of the United States, America had not yet fought in a World War, and the Titanic was still four years away from sinking. Many of our great grandparents had not yet born, and Major League Baseball was still in its infancy. Yet 1908 is most significant in sports for that year’s World Series, as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Detroit Tigers in five games for their second consecutive championship. Cubs fans had every reason to celebrate, with a dynasty on the horizon. Today, it is 2016, and in the past 108 years, the Cubs have not found themselves hoisting the Commissioner’s Trophy since 1908. Yet have no fear Southsiders – the curse of the Billy Goat will soon come to the end, and the Chicago Cubs will be your 2016 World Series champions.

To see why the Cubs have turned the baseball world on its heads and are on the cusp of glory, look no further than their front office and managerial positions. Hired in 2011 after breaking the Curse of the Bambino and wining two World Series in Boston, team President Theo Epstein inherited a club with a bright future and a strong farm system. Along with General Manager Jed Hoyer, Epstein has made a series of strong trades while running the Cubs, trading for All Star first baseman Anthony Rizzo in 2012, defensive whiz Addison Russell in 2014, and the reigning Cy Young award winner Jake Arrieta at the 2013 trade deadline. Coupled with the free agent signings of his ace in Boston John Lester, as well as perennial Gold Glove winner Jason Heyward this past offseason, Epstein has brilliantly blended youth with veteran talent to put the Cubs in a position to compete for years to come.

Widely regarded as one of the smartest minds in baseball, and one of its craftiest executives, Epstein’s biggest coup may have been in the 2014 offseason, when he was able to lure Joe Maddon away from the Tampa Bay Rays to become the new manager of the Cubs. In Tampa, Maddon inherited a young team and a franchise that had yet to experience a winning record. Undaunted, he changed the culture in Tampa, keeping his players loose, winning the 2008 AL Pennant and reaching the playoffs four times despite a revolving door of players due to payroll constraints. Maddon took over a 73 win team and promptly lead the Cubs to 97 wins and a spot in the NLCS, wining his third Manager of the Year award in the process. With Maddon at the helm, the Cubs will be led by one of baseball’s strongest and strategically crafty managers, ensuring clubhouse stability and leadership going forward.

From top to bottom, the Cubs may have the strongest and deepest line-up of any team in baseball. Starting in the infield, Miguel Montero anchors the team from behind the plate, while second year shortstop Addison Russell will look to improve upon his strong rookie season by seasoning his bat in combination with his defensive skills. At second base is likely leadoff hitter Ben Zobrist, who signed a four-year, 56 million-dollar free agent contract with the Cubs after winning the World Series with the Royals. A former All Star for Maddon in Tampa Bay, Zobrist is revered for his versatility.  He has averaged 5.6 WAR since becoming a regular in 2009, making him one of baseball’s most valuable all around players. At first base is 2015 All Star Anthony Rizzo, who out of the three hole blossomed into a legitimate MVP candidate by hitting 30 home runs and driving in 101 runs in 2015. Out of the cleanup spot is 2015 NL All Star and Rookie of the Year Kris Bryant, who lived up to his status as a consensus top prospect in baseball by busting onto the scene with 26 home runs and 99 RBIs.

The Cubs’ depth continues in the outfield, with three prolific hitters projected to start. After signing an eight-year, 184 million-dollar deal with the Cubs, Jason Heyward will operate out of the two spot. A three-time Gold Glove winner, Heyward will slide over to center field to replace Dexter Fowler and provide much needed defensive stability to the Cubs outfield, while also bringing his rare blend of power, speed, and ability to hit to for average to Wrigley Field. In the corner outfield positions are young outfielders Kyle Schwarber and Jorge Soler.  Despite struggling with breaking balls and injuries, Soler is still only 23 years old, giving him plenty of time to develop into the superstar status that was predicted of him upon defecting from Cuba. Often overshadowed by Bryant, Schwarber hit 16 home runs in only 232 at bats during his rookie year, rapidly making the jump to the Major Leagues after being drafted fourth in the 2014 draft out of Indiana.

Leading the Cubs rotation is the big three of Jake Arrieta, John Lester, and John Lackey. Arrieta was historically dominant in the second half of the 2015 season on his way to the Cy Young Award. As the ace of the Cubs, Arietta is coming off a season that saw him throw a no-hitter, win 22 games, finish with 236 strikeouts and a freakishly low 1.77 ERA and .0865 WHIP, and the baseball lead in complete games and shutouts, which does not include his shutout of the Pittsburgh Pirates in the wild card game. Behind Arrieta is veteran John Lester, who after signing a big free agent contract with the Cubs, struck out 207 batters with a 3.34 ERA, providing stability to the Cubs rotation and providing the team with leadership and a postseason pedigree. Rounding out the three-headed monster is Lester’s former teammate John Lackey, who joined the Cubs on a two year, 32 million-dollar contract at the expense of the Cubs division rival, the St. Louis Cardinals.  Despite turning 36 years old, 2015 marked what may have been Lackey’s finest season as a pro, as he combined 13 wins with a 2.77 ERA, while beating the Cubs with 7.1 scoreless innings in the Game 1 of the NLDS. With 20 postseason starts to his resume, Lackey will provide the Cubs with valuable postseason experience as they look to make a deep run on their way to the World Series. Jason Hammel and Kyle Hendricks, both valuable veteran starters in their own right, complete the rotation.

Something that Maddon has traditionally thrived with is a deep, strong bullpen, and the Cubs are no exception. Acquired alongside Jake Arrieta, Pedro Strop pitched to a 2.91 ERA in 76 appearances, while Justin Grimm produced a sparkling 1.99 ERA in 62 games. In his first full year as closer, Hector Rondon converted 30 saves with a 1.67 ERA, developing into one of the more consistent closers in baseball. Yet the real x-factor of the Cubs’ bullpen are former starters Trevor Cahill and the newly acquired Adam Warren, as both bring a bevy of pitches and can provide the Cubs with valuable innings should their rotation falter.

Although the Cubs came up a little bit short in 2015 despite the prediction of the film “Back to the Future,” the future is brighter than ever in Chicago. With as balanced a team as any in baseball, it appears that the wait may soon be over for Cubs fans, that the streak will come to an end at 108 years, and generations of Cubs fans will rejoice in the streets to celebrate their World Series champions.

title: This One Time That I Licked a Peanut Butter and Jelly Sandwich, and How That’s Exactly Like The Election Results Right Now
content:
Written By : Rohnie Williams, UCLA Radio Comedy Member

Post Date : 11/11/16

So this one time, I licked a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and it’s exactly like the election results. I should explain.

When I was a wee lad, I loved peanut butter and jelly sandwiches (I was also pretty fond of America). I probably made myself five or 13 sandwiches a day and, let me tell you, I savored every bite. This one time I made the most amazing sandwich ever (I’m talking perfect peanut-to-butter ratio and a smooth continuous spread of jelly) and I was ready to catch a dope ass episode of Spongebob Squarepants (I was like 7 by the way, I thought I should mention). So, I walk in the TV room of my house, feelin’ myself, and my dad looks over at me and my sandwich and says, “Hey, lemme have some.”

At this point a little part of me died. My father, half of a whole unit that worked tirelessly to bring me into this world, was asking something of me, a mere child. My mind began racing, I was trying to figure out how I could keep him from wanting my sandwich, but also not do anything too drastic so I could still enjoy it. So I licked it. Yeah, that’s right, I licked it, and as power began to rush to my head, my father just said, “Wow, that’s sad.” That moment of triumphant history was lost in the recesses of my memory until that fateful Tuesday night when Donald J. (which stands for John and not Jumbo Tron) Trump was chosen to be our country’s 45th president.

So who was the sandwich-licker this time? It wasn’t me, I swear. Well, for starters, it was anyone who voted for Trump. Meanwhile the dads of us are just sitting there without any sandwiches, watching our sons eat a sandwich covered in saliva (that sandwich is America by the way.)

Now I’m not here to chastise you for your vote, but the fact of the matter is, sandwich licking is actually a group effort. If you voted for Trump, you licked the sandwich. If you voted for Gary Johnson (even if it was some kind of white people protest vote because you feel that Americans need to “wake up” and realize that there are more than just two candidates even though Gary Johnson literally knows less than anybody else on the ballot and is probably the least qualified candidate), you licked the sandwich. If you voted for Jill Stein, you licked the sandwich. And if you were one of the approximately 11,000 people who wrote in “Harambe” or one of the 12 people who wrote in “Hennessy,” even you licked the sandwich. The point is, a vote for anyone (or anything) else other than Hillary Clinton was a vote for Donald Justifies Sexual Assault Trump, and that ruined the outcome for anyone who wanted an America without Trump, I mean, a sandwich without saliva.

Now you’re probably looking at your screen like, “Hold up, Rohnie, it’s not that deep.” To that, I say, you’re right - the electoral college, an elected body, chooses the president. Technically, our votes don’t matter. However, with the existence of “swing states” that are not consistently Republican or Democratic, the popular vote in some areas of the United States does matter. That’s all I’m trying to say.

On the real, if Hillary won, I’d probably have written an article about how I’m enjoying a saliva covered PB&J. But she didn’t, and however we want to feel about that, I sincerely hope Donald Just Doesn’t Know When To Quit Trump does a great job leading our nation, because it’s not like my dad was like, “I hope that sandwich kills you.”

title: XLIVE 2016
content:
Written by: Pamela Crick, UCLA Radio DJ

Get your networking game on!!!

If you’re done with finals for Dec 5th - 7th, head on over to Vegas to celebrate winter break and check out the world renowned event production conference XLIVE 2016!  With 140+ guest speakers, 80+ exhibitors and 40+ interactive sessions for participants, get ready to have your mind blown and transformed. You will learn all about the latest approaches to event production and attendee experience. 

For anyone interested in the music industry or event production, this is the conference for you. Be inspired by XLIVE’s impressive list of speakers from Billboard, Eventbrite, the Food Network, AEG/Goldenvoice, Live Nation, Airbnb and our friends over at the Confluence. 

Probably the coolest part about this event is that you can apply for the first time ever to the Young Festival Entrepreneur Mentorship Program for future festival leaders.

If you have any intention of entering the music industry this is your conference! 

See you there :)

title: Ray Orbison // Artist Appreciation Piece
content:
Many people look to the 1960s as a flowering in the medium of music and for all intents and purposes it was. Genres expanded into the mainstream, lyrical content diversified into a number of new and many previously taboo subject areas, but seemingly most important, the style of popular music was able to abandon the rockabilly and doowop roots that defined the 1950s to adopt more sophisticated arrangements. 

One could say that popular music as a whole found a way to become more seriously or scholarly appreciated beyond merely aesthetically pleasing voices and catchy tunes (not that there’s ever been anything wrong with that combination). And when people think back on this revolutionary time period of social and stylistic upheaval, the artists they come back to as the instigators are for the most part the same: Bob Dylan, The Beatles, Velvet Underground etc. but there’s a vital piece of connective tissue missing in those musical influences. Velvet Underground didn’t debut until 64 and freewheelin Bob Dylan was out in ‘63 but from about ‘59 till the release of that album was a time period when the Titans of rockabilly sound had disappeared from the popular eye. Elvis was in the army, Chuck Berry was in jail, Jerry Lee Lewis was socially ostracized after news of his marriage to his 13 year old cousin came out, and little Richard had found Jesus. 

In between that time, the forgotten voice, that both those rockabilly superstars and the future legends of the 60s agreed was the best among them, was Roy Orbison. Now I can’t necessarily say that Roy Orbison is forgotten, since everyone and their mothers cat knows “pretty woman”, but that’s not even the kind of music that makes him vitally important to the history of rock n roll. And of course, music scholars and writers know him, but his lack of presence in the public narrative of musical legends troubles me so much, I bothered to write this article about it for a blog most people will never see any way. Beginning with the creation of the “Nashville sound” which I’ve discussed previously on my radio show (check us out Thursdays at 11am!), Orbison was able to seize the opportunity with grade A backup musicians and experienced producers to craft a sound around his incredibly powerful voice. His patented style of uniquely structured recording sessions from the top down, beginning with background vocals and ending with string rhythms, was fashioned for the 1960 hit “only the lonely”, which also showcased his incredible vocal range through the addition of falsetto notes. 

Furthering the strangeness of these sessions, Orbison refused to edit songs together, insisting on a single take with all instruments together for a cohesive sound. This song and style alone shot him to the top of the charts and had him touring with country legend Patsy Cline, while Elvis was buying boxes of Orbison’s records to pass out to friends. From there his style only diversified, with his major hits being notable for all following different structures rather than the standard verse, chorus, verse, chorus, bridge structure of pop songs. “In dreams” featured in the lynch masterpiece Blue Velvet, has no repeating structural elements, while “running scared” from his career defining 1962 album Crying, repeats the same structure until the very end building suspense in tune with the lyrical content of boyfriend worrying about his girl’s ex coming back. These structures may not mean much on the page, but to the musicians that had to record them, they were baffling, with some quoted as saying they’d question Orbison the first time he directed them on what to play until finally the sound just clicked.

Words By: David Wright

title: How About Dak Prescott!
content:
Written By: James Shippy, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 12/11/16

Let’s face it.  Everyone’s thinking about it but no one is really saying it out loud.  After Peyton Manning retired there was a huge void left in the NFL, a yearly void of who to compare to the great Tom Brady.  Even Tom Brady’s biggest critics and naysayers historically have to admit he’s likely the greatest quarterback of all time…besides anyone who grew up in the Joe Montana era.  But something special happened late April 2016 in the fourth round of the NFL draft.  That something special was Dak Prescott, who received the biggest gift of all: the Dallas Cowboys drafting him.  Prescott has set the league on fire from day one and he’s showing no signs of stopping. As far as rookie seasons, Prescott is out-Tom-Bradying Tom Brady.  This is not a hyperbole and this is not being a creature of the moment, as majority of sports fans are.  Through Prescott’s first foray into the NFL, in 11 games he has completed 18 touchdowns to only two interceptions.  In Brady’s 2001 rookie season he had 16 touchdowns to 9 interceptions. Prescott has completed 231 out of 340 passes (67.9 percent.) Brady completed 212 out of 320 passes (66.2 percent.) The Patriots had the sixth ranked offense and the fifth ranked points per game defense in the league that year. Dallas has the fifth ranked offense and the twenty-first ranked defense so far this year.

The stats are strikingly the same.  But I don’t want to just focus on numbers, even though numbers never lie.  I want to focus on fate and poise.  Fate would have it that back in 2001 there were six quarterbacks drafted before Brady, including the likes of Chad Pennington and a guy named Giovanni Carmazzi from Hofstra.  Sorry Giovanni.  

Prescott had the likes of Cody Kessler and Jared Goff drafted ahead of him.  Now it’s way too early to determine what kind of careers these players are going to have, but it’s not too early to assume that the NFL is unlikely to have multiple Hall of Fame talents in the same draft class at the same position.  (That is, unless you’re talking about the 1983 draft with players like John Elway and Jim Kelly - but back then, Mario Bros the arcade game and McNuggets being sold nationwide just went into effect, so it was a very long time ago.)

Most importantly is the poise factor.  Numerous quarterbacks have arm and foot talent, but numerous quarterbacks don’t have what it takes in the space between the ears to relieve an all time quarterback due to injury - Brady to Drew Bledsoe, and now Prescott to Tony Romo.  Not only did they relieve them, but they set the league on fire and make it look so damn easy.  So instead of us trying to complain that the press is engaging in some love fest for the new “it” guy on America’s team.  It’s time we bask in the birth of a new star, no pun intended.  Because once Brady retires, the league is going to be in good hands with our new crop of quarterbacks dazzling fans every Sunday.  And Prescott can be added to that list.

title: Text, Image, Movement, Sound: Akhnaten at the LA Opera Reviewed
content:
Written by: Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date: 12/4/16

I had the pleasure of seeing Philip Glass’s third installment of his portrait trilogy, Akhnaten, at the LA Opera the other night. Visitors of this showing lucked out, as Mr. Glass himself came to discuss with the conductor-in-residency Matthew Aucoin before the show. At one point in their conversation, the master composer noted that he’s enjoyed his tenured foray into movie collaborations because it shares the same elements that the opera/theater does: text, image, movement, and sound. With that, I’ll proceed to review this opera by Mr. Glass’s own standards…

Text

This opera is the final installment of Glass’s portrait trilogy focused on individuals who changed the sociological plenum. The first two operas in the series Einstein on the Beach and Satyagraha see the role of man’s other institutional artifacts in shaping our world. The former is concerned with the Copernican Revolution following Einstein, while the latter’s lens looks to the pacifistic political revolt of Gandhi. This third story has as its subject the pharaoh Akhnaten who is historically cited as introducing monotheism to the West, because of his transition of the Egyptian civilization away from its predating polytheism. The story follows Akhnaten’s ascension to his decline. We see his move from Thebes to Amarna, a city dedicated to him by the monotheistic god Aten. After decades of self-imposed isolation, the people overtake the royal palace and killAkhnaten. He is replaced by his alleged son, the future pharaoh Tutankhamen who reinstates polytheism. In the pre-show discussion Glass alluded to his (and modern theater’s) indebtedness to the absurdist Beckett. In true absurdist style the opera cycles. The ostentatious Akhnaten is replaced by another demigod. Like a modernist film, the mechanisms of the artwork are revealed to the viewer. The story ends with a scene framed around a university lecture on the legacy of Akhnaten. Although spaced millennia apart, Akhnaten’s story ripples today: the ruling class’s self-indulging disregard for the populace, the people’s willingness to be controlled, and history’s ability to deify the human narrative.

Image

Unfortunately for Glass, the art direction failed to live up to the music. Glass admits that his creative process permits little-to-no coordination with the other artists involved in any of his operas. That was evident for this performance. It didn’t share the informed contrast of Robert Wilson’s art direction for Einstein on the Beach. Instead, Akhnaten, directed by the English Phelim McDermott, was gaudy and unchecked. If there was any precision, it was obfuscated bythe steampunk cum ancient Egypt aesthetic and the Liberace approved flamboyancy of the costuming. The opera was largely devoid of irony, except the continued submission of the populace, i.e. repetition of history. But this presence of irony wasn’t reinforced by the stylistic choices at all. The outfits flaunted lapis lazuli and gold hues (and then some) reminiscent of the precious materials of the ancients. But the rhinestone bedazzled vestments added all the tackiness of the two-thousand-and-aughts without any of the fun. The stage lighting was excessively warm. Aten, the declared god of Akhnaten, is a sun god, but yellow-tinge only emphasized a steampunk grittiness and not a royal wash. The other motivation in the warm stage lighting was perhaps the framing of a historical picture because we have collectively decided that sepia tones symbolize old-times. The text would have been better served if the tropes were replaced by sincere form.

Movement

Although hard to parse from the image, I think the movement aspect of the opera better illuminated the text than the aesthetics of the lighting, costuming, etc. The opera is sung in ancient languages (ancient Hebrew, Akkadian) taken from primary sources of sorts. Interpolated between the story is a narrator speaking in a modern language. A pre-show email from the LA Opera informed audiences that there’d be no subtitles overhead for Akhnaten. For the classical operas of Italian and German, English subtitles are always present. But this deliberateness not to provide translations of the dead languages made the audience dependent on a narrator, just as the ruled classes were dependent on a translator of the royal authorities. This narrator later played the role of the professor who serves as mediator of past and present to his students and to the audience. The opera tells us how history becomes deified. We look to it to for the same reason we look to any higher authority—we ask what our fates can be. The positing of an ineffable (nonexistent?) God leaves vacancy for mortals to dominate other mortals with the promise of fortune-telling. Akhnaten’s turning his back left the mass in a state of indetermination.
