Uncomfortable with this position, the masses revolted to reinstate hierarchy, their own domination.

Sound

Glass’s layered minimalism is sheer profundity. The boisterous visual aesthetic didn’t cooperate with the understated eidos of the music. The ineffable insight of the immortal fails when translated into the natural language, but can only be uncovered by the music.

title: October’s Show of The Month // Opposites Attract (Sundays @ 7 PM)
content:
Each month, UCLA Radio picks one radio show that has been particularly, well, rad. This month, we’ve been digging Opposites Attract, which you can listen to Sunday’s at 7:00 PM. Here’s an interview with DJ Centrifuge and Spinach Boi, the two hosts of Opposites Attract.

Describe your most memorable show as a DJ for UCLA radio.

DJ CENTRIFUGE: I liked our “songs about sex” themed show, because I got to make fun of Spinach Boi’s hickey.

SPINACH BOI: Shut up :) Anyways.. mine was our “water”-themed show because we had DJ Centrifuge’s dad come in as a special guest to talk about the drought in California! He’s a hydrologist, not just a dad. But also my friend! He brought me a stalk of rapini (aka broccoli rabe) as a thank you present.


DJ CENTRIFUGE: That was definitely a memorable show. We pushed the boundary of what a theme could be, but were surprised at how much music we found that fit in. We also got to talk about a pressing issue and be uncharacteristically serious, offering our listeners an educated perspective on something other than our great tastes in music. Haha!


What do you try to communicate to the audience through your vibe as a DJ?

SPINACH BOI: On our show, we like to provide little bursts of fun conversations that help connect each song and keep the listener entertained/never too unaware of our presence! But seriously, we try to keep a balance between our personalities and our responsibilities as DJs— sharing our favorite music.


DJ CENTRIFUGE: Viva UCLA Radio!


SPINACH BOI: Stop.


DJ CENTRIFUGE: Our main goal is to translate our enthusiasm and excitement about the songs we’re playing to the audience. I love hearing friends mention finding out about a cool new band or artist from listening to our show!


Where do you find inspiration for your show?

DJ CENTRIFUGE: Since we tend to feature a lot of new music, I’m personally influenced by artists I see live or discover through friends and music blogs. Our weekly theme determines what direction we’ll go, so inspiration for it is potentially more important than for specific songs. We might notice common elements in songs we’re currently listening to (written in second person, featuring other artists, etc) and translate these to themes.


SPINACH BOI: We also sometimes draw inspiration from what’s going on around us/in the world that week for our weekly themes! One week, it was DJ Centrifuge’s birthday, so we made our theme essentially be some of her favorite songs. As DJ Centrifuge said above, we do try to stick to the theme and concept of our show but sometimes we can’t help but play our current favs and find a way to fit them in.


How did you come up with idea for your show?

DJ CENTRIFUGE: In each episode of Opposites Attract, we connect each song to the next one by either a close similarity or stark difference, creating a cohesive chain. If Spinach Boi picks a simple song with only vocals and guitar, I might lead us in a completely new direction with something loud, complex, and chaotic. We’ve got to give credit here, though, to the original creator of Opposites Attract: the wickedly talented, one and only Annie Rimmon. She was in fact a co-DJ on our show’s very first season, in the spring of 2015.


SPINACH BOI: It was so fun having our show with Annie, but she had to leave to study abroad so we took the show over! Since then, we’ve made the show more music-centric, and have cultivated a representative sound focused on more specific genres than before. We also have themes now, to spice things up! Take a load of that, Annie! Just kidding.


How would you describe the dynamic between you two DJ’s?

SPINACH BOI: Well, we live together now, have been seeing concerts together for at least a year, and recently have been trying to learn songs together on guitar (recently = one hour ago)— so, it really just seems like an extension of our everyday lives, just with weird microphones in our faces! Of course we love to make fun of each other and be goofy as heck, but we also love keeping our show professional and putting our listeners first.
DJ CENTRIFUGE: He’s right! Although we’re comfortable with each other and maintain a jovial atmosphere on-air, we make a big effort to focus on the music. The show has been an awesome way for me to learn details and histories about artists I love. We do like to talk about our friendship on the show, and recently introduced a new segment called Opposites Attract: Friends Edition, in which we discuss similarities and differences between the two of us. There is a questionably larger proportion of the latter, but we agree that Quiznos > Subway and that the artisan sandwich place in North Campus Student Union is by far the best on campus.
SPINACH BOI: We just really like sandwiches.

title: Clippers Survive OT Scare From Anthony Davis-Less Pelicans, Hang On For 114-111 Victory
content:
Words By: Darryn Albert, UCLA Radio Sports Manager 1/15/16

The New Orleans Pelicans sure didn’t look like an 11-24 team playing without their superstar big man, and the LA Clippers came dangerously close to finding that out the hard way.
The Clippers hung on for a hard-fought 114-111 victory over the Pelicans on Sunday afternoon in front of a sellout home crowd at the Staples Center.  Chris Paul led the team with 25 points and 11 assists, DeAndre Jordan double-doubled with 12 points and 11 rebounds, and Jamal Crawford added 21 points off the bench as the Clippers won their ninth game in a row to improve to 25-13 on the season.  
Jrue Holiday had 29 points and 11 rebounds while Tyreke Evans posted 26 points, 7 rebounds, and 7 assists for the Pelicans, who were playing without All-NBA big Anthony Davis.  Davis suffered a back contusion diving into the stands on Friday night against the Indiana Pacers and was ruled out shortly before tipoff.  


But New Orleans rallied around the flag in Davis’ absence, leading by double-digits in the second quarter, then, after falling behind, rallying from a 12-point fourth quarter deficit to force overtime.  It was largely thanks to the effort of Holiday, the former UCLA Bruin, who scored 12 of his 29 in the fourth.  The Pelicans even had a chance to take the lead in the final moments, but Dante Cunningham bricked a wide-open three from the right wing with eight seconds left on the clock.  However, J.J. Redick missed a crucial free throw that left the door open ever so slightly, then Austin Rivers imprudently fouled Holiday on a three-point attempt.  Holiday proceeded to hit all three free throws in cold-blooded fashion to force overtime.  
In the extra period, the Clippers again struggled to close out the shorthanded Pelicans.  After Paul hit a long three with 1:15 remaining to put them up three, Crawford, Luc Richard Mbah a Moute, and Wesley Johnson combined to clank three clutch free throws in the final minute to give the Pelicans new life again.  But Ryan Anderson, who finished with 16 points and 10 rebounds in the spot start for Davis, missed a stepback three at the buzzer that would have re-tied the game, and the Clippers escaped.  
Clippers head coach Doc Rivers wasn’t entirely pleased with his team’s effort but was happy to get away with the victory.  “I think part of it is that Anthony Davis did not play, so they played extremely spirited,” Rivers said in his postgame press conference.  “I thought it was a tough game coming into it – back-to-back home games.  We had so many chances to put it away and we just could not.  You’re not going to win them all, but it was a good one to win because it was back-to-back games.  In my opinion, we didn’t play great, yet we still won the game.
“We had 114 points and shot 47 percent,” he continued. “But I didn’t think we did a good job, to be honest.”
Part of the Clippers’ lethargy may have stemmed from the fact that Sunday marked the second of back-to-back 12:30 PM tipoffs, an unfortunate reality of the NBA calendar, and the Staples Center scheduling totem pole.  But Jordan wouldn’t use it as any justification.
“This schedule is no excuse,” he said.  “Everybody else has 82 games piled up together also, so that is no excuse for us.
“We played poorly tonight, especially down the stretch,” Jordan continued.  “Some games you have got to grind it out and that is what we did today.
“Their guards had it going early.  We just tried to make it tough for them and not give up too many threes.  We wanted to limit those guys to one shot.  Like I said, some games you have got to grind it out and get stops when they count.”
Paul concurred saying, “They were getting in the paint, they were making shots, especially early.  But luckily we held on and we’ll take it.  All of them aren’t gonna be pretty.”
All in all, Lob City should feel lucky to have emerged victorious in this one.  While not to forget that the Clippers remain shorthanded themselves in the absence of Blake Griffin, who is still on the shelf with a partially torn left quad tendon, they looked totally out of sync at times on Sunday.  Once the Pelicans turned to heavier trapping of the Clipper ballhandlers up high in the second half, they largely failed to exploit the 4-on-3 situations generated by those traps.  Furthermore, they often looked uncomfortable executing their defensive schemes (which have featured increased switching on pick-and-rolls) against the Pelicans attack and were left with bad mismatches like Paul on Anderson for far too frequently.  
Though Mbah a Moute, another former Bruin, looked great with a season-high 14 points on some nice hard cuts to the hoop, there are still a lot of questions for this team’s identity without Griffin.  Redick, who has carried the team on many nights with his hot shooting, was just 2-for-10 on Sunday.  Meanwhile, both Lance Stephenson and Josh Smith remain bolted to the floorboard in the Coach Rivers’ doghouse.  Getting outrebounded 56-47 by a team missing their leading rebounder in Davis stings too, and the 14 turnovers and 52.9% mark from the line as a team certainly didn’t help matters either.  


Nevertheless, finding creative ways to get in the win column, even when you’re not at the top of your game, is key in the slog of an 82-game season.  Some nights, you’ll have to fight injuries, shooting slumps, or just general teamwide ineffectiveness, and that’s just a fundamental fact of the unpredictable NBA life.  What matters at the end of the day is victories, and that’s what the Clippers have been getting as of late, improving to an impressive 8-0 since Griffin went down and holding firm as the fourth seed in the Western Conference.  
The Clippers will next face the Miami Heat on Wednesday night, a 7:30 PM PST tipoff at Staples Center.  The Pelicans meanwhile, who fall to 11-25 with the loss, will stay in town and face the Lakers on Tuesday night, also a 7:30 PM PST tipoff at Staples.

title: Fallout 4 and The Power of The Soundtrack // Video Game Soundtrack Review
content:
For those that enjoy music, which I have a sneaking suspicion you do since you’re on a radio blog and reading this article, it has a power to it that can only be described as transformative.  Anything else would be a complete understatement.  It can immerse you in emotion, transport you to a far away and unfamiliar world, or evoke intense memories.  Bethesda Studios, the creators of smash hit video games like Fallout 3 and The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, are well aware of this and have paid close attention to the musical design of each of their games as a way to fully enrapture audiences in their already quite compelling worlds, but with Fallout 4 they appear to have out done themselves. 

 Taking place in a post-apocalyptic nuclear wasteland where technology kept advancing but culture halted in the 1950s, these games occupy a unique space in entertainment for their sheer scale and freedom.  As a result, it can be difficult to evoke intended emotional responses from the player simply because the designers have less control over any situation at hand.  To rectify this problem, Bethesda developed the idea of in game radio stations, often hosted by their very own DJ’s, allowing them to maintain a sense of continuity over the player experience.  While these were present in the landmark Fallout 3 and its Obsidian developed spinoff, Fallout: New Vegas, Fallout 4’s unique blend of previously used music, new tracks, and a classical station allow it to emphasize those three aforementioned abilities that music has for a listener.  

Any former Fallout player cannot help but get nostalgic when they’re roaming the wasteland with their favorite laser rifle and suddenly the Ink Spots’ classic, “I Don’t Want to Set the World on Fire,” begins.  What served as simply a main theme for the previous game due to the lyrical content relating well to a nuclear hellscape, now carries the much greater weight of each individual’s memories of their adventures in the Capital Wasteland and the nostalgia they have for that.  Then new additions like Nat King Cole’s “Orange Colored Sky” or Dion’s “The Wanderer” establish a thematic through line for the franchise and keep one immersed in a world that never made it to the latter half of the 20th century musically. 

 Finally the addition of a classical music station allows for a departure from the somewhat ironic use of the happy and romantic songs of the 40s and 50s to something more evocative.  Its hard not to feel the epic nature of one’s quest when facing up against super mutants to the tune of Tchaikovsky’s “Marche Slave” or find the kind of twisted beauty of the bombed out world while listening to Camille Saint-Saens “The Carnival of the Animals” Suite.  Overall, its position within the franchise as the game to capitalize on nostalgia, and the special attention paid to not only immersive music, but also evocative music, has made Fallout 4 a lesson to all others in creating a perfect soundtrack.

Words By: David Wright

title: NBA Stars, the Magic, and Why You Should Trust the Process
content:
Written By: Aidan Donahue, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date: 12/10/16

When looking back at NBA champions, a key trend emerges that characterizes nearly every winner: they are led by top 10, and often top three NBA players. There are few other sports that can emphasize an individual like basketball can. The players must play both ends of the floor. The best player is almost always the center of the offense, and can be the crux of the defense too. They can play every game, and can be on the floor for nearly the whole game. For these reasons, if a team is building towards a championship, it is critical to have an elite foundational superstar.

All of the best NBA teams have at least one. The Warriors trot out Stephen Curry and Kevin Durant every game. Their shooting and playmaking ability act as cornerstones for the Golden State’s offense. Steve Kerr is able to leverage the gravity that commands to free up the entire offense. If the team is sputtering, one of them has the potential to go supernova and get the warriors back in the game.

The Cavs have Lebron James, who exemplifies the need for a superstar. He can impact the game in every way. If his team needs defense, his high flying chase down blocks will provide it. If they need play making, he’ll get into the paint and dish out to shooters. If they need baskets, he’ll take his man to the cup and feast on layups. The Cavs build everything they do around Lebron’s dominance and versatility, giving them an identity and a response to any challenges.

Kawhi Leonard from the Spurs provides a two-way impact that is unparalleled in the league. Not only is he the center of their offense, but he defines their defense. His ability to guard everyone but centers impairs the other team’s offense. He can latch onto the other team’s best player, sucking the life out of them with perfect footwork, hands like black holes, and a keen understanding of angles and timing. He changes the way offenses can play. To have one player who can create that much impact is necessary if your team needs to stop the league’s best offenses.

You’re probably thinking, “Duh, having the best players makes it easier to win.” But there are sacrifices that need to be made to obtain players of this caliber: sacrifices in wins. Some franchises would rather stay in the playoffs then put all their chips into a lottery system designed to reward losing.

After years in the lottery, the Magic have committed themselves to win-now mode. They have lost patience in fishing through high draft picks, looking for a top-tier star. Instead, they have elected to sign a variety of veteran players to try and compliment their collection of young stars. They are throwing shit at a wall and hoping it makes a sandwich. However, their smorgasbord of players has left them without a direction and without an identity.

They currently sit at 6-9, one game out of the eighth seed. However, they are currently 29th in net rating (point differential per 100 possessions.) This is largely due to their last place spot on offensive efficiency. There are many factors that contribute to this, including a lack of spacing and 3 point shooting. They start Elfrid Payton (18.9 percent from three), Aaron Gordon (29.5 percent), and Vucevic (25 percent). Overall, their team shoots 31.9 percent from deep. This severely limits their ability to score (three is more than two), but more importantly, it limits their spacing. The lanes are cramped, so their players have little room to move.

This can be drawn back to their lack of a foundational star. If a team has a core player to build around, then they can surround them with role players. The Magic are forced to have everyone play a role in between role-player and centerpiece. They need to scrounge for talent to try to get some semblance of playmaking, forcing them to neglect the fit of these players with one another. In doing so, they have woefully neglected shooting. If they had a foundational star, then they could surround them with specialists, similar to J.R. Smith’s role next to Lebron.

But they have become impatient. This offseason, they moved away from young talent towards proven veterans. They signed Bismack Biyombo and Jeff Green. They traded young star Victor Oladipo and draft pick Domantas Sabonis for Serge Ibaka. Instead of diving deeper to try to obtain a young star, they moved into win-now mode. In doing so, they capped their ceiling at around a 7-seed and an early playoff exit.

The Philadelphia 76ers dove head first into the lottery system. Long time GM Sam Hinkie designed the teams to lose a lot, hoarding draft picks and other assets. They wanted a star, and they knew the best place to get one is at the top of the draft. They refrained from signing free agents, and drafted players with major health problems coming out of college, such as Nerlens Noel and Joel Embiid. Over the past three years, this has resulted in a 19-63, 18-64, and 10-72 records, in order. Pretty awful fan experience.

Yet it worked. The Sixers drafted Ben Simmons out of LSU with their number one overall pick this year. A 6’10’’ athlete with the power of a big man and the agility of a guard, Simmons combines positions in a way that is key for success in the current NBA. He has the handle and passing of a high-level point guard, but can rebound (11.8 per game in college) and dominate the paint like a high-level forward. On offense, he could be a hyper-athletic Draymond Green, with his ability to pass in both roles of the pick-and-roll and to run a fast break after grabbing a board. His potential is sky high. However, he is out with a broken foot, and there is no timetable for his return. There is risk of this injury persisting, but the Sixers have shown great patience in rehabbing injured players, as evidenced by Joel Embiid.

After rehabbing various injuries for the first two years of his career, Embiid has come out on a tear this year. He has reportedly grown to about 7’2’’, although he is officially listed at seven feet. A powerful and smooth athlete, he has the ability to protect the rim and switch onto guards. He’s averaging 3.8 blocks per 36 minutes. This rare combined ability is key for defensive success in the modern NBA. He brings a beautiful melody of modern and past center play on offense. A mix of post moves - including a nasty dream shake - allow him to score inside well. His athleticism makes him a dangerous pick-and-roll threat. His shooting stretches defense thin, as shown by his 46.2 percent split from long-range. Embiid is showing just how much a center can do in today’s NBA. Him and Karl-Anthony Towns have the highest ceiling of any young big man in the game. That potential alone makes the process worth it. Even more enticing, it looks like Embiid will reach it.

The Sixers now have a direction. They have potential All-NBA players to build around. They have the potential for an identity. This structure is invaluable. Trust the process.

title: Pineda for Montero: A Reflection on a Rare Swap of Superstar Prospects in Baseball
content:
Written By : Chase Madorsky, UCLA Radio Sports (10/11/16)

Let’s go back to January 14, 2012, when something rare occurred in the game of baseball; two teams swapping stud prospects with one another, both trading from areas of strength to try to patch up their weaknesses. Coming off of a rookie year in which he went 9-10 with a 3.74 ERA and 173 strikeouts, (at the time) twenty two year old righty Michael Pineda was traded from the Seattle Mariners to the New York Yankees in exchange for Jesus Montero. Despite questions as to whether or not he would stick at catcher, the twenty one year old Montero had impressed with his short time in the majors in 2011, hitting .328 with four home runs and 28 RBIs in only eighteen games.

Although it seemed to come out of nowhere, the trade made a ton of sense for both teams. At the time, the Yankees were rich in catching depth, with Russell Martin coming off an All Star appearance at the major league level, and Austin Romine waiting in the wings in AAA, and John Ryan Murphy and Gary Sanchez down in the lower levels of the minors as well. However, the rotation had major question marks beyond workhorse ace CC Sabathia following the season, with Freddy Garcia and Bartolo Colon both fighting father time, and with the questions surrounding young and unproved arms in Phil Hughes and Ivan Nova, as well as AJ Burnett’s continued ineffectiveness. Not only would Pineda bring his electric stuff to New York, but it was also thought he would also give the Yankees a righty ace compliment to Sabathia, while also giving them a trio of young and affordable starters (Hughes and Nova) under the age of twenty five to go along with the newly signed Hiroki Kuroda.

For the Mariners, who finished in last place in their division with 67 wins, the trade was made to give them a much-needed infusion of offense. In the 2011 season, Miguel Olivio led the team with only nineteen home runs, while Ichiro Suzuki led all regulars with a .272 average. And despite only playing in eighteen games, the Mariners front office felt that Montero would give them a true middle of the order presence, one they had been lacking greatly since the days of Brett Boone and Edgar Martinez amongst others. From their standpoint, losing Pineda would be offset by the work of their ace, Felix Hernandez, (Who was only one year removed from winning the AL Cy Young Award) as well as inning eaters Hisashi Iwakuma from Japan, and lefty Jason Vargas. Additionally, much like the Yankees were deep at catcher at the lower levels, the same could be said about the Mariners pitching prospects, with Taijuan Walker, Danny Hultzen, and James Paxton all waiting in the wings.

Over four years, and five MLB seasons have passed since this blockbuster trade, and needless to say, it did not pan out for either team. For the Mariners, Montero had a respectable rookie season in 2012, playing in one hundred thirty five games, and putting up fifteen home runs and sixty two runs batted in, albeit with a low .260 average and .298 on base percentage. However, with Montero only twenty-two, the future still seemed bright. But in reality, 2012 was the peak of Montero’s playing career, as he started the season so poorly in 2013 that he was demoted to AAA after only twenty-nine games, where he not only tore his meniscus, but was also hit with a fifty game suspension for his involvement in the Biogenesis PED scandal.

2014 presented the lowest point in Montero’s career, as he showed up to camp weighing 275 pounds, prompting Mariners GM Jack Zduriencik to proclaim he had “zero expectations” for Montero. Spending most of the year in the minors, Montero’s infamy reached a new level when playing through a rehab assignment with the Everett AquaSox, when the Mariners banned Montero from playing the remainder of the 2014 season after he threw an ice cream sandwich at and threatened an AquaSox instructor in the stands. The Mariners again brought up Montero in 2015, with little effect on the field in his thirty-eight games back with the big club; he was released in 2016. Despite being signed by the Blue Jays and being named a AAA All Star in 2016, Montero was again on the wrong side of the news, as he was hit with a second fifty game suspension, this time for testing positive for a banned substance.

Although the Yankees acquired Pineda in January of 2012, he would not make his Pinstripe debut until the 2014 season due to injury. Following Spring Training in 2012, the Yankees placed Pineda on the 15 day disabled list with right shoulder tendinitis, which later led to a labral tear in his right shoulder and season ending surgery in May. All be told, the rehab process lasted until July of 2013, where he was optioned to the Yankees AAA Scranton Wilkes affiliate for the remainder of the season.

With the anticipation for a now healthy Pineda at an all time high heading into the 2014 season, he delivered, posting a 1.83 ERA in 192⁄3 innings over his first four starts. Yet Pineda’s season would not be without controversy, as on April 23, 2014, in a start against the Boston Red Sox, Pineda was ejected in the second inning after umpires discovered pine tar, a banned substance in the MLB, on his neck. Pineda was suspended ten games, and then later strained his neck, causing him to be absent until August. Despite the controversy, Pineda did finish the year with a 5–5 record and a 1.89 ERA in 76 1⁄3 innings, pitching strong in a small sample size.

The highlight of Pineda’s tenure in Pinstripes game in 2015, when on May 10th he struck out sixteen Orioles with no walks over the course of seven innings. Outside of this one start, Pineda struggled with consistency in 2015 and 2016, as although he made 59 starts across the two seasons, he did so with an 18-22 record, as well as a very high 4.60 ERA and 1.290 WHIP. However, 2016 did find Pineda amongst the AL leader boards, as he finished in the top ten in starts, strikeouts, and strikeout to walk ratio, while also leading the league in strikeouts per nine innings.

Clearly, this trade did not work out as envisioned in 2012 for the Mariners or the Yankees. Yet if we had to pick a winner, it seems we are forced to choose the Yankees, as although Pineda dealt with his own suspension and injuries, he did give the Yankees two and a half season of solid (if unspectacular starts) starts, and despite his maddening inconsistency eventually became an arm the Yankees could give the ball to every five days. On the other hand, Montero only played one full season with the Mariners before flaming out, and in the process dealt with issues over his weight, drug use, and on the field conduct, making fans wonder if Montero was ever all that great, or simply another part of the New York hype machine. When this trade occurred, it was the talk of baseball; yet now, almost five years later, it will go down as one of the ultimate “what if” trades in baseball history had both prospects panned out and played up to their potentials.

title: Top 5 Most Anticipated Acts at ArcTanGent
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 09/26/16

For anyone who’s a fan of math rock, ArcTanGent Festival (August 18-20) is the holy Mecca. Every devoted disciple must make the pilgrimage to Bristol at least once. As someone who dedicates an hour every week to blasting my favorite math and prog jams across the interwaves, it’s a trip I was beyond excited to make and you can be sure I spent excessive amounts of time exploring every band on the lineup. While I discovered plenty of new favorite bands at the festival, there were definitely bands I was already familiar with that I knew I couldn’t miss. In conjunction with my other list here, this list could be nicknamed “Least Surprising Acts at ArcTanGent” because they were bands I had sought out early on and knew would totally blow me away (that said, there were still plenty of fun surprises to be had).

Note: Obviously with a festival lineup as deep as ArcTanGent’s, there are so many more acts I was looking forward to seeing and who blew me away than I have space to discuss. For this reason, I’m omitting many of the festival’s headlining acts from this list in order to give way to some of the lesser-known acts. So while American Football, Three Trapped Tigers, And So I Watch You From Afar and others may not be listed below, let it be known that they were not only highly anticipated leading up to the festival, but that they wildly surpassed all expectations and gave unforgettable performances that I’m thankful to have been able to witness. I’m also leaving off TTNG, even though they were one of the highlights of Day 1, since I already published a review for the opening night of their US tour last month (can be read here) However, that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t check out my interview with them here.

5) Bearded Youth Quest
My excitement to see Bearded Youth Quest on the Bixler stage was ignited earlier this year the first time I heard the opening yell of “Banana Flip-flop”, an electrifying jam with a title derived from the rhythm of the song’s opening riff. As their name suggests, the band is a fairly young group who are clearly on a quest to deliver fun, energetic guitar-driven math rock to the masses. There was never a dull moment in their set and even the most complex sections of their songs were never without lightness and joy. Whether it’s on their album or the festival stage, the group sounds primarily like a bunch of guys in a room trying to write songs that everyone can get excited about.

4) Floral
Unlike most of the other bands on this list, my anticipation for Floral’s set wasn’t because I had never seen them live before. It was because I had seen them live many times and couldn’t wait to see how they would do on the festival stage. As someone who’s known the band for many years, seeing their first tour culminate on such a monumental stage was really special. The set was everything anyone could hope for. The band brought their usual energy and tight jams with some special surprises and additions to match the grand scale of the venue they were playing. It was the longest set I’d seen them play, which was definitely a treat. They were even joined onstage by a hat juggler during one of their songs. Just as exciting as the performance itself was the audience’s reaction. When I arrived at the PX3 stage, the crowd had already overflowed far beyond the reaches of the tarp covering the stage. Regardless of their familiarity or proximity to the band, everyone in the crowd was eagerly transfixed on the music. In talking with other festival goers following Floral’s set, it seemed like at least half of the people who had witnessed the set were previously unfamiliar with the band, but all had been blown away and genuinely enjoyed what they’d heard. 
(Read my interview with the band about their UK tour here)

3) Town Portal
The word I use to describe myself whenever I see Town Portal live is one I hardly use under any other circumstances: giddy. I don’t know if it’s being able to dance to such a fat and gritty bass tone or some other ineffable quality that peaks my math rock geekiness to such obscenely high levels, but for whatever reason, I simply couldn’t keep from smiling throughout their entire set. They are one of the truest three-piece bands I’ve experienced, for while each member will individually stun you in every song, the music is never dominated by a single instrument or personality. Although each musician’s part is not without its complexities and asymmetricalities, the music as a whole is always rock solid. What made me most ecstatic about Town Portal’s set was finding out that their grooves sound just as heavy live as they do on their albums, but much louder and with the added bonus of being able to share in the excitement of all the other people who’re just as thrilled to be there as you are. The band must have caught onto some of this joy partway through their set, for they asked the audience to form a “hopscotch circle”, which was essentially a mosh pit except everyone was just skipping in circles, during one of their songs.  It would be a strange request coming from most other bands, but for this group the crowd was more than happy to oblige.

2) toe
Seeing as math and music are both universal and without cultural barriers, it makes perfect sense that math rock is a highly diverse genre that can be traced all around the world. That said, there are few countries that have provided the world with the same volume of stellar math rock bands that Japan has. Ask anyone about the Japanese math rock scene and they’re bound to mention toe as one of the top bands the country has produced. Plain and simple, they are legendary among the math rock elite. Back when I was first discovering the genre, I had multiple friends mentioning toe as an essential band to look up. This was in large part because of the band’s drummer, Kashikura Takashi, whose drum parts are both the anchor and the driving force behind the band’s music. With plenty of varying electric and acoustic instrumental textures from one song to the next, Takashi’s complex rhythmic patterns are immediately recognizable and firmly place the band on the top tier of math rock that defies the misguided stereotype of being purely mechanical and without feeling, paired expertly with melodic guitar lines that are of the highest technique yet still feel organic. Experiencing their music live in the purest form was exhilarating and definitely a huge item on my concert bucket list.

1) Cleft
When Cleft took the stage for their last ever show on Friday afternoon, they were greeted like rock stars. From the first note they played, they made it clear that they would be leaving everything out on the stage. The reception from the crowd showed that they too knew that this was going to be a very special show for everyone involved. The setlist featured both old and new songs, all of which had been chosen by fans in a Facebook poll prior to the festival. Dan Wild-Beesley’s already bulging guitar tone was further amplified by the electricity that ran through the audience, which in turn fed into the thundering energy and precision of John Simm’s drumming. To put it plainly, I have never heard such an enthusiastic singalong at an instrumental concert. Fans were singing along to complex mathy guitar lines like they were the outro of “Hey Jude”. There were even moments when Dan would omit playing certain phrases, unable to compete with the volume and vigor of the crowd. If there had been no festival and this had been the only concert I’d seen, it would still be one of the greatest shows I’ve ever witnessed. The emotions were high, the love was real, and the music was heavy as hell. The set was riddled with surprises and guest appearances from other members of the math rock community, with Ben Forrester of Bad Grammar filling in on vocals on the track “Elephant In The Bar Room”. The band saved the best surprise for last, closing the show with a medley of Motörhead, Prince, and David Bowie which was joined by Nick Duke of Trojan Horse on vocals and Tom Peters, guitarist of Alpha Male Tea Party. It was an emotional ending to say the least and while it was still very sad to see this band walk off for the last time, I will forever be grateful to have been present at such a poignant moment in the band’s, and the festival’s, history.
(You can read my conversation with Dan Wild-Beesley about Cleft’s final show here.)

title: Foxes, Mancs, and New Places: A Brief Premier League Preview
content:
Written by: Faizan Malik, UCLA Radio Sports Member

Posted: 09/19/16

After a long three months the Premier League returned this past weekend and this season bodes to be one of the most exciting of all time. With one of the most tumultuous summers in recent years, fans of the English top flight have been left with a number of burning questions.

How will Leicester City fare?

           Leicester City shocked the world last year, when Claudio Raineri led the Foxes to their first and only top flight title. They won the league by playing a pragmatic yet beautiful counter attacking style. Leicester have had a melancholic summer amid transfer rumors surrounding Jamie Vardy, Riyad Mahrez, and N’golo Kante. While Vardy and Mahrez remain in Leicester for now, Kante joined Chelsea for £30 million. The Foxes loss to Hull City this past weekend illustrated how Kante’s loss will affect Leicester. Without Kante acting as the engine of their midfield, they looked vulnerable in the middle. Drinkwater especially looked out of place without his usual midfield partner. Although Leicester bought Ahmed Musa, who should provide a lot to the team if he can gel well with Vardy, they haven’t added much depth to their thin squad. The additional Champions League matches will take their toll on the Foxes and cost them some domestic success. Fortunately for Leicester, they have Claudio Raneiri at the helm. With Raneiri’s quality, I expect Leicester to finish anywhere from 6th to 10th depending on how the Foxes deal with the added pressures of European football.

How will Manchester United’s high profile signings perform?

           In July, the Red Devils signed Zlatan Ibrahimovic, one of the most prolific strikers in the world. The next day, they bought Henrikh Mkhitarayan, the Bundesliga Players’ Player of the Season, from Borussia Dortmund. A month later, Manchester United overshadowed both of these impressive additions by signing Paul Pogba for a world record £89.3 million. At times last year Manchester United were lamented as a boring side that lacked creativity. With the addition of these three players and Jose Mourinho as the new manager, the Mancs will be anything but boring. Mkhitarayan, at least on paper, should be able to make a seamless transition to Premier League having previously played in the similarly physical Bundesliga. Furthermore, Mkhitarayan thrived under Dortmund’s direct play, which should help him adapt to Mourinho’s infamous counter attacking tactics. Mourinho helped develop Hazard into one of the best wingers in the world and I have no doubts that he can do the same for Mkhitarayan. Zlatan Ibrahimovic, like Mkhitarayan, has the tools to play well in England. On Sunday, Ibrahimovic had a dream debut against Bournemouth, scoring from 25 yards out. He has the physicality to deal with the toughest tacklers in the league, while he also has the technical skills to create goals for himself. Unless his age finally catches up to him, I fully expect Ibrahimovic to bag around 20 goals and a few assists. Despite being perhaps the most hyped of Manchester United’s recent arrivals, I believe Paul Pogba will initially struggle to adapt to life in the Premier League. Despite starting most game for Euro 2016 runners-up France, his performances were relatively anonymous and hardly representative of his price tag. Pogba performs best as an advanced midfielder, but Mourinho, like Didier Deschamps, may choose to play him in a deeper midfield role. I expect Paul Pogba to start his Manchester United with a bang, scoring a screamer, but then hitting a bad midseason slump. Manchester United fans have nothing to worry about though as Pogba is still just 23 and can only improve. United paid for his potential rather than his current quality.

Can the three newly promoted clubs avoid relegation?

           Middlesbrough, Hull City, and Burnley all returned to Premier League action. While Middlesbrough haven’t been in the top flight since 2009, Hull City and Burnley have developed into yo-yo clubs that are constantly relegated and promoted. Middlesbrough have made a statement of intent by bringing in some big names like Alvaro Negredo and Victor Valdes who boast international experience and quality. Additionally, Gaston Ramirez and Stewart Downing, know the ins and outs of the Premier League and will seamlessly transition to life in the top flight. Out of the three promoted teams, Middlesbrough have the strongest side on paper and should be able to steer clear of relegation if they perform to their ability. Hull City, on the other hand, look sure favorites to go right back down to the Championship. Although they managed to beat Leicester on the opening day, Hull City only had 13 available players. Furthermore, the club is in the process of being sold and doesn’t have a manager. Without any semblance of stability on or off the field, Hull will find it difficult to survive the Premier League. Burnley will also struggle this season in the Premier League due to simple lack of quality. Besides George Boyd, the team reeks of mediocrity. Sam Vokes and Andre Gray formed a formidable strike partnership last year in the Championship, but I’m not convinced they have the quality to perform in the Premier League. They couldn’t create many chances in their defeat against Swansea City on Saturday. Unless they bring in some new faces, Burnley won’t survive this Premier League season due to a lack of skill.

Quick Fire Predictions:

League Champions: Manchester City

Champions League places: Manchester City, Manchester United, Liverpool, Arsenal

Relegated: Hull City, Burnley, Sunderland

Best Signing for value: Zlatan Ibrahimovic

Breakout Season: Alex Iwobi

Golden Boot: Harry Kane

Golden Glove: De Gea

title: PC Music: More than overproduction and high-pitched vocals. I think.
content:
Written By : Maxamillion Polo, UCLA Radio DJ

Photos By: Jimmy Bazzy, UCLA Radio Alumni

July 27, 2016

PC Music is a UK based record label headed by A.G. Cook, one of the collective’s most prominent producers. The label has managed to quickly gain a strong and passionate following, thriving mostly amongst online communities. It is difficult to imagine talking about internet-based music collectives nowadays without including PC Music in the conversation. As for the overall sound of the label, it has been described as the future sound of electronic music, as well as being an active parody on the current direction of the pop genre, all through of the use of pitch-shifted female vocals and intense production. The label has received notoriety for having the possibility to shift the future direction of both the pop and electronic music scenes; some have even gone as far as championing it as a sign of the end of electronic music as we know it, while others see it as as a new movement with the potential to elevate the club scene back to its once vibrant ‘90s status. PC Music, along with Redbull Music Academy Radio, held a club night in Los Angeles showcasing off some of the label’s brightest stars. So, the only logical decision was to down a few Sambuca Redbulls and see for myself if these kids were another internet fad or actually capable of rejuvenating the pop and electronic scenes to a whole new height.

The first noticeable thing upon entering such an event was the aesthetic of it all. The room was brimming with twenty-something adults uniformly wearing all white or a mix of bright fuchsia and pastel pink with reflective neon sunglasses despite being indoors. It was like walking into the strange lovechild of an early ‘90s club scene and the human manifestation of internet culture. The attention given to aesthetic details extended far beyond the crowd itself and permeated every aspect of the night’s performances. First to the stage was easyFun, radiating the feeling of drowning in a soda fountain sea of Orange Crush, taking the stage in an orange sweater under the glow of orange lights. Much like opinions regarding PC Music as a whole, each artist from the collective’s atmosphere was divisive from one another as could be. Next was Spinee, a noticeable standout of the first part of the night, who followed with an ode to early MySpace electronic music all while incorporating internet in-jokes that gave off the sense of losing yourself in a twisted version of the Matrix. The night continued with Lil Data sticking with primarily minimalist techno visuals, GFOTY performing a raucous set flanked with spastic red visuals and a pair of male and female strippers, and Felicita roaming around the stage, with an iPad in hand, accompanied by performers adorning elaborate makeup blowing bubbles into the crowd. Before the main names of the label had even taken the stage, it had already felt like I had seen everything from the personification of internet culture to a fine performance art piece I was not all too sure I understood.

The next chapter of the night was perhaps the most bizarre as some of PC Music’s most prominent producers were joined by two of the biggest names in pop music. The climax was led by QT, who serves PC Music as their marketed pop star and living embodiment of a somewhat fictitious energy drink. QT took the stage in a robotic fashion where she grandiosely opened a can of said beverage, capitalizing on the crowd’s elation over such a simple yet now suddenly magical task, before jumping into a number of songs that were reminiscent of some of the best radio friendly pop hits released in recent memory. The rest of the night shifted towards a more straightforward, albeit at times slightly experimental, pop and electronic direction. A.G. Cook invited Hannah Diamond on stage to sing a few ballads revolving around young love and dreaming of being noticed by that special someone. The two ended their set with popstar Charli XCX joining them to perform a number of electronic anthems, which had the essence of eurodance hits from the likes of Alice Deejay and Underworld. The final chapter of the showcase began in extraordinary fashion as Danny L Harle took the stage. I noticed that standing beside me was easyFun, A.G. Cook, and Hannah Diamond, hollering at the top of their lungs as their friend began his set. The end of the night was signaled by the PC Music group standing beside me going hysterical with the rest of the crowd as pop idol Carly Rae Jepsen took the stage to perform two unreleased songs with Danny L Harle. The night was an infusion from the depths of internet culture, experimental electronic music, and at times pop in its purest form.

Is PC Music more than just another passing internet subculture that is likely to see its end in the near future or can it be considered the future of pop music? The only thing that I am sure of after losing my surroundings in a stream of constant fog machines and flashing purple lights, as the room filled with the mixture of early club music and modern production tweaked to its most extremes, was that it was a lively and carefree time. The night was evocative of a club scene that is rarely available now and was mostly unavailable during its peak to most of the youth-aged crowd. It is currently unclear whether PC Music is capable of anything as grandiose as being the new direction of pop music or revitalizing the club scene, but as I watched easyFun, Hannah Diamond, and A.G. Cook effervescently cheering on their peer, while dancing maniacally in the crowd, it was clear that the PC Music collective love the direction they are currently headed and have managed to find a devoted following that feels the same way.

title: Joji @ the El Rey (2/1/2019) // Show Review
content:
article and photographs by Baolinh Nguyen

A few months ago, my cousin, my roommate and I all tried to get tickets to see Joji together and surprisingly, I was the only successful one. I bought our three tickets and the show ended up selling out within minutes. If anything, this is a testament to the mainstream success that JOJI - real name George Miller and formerly Filthy Frank - and the rest of the 88 Rising, a collective of Asian artists, have attained.

Honestly, I wasn’t sure what to expect the days leading up to the show. I knew who Filthy Frank was and I knew the types of fans he had. I had also heard stories of Joji coming on stage performing drunk with a red Solo cup in hand. Knowing this, I prepared myself for an intense concert experience.

When our Uber dropped us off, I saw a sizable line wrapping around the El Rey. I was relieved to see that there was nobody wearing any pink guy suits or any other esoteric Filthy Frank related gear. We headed to the end of the line and waited outside for around 15-20 minutes before the doors opened and we began trickling in. As we walked in the staff handed us all electronic wristbands with the 88 Rising logo on them to be used later in the show.

The opener was a small artist named Rei Brown. His set was chill; his lo-fi aesthetic and ethereal-sounding vocals reminded me of Joji. (I even overheard someone new to me say “Wait, I thought this was Joji”) His performance, however, wasn’t very dynamic and at times, a lot of his songs sort of melded together and sounded like a single song that lasted 30 minutes.

The crowd became unengaged part of the way through Rei Brown’s set — you could hear a lot of talking and people were on their phones — but when Joji came on, the atmosphere completely changed.

He opened with “Will He” and the audience immediately began screaming as soon as the song began. It seemed like everyone knew the lyrics and compared to the studio version, the live version was much more exciting. One thing I noticed was the Joji was so good live. A lot of times, his studio versions were very lo-fi and the vocals sounded a bit muddy. But that night, I just kept thinking that his singing was so much better in person.

Some memorable moments were when he performed “Head in the Clouds” and his encore “Slow Dancing in the Dark”.

During “Head in the Clouds”, the wristbands we were initially given lit up in unison for the first time to accompany the song and the lights he had on stage. And honestly, even if it’s a bit cheesy, it really enhanced the concert experience.

During his encore, he performed two versions of “Slow Dancing in the Dark”, first an acoustic version and the original version. Both were incredible and really ended the night on a high note.

Overall, some of my favorite moments were those two, and also when he performed one of my favorite songs, “Yeah Right.”

Still, I was left a bit unsatisfied; his set was only around 45 minutes, which is not very long at all. I felt like there could have been more but at the same time, his discography is not very expansive and the songs he does have are already quite short. I guess one good thing that comes from that is that the songs are easy to remember and most people can sing along to at least parts of all the song. Despite that, it was a really enjoyable experience; when my roommate and I got back to our room, we just sat there and listened to the entire album over again. In the end, seeing Joji live gave me a greater appreciation for him as an artist and especially as a singer.

title: Good Charlotte @ The Wiltern (11/21/18) // Show Review
content:
article and photographs by Gomi Zhou

I hopped in an Uber super early that day and arrived about 2 hours before the doors would even open at the Wiltern, considering that it was the day before Thanksgiving and everyone was trying to rush out of the LA traffic jam. Once I saw the line that was wrapping around the venue I knew I’ve committed a crime. How could I possibly wear COLORS to a Good Charlotte show? This is just pure disrespect. The ONE day oh my god, I generally don’t even wear colors on a daily basis. I tried my hardest to not feel ashamed as I walked through the monochromatic crowd in my bright blue sweater, but the stares were definitely there. 

After camping out at the boba place across the street for two whole hours waiting for the doors to open, I got to Will Call with the hope that I can just get a balcony ticket. Of course, I got floor instead. It was a very guilty wish to have for me, since Alt Rock is indeed my favorite genre and tonight I was going to see both Good Charlotte and Sleeping With Sirens; but at this point I’ve already gone through another lecture on top of my 8am major class (for reference I was supposed to have three but I just had to skip one or else it would’ve been inhumane towards myself), few more hours being stuck in the LA traffic, all using the non-existed fuel I’ve got from my 5 hours of sleep from the night before. I had my camera, a prism, a jacket and guess what–a John Green book–stuffed in my backpack. I really should be excited for this, I thought to myself, but in reality, I was just exhausted from weeks of hard work and the resulting breakdowns. This better be a good night, I needed it. 

This was one of those nights that had to start off early because there were just so many opening acts. The Dose and Knuckle Puck took the stage for a good hour. Although it was clear that most people came for the other two bands performing that night, the crowd was actively trying to pump up the spirit by being supportive and energetic. From screamo to pop rock, everyone was aware that the first two bands were just the pre-gaming for the night; but the quality of the performances had sure kept everyone’s interest.

Because of how exhausted I was, I sat down behind the soundboard area in between different acts. Thus, I was completely oblivious of the flow of the crowd until the lights went off once again for Sleeping With Sirens. The size of the audience had at least doubled its size since Knuckle Puck had left the stage. Everyone was cheering and screaming nonsense off their lungs–just how one would expect at a rock show. Shortly after, the long-awaited band went on with one of their classic numbers, “Do It Now Remember It Later”. I had very basic knowledge of Sleeping With Sirens prior to the show. Knowing that they are one of the most noticeable figures for the emo community, I always have massive respect for the band. Although their music is really not something I would casually listen to while I’m skateboarding to class, this performance they were putting on tonight was everything a rock fan could ever ask for. It was the first time in a good while where I felt like my beloved passion in photography was becoming a chore, all I wanted was to put my camera away and devote all my attention to the performance. From “Empire of Ashes” to “Congratulations”, the crowd and I gave our all. There’s something very unique to the genre of rock, no matter what the particular branch is, rock music never fails to make someone feel more alive. Of course, this wasn’t just any rock show, it was literally Sleeping With Sirens on stage opening up for Good Charlotte. I was mostly immersed in the atmosphere throughout the band’s 10-song set, but the speech on mental health made by the lead singer Kellin Quinn really stuck with me. He mentioned his own struggle with depression, and how even though he is the lead singer who was currently standing in front of a crowd performing, depression is something that can get to anybody. “This one is for all of you who’s struggling,” he said as the band latched onto “Better Off Dead”. I could only compare the crowd to Panic! At The Disco’s crowd during “Girls/Girls/Boys” and Fall Out Boy’s crowd during “Thnks fr th Mmrs”. It was obvious that this song was particularly special for both the band and its fanbase, that it carries a meaning connecting the artists and their supporters. When it comes to Emo and Rock bands, there is always the stigma attached to them saying that this is depression music and people who listen to Emo are a group of sad losers. But to me, it is moments like this that are able to prove that Rock only connects people and brings life back for them.

By this point, I’ve forgotten about how I was severely sleep deprived. Despite the fact that Sleeping With Sirens was potentially the best opening act one can ever get, Good Charlotte was extraordinarily legendary. Though the crowd at the Wiltern that night was huge, Joel Madden, the lead singer of Good Charlotte tried his best to sneak in as much conversation as possible. He went from talking about how the band started back when they were still teenagers and how many fans were probably listening to them back in middle school, to his perspectives on the political and social climate today. Specifically, Joel even talked about how many of their songs were written from a different time when things were different from today’s context. For example, even though the song “Girls & Boys” is obviously written as a satire in my perspective, the band still took their time to explain how the stereotypical and materialistic approach mentioned in the song is not valid in today’s society. It was obvious that these genuine talks brought the crowd closer and everyone was experiencing some kind of nostalgia in their own ways. For me, it was the song “Life Changes” that brought back the nostalgia for me. Despite the fact that my roommate and I really don’t have the most sentimental friendship, we have been friends for almost 6 years and have only gotten closer even with all the changes that had happened in our lives. Even though most members of different rock bands tend to keep their own lives private, most bands want their songs to be open for interpretations and want their fans to be able to relate to their life stories. With a band like Good Charlotte, everyone has their own journey with their music, and a night like this one serves to bring the pieces back.

title: MICK JENKINS @ EL RAY THEATER (1/12/2019) // Show Review
content:
article by Maya Krishnan

Pieces of a Man is Mick Jenkins’ new self-reflective album that explores being a black male finding an identity within a new environment cluttered with fame, drugs, women, and power.  He explores how each different aspect influences his values, and how these aid with building the different pieces of himself.  

Jenkins chose two distinct openers that are worthy of mentioning because of their individuality.  Stock Marley is a rapper who used his music as a therapy to organize and articulate the struggles that he has faced as a black man within America.  He talked and rapped about lessons he had learned from the obstacles he overcame, such as mentoring a troubled friend or being incarcerated three times, in hopes of teaching the audience to be kind and give love to one another.

On the other hand, Kari Faux rapped about her zero-fucks opinions regarding men, life, friends, and her job, all while dancing; her presence made it clear that the audience was privileged to be entertained by her.  Her minimalistic style is unique, and I see her going places.

Lastly, Mick Jenkins performed.  He came out with a red plaided coat (which came off after the second song), a baseball hat (which covered his eyes the whole time), some dope white Nikes, and plain jean pants.  His presence was calming, which was carried throughout the whole performance.  

He opened with U-Turn and Plain Clothes, to please the crowd, and as they got invested in the two most popular songs on his new album, he performed songs that were the more self-reflective and personal. Jenkins also rapped with a singer that only sang during certain songs. During the songs that were therapeutic to Jenkins, the accompanist barely sang; but, during songs that were made to, probably, please his record company, like Plain Clothes, they both dominated the stage equally.  

Furthermore, he performed songs from his 2014 mixtape The Waters, which I remembering discovering on Datpiff when I was a youngin.  Before performing, his most famous songs, “Jazz” and “Martyrs,” he talked about his self-growth since he made that mixtape, and thanked his fans for sticking and listening to him. Jenkins presented himself as an artist who sees his art as a collective reflection of himself, which he is able to communicate with an audience.

Personally, my favorite part of the concert was when he was so invested in rapping a song, like “Ghost,” that it felt like he forgot about the audience to entertain.  He just stood in place, as a singular man reflecting about his years and moments leading him up to the point of being able to perform on a sold-out stage.

title: G Flip @ The Echo (11/13/2018) // Show Review
content:
“A Tuesday night at the Echo, through the eyes of a first timer.”

article and photographs by Grant Mooney

Having never been I assumed I’d be able to find parking fairly easily around the venue, but unfortunately, that wasn’t the case out there, because I mean c’mon, it’s LA. 

It took me about 30 minutes to snag a spot and headed into the venue. As I stepped in, immediately the intimate and comfortable ambiance engulfed me; two disco balls hanging from the ceiling, drink prices posted on warm movie theater style displays, low lighting all around, and Evalyn on stage. 

Although topping both following acts at the monthly listener stat on Spotify, the opener Evalyn smoothly yet powerfully got the night off to a hot start on stage. Later on, I found out from the very kind Evalyn herself that she wasn’t going to go on tour, but is a fan of G Flip and was in LA so she hopped into the night’s mix. 

As more crowd began to trickle into the venue, TOMI took the mic and got the rooms blood flowing with her powerful music and electric voice. TOMI’s diverse voice and music resemble a combination of Florence + The Machine and HAIM. 

With the crowd buzzed off TOMI, the Melbourne born former drummer now turned multi-instrumentalist singer G Flip took the stage starting where she started her career, on the drumset. With only 2 songs on Spotify, G Flip’s set included a majority of new music in combination with her two releases. 

Engaging the crowd from the moment she set on stage to the moment she stepped off, G Flip put on a show characterized by strong percussion talent. 

Speaking of engaging, before the final few songs, G Flip invited a friend on stage in order to set up a surprise engagement sealing off an already pleasant surprise packed night. 

G Flip, a humble and appreciative artist, is only getting her career started. The future of all three artists (Evalyn, TOMI, and G Flip) will be very fun to track over these upcoming years.

title: Troyboi @ The Novo (11/16/2018) // Show Review
content:
article and photographs by Mia Kayser

South East London musician and EDM revolutionary Troyboi graced downtown LA with his presence last Friday at The Novo. The venue, alive with pulsing crowds of late teens and early 20-somethings, began popping off with part lofi, hip-hop, and poppy-esque artist Bohkeh’s set, followed by the dark, bassy beats of Holly, who set the pace for Great Dane, the last opener. Great Dane’s hip-hop inspired beats appropriately braced audiences for the headliner. He maintained the crowd’s anticipatory energy, even surprising them with a brief and well-received appearance from Mr. Carmack, an EDM staple.

With a swagger palpable to everyone in the venue, Troyboi emerges onstage greeting the audience who accompanies him in the spelling of his stage name, his iconic trademark. Outside of the music, so many parts of Troyboi’s performance demonstrated the uniqueness he brings to EDM. During the beginning of his performance, breakdancers join him and impress the crowd with their gymnastic ability, never falling out of beat with the music.

The surprises don’t stop there–during “B.I.A” and “X2C”, two acrobats suspend themselves above the DJ, rotating in a hula hoop, occasionally and gracefully shifting with changes in his songs’ texture, mesmerizing audiences even more than before. Later, he even brings out a violinist to play the intro of newly released “Laalach.” She shifts into dancer mode, twirling around billowing sheets of colorful fabric, joined by another dancer following suit. Finally, he features rapper Healthy Chill to fulfill his part in “Hooper,” a Troyboi classic, and Destiny, whose vocals accompany Troyboi’s latest single, “Frustrated.”

Beyond his onstage guests, Troyboi also enhanced his performance with his epically trippy, silhouetting visuals. My favorites were during “Flamez,” where crisp footage of live flames and showering embers erupted and pulsed along with the music. Similar in sensory detail, he features visuals of water droplets during “Drip,” immersing the audience in the song in an intersection of the aural and visual. He also innovatively included an image of one of his songs’ SoundCloud profiles, which spastically glitched dynamically and vibrantly along the beat.

The show wrapped up seamlessly with “ili,” a legendary hit. The exhausted and blissful faces of crowd members trickling out of the venue indicated the show’s success. While Troyboi owes the world his signatory bouncy, hip-hop influences and his soul-infusing basslines, what’s for certain is that he’ll always have a welcoming home in LA.

title: Gus Dapperton @ El Rey Theatre (11/4/2018) // Show Review
content:
article by Anna Kondratyeva

Gus Dapperton is what 90s music would be if 90s music was stripped of its inherent nostalgia and thrust into a poppy, muted technicolor digital age. He rocks an ironic, very high bowl cut (you can DIY this if you use a very tiny bowl), jangly earrings, dad sweaters, and a Manic Panic catalog of hair dyes. His image evokes an aesthetic of social media angst, his Instagram consisting of him projecting sad boi hours while looking moodily out of his bed sheets. This makes him very appealing to young women who have pastel Instagram themes and are also occasionally sad, but then happy again because Gus Dapperton’s music is goddamn cathartic. Go on and hurt me, men. Gus is proof that you can take your heartbreak, mix it with urban ennui, and combine it to make creative genius. 

Because life is hard and unpredictable (“and I’m to blame for but once or more”, as Gus would say), my photographer flaked on me three hours before the show was to start, leaving me to utilize the only effective social network at my disposal, which, sadly, happens to be Tinder. I weeded my small army of matches for those who put ‘photographer’ in their bio (in LA, almost everyone), then ranked them in order of their expressed interest. The most non-threatening 20 received a calculated damsel-in-distress message, promising a free concert ticket and a fun—so fun! ;) —night. 

This is how I came to the show, filled with my-shared-Lyft-is-taking-an-hour-to-travel-4-miles neurotic energy, and waiting for someone who was willing to utilize expensive equipment to go to a last-minute concert with a stranger. After meeting up with my date the first thing that happened is that his backpack was searched and his (apparently expensive) bottle of tequila was angrily thrown out by security. I wanted to convince my date that I was sure Mr. Dapperton personally would not mind the tequila, but he was in mourning and I let him grieve. Gus Dapperton was delayed gratification; the prize for our patiently listening to an artist that nobody really knew before the legend himself appeared. I could feel a hundred hopeful female hearts flutter and fall as the opener, Beshken, came on stage, wearing an entire outfit of crumpled white linen and laden with a mess of electronic equipment. 

Beshken was…a character. We spent a good 30 minutes trying to figure out what drugs he was on, as well as calculate the constantly changing rhythm by which he thrashed his head up and down. The best way I can describe his music is as experimental lo-fi electro-rock, his atmospheric beats complemented by the bass guitar he would randomly pick up and riff on most of the show consisted of him moving sliders up and down on his sound mixer with great concentration and occasionally making indulgent eye contact with the audience, creating a strange sense of his sensory isolation on stage. This aura was punctuated with sporadic interjections of “LA, what the fuck is up” before subsequent retreats back into spasmodic head nodding. In the end, after surviving 15 minutes of seizure-inducing strobe lights (and a succeeding headache), I can’t say I was happy to see Beshken leave the stage, but definitely a little relieved. 

After milling around for 30 minutes and bonding over our collective music tastes, my date and I began to respect each other as more than means to achieve our separate goals. The air was taut with anticipation for our stylistic icon and emotional role model, creating a spirit of conviviality that resonated warmly under the venue’s crystal chandeliers.

When Gus came on, a wave of nervous energy crescendoed and spilled into the auditorium, with him and his backup musicians appearing like the ghosts of a coolness long past. Dapperton’s aesthetic embodies androgynous fashion—a post-modern toga-like shirt, plaid culottes (during a pause between songs, a fan screamed out “I love your pants!”), and his iconic bright hair dye (bleach-blonde). To my surprise, he sounded even better on stage—every sound was so much more amplified, so much more vibrant and colorful and resounding. Even though Gus Dapperton only has about 10 songs currently on Spotify, this worked in his favor; everyone in the audience knew everyone song and was consistently, appropriately hyped. There were points in which he invited the audience to dance because “well, we will be dancing here on stage,” and everyone did, moving their bodies to his crooning, head-nodding rhythms of nostalgia and longing love. Hugging my Tinder date, I realized that it’s been a while since I’ve been to a concert where I so genuinely connected the other people in the audience. I loved the three aging bearded men in front of me wearing Def Metal t-shirts and excitedly holding up their phones to Snapchat Gus; I loved the couples swaying together to their favorite songs and kissing quietly as the choruses came on. As I watched my date take photos with his old-fashioned film camera, capturing the light falling in rainbow petals on the crowd, I felt all the tenderness that pulses through Dapperton’s music like a heartbeat. Every song was like an individual moment in an individual rose-tinted universe, simultaneously both cheerful and wistful. After an encore (the band played a revitalized version of “Twist and Shout”), and an intense crowd-surfing session, in which our old friend Beshken reappeared like a crumpled white ghost, the instruments were packed and our spirit of love for humanity was released into the red velvet carpeting of El Rey. I walked out feeling elated, holding hands with my date and looking soulfully into his eyes, attempting to preserve in them the happiness that the music had granted us for the night. All I have to say: if you take anything out of a Gus Dapperton concert, it’s an appreciation the tiny little miracles that happen to bring humans closer together.

title: Tom Misch @ Hollywood Palladium (10/19/2018) // Show Review
content:
Article and photographs by Salma Srour

As my Uber approached the venue, I was surprised to see a line stretching a few blocks in front of the Hollywood Palladium. Walking to the back of the line, I passed Tom Misch fans of all ages- high schoolers, college students, middle-aged adults, and some families. As I stood in front of the stage, waiting for the opening act, I briefly spoke to a mother who was attending the concert with her daughter. They were excited to see Tom Misch live, and mentioned to me that they’ve both been listening to him since the release of his newest album, Geography. We chatted about the timelessness of his music and the diversity of the crowd.

We waited an hour for the opener to come onstage. The crowd began to grow restless as we waited, and someone from his team informed me that they were running an hour being schedule. When the opener arrived on-stage, he unexpectedly began to play lo-fi hip-hop beats. While I wasn’t a frequent listener of this type of music, I was surprised by how much I enjoyed his beats and the atmosphere he created. The crowd moved to his beats, singing and dancing along when he mixed popular songs. After a few songs, he brought out his saxophone, and the crowd was mesmerized by the flow of the classic jazz instrument mixed with his heavy hip-hop beats.

When the opener left and Tom Misch took the stage, the ambiance of the venue was transformed. He first performed a lively song off of his newest album, Geography, bringing up the energy of the crowd. Due to the intimacy of the small venue, he was able to connect with the crowd and set a perfect scene for his music. When he performed one of my personal favorite songs, “Movie,” I felt the softness and familiar tone of the song that I feel when playing it through headphones. When he performed “Lost in Paris,” the emotions in the crowd were elevated and the energy of the venue felt vibrant. He brought his opener back to the stage to play the saxophone, adding more depth and a familiar jazz tone to his music. The crowd was mesmerized by the pairing of Misch’s electric guitar with the saxophone.

When he thanked the crowd and wrapped up the show, the electrified audience began chanting for an encore. After a few minutes, Tom Misch came back out, performed two more songs before officially ending the show. His enthusiasm was contagious, and the dynamic onstage felt passionate and magnetic. He asked the crowd for a selfie before leaving the stage for the last time. The crowd was lively after the show, on a high after Tom Misch’s captivating performance. The feelings he was able to evoke with his live music made it undeniably one of the best performances I have experienced.

title: The Much Much How How and I - Cosmo Sheldrake // Album Review
content:
article by Mark McGreal

The Much Much How How and I is the most recent album by Cosmo Sheldrake, a British instrumentalist. The album came out in April of 2018, so it isn’t exactly new, but I only recently became aware of it due to a new Apple commercial for the iPhone XR. In the commercial, hundreds of people dressed in different monochromatic jumpsuits run through city streets while Sheldrake’s “Come Along” plays in the background. Personally, it’s a very rare occasion for a commercial to catch my attention at all, but I enjoyed the song so much, that I found the song and discovered my new favorite artist.

First, a little background on the artist. Cosmo Sheldrake (yes that is his real name), was born in December, either in 1989 or 1991 depending on which website you use to look it up. He can play keyboard, guitar, drums, the banjo, and the sousaphone. He is the son of a renowned parapsychologist and a voice coach, and his brother Merlin (once again, that is his real name) is a biologist. His songs fall into the electronica and folkloric genres. His first single, titled “The Moss” was released in 2014, and he released an EP in 2015, but this album is his first full-length album.

An important thing about Sheldrake is that he is an independent currently. He is signed to no label, and he puts the music out himself. Without corporate intervention, Sheldrake can make any music that he wishes exactly the way he wants to make it. He should be commended for such a brave move.

The Much Much How How and I is a fantastical album. The song “Linger Longer”, the first song on the album, uses the instruments in such a way that conjures up images of a circus or a ballet. The tempo is quick, each instrument plays its notes quickly and then moves on to the next almost as if the songs are in constant motion. The drums are the strongest instrument; they create a consistent beat that keeps the songs moving. It keeps the albums from becoming bogged down. The sousaphone is used extensively in the album. It gives each song a nice beautiful and rich tone. It can also be used to create a beat like the drums, but it is not as harsh to the ear.  

The lyrics in the songs are arguably their most important aspects. The songs are each chock-full of references and allusions to literature. The name of 17th-century literary character Tom Thumb is in expressly said in “Wriggle”, and “Eggs and Soldier”make some not so subtle references to both Jack from Jack and the Beanstalk and Jack from Jack and Jill. These references to fairy tale characters further the whimsical nature of the album. It’s hard to discern a theme from the album because of the nonsense poem nature of each song. They all feel so disjointed, but Sheldrake’s style binds the songs together to create songs that flow, one right into the next.

At 14 songs, the album makes for an easy listen. The songs tempos are almost universal. Personally, I have listened to the songs while going on contemplative walks, while working out at the gym, and while doing schoolwork. I’m even listening to it as I write this piece at this moment. I would recommend this album to any and all people who are looking for a talented musician. To paraphrase Sheldrake’s song “Come Along” run away from the humdrum and listen to this talented and interesting young artist.

title: Blueface @ The NOVO (1/11/2019) // Show Review
content:
article and photographs Mahala Herron-Rutland

The line was laced around the corner with young people from diverse backgrounds. Doors opened at 10:45pm and what I love about NOVO is the first 50 or so visitors get to stand in the barricade. We all flock in and the concert begins on time. While doors opened at 10:45 Blueface wasn’t scheduled to come on until 1, so the crowd did get a little impatient but we had openers such as Salah Baby, N.L.U., FT Hop Out, and so on. About half of the openers were from the Bay Area, which is something I admire about Blueface, how he shows love to NorCal being that he is an LA artist, he’s not strictly LA, he’s West Coast. 

He comes out to “Thottiana”, another banger that the crowd knows and loves. In his usually Burberry fit, girls are throwing their bras and underwear with their phone numbers drawn on, from the balcony. There were about 50 people on stage with him and while they didn’t serve as entertainment, I can say that they aided in keeping the show lively. As I imagine it being hot, eventually Blueface strips down to his pants and throws a whole case of water from bottles on stage at the crowd and all of those 50 people who got the pleasure of entering the barricade were delightfully drenched.

When I first heard of Blueface it was regarding his funny mannerisms and antics.
