Recommended Track From S Carey:

“Crown The Lines”

title: Album Review: Fennec - Beloved
content:
By: Taylor Whelchel

Fennec is an enigmatic new presence in the music industry. If you wanted to find out more about him by checking out wikipedia or his various social media accounts, you’d find yourself coming up empty-handed. Named for the adorable fennec fox that’s native to western Africa (which sheds light on why his various profiles list his location as “Western Sahara”), Fennec himself is a college grad based in United States who got his start DJing club nights and house parties during his undergrad years. We also gleaned from his twitter that he loves Taylor Swift (listen to “Woke Up Feeling Disconnected” off his debut LP for what is possibly a distorted vocal sample from Swift’s country-pop “Love Story”), but that’s about all there is in the manner or biographical facts. Fennec’s online persona is mysterious, comedic, and charmingly egomaniacal in unequal parts. But his boastful attitude is justifiably backed up by the maturity of his unique sound, crafted with artistry and precision.

Following shortly behind the early 2014 release of his debut LP, Let Your Heart Break, -which boasts 15 seamless, pulsating tracks- Fennec returns with a new four-track EP, entitled Beloved. His brand of sample-based beats beckons fans of pop, hip-hop and electronic alike and defies the simplicity of genre classifications, which makes this review challenging to write. Where Let Your Heart Break was melancholic pop of varied pace, Beloved, to me, calls more upon house influences. Particularly apparent in “Fall” with the removals and subsequent reprisals of the bassline, it stirs the listener into motion; I find myself swaying and tapping my foot as each song builds. Both “Fall” and “Wraith” exemplify the gritty groove that make a crowd move at any electronic show, but this short EP is anything but one-note. Where almost-abrasive beats are championed in the middle section of the record, the final track opens up into a lush and expansive melody with such purity of sound that it seems to smooth over that abrasive edge of the previous tracks. There’s something soothing about “Blue Spray Jacket,” despite its entirely danceable beat, that leaves me feeling like I’ve spent a day at a spa rather than listening to an electronic album.

The feature that permeates all of Fennec’s music is the artful layering of percussion, melody, and samples - which range from spoken and sung words to laughter and ambient sound - that together yield a signature complexity of sound. That signature is unparalleled and inimitable, and it’s a huge part of what makes Beloved such a compelling sophomore effort from Fennec: one that leaves me wanting more in the best way. In the concluding seconds of this fantastic record, we hear an isolated vocal sample: “I’m just waiting for my time…because when it’s my time, I’m taking it over”. If you ask me, Fennec’s time is soon upon us, and I’m looking forward to it.

Recommended Tracks: Fall, Blue Spray Jacket

Rating: 9/10

title: Album Review: Rodrigo Amarante - Cavalo
content:
By: Joe Ackerman

Coming to Cavalo, I didn’t know very much about Rodrigo Amarante. I’ve listened to it a few times now, and I can’t say I know much more. He’s played in Little Joy, Los Hermanos and with Devendra Banhart, he’s from Brazil, is thirty-seven years old, and that’s nearly it. But his new album, out now, is an introduction in itself, and a really great one.

Cavalo is an album made up of delicate skeletons made out of nylon string guitars, horn sections, shakers, chiming pianos, sung in English, Portuguese, French. “Irene” makes me think about Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast At Tiffany’s: it’s full of New York summer heat and the smell of tamales and tar and minor 7ths, and it makes me want to learn Portuguese in all its four thousand irregular verbs. “Hourglass” runs on a steady engine of motorik Fender bass, digital chirps, and 16-bit horns. But elsewhere, Cavalo is full of notes of alarm, like “Mon Nom,” which starts out with the words “I am the stranger,” sung in ambiguous French, underlaid by a nervously plucked piece of classical guitar, orchestral sounds out of 60’s Italian thriller movies and subterranean stabs of synthesizer. 

The cover, with Amarante’s trilingual lyrics on a stark white background, nothing but the music inside, reminds me of another, even more stripped down album by Mt. Eerie, which Phil Elverum wrote and recorded in a remote Norwegian cabin. Like Mt. Eerie’s Dawn, Cavalo is an album (in Amarante’s own words) about the solitude of the lonesome traveler, and that’s definitely clear in an album that’s as paranoid as it is hopeful, as lamenting as it is plain cool. But don’t let that turn you off, because Cavalo’s melancholy and reflectiveness never boils over, and for every “Mon Nom” and “Fall Asleep” (filled with chiming, cavernous pianos and slowly lilting lyrics), there’s the upbeat tropicalia of tracks like “Maná”, and group efforts like “Tardei”, which also happens to feature Devendra Banhart and Kristen Wiig.

Cavalo is an album that invites you to listen to it many more times, and with the weather getting wonderfully (and dangerously) hot over here, it’s very appropriate in its mix of joy and creeping panic.

Recommended Tracks: Nada Em Vao, Hourglass, Tardei, Irene

GRADE: 8/10

title: Album Review: Papercuts - Life Among the Savages
content:
By: Sergio Garcia

Papercuts (Jason Quever’s indie-pop-folk project) returns on Life Among the Savages with an ensemble of songs evocative of getting lost, both literally and figuratively, in the woods, possibly in the coniferous Pacific Northwest or among fresh snowfall in New England. Quever illustrates his apparent disconnection with society at large, if not depression, with an ensemble of melody-driven, bright yet somber baroque pop songs. The melodies are undoubtedly good, propelled by solid piano and acoustic guitar arrangements and laced with elegant strings, drums, and bass. Quever’s lyrics center around an unsettling alienation felt among the “savages” of modern life, proud of technological advancement yet steeped in superficial worldviews and emotional deprivation. Indeed, many song titles directly reference a sense of isolation or shallowness: the compelling “Still Knocking at the Door,” flighty “Staring at the Bright Lights,” and forlorn “Tourist” to name a few.

The music is certainly consistent, though this may come off as complacency at certain points of the album depending on the listener’s mood and interpretation. While nothing of creative achievement, the songs nonetheless convey Quever’s weariness directly and with rather pleasant production to boot. This is truly music to be lost to. The introspective, sensitive vocals accompanied by fluid melodies are ideal for quiet contemplation or melancholic musings of all sorts. Chill without being mundane, somber but never desolate, Quever hits a balance on multiple songs that makes this album of interest for pensive fans of woodsy, contemporary indie-pop.

Recommended tracks: Still Knocking at the Door, Staring at the Bright Lights, Easter Morning

GRADE: 7.5/10

title: Album Review: Palo Alto Soundtrack
content:
By: Brenda Sifontes

Scored by Devonté Hynes, also known as Blood Orange or Lightspeed Champion, this soundtrack consists of talented artists spilling out their youthful guts to feelings, struggles and choices. This soundtrack was specifically made for Palo Alto, a film directed and written by Gia Coppola. The story is based off of famous actor James Franco’s short stories and he asked Ms. Coppola to make a film adaptation of his work. Dev Hynes and Robert Schwartzman, former lead singer of alternative indie rock band Rooney, contributed to dream-like songs for the new film coming out May 9th. 

Other artists featured in this compilation/scored soundtrack are Nat & Alex Wolff, formers members of youth rock band The Naked Brothers Band, Mac Demarco, Jack Kilmer, Francesco Pennino and Coconut Records. “Rock Star” by Nat and Alex Wolff is witty and humorous with just a small hint of sadness. Their execution of the song is mesmerizing and will bring a smile to your face with natural occurrences during the song like Nat’s gurgling to produce an effect to the song. Nat Wolff is also featured in the film as the bad influencing friend. Another cast member featured in the soundtrack is Jack Kilmer, also the son of Val Kilmer (former Batman for Batman Forever), and his song “T.M.” sounds like a garage grunge rock band. This perfectly fits the concepts revolving around the film which are sex, violence, drugs and problems. 

In contrast to the crazy side of the plot, Francesco Pennino’s song “Senza Mamma” takes a ride with the classical waltz-like part of the film. Although it is waltz-like, it does give the audience a peek of Gia Coppola’s style. This piece balances the rest of the soundtrack with its traditional strings, brass and percussion. This piece of work has receive a great amount of magnificent reviews and it does not disappoint. If you are looking for dream gaze, delirious, soothing music then this soundtrack is for you. 

Recommended Tracks: All of them

GRADE: 10/10

title: Album Review: Real Estate - Atlas
content:
By: Colin Bogan

“It is a subtle landscape, where I come from”

This is a lyric from the first track on the record, “Had to Hear," which aptly describes the overall aesthetic of the album. These songs are individual pieces of a landscape. The subtlety of these colors, textures, melodies, and rhythms do not betray their potency. When looked at as a whole - these individual chunks of the landscape aggregate to a world of such vibrance that one can easily get lost in. Fortunately, I had my copy of Atlas with me to guide me through. I am still adjusting to life in the real world, following a fortnight in this landscape. 

Here are some dispatches from the other side.

To enter, one must simply isolate themselves, and begin the record. I recommend this be played loud. Loudness is key. Otherwise, it will not work. I close my eyes at it begins. I felt a momentary shock at the sensory deprivation. But reality quickly began swirling all around me - faster and faster until all of time and space are a blur, with me calmly placed at the center. I try to stay calm - any undulations emanating from my psyche could disrupt the whole process and potentially cause the entire universe to collapse upon itself. After a few brief seconds of this process, I have arrived.
I open my eyes, and I am sailing in a doorless, topless jeep, through the cosmos towards a landmass. As the record begins, the bass and drums seem to be emanating from the spinning wheels and churning engine of my vehicle. It is driving itself, taking me on a guided tour. 

I blink, and we are driving down a great expanse of highway through the American Southwest. It is dusk. Isolated from everything except myself and nature. The sky is boldly and brilliantly illuminated an entire spectrum of colors. The ground is littered with cactus and the massive monoliths of red stone. They seem to be enjoying the music as well.

"I don’t need the horizon to tell me where the sky ends”. This lyric is also from the first track, “Had to Hear.”

There are massive, swirling clouds all around and they are pulsing to the beat emanated by the jeep’s wheels and engines. With every beat, they change colors. Falling from them is a rain of melodies. As every rain drop hits me or the ground near me, a different fraction of the melody emerges from inside the drops. I strangely, do not seem to get wet, yet I enjoy the sensation of the drops falling on me.  

There is a warm, wind blowing on my face as we head towards the horizon. Carried on the wind is the lyric and vocal melodies of the record. This too, feels good. It is soft, and has the gentle touch of a love long forgotten. 
As the fourth track, “Aprils Song”(an instrumental piece - no vocals) begins, the jeep begins to gently take off of the ground and point gently towards to the sky, and I begin sailing above the landscape. 

We keep ascending through the 6th track, “Crime,” higher and higher into the cosmos from whence we came. We are flying amongst the stars, and the planets, gazing into the heart and soul of the galaxies and universe. As the song peaks into its guitar solos at the end, my vehicle takes a nose dive, moving perpendicularly through time and space into a nebula, a swirling mass of a star being born. 

We witness the grandest and most majestic of all beginnings. 

Now, we have come to the final two tracks. We pull up, sharply. We are flying vertically, higher and higher as “Horizon" plays. 

Just as the last song, "Navigator" comes to a close, we hit one point at the end of the universe. Everything slows down as we push through the edge like a finger through saran wrap, and I am back in my room. Surrounded by silence.
You can see now, why I am still recovering. 

_________________________________________________________


Real Estate has settled into a solid groove with their 3rd effort. The album is fantastically colorful, textural, and features highly relatable and cathartic lyrics. 
GRADE: 8/10
Recommended Tracks: Had to Hear, Talking Backwards, Aprils Song, Horizon, Navigator

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall Quarter 2014
content:
uclaradio:

To kick off fall quarter, the UCLA Radio Tumblr celebrating by posting a week of DJ profiles and interviews! We want you to meet our station!

title: Comedy Show Review: Not Too Shabby
content:
by Sara Karim

When you’re a broke college student, a free comedy show is never a bad idea. At midnight on Fridays, the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre opens its doors to present Not Too Shabby. Hosted by Harris Wittels (Parks and Recreation, Eastbound and Down) and Armen Weitzman (Zach Stone Is Gonna Be Famous, Burning Love), Not Too Shabby is a sketch show wherein comedians of the UCB sketch community test out skits with reckless abandon.

From an exotic dancer who confronts her “stalker” (an unsuspecting audience member) to an improv group (how meta…) dealing with a heckling frat boy, the sketches are refreshing and hilarious. At the very end, the hosts do a small improv scene with two of the writers and stars of The Birthday Boys on IFC that was without question the most enjoyable part of the show.

If you don’t want to go home but you can’t stay wherever you may be, go to UCB and see some of the best and weirdest in comedy. It’s truly well worth your time.

title: Album Review: The Pains of Being Pure at Heart - Days of Abandon
content:
By: Sergio Garcia

The Pains of Being Pure at Heart began as a four-piece New York indie pop group, causing a stir in 2009 with their deliciously fun self-titled debut. Two of the original four left after their second album Belong, causing vocalist and songwriter Kip Berman to regroup and retreat a bit from the ambitious sound of their previous effort. Known for their inspired sound similar to indie favorites like My Bloody Valentine, Belle and Sebastian, and The Smiths, The Pains continue blending classic pop structures with their own contemporary indie-ness on Days of Abandon. The result is a distinctly pleasant album. From start to finish, the Pains croon and jangle to sweet melodies and pop textures. Though never challenging, the album nonetheless presents catchy tunes sure to elicit foot taps and hums from anyone who can dig bright (but never blinding) indie pop. Berman’s lyrics are lively and personal, some noticeably heartfelt, others rather cliché, but all match the tone of the songs. A Sunny Day in Glasgow’s Jen Goma sings backing vocals and also takes the lead on two tracks, complementing Berman with her pure, clear voice.

The Pains may have retreated a little too far into their pop haven, however, as numerous tracks lack musical substance. The sound is safer and more predictable than their previous two albums, which some listeners may appreciate. I was most impressed by the album on the first listen, but each subsequent spin left me searching for more. Like those sugary heart candies on Valentine’s day, Days of Abandon goes down easy and makes you smile, but does little more than fizzle once ingested. The Pains certainly don’t lack talent or energy, so the absence of flair is likely attributed to the struggles of lineup changes and finding that spark again. A sucker for jangly guitars myself, I hope they return with the ambition that makes them so pure and enjoyable to listen to. Still, there are a few gems that makes this album worth checking out for fans of The Pains and light, sprightly indie pop.

Recommended Tracks: Art Smock, Masokissed, Life After Life

GRADE: 7/10
tags: the pains of being pure at heart

title: Album Review: The Horrors - Luminous
content:
By: Avalon Dismukes

Going through The Horrors’ discography, it’s clear that they’re a band that embraces change. The trajectory from their first album - a shock punk release that followed the guidelines set forth by the band name fairly well, a mix between The Misfits and The Ramones that led them to appearances as Shoreditch’s premiere cool-guy band (and on The Mighty Boosh). 

Since then, they’ve grown as a band tremendously. In fact, their hair volume is a good indicator of increasing restraint - from the poof of lead singer Farris’ hair on the cover of Strange House to the relatively tame long hair of 2014.

Started at the bottom

Now we here

After Strange House came Primary Colours, an eery rock record with hints of psychedelia. One of the signatures of The Horrors is their homemade pedals — Joshua Third, the guitarist, majored in physics and applies that to wiring pedals together, creating a unique sound that makes them one of the most innovative rock groups. 

The futuristic, distinctive sound that came out of Primary Colours helped push The Horrors past their niche and juvenile beginnings to a respected, musically sound band. Their sound continued to evolve in Skying. The album cover does a fair job of conveying the aesthetic of the music - there is more of an emphasis on melody and pop, totally shedding the skin of NME rock darlings and moving into NME experimentalist darlings. 

After growing with the band through these albums and marking the broad steps in evolution that each album marked, the relative slowing of that advance that Luminous has brought is slightly disappointing from a long time fan’s point of view.The album itself, though, is a gorgeous expansion on musical themes originally explored in Skying, though more atmospheric. In fact, it sounds like perhaps The Horrors got tired of shows where fans “would get too silly” and the floor would collapse, trading that energy in favor of something that would appeal to people walking past them at a festival. 

“Chasing Shadows” is a mellow opening track, but builds on itself as the track continues, eventually building up enough momentum to serve as a solid introduction to the rest of the album. Luminous seems to be about relationships - a far cry from earlier tracks like “Sheena is a Parasite,” which recalls an alien creature (Chris Cunningham did the music video): “Jealous Sun” admonishes that “your love is not enough” while “Change Your Mind” cries for a romantic entanglement (“Hey I’m still burning/Would you ever leave him for me/Hey I’m still burning/Do you look at him the way she looks at me?”). All of this is encompassed in an aesthetic reminiscent of the kind of cerebral taste of Explosions in the Sky or Tame Impala while still maintaining the idiosyncratic musical choices that make The Horrors one of the best and most evolving bands playing today. 

Recommended Tracks: Jealous Sun, Falling Star, Change Your Mind

Grade: 9/10

title: Album Review: Tribu Ultravioleta - Pinata
content:
By: Sheehan Parker

Tribu Ultravioleta is the stage name of Venezuelan multiinstrumentalist José Briceño. His worldly presence is something of a mystery: try to search for him and all you’ll find is a rather vacant Facebook page and an even more vacant MySpace page (also, does anybody know how to use MySpace anymore?) It’s interesting, then, that Pinata mirrors Tribu Ultravioleta’s own mystery. Ultimately, however, I’m willing to break with how the artist describes himself, and call it a disco album.

It’s true that mysterious undertones and disco are not generally accompanied by one another, yet there is no way to ignore the heavy dark undertones in the tracks. They are found within the timbre of the music, which seemed to resonate frequently at lower levels. These dark and somewhat inaccessible undertones draw the listener in and provoke in them some consideration. This consideration, I feel, adds an incredible level to the disco overtones.

And there’s no escaping that this is, at it’s core, a disco album. Some say disco died, but this second wave of disco that is characterized by artist such as Tribu Ultravioleta and Daft Punk is notably more worthwhile than the first incarnation. Due in part to the mysterious undertones which are added,and were added equally in the newest Daft Punk album, the disco has a new textured depth to it that makes it listenable outside of the discotheque.

Ultimately, I really enjoyed this album.

Recommended Tracks: Flying, Te Veo, Pinata.

GRADE: 7/10

title: Album Review: Beck - Morning Phase
content:
By: Joe Ackerman

It’s been nearly six years since Beck Hansen last put out an album, but it’s not like he hasn’t done anything since. There’s been a whole album written just in sheet music, time putting in producing work for Charlotte Gainsbourg, Stephen Malkmus and Thurston Moore, collaborations with Philip Glass and Jack White, and most importantly, three (two of them 15 minutes long) singles from last year that sounded as interesting as anything he’d done before. For someone who grew up in the poorer parts of Los Angeles and made a living working at video rental stores and singing Mississippi John Hurt songs on crowded LA Metro buses (just try and listen to his first few albums, released everywhere from random cassette tapes to K Records, and ranging from the insane and unlistenable to the totally brilliant), it’s pretty incredible how far Beck has come - from those first tapes to the insane and MTV-friendly noise of Odelay, to the surprisingly emotional Sea Change. That someone so utterly crazy and brilliant, in no way suited for this world, can be something like an outsider national treasure, is quite amazing. The problem with Morning Phase, out now on Capitol Records, is that it’s safe and predictable in a way those songs absolutely weren’t, and sounds like Beck retreading old territory. Morning Phase is, by Beck’s own admission, Sea Change Part II.

Morning Phase isn’t a bad album by any means. It’s permeated by string arrangements conducted by Beck’s father, David Campbell, which make you think about Serge Gainsbourg, and the most beautiful parts of Sea Change, and production that puts the music somewhere into the ethereal. It’s full of Beck’s voice, which seems to get more angelic every year. This is all good. But there’s also the problem that from the start of the album - from the slowly strummed chords and bells that come in a few seconds into “Morning,” Beck’s ghostly vocals and harmonies, impressionistic lyrics, and its feeling of utter, irreversible heartbreak - it all sounds almost exactly like the same heartbreak he told us about twelve years ago. The whole thing is something that sounds like an artist who’s perfected his form, but sadly got a little boring. That isn’t good.

On the good side, songs like “Morning,” and the single, “Blue Moon,” have all of the sadness and tenderness of Sea Change, and the album moves as a kind of cathartic whole, the opposite of the paranoid manic ironic hyperactive funk of Beck’s albums in the 90s. Morning Phase shows Beck as a really, really talented artist who’s probably one of the greatest songwriters in the world today. The problem is that when all that’s said, the album doesn’t really do any of the things that put Beck there in the first place: it isn’t surprising, or funny, or even that weird. Even after multiple listens, the tracks seem to fade into one another; maybe that’s part of the album’s lonely, rejected unity, or maybe it’s just the sound of someone who needs to start having fun making music again. 

Listen to Morning Phase a few times, because it truly is a stirring, emotional experience. But once you’ve done that, listen to “I Won’t Be Long” and “Unfriended” from last year, and you’ll know you’re listening to the real Beck.

Recommended tracks: Morning, Blue Moon, Unforgiven

GRADE: 6/10

title: Interview with Muscle and Marrow
content:
by Megan Lent

Muscle and Marrow are a great, fairly new band based in Portland, Oregon. I spoke with musician Kira Alexandra Clark about Muscle and Marrow, her influences, and how she makes music.

UCLA Radio: How did Muscle and Marrow form? Where did you get the name?

Kira: Muscle and Marrow went through two formations before this one. I knew that I desperately wanted to play my music, and I also knew I needed other people to do that, as the songs certainly call for additional instrumentation.  I had a couple of bad experiences with the wrong people and finally talked Keith, who is my partner, into playing drums on some recordings. He was playing piano in another band at the time and considered himself a retired drummer, but ultimately I’m pretty persuasive and a year later, here we are. I can’t imagine doing this with anyone else. It’s the most intimate, tedious, and frightening thing I’ve shared with anyone.

The name is a line from a poem I wrote. It references both fragility and strength which I have a lot of, and so does the music.

What are your main musical influences? What kind of genre would you consider yourself a part of, if you consider yourself a part of a genre at all?

Swans, Chelsea Wolfe, The Body, PJ Harvey, Shannon Wright, Fiona Apple. I am drawn to anything completely insane and dark and guttural and to anyone, especially if they’re female, who comes completely unhinged when they perform as though it cannot be avoided. I’ve always felt an otherness and to see anyone, especially a woman, who is utterly mad and commanding and undone is very moving for me.

We have no idea what genre we are in. We know that we like to play with dark bands. We also like to play with heavy bands. Sometimes we refer to our sound as atmospheric doom. Sometimes people refer to it as gothic. We don’t know what anything means.

Are you excited about Portland’s music scene? Or any other cities’? What bands are you really into supporting?

We are just starting to become excited about Portland’s scene. When we first started, we couldn’t find our people. The bands in the Portland scene who get a lot of attention are incredibly talented, but we really had to dig around here to feel any sort of personal community. We think we’re starting to find our people however. It turns out there’s a huge heavy music scene here. You just have to do more than read The Portland Mercury.

Our top two bands right now are Haunted Horses from Seattle and A Volcano from Portland. A Volcano is truly weird and their live show is something close to terrifying and spiritual. 

What are other influences, not musical ones? What inspires you?

Poetry. Artists in general. Women writers. Feminist artists. Experimental performance art. Experimental film. People who devote themselves to art and are not scared of that. My friend Lindsay inspires me. Emily Dickinson inspires me. That sheer desire to create, to make things. I am influenced by any sort of art that unsettles me. Going on walks alone at night inspires me.

What were your favorite albums when you were a teenager? Any “guilty pleasures?”

Alanis Morissette’s Jagged Little Pill, though I think I was a bit younger than a teenager. Nirvana. Neutral Milk Hotel. Bright Eyes. Cursive. Currently I’ve been listening to a lot of Tupac which I also enjoyed as a teenager, though the listening experience this time around has been a much more serious and political one. As far as guilty pleasures go I love, love top 40 rap.

All of your merch and photos have a really great style! Where does it all come from?

Thank you! It became clear that we had to start thinking about “branding.” We had and still have some conflicting emotions about it because it doesn’t seem very pure or organic, but honestly, I am not above vanity and it’s beneficial for us and the music to present ourselves in a certain way. I’m vaguely comfortable with exploring the idea of fashion as an art form or at least a creative expression. The branding is the visual aspect of the music that has to somehow communicate something about the music, so I guess we look at it as fun and necessary, but we’re also unsure ultimately how we feel about ego and image. Anyhow we definitely knew the photos had to be ethereal in nature, feminine but also gritty, like the music. We collaborate with who we’re working with in that regard, but so much of this is DIY at this point, that we’ve definitely had to develop a strong sense of vision for ourselves, and then find the right people to help implement that vision. Maybe one day I will be someone’s artistic prop and they will take my body and do wonderful things with it, and I’ll get to stop worrying about branding. Anyhow we’ve been lucky to have really talented photographers, artists and graphic designers working with us.

What is your songwriting and recording process like?

I write totally alone in my room on a guitar. I write simple, repetitive, droning songs that I wail over. When I’m ready I show little pieces to Keith who then usually starts singing it with me as I play it. Then we take it to the practice space and work on it again and again. Things about the song change in that process. We work on tone, tempo, structure etc. Then he will take the song and create samples to fill it in. That’s when the world is really completed. Once Keith gets a hold of the song it grows flesh over its skeleton.

Our recording process was done entirely analogue. We fought a little bit and I cried a little bit, but mostly it was okay. I’ve learned a lot and I already have ideas concerning the next album. I want to be more meticulous, subtler, patient.

Will you be performing in California any time soon?

Yes! We’re playing San Jose 8/20 at The Rock Shop, Oakland 8/21 at Eli’s Mile High Club, Fresno 8/22, and possibly LA 8/23. All of the details and up to date tour dates can be found at muscleandmarrow.com.

title: Album Review: Curtis Harding - Soul Power
content:
By: Jake Hook

Why would punks like soul music? Curtis Harding, strangely enough, did not release Soul Power through any conventional means, as far as soul music is concerned. Instead, he released it on cassette via the increasingly eclectic, ostensibly garage rock label Burger Records. Which, given that it sounds more like Curtis Mayfield than it does Frank Ocean, isn’t such a strange decision on his part. Stranger and riskier it is for Burger, whose biggest acts are, among other, street punks like FIDLAR and twee slackers like Cherry Glazerr. But his triumphal success seems to suggest that the risk paid off, not only paving the way for bigger and more interesting things for Burger, but huge opportunities for Harding, and the possibility that burnout teenagers all along the west coast might diversify their tape collection with something other than disgruntled white kids. And Harding certainly has a niche made out for him in the scene. Burger has already been known to associate with hip hop artists like Kool Keith and The Pharcyde, who at least dabble in soul and R&B, and if the music video for Soul Power’s lead single “Keep On Shining” is any indicator, Harding is able and willing to appeal to the alternative crowd, and being from the same town as Burger alumni Black Lips certainly doesn’t hurt his credibility.

But the music speaks for itself really. “Surf” sounds like it could have been on the Lips’ last record if not for Harding’s unique and charismatic vocal presence, even including a totally shredding guitar solo played by Lips frontman Cole Alexander, no less. In fact, rock instrumentation seems to dominate this album, even when their arrangement is more suggestive of classic soul. Even on the more straightforward R&B tracks like “Keep On Shining” and “The Drive,” the horns are quite subdued and play more of a supporting role than they already do in the genre as a whole. That is, perhaps, what makes this album so much more than simply an experiment in retro style. It may not be Cee Lo Green (with whom he worked as a supporting vocalist), but it’s certainly not the sound of someone who buries their head in the sand when it comes to music newer than 1979.

The album contains its fair share of experimentation. “The Drive,” in addition to an irresistible backbeat and the aforementioned horn section, has ethereal synths that recall space rock and perhaps as a contemporary touchstone in the work of labelmate Gap Dream. “Heaven’s On The Other Side” dabbles in disco, and “I Need A Friend” features an infectious falsetto that reveals Harding’s vocal talents to be impossible to deny.

This record is by all measures, adventurous, and a worthy victory out of left field for soul music and the underground in general. Splitting the difference between classic R&B and modern alternative, things seem more promising than ever for alternative music, injecting a much needed variety. Soul Power is as much punk rock as anything that King Tuff or Pangea might be doing, rejecting everything traditional about the territory that it treads and succeeding in spite of itself. Music media tends to paint Burger’s target demographic as slumming hipsters, but if my observations about the crowd at Burgerama (including the kids grooving to Harding’s set) say anything, it’s more accurate to say that a huge proportion of the fanbase here consists of teenagers who have yet to discover “Irony” in its most pernicious form. And, if Calvin Johnson’s observation that rock music is a “teenage sport,” then this bodes extremely well for the future of Curtis Harding’s career and the scene that gave it life.

Recommended Tracks: Next Time, Keep On Shining, Surf, The Drive

GRADE: 8/10

title: Concert Review: StubHub's Next Stage Series featuring Lykke Li Benefiting Mr. Holland's Opus Foundation @ The Roxy Theatre 5/18
content:
by Melina Powell

StubHub kicked off their new Next Stage concert series at the Roxy Theatre with Swedish songstress Lykke Li, whose much anticipated album I Never Learn was just released this month. One hundred percent of the proceeds from the show went to Mr. Holland’s Opus Foundation, a charity that gives instruments to local schools to benefit music education programs for children. If this great cause weren’t enough of a reason to buy tickets, Lykke’s incredible performance should convince you not to miss out on the next one.

Lykke started her set with the title track of the new album, an acoustic guitar-heavy song with dream-like vocals. The dark lighting and smoky stage combined with Lykke’s black attire produced a supernatural atmosphere, furthered by her haunting vocals. She is a remarkably expressive performer both in her songwriting and her style of movement when she performs, gliding from one side of the stage to the next while singing emotional lyrical content about heartbreak. Like many artists do at concerts today, she kindly asked the audience to put their phones away for a song, and encouraged everyone to have a moment with her.

When she began singing “Little Bit” from her breakout album Youth Novels, the audience sang along with every word. Her new album is of a slower pace, and the track “Love Me Like I’m Not Made of Stone” captivated listeners with her driving vocal melody. The higher pitches of her vocal range evoke so much emotion, as if she’s about to break into tears; and then she brings it back down to reclaim control. The trajectory of the concert as a whole was a slow build that erupted into a celebration of dance as soon as the band began playing “I Follow Rivers” from Lykke’s second album, Wounded Rhymes. The energy did not die down from there, as the pulsing bass and flashing red lights during “Rich Kid Blues” plus a brief “Drunk In Love” Beyonce interlude excited the crowd.

The distinctive drumbeat and quick tempo of the keyboard chords in “Youth Knows No Pain” kept up the momentum, pleading with everyone to “Come laugh away who you are and get down”. The outro to the song was a thumping electro-bass chant-a-long of the song title, a memorable moment in the show. Lykke’s popular hit “Get Some” carried this upbeat series of favorite tracks, and completed the set before the encore. Lykke decided to play a cover of “Silver Springs” by Fleetwood Mac, which she said always reminded her of California, where she wrote the majority of her most recent album. The set ended in “Sadness Is A Blessing”, and band walked off the stage to The Beatles’ track “Don’t Let Me Down”, although nobody was let down by Lykke Li’s incredible voice and talent. 

– photos courtesy of Getty Images for StubHub

title: UCLA Radio's Annual Pledge Drive Week
content:
Donate here!

As you all know, UCLA Radio is completely student run and internet-based. That means we’re free from censorship; there is no one telling us what music to play or what words to say and we don’t play any ads. While this is awesome and all, this means we need a little help from you, the beloved and omnipotent listener. This week is our annual Pledge Drive and we’re not only looking to keep the station running, but to finally bring our out-of-date technology up to speed.

All of the DJs at UCLA Radio are students from different walks of life that have come together to form a close-knit community that is here to bring you the best content possible. Whether it be our recent interview with Chuck D on ALL CAPS, highlighting musicians of color on Negative Stereotype or female artists on Girl Office, screwball banter on Bruin Comedy Classic, or brand-spanking-new music across all genres every day of the week. We can only do that with a little help from you.

Check out our Pledge Drive page to find out more about what your contribution will mean to us here at UCLA Radio. We’ve got a ton of awesome gifts for you guys that we’re excited to give out and you can check out all of our daily events happening this week on our Facebook page. We’re also bringing you 120 hours of consecutive broadcasting this week which means that you can tune in literally at any time and we’ll be there to fulfill your radio needs. We’re here to show you, our dedicated listeners, how dedicated we are to you.

title: Album Review: Frankie Cosmos - Zentropy
content:
By: Joe Ackerman

Frankie Cosmos is the stage name of Greta Kline. She’s from New York City, and as Ingrid Superstar, then Frankie Cosmos, Zentropy is the last of over forty-five collections of songs she’s released, and her first proper studio album. Yes, that’s forty-five albums (look here: http://ingridsuperstar.bandcamp.com/music). Fresh out of a creative New York family of artists and actors, Frankie Cosmos makes homemade music that’s washed in sorrow and modern-day confusion, hope and determination to make things make sense. Equal parts K Records and Moldy Peaches, Zentropy - recorded with Kline’s boyfriend Aaron Maine (AKA Ronnie Mystery) - comes just after the death of her beloved dog, Joe Joe. His face graces Zentropy’s cover, and it’s one of the freshest, most innocent, honest and enjoyable-to-listen-to albums of this year. It’s kind of sad music, but it’s also music about doing something with that sadness. It’s uplifting, in a sad way.

At just over 17 minutes, it’s definitely one of the shorter albums you’ll be listening to this month. There isn’t a single song here that goes over two and a half minutes. But Frankie Cosmos does in a minute what most songwriters struggle to do in whole albums, fitting whole stories into moments that are gone before you even know it. Recorded in Manhattan’s Business District, it’s also a departure from the 4-track cassette tape sound of her previous (nearly) fifty albums, with the sort of production that’s listenable and exciting without being too clean or grandiose. Listen to it now, then listen to it again and again, since you’ll probably have the time.

GRADE: 9/10

Recommended tracks: School, Buses Splash With Rain, Sad 2

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall Quarter 2014

uclaradio:

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?

“Sick Shit”

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall 2014
content:
An Interview with the DJ, Dr. Know, by Marcel M. 

Show: The Bloop (Sundays 8-10pm) 

Q: How did you come up for the name of your show?

A: Named it after “the bloop,” a natural phenomena that occurred in the late 90s. An unidentified sound was recorded out in the Pacific Ocean, the “mysterious” nature of this sound seemed fitting for the theme of the show (“weird”).

Q: How did you come up with your DJ name?

A:  I wanted to stay away fro “DJ.” I considered “Captain” and “Sir,” but decided that “Dr.” was the most appropriate title. I searched my brain for “mad scientist” names in pop culture, considered Dr. Frankenstein, Dr. Strangelove, but ultimately came up with Dr. Know as a pun on Dr. No, from James Bond.

Q: What are your top three favorite musical artists at the moment?

A: The Doors, Phillip Glass, and Pink Floyd

title: Album Review: The Trouble with Templeton - Rookie
content:
By: Jin Choi

The Trouble with Templeton open with the quiet and somber “Whimpering Child” on their new album Rookie. As the leading track, it gives the impression that the album will be based around a melancholic atmosphere with hushed vocals and moody guitar work. The next several tracks confirm this paradigm, but with their fourth song “Like a Kid”, the band suddenly transitions into an anthem-like track where the tone changes drastically to one of supreme confidence and loudness. It is this flexibility that is both The Trouble with Templeton’s strength and downfall.

Despite this variety and the transitions, The Trouble with Templeton are still able to sound like themselves. They retain their identity throughout each of the songs and are able to carve out a unique sense of who they are with each of their songs. However, while they are able to write songs of varying styles, how well each of the songs is written is a different matter. It is clear that The Trouble with Templeton prefer to stick with the hazy tone of their earlier songs as these songs make up the majority of the album. And with good reason: while the attempt to mix things up once in a while is admirable, it becomes increasingly evident that The Trouble with Templeton are better suited to this slower style, especially with their fondness of using guitar and vocal effects.

The problem with Rookie as an album is that it feels like the band is still trying to find their own sound (which is slightly fitting with their album name). The album might still be worth listening to, but it would probably be worth waiting until the band matures more.

Recommended Tracks: Whimpering Child, Flowers in Bloom

GRADE: 6.5/10

title: Album Review: Ought - More Than Any Other Day
content:
By: Brenda Sifontes

Uniting from different parts of the U.S. and the world, the band members from Ought have created an album that evokes the dissatisfaction of politics, life, and actions of others. Through lead singer Tim Beeler’s powerful Julian Casablancas/Thurston Moore voice, the audience can hear the strong imitation of the capitalistic United States. Beeler’s voice, along with the instrumental, can also present a lost soul waiting for something to happen in their lives so that they won’t have to live with political issues or societal conflicts and suffer with the consequences. 

The album More Than Any Other Day is basically a mixture of the greats such as Violent Femmes, Sonic Youth, Nirvana and Julian Casablancas. This is because Beeler sings almost like Gordan Gano and when he hits higher notes, his voice is almost like Casablancas’ higher registered singing. Beeler has the attitude of Kurt Cobain during the songs and as for the instrumental, it has a little grunge along with the day-dream sense like Sonic Youth. In some parts of the album, Beeler comes out with conversational-styled singing that follows up with outbursts of higher registered singing and louder, extravagant instrumentals. These eight tracks can take one through a journey of grunge, political activism and awareness, angered dissatisfaction and a nostalgic mixture of famous artists from the mid-90s.

GRADE: 9/10

title: UCLA Radio: Keep the internet free and open
content:
by Shane Emeis

We members of UCLA Radio understand the importance of free speech. We run programming based on the free expression of thoughts and ideas. Because we are an online-only radio station, we aren’t subject to regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, which censors and hinders some intellectual conversations and debate in other sources of media.

So naturally, when I saw a news article about a new FCC proposition that would affect the internet, I got curious.

Here are some must reads: first, this article from May 12th in the LA Times describing the general premise of the proposition set forth by FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler. It involves the costs of internet providers and the discrepancy between fast and slower internet service to be charged at different rates. Because it would need to gain some control over internet traffic in order to differentiate the internet “speeds,” the proposed regulation of this issue would inadvertently cause the FCC to gain some control over content put on the internet.

In response, this article was published in the LA Times the next day describing some of the immediate retaliation against the proposition. In response to Wheeler’s proposed regulation, 240 leading television showrunners and creators encouraged him to avoid any measures that would limit Internet freedom in a letter sent on Tuesday. The letter states, “The open Internet is the greatest technological catalyst to participatory democracy and free speech since the printing press.” Already, concern for what this action could have on the raw integrity of internet content is developing.

No decisive action has been taken by Wheeler and the FCC yet, but it is probably good to keep informed on the situation as it affects us UCLA Radio members and millions of others just like us.

title: Album Review: RAC - Strangers
content:
By: Brenda Sifontes

Synthpop group RAC performed at UCLA earlier this year and received a numerous amount of great reviews. Strangers, their newly released album, consists of 16 uplifting tracks. Some tracks portray an influence of some high-key groups such as Chromeo and Bag Raiders. Another positive point of RAC’s new music is that a lot of artists are featured on their album such as Tegan and Sara, Tokyo Police Club, Matthew Coma, Katie Herzig, YACHT, St. Lucia, Peter Morén, Karl Kling, Pink Feathers, Alex Ebert, Penguin Prison, Body Language, Kele and MNDR. 

Strangers is reminiscent of when things were fun and easy like a modernized Brady Bunch show. Picture an Old Navy or Target photoshoot at a beach with all smiles or a happy drive to the local fair; you have pictured the correct vision of this album. It is very uplifting with its synth pop sounds along with its drum machine samplings. Not only do the sounds of this album portray the greener grass of the other side but the lyrics do as well.

Their most famous single is the first track of the album, which is “Let Go”. The lyrics are uplifting and attempting to help a friend which gives the audience a soft spot for the group. The song gives a positive message to their listeners such as their song “Hard to Hold” featuring Tegan and Sara. It talks about how a person is hard to hold onto and that person does not care. Tegan and Sara then sing that the person does not deserve their love. Aside from the poppy sounds, one song hits the spot with a more serious aspect, which is “We Belong” featuring Katie Herzig. The song takes a slower pace than the other songs and transitions to another side of the group’s face.

Recommended Tracks: Let Go, Hollywood, Hard to Hold, 405, We Belong

GRADE: 7/10

title: Concert Review: Philip Glass Ensemble @ Royce Hall 5/3
content:
The polarizing nature of Philip Glass’s work can be summed up in my experience at one of his performances at Royce Hall this past weekend. While I sat through the program for the entirety of the five hours comprising it, the couple in front of me hastily departed after only the first portion. One might assume that they were expecting something similar to Glass’s soundtracks for The Truman Show or Candyman. Given the pigeonholing of Glass by amateur film connoisseurs as “the weird soundtrack guy”, this is both plausible. It is also unfortunate, because “Music In 12 Parts” is one of Glass’s crowning achievements, easily on par with his 1976 opera Einstein On The Beach and his soundtrack to 1982’s Koyaanisqatsi.

As indicated by the name, the piece is composed of twelve individual parts, which were bundled by threes into single segments, for a total of four 50-minute portions. However, there were intermissions after each portion and an hour-long dinner break was held after the second portion, so endurance was hardly an issue. In typical Glass fashion, the portions started abruptly and ended in a similar manner. Far from being disconcerting, this was a testament to the skill of the Ensemble to ensure that the three keyboards, the flute, the bassoon, the voice of Lisa Bielawa and, occasionally, the saxophone were able to play in perfect harmony off the top. Bielawa, the sole vocalist, deserves special mention in particular. Having listened extensively to Einstein on The Beach, I expected a whole chorus to perform the vocal parts at this concert. Instead, Bielawa magnificently sang all the vocal portions and perfectly alternated between the soothing melodies and ominous crescendos the piece dictated, at times rivaling the most apocalyptic moments of Einstein. This was most apparent in Part 12 of the composition where, in very small increments, her part grew more complex each time the rest of the Ensemble played the same musical passage. It is also worth mentioning that Part 12 was my favorite part of the concert.

Of course, the keyboard players drew my attention as well. Philip Glass may be the heart and soul of the Ensemble, but it seemed that in this concert, keyboardist Michael Riesman did most of the heavy lifting, playing some truly captivating organ passages throughout. This is hardly an indictment of Glass, however. Far from it, it’s quite possible that he simply deigned to play the more subdued keyboard parts. Not that I would guess that simply by watching him. Indeed, while the other players sat still and appeared collected, Glass made no effort to conceal his passion for the music, lurching forward and throwing himself back before lurching forward again, in a manner as cyclic as his music. He really felt it that night, and the audience, including this writer, did too, because it granted the Ensemble a standing ovation when Part 12 of “Music In 12 Parts”, after five hours, finally concluded. 

Written by Reggie

title: Show Review: Trigger Warning
content:
Title: Trigger Warning (Directed by Rob Janas)

Location: Second City in Hollywood

Day/Times: Mondays @ 8pm. Tickets are $10-

I saw Trigger Warning this last week on Monday at Second City in Hollywood. It is a sketch comedy show, so I came in expecting funny. And it was. Funny, that is. As the title expresses, it touched topics that could offend, but I am a big believer in the power of comedy. It is not meant to offend, I believe, but meant to expose the extreme behaviors in society and satirize what is going on with racial prejudice, gender roles/sexism, and the uncomfortable parts of the world we all experience. One sketch directly addressed racial profiling, it was a sketch about, well… a sketch artist. Two caucasian cops were taking in information from an African-American woman about the robbery she was just a victim of. They seem to be on her side, and though slightly condescending they appear to be doing their job until the first reveal of the sketch, and it is an image of Martin Luther King Jr, and she very clearly was describing a Caucasian tall individual with slightly wavy hair, NOT King. It heightens, until finally she can’t take it, and she storms out. This is not only funny and uncomfortable because it’s clearly wrong, it makes us look at the current justice system and our police force with a new eye. That’s not all though, they satirize and bring to light issues of crazy celebrity treatment, domestic “violence” but in a clever way which relieves the tension at the end, modern day consumerism and our technology based culture. It’s a fun show and if you want to laugh and feel a little uncomfortable in your seat, I highly recommend it. But do be warned, they have a loaded gun, aimed at current social and political issues (some even taboo to talk about) and they “aim to offend”. Check out Trigger Warning (the warning’s in the title!!!).

Submitted by Ken Rudnick; DJ Barbie; Host of www.facebook.com/uclawwn UCLA Weakly World News!

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall Quarter 2014
content:
uclaradio:

To kick off fall quarter, the UCLA Radio Tumblr celebrating by posting a week of DJ profiles and interviews! We want you to meet our station! 

Fall quarter intern applications are due just around the corner (October 16th!!)! Prospective DJs, this could be you! 

Scott. 1st year. Aerospace Engineering major.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I decided to join radio because I felt like I needed an outlet for some sort of artistic expression. I also wanted to talk to someone instead of just being lectured at all the time. Also, people who like listening to good music are always good friends to have!

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
Lost in the Dream – The War on Drugs. For me this is just one of those albums that I can sit down and listen to straight through regardless of how I’m feeling. It can be study music, but more than anything it’s a type of folky soul music that can be uplifting on a bad day. There is a feeling that flows through that makes me think very introspectively. It is also just beautiful music. 

Recommended Tracks from The War on Drugs:
“Red Eye”
“Eyes to the Wind”
“Burning”
“Lost in the Dream”

title: Album Review: Kate Tucker and the Sons of Sweden - The Shape the Color the Feel
content:
By: Jin Choi

Despite their name, Kate Tucker and the Sons of Sweden are in fact an indie band from Seattle. A cursory glance at their Wikipedia page shows that their top single was on heavy rotation on Starbucks playlists around the world. And honestly, that is the best way to describe their music. It is exactly what one would expect to listen to in a coffee shop or other relaxing public atmosphere. Nothing in the album is hectic or chaotic. Everything resembles the calm, yet bustling nature of a coffee shop. The sounds themselves are relatively vanilla with a traditional format of female singer plus drums, bass, and guitar. Nothing here will surprise or deviate from the norm of indie rock.

Not to say that that’s a bad thing however. Indie rock can still be good indie rock if it is executed well, and in this case it is. The structure may be lacking in inspiration, but the melodies and songs themselves are quite good. It’s just that the band itself sounds so similar to anything else one would find in a Barnes and Nobles, Starbucks, American Eagle, or other public shopping area. It’s not the type of music that would perk your ears and make you wonder who this is. It’s just background music for another activity that’s probably taking up more of your mental space, which is a shame because the songwriting talent is clearly there. It’s just that it’s going to take a little more creativity and inspiration to grab the full attention of listeners.

This wouldn’t be so much of a problem if the album had at least more than one outstanding track (Looking Around) or some kind of variance to it. The album does not make any missteps or bad songs, but maybe that was part of its failing. By playing it too safe, the Kate Tucker and the Sons of Sweden have created another album that just sounds like every other indie album released in the past five years.

Recommended tracks: Hangover, Looking Around

GRADE: 7/10
tags: kate tucker and the sons of sweden
the shape the color the feel

title: Album Review: Summer Peaks - Saturday
content:
By: Joanna Forde

Summer Peaks’ first LP, Saturday, is a diverse album displaying the strengths and style of each individual member. The group, hailing from Brentwood, California (the NorCal Brentwood), consists of a trio of high school friends who came together to create an indie rock album consisting of elements taken from a range of genres, including punk rock and dream pop. The album’s cohesive component is the dreaminess present in all the songs, which is found mainly in the echoing voice of the lead singer, who differs throughout the tracks.

The album starts off with an upbeat song, “King of the Road,” to showcase the many diverse elements the band members bring together. The echoing and unclear singing and lyrics of the chorus creates a mystical, psychedelic vibe leading the listener into a dreamy mode. The album continues on and in the fourth track, “Handsome,” strongly establishes the dreaminess factor. The lead singer in this track appears to be Melina Duterte, whose soft voice creates a mellow feeling and peaceful feeling.

The most notable song of the album is the eighth track, “Maxine.” The synth pop, the feel-good rhythm, and the combination of the soft voice of the girl with the deeper guy voice makes for a fun and dreamy song. It stands out in comparison to all the other songs, and is the perfect way to transition into the last track “Golden Age,” a slow, soft song reminiscent of the entire album and a beautiful way to end.

This album is the perfect soundtrack for a chill, mellow spring day at the beach or a park. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed it and found myself feeling mellow and relaxed after listening to it.

GRADE: 8/10

title: This Week in Music History: The Blue Album
content:
This is the introductory post for a (hopefully) new feature here on UCLA Radio’s Tumblr: a throwback/flashback to this week in music history. This week’s topic is an album that was released May 10, 1994—twenty years ago!—Weezer's Weezer, which is universally referred to as “The Blue Album.”

Weezer’s first real album, it features most of their most beloved songs, like “Say It Ain’t So,” “Undone—The Sweater Song,” and “Buddy Holly.”

Rolling Stone listed it as #35 on their “100 Greatest Albums of All Time” list, saying that it mixes “winking deadpan delivery with serious hooks, guarded sensitivity and a deep disinterest in alt-rock’s then-roiling culture wars.” And that’s pretty accurate. Because The Blue Album is at once completely silly, non-serious pop rock, and intensely emotional sad-boy indie.

It’s also, and this is very rare, an amusing album. With lines like “what’s with these homies dissin’ my girl,” you can tell that Rivers Cuomo doesn’t totally take himself too serious. (His Facebook page, by the way, is pure gold, with posts like, “I know they’re not doing it for my benefit, but I want to thank the birds for singing so sweetly every morning” and “It doesn’t take a lot of introspection to realize you don’t exist. I mean, really, he’s as good at Facebook as Ezra Koenig and David Lynch are at Twitter.)

So, you have the fun of something like "Buddy Holly,” and then the tragic emotional breakdown/relationship breakup of “Say It Ain’t So,” right on the same album. It’s quirky genius, basically.

title: Festival Supreme: A Stage-By-Stage Review
content:
By: Kim Seltzer

Photos by Katherine Leon

Festival Supreme was last weekend, and it was awesome. The one-day, Los Angeles music and comedy festival curated by Tenacious D upgraded its venue from last year’s overcrowded Santa Monica pier to this year’s much more accommodating Shrine Expo Hall & Grounds. For those jaded from a bad experience at last year’s festival, rest assured Jack and Kyle have figured things out. The complaints of long lines, standing room only, too little beer, and difficulty seeing have all been dealt with. The new venue offered ample food trucks and bars, an air-conditioned seated auditorium, and VIP areas for those willing to spend a little more for smaller crowds. Not to mention the incredible lineup. Alright alright, I’ll mention it. I’ll talk about it extensively. I’ll let you see pictures. I’ll convince you to go next year. Shh, let me in. I’ll take care of you.

Read More

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: FALL 2014
content:
An Interview with Joanna Forde by Sergio Garcia

You can catch Joanna Fall 2014 on both The Fish Bowl (Thursdays 11-12pm) and Art House (Tuesdays 9-10pm) 

One artist. One album. Go.

JF: Wish You Were Here by Pink Floyd because it puts me in a trance and the lyrics are just absolutely beautiful. Everytime I listen to it I just get so many feels, man.

What does music mean to you? Represent?

JF: For me music means being able to connect with people. I’ve always felt like I can connect the most with people through music, whether from similarities or differences. It’s just a great way to form bonds with others, and I think that’s really cool. It kinda symbolizes the love you have your friends.

What does UCLA Radio mean to you? Represent?

JF: UCLA Radio is a community. It’s a way for everyone to share their love for music and to get to know people, particularly people with similar interests and values. Like music, Radio is great way to bond with other people. For me personally, it’s the one place I feel like I really fit in at UCLA. It’s like my little niche within this really large school. It’s nice to be with such a diverse, cool group of people and feel like I have a place with them.

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall 2014
content:
An Interview with Cranberry Chutney by Regan H. 

DJs: Zach, Ryan, Connor 

Fall 2014 Show Time: Tuesdays 12-2pm 

When asked what they enjoyed most about UCLA radio, Ryan mentioned that he “like[s] the community” and being able to “just kick it and share new music”, a sentiment that resonates well.  Zach mentioned that he liked that there is “no FCC regulation” and that there is “no straight genre,” and perhaps more succinctly, that he “can do a show”.  Connor shared the same sentiments as Ryan and Zach—“they summed it up well”. 

Where did the idea of ‘cranberry chutney’ come from? It was spring 2011, some three years ago.  Ryan and Zach were studying for a physics midterm for a long time.  Afterwards, they went for grub.   A friend was obsessed with the cranberry chutney sauce on the turkey subs, and wouldn’t stop talking about cranberry chutney.  So, arrived the name of the show—“Cranberry Chutney.” 

This is fitting, because cranberry chutney is a type of jam.  Although they probably didn’t intend it, I suppose, instead of jamming—it’s cranchutting every week for two hours.

What song best describes you? 

Zach says “Spread Eagle Cross the Block” by Death Grips.

Connor says  “Kiss from a Rose” by Seal. 

Ryan says “Turning on the Large Hadron Collider” by Neat Beats 

This was a tough question for Ryan.

What was your most intense dream?

Ryan talked about being a famous skater, like Tony Hawk.  (He remembers this dream still) Zach and Connor don’t remember. They all often dream of being in public without their pants on. 

What music do you want at your funeral, as opposed to some obnoxious organ? 

All agree that nothing super sad, but touching, like explosions in the sky. First of all, it has to bump. Zach wants them to play the entirety of the Infamous by Mobb Deep. 

If you were an item of food what would you be?

Zach says “I would be a banana because its phallic.”

Connor says “I would be an onion because I have layers, but I don’t make people cry.”

Ryan says “I would be a churro because I’m delicious." 

What is your least favorite song?

Zach says "Cherry Pie because it represents everything that is wrong with America. It has no artistic merit whatsoever.”

They all agree that they don’t like the song Yeah by Usher. Ryan stutters over what to say and then comes up with, “I hate it.”  It is implied that he has had past traumatic associations with this song. 

Connor abstains for he only has love for music.

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?

Naturally, I wanted to discover the secret behind that, so I got involved with UCLA Radio.

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?

title: Daniel Bambaata Marley on UCLA Radio, tonight @6pm
content:
Legends are timeless. They have a longevity unaffected by death just on the merit of their being wildly good at something. But when legends start families, do the resulting kids get a taste of that talent?

Daniel Bambaata Marley, son of Ziggy Marley, grandson of Bob Marley, is the latest result of a long-tailed comet of reggae genius that appears to run through the Marley family. He’s also performing on UCLA Radio- tonight. Hear for yourself just how far a legend’s mojo will stretch on UCLA Radio’s BUFR (facebook.com/burgersfries) at 6pm this evening. Get ready for good vibes, man.

title: Concert Review: SBTRKT @ Belasco Theater 10/16
content:
by Melina Powell

Last night SBTRKT played his second consecutive night at the Belasco Theater in Downtown Los Angeles, riding on the buzz surrounding his new album titled Wonder Where We Land. Aaron Jerome came out with his self-titled debut LP in 2011, a highly successful album that featured other up-and-coming artists such as Sampha, Jessie Ware, and the catchy track “Wildfire” featuring Little Dragon. The new record was released on October 7th in the US, earning positive reviews and featuring additional talented musicians including Ezra Koenig, Warpaint, A$AP Ferg and more. You can stream the singles from the artist website or purchase the deluxe version on iTunes here.

SBTRKT opened the set with “Paper Cuts”, wearing his recognizable tribal mask and featuring two drummers. Their dueling rhythms and the hypnotizing background visuals created an intense atmosphere that the crowd reacted to accordingly; surprisingly for an LA audience, people were dancing and singing along to every song. Jerome sprinkled tracks both new and old throughout his set, never letting the energy die down. His own enthusiasm was infectious, and the impressive light show of lasers and animated clips combined made for an unexpected sensory experience.

An exciting moment in the set came when rapper Raury joined SBTRKT on stage, performing the single “Higher” and fed off the liveliness of the crowd. Another stand out track from the new album was “War Drums” featuring the haunting vocals of Warpaint, and the fast-paced “NEW DORP. NEW YORK” that exemplified the talent of the drummers on stage. The live drums really added a new layer of power behind the already solid songs, and “Wildfire” was the height of the upbeat set. The encore included a remix of Radiohead’s “Lotus Flower”, which Jerome introduced by saying he doesn’t usually play his remixed work during his live set, but the crowd certainly got into it. He ended the show with “Right Thing To Do”, leaving the crowd yelling for more despite already having left the stage once. Don’t miss SBTRKT’s live show if he comes through your city; it’ll definitely be a night to remember and at the very least will give you a reason to dance!

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: FALL 2014
content:
An Interview with DJ Simulation 1 by Tiffany Nakano

After interning on the radio show Altimate this quarter, I also had the chance to interview the show’s host - DJ Simulation 1.

Q: What first interested you about UCLA Radio and becoming a DJ?

Simulation 1: I watched Pitch Perfect and I realized that colleges have radios and it would be cool to join the college radio, so then I found out about UCLA Radio (the day after the apps to join were due). So then I applied the following quarter because I saw that the managers looked friendly and it looked like I could fit in.

Q: What is your favorite part about your show or being a DJ in general?

Simulation 1: I love having the chance to introduce my listeners to music that they wouldn’t have found on their own. I am pretty mainstream with music, but when I find something that isn’t on the surface and extremely known and then play it, I know I’ve introduced people to other music that they like and will check out, expanding their horizons

Q: What music artist are your currently obsessed with and why?

Simulation 1: I’m not sure. I love the Black Keys and became obsessed with the Arctic Monkeys when their last album came out, but now I’m in a state of limbo because there isn’t any one band or artist that I’m obsessed with, more like songs. I’ve played a lot of Franz Ferdinand this quarter though, and I like the Sam Smith songs that I’ve heard so far — I guess I could say that’s my new discovery.

Q: What was your aircheck like during your intern quarter?

Simulation 1: My air check was a little nerve-racking. I prepared a playlist and made talking points, wrote everything out and was all ready for it, but then when I connected my computer to the soundboard the sound wasn’t quite right. I just let it play because I didn’t know what to do; I’d never had that problem before as an intern. It turned out that although the sound in which I could control from the keyboard was all the way up, the full output sound was only at the halfway point. I didn’t know that until the next quarter when I had my first show, and then after that I didn’t have the problem anymore. But the air check itself was fine.

It may lack the normal Incubus angst, but it is such a nice treat from beginning to end!

title: Show Review: Slowdive @ the Ace Hotel 11/08
content:
Waves of thrilled fans surrounded the outside of the theatre eager to teleport themselves into the dream-pop world of Slowdive’s music. As soon as tickets were scanned, fans rushed to the merch section of the venue to take back home a memorabilia from a band that had once vanished into the abyss of the shoegaze realm. The aroma of beer and wine filled the lobby as people walked around intrigued by the architectural beauty of the theatre. As fans were ushered to their seats, one could not help but to admire the interior decor of the actual theatre that resembled an underwater setting - perfect to accompany Slowdive’s dreamy sound. 
Everyone applauded and cheered as the band took over the stage with the song “Slowdive” from their debut album Just for a Day (1991). They presented themselves with a charismatic charm that made their fans get up from their seats and bust out Thom Yorke dance moves rooted from the electrifying set. Singer Rachel Goswell wowed everyone with her radiant elegance and ageless appearance. You could catch her sometimes shying away from the microphone by hiding in the shadows, but grinning as she was clearly surprised with the audience’s collective energy. 
During mellow songs such as “Dagger” and “Machine Gun”, the audience became completely paralyzed and enthralled into the deep effects from sheer shoegaze. Couple held each other tightly, others closed their eyes as they revived memories in their head (or probably just sleeping), and others were just straight-up rocking out and experiencing pure bliss. Slowdive bid farewell with a two-song encore, “Albatross” and “40 Days”, that fit just right for everyone to treasure this intimate concert experience. 
Slowdive takes you on a nostalgic trip with lyrics about loss, yet this is hardly noticeable as the shredding of their vibrant guitars and synths push listeners to find beauty in songs grounded from memories. This unique feature is basically the main component of the shoegaze genre and later became transformed into dream-pop by musicians who owe their inspiration to these pioneering rockers. That being said, Slowdive produced a long-lasting effect that led them to come back stronger than ever and reclaim their legacy as an invincible music group. 
Words // Photos: Michelle Preciado

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: FALL 2014
content:
Choppin’ It Up W/ DJ RAWRSH (Rasheed Tulay) / By: 1TAKE (Justin Duong)

FAll 2014 Show Time: Monday 2-4pm 

First off, what’s your name/DJ name and what’s your story?

My name is Rasheed Tulay aka DJ Rawrsh. What’s my story? I’m a weird ass kid from Los Angeles that loves music and has a lot of free time, that’s about it.

How’d you get your DJ name?

In high school a lot of kids used to call me “Rawrsheed” for some reason, so I started to use it for a lot of my usernames and stuff. I kind of just shortened it to DJ Rawrsh because I thought it sounded better.

Haha, I’ll have to refer to you as “RAWRSH” from now on it’s got a nice ring to it… So I’ve seen you at a few shows like the Nosaj Thing concert at the Echoplex and that time we went to Low End Theory together. What got you into that kind of music?

I grew up listening to a lot of punk and indie rock music since I grew up in the suburbs and that’s what a lot of my friends were listening to at the time. But in high school I became heavily invested in underground hip-hop (MF Doom, Wu-Tang, Jedi Mind Tricks etc.), and instrumental type music like Nujabes and J Dilla.

I then went to UC Riverside for two years before I transferred over to UCLA. Back at UCR I became friends with this kid Christopher Norwood, who happened to be an up-and-coming producer under the name ‘Repeated Measures’. At the time I was already a fan of the beat scene type of music, like FlyLo and all that, but Chris was the one who introduced me to Low End Theory and this whole underground scene that was burgeoning in Los Angeles.

That summer I ended up going to Low End basically every week just because it was so affordable but memorable every time. It’s insane the amount of talented people I’ve been able to meet and learn from just by attending these shows. Very inspirational stuff, it has definitely shaped my overall taste and what inspired me to start ALL CAPS.

That’s dope, I see you making all sorts of friends out there too. That’s probably how you get all these guests on the ALL CAPS Show. Speaking of which, how did that all start out with you and Zach, and how did you guys come up with a theme for the show?

Honestly, I just started talking to Zach at the meetings about hip-hop and Lil B, and thought that we were on the same wavelength when it came to music. Although I was a little bit more on the underground side of things, Zach is definitely knowledgeable about the more recent side of things when it comes to the hip-hop world, and just has great energy on air. The show would have definitely not been as good if were doing it solo. 

I had the idea of ALL CAPS in my head during my intern period, and I was greatly influenced by Amber Kong’s hip-hop show, as I was her intern.

I like the shout to MF Doom with ALL CAPS, but it works perfectly because you guys play a lot of hip-hop and do a lot of yelling on the show, I guess you could say you guys speak in ALL CAPS too! It’s been pretty cool interning on the show for you and Zach; it’s definitely influenced how I want to run my show. But before I go, I have to ask… Jedi or Wizard and why? (Don’t say wizard please).

Jedi! They are just notoriously badass; wizards have been out of style since Harry Potter ended.

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: FALL 2014
content:
An Interview with Valentina Gehley & Sarit Dann Rathbone (By Virginia Pettis)
  

1.  When and how did you meet?

We met in the School in Theater, Film, and Television our freshman year, at an event called Black & White Party (freshmen wear white and upperclassmen wear black).  We came with two different groups of people, and my group was wondering around, but then I (DJ Sweets) heard “Woops!”  I turned around to see DJ Googlemaps fiddling with her blouse, followed by, “Only my boyfriend is supposed to see that!”  Now we dance around our house and cry over papers together.

2. How long have you been involved with Theater and how did you get into it?

DJ Sweets: I’ve always been adamant about what I want since birth, and am not afraid to express it loudly.  So it began as a way to get people’s attention, and I’ve just adjusted as time has gone by so that people like me, while I still get all the things I want and remain in the limelight. *heavy laughter ensues*

DJ Googlemaps: My parents shoved me into an acting class in 2nd grade to try and build my confidence.  My first role was an Italian seagull *reenacts and mentions pizza pie* I also liked to come up with elaborate stories all the time, which sometimes led to mischievous situation…

3. What is something you’ve accomplished recently that you are proud of?

DJ Sweets: I performed at Canter’s Deli last night with Melinda West!

DJ Googlemaps: I successfully produced and mounted Crimes of the Heart in my living room this weekend, and now I’ve kinda started a theatre troupe. (Treehouse Theatre Company)

4. Favorite film, currently?

DJ Googlemaps: Nymphomaniac Volume 1.  It’s kinda like if Wes Anderson directed a porn.

DJ Sweets: What by Bo Burnham.  Many opportunities.
