title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: FALL 2014
content:
Interview with The DJs of The Food Show, DJ Corndog (Tori) and DJ Panini (Darcy). 

Fall 2014 Show Time: Tuesdays 11am 

DJ’s were asked to answer the first two questions based on what they thought about their co-DJ’s…

1st Question: If your co-DJ was on American Idol, what song would she sing?
Corndog: I don’t know how to answer that question! I don’t even know if she sings in the shower…I think she sings in the shower…but it’s never something she has shared with me. I think she’d sing something by King Khan and the BBQ Show because that’s our Food Show go-to and she loves King Khan. She’d just have to make her beautiful, sweet voice go super low and become a very large Indian man.
Panini: I think Corndog would sing….hmmmmm… Perverted Girl! (by Happy Birthday) And if she didn’t, I would want her to.

2nd Question: If your co-DJ was a crayon, what color would she be and why? 
Panini: Oh, Corndog would be yellow. Like, I don’t care if she likes yellow or not, but that’s just what I see in her when I look at her. Oh yeah. It’s yellow like my nail polish right now *waves fingers*. Because DJ Corndog is just like a luminous, bright, wonderful person.
Corndog: I have two answers. If we’re going by Panini’s favorite color or one of her favorite colors, it would probably be yellow. But if it’s a color that I’m picking for her then I’d go with the turquoise color of my very specific water bottle. Because it’s pretty, but it’s spunky.

3rd Question: Why do you think a tennis ball is fuzzy?
Panini: I think they wanted to make the tennis ball like the dandelion of balls. Like I think they were going for making it the most flower-esque ball. That’s my answer. 
Corndog: Maybe it’s like soft and fuzzy so that you want to hold it? (Panini: oh yeah, like a little cabbage?) Yeah! it’s the cabbage of balls.

title: MEET THE DJs WEEK: Fall Quarter 2014
content:
uclaradio:

To kick off fall quarter, the UCLA Radio Tumblr celebrating by posting a week of DJ profiles and interviews! We want you to meet our station! 

Fall quarter intern applications are due just around the corner (October 16th!!)! Prospective DJs, this could be you! 

Eddie. 3rd year. Linguistics and Philosophy. 

Why did you decide to join UCLARadio?
I joined UCLA Radio to showcase the weird vibes I can bring to the music community. Starting off as a comedy intern has really made me see how much of comedy I want to implement on my own radio show. I want to be the mediator between comedy and music; I want to be able to play some cool new tunes and at the same time, be able to freestyle rap over the late 90’s club banger “Sandstorm.”

What’s been your favorite album released in the past year?
My favorite album of this past year has got to be Devendra Banhart’s “Mala.” Not because it’s a heartbreak record, but because it’s a GREAT heartbreak record lOl. That album is just so unique and unlike Devendra’s ever done before, but it just sounds so old-school (he found an old 4-track Tascam tape recorder in a pawn shop to give it that old-school, distorted, home recording sound) and GREAT. If you’re ever feeling like crap about a break-up or something, or even if you’re feeling great with whoever you’re with or not with at the moment, give it a listen. I swear. The songs make for great makeout music as well if you disregard the lyrics (but then again, a good amount of Devendra’s discography is like that).

Recommended Tracks from Devendra Banhart:
“Your fine Petting Duck”
“The Ballad of Keenan Milton”
“Daniel”

title: An Interview With UCLA Radio DJ Ian Webb
content:
A short interview with Ian Webb, the current programming manager and host of Thought For Food (3-5pm Wednesday, Fall 2014) by Cole Frost

Q: What led to you first joining UCLA Radio?

A: I actually joined radio as a bit of luck. I had no idea the station existed, but at a tUnE-yArDs concert I met our New Media manager Melina. Trying to avoid another girl at the concert, I talked about radio with her, liked what I heard, and signed up for an interview. The appeal was really just finding a friend group at that point, and the common denominator of good music was just a cherry on top.

Q: What do you like best about UCLA Radio now that you have been a part of it for a while and become a manager and very involved member?

A: The things I like most about the station have shifted around quite a bit since I’ve been a manager. When I first joined, my favorite part of radio was the openness with which radio operated: there wasn’t a strict hierarchy or clique mentality, it was just a group of really nice and accessible managers trying to make something awesome. As I got to know managers and DJs, that openness transformed into community, and I honestly think our DJ community is the absolute highlight of our presence on campus and sets us apart from most UCLA groups. More recently though, I’ve begun to appreciate how amazing our programming is. I used to think NPR and KCRW were the kings of unique programming, but our station’s genre variety and creativity in show themes just absolutely trumps them all. I don’t think it’s an exaggeration to say that UCLA Radio is doing things that no station is doing on-air — we are really the most unique station there is.

Q: What is one band you like to play on your show that doesn’t always fit the show’s theme perfectly but you make space for because they mean something special to you?

A: Thankfully, with Thought For Food, I don’t restrict myself to any one genre or theme, so it gives me a lot of leeway with the music I play. However, there have definitely been a couple of trends in my playlists so far this year that don’t have much to do with what I talk about on air. The first one of these is the work of William Onyeabor, who is this Nigerian afro-funk artist from the 1980s who makes these towering synth-based dance songs that groove immeasurably hard for what seems like ages. David Byrne’s label Luaka Bop just came out with a compilation of his work last year, and I’ve played at least one track off of that LP every week simply because it makes people dance. Which is very important to me as a DJ — ideally my show makes you think and dance multiple times over the span of an hour. 

On a more thoughtful note, I’ve definitely included a lot of The Beta Band on my playlists this quarter. Their music is rather undefinable and shambolic, floating between psychedlica, electronica and Brit-pop, all of which are not personal faves nor genres I expect much deep meaning in. But somehow I find that their music really matches Though For Food’s sensibility and purpose. For example, I rarely plan any theme to my shows, letting myself just pick things I feel like reading or songs that make sense in terms of tone or tempo. It’s all very arbitrary, but over the course of actually doing the show, I find myself realizing exactly why I chose one song over another or why I chose to play a Simpsons clip over a Spongebob one. It’s not necessarily that these realizations bring with them any sort of meaning, but more than it brings a bit of self-awareness and satisfaction into an arbitrary environment. I think The Beta Band’s music reflects that sentiment perfectly, and the sort of quiet realizations that their music inscribes matches the sort of casual, “huh, cool” wisdom that I intend Thought For Food to have even if that wisdom never explicitly presents itself.

title: Using Fame for Good // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Nicole Jewell 
Post Date: ¾/17

When the name “Ashton Kutcher,” is thrown around, you usually think of him as ‘that guy in that movie’, or ‘the man who managed to marry Mila Kunis.’ However, Kutcher has actually been dedicating his time to what he refers to as his “day-job,” a non-profit organization called Thorn. There has been recent attention to this organization, due to Kutcher’s appearance before and appeal to Congress about “the right to pursue happiness” (CNN). Kutcher went to defend his efforts against child human trafficking, asking for more funding to fuel technology. Funding which would go towards, specifically, the software used to locate victims of child human trafficking, as well as several other resources for victims. Some of those include building a better “foster care system” and “mental health system” to assist victims once they are saved. Kutcher spoke passionately, evoking emotion as he recalled specific FBI raids that he had witnessed.

His co-founded organization uses software tools called “Spotlight” and “Solis,” both of which employ tools that have decreases “investigation time by 60%.” Solis investigates “dark web material,” the dark web being an “encrypted network” that is used to be unconventional search engines, in this case pornographic material of minors (quora.com). It was through this software that Kutcher saw “video content of a child that’s the same age as mine being raped by an American man that was a sex tourist in Cambodia. And this child was so conditioned by her environment that she thought she was engaging in play.” It is because of this, and his natural fatherly love and instincts, that drives Kutcher to so passionately present his cause to Congress.

The site for Thorn is informative, highlighting the issue of trafficking via the internet, in how it “makes content and abuse easier to identify and participate in; like-minded individuals can create communities to justify their actions; digital imagery and videos allow abuse to be shared globally at the push of a button; and private and encrypted networks protect individuals that participate in the most egregious types of abuse” (Thorn.com). The site additionally defines terms such as “DMST, live-streaming sexual abuse, sextortion, [and] child sexual abuse imagery,” leaving the web visitor more informed and aware of the modern tools used to perpetuate sex trafficking. It is astounding to consider that children as young as one year old are subject to this (arkofhopeforchildren.org), let alone that this happens in the United States.

Issues such as child human trafficking cannot be overlooked in the United States, as it serves as a large perpetrator. Yes, it “serves” child human trafficking because it still exists - children from overseas are still being abducted and forced into sexual abuse - and American citizens pay and take pleasure in this. While it is an uncomfortable truth to process, trafficking will remain an issue until it is openly discussed and eliminated. Actions taken by important figures in society, such as Ashton Kutcher, are crucial due to their influence. After reading this article, you should learn what Thorn is for yourself, and how this program accomplishes what it does — and how you can become involved. Simply reading and reporting about this issue is not enough.

title: You Are Going 2 Hate This Fest @ SOMA (2/18) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Mackenzi Elias 

Post Date: 2/25/17

The Frights, a garage band from San Diego, hosted their second You Are Going 2 Hate This Fest at SOMA San Diego  last weekend. I took the Greyhound bus down to see the show for my birthday and as a first time user of this bus I would give it a huge thumbs down. Luckily though, the show redeemed my shitty travel experience. SOMA is in a good location but it’s a pretty weird looking venue - the front of it literally just looks like a rundown storefront and the inside is small, intimate, and dimly lit.

Doors opened at 3 pm, and the 11 opening bands alternated from the mainstage to the side stage. I got there late, but just in time to see the Buttertones. I’ve seen them twice before, but this time there was a decidedly more eager anticipation in the crowd; everyone was shoving their way up to the front before the band even took to the stage. In true Buttertones fashion, they played on the tiny, intimate side stage and were within touching distance. Each member embraced his signature individual look, and as a group they resembled a band from the 60’s, which paired nicely with lead singer Richard Araiza’s distinct, old fashioned style of singing. 

They played songs from all of their albums and EPs, including “Bad Girl” off For the Head and for the Feet (my personal favorite), “Baby Doll” and “Connie” off American Brunch, and “Luna Estupenda” off The Buttertones. They also played “Sadie’s A Sadist,” a single released this month as a sample of their upcoming record Gravedigging which will be released March 25. The crowd was going absolutely nuts in the mosh pit the entire time they were playing, which was to be expected from their intense and fast-tempoed set.

The Garden, an eccentric, odd duo of brothers Wyatt and Fletcher Shears from Orange County, also performed. Their performance was bizarre, energetic, and undeniably entertaining. Both clad in cropped leather jackets, feathered haircuts, and dangly earrings, the Garden twins darted around stage, doing somersaults, sometimes pausing to play the drums, all the while reciting (I say reciting, because it hardly qualified as singing) some of their strange, punchy songs like “All Smiles Over Here :)” off their album haha. I’m not a huge fan of their music as their voices are (in my opinion) unimpressive and their songs are chaotic and jumbled, however I have to admit that they know how to put on a wild performance.

There were a few more bands in between, including the Long Beach based Tijuana Panthers, who were incredibly good live. The highlight of the night, though, was of course the headliner and hosts of the show, The Frights. Richard (bass), Mikey (lead guitar/vocalist), Marc (drums) and a guest guitarist whom I didn’t recognize played on the main stage in their traditional casual attire of t-shirts and pants. Joining them onstage were cardboard cutouts of Donald Trump, Danny Devito, and the Harry Potter cast, which were periodically tossed into the crowd throughout the show. 

The Frights’ set was thankfully an hour long as opposed to the openers, who only played 30 minutes each. In their 60 minutes on stage they played a little bit of everything; half of You Are Going To Hate This, half of The Frights, and “Makeout Point” off of Fur Sure. They even threw in a cover of “April 29, 1992” by Sublime and, iconically, “All Star” by Smash Mouth. To end the set, they played “Beach Porn” off their EP Dead Beach, which is a classic Frights moshing song that they “retired” but will usually play at the pleading requests of the crowd. 

Overall, the set was amazing, and I, as always, was impressed by the instrumentation and how true it was to their records. The Frights are not only great live musicians, but have a refreshingly humble persona. The whole band seemed so genuinely happy to be playing, and Mikey kept repeating how thankful he was to the fans. Overall, I was impressed with the venue, the lineup, and the Frights for their hosting of the second You Are Going 2 Hate This Fest. I actually ~did not~ hate it and I’m excited for next year’s show!
tags: you are going 2 hate this fest

title: Angel Olsen & Chris Cohen @ The Wiltern (2/14/17) // Show Review
content:
Written By : Derek Khaothong

Post Date: 02/20/17

Cladded behind metallic-colored streamers that shined in a variety of hues during the concert, Angel Olsen and her band performed at The Wiltern, Los Angeles on Valentine’s Day. The concert began with UCLA Radio’s own guest DJ alumni Chris Cohen opening, who entertained the crowd with his mellow voice and dreamy guitar chords. He performed songs of his new album, As If Apart. Later in the show, Angel Olsen dedicated a song to Chris Cohen for opening alongside her during her tour.

The next opener, Jonathan Richman, displayed a wacky and wholesome performance that I had never ever encountered in a concert. He performed with a drummer and used only an acoustic guitar during his set, but the main instrument that captivated the crowd at The Wiltern was his own body. Jonathan Richman danced with a smile on his face, while thrusting his hips and arms as creatively as he could. I found myself incredibly intrigued by his set and laughed along to his care-free childish persona.

Angel Olsen opened with Never Be Mine, one of my favorites off her 2016 record MY WOMAN. Her voice sounded even better live and the heavy distortion of the guitars shined through in the background. Soon after, she sang the punchy pop hit single Shut Up Kiss Me, which many members of the audience sang along to. All the band members wore matching, pastel grey suits, where as Angel Olsen rocked out in a red-striped white button-down shirt with bright red shorts. Olsen’s set during the middle of the show was where she began to play some songs of her 2014 album Burn Your Fire for No Witness, which shifted the punchy atmosphere of the show into a dreamier vibe. With her iconic choppy bangs glistening in shades of cyan and purple, Olsen sang with great love to her own music, which definitely shown as she smiled throughout the set to the crowd.

The encore of the show was a highlight for me, where Angel Olsen showcased her belting, ethereal voice in my favorite song, Intern. She played the synthesizer by herself, with a guitarist and keyboard backing alongside.

Overall, Olsen gave a beautiful performance that felt very intimate alongside the mellow Chris Cohen and wacky Jonathan Richman on Valentine’s Day. Angel Olsen’s immensely talented skills as a musician gave me an emotional, electrifying show that stole my heart away.

title: Culture - Migos // Album Review
content:
Written By: Harry Gonzalez 
Post Date: 2/15/17

The sophomore record by Atlanta’s grimiest trio kicks off with a very obnoxious, yelled introduction by DJ Khaled. He exclaims that people have “played themselves” for having doubted Migos, and effectively contributes nothing to the track. It is thankfully unintrusive throughout the rest of the intro cut, which is carried by the trap production brought to the table by 808mafia. The rubbery 808 bass hits, flipbook-esque hi-hats, and subtle claps take center stage on many verses throughout the album. The majority of the melodies are carried by Migos themselves as they deliver their iconic, chopped flows on many cuts of the record. This turn-taking dynamic performed by Offset, Quavo, and Takeoff is repeated on songs such as “Call Casting”, “Get Right Witcha”, “Big on Big” and “Deadz”.

Unfortunately, as the album continues into the latter half, this dynamic proves to be extremely formulaic. It also prevents many of the beats’ melodies to fall far behind everything else in the mix. At the same time, not all of the hooks on here are as catchy as some of the hooks that Quavo has delivered on other tracks where he is listed as a feature. The stickiest hook is found on “All Ass”, another 808mafia slapper that works as a late night, sparkling strip club anthem. The synths that compose the melody have a sexy touch of reverb that slide around with the Quavo and Offset’s auto-tuned croons. The lyrical content of the song lines up with the themes of the rest of the album: beautiful women, piles of cash, fancy cars, jewelry, and putting enemies in their place.

The album is clearly a statement of Migos’ intention to continue holding the reigns of the South with a relentless grip. The song “Deadz” is the most persistent track off the record. The same hook and refrain are repeated without much charm for the first minute, and again every other 30 seconds or so thereafter. Despite the fact that most songs fall past the 4 minute mark, the songs are validated by the presence that Migos creates. The trio makes sure to keep the spotlight on their names despite the fact that there are competitive features by Lil Uzi Vert, Gucci Mane, 2 Chainz and Travis Scott on the record. Lil Uzi Vert comes off as a Mini Migos clone on the single “Bad and Boujee.” Migos picked a subdued beat by Metro Boomin that resembles the sluggish, murky vibe pushed by 21 Savage on “Savage Mode.” However, they perform in an aggressive and dominant way on the track. Gucci appears on “Slippery” with his slouchy delivery and adds just enough of a different flow to prevent being mistaken as a Migos clone. His influence on Migos is extremely apparent on the track, since it is really hard to pinpoint the exact moment when Gucci’s verse ends and Takeoff’s verse begins. The track “Big on Big” is one of the few songs that feels focused on a single topic. Migos warns their haters, “How you gon’ big on big?” and are self aware of the fact that they are the biggest thing “popping” at the onset of 2017. It also has an enjoyable hook performed by Takeoff. It is one of the moments where the roles of the group are switched. A dynamic change like this adds new flavors to good moments on the album and keeps the album from feeling repetitive and bland.

The strings on “Big on Big” are also a welcome addition to the overall instrumentation of an album where bass hits consistently dominate. Migos takes the sound off Travis Scott’s Rodeo on the track “Kelly Price.” Down to the melodic passages crooned by Offset and Quavo, the song is obviously crafted and inspired by Travis Scott. The flows on this track do not feel like the typical, abrasive passages that Migos is known for. In fact, the second verse performed by Offset follows the similar sporadic flow organization found on “beibs in the trap” off of Scott’s sophomore record. However, these notions do not mean that the track is unenjoyable. The melodies in the verses convey feelings of lurking through dark alleys after a loud dance episode at a club. The drug references also give the song a very intoxicating and nauseating sensation. If there is anything about the track that gives away Scott’s influence, it is the reverb-drenched, synth-driven outro. The album as a whole appropriately fits the rest of Migos’ discography, and the trio continue their reign on the southern trap sound without pushing boundaries enough to lose any of their core fans. Overall I would give the album 6/10.

Favorite Tracks : “Bad and Boujee”, “Big on Big”, “All Ass”

Worst Track : “Deadz”

title: Lady Wood - Tove Lo // Album Review
content:
Written By: Roshni Kumar, UCLA Radio Music

Post Date: 2/1/17

From the bleakness and misunderstanding of “Habits”, to the intoxicating “Talking Body”, Tove Lo, the Swedish crooner, has only just begun to introduce herself.

With the release of her new album Lady Wood on October 28, 2016, Tove Lo is kicking it off by taking her club, dazed euphoria style to a whole new platform. Whether this serves to be a reflection of her own life or the generalization of the population as a whole, she reveals an expression of the concept of finding love in this lonely world. Remaining within her typical lyrical range about desire, drugs and sex, she invites her fans to join her on an emotional rollercoaster.

This time around, Tove Lo’s motifs are told in a story that is divided into two main chapters, ‘Fairy Dust’ and 'Fire Fade.’ The cheeky title ‘Lady Wood’ terms the concept of a woman getting a hard on. However, and perhaps more importantly, it serves as a declaration of female sexual expression.

Her first song — a mix of woozy, slippery tunes — is “Cool Girl”,  an ode to the Gone Girl character Amy Dunne. The first chapter explores the initial high of a relationship with the glossy songs of “Influence”, “Lady Wood”, and “True Disaster.” Here, Tove Lo focuses on the concept of perfection, as well as her attempts to stay locked in the narrative of illusion versus reality.

In the latter half of the album, Tove Lo displays the comedown, and how drips of reality start seeping back into her cloud of vision. With the feverish numbers “Keep it Simple” and “Don’t Talk About it”, Tove Lo highlights the unspoken feelings and the darkest moments of distance and separation. She ends things off with “WTF Is Love”, an upbeat track that questions why she even decided to partake in this emotional train wreck. 

Overall, this album is quite successful and stamped with the signature of Tove Lo. Regardless of whether or not you are a fan of electronic or pop music, her music will catch you off guard and will slowly find its way into your top favorites. I’d definitely recommend checking out, it’s a solid 8/10!

title: Cole Heramb: UCLA Student Speaks about his Latest Album “Red,” Emotionality, and the Accessibility of Art
content:
Written By : Elizabeth Hsieh, Digital Press

Post Date : 1/20/17

As a second year Biology student and creative, Cole Heramb perfectly maneuvers through the complicated dichotomy of logistical science and emotionality. Heramb has been a guitarist for 12 years and has mastered the craft of song-writing despite “[not having] a lot of encouragement in that department.” Being a part of multiple social and creative realms such as comedy, tattooing, drawing, surfing, and of course, songwriting, Heramb embodies what is means to gain a greater perspective in all facets of life. He explains, “All my experiences, in and out of the classroom, really push me to expand my perspective. It’s less thinking of things as separate worlds but as possible inspiration. To me, that forms an interesting output because I am getting so many different sources of input from so many areas. I do that by having a lot of different hobbies and doing a lot of different things because it helps get to know human nature.”

With this in mind, Heramb recently joined all of his experiences together to self-produce his debut album (available on Spotify, Soundcloud, and iTunes) under the title “Red.” The album serves perfectly as a soundtrack for a beach side bonfire - a combination of soothing acoustic artistry paired with wave-y, heartfelt ballads mimicking the likes of The Kooks, Beach Boys, and Unknown Mortal Orchestra. As artists these days seem to stray from record deals and studio equipment, Heramb explains that his limited resources and decision to singlehandedly produce his album actually aided in accurately depicting what he wanted his album to portray—emotionality. He states that his music represents “an authentic representation of [his] emotions.” He continues, “I use music as another language, a universal language, of where words fall short in expressing what it means to be human.” With his album representing the color red, which is often associated with anger and other intense emotions, the rawness of the album shines through with the idea of externalized “redness.”

As a biology student, Heramb uses his large reach across campus in a way that helps him expand his creativity and in turn help other people relate to his music in personal ways. With his sphere of influence spanning in all types of areas at UCLA, Heramb’s music is easily accessible for people of all backgrounds. He states, “Having a lot of different hobbies and doing a lot of different things helps me get a larger perspective. It allows me to stay level headed and makes my music more accessible to other people because if I were just singing about certain things, cells for example, no one would be interested in it other than a specific group of people who like songs about cells.”

Although the singer-songwriter realm is hyper-saturated with musicians wearing their hearts on their sleeves, Heramb sticks to his guns instead of comparing himself to others. “There’s that old saying ‘Comparison is the thief of joy’ and I think it’s easy to fall into looking at what everyone else does. I’m more so trying to limit my thoughts about following what is popular and instead focusing on reeling my emotions rather than what I feel like my emotions should be,” he says. In a homogenous world where individuality seems impossible, combating the beast of conforming is not really about creating an entirely new sound, entirely new instruments, or even a unique worldview. Instead, the way that something is original is that the art is coming uniquely from its creator, that no one has heard this individual story specifically. Since everyone has such similar experiences, you just have to create in a way that is coming from your upbringing and your emotions. Heramb successfully does so by putting his soul on the line—open for all to see.

title: Spotlight of the Week // The Discourse
content:
Was it your New Year’s resolution to become more politically active? Are you looking to satisfy your inner student activist? Unsure of how to react to our recent presidential election? Get an in depth look into social justice work with The Discourse, hosted by Alex Torpey. The show features a variety of guests - previous guests have been students, journalists, professors, and activists - to discuss their contributions to the realm of social justice and share their unique experiences. Through this “discourse,” Torpey is able to close the gap between individuals and the complex issues they navigate, bringing humanity to political and social affairs. As he says, “The Discourse elevates the importance of lived experiences so as to humanize the civic involvement that it documents.” The show reminds listeners that each of them, even as just one person, can make a difference, and in the state of the current world, this message is becoming increasingly important.

Follow The Discourse on Facebook, and listen into past episodes of the show on SoundCloud. The Discourse returns this quarter on Friday at 2 p.m. on uclaradio.com!

title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 5 with Torey Lanez
content:
Written By: Ramtin Vata

Photos By: Brian Suruki

Post Date: 12/16/16

Going into my first concert with a press pass, I didn’t know what to expect. The concert opened up with Kweku Collins. I admit I had never heard of him before that night, but the amount of energy he had on stage was pretty amazing. His DJ hyped the crowd while he rapped a few songs to start warming up. Pell came on right after, and I have to say he has earned a new fan. Being able see Pell rap up close on stage was incredible. 

Following Pell was the man of the hour, Tory Lanez. I was able to get a sneak peek at his set list before he performed and I was excited because he performed a lot of my favorites. I’ve seen rappers get crazy on stage before but Tory is an experience in itself - as he jumps into the audience, rather than crowd surfing, he stands on the audience. As people hold his hands and legs up to balance him, he stands in the middle of the crowd rapping one of his biggest hits, “Diego”. Between songs he also performed some fun old school songs. Tory is a man of many talents, as he has an incredible singing voice to go along with his ability to rap. 

It was a lot of fun watching these three artists on stage present their work, and it was a lot more fun because of the location - the Echoplex is a fairly small venue and so the crowd becomes part of the performance, rather than just bystanders.

title: The Improv Space Has a Hilarious New Lineup // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By: Hunter Saling

Post Date: 2/25/17

Westwood’s eclectic Comedy Theater, The Improv Space, is revamping its weekly lineup. Thursday’s and Friday’s main stage improv have been jam-packed into a weekly feature Harold night, with teams known and loved (Bankroll, The 400 Cat, Fish Grease and My Favorite Customer), as well as two brand new teams to top off every Friday from 8pm to 11pm. Five dollars will get you in for the whole night! It is the best-value comedy in Los Angeles (probably), so don’t buy a coffee for the day — buy laughs!

Thursdays will soon feature rotating teams and all sorts of improv, alternating monthly shows, and a few surprises, too! In the meantime, catch weekly standup show, Boyband!, hosted by UCLA’s very own golden boys, Nathan Mosher and Austin Nasso, at 10pm! Always with free admission and free drinks! Featuring local and renowned comedians, this indie-show is one that sets itself apart from all the others around town. All the others probably also say that, but who knows! Come watch for yourself and maybe it will be true!

Mondays are, of course, still the home of The Improv Space’s Open Mic night, that goes from 9pm to 11pm with sign-up at 8:30pm. It is a great chance to work out new material, try stand-up for the very first time, or just hear the sound of your own voice — if that’s what you are looking for. We don’t judge. On Wednesdays, be sure not to miss the world famous Improv Jam hosted by Ben Crutcher (LA Times Curiosity Correspondent (Yeah, that’s a real job, and he is damn good at it. Google it!))! Come just by yourself, come with friends and go together as a team, or come as both! Either way, you put your name in a (definitely, totally not) stolen In-N-Out tray and get up and do some improv! You have no excuse! Nothing to lose! DO IT!

If you’re interested in diving into comedy, but also want some good old official instruction in improv or sketch, The Improv Space offers some of the cheapest classes in town. They are taught by experienced improvisers and writers on teams at theaters such as the Upright Citizen’s Brigade and iO West! That’s right! It’s their real life jobs!

The Improv Space is headed by improvisers and strives to provide a fun, safe, constructive space for comedy of all sorts, for performers of all backgrounds. For more information on shows, classes, and quite a nice web design, check out www.theimprovspace.com for all of that! (Donations are also greatly appreciated and will probably buy you acceptance into whatever safe-haven/ afterlife/ internal-sense-of-well-being that your specific creed/ background/ upbringing has driven you to strive for!)

title: Star Struck at the Fist Fight Press Junket // Film Review
content:
Written By: Annie Williams

Photo Credits: Annie Williams

Post Date: 2/17/17

Fist Fight from Warner Bros. Entertainment is coming to a theater near you tonight!

I had the pleasure of attending an early screening and press junket for Fist Fight at the W in Westwood earlier this month. I was excited to see members of the star-studded cast before the junket even began. Walking through the lobby I spotted Teen Wolf stars Max and Charlie Carver, and checking into hospitality I scooted past the face of the beloved character Schmidt from New Girl, Max Greenfield, who pitched the story behind Fist Fight.

The first portion of the junket featured Greenfield, writers Van Robichaux and Evan Susser, producers Dan Cohen and John Rickard, and Director Richie Keen. Fist Fight is the first feature film from Keen, who has worked with Charlie Day in the past on It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia. Day and Keen came to the film separately; Day had signed on to co-star opposite Ice Cube in the role of Andy Campbell before Keen caught hold of the script. Describing his initial interest in the film, Keen said:

“I grew up in John Hughes country. Suburban Chicago. I grew up where they were filming Ferris Bueller. I would sneak onto the set and watch them film Ferris Bueller. John Hughes was my idol, and when I read the movie I felt like this was a rated-R John Hughes movie. It had…all the tropes of a John Hughes movie: it all takes place in a day, it takes place in high school, it’s the day that changed someone’s life, but it had a piece of Animal House in it. It was a crazier look at high school. So yes, it played to my sick sensibility, and Charlie and I began a year and a half long process of being partners on it.”

The second portion of the junket featured Keen and actors Day, Ice Cube, Tracy Morgan, Jillian Bell, Christina Hendricks, JoAnna Garcia Swisher, the Carver twins, and Kym Whitley.

On landing Ice Cube opposite Day, Keen said, “I can’t think of a more comedic visual to go with the phenomenal script I read.” 

Keen won every single pick for the all-star cast of Fist Fight, rewriting the role of the nympho-tweaker guidance counselor for Bell and even getting down on his knees at a studio meeting to beg her to join the film. Bell commented on the royal treatment, saying, “It was the nicest and the most unnecessary thing anyone has ever done for me. I was like, I love this script, I love you, I love who’s in the movie, and I was so happy that he wanted me to be in it, and the knees, getting on the knees was a big bonus!”

The film also features Morgan as gym teacher Coach Crawford in his first appearance since his accident - Keen commented:

“I skyped with Tracy, and within 30 seconds Tracy’s asking me, ‘Whose Captain Kirk’s best friend?’… ‘Spock?’-‘No it ain’t Spock, Spock calls him Captain. You don’t call your best friend captain. Bones says ‘Dammit Jim,’ so Bones is his best friend!’…I’m like, he’s fine, he’s ready to work!” 

He also stated that working with Morgan was, “Above and beyond what I could have hoped for. Tracy is just such a kind, gentle, thoughtful person and also crazy. He was so on his game, I felt like he elevated the material for all of us. I’m so grateful to have been a part of his first project back.”

On “coming back,” Morgan said:

“There was a lot of funny in me. I was on the couch for a year after that Walmart truck hit me… I just let it all out, and this seemed the movie to do it at!”

“Richie thank you, I love you for believing in me… I was so scared the first day, I didn’t know if I was funny or not, after what I had just been through, and then I had the team around me…Cube was like a brother to me. They really encouraged me and relaxed me, and I just had fun after that. Fun.”

“I never left. I’m proud to be of service to you when I make you laugh. Nah, I just picked up where I left off at. Walmart can’t stop me!”

Fist Fight was filmed on location in Atlanta, and used local extras for the explosive, enormous final scene. The final fight took more than a week to shoot. On training for the battle Day said:

“I did just have like a week of training, because they had to show me how to make a fist without breaking my thumb! I tried to not make it look like I knew what I was doing, which I don’t…I trained with a guy named Edwards, who’s a big UFC guy. At one point we’re doing the moves and he’s like, ‘now you duck,’ and going two miles an hour, well I looked the wrong way, accidentally hits my head and almost completely knocked me out. So I have a lot more respect for those UFC guys, and how tough they are, and I would never, ever want to do it, and I don’t recommend it.”

Day is strung between principal Dean Norris and antagonist Ice Cube throughout the film, fighting to hold on to his dignity and his job with budget cuts cleaning out the teaching staff. On the underlying meaning of the film Ice Cube commented:

“It’s a movie about two teachers fighting. We wanted to make sure we had a cool underlying message…about the school system and how two teachers deal with it. You know, one teacher is ultra-hard and one teacher is trying to appease and get along and befriend students. It is saying a lot about our school system, what we need to tackle, the problems that we face nowadays…but the overlying message is have fun, laugh, trip off these crazy characters in this scenario. This is a popcorn movie if you ask me. If you’re trying to find a really deep rooted message in it….ahhhhh, excuse me I’ll have to work with you on that.”

I walked into the theater excited to see some of my heroes appear on screen together. The prison-riot like premise of senior prank day, with the onslaught of increasingly bizarre and violent pranks, kept me laughing the whole film. The chemistry between Day and Ice Cube was phenomenal, and the visual juxtaposition of the two actors was comedic in itself. Keep your eye out for Keen in his cameo performance as the sales clerk in the computer store - his star-spangled first feature film will have you in stitches.

title: El Ten Eleven @ The Fonda (2/3/17) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Amy Cummings

Photo/Video Credits: Bryan Villalpando

Post Date: 2/13/17

El Ten Eleven opened for Lotus at the Fonda this past weekend — and with a floor full of enthusiastic listeners, you wouldn’t have guessed that they weren’t headlining. Bryan and I headed in early and camped out at the barrier with a clear view of the stage, which was packed with an elaborate setup: at least four bass/guitar combos and a full drum kit for El Ten Eleven — a duo — alone. It was our third time seeing the band perform live, so we had high expectations. The band came on at nine o’clock sharp and delivered a consistently excellent performance, as usual.

The first time Bryan and I saw El Ten Eleven, they were nearly late to their show at the Teragram Ballroom due to mudslides across major California highways. The band joked about playing a mudslide remix of their songs in homage to the day’s events. The second time we saw them, Kristian Dunn was disgruntled that we weren’t loud enough in the crowd (we were too busy dancing; who knew?). This time, we were determined to bring the band some joy and danced and cheered loudly to show our support. I guess it worked because we brought an elusive smile to Kristian’s face. They are a joy to watch because of the sheer physicality they exhibit in the layering together of their complex music for a live performance. While Tim Fogarty goes hard on the drum kit, his hair progressively deflating from sweat, Kristian works the loop pedal and deftly swaps among his multiple double-necked guitars. You can’t help but feel impressed when you realize the amount of gear these dudes have to schlep around for a duo act, and a little bit intimidated when you actually see them put all the puzzle pieces together. But it works so well, and that’s what makes them great.

Despite a brief technical difficulty or two, the band kept the energy high for the entire hour-long set and seemed to be having a good time. I had heard others in the crowd around me talking about how they’d seen El Ten Eleven shows in the past, and that the band brought them back to this show even though they weren’t headlining. It’s extremely difficult to talk about this band since they’ve already rejected so many labels like math rock or art rock, since they create a totally unique experience whenever they take the stage. Their transcendent performance was also perfect against the backdrop of the Fonda, which was full of cool air and misty light. 

Even though the band has no vocals or lyrics, somehow their evocative song titles, like the much lauded “I Like Van Halen Because My Sister Thinks They Are Cool,” get the message across alongside the complex and beautiful music. Another highlight is in the middle of the song when Tim steps away from the drum kit and joins Kristian to drum on the frets of his guitar for a unique, tinny sound. But the best of all is when the band launches into “the hit,” “Transitions” — a ten-minute instrumental piece so energetic and excellent that you can’t help but dance and feel as if you’re singing along as you move to the funky time signatures and throbbing bass.

title: Spotlight of the Week // QUIZ NITE
content:
Post Date: 2/7/17

Can’t join your friends for trivia night at Barney’s? Stay in instead and have fun every Wednesday evening with QUIZ NITE! The show ties in songs with entertaining questions for a wild hour of trivia and music. DJ Aboney features two guests each week, who not only compete against each other but also take time to converse and sharing entertaining stories. DJ Aboney explains the trivia questions can be about anything, such as “a certain song lyric, like a word, something newsworthy, or what fast food place is closest to Amoeba Music on Sunset.” With a wide variety of content, QUIZ NITE is sure to have you brushing up on your fun facts as well as sharing a laugh.

You can follow QUIZ NITE on Facebook. Listen to the first episode of QUIZ NITE on SoundCloud, or listen in live and play along with the guests every Wednesday at 10 p.m. at uclaradio.com!

title: Spotlight of the Week // On Deck
content:
Post Date: 1/29/17

“Knowing” music is often much more than just hearing a song - a music fan can get a whole new perspective on a track by learning about its origins and creation. On Deck provides listeners with this illuminative context. DJ FroLite describes her show as “equal parts bangers and education,” that focuses mostly on the hip hop world, with the occasional R&B track. She dedicates her hour not only to playing music but also to enlightening listeners on the artists, genres, and songs themselves. In the past, DJ FroLite has addressed subjects from female rap artists of the 90′s to controversy over Drake lifting music without due credit to other artists. Coming up this month, On Deck will be highlighting Black History Month by studying hip hop as a genre, and “exploring the origins of hip-hop as a revolution and its evolution over time.”

Like On Deck on Facebook and make sure to tune in Sunday afternoons at 4 p.m.!

title: January’s Show of the Month Interview // Vertigo
content:
Post Date : 01/12/17

So, let’s talk about the show title…“Vertigo.” What’s the meaning behind it and how does it relate to the theme of your show?

I remember toying with the idea of different names during the intern class, and it truly was a light bulb-epiphany-esque moment when I realized I would name the show Vertigo.
The show title came to fruition because of two reasons:
1. Vertigo is the name of my favorite Alfred Hitchcock movie. It’s set in the SF Bay Area, where I’m from, and is a romantic psycho thriller about a detective with vertigo who falls in love with a woman he’s investigating. She mysteriously dies by an apparent “suicide,” but (spoiler alert) it’s later revealed that a woman set her up to die due to her love for him. I’m intrigued by the fanatical obsessions people have towards ideas and feelings and how irrational we are because of these passions. The same type of fear and lust the characters felt in this film is exactly how I feel when I experience live performances and music in general.
2. Vertigo’s symptoms are literally described by WebMD as “triggered by the change in the position of your head, feeling pulled to a certain direction.” I’d like to think my show is thought provoking and fun all at once, which is why the political commentary is so important to creating the balance of cool vibes and enlightenment. After all, you’re not losing your mind, it’s just vertigo

What’s your most notable memory with a guest on air?

One of my favorite memories involves me playing a prank on the artist I was interviewing. Eevaan Tre, a R&B artist who played Coachella 2015, came in for a live performance. In the middle of the interview, I had a friend who does amazing voice impersonations, call the on air line to say hi - while pretending I didn’t know who she was. She embodied her “Martha May” sales lady character, where she proceeded to try to sell Eevaan Tre a penis enlargement pump. In infomercial style and a Southern belle accent, she described all the benefits of buying a pump with “three easy payments of $59.99 to enlarge any three inch ween!” It was the most hilarious conversation I’d ever seen. Eevaan Tre was utterly confused and tried to be nice while maintaining good composure. I listen to it whenever I need a good laugh.

What’s the process behind creating a playlist for the show?

My goal is to ultimately NEVER repeat a song I’ve played on a previous show before. First, I look to see which artists are performing at upcoming festivals by researching the early afternoon or non-headlining artists and listening to their music. Spotify is my godsend because I’ll use the artists in the “Emerging Artists” section to find similar sounds and artists who could act as good transition pieces. Monday mornings I usually procrastinate any studying and spend a couple hours listening to the ends of songs so they mesh well to the next. Transitions are key. I also like to create two different vibes for the whole show, so, for example, the first half will be slower melodies with soul vocals, and then by the end will transition to hardcore rap with acoustic beats.  Of course, the artist I’m interviewing will also have their song played as well.

You can pick anybody in the universe to help co-host and curate an episode of the show… who do you pick? What do you talk about with your co-host?

If anyone knows me, they know three things: I love Red Bull, buttered popcorn, and Kanye West. As cliche as the Kanye fandom is and how diehard I profess to be on social media, I truly believe future generations will look back on the millennial generation and study Kanye’s work to understand us as a species. I’ve gotten into arguments with complete strangers about his work and even contemplated peeing my pants when I waited through a set to get to the front to see him during FYF - because aside from the arrogant character he plays for the media, I think he has the wit to make humans think again. After reading the book his mom wrote, Raising Kanye, and watching the two hour long Lou Stoppard interview, my understanding elevated to a new level of respect. He talks about “wanting to be five again” so he can experience the creative freedom that exists without being vulnerable to social norms. So, on my show, we would discuss the human condition, the commodification of art, and what a #Kanye2020 presidency would actually look like.

Any words of advice for future radio DJ’s?

CHOOSE your words carefully. ACTUALLY think before you speak. LISTEN to your shows after they air and make notes of where you think you sounded stupid and what you think really worked. Recognize which words you use too often and have fun with your vocal ranges. Create a list of topics you are unfamiliar with but have always wanted to explore. Don’t try to impress your friends - impress yourself - and surprise yourself by creating a new character that exists only in the depths of the imagination you are usually to scared to discover. This can be done when you authentically live in the moment (yeah yeah, cheesy) and if you want to interview people/artists, never think you ‘aren’t good enough’ to pitch to their PR team. Its all a numbers game - if you pitch to 15 different press teams and get three responses, you’ll book your calendar in no time.

title: Spotlight of the Week // The Awakening
content:
Fallen into a music stupor? Snap out of it with UCLA Radio’s Spotlight of the Week, The Awakening. title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 29  with YG
content:
Written By : Faizan Malik, UCLA Radio Sports

Photos Courtesy of Marv Watson, Red Bull Sound Select Content Pool

G-Funk is still alive thanks to YG. The funky West Coast sound is almost solely represented by YG in the mainstream music world. More impressively, he’s done so without the help of Dr. Dre, the genre’s godfather, who’s worked with everyone from Kendrick Lamar to Xzibit.

As part of Red Bull’s “30 Days in LA” campaign, YG performed at the Wiltern Theatre in Koreatown. Red Bull added some flavor to the event by decorating the venue with photo booths and vintage TVs displaying the names of other artists participating in “30 Days in LA.” For those wondering about merchandise available, a number of 4Hunnid (YG’s clothing brand) hoodies and shirts were on sale for anywhere from $20 to $100. Foam fingers, with “Fuck Donald Trump” printed on them, were also on sale and seemed to be the most popular item sold. The venue itself differs from most in that it has five or so general admission sections separated by empty walkways. Unfortunately, my press pass didn’t grant me entrance to the middle section in the front. I didn’t like the sections as they stifled the crowd’s energy, however they ensured that most people had a good view of the stage.

DJ Vision, YG’s DJ, came on stage shortly after 10:30 p.m. After Vision played a few bangers to hype up the crowd, YG made a grand entrance. Gunshots followed by police sirens echoed throughout the venue as four men dressed in blue scrubs rolled YG on stage in a stretcher. The visual screen displayed doctors in an operating room and YG performed “Who Shot Me?” while on the stretcher. Despite being on his back, YG possessed energy and set the tone for the show.

YG followed “Who Shot Me?” with a high energy performance of “BPT.” The Los Angeles native played an even mix of songs from “My Krazy Life” and “Still Brazy.” Despite releasing a mixtape “Red Friday” on November 25, YG didn’t perform any songs featured on the new album. Between songs YG would occasionally say a few words about the crowd or content of his songs, but the show had a good flow. He seemed especially excited to be performing in front of his hometown crowd. His monologues never dragged on and were often funny.

Technically, YG was solid. Although initially, his mumbled voice was overpowered by the backing track, after two or three songs he found his groove vocally. He often ended songs acapella so the audience could clearly hear him. The visual screen behind YG added a lot to the show as well. It went from displaying palm trees to being completely red during “Still Brazy.” The visuals made the show aesthetically interesting and added another dimension to YG’s performance.

For the more tenured YG fans, he performed a few oldies, such as “Toot It and Boot It” and “Bitchez,” the latter of which he brought out RJ for. Being in his home city, YG made sure to bring out a few other special guests. In addition, he brought DJ Mustard and G-Eazy towards the end of the show. During “Still Brazy,” a number of YG’s friends joined him on stage in an improvised manner that got the crowd hyped up.

Given the fact that YG named his tour “The Fuck Donald Trump Tour,” the crowd was extremely eager to hear “FDT,” and the performance did not disappoint. YG turned the finale into a spectacle unlike most rap shows. Despite seemingly focused on a serious subject, YG kept it lighthearted and focused on creating a fun atmosphere rather than a serious one. YG invited a diverse group of people on stage. He made sure to have a woman, as well as Hispanic, black, and white people on stage. Once on stage, a Donald Trump piñata was lowered onto the stage to an ironic rendition of “Hail to the Chief.” YG handed out some sticks and laid down some rules before telling the group on stage to take swings on the piñata. After the Trump piñata was beaten to a pulp, the visual screen simply displayed “Fuck Donald Trump,” and YG exploded into “FDT.”

YG’s performance differed from most in that he truly put made his performance a show. He did more than just show up and perform a few songs, instead he turned the event into something extravagant. The performance which lasted a little over an hour flew by. Next time YG has a show in Los Angeles, I’ll be sure to be in attendance.

title: Ambiguity Among the Bruins // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: Ryland Towne

Post Date: 3/3/17

With a record of 27 wins and 3 loses, it would appear that the Bruins have solidified a deep run in the tournament. Yet, even with such a dominant record, the Bruins’ future is still unclear.

Lonzo Ball has lived up to the hype, while T.J. Leaf, the other superstar freshman, has put up continually impressive numbers. In spite of such strong performances, the Bruins still appear to have deep flaws in their system.

Let’s take a brief look at the Bruins’ three loses. All have come within conference play.  All were manageable matchups for the Bruins. And all could have been avoided without such a heavy reliance on the Bruins’ offensive capability.

The recent thriller against Oregon — in which the Bruins came back for redemption against a wide margin — should give some hope for the Westwood fans.  It is also key reminder that the Bruins do best when they are considered the underdog.

Look at the first top-10 matchup of the year against Kentucky.  While Kentucky has been stronger in previous years, it was still projected to be a tough, but winnable game for the Wildcats. With this win, the Bruins gained a sense of confidence and swagger that carried them on to a significant winning streak.

But this win also revealed the vulnerability of the Bruins’ offense. The Bruins can certainly go shot-for-shot with any team in the nation, but if they have an inconsistent shooting night, their defense struggles to keep up.

In each of their losses this season, the Bruins were ranked higher than their opponents. The underdog mentality, therefore, was nonexistent in the locker room. Couple that with a lackadaisical defense and a subpar (all relative) shooting night, and you end up with a tough loss.

This is not to say that the Bruins will be unable to manage themselves in the tournament.  Thankfully, defense is not necessarily dependent on skill. Defense is about effort and how hard you’re willing to work to prevent your opponent from scoring.

However, defense also comes at a price. Because the Bruins lack depth off the bench, Ball has been playing a significant portion of each game. While he is a supernatural athlete, Ball will get tired. And, when this happens, the whole team struggles because he is not only an offensive threat, but a game manager on the court.

Players like Ball, Leaf, and Alford might have to put their offensive capabilities aside and focus on the hustle, rather than just the finesse. Coach Alford must harp on his players who decide to take a possession off because, as we know from experience, every possession matters in March.

title: The Zen Unmastered // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: James Shippy

Post Date: 2/25/17

Phil Jackson. Phil Jackson. How far you have fallen. When it comes to the NBA, Phil Jackson’s an icon.  He coached arguably 4 of the top 15 basketball players of all time. Including the G.OA.T. Michael Jordan. With his stint with the Chicago Bulls he coached 2 Three-peat teams. And to top it off he took his talents to the storied Los Angeles Lakers franchise and gave them 5 rings thanks to his tutelage of rising superstars, Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O’Neal.   

Then, he retired. Then, he took his talents back to the New York Knicks where his affiliation with the NBA began back in the late 60s. But his talents weren’t in coaching this time around. No, he had the bright idea to become a GM. A job he’s never possessed — a fact which he is making more obvious with each passing day.

Phil Jackson took over the Knicks with one objective: to bring a title back to arguably the greatest basketball stadium in the world, Madison Square Garden.  Instead he’s been plagued by odd hires at coach. First, Derek Fisher. Someone with no coaching experience and a slight penchant for dating his ex teammates ex wives. And now we have Jeff Hornacek, who coached one decent season in Phoenix, and then got canned the next losing season. And odd trades.

And, his greatest issue of all — his tumultuous relationship with the new generation of superstars that don’t kneel down to kiss the ring because he’s failing to show them the respect they deserve. First, it was his spat with LeBron James where he had the audacity to call his friends and business partners his “posse”. This erupted a war of words, resulting in LeBron stating that he had lost respect for Phil, even going as far as to say that Greg Popovich was the best coach in the history of the NBA. Ouch.

Then came his outright complaints about his own, fading New York Knicks star, Carmelo Anthony. This is where things got the most interesting. When Phil Jackson came to the Knicks, he was tasked with building a winning team around Carmelo Anthony, and restoring the triangle offense back to its prominence in the NBA once again. The problem with this is that the triangle offense is outdated, and, no disrespect to Carmelo Anthony, but he’s no Jordan or Bryant. Plus, Anthony is not a two-way player in the same way that Jordan and Kobe were.

But that which has transpired most recently is a heavy mutual disliking between Phil Jackson and Carmelo Anthony, thanks to a 12th place standing record of 22-31 in the abysmal Eastern Conference. They are heading to their fourth losing season in a row. Why did this happen, once again? The Knicks were supposed to be poised to make the playoffs this year. Especially when Phil Jackson attracted the goodwill from fans for last year’s surprise 1st round draft pick, Kristap Porzingis.

The Knicks are going nowhere fast, and Phil Jackson is even resorting to sub tweeting.  Are we serious? He’s actually sub tweeting and throwing shade at Carmelo Anthony. Calling him a ball hog and someone who can’t change his ways. At the same time, he has all but publicly denounced Carmelo and put him on a trading block with virtually no teams willing to meet his demands because they themselves know how detrimental an aging, one-on-one player can be to their team chemistry.  

Phil, you should be better than this. Do your GM job and stay out of the public media. Better yet, when the seasons over, do the Knicks fans a favor and quit.  Unfortunately, with Phil Jackson and Jeanie Buss ending their 4-year engagement last December, even the Los Angeles Lakers don’t appear to be a fallback for him. Maybe that’s for the better. Not the relationship ending, but the fact that he most likely won’t be their GM in the near future either. He’s tried that job already. And we’ve all seen enough.

title: From Sadboys to Gladboys // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By: Rohnie Williams

Post Date: 2/18/17

You might have noticed that social media has gotten a little bit darker these days. People are lamenting their states left and right like some kind of shitty Shakespeare sonnet (29, to be exact). It isn’t because our new overlord is dropping executive orders like Stephen Curry drops 3’s, but it’s because the sadboy aesthetic has become mainstream.

What is a sadboy? The sadboy is a person who takes one small discomfort in their life, usually relating to an inability to make a deep romantic connection, and blows it completely out of proportion (I’m talking Kilimanjaro out of an ant hill). The resulting manifestation is a whiny and dejected hopeless romantic who is constantly screaming to the sky, “Why Me?” They express their new aesthetic by writing sad statuses (saduses?) and tweets to make sure everyone knows just how sad they are.

The sadboy aesthetic can be seen rising in popularity mostly due to the efforts of Drake and his 2011 album, Take Care. The album follows Drake’s rise to fame as a heavy-hitter in the rap game and as a global icon. However, he also reveals a dark side to his newfound success: no matter how much money and accolades you receive, without the love of a good and loyal woman your life is meaningless and empty. From then on, people all over indulged in the sadboy lifestyle, taking it beyond the internet and ritualistically exclaiming how hard it is to be alive. We can see the culmination of this aesthetic again in music, with the duo mansionz, a collaboration project between Mike Posner and Blackbear, and their new song called “rich white girlz.” In the song, both individuals explain the trouble with their infatuation for, well, rich white girls. Posner himself says, “I thought that the last tour would help me fill the hole/And then came the income, outcome I’m still alone.” However, at the end of the song, Snoozegod chimes in with, “Bear got like 30 [girls] in line [and] Mike got a couple in line.” While this doesn’t necessarily solve all of their problems, the fact remains that they have chosen one instance in their life, not totally out of their control, to focus on and be sad about.

The trend of being a sadboy has ran its course. What we have on our hands, now, is too many people sulking around and grouping themselves with people who have real issues. Now, I’m not here to shame anyone who has undertaken the lifestyle and devoted their life to the cult of sorrow, but I am here as a disgruntled social media user. Sadboys have ruined my online experience because everybody and their dog is a sadboy. Everytime I go on Facebook or Twitter I’m bombarded with “ooooh I’m sad,” “ooooh why doesn’t anybody like me,” “ooooh I’m gonna die alone” (probably) and it’s honestly just depressing.

However, there is a new elite, a new underground, a new aesthetic. Trends will come and go but nobody wants to show up late to the party. The new party I’m talking about is the positivity posse, aka gladboys. These brave individuals post online about how beautiful life is and how lucky we are to be alive. Just as Drake, Mike Posner and Blackbear are the harbingers of sorrow, Chance the Rapper is the king of positivity, even going so far as to start the #positivitychallenge. As Chance grows in popularity with a few Grammy wins under his belt, we can only hope that social media will be bright once again.

title: Spotlight of the Week // National Treasure
content:
Need a reason to celebrate this midterm season? Get festive every Wednesday morning with National Treasure! The show commemorates bizarre and obscure social media holidays each week, from #GourmetCoffeeDay to #LaughAndGetRichDay. DJ Amy keeps listeners engaged with the theme through fun activities - she even offered to give away a glass of milk in honor of #MilkDay.The celebrations are complemented with a “grab bag” of tunes - listeners are told to “get ready for some mid-2000’s hits scattered in between indie and weirdo music that I find on all corners of the internet.” The highlight of the show so far, according to DJ Amy, has been #DecoratingWithCandyDay, when she and co-host DJ Paleta con Chile featured candy related tracks and swapped uncomfortable Valentine’s Day stories - such as the time DJ Amy was given candy by her “valentine” even after she politely refused him. National Treasure is a little wacky, very fun, and a great excuse for some low-key festivities.

Listen in every Wednesday at 11 a.m. on uclaradio.com. Follow National Treasure on Facebook to find out each week’s holiday and receive other show updates!

title: The Demonstration - Drab Majesty // Album Review
content:
Written By: Julian Zhou

Post Date: 2/9/17

Do you like the 80s? Do you wear a choker? Do you have a Joy Division t-shirt? If so, I recommend you listen to Drab Majesty’s album, The Demonstration. There is a certain formula to Drab Majesty’s song-writing; an attitude towards which will determine if a listener appreciates this band. Expect syncopated, echoey snare hits, surprising chord changes, and chorused guitar arpeggios that demonstrate Drab Majesty’s dogmatic genre devotion to goth pop. This is a plus for me, though it may not be for you. There is no bass guitar — the synths have taken that role. The lyrical themes touch upon cult suicide, astral projection, gender fluidity, the occult, and other edge topics.

The aesthetic of the group can best be described as “ice goth” — which, as far as I can tell, is part goth and part vapor, but not quite witch house. The two band members (Deb Demure and recent addition Mona D) perform as female, but their music aspires to achieve “genderless perfection” [Drab Majesty’s bandcamp, 2017]. Demure and D value theatricality, and use costumes and stage props such as rotating Greek busts, rose petals, shoji walls, and a fog machine, resulting in a very entertaining live show.

Now let’s address some criticisms. A possible criticism of this album, as well as of Drab Majesty’s previous LP, Careless (2015) is that both albums tend to be frontloaded with their most well-written songs. However, I find this criticism to be idiotic because in the computer era, we are not confined to listening to albums in the default order. Furthermore, this criticism presumes that albums should be evaluated as singular, cohesive work — an opinion, which I find to be rockist and regressive. The Demonstration is as much a dance album as it is a concept album, and it can be appreciated as a collection of singles. That being said, it is moodier and less dancey than Careless.

This is my first review and I have decided that instead of providing my own score, I will simply predict Pitchfork’s score when it reviews Drab Majesty. I predict it will give it no less than a 7.1, but no more than a 7.9 for being “derivative.” However, this is the sweet spot if you are looking for music that is good, yet not npr-core.

title: Sit Still, Look Pretty - Daya // Album Review
content:
Written By: Roshni Kumar, UCLA Radio Music 

Post Date: 1/30/17

At just 17 years old, Daya has already produced two hit singles to land a spot in the Billboard Top 40. Following the success of her single “Hide Away” and her featuring on the Chainsmokers banger “Don’t Let Me Down”, the artist released her new album Sit Still, Look Pretty, a work which displays her more mature side. It’s a unique mix between EDM pop and radio-Disney-friendly lyrics. Though it does show some improvements from her previous songs, Daya’s new album - if anything - is simply average.

The album is comprised of 14 tracks that all carry the manifesto of not being like “other girls”, as well as her battle to be desired for something other than her looks. While the album has been certified Platinum by the RIAA, it would seem that the album has not gained much recognition aside from the two singles, “Hide Away” and “Sit Still, Look Pretty”. The production is clean and the tunes are easy to hear, but there is nothing special to it. It could easily serve as just being the background music inside a Starbuck’s coffee.

While Daya’s style does incorporate the influence of Troye Sivan, it only shallowly encompasses that which Sivan is capable of. I am positive that with more time, her music will become more sophisticated and thought out in terms of meaning. Her lyrics carry a lot of weight and I am excited to see what she comes up with in the future. She is a musician on the rise and without a doubt someone to look out for.

The songs “Cool”, “Dare” and “Love of My Life” stand out and display her overall shift to an older, sound. If you are a fan of “Don’t Let Me Down”, then you should for sure check out the last song of her album “We Are.” Her voice really lends well to the song’s dance style of music.

Overall, I would say Daya’s Sit Still, Look Pretty was fairly decent and did carry some potentially good tracks, earning it a rating of 6/10!

title: I See You - The XX // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee, Digital Press

Post Date : 1/18/17

The xx’s Romy Madley Croft on I See You:

“This album was difficult to name. I couldn’t think of an overriding theme. But then I just started thinking about our friendship, and how we’d drifted apart and then come back together again. And how crucial it is feeling seen in any sort of relationship. We hadn’t seen each other, and I needed that.”

The xx is back, and they have returned with a beautiful album. I See You was released January 13, a full five years after their previous album Coexist. Much like Coexist and their eponymous first album, I See You delivers a first person narrative tracing the various stages of a relationship, from its reckless beginning to the reflective aftermath. Additionally, The xx’s writing still refrains from the use of gender pronouns, references to sexuality, or references to specific places or moments in time, establishing the universality of their motifs of loneliness and empathy. But different from prior works, this album feels much less like an ode to romantic love than a broader call for closeness in all forms.

For example, “Say Something Loving” mourns forgetting intimacy, with vocalists Oliver Sim and Madley Croft declaring, “I just don’t remember the thrill of affection…I need a reminder, the feeling’s escaped me.” More than a lament about lacking romantic intimacy, the tone of “Say Something Loving” expresses a failure to connect with others as a frame for confronting the more unsettling loss of self. “Brave For You” also examines the self in relation to closeness with others, only this track centers around the impact a person can leave on another even after separation. Lyrics such as “And when I’m scared/I imagine you’re there/Telling me to be brave,” are written for Madley Croft’s parents, both of whom have passed away. Yet these words strike a chord in any listener learning to live with relationships that are either gone or broken. While the xx’s hauntingly clear vocals and unadorned melodies certainly create a preternatural listening experience, their music unearths one of the most human feelings of all, the search for a connection.

Despite the melancholy lyrical themes that pervade I See You, the dynamic synth beats and samples prevent the songs from becoming depressing or moody beyond redemption. The range of samples is diverse; a Hall & Oates track makes an appearance, as does one by Alessi. Contrast between brisk instrumentals and melancholy vocal content has the potential to produce a muddled or haphazard sound, but instead the two components complement each other well. Perhaps paralleling the condition of understanding oneself through intimacy with others, the interplay between profoundly personal vocal performances, and outside samples forge a sound that resonates and unites.

Favorite tracks of the album: “On Hold” and “Replica”

title: Spotlight of the Week // Music Lovers Anonymous
content:
Today’s music scene is always looking for a unique way to harmonize classic sounds with new music trends, and expand from the confines of one genre to the blend of many. Find some of these one-of-a-kind productions by tuning into Music Lovers Anonymous, UCLA Radio’s Spotlight of the Week. DJ Strati puts a literal spin on time-honored hip-hop, soul, and funk by mixing them with current electronic beats on air. He explains, “I mix live on the show to give listeners a feel for a fluid experience.” The show also works to bring the listening experience to a more intimate level by seeking out and featuring small artists from SoundCloud, to not only bring light to the artists but also to expose listeners to music they can easily access.

Listeners can find more exclusive music at DJ Strati’s SoundCloud, where he curates playlists in his style. Also check out his favorite album of 2016, I Remember by AlunaGeorge - “a beautiful album that was as musically unique as it was socially relevant, and it had many great featured artists.”

Tune into Music Lovers Anonymous at uclaradio.com - we’ll be highlighting previous shows over the winter break!

title: Spotlight of the Week // URBANO
content:
Post Date: 2/28/17

Are you curious about Latin American music, the broader impacts of Latinx culture, and various conversations on cross-cultural issues? Satisfy all these topics in just one hour with our Spotlight of the Week, URBANO! URBANO features Latinx artists in a broad variety of genres such as “Reggaeton, Dembow, Latinx rap, and Musicá Tropical.” DJ Matovermind invites the listener to not only hear the music but understand its position within Latin American music and society as a whole. The show as well expands this conversation to the United States, exploring the intersection of Latinx influence with modern day America. Within all of this, DJ Matovermind features guests to investigate widespread issues and how they relate to the different cultures discussed - the show recently welcomed All of Us: A Campaign to Rethink Mental Health to talk about how culture and mental health interact. As DJ Matovermind says, “cultura, Latinx Identity, and h0t Urban Music is the trifecta of this high energy show that will keep ya dancing and having a good time!”

Like URBANO on Facebook and listen in every Tuesday at 6 pm on uclaradio.com!
tags: ucla radio spotlight of the week

title: Metered in Contact: Reflecting on Planet Giegling // Show Review
content:
Written By: Aaron Peretz
Post Date: 2/22/17

On the second Thursday of February, the Giegling collective held a concert to preface their LA party, one stop on their world tour. Two days later, on the fringe of downtown LA, an undisclosed location housed these laconic immigrants. From late afternoon until early morning on Sunday, the line-up—including ATEQ, DJ Dustin, Edward, Kettenkarussell (Konstantin and Leafar Legov), and Vril—rocked the warehouse with somber sounds of intercepted phonemes against wandering bass lines.

The day long nature of the event invited flux. The sun ebbed and crowds flowed. The reclined indifference of the afternoon sobered up with the onset of nighttime. This very process of building is intrinsic to Giegling’s minimal tech house sound, so that patient listeners are those most rewarded. In fact, “patient” may be incorrect. Having fun has no goal, and patience expects an end. Rather it was those people without agenda that could appreciate immediacy: knowing where you stand without expectation as to where you go. Whether or not the design was an intelligent one, the party’s timeline effectively told partiers to live immediately. Time elapsed to no one’s beat. Without legislated feeling, it was this untamed will to live that I sensed as the unofficial attitude of Giegling noise.

As a (sympathetic) person, I naturally feel bad for anyone unable to participate in this willing. Some loiter in the crowds, invested in all black wear, adhering to the unspoken rules of the game. However, immediacy warps rules, each set preserved in a moment. One individual resembles any other, but need only adhere to her own rules. Still, some ideologically weak immune systems are ruled by impulse to impose their rules on others. Insecure in their identity, they undermine themselves by being the only outdated rules they’re familiar with. This insecurity is never satiated till the world caves to its own stagnancy. Black shirts and subdued voices are not concomitant with fascism, it is merely the fascist bound to myopic principles with glasses fogged by fury that groups them.

Nevertheless, LA feels. Here, we feel the international threat to decency and to the celebration of life. We work to stay true to the outstanding will of dance, its exponents like Giegling, and its desire to contact and appreciate, not to conquer. The party was successful in its ability to inspire my sense of gratitude and make contact with a place far away through a sound near ’n’ dear. Giegling prompted LA to gather around Ausländer, its tour dusting dogma, and the connection of the universal. Los Angeles found herself reinvigorated in a responsibility to stay diverse and let the beat build.

title: SweetSexySavage - Kehlani // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee
Post Date: 2/12/17

Kehlani (to Elle magazine) on her career and life goals:

I want to leave an impact on people rather than just collecting meaningless shit. Steve Jobs was the richest dude in the fucking world and created hella shit and on his deathbed he was still like, ‘I can’t take none of that shit with me.’ You get robbed one day for everything you fucking own and what are you left with? You better hope that you was a good person. Because they can’t take that away from you.

Though SweetSexySavage is Kehlani’s first album produced with a major recording label, it would be a mistake to view the LP as a general “get to know the artist” introduction. Kehlani has previously released two mixtapes, Cloud 19 and You Should Be Here, and because of this SweetSexySavage simply feels like the next chapter in a familiar autobiography. And if you have not been keeping up with that autobiography, you better start now. As she says herself in “Too Much,” Kehlani is “too much of a woman / too much of a bad ass bitch / too much of a boss,” and she is not waiting around for anyone.

Similar to Kanye West’s College Dropout trilogy, Kehlani’s albums chronicle her rise from an ambitious nobody to a powerful, influential player in the music industry.
