SweetSexySavage emerges as the final destination Kehlani has been working for, her arrival into a life that in older mixtapes she had only been dreaming about. And Kehlani’s fiercely unapologetic attitude indicates that now that she has arrived, she intends to stay. Again and again throughout the LP Kehlani makes clear that she is a confident artist who refuses to be belittled or manipulated. This self-assuredness is reinforced with her music’s bubbly and energetic sound. Kehlani’s punchy cheerfulness in songs like “Piece of Mind” or “Too Much” reminds Kehlani’s haters that she does not need them, she is thriving without them, and her absence from their lives is their loss. This giddy independence also translates to Kehlani’s approach to dating, where with the exception of a few smitten ballads like “In My Feelings” and “Hold Me By The Heart,” she insists that if her partner is not going to treat her right, then that is his or her loss because she is “not like other bitches” (“Do U Dirty”). However, Kehlani’s self-assertiveness ought not to be confused with arrogance. The penultimate song of this album, “Thank You,” humbly expresses appreciation for her supporters, and promises Kehlani’s dedication to improving herself and her art.

One of Kehlani’s greatest artistic strengths is her ability to take her diary-entry style of storytelling and distill it into a catchy pop R&B sound without sacrificing any of her genuineness. For example, the song “Not Used To It” reveals Kehlani’s fear of trusting others, wherein she realizes that she has never known a good man, either in her own relationships or when she was growing up in a family full of single mothers. But surprisingly, Kehlani delivers this confession using a fast-paced, happy-sounding melody. “Not Used To it” is a song that could be played in a club, but its smooth, bright sound does not dilute the authenticity of her lyrics. Instead, the song, as well as the rest of SweetSexySavage, is a testament to Kehlani’s versatility as both a chart-topping star and a down to earth girl who does not sugarcoat her vulnerabilities for the sake of producing hits.

Favorite tracks of the album: “Do U Dirty,” “Personal,” and “Keep On”

title: Could California Baseball Teams Face an Unknown Opt-Out Clause? // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: Chase Madorsky

Post Date: 2/5/17

Section 2855 of the California Labor Code could allow MLB players in the State of California to opt-out of their contracts once they have been with their teams for seven years.

On January 4, Fangraphs Baseball’s Nathaniel Grow brought to light a little-known provision that could allow baseball players playing for a team in the state of California to opt-out of their contracts early, and immediately. If you are an Angels, Athletics, Dodgers, Padres, or Giants fan, you might want to pay attention.

Below is an excerpt from Grow’s piece:

A relatively obscure provision under California law — specifically, Section 2855 of the California Labor Code — limits all personal services contracts (i.e., employment contracts) in the state to a maximum length of seven years. In other words, this means that if an individual were to sign an employment contract in California lasting eight or more years, then at the conclusion of the seventh year the employee would be free to choose to either continue to honor the agreement, or else opt out and seek employment elsewhere.

Although the California legislature has previously considered eliminating this protection for certain professional athletes – including Major League Baseball players – no such amendment has passed to date. Consequently, Section 2855 would presumptively apply to any player employed by one of the five major-league teams residing in California.

This provision, although never used and rarely known by both players and their agents, would allow for players who have been under contract for a baseball franchise in the state of California for seven years or longer to immediately terminate their contracts, or activate an immediate opt-out clause. Even if the player has since signed an extension or a new contract that differs from their original one with the team, they are still eligible for the opt-out.

With that said, we will be looking at nine players that play for California baseball franchises, and who are either already eligible for the opt-out, or who will become so this summer. To calculate the players per season value if they were to hit the free agent market, we will be using the following factors:

1. The estimate made by Neil Paine of fivethirtyeight.com that teams were willing to pay $7.7 million per WAR following the 2015 season. (Calculated by averaging together the WAR values of Fangraphs Baseball and baseballreference.com)

2. Players’ 2016 WARs as calculated by baseballreference.com.

3. Players’ 2017 salaries from baseballreference.com, or their estimated salaries from arbitration using the formula of MLBtraderumors.com.

To actually calculate each player’s market value using WAR, we will be taking the $7.7 million teams were willing to pay per WAR following the 2015 season, and multiplying it by the player’s 2016 WAR. After finding each player’s market value based on WAR, we will compare the number to their actual or projected 2017 salaries.

Formula: 2016 WAR x $7.7 million = Market Value Salary

1. Mike Trout

  • Drafted in 2009, can opt-out at any time.
  • 2017 Salary: $20,083,000
  • 2016 WAR: 10.6
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 WAR: $81,620,000, a gain of $61,537,000.

2. Garret Richards  

  • Drafted in 2009, can opt-out at any time.
  • Estimated 2017 Arbitration Salary: $7,000,000
  • 2016 WAR: 0.3
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 WAR: $2,310,000, a loss of $4,590,000 based on his estimated salary.

3. Kole Calhoun

  • Drafted in 2010, can opt-out in July.
  • Estimated 2017 Arbitration Salary: $6,900,0002016 
  • WAR: 3.4
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 WAR: $23,460,000, a gain of $16,560,000 based on his estimated salary.

4. Clayton Kershaw

  • Drafted in 2006, can opt-out at any time.
  • 2017 Salary: $35,571,429
  • 2016 WAR: 5.6
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 WAR: $43,120,000, a gain of $7,548,571.

5. Joc Pederson

  • Drafted in 2010, can opt-out in August.
  • 2017 Estimated Salary: $530,000 (based on his $10,000 raise from 2015-2016; actual salary unknown at this time.)
  • 2016 WAR: 3.4
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 WAR: $26,180,000, a gain of $25,650,000 based on his estimated salary.

6. Madison Bumgarner

  • Drafted in 2007, can opt-out at any time.
  • 2017 Salary: $11,500,000
  • 2016 WAR: 5.0
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 War: $38,500,000, a gain of $27,000,000.

7. Brandon Belt

  • Drafted in 2009, can opt-out in August.
  • 2017 Salary: $8,800,000
  • 2016 WAR: 4.3
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 War: $33,110,000, a gain of $24,310,000.

8. Buster Posey

  • Drafted in 2008, can opt-out at any time.
  • 2017 Salary: $21,400,000
  • 2016 WAR: 4.7
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 War: $36,190,000, a gain of $14,790,000.

9. Brandon Crawford 

  • Drafted in 2008, can opt-out at any time.
  • 2017 Salary: $8,200,000
  • 2016 WAR: 4.5
  • Free Agent Salary Based on 2016 War: $34,650,000, a gain of $26,450,000.

While it is clear that players aren’t paid based on their WAR value, what these calculations show is that if California players were to invoke the opt-out clauses legally available to them, it could cost the Angels, Giants, and Dodgers millions of dollars.

title: Show Review // Los Angeles Philharmonics, Krzysztof Urbański, & Augustin Hadelich @ Walt Disney Concert Hall
content:
Written By: Maria Gasca

Post Date: 1/23/17

The handful of other times I had gone to concerts at the Walt Disney Concert Hall were at night, so I never really paid attention to the surrounding area. Driving to an afternoon show, I noticed how close it is to so many iconic Angeleno art institutions, like the Broad, the MOCA, and the LA Opera.

I pulled up to the shiny metallic architecture. Cutting it close to the start of the show, I rushed to will call, entered the lobby, zoomed up the stairs and entered the inside of the hall.

Every time I enter the hall, it’s such a wow moment. The exterior of the hall is bold and futuristic, while the interior is grand and warm. I sat in my seat and observed the intense wooden beams that stretched out of the organ at the back of the orchestra. Not too much later, the lights dimmed, creating a vignette effect on the orchestra. Krzysztof Urbański, the conductor for the performance, walked to the podium.

Urbański is a young conductor in his early 30s. Within his short career the Polish conductor and composer has conducted all over the globe, from Hamburg and Norway to Indiana and Toronto, and has received countless prestigious awards.

 With a lift of his hands, Beethoven’s Leonore Overture No. 3 began. It was a very majestic piece. The builds and drops of the strings and winds in contrast to the brass created a balanced tension. Urbański had a strong dynamic with the orchestra. His effortless conducting and smiles throughout the piece showed how much fun he was having. Then, there was the trumpet solo!

I love the WDCH for the visual absence of soloists. A couple years ago, when the LA Phil played “Neptune,” from Holst’s The Planets suite, I remember hearing a choir, but not seeing it. Being in the nose bleed seats at the time, I noticed everyone else trying to track down where the voices came from in the giant hall. And as soon as I heard the trumpet, I inspected the crowd and found a similar trend. As the trumpet solo faded in and out and each time it played, I observed a wave of heads turning as they tried to pinpoint the location of the soloist.

 Next, was Mozart’s Violin Concerto No.5. This piece featured German-Italian soloist Augustin Hadelich. In the pre-concert talks, which take place usually an hour before the show (10/10 recommendation), Hadelich and host Thomas Neesan talked about his Juilliard education, recent Grammy, and soloist career that has taken him across the globe at such an early age. Acclaimed as one of the greatest violinists of his generation, his solo in the Violin Concerto No.5 definitely validated his title.

Playing an instrument with sheet music is difficult, but playing a whole Mozart piece from memory while standing in front of an enormous audience is harder. Nevertheless, Hadelich delicately and deliberately felt and played each note in the concerto. From the application of the precise pressure on his bow to the reaction of the music shown through his facial and body movements, Hadelich enchanted the audience with his performance. The chemistry between Urbański and Hadelich was also amazing. It was like twin telepathy with their subtle eye contact, not only for cues, but for encouragement that was so organic and caring. At the conclusion of his performance, Hadelich received a long standing ovation which was followed by an encore solo, which also got another standing ovation.

 After intermission, the brass and wind reconvened for the last piece, Brahms’s Symphony No.2.  Symphony No.2 was a gentler piece in comparison to Beethoven, but was equally as captivating. The song seemed like the making of an intricate silk coat. The layering and receding of each instrument was interlocking. Urbański weaved the orchestra together through his gentle conducting in the pastoral moments, as well as his animated conducting in the sporadic builds. At the conclusion of Symphony No.2, the concert concluded with rounds of applause for all the performers.

An afternoon of Mozart and Brahms with the LA Philharmonic, Urbański, and Hadelich was spectacular. From the gracious music conducted and played to the rituals of the orchestra performance, the LA Philharmonic’s performance at the WDCH is probably the most essential experience for an appreciator of the arts.

title: Spotlight of the Week // UCLA Radio 1
content:
There’s one friend everyone has who is always sharing the best new music they’ve found. Have you always wanted to be able to one up them? Learn from the master himself, DJ Maxatrillion, on UCLA Radio 1. DJ Maxatrillion combines his love for the latest indie and electronica music from the UK with an intimate, friendly atmosphere. The show invites you to step in the booth for the hour and discover new music together. And it’s not just you two - DJ Maxatrillion uses UCLA Radio 1 as well to feature a number of diverse guests he brings onto the show, saying, “I have on range from anywhere from close friends to someone I just met while out getting drinks the night before.”

Follow UCLA Radio 1 on Facebook, and tune in to hear the show every Wednesday at 7 p.m. Unsure if this is the show for you? Make sure to listen to DJ Maxatrillion’s favorite album of 2016, The Life of Pablo by Kanye West.

title: Show Review // Jay Som @ The Echo (12/3/16)
content:
Written By: Amy Cummings, UCLA Radio Intern

Post Date: 12/11/16

Jay Som played to a small but appreciative crowd of fans at their Los Angeles Turn Into physical release party at the Echo. The band and their fans came together in the intimate setting of the Echo for an early show to celebrate, creating a friendly atmosphere as if we were all friends out to support each other at a house show.

While waiting for Jay Som’s set I befriended Neil, who was working the merch table, and he showed us the full array of physical albums. The physical release of Turn Into was confirmed as something to celebrate as I eyed the pressings on gorgeous white and green marbled vinyl, pink cassette tapes, and CDs. Neil offered to throw in a copy of the album if I bought the ‘$3,000 Bratz mixtape’ that was inexplicably also displayed. Like many artists who play the Echo, Melina Duterte and the rest of the band hung out in the audience to watch supporting acts Plush and Los Angeles Police Department before taking the stage to set up their own equipment. Duterte, the multi-talented face of Jay Som, plugged in cords as a fan asked her, “What’s your sign?” The drummer handed out minty chewing gum to fans at the front of the stage and shortly afterward, they started with the title track.

Considering the purpose of the evening was conceivably to promote the Turn Into physical release, the band focused on appreciating their fans and just having fun with their music, despite a solemn nod to the tragic events of the previous night’s warehouse fire in Oakland that deeply affected the artist community where Jay Som is based. Though already well-known on Oakland’s music scene, Jay Som’s popularity is growing, boosted by their national tour this year opening for Japanese Breakfast and Mitski. The tour also visited the Echoplex in July, surely resulting in a crop of new fans from around Los Angeles. But the band certainly doesn’t feel like an opener. Jay Som appears on stage as a drummer and three guitars, with vocals provided by Duterte. They are confident performers, with a rock sound but a relaxed attitude that makes Turn Into a solid listen, and no doubt helped them amass the dedicated fans that turned out to watch them headline for their release party.

Jay Som jammed through most of the songs on Turn Into, including a playful extended ending of “Next to Me,” that Duterte said she had agreed to do after losing a bet. The live performance didn’t disappoint, and the band and audience alike seemed to be having a great time. To finish, Jay Som brought up the Plush to sing on an excellent cover of “Maps,” by the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, and then invited up the audience for an impassioned rendition of Weezer’s “Undone - The Sweater Song.” A few enthusiastic audience members climbed onto the stage to provide all the in-song banter and rocked out to the lyrics with Duterte. For their musical professionalism, it’s obvious that Jay Som knows how to have fun.

After the set ended, I snagged the set list “for my notes,” bought a pink tape, and borrowed a Sharpie from my new friend Neil. Duterte was hanging out chatting with fans and graciously signed merch for a few of us. I told her I really connected with what she had said about riding the bus during her show with Mitski. Later, we caught up with a couple other students riding the 2 back to UCLA and discussed how much we all liked the show (and commiserated about the bus.) Jay Som has a bright future ahead and I’ll be looking forward to the next LA appearance.

Check out Turn Into here.

title: February Show of the Month // Senile Soirée
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee

Post Date: 2/27/17

Talk about the inception of the idea for your show. Did it occur to you suddenly in a moment of brilliance, or was this a gradual labor of love?

Doris: The initial idea was to have a show that was grandma themed. We went in the first episode and decided we would have a segment analyzing some song lyrics of a new rap song, but once we were in the booth, that part just really took off. There was just too much good music for us not to continue.

Mildred: When discussing what we wanted to do for our show, Doris and I both identified deeply as old souls and at times felt like two grandmothers living in a young person’s world. Senile Soiree began as an exploration of elderly lifestyle but thanks to D.R.A.M. and Lil Yachty, it evolved into an exploration of rap lyrics through an elderly perspective and we haven’t looked back since.

What is the developmental process behind putting together such a creative show with two hosts? Is it mostly improv or are decisions made together in advance? What makes the two of you such a fabulous duo?

Doris: For the most part it’s improv. We will come in with a theme or maybe some songs we heard and were really interested in analyzing, but the analysis and banter is off the cuff. Mildred came on my show last spring, and we had so much fun that we just had to make it more of a thing. We have good on air chemistry which is what makes Senile Soirée so easy and so much fun. We are able to get in the booth and just talk, and hash things out in a really organic way.

Mildred: Yeah, aside from the songs that we decide to play on air each week, the show is mostly improv. Sometimes we might pick a theme for the show and make some talking points off of that, or if we are doing an activity like knitting or drinking prune juice, we’ll plan that out first. After having so much fun as a guest on Doris’s show last year we decided to do a show together this year. Plus, Doris and I are good pals off air so I think that really helps us have such great chemistry on air.

Your show centers around old people confronted with music in the modern world. What music being made today do you think will be hailed as “classic oldies” when our generation is old?

Doris: Hmmmm. I think some of the classic oldies will be Drake, Yeezy, Kendrick, and Chance. Maybe Thugger too. But that is a scary thought. I wonder what they will all look like at 85…

Mildred: Honestly, the first person that always comes to mind for me is Beyonce. I also agree with Doris about Kanye and Kendrick for sure.

Similarly, what current music do you hope will be buried in the past forever?

Doris: I don’t know if there is anything I really hope will be buried. A lot of what our show goes into is how our culture and the music we listen to reflect on each other, so I think all music has a story that is important to someone. That being said, I don’t need to hear Katy Perry ever again.

Mildred:  I don’t think anyone wants Nickelback to come back. Ever.

What is one thing people need to know about you and your show?

Doris: We play bingo every show! Listeners can tune in and get more numbers and the winner at the end of the quarter gets to go with us to our favorite Californian-Italian restaurant, Earth Wind & Flour. Also, it’s knit.

Mildred: We love getting callers and/or being messaged on the website while on air! Tune in and call us and talk about rap and the best types of prune juice with us.
tags: ucla radio show of the month

title: Retrospective: What is Happening in Flint? // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Malik D. Flournoy-Hooker  

Post Date: 2/15/17

Imagine coming home from a long, strenuous day. The first thing you want to do is take a hot shower, maybe cook a meal, or have a cup of tea. As you turn on your water, you realize that something is not right. The water is cloudy, polluted, and extremely ominous. This was the reality of the citizens of Flint, Michigan.

On August 14, 2014, Flint received notice that fecal coliform bacteria has been detected within their water supply—an infestation that has been recorded in previous years before this huge breakout. 

Less than a month later, on September 5, another advisory was announced about the discovery of possibly more toxic bacteria living within the water supply. Citizens of Flint began reporting hair and weight loss, and rashes. 

Although steps have been taken in response to this, it still remains an issue years later. To give you a bit of perspective, reports of bacteria being detected within the water supply began in 2001. The “Flint Water Crisis” officially began in 2014. 16 years of strife, compiled with three years of it actually being reported, has done seemingly nothing but bring awareness to the matter. 

There have been several fundraisers created in response to the crisis, which have done well in bringing fresh water to the citizens and visibility to the issue. However, due to a strong preference of policy over people by the current government in Flint, there doesn’t seem to be a sense of urgency to get the problem resolved.

Flint is predominantly African-American and disadvantaged. According the U.S. Census Bureau, most households in Flint make an income around $24,000. There are some people who chose to make the assumption that race and class played a large role in this development. The government could have possibly not seen it as an urgent need to ensure Flint’s drinking water was healthy because its citizens were of a lower class. 

Reports show that Darnell Earley was the one responsible for switching the water system in Flint from Detroit back to the polluted river. Earley was the former Flint Emergency Manager and also one of the four people who were charged for the crisis. The other three people were Gerald Ambrose, the former emergency manager, and city officials Daugherty Johnson and Howard Croft. 

The court argued that the four had adequate knowledge of the contamination and still chose to conduct the Flint Water Treatment Plant—an option they knew would not be safe. The defendants were said to have borrowed money to construct a new pipeline, while switching Flint’s water supply to the Flint River during the process. All four were charged with conspiracy and false pretenses. Ambrose and Earley were also charged with willful neglect of duty and misconduct—these charges combined carry up to 20 years in a federal prison. Verdicts are still being determined as of now, but there is still something we all can do in the meantime and continue doing until this is resolved.

Below are some links that will take you to the official page for the crisis and another link to direct you to ongoing efforts to distribute more clean water to Flint’s residents.

Find out more information:

https://www.gofundme.com/flint-water-crisis/

http://www.helpforflint.com/

title: Show Review // Ty Segall @ the Teragram Ballroom (2/2/17)
content:
Written By: Megan Hullander 

Photo Credits: Megan Hullander 

The crowd was significantly older than I had expected. Fortunately, rage does not die with age. Ty Segall’s second self-titled album is raw and concise. In self-titling an album for a second time, I was led to compare this album to his first self-titled release from 2008. While his sound has noticeably matured, he has held onto his characteristically youthful energy. This energy bled into the crowd, resulting in the entirety of my middle-aged companions moshing. Glued to the side of the stage, I was torn. A part of me knew desperately clinging to my camera in effort to keep it from being thrown to the ground or drenched in the storm of beer flying from the crowd’s overfilled cups was the smart decision, but the crowd drew me in. Lost in the vitality of the set, there was a strange harmony within the collisions of the crowd. I decided to compromise. After exchanging a knowing look with the guitarist, I placed my camera on the stage, safely tucked beside the speaker, and let myself temporarily neglect my responsibilities of observing and documenting and fully experience the moment.

I returned to my spot, now slightly bruised, directly in front of the speaker. Ty exchanged loving looks of affection with his bandmates during particularly rambunctious parts of the songs. Though for the majority of the set, I could not hear Ty’s vocals due to my proximity to the excessive, yet appropriate, volume on the speakers, the songs matched his distinctive sound. When the opening chords of “Break a Guitar,” the opening track on his latest album, were played, the crowd immediately erupted in the excitement that precedes a classic, despite the album having been released only days before.

A mature rendition of his jazzy fuzz punk sound, Ty Segall delivered an unprecedented performance that Thursday night at the Teragram Ballroom. I left with my ears ringing, but my only regret was not purchasing tickets for the following nights, so I could relive the experience.

title: Show Review // Shy Girls @ Teragram Ballroom (1/28/17)
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp

Post Date: 2/3/17

Dan Vidmar wastes no time setting the tone for 2017. In a phone interview with Vidmar, otherwise known as the solo artist of ‘Shy Girls,’ he explains the concept behind his latest album Salt, and talks about his upcoming tour. Vidmar is unabatingly proud of this album, in which he played all of the instruments excluding the strings. As he bounces back and forth from his favorite town Portland and LA, he finds himself caught in the grind of two distinct cultures. “Portland is home for me. I’ve been in LA the past few months and have been working on this album for a little more than a year.. I’m just happy to be able to make a living off of this,” he says.

There are some dark moments in the album, and he was able to translate the darkness onto the stage at the Teragram Ballroom on January 28. Tiffany Gouche open the show, and as the crowd immerses themselves in the intimate room Fangirls anxiously sip their beers and set their cocktails on the stage. There was enough room to wiggle around to the front, and if you weren’t with any guys, you could gingerly find a way to maneuver through the blue and purple lit room.

Roadies scold the pretty girls for leaving their drinks so close to the mic on stage. A brunette with overfilled lips cringes in between sips of gin. “I’ve never heard of this guy. I’m trying to explore my vocal range…some of my agents keep it real. I just need to define my style, ya know? That’s why I don’t wear leather anymore,” she comments. The girls in the audience are grown up embodiments of the Aaron Carter fangirl era and dismiss theater etiquette for the sake of Vidmar’s approval. But he would never approve.

Vidmar speaks assertively over the phone. He’s well-spoken and clearly knows what he stands for. “I think as an artist I’m not very good at politicizing my sounds and music. Some people are extremely good at infusing that in their music…I think that’s really important,” he says. “ I think that the art that I make is more. Sometimes there isn’t a place for politics in music at all.”

On stage, he acknowledges the new immigration ban that was signed as an executive order earlier that day. After the first song, “Trivial Motion,” he pauses. Silence fills the ballroom as dedicated fans melt into the floorboards. Sexuality and longing oozes from Vidmar’s vocal range, and within the first song, is able to captivate the audience by conceptualizing the image of intimacy. “It’s a sad day for a lot of us…and I hope for the next hour I can distract you from what’s happening. That’s what I’m here for,” he says. He transitions into the next few songs off his new album seamlessly, playing “Watercolor Dreams,” “You Like the Pain Too,” and “Say You Will.”

“Everything that I write about is real…maybe I’m not a good enough storyteller,” Vidmar says as he discusses the romance behind each song. Midway through the set, he plays older music, including “Renegade,” “Under Attack,” and “Xhampagne.” Vidmar’s shyness is apparent. He doesn’t make eye contact and refuses to move around on stage. And yet, the crowd gets more restless. They need more. Cue the saxophone. On stage, a band plays the variety of instruments, and Vidmar pays ode to the saxophone player by standing to the side of the stage and allowing the spotlight to literally shine on him through his moments of glory.

“It’s funny, I didn’t know how far this would take me, until I wrote this next song… I sent it to my friends and I’ve been making music ever since,” he says. He makes the second to last song of the set his most popular, “Second Heartbeat.”

On the phone, Vidmar is optimistic about future romance and his thriving career. “My Tinder game isn’t on point… but my Bumble game is,” He says with a chuckle. Stay tuned to see Shy Girls in LA more these days at his favorite bar, West Bound, and remember to swipe right on Bumble, ladies.

title: Spotlight of the Week // Black Twitter
content:
Post Date: 1/21/17

In the modern world of rapidly shifting internet sensations and (to put it lightly) complicated politics, many people are looking to stay current with both news and entertainment. Search no more - the quest is over with the spotlight of the week, Black Twitter. With a combination of music, news, and culture, Black Twitter keeps listeners up to date on a variety of social issues and trends. DJ Rohnie Williams cites memes and the internet communities formed around Black Twitter as inspiration for the show of the same name. He names his focus as “pop culture news as well as black interest pieces.” Williams breaks down these issues with the musical guests he features each week. Black Twitter has hosted artists such as AmirSaysNothing and JAHKOY, who was recently chosen as one of Complex’s “Artists to Watch in 2017.”

Check out Black Twitter on Facebook and (of course) Twitter. Tune in to the show every Monday at 3 p.m.

title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 22 with AlunaGeorge
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp 

Post Date: 12/18/16

The Belasco Theaters’ high ceilings echoed the voices of sleepy energy on a Tuesday night. Disoriented and confused, the crowd stared eagerly ahead, and as the clock struck ten, it was apparent: the headliner would have to be fashionably late. AlunaGeorge doesn’t use a rulebook and breaks down the fourth wall of audience-connection. Aluna’s subtle eye contact and hand gestures tell a story that are only told within the confines of a best kept secret. Using her body as a work of art, Aluna’s willowy figure took to the stage to reconcile our disconnect with R&B. She makes the distorted image of a strong black woman a narrative to be proud of, and within minutes, her magnetic claim to the stage steered the ship in her favor: she was in control.

Starting the set with the 2013 classic, “Your Drums, Your Love,” Aluna made use of all sides of the stage and embraced the mic as if it were a lover. Throughout the song, she made dynamic facial expressions and connected to the lyrics, using grandiose theatrics and hip-shakes to exude sexuality.

“When I’m in control, things go really fucking well.” She paused as the first song ended. “And I mean, really well,” she explained, as she wrinkled her face and grabbed her crotch. The beat to “I’m in Control” started, and in that moment, the audience came to a heightened memory of sexual experience. This was a wet dream come to life. This is what memories are made of.

Aluna’s ability to own her sexuality while still maintaining a tasteful sense of style and dignity is unbeknownst to traditional R&B. Her uncompromising demeanor is remnant of the flapper era of the 1920s in allowing women to be frank about what they like in the bedroom. In a world where R&B style has integrated with other dimensions of EDM, Aluna’s blend of traditional sound with unconventional wisdom has created a new realm of understanding.

Aluna paused to acknowledge what weird world we are living in. “This election….” she said, trailing off with a shy smile and shook her head. “We’re here to have fun.” Her British accent legitimized her agenda and she jumped into newer songs.  Transitioning back and forth from old to new, the set list was unpredictable and upbeat. Including songs “Diver,” and her own rendition of “White Noise” by Disclosure, her vocal range revealed that not only she can mesh with a variety of sounds, but also demand attention in its acoustic moments.

Midway through the set, Aluna re-emerges, wearing a bright red kimono and accompanied by a live horn-band, consisting of trumpet and trombone players. Languishing control for these moments, the artist took to left stage and allowed the live music to lead the song, “Full Swing,” from the newest album, I Remember. As Aluna’s voice faded to the background, the trumpet’s sound became the loudest in the room. The audience paused. People stopped dancing. Boyfriends stole sips from their girlfriend’s drinks over their shoulders. The attraction was no longer anticipating what would happen next, but instead, the sense of nostalgia that came from remembering that live bands are what gave R&B life. Time stood still as we watched Aluna become so powerless, and yet so demanding as she gave the traditional horn sound a chance to reemerge as a defining piece of art.

As the last note to the trumpet cued and the spotlights shifted, rapper Pell took to the stage with a surprise performance of his part on “Full Swing,” and with high energy, he and Aluna got the crowd on their feet again. Aluna asked how the crowd how they’re doing, and to  a response of loud cheers, she finished the night with the radio favorite, “You Know You like it.” Teasing us with the last note of sensual superiority, the crowd left thinking, “We definitely do.”

title: Album Review // Bop City - Terror Jr.
content:
Written By: Roshni Kumar, UCLA Radio Music Intern

Post Date: 12/11/16

Terror Jr. remains a mystery to society today. The group first made headlines when Kylie Jenner released her commercial for her new line of lip glosses using their song “3 Strikes,” which until today remains their biggest hit. Very little information is known about the band itself except that the group is comprised of the Campa, Felix Snow, and the lead singer Lisa.

The group released their first album on October 22 and it’s deliriously delectable. With auto-tuned vocals that fill every song, Bop City is filled of bright, upset tracks about lust, restlessness, disillusion, and debauchery, with a slight taste of hope. It’s the kind of songs you would want to listen to after you’re slightly buzzed or after a long day of school, with its smooth, slippery tunes. Bop City is easy to understand and the perfect soundtrack to listen to when driving.

Though my personal favorites are “Come First,” “Sugar,” and “3 Strikes,” the remaining five songs keep you hooked and wanting to hit the play button on repeat.

A lot of their appeal is from the mystery of who exactly they are, but their album will seriously make this group huge. I would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in music that mixes indie electronica with R&B. and has the same vibes as Kiiara. It’s a solid 8/10 on my scale!

title: Pod Rec: UCB Comedy Directing
content:
UCLA Radio Pod Recs is back! Check this space for all of your pod rec (also known as a podcast recommendation) needs!

In this podcast, Upright Citizens Brigade creative director Todd Bieber holds a panel discussion with fellow directors in the comedy field. Bieber welcomes three renowned directors: Eric Appel (The Office/Brooklyn Nine-Nine), Maggie Carey (The To Do List/Silicon Valley), and Mitch Magee (Funny or Die/IFC). Listen to hear each of the panel members sharing their success stories that ultimately lead to a career in comedy. In the podcast, you’ll hear advice such as establishing a strong connection with one’s staff/actors and placing an emphasis on pre-production.

Listen here: http://ucbcomedy.com/media/7672

title: Show Review - Of Montreal @ the Regent (3/22/15)
content:
It’s not every day that you get to see the most bizarre, playful, and wildly entertaining show put on by a fantastic psychedelic mogul that in this case is Kevin Barnes. I got to the Regent Theatre with my best friend, having only known that he’s adored the band’s discography longer than I have.  However, the two of us kept from googling their live shows for the sake of surprise. This shit was a hell of a treat, I gotta say.

The show started off with an intro by Lanc, a character who introduced the band to the stage and told the audience that for the hour that the band was to play, we were to go on some psychedelic journey and be guided by Lucifer along the way. I’ve never been to a show with as much effort put into theatricality as I have with this one, and Lanc’s Intro helped me to start the night with the mindset that although I have no idea what’s in store, whatever happens will just continue to surprise and impress.

Barnes & Co. played through selected songs from the band’s discography pretty quickly and the audience had no problem with hearing a ton of new and old songs whatsoever. The band focused on a good amount of new material off of their latest release Aureate Gloom including songs like “Bassem Sabry” and “Virgilian Lots”, but played a great amount of fan favorites from popular albums such as The Sunlandic Twins and Hissing Fauna… like “Suffer for Fashion” and “Gronlandic Edit”.

Dancers in masks and wigs came on stage pretty frequently, bringing on huge circular screens to display different visuals in addition to the colorful projections shown on the backdrop. This made way for some of the most bizarre, but truly wild and times very humorous to the audience such as seeing ol’ Abraham Lincoln dance around with two dogs (who were dressed in a very patriotic one-piece with large breasts that fight each other before stripping off their clothes. YEAH, THAT HAPPENED.)

What seemed like the most nostalgic for all audience members alike was watching their reactions to the start of “The Party’s Crashing Us”, which was right before the encore. The dancing almost never stopped throughout this whole show. It was a literal party for everyone and Kevin Barnes and the rest of the band made sure everyone’s asses were shaking. Unfortunately, after the band played a gracious amount of extra songs for the encore, they closed off with “The Past Is A Grotesque Animal” (which is a great fit for such a closer as their new live movie of the same name just released last year). Kudos to Mr. Barnes. Over a decade’s worth of playing around with the live show environment for Of Montreal really turned into a unique and unforgettable time at the Regent. Much love for the laughs, nostalgia, and very impressive live Of Montreal experience.

Photos & Words: Eddie Hernandez

title: Show Preview: JRF (4/25/15) @ UCLA’s Tennis Center
content:
UCLA’s JazzReggae Festival will return for its 29th annual showcase of music, arts, and world foods on April 25th. While art and cuisine are an intrinsic part of the JazzReggae experience, the featured musical guests continue to be the selling point for fans.  This weekend, Festivalgoers can expect a fairly eclectic lineup that’ll top off with a headlining performance by D.C. rapper, Wale.  Besides the emcee himself, the festival will feature a number of other notable acts such as the psychedelic rock outfit Portugal. The Man, up-and-coming producer Lido, and Jamaica-native Keznamdi—An act that’ll remain true to the festival’s original jazz and reggae sensibilities.  

That said, it’s worth noting that JazzReggae has come a long way since it’s low-profile beginnings.  In 1986, the festival emerged as a platform for student musicians to perform for the general public.  As it garnered increasing amounts of interest and popularity over the years, the event experienced a dramatic shift away from being an event featuring student performers exclusively, and gravitated towards booking professional, mainstream acts.  Some of the more noteworthy past appearances include: Snoop Dogg, Erykah Badu, Shaggy, Little Dragon, and De La Soul.  Despite the big names that have driven the popularity of this festival for the past several years, JazzReggae prides itself on remaining an entirely student-produced event. 

After almost three decades since its humble inception, this festival has been anything but stagnant.  In its 29th year, JazzReggae Fest builds on a longstanding tradition by implementing new genres and targeting new demographics in hopes that it will serve as an ample reflection of the rich and evolving culture of Los Angeles. This year, the festival will be held over the course of one day instead of two, and will take place in the Los Angeles Tennis Center.  For even more information and tickets, check out the official website at jazzreggaefest.com.

- Doug Gil

title: Show Review: The Music of David Lynch @ the Ace Theatre (4/1/15)
content:
The David Lynch Foundation celebrated its 10th anniversary with an all-star lineup at the dazzling Ace Theatre in downtown. The sold-out show produced a massive convention as both fans and notable guests gathered to pay tribute to Lynch’s thrilling works and music on behalf of raising funds for Transcendental Meditation awareness. The concert began with a brief introduction about the charity organization then leading into the electrifying and dark world of Lynch’s music with composer Angelo Badalamenti as the first performer. The audience became immediately paralyzed as they heard the mesmerizing score “Laura Palmer’s Theme” from the mystery drama Twin Peaks. Badalamenti produced an ambience of nostalgia as fans revisited significant scenes from the television series.

The program was then followed by pioneer rock musician Donovan who created a mellow mood as he sang “Love Me Tender” from the film “Wild at Heart”. Lynch’s muse, Chrysta Bell, then entered the stage with a sparkling dress and cape that captivated the public as she enthralled them with her radiance appearance and sensuality. The lighting on stage turned completely bright, blinding the audience in the balcony area who repeatedly blinked. This was certainly an artistic move since the song “Swing With Me” is found on the Lynch-produced album “This Train”, hence, the strong lighting. Her performance was however delightful and full of charm as she bid farewell with a blowing kiss.

Other powerful performances were from indie pop rockers Tennis and Twin Peaks. They collaborated to perform Roy Orbison’s “In Dreams” from the film Blue Velvet. Alaina Moore and her husband Patrick Riley began their set standing very close to each other to establish a romantic setting. Her voice lined up with the theme of dreams, creating a surreal experience drawn from her talent. The public sang along as they revisited the memorable scene where Dennis Hopper cries and abruptly stops the song to due to its overpowering effects.

Performers like Moby transformed the venue into a dance club by presenting a musical piece with the accompaniment of bongos and soulful backup singers. This was an unseen side of Moby but fun to see how he created a funky pattern of beats without the use of a turntable. Karen O of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs also performed an upbeat song, “Pinky’s Dream”, from Lynch’s project “Candy-Colored Clown.” Duran Duran stole the night as they played their 80s classics “Ordinary World” and “Hungry Like The Wolf” making fans get up from their chairs and dance endlessly. Other artists such as Lykke Li, Zola Jesus and Flaming Lips members Wayne Coyne and Steve Drozd, recaptured the concert’s original atmosphere as they performed enigmatic songs that demanded close attention and silence. Jim James from My Morning Jacket performed “Sycamore Trees” dressed up in a black tie and suit, accompanied by a saxophone player who prolonged the mysterious aura of Lynch’s films.

Acapella singer Rebekah Del Rio completely haunted the theatre with her dynamic vocal strings as she sang “Llorando” from the film Mulholland Drive. Her performance received the only standing ovation of the night after David Lynch himself appeared on stage to conclude the concert with an inspiring message of meditation: “May everyone be free of disease. May auspiciousness be singing everywhere. May suffering belong to no one.

Photos & Words: Michelle Preciado

title: Opinions by Eric:The "Life Story" Albums of Eminem and Kendrick Lamar
content:
Eminem, as a rapper, has had high and low points of famousness and appreciation as an artist throughout his career. Starting from humble roots, Eminem first found popularity with his albums The Slim Shady LP in 1999, and The Eminem Show in 2002. Although he has continued to create albums to this very day, people have lost a lot of respect for his musical talent. One main reason that his perceived value as an artist has decreased is what I would call “loss of talent by association”. Whereas on his older albums, Eminem world consistently rap with the talented likes of Dr. Dre, Obie Trice, and Nate Dogg, many people now view Eminem as Rihanna’s “associated act” on tracks like Love the Way You Lie. The analysis that I want to explore with this piece is not about his perceived downfall, however. Instead, I want to look at Eminem around his peak, with Encore in 2005, and draw some strong comparisons to Kendrick Lamar’s highly acclaimed album good kid, m.A.A.D. city.

Both of these albums are mirrors of the respective artists’ life stories. For Kendrick Lamar, he tells his story as a teenager in Compton, and specific scenarios and feelings that made him into the person that created the album that he produced. The songs in the album have many varying topics form his lifetime- “Sherane” describes a women from his teenage years that he was interested in, “Money Trees” describes the arrival of fame into his lifestyle (and its effects), and “Swimming Pools” describes the highly prevalent alcoholism that surrounded his upbringing. As a whole, it is easy to see that all of these aspects are formative to the growth of Kendrick Lamar, and it is almost as if he wants to explain why he is the way he is through his art.

We see a lot of the same intention and expression in Eminem’s Encore.  In “Cleaning Out My Closet”, Eminem shares his childhood issues, and why he believes his mother was never fit to raise children; in “The Real Slim Shady”, he takes a mirror to his own life, and attempts to avoid the disingenuous façade he believes many artists have; and in “Mockingbird”, he talks about what he would do for his daughters sake.

Although the scenarios described in both of these works are clearly different, what remains the same is the overall intention of the work. Both artists are giving a mirror to reflect their life, and showing exactly what has lead them to this point in their career. One stark contrast that we do see is the intent with which the artists go about it. Whereas Kendrick’s album seems like a mere retelling, Eminem’s album seems an almost apologetic excuse for all of the things he’s done in his life. This tonal difference gives the artists music very different feels for this album.

Even though Eminem would later not receive the same acclaim for his rap albums, it is important to look to Eminem’s earlier works such as Encore in order to see not only his musical roots, but why he achieved fame in the first place. Encore’s similarities to good kid, m.A.A.D city help us to remind the context of both of these artists during their prime eras, and why both of them are so famous in unique ways in the world of rap.

By: Eric A.

title: Show Review: Shura @ The Echo (3/14/15)
content:
From the second I heard the opening kicks and claps of “Touch,” her single released last year, I knew that Shura was a name that I would hear over and over again in the near future. With her signature hushed vocals, throwback 80’s electro pop and 90’s R&B production, and tender, heartfelt lyrics, Shura has built a thunderous buzz around her with songs expertly crafted around the intimate murmur. She combines the best parts of Sade and Madonna, while keenly keeping an ear to hotly-tipped producers like Blood Orange and Jungle (who recently released a gloriously funky remix of her track, “Indecision"). The blend is mesmerizing, and there’s no doubt in my mind that Shura will make it big.

Her set at The Echo entirely confirmed this. Shura grooved through her set with ease and confidence. Her stage presence was magnetic, which is thoroughly impressive for such a new artist. She had the crowd in the palm of her hand; shouts of “We love you Shura” were recurrent throughout her time onstage. The venue was perfect, too: small enough to create an intimate atmosphere, but large enough to handle bass-heavy electronic instrumentation that could easily translate in a stadium festival setting. She used the intimacy to her advantage and showcased two beautiful new tracks, both skeletal R&B slow jams in the vein of The xx. Her knack for rehashing potentially tacky 80s pop tropes with grace and virtuosity shined through on her rendition of Fine Young Cannibals’ “She Drives Me Crazy.” It’s a bold move to rework a song that cheesy, but Shura managed t transform it into a pillow-soft, heartbreaking declaration of addicting, but troublesome, love.

If there was one critique to be made, however, it would be about the length of her set. It was rather short, maybe no longer than twenty minutes, and I can’t help but feel a bit unfulfilled. Once she has a few more songs to her name, I’m sure she’ll be able to put up an incredible set of pop perfection.
With a show this impressive, this early on in her career, it’s easy to forget she’s still a newbie. Perhaps the only true indicator of this was when she fumbled the lyrics to her new single, “2Shy.” But Shura handled that like a veteran, too, charmingly laughing it off and continuing on with the song. Shura’s live performance was an all-around success, and it’s clear that she is destined for bigger and better things in the upcoming year.

Photos & Words: Gabriel Brenner

title: Show Review - Check Your Ponytail (Lee Bannon, Ratking, and Trash Talk) @ the Echoplex (3/20/15)
content:
Check Yo Ponytail’s first event of 2015 proved a fitting finale for Trash Talk’s powerhouse tour with supporting acts Ratking and Lee Bannon. The groups converged with Together Pangea at the Echoplex on March 20th for a spectacle of hardcore across many genres. The tour’s diverse lineup, along with the fact that it ended in Los Angeles, gave CYP an opportunity to add to their catalogue of shows1. Together Pangea was included in the bill last minute– a sort of bonus from CYP, to solidify the event and distinguish it from the tour’s other stops. Though an interesting addition, Together Pangea’s Burgerama-ish, pop-punk sound felt out of place, and paled in comparison with the tour veterans. Given the remarkable chemistry between Lee Bannon/Ratking/Trash Talk’s sets, it is likely that many artists would have similarly stood as outliers.

^ Lee Bannon

The double bind of Lee Bannon’s opening set: it was very danceable, but so entrancing that the audience was left relatively static, admiring the soundscape and bobbing quietly.2 This quality made L.B. the ideal opener for later, more crowd-involved sets. The complex and refined nature of his glitch/IDM-inspired drum and bass acted as a starting point for the night’s musical degeneration (and I mean degeneration in the best possible punk-show way). L.B.’s industrial/electronic textures were rigid enough to distinguish his set from following act Ratking, but underlying hip-hop influences3 made for a smooth segue between artists.  

^ Lee Bannon

^ Wiki.

I found that this CYP event was like a geode in the sense that it had a gem in the middle– Ratking. Rappers Wiki and Hak, along with producer (and occasional rapper) Sporting Life form the hip-hop trio4 that, over the past few years, has risen from the NYC underground to become a staple act in modern and experimental hip-hop. Their set at CYP was a fluid tour-de-force that, in my opinion, highlighted Ratking’s signature qualities. Live, Wiki spits with vigor, his flow as tight and complex as on record. The same goes for Hak, who jumps deftly between melodic croon and gritty rap, never abandoning his signature poetic voice. Sporting Life’s live translation of beats expands his role as a hip-hop DJ into an architect-like coordinator– rather than just spin tracks, he builds them. With one hand on a drumstick for drum pad accents and the other on knobs and cues, Sport’s duties are spread out and far from passive.

^ Hak and Sport control the stage while Wiki crowdsurfs.

Ratking’s setlist drew from all major releases so far, hitting both old songs and new cuts from their most recent mixtape700 Fill (which they dropped for free via BitTorrent in March). It was encapsulated by So It Goes classics– they opened with “Snow Beach” and closed with anthem “Canal.” I was excited to hear how well material from 700 Fill was adapted to the live set– songs like “Steep Tech” and “Makeitwork” are veritable bangers. As an added bonus, the group played an unreleased track– keep your ears open, because new Ratking may be on the way.

Though the set didn’t quite reach the frenzy level of Trash Talk, it riled the crowd up and there was ample moshing/stage diving.5 It was lit.

^ Ratking

^ Trash Talk Tuning.

I’m not familiar with Trash Talk’s music, so this set was a bonus. On the spectrum of punk, Trash Talk shows can get pretty extreme (NSFW). This show was relatively less wild, but it was an experience nonetheless–stage dives every 30 seconds, etc. Frontman Lee Spielman ended up clinging to the rafters as the crowd engulfed the stage– a fittingly chaotic ending to the night. I would recommend a Trash Talk show for fans of punk music and/or contact sports. It’ll be an exciting show whether or not you’ve had prior exposure to the band.

^ Lee Spielman hydrates before annihilating.

^ Lee Spielman annihilates.

^ Power stances.

What’s Next?

Expect more LA shows from CYP with solid lineups, and according to their website, a variety TV show called The Check Yo Ponytail Show. A L.B./Wiki collab looks certain. Trash Talk plays pretty regularly, so there will be many opportunities to catch them.

–Z. Conner

Footnotes

1. CYP, an IHEARTCOMIX subsidiary, started in 2006 as a small weekly party at Safari Sam’s, and has been organizing events of increasing musical magnitude in LA ever since. CYP’s events work somewhat like a guided tour that hops between different stages at a festival: they curate diverse musicians into impressively compatible lineups at contained venues, avoiding the hassle and complexities of a festival. Previous acts vary in prominence from local obscurities to the Rolling Stones (who held their first club show in 20 years at a CYP event), and in musical style (DIIV vs. Killer Mike, The Kooks vs. Trash Talk, etc.).

2. In other words, it was chill. Apart from his music, Lee was pretty down to earth: he finished a couple tallboys during the set, jumped in the crowd to schmooze with fans, and gave out stickers.

3. L.B. started out as a beatmaker, with a stint as Pro Era’s DJ. He holds production credits for several Joey Bada$$ tracks (e.g. “Hillary $wank”). His solo career found him signed to Ninja Tune, and transitioning from boom-bap to explorations in jungle, drum and bass, ambient, and dubstep. While L.B.’s set showcased this experimentalism, certain moments were reminiscent of the organic groove and soulfulness of his beatmaking roots.

4. So Ratking is a hip-hop group with three members, which technically makes them a hip-hop trio, but they should primarily be addressed as a band, as their dynamic is that of interdependent musicians. Like their namesake (the folkloric “rat king,” where a bunch of rats are joined by tangled tails) the group’s whole is greater than the sum of its parts. I say that not to diminish from the individual talents of its members, but rather to praise their group synergy.

5. Ratking wants to be considered punk. Since punk music is linked so intractably to the live set, concerts find the group in its natural habitat. Though the internet has been incremental to their success, Ratking’s earliest exposure came from playing at lots of small, underground venues (or “dungeons,” as Wiki calls them) and their onstage confidence and vitality exemplify this.

title: Show Preview: Thundercat & Teebs @ UCLA’s Royce Hall (5/29/15)
content:
In case the announcement of Lil B’s guest lecture didn’t convince you that UCLA is in the habit of hosting one incredible event after another, this Friday at 7pm, bass extraordinaire Thundercat will be performing at our very own Royce Hall.  Thundercat is the moniker of Stephen Bruner, the Los Angeles bassist, singer, and producer best known for his work alongside the likes of Flying Lotus, Kamasi Washington, and Kendrick Lamar. Thundercat’s solo endeavors consist of two albums, each of which was commended for Bruner’s dexterous bass work and unique jazz-fusion soundscapes.  If Friday’s performance is anything like his previous live appearances, the soulful and dance-worthy nature of Thundercat’s music should translate well on stage, complete with all the extended cuts and improvised jams that make for a definitive jazz show. 

Knowing how tightly knit the artists under the Brainfeeder label are, it comes as no surprise that Teebs will open up for the headliner right after a student performance which is yet to be announced.  Teebs is an LA visual artist and DJ who puts together some of the more ethereal and well balanced beats and textures in the electronic scene today.  This producer is more adept at creating mellow moods than danceable grooves, but I anticipate that he’ll serve as an exceptional opening act nonetheless.  Teebs alone would justify the price of admission, but you can see both of these acts for roughly $25-$35, or absolutely FREE if you’re a UCLA student. You can purchase a ticket HERE using the code “SCAUCLA” for $10 off!Or alternatively, you can reserve a free student ticket HERE! If you’re still on the fence about this incredible free show, then feel free to check out either of these links to each artist’s sounds.

Teebs: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5op3PCB8i0
Thundercat:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Nq3Ls6kzeE

- Doug Gil

title: Show Review: An Evening with David Sedaris @ Royce Hall at UCLA (5/5/15)
content:
There are a few things you can expect to encounter every year: America’s love for irrational salience issues, awkward family gatherings, the strange and unlikely generosity of strangers, and David Sedaris making his yearly rounds to point out the humor of it all.  Before he was selling out venues and touring universities, the author/comedian first emerged in the early 90’s with his breakthrough piece, “SantaLand Diaries”– a stark and self-deprecating essay about his time working as an elf in a Macy’s department store.  His work has remained in a similar vein as this debut, consisting of nine autobiographical short story compilations since.  His books have garnered widespread acclaim by earning Sedaris numerous awards, and making him a regular in the bestseller lists. But what Sedaris is really known for by the average reader, is his knack for fleshing out the seemingly mundane, and endowing it with his beloved brand of wry, sardonic humor.  Last Tuesday, our very own Royce Hall received nothing short of that.  Even though its been over two years since the release of his last book, Let’s Explore Diabetes with Owls, Sedaris has been working relentlessly in between tour dates composing one essay after another, or at the very least, keeping his diary filled with outrageous musings.  English majors, literature buffs, and casual readers such as myself were treated to various readings of new material for a solid, and thoroughly entertaining ninety minutes. Shortly after taking the stage, David opened with a slightly different piece, one that reads from the perspective of a woman who is appalled upon noticing her reflection in a public art installation.  The story is cute and lighthearted– in other words, good for loosening up a crowd with high expectations.  However, this opener didn’t particularly move me as much as his other pieces have in the past.  While it was an entertaining essay, Sedaris has proven that his forte lies in his ability to express really dark humor through his personal experiences.  However, this safe opener was completely made up for during the following two pieces, “Calypso” and “Spa Music.”  The former takes many turns, going from the author’s medical misadventures, to having a tumor removed by a fan, and finally feeding said tumor to a snapping turtle.  “Spa Music” on the other hand focuses solely on his younger brother– a goodhearted guy, but also the type that spends way too much time reading 9/11 conspiracy theories. Both stories were lengthy, but adroit at keeping the audience’s interest.  The essays were written in typical Sedaris fashion, yet perfectly balanced with staggering unpredictability. David closed off the evening by sharing a series of selected entries from his diary.  I almost feel as if this portion was presented in direct response to people like myself that criticized the overt lightheartedness of the opener.  Specifically, these selections were appropriately offensive and unapologetically grim.  The entries ranged from a couple of lines to about a dozen sentences, and covered everything from a fan expressing his rape fantasy, to (hypothetically) getting a blowjob from a baby.
The evening peaked with his personal essays, and didn’t let up until Sedaris finally walked away from the podium.  The promise of laughing really hard is a good enough selling point for fans, but for me, I’m also very intrigued by the honesty and self-awareness expressed in the midst of all the comedy.  After all, the author himself made reference to how ridiculous it is that we paid to watch a guy read on stage.  However, I feel as if attending “An Evening with David Sedaris” is much more than that. Aside from a few words carried through David’s characteristic effeminate voice, the experience also lies in being surrounded by fellow fans, and enveloped in their awkward, snorting laughs.  At times, my biggest laughs came not from the joke itself, but from listening to the people around cackle and relate profoundly to some bit about prophetic driftwood.  David Sedaris’ essays seldom peak with life-changing events and overarching morals.  Instead, he proves time and time again that there’s hilarity, and sometimes even poetry, to the most average of experiences.

Words: Douglas Gil

title: Songs of Defiance Season 2 - Original Television Soundtrack - Exclusive Preview
content:
*Listen in to the new soundtrack right HERE*

Defiance, the hit SyFy series, offers one of the most eclectic soundtracks ever heard on TV. Telling the story of both humans and aliens coexisting on a completely different Earth in the year 2047, the show features an unusually heavy emphasis on music, with songs being performed by characters within the series itself. The season 2 soundtrack, available digitally on May 26 and physically on June 19 via Lakeshore Records, includes original songs and performances from Brendan McCreary, Young Beautiful in a Hurry, Raya Yarbrough and Trace Adkins.

“I began working on Defiance when composer Bear McCreary and showrunner Kevin Murphy had me contribute a few tracks with my group Young Beautiful in a Hurry for Season 1,” said Brendan. “I was beyond thrilled when they asked me back, this time, as their resident songwriter for Season 2. I was already so inspired by the material, but most especially by Bear’s theme for the show, with its dark brooding vibe and incredibly unique dub-style synths. I wanted to incorporate that futuristic vibe into my own work for the show and create a continuous musical environment to thread the universe of Defiance together.”

We are excited to offer exclusive sneak preview clips of the soundtrack. If you like what you hear, you can get the full soundtrack on iTunes now. Season 3 of Defiance will return June 12, 2015 on the SyFy channel. You can see the partial tracklisting for the Season 2 soundtrack below.

01 What’s Up (Votan Mix) feat. Fyfe Monroe 0:00
02 Doll Parts feat. Fyfe Monroe 0:30
03 One Soldier, One Axe, One Grave feat. Ayana Haviv 1:00

~Catherine Yi

title: Album Review: Ten Thousand Fists by Disturbed (2005, Reprise/Intoxication)
content:
Firstly, unless you were born between January 1988 and December 1998, you won’t have been in high school during Ross Robinson’s golden age. If you were, you would’ve experienced the opinion-dividing powerhouse that was teenage angst mixed with metal. Most kids loved it. I loved it. And I sure as hell still love it. I’m referring here to nu-metal. Right now, I’m predicting that a surge of names are being uncontrollably flung at you. Fred Durst. Linkin Park. Maybe even Korn. Or, the question of, why is mixing hip hop and sound effects with heavy metal even being considered as a good idea? But chances are, there’s bound to be band one name where the only significance is the name. For those nu metal converts who flung themselves full pelt into the subgenre, Disturbed were exactly what they wanted. Creative synths added to thundering guitar riffs, distorted yet clean vocals, and verses that nearly resembled hip hop but were accompanied by such a heavy backdrop and distortion that it couldn’t possibly be hip hop. A following was quickly amassed and within the world of rock and metal, the name is recognizable at an ear’s prick. I use the term ‘prick’ as though it is a sharp sound. For many more it is. Average rock and metal fans claim them to be either too soft, or embody too many stereotypical teenage issues. Critics who apply pen to paper, and my friend Rob, claim that all their albums sound exactly the same. With 2005’s Ten Thousand Fists, I will dispute this.

  The album opens with its title song. It signifies it is holding no compromises. Straight to the ruthless, brutal point. And yet there is build up. The first thing we hear is an ambient sound, something that isn’t created by a synth guitar or a pounding riff as with their first two albums, but a cold haunting sound that draws us into nothing but suspense. It lasts two seconds, then a quiet groove-based guitar riff starts playing its twanging melody. The build-up has begun. Within twenty seconds, we hear a melodic roar of David Draiman’s vocals, with a production quality that makes it far more powerful than the opening of their first two releases.

by: Alex H

title: Show Review: Nick Offerman & Megan Mullally - Summer of 69: No Apostrophe @ The Wiltern, 5/21/2015
content:
It’s often difficult to have any form of secrecy in a relationship between two celebrities. Every single detail of the relationship just spills out to the public, be it significant, insignificant, real, or fake; and it is very easy for the the fans to have a strong opinion on the aforementioned relationship. And as a very rare example, the lengths that Megan Mulally & Nick Offerman go to in order to disclose the genuineness of their relationship actually formed the core force underlying their public image as a comedy duo.  

Out of respect for their no-photo policy, I will take the hint and not disclose the details of the show at full length, but rather reflect on my impressions. It is a very challenging task to maintain momentum in a show that transitions between music and comedy, particularly if the show includes interactions with the audience, making it inherently off-beat. Offerman’s leg injury and one member of the audience who insisted on doing god knows what on his phone, in the front row nonetheless, couldn’t keep the show from being eclectic yet warm, organised yet spontaneous. Most of the body of work forming Summer of 69: No Apostrophe consists of the sexual nature of the relationship between the two performers. Memories, bizarre experiences and a series of recollections of unorthodox sex positions prove that with the right amount of genuineness and good rhetoric, it is actually possible to form a 2 hour set that consists of dick jokes.

Offerman and Mullaly, respectively of Will & Grace and Parks and Recreation fame, are both similar and different than their characters Ron Swanson and Karen Walker in many ways. The raw and down to earth personality of Swanson echoes through Offerman’s delivery, whereas Mullally expertly transfers Karen Walker’s inherent energy to glamorise stories into a hilarious way of sugarcoating her memories, making the show feel fresh yet familiar. As it is normal for a comedy act to have points of lost momentum, it is not often that the cause of this hitch in tempo is a member of the audience. As I have come to deeply respect a performer’s choice to keep a performance cellphone free, it feels mind-boggling to see what lengths some members of the audience go to just check their phones. In this particular occasion, a gentleman in the front row who personally got warned by Offerman on three separate occasions, somehow found the shamelessness in himself to actually boo the show and got himself kicked out of the room. For a performer to be kicking out a member of the audience is not something that can always be seen as a way of thinking that can be empathised with, but Offerman’s stance on this occasion felt both justified and necessary. It was quite interesting to observe two performers perform a solid two hour set of below the belt jokes and then outclass an uncivilised member of the audience with such grace. I sincerely hope as the use of technology begins to get more and more instinctual to us, we will somehow rediscover a way to show a performance the respect it deserves and demands.

All in all, Summer Of 69: No Apostrophe delivered exactly what it promised, two hours of sensual intimacy flowing through The Wiltern resulting in a hilarious and satisfying climax. 

- Hakancan Altiner

title: UCLA RADIO // Pledge Drive - 24 Hour Programming
content:
UCLA Radio continues its biggest fundraising push of the year, and what better way to celebrate the backing of unique, ad-free, student-run programming than by broadcasting for 168 straight hours?

In addition to all the events, giveaways, merch sales, and promotions, uclaradio.com also boasts twenty-four hour live programming during Pledge Drive’s opening week.  UCLA Radio is already recognized for its “all day every day” style of streaming, but on any other week, you normally won’t hear a live DJ on the air between the hours of 12-9AM.  For the duration of the week however, you can tune in at (literally) any time and listen to some of our charismatic DJs serenade you live.  And this isn’t just a mere extension of our regular programming!  In the past, our DJs have opted for more experimental shows and have even gone as far as to host live music within the station.

As a college radio station, we understand the 3AM struggle to finish a project and even the 5AM relentless existential crisis.  When that happens, (and it will happen) don’t forget to tune in and let the presence of a live voice comfort you in your most trying times.  We’ll be awake with you in solidarity.

Donation link for Pledge Drive: http://igg.me/at/uclaradio

Words: Douglas Gil

title: A Very Personal Show Review of Angel Olsen at the El Rey Theatre (12/4)
content:
By: Jeffrey Brownell (Beverly the Intern, on Coffee Talk, Sundays at 6-8 PM)
One of my biggest concert regrets of 2014 was missing Angel Olsen’s performance at LA’s annual music festival, FYF Fest. So naturally when I heard Angel Olsen was making her way back to play at the El Rey Theatre in Los Angeles I jumped at the opportunity, and after weeks of excitement I ventured alone into the crowded theater to see Angel Olsen play.

Kevin Morby, vocalist and guitarist for The Babies and former bassist of Woods took to the stage before Angel Olsen. The messy haired musician strolled about on stage like a cowboy accompanied by fellow The Babies member, Justin Sullivan on drums. His curly locks thrashed about as he wailed on his guitar for songs such as “Harlem River.” The lyrics of his slower songs echoed some common/played out folk music stereotypes such as wandering, traveling, and homelessness, and it was glaringly obvious that Morby drew much inspiration vocally from Bob Dylan but that didn’t down play the skill Kevin Morby had as a folk artist. Though some of his set ventured into predictable grounds (I mean he had a harmonica neck holder at one point, seriously?) the saving grace of Morby’s performance were his jarring solos on every other song, and I found myself shamelessly banging my head whilst he shred his way into experimental folk rock territory.

Following Kevin Morby’s onslaught on the folk genre and the El Rey audience alike, I waited anxiously for Angel Olsen to take the stage. I was curious to see how Olsen would follow such an upbeat performance, because everything I had heard from her was slowly paced and her music often approached very dark themes. To pass the time between sets I struck up a conversation with a rad dude from the crowd named Alex from Costa Mesa. In our conversation I mentioned that I typically enjoyed punk or any dance inducing music and that folk wasn’t my genre of choice. He told me he had seen Angel Olsen twice live, and he assured me that her performance would be special.

After much anticipation the red curtains of the El Rey slid open to reveal the headliner. I immediately felt like I was taken back to my high school’s prom night (or an even cooler prom honestly) as Angel Olsen appeared in a shiny black gown and began her set with “Free”. Drenched in colored flood lights and in the presence of her eclectic and talented band, Olsen continued delivering both old songs and her newer hits off of “Burn Your Fire for No Witness.” Everything Olsen sang she sang with a sly smile on her face, and every instance of silence between songs was down played by Olsen’s enchanting banter with the audience. She proved her almost humble and even shy demeanor when she giggled with us and told stories, before getting back to the confident self behind the vocals as she belted out the peaks of her songs and demonstrated her vocal range.

Following the song “Lights Out”, Alex leaned over to me and asked if I was enjoying the show. When I agreed that the set so far was bad ass he elaborated on his opinions on the genre. ”It’s like a romance movie versus an action movie,” He said, ”Punk shows are fun but this hits a different note.” I realized Alex was right as I found Olsen transcending her recordings and wooing me over to the folk rock scene. 

Towards the end of her time with us, Olsen’s band left her on stage for a few solo songs. Olsen prefaced her mini solo set by telling the crowd how hard it was for her to play the next song when she was having such a good night. In turn she stuttered and laughed through the lines “Everything is tragic, it all just falls apart” but slowly and surely she rose to the dark tone of her song “White Fire” and the room was full of a brief sadness. Olsen and her band returned for and encore and concluded the early 80 minute performance with a hopeful rendition of “Windows,” the closer song of “Burn Your Fire for No Witness” though she remained physically static throughout most of the show her voice was able to permeate throughout the room for a unforgettable set. 
I couldn’t believe it at first considering Kevin Morby’s stellar performance, but Angel Olsen exceeded every single one of my expectations, as she stole the show (and possibly my heart.) I would recommend anybody with even the most remote interest in American folk or either act to go check them out. Kevin Morby proved himself as a solo artist and Angel Olsen in particular was an immensely humble performer that deserves absolute respect. If I had to sum up Angel Olsen’s performance in one word I would find it difficult to use any other adjective than “charming.” 
By: Jeffrey Brownell (Beverly the Intern, on Coffee Talk, Sundays at 6-8 PM)
