title: A Review of alt-J's Newest Album
content:
“This is All Yours” shows alt-J’s soft side by showing their hard side. Don’t let Joe Newman’s warbly, comical voice mislead you—this album is heartfelt and serious, at times even suspenseful and jolting. Sensitive, slow melodies are shaken up with gripping, nervous climaxes. The album takes you on a bittersweet, reflective journey up and down the winding, mysterious hills of a land they call Nara. It is an emotional journey— pasts are confronted, memories are reinterpreted, and sacrifices are made.


The album intro alone is a musical journey. It begins with a whirling sound bath, pulsating with heterophonic, rhythmic, syllabic vocals reminiscent of Philip Glass’ “Music in Twelve Parts.” The vocal layers bleed and swirl until finally lo-fi lyrical vocals kick in, sounding like a long-lost cassette demo. The song conjures the feeling of a suspenseful, exotic circus. Layers of sound accumulate to thrilling heights. Would this song perfectly soundtrack a David Blaine escape trick? Yes. And that (probably) is a compliment.


“Arrival in Nara” is a tearjerker, a campfire nightcap, a goodbye prayer fit for a melancholy film scene where a wise and beloved elder quietly passes, or a widow mourns. It’s sung softly and sweetly— rawer than Alt-J’s more stylized musical concoctions. The follow-up track, “Nara,” is at once whimsical and eerie, playful and serious. Cirque du Soleil music composers, take note. At first Nara seems to be a magical, glittering realm, but beware of monsters lurking around the bend… we remain in Nara for ten more tracks. Or, arguably, nine: “Left-Hand Free” is the album’s black sheep (or Nara’s golden egg?), sandwiched smack in the middle of an otherwise cohesive narrative. This marks the first musical shift from ethereal, twinkly, free form soundscape to radio-polished, blues-rockin’ indie-soul. “Left-Hand Free” is a temporary free pass out of the Nara fantasyland, back to Planet Earth, where hits are manufactured. And on Planet Earth, the song happily fills the void left by The Black Keys’ latest departure from blues-rock into folky jingle-pop.


Now, back to the land of Nara. Snuggle up with alt-J’s soft side on the tracks “Pusher, “ “Garden of England,” “Choice Kingdom,” and “Warm Foothills.” If you like Antony and the Johnsons or Bon Iver, you will like “Pusher.” “Garden of England” is rose garden teatime music— a weaker strain than Mark Mothersbaugh is serving, though still pleasantly palatable. If you want to go on a coming-of-age, find-your-true-self-and-the-meaning-of-life pilgrimage, you will bring the song “Choice Kingdom” with you, if not in headphones then in spirit. “Warm Foothills” will make you want to fall in love, cozy up in a log cabin, and crunch around in piles of autumn leaves. Don’t feel bad if “Warm Foothills” is the amuse-bouche that leads to a nostalgic listen of your old Feist album.


A few musically exploratory tracks are “The Gospel of John Hurt,” “Every Other Freckle,” and “Hunger of the Pine.” If you wish Yeasayer could soundtrack James Bond, give “The Gospel of John Hurt” a try. If not, go right to the standout track, “Every Other Freckle.” It sounds like Sufjan Stevens having a bad trip, which, as it turns out, is perfect. Speaking of psychedelics, put on the orgy scene from Zoolander, press mute, and play “Hunger of the Pine” (http://alturl.com/iar9o). In this track, Nara becomes Wonderland, and you a walk a mile in Alice’s shoes.


There is a little something for everyone on this album. After a successful debut album, this second release from alt-J is just as confusing and pleasantly surprising as one would expect a second album from a new artist to be. With one hit already under their belt, they have loosened that belt a couple notches and taken full creative liberty. Besides “Left-Hand Free,” the only hits alt-J seems to care about are acid, not the Billboard charts. This is All Yours is an artistic, colorful flight of sound, with the inevitable compromise of Hit #2.

~Lauren Levy

title: UCLA Radio Comedy Recommends: Hound Tall with Moshe Kasher
content: Comedian Moshe Kasher hosts a live podcast at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre called the Hound Tall Discussion Series, wherein a single topic is expounded upon by two comedians and one expert. Topics are usually taboo (previous shows have discussed death, harems, and polyamory).  The most recent show discussed Islamophobia and being brown in America. Guests included comedians Maz Jobrani, Ian Karmel, and religious expert Reza Aslan. While not exactly the most diverse panel (Ian Karmel is neither Muslim nor brown), the show remained true to its mission statement.  Hound Tall is equal parts levity and enlightenment. You can find the show on the Nerdist podcast channel, or you can see it live (with a new topic) December 9th at UCB.

title: UCLA Radio's Top 10 Albums of 2014
content:
It’s been quite a year in music. The station gathered up their opinions, put their top 10 albums in, and together, we created a list that very much defines the majority of the stations’ highlights in music for 2014. We hope you enjoy and if you haven’t listened to any of the albums listed, we highly recommend it. Happy Finals / Holidays from UCLA Radio!

1) Run The Jewels: Run the Jewels 2 (Mass Appeal)

“Blast your head off beats from the king of the underground and an underrated workhorse finally getting his due. El-P is a living legend, one of the greatest producers ever, and after years of features Killer Mike is finally rising from the shadow of Outkast to become one of the best in the game. The album snarls and squeals at every turn, bumping bass and shrill synths combining into non-stop, teeth-gnashing blasts. Above it all, the two float like rajahs, laying down intelligent, honest, head-shakingly good bars. Last year they claimed "there will be no respect for the Throne.” That doesn’t seem like such a ridiculous boast anymore.“ - Zach North

2) Mac DeMarco - Salad Days (Captured Tracks)

The gap-toothed, gruff-looking DeMarco doesn’t look like someone with such an angelic voice as his. In his sophomore album, Salad Days, with dripping emotions he sings mainly of a woman, while also doing some soul-searching in one of the best tracks on the album, "Chamber of Reflection.”

- Elizabeth Battey

3) FKA Twigs - LP1 (Young Turks)

“An easy choice for album of the year, Twigs mixes harsh industrial beats, warm R&B chords, pitch shifted vocals, and emotionally vigorous lyrics to craft the most compelling debut release (or any release, really) of the entire year. She has a knack for dense layering without creating stuffy compositions; her songs breathe with both space and intimacy. Twigs draws you in with breathy, falsetto-filled coos, as if she’s reading you passages from her diary, only to quickly push back with jarring lines like "live or leave me.” The constant line she walks between closeness and distance makes for a difficult, but immensely rewarding listen.“

- Gabriel Brenner

4) St. Vincent - St. Vincent (Loma Vista)

5) Freddie Gibbs & Madlib - Piñata (Madlib Invazion)

"Madlib and Freddie Gibbs are a great time, Madlib gives Gibbs a more dynamic sound, while Gibbs gives Madlib a much needed harder sound.”

- Esther Robinsun-Abrams

6) The War On Drugs - Lost in the Dream (Secretly Canadian)

7) Spoon - They Want My Soul (Loma Vista)

“Not too far off from Spoon’s earlier albums, but definitely has a grungier outlook than songs like "Don’t You Evah”. I’d classify the album as both eclectic, groovy, and just the slightest bit experimental for this normally vanilla band.“

- Eric Aberbook

8) Ought - More Than Any Other Day (Constellation Recordings)

9) Alex G - DSU (Orchid Tapes)

"Considering this is Alex G’s sixth LP on top of the many other tracks he has lying around the web and on his bandcamp page, I can honestly say the 21-year old’s songwriting skills only get better and better. Giannoscoli’s (Alex’s full last name) work on DSU definitely put me in a different atmosphere from first listen onward: at home in a suburban neighborhood on the midwest enjoying some time alone or at a backyard house show with best friends on break from school. Though I can never make out what Alex wants to thematically project in his songs (in my defense, Alex himself has stated in past interviews that he doesn’t see why people would try to make a concept or theme out of his own music as his writing is almost completely ambiguous and vague enough that it’s pointless to come up with a specific "meaning” of an Alex G song), I cannot give less of a shit. This album is my personal favorite of the year. Hope you all listen to this album and feel like :/ too"

- Eddie Hernandez


10) Against Me - Transgender Dysphoria Blues (Total Treble Music and Xtra Mile Recordings)

title: Hans Zimmer @ The Microsoft Theater (04/14/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by : Ethan Lee

Film composer Hans Zimmer’s highly-anticipated Hans Zimmer Revealed tour kicked off in Los Angeles at the Microsoft Theater on the cool evening of April 14th, 2017.  With 10 total dates of this special tour set through May in North America, including two Coachella Festival dates, Zimmer prepared a concert showcasing his career-spanning repertoire riddled with guest performers and contributors.  The result was a symphonic rock concert, with more emphasis on the former than the latter, that would please both young and old fans of Hans Zimmer.  The reimagined performances of his scores stayed true to the original recordings for their respective films, but added some rock/pop elements to make the show more engaging and appealing in a live setting.  More into that later.  

THE SETUP

This concert was far from just simply a conventional 40-piece classical orchestra setup.  Including Hans, over 50 performers graced the stage.  At the very back on an elevated platform was a 16-person half male, half female choir.  In front of them was a 19-piece orchestra, with a 10-member string section (4 cellos, 6 violins/violas), and a 9-member brass horns section (As per Hans’ style, many French horns).  And, as expected from Hans Zimmer, the percussion section sat in front of the orchestra, with 4 total members serving various duties on drumset, timpani, and xylophone/vibraphone/glockenspiel.  At the very front was Hans and his frontline, including two violinists, one cellist (rocking an electric cello), an upright bassist, three electric guitarists, a bass guitarist, a flutist, and a computer musician (a la Jonny Greenwood style).  Hans often switched between playing banjo, acoustic upright piano, synth, Spanish guitar, and even timpani, a true testament to his musicianship and versatility.

THE MUSIC

OK, this is probably why you’re reading this article, because you’re a Hans Zimmer fan.  Yes, he does play your favorites.  Yes, he does them justice.  What’s interesting to note is that this concert isn’t just seeing Hans Zimmer conducting an orchestra replicating his complex soundtracks.  It’s seeing him play with his band and watch how he arranges his soundtracks in a live setting.  Most of the tracks he performed were suites dedicated to each film, finely arranged to transition between the most famous pieces out of those soundtracks.  The setlist is posted at the bottom of the article.

Oftentimes you’ll see a description that’ll say he’ll play “reimagined” scores.  Yes, they’re reimagined, but nothing in the likes of Spinal Tap experimenting with cosmic jazz odysseys where it’s odd and strange (I’m looking at you, Herbie Hancock and your classical improvisation endeavours.).  Instead, what he’ll do is he’ll add pop/rock instrumentation into his arrangements to make them more engaging.  For example, when he plays Stay from Interstellar (arguably the most famous and beautiful track from the score), he has the slide guitar play the main melody instead of how the organ and harmonics did in the original Interstellar soundtrack.  He also adds a steady drum pulse on the toms to maintain the pace of Stay, which actually explains why the percussion section is in front of the choir and orchestra: Hans doesn’t conduct them, they just rely on listening to the drummer.  Other examples include the incorporation of a rock drum beat to Inception’s The Dream is Collapsing and Mombasa.  Depending on the piece and arrangement, Hans will throw in the occasional guitar and rock drum beat to pieces that have less defined pacing to make the music more engaging and memorable in a live concert setting (because rock concerts are the only type of concerts worth remembering, right?), but still maintain the true spirit of the original soundtracks that fans have grown to love.  

The musical guests are worth a mention.  Many friends and peers of Hans’ appeared in the concert, often introduced by Hans where he would give a personal anecdote and affirmation of respect for them as musicians.  The most significant guests were Lebohang Morake, known as “Lebo M.,” and Carmen Twillie, the original singers from the Lion King soundtrack recordings.  As Hans put it after their surprise appearance, “You may hear the Broadway shows…but those are all other [singers and actors], this man is the true Lion King!”  Acclaimed composer James Newton Howard also appeared on stage alongside Hans during his Dark Knight Trilogy sequence, where Hans described how he couldn’t have written Bruce Wayne’s sequences without him for Christopher Nolan’s series.

Highlights include The Dark Knight Trilogy, Inception, Interstellar, Rain Man, Lion King, Pirates of the Caribbean (featuring the talented Tina on cello), Crimson Tide, The Da Vinci Code, Sherlock Holmes, Man of Steel, and Wonder Woman.  Hans truly brings his music to life but manages to arrange them in such a way to create an immersive and energetic live concert experience.

THE VISUALS

I’m one who normally closes my eyes roughly 57.3% of the time at a concert to listen and absorb the music being performed, but I found it difficult to do this time around with all the visual components this show incorporated.  Hans’ live show uses complex lighting adjustments and effects to create an even more immersive concert experience.  Since film rights are a pain to attain, Hans often has visual graphics interspersed with footage of his ensemble members playing their instruments to replace what potentially would have been clips from the films he worked on (Interstellar’s sequences contained a starry field with art deco-style gold buildings, while Man of Steel’s graphics were colorful lines that simulated the motion of flight).  Hans Zimmer’s excellent use of spotlights are another worthy note; often, drummers would be highlighted by having three spotlights pointed at the same drummer but alternating between lighting, creating a quick motion effect that accentuated their complex solo patterns.  The result, overall, is an intensely visual spectacle as much as it is an auditory one.

VERDICT:

Hans Zimmer’s pieces are difficult to play in a live setting due to their versatility in instrumentation and complexity in composition, but who’s better to arrange them for a live setting than the master composer himself?  Through Hans Zimmer’s impeccable ear, the audience is able to hear his career come to life as a result of his hard work and dedication to music.  His career highlights fans have come to know and love will be done justice and tweaked with some rock elements to create an immersive and energetic experience.  People coming in expecting a film concert are going to get what they expect plus much more: a symphonic rock concert calling back to Hans’ early days as a new wave post-punk musician, but staying true in homage to his success as one of the most important film composers of the modern era.

Setlist: http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/hans-zimmer/2017/microsoft-theater-los-angeles-ca-63e6ce47.html

title: Alina Baraz @ El Rey (4/4/17) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp

Post Date: 4/10/17

Photo by Alex McDonell

I wonder if Jessica Rabbit ever dressed up for Halloween. Some children had “the talk” at young ages at some procrastinated time before the pot roast was ready. They squirmed in their seats and fidgeted uncontrollably at the thought of private parts. But It wasn’t until seeing the voluptuous curves of the red satin dress on Ms. Jessica that they could conceptualize the birds and the bees. Upon first sight, Jessica Rabbit gave rise to their first epiphany - children’s first lusts and dirty imaginations. Jessica Rabbit embodied everything that men wanted to conquer, and what women wanted to be. Mysterious. Hair flips. She glistens in my memory. Of course she didn’t dress up for Halloween.

I wonder if Jessica Rabbit would be proud to know that she came alive on the stage of the El Rey on April 4. The crowd lined up to see the personified version of Jessica Rabbit in the human form of Alina Baraz an hour early. The energy was anxious for a Tuesday, and even the solo guys whose dates had abandoned them at the bar seemed content with themselves. The merch line was longer than the bathroom and bar line combined. “I don’t even like this jean jacket… but if I spend the $200 on it, I can meet Alina after the show!” a girl squealed to her friend.

Baraz’s fan base, a surprisingly diverse crowd of tweens and mid 30-something aged ladies with Yeezys, soul, and no regard to a curfew swayed to the opener. The top 40 music DJ pumped up the crowd, and as the room filled with more people, it became clear: this Tuesday night show had been marked on the calendars of every person west of the 405 for months.

The lights on the stage appeared slowly. Dimly lit in gold fluorescents, Baraz’s shadowy figure came to center stage. Like waking from a dream, her full figure took shape on stage in a blurry motion of disbelief and awe. Baraz’s perfect pitch filled the room and the crowd stood still for a minute. Playing songs from the Urban Flora EP, Baraz didn’t talk to the audience between any breaks as she played “Show Me,” “Make you Feel,” and “Maybe.” I closed my eyes and wondered how she had gotten to this point. Her voice has the right tone to be played in a fancy airport lounge or the winding-down hours of a wedding reception. As the rest of her show went on, it became apparent that she wasn’t accustomed to vocal strain, and in certain parts, found her higher notes to be cut short with deeper breaths.

Photo by Alex McDonell

Midway through the set, Baraz smiled at the crowd. “I have a new song that I’ve never played before. Do you guys want to hear?” The remaining 20 minutes were the best of the show, keeping the crowd on the dance floor and away from the bathroom line. “I want to introduce you to someone… one of my great friends.” Khalid took to the stage and they both jumped in to their song together, “Electric,” singing, “Darker than the ocean, deeper than the sea/You’ve got everything, you got what I need/Touch me, you’re electric, babe.”

Baraz and Khalid exemplified seventh grade chemistry, where crushes developed in the notes passed between sweaty fingers and puppy love dreams. They turned and sang to each other, holding each other’s hands as they harmonized and created a moment. It felt awkwardly invasive to be in the crowd watching them together as they locked eyes and sang lusty sweet-nothings to each other.

Photo by Andrew Gomez

Khalid gave a slight bow to the audience as the song ended, and Baraz transitioned seamlessly into two more songs. The crowd, hot and bothered by now, reflected the image of Roger Rabbit’s tongue hitting the ground with eyes shooting like daggers towards the stage. If we had tails, they would have wagged. As she brought our repressed notions of lust to life, Baraz read the audience and saved the best song for last, playing the popular “Fantasy” - the one fantasy we’d been hoping for.  No DJ could remix the fantasy Baraz could conjure, and no Jessica Rabbit would ever compare.

title: The Next Step in California’s Battle Against Air Pollution // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Mateo Rojas

Post Date: 4/10/17

The battle against air pollution has been an ongoing obstacle for the State of California. In an effort to eliminate the smog problem caused by greenhouse gas emissions, California has vowed to enforce tougher regulations on vehicle companies. These regulations include making automakers produce energy-efficient engines, utilize eco-friendly materials, and build more electric cars.These regulations seem ideal, but concerns with President Trump’s administration may arise due to Trump’s strongheld denial of climate change. California’s long history with pollution battles has fostered a strong feeling of resistance between the state and the federal government on the topic of regulations regarding to pollution.

According to the Los Angeles Times, President George W. Bush’s administration declined a waiver request from California to enforce air pollution regulations in 2002. Conversely, when President Obama took office, this waiver was granted to the state and sparked efforts to establish a national policy on greenhouse gas emissions. Although Trump’s conservative administration intends to halt regulations on air pollution, the state is prepared to fire back and strongly negotiate for the regulations. These efforts are significant for California’s smog epidemic, since the health and quality of life of many Californians are adversely affected by the pollution. Detrimental health effects, including airborne diseases, have increasingly affected Californians from dense industrialized areas due to high greenhouse emissions.

It is time to enforce stronger regulations on greenhouse gas emissions, in order to ensure a healthy and clean environment for all Californians. In order to complete this promise, we must all work together to bring about a change.

title: Re: “Make No Mistake, Trump Will Build That Wall on the Mexican Border” // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Sydney Matthews

Post Date: 4/3/17

Building a stronger border is inefficient because funding will be sought in American pockets. Trump proposing a “border tax” on Mexican imports is ineffective because the Mexican government knows Trump’s intentions of making Mexico pay for the southern border. Therefore,  they would not fund their own segregation from America. This means funds must generated elsewhere.The payment would be left in American hands. Intensifying borders would initially remove, according to Grieco and Ray, “13 percent of economy (immigrant labor workers).” The result would be a disturbance in the secured flow of income, disrupting in government programs and innovation.

Foremost, with the Republican Party already enacting tax cuts and the remainder of the tax investment being transmitted into strengthening the Mexican border, it minimizes government funded programs; it would cut back on after school programs for middle and low income students, public healthcare, and other essentials middle and lower class need to fully function. Essentially, by redirecting tax investment to fund empty hate, it takes away programs needed to enable an individual’s prosperity. On a broader scope, hindering innovation hinders society’s ability to remain competitive with other countries.The freedom of innovation is threatened, thus taking away one’s resources and tools needed to be innovative and leaving them no space for creativity.

It’s essential also to raise awareness around the issue of inflicting stronger borders because it contradicts American values. For one, it ceases one’s natural right of movement, as stated in the Constitution, and also dehumanizes foreigners, which contradicts the Declaration of Independence and that “all men were created equal.” With stronger borders, stronger border patrol is neede as well . Unfortunately, this demented disposition about foreigners primes officer’s associations of who belongs and does not. Therefore, through the procedure of carrying out an order, immigrants are dehumanized to targets and are ostracized from society. This disassociation becomes the foundation that drives officials to feel compelled and disconcerted with foreign murder and destruction in hopes of securing the border and protecting residents. Detachment through “stronger borders” becomes normalized within America and further feeds the segregation and polarity between Americans and foreign born. Long term effects of isolation restrict foreign resources and foreign aid utilized in times of national crisis.

In order to sustain efficient allocation of economic energy, the answer lies in diversifying the labor in economy, not exclusion. For instance, according to the New Economic of Labor Migration theory, fully functioning markets are not always applicable, therefore diversifying labor, and individuals can act collectively as a social unit to maximize income for the economy as a whole.

Read the original op-ed here.

title: The Battleground of Social Media // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Helen Lee

Post Date: 3/30/17

Deep-rooted, anachronistic, closed-minded points of view met progressive, social technology in advent of Donald Trump’s controversial presidential campaign. Not only did Donald Trump, as a presidential candidate, gain a reputation for being controversially effusive, but his vocal, animate, and hateful supporters also gained a huge presence on mainstream social media websites such as Twitter, Facebook, and even Reddit. These extremist points of view echoing themes of white supremacy gained traction and support by many who were dissatisfied with the liberal status quo with President Obama. In such cases, uprisings and social media campaigns were employed by both ends of the spectrum, in which progressive people of color fought to make equality matter. Such is shown in the 2015 case of the murder of Michael Brown by police officers, when social and political activists fought to make race relations and perceptions matter by creating huge campaigns centered around Twitter.

On the extremist right wing perspective, echo-chambers of backwards thought were created amongst the emerging alt-right. ‘Alt-right’ is a term that refers to the alternative right, a loose group of people with far-right ideologies who reject mainstream conservatism in the United States. These groups that oppose immigration and political correctness, such as neo-Nazis and white nationalists, have grown exponentially in the recent years, only to be heightened by the ascent of Donald Trump. Major American white nationalist movements on Twitter have gained about 22,000 followers since 2012, and referenced Trump in tweets more than any other topic. Likewise, the most commonly used hashtag of these groups was found to be “#whitegenocide” after it was found that Trump had referenced a user with the username of ‘White Genocide.’ While racism and colorism were not the only issues that these extremist groups referenced, it was a large focus. Issues of immigration and abortion, although arguably equally controversial, did not gain nearly as much traction on social media as issues of race and white supremacy. These mainstream platforms soon became ground for white-power groups to foster discussion about race, rally support for Trump, and grow their following. This shows that social media, while progressive, has the power and the potential to be used for the wrong purposes, and set progressive thought behind by using the same medium to infiltrate toxic ideas. For instance, white supremacy groups have used Reddit to contribute to “WhiteRights” subreddits, and even Google searched for “Martin Luther King,” leads to a white supremacy website titled MartinLutherKing.org, which paints the civil-rights leader as a fraud.

On the opposite end of the spectrum, few individuals have sparked campaigns of support for racial equality. Specifically in the case of the murder of Michael Brown, they found a voice on social media to comment on the news, describe their personal experiences and relate the everyday struggles of blacks in America. These activists used Twitter, Tumblr, and even Facebook as mediums to mobilize and raise awareness of the racial injustices and discriminatory police violence. Three key voices in this campaign, Johnetta Elzie, DeRay Mckesson, and Zellie Imani, mobilized online by taking pictures and videos and hashtagging, in efforts to document the horrific treatment and spread the word. The nature of the visual content was able to carry much further and garner the support of thousands of social media users nationally and internationally. Mckesson and a core group of other activists have built the most formidable American protest movement of the 21st century to date

In critical analysis, social media can be used and manipulated by different populations. People and political groups have agendas, while social media platforms do not. In the two different cases of both liberal and conservative-alt-right movements, it is clearly delineated that it is the people of these groups that create the content and the movements with the message that they spread. These very polarized intentions often clash and create larger conflicts of “good vs. bad” ideals and “right vs. wrong” ideals.

title: Don’t Get Lost - The Brian Jonestown Massacre // Album Review
content:
Written By: Megan Hullander 

Post Date: 3/25/17

Undeniably the epitome of the tortured, disagreeable musician, Anton Newcombe consistently delivers experimental, complex albums. More than forty members have passed through the BJM in a repeatedly changing lineup, with Newcombe as the single member contributing to each album. Given Newcombe supposedly plays more than eighty instruments and has been known to be unapologetically honest (ex. kicking members of the band off stage mid-set if displeased with their performances and physically haggling the audience during shows), fans have come to expect innovation as a result of his talent and candor tendencies from the Brian Jonestown Massacre. The BJM’s most recent release, Don’t Get Lost, is distinctly more psychedelic than the band’s previous records. While somewhat distracting, the eclectic arrangement of Don’t Get Lost only further proves the BJM’s (and specifically Newcombe’s) expansive and versatile abilities in creating music.

Perhaps better suited as the basis for a series of albums, each song is markedly different from the others, ranging from ambient to reggae to electronic. At seventy two minutes, the album is extensive and somewhat exhausting to listen to in full, yet provides an intricate soundscape impossible to disregard as inappreciable. One of the more enticing aspects of the album is its reformulation of older sounds. Groovy bass lines, echoey vocals, and trance jazz are featured throughout the album, with guest vocals featuring Tim Burgess, Tess Parks, Shaun Rivers, and Freiderike Binert.

While it is fair to assume that the album has been rethought and strategically constructed with Newcombe’s perfectionist tendencies, Don’t Get Lost feels refreshingly raw and unapologetic. Approaching twenty albums since its formation in 1990, there is no end in sight for the Brian Jonestown Massacre as Newcombe seems to have not faltered in his pace of production over the years, continuing to build a collection of music almost unrivaled in its consistently of greatness.

title: Moh Lhean - Why? // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alex Ivanova

Post Date: 3/21/17

After nearly five years of silence, alternative hip-hop and indie rock band Why? has finally released their sixth album, continuing their beloved experimental sound and now providing a more hopeful tone, even when discussing themes of death and cynicism.

Moh Lhean begins with the earlier-released singles “This Ole King” and “Proactive Evolution,” exciting long-term Why? fans and providing the same experimental sound the band is known for, with Yoni Wolf’s cleverly crafted rhymes paired with chimes, flutes, and underlying hip-hop influences. These singles are the closest we get to the sound of older Why? albums, as Moh Lhean moves into gentler sounds as the album moves forward.

While on the surface Moh Lhean does not possess as “weird” a sound as earlier Why? albums, songs that begin with gentle piano and guitar melodies eventually spur out into weirder, weightier sounds through layering of instrumentals and vocals. Similarly to older albums, Wolf incorporates whistling, xylophones, recorded conversations, and wistful, echoing female vocals, providing a depth to tracks that may seem lackluster in comparison to his earlier heavier, percussion-centric work.

Wolf’s lyrics continue to be well-crafted, although they perhaps become more ambiguous in a darker way as he subtly focuses on themes of death, which are especially poignant considering the softer sound he has switched to in Moh Lhean. In “Proactive Evolution,” Wolf compares himself to, “The negative of the silhouette/Of a dock crane backlit at sunset/Gasping for exit through unknown air.” In “One Mississippi,” he sings, “Constantly rising from/And falling into flame/My body knows more than/I can form with my brain.” These vague, dark images are scattered throughout the album, and come in strong contrast to the soft piano melodies and chimes accompanying them. However, the optimistic undertones of the album are also occasionally present in the lyrics like, “A new love blooms on the long notes of old horns,” from “George Washington.” Ultimately, it is this cryptic tone that proves Moh Lhean to be an especially personal album for Wolf, perhaps proven further by the title being a reference that Why? refuses to expand on— as made evident by Joyful Noise stating, “Don’t bother asking Wolf what ‘Moh Lhean’ means. He won’t tell you.”

Moh Lhean keeps the piano-focused melodies from earlier Why? albums like Elephant Eyelash and Mumps, Etc. “Proactive Evolution,” however, is the most we’ll hear of Wolf’s characteristic nasal, half-spoken delivery, as the album focuses more and more on more on his melodic singing in “Easy,” “Consequence of Nonaction,” and the soul-influenced “George Washington.” Perhaps it is this shift to a more mellow sound that has left many to describe the album as being underwhelming in comparison to earlier Why? albums, that were acclaimed for their weirdness both in lyrical content and instrumental experimentation.

This criticism is, in many ways, valid. Upon first listen, many of the tracks on Moh Lhean seem to blend together. Even as a long-time Why? fan, I was disappointed in Moh Lhean upon the first listen, expecting the same unabashed weirdness I had appreciated from Why? in albums like Alopecia and Elephant Eyelash. It took multiple listens for me to appreciate this “softer” and more mature Why?, now less focused on danceable drum beats and outright eccentric lyrics. This raises the question of whether established Why? fans are willing to overlook their expectations of the band as a solely experimental group, and whether new listeners will be willing to appreciate a more mellow Why? off the bat, even if it means having to listen to the album multiple times to truly appreciate all the album has to offer, in terms of lyrical content and crafted instrumentals.

Despite this, the album is ultimately worth a listen, whether it’s a chance for old-time Why? fans to see the new direction Wolf is taking the project, or a softer introduction for new listeners to become acquainted with Wolf’s work. What may seem underwhelming upon first listen Moh Lhean ultimately makes up for with a more subtle intelligence in presenting its message and perspective on a personal peace with death. Ultimately, it presents something much deeper than many other Why? albums, and its vague, lyrical impressions on life accompanied by orchestral precision are not to be overlooked or overshadowed by the band’s older work.

title: Common as Light and Love are Red Valleys of Blood - Sun Kil Moon // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alex Ivanova 

Post Date: 3/18/17

Songwriter Mark Kozelek’s eighth album under the Sun Kil Moon moniker is no deviation from his usual lyrical themes of self-reflection, bitterness, and nostalgic recollections. The two-hour long Common as Light and Love are Red Valleys of Blood, however, goes beyond the stereotypical folk niche Kozelek has been known for in the past, as he comments on the current political climate and incorporates musical elements once foreign to Kozelek’s expected folk sound.

The album begins with the nostalgic “God Bless Ohio,” with a reminiscent Kozelek singing, “Domino’s pizza brings me back to when I was younger, when I was younger, when I was younger,” over a strong baseline and a clumsily fingered guitar melody. Kozelek reflects on how “the power of song” brings him healing and a home - initiating the small midwestern town aesthetic Kozelek’s music is known for.

This mood continues until “Philadelphia Cop,” when the album switches direction as Kozelek begins to incorporate newer, less guitar-centric sounds, and reveals his unapologetic distaste of modern millennial culture with, “See I don’t give a fuck about things like who’s the best or the worst on Twitter.” His disassociation from this culture is made evident by the repetition of “I ain’t no one’s fucking puppet.” Kozelek goes as far as to poke fun at the current youth music scene with a mock conversation between a music journalist and stereotypical festival-goer:

“Oh my god, you get to meet the bands?”

“Yeah, totally. I’m friends with Jim James, Dr. John Misty, a bunch of people.

*notification sound*

Hold on a second,  Sufjan Stevens just texted me right now.“

Kozelek continues to remark on his stance on current societal issues, including the transgender bathroom bill debate and the election of President Donald Trump in “Lone Star,” gun control in “Bergen to Trondheim,” and the crisis in Syria in “Vague Rock Song.” Ultimately this rambling commentary is nothing new for Kozelek, as it establishes the personal connection he has with the listener, not withholding any part of his train-of-thought ranting. Common as Light differs from earlier Sun Kil Moon and Red House Painters albums, however, as we see a more biting, caustic side of Kozelek.

Lyrics aside, Common as Light also deviates from other Sun Kil Moon albums instrumentally as Kozelek begins to incorporate synthesizers, minimalist melodies, and subtle hip-hop influences, which come completely out of left-field when considering Kozelek’s other mellow, guitar-centric projects and prior work under Sun Kil Moon. Besides the use of synthesizers throughout the album and the deviation from the guitar melodies Kozelek focused on in earlier projects, the experimentation in Common as Light is made most evident in “Vague Rock Song.” Kozelek himself light-heartedly addresses this change in sound in the track, as he begins with a simple and stated “vague” tune, which is interjected with a Zappa reference and Afro-pop inspired break. Through Common as Light, Kozelek surely proves that his musical abilities are certainly able to push boundaries and keep up with modern experimentation.

While it may seem like an overly bitter, out-of-touch Kozelek ranting about his hatred for iPhones, Twitter, and current American politics, Common as Light still serves as an entirely unapologetic reflection of the issues being debated within our society, and is refreshing in an at times sugar-coated, media-dominated, censored world. His critique of what modern society has turned into is poignantly stated, bitter, and biting, and while many listeners have taken this as Kozelek being caught up in his own mind, the album ultimately serves as a brilliant satirical piece, proving Kozelek’s self-awareness, as well as his ability to not stray from the unconventional, both in his instrumentals and lyrical content.
tags: common as light and love are red valleys of blood

title: Interview with Hippo Campus @ the Teragram Ballroom (3/3/17)
content:
Interview by Megan Hullander

Where did the idea for the album art for Landmark come from?

Nathan: It’s a recreation of our old rehearsal space, Zach’s basement.

Jake: Each of the objects in the room represents one of the songs on the record.

Ouija boards - actual ritual or running joke?

Nathan: Do we dabble?

Jake: We dabble, we dabble.

*exchange look*

Jake: No we don’t really.

Nathan: I don’t think I’ve ever used a ouija board, there’s a first time for everything though.

Jake: Tonight’s the night.

What do you picture people doing when they listen to your music?

Nathan: Making out.

Jake: Yeah, making out.

Nathan: Honestly, I would just love if it was just a poorly lit basement and this kid is like 16 or something and he’s just trying to cop a feel…That’d be cool. There’s nothing in my head, I don’t think about it that way. I guess I would want it to be fairly romantic.

What are your Tinder bios?

Nathan: Zach is the only one who has a Tinder.

Jake: And his bio is “I play bass in a band, this is my most defining feature.”

Nathan: He also used the wrong ‘affects.’ He was talking about something that affects him and put e-ffects instead of a-ffects and I’m like, “Dude, come on.”

Jake: Like come on, your Tinder linguistics man.

If you had one, what would yours be?

Jake: Tinder-what am I doing here again?”

Nathan: Tinder more like timber cause I’m falling off the…I down know. Or…eat me. Just go straight for it.

Jake: Some Little Big Town lyrics.

Nathan: Class of 2013.

Jake: Making waves, catching waves up on the roof.

Nathan: Bible verse. I’d probably put something from “Song of Solomon” in there.

What band would you leave this band for?

Jake: I wanna be the guy with Lorde that plays the drum pad.

Nathan: I wanna be Lorde.

What is the strangest dream you have had about one of your bandmates?

Jake: The death dreams are always…

Nathan: Those are always so real.

Jake: I had one about Zach a while back. I just remember like us three going to the funeral and then like flash forward like a month and we were all like hanging out and we were like “We should call…” and then we all looked at each other and we were just like…

Nathan: NO dude.

Jake: It was so heavy. I woke up so upset.

Nathan: I think one time it wasn’t that one of y’all died, but that Justin Bieber died.

Jake: He’s one of us man.

Nathan: Can you imagine if he died? We were all together and it’s just like we all just kind of broke down. But I woke up and I was like, “Holy shit this is where we are now in the world, Biebs is dead.”

Are you guys big Bieber fans?

Nathan: Man I appreciate…you gotta respect the guy.

Jake: I kinda feel for him on a level.

Nathan: I fuck with some of his shit.

Jake: Yeah I fuck with his shit I just don’t fuck with I feel like he’s trapped.

Nathan: Yeaj he needs to find himself a little bit. He’s got like the world on a string so hjw are you supposed to maintain yourself in that?

Jake: Well from the time he was young, people were just always telling him what he was to be like ‘Justin.’ Yeah, we’re pretty deep in the culture.

Nathan: It’s weird it’s kinda like we grew up with Justin Bieber in a way. I had the haircut. It’s not like we’re fans, there’s like camaraderie.


Who would you like to collaborate with?

Jake: I mean Migos are the Beatles of our generation.

Nathan: I’d like to collaborate with… or I just want to sort of be in the same room as Young Thug. Just watch him do whatever…”

Jake: Sean Paul?

Both break out in song (again), a mediocre rendition of Sean Paul’s “Temperature.”

Nathan: Hippo Paul or Sean Campus?

Jake: Shippo.

Many artists have been getting political have you ever considered making a statement with your music or using your influence?

Nathan: It’s been talked about. It’s a weird subject. I think there is a fine line between our duty and our business. I think it’s…Yes, we have considered it.

Jake: There was an interview the other day where we talked some politics. I think within the band it’s a very person to person basis. We’re all political in different ways. And if we are getting political, we use a personal platform as opposed to the band’s. Everything is very political right now.

Nathan: Everyone is doing it. It’s very trendy.

title: Spotlight of the Week // Queers 4 Ur Ears
content:
Post Date: 3/6/17

Queers 4 Ur Ears dedicates their hour to tunes from LGBTQIA+ musicians, showcasing different artists and reflecting how their queer experiences contribute to their music and the community as a whole. The hosts, DJ Spinach Boi and DJ Special Mess, also take time to relate their own stories about queer identity and discuss aspects of the LGBTQIA+ community. The show welcomes listeners of all identities to hear the conversation about the intersection of queerness and music. Their show has featured visitors such as musician Angelina Savanna, but both DJs were certain to name their favorite guest - their current intern Bianca. Although the show had not originally planned to have an intern, they quickly found her contributions to be one of the best aspects of the show - as DJ Spinach Boi and DJ Special Mess said, “As her parent DJs, we could not be prouder, This one’s for you B.”

Tune in to Queers 4 Ur Ears every Monday night at 7 p.m. on uclaradio.com and get updates on the show by liking them on Facebook!
tags: ucla radio spotlight of the week

title: NAV - NAV // Album Review
content:
Written By: Harry Gonzalez

Post Date: 4/15/17

The Weeknd is responsible for providing the hip hop community with NAV. After being signed to XO, NAV got straight to work on his debut mixtape. He produces most of his own work, and while this is usually something worth noting as a positive aspect, most of the tape sounds sparse and thin. In fact, many of the synths that NAV uses on his tape sound like presets found on your friendly neighborhood DAW. The opener, “Myself,” is one of the few exceptions to this critique; the track contains wavy, atmospheric pads running through gates, creating interesting chord hits that play after the main hook. NAV rap-sings through the entire piece, reusing the same melodies over and over and over. This type of delivery makes it so NAV’s hooks and verses become inseparable from one another; The verses also feel drab and uninspired as a result of this stylistic decision. At the end of the opener, NAV essentially flexes the fact that he is behind the boards on his own tape - he chops and screws the last minute of the song’s hook. This is probably most fun to listen to while faded out of one’s mind, however. A special compliment in regards to the opener is that it establishes NAV’s sound and lyrical pathway. Aside from this, it doesn’t sound like a fleshed out piece.

The track “NAV” contains a sour, awkward melody that is bashed over and over and over once again from hook to verse to hook to verse. One would probably find this song more interesting if NAV added substance to his lyrics. He brags about “not paying for sneakers,” “getting money, fucking bitches, popping tags,” etc. Not that there’s anything wrong with writing these kinds of lyrics, but the entire mixtape follows this same formulaic type of writing and delivery. NAV always manages to deliver the following type of lyric: “I did this, now I do this.” And this can be found on every song, without exception. “Good for It” presents the listener with a decent melody, so it is not as drab to listen to. The track features a beat that has some underlying tones and synth notes that breathe a little bit more life into the music. However, about halfway through the song NAV attempts to place his vocals on emphasis, and the lyrics, once again, shine through as bland… wash-rinse-repeat.

The track “Up” delivers the greatest absurdity in terms of lyrical content when compared to all of the other tracks on the tape. In fact, one can argue that, “Now she gimme head outside of TOYS R US,” is a great contender for worst rap lyric of 2017, a bar so uncalled for that I laughed vigorously for a good 30 seconds. It is a real shame too that the beat is a little more subdued and one can hear the Metro Boomin side of the production in the watery bass and sporadic hi hats. NAV truly comes off as a child that stole all of rap’s cliches.

“Interlude” is an okay moment on the record. NAV’s singing feels a little more true and emotional, but that just might be the fact that it is mostly a spacey, drug-tinged instrumental piece more than anything. Moving on, I could have sworn I heard the track “Sleep” before on the same album. “Mariah” contains the most pleasing hook on the entire record - NAV’s singing is airy and done in a very breathy manner. Aside from this, the track once again falls to the same faults that the rest of the album.

The Weeknd makes his obligated appearance on NAV’s record on “Some Way.” Abel essentially steals the track from NAV; he outshines his minor in vocal performance and overall relation to the instrumentals. NAV sings, “Haters gonna say this shit is whack.” Well I personally don’t believe that one has to be a “hater” to agree that most of this can be labeled “whack.” Yet one still has to commend NAV for being somewhat different from the rest of the hip hop crowd. The difference is NAV sings so much that he can’t be boxed into hip hop, yet he doesn’t sing proficiently enough to be boxed in R&B. In retrospect, NAV can’t be boxed into anything, just as he croons on “Myself.”

title: Make News Credible Again // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: James Wilson

Post Date: 4/10/17

Many internet users have begun to complain and worry over the growth of an innocent and devious problem: fake news.  According to Webopedia, fake news refers to “false information or propaganda published under the guise of being authentic news.” Examples of fake news stretch from bogus tabloids about celebrities to phony articles about top politicians. This can lead to confusion and misinterpretation of reality. However, the biggest issue surrounding fake news is not the news itself. “Yellow journalism,” or rather sensationalist and crudely exaggerated journalism, has been around for over a hundred years. The real problem in this era of mass information is discerning the fake news from the real news. This issue is especially rampant on sites like Facebook and Twitter, where random assortments of individuals and groups post “news articles” daily, coming from generic “news sites” that may or may not be based in fact. Many beg the question: how do we tell fact from fiction?

As of 2016, 62 percent of U.S. adults get some of their news, if not most of it, from online social media platforms, like Facebook, Twitter, or Reddit, according to the Pew Research Center. Already, fake news has been identified as an issue on these websites. Facebook has been blamed and criticized for allowing fake news stories to circulate and confuse voters during the recent presidential election. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has come out saying that the issue of false information is of concern to the company, and that Facebook would work with the community and journalists to try and find a solution. Yet there are many issues that arise when trying to deal with the detection and removal of false news articles. From fact-checking stories and citations to reviewing the writer’s authenticity and past works, those that decide between fact and fiction could add their own judgements to the mix. Social media conglomerates could put filters on information that doesn’t align with their, or their investors, ideologies and interests. Another issue with fixing fake news is that many individuals have no real incentive to check the authenticity of what they read in the first place. Fake news often circulates because no one taking the time to click on articles to read them. An article by The Atlantic found that, “only about a quarter of social-media users regularly click through to read a news story on social media.” Most internet users simply read over the clickbait title full of inflammatory and emotional energy. It is apathetic to have a real conversation that breeds mistrust online and polarizes issues to a point where they seemingly cannot be discussed anywhere.

Making sure that the information we share online is credible is not only productive, but beneficial to our society. From an ethical point of view, we must take care and be responsible for what we do and do not share with our friends and family online. The internet has interconnected all our information, and it is important that rules and guidelines are formed to moderate and discern these volumes of information.

title: Heartworms - The Shins // Album Review
content:
Written By: Lillian Stanwick

Post Date: 4/4/17

There certainly is an audience for Heartworms, but it’s not the same audience that enjoyed Oh, Inverted World or Chutes Too Narrow. There are various hints of The Shins’ past on Heartworms, such as the Shakespeare reference in “Name For You.” However, this new album - the first in five years - sounds distinctly separate from the band’s previous works.

The title “Heartworms” refers to a creature which invades, a nuisance, a parasite. I cannot help but feel that fans of The Shins’ earlier albums will interpret the increased synthesizer usage on Heartworms as acting in a similar way, overwhelming the songs’ lyrics and pulling The Shins away from their past albums characterized by simpler rhythms and poignant prose. The lyrics of “Fantasy Island” ache of the emotional anxiety suffered by frontman James Mercer during his rather nomadic childhood, but you can barely make them out under the pulse of the synth-heavy song. What could have been a beautiful, introspective, stripped-down number instead sounds like STRFKR has invaded it.

“Mildenhall” returns to the simpler sound of the earlier Shins, but “Rubber Ballz” soon brings back the synth. It should also be noted that “Rubber Ballz” harks to the parasitic theme introduced by the title, as Mercer gripes about his unending lust for a troublesome lover.

The album makes a confusing change of pace with “Half A Million,” which I’d describe as the ‘one thing’ that is not like the others. The song is a catchy, pandering anthem to partying and seems devoid of any past elements of The Shins’ sound. “Dead Alive” then harks back to the sad nostalgia of “Fantasy Island,” further separating “Half A Million” as an odd track on the album.

The album’s title track, “Heartworms,” feels like The Shins of Wincing The Night Away while building on the album’s established theme. Mercer sings of the futility of trying to impress a cold woman and his frustrating inability to rid himself of the feelings he has been infested with. “Now I’m trying to figure out when it was you gave me these heartworms/I feel them wriggling in my blood, you gonna do me harm,” one verse states in blatant metaphor.

“So Now What” is an annoying addition to the album, likely only included because the track appears in the film “Wish I Was Here.” “Fear” is an appropriate closer. It is as emotionally wrought as “Fantasy Island,” with subtle psychedelic notes lent by the synth and mellotron, yet it maintains the lyrical pathos that has come to define The Shins.

If you liked Port of Morrow, then it is likely that you will be pleased with Heartworms. However, for those who fancy The Shin’s earlier work, Heartworms leaves something to be desired. Although well intentioned, the use of the synth left me yearning for something more stripped. The growing use of this type of sound with each of The Shin’s subsequent albums feels almost as invasive and unwarranted as the creature for which this most recent release was named after. If The Shin’s release of a “flipped” version of “Name For You” is any indication of their future work, it is unlikely that listeners similar to myself will be appeased with a return to the band’s older releases.

title: Hang - Foxygen // Album Review
content:
Written By: Megan Hullander

Post Date: 3/27/17

A band once seemingly broken appears to be mended. After a series of meltdowns, breakups, and the 82 minute album …And Star Power, that despite its length felt unfinished, Foxygen has turned around with a truly “genuine” album. The Los Angeles duo’s characteristically seventies-esque sound is maintained, but this time with structure and continuity throughout the album. Hang sounds distinctly more mature than Foxygen’s previous works. It features guest contributions from the Lemon Twigs and the Flaming Lips’ Steve Drozd. While still superfluous in sound, the chaos in their preceding albums is replaced with a forty-piece orchestra, maintaining their instrumentally excessive quality.

Released in the midst of the election of a controversial leader, lyrically, Hang is appropriately political. The opening track, “Follow the Leader,” advises that the only leader that is worth following is you, possibly alluding to the newly elected president and outbreak of protests that followed. The following track “Avalon” warns of impending “nasty weather.” The fourth track, “America,” is somewhat more clearly political, stating, “If you’re already there, then you’re already dead/If you’re living in America, whoa/Our heroes aren’t brave, they’ve just got nothing to lose/Because they’re all living in America.” The track later references Hollywood and the roles “you” play, potentially alluding to the celebrity intertwined with modern politics. The album closes with, “Rise up, see for yourself/You got to pull yourself up/From the fires of Hell/Rise up, and see for yourself/When all the world’s gone/Nobody else.” A call to action perhaps?

Maybe this analysis is misinterpreted and the political references previously assumed are merely desperately created mirages not intended by its creators; however, in the current political climate and in an age of artists using their work to make political statements, this analysis could very possibly be valid.

title: Op-Ed: Court is Wrong to Declare New Travel Ban Unconstitutional // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Danny Zander

Post Date: 3/19/17

On March 15, a three judge panel on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the revised executive order issued by President Trump that suspends visas and immigration from Iran, Syria, Yemen, Somalia, Sudan, and Libya was unconstitutional. This is the second travel ban Trump has issued to be struck down by the courts. The first was struck down because it broke Section 1152(a) of Title 8 of the U.S. Code, which states, “No person shall receive any preference or priority or be discriminated against in the issuance of an immigrant visa because of the person’s race, sex, nationality, place of birth, or place of residence.” The new travel ban was constructed specifically to hold up against similar legal challenges. Unlike the old ban, this one does not apply to green card holders. It also does not discriminate based on religion, since it does not include any preference towards accepting Christians facing religious persecution, and it ignores Islam and any specific religion altogether. What is left is a policy no different than President Obama’s 2011 order that suspended Iraqi refugees for six months and President Carter’s 1980 ban on Iranian visa holders. Since these two orders were clearly constitutional, Trump’s order should be treated no differently.

Rather than upholding the law established through the U.S. Legal Code and precedent, the judges decided to legislate from the bench, using their power to state that the order was unconstitutional because they did not like Trump’s policy. They did so by incorrectly stating that implied motivation is just as important in determining constitutionality as the text in the law. The court used a statement from last year, when Trump said on the campaign trail, “I think Islam hates us,” to say that the ban is motivated by the desire to limit the number of Muslims entering the country. While this may be true, when judging the order, all that must be taken into account is the text, since it is the text that would be enforced and not the motivation, and the text states that the purpose of the travel ban is to prevent immigration from countries that import terrorism until a better vetting system for refugees can be implemented. A court’s job is not to legislate from the bench, but to interpret the law, and the Ninth Circuit failed at its job.

title: José González and The Göteborg String Theory @ Royce Hall (March 4 2017) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Frankie Tyska

Post Date: 3/13/17

On March 4, I went to go see José González perform with The Göteborg String Theory at Royce Hall. I have been a fan of José González for quite some time now, but I had never even heard of The Göteborg String Theory. I’m so glad I went, however, because The Göteborg String Theory added a super interesting and surprising dimension to González ’s acoustic songs.

Most songs began softly, focusing on a certain area of TGST’s instrumentation. Sometimes percussion would bellow, other times violins would swell up. González would enter about a third through the song, piercing the symphony sweetly with his vibrato-less voice. A key focal point of the show was towards the back of the stage - some of the percussion used was very experimental, straying from rhythmic normalcy and traditional instruments. There were occasional solos from different pockets of the orchestra, adding texture to the performance.

Although I thought that I would crave for González to do his songs alone, I actually really loved, and maybe even preferred, TGST’s contribution to his work. They made otherwise simple songs feel intricate and emotionally complex. The extravagance of added instrumentation, however, stripped González’s songs of the intimacy they possessed in his recordings. Despite this step away from his personal emotion, I felt that the orchestra added an element to the songs that made them more personal and applicable to any individual audience member.

González was calm, somewhat shy, and very focused. He rarely made comments and didn’t create much of a connection with the audience. I didn’t dislike this - I’m sure it was a stylistic choice - but I would have really enjoyed learning more about the process he used when collaborating with TGST, or just about him in general. I actually felt more drawn to the conductor, one of the most youthful and energetic I have ever seen, using his whole body to let the beat pulse through him.

The arrangements that were played in the show were dramatic and interesting, but as much as I enjoyed them, I really wish that there was a visual element that would have rounded out the performance. Some sort of set, projection, or light show would have added an element of theatricality and would have made the night at Royce Hall much more of an all-encompassing experience.

I left the hall with the type of elation that usually fills my body after seeing a really good show. Everything except for the past two hours was erased from my mind. I walked home refreshed and really happy. There were some things I may have changed about the show, but I feel this way about most shows, so I would have to give my night at Royce Hall a solid 8 out of 10.

Thanks to CAP UCLA for a really unique show, and for that clutch student discount!

title: FUTURE - Future // Album Review
content:
Written By: Harry Gonzalez-Mejia

Post Date: 3/8/17

Atlanta’s most versatile crooner opens up his self titled record with a religiously tinted banger on “Rent Money.” The four chord progression vocalized by what appears to be a small choir pushes the track forwards while rattling hi hats and thick 808 bass hits bring the much anticipated trap that Future is known for. While the opener surely is a track to remember, mainly due to Future’s well crafted hook and verses, the rest of the album slowly drifts down into an uninteresting slump. 

The beat on “Good Dope,” produced by Southside (of 808 Mafia fame), is nothing to be amazed by. A couple bell hits spice up the beat on the hook yet the hook itself feels like Future is simply compromising. In fact, there are many times where Future does the bare minimum to convince his audience that he is anything else but leaned out on the microphone. In retrospect, the production on “Zoom” gave the impression that Future was going to vocalize something that would be memorable or quotable. The incessant repetition of “ran it up fast” hammers away along with the beat; while tough, cold and merciless at first, it becomes stale upon the second and third listens. The track ends with an ill-meant diss at Desiigner. I personally enjoy the deviation and, quite frankly, Desiigner has earned these shots. 

One of the better tracks on the entire 17 piece meal is arguably “Draco.” The track’s synth arpeggios, warm 808 bass, thick snare, and Future’s versatility all come together fairly nicely. Some might find the synth somewhat harsh and abrasive, but it eventually falls into the background when Future makes his appearance. “Super Trapper” is meant to be a thuggish, darkly tinted track but it comes off as, once again, an uninteresting display of flexing money, drugs, and Future’s come up. “POA” is more upbeat, and manages to barely convey the dark feelings that “Super Trapper” meant to. If anything the production of “POA” might make it worthy of a third or fourth play, but the hook and verses that Future provide here are relatively tame. 

“Mask Off” is similar to “POA,” and the flutes that are sampled throughout the track are welcoming and eerie. Yet, once again, Future fails to provide something of substance. It is important to note that this is being held to Future’s own standards that he set on DS2. Nobody comes to Future expecting bars or songs of personal substance; however the self titled record gives off the impression that most of these tracks might be leftovers of previous bodies of work. “Outta Time” is an enjoyable change of pace, where Future plays a more melodic role on his album. The hook is delicious - “P.I.M.P., gettin’ that Monica Lewinsky / Chain on freeze, wrist on jet-skis.” The beat, also crafted by Southside, is riddled with wah-wah synth strokes and small, angular guitar notes. The track as a whole gives off a carefree, sunny feeling - a context that Future would usually not be found on. 

Subsequent tracks fall into the aforementioned slump that Future carved for himself. “I’m so Groovy” contains a poor replication of Young Thug on it. “Might as Well” contains a Drake-y beat: minimal with piano hits, a sine bass, and small amounts of reverb thrown in. “Poppin Tags” is a track that Future listeners could swear they have heard before. From the construction of the beat to the lyrical content to the actual delivery that Future provides, this track feels like some kind of B-side. 

“Flip” is a track that gives the impression that a feature would have made this extremely replay worthy. The hook could use a bit of focus, as Future appears to be jumping from note to note without any idea of what the final product should be. In fact, most of this record feels very directionless despite the sensation that most tracks blend seamlessly with one another. The fact that the whole record is reserved for Future could add to that specific detriment. 

The hoover synth on “When I Was Broke” makes the beat stand out from the rest of the skeletal trap beats. It wobbles under Future throughout the majority of the track and adds a secondary melodic edge. As a closing track, “Feds Did a Sweep” is humbling and sweet. The production brought together by Zaytoven feels like it would be a track that could use Gucci, or somebody, on it. Future made a very interesting decision keeping the entire project to himself, but it is a shame that this same interesting decision did not lead to a collection of interesting tracks.

Rating: 5/10

Favorite tracks: “Rent Money,” “Outta Time”

title: Nels Cline @ Royce Hall, CAP UCLA (4/8/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by : Layla Moheimani

Photos by : Phinn Sriployrung

Nels Cline has played and filled some very impressive venues throughout his career. He has toured internationally as a member of Wilco. He has shown his undeniable prowess as a jazz guitarist and his intuitive musicality and versatility as a collaborator with everyone from Deborah Holland to Mike Watt. And yet, in the back of his mind through all of those projects, there was the constant lingering idea of an album that would combine sensual soundscapes with the classical romance of the Great American Songbook. It was an ambitious idea that Cline doubted would ever come to fruition, but nevertheless he had already come up with a name for it: Lovers.

For all the venues that Cline has performed in, he was the first to acknowledge the poignance that UCLA’s Royce Hall held for him. Being a Los Angeles native and the son of UCLA alumni, Cline had set foot in Royce many times throughout his life. Never had he thought that he could draw a crowd there, especially with his own music and for what he referred to as “a Saturday night of almost nothing but ballads”.

The night was opened by Big Lazy, a three-piece rock outfit whose blend of grit and cinematic instrumentals was a seamless introduction into the grander epic that was to follow. While the idea for Lovers first came about in the ‘80s, it was clear as the performance unfolded that this was the culmination of decades of collaboration and absorption of music from all generations and corners of the emotional spectrum. In addition to featuring original material, the group also performed material as varied from the Rodgers/Hammerstein classic “I Have Dreamed” to a stunning reimagining of Sonic Youth’s “Snare, Girl”, each song adding another layer to the music’s statement of affection for humanity itself.

Over half of the group onstage had also been involved in the recording of Lovers, including Cline’s wife Yuka C Honda on keyboard and synthesizer as well as his twin brother Alex Cline on drums. Notably absent from the stage was Julian Lage, who contributed acoustic and electric guitar to the album. Lage had been touring with the group but due to unexpected weather conditions he was forced to miss the performance, replaced instead by Los Angeles-based guitarist Ethan Sherman. Another key player onstage was Michael Leonhart, who served as conductor throughout the night as well as performing on trumpet and flugelhorn. It was off the stage, however, that Leonhart may have made his largest contribution to the project. As Lovers was coming together, Leonhart was Cline’s frequent collaborator who was critical in arranging and orchestrating the pieces to fit the scope that Cline had envisioned for it.

When surveying the nineteen musicians who had gathered on the stage, the setting was impressive both in its breadth and its variety. The standard string and brass instrumentation was compounded by a timbrally expansive woodwind section as well as a harp, synthesizer, drums, vibraphone, and of course electric guitars. While a less-knowledgeable observer could have mistaken the elaborate selection of effects pedals at Cline’s feet as being contradictory to a night of intimacy and romance, anyone who is familiar with Cline’s work is well-aware of the innovative and tasteful way he uses pedals to enhance a musical experience without ever overshadowing the grander narrative. While Lovers may have spent decades germinating within the confines of Cline’s own imagination and ambitions, the final product and performance were clearly larger than any one man or one story. The result was a stunning display of tenderness and passion set to an ensemble that even upon the first listen already felt both timeless and revolutionary all at once.

title: What Ever Happened to Stem Cell Controversy? // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Garrett Laird

Post Date: 4/11/17

When it comes to stem cell treatment, people want immediate therapies; they want a chance. The promise of stem-cells is a tantalizing one. With it could come solutions to major diseases such as cancer and birth defects, both of which can be caused by defunct cell differentiation and division. But with such potential, many worry about the viability of this strategy and the bioethical implications of introducing these cells into patients.

Today, there is a rise in unregulated stem cell clinics. Most are for-profit and they don’t always play by the rules. The New England Journal of Medicine recently published case studies I researched on NPR about three women blinded by treatment for macular degeneration from a clinic in Florida. With the hopes of restored vision, these women underwent hugely unregulated stem cell injection. It’s on the FDA to facilitate these practices and crack down on those who are putting patients at an unnecessary risk. With the visibility of these cases, it is surprising that they are still sitting this one out.

Another case of macular degeneration therapy in Japan reported more promising results. No further deterioration in the patient’s vision was observed after treatment. The difference here is that Japanese researchers used induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells in a carefully designed study. In Florida, however, adult stem cells from fat tissue of the patients were injected. After stem cells age, they become more and more specific to cell types. IPS cells, however, can differentiate into any tissue in the body. Therefore, this makes them an excellent candidate for treatment.

Great controversy lies in the use of human embryonic stem cells. Their extraction results in the death of the embryo. As such, the issue lies in the viability of the living organism as becoming a full grown human. The potency of this particular study, however, is that these are iPS cells which come from any cell in the body and can be coaxed into having embryonic stem cell-like differentiation potential. While the research community is making great strides in side-stepping the embryonic stem cell issue, their understanding and facilitation of this therapy is hugely underdeveloped. This is why patients are not receiving these injections more frequently.

To be sure, iPS cells are still new in development and application. Genetic factors associated with the converted cells still present a great level of uncertainty. Yet what this situation offers is a wide ranging social, medical, and economic study of how new technologies and treatments present important and new challenges. Health regulators keep a keen eye on clinical trials and medical developments, yet rising numbers of stem cell clinics are able to evade regulation. This is generally because guidelines and rules concerning these treatments are not yet in place. And thus, people are willing to undergo treatment under assuming pretenses, whether this be in the United States or in other countries. The danger here lies in the quality and safety of care.

title: Yesterday’s Gone - Loyle Carner // Album Review
content:
Written By: Maxamillion Polo 

Post Date: 4/5/17

The debut album from UK based rapper Loyle Carner is one that is at its core a personal and authentic exploration of the world and relationships surrounding him. Carner originally garnered attention among certain circles for the feature of his track “Florence” in an iPhone commercial and his connections to fellow UK artists Archy Marshall (aka King Krule) and Rejjie Snow, but it is with this album that Carner establishes himself as a powerful up and coming force in the UK rap scene.

For starters, what makes a rap album a good rap album? Is it a particularly infectious beat produced by a DJ with a name reminiscent of my personal favorite backyard condiment, a 16 bar count hard enough to drop, or spitting about coming from the bottom and finding yourself on top? While all those can, and certainly are, elements of a number of great rap albums, Carner employs a different tactic. Instead of speaking through elements of grandeur, the main thematic elements utilized are innately personal - from his loving relationship with his mother and his tumultuous relationship with his father, to simply messing around with friends, and the loneliness that comes from wishing for someone who is no longer around. 

The subject matter is at its heart fundamentally sentimental and the instrumentation throughout reflects this. Instead of relying solely on catchy hooks and a repetitive downbeat (not to say that the beat underlying a number of tracks is anything but infectious, which most certainly is the case with the hard-driving “NO CD”), Carner makes use of limited, and at times acoustic, instrumentation to create a musical soundscape that draws the listener into his own world, but on his own terms. Perhaps what works best for the album and helps in creating an enveloping and cohesive personal world in Yesterday’s Gone are the moments when all instrumentation and musical elements are absent. Throughout the album, Carner brilliantly interweaves samples of field recordings and spoken word that, instead of detracting from the more musical aspects of the rest of the album, manage to create a narrative framework that gives a greater sense of depth to the songs surrounding them. 

As for the the music itself, it is anything but lacking. Right from beginning, with the gospel inspired track “The Isle of Arran” to the Velvet Ground B-side reminiscent stylings of the closing track “Yesterday’s Gone,” Carner draws upon a number of genres to craft an album that never lets the listener become accustomed or weary of his noteworthy offerings. It is Carner’s ease with which he so freely experiments with music - from shifting genres to interlinking together personal pictures of his life and his music - that makes this such a great rap album. He allows us a uniquely personal glance into his life that is deeply intriguing and engaging, while never allowing us to grow tired of the sounds that constitute his world.

title: Process - Sampha // Album Review
content:
Written By: Bianca Brown

Post Date: 4/1/17

Last week’s finals were accompanied by a deluge of heightened emotions. Not only did these augmented emotions make their debut in students all around UCLA (which, if you’re going through it right now, you can get through this! Here’s the number to CAPS’ 24hr line in case you need it! (310) 825-0768) but they’ve comfortably found a home within every word, rest, key, and breath behind Sampha’s 2017 album Process.

Sampha Sisay, a 28-year-old British musician, has shared the stage and collaborated with some of the biggest names in the music industry today (ie Solange, Drake, Kanye, etc.) but has crafted his own name independent of these popular artists with this brilliantly written and angelically sung album.

Starting with the first song on the album, “Plastic 100°C,” Sisay makes sure his listeners feel every instance of helplessness, pain, grief, and self-discovery he has come across in his life thus far. “Plastic 100°C” was first released back in June of 2016 as a part of Sampha’s profile on the FADER. In the video, he can be seen performing a stripped-down version of the song on the instrument that Sisay has treated as his solace ever since it was given to him by his father at the age of three: the piano.
