Some of his deepest fears, struggles, and his methods of coping with them are underlined in the song within the lines, “Usually I’d run home, and tuck the issue under/Oh, sleeping with my worries/I didn’t really know what that lump was, my luck.” Sisay explains that he’s usually one to toss his issues to the side, causing them to gather together and cause a “lump” he’s unable to get rid of.

He also explains the alternative meaning to this relentless “lump”. Back in 2011, he discovered a mysterious lump in his throat that persisted after an illness, but the physicians he sought after were unable to find the cause of this lump. After his mom passed away with cancer in 2015, and his father’s death in 1998, this “lump” has been something Sisay has taken seriously health wise, hence his reasoning for including it in an already very emotional piece.

“Blood On Me,” the second song in the eccentric album, takes a more visual approach to presenting another one of Sisay’s internal struggles, his battle with sleep paralysis as a result of guilt that has manifested for quite some time. His sense of imagery and descriptive language can be noted throughout the entire song, adding all the more to the intense and emotive vibe the dark piano and fast-paced background music evoke: “I get up, they’re at the edge of my bed/Yeah, how did they find me, find me?/They said there’s somethin’ bleedin’ in me/Somethin’ screamin’ in me/Somethin’ buried deep beneath.“

When asked to explain "Blood On Me” in more detail, Sisay says, “I write things like a movie scene. I kind of see the camera angle, and there is someone sort of shaking me out—a Birdseye view of my bed. So there is that thing of someone there to save you from yourself. Or to wake you up out of the dream. It’s like a dog chasing its tail. You never really know where it ends.”

From song to song, Sisay’s beautiful runs, musical riffs, and heart-wrenching lyrics that speak of his struggles with his sleep paralysis, grief over the loss of his father and mother, his inability to reach out to his physically disabled brothers, and his internal emotional and physical struggles are what makes this album absolutely unique and haunting. With the help of his glorious piano-playing skills and eccentric instrumental ballads, Sampha has created an album that will no doubt keep audiences on an emotional rollercoaster for years and years to come.

Favorite Tracks: “(No One Knows Me) Like The Piano,” “Under,” “Plastic 100 C”

title: HNDRXX - Future // Album Review
content:
Written By: Ela Talu 

Post Date: 3/19/17


After becoming number one on Billboard charts with his self-titled album FUTURE, Future dropped his sixth studio album in less than two weeks, HNDRXX. Slightly differing from FUTURE, HNDRXX expresses Future’s Jimi Hendrix influenced persona who is courageous to sing with auto-tune and create hit-maker catchy beats. From beginning to end, Future discusses love and relationships with women, but from “My Collection” to “Sorry,” he transitions from being a conscious player to an apologizing ex-lover. Contrasting from his other albums, HNDRXX is somewhat apologetic and accepting of one’s mistakes rather than being depressive or raging towards an ex.

“My Collection” starts off at a confident level where Future raps about an ex, saying, “She got a few athletes on speed dial/I’m tryna get the case dismissed before I see trial.” He makes it clear that he had a lot of women in his life and keeps his past relationships as his collection. More of his savage mode continues with “Comin’ Out Strong,” featuring The Weeknd. Both hit-makers show off their strength facing with challenges from opponents or most probably haters. “Lookin’ Exotic” furthers Future’s point to prove his power, which he uses to spoil his women with luxury.

The climax of Future’s love for women starts with the upbeat track “Incredible.” He sings, “I was havin’ trust issues/But I’ve been havin’ way better luck since you/I know it’s true love with you,” showing how his new girl is not like his past relationships and how she is the reason this new relationship is “incredible.” He uses the same upbeat rhythm and singing with “Testify” and “Fresh Air,” questioning his girl’s love and attachment for him with lines like, “So you wanna fall for the bad guy?/So you wanna fall and get mad high?/Confess your love for me, testify.” In “Fresh Air,” he sings, “Sand touch your toes while you cookin’ breakfast/Pacific Ocean out the backyard lookin’ sexy,” almost painting the scenery of a refreshing new love for his listeners before moving on to the complicated side of his relationships with “New Illuminati.”

“Selfish,” featuring Rihanna, once again proves that instead of moving on from a toxic relationship caused by both sides’ selfishness, Future finds himself and his girl going back to the broken relationship and getting together for one last time. Reflecting on his consciousness towards his mistakes, Future ends the album with the outstanding track “Sorry,” co-produced by the prodigy beat-maker Metro Boomin.

After showing off his savage rap star persona with FUTURE, Future justifies that he has multiple personas in him that can create the most ratchet and dirty rap album as well as the most melodic and dramatic mainstream album. The result of this merging of personas is the great Future Hendrix and two number one albums in two consecutive weeks.

Top Tracks: “Sorry,” “Comin Out Strong,” “Testify,” “Incredible,” “Selfish”

title: Don’t Sit Down - A Benefit Standing with Planned Parenthood @ the El Rey (March 4 2017) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Lillian Stanwick

Photos By: Nichole Oshida

Post Date: 3/14/17

This benefit was the brainchild of Best Coast’s Bethany Cosentino, who addressed the crowd multiple times throughout the night and stressed how much Planned Parenthood meant to her. When she first spoke to the audience before the first set of the evening, the venue was very empty, even for an opening act. It was clear that Cosentino wanted this event to be a huge success, so the small initial crowd size was a little unnerving.

Side Eyes began playing precisely at 7:15, right on time according to the set schedule posted on Best Coast’s Twitter account earlier that day. I routinely checked this schedule throughout the night to see who would be playing next, and without fail, every band began playing either on time or early, which felt like a rare treat. Most of the concerts I’ve been to that included multiple acts on a shared stage were marred by delays and long intermissions as tech transitioned from one band to the next. At this event, each band played their set, which ranged from 15 minutes at the shortest (Side Eyes) to 35 minutes at the longest (Best Coast), and then the curtains were closed for 15 to 20 minutes while the technical crew prepared for the next band. Meanwhile, an ensemble of DJs played during each intermission period to maintain the crowd’s energy. This event was clearly well planned and well-rehearsed.

As mentioned, Side Eyes opened for a somewhat small crowd. I’ll admit, their vibe was a little strange. I’d summarize their sound as a barrage of guitar and whiny vocals. The main thing I took away from their set was that their bassist looked like Beetlejuice and the hot pink patent leather boots that the lead singer was wearing are the coolest pair of shoes I’ve seen in a long time.

Next on the bill were The Regrettes. This band really impressed me. Before that night I had never listened to their music, but I’d consider myself a converted fan after seeing them play. The strongest song of their set, in my opinion, was “Seashore,” which lead singer Lydia Night dedicated to Donald Trump, the first of many disparaging song dedications that were to occur throughout the night. The band’s sound intermixed an appealing sample of pop with an angsty punk undertone. I was digging it, and so was the crowd.

After The Regrettes came Lovely Bad Things, who regularly tour with Best Coast. They opened with “Space Waste” before transitioning to “I Just Want You to Go Away,” which was fittingly dedicated to Trump. They closed with a new song that had “never been performed live,” a nice treat for the audience.

Next up was MUNA, who recently finished performing with Grouplove on the Big Mess tour. “I Know A Place” felt like an appropriate opener - its lyrics about finding safety and acceptance in the face of adversity seemed to serve as a reminder that Planned Parenthood, although under threat, has a loyal group of supporters who believe in its cause. Lead singer Katie Gavin briefly shared a story of an instance when she and a friend turned to Planned Parenthood in a time of need and then followed the visit with breakfast burritos. The personal story and inclusive lyrics were a nice change of pace and functioned as a much-needed reminder of why this event was occurring and why it’s important to support organizations like Planned Parenthood. On a sidenote, I was really impressed with how well Gavin danced in stilettos and a special award should be given to the band for ‘Best Overall Hair.’

Cosentino returned to the stage to introduce the next band, Veruca Salt. Cosentino stressed that Veruca Salt was hugely influential on her during her teenage years. Louise Post and Nina Gordon were the only two members of the band present, and the duo played a set of five throwback songs. The punk-pop band seemed like a cohesive addition to the lineup, and although their music is from a different alt-rock era, it didn’t seem out of place.

Next up was Grouplove, the apparent crowd favorite of the night, as many of the event’s attendees were wearing Grouplove t-shirts. They carried off of Veruca Salt’s pseudo-punk energy by opening with “Borderlines and Aliens,” followed by a high-energy cover of the Beastie Boys’ “Sabotage.” They then slowed down to play “Heart of Mine” off of their most recent album before finishing off the set with fan-favorites “Ways to Go,” “Tongue Tied,” and finally, “Colours.”

Best Coast was last to take the stage, opening with their hit “Boyfriend,” to which many attendees immediately started singing along. Cosentino later welcomed Liz Phair to the stage, and the two played a couple of songs together. Cosentino told the audience she “felt honored” to be able to say that she’d played a set with the acclaimed songstress. The band then continued to play a number of songs before finishing with “California Nights,” and bidding everyone goodnight.

Overall, the Don’t Sit Down Benefit was defined by the three following ideas:

1. Stick to the schedule.

2. Planned Parenthood is important, we can’t afford to lose it, and

3. Fuck Donald Trump.

I was impressed with how coordinated and organized the event was run, and left the night feeling good about whatever monetary contribution I made to Planned Parenthood by attending the event as well as motivated to continue vocally opposing Trump and Republican lawmakers who threaten similar institutions. I’d say that Cosentino can rest assured that the event was successful.
tags: dont sit down planned parenthood benefit

title: Buscabulla @ The Echoplex (2/27/17)  // Show Review
content:
Written By: Brittany Hewitt

Photos By : Ellenwood EP

Post Date: 3/8/17

An erotic salsa pixie fest is just about what we need at this point in 2017.

Buscabulla graced Echo Park gentrifiers, young Chicano beanie wearers and 30-something-year-old couples out for a weeknight show, with their presence last Monday night at the Echoplex.

It makes perfect sense that Buscabulla, which is slang for ‘troublemaker’ in Spanish, has been all over pop culture lately. Hailing from San Juan and relocating to Brooklyn, they aren’t following the usual patterns of ethereal music.

They’re a match made in heaven, the kind girls who grew up in hoop earrings would try to aspire to. Raquel Berrios wore an OG oversized vintage T-shirt that screams “I was a 90s kid!” while semi-draped in a curtain of tinsel over her left shoulder that made her other half, Luis Alfred Del Valle, look like a beautiful side piece. Effortless and wavy, the audience all finally understood what tinsel is supposed to be used for. Raquel sported a long snaking braid and Berlin-cut bangs. Instead of your usual jean jacket with dirty pins clad, neo-electronic musical duo that has been together since meeting in Los Angeles at a bar a few weeks back, Buscabulla has a genuine, enigmatic chemistry - the only way I can actually believe they’re parents.

My favorite song performed was “Tartaro.” “Tártaro is the nickname of the late salsero and Puerto Rican cult figure Frankie Ruiz, also known as the father of salsa erótica (or erotic salsa, a very popular genre in the ‘80s),” Berrios wrote in a note to The FADER. “The song is a love letter to him, referencing some of his most famous lyrics, many of them about sex motels, extramarital affairs and passionate encounters. The video, which we self-directed, is set at the most famous sex motel in Puerto Rico, Hotel OK, where I went to find inspiration to write this song and channel Ruiz’s 'erotic’ spirit.” 

This track perfectly summed up the energy of the night: playing Candy Land in space while holding a spicy burrito.

Check out their new music, EP II, on all digital platforms, including Apple Music, Spotify and SoundCloud.

http://www.buscabulla.com/

title: Cage the Elephant @ CSUN Valley Performing Arts Center (4/12/2017) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee, Digital Press

Waiting to get into CSU Northridge’s auditorium, I watch a security woman place my phone in what looks like a lime green felt sock, seal said sock with my phone shut inside, then hand it back to me, saying that I will be able to access my phone after the concert has ended. I leave her and head inside the concert hall, trying to see if I can break my phone out of its new container. I cannot.

Tonight’s event is the second stop in Cage the Elephant’s “Live & Unpeeled: The Acoustic Tour.” As the tour’s title suggests, the show will feature acoustic versions of the band’s music and create a stripped down, more intimate atmosphere. Apparently, part of building this atmosphere of intimacy is enforcing a technology free zone. I find my seat and join the rest of the audience, a crowd of people now obliged to converse with each other because none of us can check our phones.

Eventually, the lights dim down and the curtain rises, and it’s Cage the Elephant. The stage is largely bare, with the band members sitting on barstools alongside a string quartet. In the background are a row of lamps that have been adorned with flowers. Though minimally decorated, it’s almost funny to see Cage the Elephant’s stage set-up juxtaposed with the rest of the Valley Performing Arts Center, whose stage I imagine is usually used for events like school plays and academic awards nights instead of rock concerts. I don’t think about this for too long however, because soon there’s a slamming of chords and the kick of the drumbeat and the show has begun.

The opening song is “Sweetie Little Jean,” and lead singer Matt Shultz’s voice shocks me with it’s clarity and beauty. It is powerful but still melodic, melancholy but not whiny. This is my first time seeing the band live, and they sound even better than they do on their LPs. After this first song, Shultz faces the crowd and smiles. “Hey, we’re Cage the Elephant, and tonight’s going to be a little different, is that okay?” The audience roars.

As the show progresses, I realize that the venue is perhaps a better fit for the show than I originally thought. Cage the Elephant’s presence is both theatrically exhilarating and honestly raw, an emotionally potent show that belongs in a concert hall. The band delivers charged performances of “Punchin’ Bag” and “Spiderhead,” and I stand to my feet with the rest of the crowd, awestruck. Shultz is bedecked in a gauzy scarf, snug red cardigan and bright red blazer that looks like it once belonged to Hillary Clinton. He runs back and forth across the stage and bursts into fits of dancing. He moves wildly but with conviction. He moves not in a leisurely dance, and instead moves as if he has to or he’ll go insane trying to stay still. Even when he is sitting down, as he does for gentler tracks like “Telescope,” I can see him leaning forward emphatically and occasionally jumping out of his seat in a moment of passion. Meanwhile, guitarist Brad Shultz and bassist Daniel Tichenor calmly strum their instruments, sipping water slowly in between songs. Lead guitar Nick Bockrath can be caught smiling to himself now and again, as though he also cannot believe how great the night is unfolding.

“Ain’t No Rest for the Wicked,” “Cigarette Daydreams,” and “Back Against the Wall” are incredible, and they bring the house down. I doubt there is a Cage the Elephant show review in existence that hasn’t said this about these songs, but I mention it anyway because it’s true. I marvel at how Shultz delivers these hits as expressively as he does, singing “Ain’t No Rest for the Wicked” as if it’s his first performance of the song and not his thousandth. Other memorable songs are “Hypocrite” and a cover of Wreckless Eric’s “Whole Wide World,” which sounds unusually groovy for a band so prone to an intense, even raucous, sound.

The band transitions to slower songs now, and a stillness unfurls across the stage. Clean and sorrowful guitar notes mark the beginning of “How Are You True,” supplemented later on by the quartet’s violins. The lights dim down and cascade onto Shultz, bathing him in soft, unreal light. “Trouble” is next, then “Shake Me Down,” whose crescendo in the chorus feels mournful despite the crowd cheering and jumping along to the rhythm.

Cage the Elephant tries to conclude with “Come a Little Closer,” but when they exit the audience stays, applauding and calling out for an encore. Only Shultz comes back, first picking up a guitar then abruptly setting it back down. He breaks out into an a cappella ballad that I do not recognize. He sounds clear and a little undone. Standing slouched in his little red blazer, I think he is glowing. He finishes the song, waves, and walks off stage.

The lights in the auditorium come on, and the audience staggers to the exits. Watching the concert had felt like being transported to another world, and it was a little odd to suddenly be back in Northridge, searching through my bag for the green pouch holding my phone. I get my phone unlocked and leave the venue. I drive home. Already I wish I was back, listening to the bass and the strings and that single, clear voice singing, “I’ll keep my eyes fixed on the sun.”

title: American Teen - Khalid // Album Review
content:
Written By: Bianca Brown

Post Date: 4/6/17

Feeling lonely or nostalgic for a past love, and need the perfect playlist to fit your simpin’ needs? Or maybe you’re more of a free-spirit and crave songs that encourage adventure, while also allowing you to embrace your young age and naivety? Either way, the 19-year-old, up-and-coming R&B artist, Khalid, and his debut album American Teen are exactly what you’re looking for.

Every track on this album that was released on March 3 will leave listeners reminiscing about the past, whether the focus is on the relatively carefree days of one’s teenage years or on past relationships and heartbreaks. Khalid made it obvious that he made American Teen with the intention of incorporating both overwhelming instances of nostalgia and heartache: “The album is a compilation of my youth. The mistakes I’ve made, the heartbreaks I went through, the love that I got, and all the love that I lost. A lot of my songs are about loneliness and losing relationships. Even the ones that are happy, there’s a lonely undertone to them.” (Hot New Hip Hop 2017, March 2).

The intense level of sentimentality that he speaks of is certainly present in songs like “Coasting” and “Shot Down.” The lyrics in the first verse of “Coasting” are emotional and relatable enough to leave listeners feeling as if they’d just taken a knife to the heart: “Maybe you weren’t the one for me/But deep down I wanted you to be/I’ll still see you in my dreams/All the things that I did for you, just wasn’t it for you.” Khalid’s beautifully crafted lyrics, coupled with his unique and divinely haunting vocal riffs, will have everyone hitting that ‘repeat one song’ button quicker than Kylie Jenner ‘premiering’ his most famous song, “Famous,” on her Snapchat last May.

For the free-spirits with wild hearts, tracks “Young Dumb & Broke,” “Location,” and “American Teen” are the songs for you. “Young Dumb & Broke” features more of a ‘young, wild, and free’ vibe, with its slow yet upbeat tempo and care-free, drug-referencing lyrics: “I’m so high at the moment/I’m so caught up in this/Yeah, we’re just young, dumb and broke/But we still got love to give.” “Location,” the song that launched the 19-year-old’s career features a gorgeous xylophone-sounding instrument that carries the song’s cheery and overall ‘fun, relaxed summer romance’ feeling.

Overall, American Teen is an album that someone might imagine as the soundtrack to their own melodramatic summer of high school. Jam packed with songs longing for a non-committal fling, sorrows over past love affairs, overcoming these love affairs, and a general idea of jovial happiness and freedom, American Teen sets the standard for a plethora of other up-and-coming artists planning to release music this spring.

title: Spotlight of the Week // Girl Crush
content:
Post Date: 4/1/17

2017 has already become a historic year in terms of gender and feminism, as women across the country are working to bring light to their many diverse stories. Hear their voices by tuning in to Girl Crush, an hour celebrating womxn who make an impact here at UCLA and across the world. The show features interviews with women with an understanding that being a woman cannot be encompassed by just one story - as host DJ Yikes! says, “This is a platform for women from all backgrounds and experiences.” A highlight from previous interviews was a discussion with Rachel and Helen Lee, who (along with being members of UCLA Radio!) have been making efforts to end the California tax on pads, tampons, and other menstrual products not considered a “necessity” by the state - “Their story was incredible, and their combined energy really brought the show to life during 9th Week!”

Tune in to Girl Crush Fridays at 9 p.m. and during our late night programming at uclaradio.com!

title: President Trump and the Dangers Behind Conspiracy Theories // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Brianna Klipp

Post Date: 3/29/17

Just a year ago, you could walk into any hipster coffee shop in Silverlake and overhear overly ironic outcasts bonding over the idea that a mystical reality exists. “A secular religion, of sorts,” they say. Back then, conspiracy theories survived in the dark corners of the internet where trolls spent hours connecting the dots to create a scenario in which our believed premise of existence isn’t true. Every symbolic gesture, action, and consequence was part of a grand scheme to control and manipulate for a larger purpose. But for the sake of what? No one knew. The very act of discussing secret societies made you feel that you were part of one. We become so intrigued by the idea of an entity being able to have so much power in predicting the unintended consequences of our actions that we don’t realize how much power we give to these over-exaggerated narratives as we allow them to reshape history and culture.

The dim lighting of the café blankets a shadow across the hipster’s face as stone cold expressions and solemn nods react exaggeratedly to this newly discovered reality. This reality, taken shape in the form of a theory, grounded by speculation and coincidence. In the words of Socrates, it’s true, the only thing we know, is that we know nothing. But that was then, and now that Donald Trump is president, I believe we are entering into an era where objective knowledge has become a non-falsifiable entity used to manipulate US citizens to turn us against one another.

We’ve seen the signs of conspiracy theories on the rise: the recent wiretapping scandal, voter fraud, rapists crossing the border illegally, “Pizzagate,” and the infamous “alternative facts” used to propagate the notion that citizens and government officials alike cannot be trusted. President Trump fired his National Security adviser this past February, Michael Flynn, not for conspiring with the Russians, but instead because he couldn’t “trust him.”  

Trump has created a narrative to suggest that any evidence that negates him is part of some larger scheme to sabotage him. As a result, he’s allowed for a non-falsifiable existence to take shape, wherein his beliefs – his conspiracy theories – can never be deemed as incorrect because every piece of evidence becomes part of the grand plot.

As confusion, paranoia, and combative culture have created a divide amongst races, political parties, and families, I argue that it is important now more than ever to disregard the grand scheme Trump suggests, and focus on the objective reality we can observe and prove to be true. We are entering a presidency where deranged tweets in the wee hours of the night overshadow  threats to health care and other public services may affect the lives of millions.

As millennials, we need to find a way to be creative and truly reach across the aisle to learn about other ideologies rather than allowing a master schemer to set us against one another. The first steps to fascism include causing disruption, distrust, and chaos amongst civilians - we therefore must focus on the bigger picture and not allow these conspiracy theories to cause a regime shift which undermines American values.

title: Sidewalks and Skeletons @ The Airliner (3/7/17) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Julian Zhou

Post Date: 3/20/17

Is witch house a real genre or is it merely an advertising tool to sell ninja-goth streetwear? This is the existential question facing witch house creators, evident from the final leg of the Sidewalks and Skeletons US tour that I attended March 7.

People often criticize witch house as being a formulaic, gimmicky offshoot of synth pop that primarily consists of impressions of Crystal Castles – obnoxiously distorted synths, compressed drums, rhythmic glitches, nu-rave chord patterns that have an almost defiantly amateurish quality, and vocals that alternate between high-pass filtered screaming or shoegazey whispers. Like many of the most popular witch house producers, the UK based Sidewalks and Skeletons is skilled at recreating this eerie, danceable combination. The primary addition that Sidewalks, and openers Brothel and Resonata, bring to the table is the incorporation of trap rhythms. While this sounds interesting in theory, the result often feels like the equivalent of a 2spooky, Halloween high school party while the VHS series plays softly in the background. The most disappointing thing about the direction that witch house seems poised to take is that both dark synth pop and trap are interesting genres individually. Yet somehow, Sidewalks and Skeletons and other producers have fallen to the insane clown posse curse – the inability for dark “edgy” rock music to incorporate black music tropes without sounding incredibly corny. When paired with haunting synth chords, the exaggerated tempo swings of a kick drum followed by twenty hi-hats create an effect that is not unlike the cringe-inducing beat drops that characterize dubstep. That said, let me quickly add that I love a lot of early, more straightforward Sidewalks and Skeletons singles (”Goth” is pure Crystal Castles fan service along the lines of “Suffocation,” "Pap Smear,” "Courtship Dating” etc.), and to producer Jake Lee’s credit, his use of trap beats in songs like "Frozen Star” are more tasteful and sincere than many of his peers. His music has a brooding, wounded quality, often evoking a foggy graveyard stroll more than a foggy Rick Owens photo shoot in Little Tokyo.

Nevertheless, I cannot help but wonder if Sidewalks and Skeletons, and witch house generally, suffers from embracing its post-ironic darkness. How many inverted crosses on oversized black t-shirts does it take before the symbol becomes a fetish, devoid of the philosophical angst that makes goth interesting in the first place? Crystal Castles may have always been self-consciously edgelord – but the lyrics were at least thoughtful, cryptic, feminist, and politically confrontational. With that stripped away, and the production fused with appropriated trap beats, it can be hard to take witch house seriously. Of course, many witch house producers may revel in this repudiation of critical values. The microgenre primarily exists on SoundCloud, which has a culture that is proudly anti-formal and anti-critical. The benefit of this is that its participants have summoned a unique brand and produced some extremely catchy dance music. However, without critical attention, its fan base sometimes encourages the worst aspects of the genre.

At last night’s show, for every moment of pure, tragic beauty, there was a moment where a promoter was encouraging me to “jump the fuck up.” As if that was not enough to ruin one’s immersion, there was a guy parked left of stage who took every moment of relative quiet – which should presumably be used for the audience to reflect on mortality – to yell “FUCK YEAH!” as loud as possible. My friend, a fellow sadboy, asked this man to stop. The man proceeded to pat him on the back and then yell “FUCK YEAH!” in his face. This is of course, fine, and I am loathe to police anyone’s enjoyment of a show, even if many of the audience members drove from out of state to attend. Rather, this demonstrates that witch house’s audience mirrors its artistic schizophrenia. For every Wiccan, there were also two ravebros present. Ultimately, I had a good time. Picture the rave from the second Matrix movie, but with more fog; a bit like being on the inside of a spooky vape. Whatever its problems, the strength of witch house’s single power is undeniable and during the best moments of the show, everyone was having a wholesome, angsty time.

title: Pathos - Yeule // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alana Enriquez

Post Date: 3/15/17

Two years after her debut EP, Yeule has returned with Pathos, a delicate ode to the raw emotions that come with mutual longing and quiet suffering. Releasing in spurts on SoundCloud, the Singaporean UK-based artist displayed clear growth and depth even in her rough demos. Unlike her earlier work, Pathos presents a subtle sexiness and maturity paired with lo-fi motifs that produce six cloud-like tracks that flow, but are clearly independent. She opens with “Desire,” a soft track reminiscent of her angelic freshman release, but with a new energy motivated by substantial yearning. The track clicks and bumps while immersed in airy vocals that remain consistent throughout the entire EP. However, the starry instrumental “Soul Catcher” claims its place as well, providing a brief intermission marked by twinkles, echoes, and repetition. These are standard elements present throughout Yeule’s small, yet memorable discography, with each track serving to provide the listener with an escape that is easily accessible and drenched in emotion. Perhaps the most divergent track is “Angel’s Wings,” which features Japanese vocals and upbeat rhythms, but the general feeling remains the same - Yeule is embracing her listeners, soothing them with her own emotional experiences and matured sensibilities. “About Her” is perhaps the most effective at expressing sensuality and projecting astral sounds. Yeule quietly requests tender intimacy (“Breathe me into your lungs”) overlaid with sparkly vocal samples and chiming bells. It is a lovely start to the end of the EP, filled with concentrated warmth unique to bedroom productions. The final track, “Promise,” is just what its title implies - it is a hopeful instrumental that reverberates with breathy samples from Yeule juxtaposed by tonal bursts that collect and disperse throughout. “Promise” ends rather abruptly, appropriately contrasting with the steady flow of the EP and drawing Pathos to a close. The entirety of the EP displays Yeule’s growth as a producer while also providing a unique sensory experience that is comfortable yet provocative, leaving a lasting warmth with the listener.

title: Can TV Bring America Together?
content:
Written By: Maya Khuzam

Post Date: 3/9/17

“Can television bring America together?” A panel hosted by Zocalo Public Square and The Smithsonian gathered at the Landmark Theaters in Los Angeles to discuss this daunting question. John Bowman, writer and producer of Martin, opened up the conversation with, “God knows I’ve tried,” a sentiment that each panelist can empathize with. As they each described their work, it seemed that the real question they were tackling was, “How can we represent this marginalized community without scaring off the opposition?”

Dan O’Shannon, former executive producer of Modern Family, explained how Modern Family was able to do this successfully through the relationship of gay main characters, Cam and Mitchell. On why the couple never kissed, O’Shannon comments, “We wanted to have America embrace them as a loving couple, and as real empathetic human beings, first, and as a gay couple second.”

Shows don’t want to reinforce Hollywood’s liberal reputation with clear political statements, but instead create a conversation on screen about political issues. Jennie Snyder Urman explained how Jane the Virgin approached abortion by having a pro-choice character and her traditional pro-life mother play out the conflict on screen. Similarly, Gloria Calderon Kellett, co-creator of One Day at a Time wanted to show the ‘totality’ of coming out by presenting the journey family members go through to process the main character’s sexuality. “We wanted to let the audience know that this girl was going to be supported and be ok, but that maybe not everyone was gonna have that perfect warm response to it.”

By the end of the panel, it seemed that there wasn’t a definite answer to whether television can bridge the gaps between Americans, but that people seek representation through television, and creators have the power to begin conversations in American households if they tell stories correctly.

title: 4 Political Podcasts for the Trump Era // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Shivali Gowda

Post Date: 4/16/17 

The 2016 election was a big catalyst for the podcast industry. Because more people are engaged than ever in the current political climate, podcasts are a way to get the news through an in-depth discussion. The problem I’ve had with getting news in the past is that, if you’re busy for one week and don’t have time to keep up, there’s no way to learn what is happening from the beginning. By that time, the news has usually progressed to analysis about the analysis. Some websites seek to fix this problem, like Vox, with explainers. But one thing podcasts particularly do is give you more context to the event that’s happening. Because many of them only tape once a week, it is a good recap on what is happening, how it happened, and where it is going, all for an hour or so of your time. I was among the many people who started listening to podcasts because of the 2016 election. Because of this I wanted to review and recommend a few political podcasts.

1. The Weeds

This podcast is hosted by Vox’s Ezra Klein, Matt Yglesias, and Sarah Kliff. This is my favorite podcast by far because the hosts are very knowledgeable about the policy details they talk about. Kliff specifically is one of the most informed political reporters on healthcare and it is enlightening to listen to on why the Republican healthcare plan was flawed and what is wrong with Obamacare and possible avenues to fix it. This podcast is great if you want to understand policies instead of simply listening to your weekly news. Their views are liberal, as Vox generally is, but they are not hyper-partisan and analyze policies on a fact basis.

2. Slate Political Gabfest

This one is almost tied with The Weeds for my favorite podcast for a variety of reasons. The first is that the hosts are not afraid to disagree with one another. It is hosted by Emily Bazelon (writer for the New York Times Magazine), David Plotz (CEO of Atlas Obscura and former editor of Slate), and John Dickerson (host of “Face the Nation”). Bazelon and Plotz get in arguments about various issues, from trusting police to Supreme Court cases. The arguments are constructive and even though I find myself usually agreeing with Bazelon, it is interesting to see the other side of the argument pointed out by someone who is also left-leaning. I also like this podcast because they provide perspective outside of the immediate time of an event. Dickerson brings up many historical parallels that are useful in understanding context. Their podcast is also one of the oldest political podcasts, starting back in 2005.

3. Pod Save America

This was one of the first political podcasts I began listening to during the 2016 election. I really liked the discussions between former Obama speechwriter Jon Favreau and former Obama Senior Advisor Dan Pfeiffer when the show began, and when former Obama speechwriter Jon Lovett came on as a guest, I really wanted him to host the show with the other two. Eventually, they created two shows: one with Favreau and Pfeiffer, and the other with Favreau, Lovett, and Tommy Vietor, former Obama NSC Spokesman. The hosts have great chemistry, they are really funny, and they provide an inside perspective. However, they have since become their own company, Crooked Media, and begun to do more podcasts more often, and although I love their content, it makes me uncomfortable that they are “cashing in” on Trump’s election and that their discussions generally take place within the context of the two or three days of news they’re covering. However, I would still recommend this podcast, especially for people who are looking to become more active in politics, whether it’s through protesting or calling your congressman.

4. 538’s Election Podcast

This podcast is fun and nerdy. The host is Jody Avirgan, who is a professional in the audio space, and he talks to Nate Silver, Harry Enten, and Clare Malone. They have great conversations about polls and stats about current events. The humorous banter also makes it a great listen and they bring on informed guests to talk about specific news items, like the power of protests. I like that they bring a lot of news down to the numbers, as it provides a different perspective from general political podcasts.

title: Insecticides Can Have Disconcerting Effects on Melatonin Levels // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Margaret Gallagher 

Post Date: 4/12/17

Researchers from the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology at the University of Buffalo have published findings that demonstrate that carbamate insecticides target receptors in the human brain for the neurohormone melatonin.

Melatonin is a hormone that is naturally produced by the pineal gland. It regulates cycles of sleep and wakefulness by inducing drowsiness, when it is released in the brain. It is also synthetically produced and used medically as a sleep aid.

Dr. Marina Popovska-Gorevski, Dr. Margarita L. Dubocovich, and Dr. Rajendram V. Rajnarayanan found that two carbamate compounds, carbaryl and carbofuran, mimic the chemical structure of melatonin. This allows them to attach to melatonin receptors in the brain, producing the same drowsy effect on the human brain as a release of melatonin.

Concern already exists regarding the medical use of melatonin, with research showing that exposure to melatonin in excess of the amount produced naturally in the brain can create a heightened tolerance to its effects. This means that people who take melatonin to help them sleep actually end up less able to sleep on their own, as their brain does not naturally produce enough melatonin to have an effect on them.

Carbamate compounds are found in many commonly used insecticides, including Temik, Sevin, and over 190 other chemicals registered for use in the United States. Though many of these products have been shown to be highly toxic to humans and other animals, this is the first evidence of their adverse effects on the healthy function of basic regulatory processes.

title: u stole my heart - High Sunn // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alana Enriquez

Post Date: 4/7/17

High Sunn, a five-man project hailing from San Francisco, has been one of the more prolific bedroom pop outfits of the past year. They released over ten EPs, albums, and singles since July 2016, with yet another EP set to release in May of this year. Their latest release, u stole my heart, is truly representative of the band’s unusually frequent, yet quality content that is consistent in form (quick paced romantic surf pop tracks) and intended function (making me cry, at least in my head). The album opens with “Hold Me Tight,” an ode to adolescent obsession fueled by a heavy beat and lead singer Justin Cheromiah’s hollering vocals. It effectively characterizes what is to come: synthesizers, harmonic oohs and ahhs, and a hauntingly relatable level of angst.

The second track presents elements that return to High Sunn’s base, but with a heavier emphasis on instrumentation — specifically percussion — and developing a unified atmosphere. The album continues with a flowing stream of twinkling guitars, soft electronic bumps, and hopeful requests for the affections of a universal crush. Said requests come to represent different forms of desire, with tracks such as “smol doggo” cheerfully imagining an outing to Chinatown contrasting with “spit on me,” a masochistic plea for physical contact, whether mutual or otherwise.

Despite these contrasting themes, the base sound of the two tracks remains the same, creating an empathetic listening experience that encapsulates young love: confusion and a lot happening at once, despite the general sentiment remaining the same. High Sunn continues with this pattern, taking short breaks to slow things down in tracks such as “In Your Bed,” which centers around melancholic intimacy over a fluid, synthetic beat.

The album ends on a similar note with “Taste My Sadness,” which features a glittering piano and sweetened vocals from Cheromiah that softly sigh throughout the four-minute track. It’s a proper summary of High Sunn’s usual thematic focus: love, loss, and lots of tears, all placed in a scintillating and dreamy pop package.

title: I Decided. - Big Sean // Album Review
content:
Written By: Ela Talu

Post Date: 4/3/17

Contrasting from his earlier works, I Decided. expresses the mature and grown up Big Sean through his stages of fame and success. The album can be seen as one of the most solid works from Sean, as the self-explanatory title of the album suggests he has become one of the greatest rappers of his generation. The album is a declaration to all the people who disregarded his talent back in the day and a praise to all the supporters who believed in his talent and perseverance. In every sense Dark Sky Paradise could be seen as a stronger album, but I Decided. is definitely a more meaningful one, speaking about how Sean became famous and how he cares more about the respect he receives from his loved ones than the money he makes.

Starting with the lyrics “Last night took a L, but tonight I bounce back,” in “Bounce Back,” Sean suggests that every success starts with a loss and the important thing is how a true champion handles that loss and uses it for greater accomplishments. The Metro Boomin collaboration also had an impact to make it a hit way before the album dropped. He teams up further in the album with his superior Detroit native, Eminem, and claims that to be at the top one does not need help from others in “No Favors.” Starting from “Light,” featuring Jeremih, Sean talks about seeing and using your inner potential. The album moves from coming out strong from your losses to finally bossing up in the big league.

From “Owe Me” to “Voices In My Head / Stick To the Plan,” we see Sean  questioning his past relationships and his present realizations about his inner self. He says, “I’m hangin’ halfway off the balcony,” acknowledging it isn’t only about money, sex, or power but about reality, relationships, and respect throughout his career. The distinction of these particular songs can also be seen musically with more mellow beats and singing.

Sean creates another strong hit track featuring Migos with “Sacrifices,” where he says, “I came a long way from that Marvin and Chardonnay,” rapping about his first official platinum track and how he has made many sacrifices to be where he is right now and improve his music. With “Bigger Than Me,” Sean sums up the overall message of the album, saying his job is not done now that he is at the top and he should and will continue giving back to the people who look up to him and have supported him to be here.

Top Tracks: “Bounce Back,” “No Favors,” “Halfway Off the Balcony,” “Sacrifices,” “Owe Me”

title: Obamacare Survives as Republicans Fail to Unify // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Conner Lund

Post Date: 3/30/17

The “American Health Care Act,” the proposed healthcare bill championed by House Speaker Paul Ryan, has seen its demise after the bill was pulled per Trump’s request, leaving doubt within the GOP party now struggling to find a silver lining.

The bill, set to replace Obamacare, had devastating consequences for many Americans. Shortly after the bill was made public, the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office released a report that put the bill under scrutiny. The report found that 24 million more Americans would be uninsured by 2026 under the proposed bill. In total, 52 million people could be uninsured by 2026.

As Ryan stood alone at the podium, it was clear that he was disappointed in the GOP and the White House for not agreeing on the future of healthcare, something the party and Trump had expressed as one of the first and most pressing issues facing the new administration. Now the Republicans are struggling to regain their legitimacy as a legislative force after their first attempt at governing ended so abruptly; starting with a loss means it will be an uphill battle to unify under differing conservative ideals.

While Ryan was certainly passionate about the new bill, many conservatives and liberals alike were not. The CBO findings proved to be quite alarming to middle and lower-class Americans, as well as the elderly. Planned Parenthood would have seen harsher restrictions and regulations regarding public coverage, while the top tenth of a  percent of earners with an average income of $3.9 million or more would have seen an average tax cut of $207,000 a year.

More worrisome is the backlash the Trump administration is facing after Trump’s repeated claims that repealing Obamacare would be one of the first measures of his presidency. Now, Trump must somehow explain the GOP implosion after their first major act came to such an abrupt ending with so much backlash. While under fire, Trump cited the Democrats as the reason the bill was pulled.

While Ryan, the champion of the bill, seemed passionate about what this could mean for Americans, it was clear that he stood alone. During the press conference after the bill was pulled, Ryan defeatedly said that if the party couldn’t agree on a new alternative to Obamacare, then Obamacare would stay as “the law of the land”.

title: Trump’s Wiretapping Accusations: What We Know // UCLA Radio News
content:
Written By: Angel Aparicio

Post Date: 3/20/17

On March 4, President Donald Trump set off yet another media firestorm when he seemingly out of the blue tweeted that former president Barack Obama had Trump Tower’s “wires tapped” before his winning the presidency. “Terrible! Just found out that Obama had my ‘wires tapped’ in Trump Tower just before the victory. Nothing found. This is McCarthyism!” the president tweeted, before continuing to post, “Is it legal for a sitting president to be “wire tapping” a race for president prior to an election? Turned down by court earlier. A NEW LOW!” and, “How low has President Obama gone to tap my phones during the very sacred election process. This is Nixon/Watergate. Bad (or sick) guy!”

The claims were largely unsubstantiated, as Trump has yet to offer any evidence, but speculation has focused on a Breitbart article published on March 3, the day before Trump’s respective tweets, that outlined the steps conservative radio host Mark Levin claimed then-President Obama took to bug Trump Tower. This begs the question of whether Trump trusts far-right news outlets over the United States government intelligence community, as the POTUS has offered no evidence or retraction for the claims despite government agencies acknowledging there is no proof. Furthermore, the tweets mark the first time a sitting president has made such an explosive, unsubstantiated claim against their predecessor.

Two days later, Sean Spicer, White House press secretary, did little to assuage the situation when he said he would “let the tweets speak for themselves” at a press conference. Nearly a week later, on the 14th, Spicer offered slight clarity on what exactly the president meant by those claims, saying Trump did not literally mean wiretapping; rather, he used the word to mean surveillance in general.

This mirrors the behavior of other governments under “strongman” leadership, like Rodrigo Duterte’s government in the Philippines, which has defended his bombastic claims of murdering drug dealers by stating his claims were rhetorical, and not meant to be taken literally. And though Trump has not explicitly doubled down on wiretapping specifically, he says his administration would be “submitting things before the committee very soon,” apparently referencing the House Intelligence Committee. Though no evidence has been presented or made public, Trump remains steadfast and seemingly confident in his accusations. Either a sitting president had a presidential candidate’s headquarters bugged, or a sitting president is slipping into paranoia and being fed misinformation - only time will tell.

title: March Show of the Month: Nü Indigo
content:
Interviewer: Alexa Lee

Post Date: 3/17/17

Your show description mentions “elevating consciousness through music, good vibes, and positive messages.” If you wouldn’t mind explaining a little further, what does it mean to have an elevated conscious, and how does listening to Nü Indigo help someone acquire one?

Elevating consciousness means to become more aware of everything around and within oneself. It is important to be conscious of all the information and influences that we constantly take in everyday, especially with the internet. Often times people can be misguided or misinterpret the things they see or hear. For example, a person can become misguided in trying to determine what success is by coming across a “successful” person’s Instagram page. The vision for Nü Indigo is to share mentorship experiences from people who have developed an artistry within their craft to foster a better understanding of success.

How do you spread your good vibes and make radio a shared experience if you’re on air by yourself addressing an audience you can’t see?

I once heard that you become the average of the five people you spend the most time with. This is why I make an effort to be around people who are positively aspiring and actively making their visions come true. I figured Nü Indigo could be a good platform to share the experience of being around these types of individuals with others. Even if the audience can’t be seen, I believe there are many values that the audience can draw from these conversations. Music and hearing a message are among the few things in the world that can put a person in a better feeling place regardless of where they are. Hearing a certain song or message can completely change the course of a person’s day. Therefore I try to use that power of music and message to improve any listener’s day, even just by a little.

Talk about one of your favorite guests you’ve had on the show so far. Also, who is one person you wish to have on as a guest in the future?

Every single one of my guests have been so amazing and such a blessing to share a conversation with. Off the top of my head, the ones in particular that stand out would have to be Natey, Lido, and Tyler Cole. Natey is a super talented singer/songwriter/producer, and he shared how to really just enhance the quality of living. Some of the things he shared in our conversation have personally gotten me through some of my tougher times. Lido was also really cool to have, as I’ve been a huge fan of his music and we got to go into depth about his creative songwriting process. Tyler Cole was also a cool guest as we briefly got into conversation about Indigo and what it is. Many of my guests have come as a surprise, so I am looking forward to see what surprises await in the future.

The graphic designs you have for your show are incredibly sick. What was the creative process behind Nü Indigo’s artwork?

Without a doubt. The credit for the artwork goes to my super talented roommate Michelle, who has helped so much in making dope fliers every week. You can check out her website at: http://www.michellevaquilar.com/ or Instagram: @meeeeeshell to view other projects she has worked on!

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

I guess some things that people should know about me is that I take everything as a learning experience and that my goal is to constantly create what I’d personally like to see in this world. I am personally a huge fan of motivational podcasts. But I realized that many of these podcasts were primarily based around entrepreneurship, and I could not find any that were purely focused on the creative fields. I thought that it would’ve been very helpful growing up if something like Nü Indigo existed, allowing artists to directly give advice on things such as how to get started, how to find internships, creative processes, and even controversial topics like whether school is truly necessary, all while giving the artists a platform to tell their story without it being twisted like many media outlets do.

Follow Nü Indigo on Facebook and listen in every Wednesday at 3 p.m. with DJ Medafiziks every on uclaradio.com!

title: Shannon and the Clams @ the Echoplex (2/26) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Mackenzi Elias

Post Date: 3/5/17

Shannon and the Clams made a stop at the Echoplex this past Sunday on their way back to their hometown Oakland. Opening up for them was their own keyboard player, Will Sprott, and cumbia-punk band Thee Commons. Will played guitar and sang with a female bassist and female drummer, who were noticeably out of synch at times. The trio apologized at the end for sounding a little off, admitting that they weren’t actually a well established band and hadn’t practiced in a while. Nonetheless, the trio’s beachy 60’s sound made for a good segway into the more chaotic performance put on by Thee Commons.

I’ve legitimately never seen more energy on a stage than what I saw during their set. Thee Commons, a trio from East L.A., puts a Latin twist on garage rock to produce a unique psychedelic cumbia punk sound. They reminded me a lot of Sublime, except their songs were less reggae and more rock and roll influenced. Unfortunately I don’t know any of their songs so I can’t identify what exactly they played, but all of it was very fast tempoed, upbeat, and loud. Accompanying the wild music was a colorful, erratic light show that illuminated the band’s eccentric stage antics; both guitarists played dramatically and enthusiastically, darting around the stage and dropping to their knees as if the music was literally overtaking them. At one point they both put on wolf masks and prowled around the stage, which was creepy as hell but actually very cool. The energy in the crowd matched that of the band - people were moshing fearlessly to the aggressive music. At the end, a bunch of people joined the band on stage, including someone in a really freaky looking gorilla costume. Thee Commons was definitely the most wild act of the night.

I’d say that the headliner, Shannon and the Clams, was pretty much a combination of their two openers. They played a very diverse set, performing some of their upbeat, bubblegum songs off Gone By the Dawn and Dreams in the Rat House that sound like they could be from a 60’s pop  album. In contrast to these, they showed off their garage rock side, playing harsher sounding songs that incited overwhelming moshing in the crowd, as opposed to the twisting and dancing that occurred during the doo-wop songs. They also played a couple new tracks, which were a little slower and more folky than the others, meaning that they probably have a new album coming out soon (yay!). They didn’t give titles for any of the new songs, but Cody said to the crowd before the first one, “You better like it.”

Although the overall moods of the songs were different, lead singers Shannon and Cody were consistently impressive throughout the show. Shannon’s low, husky growl paired perfectly with Cody’s high-pitched, raspy voice, and it’s crazy to me that they’re able to recreate the harmonies from their records so well in concert. They complemented each other in not only their voices, but in their wacky appearances as well. Shannon was wearing a funky, 40’s reminiscent sailor outfit, and Cody donned a cape that looked like it was made out of burlap.Their demeanor was definitely calmer than those of Thee Commons, but the passion was evidently still there. Shannon was such a sweetheart, and gave out little pieces of advice and adoration throughout their set. Overall, the show was entertaining, energetic, and diverse. It was definitely a Sunday night well spent.

title: WATERS @ The Roxy (6/8/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Lillian Stanwick 

WATERS dropped their third studio album Something More! on May 19, just three weeks before their show at The Roxy with openers Fast Friends and NVDES. The night at The Roxy was meant to be a release show for the new album. Something More! has more pop intonations in it than the two previous albums WATERS has put out. The singles “Hiccups” and “Stand By You” border on bubblegum pop, a quality I wouldn’t necessarily consider to be positive. With that in mind, I was apprehensive about their show, fearing that their set would be a hot mess of over-produced pop.

When I arrived at The Roxy just before 10 p.m., synthpop artist NVDES was playing their song “I Want to Make Out at the Gay Club.” As someone who dislikes the use of synthesizers in almost any capacity, hearing the end of their set did little to appease my hesitations about the show. NVDES finished around 10 p.m., and the curtain was lowered on the stage to allow the crew to set up for WATERS. The audience stirred for around 15 minutes. It was quiet enough to have a conversation without raising your voice considerably. Many patrons headed to the bar to refill their drinks.

When the curtain rose at 10:15 p.m., the members of WATERS were already standing on stage, prepared to play, which was surprising; I think most were expecting a grand entrance of some sort. The crew had added bunches of colorful balloons to the stage as decoration. Keyboardist Sara Ann DaMert introduced the set by throwing a bouquet of flowers into the audience, giving the band a whimsical air.

WATERS opened with a song I didn’t recognize, probably off of their new album. The songs they played throughout the set were mostly from Something More! and their second album What’s Real. However, the band hinted on Twitter before the show that they would be playing one song from their first album Out in the Light. I was expecting them to play “For the One,” instead they played “O Holy Break of Day,” which I favor. I would say it was their strongest song of the night.

From Something More!, the band played their more popular songs, including “Hiccups,” “Molly is a Babe,” “Something More,” “Modern Dilemma,” and my personal favorite from the album, “You Don’t Know What You Want.” But I must say their verbal intro for “You Don’t Know What You Want” was rather paltry. “This is a song about someone who doesn’t know what they want,” frontman Van announced to the audience. However, I did like the way they approached their encore. “This is the part where we pretend to go off stage, and then you get really loud, so we come back onstage,” Van deadpanned. From What’s Real the band played “Got to My Head,” “I Feel Everything,” and “Mom and Dad’s,” among others. I surprised they didn’t play fan favorite “What’s Real,” and disappointed that they didn’t play one of my personal favorites, “Stupid Games.”

Something that stood out to me throughout the night was DaMert’s rather dramatic performance. She was almost comically expressive, in one case imitating having hiccups as the band announced the song “Hiccups.” In another instance, she pulled on the back of her hair to mimic sinking as Van sang the lyric “feels like I’m always sinking,” during the song “Got to My Head.” Her playful expressions were almost over the top for the small venue. That, paired with her bedazzled makeup, gave her an almost clownish persona.

WATERS’ new album sounds like a work of playful pop, devoid of the austere tracks that they included on their first release, Out in the Light. It’s a development that I do not prefer, but it has evidently found an audience among the bubbly patrons who attended The Roxy. Despite my slight dissatisfaction, I believe that their new album will grow their fan base and lead to more people attending their spirited live shows.

title: Crisis Man - Crisis Man S/T CS // Album Review
content:
Written by Gabriel Cortina

This ST marks the debut of Crisis Man, the new project of Ceremony front man Ross Farrar. The band also features members from Acrylics and Violent Change.

While the influences of all three bands are apparent in this release (Acrylics especially), I think the only way to truly do Crisis Man justice is to set all personal feelings for the three bands aside while listening and instead hold Crisis man to its own light. That being said, this is a solid release.

With the title track “Crisis Man,” it is immediately apparent what kind of sound the band is going for. This release is raw, straight-forward punk rock at its best. Fans of Ceremony will have no problem recognizing Ross’s unique vocal style, which matches the band’s Bay Area punk style perfectly. The tracks in this album flow into each other seamlessly, which is a double edged sword in itself as no song stands out in particular, but the overall feel of the album is consistent. I feel the production in this album is also noteworthy. I was afraid this release would be overproduced but the band decided to go with a stripped-back, garage-esque recording style that compliments their brand of punk perfectly. The guitars are messy (and I say that in the best way possible), the bass is punchy, the drums are loud, and the vocals are angry. This is everything one would want from a Bay Area punk release in 2017.

The only real drawback of this album is that while it is good, it does not necessarily do anything new. While I feel that the band knew exactly what sound they wanted to go for and did so with precision, they failed to really bend the form of the genre and make it into something that is their own. So, while I do think this a very solid release it is not one that I think is particularly significant to the genre moving forward as a whole. Regardless, I would highly recommend checking it out and I very much so look forward to seeing what this band has to offer in the future

8/10

title: UCLA Radio Sports Predicts the 2017 NBA Finals
content:
Faizan Malik

Noah Graham/NBAE via Getty Images

Prediction: Warriors in 6

With the addition of Kevin Durant the Warriors are nearly unguardable, and the Cavs have had some defensive struggles already this year. The Cavs only have one great defender (LeBron), while the warriors have four of the best offensive players in the league. For the Cavs to win they’d need their role players (Shumpert, Smith, and Jefferson) to play flawlessly.

X-Factor: Kevin Durant

MVP: LeBron James, unless the NBA isn’t willing to give it to a player on the losing team. In that case, Kevin Durant.

Ben Sorenson

NBAE/Getty Images

Prediction: Warriors in 7

Last year it took the greatest finals performance ever from Lebron James, leading in every statistical category, just to bring the series to seven games and it still came down to the last two minutes. The Warriors came up short because they didn’t have a guy who could get them a basket when the offense couldn’t get going. This offseason the Warriors added Kevin Durant who can get that last bucket.

What would it take for the CAVS to win? Lebron replicating his performance from last year, Kevin Love continuing to be an offensive presence, and Kyrie Irving showing us all that he is better than Steph Curry.

MVP: KD who averages 30, 8, and 5 with 2 blocks per game

Trace Jansen

Gregory Shamus/NBAE/Getty Images

Prediction: Cavaliers in 7

I think the Cavaliers are going to win because they’re playing with house money. They’ll leave it all on the court. They don’t have the pressure that the Warriors have. The Warriors collapsed under pressure last year, and they’ll do it again this year. Lebron is the best player in the series, K-Love is playing like his old, all-star self, Kyrie has the clutch gene, and the veterans off the bench will prove to be key additions to the team.

X-Factor: Kevin Love continuing to perform at a high level on offense and defense, effectively neutralizing Draymond.

MVP: Nobody other than Lebron will deserve the MVP regardless of the outcome of the series. I’m sure whoever is guarding Lebron (KD) will receive it if the Warriors win.

Chase Madorsky

Gregory Shamus/NBAE/Getty Images

Prediction: Cavs in 7

Plain and simple, Lebron James is playing on a level we have never seen before, even for him, averaging 26.4 PPG, 8.7 APG, and 8.6 RPG. Look for him to singlehandedly will the Cavs past the Warriors in a hard fought series. The Cavs have nothing to lose, even as the defending champs; the Warriors are the ones who blew the 3-1 lead last season, and then went out and poached Kevin Durant during the offseason. It is up to the Warriors to prove last year was a fluke, with the added pressure only playing into the Cavs’ success. With Kevin Love finally fitting in as the third piece of the big three alongside James and Kyrie Irving this postseason (17.2 PPG, 10.4 RPG) and with Tristan Thompson continuing to be dominant on the boards, Cleveland will win its second NBA Championship in a row, and Lebron James will inch that much closer to being the greatest of all-time.

X-Factor: Cleveland’s Big Small Ball Lineup, going with Irving at the point, Kyle Korver at the two, Lebron and Channing Frye at the forward positions, and Kevin Love at the five. The best way to fight fire is with fire, and the Cavs could turn to this lineup to match the Warriors three point tenacity, with the 6’7” Korver and 6’11” Frye bringing their .415 and .526 three point shooting percentage this postseason to spread the floor alongside the Big Three. With Korver and Frye playing alongside the 6’10” Love, and the 6’8” James, the Cavs will be getting big as well with this lineup.

MVP: The easy answer here is James, who I think will win the award. But to change it up a bit, let’s go with Kyrie Irving, who follows up his dagger three in Game 7 of the 2016 NBA Finals by stepping out from under Lebron’s shadow and dominating Steph Curry, averaging 26 PPG and 6 APG.

Trevor DeLaHoussaye

NBAE/Getty Images

Prediction: Warriors in 5

Remember the 2014 finals rematch of the San Antonio Spurs and the Miami Heat? The Spurs crushed the Heat in a five game series that inevitably sent LeBron James packing from Miami back to Cleveland to join younger less injury prone stars. The same will happen this time as the Kevin Durant-led Warriors crush Cleveland in the not so epic final installment of the trilogy, giving millions of bandwagon Warriors fans a sickening and horrifying sense of cheerfulness that they don’t deserve. When we finally face the truth, I, along with everyone else aren’t Warriors’ fans, will finally be so outraged by Kevin Durant’s decision to join Golden State that we will boycott the NBA if Durant re-ups his contract with this team.

X-Factor: Mike Brown: new head coach of the Golden State Warriors who will give them a defensive edge that Cleveland has never had to face before.

MVP: I give my prediction for Finals MVP to the only player that has anything to prove to the world in this series: Javale Mcgee.

Reed MacDonald

Adam Glanzman

Prediction: Cavs in 5

Kevin Durant’s jump shot will be thrown off by an overwhelming sense of guilt for having disrupted the NBA’s cosmic equilibrium and leaving the league with a playoff system that felt more ceremonial than competitive. He’ll shoot 25 percent as LeBron barrels into his chest on every play while scoring 45 points a game to add a happy epilogue to his already completed story arc.

X-Factor: karma

MVP: James, though I’m hoping for Kyle Korver because I’m kind of friends with his cousin

James Shippy

Jesse D. Garrabrant

Prediction: Cavs in 6

They say we should pick with our heads not our hearts. I’m going with the heart on this one. And here’s why. Most experts are picking the Warriors to defeat the Cavs with ease.  Vegas has the Warriors at -240 to win it all.  The last time a team with odds this high was the 2009 LA Lakers who beat the Orlando Magic that season. Everyone’s assuming that the lethal firepower of Steph Curry, KD, and company will be too much for the Cavs. But these same Cavs rose from the ashes of a 3-1 deficit like a Phoenix last year to capture the chip. These same Cavs have nothing to lose.  These same Cavs have the best player in the universe, Lebron James, suiting up for them. Basketball is literally the only sport where one player can will his team to victory. I believe Lebron and the Cavs will leave it all out on the floor and shock the world…again.

X Factor: Kevin Love has to show up big here. If he avoids repeating last year’s finals performance of averaging 7.3 points a game, Cavs should be in good shape.

Bonus X Factor: Draymond Green’s short fuse and lack of self-awareness.

Finals MVP: LBJ.

title: Miami Horror - The Shapes // Album Review
content:
Written by Bianca Brown 

Have you ever found yourself listening to a specific artist on YouTube, jamming out to their music, having a good ol’ time, when all of a sudden a band of a completely different genre pops up in your sidebar as “recommended for you”? That’s pretty much how I came across the band Miami Horror, their song ‘Leila’ catching my eye immediately and drawing me in with its colorful cover art and bittersweet track name. This four-piece from Melbourne, Sydney, just recently released their EP titled The Shapes with hopes of gathering the attention of 80’s music fanatics and 21st-century indie music listeners alike.

After being on an extended hiatus, the band is back and better than ever with this groovy 5-song EP. When asked about their inspiration for the album by Paste Magazine’s Scott Russell, the four-set of Miami Horror had this to say:

The idea for The Shapes was to have an amalgam of music and art. We picked a bunch of artists that inspire us and got them to create street art pieces to be displayed in some of our favourite cities in the world. The inspiration for the music was 70’s post-punk and 80’s afro-funk with songs about the absurdity of existence and what it means to be alive at this point in time on planet earth and all that entails.”

The 80’s vibe is incredibly real from start to finish of this EP, but the band somehow found a way to couple it with their own unique ambient sound to create a 5-song EP that’ll have you repeatedly smashing the replay button. There’s no doubt that every track will have listeners movin’, groovin’, and vibin’ out with the intensely happy instruments but raw, passionately written lyrics. “Sign of the Times,” the first song on the EP, is nothing but high energetic fun that’ll leave listeners wanting to hop in a convertible and drive 70 MPH all the way down to the beach.

Interestingly enough, the fourth song titled “Azimba” has an added flavour to it that I certainly wouldn’t have expected. “Azimba” is like the hybrid of popular wave 80’s music and afro-funk, delivering both in style, funk, and cheerfulness. The band even went as far as to have an African chorus hop on the track! When describing the song, the band had this to say: 

This is an extremely upbeat style jam, afro-funk at it’s most simple and fun. It came very naturally and quickly, we tried to make sure we didn’t complicate it and kept the structure simple and didn’t crowd the motifs. We wrote vocal melodies ourselves and then sent them to a choir in Africa to record them and come up with lyrics. It translates to ‘laughter, joy & dancing is now,’ which is perfect for the feeling of the song.

In a bit of a simpin’ mood but still want to have some fun? The band’s song “Leila” will do just the trick! Taking a bit of the front seat of the EP, “Leila” is a wonderful upbeat, 80’s sounding song paired with a couple of heavy-hitting lyrics about a woman whom you love and lust over who simultaneously drives you mad (because we’ve all felt that at some point, right?) “I just can’t believe it/You left me here alone/When you coming back now?/Looking in the mirror/For all I used to know/I just can’t believe it/Leila, why did you leave again?Stay home/Leila, can you believe again?/Stay home” - lyrics that’ll have you in your feelings, but a beat that’ll have you moving your feet! The band commented on the song, “It’s about a woman who makes you mad with lust and love and all the other emotions. It is something most men can relate to I think, there is always one woman that floats around your mind and drives you into madness.”

Overall, this album exceeding any expectations I had and I’m very certain it’ll do the same to its listeners, whether they be pre-existing Miami Horror fans or not. The Shapes has a little something that everyone can enjoy, and you don’t always find that!

title: Flaming Lips @ The Ace Hotel (05/09/17)  // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Isabelle Abbitt

Last week the Flaming Lips, along with Dutch band Klangstof, played a sold out show at the Ace Hotel in Downtown Los Angeles. The entire atmosphere of the Ace Hotel Theater was transformed into what seemed to be straight from the imagination of artist Oliver Hibert. When first walking into the event, I noticed huge psychedelic wall posters for sale and long lines of many hip 30-somethings ordering drinks from man-bunned bartenders. Women walked by wearing huge platforms shoes and neon plastic dresses surrounded by men in full-blown 60s attire. The crowd was probably the most cohesively fashioned group I’ve ever seen at a large event in Los Angeles.

Since I had been running late (parking Downtown is sometimes impossible) I rushed to the front of the stage and immediately found myself surrounded by photographers from the LA Times, LA Weekly, and huge music magazines. Before I could really take in the environment, canons filled with confetti erupted all over the stage and covered the audience! Massive saturated balloons were released from the ceiling and people next to me started throwing them at everyone in the audience. I knew right away that this night would be wild.

It seemed that the production scale of this show had no limits. While the Flaming Lips played all of their most famous songs (Do You Realize??, Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots Pt. 1, and The Yeah, Yeah, Yeah Song), and also songs from their newly released album Oczy Mlody, giant blow-up dolls and rainbows filled the stage. During several songs blow-up eyeballs and lips surrounded Wayne and at one point the band was accompanied on stage by costumed figures that resembled Yo Gabba Gabba television characters. At one point Wayne came into the stage riding an extremely phallic unicorn with laser lights jutting around him like a halo. Very trippy. This was probably the most amazing live show I’ve ever been to, especially since everyone in the crowd was so overjoyed to see them play.

I decided to bring two of my friends up to the VIP balcony area since we had Press Passes and check out the social scene upstairs. As we walked by a bigger group of people by the balcony, I thought they looked like they would be friends with Miley Cyrus since they all had such a trippy and outrageous style. As soon as I thought that, I saw Miley Cyrus was actually sitting in the middle of their group with her fiance Liam Hemsworth. This makes sense since Cyrus has toured with the Flaming Lips multiple times and they all collaborate with Oliver Hibert who designs the Flaming Lips’ merch at shows. They seemed like a really cool group of friends so after a little while I decided to talk to them and ended up being their photographer for the night. I took pictures of the girls in the group, one looked a lot like Yolandi from Die Antwoord and had the coolest green hair. Finally, they invited my group of friends to join them backstage with the bands. As soon as we got backstage, they ran off to go talk to some people and left us there to just hang out. I took some pictures of Wayne with my friend Libby and talked to some of the band members in between songs, they were all such beautiful people.

There was an open after party after the show on the roof of the Ace Hotel where a lot of the band hung out later in the night. The pool was warm and the DJs played amazing sets throughout the night, pretty much everyone there was dancing.

Overall, I would rate their show as a 10/10 experience. Meeting the band was amazing and they were all such nice and welcoming people. I would definitely recommend their show if you want to experience something magical.

title: Faces of UCLA Radio // Meet Our New GM
content:
In honor of our annual Pledge Drive, we will be featuring various members of our station so you can get to know the many different faces of UCLA Radio. Interview by Helen Gallagher. 

Every spring quarter we welcome a new general manager to lead us into the upcoming year and see what heights our station can reach. Meet our 2017-2018 UCLA Radio GM, Maddie Gavin.

When did you first get involved in UCLA Radio?

I got involved in radio the fall of my sophomore year, so 2015.

Why did you want to get involved?

I joined a sorority freshman year, and also did a dance team which was dope, but neither of those things really gave me a place to call my own on campus. I was looking for something that was super stimulating and that I was passionate about and proud of.

How has UCLA Radio changed your perspective on UCLA?

It’s great having a space on campus that’s as comfortable and natural as home, that allows me to not only be myself but to be challenged and grow.

How has being in UCLA Radio changed your taste in music?
