It’s definitely expanded my taste in music. I’m pleasantly surprised that I’m enjoying genres that I wouldn’t normally.

What was the concept behind Reporting for Booty?

Officer Gavin was actually my AOL screen name from seventh grade and it’s always sort of been a nickname. I wanted the theme to go with the DJ name, and I knew that I wanted a Friday night slot to play very week-ending music, so people could escape their problems and necessities. I also definitely wanted people to be dancing during the show, getting hyped for the weekend.

What is your favorite memory in UCLA Radio?

Definitely opening for Esta. in Ackerman in the beginning of this (winter) quarter.

What’s a favorite memory of yours relating to music?

Whenever I get to see my sister perform. (Gavin’s sister is Katie Gavin of MUNA)

You had a pretty dope internship last quarter right? Can you tell me more about that?

Yeah! I interned last summer at RCA in New York, and I’m currently interning at RCA in LA and also at Mixed Management in LA, who manage RL Grime and Bauer.

Do you want to work in the music industry after college?

I really enjoy the cognitive science major but I also have realized that I am way too fascinated with music to not try to be directly in the industry. Ideally my career would combine those two in some way — maybe in marketing or software development.

Tune in to Reporting for Booty at 7 p.m. on Fridays!

title: Playboi Carti - Playboi Carti // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia 

After an extremely wait over a course of months, Playboi Carti finally arrives with his debut mixtape on Interscope Records. Since his take-off with the single “Fetti,” Playboi Carti has linked up with the A$VP mob, dabbled in tracks with members on AWFUL Records, signed to Interscope Records, and dropped collaborations with Lil Uzi Vert and other New Age rappers. However, the overdue mixtape falls short of feeling like a proper introduction to the rapper.

From the introductory track, “Location,” one can already taste the lack of cares that Carti brings to his own project. The track is carried by atmospheric pads and a thick, throbbing kick drum. Aside from the fun 808 bass hits that surround Carti’s ad-libs, the track does nothing, but be a simple, straightforward trap welcoming.

What follows is one of the better songs on the entire tape, “Magnolia.” Despite the fact that the beat feels more bland and more basic in structure than the production found on “Location,” Carti manages to be an entertaining force on this piece. However, the incessant repetitions of “young Carti, young Carti” and blatantly borrowed flows might be too obvious for the song to be anything special. Seriously, just play any Lil Uzi Vert track, the same triplet flow is being recycled all the time. Yet, the hook manages to be an attractive point throughout the track. The previous remark on the flows is further supported by the following track: “Lookin” featuring Lil Uzi Vert. The barrage of ad-libs and the otherwise boring verse provided by Vert make this yet another disposable track. The fact that the last 40 seconds of the track are drenched in ad-libs does not help the track’s case. 

“Wokeuplikethis*” feels like a decent track that tries to make up for the alright bars. It is a stable and steady production, with yet another “just OK” feature by Lil Uzi Vert and an “interesting” spelling of the track’s title. The hook, sung by Carti, “Woke up to niggas sounding like me,” is provided with a delivery that could be found on a reggaeton radio smash and it — objectively — provides a small angle of difference. The tracks “Let it Go” and “Half & Half” are supported with interesting, slower beats that are rich with subby 808 hits and pitch-shifting hi hats. 

However, the main criticism of the entire tape rears its ugly head once again: Playboi Carti depends too greatly on his ad-libs and not enough on interesting, witty, funny, braggadocious or just outright entertaining lyrical content. The majority of “Half & Half” is composed of ad-libs, giving a proper meaning to the title of the song (get it? Half ad-libs, Half beat production). “New Choppa,” unfortunately, depends greatly on ASAP Rocky’s performance before the track has even reached the 1 minute mark. Thank the Trap gods that Rocky isn’t afraid of a beat that sounds like a terrible chopped and screwed version of the Lavender Town soundtrack (Google it). The beat’s synths are somewhat annoying as Rocky easily and gracefully flows from bar to bar. If it weren’t for the blessing provided by the feature, this track would also end up in the recycling bin without question. 

The hook to “Other S**t” is especially annoying, there is no melody or rhythm other than the same triplet delivery in sight. At the same time Carti is clearly tending to the lowest common denominator by making notes to the insincere “other s**t” that he does: have money, have girls, have a squad with money, et cetera. By the time this reviewer hit the middle of the track “No.9,” the single word, shouty bars, and fall-to-the-background beat had driven me nauseous. The fact that the song abruptly ends provides one more reason to believe that Carti simply doesn’t care. With the support of the ASAP Mob, Carti does not need to do much more than just be present on his own material to garner attention. 

“Dothatshit!” was interesting as a track because the title doesn’t censor the swear word like the title “Other S**t.” What gives? Aside from that, however, the track is a step in the more melodic, sleepy direction in which Lil Uzi Vert is experienced. Despite the fact that he is heavily influenced by his contemporaries, the rapper manages to string together an entertaining hook towards the last 40 seconds of the track. “Lame N****z” is yet another title that is censored for some reason. Other than that, the track is not really interesting at all. The thin, scrappy voice that Carti provides on the track does not contrast well with what appears to be a sample of a lion roaring in the background. In fact, the lion roar can lead one to believe that this mixtape was instead meant to be a pretty, glistening beat tape. “Lame N****z,” like “Yah Mean,” suffers from a lack of cohesion and organization. These are characteristics that create memorable trap bangers, and are learned through experience and effort. 

One could argue that the track “Kelly K” was already played somewhere in the earlier portion of the mixtape. Thankfully, the track “Had 2” contains such a thick, rubbery 808 bass that it drowns out any annoying ad-libs that threaten to ruin the upbeat instrumentals behind Carti. It is unfortunate that Carti clearly has other priorities than making entertaining bangers that could give him the longevity he needs to survive in the trap-sphere.

Overall Rating: 4/10

Best: “Wokeuplikethis*”, “New Choppa”

Worst: “Half & Half”, “Lame N****z”

title: April Show of the Month // 2 Stones + 1 Bird with DJ Merna Rex
content:
Interviewed by Alexa Lee

2 Stones + 1 Bird presents music within a genre called “math rock.” I’m a bland suburban gal who wears khakis and listens to Drake. How would you explain math rock to me?

I’d say that math rock is less about being classified under certain criteria and more about not being constrained by common conventions and having the freedom to venture beyond into what’s exciting and - for lack of a better word - odd. The short answer that most people will give is that it’s rock that is highly technical and in irregular meters but there’s no singular rule that defines it. I’m certainly very liberal at times with how I use the term on my show. The day after the inauguration I put together a playlist that included bands like Black Flag, Dead Kennedys, and Refused. No one would consider any of those bands to be math rock but when you listen to them under that context, they fit in perfectly. The fun thing about having this platform is I get to challenge what people think math rock is. I choose to view it as less of a set of technical and stylistic characteristics and more of an approach and intention behind the music.

Honestly it’s not a fantastic term but it’s just two syllables and can be used as a blanket term for a large expanse of music that can sometimes fall between the cracks. I guess one of the nice things about having a show about it is I get to just play the music and let other people come to their own conclusions as to what it means.

What or who influences your music preferences? Would you say that your taste in music has evolved as you’ve grown and changed, or are you loyal to the soil to certain artists and genres?

It’s always evolving, or at least it’s expanding. I’ve certainly gone through phases of mass musical consumption where I would download any and every album that came my way but these days I have less free time and free space on my computer so for the most part I just go off the recommendations of others or let it find me.

I wouldn’t say I’m loyal to any genres as much as I’m just loyal to music with humanity. It doesn’t really matter what the style or instrumentation is, I just like hearing a person behind the music, which is just as common in instrumental music as it is in vocal. Although I haven’t listened to much industrial EDM so who knows, maybe I like music that doesn’t sound like humans too. I’m sure I’ll get around to trying it one of these days.

You’ve featured live music sets from groups such as Mammoth and Hollow Ran. During these close moments with the bands, how do you react? Do you play it cool and professional? Are you a screaming fan?

In both cases, I’ve actually known the guys personally before they came on the show. I met both Wes [from Mammoth] and Taylor [from Hollow Ran] on the same night at a show back in the summer of 2015. On the second ever episode of 2 Stones + 1 Bird, I had a band called Sea Monkey See come on and do an in-station performance. We posted some videos which got around so when I met those guys a few weeks later they’d already seen the videos and were familiar with the show, which was pretty cool considering how new everything was. I don’t remember who approached whom about them coming on the show but it definitely came up during that first meeting and there was a lot of mutual excitement to make it happen.

I don’t know that I’ve ever been a screaming fan in any context. The whole vibe of our in-station performances is pretty chill. That said, if you ever see me in the background of any photos or videos while the band is playing I will most certainly have the biggest grin on my face and/or will be awkwardly math-head-banging. They’re both truly phenomenal bands. There’s no way to articulate how talented those guys are without falling into cliches so I’ll just leave it at that.

Some DJs use their radio persona as an alter ego, while others are exactly the same person on and off air. What tone or image are you trying to portray during 2 Stones + 1 Bird as DJ Merna Rex?

I don’t think there’s any major difference between Layla and Merna except for outside of the show I also listen to a fair amount of non-mathy music, whereas she’s always very involved and centered in that scene. So in that way it’s really nice that no matter what I’m doing outside of the show, I always maintain that connection to this music that has meant so much to me for so long.

The tone is just me sharing music that excites me. I’m still adding new things to make it even more personal like adding pedal demos and discussions. There were a couple of times when I thought, “What if this is too nerdy? Would anyone besides me understand or be interested in this?” but I think that’s kind of the point. People can tell when you’re feigning interest and when you’re genuinely passionate about what you’re doing. I think that kind of excitement can be contagious and it helps other people to be more open to listening as well.

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

I co-host every show with my dog, DJ $aphrodite. She’s still a bit shy on the mic so I do all the talking but she puts together some pretty tight playlists and does a mean crossfade.
tags: ucla radio show of the month

title: Blind Pilot @ The El Rey (6/24/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Helen Gallagher

I had the pleasure of seeing Blind Pilot perform at the El Rey Theater on June 24th, the second time I’ve seen them live. The first was five years ago, after the release of their second album, and before the five year hiatus the band took until the release of their newest album, “And Then Like Lions.”

The El Rey is an intimate venue — the audience is practically on stage with the band. Blind Pilot takes the stage quietly, and without a word, begins the opening bars of “The Story I Heard,” a popular song from their album “Three Rounds and a Sound.” The audience grins collectively in recognition, leaning eagerly towards the stage, eyes cast towards the bewitching Israel Nebeker, the band’s lead singer and frontman.

Blind Pilot is inexplicably perfect in concert — better live than recorded, no doubt. It’s hard to believe that the velvet of Israel’s voice is untouched by audio editing, but it must be true, because his voice sounds the same, if not better, in person. He hits every note effortlessly, and the sound of the band behind him stays precisely in rhythm, a cohesive unit emitting a symphonically complex sound.

Israel’s band mates get the chance to show off their similarly celestial voices when the band strips away and three of them - Israel, the bassist Luke Ydstie, and guitarist Kati Claborn triple up to sing the song “Three Rounds and a Sound.” A couple bars into the song, Luke kicks the amp by accident, and their sound goes out. With a brief look of recognition between the three, they step forward together in unison and continue acoustically. The audience chimes in, and soon we are all singing the familiar melancholy tune, hands clasped together.

The rest of the show continues smoothly — the band is plugged back in, and continues to play popular songs from their old albums, along with songs from “And Then Like Lions,” which has a different feel from the band’s other albums, which work together almost as one. “We Are the Tide” and “Three Rounds and a Sound” feel like a young man’s ode to adventure and youthful romance. “And then Like Lions” is older, seasoned, weary, but hopeful. The album feels like its full of healing, which makes sense, considering the tragedy that lead Israel to write it.

The audience is rapt the entire time, swaying and dancing occasionally to more energetic songs like “One Red Thread.” The band finishes to thunderous applause, and of course returns for an extended encore of three more songs. First just Israel comes out, and plays us something new. My friends and I joke that he’s the only artist who could pull off playing something new as an encore, and he can. The rest of the band returns and performs two old songs — “New York,” and a personal favorite, “The Colored Night,” to which the audience sings — almost yells — along.

Blind Pilot’s growth is palpable, but the band hasn’t strayed from the core elements that make their music work so well: Ryan Dobrowski’s train-like drum tempo, phonetically pleasing harmonies, and a full, folky sound. For people like me who grew up with the band, age 16 to 21, this somehow steadfast change is poignant.

title: UCLA Spring Sing 2017 // Show Review
content:
Written by Lillian Stanwick 

I know that on May 19 a panel of D-list celebrity judges determined the official winners of UCLA’s 2017 Spring Sing. As announced in Pauley Pavilion, the winners in each category were BEL, Eva B. Ross & David Miller, HELEN, the Scattertones, and HOOLIGAN, with Inner Sanctum taking home the Bruin Choice Award and Eva B. Ross & David Miller winning the Northern California Alumni Grand Sweepstakes Award. This article is not to say that the judges’ opinions are wrong or to disparage any of the winning performers. I must say that Eva Barrosse and David Miller’s duet was superb, bluesy and worthy of winning the top prize, but I will now proceed not to mention them for the remainder of this article as I present you the REAL winners and losers of 2017 Spring Sing.

The Winners

1. Jason Earles 

I know, SHOCKING. But think about it, when was the last time you thought about Jason Earles? Did you even know who Jason Earles was before Spring Sing? Exactly. This guy is 40, divorced, and peaked on the Disney Channel eight years ago. Yet somehow he ended up on everyone’s Snapchat story, and you know that at least 1,000 people googled his name that night when they brought him out as a judge. Judging Spring Sing was probably the biggest publicity boost this actor has had in a long time. I don’t know why or how he ended up on the judging panel for Spring Sing, but it certainly didn’t hurt his career.

2. HELEN

Yes, HELEN was determined to be the best band at Spring Sing by the judging panel, so calling them a winner isn’t anything new. Libby Hsieh, Laura Savage, and Temme Scott’s performance of the original song “In the Morning,” was a knockout. All three came to the stage with exceptional vocal skills. Their song was soulful and smooth with impressive instrumentation. Furthermore, the haunting lyrics paired with each of the artist’s crooning voices made for a moving performance. It’s upsetting that this band was a Spring Sing-exclusive creation. It’s even more upsetting that all three members of HELEN are graduating this year. UCLA is losing some exceptional talent.

3. The Company

For me, the best part of Spring Sing was The Company’s transitionary comedy sketches. The first sketch that they opened with was by far their weakest. The skit about college tours just missed the mark, and it made me nervous that The Company was about to fill Spring Sing with cringe-worthy bits. But the group quickly recovered with their hilarious “Study Abroad” short, and as the night wore on, the sketches got better and better, culminating with “Powell Owl,” which took home the award for the best comedy sketch. I was particularly impressed with Avalon Penrose’s farcical song “I Fell In Love in an Uber Pool.” The lyrics were witty, and her voice could hold its own compared to the other singers in the show. I would highly recommend that one check out the Spring Sing Youtube channel for full videos of The Company’s live and pre-recorded sketches.

Unfortunately where there are winners there are…

The Losers

1. Naya Zamaana A Cappella

As a general disclaimer, I loathe a capella. I don’t love Pitch Perfect. I hate the idea of attending an a cappella showcase. And if someone ever plays Pentatonix on UCLA Radio, it may result in my sudden departure from the station. It’s safe to say that I’m not an expert when it comes to judging a capella, but I think Naya Zamaana was the best group that performed. From an outsider perspective, their performance was better than the other two, so I’m surprised that they didn’t walk away with the win for best a capella. This group was robbed.

2. Everyone who didn’t go to Spring Sing

Although every performance was recorded and posted on the Spring Sing Youtube page (again, highly recommend you check it out), the audio that accompanies them is lacking. Most of the videos included the audio from the microphones but omitted the amps, so some instruments are absent from the audio. Any performance that included an electric guitar is missing most of the guitar’s sound. You can hear the guitars, but the sound was somehow altered during the recording process. It’s unfortunate for those watching online that some of the stronger performances, such as that from HELEN, don’t sound as good on video as they did in person.

The good news is that there will always be next year.

title: Spotlight of the Week // Cabronx
content:
Written by Irlanda Mora

Cabronx is one of the most iconic shows at UCLA Radio, and is hosted by Maria and Mateo (DJ Ponte Tu Sueter and DJ Tapete/Matovermind respectively).

I asked the duo what ‘cabronx’ means to them. The inspiration for the tile was a play off of the term “cabrones” Maria recounted how her strict aunt would disapprove of her rebellious nature and sigh, “pinche cabrona.” She also explained that the ‘x’ in Cabronx is designed to represent the LGBT and gender non-conforming members of the Latino community. Mateo added that ‘cabronx’ is representative of their personalities, as they see themselves as “baddies and nonconformists because they are ‘out-there’ and make their presence known.” Cabronx provided the opportunity for them to embrace their latinidad and challenge the notions of what being latino entails.

Both DJs also elaborated on what cultura (culture) means to them. Maria explained the nuances of cultura, and the preconceived delineation of anything other, such as her artsy personality. She described people’s inability to reconcile her artsy nature with her Latinidad. In a more general sense, cultura is about being connected to the past, present and marking the path towards the future. Maria describes it as a “decolonized view of xicanismo.” Mateo added that it incorporates tradition with heritage and that it’s essentially the ability to embrace your roots with pride: “It’s about love, art, and repping all the time.”

I asked the duo why they decided to work together, as they have such undeniable chemistry, but very contrasting personalities. They explained that they met as springterns in 2016 and had always joked about starting a show together. Their idea didn’t become solidified until much later.

Finally, I asked them what legacy they hoped to leave behind. They responded that they wanted to make the Latinx presence known and show that they’re “here to stay” by using their platform to inform their listeners about injustices.

This duo is a force to be reckoned with. Tune in to Cabronx on Wednesdays at 8 p.m. It’s a guaranteed good time.
tags: ucla radio spotlight of the week

title: Alexandra Savior - Belladonna of Sadness // Album Review
content:
Written by Beliz Urkmez

Alexandra Savior’s debut album Belladonna of Sadness, released by Columbia Records, radiates a calm, mysterious force that magnetically pulls you in from the first song. Savior’s smooth voice over Alex Turner’s retro guitars gives her an old-fashioned French sound: she is soft and feminine, but unafraid to tell the truth. With a lot of character and talent, Savior launches her career on a good foundation — but Alex Turner and producer James Ford’s involvement take over the album too much, making it sound like a spin off of Turner’s side work, Last Shadow Puppet.

The first song, “Mirage,” launches the album with a bang. Savior unapologetically talks about her problems with her record label that initially wanted to turn her into the next Katy Perry. During the lines, “I sing songs about whatever the fuck they want,” she gets real and you immediately trust her experience and her story. Her lyrics emit the anger of an artist struggling to find her personality in a business that does not value her.

The following song, “Bones,” written by Alex Turner, seems more forgettable than the captivating first song. However, it still manages to be a strong piece with the bass and the percussion shining throughout. It also introduces an emotional side of Savior — one that sings, “I just can’t pretend I’m not in love with you/ That’s not true.”

The popular hit “Shades” strengthens the album with a charm that derives from quirky bass lines and an upbeat tempo. The single encapsulates exactly what Savior wanted her music to sound like: “Sassy, impolite spaghetti western music.” Besides the musical magnetisms of the song, it also delivers great lyrics, showing off Savior’s ability as a songwriter.

During the next two songs “Girlie” and “Frankie,” Savior exits her personal world and enters into the music industry, where she refuses to become another pop star that is infatuated with the Hollywood life. The ironic ballad “Girlie” depicts a profile for the banal girls of the industry. The song sounds a lot like Turner with the lyrics; “Got that look upon her face says she is twenty minutes late.” One starts to question Savior’s authenticity, as Turner’s voice overpowers hers. The latter has less influence and tells the story of a Hollywood affair, while the music is as intriguing and mysterious as it gets.

“M.T.M.E” flares in this calm album with harsher electric guitars and Savior’s haunting vocals. During this song, she yells “I’m just fine” and screams. The whole song makes you uncomfortable as Savior sings about a lover that did her wrong by leaving her unexpectedly.

The second half of the album lowers the tempo. “Audaline,” with its quirky riffs still manages to come out strong. However by the time “Cupid” and “Til You’re Mine” finish, the listener feels used to the shtick. The music starts to resemble the signature Last Shadow Puppets sound. To be honest, Alex Turner and co Miles Kane could sing these songs and no one would notice.

Turner’s influence reaches its climax in the song that picks the album up, “Vanishing Point.” The lyrics, “Spectacular black light poster neon sky/ To which the sun so quickly unsubscribes/ Want to call it a night/ But I think they might be onto us” fuses Arctic Monkeys’ third album Humbug but overall strengthens the album.

The final song, “Mystery Girl,” reminds you of what Savior is about. It encapsulates the intrigue, the deception, and a certain mystery. As she sings “Don’t try to calm me down,” the listener understands her driving force. It might get lost between the smooth vocals and old-fashioned music, but she has a message and a certain wisdom. The audience believes her perceptions of the world around her. Although her voice does not sound fully her own yet, Belladonna of Sadness describes the story of an artist finding her way with her world and with her art.

Best: “Shades,” “Mirage”

title: Vansire - The Rolling, Drifting North // Album Review
content:
Written by Alana Enriquez

Vansire is a dream pop band out of Rochester, Minnesota. Their newest EP, The Rolling, Driftless North, is best described as a hazy daydream. The introductory track, titled “Reflection No. 2 - A Treatise on Being” is an ethereal soundscape, marked by the soft rhythms of a passing train. It’s a fitting start, drenching the remaining four tracks in a yellowish hue that is reminiscent of the EP’s cover image. “Eleven Weeks” is the next track, a muted reflection on fading communication. The starry-eyed vocals and twinkling synths immerse the listener into a blurred nostalgia, filled with trees “like something from a movie.”  The third track, titled “Pale Blue,” is an upbeat ode to suburbia, reminiscent of early Craft Spells. It conjures up images of sun-soaked drives, while still maintaining the band’s soft, dreamy sound. “Driftless” continues with this mood. Chords and faint vocals build upon each other into a burst of airy energy. The final track, “Four Portraits,” closes the EP with the slow paced contemplation with which it opened. I find this song to be the culmination of The Rolling, Driftless North. It combines a delicate soundscape with gentle vocals that result in a romantic whole. The velvety instrumentation, combined with poetic vocals, completes the dream that Vansire has created for us.

I have found that tying music to emotion has allowed me to better understand its message, and Vansire’s The Rolling, Driftless North is no exception. Thus, like many of my interactions with music, I associate this EP with a very particular moment. It was early afternoon at the beginning of April. I was hot, greasy and temperamental. But as I walked home, my music library shuffled to the sound of vocals that were so soft, they sounded like bells. I immediately felt better, more rooted in place — despite the dreamscape in which I was placed. I hope that this review allows other people to experience a similar feeling, or perhaps something utterly different.

title: Mount Analog + Ninja Tune Present: Actress, Laurel Halo, Eartheater, Sage Caswell @ The Globe (05/13/17) // Show Preview
content:
Written By : Derek Khaothong & Greta Langenberg 

Post Date : 05/6/17

Celebrating the release of an impressive fifth studio album, AZD, Mount Analog and Ninja Tune are presenting a show at the Globe Theatre Basement on Saturday, May 13 in Los Angeles. Headlining the show is Actress, who will be performing a live set alongside a plethora of special guests and exclusive one-off appearances from Laurel Halo, Eartheater, and Sage Caswell.

AZD has received phenomenal reviews for his fifth studio album by fans and critics. His performance at the Globe will be his first in Los Angeles in almost three years and will surprise guests with a new, never-before-seen live show.

In addition, he is joined by Hyperdub boss Laurel Halo, who is set to release Dust, her third LP on June 23. The album features vocal contributions from Klein, Michael Salu, as well as musical collaborations from Julia Holter and Max D. Aside from Los Angeles, she will also be playing shows in Detroit, Chicago, and New York to support the release of Dust.

Eartheater promises a live performance of her experimental ancient and futuristic tracks. As a composer, singer, visual artist, and a dancer, her solo intimate performance should unmistakably stun attendees of the Globe Theater.

Up last is local Los Angeles native Sage Caswell, a DJ and producer heavily involved in the Los Angeles based collective Far Away. His debut LP, Hoop Earring has allowed him to gain a broader international audience.

Tickets for this event are now available for purchase via Restless Nites and Mount Analog.

title: Interview with Julia Jacklin
content:
Interviewed by Alexandra Ivanova

Alex: First off, how are you — I was told you were rehearsing all day!

Julia: Yeah, yeah, it was good. Playing with a new drummer and a new bass player on this tour, so we’re just getting everyone into the right space, playing the right songs and making sure we all know what we’re doing.

Alex: That’s super exciting because you’re kicking off your tour here in Los Angeles, but you also have a song called “LA Dream,” which feels like one of the most personal songs off the album. What was the process of recording that song like?

Julia: Yeah, that was the last song, I think I recorded on the album because I was struggling to get into the right headspace. You don’t realize when you are recording that you need to, kind of, perform the songs, more than just make sure you don’t mess it up. It’s more important that you actually perform them well. I struggled to get back into the place I was when I wrote the song. It’s one of my favorite songs that I’ve written, and I still enjoy performing it, which is good.

Alex: Yeah, you have these super poignant themes in your lyrics, but you’re also able to sprinkle in this really great amount of humor, like in your song “Small Talk,” where you compare your dad to Zach Braff. Where do you gather inspiration for all of your lyrics, and do they also draw on your personal experiences?

Julia: I think on that record especially they were all personal experiences, because at the time I wasn’t a professional musician or anything, so I was kind of just using music as a way to get things out and try and just figure out how to express things properly. I think that the humor… I am a huge fan of Fiona Apple and Leonard Cohen’s lyrics — I think they manage to both sing about big things like love, or loss, or life, but in a way that kind of is poking fun of it, a little bit, or at least just seeing the humor in the tragedy of something, and that’s the music I really like listening to, so that’s kind of what I try to do.

Alex: You also mention your musical influences include Bjork and Doris Day and Billy Bragg who are all incredible, but who do you listen to as your guilty pleasure music?

Julia: Guilty pleasure music…I’d say like… What’s my guilty pleasure… I don’t know. I like, I mean I guess, not to say it’s bad, I would definitely do a lot of nostalgia stuff like Mandy Moore and Avril Lavigne’s first record, which I actually think is a pretty good record, still. So I definitely listen to that.

Alex: I’ve also heard you say on an interview that you really like diners. What is the best diner you’ve been to while touring or traveling?

Julia: I wouldn’t remember any of the names of the diners, I think just more the experiences I’ve had in the diner. I think l had a really great night in a diner in Memphis— I think it was just a Denny’s actually, like a 24-hour Denny’s, and it was the Fourth of July, and I had nowhere to stay because I forgot to book accommodations and then I kind of got to Memphis thinking I would find a hostel and then realized everything was booked and so the people at Denny’s kind of were alright with me just sitting in Denny’s and eating pancakes every three hours until the sun came up.

Alex: You’ve spoken a lot about working through feeling good enough or not good enough in the music realm. How do you personally find your own confidence as a musician?

Julia: I think it changes a lot depending on the day and depending on who I’m playing with as well and how they treat me. That has a lot to do with it, because everyone contributes different things into a band and into music and I felt in the beginning I wasn’t contributing much, because I’m not technically very proficient in the way that I didn’t study music or I didn’t put in the hours of guitar playing that a lot of people around me have; but I think I’m now realizing that that doesn’t mean that you’re not contributing anything just because you can’t necessarily, you know, say you’re in music or something. I realize that songwriting is a big part of it, and that that shouldn’t be dismissed. Today I’m feeling pretty good, the band I’m playing with are all really lovely and really supporting and really keen, so that helps.

Alex: I read that you initially wanted to be a social worker and then you pursued music and then you worked on a factory production line making essential oils. What was the timeline of all of that like— when was the turning point when you knew music was what you wanted to fully invest in?

Julia: I finished uni when I was 24 and I stayed at the factory for two years, I think (so when I was from twenty four to twenty five) and I made my record just before I turned twenty five, and then halfway through last year when I played SXSW was kind of the turning point. I was just going to give myself two years after uni to see if it was going to work out, and I worked at the factory for just enough money to make the record, and then I played SXSW and had to take time off work for that, and then after that I just kept getting booked to do things, so I had to keep taking more time off work until it was just pointless going back and yeah, so then here were are today. So I haven’t really been a full time musician for that long— since August of last year, I guess.

Alex: I think that’s really interesting, because you are such a new musician and the themes of your album deal a lot with the concept of coming of age — what age do you think culminated the process of coming of age for you, or do you think that coming of age is a lifelong process instead?

Julia: I think when I wrote the record, or when I recorded it, that was my coming of age. I thought that I came through this massive learning curve of what love actually means and what being an adult actually means. and now that I’m twenty six and I’ve spent the last touring and kind of dealing with other things, I’m once again thinking, “No-no, this is my coming of age.” You realize that being a full-time musician is not some easy, fun thing that you might think it is. It’s actually incredibly tiring. You spend pretty much your whole life away from places and away from people. I think it’s just an ongoing thing, because I’m sure I’ll look back in two years time and I’m going to look back on all the epiphanies I’ve had this year and be like, “You knew nothing!” Yeah, I definitely think it’s something you’re constantly coming to. Which is good, because I think if you figured it out at one age, then your life would be pretty boring.

Alex: Throughout social media you’re known as “a singer-songwriter who will put your smile on dial but only for a short while” — what are the origins of that?

Julia: It’s funny that you say that. That was a joke that me and my drummer tom wrote — I was having to update my Facebook page, and I think he wrote that just as some funny thing and then I’ve never changed it. I don’t know what that means actually. It could mean that I’m very approachable and relatively happy in my stage presence, and then I start singing and everyone’s like, “Aww that’s depressing…”

Alex: The nostalgic themes of your album are also really strong. How does nostalgia affect you today? Do you think it limits you, or does it serve as more of a push forward?

Julia: Right now I’ve been obsessed with Dawson’s Creek. It’s been this ongoing obsession and right now I’m ridiculously obsessed, and I watch it with my little brother who is nineteen, and we’ve been working through the seasons for the last three years because we’ve both been away doing lots of different stuff— we’ve taken ages to actually finish it because we won’t watch an episode without each other, and I think that my current intense obsession with the story line is concerning, because I think nostalgia in that way, yeah it feels like you’re holding on to some kind of idealistic simple life like when you look back to life before phones and before social media and before big decisions had to be make you can totally just romanticize it and when I look back to that time in my life it wasn’t incredible. It was definitely equally as hard in different ways. So you know, Dawson’s Creek makes it look like everything was great but it wasn’t. But I think it’s good to look back and use things in your past but it’s also really important to not look back and romanticize being a teenager, because when you’re a teenager the whole time you’re wishing you were an adult. I’m trying to be more present and not watch too much Dawson’s Creek.

Alex: Lastly, what can fans expect from this upcoming tour?

Julia: I’ve got some new songs that I’m playing - just trying some new stuff out. I bought some new shoes, so I won’t be wearing white sneakers anymore which was my costume of last year. I have new band members who are Canadian and they are extremely friendly. I’d only known them for seven hours but we’re about to spend five weeks in a car together. so you might experience pure friendship on stage or irritation. I don’t know, we’ll see!

title: Boss - Flow Tribe // Album Review
content:
Written by Sam Celentano 

When I look for new albums to review I search at the bottom of the barrel. And I mean the absolute bottom; the more crude, unsightly, and strange the cover art, the greater the chance it’ll receive my review. With this being said, there is no wonder as to why I chose the album featured here. The art for Flow Tribe’s fourth studio album, Boss, is an artistic wonder and a marvel of graphic design, yet is perhaps the greatest musical example of the phrase “don’t judge a book by its cover.”

Flow Tribe, a funk-rock band formed in 2004 from New Orleans, is prominently known within the area for their high energy live performances. The city’s distinct style has certainly left an impression on the band not only in their album art, but also within their sound. The inclusion of a blaring horn section, unconventional instrumentation, and a loose backing band seems to pay homage to the second line parades of their hometown. While these aspects shine best through Flow Tribe’s live performances, Boss presents itself as a modern interpretation of the second lines, combining the traditional art form with funky synth and some light hip hop.

With an ambitious combination of styles it’s no wonder that the album doesn’t quite hit the mark. Through exceptionally shallow lyrical content and some outright forgettable tracks (see “Don’t Want to Be in Love,” “Turning Table”), there is no reason to believe that this will be a perfect listen. These tracks are akin to the filler content of a Justin Timberlake album with a few huge hits, written just for the sake of being there. However, once the listener ventures into the second half of the album, they’re greeted with a slew of catchy tunes worth listening twice or three times, complete with a swaggering brass band to round out the sound (see “Diamond,” “You Know What It’s About”).

Overall, Boss far exceeded my expectations and even offered a few moments of greatness. There is no arguing the musical ability of Flow Tribe despite their taste in visuals, and in their fourth release have remained true to their funk-rock genre while adding a touch of modern flair. If you enjoy Trombone Shorty, Tuxedo, or St. Paul & The Broken Bones, then Flow Tribe just might be the band for you.

5.5/10

title: Will Joseph Cook - Sweet Dreamer // Album Review
content:
Written by Alana Myers

 Kent native Will Joseph Cook has been making waves across the pond since the release of his debut EP You Jump I Run in 2015. Two years later, Cook carries the same elements of great songwriting with him, except this time he has a huge package in tow - his debut record, Sweet Dreamer. While some of the songs on Sweet Dreamer found their beginnings when Cook was in his early teens, each song on the record fits perfectly in line with one another. The songs paint a picture of who Cook is as both an artist and a person, and showcase the immense improvement and growth Cook has went through in terms of musicianship since the start of his career.

“Kind of used to that single bed/I loved every pixel, every word you said,” Cook sings at the start of the album on “Biggest Fan.” Backed by the sweet strum of a guitar, these lyrics stand out as listeners are left to ponder what Cook could possibly be talking about in this song. As the track continues, it becomes clearer that Cook is describing the difficulties of a long-distance relationship that’s left him more enamored with his partner than before. What sets Cook apart from other artists at the moment is the way in which he expresses his experiences through his music, as he did on “Biggest Fan.” Whether it’s through the honest lyricism on songs like “Alive,” the irresistible hook on the album’s title-track “Sweet Dreamer,” the classic “Take Me Dancing,” or even the heart-breaking message left on ‘Habit,’ Cook opens up his world to anyone willing to listen to what he has to say.

That said, the narratives found within Sweet Dreamer don’t necessarily discuss things that share a common connection with one another. However, as Cook has stated in a few interviews, Sweet Dreamer isn’t meant to be a concept album; it’s simply a piece of work that encapsulates the best of Cook so far, which he has succeeded in creating. All thirteen songs on this record are a delight to listen to, and it’s evident that Cook has spent a lot of time writing and practicing to create such quality pop songs.

As a whole, Sweet Dreamer is a great introduction to the story of Will Joseph Cook. It’s dreamy and sweet as the album’s title suggests, and while Cook may be stuck in the clouds a lot, Sweet Dreamer is one dream I’m glad was made into a reality.

Recommended tracks: “Treat Me Like A Lover,” “Girls Like Me,” “Light of the Day”

title: Billy Joseph - Ride the Mystery // Album Review
content:
Written by Sam Celentano

Unless you frequent the bars and clubs of Topanga, CA, you most likely haven’t heard the musical stylings of singer-songwriter Billy Joseph. While he’s not a breakout artist, don’t let his debut album’s crude cover art fool you. Joseph provides the listener with a wide range of catchy tunes and impressive musicianship, while lending an intimate look into his life.

With rough vocals and a powerful backing band, Joseph’s age seems evident in his music, eliciting the sounds of Bruce Springsteen in what I can only call a modern Classic Rock album. The track list begins with a highlight. The artist introduces you to his songwriting prowess with “Keep Moving Forward,” a dramatic and well-composed tune that lacks any lyrical stimulation. Unfortunately, lackluster lyrical content is a common trait among songs across the board, and, while it does not detract from the musicality, it certainly hurts to convey the emotion heard in Joseph’s voice.

Where this album truly shines is in the fullness of its sound, via its great use of backing vocals and instruments that are not generally found in a typical rock band. “Let Her See You” and “Violet Still” further down the track list are fantastic examples of this sonic richness, but leave the listener to wonder whether or not his perhaps limited resources in the inception of this album were left to these gems.

Billy Joseph’s album comes across largely as a project he started for fun to jam with his pals — which should by no means diminish the quality of its content — and is perhaps best evidenced by this music video Joseph released for the album’s single, “Dirty”:

While the artist may have been fond of this tune enough to create a video for it, this song exhibits some of the least musical, slumping parts of the album. The disjointed playing and basic rhythms seem analogous to a square wheel, plodding its way through the song, akin to Billy Ray Cyrus’ “Achey Breaky Heart.” Paired with a downright crude music video, “Dirty” is a definite lowlight of Joseph’s album.

All in all, Billy Joseph’s energetic first album surprises the listener with its mostly impressive musicality and mixing, despite its amateur release. What seemed like a great deal of fun to record was equally fun to listen to, and hopefully there will be more content and improvement to come from Joseph, who is early into his late career.

title: Interview with Thomas Mars from Phoenix (05/30/17)
content:
Interviewed by Derek Khaothong

Set to debut on June 9th, 2017, Ti Amo has been in the works as early as September 2014 by Phoenix and has been described as an album about simple pure emotions: love, desire, lust, and innocence. Ti Amo is a very picturesque album, it creates an intimate setting of a fantasized version of Italy, a paradise consisting of never-ending Roman summers, antique marble statues, and fearless desire. Beginning June 2nd, Phoenix will launch their world tour, playing alongside indie poster-boy acts like Mac Demarco, The Lemon Twigs, and Whitney. I sat down and had a chat with Thomas Mars—lead vocalist of the band to talk about what Phoenix has been up to during their four-year hiatus.

Hey Thomas! How’s it going? 

T: Good, it’s nice to chat with you.

So, what’s it like to be back after a four-year hiatus? The release of new music was quite sudden, seemingly almost out of nowhere.

T: Yeah, it really was out of nowhere. We stayed in the same room to write music for about 3 years, it’s really strange because we have the most boring, most unexciting life for three years and then for a year or half, we get to travel and live this exciting life playing music for people. It was like Groundhog day—we basically stayed in the same room just writing music for three years pretty much.

Sounds like school. Living this unexciting life for the majority of your school days and then being free in the summer.

T: It’s similar to college, I’ve always been jealous of college in the US as a highlight of your life, where as in France it’s different and right from the beginning I couldn’t see myself committing to that. I’ve always envied the US for that culture.

Yeah, I guess college is really seen as this integral time of experimental development and pressure to have the best four years of their life.

T: Oh yeah, a lot of anticipation and pressure.

Congrats on Sofia’s new movie, The Beguiled. Phoenix wrote the score for the movie. Are there any differences the songwriting process when you’re writing a score for a movie versus an album?

T: It’s easier. There are limits, and we have frames of reference when we write scores. As a director, Sofia guides us in the right direction, while when it comes to our own music, we are the captain of our own ships and it can be daunting with money and time. When we first started out, renting out a studio was so expensive and we had such a limited amount of instruments and time to play. Now, there exists all of these different possibilities, which can be overwhelming. When we have a frame it allows us to be faster and more productive. We have visual cues and a preexisting environment that lets writing come easier for us.

The new album experiments with a trio of three languages, blending English, some Italian, and French. What’s it like to write different melodies in all of these similar, but explicitly different languages?

T: When we write songs, the first few melodies that come out with chords come out from mumble and nonsense. When we blended all of these different languages, I saw everyone’s eyes lit with fear and excitement. There is this leap of faith and bonding quality when you write it together. Some of our lyrics in this album refer to obscure gelatos,—we’re always trying to tell a story.

Yeah, I’ve noticed this central theme of classic Italy in Ti Amo. Specifically, the theme of “television” seems to appear in J-boy, what’s the story behind that?

T: There was a lot of inspiration that came from Italian and some German television rom our childhood memories. Now, you can simply watch it all on YouTube [laughs]. There’s a goldmine of references, which are far enough in our memory to create something contemporary about it. We were not trying to be authentic, rather slightly off.

Aside from television, what else inspired you? I know artists can find inspiration from the most random physical objects out there like Mac Demarco and his Viceroy cigarettes; did the band find any particular “physical” items that helped shape the sound for Ti Amo?

T: There were some items in the studio that I’m sure played a role that we were probably unaware of. I remember this portrait of the first French Astronaut—it was there the whole time and you know it wasn’t the most high-tech outfit, yet the guy still went to space. It was a motivation that it’s possible for us [laughs]. Everything has a visual cue at some point, but I think it’s interesting to mix two things that shouldn’t be together and don’t really get along. When it’s on the same song, they are forced to co-habit.

Photo by Ron Elkman

Let’s talk about the tour. Any particular festivals you excited to play?

T: The ones I don’t know. To be in Chicago one night and then at the Hollywood bowl—it’s fun to get a taste of the world in one week. It’s like an extensive course. Some of the shows when you play for a small venue are really exciting. The place I’m least excited to play are the places with so music that it feels like a factory. For example, Glastonbury has over 200 bands, which feels overwhelming because it’s a giant festival. However, I’m excited to play them all!

We talked earlier how contrast and juxtaposition between two things that should not go together can be fun to experiment with. Was it hard to make upward music in full contradiction with the political climate in Paris or did you draw inspiration from that unrest?

T: Our music is the result of trying to create a conscious formula rather than a political statement. I don’t really know how to do be political with music [laughs.] The times call for being responsible—but we got into music because we didn’t want to be responsible. I’d feel like a hypocrite if I changed that. I vote, I do things my community, and the times are horrible. For music it wouldn’t be helpful for us to go there. I don’t think it’s escapism or denial, you can tell Ti Amo is made in dark times, but there are no political statements. What’s really powerful about the arts is it can be whatever it wants to be.

Catch Phoenix playing in Los Angeles on June 15th at the Hollywood Bowl with supporting acts Mac Demarco and The Lemon Twigs.

title: Andy Shauf - The Party // Album Review
content:
Written by Kaden Kotinek 

Andy Shauf, Canadian singer-songwriter and instrument-master extraordinaire, premiered his third alternative album, The Party, this past year. He hails from Saskatchewan, Canada, and currently lives in a humble abode in The 6 (or Toronto for the uncultured readers). After opening for the Lumineers on their tour, he returned in April to bring us this album a month later. It is his first album under ANTI-, an international record label, and his first to earn multiple Juno and Canadian Independent Musician award nominations.

The album opens with a hypnotizing cut labeled “The Magician.” Versatile instrumentation (Soothing strings, a floating oboe, and a driving guitar, to name a few) all blend together behind Shauf’s vocals. Singing about a person that has worked to extreme lengths to conceal everything and reveal nothing, “The Magician” is a lyrical high point in this conceptual album. Tagged with vintage EQs (with emphasis on the mid range), the melodies and ‘doo-doo-doo’s’ will have you humming along for all three minutes and 52 seconds.

The track is followed by a slower cut “Early to the Party.” Describing the multiple perspectives to a party arrival, this soft cut takes a look at all the guests, and one in particular, presumably his (ex)lover. This song is a textbook example of how to use crescendos and diminuendos, and should be observed by musicians. Shauf constantly builds and destroys this song, to leave the listener to a final 40-second session of isolated vocals that team up with a soft guitar and piano chords to mark one of the highlights in this album.

“Twist Your Ankle,” the third cut, does more of the same work that the previous song does. Featuring a paced guitar chord progression, Shauf contemplates leaving the party altogether, since he faces discomfort.

The fourth track “Quite Like You” may very well be the best on the entire album. Shauf tells of dragging his own best friend to appeal to his ex with whom he recently broke up. A drum pattern that you tap your foot along to teams up with Shauf’s best melody to provide the perfect backdrop to this story. The song dives through twists and turns that are interlaced by a hook that will not leave your head — and this only leads to a cliffhanger that transitions the listener into the second half of the album.

The fifth track, appropriately titled “Begin Again,” it reflects upon the inconveniences of a small town life through the lens of a confused lover. A driving piano progression leads the listener into the next track that ties closely with the previous one, “The Worst in You.” The inconveniences evolve into nagging complications that, as a listener, you can’t help but empathize with, as he questions his love and finds no stable solution. In this song, a rhythm guitar lays the foundation as Shauf’s vocals are tied with strings and a steady electric guitar. On the seventh song, “To You,” he reveals a love-confession gone wrong. Wind instruments dominate this track while Andy reveals what can happen when emotionally charged scenarios spiral out of control — in this case, for the awkward. He leaves the song with the classic “forget I even mentioned it” as the strings suddenly cut and lead us into the final three songs on the album.

The eighth song “Eyes of Them All” is a mini love song about the girl at the party who’s dancing in the center of the room, without a care in the world. A damp tambourine and high keys combine on the chorus to create my favorite moment on the album; outshining bliss in the overwhelming tides of social anxiety. In the sea of all the problems, discomfort, and unanswered questions, the listener escapes, dances and smiles for four minutes.

The ninth cut “Alexander All Alone” takes a dark turn that puts the listener on edge. A loud piano key tapped for three and half minutes is joined by another diverse Shauf arrangement. Shauf documents the end of a lonely smoker’s life with eerie vocals to create a distinct timbre that isolates the track. It seems to be an unrelated climax to the party as it leads into the final track of the album.

“Martha Sways” is the beautiful, minimal, simplistic bow on the album. It contains a lulling guitar, soft vocal features, and a warm, growing strings section that acts a soft close to a memorable album.

Although it is 37 minutes, this alternative album has the feel of a complete take of parties, love, and everything in between — from the perspective of a wallflower. Thanks for the music, Andy.

8.4./10

HIGHLIGHTS: The Magician, Quite Like You, Eyes of Them All, Alexander All Alone

LOWLIGHTS: Twist Your Ankle, To You

title: Spotlight of the Week // Fine Dining
content:
Written by Gabby Seok

Everyone loves food. That’s why Annie Rimmon, also known as DJ Sorta Gourmet, has dedicated her show to it. Fine Dining invites chefs, restaurateurs and even chocolate specialists to engage in a discussion about some of the most delicious foods and recipes that will make your mouth water. From Italian-Jewish descent, Rimmon says that cuisine has always been a big part of her family - “the kitchen table was the center of my home, where my family would eat a deliciously cooked meal prepared by my mom every night.” This and her growing interest in the culinary arts after studying abroad in Florence serve as inspiration for her show. Rimmon’s enthusiasm about food is contagious, so I had to ask what the three food items would be if she needed to shoot, marry or make love to each of them. She answered with glazed salmon, bolognese pasta and English toffee, respectively. To find out why, catch the show on Fridays at 9 AM for some sweet and savory sounds of flavor! Or listen to the podcast at anytime on MixCloud. 

Bon appetit!
tags: ucla radio spotlight of the week

title: Faces of UCLA Radio // Springterns 2017
content:
In honor of our annual Pledge Drive, we will be featuring various members of our station this week so you can get to know the many different faces of UCLA Radio.

Every quarter UCLA Radio welcomes new DJs into our station. Meet some of the members of our Springtern 2017 class!

Charlotte McGinn

Charlotte McGinn is a second year student in the web department, and is excited as a member of the station to tap into her technical and artistic sides by “combining my technical and creative abilities in order to make our website both functional and pretty!” One of the best concerts she’s ever attended was Cage the Elephant where she could “feel the balcony bouncing up and down” as she and fellow fans danced along to the music. Besides UCLA Radio, Charlotte is involved with ACM and the group WATT for women in electrical engineering.

Madison Feldman

Madison Feldman is a second year student in the promotions department, although she is looking to contribute to UCLA Radio in many different ways. She remembers loving music ever since her family would take her to concerts on the beach - “One time the lead singer pulled me onto stage and gave me a tambourine. Just thinking about this memory makes me want to smile.” On campus, Madison is also a part of the Student Giving Committee, the PINK campus team, and helps with digital design for calfresh.

Miranda Montenegro

Miranda Montenegro is a first year student in the photo and video department, and hopes to use her camera skills to boost promotions for UCLA Radio. She can never forget seeing Aerosmith when she was eight years old and singing along with Steven Tyler to “Walk This Way,” all profanity included (“much to the dismay of my parents.”) Outside of radio, Miranda is a member of Kappa Delta and can often be found at Salt N’ Straw.

Sahej Verma

Sahej Verma is a first year student in the sports department and is looking forward to meeting more creative individuals through UCLA Radio. His favorite musical memory was going on road trips with his family as a kid and “blaring the hottest Bollywood hits.” When he’s not in the station, Sahej can be found playing soccer, watching sports (“surprise, surprise”) as well as writing poetry and dancing.

Gillian Moore

Gillian Moore is a first year student in the music department and is hoping to join more departments and learn more about the music industry while in radio. She was excited recently to have acquired the setlist for her favorite band at Coachella. Gillian is also a coach for the Special Olympics, as well as the philanthropy assistant for Chi Omega and a community representative for on campus housing.

Gabrielle Seok

Gabrielle Seok is a third year student in the digital press department and is looking forward to contributing music writing and photography to UCLA Radio. One of her best memories involving music was interviewing Sameer Gadhia, as well as meeting Young the Giant. Aside from radio, Gabrielle runs her own blog, dances, and goes to music festivals.

Alexis Sanchez 

Alexis Sanchez is a third year student in the art and design department. She’ll always remember driving to Wyoming with her family, “listening to my dad’s old music and loving car drives ever since then.” Outside of UCLA Radio, Alexis loves yoga, working out, hanging out with her husky puppy, and dancing.

title: Stella Donnelly - Thrush Metal // Album Review
content:
Written By : Lillian Stanwick

Post Date : 04/27/17


I could easily see Stella Donnelly’s new EP, Thrush Metal, becoming the sort of debut album that is underestimated by its audience and then quickly forgotten. This would be an incredible misfortune. Thrush Metal’s composition is simple; each song features Stella’s voice, accompanied by a single guitar. However, the messages and themes woven into the lyrics of Donnelly’s tunes are far from simple. In today’s era of over-produced music, it is easy to dismiss simple acoustic tunes as ‘unimaginative.’ Our ears have been trained by recent pop music to crave songs with synthesizers, mellotrons, and additional post-production sounds. That’s not to say that these new, heavily mixed songs are inherently bad. UCLA’s Radio’s recent profile of CUCO highlighted an artist who has skillfully produced music that takes advantage of this trend and produced high-quality albums. However, given the shift towards production-heavy music of the past five to ten years, it has become reasonable —albeit falsely — for listeners to assume that a lack of manufactured sound entails a lack of creativity.

This view not only dismisses great singer-songwriters, past albums (such as a favorite of mine, Karen O’s Crush Songs), but it also makes it all too easy to overlook excellent albums that released recently. Stella Donnelly’s Thrush Metal is one such great album, and I honestly hope that it is not so easily missed. The opening track, “Mechanical Bull,” is the most popular song from the album. The lyrics about ditching a suffocating lover are at once forceful and fragile — revealing both the annoyance experienced in unsatisfying relationships, as well as the aching emptiness of deciding that one is better off alone. It’s no surprise that this track has resonated with the widest audience.

But “Mechanical Bull” is not the track that stands out the most to me. Instead, it’s the following song, “Boys Will Be Boys.” This one is the most stirring, since it references the language that promotes rape culture. The first few lines of the first verse are painful, haunting, almost, and they set a heavy tone for the rest of the song: “My friend told me of a secret/Told me that she blames herself/You invaded her magnificence/Put your hand over her mouth.” On first glance, the phrase “invaded her magnificence” seems like an odd euphemism to use. It’s awkward, and almost makes the listener squirm a bit. But this feeling of discomfort is necessary. Rape culture is supposed to make you uncomfortable. You should be bothered by these ‘alternative terms’ that are used to downplay heinous sex crimes. Donnelly’s song continues with more of these common justifications, “Why was she all alone?/Wearing her shirt that low.” These weak excuses create a feeling of disgust in the listener. By the time Donnelly first cries out “They said boys will be boys,” you’re angry that a culture that accepts such insubstantial justifications has been allowed to persist for so long.

The last three songs on the album are far less pointed. “Mean to Me” calls back to “Mechanical Bull” in that it details the experience of being in a physically and emotionally draining relationship. It effectively shows off Donnelly’s skills as a storyteller, lyricist and singer. “Grey” is a similar song, similarly detailing a relationship that is self-deprecating. Do these songs discuss the same relationship? It’s possible, but the songs seem too distinct to be about the same person.

Finally, the EP closes with “A Poem,” which is metaphorically heavy. Donnelly croons to a simple strum pattern, as she plays out the EP. It’s a fine ending to a brief (18-minute) collection of songs. Stella Donnelly’s debut is a strong one, and it shows great promise for future releases. I just hope that today’s listeners will not overlook this artist’s stripped down sound in an age where highly produced tunes are best sellers.

title: Interview with Circa Waves @ The Teragram Ballroom (6/13/17)
content:
Interviewed by Alana Myers

Since Circa Waves’ formation in Liverpool, England four years ago, the band has released two records - their 2015 debut Young Chasers, and their newest album Different Creatures, which came out this past March. Both of these records have allowed them to tour and play shows and festivals internationally. Before Circa Waves’ headlining show in Los Angeles at the Teragram Ballroom, I spoke with two of the band’s members - lead singer and guitarist Kieran Shudall and guitarist Joe Falconer - about the band’s latest stateside tour, their new album, songwriting, and more!

Well first…this year has been pretty exciting for you. Your album came out, Different Creatures, and you’re back in the States for a tour - how does it feel to be back in the States and to be touring?

Kieran: It’s really cool, I mean, I think there’s a sort of history of British bands coming over to America, and it feels very much like we’re just sort of following the footsteps of so many other bands who’ve made history over here. So it feels sort of like we’re in a movie - and we’re like the heroes of the film and we’re trying to conquer America and bring British rock ‘n’ roll to the people.

I see that, ‘cause you’ve been making waves in America! More and more people are starting to know who you are.

Kieran: I hope so, yeah. It’s hard to know from where, from you know, the thousands of miles away that we are.

Joe: I think we’ve noticed it on the East Coast and stuff that we’ve done, like more people have been coming back to shows and shows, and people sort of like know the music a bit more, it’s not just curiosity.

Yeah, I can see the big difference. I was at a show in Santa Ana two years ago, and people were just starting to know you. But now, they actually know the lyrics. That must be a good feeling.

Kieran: It’s great yeah, it’s like validation for all the hard work you put in I suppose. I always like to hear American people singing my songs - it kind of makes them sound better *laughs*

What’s been a highlight of the stateside tour so far?

Kieran: Mercury Lounge was pretty cool.

Joe: Mercury Lounge. I thought Philadelphia was one of my favorites on this tour. We’ve been there a couple of times but we’ve never done a headline show in Philadelphia. It was our first ever one, and yeah, it was just one of those ones where it felt like the people, like we brought people from the support shows we did - it was like a Monday night or something.

Kieran: Also we went out to this cool bar where we played and - what’s that ball thing called?

Joe: Skee-ball?

Kieran: We played skee-ball all night and got really hammered, so that was also a highlight. I discovered that I get better at skee-ball the more beer I drink. So, now I know that. I know what to do touring next time.

Well in terms of your records, Different Creatures sounds pretty different from Young Chasers. They both still sound like Circa Waves records, but I guess were you sort of afraid to change the sonic direction of Different Creatures to this more heavier sound?

Kieran: I think we just sort of went with our gut really. I mean, I think the songs are still pop songs, but we just turned the distortion up a little bit, and that fear sort of quickly goes away when you first play them live, and people you know, lose their minds to it and stuff, it’s really great. So, yeah I don’t feel like it was a mistake. I think it worked out pretty well.

Do you find that some songs translate better live than they do on the record?

Kieran: They’re all pretty great live *laughs* I mean the record was sort of, even though it’s layered and stuff, it’s still pretty much just the four of us. There’s not too much going on in terms of - we don’t have loads of like synths or like magical noises, I mean there’s a few magical noises. But, generally it’s still just four guys sort of playing instruments. So live, it really plays to that, but it’s just got, you know we’ve bought bigger amps, got big bad guitars, so everything’s bigger and bolder and is sort of ready for stadiums - if they’ll have us.

Looking at the “Fire That Burns” video, I noticed that there’s a lot of red imagery - there’s a lot of red objects and it’s dominated by red lighting. And also, the Different Creatures album cover is red, so what does the color red signify for you?

Kieran: It’s just a really, it’s just like it’s sexy, it’s blood, it’s love, it’s life, it just seems to be, it’s the most striking color for anything I think. And we watched, there’s a film called Mean Streets, which is like a Harvey Keitel and Robert De Niro seventies movie - I mean I go to this bar downstairs and there’s a thing in the film like it’s a weird kind of thing, this bar, and the whole bar is shot in this really blood-red sort of lit thing, and I just remember seeing that and thinking, “That would be an amazing concept for an album.” And so we just sort of pushed that through the whole thing. And it’s funny to watch that and go like, “Oh, that’d be a cool idea,” and now you’re in you know, LA, and someone goes, “You’ve done everything red, why was that?” and you go, “Oh fuck, that was just a silly idea one day we had.”

The video’s also pretty cinematic. So, if there was a Circa Waves film, which actor would you cast to play yourself and why?

*both laugh*

Joe: I think we’d get the Wilson brothers playing us.

Kieran: Yeah, you’re sort of, you can have Owen Wilson. “Woww.”

Joe: “Wow!”

Kieran: Apparently I get told all the time I look like that boy from Shameless.

Joe: Lip.

Kieran: Lip, maybe you could play me. Boy if I had a choice, I’d choose Jeff Goldblum.

Do you watch Peaky Blinders?

Kieran: I don’t. [to Joe] Do you watch it?

Joe: I do yeah, it’s amazing.

Kieran: Well he’s from Birmingham, which is set in Birmingham, isn’t it?

Joe: Some of those accents are really bad.

Really? I thought they were good!

Joe: Yeah, it’s like no one can agree how far they do the accent. So you get some people that are really pushing it.

That’s true. Yeah, I think the lead in the show looks kind of like Kieran.

Kieran: Cillian Murphy?

Joe: Cillian Murphy, yeah.

Kieran: Yeah maybe, he’s a good one, he’s a great actor.

Kieran, I know that you’re the main lyricist for the band, but [Joe] have you ever thought about songwriting for future records?

Joe: I write, but it’s yet to make an appearance.

Why?

Joe: I’m kind of too busy doing this really, yeah, I’m waiting for a gap. When Kieran runs out of stamina or just when he has a short mental breakdown, then I’m gonna put my stuff out.

Kieran: I feel like Joe, Joe writes a really cool style of songs which you know when we do have a gap year, I’ll no doubt release something.

Joe: Yeah, it’s good though ‘cause you know, it’s nice to have something that’s different than the band separately. I’ve got my little pocket full of songs ready to go - can play much, much smaller venues out in LA.

Well, lyrically, for you Kieran, what’s the song off of Different Creatures that you’re most proud of having written?

Kieran: I think “Out On My Own,” I think is one of the most personal sort of things I’ve wrote and for me, that was a step in the right direction in terms of taking it, like not just being able to sing a song every night, but you can really put yourself into, and not just like a throw-away idea, you know what I mean? So yeah, probably that song.

And lastly, we’re a college radio station, UCLA Radio, and every week our students come up with our own shows and we have our own DJ names. So, if you were a part of UCLA Radio, what would your DJ name be?

Kieran: DJ name…

Joe: I’ve previously used the DJ name ‘Bad Taste.’

I like that!

Joe: Yeah!

Kieran: DJ Bad Taste? DJ Request.

I like it, it’s simple.

Kieran: Yeah, but I wouldn’t take the piss *laughs*

Circa Waves return to America to support Two Door Cinema Club this September, and are touring across Europe and Asia this summer. Find dates and ticket links to a concert near you here!

title: Logic - Everybody // Album Review
content:
Written by Harry Gonzalez-Mejia

Maryland rapper Logic returns with his third full length commercial LP. This time, his record is inspired by his contemporary Kendrick Lamar, as he attempts to tackle many topics across an hour and ten minute time span. His album is riddled with skits that try to piece together a story between an Adam persona and God. The entire project is ambitious within itself, as from afar it is extremely well meant in terms of Logic’s intent. However the lack of cohesion causes the album to feel extremely scattered and thin; certain lyrical moments on the record lack a stronger substance - perhaps the lyricist should have taken a bit more time with the pen when it came to remarks about race and equality. The moments in which Logic considers racial equality - for example on “Black Spiderman” - feel thinly based on the sole fact that the rapper decides to rap from distinct points of view on the song. By switching scopes, Logic does not use the track as a means to push for equality in an analytical way. The notions and sentiments that Logic expresses on the track are pushed by his desire for there to be love, equality, understanding and hope between people of different creeds and colors. This is not something to loathe or specifically criticize in a review, but something around the topic begs for a little more dissection.

Something that Logic will undoubtedly be criticized for is his lack of cohesion when placed in comparison with other rappers that have successfully released “conscious” albums that touch on race and equality, such as Lamar. However, when looking at Logic’s work as a sole piece of art that exists sans-To Pimp a Butterfly, the good nature of the album shines as something that will undoubtedly keep Logic popular, well-loved, and appreciated by his fans. However, this is, once again, not too say that his message is always well structured and well-layered. He sings, “I just wanna spread the message of equality,” on “Take It Back,” and then proceeds to describe his growing up in a racist household despite being biracial. Logic also explains how he grew up in a home filled with narcotics and how he went to school being told that he wouldn’t amount to anything because he was a “cracker” despite being biracial. One could say that this entire explanation would be more effective and enjoyable as a verse rather than a spoken word piece. He ends with the phrase “stop killing each other,” and it is something that would, once again, be more potent, more memorable, and more musically appealing if it were delivered in the manner of a verse.

The track “America” is one of the moments on the record in which everyone’s passions blaze through a steady, boom bap, bouncing bass instrumental in a captivating and fiery way. Most of the bars on this track are potent, focused, and prove to be some of the best lyrical moments of the entire record. Black Thoughts and Logic steal and hold the show, respectively, on this track and it is animpressive moment on the record. There is a moment on “Ink Blot” in which Juicy J appears and seems to be talking directly to fake individuals, fake rappers, and “trappers”; the guest rapper tells them all to “kill yourselves” and one could feel that this point on the record is extremely hypocritical to the entire message of the album (that of love, hope, and positivity). Anyone could think that a simple “fuck you” would have been sufficient to get the point across, but to directly tell somebody to kill themselves, no matter how foul or purposely ignorant and enraging they may be, is a very strong sentiment to be tossed around.

On the ninth track, “Waiting Room,” listeners are reminded that there is an entire skit and undercover story being told throughout the record. Neil DeGrasse Tyson plays the God character that explains how everybody is connected to each other, that all humans are interconnected and that every act of hatred is one done to one’s self, just as every act of love is one done to one’s self. It is a difficult concept to completely grasp, but the message comes relatively out of the blue after a set of eight tracks that jump from topics of personal growth to the current state of racial relations in USA to critiques of the music industry and social media. On “1-800-273-8255,” Logic and Alessia Cara come together in an extremely heart warming, melodically inspiring way to craft a song that deals with depression and the desire to complete suicide. The instrumental, from the softly arranged strings to the somber piano, as well as the vocals and content in the verses, all shine together.

This same sensation carries onto the next track, “Anziety,” a track that deals with the depression’s worrisome counterpart. However, this track concludes with a similar verse-less ending and Logic speaking about a personal experience that is powerful. Again, if this had been delivered in a verse rather than a personal anecdote, the song would have been much more memorable and honest. One could take this track as a personal speech, and many might not find the same issue. Logic’s honesty in regards to mental health is still something to be in awe of.

Overall, Logic makes a sincere attempt to tackle a lot of topics within a small span of an hour. His attempts are honest and brief, but the overall lush presentation of the record allows for the record to be an enjoyable listen. The rapper should be appreciated for the attempt, and not criticized for falling short of his contemporaries’ achievements. Logic has certainly come into his own lane, and the peace, love and positivity that he pushes forward with each record is more resonant and vibrant than ever before on this LP.

7/10

title: Laura Marling @ The Mayan (5/2/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Helen Gallagher

Laura Marling recently released a new album called Semper Femina, a phrase borrowed from Virgil, meaning “always woman.” Indeed, the album is full of feminine energy - cheerful, resilient, and reverential of the female spirit.
