I had the pleasure of attending Marling’s LA show at the Mayan Theater during her U.S. promotion of the new album (Marling is from the UK).

I’d seen Marling perform once before, at Outside Lands Music Festival. She’s a notoriously subdued performer, and I was too far away to really hear her sound, so I didn’t think much of it. This time was totally different. I’d fallen in love with Marling’s music, and had begun to understand the quiet but fierce poetry of her sound.

The show was held at the Mayan, a uniquely kitschy space. True to its name, it seemed like a Disney theme park Indiana Jones ride. Marling chuckled to herself a few songs into her set in acknowledgment of the decor.

The crowd was loud and bustling, an eager excitement throughout the space, but as soon as the stand up bass began to crescendo for the opening tune of Marling’s first song, “Soothing” - one off her new album - a hush fell over the audience. She played three songs in a row, barely a breath in between, and the audience stood almost entirely still (except the occasional swaying), eyes cast towards the stage, mesmerized by her angelic presence.

Marling’s voice is technically perfect. She hits every note with ease, and adds beautiful vocal riffs to already complex songs, simultaneously playing hauntingly rich melodies on her guitar. All the while, she stands almost entirely still, and sometimes stares up at something we cannot see. At the risk of sounding trite, it’s a religious experience.

Marling has the captivating gentility of Aphrodite; the fierce wit of Athena. She is indeed a goddess. My camera can’t seem to focus on her because of the bright white light that she emits (a reflection off of her milk-colored hair, no doubt). She’s accompanied by a full band, who all stare at her reverentially while she sings, as awestruck as we are.

You can’t help but feel romantic when you listen to Marling croon. Couples wrap their arms around each other; single people wrap their arms around themselves. At one point, Marling’s band exits the stage, and it’s just us and her. Her band is wonderful, especially her celestial back up singers, whose clear sweet voices highlight Marling’s soulful, throaty one, but she doesn’t need them. Her voice and her guitar fill up the room. My friend and I muse to each other about the miracle of such a loud sound coming from such a tiny person. Her guitar is inexplicably voluminous. She plays a medley of three old songs, including two of my favorites, “Salinas” and “Don’t Ask Me Why.” I can’t help but feel my eyes prick with tears.

When they come back, she allows us a bit of stage banter, quipping, partially to herself, that she always gets criticized for not engaging with the audience enough. She won’t do an encore, she says - she doesn’t do that. Indeed, she doesn’t, and slips off the stage quietly to thunderous applause. But the audience doesn’t mind, and I see only smiles and the occasional tear on the faces flooding out of the theater.

I have a chance to speak to Marling for a moment after the show, and she is as ethereal in person as she is on stage. I thank her for the incredible performance, and she smiles at me, reserved but appreciatory. I listen to Semper Femina exclusively for the next three days, looking forward the next time I have the chance to see her perform.

title: Grouplove - Little Mess // Album Review
content:
Written by Lillian Stanwick 

This past Record Store Day, Grouplove released their Little Mess EP, an addendum to the Big Mess album they released in early September. Big Mess is the band’s first album since members Christian Zucconi and Hannah Hooper had their first child. Some songs on the album play like open letters to the couple’s infant daughter, especially the opening track “Welcome to Your Life.” Little Mess draws on this pre-established motif by beginning in a similar fashion. “Tell Me a Story” is slow and endearing. The chorus plays, “So tell me a story/Well, I’m in no hurry/I lay my head down/Against our baby now,” an apparent reference to Zucconi and Hooper’s new parenthood.

“Torso” follows, bringing with it an eery riff and dreamy lyrics. The song sounds as if it was plucked straight from a Grouplove concert set list by including many of the same features that have come to define the band’s sound. The keen listener will notice the Pixies reference to “Velouria.” Next is “MRI.” Hooper takes lead vocals on this track. The song radiates a subtle, warm positivity. It is not an in-your-face “look on the bright side” sort of uplifting track that is standard fare on most pop albums. Instead, it acknowledges the struggles, the “darkest hours” in our lives, but follows this with gentle encouragement to recognize the people who love us.

I would have been disappointed to have seen a live version of a song on this album — had it been anything other than “Enlighten Me.” Often, I feel like live albums are just afterthought productions forced out by record labels. In most instances, the sound quality of the recorded performances is shoddy, leading listeners back to the original album. Grouplove’s I’m With You did not explicitly contain these characteristics, but I wouldn’t deem it a necessary part of their discography. The live version of “Enlighten Me” is distinct enough from the recorded version to secure a warranted spot on the EP. The band has historically used “Enlighten Me” to introduce their encores. Towards the end of the shows they played for the Big Mess Tour, the majority of the band members would exit the stage, leaving Zucconi as the sole performer, armed with an acoustic guitar and illuminated by a single beam of light. He would then slowly begin to strum and croon out “Enlighten Me.” Eventually, the other members would return to the stage to bang out the end of the song in a heartbeat-accelerating crescendo.  On the album, an echoing piano plays instead of Zucconi’s guitar, thus differentiating the live version from the studio track. For these reasons, the inclusion of a live version of “Enlighten Me” feels well thought out, and it contributes nicely to the rest of the EP.

Finally, “Adios Amigos” closes the EP. The song reminds me of their very first album and the track “Naked Kids.” Both sound very similar. However, “Naked Kids” is a bonafide salute to dazed days on the beach, whereas “Adios Amigos” appears to be about a more austere topic, perhaps regarding misconceptions about material possessions (there’s an odd reference to Tarascon, a commune in France, that supports this hypothesis). The song plays out, repeating “All in a moment, we can live forever.” As a longtime fan of the band, this last lyric resonated with my past worry that the group was heading for a breakup. In the wake of Zucconi and Hooper welcoming their daughter Willa and Rabin getting married, it seemed to me that there was a very real possibility that Grouplove’s days, and albums, were numbered. I hope that the band proves me to be an overly pessimistic person and continues to produce more music. Overall, Little Mess is an excellent continuation of Big Mess, and it includes songs that will excite returning fans and create new ones for the accomplished group.

title: Galantis with SNBRN @ The Novo (4/18/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Helen Lee

Seizure-inducing neon strobe lights, heat radiating from jostling bodies packed in too-close quarters, and deafeningly loud mixes of popular electronic dance music tracks are not the usual indicators that it’s a Tuesday night. But this unconventional weekday night is considered anything but for Swedish EDM duo Galantis. For them, mixing hyped electronic beats and hit Grammy-nominated tracks, synergistic and energized live-performances, and making every member of the crowd dance the night away has undoubtedly become a lifestyle.

The duo made their debut in early 2013 and their rapidly growing notoriety and popularity can be attributed to their catchy dance music, dynamic and creative remixes of popular songs, and meaningful original lyrics. And on April 18, Galantis’ vivacious, larger-than-life live performance rocked the Novo, a small intimate nightclub safely tucked away behind the bustling Staples Center in Downtown L.A. With energy unrivaled by many seasoned performers, it comes as no surprise that they’ve been invited to perform and headline at music festivals such Coachella, Electric Daisy Carnival, and Lollapalooza.

To kick off the night, Galantis’ performance was opened by SNBRN. Also signed with Atlantic Records, SNBRN blends a mix of different genres including house, indie dance, and disco. The crowd was lukewarm but became more energized as soon as he played two of his most popular songs, “Raindrops” and his latest single “You Got Me.” At first, I was skeptical of the SNBRN-Galantis pairing, but I found over time that SNBRN was the most fitting opener for the night, as the mellow undulating beats of SNBRN complemented the high-pitched, high-energy staccatos of Galantis. The visuals on the screen also created a feeling of catharsis that accurately fit the beats of the songs played. While SNBRN played for the first hour, people trickled in and out of the venue, and the ground floor was fairly vacant. Given this was a sold out show and the Novo is a very small venue, I was intrigued as to what the environment would be like when it was completely packed. EDM artists are usually popular in the music festival setting because it allows guests and attendees to move from artist to artist and also dance freely to the beat drops without injuring the people around them. I soon found out that space to dance and move to the music was a luxury I would no longer enjoy as it became closer and closer to the time Galantis would perform. The upsurge of people waiting to see Galantis made it so that people were standing shoulder to shoulder and physical contact between strangers was an inevitable part of the experience.

When my phone notified me that it was 10 p.m., like clockwork, the lights dimmed completely and the venue grew silent. Almost immediately, the crowd crescendoed in cheers shouting, “Galantis!” like whirlwinds around me. The size of the venue made it so that even the smallest of sounds were amplified and created an environment similar to an echo chamber. The tension of anticipation continued to build and the energy of the crowd was overwhelming. The sounds of the crowd was immediately punctuated by Galantis’ first song, “Runaway,” as Christian Karlsson and Linus Eklöw both jumped out on stage, waving two large GALANTIS flags. Throughout their entire performance, both Karlsson and Eklow continued to amp up the energy of the crowd by counting down the beat drops, staggering between mellower songs and high-energy lineups, and dancing and jumping along with the crowd. Their exuberance and interaction with the crowd truly made the night an unforgettable one.

The beautiful visual graphics and the fitting strobe lights also made the night remarkable. The neon strobe lights fit the beats of the music and combined with the white lighting and the mythical animals that graced the digital screen of the stage made it feel like an out-of-body experience. The smoke machine and confetti were wonderful touches that completed the experience and rained down like colorful snowflakes over the raging crowd. The enticing, exuberant nature of the duo made the crowd let go of all of the stresses associated with a typical weekday night.

title: Faces of UCLA Radio // Fallterns 2016
content:
In honor of our annual Pledge Drive, we will be featuring various members of our station this week so you can get to know the many different faces of UCLA Radio.

The UCLA Radio station could not function without the hard work and dedication of our interns. We welcome an intern class every quarter, and over the next few days we are excited to share with you the new members that have joined us in the station this past year.

Megan Hullander

A first year UCLA student, Megan Hullander has been an all-star contributor to the the music, news, and marketing departments, and recently became the photo and video department manager. Catch her hosting Garage Sale every Saturday at 12 p.m., where she’s welcomed guests such as Archon and The Regrettes. When she’s not spending most of her time in the radio station, she loves hiking, camping, backpacking, and “other run of the mill nature things.”

“I love those moments when the perfect song comes on that matches your mood.”

Ethan Lee

Ethan Lee (DJ Leegato) is a third year psychology student in the productions department and the host of Musicology every Friday at 4 p.m. As a member of UCLA Radio, he hopes to contribute a greater diversity to the music culture as well as contribute his technical skills. His love for music began far before UCLA Radio, with his favorite musical memory being the first time he performed a jazz solo on the piano. Outside of the station, Ethan enjoys biking, kung fu, and watching movies.

Alexandra Ivanova

Alexandra Ivanova is a first year student in the news and music departments and host of the New York Hypnotic School every Saturday at 5 p.m. She loves as a radio DJ being able to discuss the news during one hour and play her favorite music the next. Although she admits “radio is probably the coolest thing I do,” Alex also interns with the Santa Monica Pier Aquarium, volunteers at the UCLA hospital, and does research with the Alzheimer’s Drug Discovery lab.

“I really like the diversity of radio and want to help in supporting that too, whether that’s in music tastes or political ideologies.”

title: HOMESHAKE @ The Echoplex (4/18/17) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Brittany Hewitt

Post Date: 4/28/17

It was a Tuesday night when my dad and I walked into the Echoplex around 9 p.m. A white dude, barefoot and shirtless, was singing intensely on stage. His whole body was involved with it and every ounce of him was pulsating, from his toes (since he wasn’t wearing shoes) to his raised shoulders. To both of our pleasant surprise, it was actually quite good; the audience itself was into it too, probably thinking he’s the kind of guy they wouldn’t mind smoking a joint with.

As I ordered an IPA, in true Echo Park fashion, I reflected on how Andy Boay is not particularly the same mellow vibe as HOMESHAKE, but he certainly is the same alt energy. This curatorial choice by the Echoplex probed me with questions. Do you feature similar music in the opener before the main act, so you’re lubed up, or do you go for its stimulating antithesis sound so you’re pleasantly surprised? The Echoplex chose the later, which left us all impressionistically intrigued and pleasantly surprised.

Finally the part we’d been waiting for arrived: HOMESHAKE.

HOMESHAKE is the love project of Peter Sagar, occasionally joined by Mark Goetz, Greg Napier, and Brad Loughead. Growing up in the graylands of Alberta, Canada, Sagar later moved to Montreal, weaving in suburban soundscapes with upbeat tempos. Their debut album, In the Shower, masterfully captures what this must have been like, the perfect album for steamy showers and relaxing with the bros. HOMESHAKE released another record, Midnight Snack, the next year, marking his transition from working as Mac Demarco’s bassist to developing an individualistic, slow rally for wandering the streets stoned with your homies. His latest album, Fresh Air, is sleepy, lovey-dovey, and perfect for a daytime booty call.

The Echoplex was crowded with people who look like they used to be Mac Demarco fans but aren’t now because he’s cool - retired Demarcos, if you will. This is all too ironic as Demarco himself was on the smoke deck outside the entire set, but I’m sure he was internally bobbing his head. Two disco balls hung over the audience, transfixing the audience into a slow lull, humming and bobbing along to Sagar and his side kicks.

Their live performance sounded identical to their albums. It’s incredible how you can close your eyes and meditate on this sound, and it’s just like being in your homie Josh’s backyard a few streets down in Echo Park, listening to HOMESHAKE. Still, of course, the real thing is always unbeatable.

title: Alex G @ The Echoplex (6/15/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Caroline Famiglietti

(Sandy) Alex G’s show is sold out. This comes as no surprise; he’s just released his seventh full-length album, Rocket, a critically acclaimed compilation worthy of all its praise. Originally a bedroom singer/songwriter releasing DIY songs on Bandcamp, Alex G has garnered a following across the country - I can most certainly vouch for Los Angeles. The anticipation is palpable through Cende’s energetic opening set and Japanese Breakfast’s dynamic follow-up. Alex’s first steps onstage elicit screams and blurry Snapchats from devoted fans (a sizeable group). There’s hype, and I can feel it.

It’s hard to overstate the stylistic diversity Alex and his band bring to the stage. Songs like “Bobby” and “Proud,” two twangy, folk-inspired standouts from Rocket, contrast brilliantly with the hard-hitting screamer “Brick” and the jazzy, bass-heavy “Guilty.” Alternating between playing guitar and keyboard, Alex sings with an intimacy and an intensity that leaves me self-reflecting, thinking, damn, I know that feeling.

A crowd-pleaser in the most literal sense, Alex spends the last half of his over an hour long set playing requests from front-row fans. The inclusivity of the atmosphere is striking. It’s like hearing encore after encore, as each choice satisfies a different sect of eager fans. He takes us back years prior, playing “Boy” from DSU and “Mary” from Trick. Some fans around me can’t be stumped—they know every word. Alex bridges the gap between artist and audience effortlessly; it feels like I’ve been hanging out with him for the past hour. I’ll say this: next time Alex is in town, jump on those tickets.

title: Lightning in a Bottle 2017 // Festival Review
content:
Written by Gabrielle Seok

Photos courtesy of Michael Roush (@michaelroushphotography)

Lightning in a Bottle was a four day long dream. The festival is located in the desert valley of Bradley, CA where the mountainous grounds are alive and resemble what I imagine the moon’s gravel to look like. I had heard good rumors about LiB, and I was very excited to experience the festival for myself. I attended the festival with a large group of fellow UCLA students, and we set up camp in Lot 3, which was a 15 minute walk away from the festival grounds. On Thursday morning, we grounded our tents and EZ-Ups in a communal fashion, settling into our new home for the next few days. Everyone’s excitement and joy for the festival was palpable. Smiles were contagious and high fives were ubiquitous. Many of the camp members had already been to the festival before. For many of us, it was our very first time.

Entering the festival, my eyes were captivated by the colorful and natural landscape. The lake had risen to 50 percent capacity, and the water glimmered under the sun’s rays. Large stages were rooted on different hills of the festival grounds. Each one acquired a distinct color scheme and design. All were very DoLaB-esque, well-executed and perfect for dancing. The festival grounds were connected by bridges. The bridges on the high grounds were narrow and stable for walking. Others were afloat on the lake and playfully wobbled to the march of the crowd’s steps. The floating bridges required quite a bit of trust, in both your own ability to balance and others to reassure you that no one would make sudden movements, resulting in a crash into the water. On the lake, there were motor-powered, bohemian-styled docs, enabling mobility across the waters. Festival-goers jumped onto these decorated rafts with friends, having dance parties on the lake.

The people of LiB were magical, often dressed in free-flowing fashion with outrageous colors. Weird costumes were welcomed and even encouraged. Others opted for functional outfits that were able to endure the fickle weather. The mornings and afternoons were warm, often reaching upwards of 80 degrees. Nights were colder and plummeted down to the 40-50s. It was manageable with a mid-day change in clothes, and I enjoyed the weather for the most part. Sometimes there were strong winds that did not help with the massive amounts of dust and dirt. To manage the dusty winds, it was imperative to wear a headscarf or breathing masks. I had some fun with this, and I packed a variety of colorfully patterned headbands that I wrapped around my mouth and nose. This helped tremendously, but dirt was impossible to avoid. At the end of every day, my body would be covered in dirt. Even my nose would be stuffed; however, this was a small cost to pay for the amount of joy I was having.

I participated in a variety of LiB activities. Some of my favorites were held at Yoga Sol, Mediation Mountain, and Sound Bath. Yoga Sol was a yoga class, led by a professional instructor. Meditation Mountain provided an atmospheric sanctuary for those who desired to meditate or chant in a communal and guided space. It overlooked the festival grounds, and the view was unforgettable. I peered out at the festive tents, architectural structures, crowds, and landscape and felt overwhelmed by their beauty. The festival took the form of a small village. The scene was cathartic. Furthermore, the Sound Bath was an ethereal experience. Fortunately, my friends and I caught the last session of the day. The class was held under a giant tree and its large branches and leaves overarched the class, providing shade. Participants laid beneath the tree. Instructors told us to close our eyes, while they gently played the gongs. The sound filled the air. Throughout the session, instructors used a collection of sound makers, such as a rainstick, triangle and didgeridoo. Nothing could have explained it better than the name itself- a sound bath.

The festival’s activities were great for the daytime when you were looking for a break in between performances. The music at LiB is almost exclusively electronic; however, basically every type of electronica was present. My favorite artists were Miss Cooper and Her Pet Craigslist Hookup, NomBe, Kaytranada, Big Wild, Brasstracks, Elohim, Bassnectar, Paper Diamond, and Troyboi. One of my favorite aspects about the festival is the sheer freedom of the lineup. Many of the DJs at Lightning were more established within the electronic realm; therefore, many were not as familiarized. Still, they were all amazing. When I did not know the name of the artist, I let the music carry me. If I heard something I enjoyed, I was there. This really allowed me to have a good time without having to stress about who I was seeing at every moment. I was discovering new music in the purest form of live execution. Yet, I was still able to see of the more established artists who blew me away.

In the end, Lightning in a Bottle was a festival of its own species. The festival-goers’ easy-going attitudes, coupled with their enthusiasm and mutual respect, made the musical experience a special one. Furthermore, the vibrant aura of the place that shined in its color and creativity left me in fascination. The music was insatiable. I’d like to think that this festival allowed me to dance to the beat of my own drum; however, it would be false to say so for I had an amazing communal experience, feeling love and joy for those around me. I often joke to my friends that every festival experience changes me. The truth to that statement could not be more real, as Lightning in a Bottle has definitely made its imprint on me. As soon as I arrived to the comfort of my home, I texted everyone I knew and said, “Can’t wait for next year!”

title: Budgie - Panty Soakers 3 // Album Review
content:
Written by Christian Wright

This ain’t your usual フローラルの専門店 kind of vaporwave. Nothing here suggests traumatizing typeface with loose tracking nor translating brands of coconut water into katakana. There aren’t any gradient grids signifying some MNC-controlled Matrix. I don’t hear supermarkets. No, this ain’t that kind of poetry.

Despite all of its sonic nods to  a e s t h e t i c, Budgie’s Panty Soakers 3 is an appropriation of Japanese funk done with love. Unlike most tracks sampled by the vaporwave factory, the Japanese rarities presented here don’t undergo too much stretching nor are they drowned out in delay and reverb. Budgie lets his picks play for themselves, as in his “Infatuation,” where Masayoshi Takanaka’s “Struttin On Broadway” remains virtually untouched. Any manipulation he does to a song offers up a new idea that ultimately makes the experience of the album incredibly dynamic; thus, no track overstays its welcome. That being said, the entirety of the album plays out in 35 minutes, no song passing the four-minute mark. The tracklist traverses glassy cerebral ballads with “The Vapors” to the midnight funk of “Lighter,” ending with the Nilsson-esque sunlight of “Just Hit.”

Panty mixes together an incredibly cohesive blend of Japanese funk that no one else has the brains to blend. Thus, given the incredible eclecticism of his DJ mixes, it’s no surprise that DJ, beatmaker, and producer Budgie practically grew up in London’s Honest Jon’s, a record store that his father runs. Budgie notably started digging for gospel records (His mixes, compiled on The Gospel According to Budgie I & II, inspired a Kanye West sample on Yeezus, and are definitely worth checking out.) Thankfully, he kept up the search. His dive into Japanese music further testifies to the tasteful genius of the crate digger. After all, what’s the point of an aesthete when you’ve got a DJ?

title: Captain Howdy - DEMO 2017 // Album Review
content:
Written by Gabriel Cortina

Captain Howdy is a California based powerviolence band featuring members of Scene OG’s Crossed Out. If you don’t know Crossed Out I definitely recommend checking out their split with Man is The Bastard, as well as their 1990-1993 discography. Very good stuff.

Starting with the first track “Callahan”, the listener can immediately tell that Captain Howdy sticks to their old school powerviolence roots. Ditching the sludge-centric style of more modern bands in the genre, Captain Howdy is loud, fast and aggressive. The thing that stands out to me most is the song lengths. Crossed Out rarely wrote songs over a minute (most being around 40 seconds or less), yet songs on this demo (such as the title track) reach up to six minutes in length. This is not a bad thing, however, as Captain Howdy is able to constantly engage their listeners and switch songs up enough to keep them entertaining. I did not find myself bored a single time throughout this album, and this is coming for a guy with an attention span that seldom lasts longer than a minute. The band seamlessly switches between blast beat driven segments, to hardcore inspired yelps and killer breakdowns. “Hell” is a great example of this, beginning with guitar reminiscent of early hardcore acts like Stalag 13, and then quickly transitions into a punishing breakdown. This is all followed by an almost death metal esque guitar segment over which the vocalist angrily shouts. The chorus is also very catchy, a word that I feel is not the most appropriate when talking about powerviolence, but it is 5 am on a Friday, so cut me some slack.

All in all, this release is solid. It’s everything you would expect from a hardcore/powerviolence mesh featuring members of Crossed Out — loud, angry, fast and engaging. While this isn’t exactly a life changing release, it is definitely one I would recommend to fans of the genre as I think it has a lot to offer. If you enjoy it, be sure to catch Captain Howdy live at 1Fest LA this June 3.

title: May Show of the Month // Lost in the Sauce with DJ Ry Ry
content:
Interview by Alexa Lee

Your show is usually centered around your conversations with athletes. What makes you different from the average sports reporter?

I feel that it is important to interview these athletes because in my mind, most are polarized from the rest of the student body. UCLA is known for having a rich history of dominant sports teams and I believe that these athletes represent more than that. I want to provide an outlet for these athletes where they are comfortable enough to express themselves fully. There is so much more underneath the jersey.

Since you’ve had so many different people come and talk on your show, have you noticed any common values or characteristics that your guests all seem to have in common?

Humility. Under the media microscope, so many professional and even college athletes are cast as arrogant individuals who are only successful because of their physical gifts. I have found the exact opposite is true. Each athlete is beyond humble to attend UCLA and be a part of a community where academics is stressed so heavily. Even with all of their accolades, they constantly remind me of how lucky they are.

Is there anything that guests have brought up that surprised you about their lives or life outlook?

Starting late in the game. What I mean by that is I have had quite a few athletes pursue the current sport they are playing at an older age. I found this incredibly impressive as they were able to develop extraordinary skills in such a short amount of time. UCLA is a Division I school, therefore all of these athletes perform at a higher level than most, so when they tell me that they started playing in high school it boggles my mind.

Let’s say you’re assembling a dream heist team—think the Avengers or the crew from Fast and Furious. Out of anyone in the world, who would you want on your side and why?

Former president Barack Obama would be my first pick. Not only could he eloquently talk his way out of any sticky situation, but I think he has some connections that we could certainly utilize. While El Chapo has been officially caught, he would definitely be the mastermind behind all of our heists. Lastly, one of the best climbers in the world by the name of Alex Honnold would make infiltration of any building look easy.

What does the sauce mean to you? Similarly, what is your relationship with the sauce?

Sauce can mean quite a few things. When Gucci Mane first uttered the words, I believe he was referencing fame, money, and everything that comes with those two things. You can have all the fame and money in the world, but once it consumes you, then you’re lost according to Gucci. For me, sauce is a highly enjoyable moment in time. When I’m on air, I’m trying to get the most out of the moment and appreciate the conversation that I am having with my guest. Beyond radio, sauce can be going to the gym or hanging out with friends. If I love what I’m doing at a specific point in time, I am trying to get lost in it.

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

I thoroughly enjoy making people smile. That’s usually my goal throughout the entire show. Once a guest smiles, I know they are comfortable and a great conversation usually follows. It’s the same thing for my involvement with Special Olympics. I come to practice every week with the intention of having each athlete I interact with smile. It might sound cliche, but nothing bad really happens after you smile.

Listen to Lost in the Sauce every Wednesday at 12 p.m.!
tags: ucla radio show of the month

title: Diet Cig @ The Echo (5/4/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Alana Myers 

Just a few dates before the end of Diet Cig’s West Coast tour, the duo, comprised of Alex Luciano and Noah Bowman, made a stop in Los Angeles to play a sold out show at the Echo on May 4. Before Diet Cig took the stage however, the already excited atmosphere of the room was boosted even more by the performances of two opening acts - Janelane and Lisa Prank.

First up was Janelane, whose members were ecstatic to be playing at the Echo again. Led by singer and guitarist Sophia Negrini, the band’s set was energetic, and enthusiasm radiated from each of the musicians’ faces on stage. Everything about Janelane was a delight to watch and listen to, and their sound built up perfectly to match that of the next opening act.

Lisa Prank, the second act of the night, delivered another exuberant set while telling jokes to make the audience laugh between songs. “They’re so hardworking,” Prank said after one song as she thanked her non-existent band and looked at an empty corner on stage. Comments like these were met with grins from the audience, who fully supported the one woman band in front of them. After Prank’s set, more chatter ensued among the crowd until Diet Cig walked on stage, smiling and waving.

Experiencing a Diet Cig show for the first time comes with a lot of emotions - there’s undoubtedly feelings of joy, lots of smiling, yelling, and even more dancing. Starting off with the song “Cardboard” off their 2015 EP Over Easy, singer and guitarist Luciano immediately got the crowd moving and rocking their heads back and forth. After this song began, the crowd never stopped moving throughout the night - teens and adults alike loved every minute of the set, and jumped up and down as they sang along unapologetically to the lyrics.

This concert was the first time Diet Cig got to play a Los Angeles show in support of their debut album Swear I’m Good At This, which came out this past April. Filling their set with tracks from their older EPs and the new record, the crowd responded greatly to each song with equal amounts of enthusiasm. Crowd favorite “Barf Day” was an especially cathartic moment as everyone sang “I just want to have ice cream on my birthday/Blow the candles out and wish all of my pain away,” in unison. Even the stories and comments from Luciano between songs resonated with the crowd. One story included a humorous account on how the group’s LA Airbnb wasn’t as advertised. Long story short, the place they stayed in only had one lamp, so one member of the group’s tour crew pulled a clever prank on the Airbnb owner in response. Still, the duo made their way to Echo Park for the night, creating a positive, inclusive safe space for everyone at their show.

Album highlights “Maid of the Mist” and “Leo” drew huge reactions from the audience, resulting in shouts for an encore at the end of the night, the chant “one more song, one more song!” hovering over the room. After a minute, Diet Cig, all smiles, ran back on stage to sing an encore of a few more songs. During the final  song ‘Harvard,’ Luciano threw confetti in the air as she jumped off drummer Bowman’s drum kit, and the crowd roared with applause.

Overall, Diet Cig’s show was lots of fun. “I think being tender is a form of resistance,” Luciano commented as the duo moved towards the end of their set. Words like these were one of the many positive messages that permeated from the duo that night, and it was nice to attend a show where everyone on and off stage had a great time together. If Diet Cig are coming to a city near you, I would wholeheartedly recommend seeing them live.

title: Faces of UCLA Radio // Winterns 2017
content:
In honor of our annual Pledge Drive, we will be featuring various members of our station this week so you can get to know the many different faces of UCLA Radio. Written by Andy Talajkowski and Alana Myers 

Every quarter UCLA Radio welcomes new DJs into our station. Meet some of the members of our Wintern 2017 class!

Sophia Myers 

Sophia Myers (DJ Flare Waldorf) is a third year transfer student studying American Literature & Culture along with being part of the marketing department and the host of Remote Control every Friday at 12 p.m.. As a member of UCLA Radio, Sophia hopes to bring more attention to the radio station because, in her words, “it deserves so much more praise.” She also wants to bring some new music to the station that people might not have heard of. When she’s not busy coming up with marketing ideas, Sophia loves going to concerts, writing, and drawing. She hopes to become an animator one day, and wants to use what she learns in radio to help improve her storytelling skills.

Bianca Brown

Bianca Brown (DJ Loveless) is a second year philosophy student minoring in music industry as well as a member the music department and host of alcohoLIT on Wednesdays at 11 a.m. Her favorite musical memory to date was attending Camp Flog Gnaw, especially when “Kehlani sang and pointed to me.” Outside of UCLA Radio Bianca spends time working with CAC, being part of the spoken word scene, and also making music.

Danny Zander   

Danny Zander is a second year student in the news department. Through UCLA Radio, he hopes to “add a unique voice to spotlight news stories and views on the news that usually wouldn’t be hard.” In terms of music, his most memorable moment was seeing Kanye leave halfway through his set during his infamous LA concert last year. Beyond the station, Danny plays sports and attempts stand-up comedy.

Hannah Singer 

Hannah Singer is a first year student and member of the music department. She can never forget the moment when, at camp, she accidentally sang the 50’s pop song “Lollipop” to a group of older teens who were talking about “Lollipop” by Lil Wayne - “I still think about that time to time when I’m trying to fall asleep.” Along with radio, Hannah is a part of Shenanigans, works as a research assistant at the Social Communications Psych Lab, and enjoys “over-analyzing people’s personalities when nobody asked for it.

title: Jay Som @ The Echo (4/21/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Alexandra Ivanova

Housing only 350 people, the Echo is known for housing some of the most intimate performances in Los Angeles. Jay Som’s sold-out performance on April 21 was no different, characterized by poignancy, personality, and a dreamy atmosphere.

The night began with all-female high school-trio Pinky Pinky, as well as self-proclaimed bipolar folk band Kera and The Lesbians. Both bands were female-led, energetic, and utilized biting instrumentals and gritty vocals. It was one of the few occurrences where the show openers were not only worth showing up to, but also genuinely as enjoyable as the headliner. Both bands started off the night brilliantly, getting the audience to bob their head along with the beat, as well as complimenting the music of Jay Som later that night.

When Melina Duarte first took stage that night with her three bandmates, fans excitedly whispered. There was no rushing to the front of the stage, pushing, or high-pitched screaming. Instead, there was a careful and quiet admiration that was present throughout the night. It was this quality of the audience that made the show seem even more like a personal house show or an individual peek into Duarte’s introspective lyrics, rather than a concert populated by mostly teenage and young adult fans. Throughout the night, the band mentioned the quietness of the audience with Duarte eventually saying, “You guys are so quiet… but I like it.” The band’s chemistry was also lovely to watch, as they moved around on stage, shot grins at each other, and even playfully switched hats throughout the show.

The personality of both the audience and the band fit in perfectly with Jay Som’s actual performance, as they focused on songs from their new album Everybody Works. While their performance was guitar heavy and complimented Duarte’s glossy vocals, the crowd would at most sway together and bob their heads, eventually singing along to singles like “The Bus Song.” When the band played slower songs like “Baybee,” the crowd hushed and swayed, in accordance to the emotions Duarte was so brilliantly able to convey with only her voice. The night ended with a slowed-down version of one of Jay Som’s first releases, “I Think You’re Alright,” beginning with Duarte saying, “This one’s for the lovers in the audience.” Instantly the emotive atmosphere in the room switched to the feeling of an 80s prom slow dance, hitting the audience with both nostalgia and the poignancy of all the emotions Duarte conveyed that night.

Ultimately, the hype surrounding Jay Som as an emerging music group is deserved - not only for the quality of their latest album, but for their ability to perform on such a personal level, connecting with everyone in the audience. Even after the show, the band stuck around, going as far as hugging fans and making conversation. The openers of the night are also worth checking out in the future, whether that involves their discography or attending other shows in which they are playing. This concert was special on multiple levels, as it not only was predominantly led by strong, female artists, but also truly made the music private, intimate, and more emotive than simply listening to the album itself. This ability to truly connect with the audience makes Jay Som such a distinct presence in the new music scene, and a band to certainly keep an eye out for in the future.

title: Tim Hecker - Love Streams // Album and Show Review (04/07/16)
content:
Written By: Zach Conner, UCLA Radio DJ 

Photos By: Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Digital Press Staff

Post Date : 04/27/16

The introduction to this review will be (surprise!) a flowery and digressive personal anecdote recalling my most immediate impression of the artist and album––the concert.

April 7 – Outside it was night and it was not damp. Inside Union Nightclub it was darker, and then lighter, and not a single body danced. An earless creature might have guessed that Union crowds hate dancing… yet a creature with even the faintest aural faculties would have likewise been arrested on the spot. Somewhere on the stage behind a shroud of shadow Tim Hecker, the sound sorcerer, was testing his new album/spell Love Streams. It was working a sort of magic, because the crowd was stiller than doldrums, not bored but baffled––as is a bay abruptly aflood with glacial runoff (a delta’s birth). Something like sublime sonic subsumption. Obviously it was loud and I trembled from tibia to temple. Hecker also brought an atypical light show––no strobes, no seizures––just nine horizontal racks of extremely versatile, baseball-sized LEDs, variably hued to paint-palate harmony and pouring into the venue’s swampy haze.

Love Streams was released a day later, so lacking prior exposure to the album (didn’t hear the leak), I couldn’t deduce the set list, save a single and a few older songs. I suspected my memory of the music would be vague without tethers to familiar material, but a pristine listen was appealing. I was correct about forgetting a lot of specific sound, but the show’s visual aspect and general thrust left a potent impression to enhanced my later experience of the album. In a Rolling Stone interview, Hecker lists a few functions of the haze and rich LEDs, as directed:

  • at audience: hypnotic or “narcotic” openers of “third ears”
  • and away from artist: “to circumvent the silhouetted, hunched ego of the knob-turner”

That the album, a chunk of scintillating sound, is encapsulated by darkness (opener “Obsidian Counterpart” and closer “Black Phase”) connects Hecker’s shadowy shroud to the work: the artist is hidden when the record spins and perhaps should be in concert as well. Concealed from the work, Hecker’s physical figure vacates an outlined space, which the work refills. You can bet that if possible, the reclusive Thomas Pynchon would erase his rare youthful image from our brains and leave literary style as sole trace of his character. I guess to a small extent this is Hecker’s aim. Love Streams’ stylistic complexity reflects Hecker well enough––as is usual in his work, no detail is insignificant.

Thus I wondered if the LEDs, a collaboration with visual artist Marcel Weber, were arranged to resemble a pattern of MIDI notes. Given the compositional methods behind this album, it’s not implausible: Hecker used Melodyne software to extract choral motifs from Renaissance church-music––Josquin des Prez pieces––and convert them into MIDI scores. Melodyne is apparently controversial and viewed by some as a plundering tool, but Hecker’s use of it is meaningful and constructive.

He celebrates technology’s expansion of creative endeavors. “Digital audio,” Hecker tells Rolling Stone, is “the great plastic sculptural medium.” Software like Melodyne and DAWs facilitate reevaluations of our musical past; computers are reanimating tools, by which the history of sound is rendered inexhaustibly malleable. The digital advantage is even too much: Hecker quipped in a FACT Magazine interview about the stress of choosing between “40 types of zithers,” all computer interfaces. To navigate this abundance he adheres to a method of “constraint… omitting… and putting on horse blinders.” This Cage-like hybrid of purpose and chance steers him from the unreasonable, unhealthy cathexis over perfection and originality. Idealists, with noses in the air and heads in the stratosphere will still scoff at anything less than “genius.” But critical consideration of artistic originality has broadened enough that an inspired invention is no more valuable than a warped, repurposed interpretation, perhaps even a serendipitous rehashing. Source is no richer than process and product, and all are mediated by factors we cannot know or change. There is no reason de Prez and Hecker shouldn’t share a page in a 22nd Century Eyewitness book about VOICE.

If corporate use of deep analytics for profit is data-mining at its most industrial level, then Hecker’s rush into sonic information is its simple counterpart, the exuberant prospector. A reporter from The FADER brings up minimalism and Hecker quickly makes it clear that Love Streams is not ascribable to any minimalist school in particular: the album is not very minimalist besides its general adherence to one key and occasional limited note range. However, it is relatively minimal–– its content, relative to the profuse potential content it faced in production, is a lithe current through a sea of possible sound. That sea is knowable only in streams, for its whole is as daunting and excessive as a corporate data cache. It’s also minimal relative to his old work, and less full-bodied. Compare “Whitecaps of White Noise II” from Harmony in Ultraviolet with “Black Phase” and you will find the same note progression, treated in the former as a full-bodied chunk of sound and in the latter more delicately as a thin tonal line. In general Love Streams exhibits more space and restraint than Hecker’s last few albums, but his penchant for emotionally engrossing, climactic crescendos remains.  “Violet Monumental” is the most intense example of this: it ceaselessly ascends, stacking notes up like purple obelisk bricks. Here the near-homonym of violet/violent is important, as well as the phallic implications of tall, manmade structures.

Hecker is no doubt aware of his compositional obsession with sonic climaxes and power, and addresses the subject in different ways: with Ravedeath, 1972, he interprets the musical “drop” as the crucial destruction of tension in sound waves and affective audience alike. Virgins asserts that truly political art (who could mistake the draped shape of Ali Shallal al-Qaisi on its cover?) should make no effort to ameliorate discontent if it seeks to promote material change. And Love Streams’ treatment of vocal pitch and its connection to puberty lends corporeal significance to the “drop.” “Castrati Stack,” the album’s lead single, is the most overt example: castrati were medieval choir boys, castrated to provide an ecclesiastical stock of permanent alto/soprano singers. The song is driven by a synth that hops between the same notes in different octaves like the tonal demarcations of maturity, yet floats continuously on boyish lamentations. The delicate and innately youthful character of the higher registers and the visceral power of low notes are dialectically related in the same way adulthood is often reflective of youth. Hecker brings up an old adage with The FADER reporter: “foster the child in you always.” So when “Voice Crack” follows spilling out of the tumult, there is no feeling of absolute transition, but of comfort; a calm acceptance diffuses into the garbled autotune. Every adult at some point sounded like Squidward’s clarinet, and this is a sort of beautification of the cracking voice.

Where the themes of puberty and the internet intersect, Hecker seems to strike a similar chord as Daniel Lopatin (Oneohtrix Point Never)’s Garden of Delete, released last November. Both artists (who are friends and occasional collaborators) advocate widespread use of digital audio editing technology, whether by established artists looking to diversify their sound or kids with a laptop and budding interest in music. They revere and fear the internet for its ability to educate or corrupt, and it’s no surprise that the Edenic myth is pertinent to Lopatin and Hecker’s work. Its relevance to Garden of Delete is pretty clear, but Hecker doesn’t incorporate it explicitly. A quote from the FADER interview, though,  could link them: “you need to step back and garden, but not that fruit tree. Take care of your carrots or something.” He’s talking about foregoing reliance on brute sonic force and being attentive to more important details––but we could easily apply this to the societal obsession with the Fruit of Good and Evil, sexual knowledge and its convoluted online presence. Taking care of your carrots means assigning less disturbing gravity to, if I may be permitted to use a not-so-inclusive metaphor here, the moment one’s voice and balls drop. Love Streams flows naturally, beautifully––as the varied emissions of puberty should feel.

title: To Pimp a Movement // UCLA Radio Op-ed
content:
Written By: James Wilson, UCLA Radio News DJ (04/25/16)

Race, and the politics and injustices that go with it, has forever been an issue in the American spectrum of politics. In recent months, the Black Lives Matter movement has sparked into popularity and notoriety across the nation. Through U.S. media, especially online social network sites, Black Lives Matters has brought heavy attention to the issues held between individuals of color and police forces across the nation. So what exactly is the Black Lives Matter (or BLM for short) organization? BLM was originally founded after George Zimmerman’s acquittal for the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, a 17-year-old African American. Black Lives Matter became public through the use of the social media hashtag #BlackLivesMatter, and was co-founded by three black community organizers: Alicia Garza, Patrisse Cullors, and Opal Tometi. Black Lives Matter has drawn inspiration for its organization from the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960’s, the Black Power movement, the 1980s Black feminist movement, Pan-Africanism, Anti-Apartheid Movement, Hip hop, LGBTQ social movements and the Occupy Wall Street movement of 2011.

So what is Black Lives Matter standing up and protesting against? Black Lives Matters mainly organizes protests around the deaths of black people caused by law enforcement, as well as broad issues like racial profiling, police brutality, and general racial inequality in the United States criminal system. Some examples of BLM activism have been stopping Black Friday sales, shutting down train stations, and becoming a fixture on the presidential campaign trail by calling out political figures to take action.

In terms of organization, BLM is not one single coordinated effort. Instead, it has a model similar to that of many organizations involved in the Arab Spring. BLM is a decentralized network without a formal hierarchy or structure, composed instead of smaller subgroups located throughout the country, connected to one another through communication over social media. This benefits the organization by giving each subgroup the ability to decide the issues it wants to tackle, especially issues more prevalent in their communities. These smaller groups are similar to UCLA’s Undercommons, where in the members have access to a country wide network, yet have the freedom to make their own unique impact on their community.

So how does music connect to the Black Lives Matter movement? The fact is that music is essential to the goals and ambitions of BLM. Protest songs have been used to rally support and energy since the Labor Union songs of the 1930’s. In today’s culture, protestors within the Black Lives Matter movement turn to several forms of protest music. They use both protest songs of the Civil Rights Movement and hip-hop and R&B that address more contemporary issues.

A perfect example of such a demonstration of music in protest occurred on July 28th, 2015, in Cleveland, Ohio, where a Black Lives Matter conference was being held at Cleveland State University. The events grew intense when police officers arrested 14 year-old Jonathan Walsh for allegedly being intoxicated on a bus and allegedly having an open container with alcohol. Walsh was taken into custody by police, much to the dismay of the activists nearby. Many of the BLM activists believed Walsh was being arrested unnecessarily. When they voiced their concerns, officers proceeded to pepper spray the crowd, causing more confusion and anger amongst those gathered. The growing crowd continued to peacefully exhort authorities to release the young man. Seemingly out of nowhere in the midst of all the intensity the crowd broke into a spontaneous rendition of Kendrick Lamar‘s “Alright” off of his album “To Pimp A Butterfly.” The crowd erupted into joyful dance and song, chanting “we gonna be alright” continuously despite confrontation by police. Not long after the incident began, Walsh was released to the custody of his mother, and the crowd dispersed, having accomplished its goal (James).

n the example of this protest, Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright” serves as a tool to capture the crowds wound up energy and put it to use in a positive, peaceful manner. Despite a young man being arrested and members of the crowd being pepper sprayed by police, the crowd knows that they will be “alright” and that they will overcome. The protestors turn from being mad to being hopeful of change that they themselves may not yet be able to make. Protest music like Kendrick Lamar’s “Alright” sends a clear message of the desires of the group as a whole, and helps demonstrate a collective hope for change and improvement. Overall, the music helps gather protestors and prevent outliers from inciting violence or flaring tempers even more. Such a sense of unity and direction is essential when working with such a large group of motivated and charismatic individuals.

How has a single rapper been able to capture the hope and imagination of so may people? First, lets look into his history. Kendrick Lamar was born in Compton, California, on June 17, 1987. Lamar grew up around precarious street activity, which affected his family and friends. Yet Lamar was more influenced by street culture than harmed from it, as he continued to be a good student in school who loved art and music. Lamar began to write and perform rap lyrics at age 16, performing and writing more and more music until eventually meeting with   Dr. Dre in 2010 and jump starting his career into national fame. Kendrick’s humble roots from a low-income community and his authentic, down-to earth rap lyrics has led to his mass popularity in American culture that transcends race and gender.

I have always been aware of Kendrick Lamar and the impact of his music, but never the core message of so many of his songs. Kendrick’s album “To Pimp a Butterfly”, especially the above mentioned single “Alright”, seeks to instill hope in spite of the troubling state of the relationship between America’s police forces and young black and brown men and women. As someone not of color, I have never sought such meaning from Kendrick’s work. But researching it now, I can’t help but admire the freshness it brings to the conversation of race in the U.S.

Kendrick’s message is about finding the hope and positive influence for kids like Walsh, so that they don’t lose themselves to the streets and end up in situations like these where protests could develop and become violent. This protest was not violent, but I don’t believe that Kendrick would appreciate it if say, Walsh had been selling drugs and a protest for release via Kendrick’s message was used for “racial injustice”. The song is about hope. Hope for a future generation and nation. Not about being “alright” to do whatever they want and expect that playing the race card can solve the problem. Yet despite all this, Kendrick is courageous enough to start and continue the conversation about racism in America. As Tupac Shakur once asserted: “I’m not saying I’m gonna change the world, but I guarantee that I will spark the brain that will change the world. And that’s our job, to spark somebody else watching us.” Kendrick Lamar is one of those sparks, and his influence on modern protest music has sparked numerous individuals into seeking change in their communities.

I hope one day to witness in person the grace and power that comes with such a demonstration of protest music. Protest music is a genre of it own that serves to capture the mind and soul of people who feel left out and mistreated in society. Such a demonstration of peaceful collaboration as seen in Cleveland, Ohio might be one of the most stirring example of the importance and power of protest music since “We Shall Overcome” was heard at marches throughout the south during the Civil Rights Movement.

Work Cited

James, Ariel “Inspired By A Real Butterfly, Crowd Breaks Into Kendrick Lamar’s ‘Alright’ During

Protest.” The Urban Daily RSS. N.p., 28 July 2015. Web. 18 Apr. 2016.

title: Weezer's "Weezer" ("The White Album") // Album Review
content:
Written By: Casey Lee, UCLA Radio DJ (04/21/2016)

At the end of the music video for “California Kids,” the two boys behind “Damn Daniel” join Rivers Cuomo at a beach to replicate their insanely viral Vine video.

“Daaamn Rivers, back at it again with the Ray Bans!”

With the release of Everything Will be Alright In the End in 2014, Weezer fans held onto some kind of hope for their beloved band’s return to greatness. EWBAITE represented the group’s well-thought out effort to connect back to their 90’s roots; the song “Back to the Shack” effectively acted as an apology for Weezer’s post-Pinkerton works, while “Eulogy for a Rock Band” addressed the theme of nostalgia, in which everyone knows that they their favorite rockstars were already are past their prime.

The White Album, however, turned this sentiment on its head.

Whereas EWBAITE was somewhat shaky, with its fair mix of solid and not-so-solid tracks, The White Album or (Weezer) hits all of the right notes.  Its spirit and theme are explicit; the ocean sounds heard at the beginning of the opening song elicit feelings of summer and set the stage for the rest of the sunny album.  

Primarily using SoCal beaches as their songs’ settings, Weezer expertly navigates through the ups and downs of summer romances.  The first couple of tracks, namely “Wind in Our Sail” and “(Girl We Got A) Good Thing,” sweetly celebrate the “ups” of summer love, with Cuomo crooning about the prospect of having exciting adventures with his crush .  However, the album then devolves into the “downs” of summer love, with the edgier and darker “Summer Elaine and Drunk Dori,” “L.A. Girlz,” and “Jacked Up” recounting heartbreak. The final song, “Endless Bummer,” is a poignant album closer.  It reminds us the ephemerality of summer vacation, as well as our desire to go back to certainty and security after a few months of unrestrained freedom.

Not only does The White Album act as a perfect metaphor of the evolution of the summer fling lyrically, but the music itself fits into the theme seamlessly as well.  Cuomo, Weezer’s primary songwriter, echoes shimmery 1960’s Californian sunshine pop in his composition of the record.  In a few interviews, in fact, he gives direct credit, citing influences as broad as The Beach Boys and as specific as a single track by The Left Banke.  Wherever he found his inspiration, it is clear that Cuomo put a lot of care into crafting The White Album, and it certainly shows; from beginning to end, the album is truly a pleasure to listen to.  Sonically and thematically, the tracks make sense as a coherent narrative, and with supremely catchy melodies and the dynamic guitar-work that call back to Weezer’s first two albums.

As a Weezer fan who was too young to revel in the original The Blue Album and Pinkerton hype and instead grew up during the band’s “dark era,” I am absolutely ecstatic to report that The White Album is a fresh, 2016 spin on “old Weezer” that still manages to forge its own unique identity.  And with Rivers already alluding at an upcoming “Black Album,” it will be exciting to see where the group goes next.

Daaamn Weezer indeed.

title: The Faces of NBC Comedy: A Step Forward
content:
Written By: Courtney Burness, UCLA Radio DJ (03/28/16)

The faces on NBC comedy are America Ferrera and Eva Longoria. Ferrera stars in Superstore, which follows the lives of retail workers in a giant megastore, while Longoria heads Telenovela, starring as the star of a Latino soap opera star. It is incredibly rare even to have two women as the faces of comedy on a major network, and being two women of color is practically unheard of. The most important thing about these women being the faces of comedy is that their characters are well rounded, not stereotypes. Complex characters - people with flaws, who learn and grow and change -  are the key to really moving forward with representation on television and in other forms of media. Not just placing characters in roles as the “token,” but as a fully developed character. Having diversity on-air is important for the next generation. Kids need to be able to see their cultures and backgrounds represented in media in order to inspire them to be the next America Ferrera. Another show that succeeds in doing diversity the “right” way in Brooklyn Nine-Nine, a FOX program. With multiple leads of color, they subvert stereotypes in race, gender, and sexuality, and the characters are still allowed to be funny. Racial and ethnic backgrounds are never used as punchlines; it deals with issues involving these topics through comedy but never makes jokes about the issues. They’ve dealt with police brutality, sexual harassment, and homophobia and racism in the police force. This just goes to show that a show can have meaning, include a diverse cast, and still be funny. You can have it both ways. Obviously three is still a long way to go in terms of diversity and representation in comedy. However, it’s important to recognize when networks and show creators are making conscious efforts to include complex female characters, characters of color, and LGBT+ characters. Not just stereotypes. They are by no means perfect, but writers and creators can take a lesson from shows like Superstore and Brooklyn Nine-Nine. Many people mistakenly believe the unfortunately common stereotype that “women aren’t funny.” The faces of NBC comedy and other leading ladies on different networks are here to prove them wrong.

title: Film Review // The Witch (2016) - Directed By Robert Eggers
content:
Written By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press Member (03/09/16)

The Witch (2016 – dir. Robert Eggers) is a film that will find its way around and through any expectations that you have of it.  It may disturb you and ruffle your feathers.  It might tear away the veil of adulthood that normally keeps you from clapping your hands over your eyes and watching the scariest scenes through your fingers.  It won’t coddle you, coerce you or fool you into watching even when you feel uncomfortable.  If you want to leave the screening you won’t, because as much as the movie scares you – you won’t be able to leave until you know the truth.

Christianity is not the hero of this movie, be forewarned.  The Witch is fiercely executed story about familial savagery and itchy paranoia. Set in 1630 Plymouth, it follows a Puritan family’s journey to a life at the edge of a looming wood where they are plagued by the machinations of the witch living in the forest.  But even that much is not certain.  The magic of the film is the building sense of psychological horror as family members question the nature of reality and find that their faith can’t give those answers.  

More than anything else this is a movie about women and the relationships between them.  As eldest daughter Thomasin comes of age in this isolated backdrop, it appears that the entire family is cursed.  The corn is blighted; the goat’s milk turns to blood; the witch of the wood steals the baby of the family; and religious hysteria mires the family in the dark and dirty places that Christianity cannot reach. They beg God for his attention while they neglect each other.  A puritan family too extreme to share space with other puritans, their descent into madness is as sticky as it gets as they reveal themselves unable to handle challenges to their faith without drawing blood from one another.  Thomasin’s transition from girl to woman becomes the flame put to the powder keg of repressed sexuality and pent-up frustrations that are a necessary part of religious oppression.   Her family moves in tightening circles around her, unware that their plans to snuff her out might have the opposite effect of making her burn brighter and hotter.  There is a witch.  Make no bones about it and this is in no way a spoiler, there is a witch.  However, the work here might be to ascertain who the witch really is.  You have choices.  All of them are wrong and all of them are right.  That’s one of the things that make this movie so ferocious – you will get answers and still never be sure.

Cast is outstanding with Anya Taylor-Joy becoming a star as she explodes into the role of Thomasin.  In a film populated entirely by standout performances, Harvey Scrimshaw as Thomasin’s younger brother Caleb owns a role few would even attempt, with one scene in particular that will be seared into your memory forever.  The austere setting;  the building anxiety of religious paranoia;  the growing sense of sexual tension;  the antics of one big, black angry goat;  and the ongoing menace of the woman in the wood all come together in one terrifying package that will scare the daylights out of you if you are watching at all.  This is a fantastic example of empowered and powerful storytelling and the birth of a film horror classic.  Not for children, mandatory for adults.  Highly Recommended.

title: Largo- Sarah Silverman & Friends // UCLA Radio Comedy Show Review
content:
Written By: Ben Kurzrock, UCLA Radio Comedy DJ (03/02/16)

    Beyond her brilliantly funny lifetime of stand-up, acting, voice acting, writing and making music, Sarah Silverman knows how (and loves) to bring people together. Every month she hosts a charity show at Largo, a historic venue in Los Angeles best known for its alternative comedy/music performances, live podcasts and improvised theater shows. Sarah’s comedy career has traversed an infinite plethora of genres and mediums; it should not be surprising that her guests (the “Friends”) range from various generations and styles of comedy. I have personally been to the monthly Sarah Silverman & Friends show six times and here’s who I have been able to see over the course of these shows: Zach Galifianakis, Tom Papa, Doug Benson, Todd Glass, David Spade, Dana Carvey, Bo Burnham, Chelsea Peretti, Maria Bamford, Jerrod Carmichael, and Steve Agee. And the best part is, the line-up (besides Sarah of course) is not pre-announced, so you never know what you are going to get until you get to the show to see for yourself. Believe me, it is hard to be disappointed by these delightful surprises.

           If you love comedy, music and charity, go to this show. If you want to experience an unforgettable night at one of the coolest and most intimate venues in the city, go to this show. I have brought friends, dates, younger cousins, and even my aunt; each time I shared the beautiful experience of synchronized laughter. Moral of the story: no matter who you go with and what your taste in comedy is, this show has something for you. Check it out, it is a blast.

title: Jukebox the Ghost @ The Regent // Show Review (02/09/16)
content:
Review By : Casey Lee, UCLA Radio DJ (02/25/16)

A giant doodle of a ghost with an expression that rivals that of the Kumon logo’s floated on a white canvas behind the stage. The band playing in front of it, however, could not be more different from its apathetic mascot.

On February 9th, indie pop trio Jukebox the Ghost stopped by The Regent Theater on their U.S. tour. After launching into the timelessly punchy “Good Day” from their first album released nearly eight years ago, they continued their high-energy setlist with catchy, feel-good music.  

Simply put, the band is pure fun. Drummer Jesse Kristin would casually toss drumsticks in the air as he went to grab maracas instead; pianist and vocalist Ben Thornewill fully immersed himself into the ever-popular “Schizophrenia,” cocking his head towards the audience with eyes widened and eyebrows raised; guitar and vocalist Tommy Siegel cheerfully sang about an apocalyptic tidal wave engulfing everybody in “The Stars.”

Even if the song was about a break-up, as was the case for “Made for Ending” and “Sound of a Broken Heart,” Jukebox the Ghost remained upbeat in their performances, displaying an intriguing duality and contradiction between their wistful lyrics and bright sound.

Continuing their trend of playfulness, in the middle of their set, the group brought out a “Wheel of Songs” to spin, featuring numbers that they don’t usually play on tour. For our show, the first spin landed on “Hold It In: Supreme,” in which the bandmembers switched instruments and then attempted to perform the entire song. The usual fan favorite “Hold It In” evolved into hilarious chaos, with Siegel looking particularly lost as he semi-randomly plunked at Thornewill’s keyboard. The second spin resulted in “Black Hole,” a lighthearted track that Jukebox the Ghost wrote for “The Mr. Peabody and Sherman Show,” a children’s cartoon series.

The last highlight of the show was the band’s Queen covers. Giving us a taste of their HalloQueen show from last October, Thornewill and Siegel channeled their inner Mercury and Bowie in “Under Pressure,” doing a great job in paying homage to and emulating the vocals of their respective musicians. The group further showed off their theatrical ability, as they performed “Bicycle Race” as one of their encore songs.

With more than ten years of recording and performing music under their belt, it is mystifying as to how the trio can keep up their energy as tour-centric band. However, from their silly Snapchat stories, to Siegel’s doodles posted on Twitter, to their playful live concerts, the band seems to find fun most everywhere in life — which I believe, is the true spirit of Jukebox the Ghost.

title: UCLA-Utah Coverage, February 18, 2016 // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: Chase Madorksy, UCLA Radio Sports DJ (02/21/16)

Los Angeles- In a game where Pauley Pavilion was graced with three Naismith Player of the Year Winners and National Champions, all of whom have their jerseys hanging from the rafters in Bill Walton, Sidney Wicks, and Marques Johnson, the UCLA Bruins Men’s Basketball Team (14-12, 5-8) fell to the Utah Utes (20-7, 9-5)  by a score of 75-73 in the first matchup between the two programs this season. Utah, winners of seven of their last nine contests heading into tonight, was looking to avenge last year’s 69-59 upset at the hands of the Bruins in Westwood. On the opposite bench, UCLA hoped to build off of a 78-65 victory against the Arizona State Sun Devils, while attempting to achieve their first winning streak since January 9.

The first half was a back and forth affair, with the score tied at 31 following fourteen lead changes and six ties throughout the first twenty minutes of play. The Bruins, who’s largest lead of the first half was four points, shot 42% from the field (13-31), but were hindered by making only 4-13 shots from three. For Utah, who stayed neck and neck with the Bruins early on by shooting 41% and by out-rebounding the Bruins 20-17, the first half key was attacking the paint early and often, with twelve of their sixteen two-pointers in the first half coming from inside. Both teams played an extremely efficient half on defense, committing a combined eight fouls which led to only six free throws being attempted in the first half of play.

In the second half, the Utes came out firing, as with the score tied at 36 at the 18:04 mark, Utah went onto a 21-7 run that pushed their lead to 57-43 with 10:51 left in the game. After the game, Bruins Coach Steve Alford had this to say about the run, “The first fourteen minutes of the second half were crucial and we didn’t play well.” For the rest of the game, it was all Bruins, where an offensive attack led by Isaac Hamilton and Bryce Alford produced a 25-13 UCLA run, cutting the deficit to a two point Bruin disadvantage with 2:30 remaining. However, from there Brandon Taylor hit a clutch three at the top of the key with fifteen seconds on the clock to push the Utes lead to 73-68. Following a Thomas Welsh mid-range jumper with six seconds to play, the Bruins found themselves down three points. On the ensuing inbounds pass, Utah forward Kyle Kuzma snuck past the Bruin defense, creating an outlet on a long pass and giving himself a wide open lane which allowed him to slam home the finishing touches of a 75-73 Utah win. Regarding the breakdown of the final Utah inbounds play, Coach Alford stated, “There was obviously some breakdown, because we talk about at least one guy going long.”

While the Bruins came up just short, there were bright spots to be taken out of a tough loss. Junior guard Isaac Hamilton continued his strong season, scoring twenty-five points to lead all scorers while also contributing five rebounds. Following the loss, Hamilton displayed his emerging leadership skills, telling his team, “We need to come in and play hard for a full forty. They scored 26 points (in the first eight minutes) and it was hard for us to come back once they did.” In addition to Hamilton, Bryce Alford, Tomas Welsh, and Aaron Holiday all finished in double digit scoring, with newly added starter Jonah Bolden filling the stat sheet with seven points, five rebounds, and two blocks. At the post game press conference, point guard Bryce Alford offered praise for his team, saying, “This is a team that fights, which is something that I’m very proud of and love about this team.”

For Utah, Player of the Year Candidate Jakob Poeltl led the way with fifteen points and eleven rebounds, consistently having his way with the Bruin’s interior defense. The seven foot forward from Australia proved why many project him as a potential first round pick in the NBA Draft, displaying a bevy of low post moves while anchoring Utah’s low post game on both sides of the ball. Jordan Loveridge was the leading scorer for Utah with seventeen points, one of four Utes in double figures for the evening.

Ultimately, the Bruins ran out of time in this one, which Coach Alford described in saying, “There run to start the second half was longer than our run was-our run came a little to late.” A common theme in the postgame press conference for the Bruins was the lack of consistency the team has displayed of late, with Bryce Alford even going as far as proclaiming that “We go through stretches where I feel like we’re one of the best teams in the country, and then we go through stretches where anyone can beat us.” The Bruins proved late that when they get hot, they can match up with any team in the nation; hopefully in the near future, that passion and fire can be spread out over the course of forty minutes rather than in short spurts as the team attempts to live up to their full potential.

The Bruins host the Colorado Buffaloes at home on Saturday, February 20, 2016 at 8:00 PM Pacific Time, while Utah plays at USC this Sunday, February 21st at 3:00 PM Pacific Time.
