title: Mi Gran Noche // Film Review
content:
Written By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff (04/26/16)

Last Saturday night the plan was to run out to the local mega theater, put down the forty dollars it would cost for the two of us to see JUNGLE BOOK, and try not to look longingly at the folks passing by with their eighteen dollar Raisinets and twelve dollar waters.  It’s a pretty standard Saturday night for those of us who love movies and who also like to go to really nice theaters.  But after a long week of lines, traffic and annoying miscommunication, I just couldn’t bring myself to hit the mega movie branch near me.   We regrouped and impulsively I picked a small Spanish film that was playing at the local Laemmle.  It looked fun.  It was playing in a theater made for movie heads.  My companion gave the idea a thumbs up and off we went.  Now you know the story of how I came to see the sweet, lovely, and utterly funny slapstick comedy that is *MI GRAN NOCHE (2015 – D. Alex de la Iglesia).

A film set on the set of a New Year’s Eve television special gone terribly wrong, MI GRAN NOCHE functions as an ensemble piece that extracts a large part of its humor from Spanish pop culture.  Helmed by a sociopathic seventy-year-old pop singer determined to stay on top, the cast ranges from a Justin Bieber knock-off whose compulsive pelvic thrusting in any situation or circumstance becomes a bad joke gone good.  Add to this a beautiful jinx; a mob of striking television workers; a riot outside in the parking lot; a celebrity assistant gone berserk; two gold-diggers with a uniquely gross plan for a big payday; and a psychotic superfan determined to end the night with a bang.   All of this taking place on a production set where the extras have been held for over two weeks without a break or even sleep – makes for some great and outrageous comedy.  Spanish singing star Raphael plays the sociopathic Alphonso – which I only divulge so those who might choose to see the film can look up his career on Wikipedia before they go.  If you don’t understand who this singer is in the context of Spanish pop culture, some of the humor might be lost, and it’s honestly too good to miss.

The story is brightly paced and enacted. The script buzzes with sharp, insightful jokes as well as expertly executed slapstick and bawdy humor.  Definitely not for children but a dirty and ribald roller coaster ride for adults.  This piece falls into a really interesting subset of Spanish comedy/satire that takes on ideas about contemporary media practices, the nature of celebrity, fandom and the changing economic landscape of the already economically devastated Spain.  It also delivers on dirty jokes, alternative sexuality and the isolation of lonely people in an increasingly impersonal world.  It’s a lot for one hundred minutes, but director Alex de la Iglesia puts it together beautifully.  Raphael stands out as an artist unafraid to take a shot at his own public persona, and Blanca Suarez shines as the unbelievably pretty, clumsy and shockingly unlucky Paloma.

JUNGLE BOOK will be around in theaters for a few minutes more.  *MI GRAN NOCHE, on the other hand, will probably last another weekend (maybe two) in U.S. theaters.  If you want to try something different, beautifully done and off the beaten path of the movie megaplex, please check this one out.  Absolutely worth the cost of admission and then some.

title: Yuck “Stranger Things” // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ (04/25/16)

London-based rockers Yuck share their new album Stranger Things on February 26, 2016, which is three years later since the release of their sophomore album Glow & Behold. Their self titled debut album is one of the best albums of 2011 and it was during that year that true college rock (what we now call indie rock) ended.

I didn’t remember Yuck being so garage rock-like so I was rather surprised when I first listened to Stranger Things. It sounded like the band was going down the route of teenage riot rock, similar to the likes of Burger Records artists. But when I got to the third track “Like A Moth”, I was immediately reminded of what drew me to their debut album. Yuck has a knack for writing songs that have a mellow rock base, almost like a modern The Smashing Pumpkins.

“As I Walk Away” reminds me so much of Fleetwood Mac. While the vocals don’t have the Stevie Nicks power chords, the female vocalist does have this mysterious draw to her voice that works so well with soft pop rock that Fleetwood Mac owned. The reverb on the guitar on this track give it a bit of a psychedelic sound.

Stranger Things is definitely a strange album. It has music ranging from soft pop rock to teenage riot rock. Personally, I’m a fan of the more mellow tracks on this album, which is what I gravitated towards. But, Yuck stays pretty true to their sound on their debut and it’s impressive that even with the six year gap, they can maintain that distinct quality about their music. What I love the most about this album is that you can hear how each song is carefully crafted. With every layer of sound, there is intention behind it. This album almost makes time stand absolutely still and throw you back to the good old days of college indie rock.

Favorite Tracks:

Like A Moth

I’m Ok

As I Walk Away

Down

Swirling

Yr Face

title: Night Moves - "Pennied Days" // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ (04/19/16)

Back in March, Night Moves finally released their second full-length Pennied Days via Domino Recording Co. The Minneapolis-band finally reappeared after the four year gap between the release of their first album Colored Emotions, which came out in 2012. Since then, they’ve been keeping it relatively low-key, mostly playing shows around Minnesota and other Midwest cities.

I first heard this band back in 2013 and from the moment I heard them, I fell in love. Needless to say, I’ve been waiting for Pennied Days for years and now that it’s finally here, my heart is soaring. To be honest, I was scared about this album because my love for Night Moves had cultivated for three years and I was afraid that I’d be disappointed.

Since Colored Emotions, Night Moves’ lineup changed slightly with Mark Ritsema leaving the band to pursue is own project Suzie; however, he is still featured on Pennied Days. Night Moves released their first single “Denise, Don’t Wanna See You Cry” in January and I was thrown aback. The single is a lot heavier on the synths than I had remembered and it was so clear that there was a darker and more serious sound than before. This single was a signal that Night Moves had evolved their sound into something bold and exhilarating.

Songs like “Border On Border”, “Kind Luck”, and “Hiding In The Melody” are reminiscent of their first album. I found that “Kind Luck” was definitely more soulful but Night Moves still rocks their tint of psychedelia into the track. “Border On Border” has been a fan favorite for the longest time and it is, in my opinion, a song that really shows how innovative Night Moves is as a band. I remember first hearing this song on their KEXP session, and it was that song that made me fall in love with the band. For me, the studio version on Pennied Days sounds too polished and I prefer the rawer sound that was in the KEXP session.

But besides bringing back their classic sound, Night Moves also has new sounds that they’ve been working with. I found “Carl Sagan”, “Leave Your Light On” and “Staurolite Stroll” to be particularly memorable. “Carl Sagan” was the second single released from Pennied Days and it hits their older sound better but as with “Denise, Don’t Wanna See You Cry”, this song clearly shows how they’ve evolved. Lead John Pelant is the main mastermind behind all of Night Moves’ tracks, and it’s obvious that he spent the last three years perfecting Night Moves’ new sound. I was genuinely surprised by “Leave Your Light On” because it has such an earthy and pure sound. Of all their tracks, I think “Leave Your Light On” is one of the most honest and stripped down songs. It’s refreshing to say the least and so well executed.

After listening to Pennied Days in full, I can safely and happily say that Night Moves is still one of my favorite bands. Their sound is unique beyond description — there truly is no other band that sounds like them. Pennied Days was released on March 25, 2016 and I remember running out of my brother’s house to go to the Amoeba in SF to buy it. I now, proudly, own both Night Moves albums and I couldn’t be happier.

title: Album Review // Nicholas Krgovich’s “The Hills”
content:
Written By: Sergio Garcia, UCLA Radio DJ (04/12/16)

Vancouver-based Nicholas Krgovich returns with a finely crafted sophomore LP, his follow-up to 2014’s Los Angeles themed On Sunset and drawing from the same inspiration. Active since 2002, Krgovich made a name for himself as a songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and vocalist of indie pop groups NO KIDS, GIGI, and P:ANO. He’s now found success as a solo artist blending R&B, soft rock, and sophisticated pop.

The Hills develops this genre morphing even further, incorporating lush strings, horns, and jazz guitar into sleek pop and late-night R&B melodies. Krgovich’s vocals are front-and-center, which he delivers with sublime sensitivity, predominately clear and soothing with aptly timed crescendos. The songs can be divided into three groups: upbeat, adult alternative pop à la Prefab Sprout (“The Place Goes Quiet,” “Mountain of Song,” “Out of Work Jazz Singer”); spacious and refined ballads (“The Hills,” “Sunset Towers,” “Written in the Wind”); and atmospheric, string-based instrumentals (“Backlot Detail,” “Rock’s Detail,” “Moon Detail”). The delicate, downtempo tracks are spaced evenly, helping to accentuate the quality songwriting on display in the pop-oriented songs.

Throughout the album, Krgovich wrestles with the contrasting beauty and darkness of the enigmatic LA sprawl. He paints the lyrics with urban ennui, somber loneliness, chance encounters, and portraits of the city. The themes are relatable to anyone seeking beauty, meaning, and one’s place in metropolitan society.

Ultimately, The Hills is a companion album to On Sunset, but it’s anything but an afterthought. The care that Krgovich and his team put into crafting the album is evident both in the individual songs and the overall aesthetic. Although some listeners may be turned-off by the multiple instrumental tracks, I think they deepen the scope of the album, and thus I’d recommend listening to each song in order for the full effect. If that’s not your style, The Hills still contains a few gems that are worth singling out.

7.5/10

title: “Levitation” Show Preview // (April 29 - May 1)
content:
Written By: Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ (04/04/16)

FKA Austin Psych Fest, this year’s Levitation is happening April 29–May 1 in Austin, Texas—it will not disappoint. The Levitation group is partly responsible (along, of course, with SXSW) for making Austin one of the prescient music communities in the US. This year the festival lives up to its ever-growing standards and providing fans with historic heavy-hitters and vigorous newcomers. That the festival has grown to its current size in less than a decade (the first festival was 2008) mirrors the growth of Coachella. If you can make it to Austin for the weekend, then I urge you to go and celebrate the golden age of festivals at Levitation.

If you’re limited to buying one day and you want the most for your money, I suggest going on Friday. Slowdive and Brian Jonestown Massacre will attract huge crowds of shoegazers. Nicolas Jaar is known for amazing performances. Also watch out for Mild High Club and Twin Peaks. However, if you know what’s good for you, then go see Brian Wilson perform “Pet Sounds” on Saturday! (It recalls Roger Waters performing “Dark Side” at Coachella 2008 who booked by Coachella before they reached a ten-year-tenure.) Personally, the Sunday line-up is a little more stale to me. Magic Wands’s goth pop will be groovy and Quraishi’s mesmerizing rubab playing is an essential for any self-proclaimed hippie or cosmopolitan. Needless to say, Ween is a big deal for a lot of people and if you’re one of them you will want to be there.

title: Show Preview: Alex G, Porches, Your Friend @ the Echoplex (3/29/16)
content:
Written by: Eddie Hernandez for UCLA Radio (3/15/16)

In exactly two weeks, Domino Recording Co. will bring not one, not two, but three of its finest new label roster additions to Los Angeles for a very special show. Alex Giannascoli, or Alex G for short, Aaron Maine (who records solo as Porches and performs with a full live band), and supporter Taryn Miller (aka Your Friend) have been touring the States and are making a stop at the Echoplex in Echo Park for quite an eventful evening. The three have each released their first album with Domino within the past year and have since been making their way to praised reviews and bigger audiences.

Alex G’s “Beach Music,” released just this past October, continues to prove how much Alex G has to offer. With 5 albums and 3 EPs under his belt already at just the age of 23 years old, Alex’s extraordinary talent for writing heartbreaking, beautiful lyrics and combining them with unusual experimentation (strange harmonies, vocal pitch transformations, etc.) has shared countless stories for an audience that only continues to grow. “Beach Music” offers a very positive note for older fans as the album does not stray away from the authentic melancholic lo-fi recording sound Alex has always held close. The album as a live experience is a completely different product that you can only experience with Alex and his backing band.

“Pool” by Porches, released in February, has already been named ‘Best New Music’ by Pitchfork Media with a ’Best New Track’ to support it. Aaron Maine cites electronic and pop music as newer influences towards the making of “Pool” and it definitely shows. While this marks a significant change in sound in comparison to Aaron’s discography before “Pool”, it certainly is a wonderfully crafted addition to the mix that complements Aaron’s previous works very well. “Pool” expresses optimism and melancholia both to a great length - anyone can choose to dance to or simply ponder alone on the drive home and still be satisfied with their listening experience. Aaron brings Porches to life with a live band that can help turn a concert venue into an underground after-prom party for all to enjoy and feel many emotions in unison.

Tickets have been on sale for some time now, but actually have sold out early enough to a point where the venue actually made the show (originally intended for the venue’s smaller room The Echo) even bigger. This means more space, and more space means more tickets have been released! Tickets for this show are still going very fast and will likely sell out again, so it’s best to buy in advance!

Buy yours here!

title: Women In The Industry // UCLA Radio Op-Ed
content:
Written By: Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ (03/01/16)

After reading Rebecca Haithcaot’s Broadly article “‘I Felt so Trapped’: In Indie Music, Sexual Harassment Is an Accepted Nightmare” and writing an angry Facebook status, I decided it was vital to write an depth article as to why it is frustrating being a female in the music industry.

To give a bit of background about my connection with the industry: Primarily, I am a music blogger. I get roughly 80+ submissions a day, from PR agencies to labels to managers to bands themselves. Second, I am a radio DJ. I showcase some of the best music that exists and with that, how music impacts my life so much. My show this quarter Pillow Talk is centered around music that have very specific meanings to me and the people in my life. Third, I simply love music. I love finding bands and musicians that don’t get mainstream attention and hope that my roles as a blogger and DJ can help them find the attention and love they deserve. It is magical how a song and band can mean so much to a person.

However, my interactions with other personnel is strictly web-based and I have few interactions with other people face to face. But I am still aware of the harassment and potential job threats that come with the music industry. I was especially livid when I read the part about Cascine’s project manager, Andi Wilson, getting harassed at SXSW because I’ve corresponded emails with her before. It was rather unbelievable that she was just trying to do her job and had to deal with sexual harassment at the same time. And when she said, “You can’t name names. Your reputation gets tarnished,” it really struck a core with me: why do women have to prove their capability in the industry? Men can go around and sexually harass women until an actual army of women stand up and confirm these assaults.

There’s no question that having connections in the music industry is vital to survive — it’s just part of the job. So when men flaunt their connections in order to receive sexual favors from women, what are we suppose to do? Our careers depend on these connections but we have to forego our bodies and our own peace of mind in order to do something that we love so much. As Haithcoat states, “men in the industry often dangle their connections and power as sexual carrots, with the implicit understanding they’ll be yanked away if you refuse their advances.” Women are being silenced and threatened by men of power who know far too well that they are putting us in such a difficult position to be in. And yet, people still blame women for being complacent, still blaming women when they are the victims. At point can we blame men? Never?

As much as I love music, I cannot see myself working in an industry where complacency is necessary to even have and keep a career. In my own experience, after a publicist and I became friends on Facebook, he has persistently asked me out for coffee to the point that I gave in at one point and said yes. But my mind started reeling: I barely knew who he was and yet he kept asking to meet me. I asked a male friend of mine to come with me to the meeting because I was just that paranoid. In the end, I cancelled because I just couldn’t go through with it. While my story is minimal, it still puts me on the edge as to how shady the industry can be.

What is infuriating is that men think that this is their industry and that women are there to be slabs of meat that are there for men’s own sexual pleasure. This, then, makes women question their own capabilities. What are we suppose to think when we only got our jobs because someone with power thinks that we’re cute, that we’re there just to give them an extra ounce of pleasure in their lives. Why should my career be built upon someone’s unsolicited crush on me? Women are constantly trying to do their job and battle off men and sexual assaults and the real question is why this is the norm.

Sexual harassment in the industry is covered up when the women are working behind the scenes. Publicist Heathcliff Berru had been sexually harassing women for years but only recently, he was called out for his gross misconduct. Dirty Projectors’ Amber Coffman tweeted about how Berru had grabbed her ass and bit her hair after minutes of meeting her. After that, Best Coast’s front woman Bethany Cosentino also spoke out about Berru sexually harassing her. These sexual harassment stories are only brought to light when well known women, who have a face and voice in the industry, speak out about the outrageous mistreatment of women. Once again, it takes a literal army of women to just take one disgusting sexual predator down. Why is it that one man’s words are worth more than one woman’s words?

As UCLA celebrates Female Empowerment week, I challenge you to question the sexualization of women in the industry. The media specifically focuses on the aesthetic appeal of female artists rather than their actual talent. The industry capitalizes on society’s apparently inherent need to degrade women to just their looks. It’s so much worse when women don’t have a face or voice to fight back, and the final result is how silenced and trapped we feel.

title: Ra Ra Riot - Need Your Light // Album Review
content:
Review By: Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ (02/23/16)

On February 19, Ra Ra Riot released their fourth studio album Need Your Light. The last time I listened to this band was when their second album The Orchard came out and that was in 2010 when indie pop fervently scaled the music industry with the likes of Vampire Weekend and Two Door Cinema Club. When the band released the first single “Water” from Need Your Light, I felt like they had evolved in their sound: it sounded more synthesized and more electropop-y. I completely skipped over Beta Love because it was so heavily drowned in electronica. With Need Your Light, Ra Ra Riot brings back bit of the indie pop rock that I loved in The Orchard and even a bit of the orchestral sound in their first album The Rhumb Line.

But when I hear Need Your Light, I feel a little…stuck in all its pop sounds. At some points, I even feel like I’m listening to a Carly Rae Jepsen album when I’m looking for more of their indie pop rock sound. Songs like “Absolutely” and “Foreign Lovers” just have such a standard formula for happy go-lucky songs that seemingly sounds great to any one but no actually distinguishable qualities.

On the other hand, there are some serious gems on this album like “Instant Breakup”. It could be that I just really like sad songs…but the electropop on this track has this fantastic quality of keeping the track lighter in the beginning and when it hits the chorus, it morphs into this dark entity that really gets at the heart of what the track is about. I also love the mix of pop with the orchestral strings, adding so much more depth and contrast into the track. Another one of my favorites is “Suckers” which has a much darker electropop sound compared to the rest of the album.

Overall, I think Need Your Light was almost a redemption album. Ra Ra Riot definitely returned back to their roots and what I do like about this album is that it is definitely experimenting with the balance between electronica and actual instrumentation. This era of music rides so much on experimental music and Ra Ra Riot is experimenting with releasing a hybrid sound.

Favorite Tracks:

Water (feat. Rostam)

Call Me Out

Instant Breakup

Suckers

title: Show Review // Frankie Cosmos + Eskimeaux @ Che Café (4/15/16)
content:
Written By: Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio DJ 

Post Date: 04/26/16

Originating from Brooklyn, Frankie Cosmos and Eskimeaux have probably seen their fare-share of DIY pop up shows. Their ethos calls for an intimate venue – or at least one that is compact – where it seems incredibly possible that you might bump into them after the show. That is not to say the small venue went without grandeur. Decorated with hand-painted murals and marked with ‘safe-space’ notices, the intimately-bared personality of the Che Café lent weight to the emotive connection between the music and the venue.

Eskimeaux played the entirety of their new EP, Year of the Rabbit, in which Gabrielle Smith displays her delicate craft in songwriting. The concert had an atmosphere of collaboration, Frankie Cosmos’ Greta Kline joined Eskimeaux on stage to assist with background vocals, as Gabrielle Smith would do for Kline later on with synth and vocals. After the crowd shouted requests for a favorite off of their 2015 album O.K., Smith obliged, ending their set with the song “Broken Necks.” The culmination of romping drums and wavering vocal lines filled the space where all the youthful confessionalism and nostalgia goes, akin to the last night out over summer. Purely sincere and sweet, the set ended with the social and spiritual proclamation that “nothing in this world is holier than friendship.”

Frankie Cosmos took the stage to play a set centered around her latest album release, Next Thing. Sporting a shirt which read “Small Size But Big Dreams,” which she said got from a rest stop, Greta Kline spoke with an endearing sense of humility and congeniality. She imparted a similar impression in her vocal delivery, though seemingly demure, there was a quality sense of self-assurance. With their songs existing as short-form bursts of energy with ever-fluctuating paces in tempo and rhythm, the audience had to get all of their dancing out in quick intervals. Airy synths worked to extend and draw out, while tight snare hits acted as punctuation. On songs “Tour Good” and “Outside with the Cuties,” Kline seemed to reflect on the experience of touring and songwriting with lines like, “I haven’t finished this song yet / will you help me fix it?” In those moments it was clear the concert experience was not just for the audience to soak in, but was also becoming an evolving part of Frankie Cosmos’ art.

In the midst of all this, a promposal was made for two young audience members via Kline. The answer was yes.

title: I Still Haven’t Heard The Life of Pablo & I Can’t Care // UCLA Radio Op-ed
content:
Written By: Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ (04/25/16)

Contributing factors include: school obligations; work obligations; life obligations; the drudgery of shaking-off wintertime apathy; general apathy; not having a Tidal subscription; my principle of never succumbing to pay for a Tidal subscription; seriously, fuck a conglomerate of n-number music moguls who dress up a product selling it to the public as “giving power back to musicians” when they are the few elite musicians who have the efficacy to “give back,” but instead agglomerate their energies to monopolize content distribution; Kanye and Deadmau5’s twitter beef being staged—it was merely Kanye plugging his fellow oligarch’s new DAW; the $53 million dollar debt being staged—his wife is easily worth twice that; selling out personhood to become a brand; Ye’s inflammatory comments to rile up the public for hype generation; Generation-hYpe; (whatever happened to the “KanYe West” signage?); detachment from the human condition—you can’t make soul music without a soul; similarly, you can’t listen to soul music without a soul; making ‘gospel’ music that praises the almighty Dollar; removing Good Friday songs from Soundcloud (note: I don’t believe that music should be consumed for free in every instance, but the original Good Friday releases proffered a musical common to the fans as a sign of dedication and gratitude; now it’s less about sharing and more about hype); Ye’s designing a sub-par clothing line; reading Sebald; digesting Sebald; marinating; decomposing; composing; and, of course, I can’t torrent the album because then I wouldn’t be not caring, would I?

title: Frankie Cosmo’s “Next Thing” // Album Review
content:
Written By: Sergio Garcia, UCLA Radio Music Dept (04/16/16)

Greta Kline is no ordinary 22-year-old. A born musician if there ever was one, Kline began uploading songs under the name Frankie Cosmos in mid adolescence before releasing her debut LP Zentropy in 2014. The album made waves in the indie world, notable for its heartfelt and graceful songwriting. Two years and one EP later, a bolder, more confident Kline has pushed her craft to new heights on Next Thing.

Like Zentropy, the album clocks in at less than thirty minutes, but it would be nothing short of tragic to fault it on its length. The songs all hover around two minutes long and incorporate clean, well-structured melodies that surround Kline’s delicate vocals with fitting guitar, keyboard, bass, and drums. The music’s brevity has prompted some to label her a minimalist, but I think this misses the mark. Kline’s music isn’t purposely short, as if the original songs were longer and the group tried to cut them down. Rather, they’re exactly as long as they need to be, as the ideas and emotions that inspired them demand. Consequently, the album offers an incredibly rich listening experience. The power of each song is tangible. I often found myself double-checking the track length, wondering how I could be so blown away by such comparably short recordings.

Kline’s maturity and poise throughout the album is striking. Full of meditations on vulnerability, stinging regrets, and a promising future, Next Thing excels at transforming everyday experiences into elegant sketches of humanity. Delicate and melancholic when it needs to be, energetic at other times, the album feels like a splash of cool water on the face – refreshing, serene, alive. Kline writes candidly, with just a pure desire to share her life through music. Regardless of the listener’s age, it’s hard to pass through the album without feeling emotionally connected to her in some way – a rare feat indeed. Penetrating, unassuming, and beautiful, Next Thing delivers on all fronts. For music fans, nothing could be more rewarding than witnessing a true artist hitting her stride.

9/10

title: I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful Yet So Unaware Of It - The 1975 // Album Review
content:
Written By : Casey McNamara, UCLA Radio Digital Press Member (04/05/16)

I wasn’t expecting to like the 1975’s new record. The whiny vocals and poppy-Phoenix sound of their debut actively irritated me, and their image seemed almost indistinguishable from some of the other indie-pop bands like the Neighbourhood or Walk the Moon that were blowing up a couple of years ago. However, lead singer Matty Healy’s charismatic press bites intrigued me, and I’m down for any and all attempts to combine 90’s R&B, emo, shoegaze and “John Hughes movies”. Not only does Healy actually pull these different sounds together organically on I Like It.., but he does so with wit and heart, making it one of the most ambitious pop records released this year.

Healy has been pretty open in the press about his struggles with depression and drug abuse, and he touches on these topics in most of the tracks here. “She Lays Down” is an empathetic portrait of his mother, who suffered postpartum depression after his birth, while “Nana” is an ode to his grandmother in the wake of her death. On “The Ballad of Me and My Brain” he imagines trying to literally find his brain, opening with the line, “I think I’ve gone mad/isn’t that so sad?”. Lead single “Love Me” is a tongue in cheek look at the almost One-Direction-level of fame the band struggled with during the making of the record: “You’ve been reading ‘bout yourself/ On a plane, fame for a change/ Caught up in fashion, Karcrashian panache and a bag of bash for passion/You’ve got a beautiful face but got nothing to say.”

Clearly, the 1975 have plenty to say. But their message falls to connect on a couple of tracks, which are just not on par with the rest of the album musically or lyrically. Two of the three instrumental tracks don’t really go anywhere and “This Must Be My Dream” and “Paris” are predictable and dull synth pop retreads. However, most of the record is definitely worth a listen (especially “The Sound” and “Somebody Else”).  I recommend it to pop fans or anyone who enjoyed Carly Rae Jepsen’s “EMOTION”-  I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful Yet So Unaware Of It wears its heart on its sleeve and transcends genre.

8/10

title: Dean Blunt @ The Echoplex // Concert Review (3/11/16)
content:
Written By: Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press (03/27/16)

The unmistakable elusiveness of Dean Blunt made its way onto The Echoplex stage this past Friday, ushered in by two synth-savvy producers and a wave of brooding sounds.
Friday night’s show marked my first venture into The Echoplex, but the venue immediately struck me as the perfect setting for a performance of this scope.  The Echoplex is equally intimate as it is sinister—Save for a few lights to guide guests to the bar, illumination is used very sparingly in a place like this.
Mellow spotlights bathed the stage as SFV Acid stepped up.  The 23 year-old producer made a rather quiet entrance, but was quick to capture the audience’s attention as they poured into the venue.  Acid’s live sound is very reminiscent of the likes of Aphex Twin, but he avoided too strong a comparison by sprinkling in some airy, eccentric, and especially catchy melodies into the mix.
Delroy Edwards, the second opening producer, commanded his stage time with a sound that incited a pretty foreboding mood.  The performance came across as being particularly calculated as well, especially given that Edwards would throw in the occasional synth-heavy rhythm to break up the tension and any potential monotony.
The wait for Dean Blunt himself was an experience unto itself.  After an abrupt finish and quick thank-you from Edwards, the crowd was immediately subjected to wave upon wave of fog.  Eventually the effect from this haunted house staple got so dense that I had trouble seeing people that were standing mere inches away from me.  Suddenly, the background noise cut, and we were treated to a looped three-second vocal snippet for a good ten minutes.  If I learned anything new about the ever-mysterious Dean Blunt Friday night, it’s that he takes great pleasure in pushing his audience to their limits.
Blunt loomed over the crowd long before the opening chords to “50 CENT” began, but this fact was largely unknown to the fans still struggling to keep an eye on their friends within the fog.  The performance itself was unique in that the audience had no choice but to look to each other when the stage and the performer were no longer visible.  Some members of the audience were openly disappointed about this, but I felt like there was something profoundly mesmerizing about watching people sink in and out of the fog, or having the mist clear only to reveal a circle of friends dancing to Blunt’s disquieting soundscapes.
While Dean Blunt’s “stage presence” won’t sit well with everyone, I have to give him credit for crafting a show that’s truly reflective of his enigmatic persona and nothing short of provocative.  The music itself was bizarre in just the right ways,  and I truly enjoyed watching how the playfulness of Dean’s production quips manifested itself via his relationship with the audience.
But after an hourlong debate between soothingly mellow and deafeningly abrasive sounds, Blunt exited the stage just as coyly as he came in.  Blinding strobe lights signaled us back out into the streets, where we all saw each other under new lights, refreshing clarity, and in a much more grounded context—Like waking up together from a dream.

title: The Drums @ The Observatory (2/28/2016) // Show Review
content:
Written By: Sophia Forino, UCLA Radio DJ (03/07/16)

Last Sunday I found myself flocking back to the venue that, at this point, may be considered my home away from home, The Observatory in Santa Ana. I was there to see The Drums in their first of two nights playing at the venue. While this was my fourth time seeing them this year (they seem to be on the same festival circuit I am on), I am constantly reminded of why I love them the second they step onto the stage.

Because I was a little tired and not in the mood to be standing on tip-toe or get lost in densely-packed pit, I decided to lay low and check out the venue’s new side balconies to watch from above. My plus-one and I got great standing seats right along the railing of the balcony, giving us a fantastic view of a show and the audience. To me, it was even more amazing because at my 5 feet 2 inches, it is rare that I ever actually get to see a concert, so I will definitely keep these balconies in mind for future shows.

 As soon as The Drums came on stage the atmosphere in the room completely changed. I have never seen an audience scream or reach towards the stage so enthusiastically. Part of it might have to do with leading man Jonny Pierce’s eerie and drawling voice and lyrical yet seance-y dance moves but it seemed as though every person inside the venue knew every word to every song they performed.

They opened with “Bell Laboratories” a strange song that seemingly repeats the line “get back in the car but I ran so far” and immediately segued into one of my favorite songs “I Can’t Pretend”. They continued with some of their most popular songs such as “Money,” “Days,” and “What You Were”. One of the downfalls, I felt, in this set was that they played too many of their better-known songs in the beginning and end rather than dispersing them throughout the entirety of the show. By the middle-end, I felt almost a boring lull as they played too many consecutive, lesser-known, slow ballads. The rest of the crowd, however, didn’t seem to mind for they never stopped singing along and pushing each other to get to the front to possibly touch Jonny’s hand (another perk of watching from the balcony). 

 Overall, The Drums put on a fantastic show as they always do. They have such a dedicated fan base (especially in Southern California) that induces an energy and electricity during their shows. Even if you had no clue who the band was, experiencing the crowd who worships them will leave you with a lasting impression that The Drums are a band to look out for. While they definitely have made some big moves from where they were a few years ago, I have no doubt that The Drums will continue to rise and bring more ear traffic towards the Surf Pop genre in the years to come.

title: UCLA Radio's Show of the Month - March: “Burger Radio U” w/ Joe and Issa
content:
Meet our new show of the month for March!!

Listening to Burger Radio U on UCLA Radio is possibly the most fun you can probably have on the airwaves. Burger Radio U focuses on the music that blooms out of LA’s arguably most popular Do-It-Yourself record label to come out of local Fullerton, CA. Burger Records is a label that constantly adds to their artist roster and continuously puts out releases from up-and-coming artists and LA favorites including FIDLAR, The Orwells, The Growlers, The Memories, and many many more beloved acts. Hosts of the show, Joe and Issa, never fail to provide listeners with new and exciting Burger signees and affiliates to check out with packed weekly playlists that will have you jumping up and down your seat for two hours straight.

Thanks to Joe, Issa, and UCLA Radio Alumni Jake Hook who started Burger Radio U about a year or two ago, UCLA Radio has established a unique connection with Burger Radio U that brings in fantastic acts into the station nearly every week. Acts who have guested the show in the past for an in-studio performance include Colleen Green, The Memories, Part Time, Franky Flowers, Vision, and L.A. Witch to name a few! Just this past weekend, Joe, Issa, their interns Nicole and Kyle, and all BRU listeners were treated to a special acoustic set from Kera Armendariz of Kera and the Lesbians! These two are quite the busy boys with a whole lotta spunk and a kick ass show.

Don’t forget to tune into Burger Radio U every Sunday from 2-4pm!

Follow Joe and Issa on their Facebook page here as they post about all the fun stuff that happens on the show so you won’t ever miss out!

Tune in here and on the UCLA Radio social media pages (Facebook, Twitter) tomorrow when we post some sweet q&a footage with the show’s hosts and interns!

title: Animal Collective - Painting With // Album Review
content:
Review By: Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ (02/24/16)

As a person who prides themselves in listening primarily to obscure indie music, I’m honestly ashamed I haven’t picked up Animal Collective until now. Last week I casually started with their new release Painting With, and quickly realized the atrocity I had committed by ignoring the literal dozens of times I had been recommended to look them up. Attempting to define Animal Collective as a genre is ambitious to say the least; they’ve been called everything from freak folk to experimental pop to unconventional psych-rock. I won’t attempt to label them as anything but profoundly weird and extraordinarily catchy. Painting With starts off strong with the oozing, energetic pop single “FloriDada” that instantly caught my attention. From there the album goes down a bit of an experimental rabbit hole, but manages to pull back up with track “Bagels in Kiev.” Ending on a high note with “Recycling,” I finished my Animal Collective experience with a satisfaction I rarely get from listening to an entire album. Given this is the tenth album put out by the music group, I admit there’s plenty of material I haven’t listened to that might affect my opinion of Painting With; many Animal Collective fans have found themselves to be rather disappointed with the new album, claiming the originality and creativity of their previous work seems to have vanished. Given the most intriguing part of Animal Collective could be that, in the words of critic Jamieson Cox, “nothing about their artistry felt predictable or stable,” I can concede that Painting With might feel a bit safe. The group said they was influenced by the Ramones while creating the album, which shows in the short two to four minute songs that deviate from the convoluted, drawn out tracks some fans may be used to. Listening with a fresh ears, however, I thoroughly enjoyed the new release, and consider it a perfect recommendation to that one quirky friend who knits their own clothes and likes taking psychedelic drugs. For those who may be doubtful, I encourage you to take a chance on Painting With - you may be pleasantly surprised.

title: The Role of the Narrative in Beyonce’s “Lemonade” // UCLA Radio Op-ed
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee, UCLA Radio DJ (04/26/16)

Disclaimer: This is not an album review. Frankly, I find Lemonade’s visual and musical content so rife with emotional, historical and socio-political significance that trying to write a review that does justice to all the rich, nuanced points of the album without it being a thousand pages long or an incoherent mess of my emotions seems beyond by writing capability. This is an opinion article specifically addressing the way Beyoncé uses the intensely personal experience of infidelity in marriage as a vehicle to give voice to the black American woman, as well as other silenced, trapped communities.

On Saturday night, April 23, Beyoncé unleashed her visual album Lemonade to the world. This 57 minute, twelve track narrative chronicles the artist’s navigation through her strained bond with her husband, with the different stages of her journey often coinciding with the stages in the Kübler-Ross model of grief (denial, anger, etc.). However, interspersed amidst lyrics so intimate they can only be interpreted as directly written to Jay Z are broader but equally provoking messages acknowledging and challenging the history of oppressing the self.

The film includes excerpts from a 1962 Malcolm X speech on protecting black women, as well as footage of the mothers of Trayvon Martin and Michael Brown. These portions of Lemonade, rather than contrasting Beyoncé’s emotional vulnerability, indicate that the struggle Beyoncé feels is analogous to the inherited, internalized struggle of black women everywhere. Beyoncé offers viewers a window into the hidden depths of her psyche. We are given privy to her search for resolution in the face of being cheated on. We are exposed to memories and emotions that, prior to this album release, only Beyoncé had felt and understood. But as the narrative expands to encompass the stories and images of other women, black families, southern American homes and communities—I could go on and on—it becomes clear that Beyoncé is doing more than just telling the story of her own marriage: she is telling a universally understood story of loss that reverberates across all human lives. She tells a story that is hauntingly intimate yet still evokes closeness and association in listeners. By oscillating back and forth between a private confession narrative and a narrative that represents the voices of all black women, Beyoncé reveals a unity between the two that transcends the individual.

Lemonade draws upon parallels between relationship issues specific to Beyoncé and the universal feeling of visceral, disappointed pain, particularly amongst African American females. Ultimately, the effect of this comparison creates a harmonious dialogue between the experiences of the individual and the larger collective human experience. Beyoncé’s album demonstrates that the emotions that feel most personal and unique to us are what connect us to and resonate with the souls of all humans.

title: Jessy Lanza Listening Party Interview
content:
Photos + Words By : Gabe Brenner, UCLA Radio Art & Design Manager (04/25/16)

You’re from Hamilton, Canada, correct?

I’m from Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, yeah. That (Ontario) is the province.

Do you still live there?

I still live there, yes.

Did growing up there affect the way you make music now?

I don’t know if the city itself did. I think what maybe affected the way I make music for a little while was going to school for music, but the city itself, not so much.

Does Hamilton have a developed music scene?

Yeah, they do, but it’s not like… It’s not like Los Angeles (laughs). I mean, it’s cool, though. There’s a lot of local artists and it’s cool because it’s a city where there’s a lot of… Kind of weird people doing weird art where the goal isn’t to make money or to be recognized. I think it’s more because people are compelled to. They play music just for the sake of being creative, so you get a lot of weird stuff. That’s what I like about the city, though, because there’s no other prerogatives in mind.

So you have a better idea of the type of people you’re interacting with?

Yeah, like you know their goal, and I guess it’s just to be creative.

So going back to your time at school, you have a background in jazz piano studies and spent some time in a Masters program for it. Does your background in jazz piano play a part in your current songwriting process?

Yeah, it does. In school, I learned what I feel like is one of the most valuable things, which is how to listen to music, lift the chords, and play them yourself. That’s how I started a lot of my own songs- it was by listening to other people and sort of learning the songs I really liked, and then it all kind of seeps in. Then I try those chords in a different way, or make it slower, or faster, so that plays a huge part in my creative process.

So it’s almost like remixing your faves?

Yeah! So it’s not recognizable that I’ve, like, totally ripped off somebody else’s song (laughs). But, you know, there’s so many other influences that come in. You can’t make it too close to the real thing.

True, don’t want to get sued.

Oh my god, no. No. I’m afraid of that.

I feel, especially when it comes to sampling, it’s hard to know how close is too close.

You know, you could always just Shazam something to see if it picks it up (laughs). Use the Shazam method!

For your debut album and this upcoming album, Oh No, you worked with Jeremy Greenspan of Junior Boys. What’s the creative process like when working with him?

Working with Jeremy is great. He’s really easygoing. There’s no ego when we’re in the studio and he’s willing to take risks. I think one of the most important things when working with somebody is that you’re both not worried too much about making something bad. I think in order to make something good, you have to be willing to kind of put yourself out there. You have to risk looking stupid or adding a stupid part, but you just can’t think of it that way. He’s really creative and willing to try different things to make a song work.

In that case, what’s the most “out there” thing that he, or you, have done when making a song?

In terms of “out there” stuff, I’m the more adventurous one when it comes to integrating samples and different, weird sounds. Jeremy is good at making something cohesive out of things that sound like a bunch of insanity, or things that are atonal. I’ll come back with a verse or a chorus that I’m really happy with, but I know it needs another part. Jeremy’s great at adding, like… a bridge. Or being like, “No, this should be the chorus.” He’s good at sequencing and coming up with different chord progressions. He’s a good finisher.

Oh, so like a “closing paragraph” type of guy.

Yeah, I’ll have a very strong idea. I’ll be like, “I’ve got a verse and a chorus,” but it’s only a minute and thirty seconds long. He’s really good at fleshing ideas out and making them actually finished songs, whereas I’ll have, like, ten ideas. And they’re… good, but just not done, you know?

Your music is very pop-oriented, but you also pull from more underground sources like footwork and the techno group Yellow Magic Orchestra. Do you have any aspirations for pop-stardom, or do you feel more at home slightly left of that field?

I don’t know if people would, like, accept me as I was (laughs). I’m not glossy enough. I wouldn’t describe myself as being rough around the edges, but I think you have to have a certain degree of polish to be accepted by the masses. I don’t think that’s gonna happen for me, but you never know. I feel like unconventional pop stars were much more normal twenty years ago. People have gotten more conservative, you know? But, it’s hard to measure when you weren’t there living it. I guess you could look at the numbers; even the numbers for pop stars were different then than they are now. I always think about bands like The Art of Noise going number one on the pop charts. “Moments In Love” was a number one hit on the charts, which is crazy. I can’t think of that happening now. It just doesn’t seem like something that would happen in 2016.

Your lead singles from Oh No have a lot of aesthetic and compositional elements that are similar to freestyle music. That’s something I grew up listening to, and it’s a big thing in Southern California. You actually did a project with Morgan Geist’s The Galleria that was directly influenced by Freestyle, too, so would you say freestyle music is something that influences you in your own music?

I really love where freestyle skirts the line with boogie. Like in Carmen’s “Time to Move” and “Throw Down,” you hear funk in freestyle. I love her, I think she’s one of my favorite voices. I’m not a freestyle expert by any stretch, but I do love those unconventional pop voices that are a bit rough around the edges. Madonna had that, too, when Jellybean Benitez was producing here early stuff like “Sidewalk Talk.” So I think I definitely am influenced by freestyle, and by boogie and funk and disco and all those genres that surround freestyle.

Do you have a favorite freestyle track?

Carmen’s “Throw Down,” and I love Debbie Deb’s “Lookout Weekend.” So good. She’s got such a funny story. Morgan Geist actually schooled me on Debbie Deb. She was really self-conscious about getting her picture taken, so there’s not very many pictures of her at all. She was really young, so she couldn’t perform in the clubs that made the record a hit. Her record label treated her really weird; they had a stand-in Debbie Deb!

You often talk about your wide range of influences when making your music, but do you have one particular record, album, or artist that you find yourself continually returning to for inspiration? Is there a song that changed your life?

That’s a tough question; I have a lot of songs that I’d say belong on my “Top Ten.” Evelyn King’s “Love Come Down” is one of my favorite songs of all time. From that song, I got really into Kashif who produced “Love Come Down.” He has some really great tracks that sound kind of like “Love Come Down,” except it’s him singing. Same type of funky bass lines. And Prince, R.I.P. after the shitty news that came today. He’s a huge influence for me, as well. One of his first records especially, the self-titled record. But I like so much different stuff, like Steely Dan, I’ve liked them for the longest.

Last question, what are your favorite releases of the year so far, and what are some upcoming releases that you’re looking forward to?

When did Vince Staples’s record come out? I think that was Summer of last year, but I loved that album. I like Rihanna’s new album. I mean, I like that she’s being bold. She’s kind of being like, “Fuck it, I do what I want.”

A very Rihanna move.

Yeah, I like it. I think it’s weird, and I like it. I like Rihanna. But what’s coming out in the fall? I always space on questions like this. Drake’s releasing Views from the 6. And Frank Ocean’s supposed to come out with something. I’ll probably remember after this is done. But yeah, Rihanna’s record’s good (laughs).

title: UCLA Radio NBA Playoff Preview // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: Daniil Loza, UCLA Radio Sports DJ (04/18/16)

It is the most wonderful time of the year. The NBA playoffs are upon us. Yes, our memories are still fresh from Kobe Bryant’s amazing 60 point swan song or the Golden State Warriors breaking the record for most wins in a season by reaching 73-9, beating out the 1995-1996 Chicago Bulls that went 72-10 while being led by Michael Jordan. However that was the regular season. Legacies are defined in the playoffs. Without further ado, here is our NBA Playoff Preview:

EASTERN CONFERENCE

1 Cleveland Cavaliers (57-25) vs. 8 Detroit Pistons (44-38)

Pistons 3-1 In the Regular Season

The Detroit Pistons are a young team with a concrete identity lead by a brilliant head coach, however they lack the high end talent and experience to really make a deep playoff run. The Pistons are a team with an identity: the pick and roll between their point guard Reggie Jackson and their center Andre Drummond. This play has been near unstoppable during the regular season and they surround this play with 3 point shooters that gives them an extra option in case that play is shut down. Although, this is a 1-8 matchup, the Cavaliers could have some issue defending the Pistons due to not having the personnel to deal with Andre Drummond.

However, Cleveland still has the more talented roster and arguably the best player in Lebron James who the Pistons cannot really deal with either. There are very few players that can make an impact on the game on offense and defense like a fully engaged Lebron James. Furthermore, Cleveland has a better defensive roster and they should be able to shut down the majority of what Detroit can throw at them. The Pistons have a huge coaching advantage in Stan van Gundy and I expect him to make some adjustments to make this series competitive but the talent disparity and Lebron James will be what ultimately helps Cleveland prevail. Cavaliers in 6.

2 Toronto Raptors (56-26) vs. 7 Indiana Pacers (45-37)

Toronto 3-1 in the Regular Season

Toronto has attained its largest win total in team history thanks to career years from the dynamic backcourt of Kyle Lowry and Demar Derozan furthermore their do it all defensive forward Demarre Carol is back from injury, and he should help shut down Indiana’s only really dynamic scoring threat in Paul George. The only issue with this team is the two early first round playoff exits that it has had the last two years and until they prove otherwise, questions regarding the team’s mentality will persist.

The Pacers were lead dynamic wing Paul George, who was able to come back this season from a gruesome leg injury and cemented his status as a top 15 player in the NBA. However, the rest of the roster does not inspire confidence talent wise. Credit the coach Frank Vogel for creating a top 10 defense with the players he has, but the offense is near the bottom of the league with only really Paul George being able to create his own offense. The Raptors will be able to shut them down relatively easy and score by getting to the free throw line. However, because of the early playoff exits, the Raptors may drop a couple games due to lack of mental toughness to a team they should sweep with relative ease. Raptors in 6.

3 Miami Heat (48-34) vs 6 Charlotte Hornets (48-34)

Even Series 2-2 in the Regular Season

On paper, this should be the closest series. The Miami Heat have come back from the dead with a revamped roster full of veterans and some surprising rookie contribution to become a dominant defensive team and a weird offensive team. They have Dwyane Wade still being star player he once, and dynamic center Hassan Whiteside tearing it up inside and blocking everything in sight during a career year. This team though, goes through scoring droughts that last not only minutes but can go on for whole quarters during which teams tend to catch up if Miami is ever ahead.

No one had Charlotte pegged as a playoff team, but they have exceeded expectations with a roster full of awkward white guys and a fearless sharpshooting point guard in Kemba Walker.  Kemba Walker Has made improvements that has elevated him into the elite tier at his position. Nicholas Batum, their prized offseason acquire meant via trade, has returned to form as a shooter, passer and playmaker. They play conservative and disciplined defense along with a fun three happy offense that can win them games. However, the Hornets are inexperienced and many have never been to the playoffs. Overall the Heat core has made deep playoff runs before and young teams tend to suffer from stage fright. Those one to two games that Charlotte will need to acclimate themselves to a playoff environment is enough to of a disparity for the Heat what should be a tightly contested series. Heat in 7.

4 Atlants Hawks (48-34) vs 5 Boston Celtics (48-34)

Hawks 3-1 in the Regular Season

This game is probably the most fun and interesting matchup of the first round in the east. Atlanta Hawks may have not been as good offensively this season as last, but they reinvented themselves having the second most stingiest defense behind the Spurs’ historical mark. They do not have a traditional rim protecting big, but Al Horford and Paul Millsap have been great doing that and guarding the stretch 5’s and 4’s that would give traditional big men trouble in today’s NBA. They have two amazing guards take turns being great, and they have a lot of depth in their defensive wings.

Boston has been led by a genius coach in Brad Stevens and Isiah Thomas has had an all star season scoring the basketball. But outside of him no one is great at getting their own shots. Boston however has the best collection of tenacious perimeter defense and Jae Crowder has gotten healthy right as the playoffs have started to act as fulcrum defensively and offensively. The oddball collection of bigs that Boston however will not be able to stop Al Horford or Paul MIllsap which is why In the end, I think that Atlanta pulls it out. Hawks in 7.

WESTERN CONFERENCE

1 Golden State Warriors (73-9) vs Houston Rockets (41-41)

Warriors 4-0 in the Regular Season

The Warriors just finished one of the most dominant regular seasons of all time and as mentioned in the intro setting the record for wins. They are deep, being able to play any style, but they really excel in a fast paced, crazy chaotic game. They have the reigning MVP in Stephen Curry, the greatest shooter of all time, Klay Thompson, another historical shooter and a cast of amorphous wings that can switch everywhere on defense, pass the ball well and hit the three. Finally Draymond Green is what makes them dominant in being able to defend all five positions, and acts as a release valve for Curry, rebound, pass, shoot; he is the heart and soul of the Warriors.

The Rockets returned their whole roster last year that got to the Western Conference Finals, but chemistry and effort issues doomed them to a bad start and underachieving all year. James Harden has been unbelievable on offense, but most of the role players have underachieved. Their defense has fallen off a cliff, but the athleticism and talent is still there. They like to play a crazy, chaotic game like the Warriors, but the Warriors just do it better. There is a chance that the athleticism and talent comes together to steal a game or two, but that probably will not happen as the rockets have proven time and again this whole season. Warriors in 4.

2 San Antonio Spurs (67-15) vs Memphis Grizzlies (42-40)

Spurs 4-0 in the Regular Season

The San Antonio Spurs brought back their championship winning core from two years ago and added a star player in Lamarcus Aldridge. They reinvented themselves as less of a pass happy beautiful offensive team into one of the stingiest defensive team in NBA history. Kawhi Leonard has come into his own offensively and still is the most disruptive defensive player in the NBA. Parker, Ginobli and Duncan continue to defy Father Time and went almost undefeated at home. This is possibly one of the greatest regular season teams of all time, but they were overshadowed to an extent by the Warriors’ greatness.

Memphis had a lot of bad luck this year. Their two best players have missed the majority of the season and they have had a record 28 players suit up for them this year. Tony Allen and Zachary Randolph have played great, but they are 2-14 in their last 16 games and do not stand a chance against the Spurs. Joerger, the coach has done an amazing job getting them into the playoffs, but they will not get very far. Spurs in 4.

3 Oklahoma City Thunder (55-27) vs 6 Dallas Mavericks (42-40)

Thunder are 4-0 in the Regular Season

Oklahoma City were able to make a comeback into the playoffs this year thanks to a mostly healthy season from Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook, who provided transcendent offensive play. They have a great role player in Enes Kanter, Steven Adams to pick up offensive rebounds and Serge Ibaka who continues to defend at a high level, although his shooting has fallen off a bit. Their biggest issue remains scoring crunch time scoring as they run the predictable “give the ball to Durnat or Westbrook and watch them make something happen out of nothing” offense. Furthermore they are are guilty of not trying on defense for the full 48 minutes, but despit these shortcomings, OKC still won 55 games due to the sheer talent and athleticism.

Rick Carlisle has continued to do the impossible: he has taken a team of unwanted veterans and Dirk Nowitzki into the playoffs. Due to their age, the Mavericks play a very deliberate and conservative style that values every possession and reduces chaos when it comes to games. DIrk can still transcend on offense, but their defense has just not been very good this year. A young, athletic Thunder team should be able to run the Mavericks out of the building, but out of respect for the greatness in RIck Carlisle and Dirk, I predict only a gentleman’s sweep. Thunder in 5.

4 Los Angeles Clippers (53-29) vs 5 Portland Trailblazers (44-38)

Clippers 3-1 in the Regular Season

The Clippers had another 50 win season even though arguably their best player, Blake Griffin, has missed 60% of the season. He returned recently, but has not looked the same. In his absence, Chris Paul kept the ship steady submitting an mvp-like season. Deandre Jordan has been dunking everything in sight and taking advantage of teams. JJ Reddick had a career year shooting, hitting over 200 threes and leading the league in three point percentage. Their wing play remains a question mark along with their bench, but the Clippers are talented enough to if things go their way, they should be making a deep playoff run.

Portland lost 4 starters from last years 50 win team, but kudos to them in finding a way to make the playoffs and nab the fifth seed. Damian Lillard has proven to be a superstar and taken all the snubs personally providing an amazing season. His backcourt mate CJ McCollum has become a great shooter and a dynamic of the dribble creator giving Portland two players who can carry an offense any given night. The coach Terry Stotts has been able to craft an offense behind these two dynamic players that is both fun to watch and is highly effective. However those two guards are not good defenders and will not be able to stop LA. Clippers in 6

title: Clippers Cruise Past Lakers 103-81 in Kobe Bryant’s Final Away Game At Staples Center  // UCLA Radio Sports (04/05/16)
content:
Photos Provided, and Written By : Darryn Albert, UCLA Radio Sports Manager (04/11/16)

History tends to forget how dangerously close Kobe Bryant came to signing with the Los Angeles Clippers in the tumultuous summer of 2004.  But history was all that was on anyone’s mind as Bryant waved to the home crowd of those same Clippers for the final time of his legendary 20-year NBA career.

The Clippers played the role of spoilers in Bryant’s last away game at the Staples Center, coasting to an easy 103-81 victory over their cross-arena rival Los Angeles Lakers on Tuesday night.  But much more so than any final score, this evening was about paying tribute to the man who had brought countless unforgettable memories to this very building over the course of the last two decades.  

“He’s entertained the whole city, the whole country, the whole world for 20 years,” said Clippers guard Chris Paul, Bryant’s close friend and almost-Lakers teammate if not for a fateful executive decision by then-commissioner David Stern in 2011, of The Black Mamba.  “Everything that he gets, he deserves.”

Paul, who led the team with 25 points and eight assists in the victory, was far from the only Clipper to reflect on what these last battles against Bryant meant to him.

“Ever since I’ve been in the NBA, Kobe has been the one constant,” said guard Jamal Crawford, who has been in more than his fair share of shooting guard duels with the five-time Lakers champion over the years.  “He’s the guy everybody from his age down looks up to.  He’s a star amongst stars.

“He’s somebody who has left his imprint on the game,” continued Crawford, who finished the night with four points in 18 minutes.  “I’ve always said, I think that we’ve seen that from Michael Jordan, but he’s the closest one to him.”

Clippers forward Blake Griffin was equally sentimental about Bryant’s final NBA season.  “He’s meant a lot to the game of basketball.  You can see, not just to Lakers fans, but to fans around the world.  He’s been great.  He has been motivating, inspiring.  He has done a lot of things for basketball.  So being able to be on the court with him these last couple of times is special.”

Even Clippers head coach Doc Rivers, who did battle with Bryant and the Lakers in some bitterly-contested NBA Finals matchups in 2008 and 2010 as coach of the Boston Celtics, could do little but convey his deep admiration for the Mamba.  “Just mad respect.  I have always had that for him and for each other.  My job was to try to stop him or frustrate him when we played him, and his job was to try and inflict pain.  It’s the type of relationship we have.  But the respect is amazing.  I’ve always respected him.  I’ve always respected the way he approached the game.”

Bryant himself was humbled on a night where he was honored by the Clippers with a 25-second video tribute before the game and was showered with “MVP” chants every time he touched the ball, even hearing “WE WANT KOBE” echoing throughout the arena as he sat on the bench down double-digits in the fourth quarter of a Clippers home game.

“"It’s crazy to think how far this [Clippers] organization has come itself from when I first came into the league to where they are now,” Bryant said.  “All the battles that we’ve had, sharing the same building. So it’s pretty cool for them to be able to give me that type of tribute. It felt good.

“"I think the organization’s doing things the right way,” continued the 18-time All-Star.   “I think they’re really looking to turn things around. I think the passion that they’re bringing is remarkable.“

Bryant also expressed particular fondness for Paul (“He’s a vicious, nasty competitor, and I love that about him. I absolutely love him,”) and interestingly enough, resident superfan Clipper Darrell (“I’m gonna miss Clipper Darrell. His passion and enthusiasm for the game and the constant booing in the night and the cheering. I had a couple moments where I was able to acknowledge him and acknowledge the fans here in this building.  Clipper Darrell is just as much a part of this organization. He’s been there from the beginning, so he’s never going anywhere”).

With the Lakers long eliminated from playoff contention and the final game of his NBA career set for April 13 against the Utah Jazz at the Staples Center, this is just about the end of the line for Bryant.  But for the Clippers, there is still much work to be done.  Firmly entrenched as the fourth seed in the Western Conference, many questions still linger in the final week before the playoffs.  

Griffin is still working his way back with Tuesday’s victory being just his second game since returning from injury/suspension.  He was visibly rusty in his 17 minutes, shooting just 1-for-5 from the field to finish with 4 points and 3 rebounds.

“This was not a great one for him,” said Rivers of Griffin’s performance.  “I just felt kind of trapped watching the game.  I just did not think it was the right place to put him back in.”

Griffin himself acknowledged as much saying, “I was just trying not to force anything.  I was not playing a lot of minute either.  [I have] to find [rhythm] somewhere.  It will come.  I just have to be patient.”

The rest of the team is also struggling to readapt after over three months without Griffin.  Clippers forward Jeff Green, who was the only other Clipper besides Paul in double figures on the evening with 21 points, said, “We are just going off [Blake’s] vibes.  Going off how his body is reacting to the minutes and just going from there.  We know it’s going to take time for him to get his rhythm and his basketball legs up under him.”

There will always be a significant adjustment period when reintegrating a high-volume, ball-dominant player who shapes so much of your offensive identity like Griffin does into your lineup, especially after such a lengthy absence.  But with the NBA playoffs set to begin on April 16, the Clippers need to find the answers and find them soon.  For come the postseason, greatness waits for no one.  Just ask No. 24.

title: Film Review // Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny : Directed By Yuen Woo-ping
content:
Written By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press (03/13/16)

After taking the time to watch Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016, dir. Yuen Woo-ping) I will admit that I was confused.  That was probably the part of me anticipating an earnest sequel to Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon (2000, dir. Ang Lee), tearing out her hair in disappointment and making as much of a protest as possible from inside an annoyed psyche.   Sword of Destiny is neither the high art experience that Ang Lee gave us in its predecessor in 2000 nor is it a high-camp homage to Kung Fu.  It’s a difficult film to define because it’s impossible to approach it without thinking of and referencing the first film, and the only thing that the two films have in common is the title.

Sword of Destiny picks up the story of Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh) eighteen years after the events of the first film.  To protect the Green Sword of Destiny she leaves a life of solitude and picks up a band of misfit warriors who plan to help her save the world, basically. After that, it’s anyone’s guess as it what is going on.   As hard and cynical as this estimation might be, it’s also truthful and correct.  Michelle Yeoh and Donnie Yen (as Silent Wolf) are lovely in action. No two living Wuxia stars out there can rip out a Kung Fu battle the way these stars can with some notable exceptions (Jet Li?), but the fight scenes disappoint.  Choreography is decent but there cinematographer doesn’t seem to have a lot of reverence for the material or how magical these scenes can be in the right hands and shot through the right lens.  Connective tissue between actions sequences isn’t there, the film lacks story.  The loveliness of the original: the wind in the trees, the desert landscapes; the realness of life lived as a dream – there is not a whisper of it here.  The narrative is close to non-existent and the piece feels like an opportunity lost.

There are moments that work; Shu Lien’s moment of repose overlooking a misted valley is lovely.   A battle scene on an ice covered pond screams creativity and original thinking.  Pretty much every sideways glance from Donnie Yen toward an adversary works without having to add anything to it.  It’s frustrating that there wasn’t more material like this. The addition of a new sub-plot to accommodate two new young additions to the cast doesn’t help anything – the story is confusing and murky.  After taking it all in I found myself feeling taken advantage of.  It feels as if the film was made because filmmakers knew that people would see it, but that they didn’t particularly care why people would see it.  The energy, pacing, story and beauty of the first film aren’t here, not even in an incremental amount.  Standing on its own it’s a below average Wuxia movie that doesn’t compel excitement or any kind of emotional reaction.

I have a lot of admiration for filmmakers who embrace new media.  The fact that Sword of Destiny released directly to Netflix and bypassed theaters seemed like a brilliant move. But it’s not going to last long if Netflix acquires high profile properties like this one without focusing on quality.  I came to this film with my heart open, and mid-way through I felt its doors slam shut.  If you love Kung Fu and were praying that this would be a spectacular fix, check out The Legend of Flying Daggers instead.

title: Album Review // Radiation City’s Synesthetica
content:
Review By: Sergio Garcia, UCLA Radio DJ (02/23/16)

Cameron Spies and Lizzy Ellison, Radiation City’s founding couple, experienced much relationship turmoil leading up to their third full-length Synesthetica. Thankfully, their work did not just thrive; it may have provided the creative fuel needed to propel the Portland 5-piece to glorious new heights.

Synesthetica is a departure from the retro revivalist blending of doo-wop and guitar-based indie pop the band was known for on its previous LPs. The name itself is based on the condition of synesthesia where a person experiences multiple senses at once, such as seeing different colors while hearing different types of music. The songs seem to take after this condition, blending R&B elements, electronics, and a more sophisticated sound with their established retro indie aesthetic. This seems to have been a focus of the group, with Spies commenting “We wanted to destroy the barriers between all the things we keep separate in our daily lives.”

The result is 9 well-crafted, self-contained modern pop songs – sharp and punchy, bright but not blinding. The electronics compliment the guitars, drums, and vocals in subtle, exquisite ways. Beautiful melodies and climaxes appear in the midst of rolling soundscapes. At times groovy and danceable (“Oil Show”, “Milky White”), mellow and serene (“Butter”, “Separate”, “Fancy Cherries”), catchy and infectious (“Juicy”, “Come and Go”), no one theme dominates the album. Instead, the grandness of the songs is well met by subtle arrangements that let Ellison’s radiant vocals shine true despite the varying emotional palette.

Though not particularly revolutionary, Synesthetica nevertheless is a wonderful addition to the sophisticated, modern indie pop canon.

Rating: 8/10

title: You’ll Pay For This - Bear Hands // Album Review
content:
Written By: Alexa Lee, UCLA Radio DJ (04/26/16)

I really wanted to like this album. Although indie-electronic music, as Bear Hands’ genre is loosely described as, is not the type of sound I typically gravitate towards, I had high hopes for You’ll Pay For This, the group’s first LP release in two years. But sadly, the lead singer’s angsty tone coupled with the overall aggressively techno backing music created a listening experience that was uninspired and distasteful.

First off, the mediocre lyrical content. Eleven out of the twelve songs are defiant odes to rebellious, controversial youth. The one song that diverges from this theme is “Like Me Like That,” and it is about a girl who loves the narrator because he is a rebellious, controversial youth. And while I can certainly appreciate music written about nonconformity and the struggle of finding oneself, the lyrics of this album are largely repetitive and flat. (“Making love is fine/but all I want is to forget/how old I am” is a line from one of their singles “2AM.” Well Bear Hands, all I want is to forget how uninspired your writing is.) Ultimately the messages of the music come across as merely whiny. But perhaps even more embarrassing for Bear Hands than their lyrics is their lack of impact on the listener. Thrashing drums and slamming electric guitar chords are intended to startle, but the different hooks and melodies muddily blur into one another throughout the album, making it so that no song truly stands out. Conversely, “The Shallows” and “Purpose Filled Life,” which appear to be the designated slower, emotionally meaningful songs, are quietly soft but without soulful depth. Only “Winner’s Circle” exists clearly in my memory, and that’s because that is the track I found most unpleasant to hear. This album manages to be a disagreeable experience while one listens to it, but still forgettable and insignificant in the long run.

As I read over my review, I almost feel guilty for how strongly negative my opinion of this record is. I will say that if someone is a fan of Hippo Campus or Grouplove, but wishes that these bands would incorporate more garage pop punk vocals like those of Blink-182, this could be the album for that person. In another attempt at positivity, I will also say that You’ll Pay For This has the potential to be a great soundtrack for a young adult indie movie, one in which the protagonist is a frustrated skateboarding teen trying to “take down the system” and “live in the moment.” But until that film is produced, I will not be listening to Bear Hands’ newest LP anytime soon.

title: The Strumbellas // Album Preview (Release Date : 04/22/16)
content:
Written By : Jacob Nober, UCLA Radio DJ (04/21/16)

You know when every once in a when you are really excited for a new album to come out that you eagerly listen to the single every waking moment? Well in case you were wondering, I am experiencing that right now anticipating The Strumbellas new album Hope, which is coming out this Friday, April 22. The first single “Spirits” off the album is the now notorious song that has taken over my daily focus. I have quite literally have had Strumbella “spirits in my head” from this song. This is the kind of song (and probably album) that before you know it is going to follow you everywhere and have you singing to yourself without you noticing.

To be honest, I didn’t know the Strumbellas before stumbling across “Spirits,” which might make it seem kind of peculiar why I am so excited for the album if I haven’t been a long-term fan anticipating it. Since hearing “Spirits,” and instantly having it stuck in my head, I have gone back and adventured through some of the Strumbellas other music. Everything I’ve heard has made me happy and want to dance around a little bit.

You may be wondering, who are the Strumebellas and why should you care? Well, let me tell you a little bit more about who they are and what makes them special. They are a six-piece band straight out of Lindsay, Ontario (Canada). Their first EP was released in 2009 and since then they have continued to expand their fan base.
