They began in Canada and quickly spread across North America. As a testament to their talent, they won six awards on their second (and most recent) album We Still Move On Dance Floors, including a JUNO award! The Strumebellas exemplify the magic that can happen when six talented musicians come together to create something special.

If you haven’t noticed yet, I’M EXCITED FOR THIS FRIDAY! Keep an eye out for the release :)!

title: Festival Review: JASH FESHT (April 01-03)
content:
Video and Words By: Kim Seltzer & Aliya Kamalova, UCLA Radio Comedy Department Managers (04/07/16)

Last weekend, UCLA Radio Comedy attended JASH network’s first comedy festival JASH FESHT. This three-day fest was held at Snapshot Studios in Palm Springs, CA and consisted of stand-up shows, screenings, musical performances, panels, podcast recordings, food, art and a special trailer that hosted a marathon live stream of performers smoking weed. The fest, although small in size with only two stages, boasted an impressive lineup and had an overall relaxed and casual vibe. Comedy managers, Kim & Aliya, laughed along with the crowd and documented their experiences in the following video.

title: Show Review // This Will Destroy You @ The Roxy (03/14/16)
content:
Written By: Jeffrey Wang, UCLA Radio DJ (04/01/16)

On March 14th, post-rock band This Will Destroy You brought their “Another Language” tour to the Roxy in LA. This LP consists of darker, more ominous sounds compared to their previous albums. I was beyond excited to see, for my first time, one of my long time favorite artists perform.

Having experienced a slew of post-rock and thick guitar heavy shows in the past year, including Explosions in the Sky, Godspeed You! Black Emperor, and Slowdive, I went to this show expecting songs with similar atmospheric buildups to incredibly loud climaxes. I had moderately high expectations for them to bring out a thick, continuous stream of guitar noise, and I was not disappointed.

This Will Destroy You played one of the loudest shows I have heard at a venue that only amplified their sound. The Roxy is quite a small venue for the power their music brings from the stage. Though I would have preferred their sound in a stadium or festival stage environment, this was their only LA show, and the only one of their shows I could attend.

The opened with “Dutism”, which features a strong guitar and cymbal entrance, and immediately I could feel the rumblings from below the stage. Although they admitted to facing technical difficulties in their first few songs, it was not noticeable until the audience realized the lights were supposed to be turned off. Their serious and focused stage presence kept the show going. This tends to be difficult especially since their songs heavily depend on calm intros, but they managed to pull through.

Their set took a bit of an electronic turn in the second half of their set with the intro to “Killed the Lord, Left for the New World”, which features several samples. It served as a pleasant interlude between their heavy energy tracks. I was fortunate to hear this track performed, as it is my favorite from their “Tunnel Blanket” LP and they rarely play it.

I’m glad they ended their set with “New Topia”, which I feel is the most representative track of the “Another Language” LP, and has the one of the most emotional guitar and drum entrances. For the encore, they followed up with “Quiet”, one of their older songs that has a similar volume progression.

I am happy for This Will Destroy You’s progress over the years, with appearances in a few recent movie soundtracks, and I hope to see them again, possibly on a bigger stage.

title: Album Review // Matmos - Ultimate Care II
content:
Review By: Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio Digital Press (03/13/16)

The experimental electronic duo Matmos recently released their new album Ultimate Care II, which is aptly the name of their instrument of choice on the record, a Whirlpool washing machine. The album is constructed as a single song, though it is not as much a song so much as the totalization and exploration of the object, the machine itself. Matmos programs, sequences, beats and applies the washing machine to orchestrate the sonic capabilities of a single electronic appliance.

At times there’s the cavernous and ringing gong of metal, the percussive hits of clanking machinery, the glitch patterns from a soundboard, and even the sloshing of water in a rinse cycle heard in the mix. There is little tonal sweetness to be grasped from the album, with the exception of the occasional play with the electronics of the machine. This allows for the more immediate and percussive elements to dominate. Now and then the cacophony of metal fades gradually, drowning into a synth landscape, only to supplanted and swallowed again by the machine.

The album draws on the practice of musique concrète, the process of recording, sampling and manipulating raw sound material. Of course, this material is all from a single place, the Ultimate Care II. One of musique concrète’s pioneers, Pierre Schaeffer once said, “one might say that the origin of this music is also found in the interest in ‘plastifying’ music, of rendering it plastic like sculpture.” In this case, the sculptural form of the music is already assembled in the washing machine, and it is Matmos who are using their music to deconstruct the appliance.

The allure of Ultimate Care II rests in the “machine-made-instrument” mystery. Because the sounds all have a source, the listener has the puzzle of trying to reconstruct the washing machine from its sonic remains. It’s a task not without reward. By the end, Ultimate Care II is working in full force, the album becoming a machine all its own.

title: 5 Point Play // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By: Ryland Towne, UCLA Radio Sports DJ (03/03/16)

I genuinely feel bad for the 3-point line.  Why you might ask, well just ask Warrior’s megastar Steph Curry, he seems to ignore its existence completely.  And he’s not the only one, more and more NBA players are simply disregarding that the line is even on the floor.  

The Warriors are second to the Houston Rockets in three pointers attempted per game this NBA season with an average of 30.8.  Looking back to the 2003-2004 NBA season, the Warriors were averaging just half of that, around 15.6 threes per game.  In just over a decade, the Warriors along with most NBA teams have progressively begun to jack up more threes.

First and foremost, the NBA is entertainment.  Millions of fans around the world would not be glued to the television (or smartphone) with their favorite player’s signature shoes on their feet if the NBA was boring.  

When the 3-point line was introduced to the NBA during the 1979-89 season, players and fans alike were skeptical.  The ABA years before had integrated the 3-point line in order to create a new dimension to the game.  Eventually the 3-pointer became an integral part of the game and the rest is history.

In today’s game however, we have reached a metaphorical roadblock.  We see players taking deeper shots than usual from behind the line, and to our surprise draining them on a regular basis.  

So what gives?  Are NBA players developing supernatural powers with the ability to shoot anywhere on the court?  Highly unlikely, yet it forces us to reexamine why the 3-point line is there in the first place.

In my opinion, the deeper the shot, the louder the roar from the fans.  The NBA is a show, so why not make it as amusing as possible.  

The future of the 3-point line has been hotly debated for quite some time now.  Should it be moved back?  Should there be a 4-point line?  While it is improbable that we will see these changes in the near future, they will continue to be in the back of the minds of all NBA fans as we enjoy every 30 footer that is drained with ease.

Time will only tell, along with Curry’s jump shot, whether the fans will ever witness an actual 5-point play.  And if they decide to move the line back, well, expect players like Curry to be even more instrumental to the success of their team and the league as a whole.

title: Show Review // The Growlers @ The Observatory (02/15/16)
content:
Review By: Sophia Forino, UCLA Radio DJ (02/28/16)

This Valentine’s Day weekend, the Growler’s returned to their home at The Observatory in Orange County (also home to their ever-growing festival Beach Goth) to deliver two sold-out shows during their “Smile Now Smile Later” winter tour. Having seen the Growlers about 10 times already, as many of their local Orange County fans have, I arrived at the show with relative expectations of a colorful and eclectic crowd, an undulating pit of tightly condensed teenagers, and a slightly sloppy, though always great, performance. Unsurprisingly, the show was filled to capacity with OC residents of the “underground”; pierced teens and young adults in patched and pinned denim jackets were densely dispersed throughout the loving couples composed of guys, gals, and the in-between. However, I was pleasantly surprised when the Growlers’ came on stage and gave a lengthy, tight, and seemingly sober performance. More on that later.

Upon walking into the venue, like with all Growlers shows, I did some exploring to see what fun stuff they had laid out for us fanguys and gals. After taking a pic with my boo in the yellow, hand-painted, wood cut-out heart advertising the tour (a marketing dream!) with, not to mention, set up photoshoot-style lighting (an Instagram model’s dream!), I ventured over to the Mexican corn and fruit-cup carts and didn’t buy anything because of its poor person unfriendly prices. Inside the Constellation Room (a room that holds smaller shows) I was confused to see several blow-up mattress-type loungers facing a half-assed held up white sheet showing a screening of the film “La Bamba”. However, upon cuddling up on one and catching the plane crash scene and, subsequent, death scene of Ritchie Valens and Buddy Holiday (so romantic, I know), I realized it was it was a pretty cool and unique idea to screen a movie and offer luxurious comfort for one’s horizontal body, especially at a concert. With the exploring and cuddling out of my system, I made my way towards the main stage, caught the end the opening act, Johnathan Richman (of the Modern Lovers) and Tommy Larkins, and awaited the Growlers. 

Like I said, this was a Growlers show unlike any I’ve ever seen. While the Growlers aren’t ones to play the same exact songs at every show, throughout the set they performed songs from the deep inner depths of their discography that I had never even expected to hear live such as, “The Moaning Man From Shanty Town”. They even whipped out an unexpected “beach gothy” cover of The Shirelles’ “Mama Said” (Mama said whaat?). Of course they played the hits such as “Humdrum Blues,” “One Million Lovers,” and “Going Gets Tough”; it is easy to tell they are crowd favorites when suddenly your view is blocked by the endless screens of recording and snap-chatting cell phones (tsk tsk). 

 Beyond that, they truly sounded better than ever. Ever-present where the same silly stage antics — strange noises and tacky ironically-done crowd interactions — that make us love them, yet there was a noticeable absence of frequent lyric blunders and messed up time changes. Brooks Nielsen even hit the high note on “Wandering Eyes,” which I am sure made all the ladies and gentlemen swoon. Overall, it was definitely the best Growler’s show I have experienced and I give them mad credit since they are pretty much touring 24/7 and don’t even have time to surf the waves their songs are about (a California crime). Maybe it was because they were back at their home venue that made them sound so damn great. Maybe it was the saturated Valentine’s Day love in the air. Regardless, I left that show in such a swell mood that I wasn’t even fazed when I realized my car had been towed.

title: Lightning in a Bottle // Festival Preview
content:
Written By : Alison Chi, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff (02/22/16)

I’ve been a huge fan of Lightning in a Bottle since 2013, which was also the year they had the festival in Temecula but for the past three years, they’ve since moved the festival to Bradley, CA. I’ve always found their lineup to be eccentrically electronic with a couple of folky, spiritual bands to mix it up a little.

My relationship with music festivals have been relatively finicky but what I appreciate most about Lightning in a Bottle is its emphasis on a wholesome and environmentally friendly experience. A huge part of this festival is definitely its focus on getting in touch with your own spirituality and overall human goodness. This year, the festival is featuring all sorts of activities and performances besides music such as the Temple of Consciousness and The Learning Kitchen, places where you can enhance your own mental, emotional, and physical well being.

An extremely important part of Lightning in a Bottle is its focus on being environmentally conscious, their ethos. They’ve implemented a Green Report, which includes workshops on being more green and a speaking panel that’ll encourage attendees to live more sustainable lives. Lightening in a Bottle will also be using solar lights wherever possible and using more environmentally friendly lighting. Finally, the festival wants its attendees to not only feel inspired at the festival but to also inspire them to make a big difference in their own communities.

This year’s lineup definitely features some huge acts such as Chet Faker, Grimes, Jamie Xx, Cashmere Cat, and Tokimonsta but there are definitely a couple of hidden gems in the lineup. I didn’t really find a pattern to the stages but for The Woogie stage, it’s a lot of house and EDM so if you’re into that, The Woogie stage is the place to be. Personally, I was really feeling the Lightning Stage and a couple of acts on the Thunder Stage. But all in all, the lineup looks pretty solid with some smaller acts that’ll definitely surprise you.

The beauty of Lightning in a Bottle is the whole experience. I remember watching one of their promotional videos last year and you can feel the love and spiritual loving that flows throughout the festival. I love that this festival focuses on being environmentally conscious, promotes human balance and well-being, and even provides great music. It’s almost like a modern version of Woodstock, three days of peace, love, and music. I have a couple of friends who have gone to Lightening in a Bottle and they always tell me how amazing the experience is.

Similar to my Eaux Claires piece, I’ve listed a couple of artists that caught my attention while exploring the Lightening in a Bottle lineup. Included is a small sampler playlist that captures just a snapshot of the eclectic mix of sounds that’ll be present this year.


Artists to Watch:

Elderbrook

Lafa Taylor

NoMBe

Whilk & Misky

Hayden James

Ekali

CloZee

Andhim

title: Show Review: Chvrches + American Football @ The Shrine (10/17/15)
content:
With the release of their new album Every Open Eye, Chvrches, a synth-pop trio hailing from Glasgow, has amassed a far-reaching audience that seems to disagree on what particular aspect of Chvrches makes them special. Some find the infectious bounciness of their synthetic sound akin to an indie take on EDM, some find the sound a blend of 80’s nostalgia and futuristic pop, and some reach catharsis through Lauren Mayberry’s emotional yet unforgiving lyricism. It was not hard to see their impending mainstream success after the momentum started with their debut, The Bones of What You Believe.

The sleek and soulful Mansionair opened the show, blending smooth-textured synths with more biting blues guitar. The frontman’s breathy and wailing voice which strikes resemblance to Hayden Thorpe of Wild Beasts soared at times but often got buried.

Next, the resurrected poster boys of emo-revival, American Football, joined to play songs from their seminal album from 1999. Self-awareness was present in their set, as frontman Mike Kinsella jokingly introduced the band: “we’re the American Footballs.” Well-concocted layers of intricate guitarwork might have lulled for some, but it was clear a large portion of the crowd had not only come for the main act, but expressly for American Football. Moments from their set diverted to a simpler state of musical bliss, with all cutting out except for a lone, crooning trumpet. While the contrast was soon to be felt with Chvrches’ wall of synth, it was a welcomed respite before the show’s true energy came loose.

Chvrches  arrived with concentrated bursts of spiraling synth that enlivened the crowd, segwaying into the album opener “Never Ending Circles.” Though their set was at first hampered by sound issues, the levels balanced out and Mayberry’s vocals could rise over the high cutting bursts of sound. Playing a balance of songs from their debut and latest album, the variety and pacing of set choices sustained the high energy of the set. The occasional dialogue between songs at times seemed offhanded, but fanboys and girls nevertheless laughed and cheered, no doubt a cause of Mayberry’s charm. Blazing through track after track with ferocity, the band closed with “The Mother We Share.” Exploding with that opening burst of voice and machine crunched into one, reminded all of that distinct Chvrches sound that first caught their attention.


Written by: Dylan Karlsson

Photos by: Dylan Karlsson

title: Show Review: FC x USA: A One Night RHONDAVOUS with FUTURE CLASSIC (10/23/15)
content:
PART 1: ZACH MEETS RHONDA 
By Zach Conner

View from the Balcony

A woman waltzes into the Belasco. She’s adorned in every conceivable best look and her presence bathes the ornate theater in a red, sensuous glow. Hers is a ceaseless dance of chrome skin and pheromone sweat. She scans the crowd for partners with laser eyes and finds that all are willing to join her. This woman is called Rhonda and she is billed as many things:

  • Club 
  • Party 
  • Label
  • Ideal
  • Feeling 
  • Trait 

The Rhondavous experience is a traveling venue that since 2014 has rounded up the biggest DJ names in contemporary dance/house for massive, extravagant club events. Rhonda descends on theaters and adorns them with giant lollipops, shiny mannequins, disco glitter, and the leg logo. She is also a priestess of sorts, raising statues to Dionysius and offering him vases brimming with grapes. The Belasco Theater, an old DTLA gem with dual experience as burlesque theater and Immanuel Gospel Temple, proved a fitting venue for Rhonda– a hybrid, Temple of the Burlesque.

Brendan Cameron (@namasgurt)

For this event Future Classic, a Sydney-based independent record label, teamed up with Rhonda for the final show of the US showcase tour. I spent about five whirlwind hours dancing to the likes of SOPHIE, Classixx, Basenji and many others, and absorbing / photographing as much of the bizarre club extravagance as possible. There were three stages:

  • The Basement (small, dark, intimate)
  • The Ballroom (medium, full of Doric pillars and statues, neon)
  • The Theater (huge, groundling access + balconies, massive RHONDA marquis sign)

…which made my experience more active, as I was cycling between artists as their sets and my impulses changed. I wove through the theater’s maze of bustling corridors, hallways, and staircases, through cheery throngs of shirtless gay men and prowling packs of shirtless straight men, past first-time clubbers in office attire clinging timidly to walls. I tiptoed around smooching couples. With my camera and dumb thrifted airforce jacket I looked unkempt and out of place but felt in tune. From my perspective Rhondavous seemed exactly what it claims to be: a well-established dance sanctuary shameless indulgence and pansexual acceptance. A drag queen with an indomitable flare and unbelievable endurance graced several stages throughout the show, to the crowd’s sustained delight.

SOPHIE + Brendan Cameron

SOPHIE, Basenji, and Touch Sensitive topped my favorite sets list. It was my second time seeing SOPHIE in concert, and though my taste for the twee PC Music bubblegumbass sound has waned, it never fails in a dancey setting. Having no prior knowledge of Basenji’s style I was pleasantly surprise to stumble into his set (lit). Touch Sensitive was also a great find– he DJs with a 5-string bass slung over his shoulder, using it for deep and solid funk pockets. Charles Murdoch and Kenton Slash Demon had inspired and energetic sets as well. I left most of the Classixx coverage to my friend, as their set overlapped with SOPHIE’s.

Touch Sensitive 

Ultimately? It was a big club, with tantalizing atmosphere and stellar DJs– maybe not as niche and diverse a lineup as you’d find at say, Boiler Room or HAM On Everything events, but still incredible, and absolutely suited to Rhonda’s glitz, glam and appreciation for music that stirs our passions most. I am wildly grateful to have had this coverage opportunity– thanks Future Classic! 

Check out upcoming Rhonda events and FC shows in the US.


PART 2: AARON MEETS RHONDA
By Aaron Peretz

After consulting the set times and cross-referencing my Snapchat story with Zach’s photos, I’ve concluded that twenty minutes into Sophie’s set would mark the schism of the night: my sudden departure three floors below to beat the crowd to Kenton Slash Demon’s set. Thus my night of juggling was just beginning. 

I’d made up my mind that Kenton Slash Demon and Classixx were my priorities while Sophie occupied spot no. 2—unfortunately, all three artists’ times were conflicting. I made a plan and stuck to it. 

Before the schism, the group mobilized from the beginning of Classixx’s performance to the upstairs Ballroom to catch the end of Basenji’s set and situate ourselves up for a prime spot as the forthcoming PC Music forerunner Sophie was next. The excitement in Basenji’s voice was apparent as he announced the next artist, like Basenji predicted that opening for Sophie meant transcending his Future Classic listener demographic and reaching across the aisle for the fans of PC Music. It was like seeing someone get a promotion.

Sophie opened up with the chewy sound that raised him through the ranks of Soundcloud DJ to Blogosphere Darling. The pop began to evolve into Sophie’s latest sound, emulating the trap EDM music that is commonplace in the cumbersome rave festivals of today. Although a trap sound was always at least available in Sophie’s repertoire, it is only now after much more garnered attention and one of his songs appearing in a McDonald’s ad that Sophie is candid in playing trap music. All of this is evidence that Sophie has truly achieved what he set out to do: become a pop star.

The concert-imperative-nodule in my brain began ringing and I knew it was time. I gave a quick slap on the back to my friends and rushed down the Basement to witness Kenton Slash Demon’s opening. The basement was relatively quiet as the other two stages were being dominated by dance music powerhouses, but I knew this set was one not to miss. 

Kenton Slash Demon

Any awkwardness I might’ve felt for being by myself at a club for the first time was mitigated by the group of twenty-nine year olds making their first and last hurrah at tasting the club scene. The group of women swayed with a side-to-side dance action and congregated. Like a council of tribal elders, the group reached a decision to send forth one of their braves and engage in a mating dance. The first interacted with me, occasionally cocking her head back to see if I was paying attention or if I had left. I smiled as a nicety, but the kind of false nicety that is not supposed to be seen as an affirmation, but rather an empty gesture—the kind not to be acted upon. Sensing rejection, the first brave returned to her tribe and another was sent in her place. This cycle continued with different braves opening themselves to rejection. Still, I admired their perseverance. This was the first group of the night to leave an indelible impression on my experience, and if their fun time was ruined I wish they knew that my night was made because of people like them.

After some minutes into the KSD set “Syko” played and I lost myself for a little while. While the song transitioned out I decided that Phase II of my plan had to be put into action. As I ascended upstairs and flew through the Theater it felt as if Classixx was awaiting my arrival. The lasers and lights dimmed. All was dark. The RHONDA sign made of lightbulbs, functioning like a vanity to a star, lit up. The strobes flashed and “All You’re Waiting For,” thumped from the speakers. 

Now the Belasco Theater felt like a discotheque, the strobes imitating a disco ball and the nu-disco sounds of Classixx titillating the ears. A pair of middle-aged women taught the younger generations how to groove. A locking of eyes revealed their lives to me—the slip into stagnation, their husbands’ lack of trying, the existential boredom that filled their lives. They were resuscitated that night from the attention of twenty-somethings. Another glance. It was a lascivious invitation thrown my way. I had the power to ruin a life. Like an introvert drunk on power from making Tinder decisions, the speakers resonated and Rhonda breathed agency back into the lives of two women that needed a reminder of how fun life can be.

More Kenton Slash Demon

Classixx climaxed and I rushed upstairs to rejoin my friends who were awaiting the finale at Sophie’s set. With a declaration of one-part concern and three-parts excitement that, “I NEED TO FIND MY FRIENDS,” the PLUR-friendly attendees allowed for an easy path to the front of the Ballroom where I could find my friends. Hugging and selfies ensued. In uncanny fashion Sophie dropped one of his new songs “Just Like We Never Said Goodbye” as I found my friends. 

A man in business casual clothes stood in rigidity. His expression was plain and he stood with a generic beer in his right hand. I tapped his shoulder and pointed two index fingers to the sky. He acknowledged, made a smile that looked like it hurt him and nodded. This man’s wife would come to this club in 25 years for a breath of life. He probably wears Invisalign.

Sophie ended in explosive fashion and all of my excitement and energies were turned toward finishing the night at Kenton Slash Demon. Phase III of the plan could not be stopped. I knew how the night would end. I grabbed Zach and jumped down three stories making a safe landing at the entrance of the Basement. The chill of the Basement welcomed us, so that I got goosebumps on my arm. It was coming. I danced. Soon, our club corroborators showed up to complete the group dynamic. No time was wasted on hugs now. The low reverberations permeated my body and my being and the significance of the night, although irreproducible, hit me. “Harpe” played. My phone was dead so I couldn’t videotape the moment. All I could do was be present. All I have are the memories and feelings.

title: UCLA Radio News Team Interviews Yaki Lopez, Israeli Consulate Member
content:
Today Yaki Lopez, Consul for Political Affairs at the Consulate General of Israel in Los Angeles, joined James, Britt, and Lisa for a discussion on various topics concerning Israel and also California.

To start off, Yaki explained his position and experience in diplomatic and political action across the globe. Before joining the Consulate, he acted as Deputy Ambassador for Israel to Kenya. While there he “spearheaded an unprecedented trilateral initiative between Israel, Germany, and Kenya” that solved food and water insecurity issues for many thousands of people. The initiative stands as a testament to attempts at peace between formerly antagonistic peoples.

The theme of striving for peace carried through the next discussion on the Iran Nuclear Deal recently negotiated and passed by several nations including Iran, the United States, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Russia, China, and others in the European Union. Notably, Israel was absent from negotiations and spoke out against the terms of the deal. Yaki explained that one of the problems Israel has is the lifting of decades-old economic sanctions on Iran that they feel may allow illegal materials into the country and eventually lead to Iran’s possession of a nuclear weapon. While the deal guarantees agreeing nations the right to inspect Iranian facilities for illegal materials, Israel feels this is not enough of a guardian against what they see as a seriously grave threat.

Yaki pointed out that it is not an issue between Israelis and Iranians as citizens; there are many on both sides and outside these nations whose greatest desire is for peace and cooperation. It is to be noted that Iran’s new president, Hassan Rouhani, is touted as a moderate force unlike past leaders that verbally expressed desires for the end of a Jewish state. Yaki commented that such threats must be taken seriously, especially in light of real violence that is committed against Israel from its neighbors.

From there the discussion turned to Palestine. Yaki made sure to correct the idea that Israeli President Benjamin Netanyahu is against a two-state solution and, in fact, has for years showed support for such a plan. When asked if Israeli settlements are a major component holding back peace talks, Yaki expressed that he did not believe it was and the real concern is the violence against Israel and leading factions in Gaza and West Bank. Hamas, which has power in Gaza, declares in its founding documents it seeks the removal of the Jewish State. This fact, says Yaki, dismisses any claim that violence done in Gaza is by radical offshoots and not by Hamas itself. “From the river to the sea”, Yaki reminded us, is the rhetoric used in Palestine to express the sentiment of “wiping” Israel off the map. Throughout all this, the desire for the people of Israel and even for many in Palestine, is for peace; however Israel must keep the security of its citizens, which does include many Palestinians living within its borders, as first priority.

To conclude the hour on a positive note, Yaki discussed Israel’s desalination developments and its ties to Southern California specifically. Among Israel’s security problems, it is also a small nation with little access to fresh water within its borders. For decades Israel has been funding development into technologies that can turn seawater from the Mediterranean into drinking water. As much as 80% of Israel’s drinking water now comes from these

desalinization plants. California’s current mega-drought has put desalination in the spotlight as a possible solution to our water needs. Yaki spoke about the new plant in Carlsbad, north of San Diego, that has been designed by Israeli-based IDE Technologies. However, while Israel can meet the needs of its 8 million people with desalination, it will be a long time before the technology can be a viable long-term solution for California’s 55 million.

Written by: James DePaola
Photos by: Terry Hu

title: UCLA Radio Sports // “Bruins Shocked In Men’s Basketball Opener by Monmouth, Fall In Overtime 84-81″
content:
UCLA’s Basketball Coach Steve Alford

As the late great John Lennon once said, “Reality leaves a lot to the imagination.”  In all honesty, that’s probably the only way to comprehend the events that went down at Pauley Pavilion on Friday night.  

The UCLA men’s basketball team was stunned in their 2015-16 season opener by the visiting Monmouth Hawks, who defeated the Bruins on their home floor in overtime by the final of 84-81.  

It was a sloppy, out-of-sorts, and wholly uninspired performance by the Bruins, who turned the ball over 23 times and missed 12 free throws to seal their fate.

Junior guard Bryce Alford led the team with 22 points, 5 rebounds, and 5 assists, but shot 5-for-17 from the field with most of his misses coming on ill-advised stepbacks and contested jumpers.

The UCLA frontcourt fared well on the stat sheet with senior Tony Parker posting 19 points and 19 rebounds before fouling out and sophomore Thomas Welsh also double-doubling with 12 points and 10 rebounds.  

Coach Steve Alford was forced to play Parker and Welsh extended minutes next to each other with versatile sophomore forward Jonah Bolden suspended for Friday’s game for an unspecified disciplinary issue. While the post duo dominated the glass (UCLA won the rebounding battle, a historic weakness for them, 60-37 on Friday), Parker was a nightmare defending in space against Monmouth’s quicker forwards and Welsh made lethargic weakside help rotations that often resulted in drawn fouls and free throws for the Hawks.  

While they had their moments attacking the basket and controlling the tempo, the freshman backcourt tandem of Aaron Holiday (brother of former UCLA Basketball and current New Orleans Pelican Jrue Holiday) and Prince Ali were largely underwhelming with a combined 17 points on 5-for-20 shooting. 

Holiday, who got the starting nod, had a wide-open 3-point look from the right wing that could have tied the game at the end of overtime, but it clanged off the back iron as time expired.  

For the Bruins, who blew a 13-point lead in the second half and a 5-point lead in the overtime period, on top of allowing Monmouth to score all of their final nine points at the free throw line, they were understandably downtrodden about their subpar effort.

“Our guard play was atrocious,” said head coach Steve Alford in his post-game interview.  “You don’t make free throws, you don’t make layups, you don’t handle the ball well, and then you don’t guard in the last 10, 15 minutes, it makes it hard on you.

“From halftime on, I didn’t like how we guarded,” he continued.  “And for the entire 45 minutes, I couldn’t stand the way we took care of the ball.  We were really, really careless, and that falls on me.  I’ll take a responsibility of that.

“We gotta figure out how to get average, before we can take a step towards being good, because we’re bad right now.  And that’s a lot of credit to Monmouth.  They outplayed us in every area.”

“We couldn’t control the ball and a majority of that’s on me,” agreed Alford’s son Bryce, pinning the much of the blame on the Bruin guards as well. “We had guys running into each other, dribbling off our knees out of bounds, passing the ball to nobody.  I think a lot of it had to do with a lot of bad spacing.  

Guards driving in and not being on two feet, not making grounded plays, smart plays.  It’s just unacceptable from start to finish.  All of our guards have gotta be better.”

“We know we gotta play better,” added Parker.  “We really turned the ball over a lot. Credit to them and their defense.  They did well with playing passing lanes and being more active than we were.  But 13 assists and 23 turnovers. That’s not the kind of team that we are.  Not at all.”

The schedule doesn’t get any easier for the team from here. Dates with Pepperdine and UNLV beckon in the next eight days after Sunday’s step-forward victory over Cal Poly, so the Bruins will have to find their identity and their mojo quick before they dig themselves in too deep of a hole in the Pac-12 standings.  

Because after this kind of abominable loss to start the year, the Bruins’ season may already be on life support.

Written by: Darryn Albert

title: Album Review: Grimes’ 4th Studio Album “Art Angels” by Dylan Karlsson
content:
Following the release of her new album, Art Angels, Grimes tweeted, “there is so much beauty in music. I wish perceived commercial ambition was not the topic sometimes.” Of course, this can often become a mode of discourse when critiquing independent artists, whose “artistic authenticity” is linked with their relationship to the mainstream. Art Angels is clearly a step into the realm of mainstream pop music, featuring production at its most glossy, robust, and extravagant for Grimes. Though this is a steep departure from 2012’s Visions, it in no way shows a waning of her artistic authenticity. Grimes as a full-fledged, bizarro pop star is perhaps the most authentic version of Grimes.

The album’s sound pulls inspiration from 90’s dance pop without bending to any sense of nostalgia. In fact, Grimes’ added experimentation and quirkiness keeps such reminiscent sounds fresh and surprising at moments. In “Kill V. Maim,” a deep, chugging guitar with punchy beats sets the foreground for Grimes’ animalistic yelps, which quickly transform into a peppy and demented cheerleader chant: “B-E-H-A-V-E aggressive!” The song is a prime example of how Grimes injects her oddball idiosyncrasies into pop-minded music, never letting the varnish of production dilute the personality of the songs. 

The album version of “Realiti” provides a good point of comparison for Grimes’ growth as a producer. Whereas the demo release remained in an ethereal space, soaked with synth pulses, the new “Realiti” removes its shroud of reverb and haze and grounds itself with a heavier beat. In the intermediary time between these releases, it is as if Grimes has re-evaluated the actual realities of her music. On Art Angels Grimes lets her voice stand out – with the occasional vocal manipulation of her yelp that recalls its use on Visions – letting clarity co-exist with her emotive vocal style. At times the album seems like a love-letter to pop music, with tracks like “Belly of the Beat” and “Artangels” which revel in a heightened state of pop euphoria, where fantasy mingles into reality. At other times, tracks like “Flesh without Blood” and “Venus Fly” pose empowered affronts against the hierarchies that critique and delimit pop as mere kitsch, insisting that pop can have real meaning.

Grimes wields her pop artillery with a clear and acute self-awareness through it all. In the closing track “Butterfly” she muses, “if you’re looking for your dream girl / I’ll never be your dream girl.” Art Angels’ self-awareness is its hidden weapon. Her role as a pop musician is here indisputable. Any fan or critic dismissing Art Angels for its “perceived commercial ambition” is relying on their own fantasized conception of what Grimes is. Though the “dream girl” doesn’t exist, there’s a real one who can do things even better.

Reviewed by: Dylan Karlsson

title: Show Review // Red Bull’s 30 Days in LA Presents: Joey Bada$$ @ the Belasco Theatre (11/04/15)
content:
“They say money is the root of all evil, I see money as the route of all people…” Joey began, as he crusaded across the Belasco stage to its center point, where six stark, white lights illuminated his glistening skin.

November is an exciting month for those of us addicted to pressing play, as Red Bull puts together a concert list of all your bucket-list performers.  Day Four of the kick off week set the bar high, as Joey Bada$$ joined G Herbo and Warm Brew on the Belasco stage in Downtown L.A. For a man born in 1995, Joey commands an audience that practically all outnumber his age, like a religious savior. Vanishing in and out of the luminous nexus in front center stage, we see how Joey is hailed as the savior of the hip-hop/R&B genre. 

Originating from Brooklyn, he invigorates his music with a fusion of political and satirical lyrical genius, backed by scratchy turntables, serenaded by smooth jazz. Joey has kept his music authentic, experimental and raw, starting new trends and becoming a staple in modern hip-hop culture. Progressive Era, or Pro Era for short, is Joey’s Brooklyn hip-hop collective that is at the forefront of bringing old school style to new wave listeners, including housing Joey’s four mixtapes: “1999” (2012), “Rejex” (2012), “Summer Knights” (2013) and “B4.DA.$$” (2015). Joey’s latest tape is a monumental step in the right direction, epitomizing his lyrical verve and grabbing presence, to place him on top of the hip hop game. “It’s been a minute since they seen a style with no gimmicks,” off the Intro to Joey’s second mixtape, “Rejex.” Joey lives and breathes these words, evident in his entrance dripping in young blood swag, hailing himself as king. Sporting platformed kicks, ripped jeans, a black band tea barely legible under his draping gold chains and an army jacket, Joey commanded us he is here to stay.

Throughout the show, Joey threw off articles of clothing, in sync with the growing hype within the crowd. The verve transitioned in and out of trances during Joey’s slay of lyrics and mosh pits as Joey popped off. This sort of conversation between the energy of his audience and the sound waves in the air is a tribute to the original art of performance. Joey ended his show, bleeding beads of sweat, with a call for a moment of silence, with lighters in one hand and peace signs with the other, for loved ones who have fallen victims to police brutality and other atrocities. After 20 seconds of deep-breathed, sweaty silence, Joey directed the audience to turn their peace signs into middle fingers towards the police force. Joey then requested a “hyped mosh pit” and tore up his final lyrics, swooning in and out of acapella, for his final number.

Words by: Brittany Hewitt
Photos by: Olivia Lim

title: Show Review: El Ten Eleven @ Teragram Ballroom (10/16/15)
content:
El Ten Eleven toured for their newly released album Fast Forward and I had the opportunity to be blessed by them on October 16th at the recently opened Teragram Ballroom in Los Angeles. They opened the set with Point Breeze, the opening track of their newest album, which set the mood for the entire performance: raw energy with a hint of ambient.

“I’d like to dedicate that fuck up to the landslides… mudslides on the 5 freeway. Alright here we go, from the top without mistakes.” says Kristian Dunn, one half of El Ten Eleven—rocking out on his 1977 Carvin guitar/bass doubleneck—as they begin to play “Thanks Bill” from one of my personal favorite album, Transitions. The band had some travel obstacles due to the recent flashfloods on the grapevine section of the 5 but that in no way affected their overall performance.

 

From beginning to end they had control of the entire audience and knew when we wanted to rock out to some of their more intense songs such as “Indian Winter” from It’s Still Like a Secret; they also knew when we wanted to relax and be taken away with some ambient vibes from songs like “Fanshawe” from their self-titled album El Ten Eleven.

We danced with them, we laughed with them—every mistake would be dubbed the “grapevine remix” or the “Flylo remix”—but most important, we were surprised as an audience. One of my all time favorite moments of the show was when Tim Fogarty, the drummer of the band, stood up and began gently tapping the guitar strings of Dunn’s guitar. We were all intrigued and suddenly realized that they were playing “Every Direction is North” from the album Every Direction is North. The synchronization and the the sheer trust they had in each other was prevalent and it made me smile.

Their 80-minute set concluded with arguably their most famous song “Transitions” from their album Transitions. With that, concluding the end of their concert and the end of one of my favorite concerts this year. 

Photos by: Bryan Villalpando
Words by: Bryan Villalpando

title: Show Review: Rhye @ the Observatory (6/17/15)
content:
The lights in the Observatory fade to black and a melancholic soft blue light illuminates the stage from behind. Silhouettes enter stage right and slowly settle into their instruments. They begin to craft a meditative, ambient wall of sound that washes over the audience like a plush blanket. An electric organ eases into its single long bass note before diving in completely; an organ softly murmurs in the background; a violin quietly weeps (or is it a moan?) above its counterparts; a rimshot acts as a heartbeat, maintaining the pace of the ebb and flow. Suddenly, another silhouette enters the stage and takes residence in front of the microphone while the band finally settles into the familiar, albeit slowed down, groove of “Open.” The crowd goes wild.

This moment is perhaps the best summary of Rhye’s musical practice: sleek, sensual, seductive, a little sad, and downright sexy. They take their time with every aspect of their sound, sliding into a melody precisely when it feels right. Vocalist Mike Milosh unfurls his breathy coos over unobtrusive beats while sophisticated strings swell up from beneath him into a massive wave of emotion, only to fall back down at and settle into subtlety. The effect is infectious.

The lead-up to Rhye’s excellent debut album, Woman, was met with immense music blog hype. Initially, the duo, now revealed to be comprised of vocalist/producer Mike Milosh and Danish producer/songwriter Robin Hannibal of Quadron, shrouded their identities, releasing the tracks “Open” and “The Fall” with little accompanying description. But with its silky production and cleverly constructed lyrics about sex, love, heartbreak, and more sex, the music spoke for itself, and the internet went wild. 

Despite the hype, it’s nothing short of mind-blowing to think that something as patient and free-flowing as Rhye, music as deeply indebted to the sophisti-pop of acts like Sade and Avalon-era Roxy Music, would develop such a massive and dedicated following in 2015. Even more shocking is that Woman was released on Republic/Innovative Leisure/Loma Vista in 2013, and Rhye, the live-act, has been touring basically ever since.

Given that their album spawned two years of successful touring to sold-out shows practically everywhere they went, my expectations for their live show were rather high. I was not disappointed in the slightest.

Since Rhye only has 10 songs to their name, much of their performance at the Observatory was made up of reworked and extended versions of their catalog. They opened with a pared back version of already minimal cut “Open,” in which they honed in on the rhythmic guitar line in the recorded version and laid it down as the foundation of the groove for all instrumentation. It was an interesting flip, and one that worked in their favor, as it allowed Milosh to show off a funk-tinged, punchy vocal performance that was a refreshing change of pace from the atmospherics of their recorded work. Standout performances of “Last Dance” and “Hunger” turned into seemingly endless jam sessions not unlike the best of Maxwell or even D'angelo, transforming the songs into soulful, funky, almost psychedelic behemoths that grew and grew until they reached mind-bogglingly satisfying climaxes that left the audience in pure awe. What was most satisfying about those performances, though, and throughout the show in general, was that the band felt like a single unit, truly in tune with one another, not overpowering anyone else unless they were being showcased for their musical prowess.

One of the highlights of their set was their performance of new song, “Waste.” After all the online murmurs of Rhye being a one-album project, I was thrilled to hear new work from them, and hope this is an early promise of a new album on the horizon. The song, which he stated was “pulled together during soundcheck,” was more groove-based than the rest of their recorded work, and welcomed a few licks of preciously plucked xx-esque electric guitar into the Rhye texture. It’s definitely a promising track that sounds like it still may be in the early stages of its conception, but the magic is undeniably still there.

For their closing song, Rhye performed one of Milosh’s solo tracks entitled “It’s Over.” With the directive to make us cry, as suggested by an audience member, Rhye delivered one of the most beautifully heart-wrenching vocal performances I’ve seen at a live show in recent memory. Beginning with subtle accompaniment, every member on stage eventually stepped away from their instruments and sang in perfectly pitched, multi-part harmony with Milosh. The performance successfully silenced the audience, and Rhye were able to slowly fade into murmurs before ending their song with, “Thank you.” I may regret saying this, but I may have shed a tear or two.

What Rhye does may not be new or groundbreaking, but their music doesn’t need to be so. They are an act that’s equally as captivating recorded as they are live, and their streamlined sensuality is so perfectly constructed that it’s difficult to deny they’re more than the hype that surrounded them. Their performance at the Observatory is one that will probably stick with me for a while. It was a truly magical showcasing of expertly executed pop, soul, R&B, and funk that left me speechless. If you have the chance to see Rhye live, do not miss it; you will not be disappointed.

~ Gabriel Brenner

title: Show Review: Neutral Milk Hotel @ the Observatory (5/29/15)
content:
On the road down to Santa Ana, my friend in the passenger seat of my car turned and said, “We are seeing a band perform an album that has always existed in myth to me.” Neutral Milk Hotel returned in 2013 for their extended tour after nearly fifteen years of inactivity for what is considered to be their last time performing together. The band’s website reads, “Dear friends we love you but it’s time to say goodbye for the never ending now to announce that spring 2015 will be our last tour for the foreseeable future…”

When we arrived to the entrance of the Observatory, we were informed that we had to return our cellphones to our cars. The gratitude I felt from being liberated from staring through cellphone screens the entire show cannot be understated. I now understood the show would become more of a moment.

As Jeff Mangum ushered the band out playing A Baby for Pree, I could feel the crowd holding their collective breath. It wasn’t until Neutral Milk’s third song, The King of Carrot Flowers, proclaiming, “When you were young,” that patrons who have all waited so long to see this band perform erupted into whimsical hysteria. The mosh of Holland, 1945 catapulted me to the front of the crowd, where I would stay for the remainder of the show (thirteen or fourteen more songs). Being able to see the quirky and cute Julian Koster play his bass adorned with snowflakes and three different musical saws for songs like Ghost was a beautiful manifestation of the band’s truly unique sound. The longer Neutral Milk played, the more entranced I felt in Mangum’s soft, cold voice. Even drummer Jeremy Barnes, the coolest of cats, took a turn playing the accordion. The show was more of a going-away party than a performance.

As Mangum played the simple chord progressions of Two-Headed Boy, Part Two to close the four-song encore, I was reminded why I love Neutral Milk Hotel so much: they still care about the music.

~ Chase Bishov

title: Film Review: Scout’s Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse
content:
Allumeuse – according to most online French-English dictionaries this word means “tease”. In contemporary spoken French however, the translation would be closer to “cocktease”.  It’s not a nice thing to say to or about anyone. A boy in Paris said it to me once when I when I wouldn’t go out with him on a second date.  I guess he wanted more. After seeing Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse, I finally knew how he felt.

Scouts Guide starts out strong, and when I say “starts out” I mean the very first scene and five minutes of the film.  It opens with an indescribably funny treat of a scene that grabs you by the collar and whispers into your ear of the great ride that is soon to come.  Your eyes widen, your respiration and heart rate rise a little and you begin to anticipate a fantastic evening ahead of you.  Then the rest of the movie rolls and you realize you’ve been duped.  What you got up front is all you’re getting and you’ve been tricked into spending the evening with a movie you don’t want to spend time with.  The fact that you’ve spent your money, two hours of your life and dragged your now-annoyed significant other along for the letdown just adds insult to injury.  If you really want to see Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse, let me run down a few key bits for you.

One fantastic opening scene followed by a couple hours of bad ones.  One very funny zombie genitalia joke mid-movie.  One very NOT funny sexual assault of a zombie a few minutes later that still baffles me – did someone actually sit down and make the decision that this was appropriate? Yes, successful comedy locates humor in unpleasant subjects, but it didn’t find any in this particular joke.  Three teenage scouts tackle the zombie apocalypse, changing relationships and adolescent sexuality using a bad script and a pretty decent soundtrack.   It may have been a good idea at one time, but a quick IMDb.com check shows the story creator didn’t write the screenplay. Given that she has a track record the screenwriters don’t maybe they should have left her on the project. I would say the film is phenomenally bad, but it doesn’t have the charm of The Room, Showgirls, Battlefield Earth or Plan 9 From Outer Space.  If you miss it, I sincerely doubt that ten years from now you’ll be watching this at midnight in some indie theater throwing Barbie dolls in the air and engaging in scripted call-and-response.  It’s not fun bad.  It’s just bad.

Casting had a couple of high notes:  lead Tye Sheridan does what he can and given that there isn’t much to do, still brings sweetness to the lovable dork antihero. Sarah Dumont as a the strip-club-cocktail-waitress zombie killer is a surprise – she’s a gritty, sandy beauty with deadpan delivery that works here, even if the movie falls apart around her.  Patrick Schwarzenegger excels at playing a spoiled rich kid who torments people lower down on the food chain, but is that really a surprise to anyone? Cloris Leachman and David Koechner bring superior chops to a lost cause. Joey Morgan and Logan Miller do their best to rise to the occasion but are hamstrung by inferior material. Blake Anderson steals the show for five wonderful minutes, like lipstick on a pretty girl that comes off when you kiss her, only to realize it was all makeup – she’s not that hot.  In the case of Scouts Guide she also has really bad breath.

You’ve been warned.  Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse opens up with a brilliant and sexy tease of what is to come, and then proceeds to throw mud on your arousal for a whopping ninety-three minutes of your life that you can never get back.  If you want zombies and humor, Zombieland is still out there and waiting for you to come back home.  My advice is go back to her instead.

Reviewed by: Anastasia Gershman

title: Film Review: SPECTRE by David Wright
content:
While this may a strange statement for the die-hard Bond fan to take in, Spectre, the fourth in Daniel Craig’s tenure as the famed British spy, relies heavily on the continuity of the previous three films to lend it weight. So in this review, I will attempt to avoid spoilers for all four films to the best of my ability, but bear with me as it is not easy.

Spectre is a hollow film, as if the tropes of a James Bond movie became the basis for a perfume commercial. The audience is given beautiful people in expensive, often monochromatic settings, grimacing at one other with the occasional quippy line lacking the smirk to sell it. Every character is seemingly devoid of passion regardless of the situation, and the situation is never really clearly explained to the audience. There is a sense that James is very driven to find out more about the eponymous organization but he never discusses why, and even when his connection to said organization is revealed, not a single character in the film seems shocked. I am not kidding; the lack of emotional payoff made me question whether I had missed a scene where the shoe dropped for the first time, and they were just rehashing it now. 

From here on in I am going to break down the facets of the films in some semblance of order, so for those of you looking for a tl;dr: This is a disappointing entry in the series, especially considering the pedigree of involvement. Outside of two great action sequences, this is a bloated, passionless film that calls back to some of the franchise’s worst films while attempting to emulate the classics.

The newest Bond theme, written in 20 minutes by Sam Smith and his musical partners, is, like the rest of this film, a disappointment. Shallow lyrics do not necessarily ruin it, after all Tom Jones showed off just how effective shallow lyrics can be in his legendary Thunderball theme, but the song just does not materialize around them. Crescendos seem out of place, and while Smith has an incredible vocal range, it is wasted on sections where his falsetto voice seems hardly appropriate. The booming orchestrations that backed up Adele on “Skyfall” seem to miss their cue, making the repetition of the song’s chorus, which is meant to harp on the theme of the film, seem like the least important lyrics. That being said, the opening credits sequence itself is quite impressive visually despite verging on tentacle porn (see the film, you know I am right).

Now let’s talk about the characters and acting. Daniel Craig reprises his particular Bond in a similar way as the previous three films: he’s cold, brutal, emotionless, and often times has few words about his situation or feelings. While these work to be the definition of cool in two of the previous three films he has done, here it most strongly resembles Quantum of Solace in his lack of ability to be invested in the proceedings. One particular car chase through the streets and canals of Rome exemplifies this best as there are shots of Craig looking more bored than I was. His collected nature worked in Casino Royale and Skyfall because there were vulnerable, emotional, and charismatic characters for him to play off of, and this film constantly reminds of their existence to its own detriment. Christoph Waltz’s performance as the mysterious Franz Obenhauser is the biggest offender in this category. His essential character trait seems to be merely aloofness as he never really reveals his motivations for getting involved in Bond’s life or how he came to be involved with Spectre. Instead he is given approximately 30 minutes of screen time and very little dialogue to get across that he is menacing in some way, yet we never see him be menacing. The movie commits the cardinal sin of filmmaking by opting to tell rather than show its audience about its cast. Waltz gets to monologue to no end about how he was behind everything in the past three films (which itself is a stretch of the audience’s memory to expect them to be invested in the Bond of 2007). Additionally, his character is given a couple of twists within the film’s plot that he does absolutely nothing with, and no other character seems to care either. Lea Seydoux delivers probably the best performance of the film (not saying a lot), as she actually gets to shed some tears and demonstrate some emotion. Unfortunately her performance is undercut by a shoehorned romance a la Casino Royale that has no basis in the film. Her particular Bond girl also lacks in any defining characteristic for the most part, acting as an amalgamation of all of them to the muted effect that one would expect. Bond’s team of M (Ralph Fiennes), Q (Ben Wishaw), and Moneypenny (Naomie Harris), are also forced into this plot but at the same time feels as though they are doing nothing. Bond’s interactions with Q and Moneypenny however are some of the brighter spots of the film’s poor dialogue, showing off some of the Connery esque charm that launched the series in the first place. These characters are dragged into a fight on the homefront for the very sanctity of espionage operation…yeah, exactly, but more on that in the plot section. In this fight we are introduced to newcomer, Andrew Scott as C, who (SPOILER) might as well have had villain stamped on him from his introduction (END SPOILER). Former wrestler Dave Bautista acts as the Red Grant/Oddjob of the film, capturing the strength and kinetic energy necessary for the role, but only given one word of cringe inducing dialogue. Overall the performances best encapsulate this film’s failing, as each character is essentially going through the motions without any displayed motivation to do so. Their hollow performances echo the identity crisis of the film in being unable to do decide what sort of Bond movie it wants to be.

The shots and production design are top notch as one would expect from a film of this pedigree. There really is not much to say on this particular facet as it is serviceable, though it should be noted that the film seems obsessed with a dichotomy between the Western world and the Eastern world displayed entirely by color palette choices. All of Europe is mostly grey, all of North Africa is brown, and that is about it. Mexico City gets trapped in weird grey-brown mixture that muddies some shots of otherwise well done cinematography.

The plot and script are huge failings. The film is divided into two conflicts that are meant to coalesce but never do in any meaningful way: Bond searching for Obenhauser and SPECTRE for unknown reasons, and C attempting to create a private organization that stories everybody’s information for “global security”.  The first part of the plot consists mostly of people telling Bond how dangerous his situation is, and him escaping that danger with literally no problem (this happens three times). Even in the classic Bond torture scene, he walks away without any issue and it is never brought up again, while his reactions during are so controlled that it’s impossible to empathize. It compares quite poorly with similar scenes in Casino Royale and Skyfall where Bond’s torture tests his physical and psychological limitations in a way that is painful for the audience. Obenhauser’s scheme, which of course he delivers to Bond in a monologue, lacks an ultimate goal as he divides his time between world domination and the death of Bond. Mind you, this isn’t a classic situation where Bond has managed to get in the way of the villain, as Obenhauser seems to have a convoluted Saw-esque plan for Bond’s demise that could’ve been escaped quite easily as the film demonstrates. Despite these complaints, it should be noted that it is this portion of the film that provides whatever interest is present in the film. The secondary plot is by far more tiresome, as C repeatedly harps on a sentiment that was overdone in Skyfall to begin with, by telling M that he is old and C is new. This was permissible in Skyfall because it is the crux of the film’s theme and mirrored the franchise in a meta way, but here it appears to be a lame attempt at topicality, like the switch to drug dealing villains earlier in the franchise, and an excuse for lazy writing. The ultimate sin that this side of the plot commits however is that the writers could not commit to even allowing C’s motivations to be genuine, despite his concerns about the double 0 program (007) being rather rational. After all, James spends the film causing millions of dollars of damage across multiple countries that most likely resulted in some if not extensive collateral damage. Of course C has to be proven wrong for the franchise to exist but why does he also have to be the bad guy? The film’s dialogue is simply poor. Bond’s exchanges with most characters are sparse, devoid of charm outside Q and Moneypenny, and often reduced to one liners that never land. Waltz delivers his straightforward “mystery villain” lines with nothing interesting behind them. Lea Seydoux is given some bits of interest in regards to her father, but these are abandoned half way through the proceedings in favor of love.

Action is present throughout the film though only portions of it are compelling. The opening sequence in Mexico City is a standout as a setpiece, and the homage to From Russia with Love halfway through the film is the best hand to hand fight scene the series has seen since that film. Beyond that, there are some car chases, a plane/car chase, and bouts of shooting that lack any emotional weight or energy. The aforementioned plane is such a ludicrous idea that it is immersion breaking, especially when the final result is shown.

There are more specific criticisms that can be used against the film, such as the poor plot device of mouse that the film relies on, or the pointless call backs to much better films like Goldfinger, but ultimately none of that would change that this is a massive step down in quality for a franchise that had delivered one of its most crowd pleasing entries in decades just three years ago. It sticks to the Bond formula to a fault, adding nothing and refusing to fix some of its demonstrated failings. This is a Bond movie that takes itself very seriously and expects the audience to do the same by layering a kind of mock gravitas over every event, resulting in totally watered down emotional beats. Coming off of the Craig saga, the franchise should be looking for new avenues to explore within the action genre while staying true to the essence of the Bond film. Spectre demonstrates that the outdated formula in combination with persistent melancholic melodrama represents a bad path for the series (this is not Batman Begins), and hopefully will act as a lesson to those who direct and act in the next installments.  It is not so bad a film to cripple the franchise, but it is a misstep for what felt like the verge of a Bond renaissance.

Reviewed by: David Wright

title: Show Preview: Young Rival @ Teragram Ballroom w/ Born Ruffians (11/14/15)
content:
This Saturday, Born Ruffians will take the stage at one of Downtown LA’s more intimate venues, the Teragram Ballroom. Joining the Ruffians for this evening of tactfully domineering guitars and sticky riffs will be Young Rival, the Canadian indie rock trio hailing from Hamilton, Ontario. This rock outfit boasts a sound that’s raw and hazy, yet discernable enough to come across as distinguished and effortlessly catchy all the while. 

Saturday night, you can expect Young Rival to kick off what’s expected to be a very loud evening with plentiful material from their latest effort, Interior Light. Their third studio album is characterized by tracks that are easygoing enough, but dark and melodic when they need to be. As a rock fan however, you might find that Young Rival’s sound is best experienced in its most uninhibited state: The live setting. Rival’s interesting mix of subdued moods and effervescent energy is a perfect companion to Born Ruffian’s signature act, and the performance will undoubtedly shake up an antsy crowd of teens and twenty somethings. 

Tickets are still available!  On November 14th, you too, can see Young Rival open for Born Ruffians at the Teragram Ballroom.  Doors open at 8, and the show is expected to start off at 9. For more information and tickets, see: http://www.teragramballroom.com/event/905785-born-ruffians-los-angeles

Words by: Doug Gil

title: UCLA Radio’s Show of the Month: “Free Time” with Kim and Aliya
content:
Every kid wanted to be “Student of the Month” in Elementary School. Unfortunately, not everyone is that cool and we have to settle for that damn “Best Attendance” crap. Where did all the commemorations go in middle school or even high school? Whatever the hell a “Dean’s List” is, we’re glad we’re not on it, that’s for sure.

Thankfully, UCLA Radio has made the “Show of the Month” - honoring one show every month hosted on UCLA Radio’s online frequencies. This is a show that goes above and beyond in what they do and sets an example for all UCLA Radio DJs throughout the station what it is to put on an outstanding hour or more of radio programming.

Kim and Aliya are two cool, wildly humorous DJs who most definitely deserve the honor. “Free Time” is an hour block of sweet goodness that proves comedy shows are just one of the many prime examples of how diverse the UCLA Radio station is. On top of that, these two RUN UCLA Radio’s comedy department! Go figure!

The two comedy heads chatted a bit about their show and the importance of comedy in radio in this short q&a video complement to the honor of being considered “Show of the Month”.

Make sure to catch Kim and Aliya on “Free Time”, Wednesdays from 3-4pm on UCLA Radio! (but don’t worry about us undergrads, please, just enjoying our “free time” aka “midterms”)

title: Throwback Concert Review: Bowling for Soup
content:
The historic stretch of Sunset boulevard, where the well worn and well stained halls of The Rainbow and The Roxy stood, was about to see its next milestone: my first concert. This was one of the few experiences in my life where I can solidly say I had absolutely no idea what to expect, and from my confusion about where one goes: shall I try my luck with this massive line or talk to the guy at the box office regarding my online ticket purchase, I’m sure everyone could tell I wasn’t supposed to be there. I had never even been a big fan of Bowling for Soup. Sure, like anyone else around my age at the time, I listened to 1985 a few times, but here and now, being dragged to this club by my self-proclaimed die-hard fan of a friend, that seemed like a lifetime ago. I had been able to brush up on their discography over the years, as long drives around LA provided this friend with a perfect platform to demonstrate her perfect imitation of lead singer, Jay Reddick’s, one of a kind voice, conveying all the teenage angst that any of us may once have been capable of while still being emitted by the vocal chords of a 40 year old. For her, they fell into the pantheon of pop punk, which, having run out of legitimate social issues to possibly provide a unique voice on, had shifted to deal with the never ending issues of “misunderstood” and “mistreated” adolescents. Sum 41, Blink 182, you name it, products of an audience rather than an era, that still clung onto the nostalgic hearts and ears of the faithful who longed for a simpler time in which they were the sole arbiter of right and wrong in the world and everyone’s inability to see it kept that particular young adult trapped in perpetual victim hood. This music had a time for all of us, and so this night would be the litmus test for this music’s relevance and enjoy ability, at least for myself and this friend of mine. Would it matter anymore?

Owing to my lack of experience with concerts Liz (the aforementioned friend) and I were totally unprepared for the announcement, upon our entrance to the venue, that the FIRST opening act will be starting soon. First? It was shocking enough for us that there was an opening act, but that there are instead multiple, and that as a result, bowling for soup would not even be on till at least11:00, this was simply unbelievable. We really had no choice but to stay for the entirety (she had decided to write a paper on this concert for a class), so we awkwardly found places in the crowd gathering in front of the small stage, and braced ourselves for what might appear there. I would say I attempted to drink the environment in, but doing so probably would’ve left me quite parched. The place was straight out of the dive bars featured in Scott Pilgrim vs The World, consisting of one black room, bar to the back, merchandise and tables on opposite sides, and their packed into the middle were the eager fans, being accosted by the occasional piercing light of the neon lamps on stage. 

~David Wright

title: Show Review: Alex G @ the Echo (5/21/15)
content:
Upon entering the near empty room, The Echo was quiet when I saw three girls on stage who make up the band SLUTEVER, are cleaning up and moving off the stage. I figure I have about fifteen minutes of an intermission before the next band to come on. To the right are small booths and tables reserved for merch vendors for the band. To the left, the wall is lined with a bar and men and women are sharing drinks complacently, clad in ripped 90’s full­house dad jeans and antique sweaters. I exit through the back of the bar to get a breath of fresh air before Alex G goes on stage. The back, an even smaller space is lined with past show lineups and people clad in similar attire chain smoking on a ripped couch.

A bit of loud murmuring from the inside suggests that Alex G and his band are preparing and setting up. My friend and I retreat from the couch full of lounging smokers and I wonder if they are here to see any bands or if they are just here to be seen. I walk into the now crammed and hazy thirty by thirty room full of heads. I lean up against the side of the stage close to Alex G’s rhythm guitar player. Within the minute I walk in the band is about to play and what seems like a six foot tall version of a ten year old boy introduces himself as Alex G and says about nothing else. Shortly after, the band starts off abrupt, playing recognizably a good grip of songs from his most recent album, DSU. What surprised me the most was the speed, clarity and more complex instrumentation demonstrated in this live performance in contrast with his intimate bedroom recordings on the album. Somewhere near halfway through the set a sped up, though recognizable version of one of my favorite, older Alex G songs, “Wicked Boy” is played.  Again, I am taken aback by the song’s difference from the album. The muffled, nasally and nostalgic voice of a younger Alex G is replaced by a matured one. The minimal and quasi­-electronic drumming from the album is replaced by a highly competent drummer and a very present bassist. While I’m not sure if I actually prefer the seemingly rushed and complex instrumentation of the live performance when faced with the solo bedroom recordings of Alex G, I was definitely impressed by the overall engagement with the audience and enthusiasm. Never would I have guessed that one could be so excited to sing songs that mutter, “You think you wanna die, but I watch you close your eyes, it’s alright”. Following the final song, I didn’t plan on doing much lingering due to the flocks of fans hitting the merch booth to smother the band so my friend and I split. Strangely enough, my way out was greeted by Alex and his bandmate smoking outside of the venue and I chatted for a second, not really saying much other than nervous fanboy jargon. On top of his performance being pretty good, him and his band are really friendly people and I will certainly make an effort to see them or any other Orchid Tapes band again.

Words & Photos by: Jake Stutz

title: Show Review: Snoop Dogg - Odd Future Carnival @ LA Coliseum (11/14/15)
content:
Snoop Dogg’s performance at the carnival was nothing short of legendary. With his enormous gold chain, Adidas shoes, and classic french braids, he killed it.

The show consisted of a combination of both his old-school classic songs from the “Doggystyle” (1993) Album, along with his newer works, like his collab-o with Katy Perry on “California Girls” (2010), and other pop artists. He also had his Doggpound crew up on stage with him, not to mention a giant mascot of a “Nasty Dog”. Snoop didn’t only play his own music either, he paid tribute to his fellow rap/hip hop legends, Tupac and Biggie, with the tracks “2 of Amerikaz Most Wanted” (1996) and “Juicy”(1995). 

The large screen display behind him would show photos of what album he was playing from, or some random image. Often times it would be either a weed leaf, a girl twerking, or a Rastafarian themed photo of Snoop himself. Very appropriate for one of his shows. 


The show closed with Snoop serenading Tyler the Creator, alongside ASAP Rocky, with the song “Young, Wild, and Free”(2011) and the crowd all sang along.

Words By: Aliza Maynard

Photo By: Aliza Maynard

title: UCLA Radio Sports // “Hope Still Remains for the UCLA Football Team”
content:
The Bruins continue to struggle on the year against lackluster opponents, losing to an unranked team for the second time this year.

UCLA suffered a 31-27 home loss against Washington State this Saturday, an opponent that they were favored over by 11.5 at kickoff. The loss drops their record to 7-3 on the season, effectively eliminating any chance the Bruins had at making the College Football Playoff.

There are some positives following the loss though, as the entire conference was shaken up over the weekend. The top two teams in the conference, No. 7 Stanford and No. 10 Utah, both experienced losses to unranked teams on Saturday.

The Cardinal was defeated for the first time since week one, losing to a resurging Oregon Ducks team 38-36 at home. Stanford falls to 8-2 on the year, maintaining a one game lead over Washington State and Oregon in the Pac-12 North standings.  

The Utes were outlasted on the road against the Arizona Wildcats, losing in double overtime 37-30. Utah still holds a one game lead over UCLA and USC in the Pac-12 South, but will play the Bruins on Nov. 21. 

With losses by Stanford, Utah and UCLA, the Pac-12 likely has lost any possibility it had at sending a team to the College Football Playoff. 

UCLA, who was ranked No. 13 by the AP to start the season, still has two tough road games left on their season. Trips to Utah and USC should be beneficial to true freshman quarterback Josh Rosen, who established himself as arguably the best quarterback in college football this past weekend.

Rosen had a phenomenal performance against the Cougars this weekend, almost sealing a win for the Bruins with a 37 yard touchdown run to take a 27-24 lead late in the fourth quarter. He continued his streak of consecutive passes without an interception to 189, with his last interception coming against Stanford on Oct. 15.

For the remainder of the year, UCLA is still in control of its own destiny, as they can win the Pac-12 with by defeating Utah, USC, and the eventual Pac-12 North champion.

Optimism remains mostly though for UCLA’s upcoming seasons. With two or three years left of Rosen, the Bruins are bound to be contenders for a spot in the College Football Playoff. As Rosen improves, so will the likelihood that the team will accomplish it’s lofty goal of winning a national championship.

Written by: Brent Troop

title: Show Review: A Great Big World @ the Troubadour (11/6/15)
content:
Had a moment at the A Great Big World show at the Troubadour on Friday night. The gist of it is that my generation has seen substantial and impressive change in the area of LGBTQ rights. Young people of every gender and persuasion (in Los Angeles at least) walk down the street hand in hand, share affection, live their lives more openly than their predecessors - and it’s beautiful. It was always beautiful, but now they can share it with the world a bit more freely.

So why do I feel apprehension when the subject of Gay Rights comes up? Here’s why:

At the show on Friday, one of the artists mentioned that some radio stations won’t play their music because they deem it “too progressive”. This means the music tackles subjects like same-sex romance with the same reverence and attitude as the traditional boy-girl love songs. We have come a long way, but this saccharin sweet G rated little love song can’t get played on the radio? Listen up.

I saw a little bit of what life was like before. I remember being frightened for my life when my highly effete friend faced down a group of homophobic frat boys in a McDonalds in 1986. I remember seeing black eyes, bloody noses, cringing men puking up blood on the sidewalk while the gang roughing them up went in for few more kicks. I remember boys being thrown out of their homes at 12, 13, and 14; and others in the Midwest were lynched and left to die with razor wire wrapped around their throats.
