Girls who dared to claim themselves as anything other than needing a man were raped, stripped in public, humiliated. Even now if a girl rejects a man’s advances its common enough to hear the words “Fucking lesbian…” as the loser who is unworthy of any woman’s attention tries to reclaim his lost honor. Doesn’t matter than he never had any in the first place, because he can just blame it on the women who refuse to respond to his toxic gaze.

What does all of this have to do with my feeling of apprehension?  It all still frightens me deeply, down into my bones. I’m afraid that all of these advances and all of this progress that we have made could be taken away. I’m afraid that marriages that people waited decades to seal will be invalidated. I’m afraid that children in these families will go back to fistfights every day at recess when some 2nd grader talks smack about the parents he or she loves. I’m afraid that everything gained will be lost. If you say that’s improbable, look at the Civil Rights Movement and tell me we  haven’t lost a substantial portion of the ground we once gained (I’m talking about you Voting Rights Act).

When I was a teenager in the 80’s I feared for anyone who claimed sexuality outside of the heteronormative standard. You didn’t know what was going to happen to them. To some degree that risky area between heterosexuality and everything else still exists – but it’s been getting better. Really. And the sad and scary time when I grew up was better than the decades before. There has been progress. But still, radio stations in this country won’t play music by a band that is about as offensive as a cherry coke because it’s “too progressive”. This is a red flag to anyone who thinks that the struggle is over. This is a warning to you, if you are one of those people who believes in equality. Don’t rest on your victories. Don’t imagine that this is over. Don’t think that these new freedoms can’t be taken away. We have to keep fighting. If this doesn’t seem like the forum for this kind of rant, totally not sorry. I went to this show and this is where the events that transpired took me.

All that being said the show was fun. Sawyer Fredericks opened, fresh off his victory as winner of the The Voice last year. I will honestly say that someone in the audience told me that. Until then, I had zero idea of how this sweet and fresh faced sixteen year old with an otherworldly voice had attracted legions of middle aged and even senior women who screamed his name as if he were Paul McCartney in 1964.  He performed a series of original songs playing an acoustic guitar. His instrument and vocal skills notwithstanding, the set suffered from a lack of diversity. He is writing his own material and evidently understands song structure and vocal delivery, but one song blended into the next and then into the next. I would have appreciated a few covers of artists like Merle Haggard or Willie Nelson, whose influences are reflected in his playing and composition. It looks like he’s set to become a very big star. As he moves forward and matures as a songwriter, I think it will be an awesome career.

A Great Big World wandered onstage after a super-short break, bringing a talented and enthusiastic back-up band. The set consisted mostly of new material off of the album When Morning Comes set to be released this upcoming Friday, November 13. This band hails out of the NYU musical tradition – which is to say non-mainstream in look and sound without necessarily screaming out “rebel”. Their sense of humor was in place and lent a very personal feel to what is already an intimate venue – it was appreciated. Given that the show was intended to serve as a release event, new songs dominated, and the crown responded with restrained emotion. Things fired up toward the end as they launched into more established hits like “Say Something” and then visited the first single off of the new album “Hold Each Other”. Hip hop artist Futuristic jumped on stage to lend a few words in this last selection, much to the surprise of a very happy audience. “Shorty Don’t Wait” brought Sawyer Fredericks to the stage for a great sing-a-long type of experience and the show ended with an encore performance of “Rockstar”.

What can I say? A record release event always trots out new material that hasn’t made its way into the anthem arsenal yet, and the set was a reflection of that. The crowd ate it up, everyone left happy and by 11pm most were heading out the door in search of all the fun that Boystown has to offer on a Friday night. Overall notes were that the show suffered from a lack of consistency in the energy department, but that the charm and humor of the performers held it together even when the music and overall tone failed to stay in place. Good show, killer venue, extremely awesome people watching, and some serious food for thought as evinced by the first portion of this review.

Reviewed by: Anastasia Gershman

title: Interview: Virginia Beach’s Turnover Talks Latest Album and Tour with Catherine Yi
content:
Turnover released their 2nd full-length, Peripheral Vision, a dreamy-emo masterpiece, in May and have been on a heavy tour schedule ever since. The band stopped by The Glass House in Pomona opening for Lydia and took the time to shed some light on their busy year.

You guys make a pretty big sonic leap with each album. With Peripheral Vision, do you think you’ve landed on your sound yet or is there still much further to go?

I feel like we’ll always be changing music just because we’re always so eclectic and listening to new things all the time. I would say that Peripheral Vision is probably closer to what you could call the foundation of a sound but I still wouldn’t say you should expect anything really like it to continue.

So you think even the next record could be something totally different?

Probably. Like maybe less of a leap from Magnolia to Peripheral, but who’s to say.

You said you’re always listening to new things. What were you guys listening to that went into this record?

I was listening to a band called The National a whole lot. A lot of indie rock from a couple eras ago, like Modest Mouse, The Shins, The Strokes. Some new bands that are around doing revival stuff, like Beach Fossils, Wild Nothing, Real Estate. Just like soft rock, indie rock bands, I would say we listened to the most. There’s also some retro stuff in there, like The Smiths, The Cure, New Order, Joy Division. It’s really all over the place. That’s just me personally. Casey, Danny, and Eric all have eclectic tastes in music. Eric and Danny both really like rock like Oasis, Dinosaur Jr., stuff like that. Casey’s pretty mellow. He’s really into Mac Demarco, The Growlers.
So we’re all over the place.

Did you change anything with your songwriting on this record or were there any specific goals you were really shooting for on this one?

This is the first full-length that we’ve done with Eric being a member. We wrote Magnolia when the band was in a tumultuous place as far as members go, so that was a bit different. This is definitely our most collaborative record, which is one of the reasons that I think that it’s better. It’s a bunch of minds working together rather than a bunch of ideas and just being like play this.

I’ve heard on this tour and your last tour that you’ve only been playing songs off this album. What’s the reasoning behind that?

On these tours, we’re pretty much just opening so we don’t have as long as a set. When we only have 6 or 7 songs, we want to showcase the new stuff as much as we can. If we had a longer set where we had the opportunity to showcase the record on top of playing older stuff we would, but if we’re gonna be limited to only a few songs we want to play the stuff that we feel most accurately depicts the band.

You guys have been touring a lot. You’re literally coming back here in a month. Do you see the touring continuing into next year with headliners or maybe just longer sets?

I can’t say anything for sure. We’re off all December and then in January we go to Europe with Citizen. Then next year, we’ll still definitely be touring on the record, trying to get it out there, but nothing confirmed yet.

Do you guys consider yourselves part of the emo revival?

I don’t consider us part of anything. Whatever people want to say, they can say and I feel like time will tell in places wherever we wanna be.

Do you think you’ll ever write a happy song again?

I think “Humming” is pretty happy. I think that there’s happy songs. Realistically I feel like Peripheral Vision is the happiest record we’ve put out in a while. “Sasha” and all those old songs are definitely tinged with a lot of angst and I feel like Peripheral Vision is the most dynamic in terms of the spectrum of emotions. I would say there will definitely be more happy songs to come. I want to be able to write songs that people can relate to in any period.

You guys have a fish graphic that you’ve been using a lot on your posters, merch, etc. My favorite movie of all time is Big Fish so I was wondering what the meaning behind that image is?

Danny designs all the merch. He has his own style with stuff. I’m not sure what his artistic vision was behind this as far as meaning goes. He’s probably the type that wants you to apply any meaning that is fitting for your own mind, I guess. But I don’t know what it is. I’m glad you like it.

Written by: Catherine Yi

title: UCLA Radio Sports: Film Review - City Slickers Can’t Stay With Me: The Coach Bob Larsen Story by J.T. Osborn
content:
Two months ago I took part in the Disneyland half-marathon. It was one of the most rewarding and exhilarating moments of my life so far. I clocked in around 2:22:15 or something very close to that for the 13.1 mile trek through Disneyland, Harbor Blvd, and Angel Stadium.

There really is some renounced mental poeticism as you run. It’s beautiful, and frankly a little odd how focused you can become as you run for such a long period of time.

City Slickers: The Bob Larsen Story is a film parallel for exactly the act it represents. At times it’s a very odd, the montage sequences are abrupt and choppy. The Instagram-like still shots of nature juxtaposed with close-ups of Larsen or of someone running from the background into the foreground is anything but oblivious for its intentions. The film seems to try to make some parallel from Larsen, and to an extent his runners, to Mammoth Lake—the running ground for his trainees—as if to yell at you that he isn’t just some city slicker, ‘HE’S MORE THAN THAT DAMMIT!!!!’

What City Slickers lacks is stylistic continuity in delivering its message, and honestly, I’m still not entirely sure what it was. It featured the History Channel style montage of interviews and archival photos coupled with what was an attempt at motivational music.

About a quarter-way through the film I didn’t know if I was going to finish it. The odd cuts where the screen would cut—not fade—black for about 2 seconds then fading in to some romanticized shot of nature had me feeling empty. What kind of connection was it trying to make? Like a donkey’s ass with lipstick on it, it was trying to be more than it was.

As I stuck it out, I began to forget or care how the film was shot. Bob Larsen just has ‘it’. That type of reserved intangible quality where you really didn’t need to know much about him to see how great he was.

It didn’t matter whether I could exactly pinpoint what made him great, I just knew, and that’s definitely something this film was successful at capturing. As he would talk the score would quiet so that you could not only hear, but more importantly, feel what he had to say. It really captures Larsen as a simple man with something indescribable about his being.

Now, this isn’t the type of documentary that’s going to be nominated for any awards, but it has an enjoyable subtleness to it carried by its subject.

This documentary isn’t about a man who’s going to be in elementary school textbooks or anything similar, but it is about some farm boy who grew into something admirable.

City Slickers is however, a documentary that captures a contagious greatness permeated by one hell of a human being. It entrances you into watching and wanting more about who he is.

Isn’t that what films are supposed to do?

Words by: J.T. Osborn

title: Film Review: Todd Strauss-Schulson’s “The Final Girls” by Dylan Karlsson
content:
With the inevitable wave of horror movies profiting off of the Halloween season this Fall, comes The Final Girls, a spoof and modern reflection of the slasher flick genre. Directed by Todd Strauss-Schulson and starring Taissa Farmiga (American Horror Story) and Malin Akerman (Watchmen, Children’s Hospital), the movie centers around a group of modern teens predisposed with modern feminist ideals, who are then sent into the backdrop of a cheesy, summertime, slasher B-movie. Once there, Max (Taissa Farmiga) must escape the vindictive hands of a killer while reconciling the loss of her mother (Malin Akerman), who is present as one of Camp Bloodbath’s counselors awaiting a scripted death. The film’s aim lies somewhere between critique and homage, toying with the film’s meta-structure to elicit a laugh or to bring up the more poignant critique of the ‘final girl’ trope in horror cinema.

Coined by Carol Clover in her book “Men, Women and Chainsaws: Gender in the Modern Horror Film”, the ‘final girl’ is the virginal, tomboy-ish female character who outlives the rest of the cast, and ultimately lives to see the downfall of the film’s antagonist. It’s a trope often played out to suggest that this ‘final girl’ is somehow more deserving of survival because she appears to be more wholesome and less sexually available. Clover goes further to analyze the genre under the Freudian lens, stating that each murder is a symbolic act of sex. Each girl is stabbed with the conveniently phallic-shaped knife, causing for some sadistic free associations. This wholesome girl’s shift into the role of the weapon-wielding heroine is, in Clover’s view, a masculinization of the female protagonist. Her donning of the same phallic-shaped knife is then assumed to be the source of empowerment for taking down the killer.

The film deliberately calls out the trope for its misogyny while playing along with the rules of this kitschy, alternate universe. It’s intentionally goofy at times, and drippingly heartfelt at others, to the point where sincerity and flippancy melt to a dangerous point of confusion. The film’s central romance between Max and the ‘sensitive nice guy’ love-interest played by Alexander Ludwig (The Hunger Games, and hilariously, The Final Girl (no joke)) is obvious and disinteresting in the midst of a more eccentric cast. Adam Devine (Workaholics) and  Angela Trimbur (Halloween II) play the respective horror movie stereotypes of the ‘dumb stud’ and ‘airheaded party girl’ with just enough accuracy and outlandishness to make a mark. A lot of the strongest comedy comes from Thomas Middleditch (Silicon Valley), an oblivious fanboy who seems to resemble a stereotype from the spoof movie genre at times. Nevertheless, Middleditch interacts with the B-movie scenery with a giddy awe that drives the film through its most absurd and suspect moments.

One strength of the film is its art direction, which resists the urge to settle with the classic 80’s movie style and rather assumes an augmented, hyper-real visual palette. The airbrushed and modern CGI visuals catch one off guard in this supposed B-movie world. It’s reflective of today’s blockbusters, which will someday (though many already do so) be laughed at just as ridiculous 80s slasher scenes are now. As these modern teens enter into the vintage and trope-laden landscape they alter its contents to match their own culture of blockbuster effects and trendy tumblr-isms.

When The Final Girls came out, it was debuted and followed by a Q&A session with Strauss-Schulson and one of the film’s writers, M.A. Fortin, at UCLA through “Melnitz Movies”. Though the film wavers between self-awareness and incapacity, the story is held together at its crux by the mother and daughter dynamic. Even through the goofy and garbled antics that frame this central narrative, the emotion translates as Max comes to terms with her loss. When it comes time to realize the twisted rule of the ‘final girl,’ there is a knowing between mother and daughter, and perhaps a knowing for the audience that, that’s just how movies go.

~ Reviewed by: Dylan Karlsson

title: Terminally ~*Chill*~ Summer Playlist
content:
If you’re in dire need of something to blast on your way out of your last exam or during your journey home for the summer, we’ve got you covered.  The following playlist is a short, wondrous mix of staple tropical sounds, breezy beats, and carefree moods perfect for experiencing during the summer ahead.

Making it through yet another year of schooling is an admirable achievement. So here’s to you, listener!

~ Doug Gil

title: UCLA Radio Sports // “UCLA Basketball Beginning To Find Its Groove, Defeats Pepperdine By Final of 81-67″
content:
Hosting the Pepperdine Waves at Pauley Pavilion on Thursday night, as it turns out, the UCLA Men’s Basketball team was the one doing most of the peppering and the dining.  

The Bruins coasted to an easy 81-67 victory over their WCC counterparts in front of a home crowd of 6,063.  Five players scored in double-figures, led by 19 points from junior guard Bryce Alford and 15 points to go along with 15 rebounds from senior forward Tony Parker.  Freshman Aaron Holiday added 16 points, 4 rebounds, and 4 assists while fellow newcomer Prince Ali posted 12 points and junior Isaac Hamilton added 10 points.

UCLA’s offense, which had sputtered for long stretches over the course of their first two games of the regular season, was firing on all cylinders Thursday.  The team shot an impressive 50 percent (30-for-60) from the field for the entire game as head coach Steve Alford’s offensive sets really let the UCLA guards push the pace, go downhill, and make plays.  

Whereas the team often suffered from aimless ball movement, careless turnovers, and inefficient shot selection against Monmouth and Caly Poly, that was solved in large part against Pepperdine through off-ball motion, drive-and-kick action, and a healthy dose of corner three-point attempts.  The Bruins used their newfound offensive revival to jump out to a 29-11 lead within the opening ten minutes and never looked back, leading by as many as 20 in the second half.  Though Pepperdine got the deficit to within 10 by the closing minutes, they never saw the lead at any point of the game.  

It was also an inspired effort by the Bruins on the defensive end as they allowed the Waves to shoot just 38 percent for the evening (including just 4-for-20 on three-pointers).  The team was defending with energy, clogging the paint and the middle of the floor, and fighting for loose balls.  While they did concede far too many second and third chance opportunities to the opposition (19 offensive rebounds for Pepperdine), the Bruins contested without fouling (just 14 free throw attempts by the Waves) and looked like a cohesive unit in their zone defense for much of the night.  

“Now this is three games in a row playing big-big that we’ve been in the 80s, so offensively, things are starting to smooth out,” said Coach Alford after the game.  “Overall offensively, it was pretty good.  Shoot 50 percent, we had a good inside-outside approach.  We took good shots, high-percentage shots.”

“The positive was the defensive end,” Alford continued, turning the attention to the other end of the floor.  “We gave 34 and 33.  We haven’t done that yet this year in back-to-back halves…Other than the backboard, obviously we gave up way too many offensive rebounds, but I thought defensively, our second half got a little bit stagnant offensively, but we didn’t lose any points because our defense was pretty sound…I thought this was the best game we had to date on contesting shots, forcing teams into some difficult shots, and I thought that was a big key.”

The 50-year-old head coach also praised son Bryce, the team’s leading scorer on Thursday, saying “I thought Bryce did a really good job leading.  That’s the most vocal he’s been.  He’s learning to deal with that mouthpiece now where he can take it out and talk.  And I thought he did a really good job leading us on both ends tonight.”

“I think we came together, especially Isaac, Aaron, and myself,” said Bryce for his part turning to the chemistry of the guard rotation.  “We gotta play together to help this team win and I think we did a much better job taking care of the ball and getting us in offense and getting us back on defense and getting things set.”

“Just gaining confidence in practice,” added Holiday when asked to the key behind his own stellar performance on Thursday.  “Playing against Bryce, Isaac, and Prince just helped me get in the game and be more confident and staying in attack mode.”

Parker meanwhile commented on his slowly improving frontcourt dynamic with seven-footer Thomas Welsh, who finished with 6 points and 6 rebounds.  “Just talking with Tom and getting him on the same page with me.  That’s basically what it is.  Me as an older guy.  I let Tom listen to rap and he makes me listen to country.  Those are the kind of adjustments you gotta make when you’re playing with somebody and you really wanna get the camaraderie down.”

The Bruins are feeling that camaraderie right now, and with the team set to be tested at the Maui Invitational before a date with CSUN followed by a true David vs. Goliath matchup against college basketball powerhouse Kentucky, it couldn’t have come at a better time.  

Written by: Darryn Albert

title: UCLA Radio Sports // “A Duck vs. a Bruin”
content:
…Wouldn’t you think the Bruin would always win?

Sadly a win wasn’t the case on this fine Thursday night for UCLA women’s volleyball team. How I ended up at this game is really a mystery because one minute I was enjoying the Thursday special of teriyaki chicken bowl at rendezvous than the next minute I was sitting in Pauley Pavilion watching our number nine team take on the unranked Oregon Ducks.

The game was actually a lot more interesting than I thought it would be because everyone in the audience, including myself, assumed that our nationally ranked team would beat the Ducks in an easy three sets however this was not the case at all. The first set was what everyone expected out of the Bruins when they won 25-17. This set win was due to the mixture of the kills from Frager, Anderson and Ngauamo, the setting from Muno and the blocking from Rodgers and Felix to make this team look unstoppable.

However, the Bruins’ luck went down hill after this first set.

The Ducks showed that they are a completive PAC-12 team in the next set by leading the Bruins the whole set, minus the first two points. The Bruins were leading in the beginning but quickly fell behind to lose to the Ducks 25-17.

Now on to set three when the game got interesting because everyone’s assumptions about our UCLA teams ability went away but loyal fans still believed we could win the next two sets to take away the W. The third set consisted of nine ties and consent back and forth between the two teams that tested both their abilities. With a tie of 25-all, the Ducks then got two incredible kills to win 27-25.

The Fourth: where the Ducks could take it all. However, our Bruins weren’t giving up just yet. I could not believe that a set could get more exciting than the third but it did by having 15 ties and eight lead changes causing these two teams to go back and forth on almost every play. The Bruins weren’t going to let the Ducks win without a fight so the end score of this set was 25-23 the Bruins with an amazing performance from all the team but especially Anderson and Felix whose kills were what won them this set.

Finally, it was the battle to the win. The game that was suppose to be an easy 3-0 set win for the Bruins turned into a tie game going into the fifth set. The fifth set was nothing as exciting as the previous sets due to the fact that after a 3-all tie, Oregon took the lead in the set with a 15-12 win.

This match between the Ducks and the Bruins moved us down by only one rank to number 10. Even after this lost the Bruins proved that they are a strong team that is trying to prove themselves in the very completive PAC-12.

Written by: Emma Nairin

title: Show Review: Toro Y Moi @ Teragram Ballroom (11/9/15)
content:
Photo by Bryan Villalpando

November is a hot month for concerts in Los Angeles; Red Bull Sound Select Presents: 30 Days in LA is taking over the music scene in Los Angeles. Hosting a different concert each night of November, I got the chance to catch Toro Y Moi at the recently opened Teragram Ballroom in Downtown Los Angeles on Day 9 of the series. This is the third time Chaz Bundick, the lead singer of Toro Y Moi, blessed me with his funk-infused indie rock band and it was by far my favorite—the psychedelic backdrop added flare to the entire experience. What I found most interesting is that Chaz was located stage right and the bassist was the center of the stage. I felt as if this forced the audience to focus on the entire band rather than put their sole attention on the lead singer.

They opened the set with Half Dome and Buffalo, two songs from Toro Y Moi’s most recent album What For? (2015) released in April of this year. The mood was set to a summer vibe induced by the wah-wah effect with treble guitar riffs and psychedelic/electronic undertones. It quickly transitioned to a chill vibe as he played Talamak, from Causers of This (2012) and Still Sounds from Underneath the Pine (2011). The crowd began dancing to the chillwave sound and together we enjoyed the show: the dancing was just beginning. The energy from the entire band was electric. The peak of the performance was during Rose Quartz from Anything in Return (2013). A funky bass line backed behind a synth was the perfect combination for the crowd. Everyone was vibing to the psychedelic ambience of the Teragram Ballroom. The 808s arise at the end of the song that brought an energy that could only be described as a warehouse party in the 80s alongside the coast.

The band played hit after hit and before we realized it, they played 18 songs in 90 minutes. There was a nice mix of both old and new songs on the band’s discography, they ended with Empty Nesters, arguably the biggest hit from What For? The crowd went wild. The band stepped off and the crowd screamed “one more song!” Although the band did not return, everyone left with a smile on her face.

If you ever have the chance to catch Toro Y Moi live, I highly recommend it.

Setlist:

Half Dome
Buffalo
Talamak
Still Sound
Grown Up Calls
Campo
The Flight
Lilly
Rose Quartz
So Many Details
High Living
Cola
Ratcliff
Run Baby Run
What You Want
Say That
New Beat
Empty Nesters

Words by: Bryan Villalpando
Photos by: Olivia Lim (unless otherwise stated)

title: Show Review: Greensky Bluegrass & Tumbleweed Wanderers @ Teragram Ballroom (10/30/15)
content:
Walking into the Teragram Ballroom on the night before Halloween, I was one person. Walking out later in the wee hours of the next morning, I was another. Arguably, this transition would have occurred anyway the way it does for most of us. We experience whatever it is that we experience and it changes us, be the change moment to moment, minute to minute, day to day (etc.). In this particular case, however, I am going to make a special note of the person I was before I saw Greensky Bluegrass for the first time and the person I was after the taking in the show last Friday night. I would have to say of the two people I described here, the latter is my new favorite. I walked into the old Teragram expecting a show and got a full on Bluegrass hillbilly (punk) rock experience. Check it out:

Opening band Tumbleweed Wanderers kicked off a strong set to a mostly empty space. People trickled in and the music grew stronger and more soulful as the set progressed. There may or may not have been an issue with the set order – the energy built up, got down and then did an abrupt upward turn at the end. The shift was palpable and not necessarily in keeping with the vibe of a band who obviously puts a huge amount of thought into everything they do. Emails to band management went unanswered so we’ll never know. It was a successful and exuberant expression of rock’n’roll energy, but the end was question mark for me – is this the way they wanted to leave us? I was probably the only one who noticed – it was a very happy crowd, and wouldn’t you know it?  I was pretty happy too. 

The break wasn’t too long (always appreciated, right?) and then out they came. Surrounded as I was with loyal fans wearing all types of Greensky hats, sunglasses, t-shirts and other assorted gear – I figured I was in for an interesting fan experience. Five men on strings walked out, lined up parallel to the edge of the stage, and proceeded to take the entire place and a fantastic, wild hillbilly punk rock ride to dancing oblivion. Dobro, mandolin, banjo, guitar and upright bass – it was a rock’n’roll acoustic bluegrass event. The band launched the first set with Dustbowl Overtures, and it became rapidly apparent that this was a) a singalong crowd, and b) a dance-until-you-drop type of experience. Up front was the place to be. When the band slid into Burn Them, people got a little crazy. When toward the end of the first set they offered a rousing rocking cover of Springsteen’s Dancing in the Dark, the sing-a-long aspect got pushed about as far as it could go. Instrumental Clinch Mountain Backstep finished up the first set, which was a good thing given half the audience was about to drop. Energy was high and the smoke from both stage and audience was dense.  

The music started up again VERY quickly, which worked with the vibe, and started off with a killer version of Radio Blues. When energy gets this high in a crowd, its not always fun. However, to the credit of the band and everyone there, I was happily reminded of Dead shows in Berkeley when I was a kid: good vibes, happy campers, much weed smoke and incredibly fun music. The second set moved as fast as if not faster than the first, and dazzled with a strong selection from across Greensky’s body of work. A clear and awesome standout in what was already a standout show was a fantastic cover of Flatt and Scruggs 1967 Bringing in the Georgia Mail. Greensky’s version added pacing and a little punk rock ethos to the song, and in doing so honored the original in a great and lovely way. There was probably more than a tip of the hat to the Sam Bush Band cover of the same song.  It had beauty to it and some serious magic – I felt lucky to be there. Hats off. The wrap up and encore ended with attention grabbing cover of Springsteen’s Atlantic City.  I might normally raise an eyebrow at a band covering two songs by the same artist in a single show – but my eyebrows stayed in place. It worked. Everything about this show worked. When folks poured out onto the sidewalk to mob the taco trucks lined up on 7th Ave it was pretty clear that everyone there was exactly where they wanted to be, yours truly happily included in their number. 

So, the person I was before the Greensky show compared to after?  Before I probably wouldn’t have been quite as determined to dance until my vision shook and my head spun – but now I’m feeling the vibe and gearing up for the next show. Emails to band management regarding the set list were answered at light speed, btw – always nice. If you get a chance to take in this band – just go.  If you’re hip-hop, deep house, outlaw country or purely classical – it doesn’t matter.  If you can’t have fun at a Greensky Bluegrass show, you probably can’t have fun anywhere.  If you need to have some fun, quit your whining and buy a ticket already. Just go. 

Greensky Bluegrass is based out of Kalamazoo, Michigan.  Band members are Paul Hoffman (mandolin), Michael Arlen Bont (banjo), David Bruzza (guitar), Anders Beck (dobro), and Michael Devol (upright bass).  They are totally awesome.

Reviewed by: Anastasia Gershman

title: Album Review: Joanna Newsom’s“Divers”
content:
If Divers and the very essence of Joanna Newsom could be represented by a single word, that word would be “esoteric.”  Lyrics about interdimensional travel, a distinctive yet polarizing vocal delivery, and a myriad of sonic concoctions make Newsom’s work something that might only appeal to a special few, but will demand a response from all. 

Its been five years since Newsom’s massive two-hour LP Have One on Me, but from the opening seconds of Divers, I’m reminded that one needs little to no reacquainting with this one-of-a-kind brand of experimental folk.  Joanna’s voice, which ranges from airy timbres to a forceful squall, follows the expositional piano chords before it’s joined by her signature harp work.  The overall sound is familiar, yet more ample this time around.  From its opening minutes, every track on Diversis engorged with meticulously arranged instrumentation that fills these songs out.  The result is an hour-long battle over the listener’s attention, and a very satisfying one at that.  While we’re used to vocal performances being at the forefront of a song, that isn’t exactly the case on Divers, even with a voice like Joanna’s.  Her singing, while commanding, never overpowers the instrumentation. Instead it floats comfortably atop sounds of woodwinds, and is laced neatly between alternating strings. 

This balance is one of Divers’ stronger suits—The listener isn’t too distracted by one aspect to allow the overall composition go unnoticed.  This album isn’t exactly boastful, but once it has your attention it almost beckons you to be surprised by its unexpected “instrumental cameos” and stylistic changes.  “Leaving the City” for example, starts off like any other Joanna Newsom track before jumping into what almost feels like a prog-rock nod, especially with the drums and electric guitar chords uplifting the vocals.  Live drumming is an idea that sounds almost alien for a Joanna Newsom song, but this kind of instrumentation makes a couple of appearances on this LP, and it sounds just right when it hits.  Similar points can be made about songs like “Goose Eggs” and “Waltz of the 101st Lightborne.”  Before you know it these two tracks sound nothing short of country ballads on both the vocal and instrumental fronts.  Revealing these outside influences hardly feels like a gimmick, and that’s largely due to the fact that Joanna can ease into these new territories almost seamlessly.  By the time you notice this change you’re already in the thick of it, and at least for me, the subsequent reaction isn’t one of questioning but rather one of gratitude, almost.  I find that this applies to the album as whole, too.  Each repeated listen catches me off-guard with some clever metaphor in the lyrics, or maybe an intricate little sound hanging in the background that I didn’t catch beforehand. 

In short, Divers is a very pleasing listen and it unquestionably continues the streak of quality albums under Newsom’s belt: It’s intricately constructed, surprisingly conceptual, and almost impossible to loathe.  My only complaints about this LP include the fact that the latter half is a little subtler and even abrupt in many instances.  And while I have many great things to say about this album, I still don’t think Divers is the one to change the minds of listeners that were adverse to Newsom’s style on previous efforts.  Her voice and experimental tendencies are acquired tastes of sorts, but that makes for intriguing listen at the very least.  So yes, Joanna Newsom’s Divers may be one of the more esoteric releases to hit the indie scene this year, but that doesn’t imply that it isn’t one of the most beautifully welcoming experiences of 2015 as well.

~ Written by: Doug Gil

title: Album Review: Deafheaven’s New Bermuda
content:
You’ve probably seen photos of confluence before– when two rivers converge at a swirling median of two-toned tides, natural proof of yin and yang. I’m going to briefly use this stunning riparian phenomenon as a visual analogy for Deafheaven’s genre-synergy:

Deafheaven has championed the “blackgaze” sound since their 2013 sophomore release Sunbather. Its widespread critical acclaim set expectations for a follow-up album incredibly high, and New Bermuda exceeds them. It comprises five tracks, each around ten minutes long, each a balladic journey wavering between frenetic metal fury and spacey, shoegaze breakdown. Opener “Brought to the Water” marks Deafheaven’s return with knelling bells and a heavy burst of classic metal instrumentation that marches along to vocalist George Clark’s Draugr-like growls. It is morbid, violent, and angry in the most thrilling of ways.

I would guess that these screamy vocals tend to be Deafheaven’s most off-putting musical quality for new listeners with no exposure to black metal– I however have come to appreciate it as being more instrumental, like a sharply distorted guitar. So my advice to new listeners is to get past the growling and focus on the full-bodied chords and uplifting melodies. Deafheaven seems to craft every song for maximum cathartic effect. The chords on lead single “Come Back” are the most frisson*-inducing, but nearly every track has a climax that could work as the album closer.

Like on Sunbather, the band makes ample use of airy, spacious intermissions to provide listeners a break from the saturation of New Bermuda’s intense parts. “Brought to the Water” ends with a lone piano part Elton John could probably work with. “Luna” drops its rhythm guitar in the middle to isolate the ethereal, reverbed lead and coasting bass. The entire second half of “Come Back” is clean and dreamy shoegaze, a pretty counterpart to initial rawness. Given their stylistic duality, and how deftly they diffuse two incongruous genres, it’s fitting that Deafheaven found** their name in Shakespeare’s “Sonnet 29:”

        “I alone be weep my outcast state,

         And trouble deaf heaven with my bootless cries”

This desperate pathos is apparent throughout New Bermuda’s metal portions. But just as “Sonnet 29” redacts upon its gloom:

        “Yet in myself these thoughts almost despising,

          Haply I think on thee, and then my state,

          Like to the lark at break of day arising

          From sullen earth, sings gyms at heaven’s gate”

…there is always an exalting answer, this shoegaze beauty that can be sad, ecstatic, wistful, cozy, or whatever depending on how you feel while listening. That the album demonstrates such emotional versatility and variance I think is important to many fans and to metal as a genre. Despite the allegations of some staunch metalheads that Deafheaven is “hipster metal” tainting the scene, I believe the opposite: New Bermuda celebrates, and more importantly, humanizes metal as an immensely emotional and powerful form of expression, with as much grace as aggression.

Notes:

*French for when something sounds so nice or strikes you in such a way that your skin prickles and undulates in waves of goosebumps. You all know what I’m talking about.

**Not sure if this is actually where they got their name. By my own inference.

~ Words by: Zach Conner

title: Show Review: Pokemon Symphonic Evolutions @ The Greek Theatre (7/11/15)
content:
On the road this summer is one of the most unique musical experiences ever performed - Pokemon Symphonic Evolutions. At the Los Angeles stop on Saturday, The Greek Theatre Orchestra brought to life in stunning vibrancy over 20 years of video game music from the Pokemon games. People of all ages gathered in the amphitheatre nestled in the Hollywood hills to hear the soundtrack of their childhood. On a screen hovering above the orchestra, original game graphics augmented by realistic visuals kept attendees constantly engaged and enthralled.

The concert began appropriately with the intro theme music while the large projection scrolled through the title screens of all the games in chronological order. For someone like myself who has been playing Pokemon since Red, Blue, and Yellow Version were released, it was incredible watching the graphics morph through time and realizing how quickly the technology has progressed. After the introduction, the orchestra wound their way through every generation of Pokemon games in two 45 minute acts, playing highlight pieces from each.

First up was the Pallet Town theme from Red, Blue, and Yellow, which cranked the nostalgia up to the max. The orchestral arrangements were absolutely breathtaking. I’ve been playing the games since I was 3 years old, but until that night under the clear Los Angeles sky, I had never realized how beautiful those 8-bit compositions really were. Live strings, vibrant horns, booming percussion, and more, created an incredible sonic tapestry as we watched Red go to Professor Oak’s lab and choose his starter Pokemon. The Team Rocket theme was bolstered by huge techno beats in an eclectic medley of classical and electronic music. I doubt any other orchestral performance held kids’ attention for so long.

While the orchestra played a well-balanced repertoire of intense and calm pieces, it was the latter that truly shone. The Ekruteak City theme from Gold, Silver, and Crystal Version was the prettiest piece I heard that night, and one that I had nearly forgotten from the games. The credits theme from Ruby, Sapphire, and Emerald Version was also wonderfully poignant played just on a piano with the rest of the orchestra softly backing it.

After intermission, the orchestra returned with the universally known Pokemon Center theme before moving into cuts from the later generations - Black and White, and X and Y. While the pieces were still just as compelling, many adults in the crowd naturally began to lose familiarity. The encore brought everyone back together as the entire theater sang along to the much-beloved TV show theme song. The orchestra finally closed the night with a piece personally handpicked by the game director: “Kiseki,” from X and Y. Unsung lyrics appeared on the screen, leaving attendees with a final message of peace, friendship, and gratitude.

Pokemon Symphonic Evolutions was the perfect tribute to a legacy of one of the most influential video game series ever created. At times it was hilariously nerdy, yet also powerfully emotional. If the Pokemon games defined your childhood as strongly as they did mine, it’s a can’t miss experience. 

~ Catherine Yi

title: Jesse Rutherford @ The Echo (11/24/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Natalie Benudiz 

Photos by Natalie Benudiz

I wish I had a way of embedding audio into this blog post. The piercing screams of the mostly-female crowd rivaled that of a One Direction concert. The amount of estrogen that permeated through the air almost condensed into a tangible cloud of teenage hysteria. When Jesse Rutherford finally leaped onto the stage, it wasn’t hard to understand why. From his bleached blonde hair to his glitter eye shadow, he looked as if he could be a living, breathing renaissance painting, a perfect cross between Sting and Billy Idol, appearing on stage with a halo of blue light as if to present his divinity to the audience. Standing perfectly still, his hand delicately placed over his heart, staring piously into heavens only he could see, Jesse was a perfect being. Almost out of nowhere, he dives into “Born to Be Blonde,” and the audience surrenders to him completely.

About halfway into Jesse’s set, eight shadowy figures emerged from the audience and jumped onto the stage, as the opening bars of “GOLD” signified the arrival of BROCKHAMPTON. Whatever sense of chill the crowd had left by that point was gone. I can’t even recall what happened during this time because the entire audience basically became a giant mosh pit. No one could have predicted BROCKHAMPTON’s unexpected appearance, but it was somehow a perfect compliment to Jesse’s androgynous style. Without warning, they finished their last song and jumped off the stage back into the swirling vortex of bodies and disappeared as quickly as they came.

The sheer visual smorgasbord of Jesse’s performance rendered the music almost pointless. His outfit changes alone were enough to carry an entire show, ranging from a perfectly tailored suit to a red 49ers tee, even to the extreme of boxers and bondage attire. His movements shifted with each new costume, ranging from sensuously caressing himself, to grabbing his crotch, to rolling around onstage in a fetal position. It was as if he was determined to display the entire range of human emotion onstage. Visually, Jesse is a work of biological art, and the show he put on was a visceral piece of performance art. Jesse himself is known for his mercurial periods of different personas, and his performance reflected multi-faceted quintessence of who he is. That night, Jesse was every version of himself that within his one body. One moment, he was a sensitive boi crooning to the audience with a guitar, the next he was thrashing a microphone around his naked torso in a fit of dangerous manic energy and a flash of diamond grills, then rolling around on the floor losing himself in his own melancholy. He was drunk off his own ego, and the crowd was equally intoxicated. Everyone in the audience wanted to touch him, to feel the raw sexuality that sublimated off his skin. At many points throughout the show, he leaned into the crowd to bless them with a fleeting chance to caress his stomach or his hands or his face.

His last outfit of the night featured his classic black leather jacket that marked his distinct style since the formation of The Neighbourhood. It was almost his way of saying that no matter how many times his identity shifted, he would always be Jesse of The Neighbourhood, which was a perfect way to end his very first solo show without them.

title: Baio @ The Zebulon Cafe (11/19/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Casey Lee

“Early Sunday café concert techno vibes.”

That’s how Baio (the solo project name of Vampire Weekend’s bassist Chris Baio) characterized the mood of at his most recent show in Los Angeles — which was indeed on an early Sunday night at the Zebulon Café. The atmosphere ended up complementing the artist quite well; like the disco ball that spun above his head, Baio’s electropop was dance-inducing, and like the plastic tangerine-hued chairs to the side, his live performance was charmingly quirky.

Vancouver-based Teen Daze opened the evening by DJing.  As concertgoers situated themselves at the bar or on those orange seats off to the side, Teen Daze’s soft electronic picks filled in the gaps between conversations, rather than overtake them. Before exiting the stage, he commented that Los Angeles was his favorite city - a pleasant, unpretentious sentiment to end his pleasant, unpretentious set.

Baio quickly took over the stage, donning a dark suit and accompanied by similarly dapper George Hume on guitar.  Launching into “Needs” from his first album The Names, the pair injected preppy pep into the small crowd that had gathered at Zebulon’s dance floor.  Baio, known for his unquestionably hip dancing at Vampire Weekend concerts, was no longer tethered to his bass guitar and was able to show off a few of his adorkably groovy moves when he grabbed the mic and let loose in the front of the stage. Sadly, these delightful moments were somewhat limited, as Baio often retreated back to playing behind his mixer.

Adding to the on-stage entertainment, Baio also incorporated projections as background visuals during his set.  Most memorable of them was the “Man of the World” music video that played along with the song’s live performance, in which different Baios clad in white tuxes shimmy at the Palace of Versailles, read The New York Times at Grand Central Terminal, or fly up Burj Khalifa behind the artist singing in real life.  With this set-up, however, there was little room for spontaneity during songs, as Baio and Hume had to perform in time with the projections behind them.  Nevertheless, the duo delivered a spirited yet intimate act full of tracks mostly pulled from the artist’s latest album Man of the World.

Other highlights were the ultra-catchy “PHILOSOPHY!,” anxiety-ridden “DANGEROUE ANAMAL,” the seamless transition between the purely electronic “Sunburn Modern” into the bubbly “Sister of Pearl,” and the punchy and playful “The Key Is Under The Mat.”  Throughout the set, Baio was the paragon of a “cool nerd,” from bopping to his beats at his mixer while sporting a mustard yellow bowtie, to crooning in a David Bowie-esque, syrupy baritone while lamenting about climate change and being a sensitive guy.

“Endless Rhythm” wrapped up the synthpop-filled evening at a sensible 9:00.  The prudent concertgoers dispersed from the dance floor, most leaving to go home and a few sticking around to chat with Hume packing up the equipment, or with another VW member who had shown up to support his friend.

title: NSTASIA Listening Party // Show Review
content:
Written by Helen Gallagher

NSTASIA is a name you might not currently know, but should absolutely remember. Recognized first for her songwriting, she has collaborated on songs for artists including Beyonce, Usher, and Skrillex. Recently, NSTASIA completed and dropped a solo album that has already gained some critical acclaim, and has her in hot demand for collaborations with major artists.

NSTASIA performed at a brand new underground speakeasy in Los Angeles last Thursday,  11/16, the same night she dropped her album New Religion. The venue itself was understated from the outside, a warehouse that blends easily into the landscape of east Los Angeles. The only sign of the party inside was the faint blue neon light cast onto the pavement, along with a hum of laughter and chatter from inside, and the small cluster of people at the door. Upon entering the party, we are greeted with a small art gallery and a clustering of excited people, NSTASIA mingling among them. The gallery itself was made up of album art, all fresh and bright, mirroring NSTASIA’s sound.

Downstairs we find a sleek speakeasy, with leather couches and chairs, and bartenders serving up a variety of palatable whiskey-based drinks. The crowd moves its way down, and there is a last rush for the bar before NSTASIA takes the stage, anticipatory murmurs and the occasional shout of laughter the last sounds before she begins to sing.

NSTASIA launches right into her first song, “Trap or Die,” the most popular off her album. She has an ethereal presence on stage, singing the soulful melody with a gleaming smile and effortless connection to her accompanying band. She is clearly influenced by other women in her genre, including SZA, Rihanna, Beyonce, The Internet, but her sound is unique, a little bit more country, perhaps informed by her earlier experimentation in the genre. 

NSTASIA’s music is a little bit mournful, but empowered; she sings of troubled relationships, but with a love and affection that is palpable. NSTASIA continues with more electro-R&B songs such as “Hell of A Time,” and “Parachute,” and the audience bops along — it’s impossible not to.  

NSTASIA grew up with music, and that’s apparent in her technical skill. There’s something else about her that distinguishes her from the technically skillful, and I have a hard time pinpointing it during her performance. Around the last song, I realize: it’s the joy that emanates from her performance and through her music, the bright neon of her album art realized in sound.

After a brief set, just six songs, NSTASIA thanks us profusely, and tells us to drink and celebrate, joining the mingling crowd. Keep an eye out for her in the coming months — with her voice, talent, and friendly charisma, she’ll be impossible to miss.


Photo Credit: EAST

title: Show of the Month: Redolence with Father Felicity // November 2017
content:
Interviewed by Alexa Lee

The word redolence means “fragrance,” or “the state of being reminiscent of something.” How do these definitions relate to your show?

I guess in the context of fragrance is how I first heard the word. I was reading George Orwell, not the overplayed 1984, but Burmese Days, something with relatively no standing in the literary world; something about the fragrance of frangipani trees. It reminded me of home in Arizona where the creosote illuminates the desert with fragrance after a monsoon rain. That means something to me. It evoked feelings of nostalgia of home and all of the beautiful rainy days, friends of the past and so on. That’s when I googled the word and found out about its “reminiscent” characteristics as well. I equated the two definitions as meaning the evocation of emotion through nostalgia, which is exactly what I want to do with my show. Instead of fragrance, however, my show focuses on sound.

You mention in your show description that “it has been hard for [you] to enjoy immediacy.” Why is living in the moment a challenge for you?

This is a difficult question for me because I truly have no idea why it has been hard for me to enjoy immediacy. Something just feels a bit off, like I’m too self-aware. Recently, I’ve been very within myself, adding an element of analysis to a situation that needs no interpretation. I suppose it’s almost as if I’m focused on the act of being in the present, rather than being in the present. To be in the present requires no means, it just requires being. Although recording everyday situations seems paradoxical to actually engaging with the present, I don’t create the moments with my field recorder. The moments in which I am truly present happen on their own, and I simply use the field recorder to capture them and ultimately engage with them further in my show. Capturing everyday audio as a medium of expression of my present being allows me to quite literally capture my moments of immediacy and share them with everyone.

How does “Redolence” enhance listeners’ (and your own) ability to be emotionally present and thoughtful?

I wouldn’t say it helps anyone else be thoughtful, or emotionally present. In this regard, the show is really based on a selfish concept. However, I’ve always thought art to find merit in its ability to express a piece of the artist’s self. I am simply trying to share a sincere moments of my life. Therefore, it doesn’t enhance listeners’ ability to be emotionally present and thoughtful, but rather to share in my life.

I had a close friend of mine approach me with regards to the show. Following the traditional stand on ceremony, she asked what it’s about. This was difficult to explain. All I can say in the case of “Redolence” is that it is a direct way to share a part of myself with the world, the listeners. In addition to quite literally recording bits and pieces of my life, I hope that with the placement and editing of audio and musical/literary accompaniment that these moments feel to you as they felt to me. I hope that even if slightly, you get to feel a little of what I felt and choose to continue following me on my journey!

How does confronting emotional experiences in the present moment differ from reflecting on past emotional experiences?

Confronting emotional experiences in the present is a rather passive event in terms of conscious thought. You’re there, something happens, you smile, maybe, but it’s over as soon as it starts. Maybe you reflect, but the beauty of it is in its happening and your unconscious response. Reflecting on past emotional experiences, however, allows me to consciously interpret the unconscious experience of immediacy. To interact with the experience in different ways and in a different mindset. I haven’t figured out if this is damaging or helpful yet, but I’m definitely experimenting!

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

I hope to exude an air of vulnerability that displays my passion in every episode of “Redolence.” More importantly, though, on November 3, 2017, I will be the proud owner of a cowboy hat.
tags: ucla radio show of the month

title: Interview with Tei Shei (10/20/17)
content:
Interview by Lillian Stanwick

On a reasonably warm Friday night, New York-based artist Tei Shi gave an unquestionable sexy performance at the Echoplex to the audience assembled at one of the last stops on Tei Shi’s longest tour to date. Before the show, Tei Shi answered questions about her debut album and its lengthy tour.

What makes Crawl Space distinct from Saudade and Verde?

Being a full-length album as opposed to an EP, it was a bigger endeavor and I took a lot more time making it and shaping it than the EPs. Both EPs were made in a very DIY way, on a laptop, in bedrooms, having minimal resources. I made them both within a month as well, while the album was more or less a work in progress for almost two years. I was able to learn a lot more about recording and production and just figuring out what I wanted with this album, since I had the experience of playing live and touring, and releasing stuff publicly. Sonically it’s different too in that I wanted it to have a much bigger range of styles and genre within it than I’d had a chance to display on the EPs.

How did your time at Berklee shape you as a musician?

I’m not really sure, to be honest. I learned a lot in terms of getting to understand music on a more theoretical level, because I had zero knowledge of music theory before going there. But as a writer or creator, I think being at school for music, it just allowed me to make music my main focus for a while and gave me the space to start writing and recording more and figuring out my sound on my own.

Have you collaborated with any of your former peers?

Not yet, but there are so many talented musicians I went to school with that I’m always talking to about doing something together…soon hopefully.

Which interlude is your favorite on Crawl Space and why?

I think “Bad Girl” is my favorite, because it kind of tracks this very quick switch from the self doubt and insecurity of thinking I was a bad singer to this kind of empowered, confident spin on it where I say, “I’m the hell of a bad girl.” I can relate to those two mentalities and the duality of those emotions that I still experience all the time.

Is the little girl on way to record you?

Yes, that’s me on all of the interludes. I was about nine years old in those…I used to record myself on cassette tapes singing, making up songs, talking to myself, all kinds of stuff.

Who are your musical influences?

They’re all over the place. To name a few: Kate Bush, Beyonce, Gal Costa, Manu Chao, Prince, D'Angelo, Jack White.

How has your tour been treating you?

It’s been pretty good, it’s the longest I’ve been on tour so I’m definitely tired and ready to get back home. But it’s been really positive and fun, and it’s been pretty awesome to go out and meet people at the shows all over the US and Canada.

What’s your favorite “new” album?

Even though it’s not a super new album, I just recently made my way to it so it feels now to me–Do Hollywood by The Lemon Twigs.

Dogs or cats?

Cats (though I love dogs too.)

Which music video of yours was your favorite to shoot?

This is such a tough one! I think “How Far”…because I got to do a car chase.

How much does you your upbringing in South America play into your music?

I think it definitely plays a lot into it, but in subtle ways. I don’t think there is a super direct influence that I can trace, but overall just having grown up in a lot of different places, different environments and cultures and being in a culturally eclectic household made it so that I was exposed to a lot of different music and diverse influences. So all of that definitely influences the kind of music I make.

title: 5 Rad Albums of 2017 So Far (As Seen at ArcTanGent)
content:
Written by Layla Moheimani 

Photo Credit: Nick Sayers

It is no secret that I have long been a bona fide concert junkie. However, my festival attendance has taken a major hit over the past several years. There is a simple reason for this: ArcTanGent Festival. It’s simply the best festival on so many fronts and if you have a love for mathy/prog/experimental/good music, there’s nowhere else you should be. Every August, 5,000 fans from all over the world congregate on a farm just outside of Bristol in the UK for three days of glamping, stellar performances, and the best pad thai on the planet. I’m fortunate enough to have been part of that group for the past two summers and as a result I just can’t bring myself to shell out hundreds of dollars to eat nothing but popcorn while watching merely adequate bands and trying to avoid getting whacked by selfie sticks in the mosh pit. Anyone who knows me knows that I’m a fan of efficiency and killing as many stones with as few birds as possible. So once I noticed that a disproportionate number of the bands I was featuring in my festival recap had also released new music this year, I jumped at the opportunity to lessen the inevitable burden of what is certain to be a loaded “Best of 2017” wrap-up and get a head start on spotlighting some of this year’s most exciting releases. The ability of a band to excel both in recording and live performance may be an anomaly to some, but it is a testament to the organizers of ArcTanGent that they are able to consistently put together such quality lineups and find the bands who are just as stunning in the studio as they are on the stage.

5) tricot

As with every “top” list that I make, I must open by reiterating my belief that rankings are arbitrary, counterproductive, and serve little purpose aside from aesthetics. This has been a spectacular year for music, as was exhibited at ArcTanGent and especially at these five bands’ sets. I’m not listing tricot at number five because they are on a lesser level than any of these other bands. I’m doing it because I can’t go much further into this piece without talking about how incredible their performance was. This being my second time at the festival, I knew that it was intrinsic in the ArcTanGent experience to encounter bands that absolutely blow you away. However, that still didn’t prepare me for tricot’s set. Watching the unbridled fervor of their performance, I felt like I was witnessing lightning in a bottle - the coming together of energy and musicianship, heightened by the adoration of the live audience, in a way that could only be experienced in a festival setting. And yet, it is the same level of thrill that I feel every time I listen to 3, the band’s new album which dropped this past May. With this album, the band has managed to capture the same balance of unrelenting aggression and unwavering grace which they have mastered through years of touring the world together. Of the five bands featured in this piece, tricot is the only one with vocals, which is indicative of the larger struggle many musicians in math rock face when trying to fit vocals into the already complex web of intricacies within the instrumental parts. Listening to tracks like “Tokyo Vampire Hotel,” you would never know that this struggle exists. The vocals are impeccably integrated into the music without ever feeling stretched or strained in accommodation to the other instruments. Japan has long been known for having one of the most loaded math rock scenes in the world, and with their hard-hitting live shows and the completion of their third album, tricot is rising to the levels of LITE and toe as essential bands for anyone looking to kickstart their exploration into the scene.

Photo Credit: Jonathan Dadds

4) The Physics House Band

When discussing five acts that have all produced such stellar music, it is easy to fall into cliches. I can say with certainty that The Physics House Band’s second album, Mercury Fountain, was one of my most highly anticipated releases in recent memory, and the band did nothing to disappoint. If I had spent all of this year in a coma and awoken at 11:52 p.m. on New Year’s Eve just to hear “Holy Caves” build up into “Surrogate Head,” I’d still tout 2017 as being one of the more incredible years for music. From the opening riff of “Mobius Strip,” I was immediately struck by both the raw and the symphonic elements, which were always present in the band’s music but have been expanded and fine-tuned in this new album. The band’s seamless integration of the gritty and the grand was on full display at the ArcTanGent main stage. This was further augmented by their choice to invite a guest saxophonist to perform with them on several songs in order to wholly do the tracks from the new album justice. Later that day, I saw sleepmakeswaves play the same stage which was an incomparable experience, since The Physics House Band’s sound could easily be described as “if sleepmakeswaves spent their formative years in a dark, gritty garage in Brighton rather than traveling across Australia.” In a weekend of extraordinary performances, The Physics House Band still stands out as one of the most dynamic acts that I have witnessed. The grooves on Mercury Fountain are stunning in their own right, but the band’s ability to maintain that tightness in a live setting, even within such a heavy expanse, was truly a sight to behold.

3) sleepmakeswaves

As several of the bands listed in this piece will indicate, the main stage at ArcTanGent brings something different with every act that sets foot on it. This is very exciting for fans, since you never know what to expect other than a great show. sleepmakeswaves’ performance was neither flashy nor over the top, yet each member still exhibited incredible amounts of showmanship without ever neglecting musical nuance. Their music is awesome in the truest sense of the word, as they are able to invoke so much power with both heavy riffs and lush electronics without compromising one in favor of the other. sleepmakeswaves is among the most accessible instrumental bands I’ve come across, and I think that is in large part due to the cinematic quality of their music that can resonate with people on such a fundamental level without ever needing lyrics to convey a message. While many bands face the struggle of being unable to replicate the polished, high-production recordings of their songs in a live setting, sleepmakeswaves faced the opposite problem early in their career in that they couldn’t quite capture the energy and depth of their live performances on their albums. However, with their more recent releases, especially this year’s Made of Breath Only, they have made a concerted effort to release an album that holds all the heaviness and glory of their live performances. It was the larger-than-life recordings of tracks like “Tundra” and “The Edge of Everything” that drew fans to the main stage and captivated every member of the audience with such gravitational force. Across the crowd, you could see a variety of responses as the band was playing; some people were jumping around, others were dancing or emphatically math-head-banging, and several more were just standing and letting the music wash over them. But whatever their physical manifestation, everyone was connected to the music and in absolute awe of what they were witnessing.

2) The Evil Usses

Coming back to the United States after ArcTanGent, I’ve had to find a way to relay my overseas experiences to my west-coast American friends in terms they would understand. This is what I came up with: If ArcTanGent was hitting up In-N-Out with your squad, The Evil Usses would be that one homie who showed you how to dunk your fries in your shake. You thought they be hella cray and kept sipping your La Croix but then you started munchin’ and it turned out to be next level dopeness. Translation: The only experience I can equate to the first time I heard The Evil Usses to is the first time I ate a french fry (or “chip” if that’s your thing) covered in chocolate milkshake. It simply blew my mind and awoke cravings I didn’t know I had. I also found myself describing them as “if The Physics House Band played four different songs at four different tempos simultaneously but they were all super happy” (and I made that assessment before I found out TPHB’s set would feature a guest saxophonist). Their album Amateur Pro Wrestling immediately jumped out at me during my pre-festival research, due in large part to tracks like “Gambino” and “Pre-Op Pop,” which I have spent as much time dancing around to in my bedroom as I have sitting with my head in my hands trying to wrap my brain around all the layers of rhythmic intricacies emanating from my headphones. The unwavering steadiness of the rhythm section holds down the beat while the guitarist and the keyboardist/saxophonist explore the depths of tone and texture with a plethora of delays and modulators. The songs are loose and playful until you realize how incredibly complex they are. Purists beware, this band is full of contradictions and will defy any label you try to apply to them. But if you’re like me and find immense amounts of joy in odd music that can both challenge and uplift you and is genuinely fun to listen to, buckle up because you’re in for something special.

Photo Credit: Ed Sprake

1) Alpha Male Tea Party

There are albums that you share with your friends right after you’ve heard them. Then there are albums you text your friends midway through telling them under no circumstances should they listen to before you can be there to see their reaction in-person. The latter was the situation I found myself in the first time I heard Health, the new Alpha Male Tea Party album and their first release in over three years. Following their main stage set at ArcTanGent, I heard someone refer to the band as “riff machines.” While I understand the sentiment and agree that the riffs are certainly present and as heavy as ever, I’ve found that in comparison to the band’s 2014 album Droids, their new album hardly has a mechanical moment to be found. On the contrary, the album as a whole is deeply emotional right from “Have You Ever Seen Milk,” which opens with near-offputting introspection for those who were simply expecting fat guitars and polymetric bangers. The album name itself is very telling of the circumstances from which the music was created since in the years following Droids’ release one band member has had a baby while a close friend of the band was diagnosed with a brain tumor (That friend is Dan Wild-Beesley, who I spoke with at last year’s ArcTanGent Festival. You can read my conversation with him about his friendship with Tom Peters of Alpha Male Tea Party as well as the breakup of his band Cleft here and I sincerely hope you will check out this page to read his story and find out how you can help). The band’s main stage set brought all the tight jams one would expect as well as the all the emotions of the album compounded tenfold from the sheer volume and depth of the crowd, which was said to be one of the largest main stage turnouts the festival has ever seen. There was also a special addition to the set in the inclusion of a chorus onstage for the final song, “No More,” which was dedicated to Dan. While there was a significant degree of poignancy throughout the set, it never eclipsed the hard and pure rock grooves which have long held Alpha Male Tea Party at the top of my list of “true power trios,” which is how I have come to refer to trios where all three instruments play equal but crucial roles (see also Town Portal and Vasudeva.) You can read my interview with Alpha Male Tea Party here. As Instagram informs me that in other parts of the world, leaves are changing and the temperature is cooling below 70ºF, I am reminded that before you know it 2017 will be over and I will be putting together my list of this year’s top releases. When that time comes, you can bet Health will be near the top of that list and among impeccable company.

title: Fall is Life - A Playlist to Get You Spirited for the Season!
content:
By Alexa Lee

Although UCLA still shows no signs of the evolving seasons, in other parts of the world a phenomenon known as “fall” is occurring right now. While you can’t watch the leaves change colors or drink your steamy pumpkin-flavored drinks just yet, here’s a playlist perfect for making you feel like you’re in the midst of your own autumnal oasis!

“Seasons Run” by The xx

What better way to embrace the fall season than by comparing a storm to your own turbulent emotional state? A pensive, stripped-down track detailing lead singer Oliver Sim’s self-doubt, “Seasons Run” is best listened to when wearing a large wool sweater and driving home from work in the rain.

“Just A Memory” by ODESZA

Regina Spektor graces ODESZA’s newest album A Moment Apart on this track, using her clear and pristine vocals to ruminate over a lost love. If previous ODESZA records captured the carefree mirth of a summer night, bittersweet songs like “Just A Memory” reflect the somber transition period where summer becomes winter.

“Seaside” by The Kooks

Do you want to go to the seaside? Well, you can’t, because now it’s fall. You can, however, listen to The Kooks’ simple acoustic track about falling in love with an emotionally distant woman.

“Berlin” by RY X

I like to imagine RY X singing this song softly to himself as he rakes crimson leaves off his lawn. Every now and then there’s a small but cool gust of wind. “Tell me I’m not going home,” he whispers. Leaves scatter in the crisp air.

“Chihiro” by Yoste

An elegant and understated electronic track, the title “Chihiro” is a nod to Hayao Miyazaki’s animated film Spirited Away. Listen to the song and be calmed by its soothing vocals, or be haunted by its reminder that youth is fleeting and summer is over and the movie you loved as a child was made sixteen years ago.

title: Girl Pusher @ The Hi Hat (7/16/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Cristina Delgado 

Minty Boi hosted his third show in a month at The Hi Hat. The venue’s unique space was ideal for the night’s performances. It feels like a bowling alley, with pool tables and high ceilings with low hanging lights, where you can grab a burger from Burger Lords and a beer within 10 feet of each other. A good place for a punk show.

We arrived as the night begun, with the first opener Brutus VIII in the middle of their set. His synth goth-punk set was both dreamy and satanic. He wore all black but the contour of glitter on his cheekbones made his nightmarish music a little tamer. His voice gave me Ian Curtis vibes that I really enjoyed. The song “A Friendly Commandeering,” from his album Live at Corporate, had a playful element that would pull back from the synth-punk and take a moment to jump back in. I always find those moments comical especially because of you expect punk music to have this roaring upbeat effect that allows you to disassociate from yourself. Having been the first on the lineup, the fans were light and Brutus VIII received a humble crowd that I wished more people had joined.

Next Matter Room took stage and and seemed off pitch from the rest of the night’s bands. They were a jam band that employed useless power chords and gyrating with their instruments. I usually don’t mind jam bands with dark punk but they were not connecting with the audience. They kept to themselves on stage and the lead singer wore a hood. Yet these Highland Park natives had an energetic sound that didn’t add up in a live performance.

Model/Actriz stole the show. Their intensity was an out-of-body experience. From waving his mic over his head in the middle of the pit to having a member of the crowd and vocalist rolling on the floor together, Model/Actriz does not give a dull show. What blew me away was in the middle of their set Cole jumped into the pit and climbed the high beams of The Hi Hat, and the whole time the band was with it. That’s the type of shit I like to see, a whole band on the same level and working together. while most of the previous bands on the night were self-professed punk bands, Model/Actriz and Girl Pusher had a genuine element to them that I absolutely loved, and although this was my first time seeing Model/Actriz, I had heard a lot of great things about them. They have a very heavy noise and avant garde sound in a Death Grips kind of way.

Lastly, the crowd swelled for Girl Pusher. The vocalist Gabby brought an emotional and powerful presence to the stage. She keeps to herself, hunched over toward the mic, but moves throughout the stage. On stage was only Gabby and drummer Jarrod with a laptop of generated beats. Having a loop on stage would usually annoy me but it didn’t make them seem any less musical or bring them down. Instead, it elevated Gabby’s lyrics and Jarrod’s drums while they performed. Since they haven’t released any music for about two years, their set list has stayed the same since I last saw them around the time they released Groceries EP 2. Their signature closer, Alice Deejay’s “Better Off Alone,” is always a crowd-pleaser and after seeing them many times I am never disappointed. Even though it’s a cover, I had a lot of fun getting into it. My favorite song from this LA native duo was “Thanks Bitch” from their singles, because of the parallel relationship of the lyrics and the music and its overall depth that you can get lost in. I hope for new music from the duo in the near future.

Lastly, Minty Boi is a booking beast. Be sure to look out for his shows in the future!

title: Lil Yachty - Teenage Emotions // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia 

The Atlanta crooner with the voice of a cartoon cat disappoints on an in cohesive, unfocused, and hard-to-listen-to debut album, despite having released one of the most unique and interesting mixtapes of 2016.

One can argue right off the bat that the main problem that Lil Yachty has is a lack of overall talent and focus. There is no doubt that the teenager has the ability to construct a very infectious, silly, and fun track that manages to strip off all stereotypes of grit and darkness that is usually associated with hip hop, like enjoyably free spirited and energetic songs such as “Minnesota” and “1 Night.” However, on Teenage Emotions, the crooner does not manage to string together any worthwhile, digestible or entertaining tracks. In fact, on many instances the crooner’s amateurish charm has disappeared and instead the kid falls short of any kind of previously established value.

One can begin to pick apart the flaws of the record in terms of over-production, mismatched with the same foolish voice that he worked well with on the Lil Boat mixtape. Yachty’s voice made complete sense played on the production that was found on the mixtape: fun, bouncy, colorful production that was assembled with purposely mediocre mixing cuddled the squeaky, wobbly voice provided by the artist. The little mumbles of autotune that dressed Yachty’s voice worked well on simple, straightforwardly melodic beats found on Lil Boat. The rapper has instead abandoned the fun production in exchange for various types of big budgeted production that instead betrays his own unique, fun voice. The various beats, from the reggae-tinged “Better” to the slowly churning “Lady in Yellow,” and the tropical bore that is “Forever Young,” all make the rapper’s voice stand out violently like a sore thumb.
