There are various moments where the singing provided by Yachty is painful, and falls dramatically short of being as endearing and cute as it did on various moments on Lil Boat. The rapper clearly has to have the correct team behind him on the record in order for success to be achieved.

This can lead one to wonder, “Where the fuck was the Sailing Team?” all over this album. And when Yachty is not providing hard to hear vocals passed off as “singing,” he is falling completely short of being an adequate rapper. Of course, one has to consider that Lil Yachty is no Nas. Nobody is going to this record expecting bars to riddle the entire tracklist through and through. In fact there are gross, unexpected and disgusting mentions of incest and whore fucking throughout the record which leads one to believe that Yachty himself is not capable to carry himself over as a charismatic, slick, or even successful player or ladies man as he so fondly believes he is. “Peek a Boo” is a terrible misunderstanding and execution of a sex driven, dark and hard image. The hook on this track is not memorable as Yachty goes forward to annoy the listener with a horrible repetition of the same phrase, while managing to successfully stay off tempo throughout. The beat on the track is indefensibly boring and quite honestly garbage. Even the feature provided by Migos couldn’t save the track from being forgettable and unsettling. It sounds like Yachty was whispering in the booth to prevent from being found out by his friends for trying to make a banger. Instead of sticking to his guns, the rapper attempts to become something that he will probably never be (in terms of image).

The closest success that Yachty finds to having a banger on the record is “X Men,” but even then if one were to want to slap a slapper, they wouldn’t turn to this song before turning to one of the crooner’s contemporaries. On “DN Freestyle” Yachty sounds like he is angrily ranting on beat. It is as if the rapper has forgotten to truly stay on tempo, or somebody needs to tell his producers to throw the metronome on while the guy is recording. And it is very important to note that the bars don’t have to be extremely well written; Yachty is not putting out a lyrically potent record, but if one is to do this in the current age of hip hop there have to be memorable hooks, memorable slapping beats, memorable features, and very well constructed, vibe driven songs. There is a complete lack of focus throughout this record and nobody is helping Yachty with any of these things. The quality of the record must improve if anyone is willing to slap any of this guy’s records in the near future. It is certain that hype dies with time, and there will not be enough hype to protect Yachty from criticism for his mediocrity if there is no product to support said hype.

3/10

title: Kommode - Analog Dance Music // Album Review
content:
Written by Sam Celentano 

Kommode is not par for the course for avid fans of Eirik Glambek Bøe, who is predominantly known as half of the Norwegian folk duo, Kings Of Convenience. In his first full length release as Kommode, Bøe created Analog Dance Music with two goals in mind: to make art the individual can sing and dance to even amidst the turmoil and strife of the world today, and to break from the distractions of a digital society by recording with a band playing physical instruments (hence, “analog”). While these goals are largely accomplished, Analog Dance Music mainly plays it safe with a homogenous style and seems to straddle the border between ‘introspective work of art’ and ‘happy dance album.’

Analog Dance Music starts out strong on first listen - in fact, the listener is immediately confronted with three bouncing tunes complete with thick bass lines, tasteful embellishment, and a driving uptempo feel. Bøe’s soft vocals evoke the feeling of an intimate performance, as if you’re sitting in the living room with the musicians themselves. The issue of repetitiveness (as so commonly found in dance music) is eliminated from the instrumental breaks of each song; a phrase begins to grow stale just before a lush trumpet or a soft arpeggiator is brought into the fold and adds new intrigue to the sound. Even technically this album shines brightly, for it is engineered to near Steely Dan-type quality. This is music that demands to be listened to in headphones, or on quality speakers.

While the songs after “Lady-Logic” do not differ significantly in quality, they do not seem to differ in practically anything at all. That thumping bass, compressed percussion, sleepy vocals, and uptempo, common time beat lets one song flow to the next with a little too much ease, each new song nearly indistinguishable from the last. It is here after the first three songs that the originality of Kommode’s sound starts to break down, encroaching on one trick pony territory. Bøe’s lyrics only add to the problem, for though each song contains his signature vagueness and obscurity, a third of them are about dancing. More than halfway through the album, the initial groove and intrigue from one’s first listen is gone, and by the last song the listening experience is indiscernible from that of an hour long “House Music Mix For Studying - Vol 1” on YouTube.

Kommode effortlessly accomplishes their goal to get the listener moving, as the mix of pop, funk, and house paired with a finely polished mix makes for an easily danceable set of tunes. However, the lack of originality and deviation from form makes these songs fall into an unfortunate sameness that plagues the second half of the album, after an enjoyable first.

title: Kyle Dixon and Michael Stein @ The Ace Hotel (11/8/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Natalie Benudiz

For the first time ever, the composers behind the Stranger Things soundtrack played a live orchestration of the music onstage at the Ace Hotel on November 8. The duo Kyle Dixon and Michael Stein, members of the Australian synthwave band S U R V I V E, rose to astronomical acclaim for their dark and unnerving sonic landscapes. Anyone who has watched the show will agree that the soundtrack played a significant role in the aesthetic of the entire production. As someone who is completely obsessed with Stranger Things, the chance to hear the music live was enough to persuade me to drop $130 on one ticket to a completely sold out show (yeah, you read that right.) I was expecting a cosmic journey through the esoteric landscape of human existence.

…but, myself and 1,600 Stranger Things fans were bitterly disappointed. I wanted so badly to write a rave review of how amazing this show was… but I just can’t. So without further ado, let’s get down to (some ugly) business.

I’ll start with the fact that the set, which was listed as a two hour show, lasted exactly 46 minutes. Yup. 46 measly minutes. Compared to the show, the actual lengths of the soundtracks are one hour and eight minutes for Season 1, and one hour and 13 minutes for Season 2. I don’t need to do the math for you. This in itself was outrageous, purely in consideration of the amount the tickets cost (the cheapest seat was 42 dollars BEFORE scalpers and StubHub). For the price, they could have stayed onstage for AT LEAST a full hour before disappearing mysteriously into the curtains.

Speaking of curtains, let’s move to stage setup. The music itself is undeniably cool, so it would be reasonable to expect equally cool staging and lighting to add to the experience. This seemed to be too much to expect, as there was only two light riggings onstage and a synth setup, and that was it. The stage was completely bare. No lasers, no special effects, no projections, just some weak fog machines pitifully spitting out a pathetic amount of smoke. Watching two shadowy figures press buttons on synth boards while only two light patterns alternated back and forth was arguably as exciting as a CS31 lecture (and I’m talking Stahl, not Smallberg). Seriously, I was so bored without visual stimulus that I just started scrolling through Twitter, which was much more entertaining than anything happening onstage. This was all disappointing in itself, but not as disappointing as the missed opportunity to create an intensely spectacular lighting accompaniment that would have escalated the entire show. The whole thing was so visually static and boring that people got up and left. Seriously.

Now, I know what you’re thinking. You go to a show for the music and everything else is just extra. Oh, dear reader that probably doesn’t exist, I WISH the musical aspect was enough to save the show, but even that was a disappointment. I’ll start by saying that THEY NEVER EVEN PLAYED THE THEME SONG. At the end of the day, synth is synth, and to make it exciting is a hard task that seemed to be insurmountable for even Kyle Dixon and Michael Stein. They tweaked a few sounds here and there, added some eerie chorus vocals, but they played only two recognizable songs (“Agents” and “Eleven”). Soundtrack music often tends to sound the same, and there was no way to differentiate what I was hearing during the entire show except for the two instances that notable songs were played. Listening to straight synth for that long when it is hard to decipher what specifically you’re hearing is not the most enjoyable experience, and it ended up feeling like a chore.

Live orchestrations of soundtracks have been successfully done and are successfully done all the time. When done well, they are incredibly worth it. Take a page out of the Game of Thrones book. At the concert that was held over summer at the Forum, the composer interacted with the audience by sharing insight into the compositions, and the performers themselves had choreographed stage presence while scenes from the show were projected onto screens above the stage. Or even Alt-J, who are pretty undynamic as performers on a stage, make a point to create a visually captivating setup. One could argue that the point was aesthetic. But to be honest, aesthetic means nothing when your show falls flat. So argue all you want if you’re willing to pay $130 for a ticket to be bored for the ~aesthetic~

All in all, I truly wish I hadn’t spent the time, energy, or money to attend such a lackluster show. But I did, so all I can do now is write a bad review about it. And if anyone is even reading it at this point, feel free to let Kyle Dixon and Michael Stein know that they need to step up their game.

title: Filling the Void // TV Recommendations from UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written by Maddie Young 

Whether the news was broken to you by the disappearance of the “play next episode” button, or if you were left waiting far too long for the next season, it’s always unfortunate to fall in love with a show that was canceled. When the future of your favorite show is non-existent, it may be difficult to navigate your own fate. In these dark times, I advise fellow viewers to remember this old adage: it’s better to have loved and lost than to have never loved at all. Take whatever time you need to mourn your fallen series, but once you’re ready to move on, you’ll see that the internet is host to many other promising options. There are other fish in the sea — or should I say, “shows in the stream” — just waiting for you to find them, if you’d only open your eyes. I’ve lost a few favorites too soon myself and would like to share some recommendations for series with releases within the past year to fill the void.

If You Loved: Freaks and Geeks

Freaks and Geeks was Judd Apatow’s magnum opus, documenting the brutally realistic yet entertaining 80s high school experience from many perspectives. The show was cut short after just one season due to a combination of several tragic errors that led to low viewing rates. From a poor show time at 8 pm on a Saturday evening, when its intended audience was likely not home, to a three-week gap between the airing of two episodes, the show could not catch a break. Freaks and Geeks was canceled after only 12 of the 18 episodes had aired because it had such a rough time building a following. The show is now a classic, known for launching the careers of Seth Rogen, Martin Starr, Jason Segel, and, our very own UCLA film professor, James Franco.

Recommendation: American Vandal

Many are still heartbroken about this loss, and while no show can truly replace it, American Vandal comes damn close for younger generations. This Netflix mockumentary series cracks the case of who spray-painted large, red, phallic images on the cars in a high school parking lot. The show hones in on lead suspect Dylan Maxwell, the ringleader of the “Wayback Boys.” His squad is a group of “freaks” who are just as rowdy, crude, and unliked by their peers as Daniel and Lindsay’s gang from Freaks and Geeks. American Vandal does an excellent job of portraying what high school for recent graduates was like, complete with competitive water bottle flipping, tasteless 9/11 jokes, and trashy Instagram boomerangs. Check it out if you enjoyed Freaks and Geeks, but were too young to find it relatable.

If You Loved: Flight of the Conchords

New Zealand musical comedy duo Jemaine Clement and Bret McKenzie starred in and wrote for their own show, Flight of the Conchords. In the series, the two were in a band and had just moved from New Zealand to New York in search of fame and love. The partially improvised show, smattered with digs at romantically unaware men and clever songs, ran for two seasons, from 2007 to 2009. The pair halted the project for fear of dragging on too long — a move that was both a blessing and a curse to fans.

Recommendation: Portlandia

Once you’re over this loss, check out Portlandia. This IFC sketch comedy with graduated SNL star Fred Armisen is lauded for its tasteful mockery of hipsters and ultra-liberals that one might find in Portland, and has SEVEN WHOLE SEASONS available for viewing on Netflix. Never have your heart broken again with this solid watch to satisfy cravings for Flight of the Conchords’ jestful sense of humor.

If You Loved: Zach Stone is Gonna Be Famous

Bo Burnham’s first and only television series to date was ironically and unfortunately aired on MTV. The show, Zach Stone is Gonna Be Famous, followed recent high school graduate Zach Stone, who only wants one thing: to be famous. To achieve this, he hires a camera crew to document his life for the world to see, but has trouble maintaining a facade for the camera. In reality, Zach is horribly socially inept and has no understanding of what people would find interesting and cool enough to watch. While it may seem like an idea so crazy that it just might work to air such a program alongside exactly the type of show it pokes fun at, it ended up really just being a crazy idea. Bo’s show was cut off after just one season because it failed to find its appropriate audience.

Recommendation: Nathan For You

Of course, Bo Burnham has a few stand-up comedy specials to choose from if you’re missing his sense of humor, but if you’re craving the extra cringe-y-ness that Zach Stone provides, fear not! Nathan For You, a Comedy Central series, is an excellent alternative. The cold and alien host of this show, Nathan Fielder, finds real small businesses that are struggling and provides them with avant-garde business strategies to try as serious solutions. Some of these appalling fixes include fabricating a permanent, fake movie set around a Hollywood souvenir shop to attract star-struck customers and marketing furniture moving as an exercise craze to create a free labor force for a moving business. (Sidenote: said exercise craze had a spokesperson chosen for it, an entire book ghostwritten about it, and appeared on several real news channels.) If you liked Zach Stone is Gonna Be Famous because you like to cringe, this show is for you.
tags: zach stone is gonna be famous

title: Yung Lean - Stranger // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia

It has been a long while since Yung Lean has provided his cult following with something to mull over and cry to. I say “cry to” in the loosest sense possible, as the Sadboy themes that were prominent all over Lean’s first and second full length LPs were never truly emotionally impactful to begin with; they translated over as bouts of slow, audibly high, drowsily delivered rap flows. However, with Stranger, Leandoer has a chance to strip away most of the reverb that made his tracks indulgent and syrupy. In fact, the production on Warlord is what made that record one of my favorites of 2016. Now, less than two years later, Yung Lean forgives his producers from having to construct large, grandiose, enigmatic, and punishing cloud rap beats in exchange for layouts that are more melodic, full of bells, sobering, and minimalistic. “Red Bottom Sky” is an effort made by Lean to be significantly more melodic and structured than he usually is, as the Swede makes a valiant effort to sing profoundly and calmly throughout most of the track. This is a color that Lean has not really painted himself with, at least not in the endearing and determined manner he does in this song. The chorus is soft, simple, and prominent. On various fronts, Lean contains this type of energy throughout the album, as his vocals are never truly cloudy or as atmospheric as they were back in 2016.

“Ski Mask” is a brash, melodic unraveling of drug use and “laying low” as the hook repeats. Lyrically, Lean stays within the similar boundaries that he usually does as he presents his “reality” through a very fantastical, drug fueled, and hypnotic lens. The repetition of various words throughout the song prevent Lean from stumbling awkwardly across the track as he otherwise could be if he were to switch up his cadence every couple bars or so.

“Silver Arrows” is similar to “Red Bottom Sky” in how the flows are consistent and the beat is composed mainly of bubbling bass hits and slow, echoed bells and synths. There is not much going on in this song except for a couple small blossoms and crashes that appear before the chorus hits. “Metallic Intuition” is a track that proves to be a sort of weak point throughout the record. It is low-key, intimate, and simply straightforward, but the beat shows a lack of rhythm that has been prominent on the album so far. The bars are washed away in reverb and Lean can be hard to understand at certain points in the mix.

Many of the songs on this record are significantly easier to digest than other previous Yung Lean tracks on Warlord and even Unknown Memory. However, the payoff is significantly less; The intricacies found on instrumentals on Warlord and Unknown Memory made the songs unique in their own way and presented Lean in a nest of noise, massive energies, and tsunami sized winter vibes. Here, the winter tones are still prominent, yet the sweetness displayed through most of the bells and the light, bouncy synth bass that is found on almost every track here provides a stark contrast to what Lean was doing before. The happiness can be short lived, however, since the often minimal and skeletal beats that Lean plays around with do not provide much substance. Lean is therefore forced to use his voice as either a prominent instrument on the tracks or as a lyrical palette that describes his fantasies, his achievements, and his emotions. I must admit, that Lean does not provide either one of the aforementioned tasks in a fleshed out, well developed method. As a result, his songs often feel very mindless and off the cuff. A great example of this would be the track, “Salute/Pacman,” where Lean attempts to sing in a brash way in order to use his voice as an extra instrument on the sluggish, unadventurous beat. The lyrics are an endearing thank you to his fans, but they do not go deeper into his relationship with his fans or his perception of the people that put him where he is now other than that. “Drop It/Scooter” is a more appealing attempt at achieving what he aimed to do on “Salute/Pacman.” However, the metaphors to Johnny Depp and Freddie Kruger, and a short lived attempt to ride the same triplet flow popularized by Migos and Lil Uzi Vert, take away from the bravely yelled and howling chorus presented on the track.

“Hunting My Own Skin” is a better presentation of the energy given to listeners on “Red Bottom Sky,” laced over with icy, solid synth bells and atmospheric pads on top of a thumping kick pattern. It is a reminder that Lean had all the talent on his team to achieve the vision he presented early in the record; but it seems that he got carried away, or maybe even lazy, throughout the entire middle portion of the record. The album is a mixed bag, but it all ends up falling short of the marks that he set for himself on earlier records. I wouldn’t be surprised if many fans end up deserting the entire collective completely.

6/10

title: Alvvays @ The Roxy (10/23/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Ashley Hoffman

It was awkwardly a Monday night, but the matte-black Roxy was sold out for the dream-pop band Alvvays. Antisocialites, the group’s second album, was just released in September, three years after their debut Alvvays. Antisocialites distills the sound of their first album: overlaid harmonies with clean pop-rock instrumentals and repetitive beats, wrapped together and kept alive with Molly Rankin’s effortless yet strong vocals. Above all, the record sounds clean and deeply intentional, and this show only further emphasized that impression through Alvvays’ precise, largely emotionless performance.

The very adult audience for this show ranged from fans in their twenties to their sixties, mostly balancing around 30 to 40 year olds. The only two teenage girls I saw were standing with their mom. Many men and women donned plaid button-down shirts and glasses. “It’s indie music, what are you afraid of?” one thirty-something-year-old woman asked her friend, who was hesitating from cutting into the peaceful crowd. Someone else in the crowd asked, “How do you say their name?” The answer is “like always,” by the way.

Alvvays’ opener, an all-male indie four-piece called Nap Eyes, was a pleasant prelude. Their songs were enjoyable, not particularly unique but high quality. They kept thanking the audience for listening or paying any attention to them, and re-emphasizing that they’re called Nap Eyes, the long-haired bassist joking, “In case it slipped your mind.”

On the dot at 9:30 p.m., Alvvays sauntered on stage amid a monochrome backdrop which projected their name crookedly in massive block letters. The fan-favorite is definitely their lead singer and guitarist, Molly Rankin, a composed young woman with white-blonde hair that captured the colors of the stage lights. Despite being at the forefront for the band, she remained largely silent between songs. The other four members of the band barely engaged with the audience at all: a male guitarist in a black polo, a curly-haired female drummer, a bored male bassist, and a brunette female keyboardist with thick glasses. The five performers spread themselves far apart on the stage, just occasionally glancing at each other. Frankly, Alvvays looked like they were going through the motions to finish their jobs for the night, but their obvious over-rehearsal paid off in their sound.

The band shuffled the songs on their new album, for example, bouncing from “Plimsoll Punks” to “Lollipop (Ode to Jim)” to “Not My Baby.” They also added in some old hits including “Archie, Marry Me,” which brought out the most audience enthusiasm among bright yellow lights. Hats off to Rankin; her voice sounds just as clear and angelic live as recorded, if anything too covered by heavy instrumentals and dreamy reverb at times in concert. The overall sound was very similar to the record - the audio was no disappointment.

However, their performance seemed distant. It felt as if Alvvays was re-recording the album, going through the songs with wonderful precision, rarely commenting. Rankins’s occasional transitions were at most brief sentences, like “Mind if we play an escapist ballad for you?” before “Forget About Life,” or introducing “Dreams Tonite” with simply, “Time to get romantic.” Even their few moments of grandeur, a bold drum solo in “In Undertow” or an extra high note, appeared calculated. No one broke the stiff facade. The bassist looked so underwhelmed at times that he stared out, mouth agape.

I don’t mean to imply that the band was rude; they simply seemed reserved, or disconnected from the room. The performers rarely smiled, but when Rankin did chat she put on a quick grin. Also, her hands are full, literally; her guitar I’m sure takes much of her attention. Their rigidity also didn’t stop the fans from being fairly enthused. Only about 45 to 50 minutes in, Alvvays announced that they just had one song left, which the audience actually booed. The moment the final pre-encore song, “Party Police,” finished, Alvvays hustled offstage without even looking at the audience, but one fan still playfully yelled the chorus lyric back to them: “You don’t have to leave!” Aside from that booing, the crowd was nodding throughout the show, even jumping, and consistently resembled a whack-a-mole of recording devices, iPhones peeking up to take a picture or two before retreating.

NPR’s First Listen reported that Rankin described Antisocialites as a “fantasy breakup arc,” but live it felt more like when you’ve talked about a breakup so many times that you no longer draw any emotion when explaining it. And that’s fine; being loose or messy is not their scene. The impression left on me was just a numb performance, bored but not bad.

People go to concerts for different reasons. If you go to a show to hear a band live and just focus on the music, you should definitely go to an Alvvays show, the music was superb. If you just love the concert experience and want to meet fellow fans, sure, go. Or if you’re in love with Rankin as so many other fans are, go (but don’t try to kiss her like some jerk did in Belgium this September – respect, people!). However, based on this performance, don’t go if you expect audience engagement, interaction with the musicians, or being entertained by bold, outgoing personalities. Personally, I’m the kind of audience member looking for something more than just the record, and I didn’t really get that. Alvvays is very talented but I’ll likely skip their next show and just listen to their recordings at home instead – they sound the same.

title: Escape: The Psycho Circus 2017 // Show Review
content:
Photo Courtesy of aLive Coverage for Insomniac

Written by Jenny Tong and Alexis Chung 

Escape: The Psycho Circus was a halloweekend well-spent in the NOS Events Center in San Bernardino. At the largest halloween festival in North America, comprising of four stages - the Slaughterhouse, Ghouls’ Graveyard, The Chopping Block, and Cannibals’ Tea Party - sending beats down concurrently, we had to shuttle ourselves back and forth between the stages to catch all the artists that we wanted to see. The event setup lived up to its name; we were truly convinced that we were part of a movie set in a circus - think Christmas bulbs, fairground lights, circus tents, carousels and performers.

THE VIP EXPERIENCE

We enjoyed the concert at the VIP section, which was an area to the front left of each stage with seats in an outdoor patio, abundance of photo opportunities and refreshments, as well as wifi and electrical plugs.

There was also a sectioned off area next to the crowd, which allowed those with VIP wristbands to get a close view of the performers but also have enough room to move around and dance. The convenience and comfortability of it all definitely merits the extra price of a VIP ticket.

THE MUSIC

The line-up this year matched the unprecedented scale of the event that hosted 125,000 costumed fans - absolutely mind-blowing! Ranging from trap-heavy Flosstradamus and techno-oriented Pan-pot, to deep house legends Duke Dumont and Jamie Jones, there was a comprehensive selection of 75 headliners under the electronic dance music umbrella. Out of serendipity, we found ourselves at Bauuer’s set at the Chopping House. The New York native  knew how to throw a hardstyle party, enrapturing the tent with flaming-hot beats and cross-genre mixes (a.k.a. “headbangers”). Among many others, R3hab, Tïesto, Don Diablo, and Afrojack had all begun my electronic dance music journey with me, so I had an overly joyous moment to myself when I met some of them in real life (or as Alexis would put it, “actually fangirling”). Finally, NGHTMRE, one of my favorite emerging artists, owned the last set at the Ghouls’ Graveyard stage, which made a perfect end to the festival on Saturday night.

Photo Courtesy of Da Black Swan for Insomniac

THE VISUALS

Photo Courtesy of Jake West for Insomniac 

Although the photo has captured the light arrangements to the best of its abilities, it still does not compare to the effect it achieved in real life. Housing 375 lights and 24 lasers, the performances were taken to another level of excitement and intensity. We highly recommend getting a pair of kaleidoscope glasses too for the full sensory experience (we found ours on Amazon); it is definitely worth the investment.  

ADD-ONS

Before we saw any artists, we were fortunate enough to experience the horrifically immersive environment of the Asylum, where we were first dressed in straitjackets and a mask before we entered the world of gore and blood. There was something new with every corner we turned - bleeding nurses chopping up their patients, creepy creatures shouting in your ear, and circus performers twisting and contorting in ways that were not humanly possible.

Photo Courtesy of aLive Coverage for Insomniac

The production quality was amazing, I had to constantly remind myself that it was all manufactured to keep myself from getting too scared. The makeup, costumes, and set design made it feel like we were in a horror film, keeping ourselves on our toes so we would be prepared for the next scene we were about to experience. Adding onto the surprise factor, our straitjackets fell off mid-way because they “weren’t made for small frames” like ours.

We were also able to experience the Shanghai Surprise speakeasy, a word-of-mouth bar that was only accessible through a refrigerator door in a Chinese restaurant’s lobby. Inside there was a bar serving festive drinks, huge neon Chinese characters, and chairs to lounge and rest in.

Photo Courtesy of aLive Coverage for Insomniac

VERDICT

Escape was both of our first electronic dance music festivals in California, setting the bars high for future events that we will attend. Having that said, one thing we we wish we could have also experienced was the underground scene in Factory 93. Nonetheless, the contagious exuberance of the crowd as well as the new music that we have discovered and fell in love with (welcome to the trap scene @ Alexis) will remain in our hearts forever. Till next time!

title: Interview with Vasudeva @ ArcTanGent Festival 2017
content:
Interview by Layla Moheimani 

Photos by Ed Sprake

August 19, 2017 - Fernhill Farm, Bristol, UK

In previous decades of rock music, the term “power trio” would refer to acts like Cream and the Jimi Hendrix Experience; a tight rhythm section supporting a superstar guitarist frontman. These days, and especially within the realm of what some might refer to as math or progressive rock, the most exciting three-piece bands are those in which all the instruments are perfectly balanced whilst still maintaining their individual complexities (see also my writings on Town Portal and Alpha Male Tea Party). Niche music festivals can often run the risk of redundancies within the lineups, but during both of my years at ArcTanGent Festival Vasudeva has always been a standout. Two-guitar bands are certainly not a new revelation but Vasudeva holds a high distinction in that each part truly carries its own voice. There is no lead or rhythm guitar between the two, just lyrical lines that flow seamlessly into one another without ever losing their distinct personalities. The musical chemistry which all three members of Vasudeva share stems largely from the fact that they are friends first and bandmates second. I sat down with guitarist Grant Mayer and drummer Derek Broomhead in their mansion-tent at ArcTanGent Festival in Bristol over the summer to discuss the band’s early development, their love of Blink-182 and the release of their new album.

Layla: When did you guys first start playing together and at what point did it become what it is now?

Derek: I was playing in a band with Corey [Mastrangelo, Vasudeva guitarist]. We were playing post-hardcore when we were fifteen years old. And we knew of Grant and we asked him to join the band. He played one rehearsal and was like “Nah,” he just dipped. Then three years later we all realized we were playing music alone. So we [decided] “Let’s do this together.” And it turned into something that we were proud of.

L: It’s just a band of three people playing alone in a room together.

D: Yeah. Before we had our bass player it was just me, Grant and Corey figuring things out. Grant was just learning how to tap. But because of his piano background [he] was able to figure it out really quickly and in a unique way.

L: What were some of the bands you were listening to early on?

D: Obviously, Minus the Bear. We were big into Maps & Atlases -

Grant: toe.

D: Yeah, we were listening to a lot of toe. Just music that makes you feel good, nothing too techy or thrashy. Although we were listening to Veil of Maya a lot and that is like the heaviest band ever.

L: You were like, “Okay, that’s the threshold we are not crossing.”

D: laughter Yeah, it’s just something we’d always throw on and have a laugh to.

G: That’s the fucking breakdown kings right there. Those breakdowns are the best I’ve ever heard.

D: Yeah, totally.

L: Your live setup is unique in that the bass lines in your music are very prominent but you don’t actually have a bassist onstage. How did that come about?

D: My good buddy Chris Ratay, we’d always played together but never started a band. There was this one day, the three of us were jamming and I invited [Chris] over and he was like, “I think this is sick.” He was actually a guitar player but he picked up the bass to fill the slot. We were with him for two and a half years and when he was leaving the band, we still had a lot of opportunities and were like, “What are we gonna do? We can’t replace -” Because when you’re in a band, it’s really hard to find someone that fits the mold because you have to live with those people essentially.

L: Yeah, especially because your band isn’t a standard operation either. You can’t just hold an audition and have some dude show up.

G: Yeah, I’ve known Corey since I was seven. We’re not even friends, we’re fucking brothers. It’s such a deeper level of relationship that I can’t even describe.

L: How did you guys first meet at age seven?

G: First day of school on the bus. Classic suburban shit. Bonded on Blink [182].

L: Were either of you even really into music at that age?

G: Yeah, we loved Blink.

D: We all grew up on pop-punk. We were all skater shitheads to the core. Grant and Corey have known each other since they were children and I’ve known Corey since I was maybe 13. I was starting a band and we were pretty into the emo thing and my friend Mark was buddies with Corey. He brought him in and we instantly clicked. I think when I was 13 or 14 he stayed at my house for two months. We never separated. We were that close right off the bat.

L: Wow. And it’s actually sustained since then.

D: Yeah, absolutely. And then I met Grant. The thing about me and Grant is we’re the exact same person but in a strange, different way.

L: What instruments did you guys start on that led you to what you play in the band now? 

D: My dad always wanted me to play guitar. I learned a bunch of blues tunes on guitar when I was 5 or 6 and liked it a lot but I was the kid just banging out rhythm from Day 1. I asked my dad for years to get a drum kit and it got to the point where [I decided to] save up money so I had to work and basically do things for him to show I was dedicated to playing drums. I bought my first drum kit when I was 10 and it was a piece of shit. We bought it on eBay for maybe $300 but I was proud of that thing. I just remember jamming out to Blink when I was 10, trying to learn what Travis Barker was all about. That was a serious learning experience for me. Just to be on your own doing exactly what you want and figuring it out without anyone telling you what to do.

L: It has a very organic feel to it.

D: Yeah, I guess. I don’t think I ever wanted to be in a band. It was just something I had to do. I never looked up to rock stars aside from Blink. I never [thought], “I want to be a sick drummer.” I just kept playing. I guess I was 14 when I decided I wanted to do this for a living. It just made the most sense and it’s been the most fun. Seriously, I could be doing bullshit but I’m out here having the best time. To Grant What about you? You started on piano, right?

G: Yeah, it was a similar thing. My dad played guitar but he didn’t want me to play guitar. He pushed piano and saxophone onto me but I always wanted to play guitar. So I ended up teaching myself guitar while [taking] more strictly regimented lessons for the other two instruments. I gave up sax earlier, then gave up piano and focused on guitar and just taught myself how to play that with the tools I’d learned from the other mediums.

L: You guys have toured extensively over the past seven years. Would you consider that to be more of your [focus] while releasing records intermittently or do you want to spend more time as a recording band as well?

G: I think it’s 50/50, honestly. They are both so necessary and I see them as such fundamental parts of what we’re doing. At this point it’s cut even down the board. The more we tour the more I feel like we’re neglecting recording. And the more we’re recording [the more] I feel like we’re neglecting touring.

D: Yeah. Trying to find that balance is hard.

G: But we’re definitely eager to get back in[to the studio] because it was a long time coming for [No Clearance, the new album].

L: Yeah, it was like three or four years.

G: Exactly. So we’re not trying to push that again.

D: The thing is, we always have music. We sit on our music for so long. We could record a lot right now. It’s just about finding the structure and the time to get to business.

L: Were the songs on No Clearance ones that had been piling up over time?

D: Yeah. I feel like with a lot of those songs, we reworked them to where you can’t even recognize them.

G: We definitely had a cohesive idea towards the whole thing. We picked and chose what we thought would be a good album together, you know? We wanted an album [where] each song would speak for itself. We didn’t want an album of a couple singles. We struggled even choosing the singles as we released them. It was arbitrary. Like, that’s what you have to do but the whole album’s a goddamn single for us.

L: Did you guys have a different intention going into this one over the previous one?

D: I feel like we learned a lot from our first release in terms of structure and songwriting. We really wanted to write songs that made sense and never lost a vibe, but could just keep it going.

L: So Grant, why did you want to start tapping in the first place? What brought that on?

G: Definitely just listening to the bands we mentioned before. Like, Minus and Maps. And I was like, “Yeah that’s cool. I could definitely do that for sure.” and I just [started doing] it.

D: Every[day at] 5:45 in the morning you’d just be ripping a waterfall with Corey, learning how to tap.

G: Yeah, we were teaching ourselves together, the two of us.

L: How do you and Corey put those two parts together?

G: It’s a lot of back and forth. The more we’ve grown, we’ve learned to really sit and complement each other. That’s always a growing concern of ours. We’re always trying to push the limits of that, just playing your place in the song. I feel like [with] some of our earlier stuff, people almost put the math rock connotation to it because it’s two intricate guitar parts going over one another. But at the same time, it’s all 4/4. It’s all verse chorus verse, traditional song-structure. It’s just intricate. We’ve really tried to hone the songwriting process and complement each other rather than compete.

L: I feel like with two-guitar bands it can be all across the spectrum as far as that balance is concerned. But you two actually have your own really distinct voices within the music, which is super cool.

D: Yeah, I would agree. These are the most unique players that I’ve hung out with. It’s really cool to be in a band with someone that you actually love as a person [who] can also blow your mind every single time. It’s always fucking sick.

You can read my review of Vasudeva’s set at last year’s ArcTanGent Festival here and watch video from the London show of their 2017 UK tour here. Keep up with music and upcoming tour dates from Vasudeva here.

title: Fenech-Soler - Zilla // Album Review
content:
Written by Beliz Urkmez

Fenech-Soler’s third album Zilla comes out at a crucial time for the band of two brothers, who lost their bassist and drummer. It departs from their earlier psychedelic, glam pop influences and embarks on a more energetic pop vibe. The album seems fresh and bright, however it struggles with identity and falls short of expectations after the second half.

The album starts off with the pop banger “Kaleidoscope.” It is a great start to the album with your regular pop sounds of the summer. It differs because the music has more depth to it on the background with vocal effects and unique keyboard riffs. The lyrics do not offer much but you don’t expect it to. It is fun and refreshing.

The second song “On Top” follows the same themes but with the addition of 90s pop vibes. Just like “Night Time TV” following it, the song is filled with funky instruments and a banging chorus. Both these songs sound like they could be played in a club because of their ambient sounds and surprisingly are the two best songs off the album, even though they’re not singles.

The second hit off the album, “Conversation,” unfolds as a better “Kaleidoscope.” The powerful piano with the claps and electro pop drums is reminiscent of Foster the People’s Torches and delivers a fresh sound. It has everything that a hit song needs and succeeds in becoming one of the most memorable songs of the album.

The album has two instrumental intervals called “Zilla I” & “Zilla II.” They are overall very good instrumentals with deep sounds and voice effects. Considering the whole album though, they do not represent much and does not fit the theme. “Zilla I” feels like a pause between “Conversation” and “Grace” rather than a cohesive transition between the two songs. “Zilla II” on the other hand, while more lively, fails to add depth to the album.

Following “Zilla I,” the album starts to lose its energy and novelty. While “Grace” adds a difference with its explosive beginning and calm guitar ending, there is too much going on in the song. “Cold Light” and “Undercover” drop down the tempo with an attempt at romance but falls short of their promises and comes off as unexciting.

The three ending songs, “Touch,” “Be Someone,” and “From Afar,” have the same formula that the brothers used in the entire album with the same electronic build up followed by uninspiring lyrics. Unfortunately, the same sounds that seem fresh at the beginning start to feel old mostly because apart from the music, the album conceptually does not have much to offer. Fenech-Soler embarked upon a new musical journey for themselves with Zilla, but they still have a long way to go before they find their identity.

title: cybersex - blackbear // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia

This is probably going to be the most forgettable trap, “contemporary R&B” record of the year. Blackbear is a up and coming crooner out of Florida, fresh off a couple mixtapes dropped within the last couple years. After sitting through the entire piece, my main gripe with this record is that the artist truly lacks any sort of unique, revealing quality to his music. From the opener, “Gucci Linen,” blackbear sifts through a run of the mill trap beat; boastful and braggadocios, yes…entertaining and rich with personality, no. I could go on a limb and state that this is the most obvious attempt at a label attempting to capitalize off of an artist that is more generic than G Eazy. 

There is not a single redeeming quality in this album. “If you rock Yeezys, we can’t be friends,” and similar one liners that reek of forgettable, boring, and overly materialistic ideas are riddled over beats that are certainly unrecognizable in a pack of online YouTube ‘FREE (INSERT RAPPER NAME HERE) TYPE BEATS.’ “Bright Pink Tims” is a boring excuse for a fashion driven banger that could never rival anything similar to “RAF” by A$AP Rocky. “Playboy Shit” is an overly sugared, criminally absentminded and undercooked song with a mediocre hook and thumping kick drum. “I need a couple bands before we talk,” “That’s some playboy shit right there,” “Swear to God I got a lot of money,” and other pathetic bars that do not do anything but make audience’s eyes roll. 

Blackbear arguably does not have a voice that commands or stirs emotions in the listener; matter of fact, the remedial chorus gets repeated about four times on the track, and his singing voice honestly does not draw the slightest need for such repetition in the listener. Aesthetically, the album is nothing but glossy synths and rattling trap percussion, with blackbear’s slightly autotuned crooning spewed all over the beats in organized, cabinet filed fashion. “Sex on the couch, it was cool, it was basic,” and many other attempts at being truly sexy, truly passionate, and truly anything fall flaccid, weak, and unentertaining. Blackbear enlisted the services of the “FKA Twigs for normies” and discount Rihanna, Tinashe, for another ultra basic bitch chorus on “Up in This.” The subtly corny and glossy hook, “We up in this bitch now,” paired with ugly stretched vocalizations around the 2:50 mark is certainly not enough to make listeners remember who this newfound crooner is. 

The charisma that the rapper brings about on this record is about as potent as a Macy’s Calvin Klein styrofoam mannequin torso. The track “Anxiety” bends to the trend of making notable references and building song topics around the mental hell that some people face on a daily basis. “You give me anxiety,” followed by some cheap, dollar store quality bubble bass drops and glitched, annoying vocalizations give no true experience, storytelling quality, or feeling for listeners. There’s nothing more repugnant or disgusting than taking the true experiences of a mental illness for garbage, trendy, and basic music. Matter of fact, blackbear has the guts to claim that he “sets trends” on the track “Bright Pink Tims,” a claim so ridiculous and so preposterous that anyone who can bring themselves about to believe such a fib would probably claim that Santa is still going to bring them their Call of Duty game for Christmas. (Hey, I’m not bagging on you Santa, you fucking rock). The putrid howls that pour out of this empty husk of an “artist” give no reason for letting up or going easy on the record. 

There is, aesthetically, no reference or slight construction of a world around, and the beats give room for creativity to do so, but blackbear would rather remind you that he wakes up with money and gets paid to perform. After listening to this watered down, substance-less record, one gets the premonition that, “Yea, sure, maybe blackbear is an industry plant, a meat puppet, set abound to make as much money as possible before he is replaced with the next faceless meat puppet in line.” It’s cruel to consider such a thing, but not once on this soul forsaken album does blackbear make reference to his personality, his well being, his personal life, his upbringing, his hometown, his aspirations. Fuck no, blackbear would rather let you know that he has fucked the same women that Chris Brown, Jared Leto, Lil Uzi Vert, G-Eazy, etc., have fucked. Apparently, like his album, blackbear loves to revel in leftovers. Blackbear loves being the subpar, unoriginal carcass that provides empty aesthetic via edgy album art, and not much else. Sitting through cybersex, which again, great edgy album name, is like sitting through the leftovers of every single trap artist from 2010 to the present day; and all these leftovers are cold and have mold growing on them.

#basicbitchmusic/10

title: Knox Fortune with Banes World @ The Troubadour (12/4/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Elisa Park

Kevin Rhomberg’s performance as “Knox Fortune” was greeted by a packed audience anticipating his live solo debut at The Troubadour.

Opening the show was Long Beach native Shane Blanchard, who performs under the stage name Banes World. Co-signed to Tyler, The Creator, Banes World is a rising star in the Los Angeles indie pop scene, known for his hazy jazz-tinged tunes. A considerable number of fervent fans showed up to see him play, and many audience members sang along word-for-word to several of his songs.

The overarching theme of his performance was lush tones accompanying dispirited lyrics about love and longing. Popular tracks like “Drowsy” and “You Say I’m in Love” were extremely well received, and Blanchard had the opportunity to showcase his guitar skills with refreshing hints of both blues and jazz lingering in the instrumentals. Vocally, Blanchard had impressive control and a superb smooth tone that emoted an air of nostalgia.

By the time Knox Fortune took the stage, the room was filled with both curiosity and excitement. He is most notable for producing tracks for Vic Mensa and co-producing Joey Purp’s iiiDrops mixtape, but rose to solo prominence for singing the hook on Chance the Rapper’s “All Night.” However, aside from a quick thirty second snippet of “All Night” to get the crowd moving, this show primarily featured his first solo album Paradise, revealing Knox as an upbeat, indie pop artist.

The performance exuded liveliness and excitement; Knox made an effort to maintain a spirited atmosphere that complimented his light, synth-based beats. However, in many songs, including “I Don’t Wanna Talk About it” and “Seaglass,” the vocal backing tracks were quite overbearing and it became difficult to pinpoint the actual live vocals. “Help Myself” was a fun, airy electro-pop tune, but unfortunately the vocals throughout the night were quite pitchy and slightly off.

Having listened to Paradise prior to the show, the vocals seemed considerably modified in the studio version with heavy effects, which accounted for the disparities heard during the live show. The songs “Torture” and “Keep You Close” were particularly pitchy, but did show definite signs of potential as catchy pop tunes with mass media appeal. “24 Hours” too showcased Knox’s bouncy beats mixed with fuzzy vocals and carefree lyrics. By far his best performance was “Lil Thing”—a sweet, breezy mix that supplemented his high pitched, effeminate vocals.

Overall, Paradise is a lighthearted encapsulation of pop tinged with synth, electronic and even a bit of rock; Knox Fortune provides a lively and sincere stage presence that is refreshing to see. With a serious effort to improve live vocals, or incorporate more audio effects as heard in the studio versions, he could quite possibly possess the tools for creating a popular act.

title: UCLA Radio’s Top 10 Albums of 2017
content:
We asked our DJs to list their favorite albums of 2017 and these are our top 10 albums of the year. While many great artists and bands came back this year (looking at you LCD Soundsystem and Feist), here are the albums that we couldn’t stop spinning on and off air. Shouts out to another fabulous year of music 💋

10. Toro y Moi - Boo Boo

- “Should be at #1, I listen to this album all the time. The instrumentation on this album has a really unique feel to it – it seems like every time I listen to a song I hear some little part that I didn’t notice before.” - Fernando Fine

9. Kevin Morby - City Music

- “It’s about living in a city. All of the attendant troubles, hopes and dirty dreams. About being on the wrong side of hope but knowing how to get back. It’s fucking ace.” - Ian Webb, UCLA Radio Alum

8. Thundercat - Drunk

7. Sampha - Process

- “This album is brilliant. From the moment it released in February to now, I’ve been playing this album daily front to back. The record has this impact that I’ve heard been called the “Post-Blonde Era” impact. Much like SZA’s Ctrl, this record plays very much like Blonde, except it really emphasizes Sampha’s ability to construct a very vibrant world within not just a record, but a song as well. On records like “Blood On Me” and “Reverse Faults,” Sampha does an incredible job at using his voice as a part of the song’s production before actually singing the song, and encompassing the character he portrays. And to me, this is what separates him from other artists, because he is able to not only write such vivid stories (which also really draws me to his music too) but he is able to create a whole world within his music…” - Daniel Leka

6. Mac DeMarco - This Old Dog

- “That’s my boy ;’)” - Chris Laganiere, UCLA Radio Alum

5. BROCKHAMPTON - Saturation Trilogy

4. Tyler, the Creator - Flower Boy

- “Tyler’s most complete album to date. Blurs the lines between genres and showcases great musical talent all around.” - Skyler Mizokami

3. Lorde - Melodrama

- “Um, because Lorde writes about the vulnerability of young adulthood in a way that is both exhilaratingly dance-tastic and hella poignant? Melodrama is the perfect soundtrack for breaking free from heartbreak.” - Alexa Lee

2. SZA - Ctrl

- “Find me one person who doesn’t like this album.” - Andy Talajkowski
- “Every song is the song of our generation.” - Jeremy Elder

1. Kendrick Lamar - DAMN.

- “YAH.” - Jason Mally

title: “Genre Confused” - An Interview with Girl Friday
content:
Interviewed by Lillian Stanwick

The members of Girl Friday have long hesitated to define their genre of music. On Bandcamp, they are self-described as “genre confused.” On Facebook, you’ll find a question mark instead of the name of a definitive style of music. But don’t mistake their genre ambiguity as a lack of certainty. The women of Girl Friday without a doubt know who they are and what their music means.

Lead vocalist Natalie Morace and Libby Hsieh (bass) initially met at a show where they found themselves outside the venue, bonding over their mutual disdain for the excessive machismo of the artists displayed on stage. They later met lead guitarist Vera Ellen Williams at a house show on the East Side.

Vera: We jammed immediately. We met because we were gonna play together, we didn’t meet as friends who were like, “Oh yeah, let’s just hang out and play music…”

About a month ago, rhythm guitarist Sierra Scott joined the group, a much-welcomed addition to the trio.

Vera: It’s been so much better having a second guitarist, it feels very good.

The original three members seem to agree that having a second guitarist has benefited their sound, especially on their recently released single “12 Hour Turnaround.”

Natalie: When doing it [the song] originally, it was a little softer, and then obviously we didn’t have a second guitarist, so we always felt like it wasn’t full enough. But what’s rad is now, when we get to perform it, it sounds way more like a banger because there’s actual support.

The new single, now available on Spotify and Bandcamp, is a strong first release from the band. With its pithy lyrics and exhilarating outro, “12 Hour Turnaround” represents Girl Friday’s dedication to smart verses and uninhibited performance.

Libby: The song is basically about that idea how when you’re in a relationship, or you’re seeing someone, men always assume, they kind of play girls by being super catering to the emotional side…they kind of like thinking that you want a deep relationship, but the song is taking that and subverting it … It’s about hooking up.

Vera: So your bed has a ‘12 Hour Turnaround.’

Natalie: This person is coming in and out of your room like a hotel.

To say the song takes a deprecatory attitude towards men would perhaps be a little mild.

Libby: The original one [lyric] was like, “Fuck me sideways or get out of the way”…. and one of them is like, “The way your words need a fresh castration”… just like cut the shit and stop leading me on.

Natalie: It captures the variation in our sound, which is playing on femininity and the more masculine, aggressive side of that coin.

The band blends provocative lyrics with a mockery of cloying archetypes surrounding femininity in their other songs as well.

Natalie: At times we’ll talk about homicide with a very fun upbeat.

Although the members Girl Friday remain undecided on their choice of genre, explaining that:

Vera: We’re still new. We want to be secure in what our sound is before we come forth and say, “This is the type of band we are.”

Their commitment to raw, genuine songwriting and performance counters this ambiguity. The members of the band share a mutual admiration for Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth, whose sound has been described as "somehow effortless but also profoundly charged and energetic.”

Libby: I just hope that we reach that level because the best performances I’ve ever seen are the ones where you can tell that this is what they’re meant to do because they’re so engrossed in playing.

Sierra: There are certain songs when we play where we’ll all look at each other and realize we’re all completely in the zone and we’re on a different level, and there are some where we felt we kind of need to mean what we’re playing more.

Libby: We want people to believe it.

Vera: A lot of what’s cool is apathy and to just play and not really mean what you say and not really have any important message and just be like, “Oh, I’m playing music but I don’t really care about this.” What we hope to achieve is to bring a lot of…energy on stage and perform like, “Hey, we want to be here and this is our favorite thing in the world to do and thank you for letting us do it.”

Girl Friday’s self-awareness and fervent dedication to passionate playing is exciting coming from such a newly minted band. This spirit can be seen especially in the members’ attitude towards what many would falsely assume to be the band’s defining feature: they’re all women. In addressing this characteristic, they recognize its limitations and exceptions, showing once again a mature understanding of the elements that affect their music and drive them forward as a (girl) band.

Vera: What’s really fucked up about being in a “girl band” is that you’re automatically politicized so it’s like you’re gender specified, and now you’re representing all females because you’re in a “girl band,” but you don’t say “boy band.”

Natalie: It’s demoralizing. “Female rock artist event” … c'mon can’t we just play?

Libby: You only thought of us because we’re all girls, c'mon do you not like the music just with that, but it’s also good because it’s good to see females on stage.

Vera: It’s something we’re really proud of and we want to be political and we want to be activists. So it’s something we’re gonna run with and talk about a lot.

Sierra: It’s been nice for me at least that there feels like there’s a different energy sort of when you’re playing with people with a shared experience. I feel less intimidated sometimes compared to playing with guys.

Natalie: As women there’s this idea that you just have to be showing off your skills on the stage, but that’s bullshit because there’re so many bands with dudes showing off their chords and the lyrics and vocals are really basic… so with all that in mind it’s like being in a group with each other, we don’t feel weird like you’ve got to show off to make yourself seem worthy of belonging.

Vera: It’s the greatest feeling in the world playing with a bunch of females, it’s so empowering and beautiful and fucking cool because there’s no ego. There’s definitely a different energy playing with women I’ve found. Which has only been positive for me.

Girl Friday will soon be releasing an EP under the label Economy Music.

They will be playing a semi-secret show hosted by Make Out Music on Friday, December 1.

title: The Cults @ The Teragram Ballroom (11/7/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Breanna Nery

The Cults have come back from a four year wait with their latest album Offering, released October 2017. Since their debut in 2010, the duo Brian Oblivion and Madeline Follin have released three albums, temporarily broke up as a band (and as a couple), and are now embarking on a nationwide tour.

LA was the second of three Southern California stops The Cults made. The day before, The Cults visited Santa Ana at the Constellation Room, where lead singer Follin noticed several dedicated fans who came back for the second show. Their dedication didn’t go to waste, as two special surprises happened at The Cult’s LA show. First, The Cults debuted the trippy and surreal music video for their song “Right Words” off of Offering. Second, the crowd also got the chance to celebrate Follin’s birthday where everyone sang-along as Follin was gifted with an adorable donut decorated cake.

The band played hits primarily from their latest album Offering. The upbeat and whimsical songs, a departure from the darker tones of their 2013 album Static, were accompanied with a colorful projection backdrop that illuminated Follin, Oblivion, and the rest of the band. When it was time for the crowd to finally go outside, The Cults appropriately ended their set with their breakout hit “Go Outside” to close off the night.

title: Lil Pump Mixtape // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez

Let’s get stupid for a minute. Let’s get significantly stupid. It’s gonna be fun.

I knew exactly what I was walking into with this self titled Lil Pump tape. The youngest flexer at only 19 years old from Miami, Florida arrives on his purple, lean soaked jet ski to deliver a series of short, focused, pummeling and overbearing trap anthems for anyone ready to get extremely stupid. It is extremely safe to say that Lil Pump is definitely not staying in a unique lane, as the teen stays well within the boring boundaries that trap has established for the last ten years or so. Cocaine, Balmains, wild sex, and a whole lot of overdone, layered ad-libs find a cozy home on this tape. It is not anything that is meant to challenge a listener; it is a tape that fits snuggly in the current SoundCloud landscape alongside other unconditional names like XXXTentacion, Ski Mask the Slump God and Smokepurpp (who also finds himself spitting incessantly annoying ad-libs all over this record). 

In terms of production, the tired, SoundCloud formulas are repeated: overblown bass, sometimes to the point of being overwhelmingly distorted and suffocating, runs underneath repeated, atonal instrumental riffs provided by bells or spooky sounding synths and trap style drum production. The beats do not vary distinctly on many of the cuts found on this tape. It is evident that Lil Pump knows exactly what he is dealing with, who his audience is, and what they are so thirsty to take in. He keeps his features relatively sedated, as most of them fail to outperform and outshine the youngster on his own tape. Lil Yachty on “Back” reminds us once again that he is capable of rapping on tempo, while Gucci Mane stays collected and supportive on “Youngest Flexer.” In fact, the pairing could be some kind of torch passing moment, as Gucci Mane’s repetitive and slouched demeanor fits as a polar opposite to the energy and noisy presentation Lil Pump comes through with. It is easy to personally prefer the lyrics that Lil Pump delivers when paired alongside the sleepy coma that Gucci Mane woke up from.

The fact that the original songs that Lil Pump blew up with are found on this tape is a little disappointing, but aside from this matter the tape proves to be an enjoyable, sugary pill of stupidity. It is a tape that annoys if one allows themselves to be annoyed by it. It serves the purpose that not many rappers are prepared to take on in a natural sense; Lil Pump naturally fits this bill. Everything from the production to the vocals and lyrics fulfill their intended tasks, and Lil Pump’s enthusiasm for xanax and “thots” never lets up during the duration of the entire project. It is something to throw on when the cares in the world are long gone and the night is ready to be torn up. Songs like “Molly,” “Boss,” and “Gucci Gang” stay consistent and ridiculous; Songs like “Flex Like Ouu” and “D Rose” were produced with obviously lower budgets but still present a reminder as to why Lil Pump is able to bring listeners an entire tape ready to tear foundations out of apartment parties and entire suspensions out of vehicles. “Iced Out” probably wins the award for best, most balanced, and easy to stomach beat, as the bass is just slightly understated and the popping mallets all over the beat add a distinct texture to the track. Yet the considerations truly make one wonder how long this repeated process can go on and whether or not the kid has any staying power after this tape. It is evident that Lil Pump sticks to his guns, but how many guns does the kid have left upon releasing this project?

If you know what Lil Pump’s mantra is, and it annoys you just knowing that this kid exists, this is your warning: stay the fuck away from this nonsense. It is not a tape for the hip hop traditionalist, bound on reminding the world that nothing will ever be able to put blasphemy on the temple of Wu Tang or the beat finessings of Madlib. It is a tape to throw on when you’re next up on the aux rotation in the Corolla and your friends are desperately looking for an excuse to yell obscenities out of the window at bored-out-of-their-mind pedestrians. It is a tape to throw on when the sky is as purple as the lean you wish you could drink if it weren’t such a fucking destructive heroin in liquid form. It is the tape to throw on to get your friend awake out of the xanax induced coma they put themselves in. It is the tape to throw on when you get that paycheck and want to feel livid on the way to the bank. Other than this, this thing is as dumb as a can of soup.

6/10

title: Interview: Alpha Male Tea Party Discuss Health, Humor and How to Help Dan Wild-Beesley Fight Cancer
content:
Written by Layla Moheimani 

Photo Credit: Joe Singh

For my final UCLA Radio press piece, I spoke with the Liverpool-based trio Alpha Male Tea Party following their stellar performance on the main stage at ArcTanGent Festival in Bristol, UK. Their set was one of the highlights of both my summers attending the festival, which says a lot considering the immense quality of the bands that play ArcTanGent. Yet the most striking thing about the festival as a whole isn’t the music, but the community and camaraderie surrounding it, which was made especially clear towards the end of Alpha Male Tea Party’s set. Prior to the band’s final song, guitarist Tom Peters took a moment to address the absence of a key figure within the math rock and ArcTanGent scene, Dan Wild-Beesley, who was most commonly known around the festival as the former guitarist of Cleft, a band which had played every prior year of ArcTanGent including their final show as a band at last year’s festival. Dan also happens to be in a new band with Tom called GUG and is also Tom’s best friend. It had been announced several months prior that Dan, who was first diagnosed with a brain tumor in 2015 and had been in remission for almost 2 years, would be unable to attend the festival or play with GUG as his tumor had returned along with a second inoperable one on his cerebellum. I personally came to know Dan under the unlikeliest and most unfortunate of circumstances when I was in the midst of my own battle with cancer. Since then, the impact he has had on my life has been ineffable and I know there are hundreds of people who could speak at length about how Dan has touched their lives both as a musician and as an incredible human being. When I interviewed Dan at ArcTanGent last year, he mentioned Tom and Alpha Male Tea Party multiple times as being his best friends and “a fucking awesome band as well.” In my interview with Alpha Male Tea Party this summer, they too spoke at length of their love of Dan and the massive hole that they felt from him not being able to attend the festival. Before I get into that interview, I wanted to first let you hear from Tom about Dan, his illness, and how you can help to support him.

Photo Credit: Trash Monkey

Layla: You guys did something really special at the end of your set and obviously we’re all gutted about Dan not being here and GUG [not being able to perform] as well. When I spoke with Dan at ArcTanGent last year he talked a lot about your friendship and Cleft’s relationship with Alpha Male Tea Party. Do you want to talk about that and the fundraiser that you’ve got going on?

Tom: I need to just say that Dan as a person has never at any point let [cancer] control him or let it stop him from being or doing what he wanted to do, and that’s an amazing testament to Dan as a person. He’s a wonderful guy. He’s my best friend, I was the best man at his wedding. There’s so many wonderful memories I have with Dan and I wish that he wasn’t going through what he’s going through. But he’s dealing with it in the best way that he possibly can and that’s amazing. He’s had various different types of treatment and I think he’s at that point where he needs to [be] looking at alternatives. So at the moment we’re trying to raise a bit of money so that he can go and do a specialist treatment out in Istanbul. The treatment has shown an 80% success rate of pushing cancer patients into remission. So we want to try and raise enough money that Dan can go and get that treatment. It’s a really amazing program that they have over there. It’s a combined treatment including well-being and dietary stuff as well as a really amazing groundbreaking chemotherapy program that uses targeted chemotherapy. And, your know he’s 32. He deserves that and I think all we can do is help him, all I want to do. So there will be a JustGiving set up so anyone that’s not at the festival right now can donate in some way. I mean obviously when we played earlier I made the point that there’s 5,000 people [at ArcTanGent]. If everyone put a tenner in, that’s it covered.”

To read more of Dan’s story and offer whatever support you can, please donate.

Photo Credit: Trash Monkey; (from left) Ben Griffiths (bass), Greg Chapman (drums), Tom Peters (guitar)

August 18, 2017 - Fernhill Farm, Bristol, UK

Layla: I do want to start by saying, I had so much fun at the set today. It was really exciting to see you guys on the main stage too.

Tom Peters: It’s nice up there.

Ben Griffiths: Very nice.

T: It’s so big!

Greg Chapman: It’s massive, isn’t it? I had to get the techies to push the riser all the way forward.

T: They put my amps on the stage and they just looked like a fart in a corridor or something. They just sat there.

B: It’s definitely hands down the biggest stage we’ve played. We’ve played [the main stage] twice now. It’s really nice to play the Arc stage. It feels good.

T: It’s quite interesting for us. I mean, we played Trowbridge on Wednesday night in this tiny room. It was really small. It was still a really fun gig but it was the contrast between playing in this tiny room where we were going, “Is there actually enough room for us to get our equipment on the stage?” We ended up playing on the floor because we couldn’t actually get it in place. And then you get to [ArcTanGent] and you’re like, Jesus Christ.

G: For a three-piece, we need to gaggle together. Otherwise the vibe is lost.

T: I felt like you were a mile away from me.

G: Yeah, like 20 meters away from each other. It’s like you’re playing in different time zones. Really bizarre. There’s no vibe. Because we’re so used to literally playing on top of each other in small clubs.

T: I felt like there was a decent amount of vibe today though.

G: Oh yeah, totally.

T: I do like it when we get the rare opportunity to play on a massive stage. It is fun.

L: You guys just released a new album, which is spectacular by the way.

T: Thank you very much.

L: I was, I don’t want to say unprepared for how good it was. But over the summer my friend and I who I would co-host my radio show with would plan playlists and [after listening to the new album] I just texted him: “Whatever you do, do not listen to the Alpha Male Tea Party album. You need to hear it right then and there [on the show] because I want to be there and see your face when you are listening to it.” So that is the highest honor, when I tell my friend not to listen to it.

T: That’s really nice to hear. It’s definitely been a fucking huge labor of love for us. Because we self-produce everything. I’m a recording engineer by trade so I’ve done all the recording and mixing and stuff like that. So for me, I can’t tell if I absolutely hate it or love it still.

B: I love it, as a man who’s on the outside of that kind of spectrum.

T: Yeah, it can be challenging when you do your own production. But it’s lovely to hear that being said.

L: Was the process of writing and recording this album standard for the previous one or is it different every time?

T: No, very different.

B: Wildly different.

T: I think this album, generally speaking, has been a significantly more emotional process for us all. Because a lot had happened. What we’ve done with this record is try and translate how we are feeling about the world and our personal situations into music more than we have done before. So it was different. We made more of an effort to really concentrate on the writing in places. It was harder to write. It took a lot longer than we expected.

G: But it was written in one lump whereas [the band’s previous album] Droids was written in various lumps and recorded in various lumps. Health was written in one lump and recorded in one lump. So it was a much more manageable process and a very enjoyable process.

T: Yeah, it was. When we got into the thick of it, it was a really good. I loved writing the songs.

G: We went off to Oxfordshire into the country in the middle of winter and holed ourselves up in a little studio and it was lovely.

Photo Credit: Jonathan Dadds

L: I don’t know if this is just my own personal weird sense of humor, but I’ve found there to be a lot of humor in math rock and among math rock bands. Would you agree?

B: I think there has to be because there’s very little lyrics.

L: Yeah, it just doesn’t take itself as seriously.

B: Absolutely. Well, there are certain math rock bands that take themselves incredibly seriously. But the ones that have longevity are, I think, the ones that don’t really care and will just laugh about it. I think the perfect example of this is a band called Future of the Left. They’re not a math rock band at all but they play math rock festivals all the time because their music’s a bit on the odd side. But they’ve got this sense of humor which appeals to a lot of people and their lyrics are fantastic. I think humor is, for us it’s used to process the world and I think for a lot of people it’s used to display personality. Because we’re not, as people, we are not posers. We laugh at everything. And [Tom] said it really well in an interview before, it would be wrong of us if we did anything else. It would be untruthful to our own personalities. Because we are massive piss-takers. But to the point that we don’t take a piss with our music. We take our music very seriously. The song titles are an opportunity for a band like us to kind of go, “Ah, fuck it. Let’s use that hilarious thing you shouted at me in a bar in Edinburgh once.”

T: It’s as much as a coping mechanism as well as anything else. Some people express themselves in totally different ways and everybody has to try and find a way to express themselves as naturally as they possibly can. For us, humor is the way to do it. It wouldn’t necessarily feel right for us to not be, you know, on a personal level and this is the thing that I think sometimes is a little bit of a misunderstanding like, our music isn’t funny music. We take the writing of our songs very seriously and the emotional meaning of all of our music is very serious to us because a lot of the time it is about us translating the way that we are particularly feeling about something awful into something creative.

L: Do you guys have a favorite memory of any of the years you’ve played ArcTanGent?

G: What we’ve just done was the best.

T: I have to make special exception because the riff medley with Cleft is a moment that will never be surpassed. That was very fucking special. But as a band, today was our best set.

title: So You Wannabe an Outlaw - Steve Earle // Album Review
content:
Written by Brandon Craig

So You Wannabe an Outlaw, Grammy winning songwriter Steve Earle’s latest album, marks his anticipated return to the country genre. Released June 16 under license by Warner Bros Records, the album consists of 12 songs and is roughly 40 minutes in duration. 

Notoriously political, Earle adapts to the rigid, formulaic song structure expected of major label country music. Earle’s raspy “talk tone” voice, paired with traditional country instruments such as fiddles, an array of guitars, and Waylon Jennings timbre, set his album apart from the popular country pack. Memorable tracks include “So You Wannabe An Outlaw,” which showcases exceptionally arranged instrumentation and lyrics retrospective of his renegade years. “This Is How it Ends,” featuring a duet with Miranda Lambert, is my favorite track on the album. A compelling song about divorce, it features savory harmony and well-written lyrics. “Goodbye Michelangelo,” the final track, pays tribute to Guy Clark, Earle’s former mentor. Its simple instrumentation highlights its emotional message. 

Overall, I’d recommend Earle’s latest album to country fans, especially those over 30 years old, who seek to expand their musical palate.  Earle, 62, has a very devoted fan base, and continues to sell out live shows nationwide.

title: Jesu, Sun Kil Moon - 30 Seconds to the Decline of Planet Earth // Album Review
content:
Written by Alexandra Ivanova

Last year, fans of Mark Kozelek were excited at the release of Jesu/Sun Kil Moon — an album-length collaboration between Mark Kozelek (of Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon) and Justin Broadrick (of Godflesh, Napalm Death, among others). The collaboration presented Kozelek’s narrative lyricism over Broadrick’s metal-centered guitar melodies. While it was a collaboration I was skeptical about during its release, Kozelek and Broadrick certainly complemented each other and present a melding between “soft” lyrics and “harsh” instrumentation that made the album one of the best collaborations to date in its innovation and surprising ability to balance two completely different genres.
