Now, a year later, fans of Kozelek, Broadrick, and the Jesu/Sun Kil Moon collaboration are met again with a collaboration between the two in 30 Seconds to the Decline of Planet Earth.

Similarly to the Jesu/Sun Kil Moon album, 30 Seconds takes both artists in a new direction. 30 Seconds, however, is less concerned with the jarring appeal of harsh metal-based guitar sounds, and instead focuses on glimmering and positive synth melodies and quiet, almost trip-hop sounding beats. In fact, the album has no metal influence at all, and sounds more similar to Kozelek’s other work, including Common as Light and Love are Red Valleys of Blood, released earlier this year— both in its underlying beats, as well as Kozelek’s lyrics focusing on both his own life in songs like “You Are Me and I Am You,” discussing his relationship with his father, and “The Greatest Conversation Ever in the History of the Universe,” ranting about the current American political climate.

Innovation aside, there is some musical and lyrical skill that is sacrificed in 30 Seconds. At times the electronica is dull-sounding, even though it is bright on the surface, and the lyrics are mediocre when compared to Kozelek’s other poignant work that simply outshines the concepts he discusses on this album. I am hesitant to say this is the result of the fact that the album is a collaboration, because Jesu/Sun Kil Moon was so impressive, as was Kozelek’s 2013 collaboration with Jimmy Lavalle. Instead, perhaps this is the result of Kozelek producing two full-length albums within the last year, and the creative burnout that may result.

That being said, the album has its own pretty and tender moments that show Kozelek’s autobiographical appeal in his music, as well as Broadrick’s skill in instrumentation. While 30 Seconds is not as impressive as Jesu/Sun Kil Moon or Kozelek’s other releases, it is worth appreciation regardless, as its moments of innovation make it a worthwhile listen, even at 70 minutes in length.
tags: 30 Seconds to the Decline of Planet Earth

title: UCLA Radio’s Best of 2017 - Music and Genre Directors
content:
This year, UCLA Radio’s music director and genre directors compiled a list of their favorite releases this past year. Take a peek and explore some of our favorite albums of this past year. 

Alison Chi - Music Director

1. SZA - Ctrl

I don’t know a single person who doesn’t like SZA’s sophomore album Ctrl. There are so few albums that can capture people’s attention these days - it’s all about the singles and never the album as a whole but something about Ctrl is cohesive from start to finish. The way each song weaves into each other is seamless and you’ll truly be rewarded if you sit down and listen to the album straight through. Is there even a single bad song on this album? 

2. Giraffage - Too Real
3. Slowdive - Slowdive
4. Turnover - Good Nature
5. Land of Talk - Life After Youth
6. Cigarettes After Sex - Cigarettes After Sex
7. Julien Baker - Turn Out the Lights
8. Valerie June - The Order of Time
9. Slow Dancer - In A Mood
10. Mount Eerie - A Crow Looked at Me

Megan Hullander - Rock Genre Director

1. King Gizzard & The Flying Wizard - Flying Microtonal Banana

King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard’s Flying Microtonal Banana was the first in a series of five albums promised to be released in 2017 (one of which has still yet to come) including a concept album ridden with the drama of human and non-human emotions, a jazzy collaboration with Mild High Club, and an album given as a gift to fans - the rights of which are “owned” by all. Flying Microtonal Banana is unique in that the band customized their instruments in effort to find spaces between existing tones, or “microtones.” The album is named for one of these instruments which does, in fact, look quite similar to a banana. 

2. Thee Oh Sees - Orc
3. The Brian Jonestown Massacre - Open Minds Now Close
4. Alex Cameron - Forced Witness
5. Ron Gallo - Temporary Slave
6. Ariel Pink - Dedicated to Bobby Jameson
7. Ty Segall - Sentimental Goblin
8. ORB - Naturality
9. Kikagaku Moyo - Stone Garden
10. Courtney Barnett & Kurt Vile - Lotta Sea Lice

Gabe Cortina - Rock Genre Director

1. Limp Wrist - Facades

Featuring Martin from Los Crudos on vocals as well as members of Hail Mary, Devoid of Faith, By the Throat, and Kill the Man Who Questions, the versatility of Limp Wrist sound has never been more apparent. Identifying as queercore, the band has a fast hardcore sound and lyrical themes concerning gay identity politics. The mixing of album is something which also stood out to me, it’s able to polished without sounding over produced. Martin’s vocal style perfectly matches the killer riffs and speedy drums in both intensity and aggression. Halfway through this album, the band’s sound switches to a disco-ey almost dark-wave- techno sound which they pull of with perfection. This album is solid and I highly recommend it to both longtime fans of punk and people who are looking for an introduction to punk music alike.

2. Despise You / Coke Bust - Split LP
3. Gay Kiss - Rounded Down
4. Exit Unit - St 2017
5. Glue - S/T MLP
6. Lumpy and the Dumpers - Those Pickled Fuckers
7. Goolagoon / ACxDC - Split
8. Burnout - West Coast Tour 2017 CS
9. Sex Prisoner / Harm Done - Split
10. Meth Leppard - Discography 2015-2017

Gabe Punk Genre Director Top 10 Albums of 2017 from anon-10212970514769336 on 8tracks Radio

Alana Enriquez - Pop Genre Director

1. Beach House - B-Sides and Rarities

This compilation happened to be release on a day where I had only gotten around an hour of sleep the night before, and I cried within one minute of the first track. It’s Beach House at their most dreamy, their most blaring, their most haunting. Old tracks with new renditions and fresh ones meld into something spellbinding that doesn’t require the logistical unity of a formal album. B-Sides and Rarities has been on a weekly rotation for me for the entire second half of 2017, and probably for the entirety of 2018, unless they release something else for me to cry to during my morning routine. 

2. Florist - If Blue Could Be Happiness
3. High Bloom - Implied Sun
4. Alvvays - Antisocialites
5. The Drums - Abysmal Thoughts
6. Slowdive - Slowdive
7. Steve Lacy - Steve Lacy’s Demo
8. You’ll Never Get to Heaven - Images
9. Pedro Infante - Cien años… pensando en ti
10. Big Thief - Capacity

Alana Myers - Pop Genre Director

1. Wolf Alice - Visions Of A Life

Looking back at this past September, I remember sitting in my apartment late at night, counting down until midnight when Wolf Alice’s second record Visions of a Life would be released. I haven’t ever heard anything quite like Visions of a Life before, and I think the reason it resonates so much with me is the way it perfectly encompasses the feelings that come with the uncertainty of young adulthood, and the feelings of life in general - love, anger, sadness, extreme joy, and everything in between. The album digs itself into darkness, but at its core, lies a piece of work that is ambitious, honest, and a solid listen from start to finish.

2. MUNA - About U
3. Tei Shi - Crawl Space
4. Declan McKenna - What Do You Think About the Car?
5. Stormzy - Gang Signs & Prayer
6. Will Joseph Cook - Sweet Dreamer
7. HAIM - Something to Tell You
8. Lorde - Melodrama
9. Paramore - After Laughter
10. Circa Waves - Different Creatures

Alex Saakyan - Pop Genre Director

1. Lana Del Rey - Lust For Life

With an album cover that graces a smile, cheek to cheek of Lana Del Rey, it is no surprise as to why this record has been nicknamed as Del Rey’s first ‘happy album.’ Retiring from the ‘sad girl’ aesthetic of her previous records, Del Rey delivers an optimistic and authentic approach to her music. With tracks like ‘When the World Was at War’ and ‘God Bless America’ we see Del Rey take a more honest approach from her Americana aesthetic as she speaks of the hard times people in this country face. With tracks like ‘Get Free’ she delivers her mission statement: “Finally, I’m crossing the threshold/From the ordinary world/To the reveal of my heart,” She’s honest, she’s free, with a much optimism and a lust for life. 

2. Kendrick Lamar - DAMN.
3. Lorde - Melodrama
4. Kelela - Take Me Apart
5. Majid Jordan - The Space Between
6. Harry Styles - Harry Styles
7. Calvin Harris - Funk Wav Bounces Vol. 1
8. Tyler, the Creator - Flower Boy
9. Dua Lipa - Blow Your Mind
10. Kesha - Rainbow

Christian Wright - World Genre Director

1. Jay Som - Everybody Works

Melina Duterte’s sophomore album is a bedroom production jewel. Every song, incredibly cohesive as a whole, traverses the beautifully lush sonic worlds her mind seemingly conjures up. That’s not to say the ten tracks that span Everybody Works are simple happenstances that fall together nicely; they definitely sound like labors of love. Rather her voice, certain of itself, transmits to the listener so powerfully, making sense out of all the disorder that comes with self-doubt and personal struggle. “Won’t forget to climb,” she sings on E.W’s. final track, “For Light,” beautifully steering the qualms of trying to make it in this world.

2. Nikolas Escudero - Synthesis
3. Haley Heynderickx - Unpeeled (Live)
4. Fleet Foxes - Crack-Up
5. Bedouine - Beduoine
6. Japanese Breakfast - Soft Sounds from Another Planet
7. Lomelda - Thx
8. Hand Habits - Wildly Idle (Humble Before the void)
9. Kevin Morby - City Music
10. Wednesday Campanella - Superman

Ethan Lee - Jazz Genre Director

1. Nick Hakim - Green Twins

Nick Hakim blurs the line between psychedelic, soul, funk, rock, and jazz with his debut album, Green Twins. With lush melodies to command his songs and a spacey approach to recording production, Hakim creates his own unique sound and challenges the notions and implications of a music genre.  With a brand of sound that emulates Unknown Mortal Orchestra, Hakim’s soundscape fills in colorful textures with his diverse instrumentation on top of steady, pulse-like rhythms.  From spacey, reflective post-R&B rock songs like “Bet She Looks Like You” to jazzy, rhythmic pulses in “Miss Chew” and slow, soulful ballads like “Needy Bees,” Green Twins has just about everything you need in a debut album from an artist as complex as Nick Hakim.

2. Tyler the Creator - Flower Boy
3. Kamasi Washington - Harmony of Difference
4. Rex Orange County - Apricot Princess
5. Christian Scott aTunde Adjuah - Diaspora
6. Moses Sumney - Aromanticism
7. Steve Lacy - Steve Lacy’s Demo
8. Brockhampton - Saturation II
9. Smino - blkswn
10. Antonio Sanchez - Bad Hombre

Mark Edmonds - Electronic Genre Director

1. Moon Boots - First Landing

First Landing is Moon Boots’ debut album. Moon Boots manages a deep overtone with techy-melodies. ‘Never Get to You’ is a standout track that will light up any dance floor or pool party. 

2. Rezz - Mass Manipulation
3. Oliver - Full Circle
4. Various Artists - Anjunadeep Vol. 9
5. Illenium - Awake
6. Giraffage - Too Real
7. Four Tet - New Energy
8. Odesza - A Moment Apart
9. Cosmic Gate - Materia Chapter.Two
10. Bicep - Bicep

Beliz Urkmez - Electronic Genre Director

1. Lorde - Melodrama

For me, Lorde’s music means emotion in its purest, most honest form. Her sophomore album, Melodrama, captures her youth, her growth, her path to becoming a woman of her own and loving herself and all the ephemeral experiences in between. Mastering her craft, Lorde finds a cohesion between her atmospheric synths, harmonies, beats and the bittersweet wisdom in her lyrics. Especially in “Liability,” a beautiful piano-ballad where she sings, “I understand, I’m a liability/ Get you wild, make you leave/ I’m a little much for everyone.” Lorde is truly one of a kind and Melodrama proves she is one of the best artists today.

2. Gorillaz - Humanz
3. London Grammar - Truth Is a Beautiful Thing
4. HAIM - Something to Tell You
5. Alexandra Savior - Belladonna of Sadness
6. Temples - Volcano
7. Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds - Who Built the Moon?
8. Wolf Alice - Visions of a Life
9. Cigarettes After Sex - Cigarettes After Sex
10. Mura Masa - Mura Masa

Alex Ivanova - Folk/Singer-Songwriter Genre Director

1. Kiran Leonard - Derevaun Seraun

This is probably the most sonically beautiful album I’ve listened to in years. 22-year-old Kiran Leonard blends voice, piano, and string trio into an album with each movement representing a different piece of literature, seeing as the album was written to celebrate the re-opening of Manchester’s Central Library. The album is intensely personal, and raw, as Leonard’s voice is in the spotlight, accompanied by mournful accompaniment. I recommend this album endlessly.

2. The Spirit of the Beehive - pleasure suck
3. Jay Som - Everybody Works
4. Joan of Arc - He’s Got the Whole This Land Is Your Land in His Hands
5. Kindling - Hush
6. Синекдоха Монток - MMXVII (Parts 1 & 2)
7. Phoebe Bridgers - Stranger in the Alps
8. Sidney Gish - Ed Buys Houses
9. Tagubu & Klimperei - I Don’t Remember The First Time 
10. Nnamdi Ogbonnaya - DROOL

title: Gryffin ft. Autograf and Ayokay @ The Wiltern (11/18/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Jenny Tong 

Photos by Miranda Montenegro

Having heard about the Gryffin’s “Castle in the Sky” tour months before the show, I was strongly anticipating his show and the performances from his openers, Autograf and Ayokay.

We were settling in while Ayokay performed, and managed to catch the last part of his show. He had a contagious exuberance as he pranced around during his set. Much to everyone’s surprise, two-thirds of the Chicago-based electronic trio Autograf (Louis Kha and Jake Carpenter) also came to play at the Wiltern show - they were originally only scheduled for the Observatory show the next day. Guest appearances are arguably one of the highlights of live shows, particularly in EDM (shoutout to our UCLA alumni-founded music event organizer, Brownies and Lemonade.)   

I was intrigued by the four looming Chinese words that flashed repeatedly in the backdrop, 流芳百世, which I was quick to assume was their music mantra. The phrase means to pass on a tradition or ideology to many more generations to come, which matches very well with their SoundCloud bio: “It’s about leaving your mark in the world. It’s about leaving your Autograf (autograph).” Jake was playing the beats live throughout the show, which I dare say is not very common, and may be the first EDM show I have seen that incorporated such extensive live instrumentals.

Classified as part of the future electronic genre, Autograf is definitely setting the bar high up for what up-and-coming house music performances should entail. MusicianBio reveals that Autograf keeps a lot of its production in-house, from the stage installations to its album artwork, thus walking the talk of their dream to revolutionize digital music picture. From the vibrant lighting, pink and yellow, I could definitely see how Andy Warhol’s fascination with pop art serves as an inspiration to their look and feel. Arguably, I see more traces of hypebeast vibes on their socials, particularly Instagram and their merchandise.

In terms of music, it was a little more dramatic than what I was expecting. I have always defaulted to listening to Autograf on SoundCloud when I needed ambient music to listen to while studying, and most of their original music is more laid back. However, they tried to mix things up a little in their live performance and threw in a couple of trap songs, as well as songs that reminded me of Sam Feldt’s music (I attribute it to the prominent horn solos in the songs.) Of course they also played their top hits like “Sleepless in NYC,” “Simple,” and “You Might Be.” “Sleepless in NYC” did not disappoint, although if I could wish for one thing, it would be that they played with a xylophone as well, like they did in this Instagram video. Nonetheless, the headbanger they played towards the end of the show was a great segway into Gryffin’s high-energy performance.

After much anticipation, Gryffin started his set almost three and a half hours into the show. It began with him drumming intensively with flashing lights in the backdrop, marking his presence to the stage. He proceeded to hit the keys, showing his full range of musical talent right off the bat. We were all directed shortly after to put our hands up in the sky, partially mirroring the theme of the tour.

Gryffin playing the drums

With the Japanese caricatures and neon street signs featured in one of the screen display designs, taiko drumming style, and his clothing and bandana, Gryffin had the full package of an incredibly musically talented anime character. These little things differentiate him from other artists, as I felt fully immersed in his performance. The gear that he wears to all his shows reminds me of Japanese school uniforms (towards the trendier, more fashionable end of the spectrum.) The lights in the back even flashed in sync with the beats on his drums, just like how it does in the taiko drum games I played as a kid at the arcade in Hong Kong. Although the lighting plays a role in delivering the performance, I would not say it is as dominant as it is with other EDM artists, especially trap-heavy or larger artists at music festivals. Going down memory lane, the tour’s name references a famous Japanese animation that I watched as a kid of the same name, “Castle in the Sky.” It was a largely imaginative animation - I guess Gryffin was going off tangent of being futuristic in his musical production as well in the future bass genre.

Gryffin and Katie Pearlman

Gryffin brought out not one, but two of his singers - Bipolar Sunshine for “Whole Heart” and Katie Pearlman for “Nobody Compares to You.” I love it when vocalists are showcased at the DJ’s live performances - the synergy is much more amplified, as opposed just hearing a song get blasted out of the speakers (followers could easily just do that at home!)

He also did not skimp on playing his popular remixes, such as “Feel Good ft. Daya” with Illenium, while strumming on his electronic guitar, jamming to Years and Years’ “Desire,” and my personal favorite, “Don’t Leave” by Snakeships and MØ, on the keyboard. I had no shame in singing my heart and soul out to these songs, in spite of what I claimed earlier about the ideal of having the featured artists perform live.

With a duration of close to five hours, it was quite a journey that I was really grateful to be part of on the Friday night before Thanksgiving. Gryffin, Autograf, and Ayokay will be shaping the future of house music track by track, performance by performance, and ultimately, one by one of us as listeners.

Gryffin (potentially) pointing towards the Castle in the Sky

title: Daniel Caesar @ The Fonda (11/1/17) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Breanna Nery

Fresh from his late summer release of Freudian, Daniel Caesar embarked on his Freudian tour this fall. Caesar gifted LA with two sold out shows, October 31 and November 1, at the Fonda Theatre.

Accompanying Caesar for the tour was Snoh Aalegra, a Stockholm born, LA-based singer. Aalegra made an appearance with another Toronto artist earlier this year - her vocals were sampled in Drake’s “playlist” More Life. Aalegra opened the show with hits from her latest album Feels released in October 2017.

After Aalegra’s opening set, it would be another hour and a half before Caesar appeared at 11 p.m. The crowd grew restless during the wait, with frequent chants calling for Caesar to appear. The tension dispersed once Caesar arrived and opened with his single “Japanese Denim.” Throughout the night, Caesar repped Toronto and the music scene by bringing out Toronto-based artists Jessie Reyez and Charlotte Day Wilson. Syd also made a surprise appearance for their song “Take Me Away.” Caesar even brought out Arin Ray, after announcing that he would listen to Ray’s song “We Ain’t Homies” non-stop while on tour.

From Caesar’s past appearances in LA at the Echo and UCLA’s Jazz Reggae Fest, it’s clear that performing his music is as easy as breathing for him. Caesar flawlessly delivered all of his hits and closed off his night with his most famous song “Get You.” While Kali Uchis didn’t appear, the crowd (and Caesar) happily sung along.

title: Mitski and Palehound @ The Fonda (10/22) // Show Review
content:
Written by Jennifer Ward

The two most prominent groups of people at the Mitski show at the Fonda were (1) the high school indie art kids, as characterized by an intense and vocal desire to attend NYU, high waisted mom jeans, and an aversion to Sonic Youth, and (2) the indie art kids dressed in all black whose every conversation eventually circles back to Death Grips. I had trouble with reconciling the presence of both very different groups, but then I realized: it’s Mitski. She has both the technical appeal of strong arrangements and melodies in addition to the emotional appeal of overly relatable sadgirl lyrics. It makes sense. I had lukewarm feelings about Palehound after watching their NPR Tiny Desk performance, but my opinion quickly changed after hearing “Feeling Fruit,” a heartbreaking song about loss. This, the silly lyrics, and the super cute bass player more than balanced out the sometimes excessive and slightly detracting Dinosaur Jr. influence.

Mitski came onto the stage with sparkly kitten heels, a black dress and strong looking shoulders. Her elegance and delicate fluttering vocals, even on her scream-y Audiotree rendition of “Class of 2013,” prepared me in no way for the air of confidence and understanding she exuded. After the applause, someone in the crowd yelled out, “Do you like girls?” Mitski smiled for an instant before beginning a dark bassline. The emotional intensity of the performance slowly built through the set.

Mitski performed songs dealing with chronic depression with simultaneous raw emotion and straight-backed confidence. Mitski represents a very specific intersection that is frequently ignored by artistic expression - most artwork does not represent what it is to be a woman, or what it is to be queer, or what it is to be Asian, or what it is to be Asian-American. “Best American Girl,” in contrast, addresses the difficult choice between conforming to white heterosexuality and realizing an individual identity. To be in a space where these experiences were actively recognized and portrayed as a source of pride was a cathartic experience for many.

Mitski took her hair down before beginning the solo portion of her set. Back to back, she played “My Body’s Made of Crushed Little Stars,” “A Burning Hill,” and “Class of 2013,” making for a beautifully sad set finale. Returning for an encore, she fittingly whispered “Last Words of a Shooting Star,” whose vocals end halfway through the last chorus - “goodbye.”

title: Interview with Ron Gallo @ The Mayan (10/18/17)
content:
Photos/Interview by Megan Hullander

It is not often that an artist tours on the same album for three years, but Ron Gallo does it with pride. Heavy Meta is lyrically dense with cynical content and he and his band perform with an energy so contagious it left me sweating more than Gallo himself.

I’ve noticed lyrically a bit of snarky humor in Heavy Meta working towards a social commentary, especially in songs like “Put the Kids to Bed” and “Kill the Medicine Man.” When writing songs, did you draw inspiration more from personal experiences or modern culture as a whole?

RG: Well, I guess all of them are different, but I think that all of them are my personal experiences in response to society as a whole. Because everything is perspective. If I’m walking down the street and I see something happen that might spark just a general, wider view on how I feel about things. I always try to get to get to the root of what is going on and what is happening. I always feel like it can relate back to one thing, so I am always trying to figure out what that one thing is. Like what is the one thing that causes all of the suffering in the world. But I always just think it’s just good humor, because that is always what I am at the core.

In a moderately recent interview, you said your outlook on life has changed drastically since you released Heavy Meta, what do you see your music looking like thematically moving forward?

RG: Well I think with the album that is out now it’s a much more frustrated me being like “what the fuck is wrong with the world?,” and being very outward about it and where I am at now is more taking responsibility for it personally and saying well, what can we do about it? So it’ll come from a much more compassionate place and I think a much more constructive place than just, you know, pointing out what’s wrong with everything.

I don’t really see a lot of intersection with americana and garage rock, so what aspect of these styles do you see as a point of conjunction that makes your music work?

RG: I actually really kind of despise americana music, it really just puts me to sleep at this point. I think my old band spent a lot of time in that world and I just don’t even know what it means, but when I think of it I just think of songs that make me glaze over about whiskey and trains and mountaintops that really don’t have anything to do with my life. I feel like I shed a lot of that and I don’t really feel rooted there at all, but I definitely, at least in the past, have pulled a lot from American greats like early rock and roll, and a lot of the best music was sort of pioneered in this country.

Within the last few weeks there has been a series of sexual assault charges, many of which are against musicians, and the photographer on tour with you (CJ Harvey) has been pretty active as far as posting about the sexual harassment that exists among the music community. Where do you see the boundaries being between the rawness of experiencing live music and the interactions that come with it, in opposition with the necessity of being conscious and considerate of the space of others?

RG: I’ve been thinking about this a lot the last few days and it’s a hard thing to really pinpoint because it’s so much about perspective and people’s perception. It’s like something can happen, and one person can take it one way and the other person can be completely unaware and think of it a completely different way. So, really, at the end of the day, I think what everybody lacks is a sort of general sense of awareness and I think we could all be a lot better at that, and that’s not just in regards to this, I think in general it’s just being in the moment and being there and being connected with what everything is all about. There’s not really any room for error there if you’re actually aware of what you’re doing and aware of the point of everything, which is not negativity, is not harassing or assaulting or offending. I always try to look from both perspectives and try to look at everything with some sort of sense of compassion with the belief that no person is inherently evil and that any person can change which I believe to be true based on things I have seen in my life. It’s crazy to see people be ostracized on the internet based on something that may have happened ten years ago, that they didn’t even think anything about. And I’m not justifying any kind of behaviors, but I think what bothers me is when something like that comes out and immediately, for everyone’s own ego, they jump ship. And they don’t want to try to understand what really happened, maybe this person was going through something really terrible at the time, this is not who they are. And then their whole life and career is like - poof. And again that’s not justifying people’s behaviors and I believe that if just everybody, in the world, could just approach everything with a sense of compassion, we can just heal these things and heal these behaviors. It’s the same thing with like the Nazi rallies in Virginia. We can all understand that there’s an illness here. These people are so passionate about hating other people based on things that are not real. It’s dilution to think that there’s any superiority between people based on race - all of this shit is made up - none of its real. So for people to think that it is valid, is a sign of illness to me. So I can compare that to any situation, even the sexual assault allegations. If everybody can look at it like, okay, this person is troubled and they need to be awakened from this unconscious state causing them to act the way that they are. So rather than go out and say “Fuck Nazis, kill Nazis, die racists,” when you think about that, what does that do? How does that allow you to approach these people as human beings to get them to the place that they need to heal to actually solve the problem. All that does is feed the fire, all that does is react with the same thing that they are doing, you just think that it’s on a better side, and we can all agree that there is certainly a better side, a side that is more rooted in reality which is not hatred or assault. But it’s about people going beyond themselves and seeing the humanness in all of us, which creates a universal sense of compassion, it’s not about creating divides. And that’s what freaks me out about this stuff a little bit is that I understand that men are in the wrong here and there are things that happen towards women and there could certainly be a big improvement in that, but let’s go beyond ourselves best we can to actually fix it and that always comes from a place of compassion. Somebody has to take that step, because if we just keep responding to the same thing with the same thing, we’re never gonna get anywhere. So that’s a really long answer to it, but I think that’s what it is. I’ll use something very simple. If somebody cuts me off on the highway there are two ways I can respond to it. I can say “What the fuck is wrong with you, you piece of shit?” and honk on my horn, or I could say, “That person is clearly wrapped up in their own head and might be having a day, so I’m just not going to react.” And then there’s just less negativity in the world. And if we can just be mirrors for people and let them see what they are doing, the world can be a better place, but people are just so wrapped up in right or wrong or dividing themselves further.

Going off of that, like you said, there seems to be a tendency to sort of “disown” music when allegations like this come out, but over time they seem to matter less and we take their music back in, such as many have done with artists like Michael Jackson and Tupac. And with situations like PWR BTTM, while people can reject the artists, the music can still hold a lot of meaning to them, so where do you see the separation of artists and their music being?

RG: The separation is actually pretty large. Because that’s the thing about it, you can develop a really intimate relationship with music, and you don’t know the person at all. It’s like when you meet your idols you’re nervous because the dynamic is you think you know this person well because you develop a relationship with what they created, but then the disconnect and the weirdness comes from you not knowing actually who they are. So I think those things should remain separate, because when you think about it, a song came from a moment in one person’s life that they happened to channel and they made a song of it. So if anything we are merely channels for creativity. It’s not us building more limbs are we are extensions of the songs we create. Even the songs in Heavy Meta that we wrote like three and a half years ago - I don’t identify with the person that wrote them anymore. Even John Lennon and some of the people who made some of the greatest music ever, weren’t traditionally the most sound, positive people all of the time.

Even as a solo artist, there is consistency in the members of your band; how do their styles play into the music or affect your process at all?

RG: Well, what’s cool is I write the songs by myself, guitar and voice, and then when I bring it to Joe and Dylan, it’s like free reign and that’s when I feel like it really becomes a song, when they put their part in. I think they both have very unique ways of approaching it, so that’s kind of why I think we are together, there’s and electricity, an energy, that we convey together. I’ve played with thirty different people over the last few years and when it came time to put together a solid band that was the combo that felt the most [makes grunt of assent]. There’s some weird magic there, and we are all idiots. We have our own language at this point, we’ve become so alienated at this point because of the way that we talk. We have to hide from the rest of society because it’s nonsensical.

Do you ever dream about them?

RG: Not a lot, thankfully. The nightmare that I wake up in every day is them, so my dreams are my escape from reality. I try to not see them when I sleep.

Alright, we’re going to go into a sort of power round of more get to know you questions. On average, how many baths do you take per year?

RG: Oh man, the average is about zero at this point. I think the last time I took a bath was about five years ago, but that includes all bathing. I think that’s something that one day I will earn. I just haven’t had a tub that’s acceptable to bathe in. It’s like a vacation thing. Maybe someday.

Create a boy band that you would give up your solo career for.

RG: Dead or alive?…I like this question so much, I wanna get it right…Me, Iggy Pop, Ray Charles, John Lennon, and…maybe put David Lynch in there.

If you had to perform on tour in a profession specific uniform, what would you choose?

RG: Probably a hazmat suit and just install a microphone into the helmet area. I could just be totally separate - I would feel like I wasn’t even here.

What is a food that you can eat really fast?

RG: My favorite snack in the world is dried mango from Trader Joe’s - and I crush those. Like, goodbye. And smoothies, I just down those in five seconds. Not sure if that’s how you’re supposed to consume them, but I do.

When is the last time you had to pee, but couldn’t due to situational circumstances?

RG: That was today. I was skateboarding down to a thrift store near where we were staying and I found a bunch of good items and was committed to it so I didn’t want to leave the store, so I stuck it out and then I got back to the house and had forgotten I had to pee. I was like, oh shit, I’m gonna pee myself, I had waited like actually an hour. That was pretty self inflicted though.

The guitarist of Sunflower Bean has a sort of Bob Dylan look and you embody more of Dylan’s persona lyrically, so who do you think would be better playing Bob Dylan in a biopic, and why?

RG: I think I’ll go with him because I just think I would be terrible. So by default based on how terrible I would be, it would have to be him.

title: Son Lux - Remedy // Album Review
content:
Written by Alexandra Ivanova

After two years since the full-length album Bones, Son Lux has finally released their 18-minute EP Remedy under Joyful Noise Recordings. While three of the songs off this four-song EP were released as singles, the EP is cohesive in its dark sound and distinctive Son Lux groove.

As usual, Son Lux manages to take lyrics that would typically be considered untastefully cliche and bring them down to earth and modesty in a shaking falsetto. The vocals and grim themes that made At War With Walls & Mazes one of 2008’s best releases are present again in Remedy, and continue to define the charm in Son Lux’s emotion, even as an electronic-focused group. Often personality in electronic groups are lost, yet Son Lux utilizes both emotive lyrics and clever instrumentation to present poignant concepts, feelings, and themes without ever becoming cliche. Even in lyrics like “Stolen”’s, “May you die wide awake / With a look of great surprise / May your eyes be taken just before you can weep / As you see what you stole stolen from you,” and “Remedy”’s, “Find your voice in the sea of surging bodies and breath,” the listener is never met with a feeling of too much angst.

Perhaps this is a quality unique to pop and electronic music, where lyricism is not as strong a focus when presented in a package with strong bass and a catchy beat, but Son Lux succeeds in presenting these lyrics in an admirable light. While the lyrics presented on their own seem too invested in their darkness, they are certainly not buried by instrumentation, and instead, are presented in a perspective where they can be appreciated. Son Lux takes a stance more along the lines of The Cure’s appreciative broodiness, as opposed to the masking of dark lyricism that bands like Crystal Castles hide through harsh synth and noise.

In addition to well-presented lyrics, however, Son Lux’s skilled instrumentation is as good as ever. In addition to the typical synthesizer beats utilized by Son Lux, they also incorporate quick violin and flute melodies, as well as choral harmonies under Ryan’s vocals in Remedy.

Ultimately, the Remedy EP presents the characteristic balance between brooding lyrics and danceable synth beats Son Lux is known for. While it may not be their best release to date necessarily, it certainly satisfies Son Lux’s legacy as being a major indie electronic group, and gives hope for future releases and musical growth.

title: Compatibility by Satchy // Album Review
content:
Written by Alexandra Shambayate 

I found Satchy through his song “Where’s The Sex” on Youtube before his album came out on Spotify. As soon as I heard the first few cords of that song, I loved it. The song was so groovy and perfect for a sexy summer day. I ended up finding more of his music on SoundCloud, where he had a few thousand listens on various songs. Some day in July I was listening to my “Discover Weekly” playlist on Spotify and one of his songs played; I immediately went on his artist page and saw that he had released an album. I saved the album and listened to it in about 30 minutes. For his first ever album, it’s pretty good. It felt as though some songs had more effort put into them than others though. For example, some songs are just filler/transition tunes leading up to a few better songs. So it felt like the album was really just five or six sounds, with some transitions in between. Other songs are just demos of the same songs on the album, which I though was kinda redundant and nothing new. The album sounds as though it was very influenced by current lo-fi-sythy-dream bedroom pop music mixed with some slow jazzy beats and mellow, groovy deep bass riffs. The songs that stand out to me the most on this album are “In Your Sheets,” “Where’s The Sex,” and “Compatibility.” These songs are very well composed and contain all the elements needed to make you feel as though you’re in some dreamy love state parked in a car at 2 a.m. Overall though the album is cohesive – every song is relevant to the next, containing chill beats throughout. This album is a collection of smooth tunes that complement one another and just put you in a super lax mood.

title: Tropicalia Fest (11/11/17) // Festival Review
content:
Written by Maria Gasca

Photos by MacKenzi Elias 

As my friend’s car pulled up to the parking lot of Queen Mary Park, my heart began to melt. I saw seas of brown faces and enough winged eyeliner to star in a Red Bull commercial. It was so surreal seeing so many Xicanx Latinx congregating for a music event! I kept pinching my friend and telling him, “This is so crazyyyy.” And crazy is what I got. Here’s some of my highlights from that day:

1. I touched Ginuwine

Once we arrived at the venue we took a mandatory picture in front of the “sad girl” themed Tropicalia backdrop and ate some free vegan tacos. With our panzas full we headed out to see Ginuwine. A few minutes into his set, Ginuwine had entranced us all, and even though I had my eyes on him the whole time, I lost him in the middle of his set. I still heard him singing, so I scanned the crowd only to see people moving away from the stage. Ginuwine was in the pit! Like any logical person would do, I ran towards the crowd and although my dinosaur Android wasn’t able to load my camera fast enough, I was able to TOUCH Ginuwine! Needless to say, I can die happy now.

2. Baile pero Baile (I danced but like I DANCED.)

When I saw Sonora Dinamita on the lineup, I warned my friend that I was going to dance, and I prepared accordingly. I wore my comfy shoes and my Oaxaqueña manta dress (for extra comfort and breathability). However, I danced to a lot more sets than I thought I was. During the Thee Commons set I joined the mosh pit during “Demolicion,” and not the cheesy ones that form at indie concerts, like the real ones. A couple minutes later, while waiting for my friends to get merch, I found myself in La Banda Skalavera’s ska circle skanking. Later, I danced cumbia at the Sonora Dinamita set. Sonora Dinamita even made my friend that doesn’t dance, dance. I was so hyped because I got him to do a vuelta. However, when turning, he almost ran into someone’s Michelada so he got scared and stopped LOL.

3. I got emotional (but I’m a cancer so duh.)

In my preview I mentioned how Tropicalia was going to be more than a concert, how this was going to be a defining moment for a lot of Latinx/Xicanx people, and it was. I saw people dressing unapologetically to the nines, puro pinche winged eyeliner, eyebrows laid, hella cortezes, and crisp pants. I also saw representation of so many identities: Latinx, Mexicanxs, Centro Americanxs, Afro-Latinx, Indígenxs, Mestizxs, papas, mamas, mujeres, hombres, agenrex all conviviendo, dancing, crying, fangirling. Tropicalia’s foundations created a greater connection between the audience and the performers than any typical festival. All the people there brought so much good energy, and that energy was reciprocated by the performers and vice versa. All the performers were wishing they could perform longer, and the yelling from the audience showed that they didn’t want it to end either. Then, Los Tigres del Norte played their last song and we all headed home. But Ojala, we’ll all meet up again next year! ‘Till then pues!

title: Nilüfer Yanya @ Hollywood Forever (11/16/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Alexa Lee

Sitting in the dark confines of Hollywood Forever’s Masonic Lodge, I take in my surroundings while I wait for the show to begin. The venue is intimate in both size and interior design, furnished with Downton Abbey chandeliers along with Game of Thrones chairs. The crowd seems to be a diverse collection of Los Angeles’ wealthiest hipsters, with the man next to me sporting cuffed designer denim with a pair of dirty Converse sneakers (because, you know, he’s really down to earth.) This surprises me, since Nilüfer Yanya’s soul-inspired rock, though enchanting, is hardly the soundtrack of the trendy mainstream. Before I can contemplate the crowd’s demographic any further, however, the lights dim, the audience members take their final Snapchats, and Nilüfer Yanya makes her way to the front of the stage.

Yanya exudes humility. Before the show began, the 21 year old artist was the one setting up her own microphone and amp. Her stage is small and austerely decorated, making the atmosphere feel less like a Hollywood concert and more like a school talent show. A single colored spotlight shines on Yanya, but this is her only theatrical embellishment. She has no live band, apart from a saxophonist who, as it turns out, is an old friend from high school.

Yanya exudes humility, but not weakness. When she sings, she directs her gaze straight ahead, her fingertips gliding over her electric guitar with minimal effort. Her voice is tranquilly sonorous, and her spare use of instrumentals only accentuates the uniqueness of her vocals. She speaks very little throughout the show — a brief “thank you” to the audience here, an apology for being sick there — but her demeanor is not aloof, merely calm and focused.

Sharing a central theme of disappointed love, Yanya’s songs are bitter without being hysterical. She conveys the measured poise of someone reflecting on the past, someone whose heartbreak is sincere but no longer frantic. “Is this the end?” she calls out on “Thanks 4 Nothing,” “I don’t think we can be friends.” On a different track, “Keep On Calling,” she sings, “I’m done feeling for you/Boy, I’m getting bored of your ways.”

As Yanya waxes lyrics about sorrow, love, and nostalgia, I marvel at how her nearly acapella performance suddenly makes the flashy beat drops and light shows of other artists (ahem, Diplo) seem ostentatiously overwrought. In each song, the occasional guitar and saxophone melody run through like an electric current, lighting up Yanya’s stormy vocals without diluting their powerful delivery. Tonight at Hollywood Forever, Yanya conveys a candid and charged simplicity that is all her own.

title: Dagny and LANY @ The Wiltern (11/3/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Joey Wong

LANY, a three person alternative band with Paul Klein, Jake Goss, and Les Priest, returned to their home city of Los Angeles as part of The LANY Tour: Part 2 with two nights at The Wiltern. The venue was intimate and the acoustics were bound to be amazing, and the performances by opening act Dagny and LANY only reaffirmed that.

Dagny, a Norwegian pop artist, opened the show with several of her best hits. Armed with only a guitar and a set of drums, she gave Los Angeles a run for their money with a performance that I personally would’ve paid to enjoy a full show of. At times, one could say that she might have been trying too hard to convert an audience that was not exactly looking to pick up a new Spotify favorite, as some songs were unenthusiastically received. Nonetheless, Dagny did manage to pull through with some of her more popular hits, and it’s no surprise that they were all upbeat and great songs to dance (or sway, if that’s your limit) to. While I’ve only heard to several of her songs in passing, her live performance of “Backbeat” was nothing short of incredible, especially as I relisten to the studio version of it now and realize that it was in that theater that I was exposed to the best and most deserving version of it.

Even in the tiny section of the stage that was partitioned off by her banner, Dagny grazed each square foot of the stage with her mesmerizing presence and built up the excitement for the night. With the thumping of the bass drums and her ability to give some well-planned variations in her songs, the crowd was driven to pure euphoria, albeit it did take the concert goers some time before they realized that Dagny meant business and was not someone that deserves a passive listening.

As Dagny finished her last set and stage assistants started preparing for LANY, the crowd began piling in and smoke machines were deployed, setting a hot and hazy atmosphere that amplified LANY’s style of music. If one were to describe “The Dagny Experience” as an ultra-vivid dream with clear progression and bright colors, LANY’s would be one that’s muddled, dreamy and hypnotic. The stage setup was interesting; with nothing but their respective instruments, an upright piano in the middle, and three giant LED screens spread across the back of the stage, Klein had more than enough space for his electrifying, high-energy presence that is hard to not fall in love with, in an obsessive yet platonic kind of way. And yet, even as they went through their setlist, Klein seemed to have endless ways of interacting with the stage equipment: from squatting on the piano chair and shredding a solo on the amplifier, to even running along the back where the presumably fragile LED panels are. Loyal fans would’ve been ecstatic with the screens as they complemented the songs and its lyrics: rose graphics going with “Flowers on the Floor” (and might I add that there were indeed plenty of actual roses on the ground next to him), a 5 a.m. digital clock for “Tampa,”,and bright pink for “pink skies.”

LANY was heartfelt, truthful, and exactly how I would’ve pictured them to be based on their emotionally varied compositions. Their vibes were adequately balanced between what you would feel during late night drives at 3 a.m., and feel good tracks at 8 a.m. on a good day. The set list did, however, make me a little confused and left me wanting better from them.  During phases in the night where many already had their heart rates at 120bpm and were ready to jump to beats of the next track, LANY came in with an emotional experience that makes you wonder why you’re still stuck with an absent lover, be it emotionally or physically. While I’m definitely not complaining and admittedly I did have a good cry, it was tough to dance while tears were barely dried from the previous track.

With a genuine expression of gratitude, LANY ended their show with an impressive performance of “ILYSB,” leaving us with the emotions embedded in the same song dedicated to the band itself.

title: SadGirl @ The Hi Hat (10/27/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Rio Hayashi

On October 27, I returned to the Hi Hat for the Halloween season. The brick walls were covered in cobwebs and the audience lurked in elaborate costumes ranging from bloody clowns to Street Fighter characters. This is one of my favorite venues - an abandoned Highland Park pool hall transformed into a rustic warehouse, it is the perfect, hole-in-the-wall venue for an intimate gathering of lo-fi and garage music.

This time, I came for SadGirl for their Halloween tour kickoff. I find it hard to describe SadGirl’s sound. From LA, they’re a fusion of surf, garage, punk-rock with an all-American nostalgic aura… I can feel myself referencing classic west coast films like Quentin Tarantino and Chinatown or sixties bands like The Ventures in every song.

At 11:30 p.m., the stage shone in blue and purple, as Misha Lindes (guitars/vocal) lurked in as a cowboy with bullet holes and blood dripping on his head and neck, along with Dakota Peterson (bass) as a zombie, and Paul Caruso (drummer) in a red devil onesie. They opened the show with “The Hand That Did the Deed,” an instrumental song with a mix of Kill Bill and Dick Dale vibes. The murmuring crowd quickly hushed and was transported into a different era, as SadGirl never fails to do, when Lindes and Peterson began strumming their guitars. After the mellow entrance, they quickly switched pace with “Swine,” and the crowd went ballistic. A mosh pit began in the middle of the floor, with beers flying and toilet paper rolls in the air. Peterson’s bass dictated the heat and the unstoppable force on the dance floor. Lindes looked down and laughed a bit, and returned himself back completely into the performance.

I noticed that they consciously alternated between their upbeat, punk songs and their lo-fi, psychedelic tunes, and cleverly inserted their notable instrumental guitar covers in between. After the audience went berserk over “Swine” and “Penelope’s Leg,” they slowed our heart rates with “Little Queenie.” Lindes’ voice is low and rough but the way it transferred out of the mic was effortlessly clean, pure and silky. His body flailed around to the beat and his eyes rolled around to the melody. I could feel the audience collectively becoming hypnotized by the gentle strumming and his husky voice. I did the same and let my head fall back and sway. He also played my personal favorite, “Jack the Ripper,” a cover of an instrumental guitar song by Link Wray & The Wraymen. They dimmed the lights in red so you can barely see their shadow, and I felt like I was being rocked to bed.

They picked up the pace once again with “Born Dumb” and “Take Me Home,” which are their more aggressive rock selections, and ended the show with “Breakfast Is Over” and “Norma & Jessica,” the two crowd favorites. I was looking forward to these songs because I expected the space to silence in the psychedelic atmosphere, but I was surprised to see that the audience began crowd surfing (one person even got on stage) and toilet paper once again began flying around, even hitting the cymbal at one point. As riveting as the scene was, I felt the audience to be disrespectful throughout and it almost ruined the entire experience for me. Nonetheless, SadGirl never fails to transcend multiple vignettes through their music variety and delicate strums and vocals that keep the audience alive and collective the entire night. When the show ended at 12:08 a.m., it felt like only five minutes passed. I wanted more, and surely will return.

title: Tropicalia Music Festival // Show Preview
content:
Written by Mackenzie Elias and Maria Gasca 

“To survive the Borderlands you must live sin fronteras be a crossroads.”- Gloria Anzaldua

Music is a huge part of one’s identity. It’s not just a listening experience, but can make us feel a wide range of emotions and gives us context and validation for our own feelings. That’s why most of my earliest memories revolve around music.

The sonora dinamita that crackled through the speakers of parent’s vans as we drove on the 210 to get el mandado.

The smell of fabuloso and sounds of Celso Pina ft. my mom’s vocals  at 6 a.m. on Saturday mornings.

Trying to fix the antenna to watch Ivy Queen’s “Que Lloren” on MTV3 because she had me gagging every time.

But as I got older I started to feel disillusioned. I distanced myself from my culture and listened to pura music gavacha, like the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Kings of Leon, No Doubt, and even The Killers (OMG OK, I said it!)

As I got older, I went through a bit of self reflection, and began to listen to my “parents’ music” again. I instantly felt the familiar warmth of nostalgia. But this time I saw myself as a borderland, ni de aqui ni de alla, not being able to be on a side, feeling like a poser on either end. I soon realized, though, that music is borderless, both intangible and present ,and my playlists began to reflect that. Cumbia to rock, bachata to R&B, EDM y reggaeton. I am not a bordertown, I am a crossroad, where cultures meet and live at peace.

This is exactly what the Tropicalia line-up embodies. Its diversity fuses genres and cultures and creates a space where all can feel welcome and accepted. When I saw the line-up, I experienced an intense sense of belonging and joy, because the festival seemed tailored to me. This is the validation I needed growing up.

When I saw Jeanette & King Krule, Tigres del Norte y Banes World sharing space on the lineup, I knew I was not the only one. Tropicalia shows that us “Crossroaders” have enough influence to have our own festival.

November 11 is not just the day of a musical festival in Long Beach, it’s a congregation, a place where we can feel like ourselves, not justifying our identity to anyone, to dance to Thee Commons, eat vegan tacos, and then cry about our exes during Cuco’s set.

title: Father John Misty @ The Greek Theatre (10/13/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Andy Talajkowski 

As crisis looms on the horizon of the USA, more and more of the dazed and confused young population have found solace in the teachings of musician Father John Misty. The most dedicated of the liberal, disillusioned mid-20s Los Angeles crowd sold out the Greek Theatre to share the last ironic laugh with Josh Tillman on his “Pure Comedy” tour.

Weyes Blood (singer-songwriter Natalie Mering) started the night with a satisfying but wholly unexciting opening set. Framed by two electric candelabras that may have been stolen out of a haunted house, Mering’s small touring band took up only a fraction of the stage. But it was Mering’s vocals that took the spotlight (and appropriately so), its rich, mellow, and slightly haunting tone only needing the embellishment of a couple piano chords and her acoustic guitar, the other accompanying instruments chiming in. Her lyrics contain enough curiosity, longing, and love to feel like late night ballads. Indeed, wearing what looked like white silk pajamas, strumming her acoustic guitar, it felt like Mering had just gotten out of bed and walked on stage to play sweet songs into a sleepless night. As she sang Mering’s eyes gazed out to a faraway place, reminding us she belongs to some other world, whether it’s to the audience’s sympathy or chagrin.

While Mering gave a beautiful performance, its low, steady energy didn’t feel appropriate as an opening set. My friend put it a little more bluntly: “I’m bored.” I did feel slightly sedated, Mering’s voice echoing slightly in my ears, as I waited for the headliner.

After a strange period of psychedelic instrumental tracks between sets that could’ve just been Tillman’s personal meditation playlist, the headlining performance began. On the back screen of the stage played demented amateur cartoons that looked like they were lifted from the journal of a sociopathic child (the same creepy characters that decorate the website for Tillman’s new album). Finally Tillman took the stage, his face cast in perfect halves of yellow and blue light, the golden bad, kinda sad boy of folk rock, purveying the crowd for a moment before launching into “Pure Comedy.”  

Unlike the modest cast of Weyes Blood, Tillman filled the stage and his sound with a substantial brass and string accompaniment. The backing flowed with his hopping between folk, rock, and country with an ease even Tillman acknowledged with appreciation towards the end of the night. The variety of songs provided snapshots of the many moods of Tillman, from him strolling across stage declaring war against cell phones and prescription drugs, to his sweet, bumbling comments between songs, to a daring throw of a guitar to a stagehand in a seemingly endless series of instrumental changes. And then there was the dancing. Tillman exhibited sashays, hip thrusts and backwards dips in a style so ungainly yet confident it reminded you that Tillman is a very strange man, who must have quite a bit of sex. His performance was not a centimeter less than the full nine yards, a two hour set with a multiple song encore.

It’s hard to tell how Tillman expresses believing in both everything and nothing. His unrhyming, unadorned lyrics take on the height of American disillusionment in “Bored in the USA,” while he woos adoring listeners with the sweet possibility of “Real Love Baby.” The enthusiasm of the crowd, who stayed out of their seats for the majority of the show, a pair of young men even thrusting their fists into the air with shouts of admiration, proved however he does it, he pulls it off pretty damn well.

title: Current Joys @ The Factory (7/15/17) // Show Review
content:
Written by Duncan Brouwer 

Originally from Arizona and heading into my second year at UCLA, I was, and still am, new to the Los Angeles DIY concert scene. It’s a scene that in large part is spearheaded by independent, often extremely young individuals with a passion for making music accessible to everyone. Although not an expert, I often find that financial and logistical means limit music accessibility more and more every day. I believe that music and its presentation as a commodity modifies its artistic expression for the worse, and that’s why Minty Boi Presents DIY shows in the Los Angeles area are so special. You see not only that Yi Wei (奕维), the man behind the action, is a purveyor of artistic expression, but also that he cares about making music accessible to everyone.

I was fortunate enough to talk with Yi Wei when he guest DJ’d for us on UCLA Radio, and gave away some tickets to his show on July 15. With Current Joys headlining and a rad set including none other than T-Rextasy, Ian Sweet, Hardly Boys, Goose Pimple, and Rumblepak, I was stoked.

Following a visit to the 7-Eleven across the street, me and two friends step into the freight elevator and ascend into Minty Boi’s Factory, a DIY venue in DTLA.  I’m met at the door with a hug from none other than Yi Wei, the Minty Boi himself. Unsure of what to expect other than a lot of black skinny jeans, I find a group of people present for the music, to hear the bands that they love, and in an intimate setting to do so.

My first assessment of the room leaves me lost; maybe because I pictured a warehouse full of laborers, or maybe because the situation is so new to me. Maybe I’m just unsure. I look at the faces around me, I take a deep breath in of cigarette smoke.  The room smells strongly of weed and Goodwill, but it’s not bad. In fact, it is a community of Los Angeles friends who have been a part of the DIY scene forever.

The fluorescent, pink and blue dim combined with the echo of the amber lights lining the street below relaxes me. The paint on the walls is chipping, tin-foil as a repair agent, black paint. The LA skyline is romantically explained through the drone of the guitar and the large windows. The music was complementing the location for a change. The music was complementing everything and everyone.

Surrounded by tiny backpacks, round, gold-rimmed glasses, and leather jackets, “I was happy, weirds me out dude.” In a sea of music and beautiful people, I danced. We danced. It was refreshing to feel a part of something; to feel even the slightest bit of a collective. My night peaked when a glowing, shirtless boy with the mane of a competition horse dove past me into the flow of the crowd. It took me longer than my pals to realize that man was Yi Wei.

Follow @Minty_Boi on Instagram and @MintyBoiShows on Twitter for updates on upcoming shows!

title: High Sunn - Hopeless Romantic // Album Review
content:
Written by Alana Enriquez

San Francisco’s High Sunn, the prolific bedroom pop project of Justin Cheromiah and friends, has returned with its first studio recorded release Hopeless Romantic. The EP is the culmination of three years of astonishingly rigorous production that has resulted in thirty total tracks. Shifting away from their usual lo-fi sound, High Sunn gives us a twinkling dream pop record that Cheromiah describes as a reflection of his “experiences dealing with love, rejection, and yearning, and having a heart and mind full of dreams and desires.” This holds true from the EP’s start to finish, as each track presents a unique glimpse into tender teenage romance.

Hopeless Romantic’s opening track, “Joy of Romance” is a beaming declaration of affection paired with upbeat guitar and drums with a forlorn twist. It’s a suitable introduction, giving us a taste of the key themes and sounds that will proceed throughout the entire EP: beachy rhythms and delicately crooned romantic proclamations. The next track, “Ramen Waitress,” picks up the pace with intense riffs and Cheromiah purring over a “delightful” individual who is “just the one” for him. The track is a heartfelt request for physical contact, all the while keeping with the EP’s upbeat, danceable sound. “Holding Hands” is next, and it’s slower, sing-songy tone brings a new sentimental flare with yet another breathy, sweet message: “all I want is your hand.” Cheromiah is joined by another vocalist on the track, suggesting mutual feelings that are only strengthened by the following song titled “Tears.” The track introduces glimmering synthesizers with a deeper, slower sound, and serves as a promise of emotional support and escape. It highlights a key theme that is present throughout the entire EP, one which emphasizes the hard but wonderful effort that romance requires, and what that looks like for Cheromiah.

“Polaroids” trails this message with distorted vocals and dancing synthesizers. Hopeless Romantic closes with the paradoxically sun-filled “Good Evening,” a familiar celebration of discovering a special person who you desperately wish to stay, or at least meet again. Yet, Cheromiah admits this second meeting doesn’t always goes as planned, lamenting over a relationship that changed, but whose impression remains. “You’re still haunting me” is the final, abrupt end to Hopeless Romantic, leaving us yearning for more.

title: Lightning in a Bottle: Today’s Most Unique Music Festival
content:
Last month marked Lightning in a Bottle’s sixteenth year of providing festival go-ers with a unique five day experience filled with music, food and thought provoking panels. LIB is not your typical festival. It goes above and beyond a traditional music festival experience through its incorporation of art, yoga and guest speakers to not only entertain you but to provide you with some food for thought during this weekend of soul searching. The first thing that stood out to me about LIB was the attendees. Everyone at Lightning in a Bottle is there for a reason that goes way beyond partying. People come from all walks of life; from college kids, vegan enthusiasts to even families. There truly is something for everyone at this festival.

Photo by Juliana Bernstein 

LIB is much more than a music festival. Some of the highlights of the festival include its amazing sunsets and vistas. LIB is set in Bradley, CA among remarkable rolling hills and desert landscapes. You’ll feel completely cut off from the rest of civilization, in a world of serene tranquility and smiling faces. The breathtaking views are contrasted beautifully with intricate art and light displays set up all around the stages. World class DJs dropping huge tracks throughout the weekend is the icing on the cake to this already incredible set up. I highly recommend the meditation look out for some of the best panoramas of the festival.

Photo by Aaron Glassman

You can go as hard as you want at LIB. Make sure to check out the after-hour events all weekend long. One of my personal favorite memories of the festival was Chet Faker’s 3am DJ set. People gathered around in a small tent, laying on the ground and practicing yoga poses to pulsing bass and trippy visuals. But if you do go out and explore all night, make sure you still get up early enough for some morning yoga or check out the 33 singing bowls ceremony at 8am.

Photo by Jacob Avanzato

If you haven’t been to a Do-Lab event, you need to put that at the top of your to-do list. There is such an awesome community of people that emerges at these events that cannot be compared to any other festival. UCLA Radio is a huge supporter of all the Do-Lab events because of their commitment to sustainability and mental growth. Make sure to check out their next festival, Woogie Weekend this July!

title: The Lobster (Dir.Yorgos Lanthimos) // Film Review
content:
Written By : Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 06/03/16

Yorgos Lanthimos’ The Lobster is an unsettling and perplexing look at romance and the unquestioned structures of authority constrict our social relations. In his latest, the Greek film-maker transitions from the anxious and claustrophobic settings of Dogtooth (2009) and Alps (2012) to the sprawling and bleak Irish scenery, lending to The Lobster’s dystopic mood. In the movie, David, a newly-divorced architect (played by Colin Farell), arrives at a hotel where he has 45 days to find a new lover. In the case that he does not succeed, David, as all guests who fail to court a partner, is to be turned into an animal of his choosing – he picks a lobster because of its longevity and fertility. Bereft of reason, the hotel is tinged with alienating power dynamics: single guests at the hotel are treated as subordinates to couples, and compatibility is reduced to a “defining characteristic” shared by two people.

The hotel’s insular nature is disturbed once we are introduced to the Loners, abject dissidents who live in the woods, without partners. These rebels are hunted down by hotel inhabitants in exchange for extra days at the hotel, turning the natural process of love into a question of survival. The film is bifurcated as David soon joins this band of Loners. Here he encounters the Loner Leader (Léa Seydoux) and a Nearsighted Woman (Rachel Weisz), with whom he shares this characteristic. Though this faction strives to undermine the hotel’s way of life, the Loner Leader enforces her own laws to prevent the formation of relationships (including mutilation and the secluding effect of electronic music). In this gradual, yet startling realization we find that perhaps no relationship and no community is formed organically, but only within the bounds of these strict social norms, which to us seem all but normal.

The world of The Lobster is rife with allegorical connections to the world we inhabit. It’s absurdity reflects upon the anxiety of modern-day relationships, in the ambiguous and interpretive way Kafka treated isolation under a growing totalitarian state, or as Buñuel treated the complacency of the bourgeoisie. The film first alienates: with consciously non-emotive performances, jarring scenes of violence and mutilation, and musical accompaniments, which further mystify the film’s tone. But beyond this initial alienating effect, the film resonates. Absurd moments strike horror just as easily as they incite laughter, and tenderness comes in the form of coded gestures, far removed from the direct affection we comprehend. There are informational holes that leave me questioning the schematics of their society long after my first viewing, and performances that expose the fabrication and implausibility of these characters. In questioning the dictums of this world, Lanthimos succeeds in creating pause for us to reflect on what affects our capacity and ability to form relationships.

title: Messenger’s Threnodies // Album Review
content:
Written By : Max Nath, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/22/16

For my air-check last quarter, I desperately searched for music to stream for NMF’s. I had, obviously erroneously, convinced myself that it would be a near-impossible endeavor to find any new music that could even remotely embody the bold, experimental classic (mainly focusing in progressive) rock sound that I have come to treasure. So, to set out in my search, I simply googled the phrase “new prog rock”. I sifted and clicked, scrolled and refined — and eventually, I came upon a new English group called Messenger, that had recently pre-released a song titled Balearic Blue, from their then-upcoming album “Threnodies”.

I was relieved, entranced and at peace. Coming from a music lover whose appreciation of music stems from lying down and listening to Wishbone Ash for hours, I was ecstatic. The long intro. The feeling of countless intricate components coming together to form a boldly beautiful whole product. The spikes in passion and tempo that fade away into whining guitar solos and tranquil bass riffs. The lead singer’s droning — for lack of a better, more technically and lexically positive description — voice. All of these components reminded me of the music that made me fall in love with, well, music.

And then came the next pre-released song, “Calyx”. And then came the disappointment. What I had expected to be another piece of infectiously interesting old-style progressive rock, was instead a boring, run-of-the mill ambient experimentation that loses itself in a desperate attempt to capture a tone of intensity. The elements of the song feel disconnected and disinteresting, and the band seems to focus their energy on building a cheap, movie-trailer style of escalation instead of creating a cohesive and fluid piece. It is rushed, loud, excited — but pointless and random. I felt disillusioned and cheated — my cynical bitterness had been verified.

And then came the album. I went with a “pin the tail on the donkey” style of picking which song I would take the chance in wasting my time on, fearing further disappointment. So I closed my eyes and clicked. On came the song Celestial Spheres. Then, of course, I smiled. And then came the salvation and the redemption.

I could hear the bass and an intentional, inspired groove. An intro that set the tone to tap along too, as ambient background guitar and David Byron-esque vocals set the stage for an explosion of harmonies and melodies that stay true to the original rhythm the listener is initially promised with the onset of the bass. The song tells a story, evolving and ever-changing. The bass is consistent and strong, while the guitars and perfectly unintelligible lyrics combine to spin a tale of majesty. And then — out of nowhere — comes a change in the song with a transition of seemingly spontaneous 3 seconds of jazz-style scatting. The bass increases in strength, and the group effectively employs a frequently overlooked key component: silence. Before the song bursts into its final phase of instrumental passion, the escalation is marked by sudden pauses. Each of these pauses is ended abruptly by an exponentially louder (appropriately so) rush of emotion. The inspired vocals, the powerful bass, the guitars that complement each other so well, and the keyboard that ambitiously lays an intricate layer on top of it all, all combine to the buildup we have all been waiting for. And then the song fades into a calmer, bass-heavy ending, and culminates in a satisfying abruptness that shifts even more attention to the journey Messenger has taken us on.

What I see in this album is the start of something great. Although some of the songs on the album come across as uninspired and uninteresting, they are redeemed by their attempt to capture the essence of the fun, snappy and lengthy tracks that set the original groups that founded the progressive psychedelic genre apart from the rest. Messenger capture a sound and style of music that has been missing for quite some time. And when I experience songs like Celestial Spheres, I find it exceptionally difficult to ignore the massive potential that they have moving forward — the potential to make some kick-ass music.

title: 5 Music Festivals You Can Actually Afford // UCLA Radio Digital Press
content:
Written By : Andy Talajowski, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/16/16

Music festival season is upon us. Already this year’s hype around Coachella and SXSW has us wishing we joined the party in Indio and Austin. Yet the more you look into it, the more you see these shows come at a price - literally. The reality of festivals these days is that if you want to attend, you have to spend. Tickets alone can be upwards of $300, and the added costs of transportation, lodging, and food means the closest most of us get to any of it is the flower crown filter on Snapchat. As much as we’d like to go insane at Bonnaroo or FYF or EDC, the emptiness of our wallets reflect the emptiness of our hearts - that is, until now. In light of the ridiculous cost of mainstream music festivals, I made it my mission to seek out shows across California broke college students would be able to attend. Here are five summer music festivals you can actually afford:

Phono del Sol Music Festival

Where? San Francisco

When? July 9

Phono del Sol has consistently produced lineups that incorporate both great up and coming indie talent (past performers include King Tuff, Thao and the Get Down Stay Down, and Thee Oh Sees) with local Bay Area bands, and this year is no exception. The festival is set to feature Chairlift and Alvvays as headliners, along with SF locals The She’s, Hot Flash Heat Wave, and more. Tickets start at just $40.

In The Red Records 25th Anniversary

Where? The Echo/Echoplex

When? July 14, 15, 16

Garage rock fans, rejoice - The Echo is holding a three day show of your wildest dreams. In The Red Records is celebrating for three days with bands such as The Oblivians, Meatbodies, and The Hunches. The most exciting part? Ty Segall and Mikal Cronin will be performing the entirety of their collaborative album Reverse Shark Attack. Single day passes start at under $30.

Woodsist Festival

Where? Big Sur

When? July 26-27

Get in touch with the trees and some of the best new folk artists in the midst of Big Sur at the Woodsist Festival. Kevin Morby, Woods, and White Fence are already confirmed to perform, although more artists will soon be revealed - groups such as Real Estate and Foxygen have made appearances in the past. Attendees staying for both days can also camp overnight. Prices are more hefty for this festival, but two day passes are still under $150.

San Diego LGBT Pride Music Festival

Where? Balboa Park

When? July 18-19

Not only does San Diego host a pride parade, they throw a dope music festival while they’re at it. Past years have been full of fantastic queer musicians like Mary Lambert and Ruby Rose, and while this year’s full lineup has not been released, Kesha is confirmed to headline. Tickets start at $15, and since it’s a non-for-profit event, all money will go to helping the LGBTQ community. In the past the festival has raised as much as two million dollars in charity (!!!).

Alice’s Summerthing

Where? Golden Gate Park

When? TBA

Bay Area radio station Alice 97.3 hosts a free (that’s right, free) one day concert each summer at Golden Gate Park for their listeners. While the specific date (sometime late June) and performers haven’t been announced, past headliners have been impressive to say the least - Kelly Clarkson, Ed Sheeran, Sara Bareilles, and Ingrid Michaelson have all stepped on stage. No tickets are required, but make sure to show up early - this festival gets packed, fast.

title: Everybody Wants Some // Film Review (Dir. Richard Linklater)
content:
Written By : Anastasia Gershman , UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/11/16

There is something to be said about a director who can make a movie about baseball players that doesn’t show us any baseball for the first 80 minutes of the film, and who then gives us 3 minutes of baseball before turning the camera away.  If that director is Richard Linklater, said film may also stand as one of the sweetest and interesting homages to baseball; college life; the 80’s; and male camaraderie that’s rolled around in a long time.  

Everybody Wants Some!! (2016 dir. Richard Linklater) posits an immensely like-able protagonist in Jake, a freshman baseball player for a Texas university rolling into town on the Thursday prior to the start of classes on Monday.  Ensconced in a rundown house designated for the team and instantly surrounded by the rituals, rites of passage and general antics-about-town of the only sports team on campus that actually wins any games; Jake navigates the weekend with a sense of grace that while understated, is immensely refreshing in contrast to a lot of contemporary narrative heroes.  Jake is young athlete, a kid new to college, and an intelligent and reasonable guy.  He manages to be all of these things without saccharin behavior or any sense of “jumping the shark”.  His ability to roll with the weekend and the team while ferreting out the spaces in his environment where he needs to be an individual form the basis of a gentle, engaging, and ultimately powerful story about what happens when life is right.

As much as the film is Jake’s story, the team itself is the star.  The film feels personal.  A house filled with hyper-competitive young men who compete at everything from ping-pong to bong rips looks different from the inside.  Linklater infuses these scenes with a sense of immediacy and a lived-in experience.  Almost every scene involving the young men who Jake lives with feels genuine, as if we are wandering through the memories of a man who remembers this time of his life with fondness and frankness.  These players compete at any and every game they can possibly devise including the most brutal game of knuckle-flicking ever to make the silver screen – yet manage to band together in their pursuit of every girl on campus in a way that would make any coach proud.
