Jake’s teammates run the gamut from professional college students in their sixth year; to blowhard braggarts with anger issues; to a knock ‘em dead ringer destined for the pros.  Their differences give detail and texture to the unified front that they present to the world and also within the group.  “I can’t believe I’m fighting for this guy” opines a player after their resident hothead gets them thrown out of a bar, and yet he does without question.  When the dressing down of an out-of-line teammate happens on the field through a little mid-game humiliation, his choked-out apology “That was a good hit” shifts his role from bigmouth to bruised compatriot, and with that all is forgiven.  These guys compete at everything; self-police; run their own practices; and do what it takes to get along.  It’s an astute and insightful look into athletic life and team politics when the members of the group are determined to be successful and functioning (for the most part) at a sane and reasonable level.

Set in late summer of 1980, the boys navigate a world before cellphones, HIV and college debt.  When Jake falls for a pretty freshman, he goes to her door and tapes a handwritten note.  It’s a device that takes us back to the time when pursuit of a girl meant actually going to where the girl was, and even to young eyes that might not remember these days, the moment rings beautifully true.  When she calls, we share in his elation and go for the ride right along with him.  The same can be said of the rest of the story.   Everybody Wants Some!! is a graceful film that brims with nostalgia without becoming syrupy or treacle.  Instead, it’s a moment to wander in memories that you wish were your own. The best film I’ve seen so far this year. Check it out.

title: Kevin Morby : Singing Saw // Album Review
content:
Written By : Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 05/05/16

I had the pleasure of seeing Kevin Morby perform live the day after the release of his newest solo album, Singing Saw. I showed up with relatively little knowledge of his music, a gamble that soon paid off - I immediately listened to the entirety of Singing Saw upon returning home from the show, and without doubt found it to be my favorite album of 2016 so far. Morby, while maintaining an overall rock feel, incorporates strong influences from country, folk, and blues, creating a deep yet gentle sound. The feel of the album shifts and evolves - the upbeat “I Have Been to the Mountain” integrates brass instruments with a funkier bass line, while “Singing Saw” evokes mystery with haunting backing vocals, and “Destroyer” juxtaposes a breezy, carefree sound with eerie lyrics of a love long gone. Overall the rich, simple sound immerses you in feeling of calm introspection. Singing Saw evokes many emotions - wonder, contentment, nostalgia, sorrow - but doesn’t force you to confront them, choosing instead to allow you to reflect and appreciate. The music also provokes strong imagery of nature - the lyrics use wilderness metaphors galore to explore deeper themes of religion, life, and love. The music feels as if it’s being played to you like a tale being told beside a soft, crackling campfire in the woods. As the storyteller, Morby intrigues you with his strong, bittersweet vocals that make your heart ache, and makes himself sound like a man much beyond his mere 28 years. Overall Singing Saw awakens a quiet and honest beauty within itself that makes it so damn good. I recommend it to any fans of Kurt Vile and the like or Morby’s other projects (he is also part of The Babies and Woods), along with anyone who’d rather be reminiscing in a log cabin instead of procrastinating on midterms.

title: Drake : Views // Album Review
content:
Written By : Harold Gonzalez, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 05/03/16

VIEWS was meant to be Drake’s Magnum Opus. All the previous works leading up to this album implied that the Canadian rapper had evolved into a confident, vicious and quite frankly immaculate figure in pop culture. Fresh off the hot streak that was the success of his “mixtape”, If You’re Reading This, It’s Too Late, and a lukewarm yet extremely quotable What a Time to Be Alive, Drake was setting the scene for an album that would change every single nonbeliever’s opinion that he was indeed becoming the pop culture tyrant nobody could touch. He was no longer wallowing in empty feelings brought on by his past-relationships, he was no longer desperate to prove his worth to other critiques, and he felt secured in his own holy city. So when the album’s title gave the impression that Drake would piece together a love-letter to his home fueled by the fire of having reached the peak of his career, many sat back and anxiously waited for the awe-inspiring arrival of the 6god.

Many are still waiting, myself included.

The opener to this hour-and-a-half journey is built around sincere feelings of lost friendships and dead intimacy. Drake’s passionately sung vocals are glossy and vibrant; they sit on top of what sounds like the most grandiose and expensive orchestral arrangement that hip hop has seen in the past decade. This façade of beauty and elegance acts as an intriguing doorstep to Drake’s soul-in-audio. If one pays close attention, however, we can find missteps in lyrical direction right from these beginning moments, such as “Ever since you met me / Like when Chrysler made that one car that looked just like the Bentley”. The number of offenses increases as the cuts on the record quickly run by. References to Happy Meals, keychains going “jang-a-lang”, “LOLOL”, being “green like Earth Day” , keeping it “100 like a fever”, and other blatantly cheap, amateurish punchlines take away from any kind of honest and solemn tones that run through extremely sparsely produced tracks. It is as if Drake forgot how to piece together a cohesive and interesting thought without wanting to be cheeky. At the same time, the VIEWS themselves are not really relating at all to the city as much as they are VIEWS into a rearview mirror. Drake has not completely forgiven many instances where he was either betrayed or set aside and he is painfully bitter on many tracks (most notably “Child’s Play”). The 6god has resorted once again to attempting to reconcile with individual women instead of glancing forward to the future. VIEWS, lyrically, on various occasions resembles more like a hastily, handwritten note directed at individuals from his past than the boundary-pushing ode to his efforts to reach success and his city that many desired.

And it’s not like Drake is not capable. “Weston Road Flows” is a great example of a track that invites his listener to walk alongside him, a humble messiah-like figure that delivers flawless flows riddled with details and scenes of his youth. The production on this track is sweetly enveloping, with a honeysuckle sample of Mary J. Blige’s “Mary’s Joint” hanging behind his vocal mix. As his disciples listened onward, they prayed he would deliver more infectious picks like this one.

Deliver is a strong term for the next three batch of tracks that listeners are introduced to. “Redemption”, “With You” and “Faithful” are rich with filler. They are beautifully produced, yet not the standouts of production that other tracks like “Feel No Ways” are. They touch on unnecessary topics from the chick who finessed Drake out of money for using a voicemail without permission (“Redemption”) to cliché remarks on being a secondary priority in a relationship where the listener can plug their own names into the Mad-Libs and feel special (“Faithful”). These songs aren’t horrible, but they’re extremely forgettable. There could be a slight saving grace on “With You” but as of listening to this over and over for the past three days, the lack of lyrical depth makes me only question whether or not Drake needs help when writing. The credits don’t list many writers, and where I usually find it admirable to be genuine and not use any ghostwriters, the 6god could have had a saint or two help him out with his depth.

Drake is his most influential when he oozes with confidence and self-respect. A god has no reason to wallow over petty missteps, especially those which happened long before the power and success was granted. “Hallelujah Hallelujah Hallelujah, 6 point star, lion of the Judah”: THIS 6god was missing a lot on this record. The 6god that demands attention and acknowledges his affluence over many while still remaining humble to the people and city that placed him where he is currently was desperately needed on many bits of this record.

Nope. Instead his followers receive, along with the aforementioned cascade of filler, three blatant attempts to reach a #1 on Billboard by piggybacking on the, quickly being exhausted, Dancehall style. It’s not to say that these tracks, “Controlla”, “One Dance”, and “Too Good”, are not audibly pleasing or festive. They will be frequent go to’s for this summer’s gatherings. However, the 6god pretending to be a Caribbean diety is distasteful for an album that is meant to be a culminating project. This is a relatively recent trend that the Canadian has milked and extorted without any remorse on VIEWS.

The title track is another great reminder of how Drake could have decided to handle his apparent Magnum Opus. “Views” opens with the ferocious flow that can only be attributed to a drive for more success. It is an anthem for his followers, for the OVO label, for the people of Toronto to nod their heads to as they visualize the snow falling once again in the middle of a heat wave. These kinds of tracks are extremely reminiscent of vintage mixtape Drake, and that’s not a bad move at all. Inspired by movements of his city, “Views” has a couple lyrical jewels that address haters and genuine friends’ loyalty to the man. It makes me acknowledge that despite these shortcomings, Drake managed to piece together an album that is just a conglomerate of all his past styles, just unfortunately too heavily focused on petty relationship issues. Drake proved he could be a big boy on IYRTITL and a return to the days of Nothing Was the Same just feels extremely out of place on this album. The imagery, the tone, the sentiments that are delivered by the artwork on this record do not match those that are vocally expressed. In terms of production, the team behind Drake should really be getting a large cut from all the monetary figures. Drake picks a handful of beautiful, spacious beats but they are easily forgettable when Drake himself has nothing special to mention.

Favorites: “Still Here”, “Hype”, “Weston Road Flows”, “Keep the Family Close”

Least Favorites: All those Caribbean ones and “Grammys”

5/10

Quick side notes: “Grammys” feels like a “Future featuring Drake” track and Future is nauseating. I don’t really want to listen to that again despite the fact that What a Time to Be Alive was a generally amusing record. Also, the 6god was afraid to be overshadowed on “Pop Style” by Kanye. “Fire & Desire” was more beautifully spacious filler as we see the 6god once again succumbing to a woman who he can’t have. I was also afraid not a lot of people had heard “Hotline Bling” so it’s good to see it wind up on the track list.

title: Explosions in the Sky’s “The Wilderness” // Album Review
content:
Written By : Stefanie Tam, UCLA Radio DJ 

Post Date  : 04/29/16

Too often do we listen to albums and narrowly see that the emotional and impactful part of music comes directly from the lyrics, and too often do we rely on listening to the lyrics to explicitly and concretely communicate the artist’s emotions; Explosions in the Sky’s album, The Wilderness, begs you to question this habitual state of listening, as it acts as a very important reminder that, music, stripped down to nothing but pure instrumental sound, can still clearly communicate a strong narrative and express emotions that one can resonate with on a subconscious, unexplainable level.  Released on April 1st,  The Wilderness is a 9 song, 46 minute album, and is the first non soundtrack album that Explosions in the Sky has come out with since 2011.  Instead of the music being driven by a previously created plot of movies, this album paints entire natural scenes with the layered, methodical sounds found in every song.  

Listening to instrumental music always gets me excited, as it leaves more room to the imagination; I find myself closing my eyes in a near meditative state, allowing the music to transport me to a whole new natural environment.  From the beginning to the end, I can’t help but imagine myself flying over these dramatic, vast, unadulterated landscapes that one only sees in drone-recorded movie shots like that found in National Geographic that highlight the overwhelming and endless beauty of the natural world– it brings us to exactly what the title is, the wilderness.  As I envision myself soaring through, there’s a great sense of hopefulness that there is more to come as every new drumbeat or instrument is introduced.  At times, with songs like “Tangle Formations” we are given only hints, whispers of the images they try to create, and all at once it will hit you, much like that of seeing the first firefly of thousands light up, only to be followed by the rest on a warm summer midnight.

While The Wilderness is a newly released album, it feels like an album that I once listened to in a distant past, as it brings this great, romanticized sense of nostalgia, whether it be of good or bad memories.  The song “Wilderness” has that feeling of self-growth, hopefulness, and attention/appreciation of the beauty of the world, all while the slightly unsettling sounds of “Logic of a Dream” and “Losing the Light”  bring upon the memories reflective of both the fear of the monsters in the closet one had as a kid, but also the comforting memory of one’s mom coming in to hold and reassure that it’s all a dream.  Even with this contrast, there is a sense of warmth and coziness with every song that comes hand in hand with the sentiment of our nostalgic pasts that every song in The Wilderness has.

The Wilderness makes one feel alone– alone in the self reflective sense– like traveling through a neighborhood slightly brushed in snow as everyone is tucked away under their warm blankets, as you walk through, warm and introspective, with only the low-lit yellow street lamps illuminating your way back home.  It is only when one experiences this aloneness that one can notice the little things, like the chilling, yet refreshing inhale of the cool midnight air, the light crushing sound of snow beneath one’s feet, or the crisp breeze through one’s hair, and the rhythmic, intricately layered sounds that Explosions in the Sky continuously produces throughout this album.  The Wilderness’s rhythmic, yet mysteriously comforting sounds make us unconsciously think introspectively in relation to the great, yet slightly unnerving world that envelops us.

title: Tacocat - “Lost Time” // Album Review
content:
Written By : Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 07/04/16

UCLA Radio note: UCLA Radio will be co-presenting Tacocat, with Spaceland Presents, at The Echo this month on Tuesday, July 19. As the show date gets closer, we will be promoting the fabulous band and their upbeat music. Below is our album review of their newest record Lost Time. We’d love to see at the show ~ tickets are just around $10 and it’s an 18+ event. Come hang out with some of your favorite DJs!

The term “summer anthem” is useless in many ways, given it’s mostly manipulated to sell mediocre likeable pop singles, but there is some music that feels like it belongs to the summer, and Tacocat’s Lost Time is just that. The album, which features an excellent blend of garage rock with a healthy dose of riot grrrl, elicits those old, familiar feelings of frustration, exhilaration, and mischievousness that perfectly complements a nostalgia for adolescent boredom and the shenanigans one inevitably falls into during the long summer days and nights.

While the album initially feels a little tame, it unleashes itself with the raucous “Lost in Seattle,” and blossoms from there. The teenage angst sound is layered with quite witty commentary on a variety of issues, from internet trolls to gentrification to X-Files. Tracks “Plan A, Plan B,” and “Men Explain Things to Me,” take on current feminist concerns with a cleverness and vigor that would make Kathleen Hanna proud. “Talk,” one of the strongest tracks on the album, draws you in with a swaying rhythm and the seduction of Emily Nokes’ vocals, and forces you to acknowledge its request, “I wanna dance.” The frankness and quirkiness of Tacocat’s sound allows it to pull of some tracks that, under other circumstances, would most likely crash and burn - it wasn’t until the chorus of the upbeat “Horse Grrls” that I realized I had been jamming out to a song that was actually, totally about horses.

The subject matter of and critiques made in the album are most definitely its strongest feature, and lifts the album above the sea of recent garage rock punk releases. Yet the rich variety of themes isn’t quite matched by the sound, which, while fun and carefree, doesn’t quite manage to break free of repetitiveness and monotony by the end of the album. Still Lost Time is a success for the band and the use of music as cultural criticism, and even though Tacocat had already won my eternal admiration when they announced they were recording the new Powerpuff Girls theme, their newest album left me overall impressed.

title: Blonde Redhead Concert Review @ Masonic Lodge at Hollywood Forever (5/27/2016)
content:
Written By: Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 06/13/2016

Just hours before the final show of their West Coast tour, the band Blonde Redhead posted a photo from the previous night’s show with the caption “Woooow Masonic lodge! What a venue/cemetery/chapel! We are honored to play there for 2 nights. I wish it was not sold out and lots more people can come. If it was in Japan, they would let twice as many people in 🙊but I respect it.” While I certainly understand the sentiment, I must say that in all my years as a patron of concerts big and small, across all genres of music, I don’t think I’ve ever witnessed a more perfect pairing of artist, venue, and audience than Blonde Redhead and the Masonic Lodge at Hollywood Forever Cemetery.

The Lodge’s high ceilings gave the layers of music plenty of room to travel. The guitars and vocals, already drenched in reverb, echoed through the hall. The crowd with the intimate energy of 150 true fans carried with it a special kind of buzz. Every emotion was heightened. Songs with stripped instrumental textures like “Barragán” and “Lady M” had more space to resonate while the faster, energetic numbers like “Spring By Summer Fall” and the closing number “Equus” were compressed and transformed into hardcore garage rock.

Throughout their 23 year career, Blonde Redhead seems to have mastered their own brand of minimalism. Each member walked onstage with the sole intent of allowing the music to play out in the purest way possible. Kazu Makino seemed to effortlessly flow between her guitar and keyboard, sometimes even eschewing both and taking the stage with just a microphone in hand. Vocals alternated between songs with Kazu’s delicate and airy siren and guitarist Amedeo Pace’s strong tenor providing beautifully unconventional contrast in colors and lyrical stories.

Whatever arrangement the song called for, no one in the band missed a beat. Sometimes Amedeo would end a song kneeling at his pedalboard, turning knobs and activating loops, deconstructing the well-crafted riff that had been a melodic centerpiece just moments before. Transitions like this between songs kept everyone in the audience swaying even when no discernable melodies or backbeats could be heard. The Lodge’s acoustics transformed Simone Pace’s (Amedeo’s twin brother) tight drums into an expansive wall of percussion. Every sound from the lowest tom to the strike of the synth pad echoed across the room. Rhythm tracks that served as a solid foundation on the recordings became moving pieces of a train on which the minimalist melodies and textures of the other instruments were carried.

While it’s true that the room could have held more than 150 people, the extra space made for larger than life acoustics and allowed everyone to sway and dance freely without worrying about tripping on anyone else’s toes.

title: DJ Best Case's Guide to Summer 2016 Films
content:
Written By : Casey Lee, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 06/03/16

Ah, summer. Not only is it the season for frolicking in the sunshine, but it’s also the time of year where film studios churn out their big blockbusters and hope to attract hefty audiences. Last year, we saw quite a few flashy flicks such as Avengers: Age of Ultron, Jurassic World, and of course, Minions. Despite the lineup breaking a few box office records, I wasn’t impressed by these offerings, with Inside Out as the solely enjoyable exception. This summer, however, I have a higher hopes. With a mix of splashy action and family-friendly fun, here are five movies I’m personally looking forward to for the upcoming months, ordered by their release date.

Warcraft (June 10 2016)

I’ve never played World of Warcraft (#2007Runescape4lyfe), but I am nevertheless curious to see how Duncan Jones’ adaptation of the beloved computer game will turn out. Featuring a fantasy clash between orcs and humans and ambitious CGI, Warcraft will either achieve greatness and break from the pattern of failed cinematic retellings of computer and video games, or become yet another victim of its own genre.

Finding Dory (June 17 2016)

Apparently, the first 27 minutes of this film reminded people of the opening sequence of Up. Aside from the Toy Story series, I am pretty wary about Pixar sequels (I didn’t even really hate Cars at all, but Cars 2 was something else), but the vibrant underwater world of Finding Nemo should give plenty of fun material for Pixar to continue to play with, and I am intrigued to see where they went with for Finding Dory.

The BFG (July 1 2016)

Roald Dahl’s novels are utter delights. With imaginative classics such as Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Matilda, and James and the Giant Peach, it is no wonder that Dahl’s stories are frequently adapted for movies and musicals. This summer, The BFG (my personal favorite!) is finally getting its turn in the limelight. Its recent trailers show promise, as The BFG looks to match the fantastical aspects of its source material with giants and dreams abound.  And hey, if it doesn’t turn out as great as we’d hoped — there’s always the book.

Suicide Squad (August 5 2016)

The premise of Suicide Squad is a refreshing take on the typical superhero team movie; whereas the Avengers and (probably eventually) the Justice League fight for good because they are good, the Suicide Squad is made up of dangerous, unstable supervillains that do what they’re told simply because they’re forced to. With an exciting premise and great cast, one can only hope that DC will more than redeem itself from Batman v Superman.

Kubo and the Two Strings (August 19 2016)

Produced by the same studio that gave us Coraline, Kubo and the Two Strings is a stop-motion film set in ancient Japan.

Its trailer fascinated me, as I am a sucker for fantasy, beautiful stop-motion, and creepy witch characters , and it also gets bonus points for having an epic cover of While My Guitar Gently Weeps play as the background song.

title: Bibio - Mineral Love // Album Review
content:
Written By : Alison Chi, UCLA Radio Music

Post Date : 05/30/16

English producer Bibio released his seventh studio album A Mineral Love on April 1, 2016. The album is significantly different from his 2013 release Silver Wilkinson — A Mineral Love is like a self-exploration with Bibio playing with more synth pop and vocals distortion. Before this album, Bibio mostly crafted chill electronica that had a lot of experimental pop to it.

Bibio still creates songs that are classically pop and appeal easily to listeners. Tracks like “Town & Country” and “Why So Serious? feat. Olivier St. Louis” have the catchy rhythm and blissed out synth pop that make it an easy favorite. However, there are tracks on this album that are darker in sound that set a more serious tone and sound. “A Mineral Love” and “C’est La Vie” both take things slower and have muted vocals that almost give the tracks a sense of nostalgia, like hearing the song through the phone.

The album finishes with “Light Up The Sky”, which is a perfect culmination of the album. The rhythm is slow and the Bibio really plays with the different layers on this track: using delays and slight reverbs to great this dreamy song. The high pitch of the vocals is also reminiscent of some Passion Pit tracks but there is also a mild funk on the track that echoes the likes of the Minneapolis psych funk scene.

A Mineral Love is a collage, a collage of the different sounds Bibio can craft. No two songs sound the same on the album and each song has some elements from different songs, allowing all of them to fit into an album. What I love the most about this album is that there’s a song for almost any mood: some songs are slow, some are bittersweet, some are happy, and etc. It’s definitely an album worth exploring, figuring out what you like and what you don’t but there is definitely something for everyone.

title: Weekly Recommendations // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Here are some comedy things that we recommend checking out this week:

The Meat Improv: In this brand new podcast, Josh Simpson and Jake Jabbour bring on improvisers to tell meaty stories, and then improvise scenes based on them! Casual, professional, and to the point. Don’t listen to it on the bus because people will think you’re crazy for laughing so much.
With Special Guest Lauren Lapkus: She’s the host but she’s also the guest! Every episode Lauren Lapkus brings on different guests to host the podcast while she performs original characters coming on as guests. It’s always a new podcast and always a new guest.
Dean Cole: ​Stand-up comedian, used to write for Conan, go see him.
Gayle: Chris Fleming plays a deranged hardcore East Coast soccer mom.
Mr.  Pickles​: Cartoon on AdultSwim about a satanic dog who malisciously murders people. One of the most fucked up cartoons ​we​’ve seen but it’s hilarious. ​You can watch most episodes onadultswim.com.
Catastrophe​: The creation of the British and American comedy duo Sharon Horgan and Rob Delaney. The British sitcom is blunt and sharp while maintaining a light, lovable quality. Available on Amazon prime.
Baby Cobra​: Ali Wong, writer for fresh off the boat, performs while 7 months pregnant in this Netflix special. Unafraid of embarrassing herself, Wong discusses her sex life to what noises her body makes. Maron noted, “she has huge balls​.​”

title: Captain America: Civil War // Film Review
content:
Written By : Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press (05/18/16)

Post Date : 05/18/16


Captain America: Civil War is the third film bearing the Captain America name, and of course, one of countless other titles in the slew that shapes the Marvel Universe.


Admittedly, “Superhero" sits right behind “Post-Apocalyptic” when it comes to genres I’m beyond exhausted with.  I’m bored with origin stories, citywide destruction, empty motivations, and final battles at high altitudes.  If variety is the spice of life, superhero films are an unseasoned chicken breast.

Once the title card dissipates in Civil War, we’re treated to an espionage-type sequence featuring Black Widow, The Falcon, Wanda Maximoff, and our title character himself.  If you saw this film’s predecessor, The Winter Soldier, this scenario should feel pretty familiar to you.  But once the real confrontation starts, the action is impeccably choreographed, and the shots are actually sympathetic to what the human eye is capable of processing.  The Russo brothers endowed so much imagination into every single fight scene in this film, and it’s absolutely refreshing to be able to see every detail of it.

The opening sequence culminates in, you guessed it, an explosion.  What happens next however, is what kind of took me by surprise: Dozens of civilians are unequivocally dead, and our heroes are visibly distraught over their own actions.  Meanwhile, Iron Man’s alter ego Tony Stark, is confronted by a grieving mother whose son was killed in the aftermath of a battle initiated by The Avengers in the previous film.

In its exposition alone, Captain America: Civil War manages to do something groundbreaking for the genre.  Finally, our protagonists are forced to deal with the inadvertent consequences of their “heroism.”  Most importantly, they face the reality that these large scale threats are caused by the very existence of superheroes themselves.


The actual war between our heroes is set in motion when the US Secretary of State (played by William Hurt) suggests that The Avengers should agree to government oversight in the wake of recent events.  Steve Rogers (Captain America) is immediately opposed to the plan, fearing the government’s agenda and the very notion of having to be dispatched at its discretion.  Stark on the other hand, believes that The Avengers should be put in check, reminding Rogers of all the needless death and chaos that has occurred on their behalf.
You may go into the film knowing full well that you’re #TeamCap or #TeamIronMan, but the film will challenge you to see both sides of the conflict: Captain America’s position is driven by foresight and confidence in The Avengers’ judgment without government intervention.  Conversely, Iron Man is coming from a place of pure remorse and a newfound sense of responsibility. 

You’ll be hard pressed to pick a side, and this works especially well for a film that deals with a split between protagonists.

While the film’s focus is primarily the aforementioned conflict, various other story elements come into play to enhance the plot: We get an origin story for Black Panther, a very significant role for the Bucky the Winter Soldier, and, my personal favorite, a sweet introduction to the new incarnation of Spider-Man. 

Tom Holland’s take on Spidey may be my favorite thus far, and that’s saying a lot given his limited screen time.  At this point, its worth noting that this film runs a significant risk by including so many characters in its lineup, but it mostly succeeds in giving everyone a chance to play a significant, or at least memorable role.  Yes, the Spider-Man and Black Panther appearances partially serve to hype up their upcoming solo films, but these characters stand up so well on their own that I don’t even mind the implicit advertising.  Other characters, namely Hawkeye and Ant-Man, are extremely fun to watch during the big battle, but are pretty much only added to increase its scope.

Speaking of the much anticipated battle scene between the two camps, I thoroughly appreciated how fun and astonishingly creative it all feels when it comes together—Almost like the action figure battles you’d stage during elementary school summers.  It would have been easy for the Russo brothers to bog down the battle’s tone in order to fit in with Civil War’s darker themes, but the bright mood they chose made for a very refreshing balance.  Our characters can face trauma and deal with real-world conflict, but we also have to remember that this film takes place in a universe where superheroes are fathomable.

Without spoiling too much, I also want to add the fact that Marvel was finally able to craft a villain that doesn’t feel completely uninspired.  The conflict could have been left up to the heroes alone, but the inclusion of this surprisingly sympathetic third party further strengthens the overarching notion about the unintended consequences of heroism.

My complaints are sparse, but they have to do with the film’s 3 hour runtime and the eventual resolution.  While not bad by any means, I found that Civil War’s conclusion stopped on a harmonious note that just didn’t seem likely to me considering the events that had just taken place.  I think the writers should have taken a risk by proposing a more somber ending, just to make the impact of this civil war seem that much more resonant or meaningful.

After the success of Deadpool, Civil War comes as another big win for Marvel both at the box office and in my heart.  So maybe I’ll consider taking back what I said about the redundancy of superhero flicks for now.  Captain America: Civil War sets a new bar for the genre and spruces up the formula with zestful creativity.  Not an unseasoned cut, but a piquant chicken parm.

title: EDM Sub-Genre Breakdown // UCLA Radio Digital Press
content:
Written By : Ivana-Beija Faria, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/15/16

The term EDM broadly encompasses a plethora of genres and sub-genres of percussive electronic music. According to Magnetic Mag, the acronym “EDM” was created by, “the American music industry and press as a buzzword to describe the increasingly commercial US electronic music scene” in order to re-brand rave culture.  Therefore, EDM is not a legitimate genre of music but a handy blanket term describing music stemming from a mixture of Funk/Disco/Hip Hop/Pop and Early Synth Music from the 1960s-1980s.

I’d like to shed some clarity on a few sub-genres of House and Breakbeat that are often categorized under the umbrella term, EDM. It is important to note that it is not only common, but most often the case that DJ producers harmonize several genres and sub-genres. Like with most music, it is not always a clear divider between genres but a continuum.

HOUSE

House music is said to have originated in Chicago in the early 1980s. It is characterized by repetitive 4/4 beats provided by drum machines, making this music very easy to dance to. Spring forward to the present day and some styles of House music have commercialized by collaborating with Pop sounds and vocalists, leading to a pervasive and infectious beat often heard on the radio. Present leaders in this genre include:

-Steve Aioki, Avicci, Alesso, Hardwell, Alvaro, Calvin Harris, Above and Beyond, Porter Robinson, and Kaskade

Subgenres include (but are not limited to):

-Tropical House

-Kygo- https://soundcloud.com/magictomyhears/often-kygo-remix

-Years & Years- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6nJCF01b510

-Matoma- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sb3XfrCtjVU

-Electro/Future/Deep House

-Disclosure- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bkk2H3Ztrfk

-Tchami- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EFS3T321VUY

-Gorgon City- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j8yn-5S6Bnc&list=PLpNx9qIt3HLyzW42zygPnLBfOtEhtInpO&index=9

-Big Room/ Tech House

-Hardwell- https://soundcloud.com/hardwell/hardwell-spaceman-out-now

-Calvin Harris- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgqUJOudrcM

-Martin Garrix- https://soundcloud.com/martingarrix/martin-garrix-animals-original

BREAKBEAT

Breakbeat music is a vast genre that includes many subgenres characterized by syncopated beats and hip hop samples. This genre originated in the 1990s from the American rave scene that then, typically stuck to house and techno. What distinguishes Breakbeat from House is its use of heavy bass and fast tempos.  Present popular artists include:

-Daft Punk, The Chemical Brothers, Bassnectar, Fatboy Slim, Feed Me

Subgenres and their artists include (but are not limited to):

-Bass House

-Jauz- https://soundcloud.com/jauzofficial/feelthevolume

-AC Slater- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xHTbqAfFbVo

-Dr. Fresch- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xkMIJIklxYs

-Ghastly- https://soundcloud.com/ghastly/bitchughastly

-Future Bass/Experimental Trap

-Flying Lotus- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ScYz9sNaQk

-Shlohmo- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MHMcrfXxlDM

-Odeza- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UW0vOum0mBM

-Moombahcore

-Major Lazer- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RljexCqQC0w

-Dillion Francis- https://soundcloud.com/dillonfrancis/dillon-francis-dj-snake-get

-Trap

-Flosstradamus- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OcvunrplrZc

-RL Grime- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=04ufimjXEbA

-Valentino Khan- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1wl5BbUg05M

This is a very cursory exploration of theses genres. It is difficult to adequately describe these complex genres and sub-genres so succinctly. This is a mere attempt to educate one on the basics of popular “EDM” style music.

Source: http://www.magneticmag.com/2015/10/stop-calling-edm-edm-here-is-a-proper-definition/

title: Cellars “Phases” // Album Review
content:
Written By: Stefanie Tam, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 05/09/16

Like a deep maroon shag carpet laced with glitter, Cellars’s album, Phases, is drenched with shimmery notes and echoey reminders of the overdone 80s.  Phases exists from a different time; it’s not an album we can identify with, resonate with, or be reminded of a very real human emotion we’ve experienced in our past bringing a wave of nostalgia, but it is an album that we can appreciate for the image it paints of the very campy time of the 80s.  It highlights the clashing colored clothes, the over romanticized and tacky high school dances, a bubbly, exaggerated way of perceiving the world– but not necessarily in a way that sounds nearly as bad as how I describe it.

At times throughout the album, especially during that of “Still in Love,” one can’t help but feel as though they’re uncomfortably witnessing a tacky 80s movie where the lead has an overdone perm, all while catching the eye of her romantic interest from across the disco lit dance floor.  While we may not like to admit it, maybe Norton has captured that gross, glittery, shimmery look in our eyes that we have when we are in love that we now so desperately try to hide in this time of empowerment of the individual.  At the same time, it feels somewhat resemblant to that of a corny soap opera, something that people shamefully watch at 2 in the morning when no one else is aware.  We fear the judgment of others; we fear the idea of liking something tacky and sappy, what one could argue to be an embodiment of the 80s.  Yet, with Cellars’s mesmerizing voice and repetitive pop synth sound, we can learn to let go and just indulge ourselves in tapping into the sappiest level of our subconscious emotions and not care about this the judgment of others.

Once one, especially myself, lets go of this negative impression of the tackiness and melodramatic ways of the 80s, there is much more space to enjoy the layered, glimmer-y, and grossly nostalgic aspect of this music.  While many of the songs on her album take on the more darkened, sexually layered side of the 80s, like that of “Curse Your Love,” the album also has a few playful songs like “Toys” that remind us of that fun, shamelessly colorful side of the 80s that we can look back at and say, “Hey, at least we tried it.”  What is entirely captivating about this album is that, while it would be very easy for Allene Norton’s music to all mash together into one big pile of shimmery goo, each song stands uniquely on its own– something entirely credited to Cellars’s talents, rather than the era by which she was inspired.

Like in the beginning of my review, many have these negative preconceptions of the 80s and see it as a cringeworthy time that we can now mindlessly joke about.  However, what Allene Norton is doing here is creating revivalist music to perhaps redeem and showcase the free spirited and unashamedly gross, sentimental times that we call the 80s.

title: Show Review // Grimes + Christine and the Queens @ Shrine Expo Hall (4/21/16)
content:
Written By : Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio DJ 

Post Date : 05/05/16

With a title like ‘March of the Pugs,’ I didn’t know quite what to expect for Grimes’ tour with Christine and the Queens and Tei Shi. But the title seems to communicate the instinctual whim artists like Grimes have to disregard tradition taste-making and to embrace pop culture, along with all of its kitsch and pomp.

While I missed Tei Shi’s set, her experimental and slick pop sound on the 2015 release Verde fits perfectly with that of the following acts. Christine and the Queen’s set began with a deep, pulsing bass which grew into a striding beat as the lively frontwoman Héloïse Letissier entered on the stage for the song “iT” with a group of male dancers clad in black. While I had no experience with the band before, “iT” was a great first introduction, complete with Christine’s playful and theatrical style. As Letissier displayed her syncopated dancing, the song moved into a melodic dialogue on gender and sexuality. Transforming the venue into a French discotèque, Christine and the Queens put on quite a performance, with choreographed dance sequences and explosive outtros. The group paid tribute to Prince on the eve of his death by covering his song “I Feel For You,” which was originally performed by Chaka Khan. Letissier praised Prince’s extraordinary creativity and ability to break from pop music’s gender norms. It would be fair to say that Grimes, Christine and the Queens and Tei Shi follow him down this path.

Entering in with “Realiti,” Grimes introduced the audience to her own world of warped poptimism and upbeat eccentricity. While there were no costume changes during the course of the show, one could feel her voice underwent many transformations. On songs off of Visions her voice took on a sweet and mystical quality, while clarity on songs from Art Angels evoked confidence, passion, and even fury. Performing “Scream,” Grimes gave an intense rendition of Aristophanes’ verse in Russian, doing her own screaming throughout, of course. After flippantly remarking that she thought the song was great, despite its apparent controversy, she played her moody banger, “Go,” to the delight of the crowd.

The show was geared towards spectacle, the stage and costume design looking as if it were off the set of Mad Max: dystopian and chic. Grimes was accompanied by HANA on backup vocals and by an all-female dance crew, equipped with acrobatic ribbons, sai, and flowers to toss out to the audience. After closing out with the raucous “Kill V Maim,” Grimes left the stage to be played out by Prince’s “Let’s Go Crazy.” Though we’d spent the whole night dancing along, there was time for one more go.

title: To Dip or Not to Dip ? // UCLA Radio Sports Op-ed
content:
Written By : Chase Madorsky, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date : 05/02/16

It has been as synonymous with baseball as the fastball, bat flip, and suicide squeeze, and has been a staple of the game dating back to the days of baseball’s first superstar, Babe Ruth, who endorsed the Pinch Hit brand. Ranging from kids movies such as Little Big League, where a player wraps a string of gum around an egregious wad of chew, to watching current sluggers such as Chris Davis play with bulges in their lips, chewing (smokeless) tobacco, or dip, has long been associated with America’s national pastime.

Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Francisco; all cities home to some of the MLBs largest and most profitable markets, and more recently, home to chewing tobacco free stadiums. Recently, by a 44-3 vote, the New York City Council added the city to this growing list, banning the use of chewing tobacco at both Yankee Stadium and the Mets’ Citi Field for both players and fans. This legislation has led to a mixed response amongst the baseball community, with fans applauding the vote due to the well known health dangers associated with dip due to its addicting nicotine content, and because the ban on players use sets a better example for children, who make up a large portion of the MLB fan base.  However, players have been outspoken against the ruling, with Chicago Cubs pitcher John Lackey stating, ““I get it, you don’t [want] your Little League kid to do that. I don’t want him [gestures to his nearby son] to do it. I don’t do it personally, honestly. But grown men should have their own choice.” Additionally, New York Mets outfielder and MLB Players Association representative Curtis Granderson was also skeptical about the rule, chiming in  “If you see a player doing something, do you give him something, during the game, after the game?

As someone who has been dipping on and off since I was a sophomore in high school, and has seen first hand in my family the damage and addiction that chewing tobacco causes, I wasn’t sure at first how I felt about these new rules and regulations. My first reaction was one of anger, thinking of all the good times I have had “packing lips” with teammates on the bench, or in the bleachers of Yankee Stadium on a warm summer afternoon. Not only was dipping used as a bonding experience, but also it almost took the substitute of coffee, in that we’d hang out, and shoot the breeze while throwing in a lip, feeling “cool” in the process. The fact that I would no longer be able to partake in what had almost become a tradition my friends and I in the Bronx left me upset, while I also sympathized with players who will struggle with this new rule because they are addicted to chewing tobacco, which will likely affect them both mentally and in terms of on field performance.

However, the feeling that ultimately won out was that these rules are not only just, but necessary. In 2014, Tony Gwynn, one of baseball’s greatest hitters and ambassadors off the field, passed away of Cancer of the salivary gland at the way to young age of fifty-four. Gwynn contributed his diagnosis to his use of chewing tobacco that dated back to his time in rookie ball in 1981. Earlier in the year, perennial All Star and ESPN broadcaster Curt Schilling was diagnosed with throat cancer; although his diagnosis differed from Gwynn’s, he to felt that his cancer was result of thirty plus years of dipping. Although there is no direct correlation between the new rules and the cancer diagnoses of two baseball legends, it appears that this was the wake up call baseball needed, as teams soon after began to ban chewing tobacco at their stadiums.

Yes, players should have every right to do what they with their bodies, and yes, chewing tobacco has been a part of the game longer than most of us on Earth have been alive.  But at the end of the day, these rules are meant to do one thing and one thing only, and that is keep MLB players, and possibly more importantly the fans, healthy and alive. While my own dipping has greatly subsided over the past two years, there are still times, where I, like many of the players who will be affected by this rule, will crave nothing more than to throw in a lip. Yet here I am, still trying to quit, because (and hopefully the MLB will realize this) if a guy who was a superhuman on and off the field like Tony Gwynn could fall because of chewing tobacco, what makes us think we are invincible?

title: Low End Theory Festival Preview
content:
Written By : Brian Suruki, UCLA Radio DJ

Whenever anybody asks about the Los Angeles music culture, Low End Theory is the first thing that comes to mind. Low End Theory is the heart of the ever-flourishing hip-hop and electronic beat scene. It has been tied to jumpstarting the careers of artists such as Flying Lotus, Nosaj Thing, Tokimonsta, the Gaslamp Killer, Daedelus, and The Glitch Mob. Their weekly events at The Airliner are also legendary for having secret DJ sets by special guests such as Thom Yorke and Erykah Badu.

Daddy Kev, the founder of Low End Theory, explains the thesis of Low End Theory: “Taking all these different genres of music, and recontextualizing them, with just a pair of turntables and a mixer. Taking certain segments of certain songs, and presenting them in a way that on their own, these songs don’t have a lot to do with each other. But play the right sections in the right order, and all the sudden this makes sense.” In other words, Low End Theory serves a purpose to piece together the diverse and complex map within the realm of music. The audio pioneers of Low End Theory are constantly breaking barriers and bringing together the worlds of multiple genres into a place where they can all harmonize as one. The experimentation of this thesis has resulted in giving birth to a new and original sound. This sound has become vital to the Los Angeles music culture. This sound is Low End Theory.

As Low End Theory almost reaches a decade of crafting and honing their movement, Goldenvoice presents their third annual Low End Theory Festival. Low End Theory Festival 2016 will be held on Saturday July 23, 2016 at the Shrine Auditorium and Expo Hall. The festival will headline two of Wu-Tang Clan’s heavyweight lyricists, Raekwon and Ghostface Killah. The two emcee’s are notably known for Only Built 4 Cuban Linx…, which is considered to be one of the greatest Hip-Hop albums of all time. Rolling Stone magazine has also placed this album on their 500 Greatest Albums of All Time list.

Another exciting group featured on the lineup is Invisibl Skratch Piklz, which is a supergroup comprised of legendary DJ’s who pioneered the turntablism movement. Every individual in this group has revolutionized the turntable and mixer in a similar way to how Jimi Hendrix revolutionized the guitar. The members of Invisibl Skratch Piklz reinvented the record player into an instrument of its own. At Low End Theory Festival 2016, you can witness Invisibl Skratch Piklz come together and showcase their phenomenal techniques on the turntable and mixer.

Other acts include Hippie Sabotage, MixedByAli, Daedalus, Prefuse 73, Jonwayne, Gonjasufi, Teebs, Milo, Samiyam, Dibiase, Sosupersam, Great Dane, Taylor McFerrin, Sonnymoon, Sahtyre, Eureka the Butcher, Shiva, Taso, and Linafornia. The Low End Theory residents, Daddy Kev, Nobody, the Gaslamp Killer and D-Styles, are also included in the lineup.

In addition to providing great music and vibes, Low End Theory Festival will allow you to be a part of the movement and partake in a production workshop and beat invitational. The beat invitational submission will open on July 1st and will give all aspiring beatmakers an opportunity to showcase their beats at the festival.

Low End Theory Festival is a place where music lovers of all realms come together with a simple purpose of appreciating sound. It is a place where one can partake in the celebration of piecing together and pushing the conceptual map of music forward.

title: Breakbot Concert Review @ El Rey (05/26/16)
content:
Written By:  Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 06/05/16

Breakbot’s live performance is many things, but above all: Impossible to hate. There’d be something a little.. “Off” about a guy that walks away from this exposé of delectable synths, enthusiastic vocal performances, and resounding grooves with anything less than joy in his heart.


Last Thursday, Thibaut Berland (aka Breakbot) led his North American tour into Los Angeles for an electrifying set piece at the El Rey Theatre.  The curtains drew open to reveal a rather drab, simplistic scene.  Drenched in pale blue lighting, Berland’s trademark synth + keyboard setup stood elevated at the center of the stage with no one to pilot it.  Instead fans were greeted with a cinematic orchestral piece emanating from the venue’s humble sound system… “Is this Star Wars?“After a few more moments, Breakbot himself finally came out to greet his audience of juvenile House aficionados—A crowd yearning to get a taste for a sound developed long before their time.  Berland exchanged a shy wave hello for a resounding cheer from the audience, then began to put the pieces together at the keyboard.  His contribution to the Star Wars Headspace album was an interesting choice for an opener, but it simply worked as an ample introduction.  Dazzling electronic shows would normally be limited by small stages like the kind sported by the El Rey, but Breakbot was fairly quick to prove that his music could certainly speak for itself.


“Star Tripper” immediately gave way to the second song of the night, “Back for More.”  Following the transition, Lights came up to reveal instrumental accompaniment, Berland’s cream-colored suit, and our pair of vocalists waltzing in from each side of the stage.  The latter introduced some much needed charisma to the stage, successfully balancing Breakbot’s characteristic awkwardness at the keys.  Despite being used to their vocals going through a ton of after-effects on the albums, Irfane and Yasmin’s vocal styles sounded right at home over the live versions of each subsequent track.


Since Breakbot’s breakthrough single “Baby I’m Yours” in 2010, Irfane’s been around to provide his distinctive vocalizations over every stage of Berland’s excursion of the dance genre up to present day.  Yasmin however, seemed like a harder sell being as fans were just introduced to her back in February via Breakbot’s latest full-length, Still Waters.Now I don’t know much about theater, but I do know that performers strive to be just as interesting to the back row as they are to the front.  Luckily Yasmin commanded the stage with the type of confidence that made her exciting to watch from all angles of the El Rey.  The way she interacted with the dancing teenagers in the front row felt nothing short of charming, and I was especially impressed at how she was able to reimagine older Ruckazoid-led Breakbot tracks such as “Why” and “Fantasy” in ways that were all her own.


Another commendable feature of the performance has to do with Breakbot’s actual mixing ability.  Of course, I should expect nothing less from such a renown DJ, but it was especially exciting for the audience to hear something like a remix of Pnau’s “Baby” gently give way to an old favorite like “One Out of Two.”  This live act relies on a predetermined setlist of course, but it was curious (and a little cute) to see Berland occasionally glance up with a concerned expression—An attempt to read the crowd for his own sake. 


I’m happy to report that the French House icon had very little to worry about. Songs that failed to win me over back when I reviewed Still Waters were so effortlessly enjoyable in the context of a live performance.  The undeniable on-stage chemistry of the band coupled with some genuinely contagious grooves simply “sold” the show right off the bat.  It even got to the point that “Baby I’m Yours” somehow felt more refreshing on Thursday than when I first heard it through some cheap headphones back in high school English.

I’ve been in the middle of many shows where I’m just begging for it to be over, even really good ones oddly enough.  At no point was this one of them.  While Breakbot’s latest musical efforts may be hit-or-miss for some, his live performance is definitely one of the most fun concert-going experiences you can have sober.  If you focus hard enough during some parts of the set, you can almost imagine tearing up the dance floor in a French discotheque yourself.


An extended cut of “You Should Know” wrapped up the night.  With a few stray keyboard notes and a peace sign, Berland and his bandmates exited the stage just as coyly as they entered.  The houselights revealed a group of friends in front of me, freaking out over a CD booklet they had somehow gotten Irfane to sign in the middle of the encore—We had truly been a part of something remarkable, I suppose.

title: Radiohead - A Moon Shaped Pool // Album Review
content:
Written By : Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/24/16

Given a week to digest, Radiohead’s latest effort decompresses in satisfying form.  A Moon Shaped Pool melts into a puddle of despair, yet effervesces with unwavering fervor.

This new Radiohead project follows 2011’s The King of Limbs, and a number of other Thom Yorke ventures including forming the supergroup Atoms for Peace, and releasing his 2014 solo LP Tomorrow’s Modern Boxes.  While each of the aforementioned efforts are commendable in their own right, they ultimately suffer from drab moods that fall short of being interesting in a full length release.
Given Yorke’s recent musical direction, some fans worried that A Moon Shaped Pool would again demonstrate that inorganic, mechanistic feel that has bogged down his recent projects.  Rest assured, a King of Limbs Part Deux it is not.  While it may require repeat listens, A Moon Shaped Pool is both challenging and interesting enough to make this an inviting task.

The album opens with “Burn the Witch.”  While the track is seemingly simple, it’s immediately distinguishable by its dizzying chord progression: The instrumentation swells and climbs as ominous strings dominate in the background.  The track feels very new to start, yet familiar again as Yorke introduces himself via his characteristic croon.  With help of the lyrics, the result of the song is a very palpable sense of anxiety, and it’s a feeling that stretches for almost the whole length of the LP.


That’s not to say that this album is entirely one-note, either.  Songs like “Desert Island Disk” cleverly layer the vocals over a folk guitar.  More interesting still is how this mixture sits over a bed of “droney,” astral sounds straight out of the Kid A era.  You’d never think that a concoction like “folk-drone” would work in theory, but perhaps a goal of A Moon Shaped Pool is proving that Radiohead is still bold enough to pull it off.

But yes, Radiohead is just as sad we left them in 2011—Yet their dread evolved into something profound and almost refreshing five years later.  “Daydreaming,” possibly my favorite track on the record, continues the climb initiated by the opening track but in much slower strides.  It’s a piano-heavy song, but a faint glockenspiel tops off the track with Radiohead’s characteristic iciness. 

The lyrics are also a definite highlight on this track as well.  Thom Yorke’s vocal style alone can be more attention grabbing at first however, especially as his voice distorts and plays in reverse toward the end of the song.  The result is beautiful, yet strikingly sinister all the same.  “Daydreaming” is my favorite not just because of its understated beauty, but because I feel it’s indicative of the album’s primary strengths: Detail and subtlety.

As I mentioned before, A Moon Shaped Pool demands subsequent play throughs.  While definitely a “grower,” the LP’s primary incentives are the intricate details you won’t catch with a cursory listen.  Almost as enjoyable as the songs themselves is the “picking apart” of each moment.  If you think of this album as a delicate piece of machinery, then the listening experience resembles examining the cogs that make it work, and effectively creating a blueprint in reverse.

If this album suffers from any shortcomings, it’s definitely the fact that the sounds more or less meld together after the first handful of tracks.  While this aspect is appealing to some, for casual listening purposes, the LP may be too subtle for its own good.  As a result, I wouldn’t blame any Radiohead fans that chastise this record for being too slow.  It would require some some divine multitasking skills however, to be pulled away from “Daydreaming,” or better yet, the closer “True Love Waits.”  While its just as deceptively simple as its predecessors, this could be one of Radiohead’s most devastating tracks in their entire catalogue. 

Fans can breathe a much deserved sigh of relief in that this LP isn’t the soundtrack to yet another Brit-Rock band well past their prime.  A Moon Shaped Pool wasn’t released to fulfill an album quota, but rather, to push the envelope just another inch further—An astonishing feat by a band as erratic and boundary pushing as Radiohead.

title: The Colour in Anything - James Blake // Album Review
content:
Written By : Alexa Lee, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/23/16

A friend once described James Blake’s music to me as sounding like “if an alien came to visit Earth and Bon Iver was his tour guide, and then that alien took what he learned from Bon Iver about the human experience, combined it with his futuristic spaceship instruments, and became a musician.” Although a strange and borderline incoherent description, after listening to Blake’s most recent album, I think it is one that captures well the unique nuances of Blake’s music. Released May 6, 2016, James Blake’s third album The Colour in Anything fuses moody electronics, graceful orchestral pieces, and haunting soul to ultimately deliver something greater than the sum of these parts and a style that is all his own.

A seventeen track record wherein almost every single song is slow, dreamy, and lamenting, The Colour in Anything risks being boring or losing its listeners in a haze of echoing songs that blur into each other. But impressively, Blake’s dynamic melodies and the somber, enchanting timbre of his voice breathe life into every song, preventing tracks from becoming repetitive despite overarching similarities in tempo and lyrical themes. Each song manages to bring a new dimension to the LP, whether it’s from an engaging synth drum hook (“Choose Me”) or a new insight written about a relationship destined to end (“f.o.r.e.v.e.r.”).

Lyrically, the album grounds itself around the central theme of ephemerality and how awareness of this ephemerality affects our relationships. Songs like “The Colour in Anything” and “Radio Silence” despair over the decay of a fleeting, irretrievable love. But in one of my favorite lines of the album, Blake expresses the larger, more optimistic perspective of the album: “I suggest you love like love’s no loss” (“Waves Know Shores”). And here lies the deeper significance of Blake’s album, which is the importance of not guarding oneself from love regardless of its inevitable end. The Colour in Anything acknowledges the idea that nothing lasts but responds not through mourning but rather acceptance, creating a message that is nostalgic and reflective without being tortured.

On a more critical note, although the experimental electronic notes and rhythms are what many see as Blake’s trademark sound, I don’t think that they are what make the album strong. To me, the captivating lyrical refrains and Blake’s own poignant voice are what elevate the music and produce connection with the listener. The dubstep elements at their best are fascinating in songs such as “Always” and “My Willing Heart” but distracting at their worst in a song like “Put That Away And Talk To Me,” in which a beeping telephone ringtone repeats throughout the song. I suppose it is possible that this ringing noise is some sort of sonic metaphor used to reassert themes of missed communication, and I am simply not in tune with these sublime, higher meanings. However, for now I will continue to view the recurring beeping as one of the several instances where electronic influence falls short and reduces the overall quality of the album’s tracks.

But apart from the occasionally extraneous dubstep loops, I think this is a beautiful album. Blake balances abstract and experimental instrumentals with a vulnerable yet passionate vocal performance to present a melancholy but not bitter portrait of love amidst loss.

title: Weekly Recommendations // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Our comedy department curated this ~very~ *special* ~*list*~ of comedy things that we recommend. JUST. FOR. YOU. Check it out:


Skateline NBD

Every Tuesday on the Thrasher YouTube channel. It’s a comedy news segment focused on skateboarding. For most of the humor you need to be familiar with skate culture, but the host Gary Rogers is hilarious


California On

Comedian Kassem G interviews people in Venice about broad topics. Very funny and almost awkward humor that’s supposed to make you uncomfortable. You can find them all on Kassem G’s YouTube channel.


Brian Jordan Alvarez

​Check out his funny short sketches and​ a​ crazy web-series that played at Tribeca called ​"​The Gay and Wondrous​"​​

Maria Bamford

Her niche stand-up and expansive voice acting career is worth checking out.


Don’t Get Me Started


​​A podcast ​hosted by Will Hines and Anthony King. I particularly love the episodes with Paul Scheer, and Jason Mantzoukas. They each spend the full podcast discussing improv, equally hilarious and insightful.

2 Dope Queens​

A stand up comedy podcast hosted by two 30 somethings living in Brooklyn, often times representing the underrepresented.​

title: The Yankee Warrior // UCLA Radio Sports Op-ed
content:
Written By : Chase Madorsky, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date : 05/06/16

To a newer generation, he is the casual, “cool” color commentator covering Yankee games on the YES Network alongside Michael Kay and Ken Singleton. Yet as a 90s child and Yankee fan, I’d be remised to say that while Derek Jeter will forever be known as the captain, the real heart and soul of the Yankee Dynasty roamed right field for nine seasons, number 21, Paul O’Neill.

Acquired from the Yankees in 1993 for Roberto Kelly, O’Neill immediately had huge shoes to fill, replacing fan-favorite and Yankee captain Don Mattingly as the team’s number three hitter. Pauley, as he has come to be known amongst Yankee fans, immediately responded, rattling off the first of what would be six straight .300 seasons as the anchor of the lineup. On the field, O’Neill blossomed while in the Bronx, reaching four all star games, winning the 1994 batting title, and driving in over 100 runs in a season four times.

While Pauley was certainly no slouch on the field, it was off the field where he made his true mark as a Yankee. Known as a fiery competitor, no water cooler or bat was ever safe from O’Neill’s wrath, as he was prone to competitive outbursts that often left destruction in their path. O’Neill’s love of the game and competitiveness was on full display in the 1999 World Series, where hours after his father passed of a heart attack, Pauley took the field with his teammates. O’Neill’s drive made him a fan favorite, prompting Yankee owner George Steinbrenner to label him as a “Warrior,” and led Yankee Stadium to chant his name in unison in Game 5 of the 2001 World Series, where he responded by tipping his cap to the crowd, tears flowing down his face and all in his last home game in the Bronx.

Overall, the biggest impact O’Neill made in his time, as a Yankee was a change in the franchise’s culture. When O’Neill joined the squad, the Yankees had not reached the postseason in twelve years; by the time he left, they had appeared in five World Series in a six-year span, winning four. At a time when the entire Yankees franchise desperately needed a spark, O’Neill not only brought leadership, but also a winning attitude to a team that was in desperate need of a jolt in the right direction. He may not be the most well known Yankee of all time, but without a doubt, Paul O’Neill will go down in Pinstripe lure with the likes of Mantle, Ruth, and DiMaggio in the eyes of Yankee fans.

title: Interview With Raphaelle Sandell-Preston of Braids @ The Echo (05/26/16)
content:
Written By : John Sanchez, UCLA Radio DJ 

Although nested within the modern music forms of verse/chorus and constructed melodies that define the popular, Canadian electro art-pop trio, Braids, explores a vast middle ground between the dualities of pop and not-pop, form and free-form, natural and electronic, man and woman. Raphaelle Standelle-Preston, Austin Tufts, and Taylor Smith seamlessly blend conventional rock band instrumentation (guitar/drums/voice) with brooding, bombastic electronic soundscapes to create an audio environment that is completely manipulatable by the band as a unit; despite the band’s complex audio manipulation and conceptual blurring of lines between convention and experimentation, the melodies are catchy earworms that burrow themselves into the listener’s memory and the beats are hard, danceable grooves representational of this era’s pension towards deep bass and pulsing rhythms. The group has released three captivating full lengths and, after the release the new Companion extended play, recently shared Braids with a Silverlake eager to expand upon their preconceived notions regarding what a live band is capable of doing in a single, enchanted evening.

The trio is an idealistic beacon. After catching glimpses of their involved set-up process, one can assume that Braids ascribes to the Do It Yourself aesthetic governing the practices of groups who want complete artistic control over their sound and iconography. They set up their own gear; they travel with their own sound team; they are their own press contacts; they manage their own merch table. Braids’ subscriptions to DIY practices makes them available, tangible people who are able to connect to audiences before and after they perform on stage, further encapsulating an already memorable performance while also circumventing some of the nastiness that emanates from the questionable behaviors of seedy venue men.

Braids is a band that genuinely loves what they do, their passion for their artform evident in their animated faces and body movements. Standell-Preston, frontwoman and primary vocalist, has an open, charismatic presence that completely filled the Echo. She was warm, collected, and content to share her work with a supportive audience. Due to the introspective, personal quality behind her lyrics, each word sang cut to the bone while interacting with the audience’s emotions in a relatable, visceral way. UCLA Radio had the immensive privilege of interviewing Raphaelle before their performance regarding the psychological trauma felt upon releasing a personal body of work, meditation, and the current status of women in the music industry. The full transcription of the interview can be read below.

J: So you’re Raphaelle?

R: I am Raphaelle! Laughs

J: Cool.

R: I am one of many Raphaelles…in the world.

J: How many do you think there are in the world?

R: Oh my gosh…

J: A couple?

R: I don’t know, but I remember there was, there was a Raphaelle. I was, like, the only Raphaelle always growing up and then there was a Raphelle in the debate time and I was thinking of joining and I went to, like, the debate meeting and I decided not to do it because I was like, “I don’t want to debate against another Raphaelle! So…I didn’t join the debate team. There are probably, like, other reasons, but I just use it as an excuse.

J: Cool. Well you just came in from San Francisco, right? Cool! How was it?

R: It was great.

J: Yeah? 

R: Yeah.

J: Where’d you play?

R: We played at the Swedish American Music Hall.

J: Sweet.

R: Yeah.

J: Sweed (a bad joke).

R: Sweedish. I know. I always wonder if it’s two e’s. It’s not.

J: Oh, it’s not?

R: No!

J: Sweeedish.

R: I did this yesterday and I was like, “is it sweedish?” No, it’s just…it’s kind of like Swedish.

J: Swedish.

Both: Laughter.

R: Swedish.

J: Cool. And you drove down all today?

R: Mhm. It’s pretty typical. Big driving day and then a show.

J: Yeah. Uhm…what’d you listen to on the car ride?

R: Actually, I just listened to the new Radiohead record.

J: Cool! How is it?

R: Is it called A Moon Shaped Pool?

J: Yeah, A Moon Shaped Pool.

R: It was beautiful. Uhm, it was very very delicate. Much more delicate and, like, much more of a grower than their other records. It sounded like very, like much more restrained and like much more patient.

J: Yeah, I’ve only listened to single, so.

R: Oh, you should. Yeah, just listen to it on like, a good pair of headphones or a good sound system when you have some time to just like kind of get lost in it. Uhm, but it was, yeah it was really beautiful. And then we listened to it again in the car, because everyone listened to it before me and I was like, “I can’t listen to it on the car stereo speakers, like I actually have to do it.” So then, I sat in the back and listened to it on headphones.

J: Cool.

R: Yeah.

J: Was it worth it? Worth the wait?

R: Oh yeah, it was very worth, yeah it was good. I was just like putting it off until it was the right moment. So. So, I was in the mood. I definitely was in the mood for it. So…

J: In the mood for the Radiohead.

R: Mhmm!

J: Are you a big Radiohead fan?

R: Big Radiohead fan.

J: Cool.

R: Yeah. Big big big Radiohead fan. Yeah. Radiohead and Bjork I’d say are the two…the two big influences for our band.

J: Cool. Uhm, cool! Now, so, you’re on tour.

R: Mhm.

J: Playing some shows.

R: Mhm.

J: Do you have any, uhm, quirky, like folk remedies to…to ward off bad luck?

R: Folk remedies? 

J: Yeah, you know

R: Oh, to ward off bad luck.

J: You know, like, wearing the same pair of underwear over and over again on tour.

R: Laughs. Over and over again. That’ll just like, give you infection. That’ll like, won’t maybe won’t give you good luck, but like, bad health. Laughs.

J: Bad health, yeah.

R: Laughs.

J: But you know, along that vein.

R: No, I don’t have any good luck things. Like, I’m not a super super…I’m not a super superstitious person. Uhm, laughs. I…I’m definitely, like, very, uhm. I’m overly protective of my throat.

J: Okay

R: Uh, and so I have a ton, I should have brought them out, but I have a ton of tinctures for that. Actually, I kind of blew my voice a little bit yesterday. We’re playing this new song called “Joni” and, uh, it’s really…

J: I love that song!

R: …thank you. It’s really hard to sing. It’s like, really, like it’s, it’s a high part in my register that I have to sing really powerfully in like a full voice and so I, I went, we, we played it first yesterday. The boys really wanted to play it first and I was like, “no, like, please, can we put it later on in the set.” And they’re like, “no we have to open with it!” And I was like “fine, but I’m going to blow my voice.” And I did. And then I sang on my, my voice kind of blown for the rest of the show. Uhm, and today it really hurts. It feels like I…it feels like a pulled muscle, which I know is, it’s a bad thing. And like, “oh no, I hurt my throat.” So in that, I guess I carry around, like, I carry around a special rock for my throat. But, it’s like, here….

J: What kind of rock is it?

R: It’s uhm, I can’t remember what this stone is called. It’s supposed to be like a throat chakra protector if you believe in that sort of stuff, which I do to a degree. I like, I like, I want to believe in it, so I do.

J: Yeah.

R: Ahum. Where is she? Where’d she go? Oh I think maybe she’s in here. Did I put the blue guy in there? Oh no, it’s somewhere in one of my…oh here it is. So yeah, this guy. You can actually, I was told by, by a wise lady, uhm, you can put it….

J: Oh, that’s nice.

R: Yeah, I got, I don’t know what it is, but yeah you can put it on, like, your throat chakra and you can just like, I can like put it actually with a scarf around here.

J: Yeah.

R: There you go. There you go like that….I’m trying to get it in there. In that little crevasse.

J: Yeah.

R: Yeah. I could just like chill with it. Oh no, it came out.

Both: Laughter.

R: But I guess that’s the only like good luck thing I have!

J: Okay!

R: Mhm.

J: Uhm, any like routines that you go through before you go on?

R: Yeah, I do a lot of meditation. Uhm, so, if I have time, which usually I don’t, I’ll try and do, like, fit in another, like my second meditation of the day to be around, like an hour before I play. Uhm, and that’s really nice and makes for a really grounded set. I’m like a lot less jittery and like, more focused. Uhm, I’ve been trying to run on tour ‘cause I’m, I’m 26 now and I’m starting feel the effects of like, passing 25. Laughs. Just like, how my body feels a bit slower and like, feels a bit more pillowy, which is fine, but I just, you know, starting running, which I used to not have to. And just like, get your heart rate up when you’re sitting in the van for so long. And just sitting on your ass all day driving. Laughs.

J: Well, you just released a new EP, Companion. It’s great!

R: Thank you!

J: I love the artwork on it.

R: Mmm, we worked with the same person that we always do for everything, Marc Rimmer.

J: For all three of them?

R: Uh, yeah. Every record we’ve done.

J: Cool.

R: Yeah.

J: Do you feel any sort of, like, postpartum depression after releasing a big thing?

R: It’s so funny that you say that. Uhm, it does kind of feel like some sort of postpartum depression, usually, but this one didn’t. But every other record I’ve released, I have like a huge breakdown or like a huge nervous energy comes about me when I release it and I think because I’m usually like, I usually question it just because like, once we release it finally, you’ve just had it with yourself for so long that…it’s like when you do anything for too long, you just start to question it. It’s like if I could put it out the week after I finished recording it, probably wouldn’t have that, but it’s like sitting on it. And same with the last record, especially. I just wrote an essay about what it was like to release “Miniskirt” and release that last record and just talking about like the anxiety that surrounded coming out with that record.

J: Interesting.

R: I don’t know, have you, did you read the essay?

J: No!

R: Oh, okay.

J: I have not. I would like to though. Where is it available?

R: It’s on Pitchfork. It’s called “Reclamation Through a Microphone.” (http://pitchfork.com/thepitch/1129-reclamation-through-a-microphone-braids-raphaelle-standell-preston-on-how-songwriting-helped-her-process-sexual-abuse/)

J: Cool!

R: Yeah.

J: How do you deal with the anxiety of releasing new work?

R: Uhm, meditation.

J: Meditation?

R: Yeah. Laughs. Or just, now that I’ve done it so many times, I’m just like, “okay I’m going to feel pretty weird for a little bit.” I guess, just like, being able to articulate it now that I’ve gone through it so many times really helps because before, it was like, I didn’t know how to identify it. I was like, “oh I just feel really bad all of a sudden.” And like, I don’t want to talk about the process and usually the first couple months of interviews are really hard and then you just get into the flow of things and like, you’re happy that people are interested. But yeah, definitely meditation has helped me a lot with many areas of my life including that one.

J: Cool! I’m glad you found something for that.

R: Yeah! I do a type of meditation called transcendental meditation which I actually learned in LA at a Los Feliz location.

J: Which one?

R: Yeah, it’s called Transcendental Meditation Los Feliz.

J: Oh, okay.

R: Yeah, it’s like a specific studio that they have there. They have other locations, I think in Hollywood, but that’s my favorite one. Those are my favorite teachers for sure.

J: Well, hopefully this interview isn’t too angst inducing.

R: Oh no! I don’t get anxious anymore. Not at all. Like, I’m fine. Like, it’s just, it’s honestly just like, and actually to come back to your question of like, releasing this record. I haven’t felt any kind of hesitation with it. I think it just happens with getting older and just doing it a lot more. And yeah, like I said, being able to give your feelings a name, or a process.

J: I like that.

…

R: Well, do you have any superstitions?

J: Kind of. I don’t know, I’m like you where I’m trying to believe in it, but don’t know if I actually do. I like to meditate as well.

R: What kind of meditation do you like to do?

J: I don’t know. I’ve never…

R: Just like a bunch? Or do you do guided?

J: No, I’ve never done guided. I just do it on my own.

R: Oh, that’s really cool.
