I have some friends who are like that where I’m like “oh, do you meditate?” And they’re like “yeah.” And I’m like “well, what do you do?” And they’re like “well, I just meditate.” And then, like, for me, it’s always been very like, I guess, very understood of what it is I’m doing or guided or given a term.

J: Right.

R: Yeah, or like part of a certain sect of this kind of mediation. But that’s cool!

J: So, last question. It’s kind of, more personal I guess, so don’t feel like you have to it.

R: Okay!

J: In light of stuff that’s been happening with Amber Coffman. Do you know Amber Coffman from the Dirty Projectors?

R: No, I don’t.

J: Did you hear about her PR…their PR man, Heathcliff Berru. She recently outed him as a sexual offender.

R: Oh, you should definitely read my essay because it’s all about that.

J: Oh, cool! Yeah, I’d love to read it. But yeah, in light of that and like, the Kesha controversy, I’m just curious if you experience any similar difficulties being a woman fronting a band.

R: Uh, yes and no. Like, I don’t know if I can necessarily pertain it to the music industry. I have experienced sexual abuse in my earlier childhood, which I’ve come out about recently. Which is really scary to come out about, but I’m happy it did. But in terms of the music industry, I’ve had some people…no I wouldn’t say I’ve had anything to that degree, at all. Like, I’ve had some shitty sound guys who’ve made misogynistic comments to me. Not my current sound guy, obviously, because he’s with us for a reason and he’s like our best friend but like, before when we were kind of jumping around without a sound person, yeah I definitely have had some comments made towards me. I think that just unfortunately happens towards women. I think that we’re still on a path of trying to reclaim, or claim, because we’ve never really been given it, the kind of respect that we deserve or, like, the kind of equality that we deserve. I’m really happy though, that, I guess that people are paying more attention to it, but there still is the…there still is the unfortunate reality that like, when these women come forward about these kind of events, that they’re questioned about it and not believed and to me, I think that if anyone is to have said, of course if it doesn’t come from a vindictive place where you’re like, lying, but I don’t think that…I have never known that to happen in a sexual assault case that at least I’ve come across, but when a woman comes forward and says she’s being harassed, she’s being harassed. You know? And we should believe that and I hate that we question that. Very recently there was a case in Canada for an interview host named Jian Ghomeshi. Did you hear about that shit?

J: No!

R: It was crazy. So he was like, one of the most popular men in Canada, like, everybody loved him. And these women…oh he was actually asked to leave the CBC, which is the show he was apart of, and these women came forward, a few of them I think with their names concealed, came forward saying he had beat them like on dates. He had randomly, like, hit them and stuff and the amount of people who didn’t believe these women was just like, it was appalling. And also, in the court system too, like when you take a seuxal assult predator to court, they often times don’t have to testify. It’s the victims who are already very traumatized who have to stand trial and who are questioned while the person who is at fault just looks and watches the whole thing from, you know, the audience or from the bench or whatever. So that’s shitty. The whole thing is shitty. The system doesn’t work for dealing with sexual assault victims. And media doesn’t work either, I think, for helping sexual assault victims. I was actually really really impressed with Pitchfork’s willingness to run the essay that I wrote and the woman who helped me edit it from Pitchfork and I was just like, very, they were just like very supportive and it gave me a lot of respect for them.

J: That’s cool! Yeah.

R: Yeah so. Yeah.

J: Well, I’m glad that you’ve never had to experience any of that firsthand.

R: Yeah, not in the music industry. I’ve definitely been dealt my fair share of shitty male experiences. But like, all the men in my life are wonderful, wonderful human beings who are like, very loving and kind towards women.

J: Cool!

R: Yeah, I hope that transcends to all people. Laughs.

J: Do you have any advice for any women or any all-gender bands who are trying to get into the scenes.

R: Like it, oh, like who are trying to like, I guess, what do you mean by scenes?

J: I guess who are just trying to be working musicians.

R: Yeah, I’d say that like, as a women is all that I really speak to, but I would say that if you ever feel uncomfortable, like, if you feel safe enough to say something, then do and if you don’t, then try to remove yourself from the situation. And just don’t, like, I think it’s really important to shape your career based on your values and people you want to work with. And like. Like, for me, if I get a sense from somebody that they’re kind of dick and that they’re like, not going to treat me well, if it’s like a recording session or whatever than like, even if it could really benefit my career, I won’t work with them. Or if I look into their, just like what it is they’ve believe in, whether it’s going on their Facebook or their Twitter. To me it’s really important to do a little bit of research into what the people you’re going to work with are kind of like, and just get a sense for them. I think that as a woman, it’s important that we start standing up to that. With Kesha being like, no I don’t, even though it’s, what was his name, Dr. Luke? That’s the guy’s name that Kesha was…

J: Oh yeah!

R: Yeah, coming out against. He’s a very very powerful man and it was probably very scary to come out against him because a lot of the times the men who are taking advantage of these women are in positions of huge power so it feels like, they have to, like if they were to go against them that they would, they would maybe have nothing left or something. And I think that if we are able to stand together as a people and as a force then it’s going to be a lot stronger in changing those kind of behaviors towards women in the music industry.

J: Right.

R: So yeah, I feel kind of conflicted sometimes when I like listening to rap and stuff that is really misogynistic and that I like enjoy it, and I like singing along to it and I’m like, “oh shit, this is really not what I believe in.” And like, for me that’s another conflict, is when it’s like… Sometimes I’ll like…I was doing this track where I’m singing on this rap track and I like the sound of it and I like the beat so much, but the lyrics are a little like, “eh,” you know? And it’s like, well, how do we separate the art from the people, and then there’s also that kind of imbalance or balance that we need to strike, which is like, do you want to separate the person, like if they’re a shitty person, or like, if maybe they’re an awesome person but they’re writing lyrics you don’t really want to stand up for. So, it’s a whole like, it’s a whole like conundrum.

J: It’s a paradigm.

R: Yeah exactly. Like, I love Katy Perry. She’s one of my favorite singers, but sometimes I’m like, “really Katy? Did you really have to go and sing that? Did you have to go and say that?” Laughs.

…

R: Yeah I love her, but yeah there’s, I think there’s, I think that everything’s somewhat conflicting to a degree, like you can never be 100 percent Kosher, but you definitely should never tolerate anybody being abusive. You know? Like lyrics, to a degree, lyrics aren’t somebody hurting you. Or like somebody taking away your, I don’t know this is getting even more philosophical than I feel you even asked me to get. I’m like, “hmmm.” Laughs. But, yeah, I think it’s really important to stand up against that. And like, yeah, if you feel uncomfortable like, remove yourself or speak with somebody or if you can, just point it out. Just bein like, “hey, I really don’t appreciate that. I don’t respect that. Why’d you do that. Don’t do it again.”

title: Chance the Rapper - "Coloring Book" // Album Review
content:
Written By :  Paul Angheluta , UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 06/02/16

With “Coloring Book”, Chance the Rapper further distinguishes his sound from the rest of modern music. His earlier works stood out due to his melodic, cartoon-sounding voices and lush production. Rather than emphasizing his playful character, Chance uses “Coloring Book” as a canvas on which to paint introspective recollections of his childhood, the city that has lost identity in gang culture in “Same Drugs” (where Chicago is characterized as a girl named Windy, see: Kanye’s Homecoming), and of love, hope, and marriage.
This growth and maturity contrasts with Chance’s voice to create one of the most fascinating projects in music, as every song contains beautiful harmonic keys and strings with lush choir accompaniment. The use of autotune and other futuristic elements makes this project stand out as one of the best musical curations in recent memory, and the big names that appear on this project deliver (Kanye on the “Ultralight Beam” mirroring “All We Got” intro, 2 Chainz on “No Problem”, etc). 


On the lyrical side, Chance delivers his most poignant work, and it seems that he is beginning to understand his role in music. Chance discusses his love and excitement to build a strong relationship with his girlfriend (and now mother of his child), his dismissal of labels in favor of an independent approach to creating music, and his spirituality in the midst of issues in his beloved city.
Chance the Rapper shows with “Coloring Book” incredible, soulful production and honest lyrics, and stands out even more with his insistence on making his music free. “Coloring Book” is a beautiful and intimate project that is worth taking the time to listen and re-listen to.

title: Pledge Drive Update 5/12
content:
Written By : Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/12/16

Halfway into our annual Pledge Drive, UCLA Radio has been making a strong presence throughout campus, on social media, and in your hearts. So far the station has brought music to UCLA’s ears with 24 hour programming, given out rad radio merchandise and concert tickets on Bruin Walk, and reached 51% of our fundraising goal in just two days!  

Yesterday we continued to bring our voice to campus with a fun-filled radio carnival in Bruin Plaza. Various UCLA Radio departments were present, showing the student body the many diverse components of our station  through fun games and giveaways. Highlights included zines created by Art and Design, music matchmaking with Programming, and and a pop up thrift shop contributed to by many of our hip DJs. The festivities didn’t end there - the night was filled with laughter spreading from a free UCLA Radio and Shenanigans comedy show, featuring comedians Rhys Darby of Flight of the Concords and Ian Abramson of 7 Minutes in Purgatory along with student performances.

Pledge Drive fun continues with a fundraiser at Rubio’s today! (#thacothursday.) We also have your weekend plans covered with a night of live music and other shenanigans at a special UCLA Radio house show on Friday night. Ticket giveaways, fundraising updates, and other exciting Pledge Drive surprises will be announced on UCLA Radio social media, so make sure to follow us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and Snapchat! If you’d like to donate, please visit spark.ucla.edu/uclaradio - any donation, big or small, is enormously appreciated by our station and allows us to continue to bring our programming to UCLA. A complete list of our events is available on Facebook - follow this link! 

https://www.facebook.com/events/711303795676795/

title: Show Review // The Last Shadow Puppets (4/20/16)
content:
Written By: Sara Karim, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 05/04/16

Alex Turner and Miles Kane, the duo who make up The Last Shadow Puppets, are well-suited to Los Angeles. The two British artists, both clad in Miami Vice pastel suits and crisp white loafers as they took the stage April 20, offer a kind of sound that is distinctly Hollywood, evocative of mobsters, spies, and the seedy underbelly of the city.

Their newest album and the second they’ve released together, Everything You’ve Come To Expect, provided most of the material of their setlist, along with a few hits from their debut The Age of the Understatement. The opening chords of each song was met with a roar of recognition from the crowd. Kane and Turner don’t waste time with banter between songs. Every now and then, they belted out an obligatory “LOS ANGELES, BABY!!” that sends the crowd into uproar. They instead allowed each song to speak for itself, cinematic in its scope both lyrically and musically. Backed by a small string quartet (in addition to the standard drums and bass guitar), every song could easily be the musical opening to a 007 movie.

The Theatre at Ace Hotel is just as dramatic as the Last Shadow Puppets themselves, with gothic high ceilings like the Sagrada Familia and velvet seats like earliest days of the movie industry. Those who flocked to the downtown venue ran the gamut from excitable high schoolers to crotchety, greying men in horn-rimmed glasses to too-cool-for-school twenty-somethings, folding their arms and nodding.

But the show left all in attendance breathless, standing out of their seats, shoulder to shoulder. There was no moment of quiet, no slowing down of the theatrics. Each song only ratcheted up the energy in the room, and by the end all of us were wanting more. Truly a historic show, I can only hope it isn’t long until the Last Shadow Puppets return to their new home.

title: Frankie Cosmos Concert Review @ L’Espace B – Paris, France (05/17/2016)
content:
Written By : Britt Hew, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 06/14/2016

My Berkeley roommate, and only proclaimed “Cali” style-friend I have made while in Paris, had done our usual ritual these days: one 86 beer and one Amsterdam, 8.6% and 11.4%, respectively. We were gearing up for a Frankie Cosmos show.

Upon leaving the underground world of business workers coming home for supper, for the above, we spotted a girl - 5'11’ in all denim, with sheer, slightly ripped tights, slowly meandering out of the metro tunnel. I immediately knew we could just follow this California aesthetic manifesto instead of pulling out Google Maps to make our way to the venue. (Always knew indie music was homey.)

As my roommate and I followed denim, we walked towards a shitty burgers and fries joint, with hipsters all wearing pants cut 2.5 inches too short for their ankles and large, circular glasses. In the backroom was the venue: L’Espace B.

The line to enter was next to the restroom as a boy with electric white hair in all leather motioned to stamp our wrists.

Inside, everyone was light. And ready for Frankie Cosmos and her bellowing presence. 

The opener was an unknown indie kiss pop / surf pop band, who I’m sure we’ll all be coming to see in a few months. The lead awkwardly danced around a street level stage, in her Bobbie haircut and Hawaiian shirt.  

In front of the eagle winged background, Aries Sun fledged about, speaking mostly French which was nice for an audience who was a few beers in, in preparation to only hear Frankie’s American accents. She calmly drank wine and joked about Frankie. 

Greta Kline, or better recalled as Frankie Cosmos, finally came out with a snapback and her 5'2" self stood a little too small for the mic stand. Frankie gripped her guitar letting everyone know she was here to rock. 

She opened, “Je ne parle pas et je ne comprends pas.” Everyone laughed.

This was Frankie’s first show of their first tour in Europe. Frankie basically said if you don’t understand English - fuck it. 

Everyone pretty much respected that. 

Throughout the show Frankie would say something in English, "Now I’m going to play songs from my new album, and after I’ll play old songs,” then passing the mic to her drummer who would (loosely) translate every word. 

Not that the audience really cared, singing along all the vowels with her, as they barely understood, but wanted so hard to mimic the soft, melodic sound in the air. I guess that’s all that really matters anyways. 

This is to say, Frankie herself isn’t an amazing singer, just really real (and makes very mosh-able music for a 2016 world). 

Amidst shockingly good sound quality (for a small venue in the back of a mini bar diner shack), the show really fared well. Lots of head bobbing and the music perfectly matched what you would hear on a Frankie Cosmos vinyl.

Everyone welcomed them, not as 4 “Burgerkids” Americans, but as 4 sun kissed Californians, under shitty yellow stage lights, came to really put on a show that a foreign audience would enjoying jamming to.

"I have a bilingual joke,” Frankie began. “In America, we eat two eggs for breakfast, but in France, one is enough” - a play on words on un œuf – the French word for egg. Pretty sure this very French audience barely got it, but she thanked them anyways. 

Moments where there should have been a mosh pit (if this were Los Angeles, there was careful head bobs, in sync and tune.

She announced her last two songs, met by a muted “woo” (because these people don’t quite get the concept of “boo”). It was adorable and very French. 

Frankie ended with “Young,” followed by “Leon.” Everyone classically knew the words, cheesing across both cheeks as they gripped their IPAs and sang along.

"I feel like we’re really spoiled now,” Frankie said. “The tour can only get worse from here,” she laughed about how everyone vibed so hard.

title: Shlohmo Concert Review @ La Maroquinerie - Paris, France (05/27/16)
content:
Written By : Britt Hew, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 06/12/2016

Last Friday night, I went on my second tinder date (TD) in Paris. After climbing a 7-12 minute upward incline to get to the top of the hills where the venue was, my TD and I finally finished our bottle of wine and went inside.

The Maroquinerie has a specific vibe. The top is a Los Angeles - Silver Lake coffee shop/bar, with white tinsely hanging lights and candles in mason jars, while the bottom captures London grime. The basement, cradled in stone cave walls, houses a large pit with two stadium rows where everyone can neatly watch a performance, hidden in smokey dreamhood.

Impressively, American artists in Paris somehow find a crowd that is exactly like theirs back home. This audience brought in the ranks of the Internet meme culture crowd; boys in pastel pink bucket hats with a single, dangling silver cross on their left ear. They all flooded in, excitedly, discussing how Shlohmo is big in the States and will probably come on really late for that reason.

Shlohmo entered the smokey void around 2:30am. Clad in an old school cartoon T, his skinny self came on demanding respect as he pressed his hands together in praise of the audience. Tracks like “Empty Pools” were changed to trap tracks, suitable for an audience that had been pregaming for Shlohmo for at least 4 hours now.

Shlohmo considers himself to be a god - in the best way possible. He killed beers as he DJed a two hour set and mindfully succumbed to the drop when appropriate (even wearing his sweat towel as a hat).

My TD and I surfaced the basin a few times, mingling with the local frenchies. A couple sat next to us on the curb that lead to the bar area. In their hands were Apple compotes infused with vodka (a homemade creation), while taking care not to spill on their full blown grunge adult attire.

Shlohmo finished his set around 4:30am and I, my last drink.

title: I Am Wrath : Dir. Chuck Russell    // Film Review
content:
Written By : Anastiasia Gershman , UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 05/30/16

Art doesn’t exist in a vacuum.  This is especially true of film. It’s not a solitary enterprise created in a lab and consumed in sterile spaces.  It’s the product of hundreds, if not thousands of individual contributions to the finished piece, with each contribution leaving its own unique signature on the product.  I point this out because a great film is a little bit like a miracle. When that many people, points of view and different styles mesh into something cohesive, concise and beautiful, it’s kind of a magical thing.  That being said, none of these things occurred to me while I was taking in I AM WRATH (2016, Dir. Chuck Russell).  It’s one thing to think about a film after you see it.  It’s another thing to know that all along the line, choice after choice was made that eventually resulted in this writer sitting in a theater the night before this review was due, wondering what the hell was going on.  I’m still wondering.  

I AM WRATH raises a lot of questions.  Who wrote this?  Who green-lit the production?  What backstage deals or blackmail resulted in a project this unfinished being finished?  It’s conceivable that it might be dangerous to trash a Travolta pic in this town – I’m not unaware of how information moves around, but I’m honor bound to say it: Why would my beloved Tony Manero make a movie this bad?

I AM WRATH tackles the story of John, a mercenary turned factory manager who returns to his killing ways after his wife is brutally murdered in a mugging gone wrong.  He re-teams with an old Black-Ops buddy, deftly played by Christopher Meloni, and they go on a predictable killing rampage through the underbelly of Colombus, Ohio seeking vengeance and uncovering a conspiracy taking them into the hallowed halls of state government.  It reads a lot like a Nick Cage movie, which it was until Cage quit the role and Travolta stepped in.  Rebecca de Mornay plays the fleeting role of John’s wife Vivian.  Fans of the genre will see hints of every Steven Segal and Charles Bronson film (yes, I’m talking DEATH WISH) from the 70’s and 80’s, a touch of DIE HARD and a splash of TAKEN.  Fans of the genre will also probably come away from this film as confused as I was by it.  

A lot of things aren’t clear.  In a world full of formulaic scripts, how are films like this one chosen over others? Why? Does this type of storytelling appeal to foreign markets?  Is it released in the states only as an appeasement to consumers following the career of a particular actor?  Did a film student edit this? Why is John Travolta acting like Liam Neeson and does he know it’s not a good look on him? Does he care? Does anyone care?  It’s hard to imagine that PULP FICTION was released 22 years ago, and that it was a comeback film for Travolta then.  No one has forgotten PERFECT – and frankly I don’t want to – it’s a California classic. But clinging to an archetype that he has assiduously avoided for the length of his career doesn’t change the fact that he’s growing older.  If there’s one character type he has been the master of, it has been that of men who don’t take themselves too seriously.  Vinnie Barbarino, Tony Manero, Vincent Vega, Chili Palmer – every single one of these roles proffered flawed anti-heroes and a sense of humor.  I AM WRATH’s John, on the other hand, is a sour, basset hound of a downer who can’t even knock out his one-liners without looking like he is going to burst into sobs.  Christopher Meloni adds spice, timing and texture to what would otherwise be 90-minute crying break.  Even THE BOY IN THE PLASTIC BUBBLE had a sort of 70’s beauty to it, and I remember it for that smile, those eyes, and Travolta’s easy-going take on terminal illness.  WRATH has none of those things.  WRATH doesn’t even seem to like itself.  I’m not even sure what it is – but I know that it’s wayyyyy beneath John Travolta.

title: UCLA's Hidden Luxuries // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By : Elliott Desai, UCLA Radio Comedy

Post Date : 05/24/16

Even after attending UCLA for two years, I continue to discover new gems on this campus every day. Janss steps, the inverted fountain, and the sunken gardens are all spots pointed out on tours and in magazines, but the spaces that truly make this school unique take more time to uncover. One might assume that I’m hinting at the nature walk behind the Anderson School of Management or the free printing inside the Student Activities Center, but I’m actually referring to a resource much more important and one of much more luxury. This is a place that not only brings people together, but also fulfills a basic human need.


The next time you’re on campus and have intentions of going home… don’t. Instead, take a trip to the third floor of Ackerman. This building is typically known for having UCLA apparel, a food court, and a grand ballroom. But on the third floor you can indulge yourself in a porcelain haven known as the “Mens Restroom.” Swing open the wooden door and a tiled runway unfolds in front of you. There lies a hallway of toilet stalls and foyer full of sinks, but if you search a little further you’ll find the URINAL SUITE.
Some think it’s a myth. Some think it’s a legend. Time to find out for yourself.

title: Thunder upset Warriors to set off thrilling Western Conference Finals // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By : Aidan Donahue, UCLA Radio Sports

Post Date : 05/18/16

The highly anticipated opening matchup of Western Conference Finals was a tale of two halves. The Warriors finished the first half up 60-47, riding a wave of swarming defense, gang rebounding, and an offensive flow that led to open 3 point looks. The Thunder would not be deterred. They came out of the locker room with a higher degree of focus and energy than the Warriors. Westbrook and Durant stayed much more aggressive than Steph and Klay. OKC ground out stop-after-stop with tough physical defense. The Thunder were a plus 9 on the boards in the second half, much improved from a minus 2 in the first 24 minutes. The warriors lack of focus was evident on offense: they took hurried shots, and committed 12 turnovers in the second half, as opposed to 2 in the first. In the end, a Durant pullup jumper with 30 seconds left was the dagger that finished off a 108-102 Thunder win. Here are some thoughts on the game:

Westbrook

Westbrook has risen his game in this year’s playoffs, and is probably the MVP of the postseason so far. The most impressive thing about him is how he has been able to maintain his maniacal competitiveness while adding a new found degree of discipline. This discipline is showing up on the defensive end. A freak athlete and hellish competitor, his propensity to gamble and get lost has often plagued him. Not anymore. Save for a few plays were the slippery Curry got away from him, Russell was hounding the MVP. He rarely lost him off the ball, stayed attached to his hip on the pick and roll, and forced him baseline on drives. Curry had 7 turnovers on the game to Westbrook’s 7 steals, a testament to his activity level. Russell’s defensive discipline will be key going forward in the series.

Pace

Pace– and who is utilizing it– will be a significant factor in this series. Despite the Warriors famed 3-point attack, the team’s rhythm starts with defense. In the first half, they swarmed passing lanes, utilized their hands, and pestered ball handles into turnovers. When the thunder missed, they gang rebounded. This got the pace flowing for the Dubs, which created penetration, ball movement, and open looks. The warriors do not just profit on the quick looks from a fast break; they utilize the rhythm and penetration generated by pace to get the ball moving around. They have so many playmakers and shooters that this gets them great looks. Their defensive strengths translate to good fast break defense too. Great communication and the army of 6-6 to 6-8 players allow them to pick everyone up with a good matchup.

Although OKC was second in pace this year (to the Warriors first), they found success when they slowed the game down. They run to get Westbrook and Durant in transition, a smart move considering how dominant the two are in space. However, they simply don’t have the team wide playmaking and shooting to hang with the Warriors in and up and down game. They found success on defense when they were able to match up 5-on-5, overloading the strong side, staying attached to the Splash Bros, and forcing the warriors off the 3 point line. Golden State responded by driving to the rim, where they were met by Adams and Ibaka. This defensive scheme generated turnovers, getting Westbrook and Durant easy buckets on the break. The Thunder should attack these opportunities, but refrain from pushing the pace in other situations. This way they will be able to rely on their physical defense, but still benefit from easy fast break looks.

Ibaka and the Death Lineup

The warriors trotted out the death lineup three times this game, and the Thunder responded each time by rolling with Ibaka and another big, usually Adams. This lineup was as successful in containing the Warrior’s juggernaut as any other one has. Ibaka’s versatility is a key part of this. He provides tough interior defense, but still has the speed to run with the quicker Warriors. He also grabbed 11 boards, a key area that the Thunder will need to take advantage of against the smaller lineup. It will be interesting to see if Kerr makes any adjustments to try to free this lineup up more.

Steph, the Pick and Roll, and the Thunder’s Defense

The Thunder did a good job of guarding the Stephen Curry pick and roll. They blitzed the pick hard nearly every time, forcing Curry to slip the pass to the big, usually Draymond. OKC stayed home on the shooters during this, forcing Draymond to shoot, usually over Adams. Green went 9-20 from the field and shot 9 free throws, efficiently taking advantage of the looks they were giving him. This helped to free Steph up for some of his 6 threes, but the swarming defense forced him into 7 turnovers and 9-22 shooting from the field. Most importantly, they got the ball out his hands in the fourth quarter much more than usual. Curry will respond with a better aggression and control, he seemingly always does.

Moving Forward

It looks like we have got ourselves the series we all wanted. The Thunder won a gutsy game, taking control after a strong first half from the Warriors. Golden State didn’t play with the level of focus and competitiveness necessary to win in the second half. They were hesitant, careless with the ball, and fouled too much. They will be much more focused in game 2, so I see them coming out with a win at home. What a series we have.

title: NBA ‘Around The Leagues’ Awards // UCLA Radio Sports
content:
Written By : J.T. Osborn and Daniil Loza

Post Date : 05/13/16

This is a series of awards that you won’t find anywhere else; however, perhaps they should be. This is the ATL NBA Awards!!!

Blackout Award
1. Kobe scoring 60 in his last game 
2. Warriors winning their 73rd game 
3. Aaron Gordon, Dunk Contest Dunk 

J.T.: So the blackout award goes to the moment that one would be most likely to remember if you were to blackout and forget the entire 2015-16 NBA season–so every 76ers fan–but you did remember one thing that happened, what would it be?

Daniil: I think that moment for me would be Kobe scoring 60 points in his last NBA game. I know both of us are not the biggest Kobe Bryant fans, you more-so than I, but I think it was impossible not to root for the absurdity and theatricality of the situation, especially in that 4th quarter. 50 shots JT!

J: I’ll be honest, I was revelling in the fact that he was stinking up Staples in the 1st quarter, but as the game progressed it was like watching a Kobe Bryant dream sequence: ‘ya’ll really want me to shoot every time? OK, IF I HAVE TO…’, on a serious note though, it really was such a magical experience watching it go down. That 4th quarter was the most excited I ever got for a non-Timberwolves game ever (try to find that sentence in the history of the internet).

D: What is funny about the whole Kobe situation, is that it overshadowed arguably a more impressive accomplishment by the Golden State Warriors. While Kobe was taking all the shots, the Warriors were setting the record for most wins in an NBA season by destroying the Grizzlies. 73-9 is nothing to sneeze at.

J: I saw on ESPN that the Lakers game peaked at 8 million viewers while the Warriors peaked at 6 million, and the Lakers were on ESPN2! No one has watched ESPN2 for that long since ESPN8: The Ocho went under 10 years ago.

D: Man I really miss watching lawnmower races and amateur team bowling competitions.

J: April 13th, 2016 was a magical basketball day, but quick shout out to the 2016 NBA Dunk Contest for reviving what used to be a dead art, that Aaron Gordon dunk over Stuff the Magic Dragon was the kind of dunk that Vince Carter dreams he would have thought up first. Extraordinary.

Slam Hunk Award
1. Gordon Hayward 
2. JJ Reddick 
3. Dwyane Wade 

J: This award was possibly our hottest debate. LULZ. This award goes to the most attractive NBA player because why the hell not? After much debate and some politics, I will was able to convince Daniil about Gordon Hayward being number 1. I mean his hair is perfect Daniil. IT’S PERFECT!

D: I feel that Dwyane Wade should be higher on this list. When it comes to look, style, and even girlfriend, Dwyane Wade is the complete package for looks in the NBA. I mean Gordon Hayward still lives with his mom and plays League of Legends on off days. How is that hot?

J: Nerdy is the new hot Daniil. #Obvs.

D: I think JJ Reddick was a pretty obvious choice here. He’s only gotten better with age, like a fine wine.

J: Yes, his jaw structure is phenomenal. Very typical GQ looking type of guy.

D: Would you rather have Reddick’s jaw structure or Hayward’s hair?

J: You already know my hair is flawless, so it’s Reddick’s jaw. Easy choice. Let’s move on before we both lose our masculinity cards, I just made a payment so it’s good ‘till next December and I don’t want to waste that kind of money.

Dr. Evil Award
1. LeBron James 
2. James Harden 
3. Charles Barkley 

D: So this award goes to the player that we feel is the biggest villain in the NBA. Someone we love to hate. In our case, the first person that totally fits that description is LeBron James. He is the ultimate evil mastermind, pulling strings from behind the scenes to get his coach fired. Using the subtle manipulation technique known as “The Twitter” to constantly undermine his teammates.

J: It’s funny because I actually like LeBron, but I’m aware of how much of a whiny, entitled little jerkface he can be sometimes. He’s like that snobbish British elitist you always hope gets what’s coming to them in whatever romantic comedy film starring Ryan Reynolds.

D: However I still think I’d rather be on the same team as LeBron than James Harden. If we extend the romantic comedy analogy, he’s the guy who is only obsessed about himself and does not give the female lead any attention. Harden barely passes to teammates, shoots terrible shots constantly, and complains when he does not receive help from help defenders when he lets an opposing player blow by him.

J: You had to sell me on this one, but I agree with you now, I don’t think I like him anymore. Everything you said is spot on, and the fact that it took me this long to realize it makes me feel dumb. So s/o to Daniil Loza: NBA Detective Extraordinaire.

D: Aww shucks. I, a simpleton from the Great Area of the Bay do not deserve such praise. Moving on, Charles Barkley has been the ultimate foil to jump shooting teams everywhere.

J: His stubbornness on perimeter centric shooting teams has been known for some time, but it’s time we call him out on it. It’s ridiculous to think that just because someone else’s method of success is different from yours, doesn’t mean it’s inferior–sans Wildcat offence circa 2006 Miami Dolphins–he needs to be knowledgeable that this type of offense works, and it already won them 1 championship, maybe more.

D: He’s just salty he does not have a ring.

Columbus Average Joe’s Starting 5
PG: George Hill
SG: Allen Crabbe
SF: Jeff Green
PF: Jason Smith
C: Robin Lopez

J: This is a fun one, we came up with what we thought was the most average players at each position and end up with what would be around a .500 record, we also chose the most average city: Columbus. I think the easiest decision we settled on was Jeff Green wouldn’t you say?

D: Agreed. When it comes to mediocrity, nobody personifies it better than good ol’ Jeff Green. All of these players are too good to be cut, but when you look at each one you go…eh.

J: EXACTLY. I think that’s what sold you on George Hill and Robin Lopez, you think of them and just go “Eh, he’s okay.”

D: Who is the leading scorer on this team and who takes the last shot during crunch time? Also would you rather have this roster or the 76ers roster?

J: I think your boy Green takes the shot, he’s shown to be pretty clutch actually in past seasons. That follow-up question is really tough, because who would want to pay money to see this team? Like, you can sell seats for Nerlens, Okafor, and even Sauce Castillo, but you can’t market any of these guys from Columbus. Plus, all of those 1st round picks… NOICE. I can’t believe I’m saying it, but I’d STILL rather have this roster… only to get swept as an 8th seed in the Eastern Conference.

Garbage Award
1. Ty Lawson 
2. Jahlil Okafor 
3. Shabazz Muhammad 

J: The Garbage Award goes to the worst NBA player that had a considerable amount of minutes played, whether he hid his garbageness underneath padded stats or he was a completely one-sided player–and that side was hardly good anyway–he was considered for this list.

D: I think the biggest disappointment on this list was Ty Lawson. This guy only 3 years ago was the best player on a 57 win team, someone who ran the pick and roll beautifully and was a borderline all star. To see him play this poorly was jarring. Granted he did have problems with alcohol addiction, but he’s still fairly young at 27 and should only be reaching his prime.

J: Yeah, this guy was like a really bad joke, I kind of feel bad for him because he really was a borderline star and now he’s the first winner of the ATL Garbage Award, what a fall-off. We both agreed on Okafor at 2, which is crazy when you look at his stats, you’d think he was a solid contributor to a…well, terrible team, but he was crazy inefficient. Like ‘2006 Gnarls Barkley’ Crazy.

D: I don’t really blame him for his offense, he shot okay on really difficult shots as the only real offensive threat on that team. It’s the total lack of defensive effort and discipline that has me really soured on him. Not only did he not try on that end, he did not care. And finally Shabazz Muhammad. I will admit, I have a personal bias towards him as a UCLA guy and I tried to find others that were worse, but I failed at that endeavor.

J: (Sigh) I know, as a double-homer guy here–UCLA and T-Wolves fan–it’s tough to say that he had the worst Win-share percentage of any guy with 20+ minutes. His defense, like Okafor, is God-awful, and it’s not out of a lack of trying, he’s just really, really, really, really, bad at it. Also, he is a bit of a ball hog on offense, he’s a decent shooter and decent driver, and actually a good rebounder for his size, but he probably loses Win-shares because he puts up so many contested shots that don’t go in.

D: I think this is a good list of varied and fun NBA awards that actually paint a nice picture of the season. I hope you had just as fun of a time reading these as we had coming up with them.

J: I did, #T-Wolves2017PlayoffBound. ATL out.

title: How Improv Has Made Me a Better Writer // UCLA Radio Comedy Op-ed
content:
Written By: Courtney Burness

Post Date : 05/08/16

Most people view improv as something narcissists do to get a quick laugh from an audience and boost their ego. While this is definitely true some of the time, good improv requires so much more thought and effort than just getting a quick laugh. Improv can benefit people mentally and emotionally in so many different ways; for me, it’s not only helped me get through hard transitions in my life, but has made me better in unexpected ways, including improving my screenwriting skills. Doing improv has not only taught me a lot about writing characters, but about the writing process overall.

With regard to characters, improv has taught me first and foremost to give your characters a philosophy. In an improv scene, no one should act a certain way “just because.” A dad shouldn’t be passive aggressive towards his son just because it’s funny for the audience to watch, he needs a reason why he’s acting that way. Otherwise, the scene will never progress past that point. It’s also taught me that you need a voice of reason. Scenes can’t just be crazy characters doing crazy things together. That’s a ticket for a one-way trip to confusion, and if it doesn’t make sense when performers act it out it definitely won’t make sense on paper. What it’s taught me most about characters is conflict. Improv scenes are boring if they’re just people agreeing with each other. Of course, the first thing you’re taught in improv is “yes, and” so this may seem contradictory. However, while you should accept the reality of the world that your partner has created, you can’t just agree with everything they suggest. That’s not interesting and it’s not funny. The same goes for writing. Characters need to have some tension or disagreement between each other, otherwise your story is of no interest to the audience. No one wants to watch people live perfect lives, it’s uninteresting and depressing for the rest of us.

Through improv, I’ve learned to accept critique and welcome collaboration. There’s always something that can be better about an improv scene. If it’s a hilarious scene, it could probably benefit from heightening and exploring those fun moments even more. If a scene is technically “correct” but isn’t very funny, test out some walk-ons; there’s always a funnier thing. In improv scenes,  it’s never about one person. Even if you’re the one to initiate you have to be open to the fact that your ideas will change. You can’t plan an entire scene in your head before you start it and expect everything to go that way. You’ll just end up getting flustered when your scene partner makes a choice that doesn’t line up with what’s in your head. And the same goes for writing. You may have an idea in your head of a complete story, but when it comes down to writing and drafting and redrafting, you have to be willing and open for these things to change to make your story better. If you’re too stuck in your original idea, there’s no room for growth.

Finally, improv has taught me to have fun and not to think so hard. So many times when I write I come to roadblocks when my characters have to solve problems. Improv has taught me that you can find solutions in easy ways; not everything has to be complicated. Audiences won’t laugh if they’re confused at an improv show, and the same goes for a novel or a script.

Overall, improv has done so much for me. It’s given me confidence when I meet new people, it’s been a way for me to get out of my own head and be someone other than myself for a few hours. And it’s improved my writing so much in ways that no book on screenwriting ever could.

title: Show Review // LCD Soundsystem @ Fox Theater Pomona (04/11/16)
content:
Written By: Derek Khaothong, UCLA Radio Digital Press Manager 

Post Date: 05/02/16

Announced three days in advance, LCD Soundsystem’s bona fide return to California was unexpected to say the least. Whereas most fans had either camped out for tickets at local record stores or waited anxiously online for a chance to get tickets, I had a spontaneous opportunity at 9:30 A.M. on the day of the concert to purchase a ticket through a friend. I impulsively reached out, not knowing what I would get myself into.

Situated in Pomona at the Fox Theater, the pack-jammed line to get into the theater had formed an hour before the door would open. At the top of theater, the marquee stated: “Nothing to See Here. Keep Moving.” The stage was cluttered with instruments, specifically large analog synths lighted with red LED lights and various keyboards as people made their way towards the smoky pit.

When the surrounding lights had dimmed, each member had made their way into the stage individually, ending with James Murphy in his trademark blazer and scruffy grey hair. They opened with the thumping drumbeats from “Us Vs. Them” on Sound of Silver, eventually shifting over to heavy synth-arranged sounds like “I Can Change” from This is Happening. The energy in the crowd was intense; nearly everyone in the pit was jumping to the vivacious music and chanting towards the band.

During a short water break, James Murphy referred to their 2010 show at the Fox and explained that they decided to have their revival show back again at the Fox because they had a good show in 2010. Oddly enough, the day also happened to fall upon James Murphy’s nephew’s birthday, who happened to be hidden somewhere in the audience. LCD Soundsystem brought a chaotic environment in “Yeah”, where I found myself surrounded by others screaming “yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah…,” and followed suit, furiously jumping into a sweaty mosh pit as I banged elbow to elbow with strangers.

The set closed with “Home” and “New York, I Love You But You’re Bringing Me Down” as a blinding disco ball scattered the roof and walls of the theater. “New York” was triumphant and a high point of the concert that was concluded with a distorted jangly guitar solo. The band took a short break after, announcing previously that they would be back with an encore to finish their set. The lights brightened as the sweat-drenched audience shouted out cheers and applauded during the break.

The encore concluded with a trio of “Dance Yrself Clean”, “Yr City’s a Sucker” (a song only played at Pomona), and “All My Friends”. As the iconic piano from “All My Friends” endlessly built to a climax, the audience in the pit became hysterical as we fist pumped and sang the song lyric-by-lyric. Monochrome lights illuminated the stage as the band and audience sung out the chorus for the last time. Nostalgia of past experiences and past friends rushed in my memory like a bullet train as everyone echoed “where are your friends tonight”.

Overall, LCD Soundsystem’s intimate revival from the dead in a 2000-person venue in Pomona for a monstrous two-and-a-half-hour set equated to an epic intimate party that I was honored to attend from one “stupid decision” I made to impulsively buy a concert ticket.

title: Lil Skies - Life of a Dark Rose // Album Review
content:
Written by Daniel Leka

Every year in hip hop, a plethora of artists have a success story that consists of them releasing a single and seemingly garnering success out of nowhere. Though their name has gathered popularity within the underground, their rise to prominence is one that is barely documented, and it is not until they are at their heightened positions that they are seen in a different light.

However, with Lil Skies, this seems not to be the case. On the contrary, his journey is one that has seen significant coverage.

My exposure with Lil Skies began via a Cufboys YouTube video towards the beginning of June, one in which he was only present for a solid 45 seconds. However, it was through Cufboys’ Cameron Haller’s decision to incorporate Lil Skies’ songs as intro music that I was able to discover more of his work. And sure enough, not long after he made his appearance, he released the single “Red Roses” with Landon Cube, one of his biggest charting singles to date. From there, Lil Skies has seemingly erupted as rap’s next star, releasing songs that encompass strong melodies, lively cadences, and energetic production. Alongside support from established brands like Lyrical Lemonade and No Jumper, Lil Skies has seen his strong home following grow into a country wide one that has allowed him to play shows that have only grown larger and larger in size. His popularity has seen him on websites and blogs like Genius, Pigeons and Planes, HotNewHipHop, and a plethora of others.

With momentum from his debut single alongside his latest release “Nowadays,” also with Cube, as well as a few complimentary visuals, Lil Skies released Life Of A Dark Rose at the top of the new year, a project that fully utilizes everything that he does well, but does not offer much insight into who Lil Skies is as an artist.

The project starts off with a strong opener entitled “Welcome To The Rodeo,” a Taz Taylor produced track that shows Lil Skies’ ability to rap and articulate his story. With production that mirrors Travis’ Scott “Antidote” if it were to take place in an alternate universe, Skies talks about his come up as a young artist. Talking about some of his hardships, like selling drugs to book studio time and some motivation in his actions (”I got tattoos on my face, I use that shit as motivation/I could never get a job, so for my dream, I’m dedicated”), Skies offers something different from an assortment of other artists - insight into his perspective. In an attempt to differentiate himself from other rappers (”All these rappers want the clout and the life of bein’ famous/I just wanna be stable, tell my family we made it”), Skies draws me in as a listener here but sadly does not maintain this throughout the duration of his album.

Following the strong opener is the album’s second track “The Clique,” a song that takes immense influence from Playboi Carti and Lil Uzi Vert but offers nothing different than what those two artists have already done. Produced by frequent Lil Uzi collaborator Maaly Raw, Skies announces his allegiance to the ones that he came up with while dismissing those who don’t have his best intentions. While the subject matter of the song is one that doesn’t necessarily break new ground, the track suffers musically through a slow tempo and lack of originality in regards to cadences and rhyme patterns. It is a huge drop off from the album’s strong opener, and a little disappointing at that.

Following is the breakout single “Red Roses,” as well as another single entitled “Lust.” To me, this is where Lil Skies thrives, especially in regards to the new age of hip hop we currently live in. Produced by Menoh Beats and CashMoneyAP respectively, both songs have a hypnotic quality that lends itself to the tempo that each song possesses. With “Red Roses,” Skies slightly changes his manner of delivery through the engineering of the record but keeps his pacing consistent throughout, leaving room for Cube to seemingly steal the show. A talented artist in his own right, Cube’s vocals reign supreme on this track as well as the album’s closer “Nowadays,” bringing a commercial quality that might not have been present had he not been on either song. Though both songs don’t necessarily rely on Cube, they most definitely find their full potential due to his contributions.

As opposed to “Red Roses,” “Lust,” through its energy and liveliness, shines as one of the best tracks on the album. “Lust” encompasses all that is good with today’s rap in my opinion, from its fun, upbeat production to Skies’ singing on the record, and even his rapping as well. The record is easily digestible, which makes it great to play around friends or in a car, or whenever the moment is opportune. To me, it is a song with immense potential and it continues to grow as a favorite, even months after its release.

Though most of the songs on this record lack the diversity of three of the first four songs on the record, when Skies applies his formula to records precisely and incorporates his own style, it still works effectively. Songs like “Cloudy Skies,” “Signs of Jealousy,” and “Lettuce Sandwich” work because they go off of what Skies knows thus far and try something a little different. “Cloudy Skies,” produced by Ghxst, sees Skies using an entirely different approach that consists of him singing for the most part over a Silversun Pickups’ “Lazy Eye” sample. Though subject matter is no different than any of the other tracks, it is through Lil Skies’ attempts to try something different that this track immediately sticks out and works for me.

On the contrary, when Lil Skies makes records that borrow from his contemporaries, his attempts can often times come off as lazy and uninspired. On records like “Big Money,” “Boss Up,” and “Strictly Business,” Skies either blatantly reiterates on a cadence that he has already used (“Strictly Business” sounds like a lazier “Red Roses”) or relies on the subject matter to carry him. However, when a 14 track album has repeated themes and concepts, there is only so much that one can listen to before growing tired and weary of the music.

To me, Lil Skies has much room to grow as an artist. However, considering that this is his first major release, he shows flashes of maintaining longevity in the music industry, through infectious melodies and incredible live energy. Though I am not one to consistently play this type of music in my own personal life, I understand that there is a place for all music, and Lil Skies has done a great job of etching his own place in today’s musical landscape. Furthermore, being the age that he is (19), Skies has put forth a decent effort that will only be fine tuned from this point moving forward, and I cannot wait for his next release as a result.

Favorite Tracks: “Welcome To The Rodeo,” “Red Roses (feat. Landon Cube),” “Lust,” “Cloudy Skies,” and “Nowadays (feat. Landon Cube)”

Worst Track: “The Clique”

Overall Score: 6/10
tags: life of a dark rose review

title: Fetty Wap @ The Belasco Theater (2/2/2018) // Show Review
content:
Written by Alexa Lee

Fetty Wap moves erratically across the stage, smiling for the audience’s Snapchat stories one moment, then breaking into abrasively dynamic dance moves the next. Meanwhile, the Remy Boyz rhythmically hop around, and every now and then one of the Boyz throws out a “1738!” or “RGF Productions, RGF!” to supplement Fetty’s rapping. Watching this group of men dance around in their black joggers and slim gold chains, I wave aside the clouds of vape smoke from my face and dance.

In the musty, poorly lit theater, Fetty Wap swerves and jumps around, all the while unleashing his warbling vibrato and candid lyrics (“She fine as hell and she know that shit/Baby, welcome to the money”). For someone who shows complete disregard for enunciation or vocal control, Fetty Wap demonstrates a surprising mastery over melody. His voice conveys sweet poignancy even on his more aggressive “slay the rap game” songs, and on his softer track “Again,” he sounds almost mournful. Meanwhile, Monty (one of the aforementioned Remy Boyz) rapidly sways back and forth and raps enthusiastically about his YSL denim and how no one can take his bitches.

Obviously, the highlight of the night was “Trap Queen.” I know, I know, I’m basic and lack the sophisticated understanding of Fetty Wap’s discography required to savor his lesser known music. But in my defense, Fetty himself seemed to light up during this song’s performance, flashing a smile and gracefully tossing his hair to the beat.

Contrary to my expectations, the show does not end with the energetic “Trap Queen.” Instead, Fetty Wap finishes his concert on a gentler note, as if gradually lowering his audience back to reality. He transitions into a series of a capella raps, dedicating one verse “for the ladies,” another “for his fellas,” and finally concludes with a song “for his day ones.” He “th-th-th-thanks us all so-so-soOo much for coming out tonight,” then breaks into “679,” flanked by his bouncing Remy Boyz. As “679” fades out (Fetty Wap stops singing about two-thirds of the way into the song, allowing a recording to take over for him), more people in joggers rush out from backstage and thrash around on stage with Fetty. The drum-heavy hook pulsates throughout the Belasco, and Fetty Wap grins at the enthralled audience one last time before disappearing from sight, ending the night with mystery and flair.

title: Village of Love Planned Parenthood Benefit (2/14/18) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Megan Hullander 

The lineup Panache Booking put together for their Valentine’s Day “Village of Love” Planned Parenthood benefit was hard to resist, consisting of artists such as Mikal Cronin, Nick Waterhouse, Ty Segall, Shannon Lay, and many more. At the end of the night, Panache, with the help of the artists who volunteered their time, the Teragram Ballroom, Planned Parenthood representatives, and all of the people who came out, raised over $18k for the nonprofit.  

The night was stacked with memorable performances. Cones opened the night with a short, heartwarming set. Meatbodies’ Chad Ubovich was the first of many to cover classic songs. Ubovich’s rendition of The Brian Jonestown Massacre’s “Miss June 75″ was uncharacteristically gentle. He was followed Drugdealer, who, in the absence of their lead singer, spent the day learning new songs, feeling wrong performing their original material without her.

Lay then took the stage, opening with an a cappella cover of The Zombie’s “The Way I Feel Inside,” during which the crowd fell silent, their jaws rightfully hanging in awe. Lay continued with a cover of George Harrison’s “If Not For You,” which she dedicated to those in the audience who were in love, followed by J. Giels Band’s “Love Stinks,” which many in the audience joined her for. William Tyler followed, sheepishly introducing his set of failed love songs, shocking the audience with the quickness in which he plucked his guitar strings. King Tuff then played a couple of covers before an original “about loving people, no matter how fucking butt ugly they are.”

Cronin gave a heartwarming performance of covers, one of which was a Neil Young song that he had learned to play the harmonica for. Segall poked his head around the corner from the side of the stage for the entirety of Australian actor Neil Hamburger’s comedic performance.  

Julianna Barwick entranced the audience with her electronic loops and mesmerizing voice, creating a gentle environment that reminded the audience why they were there. Rodrigo Amarante came on next accompanied by two female back up singers, giving a performance reminiscent of 60s gospel rock.

Segall, who was more than a few beers into the night, surprised the crowd with a fairly long set of drunken karaoke, most of which was dedicated to his wife, who watched with what seemed to be both pride and shame from the side of the stage.

Segall’s garishly humorous performance was followed by Best Coast. A few young girls shrieked with glee as Bethany Cosentino took the stage. The band opened with covers of songs by The Jesus and Mary Chain and then a rendition of Sheryl Crow’s “If it Makes You Happy,” which Cosentino dedicated to a man who once referred to her as the “indie Sheryl Crow.” Waterhouse, a universal crowd pleaser, closed the night with songs characteristic of his bluesy style.

title: In Station Interview with The Garden (2/12/18)
content:
Transcribed by Lillian Stanwick

In-Station Performance Set List: Call This # Now, No Destination, Call the Dogs Out, Have A Good Day Sir, Haha, Make Yer Mark, Clay, Vexation, All Access, Egg, All Smiles Over Here

DJ Soft Cell: Now we have The Garden in for a little interview for you guys. Ok first off, for my sake, are there any interview questions that really bother you guys, that annoy you guys so much, that you’re overhearing.

Wyatt Shears: Um, I just say go for whatever you’re gonna do. We’ll run through it regardless. I mean we’re not gonna judge.

Soft Cell: Ok, dope. Can you guys tell us a little something about the cryptics going on your guys’ Twitter? You have that very vague “23 more days.”

Fletcher Shears: That’s just 23 more days until “Stallion” comes out, the next single.

Soft Cell: Oh, ok, dope.

Fletcher: I thought it was kind of obvious.

Soft Cell: Yeah, not for me, obviously (laughs)

Fletcher: I think it’s just me in my own personal world. It looks really obvious to me.

Wyatt: No, no one’s just gonna magically know what you’re talking about (laughs)

Soft Cell: I assumed it was the record at first but then I realized that’s not out, till like March.

Wyatt: That’s like another month after then.

Soft Cell: That’s in so long. What is your opinion on festival culture? Do you guys like the intimate setting more or playing to huge live audiences?

Wyatt: Personally, I like both at different times. Festivals, they offer a little bit of something different because you have to more work for it unless you’re huge and everyone’s there for you; but for us, it’s not the case so we have to work for people’s … the crowd or whatever.

Fletcher: Agreed.

Soft Cell: Speaking of which, your guys’ outputs seem to be on full blast, song after song, show after show, music video after music video, but there doesn’t seem to be a lot of stuff that is coming out that is very personal. As corny as it sounds, I feel like people don’t really know who Fletcher and Wyatt are. Are you guys doing this on a conscious or unconscious level? And whatever it is, do you guys like it this way or do you want people to know more?

Fletcher: I think the next album is really personal, but I don’t know how hidden that is to some people. I think we put a lot of our personal lives into the next album. I don’t know if that’s going to be obvious or not. We also do the side projects Puzzle and Enjoy, and those are pretty much … I know when I speak for myself, Puzzle is all about my daily life, and it’s literally all about just … it’s all pretty personal for the most part, but I don’t know how much comes off like that or not, but to me all the songs are pretty personal.

Wyatt: Typically, with The Garden as well, we never really have operated on a lyrical level of being like “I love you baby and I’m blah blah,” you know to the next step. We’re more … I don’t know, I guess we just say it in a different way. I thought it was obvious, but I guess it’s not (laughs). With the lyrics the next album is definitely a lot more personal, and the EP we just put out kind of was too. Can’t say that as much for Haha though, but some parts of it I guess.

Soft Cell: Is there are misconceptions you think people have about your guys.

Fletcher: Probably a lot.

Wyatt: Yeah, there’s probably a lot more than we even realize honestly.

Fletcher: It’s hard to say.

Wyatt: They are always out there. That we were doing modeling before music and then that’s how we got into music, and modeling lifted our music and what not, which is untrue, but it’s just one of those things that’s not even worth arguing about because at the end of the day people are just going to want to believe what they want to believe so, you can only say so much. So that kind of died off for us years ago.

Fletcher: I think we most of the time choose to say nothing because at the end of the day people are always gonna have their opinions on what you’re doing, so it doesn’t really matter at the end of the day. We just like to do what we’re doing, that’s what makes us happy.

Soft Cell: That’s part of the point to, to let the people interpret everything that you produce. You give it to them and they pick up whatever they want to pick up.

Wyatt: Yeah, it gives them the opportunity to also take it how they want to take it, like you were saying. The could make it personal to their own life you know, and then it sticks with them for a while hopefully.


Soft Cell: Your new music seems to explore a lot of new grounds. Do you guys consider yourself “experimental” in any way?

Wyatt: Yeah, for sure, I’d say that’s probably the best way to put it honestly.

Fletcher: I think we experiment less with new sounds, and more with … it’s hard to say.

Wyatt: At the root of it we’re just “experimental,” I guess that’s how it would go.

Soft Cell: And with that are you guys hoping to find something in particular? I have one friend who asks if this search is eschatological in nature, which basically just means “discovering the destiny of humankind.”

Fletcher: Um, is that what we’re doing, is that the question?

Soft Cell: In any way do you guys feel like the way you’re progressing in your music is to search for something within yourself or within the world around you?

Fletcher: I think it’s more of like a spontaneous creation, less with like a mission, more with spontaneity in what we create, because we make so much music. It’s almost like a spontaneous form of therapy in some way that we really enjoy doing.

Wyatt: [Referencing the comment section] They’re liking your questions.

Soft Cell: Oh, hell yeah! That’s good, because I’ve been watching some of your Youtube videos and lot of people are always commenting how these interviews, the questions suck, so …

Wyatt: Yeah, they want to know the same thing over and over again, I guess. We’re here to give it to them!

Soft Cell: I tried to avert that just a little bit. That’s what UCLA Radio brings, keep listening to us. I have some random questions. What songs would you guys think would be playing during the apocalypse, a birth, and Trump showers. If these things had a theme song to them, or just like any sound really, what would be playing? Apocalypse, birth, Trump showers …

Wyatt: What’s “Trump showers”?

Soft Cell: Like Trump, taking a shower.

Wyatt: Oh, oh.

Soft Cell: Sorry, I worded that strangely.

Wyatt: For the apocalypse, probably some sort of alarm. For a birth, maybe a harp. And then for Trump taking a shower, I guess, a tuba.

Fletcher: I was thinking the same thing on that, actually, on the tuba one. I’d say, apocalypse, a lot of screaming. That’s it. Birth, a lot of screaming. And Trump taking a shower, everybody who’s watching, a lot of screaming.

Soft Cell: That’s funny, because my answers for these were, have you guys ever seen that one art piece by Yoko Ono where she just screams?

Wyatt: I’m not a big Yoko Ono listener.

Fletcher: I don’t know much about her actually.

Soft Cell: Ok, I’ll show you the vid or a clip or the vid after, but that was my answer for everything: Yoko Ono screaming. Ok, next question, if there was one specific event in time where you could go back and watch, what would it be? (A long pause) Ok, my answer while they think is Jesus’ cruxifiction, if that happened, but, you know… “experimental.” (Another pause) It doesn’t have to be too…

Wyatt: Yeah, I just can’t think of anything that I would care to go back in time for.

Fletcher: I think if I had the opportunity to go back in time, see now I’m elaborating on the question, I don’t even want to go down that road, I’m just going to try and answer the question you asked.

Soft Cell: No, you could go down that road if you want, we’re all here for you guys. If you want to go down that road, go down that road.

Fletcher: I don’t know if I would even go back and time … I don’t even know if I would take the opportunity, I might just give it to somebody else who had something more important to do.

Soft Cell: That’s a good answer.

Fletcher: Oh, I might go visit and see my grandmother before she died. Because I didn’t see that, my whole family was there and I wasn’t there.

Wyatt: Yeah, I would pick that too. It’s an easy cop out, but it is true.

Soft Cell: Ok, it went serious, but very wholesome.

Fletcher: (Laughs) I was trying to take the question seriously.

Soft Cell: Last question before we throw this set back to its owner, Carla … sorry I just brain farted for a second. Humans, we look at birds as flying. Do crabs in the water look at fish as if they’re flying?

Fletcher: Uh, probably.

Wyatt: That’s a good strong maybe on that one.

Soft Cell: Nice! Ok, that’s it, “good strong maybe,” last words from The Garden, thank you for tuning in to The Experimental Hospital.

Fletcher: I saw that question [referencing the comment section] “Del Taco or Taco Bell.” Del Taco.

Wyatt: D-tac. Of course Del Taco.

Soft Cell: Um, I’m thinking. Taco Bell for me. I’ve never had Del Taco, but I feel like I probably had, I just can’t distinguish between the two. Ok, that’s it, thank you for tuning into The Experimental Hospital, this is UCLA Radio…

Wyatt: Sorry, can we plug something really quick?

Soft Cell: Oh yeah! Sorry, plug anything you want to plug [ ;) ]. No I totally forgot too, that’s my bad.

Wyatt: No, it’s ok. We got a U.S. tour coming up in April, and we got a European tour coming up in March, then we have a quick Spain run with two shows, Barcelona and Madrid, in a couple of days, that starts on the 15. And then we have an album coming out March…

Fletcher: 30. He doesn’t even know when his own album is coming out.

Wyatt: And then the knew single, called “Stallion,” comes out February 27, so stay tuned. Thanks for letting me plug that.

Soft Cell: Yeah, that’s it. Go check them out, go watch them live. It’s amazing.

Wyatt: Oh yeah, we’ll be at The Regent Theater, April.

Soft Cell: Hell yeah.

Fletcher: [To Wyatt] You’re looking at me like I’m the fucking calendar. Oh sorry!

Soft Cell: No, it’s cool. We’re not regulated, so you can cuss as much as you want.

Wyatt: He’s trying to be hard.

Fletcher: Trying to be hard.

Wyatt: Regent Theater, just go on their website, I forgot the date.

Soft Cell: You’ll figure it out.

Wyatt: It’s like the second show of the U.S. tour.

Soft Cell: They will be playing with Cowgirl Clue who is coming onto my show in two week’s time.

Wyatt: And Tijuana Panthers as well.

Soft Cell: Yeah, so stay tuned for that, go check them out, go listen to all their stuff, and have a nice day. Thank you for listening.

title: Fred Armisen - Stand-Up for Drummers // Comedy Review
content:
Image courtesy of Netflix

Written by Ruhi Shah

Fred Armisen’s new Netflix stand-up special is a music and comedy lover’s dream come true.

At first glance, it is hard to imagine why Netflix chose to include such a niche stand-up special in its library.  From the intro, the audience knows that this performance was literally meant for drummers, starting from the drum pad mini audition in the lobby before entering.  However, the performance is still fun for all audiences, and there are non-drumming comedy bits for anyone to enjoy if the drummer humor goes over your head.  Fred Armisen, SNL alum and co-creator of Portlandia, combines his love and expertise of music and comedy with a childlike enthusiasm to perform a very entertaining hour of jokes.

Although dull at some specific moments, the stand-up special was overall a showcase of talent. Armisen’s drum playing is almost as good as his expert impressions.  He combines these talents to give the audience both musical and physical impressions of drummers, from Ringo Starr, to a jazz drummer, to “that friend who thinks they can play the drums,” in a highly entertaining and expressive way.

The show is extraordinarily diverse in its content.  Armisen includes an entire bit where he is playing drums from different eras, including just a hint of humor, and another where he is simply going across a map of North America performing accents from different regions, which is overtly comedic. The special’s lack of clarity and focus (other than drumming) contribute to its randomness, which many find funny. He takes a fresh and unexpected take on comedy by performing for a specific audience, but including more universal, objective, and even unrelated humor simultaneously, and it all somehow works.

This standup special is for musicians, particularly drummers, looking for relatable content, but the show could be funny to any audience.  A lot of the hour is filled with general jokes.  For example, he addresses doctors from the 1700s, a childhood letter, Burger King, and much more, performed in a purely playful way. But as Armisen performs, he might lose some people. His jokes aren’t all fully developed and strong, but they all have a recognizable root value that still makes them funny.

It is impressive and rare when a comedy special includes absolutely no profanity. This special is for all ages and hardly contains a questionable word or joke. This choice demonstrates Armisen’s cleverness and raw skill when it comes to comedy.  

His impressions and celebrity guests, along with his drum playing in the audience, make this show interactive and transport Netflix viewers to the theater.  His talent, paired with his enthusiasm, makes the whole show feel like it was a childhood dream of his come to life, and his excitement is contagious. You can feel his passion and energy, even when the crowd might not. The whole stand-up special is brought to life by Armisen’s performance, and the experience of watching is hard to forget.

title: SiR - November // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia

Can Top Dawg Ent deliver another satisfying dose of thoughtful, sexy, laced R&B? Are we to dream continuously over the recent Grammy nominated SZA album? After all, when I heard SiR was meant to deliver a record in early 2018, I had simultaneous goosebumps mulling over the Ctrl record and nightmares regretting the aimless Lance Skiiiwalker record.

Yet as the record opens, with a dimly lit chit chat between SiR and what seems to be a flight attendant, or futuristic space dash, one can’t help but imagine the TDE crooner might have something ambitious prepared for the masses. It is a soft spoken exchange about moving forward, confirming that the “engines are ready at 100,” and it arguably sets a scene for a forward thinking album.

The true opener, “That’s Alright,” presents a dreary, psychedelic and colorfully bleak picture of a hopeful girl and her eager love, as SiR sets her aside over and over and satisfies her over and over. It is a groovy piece for the bedroom, as clacking percussion and junky, seducing bass notes bubble under the soft spoken vocals. One has to admit that for an opening statement, the vocals play a more disinterested role as the song proceeds. The second chorus does not hit as hard as the first, and gives up entirely as the track reaches its short lived end. As it echoes away, one can understand that just like the love for this girl, the vocals are ready to disappear at a moment’s notice. It leaves a dry taste in one’s mouth. 

As “Something Foreign” continues, one can’t help but anticipate the ScHoolboy Q feature, as SiR enters the picture and leaves with the same sense of disinterest, or perhaps shallow moodiness that only comes off as unexciting. ScHoolboy Q’s demeanor is along the same lines, and he comes and goes with the same jazzy piano notes skipping across the boom bap beat. It is another perfect ballad for the bedroom, but perhaps too short to possibly be enjoyed to the fullest degree in that setting. It is now two instances of a track not being fleshed out enough to be poignant or impressive, despite being smooth as silk. 

“D’Evils” is an ode to marijuana, and it comes and goes just as an inhale and exhale of the drug does. Yet the hauntingly high pitched sample keeps the song fresh and addictive between takes of SiR’s, once again, backseat vocals. “A one spliff a day’ll keep the evil away,” is as sticky a refrain as actual top shelf nugs are. “Something New” features British artist Etta Bond, as the two exchange sincere, yet short lived, loving phrases. As the vocals intertwine in the second half of the piece, it is once again evident that the record can have such an imposing presence in a bedroom, yet can be saltless and bland aside from that setting. Etta Bond and SiR have a low amount of chemistry, yet the reverb on the vocals and subtle panning makes the duet a sweet and endearing one.

A second interlude follows the end of this track, as it is revealed that SiR is currently on a spacecraft of some kind, headed to a destination that is “three trillion kilometers away,” yet one can’t help but feel that this entire time the ship has been either stagnant or moving at a sluggish pace. It is an interesting interlude to include in a record where the sentiments and beats are more rooted in the past than they are in some kind of futuristic environment.

The track “I Know” is arguably the worst on the record; A song that is so out of place, so aimless, so grating and discomforting that one has to wonder who was the “yes man” that gave this piece a thumbs up. From the uninteresting and uninspired beat to the plain, drone chords hanging in the background, nothing takes the title of worst channel on the track as the ugly, attuned vocals. This is a track that fails in terms of being interesting, being enjoyable and, worst of all, being sexy. It completely derails the record’s small momentum and sexy aura in the first few seconds when the vocals are introduced.

“Never Home” makes a small attempt at trying to recapture the sexy wave that the record was flowing on in the first half of the record. The tiny, angelic harmonies behind the “I’m never home” refrain are honestly ruined by the harsh phone call that rambles on and on in the forefront. Between these two previous tracks, the record needed some desperate help.

“War” is a slight return to form, as SiR regrets and simps over a failed relationship displayed in the previous track. “I’m ready to fall for ya…I’m ready to fight for us,” are modest remarks crooned and whimpered graciously that are ready to make and can spice up the bedroom once again. However, the “da da da da da” vocals riddling the last third of the track are, once again, a questionable decision on behalf of the TDE singer. They take away from the lo fi aesthetic and are, to put it bluntly, flat out ugly. “Better” is a hollow trap-influenced R&B song that contains certain pauses where one can only assume a guest rapper was to have found an entrance. The vocals that SiR provides here are a bit monotonous and robotic, but can still work in the bedroom if played at a lower volume that the first half of the record. The interlude at the end of this song also presents the same setting where SiR converses with his “mothership,” and a much more intriguing and colorful instrumental, only referred to as “ultralight,” is played. Now would be a better time than any to mention that the voice of the “mothership” has changed across the three interludes.

SiR then proclaims going into “autopilot” and the final two tracks do just that. “Dreaming of Me” is a sensual piece that depends a lot on glitchy, alternating pitch vocals that pop in and out of the mix along with the lo fi beat and wahwah guitar licks. The closer, “Summer in November,” is an endearing love song directed at a woman that changes the ambiance of SiR’s environment. As he presents his most energetic and dominant vocals on the chorus, one can only wish that the middle portion of the record had continued with the same energy and ambiance. The interludes were misleading, but it is safe to say that there is a healthy batch of great bedroom tracks on the record and that it satisfies as a prequel to what SiR can potentially deliver in the near future. It is not a grand presentation, as Ctrl was, but it is definitely another modest delivery from the TDE camp.

6/10…

#somereallygreatbedroomsongs/10

title: Golden - Romeo Santos // Album Review
content:
Written by Irlanda Mora

I was excited when Romeo Santos announced his sophomore studio album as a solo artist. He, alongside Aventura, helped commercialize and make bachata mainstream in the early 90s. With over twenty years in the music industry he has rightfully earned the title of “king of bachata.”
