Golden is an interesting album. As a whole it is okay, but I had higher standards for Santos. The album begins with an electronic synthetic beat combined with lyrics in English. This serves to welcome new listeners that have been recently introduced to the Latinx music market via the now deplorable “Despacito.” This introduction commemorates his experience in the music industry. He singsongs phrases that are commonly mistaken as arrogant such as, “every hundred years an artist like me is born,” yet the delivery simply suggests that listeners appreciate his music now that he’s alive. A common trope in Latin America is uplifting artists after death.

Then there’s “Tuyo.” This song has traditional bachata guitar strumming coupled with assuring romantic lyrics of loyalty, and devotion sung in falsetto.

“Perjurio” has an alluring beat, one where the listener must nod along and cannot resist dancing. However, this uplifting vibrant beat is juxtaposed with cynical lyrics of moving on from a fling, one devoid of emotional attachment and rampant with disloyalty.

“Premio” features Swizz Beatz has the most synthetic sound from the whole album. At 54 seconds the beat completely changes and the guitar stops, there is an intermission that captivates and soothes the listener.

“Carmín,” a ballad sung in falsetto, begins with a piano run. Juan Luis Guerra makes his presence known and he harmonizes with Santos seamlessly. Overall it’s extremely soothing. This is a song for anyone that’s caught up in their feelings! The outro of the song is the highlight.

“Centavito” has a very 90s vibe, it reminded me of “Obsesión” Santos. It covers topics such as masculinity. At 3:06 the guitar riff is phenomenal. This song is one of the top ones in the album - thelyrics are very clingy though.

“Sobredosis,” featuring Ozuna, is a sensual song. Ozuna singing in bachata wasn’t something I thought I needed, but he’s pleasing to listen to. His voice is softer than usual and he steals the show away.

Then there are “El Papel 1: versión amante” and “El papel 2” The first is a song from the side piece point of view. It’s a nice contrast of a relaxing beat and the vivid imagery of a person trapped in a toxic relationship. “El papel 2″ is extremely vulnerable and the instrumentation reflects this.

“Bella y Sensual,” featuring Daddy Yankee and Nicky Jam, has an engaging and festive beat. If any song off of Golden will get a tremendous amount of radio play, it’s this one. It differs from all other songs in the album because is has a very pop beat. In terms of verses, Nicky Jam topped this one.

“Doble Filo” has the most bachata sound. It sounds as if it was recorded right out of a barrio in the Dominican Republic. This song is traditional bachata, it has hurt lyrics coupled with rhythmic guitar.

“Ay Bendito” talks about heartbreak. “Heroe favorito” is the most romantic song on the album.

“El amigo,” featuring Julio Iglesias, is comedic because they essentially wrote a song about their penises. *sigh* someone needs to give straight men a lecture on comedy, but I digress.

“Reina de papi” reminds his listeners to avoid settling for just anyone.

“Imitadora” is a BOP. Easily the most commercialized sound, it also carries a common theme of falling out of love with someone.

“Un Vuelo,” featuring Jesse Reyes, is a song of two exes bantering back and forth, and thankfulness over their break-up is juxtaposed with a slow, romantic beat.

Golden ends with “Sin Filtro,” in which Santos proclaims that he has proven himself as an artist.  Overall, the album is an interesting roller coaster ride, where you’re perpetually heartbroken, attempting to woo someone, and laughing at the shenanigans of some of these lyrics.

title: SYRE - Jaden Smith // Album Review
content:
Written by Daniel Leka

“Most Trees Are Blue”

“If A Books Store Never Runs Out of A Certain Book, Does That Mean Nobody Reads It, Or Everybody Reads It”

“When I Die. Then You Will Realize.”

“If Newborn Babies Could Speak They Would Be The Most Intelligent Beings On Planet Earth.”

“How Can Mirrors Be Real If Our Eyes Aren’t Real”

To the public eye, these tweets are none other than the work of the “pretentious,” “self-absorbed” son of Hollywood juggernaut Will Smith that screams for attention. However, what many people failed to recognize is that Will Smith’s son has a name, and he goes by the name of Jaden Christopher Syre Smith. A teenager who has had to live in the shadow of his parents for his entire life alongside his sister Willow, Smith has seen scrutiny time and time again from the public for his artistic decisions as well as the public persona he portrays. However, what was often neglected was the content and the work he was putting in to create his own legacy. Now, at 19, Smith is one of the figureheads of his own clothing company/collective/music label called MSFTSREP, is a co-founder of boxed water company JUST water, and has had a hand in a multitude of other mediums, including a collaboration with Umami Burger on a vegan burger. However, more than ever, it feels as though Smith’s music was bound to get more attention after he had posted an assortment of snippets onto his Instagram (@c.syresmith). These snippets had generated a huge assortment of excitement, particularly the snippet entitled “ICON.”

So with seemingly all eyes on him, Smith released his debut album entitled SYRE, which he says was three years in the making.

Coming into this record, I had high hopes considering that I have been a huge fan of Smith’s for around three to four years. After hearing his previous projects such as Cool Tape Vol. 2 (CTV2) and his This Is The Album EP, what I had gotten from Smith up to that point was that he was a thinker who merely wished to translate his thoughts into mediums of expression. That was what justified his early tweets, as well as opened up a new perspective about the person Smith was becoming right before my very eyes. And the opening track of his album, the four track opener “BLUE” (stylized “B,” “L,” “U,” and “E”), showcases such incredible growth that is apparent through the musicality, experimental vocal cadences and pitches, and precise focus that was displayed on verses that he uttered throughout the four tracks. It was a phenomenal opener, and one that was bound to catch the attention of Jaden Smith naysayers.

Essentially, the first half of the record plays along the lines of these four songs, seamlessly flowing from one track to the next and articulating the story of the character Smith has opted to create that is based around one of his middle names: “Syre.” As a listener, the more I delved deeper and deeper into the record, the more nuances I was able to pick up on, and the more I came to appreciate the attention to detail that Smith provided for this project. The track durations ranged from a couple of minutes to nine and a half minutes at most, and each song utilized Smith to the fullest extent. On the first half, the record plays like a film that Smith aspires to make, and the second half, though not as concise as the first, showcases a broad range of Smith’s skill set as well as his influences. 

Hints of Childish Gambino, Kid Cudi, and Kanye West reign supreme on certain tracks; however, what I find particularly interesting about Smith’s music is he does not shy away from his influences. Rather, he is very blatant in showcasing his interpretations of his idols, even stating on the track “Icon” that he “owes it all to Cudi and to Tycho.” On a track like “Watch Me,” it is very easy to see the resemblance to Kanye West’s “Black Skinhead” off of his Yeezus LP. It is also intriguing to see the resemblance to Kid Cudi’s song “Surfin,’” off of his recent LP Passion, Pain, and Demon Slayin’. Other tracks such as “George Jeff” showcase even more similarities to artists like Childish Gambino, and how he utilized his skill set on a track such as “I.The Party.” Smith incorporates such various styles that it creates an enjoyable listen, with very heartbreaking overtones and occasionally braggodocios undertones.

This album is not perfect, and not without its flaws, particularly when reflecting on run time and transitions within songs that are at times underwhelming in my mind. However, what SYRE presents is a nineteen year old who is attempting to do something that strays away from conventional formulas, and inspires a new generation to do the same. Considering the people that are around Smith’s age that are getting popularity, particularly the Lil Pumps, Lil Yachtys, and Desiigners of the world, Smith elects to not solely follow trends. Rather, what he offers is his own interpretation of these styles in an attempt to create sounds and music that drastically differ from the pool of new music we receive day in and day out. And on that front, SYRE is a successful record and one that has immense potential in kickstarting the career of Jaden Smith as more than just the son of Will Smith.

8/10

title: How TV Screwed Up Selection Sunday
content:
Written by Spencer Weissman

Selection Sunday is supposed to be the kickoff to the most intense thrill ride of college basketball season. The point of the show is to build excitement for the next three weeks of college basketball. It is supposed to be the quick taste to the madness that will ensue. However, over the last few years, the coverage of the selection show has fallen off. At 6 ET and 3 PT, everyone gathers around their TV as the brackets are released. For most, we are most curious to see the seeding, the region, and the date of our teams first game. For people like me, that first Thursday and Friday is a lost day of school. It is my favorite sports weekend of the year. But it all begins with the selection show.

Where they went wrong?

It used to be that the Selection Show lasted around 30 minutes as the regions were announced and the teams in them were promptly announced. Over time it has become a more drawn out process as making teams sweat out their seed and the bubble teams more uneasy. When the concept of the First 4 Games in Dayton began is when the show moved to around two hours. Many college basketball fans have complained this a dumb set up as we just want the bracket out as fast as possible. However, this year they are going about it a whole new way.

The New Way of Announcing

Rather than introducing the brackets, TBS is starting off the show announcing the 68 teams in the field. Around 60 teams that make the tournament are all a given come Selection Sunday. The main attraction of the day is going to what region you are in and who you face. By doing it this way, it drags out a show that is already too long. In addition, for the bubble teams that do get in, you still do not know your seed and whether you are in Dayton for a First 4 Game. Most fans like myself remember the best year in recent years of Selection Show came when the bracket was leaked early.

The Solution

Go back to what has worked in the past. Make the Selection Sunday Show just 30 minutes. The “bracketologist” is almost 95 percent accurate with the teams that make the field, so that is no longer as pressing. Where the fans truly care is finding out the regions, game dates, and match ups. All of that can be done in 30 minutes like it was in the past. As a fan, I do not need to hear Charles Barkley comment on any team for more than 30 seconds. It just is not as enjoyable as getting the bracket out as early as possible and being able to make my picks.

title: Show of the Month: experiMENTAL hospital w/DJ soft cell // March 2018
content:
Interviewed by Alexa Lee 

What inspires the talking points and playlists of your show? Obviously the experimental music genre, but beyond that — you incorporate such abstract concepts/art visuals into your show that I’m very curious.

even though the experiMENTAL hospital is my entire heart i’m afraid the talking points aren’t very produced. i’m inspired by that very day, and my new genres art class happens to fall right before. one time my instructor disbanded the original lesson plan (which is usually just him commenting on art videos/performances) and had everyone pile into cars and follow him around various points of LA including the infamous beverly hills witch house, randy’s donuts, hobbit house, and a scenic drilling rig. it took three hours, by the second the sun and ambiance had a pressure drop. that pressure drop that reveals itself differently every class, and which up until then i didn’t realize had been present since the first day of class, follows me every monday and that is what inspires my show. as far as playlists go, those abstract concepts and art visuals inspire them, which all usually reference films. a sacrificial malchik seduces me into a frame of mind in which produces those concepts and thus the experiMENTAL hospital is reborn every week.

If you had to describe the overarching mood or emotional theme of your show, what would it be?

the overarching mood or emotional theme is whatever the listener wants to make of it. i release what is inside me and ~they~ absorb/transform to their liking. to me the mood is a crisp walk right at 5:30 pm (late winter) when the skin is tight and air is brisk and everyone is crying naked on the bathroom floor listening to a combination of tr/st and kate bush and the sun is almost gone and plasma reigns strong and you have so much hope and can visibly feel yourself and hair and teeth and lungs and you scream out to the world but no one can hear and you sit in this pool holding yourself until there is nothing left but everything is shaking and he’s gone and it’s wet outside and tomorrow is alright. or also someone crying to puppy videos laying on their bunk bed in the dark. but like i said, i am whatever you want me to be

Your radio bio states, “I am a hypocrite.” Could you elaborate on this statement?

no

What is the biggest difference between your show and other radio shows that gives the experiMENTAL hospital that razzle dazzle? Was this difference intentionally crafted, or did it come about more naturally?

a chlorine gargoyle runs mine, that’s the only natural thing about my show

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

i am a hypocrite
tags: ucla radio show of the month

title: Interview with Kimbra
content:
Interview by Pam Gwen 

Photos by Katy C. Ramage

DJ Spamela: Hello! You’re listening to Cosmic Harmony on uclaradio.com with DJ Spamela! Today I am interviewing Grammy award-winning Kimbra Lee Johnson, known as Kimbra, from New Zealand. I am so grateful for your presence and enamoured to speak to such a powerhouse. Hello! Kimbra, what are your preferred pronouns?

Kimbra: Haha, thanks for asking! I go by she or her.

DJ Spamela: I just want to start off by saying, I’ve been listening to you since I was 14 and I turned 21 last week. I watched your Two Way Street live performance at Sing Sing Studios and was hooked. The way you get lost inside your music and allow your dance moves & body to overcome you with each beat perfectly encapsulates how your music should be listened to. So it is an honour to be both a fan, journalist, and radio DJ all at the same time with your presence right now!

Kimbra: That’s really sweet of you to say. Thank you so much, that means a lot to me.

DJ Spamela: All my friends wanted to send some love to you and we truly thank you for the dance parties that we’ve had over and over again because of your music.

Kimbra: That’s fantastic that you said that. I’m so glad you shared that with me!

DJ Spamela: No, thank you! I wanted to start off the interview by asking how your morning has been so far? And if you did any favorite acts of self-love or inspirational rituals you do to keep yourself grounded among the chaos of being an amazing artist?

Kimbra: Oh, well I’m sort of currently talking to you and I’m about to make an Indian dinner for a friend that I have coming over. I’m making an vegan Indian dal and chick-pea curry so that’s a real nice way to wind down. But it’s been really busy because we’re about to embark on this US tour, so I’m sort of on emails every second. But, I’m so excited! To tour in LA, of course, and all around the country. It’s going to be so great!

DJ Spamela: Congratulations on the journey to releasing your new album, Primal Heart. Coming out April 20 y’all! Put it on your calendar. Big things are happening for you! “Somebody That I Used to Know” hit 1 Billion and 200,000+ views on YouTube! The idea of 1 billion people in general is mind boggling, but so many souls have listened to your craft. You are about to touch a bunch on your tour! I will be seeing you in LA on Valentines Day at the Ace Hotel! Los Angeles, get your tickets! Don’t miss out.

DJ Spamela: What is one piece of advice you would give to young artists out there who aspire to be like you one day? Especially young female artists who want to get into the producing business and music industry, because you yourself produce so much of your songs! Because there isn’t female visibility in the industry.

Kimbra: Yeah I absolutely agree. There’s a lot of advice I could give, but maybe one really big one is kind of building the confidence to share your craft with people and actually ask for help. You know, I think that sometimes as women, unfortunately, we don’t put ourselves out there and say, “Look! I’m learning this thing. And I really would love some help.” You could ask around and say, “Do you think you could come over to my house and tomorrow we could learn Able-ton? Or could you teach me how to be able to work at a time-signature when I’m listening to a song?” So you can learn the vocabulary to be a producer or an artist. And it can help to have so many mentors in your life to continue to guide you and teach you. I try to put myself out there a lot and if I meet someone that I have a connection with, I ask for their email and suggest if I could send them something. And I think that can go a long way. Especially with the age of the internet, with everyone being so accessible now.

DJ Spamela: So I know you’ve delayed the release to truly commit to your artistic vision. This makes it that much more exciting for your fans. Plus, I love it when my favorite artists truly commit to the idea of a whole album rather than just radio hits they chug out all the time. Listening to an album from top to bottom is SUCH an experience and form of art. What are you personally most excited about with this album and how do you think it differs from your previous albums?

Kimbra: Yeah, well I think every album I make is a reaction to what I’ve done before. The last album I made in LA, called Golden Echo. I kind of lived in this world of imagination and it was very psychedelic. I’ve gotten so many people to help me and it was a really important record for me to kind of celebrate a lot of music I love. It was wild and encompassed everything in my mind. But with this record, since moving to New York. I feel like I’ve become level-grounded as a person and I’m a lot more focused. I’m ready to share some of my pain as well. Some things that are closer to my heart, its a lot more confrontational and bold. Instead of escaping from reality, I think that I’m more grounded to reality on this record. But still, highly imaginative and colorful, that’s always going to be a part of what I do. But, I think that, I don’t know it’s a maturity thing. I think I’m learning to be more personable with my work and it is quite liberating.

DJ Spamela: That’s really beautiful. It’s your peaceful purgatory where you’re in the middle of your fantasy and reality world into one beautiful landscape. Which is why your fans love your work. I personally feel like I’m always in your world and transcend it to all parts of my life listening to your album from top to bottom.

Kimbra: Ah! I agree, I love that. That’s great. I’m glad that you see the importance of an album from top to bottom. I like a narrative and I promise Primal Heart will be the same.

DJ Spamela: Do you have any favorite albums that you use as inspiration?

Kimbra: Yeah! There’s so many. I’m a big fan of a lot of prog/rock bands. They’re very good at designing a cinematic arc. Even indie bands I listened to in high school like Interpol. I still listen to those albums and think, wow, they really made a lot of choices on this record. Definitely Radiohead for full-length albums. They say such interesting stories in their records, like Rainbows. But, there are definitely a lot more records I love and stick out to me.

DJ Spamela: I know you mentioned bringing some personal pain into this record, but what makes you feel like you’re on “Top of the World” these days in honor of your new single that just came out, “Top of the World!”

Kimbra: Hahahahahahaha. Oh, let’s see. I would say that I do get a real high when I’m on stage performing for people. I’m actually kinda shy out sometimes in the real world, and I’m like every person in the world. I’m 27, I have insecurities and I have fear. And I have all these things that we’re all coping with. I feel like it’s such a God given gift to be able to be on stage. And I feel like that so much of that fear and self-conscious just goes. I feel like I can channel something greater than me and I feel like I can do anything you know? It’s kind of beautiful. It’s a really special feeling for me to be able to sing, create, and it truly gives me a real high.

DJ Spamela: Thank you for your time. Have an amazing, prosperous, fulfilling, and positive day Kimbra. It was such a pleasure and honor to talk to you. I’ll leave you to your Indian curry and I’ll see you in Los Angeles!

Kimbra: Ah of course, it was so lovely to chat with you. Bye and see you soon!

title: Triathalon - Online // Album Review
content:
Written by Alexandra Shambayate 

Following up their 2015 album, Nothing Bothers Me, Triathalon just released
their new 2018 album Online. Right off the bat, I was drawn to this album
because of the simple, yet cute pink~y aesthetic album cover; it’s much different from their older, dull-nostalgic covers. I have personally been listening to this band since 2016 when I first discovered their song “South Side” off their Cold Shower EP. I instantly loved Triathalon’s dreamy, bedroom-synth sound. Although their sound is very much influenced by current lo-fi-sythy-dream bedroom pop music mixed with some slow jazzy beats and mellow/groovy deep bass riffs, I have still been happily listen to everything they’ve been putting out through the years. 

The new album itself is not the most extraordinary musical production ever; It has a few catchy tunes with some groovy beats. Their sound is very much the same in comparison to their past albums, but a bit more upbeat. My favorite song off their newest album is “Bad Mood”. They first released this song in 2016 on a various artist album called Everything Melts Eventually, Vol. II. The version that was released off the 2016 album is much more stripped and slowed down, adding a cooler and unique sound. The newer version on Online is much more upbeat, and contains less of the reverb effects that gave the sum so much more character on the original version. Although I prefer the original rendition of the song, I still very much enjoy the track and consider it one of my favorites, along with the song “True.” 

Triathalon in the UCLA Radio Station (2/13/18).

The closing song off the album is “True” and has a completely different theme and sound from all the other songs they’ve composed. This song almost seems to be influenced by early 2000s Usher, Lil Wayne, Kanye sort of R&B, along with current bedroom-pop sound. I really love this song and wish they would’ve created more songs with this sound. 

Overall, the album is super chill and easy to listen to. Although it isn’t the most unique album out, it definitely carries itself with the majority of well composed and lyrically significant synthy tunes. I am happy this band is growing and creating more music that sounds so effortless and relaxing, yet contains so many elements that overlay and complement one another. I would definitely recommend this album along with their projects as well!

title: The Other Favorites - Fools // Album Review
content:
Written by Sam Celentano 

While there have been no shortage of musical projects for YouTube star Josh Turner (see Coyote Armada, Kingdom Jasmine, multitudes of collaborative efforts, etc.),The Other Favorites is the crown jewel of an impressive resume. Joined by childhood friend Carson McKee, the singer-songwriter duo’s six-song EP is their first collective release in nearly five years. On the whole, Fools is a delightful blend of Americana, folk, and bluegrass that demonstrates musical and lyrical maturity previously unheard from Turner and McKee.

For the average listener, the album starts strong. For the listener who has followed Turner’s YouTube channel for years on end, this is a polished throwback to a cherished Other Favorites video released in 2015, so I would say it starts very strong. “The Levee” not only introduces the listener to McKee’s dulcet tones and Turner’s impressive virtuosity, but also lays ground for a six-song demonstration of strong songwriting. One encounters a gentle ebb and flow as they press on to the next few songs, gliding from uptempo bluegrass jams, down to soft folk ballads, and back up once more. The thoughtfulness of its track organization contributes an immense amount to the enjoyability of this project, however, the hard-hitting lyrical content and thought-provoking chords (see “Angelina”) make this more than just another drop in the bucket of uninspired folk albums.

It’s a fine line that I walk on when I write for the uninitiated listener, the line between being an impartial reviewer and a fanboy. I should be hesitant to give this EP such a favorable review, but it should be no surprise that one doles out praise more readily to music that better suits their tastes. So I speak to those of you whose tastes are suited by minimalist Americana/bluegrass music: Fools is a record worth 20 minutes of your time.

title: CTRL - SZA // Album Review
content:
Written by Kaden Kotinek 

In the vast, everchanging music landscape that was 2017, the release of CTRL, SZA’s debut album, tackles insecurities, jealousy, and other modern elements of love. Born in St. Louis under the name of Solána Rowe, SZA entered summertime 2017 in a precarious scenario. In the three plus years since her last official musical release, she had begun to garner comparisons to superstars of the like of Beyonce and Frank Ocean. With the release of CTRL, SZA finally establishes herself within 2017’s R&B landscape as a force to be reckoned with.
The album is a 14 track escape that features lush production and lyrical growth, all backed behind the fearless yet fragile delivery of SZA. The album takes a look at love from her perspective that applies a beauty so raw and real to the lyrics that, as a listener, you wish you could apply to yourself. As the album progresses, her criticisms of modern love and dating become a tug-of-war
between issues that need to be taken seriously and changed versus accepting what is that cannot be changed. 

From a musical standpoint, the record takes on a much more modern version of
R&B. Guitar riffs lay the foundation for a borderline ‘indie-rock’ feel on cuts like “Supermodel,” while other songs like “Go Gina” are driven by repetitive percussion. We will take a look at some of the specific highlights (and few lowlights) on the album:

TOP Tracks

“Drew Barrymore”

The first single of this album features guitar chords that blend together with
reverb, and is an ode to fellow actor and friend of SZA’s, Drew Barrymore. The song’s hook introduces the listener to a feeling that we are all familiar: loneliness and not being good enough for the crush we adorn.

“Wavy (interlude)”

The shortest minute and fifteen seconds on the album are dedicated to an upbeat change of pace before the album raps up. The most refreshing cut on the album features vocals from James Fauntleroy, leaving listeners craving for more. (SZA has since promised a full length cut per fan requests)

“Supermodel”

The album’s opener starts with a sound bite from her mother talking about finding solace in the things she cannot control, a constant theme in CTRL. What follows is the most intimate track SZA has released to date. Real, personal lyrics about her dating failures turn up the heat on her former lovers, and every listener can feel it. In a track that features a surreal amount of emotion and a vocal range to emphasize the message, “Supermodel” is the standout track that sets off her album on the best note possible.

UNDERRATED Tracks

“Go Gina” 

For a repetitive ode to a sitcom character, this song was one of the more memorable cuts on the album. The production by Frank Dukes shines on this record, and it is a track you cannot resist to sing along to.

WORST Track

“Doves in The Wind”

A Kendrick Lamar feature with one of the most talented voices in the past
give years on a track together would harmonize into a mega hit right? WRONG. In order to dive through the song the listener hears SZA and Kendrick use the word ‘pussy’ at least 30 times, which wouldn’t be half as bad if the song’s message wasn’t contrive and ironic in its own sense. Listen and make your own informed decision, but this track was far from memorable.

OVERALL: 8.6/10

CTRL was named UCLA Radio’s second best album of 2017. See more of our year’s album wrap up here.

title: G-Eazy @ The Wiltern (2/23/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Helen Lee

“The first time we were here in LA, we had just sold out in a tiny, tiny theater and I thought to myself, man, we made it. How amazing, how beautiful is it that we could be anywhere in the universe right now, and right here in this moment we are here together in the beautiful city of Los Angeles?”

Right here in this very spot on the concert floor, screaming my lungs out crammed next to 1600 strangers, two of which just had to be escorted out by security, G-Eazy. I replied rhetorically in my head. By the way, can I call you Gerald– is anyone allowed to call you Gerald?
* * *
Not too many artists hone the ability to make a large theater filled with 21873 different people of different ages and backgrounds feel intimate. Even fewer artists hone their craft to tell a natural, rhapsodizing story, a progressive narrative. Every act felt so natural, as eazy-going as having a mental conversation with him when he addressed the audience, singing along with the bangers on his new album The Damned & Beautiful, and feeling a thing or two when he introspectively reflected on the themes of growth and change. Watching G-Eazy perform live at the Wiltern was an experience that both carefully straddled and boldly meshed these concepts.

Walking in, I was immediately swept in by the grandiose, lavish Art-Deco inspired beauty that the Wiltern Theatre boasts. I immediately thought about how fitting the venue was as an accompaniment for the themes of fame and glory that The Damned & The Beautiful explores. The glittering interior evoked a period of elegance and cheerfully extravagant style that made me glad I wasn’t drinking anything, as drinking anything less than champagne would feel like a disappointment - and if I were drinking, I certainly would not have been drinking champagne. The hallmark of this show, aside from the allure of the beautiful lights and the glamorously retro theatre vibes that the Wiltern had to offer (and the surprise appearance by Halsey during the Epilogue-encore that could only be described as a cosmic explosion of chemistry) was the thematic elements of the show. The show itself was broken apart into three separate parts and
then intricately woven to create one dynamic show. “Part 1: The Beautiful,” “Part 2: The Damned,” and “Part 3: The Epilogue.” 

In “Part 1: The Beautiful,” G-Eazy opened with the melodical hits of the album, like “The Beautiful and Damned” and “Pray for Me.” He began explosively, wowing the audience with colorful blends of smoke, and shooting fire into the air. At 6’4”, G-Eazy commandeered the vast and expansive stage with his larger than life stage presence, dressed in a black leather motorcycle jacket and simple black ensemble. While he was dressed simply, the bright, flashing graphics behind him visually contraposed him and with each and every song following suit, like “Some Kind of Drug,” it felt like a slow and steady build-up, a tension of opposing ideas. Thematically, “The Beautiful” seemingly represented the inner tension of losing values to fame, and even represented a simpler, more beautiful time with reminiscent songs like, “But a Dream.” Throughout this entire
act the audience went wild, singing along and yelling, while also engaged in a
thoughtful inner dialogue. To me, this entire act could be summed up by feeling like I was chasing the ephemeral and intangible, while being thoroughly enthralled by wondering, “Who is this incredibly talented and captivating man?” The graphics portrayed the troublesome and contemplative dichotomy of the struggles between good and evil, rich and poor, the beautiful and damned while the theater pulsed with the rhythmic beat drops and the rhyming of cleverly spun lyrics. 

The crux and build up led to “Part 2: The Damned,” where G-Eazy momentarily disappeared off stage to reappear in a bright white strait-jacket. The whole theater reverberated with the first key opening bars of “Leviathan,” and the rest of the stage was engulfed by the bright red-orange hues of heat and flames. As the stage lit up with flames, G-Eazy also kept up with the new dynamic, and figuratively spat fire line-by-line, especially with tracks like “That’s A Lot” and “You Got Me,” coming full circle and concluding his act with “Eazy.” This act was full of themes of rapture and paying homage to his long journey of music, as well as dissecting what fame and “making it” really entails. In comparison to “Part 1: The Beautiful,” Part 2 was much more lyrically intense and powerful and rather than introspective, it was retrospective and reflective.

* * *
“I remember when I was bouncing around, living out of a suitcase, crashing on friends’ couches living at AirBnbs, hotels, trying to make the album. But look at us now, Los Angeles. We made it. Tonight, we made it.”

Sensing that the set was coming to a close, the audience roared, clinging onto every word that he was addressing to each and every one of us, in the midst of singing “Eazy.” We were drunk on the atmosphere (definitely not champagne), intoxicated by his influence and charisma, and addicted to his flow. The final few lines of “Eazy” set the reflective, reminiscent tone of looking back at his entire journey to get to where he is. I reconciled this being the closing and contently accepted that this would be it. Boy, was I wrong. These final lines became the perfect segue to “The Epilogue.” This was just the beginning, the beginning of the actual climax of the show. 

G-Eazy left the stage, and the lights went out, leaving the audience enraptured in complete darkness and silence. In response, the crowd began to shout “Encore,” until the entire theater was filled with screams of anticipation. At the zenith and peak of expectation, the screen flashed with the words “Part 3: The Epilogue.” Then the first few familiar bars of “Him and I” filled the room. Before our very eyes, Halsey walked across the stage, followed by G-Eazy. The crowd exploded in a frenzy of excitement and gratification, as the chemistry between Halsey and G-Eazy was so passionately apparent. Sparks of connection and sexual tension heated up the stage to create a phenomenal performance between the duo. The epilogue represented G-Eazy’s life in the present day, with his greatest hits following such as “Me, Myself & I” and “No Limit.” The final moments of his entire show can only be described as purely euphoric, and the crowning glory of G-Eazy’s career.

Overall, G-Eazy is not only someone who has the talent, drive, and unique ability to make a crowded room feel intimate, but an artist who knows how to meet your expectations and then completely ignite them to create a completely inexplicable and extraordinary experience.

title: Lady Bird // Film Review
content:
Written by Emily Pitcher 

Coming-of-age film Lady Bird is a poignant insight into the person we simultaneously wanted and did not want to be in high school. It tells the story of Christine “Lady Bird” McPherson, an angsty high school senior who desperately wishes to escape the monotony of suburban Sacramento. The film navigates her turbulent relationship with her parents, virginity, the difficulty of fitting in, and her poor socioeconomic status. From prom dress shopping with her mother to crying over her first love, Lady Bird’s narrative follows many of the arcs that our younger selves experienced, only with an audacity and drive that we do not always agree with but cannot help admiring.

At its core, Lady Bird is a celebration of youth, of being confused and scared and how all of that is perfectly okay. One of the film’s biggest strengths is how relatable Lady Bird’s persona and struggles are - her concerns reflect the anxiety of teenagers who don’t have all of it figured out (i.e. all teenagers). At times, she is fearless, and other points, fearful, but most importantly, she’s still figuring it out. Greta Gerwig understands how actual teenagers work – Lady Bird is one of the most accurate portrayals of a young woman that I have seen. She is flawed, sometimes to the extent that we do not want to forgive her, but because we resonate so deeply with her journey, we have to. We forgave our younger selves, and we forgive her.

The film focuses largely on Lady Bird’s relationship with her mother, who just doesn’t get it. Films set in high school often neglect parental figures, and I loved how her mother was not comedic relief or merely present. Her mother is always looming, even if it’s unwanted, like how actual parents work. The building tension between the two is so painfully authentic – you even see yourself in the mother’s shoes, and you wish you treated your parents with more appreciation. The final scene between the two reminds you of how important family is in shaping your identity. You nag and create havoc for them, but ultimately, they are a larger part of you than you realized then.

Lady Bird captures so many of the hallmarks of youth: friendship, high school culture, the college search, dirty jokes, prom. It reminds you of how everything felt so big at the time, like how your crush liking you back was somehow so important. The film creates a caricature out of the classmates - the theatre kid, the popular girl, the outsider - all serving as individuals who fade in and out of Lady Bird’s life. They represent the transience of this period, when emotions are heightened and everyone is trying on identities like poorly fit shoes. Lady Bird goes through phases like how we did and possibly still do, and we find comedic relief when she adopts a character that screams short-lived.

This film reflects so much typical high school turmoil, and it does so with nuance and complexity. Lady Bird allows us to remember the wonders and gripes of youth, bringing up the moments from this period that we will never forget.

title: Collection - RR000 // Album Review
content:
By Emily Aitken-Rocco

Rodolfo Cruz and Jules Savery’s collaboration with Rønin Recordings’ creator, Daniel Azor, has sparked global interest since its release in September 2017. With all parties involved eager to begin their collaboration, Azor traveled from Palma de Mallorca, Spain, to produce with Cruz in LA back in January 2017. Azor crashed at Cruz’s humble abode for a short two months before flying back to Spain to continue individual work on their project. For his part, Savery composed his music in the Dominican Republic, contributing to the album’s ethnic flare from abroad. 

The beginning to each song builds the track as if from a teaser- a single repetitive beat that smoothly escalates into a mind warping, hypnotizing trance. Echoes of subtle tremors in the background make one feel as though they are confined in an unfamiliar space, before emerging into a velvet blanket of epiphany. Every snare, tap, drum, and kick move one to a state of uncertainty to one of clarity.

Listen with eyes closed…the collection mirrors the mind. If the consciousness had a sound, a rhythm, a melody, it would equate to similar sounds of what this multi-national collective produced. I lived at Cruz’s place while Azor was here, and watching their creative process is what essentially drew my immense appreciation for their work. I would wake up to a haze of smoke and a new beat they had only started the night before. Night and day, their eyes were
fixed upon their screens as their fingers were glued to their computers, drum machines and synthesizers.

I asked them what their album’s theme was - “I don’t know how to translate this from Spanish, but I guess the whole thing would be a mind-static-ness…Queríamos llegar a un estado mental de claridad… but more than clarity…a different dimension maybe.”

Far too often do I hear the same beat or progression echoing throughout contemporary music. This album’s rarity is what deems it as a true work of art. One can hear sounds from all over the world in a single collection - originality at its finest.

title: Zo - Born 2 Ball // Album Review
content:
Written by Harold Gonzalez-Mejia 

I only chose to review this because the kid is a Bruin himself. Wow, I really regret that decision.

Nobody is trusting yo’ brand, Lonzo. I don’t know who the fuck paid for this to happen, but apparently if you got any spare cash laying around you can pay for some mediocre studio time and put together an egregiously lackluster, mind-numbingly boring and goofy sounding mixtape (or half-baked studio album if you really want to call it that). Lord knows even the name of this thing is corny: “Born 2 Ball”. “Born 2 Ball”? Here’s where I would insert a water drop - okay, hand sign and 100 emoji out of pure irony.

The opening track, “Grind On,” starts with the most out of place eagle-soaring-in-high sound effect fresh off of soundbible.com and probably the most annoying producer tag I’ve heard in the last decade. The main issue I have with this entire project, however, is the fact that Zo himself clearly is not ready to be caught anywhere near a studio booth. The goofy sounding, awkward, broken, uninspiring and no clout having voice that Zo presents all over this thing lacks any sort of charisma, prominence, anger, passion, grit, potency, restraint, growl, honesty, moodiness or any sort of feeling. It is, without a doubt in my mind, going to be the driest presentation of vocals or bars of the year, if not the last decade. Zo sounds insanely goofy, extremely out of place and without an ounce of the amateur charm that someone like Yung Lean might have had a couple years ago starting out. There is nothing about Zo’s character, or “come up” (God forbid I ever have to refer to his coming up as a struggle again) that is remotely intriguing. Ball really believes that he can do anything; putting together a decent rap record is not as easy as a task as some people might believe it to be. This album is forgettable to the core, and falls at the same sins that the overhyped, overrated and fake-deep Jaden Smith album does. Like the “heir to the Smith family fortune,” Lonzo has yet to develop a sound or a personality that is genuine or magnetizing enough to warrant an entire hour of fucking content.

Honestly, please, go through the song “Get Off” and have the spine to tell me that it doesn’t sound like half the faceless and nameless shit on DatPiff. The hook is vomit-enducing…as his “ooo”s and “ahh”s, followed by the “I had to get off”s, stumble over each other like some 14 year old, Atlanta bedroom SoundCloud kid’s most hype creations. He cuts away at his own clout as he speaks about his complete lack of struggle as if it was a struggle, claiming he has never had to flip drugs and never had to throw dice. He throws a light jab at being a Bruin, claiming he doesn’t ride with UCLA when they lose (lol) but I can’t be mad at that, especially when it’s comforting to know his album is so fucking garbage that it essentially disses his own persona. It’s almost as if he’s annoyed that the institution got rid of his crusty little brother, because the shots at the institution continue on the next track, “Z02.” But again, please answer this, what kind of rapper fucking disses a specific institution as if it was some kind of enemy? Only the most privileged and no clout having ass rapper will, that’s who (insert several gun emojis here).

By the time the over-excited, too-much-treble having ass beat on “Puttin in Work” ends, I’m astonished at how forgettable every verse and beat has been thus far. There is not a single moment that warrants a slap in the automobile on this album. If your friends throw one of these tracks on, you officially have 100 percent authority to rip the aux from either the phone plug or the vehicle’s sound system. Aside from this, the features on “Puttin in Work” are the hottest of trash; dumpster fire tier mimicry brought onto the track probably makes this the worst song on the entire album. Zo has the guts to claim that other people are in it for the fame and that everybody is sounding the same, when he has the least iconic sounding voice, delivery, flow, bars and presence of anyone I’ve heard on iTunes this decade. On “Better,” Zo authentically sounds like he’s verbally constipated and pushing the mediocre hook that was prepared for the song onto yet another forgettable beat. “

LAML” is ultra corny, and the weak yelling on the hook reeks of a Drake influence that should never have materialized into a piece of audio. “You see I made it…You see me skating…Big Baller Brand” - all extremely boring interjections that mean absolutely nothing in a genre where charisma and authenticity and braggadocio are weighed as some of the most important aspects of a rapper’s presentation and worth. Zo’s incessant references to “Triple B’s” are, lowkey, annoying; And while I understand that having a company or brand must be a fulfilling experience, one has to remember that the cultural prominence of the entire BBB company is for the fucking memes. Are we taking this as seriously as other brands that are mentioned boringly on the next SoundCloud rapper’s tracks? No. Are we taking BBB as the next big Nike cultural giant? (or culturally predatory giant, however you wanna see it) No. Stop trying to force this down our throats, b. You’re corny. This is corny. Me reviewing this is corny. If you would not have recorded this maybe the Lakers would be in a better position right now. Please, for the love of all that is holy, stay on the court, bro. Keep your shit talking on the court. Keep it out of our playlists.

1/10

Favorite Track: When I turned this shit off and went to go listen to Nipsey Hussle’s “Victory Lap” instead

title: Show Preview: G-Eazy
content:
Photo Credits:  Bobby Bruderle

Written by Helen Lee

“I’ve put myself in this position where I haven’t set myself up with a plan B. I don’t have a safety net; it’s all in.” – G-Eazy

For any musician, music is often as natural and second nature as channeling the melody that courses through their bloodstream and harnessing the beat that is as continuous as their own pulse. But for a true artist, it’s all about escaping the body of norms, embracing the opportunity to disrupt what’s already established, and shattering safety in order to piece together something truly revolutionary.

In a few words, a true artist knows no limits. For G-Eazy, it’s a no-brainer. Like his lead track, “No Limit,” which features A$AP Rocky and Cardi B and has been streamed over 183 million times on Spotify, his bold, uncompromising message and colorful music is all about no holding back. His newest album, The Beautiful & Damned is just as risque, daring, and no-balls as the life philosophy he lives by. His attitude is a reflection of just that.

This daring, progressive, and experimental mindset is what sets G-Eazy apart from many artists. The position that G-Eazy finds himself in is not simply one where he doesn’t have a plan B. It’s titles like “Favorite Hip-Hop Artist” at the 2017 People’s Choice Awards, Forbes’ 30 Under 30, and most recently, Co-Creative Director role of Stillhouse Spirits Co. It’s two years of selling out shows worldwide and releasing singles alongside timeless artists like Snoop Dogg and Kehlani.

Most importantly, the same fearless, raw, and carefree attitude that makes his music impactful is the same attitude that always keeps the listener on edge and hanging onto his every lyric. The Beautiful & Damned is a more personal, intimate glimpse into the artist’s personal life and perspective, one that carefully and rigorously combines the audacious “fuck everything” persona with his deeply thoughtful, reflective and often political insights. It addresses fame, money, as well as the duality of good and evil in following the path of notoriety, and includes highly anticipated collaborations with artists like Halsey, Charlie Puth, and Son Lux. 

His tour includes the lineup of Phora, Trippie Redd, Anthony Russo. Sometimes, Plan A is all you need. With The Beautiful & Damned, it’s all in.

title: Blood by Rhye // An Album Review in Two Perspectives
content:
Part One - Written by Emily Pitcher 

Romantic soul-pop group Rhye has released their sophomore album Blood, a sultry dance collection of songs about Michael Milosh’s new wife, who appears on the cover. With Robin Hannibal leaving the once duo, this new album was primarily written by Milosh.

Similar to the debut album Woman, Blood is a sensual piece, filled with texture, emotive string instruments, and a strong beat. Unlike Woman, however, Blood lacks the raw sexiness that made Rhye so powerful. It mimics some aspects that made their older music so enchanting - smooth vocals and groovy beats - yet by not committing enough to these characteristics, the music falls flat. Woman exuded intimacy and hot flashes of first love. Blood pursues the same vulnerability, yet it loses the heart of the original.

Rhye is all about sex: romantic, candle-lit, making love sex. This stems from Milosh’s silky, fragile vocals to even the nudity of the album covers. Yet Blood is barely provocative; it incorporates all the elements of so-called “sexy” music, yet does not take any risks, and in its uniformity, becomes boring. It feels like a formula, devoid of the lust it seeks to evoke.

Milosh’s breathy, nuanced voice is the most notable parallel in every Rhye song. This is his terrain, creating a delicate mood with his feminine singing. While this in itself was unable to carry the entire album, it gave the tracks a particular allure, an invitation to continue listening, an answer to some of the questions Woman asked about the longevity of love.

A couple standout tracks include “Taste,” about the healing nature of his love’s loyalty, and “Phoenix,” a warning that his relationship harms his mental health. The rhythm in “Taste” keeps the song engaging, as the listener hears Milosh reflect on his appreciation for his new love, a groovy homage to giving love a second chance. In “Phoenix,” the magic of Milosh’s gentle voice is the most apparent - sweet, biting, and deliberate. He fears for the impermanence of love, and this confession, the reality of many relationships, feels jarring to us too. We can feel his concern for what is to come.

Yet despite these songs, the album does not feel purposeful. Blood is overproduced, lacking the authenticity and tenderness that I had wanted from this piece. The elements from Woman that Blood mirrored kept the Rhye “sound” succinct, yet these new tracks do not have the intrigue that makes me want to continue listening. Blood is mildly catchy but did not capture my attention. Blood is a diluted Woman.

Most of the songs from Blood blur together, to the extent where I cannot distinguish the tracks. While it’s natural for songs on an album to have a particular style, the songs on Blood feel similar due to how tame each track feels on its own.

I wanted seduction. I wanted breathlessness. I wanted sincerity. Blood only moderately fulfilled these expectations. Rhye’s sophomore album is worth a listen or two, but it does not have the charm of a staple album.

Part Two - Written by Anshu Patel

Milosh exudes “I make love, I don’t fuck” vibes; it’s established that Rhye is music to have sex to. The project’s dedication to mood is so strong strong that Milosh actually asked KCRW to turn off the lights during an in-station performance so he could instead sing by candlelight. The group has always been unintentionally mysterious and resigned – Rhye made an inconspicuous debut in 2012 with the release of “Open,” a single that later appeared on the highly acclaimed album Woman. Producer and songwriter Robin Hannibal has since left the project, metamorphosing Rhye into more of a musical collective. It’s no surprise that the announcement of an upcoming album caused much anticipation; Blood was finally released this past week. 

Rhye’s luxurious sensuality is still hypnotizing, with every track encapsulating their seductive sound. Milosh’s gentle croon gives the record a sense of cohesion. Essential tracks from the release include “Stay Safe,” “Taste,” and “Count to Five.” The synth beat in “Sinful” resembles the soft alien noises that are whispered during hearing exams, an interesting variation on their usual sound. Songs do begin to melt into each other in some places on the record, to the point where it’s very difficult to distinguish one from another. “Blood Knows” and “Waste” become forgettable without a distinctive beat layered under Milosh’s smooth vocals. I wouldn’t say that Rhye has fallen into a sophomore slump, as their powerful, alluring sound permeates the album, but it is clear that their debut was a much stronger collection than Blood. Milosh claims that he wanted to make an album that translated better into live music, but the record has suffered slightly as a result. Additionally, the themes touched upon in their music are almost hollowed by the album and single artwork - what could be a beautiful exploration of physical love becomes an obsession with the female form, faces are hidden and bodies are warped into highly sexualized positions. Blood is a gorgeous, albeit flawed record, leaving the listener wanting just a bit more.

title: BlackGummy @ Sound Nightclub (1/25/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Mark Edmonds

The dance floor is draped in velvet. Silhouettes of gummy bears flash on retro TV screens lining the walls. Pulsing lights break the darkness of the club to reveal BlackGummy prepping to take over from Monstergetdown. These are not the type of DJs to tell you to “f**ckin jump.” The handoff from Monstergetdown to BlackGummy would have gone unnoticed to the causal listener. BlackGummy starts the set with “Adapative Radiation,” one of his signature tracks. The thumping baseline and melody instantly elevates the crowd to a new level. 

BlackGummy’s sound is hypnotic, ethereal and satisfyingly filthy. His mastery of dark, progressive house and techno captures the minds and feet of everyone in ear’s reach. The name “BlackGummy” is fitting. BlackGummy embodies his monstrous caricature by filling the dance floor with enormous bass lines and ominously hypnotic melodies.

To borrow a term from Anakim, BlackGummy’s flavor of progressive house and techno takes you to deep space. Everything is dark, and you certainly aren’t on Earth. He successfully took the entire dance floor to another dimension. The same is true for any club where BlackGummy lands. And he’ll do it again and again. This is not a show you want to miss. 

BlackGummy continued to captivate the dance floor for two hours. Track after track was full of banging techno. The darkness of the club only broke when the enveloping lights pulse across the dance floor. The set ended with his own remix of Strobe from mau5trap’s godfather and creator, deadmau5.

This was the start (precursor) of BlackGummy’s Mesophase tour. He’ll be touring around the US through early April. For Southern California, you can catch him at La Cave in Costa Mesa, and for our readers up north, you can see him at The Independent in San Francisco. If you’re not in California, you can check this tour schedule on his Facebook.

I can’t speak highly enough of BlackGummy’s hypnotic sound. If you are a fan of techno, progressive house, tech house, or honestly any electronic music, this show is for you. You’ll be transported to a dark, melodic state for hours and the catharsis of the dance floor will leave you buzzing for days. See you out in deep space.

title: Twin Peaks @ Thalia Hall (12/30/2017) // Show Review
content:
Written by Natalie Benudiz

Alright boys and girls, strap yourselves the fuck in: this was the concert to end all concerts. It feels unfair to be so limited by language in trying to communicate the sheer epicness of what I witnessed on December 30. The dudes sold out three damn nights for a New Years Eve run to close out 2017 at Thalia Hall in Chicago, joining forces with Dehd and Post Animal for the Saturday night show. This performance was truly Twin Peaks at their… peak.
The evening began with a performance from the band Dehd, a Chicago based post punk trio. Though the name sounds edgy, their sound was surprisingly upbeat. They delivered a decent set, but the audience’s anticipation for the following bands was painfully obvious in their indifferent restlessness, eclipsing the performance.
When Post Animal took the stage shortly after, the mood shifted almost instantly. Their distinct blend of Cream, Tame Impala, and Black Sabbath influences incited headbanging, crowdsurfing, and moshing, setting the tone for the rest of the night. By the time they had finished their set, I had already accumulated a sweet collection of bruises. As they came to the last song of their performance, they did the one thing that finally pushed the audience to the point of delirium: they brought out Joe Keery (Steve from Stranger Things). At this point, I can confidently say that I lost my shit. Though he hasn’t played a show with the band in months, Joe and his luscious head of hair shredded for one song before ducking back to the safety of the side stage. Speaking of hair, every other member of the band also had some bitchin’ hair, which is essential if you’re going to be headbanging as hard as Post Animal does. They’re definitely a band to see if you’re into the possibility of giving yourself an aneurysm during a show (which actually happened to Javi Reyes onstage a few weeks ago). Just when it seemed that there were no surprises left, Jack Dolan of Twin Peaks darted out from backstage to jump into the crowd during Post Animal’s last song, teasing the audience.
Okay kids, make sure those seat belts are buckled nice and tight, because this is where shit really gets rowdy. When the dudes finally took the stage and blasted into “Strawberry Smoothie,” the audience lost whatever chill they had left: bodies immediately went over the barricade, beer cans went flying, and a mosh pit opened up into a swirling vortex of thrashing limbs. The stage was equally as chaotic, with Cadien Lake James whipping his head back and forth and Clay Frankel thrashing on his white teardrop guitar and jumping around. By the third song, a girl in a red felt cowboy hat had already broken the nose of the poor dude standing next to her. At some point south of “Have You Ever,” a bra flew onstage from somewhere near the barricade, but it didn’t remain there for long. By the next song, the owner of the bra crowdsurfed onto the stage to personally retrieve the bra from Frankel, who responded with a confused remark of “Uh.. she wants her bra back.. I’m not sure what to say about that.” I literally cannot make this up.  
In the midst of the absolute chaos in the pit, it would have been easy to miss the extra members onstage. Accompanying Colin Croom, Connor Brodner, Frankel, JD, and James were three horns and three backup singers. Though their presence in the background seemed a little out of place, the layer of sophistication they provided served as a delicious contrast to the shouted lyrics. Twin Peaks is one of those rare bands that actually sound better live - the boys somehow harmonize their screamed lyrics (I wonder if they ever lose their voices). This was especially evident in “Wanted You,” “Butterfly,” and “Walk to the One You Love.” (FYI: the set list is below! ur welcome.) The screaming took a backseat near the middle of their set when Frankel brought out his roommate, Marisa Nakamura, to sing “Shake Your Lonely.” The cute duet was a brief moment of relief from the headbanging and moshing, which picked right back up again at “Have You Ever,” continuing all the way to the last song in the set, “Butterfly.” But what’s a show without a shirtless Frankel and a gigantic confetti cannon to close out the encore? Not a Twin Peaks show, that’s for damn sure. The encore featured four gems - “Heavenly Showers,” “Blue Coupe,” “We Will Not Make It,” and “Boomers.”
On the real, this show was so good that I spent an obscene amount of money to do it all over again on NYE. I think what makes a Twin Peaks show a Twin Peaks show is the excitement of its sheer unpredictability: will you crowd surf? Will there be a riot? Will you do drugs? Who knows! (You’ll probably do all these things.) It’s like a rollercoaster of hysteria that you never want to get off. Chicago, you truly know how to get down.
If you haven’t listened to their new compilation of singles, stop reading this right now and go listen. And if you have, do NOT miss out on their only LA gig at Air and Style in March. It’s been a hot minute since they were here; they are notorious for their fierce loyalty to Chicago and the Midwest in general, so it is extremely rare that they’re playing in LA. Spend the money. Hell, spend someone else’s money. Do whatever you gotta do to get a ticket, because this is a once in a lifetime band. I’m begging you, go see them. 


Set List

Strawberry Smoothie

Fast Eddie

Got Your Money

Sloop Jay D

Holding Roses

Getting Better

Walk To The One You Love

Shake Your Lonely

Have You Ever?

Keep It Together

Sweet Thing

Flavor

Making Breakfast

In The Meadow

Tossing Tears

Wanted You

Butterfly

Encore

Heavenly Showers

Blue Coupe

We Will Not Make It

Boomers

title: Screen Memories - John Maus // Album Review
content:
Written by Tara Kazimi

After an extensive five years in hiding, John Maus has finally re-emerged from his hibernation and come out with the long anticipated Screen Memories. While not his worst work (if you can possibly even use a word like “worst” to describe John Maus’ music), it is also not his best. This may disappoint even some of his most generous fans, given that the grace period between his two most recent albums was so substantial. Back in November of 2014 he even tweeted at an impatient follower about how he was “shooting for 2015!! Only just finished a dissertation and building the instruments” he needed. Nonetheless, the record has arrived and it doesn’t stray very far from what he is known for: extravagant reverb, minimal lyrics, and luxurious synthesizers. Synthesizers which he built himself, and that in the end “didn’t really make that much of a difference sonically,” according to a slighty disappointed Maus. 

While “Touchdown” seems to be the favorite according to the Spotify Top Ten list, “Bombs Away” should have taken that spot, in my opinion. The instruments were clearer and more distinguished than ever, allowing for a refreshing add to his discography. Particularly in his earlier music, circa album Songs, prominence would never have even been considered, only beautifully muddled harmonious chaos was able to shine. Along with “Bombs Away”, “Walls of Silence” stood out respectably, this actually snagging the number eight spot on his Top Ten hits on Spotify. “Walls of Silence” holds an extra repetitive nature close to its structure, yet without still having the negative connotations that come with the word monotony. That particular song could be played on loop and after a certain point the beginning nor the end would be able to stand out, in a good way. In a way where if one were to lay on the cold hardwood of their bedroom floor all by themselves on a lonely Saturday night, only to to have this song on repeat, they would fall deep into a warm amber embrace, and a forgiving trance within their own thoughts only a natural disaster could shock them out of.

title: Black Panther: The Album // Album Review
content:
Written by Daniel Leka

“It’s all prophecy and if I gotta be sacrificed for the greater good/Then that’s what it gotta be,” Kendrick Lamar proclaims on the album’s final track “Pray For Me.” A song that proves to be an anthemic component for the film, “Pray For Me” is a perfect summary of the album, a euphoric ode to the fictional country of Wakanda and the pride its people represent. And pride is the perfect word to describe the Black Panther album because it is cultural, it is timely, and above all else, it is “Black.”

The album starts off with the title track “Black Panther,” a sole effort by Lamar to introduce the world of Wakanda and the mind of the film’s protagonist T’Challa. Lamar raps with precision and focus, utilizing repetition to highlight the significance and viewpoints of T’Challa and to introduce the opposing nature of antagonist Erik Killmonger. Hearing this song reminds me of an earlier Lamar song from his 2010 album Overly Dedicated called “Heaven and Hell.” In this song, Lamar draws this distinction between good and evil, a tactic he uses in “Black Panther,” but rather then clearly distinguish the two, Lamar relies on ambiguity. It is through this ambiguity that we are engulfed not just into this opening track, but in the rest of the record as well.

Following the minimalist, constantly progressing opener is the album’s lead single “All The Stars,” with Lamar and SZA. With two of 2017’s biggest stars coming together for this track, the result is an undeniable hit, filled with a solemn, truth riddled verse by Lamar and a show stealing performance by SZA, who delivers dynamic vocals on the song’s chorus and a verse that is very reminiscent of her critically acclaimed Ctrl album. The song is a perfect combination of two musical juggernauts and it does a fantastic job of setting the tone moving forward.

After the lead single is an assortment of collaborations and production stylings that highlights a barrage of both vocal and production talent. The highly energetic and infectious “X” features a charismatic chorus by Lamar, and diverse, rapid fire verses from South African rapper Saudi, fellow TDE member ScHoolboy Q, and Def Jam signee 2 Chainz. Produced by !llmind & Sounwave, the track constitutes everything that makes a great hip hop record. However, following that record is “The Ways,” a tropical sounding, free flowing track that utilizes the self proclaimed “American Teen” Khalid and Rae Sremmurd member Swae Lee to full effect. Once again produced by Sounwave, but this time in collaboration with Lamar and music group BADBADNOTGOOD, the track is a departure from the energy prevalent on “X” but instead brings a much more mellow side that is apparent in the Wakanda universe. However, this mellow side is short lived, for immediately after this track is the bass heavy, highly eccentric “Opps” featuring Vince Staples and Yugen Blakrok, with uncredited vocals by Lamar again. A track produced by Sounwave and frequent Childish Gambino collaborator Ludwig Göransson, who is also the film’s composer, all three vocalists deliver verses that illustrate a fast-paced chase scene that is present in the film through a multitude of trailers. This song punctuates a three track run that houses a variety of features that fit seamlessly with the production, but only serves to be the beginning of this impeccable soundtrack.

The next three tracks make up, in my opinion, the best run of the whole record. “I Am,” a track that samples Travis Scott’s “Drugs You Should Try It” off of his 2014 effort Days Before Rodeo, features the soulful stylings of Jorja Smith, who brings a vibrant presence that is matched by very few others on the whole LP. And much like Smith’s contributions to the album, very few contributors matched the raw energy that SOB X RBE brought forth on another standout track “Paramedic!” A track that accentuates the Vallejo, California’s hard hitting punchlines and multiple styles altogether is culminated by a Lamar hook that does not disappoint. Plus, the manner in which this song transitions flawlessly into “Bloody Waters,” by Ab-Soul, Anderson .Paak, and James Blake, makes the run that much better. In regards to “Bloody Waters,” speaking from a technical perspective, the track features some of the most prominent rapping aspects on the whole project, thanks to Ab-Soul. Showcasing wit and lyricism that was perfectly balanced with Anderson .Paak’s chorus and James Blakes’ intros and outros, the track plays immensely well and, as a result, is one of my favorites.

The soundtrack flows like an album in spite of it featuring different talent all across it. This can in large part be attributed to Sounwave’s production talents, as well as Lamar and Top Dawg’s “Anthony Tiffith’s” overall vision and the execution by the talent recruited. However, what it also does is provide something for just about everyone. For those that want high energy hip hop tracks that they can vibe and have fun with, there’s “X,” “Paramedic!,” “King’s Dead,” and even “Big Shot.” However, for those who place an affinity on rap lyrics, there’s “Black Panther,” “Opps,” “Bloody Waters,” and “Seasons” as well. All songs on this album are placed and sequenced well, showing black culture in a way that has not been showcased to mainstream media ever.

Furthermore, Black Panther: The Album is a microcosm of the impact that the film Black Panther has had. With music that perfectly embodies not just the fictional country of Wakanda but the actual continent of Africa, and the struggle and plight of African-Americans, this album will prove to be a memorable soundtrack down the line, and not just because of its attachment to one of the year’s biggest films. Rather, it will be because some of music’s biggest stars were able to compose music with artistic integrity that reigns true to not just African-Americans, but also to the African heritage as well.

Favorite Tracks: “All The Stars,” “I Am,” “Paramedic!” “Bloody Waters,” “Seasons,” and “Big Shot”

Worst Track: “Redemption”

Overall Score: 8.5/10

title: Alex Cameron @ The Lodge Room (2/22/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Clea Wurster 

The Lodge Room is aptly named. Upon entering and joining the scattered crowd, I looked to the walls half expecting to find taxidermied deer and elk mounted, but was pleasantly disappointed when I found no such decor.

The stage sat opposite a big, welcoming bar - both cozy and open, luring audience members to spend absurd amounts of money on PBR to clutch as they swayed to the music. During the sets, front-row members of the audience treated the stage as though it was an extension of the bar, placing drinks along its edges to dance or leaning a hip against it, as though the weight of their own bodies was too heavy to attest to the quality of the music with the appropriate movements. The stage was so much a part of the room, it seemed difficult to separate a performer from an audience member at first glance.

Molly Burch quietly took the stage to open for Alex Cameron. She started out with her love song “Please Be Mine,” recorded on her first album of the same name which was released last February. Beginning with the loud chatter of the bar as a background to her voice, she appeared subtle in all possible ways, sporting simple contentment that felt at odds with the emotionally torn sentiment of the song. The past year of touring that she’s done didn’t seem to give her more comfort on the stage - it seemed like this could’ve been her first, nervous experience on stage had I not known otherwise.

Everything about her presence felt out of focus, warm and sweet, down to the asymmetrically collared, knee-length dress that she wore - reminiscent of a schoolgirl’s uniform. Her voice, her face, even her hair suggested timidity and kindness with a twist of what could be construed as seduction, if the lighting were just so. And the lighting was just so: she was back lit by deep red and purple hues that gave the Lodge Room, and Burch, an unexpected air of  intimacy that perfectly accented her set list, which told the story of losing someone and finding them again.

With lyrics such as, “I’d never felt like this before,” in “Not Today,” and, “You said I was the only one, but I know you say that to all the girls,” Burch wrapped the audience up in her lovesickness, folding us up in her pining after love and making us all complicit in the messy break up that her music recounts through honest and clear vocals.

Her voice rang true to her record, at times soft and soulful, and often matched with a furrow to her otherwise pleasant smile or soft frown, but even as she hit the deeper, more expressive ranges that her voice has to offer, the audience seemed wary of tuning in. While some in the front row closed their eyes and swayed softly along with Burch, most continued to raise glasses to their mouths, laughing and talking loudly about the next set and tuning out her performance. That being said, Burch truly embodied her work.

As the performance continued, the persuasiveness of her sultry girl-next-door charm seemed to win over more and more of the crowd. As she continued her set list, singing what can only be described as sappy love songs (allegedly about her guitarist), couples began to fold into each other, lazily hanging on to one another’s arms and glancing into one another's’ eyes. Burch’s voice spread to the edges of the room, enticing even those still firmly planted at the edge of the bar to glance her way.

Her performance began with an uncertainty, a quietness, but Burch seemed to push further and further away from this feigned insecurity, becoming more sure of her own voice and body. At first, she had wandered away from the mic, seemingly unaware of her audience - encapsulated by her music and framed by her nondescript musicians. She could have been singing to herself in an empty room for all we knew. But as the evening progressed, Burch found purchase in her voice and her crowd, relaxing into the performance, casting playful smiles and bashful flutterings of her lashes to match the tones of her jazzy, but pop-ish sound.

While her stage presence came off initially as underwhelming, consisting only of small hand movements and haphazard swaying, she perfectly embodied the sickly sweet tones of her music and her voice. By the end of her set, each song had elicited a louder response than the last and the audience had relented to her consistent and unflinching voice, which broke only in the ways you hoped it would and swayed delicately along with her body.

Between sets the audience buzzed with excitement for headliner Cameron, chatting about his music and bobbing their heads to the 80s-esque muzak that emanated from the speakers.

When the band took the stage, the audience immediately dropped their conversations and directed their attention to the tall, slim Cameron, who was dressed in all black with his characteristic slicked back hair, though it was much shorter than I expected, having watched too many of his oddly curated music videos.

Once mics were adjusted and instruments were picked up, Cameron wasted no time in jumping into his first song: “Studmuffin96.” Cameron cheekily danced at the audience, capturing their attention and prompting varied shouts from across the venue. While his persona was difficult to resist, the monotony of the first song left me feeling as though I’d somehow gotten stuck in a loop of the same 10 seconds, destined to continue hearing the chorus, “I’m looking for my lover, she’s almost 17,” an infinite number of times and rolling my eyes at the notion of this fully grown man seeking out children.

But his humor soon won me over, and I let myself relish the saxophone, masterfully played by Roy Meloy, amid the retro-pop-ish feel of the songs. Even those listeners who looked like they wished they could vacate their own bodies and exist externally from the awkwardness of their elbows and ankles were doing their best to move along with beats. The stilted dancing fit perfectly in with Cameron’s own absurd moves.

Though some seemed resentful of the downright grooviness of the set, others relinquished themselves to it - genuinely headbanging to a saxophone, something I can say I haven’t quite seen before.

Cameron seemed sharply aware of his own presence - an irony colored each song and every twitch of his hips. He carried on conversations with his audience, never missing an opportunity for a witty anecdote about the song he was performing. It felt like the cool kids club – we were all in on something, we all got it. Whatever Cameron was hip to, he made sure we were cued in and we ate it up.

The uncomfortable, posed appearance of the band only contributed to the performance. It seemed that even his bassist, who looked like a 12-year old amongst a crowd much too old for him, was putting on his own show. Not to mention the guitarist faintly reminded me of a Beetlejuice character, sporting a teased mullet and standing expressionless to the left of Cameron.

Cameron himself characterized the energy as “good,” and while I may have chosen a more poignant adjective, I couldn’t agree more. There was something special about being in that audience, something joyful and cynical all at once.

His wit was matched only by his own dance moves and the steadiness of his voice. Some choice jokes were darker than others: he introduced “Take Care of Business” as a song that he thought was about his ex-girlfriend, but he soon realized was about his mom.

Cameron proved himself as not only a clever lyricist and consistent vocalist, but a comedic figure and a well-rounded performer capable of convincing anyone, even me, of his charm and biting hilarity.

title: Kimbra @ The Ace Hotel (2/14/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Pam Gwen

Photos by Katy C. Ramage

Driving down to downtown Los Angeles on a Wednesday night, facing the 405 traffic, and finding affordable parking is a mission and a half. Add the fact that it was Valentine’s Day as well! Couples going to their dinner date nights, partners racing across LA to meet each other, and last minute flowers being bought. However, if the mission is to see Kimbra Lee Johnson, known as Kimbra, perform her new album, Primal Heart, live? Well, the road rage and $10 is well worth it. Kimbra performed at the glamorous, elegant, and beautifully designed Ace Hotel. The minute you walk in, an aura of regal charm and fantasy entrances you. Love was in the air. Chatter about seeing everyone’s Valentine, Kimbra, that night perform made the anticipation of her set so much more exciting.
