​Kimbra had the amazing Grammy-nominated KING and Rhode-Island based Aric Iris open for her. After their sets, more people trickled into the luxurious theatre and bubbled in anticipation. As soon as the lights were cut, the whole theatre screamed, sucked in an extra long breath, and clapped. Our breathes were soon taken again as Kimbra’s stage lit up. Lights flashed and two translucent cubes were illuminated. Behind the cubes were Kimbra’s bassist/guitarist and keyboardist. They were clad in rad modern pop abstract black and white blazers. Soon afterwards, Kimbra came out in a variously striped high-fashion black and white dress and black heels, perfectly synchronized with her band.

​Kimbra smiled at the crowd and began expelling her magic. Kimbra started with “Version of Me” and the minute her mouth opened, handfuls of fans screamed in amazement of her energy and powerful voice. Her voice radiated the whole theater and the geometric cubes behind her changed colour. The landscape of the cubes were in perfect pulsation of the vibrations and melodies within every song. She played multiple new songs off her album, Primal Heart, set to release April 20. She went on to play, “Hi Def Distance Romance,” “The Good War,” “Black Sky,” and her latest single, “Human.” Every new song entranced you into Kimbra’s psychedelic world, but also forced you to confront personal parts of yourself in an extremely healing, but dance-provoking way. Her lyrics eviscerate your emotions, but the beats and energy surging out of her body rose the audience into ecstasy. The crowd was clearly eating her up. Random spurts of fans yelling out, “Yessss queen, kill it!.” Or, “I love you so much!” Or, “Please never stop making music!” Or just plain and simple screaming out of excitement, joy, and amazement.

​Song after song, Kimbra’s voice never waivered, but most importantly, her energy, charisma, and dynamite presence on stage proliferated as the show went on. As fans and audience members, the sight of an artist embodying her most creative and abundant spirit on stage was intoxicating and infectious. Kimbra transformed into an intergalactic goddess, dancing in front of human, yet alien-like faces, heat-maps, clouds of neon lights, and waves of light, to an earth princess soaring through the ocean and rock formations, flowers, and elemental and transcending waves. At one point, the background even turned into black and white stripes. The background blended in with her dress and within every one of Kimbra’s electrifying dance moves. It was almost as if she was disappearing into a melodic abyss. Finally, Kimbra also transformed into the simplicity of an atom…blending in with geometric shapes and sparkling beams, as if your eyes were closed and the darkness turned into the colourful speckles of light that appear, gracefully beckoning our ascendence into the world she had carefully constructed for the audience that night.

​Kimbra also sang songs off her beloved 2011 album, Vows, and the hits, “Settle Down” and “Two Way Street.” Though these songs came out in 2011, it is seven years later and Kimbra managed to remix and play these songs in perfect embodiment of the musical level she was showcasing for Primal Heart. Kimbra’s growth as an artist came full circle and she proudly showcased it during this part of the set. The songs I loved playing on my iPod in 2011 were brought to another elemental, soul-striking, and transcending level and I could not get enough. She also played songs off her 2014 album, The Golden Echo, which she created in LA when she was living here. Off of The Golden Echo, Kimbra played “As You Are” and “Love in High Places.” On Valentine’s Day, Kimbra was Cupid, pointing her arrow to all of our hearts and taking the love we have for her to an exponentially higher caliber. She even went back to her original place, picked up her guitar, and played “Past Love” off of Primal Heart.

​In picking up her guitar and going back to the roots of her singer-songwriter career, Kimbra proved she is a musical legend and a force to be reckoned with. The geometric cubes go dark and soft lights are directed at her on the right side of the stage.

​One minute she was singing with her whole entire body, being in tune with her melodies, lyrics, and beats, gracefully pounding on the impressive set of electronics in front of her and then, was simply strumming her guitar and commanding the entire audience with her raw and emotionally-vibrant voice. Her soul transcended throughout “Past Love” and was an excellent highlight of her talent. The chords are lush, dreamy, and sounded extremely full. Kimbra sang out the last lyric, immediately put her guitar down, and went back to her electronics. Kimbra bumped “Two Way Street” after, and then “Lightyears.” The geometric cubes behind her continued to radiate behind her. Kimbra even stepped away from her electronics and danced where the cubes meet, creating a vertex of illusion, laced with her whimsical energy.

​Kimbra then beckoned her audience to stand-up and dance! It was Valentine’s Day, after all. She said, “This one is SEXY.” The song was extremely groovy and reminded me of disco-funk. The whole audience was jumping, dancing, and laughing. The genuine and pure look of euphoria on Kimbra’s face after the song ended was priceless. Kimbra then finished her set with, “Top of the World” - another single off of Primal Heart.

​Within each new song off her album, Kimbra explores a multitude of personas and musical dimensions. But “Top of the World” takes you to the most primal and powerful part of your heart. The minute the first beat dropped, the crowd, and myself, went nuts. This song is empowering and motivates its listener to do just about anything your heart desires. It encapsulates everything about art pop and alternative R&B. The subtle anger Kimbra exudes pumps you up with angst and aggression, but ultimately uplifts you, makes you soar, and feel seen.

​Kimbra thanked her fans, the crowd, her opening acts, her band mates, and humbly left the stage. For an encore, Kimbra walked back alone and told the audience that this was a song she has been experimenting and tinkering with throughout the tour. She was vulnerable, but open to mistakes, which is something so beautiful to see after such a bad-ass and empowering 13-song set from Kimbra. She performed “Real Life”, a stripped down, emotional, and ambient tune. She finished, smiled the biggest smile she had throughout the whole concert, bowed, blew a kiss, and exited the stage.

​Kimbra truly makes her audience feel…..on Top of the World.

title: Chris Rock - Tambourine // Comedy Review
content:
Written by Anish Vishwakoti 

At age 53, veteran comedian Chris Rock delivers his most unique stand-up yet. While Rock still tackles the themes that he’s grown so familiar with, of race relations, poverty, and other perceived flaws in America, he does so for the first time with the backdrop of his own personal problems as a self-deprecating contrast point.

Unlike his previous shows, namely 1999’s “Bigger & Blacker” and 2004’s “Never Scared,” Rock doesn’t play around, or ease his audience into any false sense of stability before hitting them with big jokes. Rock starts off his show very quickly with a joke about police brutality, not only to register a big laugh, but also so that his audience knows to stay on their toes.

At this point, hearing the state of the audience’s laughter after more humorous analysis of police brutality in the United States, it’s clear that this special is in a far more intimate setting than the stadiums that Rock’s earlier shows played host to.

It’s clear that the more closed setting reflects Rock’s mental space at this point in his career and life. His analysis of gun violence and the attitude towards it in American society is only an opener. He hits the audience with quick but nonetheless funny jokes such as, “If a 100 people ever got stabbed to death at the same time, in the same place, by the same person, you know what that would mean? 97 people deserved to die.”

Material like this isn’t the meat of Rock’s routine, but it’s still in line with the theme of the special. The show follows a clear trend of getting closer and closer to Rock himself. He next focuses on his attitude as a black parent in the modern world.

Rock at this point treats the audience like they are his kids and he is delivering a lesson to them in the form of a stand up. Rock’s key line in this segment of the stand up is his lesson, “As soon as you leave this door, nobody gives a fuck about you!”

He’s referring to the attitude he wants his kids to have, and as funny as the line is, it also seems to go deeper. Rock is trying to send a message to his audience, not only to his African American listeners, as he does make it clear, like in previous specials to include brief remarks, excluding the white members of his audience to comedic effect, especially when criticizing his perceived societal bias towards white people.

After a clever and hilarious critique of the current state of America, Rock circles around to the common trope of relationships, but this is Rock, and of course he brings his own flair and perspective to it. Quite distinctly, he also brings his own experiences, cheating on his wife, and the divorce he went through.

Rock makes this final part of his special a cautionary tale for his audience, essentially berating his own decisions as a married man and laying out his mistakes in humorous fashion to great effect, both inducing laughter and to a certain extent sympathy.

Overall, Rock’s “Tambourine” (I’d reveal why It’s called tambourine but that would void one of his best gags,) is a solid addition to Rock’s already infamous stand up record. Scaling down seems to be the underlying theme of the special, not only the stadium, but also his ego, and his usually grandiose style of comedy. He does not, however, scale down the laughs, and if you’re a fan of any of his shows, movies, previous stand up, or just want an hour to laugh and give you something to think about, then give Rock’s “Tambourine” a shake!

title: 2 Chainz - The Play Don’t Care Who Makes It // Album Review
content:
Written by Ela Talu 

After his successful album, Pretty Girls Like Trap Music, which eventually became a sensational project of its own, the Atlanta rapper 2 Chainz hit us with a short but concise EP, The Play Don’t Care Who Makes It. The rapper is famous for dropping this kind of EP along the way to promise the listeners that he is working on more hitmakers for his later albums like the tracks on his EPs. 2 Chainz’s new wave of having long names for his album titles became a way for him to step up as an artist and truly share his moments with the listeners. The choice of making the titles of the tracks uppercase gives out the statements that will be made with each tracks, a little reminiscent of Kung-Fu Kenny style.

The first track, “OK BITCH,” starts off with melodic rapping, along with the support of trap sounds like rap flutes and piano loops, that together create a flowing harmony. Continuing with “PROUD,” featuring YG and OFFSET, the rappers do exactly the opposite of praising themselves, and are delicate and appreciative of their mothers - 2 Chainz raps, “I’m just tryna make my mama proud.” But 2 Chainz really show his power with rhyme with his chorus, “I hop on the beat/Her body on fleek/My pockets obese/My partner gon’ eat/My partner a G/We straight out the street/Home of the Braves/Land of the freaks,” on “LAND OF THE FREAKS.” 

Finally, the rapper finishes off his EP with another powerful statement piece, “LAMBORGHINI TRUCK (ATLANTA SHIT).” 2 Chainz deeply shows his emotions, asking for a better side of the times we are living in. He sentimentally raps about his hometown of Georgia accompanied with slow vocals. The track calls-out the underrated rappers of Atlanta and the friends that 2 Chainz has lost in the same city.

Composed of only four tracks, the EP is more than enough to state what the 40 year-old rapper, 2 Chainz, had witnessed in his city and within the rap game over the years. His success comes from understanding his environment in Atlanta and knowing how to share it with other people. Therefore, the title The Play Don’t Care Who Makes It is very self-explanatory and inspiring to the new generation.

title: MANIA - Fall Out Boy // Album Review
content:
Written by Gomi Zhou

Now, I was nowhere close to being a fan of Fall Out Boy. Before the release of MANIA, my knowledge to the band was limited to 3 singles: “Centuries,” “Sugar,” “We’re Goin Down,” and “Thnks fr th Mmrs.” Unlike most people, who have long abandoned their emo phases and arespending their efforts on forgetting their cringey teenage years, in recent years I become increasingly interested in the alternative rock community. I have no problem admitting that Brendon Urie is my religion and sexuality (please don’t take this offensively) and that I am a big Panic! At The Disco fan. Thus, when Urie tweeted about MANIA as his way ofsupporting and promoting, I thought it was a great opportunity for me to dive a bit deeper into the abyss of emoness.

I was in the gym when I first listened to the album. Undoubtedly, it’s a great workout track (insert edgy teens screaming with angst). Jumping from different genres like EDM to the usual pop rock, from the familiar inspirational anthems to the slightly more mellow self analysis…Fall Out Boy as a band is seemingly trying to figure out a route for their future direction. MANIA in many ways serves as a transitional album, yet nevertheless, it is still a great record consisting of the normal Fall Out Boy elements - angst and determination. The theme remains mysterious, experimental, and steadily on edge throughout the whole album. Something new, mostly as usual.

ACTUAL SONGS

“Young and Menace”

“Young and Menace” was released as the first single way back in April 2017. I really don’t want to imagine the initial reaction of their die-hard fans - this song follows the generic EDM style. If I wasn’t on the treadmill running, I would’ve probably stopped listening to the entire album all together. It’s just…very different from what anyone would expect from Fall Out Boy. Though, after the whole album was released, “Young and Menace” does seem like a good fit for a slightly slower opening that is anticipating for more. In addition, it does follow the general Fall Out Boy equation: I’m the best, you just need to wait and see. Thistrack was a lure put out by Fall Out Boy as a tease, it’s just a smoke bomb.

“Champion”

I really, have no idea how did I make through the first two tracks. “Champion” can almost be considered as a direct sequel of “Centuries” from their last album. This is probably the most Fall Out Boy song out of the entire album: heavy drum, main melody illustrated by electric guitars, a build-up anticipated for an absolute explosion for the chorus. Which means the lyrics of “Champion” are just as corny and inspirational as all their other singles in recent years. Well, it’s a great song for its purpose, I’m just really spoiled by the meaningful and dramatic lyrics by Panic!.

“Stay Frosty Royal Milk Tea”

Speaking of Panic!, this is actually Urie’s favorite song from MANIA. Dramatic to a point where you can feel a sense of violence, packed with metaphors and allegories…wait but what the hell is “Stay Frosty Royal Milk Tea” actually supposed to mean?! There are really about only two bands left who would dare to have such random names for their songs. Particularly, “Stay Frosty Royal Milk Tea” can easily be qualified as a song from Panic!–if it didn’t have the repetitive lyrics. Oh, Fall Out Boy with their reassuring, repetitive lyric patterns. Well, it’s nice branding. Nevertheless, the drama and intensity always ensure the uniqueness of the band. Not that many drummers would go hard on the drums like how Andy Hurley does it.

“HOLD ME TIGHT OR DON’T”

This song leaves me with so many questions. As the only song title with capitalized letters, “HOLD ME TIGHT OR DON’T” is the least rock song from this rock album. Patrick Stump’s voice sounded almost a bit naggy, accompanied by a repetitive guitar chord pattern throughout the whole song - this is Fall Out Boy’s take on love and breakup songs. The right amount of hesitation, passion, and as usual, right amount of drum and electric guitar ringing in the back of your head. I always see this song as an intermission of MANIA: the calmness before the return of the storm, the last goodbye before the start of a war.

“The Last of the Real Ones”

From this point on, I love every single song remaining on the album. “The Last of the Real Ones” is my second favorite from MANIA. The whole song is preaching the glory of someone, with an overuse of metaphors and exaggerations. Can you tell? I. Love. Drama. In today’s music industry, where people praise EDM, tropical beats, and hip-hop more than anything, bands like Fall Out Boy become increasingly niche-like (always has been, but increasingly). They ARE the “last of a dying breed,” but I love alternative rock way too much to ever let go. I take this song as a scream of truth from the band, and I just love the cheeky, mellow piano sub-melody in the background so much.

“Wilson (Expensive Mistake)”

It’s still too early into the year for me to call this song “Song of the Year,” but I love it so much I just want this year to be over already. “Wilson” portrays a loser’s story, someone who had made too many expensive mistakes, an outcast who was left reminiscing and questioning their leftover existence. Call me an angsty teen, but I love loser anthems like this one: “Death of A Bachelor” by Panic! At The Disco, “Cancer” by My Chemical Romance, and the iconic “Bohemian Rhapsody” by Queen. “Wilson” illustrates such a sad story with Fall Out Boy’s (almost sardonic-sounding) slightly less intense drum beats and oddly unusual major key melody. The absolutely amazing irony of this song needs to be appreciated more in the coming year, please.

“Church”

I always find it interesting when the emo rock bands use religious allegories - even though they really don’t give much of a shit about religions at all. There is one particular line from “Church” that I love: “And if death is the last appointment | Then we’re all just sitting in the waiting room | I am just a human trying to avoid my certain doom.” This is probably the best way to summarize my own atheist belief. It was also really interesting to learn about the backstory behind the production of this song. The way they manage to incorporate everyone’s style for songs is something that many other bands have failed to do, but something that should definitely be considered and treasured more.

 Fall Out Boy’s Patrick Stump Breaks Down Cinematic New Song “Church" 

“Heaven’s Gate”

Personally, a more jazzy, chill vibe is always needed in the middle of an album. “Heaven’s Gate” is the most stand-alone song with a distinguishably different style from any other number from MANIA. I remember letting the record play on the highest volume as I lay on the floor, trying to recover from my cold. Well, I just ended up feeling like I’m really, really high. The story within the lyrics is just way too beautiful for an emo who might never get in a worthwhile, intimate relationship like the one in “Heaven’s Gate.” It’s also just amazing to see Fall Out Boy stepping out of their comfort zone to do a more folk-like song, yet they somehow managed to keep their own style going.

“Sunshine Riptide”

MANIA took a long time to be released. The band started the production of it way back in 2016 and pushed the release date back multiple times. This is an album for nobody but Fall Out Boy themselves, an album about their own growth as artists and creators. “Sunshine Riptide” is another one of those Los Angeles songs. There are so many songs about LA that it should just become a genre on its own. Fall Out Boy’s approach is a bit less sardonic than most other LA songs; instead, “Sunshine Riptide” is just plainly sad, a song about winner’s loneliness and sorrow for limitations and misunderstandings. Perhaps after all, this is something that the band members themselves had experienced/are experiencing.

“Bishops Knife Trick”

I love it when an album has a proper conclusion that ties the whole theme and story line back together. “Bishops Knife Trick” is an unusually slow song for Fall Out Boy. Instead of being an inspiring, upbeat song, this song is a self portrait for the band itself. 15 years after the band was formed, there seem to be many things that are still left unresolved for the boys. Yet, it is clear that the dedication and passion of the members will continue to lead the band towards new highs. 

 Once again, I’m only a part-time emo who’s trying to understand this world, don’t come at me if this is a bit superficial. I want to conclude this album as something that’s enjoyable for many different groups of music listeners. There is much more to MANIA that can be further broken down, such as the mysterious purple llamas in the music videos. I also found a great video breaking down the style and general theme of the album, it helped me a lot when I first listened to the record. Overall, 10/10 as an emo album, 8/10 as a great album in general.

Additional video link: ENTIRE MANIA ALBUM EXPLAINED | Fall Out Boy

title:
Show of the Month:
 Musicology with DJ Leegato // February 2018
content:
Interviewed by Alexa Lee

Your show centers around a different music theory topic each week. Is your knowledge of music theory self-taught, were you classically trained, or are you just oddly knowledgeable?

I’m actually classically trained on piano. I studied classical piano for about eight years, then moved on to studying jazz piano right when I started college.  While I was studying classical piano, I took an annual Certificate of Merit exam that required certain levels of music theory knowledge and performance skills, and passed the highest level when I finished high school, so that’s where I got all of my music theory knowledge that I use on Musicology. I center my themes on different music theory themes because I feel these themes represent different aspects of music that deserve to be looked at.

Do you think understanding technical music theory or structure enhances people’s abilities to emotionally respond to music?

Definitely.  As boring as studying music theory is, it becomes applicable to all the music you listen to.  It really helps break down the science of music and changes your approach to listening to music.  Music itself is already emotionally powerful enough, but knowing music theory will teach you WHY it’s emotionally powerful to you, and it’s a really ear-opening experience in my opinion. You start noticing all these little things that you never would have noticed if you didn’t know music theory, which is why I do Musicology in the first place - to teach everyone some basics and tips for appreciating the artistry of music that isn’t immediately noticeable.

Technology is rapidly advancing to create music using algorithms and pattern-detection software. As someone versed in the “rules” of music theory, will there ever be a day when computer-generated music creates better music than humans themselves can compose?

When I would practice piano as a kid, my dad would always tell me to never “play like a robot” (he’d likewise criticize pianists who did.) That’s his way of saying that a good pianist doesn’t just play every note perfectly; a good pianist feels the notes. I think the same applies to composing music. Music has always been an emotional art form of expression, and the process of writing music extends beyond technical knowledge and involves a deeper emotional knowledge of expression. Music theory is ultimately just a useful tool to express the greater emotional idea of music, it’s not a definite formula to writing good music. Part of what makes music exciting for me is that humans are able to break the established rules of music theory to create innovative new sounds, rhythms, and compositions to express more complex ideas, effectively creating new rules of expression. Erik Satie was criticized for breaking Impressionistic musical conventions, but now he’s viewed as one of the more well-known innovators of avant-garde music (don’t quote me on that). Or even look at Death Grips today.  Do you think a computer program could come up with that, let alone a human other than MC Ride and Zach Hill? It’d just be an incoherent project if an algorithm tried to develop an innovative song, due to the near infinite possibilities of chord tonalities and voicings, what “rules” to break, when to break those rules, or how to break those rules. And, above all, there’s no emotional backbone to construct these notes. You can give a program every “good rule” in the music book and I’m sure it’ll write good music, but I doubt you can program the innovation or heart to produce great music.  And humans are very good at determining whether a song has heart. Even if an algorithm wrote a good song, you’d need human musicians to convey the song’s emotion by performing it.

I was looking through your playlists and noticed that like me, you are a member of the BROCKHAMPTON’s large and angsty fan base. Of the members, whose musical style do you admire the most and why?

I’ll be honest, I’m very bad at following BROCKHAMPTON as a boy band and only know their music well, not so much the individual styles. But, that said, in terms of musical style, my favorite is Bearface. I always have a soft spot for heart-wrenching melodies and lush guitar chords, and he’s honestly the reason I look forward to the end of a BROCKHAMPTON album.  He’s like Daniel Caesar in that he uses some of the most formulaic chords and structures but manages to make it so fresh in the context of soul and hip hop. Plus, all of those songs are dreamy. In a few years when those songs become pop standards, they’ll be a guilty pleasure of mine.

What is one thing that people should know about you, your show, or both?

As much as I’m a nerd for music, I’m also a huge nerd of all things pop culture, sci fi, comic book, and fantasy. I write IMDb film reviews, and even host a second talk show about that on UCLA Radio called Geek Squad, Sundays at 7pm!  I also write my own music on the side which you can find here.  Most importantly, I’ve reworked Musicology this quarter to center around music terms while also retaining its music theory analysis; Musicology is on Mondays at 11am on uclaradio.com!

title: Black Mirror // TV Review
content:
Written by Irlanda Mora

If you’re a Netflix fiend, you’ve probably heard of Black Mirror or binge-watched the episodes. It is currently a trending topic on Twitter, but anyone unfamiliar with the show may be lost when they see memes referencing it.

So what is Black Mirror? Maybe you’re trying to convince yourself to watch the show but you haven’t read a review worthy enough to sway you. Well, if you’re looking to be persuaded, I’m not sure that’s what you’ll find.

Black Mirror is a show on technology and how it can impact humanity. Usually it’s a negative impact, so if you’re tired of hearing from your parents that any shortcomings of yours are “because you’re always on your phone,” then maybe this isn’t the show for you.

But if you’re interested in seeing several unrelated, stand-alone episodes, then this is the show for you. Now, anyone who listens to my radio show (Mama Rumba on Tuesdays at 7pm) knows that I cannot commit to television shows. I simply do not have the patience to watch a year’s worth of a character’s storyline, I’m no “commitment-phobe” person but I heavily dislike cliffhangers, and having to wait a year or so for a show to start up again after its season finale is not the way I live my life.

Point being, Black Mirror helps you avoid this dilemma, each episode has new characters, a new setting and a new technological advancement. *sinister laugh*

I’m really not attempting to sell this show to anyone. Honestly, some episodes have you downright disgusted with the fragility of our moral compass. Other episodes, though few and far in between, show a livelier side to humanity.

This show is a rollercoaster. I mean, it is truly a rollercoaster. Season 4 is perhaps the most frightening experience of all of the seasons I’ve watched so far. You’ve probably seen a hashtag on Twitter  - #blackmuseum. Well, if I were to try to convince someone, anyone, say Netflix was sponsoring me to really convince people to watch the show, then I’d tell people to watch “Black Museum,” the final episode of season 4. This episode alone encompasses the entire series.

This episode prompted intense feelings of disgust, both at some fictional technological advancements, and how desperate people were coerced into using these devices by businessmen. If you were to watch this episode, and did not like it, meaning your repulsion was too much to bear, then rest assured Black Mirror isn’t for you. Yay, at least you tried. But if you really enjoyed this episode, then you’ll surely enjoy what all four seasons of this show has to offer.

title: Lotta Sea Lice - Courtney Barnett and Kurt Vile // Album Review
content:
Written by Anshu Patel

Kurt Vile and Courtney Barnett come together for the folksy jam-session Lotta Sea Lice, released on October 17. Lotta Sea Lice mostly consists of country duets between Vile and Barnett, save for a few songs with solo vocals (”On Script,” “Peepin Tom”). Though both artists have a background in folk rock, the album more closely reflects Vile’s style. Barnett’s usual garage sound has very little influence on the collaboration. Vile’s gruffness and country twang exists for duets – late last year he contributed to the Hope Sandoval and the Warm Inventions album Until the Hunter with the lead single, “Let Me Get There.” “Let Me Get There” pairs Vile’s rough tone with Sandoval’s ethereal vocals, a highly successful combination. The track highlights what Lotta Sea Lice is missing– a better contrast between vocal textures – Barnett’s voice is simply a different shade of Vile’s, with a similar huskiness. The songs that work best on the album are the ones in which Barnett’s voice sounds brighter and distinguishes itself from Vile’s, such as in “Over Everything,” one of the principal tracks. 

Other highlights of the album include “Continental Breakfast,” the playful “Blue Cheese,” and “Untogether.” “Continental Breakfast” is an airy, sweet song that feels fresh against the rest of the album. “Blue Cheese” features a lighthearted exchange with childish teases and taunts. “Outta the Woodwork,” a less distinctive tune, is a cover of one of Barnett’s own songs; however, the original is preferable as Barnett’s vocals work far better on the track than do Vile’s. The fun that went into creating the album shines through, making it impossible for the listener not to appreciate the work, though at points it feels as if the songs meld together without distinct tracks.  Overall, the collaboration between Barnett and Vile is enjoyable, however, it does not make a lasting impression.

title: Interview with El Haragán
content:
Photo courtesy of  El Haragán

Interviewed by Irlanda Mora

I had the opportunity to interview Luis Alvarez, “El Haragán,” one of the most popular and influential musicians and singers in Mexican rock and roll history. Alvarez is the lead singer, composer, and founder of El Haragán y Compañía. Alvarez is most known for his lyrics that reflect the cultural reality of Mexico. He is known as a social portraitist for the vivid narrative of his songs. El Haragán y Compañía  are currently on their “Revolution 27" tour across the United States. I interviewed him at a venue in Los Angeles for his performance.

Irlanda: Buenas noches estan escuchando UCLA Radio con DJ Yoli aquí estoy con el Haragan. Gracias de antemano por aceptar la entrevista.

Haragán: Claro! Dejame nomas ponerme el rockeron. Aquí estamos a la orden.

Irlanda: Yo le tengo varias preguntas. ¿Primero, que es la diferencia para usted entre el rock Latino y el rock Americano?

Haragán: Yo creo que, bueno el rock se invento, se hizo aquí en Norte América. Recuerdas, con los afroamericanos Chuck Berry. Luego Elvis Presley que lo dio a conocer al mundo. De ahí se va para México y es un ritmo que se sale de Estados Unidos para el mundo entero desde México a Argentina, hay rockeros en Japón, en Alemania en Rusia donde quiera hay. Es un ritmo que vino para la humanidad. Ahora yo creo que la diferencia entre el rock de  Norteamérica  y el de México pues es obvia mente la sociedad. El rock siempre ha sido un grito de libertad de rebeldía. Siempre nos ha hablado de cambiar de rebelarnos ante las normas establecidas entonces de alguna manera el rock es un opositor al sistema. Entonces igual en México funciona, que quiere decir, a través de este ritmo de esta música, hablamos de las cosas que nos afectan. Y de alguna manera a veces es denuncia a veces es protesta a veces simplemente son vivencias de amor lo que sea pero tiene esa particularidad. Que cada pueblo lo adopta y lo transmite desde su punto de vida, de cómo se vive en cada sociedad. Y México tiene una forma muy particular de decir las cosas.

Photo Credit: Ivan Salinas (@nepant_la)

Irlanda: ¿Usted piensa que el rock como género quizá ha perdido popularidad en México? A través de lo años?

Haragán: Yo creo que no hay un público muy específico que sigue el rock al ritmo del rock mexicano. Este púbico generalmente se dice que el rockero es más inteligente. Se han hecho  estudios que el rock y rolero por lo mismo que tiene rebeldía, y que te incita el cambio. Y lo adopta la gente más inteligente e hay un público muy grande el hecho es que hay festivales gigantescos en México. Vamos a tocar en el vive latino por ejemplo donde van 50,000 personal 100,000 mil. Quiere decir que hay un público muy grande que escucha rock en español y el Haragán va estar ahí esperamos una gran respuesta.

Irlanda: Usted lleva más de veinte años en la industria de la música. ¿Usted cómo siente que ha cambiado rock ó a permanecido igual durante este tiempo?

Haragán: Tenemos 28 años tocando y obviamente seguía el movimiento desde atrás. Tenía mucho tiempo tocando pero desde que hice Haragán y Compañía tiene 28 años. ¿Y que ha cambiado? Sigues siendo lo mismo  en cuanto él inquietud de la gente. En cuanto las cosas que hablamos, parece que hablamos de lo mismo, como son problemas humanos hablamos de la represión policíaca, de las cosas que han pasado en la calle hay una canción por ejemplo que se llama “El no lo mato” bueno eso sucedió en el 1987, y hoy en día sigue sucediendo. Entonces qué quiere decir que nos repetimos como humanidad tenemos una tendencia de repetirse muchas veces. El rock evoluciona yo lo que veo es que al rock no lo puedes engañar rock es un ritmo puro es un ritmo que no engaña y se renueva cada diez años. Vuelve ser como el mismo ritmo otra vez vuelve a la base y vuelve a ser rebelde otra vez. Nuevamente la industria lo quiere vestir de rosa, hacer de una manera más digerible para las masas, es más pop pero de pronto el rock regresa de nuevo a sus raíces Y surge nuevamente grupos que le dan de vuelta al mundo y al sistema.

Irlanda: ¿Más auténtico?

Haragán: Si más auténtico, el rock es una guitarra de pronto ronca un grito de desesperación de libertad.

Irlanda: Y ahorita mencionó la canción “el no lo mato” ¿Es basada en una historia real?

Haragán: Definitivamente si. Lo que hago en la canción es nada más narrar lo que sucedió. Se puede decir que es una canción muy fácil de escribir pero es una canción muy difícil de vivir porque le sucedió a un amigo mio. Entonces tuve que vivir eso tuve que ir a sepelio al velorio fue algo muy triste porque tenía 17 años. Y yo nada más lo que hice fue describir lo que pasó. Fue fácil y ha sido una canción muy famosa.

Photo Credit: Ivan Salinas (@nepant_la)

Irlanda: Y si la verdad. ¿Usted quizá al escribir esta canción y presentársela al mundo quiso tener un impacto público, que hubiera cambios en la sociedad cómo se comportan los policías y hasta los jóvenes?

Haragán: Mira, cuando yo compongo una canción, no pienso en el éxito. Y en ese tiempo yo no pensaba en nada, yo nada más hacía canciones y no pensaba en el impacto que pudieran tener. Pero definitivamente pienso que la canción si ha concientizado a la policía de México  a la policía de muchos lados sabemos que hay mucha violencia policíaca generalmente quien quiere ser policía, es alguien que es muy violento y este, el gobierno los utiliza para eso, para la represión. Pero yo me encontrado muchos policías en México que luego me cuidan en los eventos y me llevan al camerino yes gente que cuando canto la canción ellos la están cantando también. Entonces como que si despierta conciencia. Creo que sí ha habido cambios como la gente que escucha el mensaje y ese es el impacto más grande que puede haber el impacto mental

Irlanda: ¿Y de todas las canciones que usted ha tenido en su carrera cuál piensa usted que es la que as ha tenido popularidad hasta en el mainstream, como se dice?

Haragán: Mira ahora hace  poco hicimos una impuesta en a propósito de los 28 años que cumplimos hicimos un evento en Agosto pasado y por Internet una encuesta por face [Facebook] cuál canción era la que más querían a mí me sorprendió porque surgió que hay una canción que le ganó a todas. Se llama purgante de amor. Esa le ganó a todas seguida por gran velocidad, y el no lo mato estaba como en el puesto número seis por ahí. No te explicas porque les gustas, no sabes.

Irlanda: Y fíjese que es algo que estaba pensando, la música que suele pegar al mainstream que la gente toca mucho, son generalidades como el amor, y hasta eso es algo un poco oscuro. Si estas enamorado pero de quién, porque nunca en realidad dicen algo contundente algo específico, o único.

Haragán: ¡Exacto! Por ejemplo “Purgante de amor” no habla de un amor color de rosas o nada así. Habla de que estoy perdido enamorado y no lo puedo entender, “no lo puedo evitar quiero y no puedo dejarte de amar y al final hay una frase que dice cuando te sientas asi igual que yo ve a la farmacia de la esquina y tomate un purgante de amor. Un brebaje mágico que te cure de amor.” Eso les gusta. Les gusta pero es una forma de hablar del amor, no metafórico es más directo.

Irlanda: Claro que si. ¿Cual es un tema que cuando usted empieza a cantar, el público le pide.

Haragán: Hay una canción que siempre la piden es me sorprende  también está en el número 12 de las más preferidas. Se llama, “En los años treinta” habla de mi papa se la compuse a mi papá que nació en los años treintas y entonces mi papá ya murió. Pero se identifican con eso yo pienso que tiene un sentido muy paternal la canción se acuerdan de su abuelito no sé. Es una canción como para niños.  Yo creo que les tocó el niño interno y la quieren escuchar. Es sorprendente. No se puede uno explicar como.

Irlanda: ¿Y cual es su meta artística? Que la gente venga a su concierto y se salgan sintiendo alegres o sintiéndose radicales tratado de cambiar el mundo o de ser mejor. ¿Cual es su meta como artista? Qué mensaje quiere dar?

Haragán: Precisamente hace rato estaba pensando eso. ¿Por que hago esto? Es como cosechar lo que sembré hace muchos años. Afortunadamente tenemos trabajo nos quieren ver aquí en Los Ángeles nos quieren ver en Nueva York. Nos quieren ver en Oregon y estamos de gira siempre. De hecho nos vamos de aquí, de Estado Unidos el domingo y el lunes tocamos en Hidalgo en México y el martes volamos a Chicago. Entonces es un itinerario a veces cansado. Pero cuando te preguntas, pues “¿porque quiero estar aquí? Y ¿La gente porque te quiere ver? De alguna manera les entregas algo. Y este ellos con mucho gusto se preparan desde temprano para verte hay algo que tú les das que ellos quieren ver. No sé desahogarse, gritar, bailar, a veces hasta emborracharse, si tu quieres llorar, cantar porque así es. Estamos hablando de la transmisión mutua de sentimientos entonces ahí es donde entra la magia de todo esto y yo digo bueno pues voy a seguir en esto siempre.

Irlanda: La verdad que bueno, estábamos escuchando sus temas en el camino aquí, y “Mi muñequita sintetica” en Youtube tiene 26 millones de views.

Haragán: 26 millones, no hombre ya quiero mis regalías. Jaja. Acabo de hacer un trato con, bebo, me va a pagar las regalías ya jaja.

Irlanda: ¿Usted como compositor que lo inspira? Hablamos un poquito sobre la sociedad, a lo mejor usted va y medita o va a cierta localidad para inspirarse? O medita antes de escribir, o no más le llega repentinamente una canción?

Haragán: Yo tuve una época muy prolífica de composición entre los diez años y los veinte luego sigue una segunda de los veinte a los treinta y así. Le he disminuido a la composición un poquito pero lo que me nutria en ese tiempo es que caminaba yo salía a caminar, caminaba en la calle iba en el metro,  en el autobús donde fuera veía y observaba los cuadros citadinos lo que la gente  veía. Veías a la gente triste en el metro y surgía una canción. Veía la muñequita sintética que estaba ahí en mi colonia en el pueblo donde yo vivo, y de pronto surge “La munequita sintetica” y es eso. Es observación. Mi mejor terapia para componer es caminar nada más. Donde sea hasta en el cerro. jaja.

Irlanda: Bueno muchísimas gracias por la entrevista fue un placer.

Haragán: Gracias a ustedes, muy buenas— muy inteligentes tus preguntas.

Luis Alvarez with Irlanda Mora. 

Listen to the full interview here!

title: Interview with Molly Burch
content:
Interviewed by Clea Wurster

Image courtesy of mollyburchmusic.com

Clea: My first question just has to do with your move to Austin from Asheville. What drew you to Austin in terms of the music scene? It seems like if you’re from LA, that might be the place to be.

Molly: Yeah, well I grew up in LA and moved away after I graduated high school. I spent a year in New York. I went to Sarah Lawrence College for a year, then I transferred to Asheville to study music there. It was a really wonderful community and place, but it was a little small at the time. After I graduated I wanted something bigger, but I wanted something more manageable than LA, I think. I think I was a little scared to go back to LA and Austin just seemed like a safer choice at the time. It was an exciting new adventure, because I’d never really been there before. It pushed me to go out of my comfort zone, but it was also, I think, probably easier than moving back to LA.

Clea: Did you have any family or connections in the (Austin) area or did you just pick up and go to Austin?

Molly: I kind of just picked up and went. I have family in Dallas so that’s always, that’s been really nice to have close family. Other than that, in Austin, I rushed into a relationship so I had a boyfriend, but other than him I didn’t know anyone who lived there.

Clea: What was your process for writing this album, it sounds like a lot of it is autobiographical about your relationship. So, was the writing process also one of healing from the end of a relationship or, what did it look like?

Molly: Yeah, it definitely was..Before I moved to Austin I didn’t really write too much, I was sort of scared to start writing my own music, but when I came to Austin and I was sort of by myself, it kind of just pushed me to come out of my comfort zone. I was dealing with a break up at the time, I had left my boyfriend in Asheville and then jumped into a new relationship. So, a lot of it is about that and then in the middle of writing the album I got back together with him. So some of the songs are about that as well.

Clea: How would you describe your musical style? I’ve read that you studied jazz music in Asheville is that correct? You’re sound is similar to Patsy Cline and Billie Holiday, and from listening to you, I would agree, but there’s something different about your music. How would you describe that difference?

Molly: Oh thanks, yeah. Well, I studied jazz in college. And I did vocal performance and grew up listening to jazz. But I also grew up listening to pop music and R&B and I think I’ve always just been really influenced by voices and that’s my main instrument, so I think I just like followed what made sense for my voice. I definitely have a lot of jazz influences, and I don’t know. I think it’s just like a mix-up of everything that I listened to as a kid and studied in college.

Clea: Are there any experiences that you think have most informed either your writing style or your musical style in terms of singing?

Molly: Yeah, I guess, like well definitely going to college for jazz and performance that really helped me get comfortable with singing and performing in front of people. Growing up, my sister was a big influence for me because I was too shy to pursue singing, or anything. It seemed like it was a crazy concept so she really pushed me to do it. And yeah, I think really moving to Austin…That was another big thing in my life that really pushed me to dedicate my time to music.

Clea: You’d mentioned that at first you were really just singing and I’d read that on your website, but um that you didn’t do any songwriting because you were afraid. So I guess, where was that fear coming from or, what was holding you back from dabbling in songwriting?

Molly: I think just, just being insecure and not having the confidence. It just seemed, I don’t know I just had a such a block; I felt like I didn’t even want to try because I felt like I was just afraid to look stupid, or I don’t know it was really just insecurities. And it took me a long time to even just be comfortable with singing or having, you know, i didn’t want to be so vulnerable in front of people and I think that just the more I did it…and same goes for writing, once I pushed myself, and just the more that I did it the more comfortable it felt and the insecurities just go away, it’s just learning how to deal with insecurities in the process for sure.

Clea: You said that you didn’t want to be vulnerable, but having your music be so autobiographical and having talked about it being autobiographical do you ever feel that, you know, your personal feelings or your personal life are on display in a way that you don’t want them to be or has it been something that you’ve embraced in order to inform your music?

Molly: I think that, yeah, its definitely been something I’ve embraced. You know, i"m at a point where I am comfortable performing and more comfortable writing I don’t know, yeah, I’ve totally embraced it.

Clea: So, you’ve lived in three very different places I would assume for musical sounds, is there any one that, or I guess could you just describe the different music scenes and your experience of them in the 3 different places that you’ve mainly lived, like LA, Austin, and Asheville and maybe even New York too, if you’ve also lived there.

Molly: I don’t have much experience really in LA or New York, cause New York I was living like upstate. I really only know Asheville and Austin and even Asheville has changed so much since I left `so I don’t feel like I could talk about it, but when I lived there I was in college, I had like a college band and it was pretty easy to play out and it was a really, really like small community so I think that was a nice introduction to being in a band. We did a lot of house shows, people were really supportive and super nice. and I love going back there. And Austin, has been it reminds me of Asheville in a lot of ways, it’s just bigger. It’s been super supportive and I feel like quite easy to…When I first started playing shows it was pretty easy to get shows and I feel like its a pretty supportive community, I like it.

Clea: You mentioned that you were in a college band, what was the sound of that band or how did it differ from what you’re doing now?

Molly: Ummm. It was kind of like a folk band, um, I don’t know it was me and my three other friends at the time and we all had like really no experience playing in bands and we would write songs together, like in the same room, it was pretty sweet. I think it was a good thing for me to have just some experience, I’m glad I had that before moving to Austin and really doing it on my own.

Clea: This last year for you has been kind of a whirlwind it sounds like from what I’ve been reading, with releasing your album and touring nationally and internationally, is that right? I guess, what’s been your biggest take away or lesson learned about the music industry, or yourself, or really anything?

Molly: Umm, I think yeah, this year’s been really wonderful I didn’t, I don’t know it’s just been a lot of new experiences. When I recorded the album I had no idea that it would be, I hoped it would be able, I would find someone to release it, you know I didn’t know if I’d be able to do that at the time and um, so yeah, just putting it out that was such an accomplishment for me and then I didn’t expect to tour so much, but it was definitely a good amount and I learned a lot about being a band leader and just about touring in general. It’s been really wonderful, but then you know a lot of difficult things along the way I’ve learned so much this year, so I think it was a pretty great year for lessons.

Clea: What’s it been like to have your music take off so quickly and with such positive response, were you expecting it or are there drawbacks to all the attention or expectations people have for you or has it mostly been a positive, gratifying experience?

Molly: I think its mostly been positive, I think its hard to see clearly sometimes with like how it’s being received, I guess. And I also don’t like to think about it too much, but I feel overall really positive about it and I feel really grateful just with everything, just I’m grateful I got to release an album I’m grateful that I have a really supportive label and I feel happy about how it was received.

Clea: Are you working on anything new right now or have you just been focusing on the album and touring it?

Molly: Yeah, well we have another tour coming up, we’re going to LA, we’re going to be supporting Alex Cameron on tour and, but yeah, definitely I’m working on new stuff. I feel like pretty done with focusing on the last album, but I’m glad that we could have another tour with and maybe another tour in the spring.

Clea: Is the new stuff also autobiographical, are you kind of moving away from that, if you had to describe it or if you can describe it?

Molly: Sure, yeah, I think that its um, definitely, still very personal..It’s just not so much about love, I think, you know.. There are some songs like that, but it’s.. I think the more personal songs are about self-reflection and self-growth, yeah.

Clea: What’s been your favorite show that you’ve played? Either the venue or the audience or whoever you were playing with? What’s been the coolest experience you’ve had performing?

Molly: I guess one of the coolest most recently is we opened up for Grizzly Bear in Austin and that show was really special cause it as ??????? and that felt cool that felt like Austin pride. I think the other great show was our record release in New York. Last Feb, it seemed like the most exciting show because it was so full of nerves and just the excitement of the album coming out. And it was the first time we’d played for our label, so that was exciting.

Clea: I was reading some interviews with you from earlier in the year, from right after your album had dropped and it said that you hadn’t yet played in LA. So, I guess now you probably have played in LA quite a bit more, and will be playing here again…What’s it like to be playing in the city where you grew up?

Molly: So yeah we played in LA just one time and it was like yeah, it was like the most nervous I’d been all year probably just because. I don’t know it should feel the opposite, because its like all your friends and family. I think that was, i don’t know, it was awesome.. I love coming to LA it was a really nice show, but it was, I was so nervous I like wanted to throw up I was so scared. You know, it was just so many people that you grew up with and my favorite teacher from high school came, but the more people I know, the more nervous I get, but it was nice.

Clea: Will they all be there again for the show with Alex Cameron?

Molly: I don’t know, some people

Clea: Are you excited for it then? Or nervous?

Molly: Yeah, I’m still nervous.

title: 21 Savage @ The Conga Room (2/15/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Skyler Mizokami 

The first thing I noticed when I entered the Conga Room late on a Thursday night was the intimacy of the venue. Quite literally a room, the place is made up of simply a couple of cocktail bars and a stage, with a small area for the crowd. This increased my excitement for the show, as 21 Savage would be only a few feet away when performing.

The event was put on by KJLH, so accordingly, the DJ sets were solid. The opener for 21 was Mike Free, a producer and songwriter from LA who is responsible for the Big Sean banger “I Don’t Fuck With You.” Free provided vocals, while the DJ played some of the songs that Free has produced. The music was good and the crowd was moving, but the overall energy of the venue was still low. Free himself seemed anxious for 21 Savage to take the stage. The DJ had to convince him to stay on for few more songs, as Free was ready to hand the mic over.

After Mike Free left the stage, the DJ announced 21 Savage. “Bank Account” started to play, and I was ready to jump around. 21 came out rapping with energy, and almost everybody in the small crowd took out their phones to record. “Bank Account” is a great song to hear live with its booming bass and catchy hook, but as I looked around barely anybody was actually dancing. A worrying sign. Next up he played his song “Rockstar,” another of his more popular songs, and again, there was not much energy in the crowd. I started to think of the songs that I wanted to hear from him, such as “Bad Business,” “Thug Life,” and “Rap Saved Me.” However, these hopes were never made a reality.

After just two songs, 21 Savage jumped off the stage without warning. The DJ began playing songs that weren’t 21’s, and I stood there confused with the rest of the crowd. It took awhile for me to really believe it, but 21 Savage truly performed only two songs and was on stage for less than ten minutes. My initial anticipation and excitement turned to disappointment. The crowd was partially to blame for the short performance, as I felt like one of five people who were actually dancing and singing along to the music. This was in high contrast to 21’s performance at Day n Night Music Festival, where the sea of people turned into one gigantic mosh pit. It seems that 21 Savage is a rapper who thrives in large crowds, rather than smaller venues like the Conga Room.

title: One Love Cali Reggae Fest 2018 // Festival Review
content:
Written/Photos by Maya Gutierrez 

I glided my way onto the Queen Mary grounds, with my best friend leaning on my left shoulder and camera bag hanging off to my right. The Queen Mary in Long Beach was home to the people who attended The Annual One Love Cali Festival, presented by The Observatory February 10 and 11, 2018.

I felt so calm and at ease when waiting in line. It didn’t take long to get into the festival both days, which made me wonder if it was due to the festival not selling out, which meant that less people were the cause to the the festival’s easy entry. I picked up a penny that was heads up on my way into the venue that I saw shining on the floor, and was thankfuI I had the agency of not “waiting in a long line” for the first time.

Long Beach is home to the cutest couples and nicest people. Being a Long Beach native, it was a form of medicine being around people of color and familiar auras I grew up surrounded with. The love at One Love was overwhelmingly admirable. Couples were folded into each other’s arms and bodies like DNA chromosomes; perfectly fitting and aesthetically pleasing. The ground was littered with people who wouldn’t stop kissing, dancing, or drinking. The crowd at One Love was more of an older one, with the lengthy beer tent lines being one of the many indicators. My friend and I had been approached by many kind people throughout the weekend; with either genuine compliments or friendly conversation. A guy named Skittles asked us for a lighter, so we handed him my lucky yellow paisley one I had tucked in my back pocket, not knowing we would be spending the next hour talking life, people, and colors with Skittles. Another girl, Loni, saw me snapping photos of some people, when she tapped us on the shoulder and said, “I have to take a picture of you too.” Before she left us with her Instagram that I asked for (this is how I like to get to know people), she gave us the nickname “Baby Dolls” for the weekend. Watching Iration from the back of the venue Sunday night, this really nice guy named Jacob, approached us with a smile with the following words, “I see you girls just standing here while everyone is smoking, do you want to hit this?” Observing my audience and environment all weekend, I noticed the sea of people whose bodies were enclosed in their own constant handmade clouds of white smoke; a color that could have easily been mistaken as their aura. We finished dancing to the rest of Iration’s set, getting to know our new friend in between Iration’s many jams. It was nice being around a sharing energy this whole weekend, seeing everyone smoking each other out. That was the major vibe of One Love.

Advertised heavily throughout the weekend were vapes. The same AD lit the screen in between sets; a girl of color in a beanie, smoking an e-cig. This advertisement began to make sense when I looked around, and noticed that half of the smoke in the air, pervading its way to hug the clouds, was due to the excessive use of vapes and e-cigs, not just marijuana.

Fortunate Youth was the first performance I saw at the festival. With the band jumping around the stage, happy to be in this space together, I felt the day start off really well. At the end of their set, they lit big joints, taking a few hits among themselves on stage, then proceeding to offer it down to the crowd of photographers and to the sea of people we call crowds. A woman who looked about the age of my grandmother, took a couple long hits before handing it off to someone behind her. This was the movie scene I remember distinctly all weekend, because it was wholeheartedly the best part.

J Boog and his band lit the stage with their presence. His facial expressions while singing were juxtaposed with the grace of his voice. Playing, of course, his familiar hit “Let’s Do It Again,” he sadly did not play “Ganja Farmer,” subtly breaking my expectations. His band had the perfect energy and radiance that matched his music and stage performance; fitting together like puzzle pieces on a good day.

The front of the festival consisted mostly of the people smoking mary jane, standing shoulder to shoulder, swaying in the Long Beach breeze. The people that were drinking a lot were the ones who usually set up camp with their blankets and friends/family/lovers; wanting to dance all night in a space they created and called their own for a day.

Iration and Matisyahu played the main stage, both Saturday and Sunday. I had never been to a music festival where this was ever a thing, so it was interesting to see it unfold; I liked it because I admire both of these artists a lot. Iration’s set was predictable, but comforting. What suprise can a band have when all their songs are good? Matisyahu’s energetic stage presence held the crowd together like peanut butter and jelly. He hopped around stage in green pants, colorful shoes, and hair white as snow. It was a beautiful and youthful presentation of a being, and his musical performance molded him into a genuinely charismatic moving statue the audience could remember.  

Atmosphere played his familiar old tunes, giving the crowd the comfort they wanted to hear. His spin on “The Best Day” included him freestyling half the song, throwing in words like “Long Beach” and “palm trees,” so the audience could relate in the moment. Towards the end of his performance, Slug chanted to the crowd, with his spirit exposed, at the end of probably the greatest song in rap history, “Yesterday,” and said, “It might seem weird but do me a favor and make some noise for everybody that ain’t here.” It was the best performance of the weekend, and it was only the end of Day 1.

Rebelution followed Atmosphere’s performance, closing out the main stage. Hand in hand, people in the back of the venue were now singing together in lucid states; the moon had rose fast, and it was now really late. Rebelution played some local favorites, “Feeling Alright,” “Count Me In,” and “Ordinary Girl,” closing off the night with their upbeat and resonating sounds.

Watching Common Kings was an amazing decision. They interacted with the crowd and each other in the same loving way. They played their familiar “Wade In Your Water” and “Alcoholic,” the two songs my friend introduced me to. The lead singer, at the end of a song, encouraged the crowd to hold up their flashlights on their phones as lighters - an act of establishing community and nostalgia together in this day and age of 2018.

The beginning of Day 2, I accidentally napped during Stick Figure, dozing in and out, because the sun was just right. I was swinging my feet to the familiar beat when they decided to unconsciously wake me up by jamming to my favorite tune of theirs, “Smoking Love.” I wish there was a way I could have thanked them for the perfect timing.

Landon Mcnamara played the Flav Stage Sunday, playing all his new music from his latest album, A Dollar Short and a Minute Late. With a familiar ball bouncing back and forth between the crowd, Landon was laying down powerful words and verses with grace; matching the rhythm of the sun setting in the background. Grabbing the crowd with his single “Loss for words,” the crowd was singing along, waving fingers in the air, trying to catch hold of this beautifully written empathetic song.

I had never, before the night of February 11, heard Ben Harper before. After his performance, I was overwhelmingly glad that this was the first time I had experienced him and his band. Sometimes, solos can be dreadfully long and get to a point where you feel guilty for just wanting the chorus to come back, but Harper and his band killed the stage with their solos. I couldn’t take my eyes off of Leon Mobley’s (percussionist and drummer for Harper) beautifully curated solo.

I was front row when Nas closed the stage out on Sunday. It was painfully ironic to watch him perform “If I Ruled The World,” when at the same exact moment, the queen Lauryn Hill herself, was at The Observatory in Santa Ana. Why was she there and not helping headline down here for us in Long Beach? We’ll just have to leave that up to corporate, seeing that it just wasn’t meant for us. When “The World is Yours” came on, my millennial film loving self immediately pictured the scenes from Dope, an amazing film about black youth that Nas is featured on. He was dressed warm in dark colors, rapping to an audience who looked like they were staring at a god the whole set.

One Love Cali Reggae Fest was a cumulation of 90s Long Beach nostalgia, a spreading of good energy among people, and a space that established itself with serenity and ease. It was an environment for people to come together and legally smoke marijuana among relaxing and comforting music that genuinely bled yellow and warmth.

title: Lucy Dacus – Nightshift  // Song Review
content:
Written by Sophie Taylor 

“Nightshift,” the single off Lucy Dacus’ up and coming album Historian, is a dynamic departure from your typical tale of heartbreak. It starts off with soft, solitary strumming, invoking the fragility and vulnerability that comes with a freshly broken heart. Her crystalline voice cuts through the staccato strumming like a dagger, each phrase driving that blade just a little further into your already bleeding heart: “ The first time I tasted somebody else’s spit, I had a coughing fit//I mistakenly called them by your name.”  Around the two minute mark the band joins in, vanquishing the vulnerability felt in the previous section and molding the melancholy mood into a more uplifting one. Dacus’ vocals begin to escalate, transforming conflict into conviction: “You don’t deserve what you don’t respect// you don’t deserve what you say you love and then neglect.” Nearly four minutes in, the band gives out and her voice pierces the gentle guitar chords once again, no longer fragile, but solid and earthy. From here to the end of the over six minute long track, she builds upon this simple and strong verse, belting it over and over again, gaining ferocity with every repetition, climaxing in a celebration of personal growth and inner strength. At its finish, the song manages to leave you with a feeling of wholeness that only comes from years of growth and healing in the wake of heartbreak. The song can seem a bit incongruent at times, almost like three completely different tunes, as opposed to your typical verse-chorus-verse-chorus structure. I’m not gonna lie, it threw me off at first; it wasn’t the comforting repetition I was so used to, I was uneasy not knowing where it would go next. But that’s when I realized that’s what made this song so beautifully composed—growth isn’t comfortable, predictable, or linear either. It replicated the imperfectly human experience of growth, a tough-to-tackle concept that she executed boldly and beautifully, leaving me absolutely breathless.

title: Belle and Sebastian - How to Solve Our Human Problems (Part 2) // Album Review
content:
Written by Sophie Taylor 

How to Solve Our Human Problems (Part 2.) by Belle & Sebastian, the second of three EPs comprising their latest album, is a groovy, twenty-one-minute-long flashback to the reckless abandon of youth, injected with all the wisdom that comes with having lived through it. Written with his youngest son in mind, the EP can be regarded as a thoughtful piece of parental advice, but also doubles as a call to preserve your inner child as long as you can, which is particularly relevant for those of us leaving college, and with it our childhood, as we get ready to enter the real world.

The opening track, “Show Me the Sun,” is an up-tempo groove—complete with psychedelic interlude—that manages to capture the carefree essence of youth. There is a certain sweetness to their voices that places you in a world tinted with warm summer sunshine, forever suspending listeners in the joy and freedom of summertime youth.

If “Show Me the Sun” radiates summer spontaneity, “The Same Star” represents the explosive, irrational love that accompanies it. The funky beat is a poignant testimony to the reckless and self-destructive nature of young love: “Feeling blue, and I’ll do it again/In orbit ‘round the same star ‘till we fall apart.” The cosmic imagery is a perfect metaphor for the inescapable gravity love can have, as well as its often violent and messy end, a feeling that can be painfully familiar for some of us.

“The Same Star” is followed by easily the most sentimental song on the album, “I’ll Be Your Pilot.” The clean, clear vocals, pared down composition, and charming melody mirror all the purity and innocence a father admires as he watches his child drift into slumber. Cherishing this ephemeral innocence, he recognizes the challenges of growing up and urges his son to resist the pressures to conform to a rapidly maturing society as long as he can: “It’s tough to become a grown up, put if off while you can/When you land in the real world, it’s like quicksand.” However, I think this song simultaneously entreats us to cherish and preserve our inner child as we grow up, a much needed reminder for my fellow freshly blossoming adults.

“Cornflakes” makes a complete 180 degree turn, with its slight dissonance and loose structure, allowing our hearts to rest a bit before segueing into the final track, “A Plague on Other Boys” - yet another painfully relatable tale of young love. It tells the tale of a student who is crushing hard on a fellow classmate, something all of us may have experienced first-hand. However, this student falls just a little too hard for this girl, losing himself in a passionate fantasy: “They say how can you know love, you’re a minor/And you say what else could I know, this defines me.” Spoiler alert: his fantasy is ultimately shattered by a cold, hard, reality, and he’s left picking up the pieces. While the protagonist finally got over the heartbreak and moved on, Belle & Sebastian point out that, “There’s a roped up part of every human heart for the first one you love,” a line that somehow left my heart both broken and full of hope, a perfect ending to an album about the complicated relationship between youth and adulthood.
tags: how to solve our human problems
how to solve our human problems pt 2

title: Boy Harsher @ The Echoplex (1/28/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Viviana Lira 

Having first seen Boy Harsher live in New York at the Brooklyn Bazaar, where they opened for Soft Kill, nothing could have prepared me for what was unleashed at the Echoplex on a Sunday night. Their performance in New York was greeted with an unbearable apathy that obstructed my own enjoyment as I struggled to dance among an inanimate crowd of darkwave scenesters, who were awfully concerned with maintaining a veneer of composure throughout the entire show. All I wanted was to transform into my little-Russian-techno-boy persona (image below) but that desire was tragically repressed once I was told to “calm down” by multiple people around me.

As soon as I walked into the Echoplex and bumped shoulders with the darkwave mob in what felt like every direction, memories of my disappointment in New York began to resurface and filled me with an agonizing dread when I thought about having to deal with another passive audience in the face of my biggest musical influence.

Boy Harsher went on at 11 pm, with frontwoman Jae Matthews slowly emerging from stage right into a cloud of red mist, delicately moaning and breathing into the mic with a demonic appetite. Her echoing vocals permeated the atmosphere and were followed by an ardent wave of static noise that paralyzed the body with its lurid vibrations, hypnotically easing the mind into a deafening reverie infused with disorientation and the purest ecstasy imaginable. This prolonged trance was then forcefully intercepted by an icy drone and a burst of minimal synth, subsequently overpowered by the mesmeric drum beat from “Yr Body is Nothing,” which is the song that very much inspired me to make music. The crowd screamed with an air of pleasure, and in an instant, I and many others rushed to the center of the pit to dance undisturbed. Surrounded by strangers who expressed the same uncontrollable hysteria, I was able to release every bit of tension that had been growing inside of me.

Matthews sang the lines, “What do you want from me? What can I give you?” with a melancholic tone drowned in ghostly reverb, which contrasted the sensuous and captivating nature of the instrumentals coming from Augustus Muller’s end, ultimately creating a sound that simulated the emotional state of ambivalence. The duo’s live rendition of the song captured the impotent despair that their music is evocative of, and they harmoniously fused this emotive quality with feelings of vehement obsession and desire through the seductive reverberations of dark industrial techno.

Unlike any other electronic artist I have seen live, Boy Harsher beautifully incorporates the art of storytelling into their music through the use of a personal narrative form that goes beyond the creation of stylistic effects. Even though their lyrics are manipulated by means of repetition and simplification in order to blend with the instrumentals, they do not suffer from methods of abstraction that complicate the modes of communication.

Throughout the performance, Matthews exhibited a powerful stage presence that actively engaged the audience by drawing attention to her gestures and motions that aided in the narration of the lyrics. Instead of losing myself in the instrumentals when “Pain” came on, I was completely drawn to the theatricality of the performance and the manner in which Matthews delivered the relatable story of being invisible to the person you desire the most. All in all, Boy Harsher exceeded my expectations and provided me with a much needed transcendental experience that was cathartic to the highest degree.  I was able to mercilessly dance for two hours non-stop in my dripping sweat without any repercussions, and in those moments I truly became the little-Russian-techno-boy that I have always wanted to be. Considering that the Echoplex was sold out and packed with dozens of people passing out left and right to the point where Boy Harsher had to pause their set, the LA crowd was pleasant to be around that night. The duo will be returning to the West Coast in April to play a show with The Soft Moon in San Diego, and this is a tour that you will not want to miss!

title: Coco // Film Review
content:
Written by Irlanda Mora

I didn’t know what to expect when I agreed to watched Coco with some friends. I had never felt like my community had been represented on mainstream films, much less a Disney film.

At the theaters, I was disappointed when I saw that Disney had tactfully provided a Frozen “short” that lasted upwards of 40 minutes. I was bored and felt a degree of detachment. I had come to see Coco, not Frozen. I sat there and glanced around, observing everyone at the theater. I just wanted to do anything that would distract me from the painfully boring short where the protagonist was attempting to define tradition.

The movie theater was filled with people of color, a large majority were Latinx. The beauty in the audience, I found, was in the age range. You had young kids of about five years old up to other people well into their fifties, and of course you couldn’t ignore the college-age demographic the room either. Regardless of age, we were all sharing an experience, we were all excited to witness Disney and Pixar’s first attempt at truly capturing and representing the Latinx experience on screen.

Simply put, I was impressed. Not only was the protagonist nuanced and relatable, the antagonist reminded me of Mexican idols such as Jorge Negrete and Pedro Infante. The attention to detail was mesmerizing, the world of the dead with its vivid, enchanting colors and shapes reminded me heavily of Tijuana and Mexico City.

What I really appreciated in the film, was how the family was matriarchal. The mujeres in the film were strong-willed and tenacious, but also flawed and human.

The depth of the story was heartwarming, and the message of the film truly described what Día de los Muertos represents to us. Our loved ones who have passed are forever with us in our memories - their real departure occurs only if we forget them.

Overall, Coco is a must-watch. I will warn you, you must have tissues when viewing because you will cry. The film was beautifully crafted and the emotional ride is simply lovely.

title: Head in the Clouds Festival Review // Show Review
content:
photographs and article by Michelle Stensby

Originally from Miami, a city largely known for it’s almost entirely Latin American population, I’d say I’m still very new to the various Asian and Asian American cultures around me in LA. It’s various cultures, at large, make Los Angeles the vibrant city I’m proud to call my new home. The inclusivity of the Los Angeles music scene and all those involved in it make me proud to be a part of a radio station I call my new home too. With that being said, when I was asked to cover 88Rising’s Head in the Clouds Music and Arts Festival, I was quick to respond with a heightened sense of excitement, “YES!” 88Rising’s Head in the Clouds Music and Arts Festival filled Los Angeles Historic State Park last Saturday, September 22nd, with an atmosphere almost difficult to describe. I could say that it matched the energy of any other music festival but, then again, it didn’t. The level of excitement I was fortunate enough to witness and be a part of was something not only beautiful but, historical as well. The lineup featured Rich Brian, Joji, Keith Ape, Zion. T, Higher Brothers, NIKI, Sen Morimoto, and KOHH, making it the largest festival lineup of Asian artists in North American history. In addition, the festival was a nice salute to the 88Rising’s crew album, “Head in the Clouds,” just released earlier in 2018. The festival was a celebration of all 88Rising has accomplished within the past five years. 

I had the privilege to spark conversation with some of those who had waited in line to see their favorite artists since early in the morning, those who felt deeply connected to them. When I asked one young girl pressed up against the barricade, happy as ever, clinging closely to her large Japanese flag, why this festival held importance to her, she responded, “I never grew up with artists like Joji being so popular in mainstream culture. It makes me proud to be Japanese and to feel like my voice is heard.” She was right. Throughout the festival I continuously found myself in awe at how the music of Higher Brothers and Zion.T, both of which sung in their native Chinese and Korean, transcended language barriers. People were simply there to enjoy the music, enjoy the atmosphere, and enjoy the company. 

In addition, the festival grounds itself offered a wide variety of food and drink for its attendees to choose from. With three different beer gardens, free water booths, and a night market featuring Howling Rays, Chris Oh, Seoul Street, and Baohouse, guests had no problem entertaining themselves with more than just the music. The VIP area also offered a great way to attend the concert in an intimate way. With white lounge couches, a private beer garden, and a small pit close to the main stage, those in VIP had the option to enjoy the festival in a more intimate, private way. 

However, the main attraction for the day-long festival was, of course, the music. With artists having 20 to 30 minute set with short 2 to 3 minute breaks in-between sets, the entertainment was near constant and the energy levels remained high the entire afternoon blending into the night. One group, in particular, that created a good vibe leading into the evening was Higher Brothers (海尔兄弟). This Chinese hip-hop group consisting of members MaSiWei (马思唯), DZknow (丁震), Psy.P (杨俊逸), and Melo (谢宇杰) re-established the hype going into the evening, preparing the audience for artists like Keith Ape, Murda Beatz, Anderson Paak, and Rich Brian, with their songs like “Made in China” and “WeChat.” Joji was another personal favorite of mine from the evening. With songs like “SLOW DANCING IN THE DARK” and “YEAH RIGHT,” Joji stripped the energy down to one resembling a high school dance in the school cafeteria. You’re dancing with your high school sweetheart, shitty decorations for a theme you can’t quite make out, the smell of lunch served earlier, but you’re just in love and happy to be there. It was an almost romantic atmosphere, making a nice shift from the high energy performances of the evening.
