Granted, the most exciting part of the evening for everyone, as seen from the photo pit, was definitely when all artists of the day came out to sing their summer hit, “Midsummer Madness,” and other hit songs from their group album “Head in the Clouds,” at the end of the night. It was in this moment, I sensed this large community of people from the audience, different backgrounds, different ethnicities, and different stories all coming together to celebrate the great success of 88Rising and of Asian artists who’ve broken serious glass ceilings in popular culture. Singing and dancing along, creating bonds with complete strangers around me, I couldn’t help but feel so fortunate to have been a part of the crowd, the fans, and the history made that day.

title:
Sons Of An Illustrious Father: Or, The Coriolis Force
@ The Echo (6/23/18) // Show Review
content:
Article and photographs by Tara Kazimi

With such an adrenalized and fervid sound, it’s a surprise that Sons Of An Illustrious Father have flowed so inconspicuously thus far. However, this result is not a matter of worth, but rather an inadequacy in their coverage that will inevitably reverse itself as the days go by. It’s only a matter of time that Sons of An Illustrious Father are seen as the worthy entity they truly are, not only for their extravagant music, but the profound and stimulating messages they stand by.  

Their recent show at The Echo is a testament to the power and beauty they hold, welcome to the world and welcomed by all who cared to absorb. Their live performance is a catharsis, it’s raw, it’s healing, it’s everything in between and nothing short of pure. They mainly performed gut-wrenching songs from their new record Deus Sex Machina: Or, Moving Slowly Beyond Nikola Tesla. With “U.S. Gay” being an obviously engaging and enraging, in the best way possible, favorite among the eclectic crowd. With Lilah Larson’s sweet harmonious drones and Ezra Miller’s aggressively grinding vocals the song leads as a sort of anthem, when directly compartmentalizing the specificity and bluntness of its cries. It’s a pact between the trio, Sons Of An Illustrious Father and their listeners, their listeners and their friends, their listener’s friends and their local “superiors”, between whoever cares enough and whoever doesn’t care at all. It’s as if you’re being stared into the eyes, through your soul, having every internal cog and mush and wheel caressed lightly, promised personally that “if you wanna fuck shit up, I’ll fuck with you, and if you want to fix it up, we can do that too”.  Often music is nuanced by many different factors, however, in this case, the simplicity is what makes it powerful.  

At one point they broke out in an a capella version of “All Apologies”, clutching each other gracefully, as if by that they were able to evaporate the pain out of their own bodies. Josh Aubin, in particular, seemed to step out of his performing comfort zone at that moment, joining the two high school friends in a passionate embrace and truly enjoying and embracing every second of it. It was touching and intimate and called for all the energy in the room to level at the same trajectory.

Sons Of An Illustrious Father want to, and urge others to make a complex and beautiful assemblage sculpture out of this pseudo not so pseudo apocalyptic age. Just because we are up to our necks in debris and wreckage and filth doesn’t mean that we are destined to asphyxiate in it. It’s refreshing to listen and experience such a forward motion in music these days. A lot of the time heartache and destruction rein free, with only negative connotations allowed to not only withstand but be promoted. But here, there is a hope, there is a tomorrow where black holes and their infinite density eventually disappear. Music like this feels like the personification of the Coriolis effect, a stronger and more hopeful deflection in wind patterns, igniting itself in each and everyone allowing the power of change.

title: HOMESHAKE @ Natural History Museum (5/4/18) // Show Review
content:
Photos and article by Lillian Stanwick

Oh fuck, this was not an ideal start, I thought to myself as a series of unpredictable metro line disasters resulted in my strolling into the, uh—unique, venue at 9:16, right as HOMESHAKE began playing the first song in their set.

I was given a photo pass with a bright yellow “all-access” wristband, little did I know about how powerful this bright yellow marker could be. As I approached the North American Mammal Hall, where the concert was happening, I was stopped by a security guard and told, along with a large group of other youths, to wait on the side.

Fuck. I thought to myself again. In what I thought was a vain attempt, I lifted my wrist to show him the yellow band, distinct from the pink GA ones. Somehow that neon strip of paper afforded me the privilege of walking straight in without having to queue up. I couldn’t believe it. What I was greeted with was around 250 people all crowded as close as they could get to the barrier as Sagar and company’s dreamy tones started to drift over the audience.

So many people were crowded into a dark rectangular space; there was little difference in elevation between the stage and the audience. The result was that very few people could see very much. I tried, futilely, to edge my way in between people to try to get to the front. After half a song’s worth of struggling, a radical idea occurred to me…maybe the wristband could get me even closer.

I walked to the edges, where knee-level bars usually keep proper distance between the public and the exhibits, but tonight they separated the maximum-capacity audience from those who were filming the concert and broadcasting it outside the entrance of the hall to those not lucky or dedicated (I heard of some kids waiting in the hall since 6:30 for the group’s 9:15 set) enough to make it inside. The personnel filming gave me wary looks at first, but as soon as they caught sight of the ~magic~ wristband, I was in like Flynn.

I strolled right up to the front and was soon stepping around big burly bodyguards to get into a proper position within the photo pit between the clearly temporary stage and audience. I tried my best to fake it and hoped for minimal graininess despite the absence of flash. After the first couple of songs, I saw the “professional” looking lot exiting the pit and circling around the stage, getting different photos from behind the musicians.

This possibility had also not occurred to me, I was amazed as I walk backstage and suddenly found myself rubbing elbows with HOMESHAKE’s inner posse of impeccably dressed friends and female companions. Unbeknownst to me at the time, indie-royalty Mac Demarco and Kiera McNally were casually strolling through the lobby, hugging wide-eyed adolescent fans as I tried my best to give off the air of a proper member of the press. Backstage, and newly emboldened, I continued to snap some photos until the end of the set.

HOMESHAKE’s performances are nothing thrilling. Their music does not have peaks and valleys for the audience to ride, but rather mellow ripples that are meant to flow around you, to be felt, and then to dissipate. Certainly, more sonic than melodic, but not immune to its appeal.

“Khmlwugh” was the only song where the audience became enthralled enough to sing out in a hushed chorus the irresistibly cheeky and lyrics which form the song’s acronymic title, “kissing, hugging, making love, and waking up and getting high.” Sagar hits a button on his Finland SP-404 and suddenly the falsetto bridge is cooed out from the speakers, and the audience goes crazy for something that isn’t all that impressive.

At times Sagar looked tired, or just plain disinterested, but at one point he asked, “Is everyone ok?” checking in on the tightly packed audience before following it up with the bluntly delivered, “Are you enjoying the presence of taxidermy all around you?” to which a few beaming fans cheered back in affirmation.

A rare little jig from Peter Sagar

The band trudged through their set without spending much time interacting with the audience in between songs. The entire time I found it strange yet kind of funny to watch them calmly bob their heads and then suddenly catch a glimpse of a massive bison or walrus perched behind them.

As the end of the allotted time approached, Sagar rhetorically asked the audience “Do you guys think we could play three songs in ten minutes because I sure don’t,” before resigning to play two more songs. In between the two songs a special guest, who few people in the audience recognized, myself included, hopped onstage and played a couple riffs on a keytar.

When the night ended without much fanfare at 10, maybe 10:02 pm, everyone began to shuffle out. My neon wristband somehow transported me all the way to the outside of the green room, where I recognized their bassist and saw who I assume was someone’s girlfriend.

I decided that I could fake my professionalism no longer before I inevitably get in over my head and make a fool of myself, so I retreated out the front door and into the night. If I learned anything from the experience, it is that I am still underwhelmed by HOMESHAKE’s performances (despite my optimism) and that neon wristbands can afford you special privileges like you wouldn’t believe. Whether I was deserving of all those privileges, I am not so sure, but I am grateful for them nonetheless.

title: Grid of Points - Grouper // Album Review
content:
by Clea Wurster

Released on April 27th, Grouper’s latest album Grid of Points carries on the sobering tone we have come to expect from Liz Harris’ compositions.

More so than previous works, the album seems to abandon the semblance of a narrative in favor of an abstract exploration of pure emotion or a lack of it. The album pulls listeners by the gut with a deep melancholy ambivalence - there is almost no need for comprehension, only experience.

Liz Harris stated in a press release that the album is meant to carve out “The space left after matter has departed, a stage after the characters have gone, the hollow of some central column, missing…“ and it does just that, occupying a suspended state between what has been and what could be.

With only 7 tracks lasting a total of 22 minutes, the album is much shorter than most, but as Harris herself has said: it’s complete. And it feels that way, or maybe it doesn’t, but that kind of seems to be the point.

Songs end just as you think they’re about to begin. Piano keys are slippery, dropping off into a void prematurely and leaving an emptiness where it feels like there should be something, anything. These subtle hints toward the accidental and unpolished mimic the brevity and disintegration of the album itself.  By the time “Breathing,”  the final track on the album, reached its end, I felt like I inhabited the same placid emptiness that Harris found when she wrote the album in the rural state of Wyoming.

The first track on the album, “Races,” begins with static. I almost questioned whether my headphones were working, but it was soon replaced by a soft voice, hymn-like in its demand for solemn reverence and respect. Breaths populate the lengthy gaps between lyrics and instrumentals. Though seemingly haphazard, they claim a central space within the piece serving to generate a purposeful disquietude.

“Parking Lot” begins after another bout of uncomfortable fuzz-filled moments. Strong piano keys interrupt the almost-silence and a raw voice soon joins in with a similarly angelic twinge as in “Races.”

The piano here is simplistic and uncertain, but rather than seeming unskilled it bears a certain weight, holding the emotions in balance. The keys threaten to become overbearing but carefully shrink back avoiding a melancholy only narrowly kept at bay throughout the entire project. 

The album follows its path toward a continual, unplaced longing. Between the tracks, moments of unfilled air create an absent-mindedness that could almost have been caused by a simple overlooked “record” button.

The lyrics of each song are simple, short and repetitive in some cases and they seem secondary to the innate emotion present in the tones and careful notes. Each word is drawn out past its end, heavy in a way that contradicts the high pitch. They’re enveloped in a light sadness, creating a difficulty of comprehension which builds an incessant desire for answers that are only met with disappointment. Though each track has its own specific flavor, they all follow toward what can’t be defined.

This short album asks that you sit with this restless uncertainty quietly. If the album continued on any longer, it would be nearly infuriating. Poised at the edge of an obscure brink, stuck between something and its completion is a locale that proves to be nearly unbearable. To be pressed against such a precipice for longer than 22 minutes would instill a permanence of emptiness that makes me uneasy. Grid of Points carefully spans the liminal space between expectation and reality, forcing us towards neither and ending before the limbo finds purchase outside our headphones.

title: Interview with Jack Steadman of Mr Jukes and Bombay Bicycle Club
content:
Interviewed by Alison Chi

The following interview was conducted at the Mr Jukes show on Monday, April 30, 2018 at the Echoplex. The interview has been condensed and edited for clarity.

AC: Thank you for agreeing to do this audio interview! …I really love how collaborative how this entire album has been.

JS: Thank you.

AC: And I guess you’re one of the last people to work with Charles Bradley.

JS: I think the last.

AC: Yeah, and hearing that song (“Grant Green”) every time honestly just hits home every time. So I was kind of curious because I’ve seen in some different interviews that when you play live, you play with a different band every time, like playing with a 12-piece or 8-piece – so I’m curious how each show is different and morphed together, especially because this album (God First) is jazzier and kind of the influences of playing live.

JS: I think the whole thing has been a reaction to being in a sort of, very tight, rehearsed band for 10 years, which was Bombay Bicycle Club. So you play the same set every night, in the same way, and there’s nothing wrong with that – it was really fun and I loved it. But it got to the point where I wanted to do the opposite of that, so something looser, something where if you make a mistake, it doesn’t matter – it’s almost encouraged, something interesting could happen. And change the songs up all the time, change the band, just be a bit looser. But that’s just a case of something getting saturated, which was how I played in Bombay.

AC: Since there were so many collaborations, how many people did it take to complete the album?

JS: Quite a few…But just the right amount

AC: I have a couple questions about your music videos because those are always really cool. They were all animated – I was wondering if that was a conscious choice.

JS: Yeah it was, totally. Because you can be a little more experimental, you can let your imagination run a bit further because you don’t want to be disappointed by a director saying, “I love your idea but it just can’t happen.” And secondly, I don’t like being in videos so this is a way for me to be in it in a way I was comfortable with it, which is like an avatar or some weird alter ego.

AC: And for “Leap of Faith” and “Angels” video, they both have a space-y theme to it. Is there a storyline you’re going with for those?

JS: I’ve just become very fascinated with astronomy. I’m actually doing a degree right now, like a bachelor’s degree in astronomy.

AC: Oh yeah! I saw on your social media that you’re part of the British Interplanetary Society.

JS: I am.

AC: Okay – is that just an intellectual pursuit?

JS: Yeah it is, just something to do on the side.

AC: On top of like making music…

JS: It’s a field I want to get into, and I never went to university so I’m finally going back and studying.

AC: So you’ve been doing music for a really long time, so how, starting off pretty young and coming to this point, how has that journey been, identity-wise?

JS:  It’s a trip. To do it at quite a young age is very strange because we obviously had a lot of success as Bombay Bicycle Club. And you get to a point, I was probably about 26, where you’re like, “You’ve done a lot”. A lot has been achieved. But there’s so much more of your life remaining and it’s a feeling a lot of people have in the later years of their life. And I’m not saying that I’m complacent and think that’s all there’s to do and that I’m satisfied but it is just quite a peculiar way to be at that age…almost like just feeling exhausted sometimes. So much has happened such a short amount of time but you still were young and have this vitality – it’s weird.

AC: I wonder if this like a quarter-life crisis?

JS: Yeah probably! A beautiful one.

AC: With making this record, I saw that you traveled around – you went to China, Korea – all these different places. You didn’t travel by air, you only traveled by ship or train, so which do you prefer?

JS: It’s hard to say, the ship was amazing. It was the only time I’ve been on a long voyage on a ship but I loved it. They’re both great – anything that allows you to just daydream all day, just look out the window and not have any responsibilities is fine by me.

AC: I read that when you were on the freight company Hanjin, some of the crew recorded songs in the studio that you made. Are thinking of maybe using some of those recordings?

JS: Absolutely not! No disrespect to the crew on board. They were incredibly corny love songs for their families back home – how much they missed them. I’m not saying it wasn’t emotional but it was cheesy.

AC: We usually do some fun questions on the air, just to break the ice a little bit. So what’s your favorite karaoke song?

JS: It’s a song by Roxy Music – it’s called “More Than This.” It’s because Bill Murray sings it in Lost in Translation. It’s one of my favorite scenes. I think it’s beautiful and he’s staring at Scarlett Johansson.  

AC: Do you have a childhood nickname?

JS: No, not really. Some people used to call me Steadbomb.

AC: What’s your favorite song lyrics that you’ve written?

JS: There’s a song called “Jewel” and it says, “Our love was just like one of your expensive jewels, you think back to its price and you feel a fool but in that certain light, it looks so beautiful.” Yeah…I don’t know that’s really cheesy though. But when I wrote that, I felt quite clever.

AC: With this new album, it was very jazz – and I know you had an old hip-hop pseudonym under J. Stiller, I was wondering if you’ve heard of chillhop music.

JS: Of course! I listen to it regularly. Probably the only thing I listen to right now.

AC: Awesome, I thought it was really cool because in some of the articles you were talking about sampling and in chillhop music there’s a lot of sampling.

JS: It’s such a beautiful community. I basically went from buying records in shops to just going on YouTube and listening to channels. And it’s such a transition but it’s a really healthy scene. It’s growing and I think a lot of people don’t know about it. They’re like, “What’s people listening to now? What’s music become?” Go on these channels which have millions of subscribers, of people just hanging out or studying or living their life listening to these great, live mixtapes…and all that vaporwave stuff. I feel like that’s where everyone is right now.

AC: It’s a really interesting way of discovering music now. You’ll hear a sample and you’re just like, “Wow, that’s really soulful and just full of love,” and you’ll just go and try to find out. It just sparks this…

JS: You’ve gone down a rabbit hole

AC: Yeah, and now there’s a fascination with 70s soul and funk music that I just really appreciate.

JS: Oh that’s beautiful. That’s what happens with sampling. And it’s all just bedroom producers, which I think is amazing. And a lot of them seem to really like The Simpsons.

AC: Yeah Simpsonwave!

JS: Yeah it’s great – smoked way too much weed listening to that music.

AC: You have some of your older tracks on Soundcloud. With Mr Jukes, how did this manifest what it is now, was it just something you’ve been thinking about, maybe the past couple of years or has it just been something always gnawing at you?

JS: I’ve always been making stuff on the side which is all the Soundcloud stuff, even when I was touring with Bombay Bicycle Club. And I guess I just took some time off to do this project properly. And it has kind of spiraled and snowballed. Like it could’ve just been a bedroom hip-hop record like what we were just talking about. And you just get more ambitious like I have the resources to get some musicians on it and book a studio and take it out of the bedroom. Now I’m just some guy making beats into something else. And so I did. And it kind of grew in that way. You could take all those songs…if I just played you the demos, it would just be bedroom production so I guess that’s the difference.

AC: How do you feel about recording in a studio in your own home?

JS: I’ve gone through so many different phases. I just left my studio in a big emotional “Fuck you, I’m leaving now” because I hated it. But because I’ve been there such a long time, I started to miss being at home and I felt like I was changing because I was in a professional environment. So now I’m back in my bedroom now. I think a lot of artists go through a cycle and they get bored of their bedroom and want all the fancy equipment. And they spend a couple years with the fancy equipment and get nostalgic for the pureness that was in their bedroom. And it’s just a cycle basically.

AC: Okay last question, did you use GarageBand back in the day?

JS: I didn’t, I had a Windows computer but it was something similar.

AC: Thank you so much for your time!

title: Perfume Genius @ The Mayan (4/12/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Gomi Zhou

“You’re not 21? You look 21.” My evening started with some nice and surprised greetings from the security guards at the bar section. Granted, they had their reasons to make the assumption. The audience at the Perfume Genius concert looked significantly older than the regular concert crowds I’m used to. I expected the audience to be a lot younger for some reasons (probably because there are usually a lot of queer youth at queer artists’ concerts), even though the music of Perfume Genius is known to be sensual, mature and evocative.

When a purple hue took over the stage, the opening act Big Thief walked on the stage gracefully and casually. The crowd, instead of screaming cheerfully, welcomed the band as if they were just some old friends. Without any sort of introduction, Big Thief jumped straight into playing the first number on their last album, “Pretty Things.” I had very minimal knowledge of the band, but their dream-like, soothing style was exactly what I needed. I remember zooming out and staring at the colored smokescreen–not because they were not interesting enough for me to remain focus, but simply because the Mayan was then a completely different utopian dimension under the soothing melodies.

During the intermission I walked around the venue for a bit. The Mayan is unique in the sense that it was made to resonate with the Mayan culture. Though I’m not sure whether the interior decor was simply a sign of cultural appropriation, the sights of Mayan masks and columns inside the theatre did make the medium size venue look more grand and exotic. People were either rushing towards the bar area or towards the merch stand. With a few lovely couples left on the dance floor swaying in the company of each other, very spontaneously I chatted with a pair of strangers, and came out to them as well. This was going to be a good night for everyone, simply because of the welcoming atmosphere created by the excited queer community and allies who were there for a great show. I felt safe being myself with the strangers there, I think everyone else felt safe as well.

It was worth the wait after all. In a similar fashion, the band got on gracefully. But now the crowd was cheering, and the long-waited screams were finally let out as Mike Hadreas, the lead singer took the stage. After showing off his shiny silver suit and making a few quirky face at the crowd, Perfume Genius was no longer just “Mike”– he was ready to put on a show only he was capable of doing. The pianist started playing the intro for “No Shape,” the night was now heated and the crowd was ready for a phenomenal show.

I went to the back after the first three songs. Already head over heels from the luring, seductive energy that was filling up the venue, I was witnessing two shows. Under the whimsical rainbow-like lights and the echoey, alluring voice of Hadreas, people in the back were dedicated to dancing their night away. In the best way possible, couples were now free from the odd stares of bystanders (although here I was, staring). People had their own dance moves to accompany Hadreas’ strange yet beautiful movements on stage, free of judgement and worry.

The whole night felt more like a gathering of passionate people than a concert. People were there to dance to the great beats and enjoy each other’s company. The only difference between this and a regular Thursday night was that Perfume Genius, sounding almost exactly the same as their recorded music, was giving one of the best shows ever. Nobody remembered when Hadreas took off his jacket, nobody remembered the clear order of set list even though the amazing live performances of “Die 4 You,” “Wreath,” “Sides,” and many more songs from both the new and older albums were now carved in everyone’s memories. Towards the end of the show, the rest of the band left the stage. Hadreas played a few acoustic songs, magically sang in an even more dreamy voice. He brought Alan Wyffels, his long-term partner and band member onto the stage again. Together they played the piano in such a playful yet loving manner. I’m sure their Coachella show just the day after was drastically different, but I’m sure the accepting and welcoming vibe of this night was just equally as memorable for Perfume Genius as that huge, glorious stage in the dessert.

title: Love, Simon // Film Review
content:
Photo courtesy of 20th Century Fox

Written by Emily Pitcher

Inspired by the book by Becky Albertalli, Love, Simon is bringing the much needed coming-out narrative to our movie screen. The film is about a gay high school student Simon who has a secret online friendship with another gay student, Blue, but here’s the catch: Simon is being blackmailed. Martin has discovered Simon’s conversation thread, and in exchange for not outing Simon, Simon must help him get a girlfriend.

I originally discovered this story when I read Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda and fell in love with the humor and flirtation between Blue and Simon. The book was focused on the agency of coming out, but it was also about friendship, theatre, and Oreos. There isn’t a novel that has caused me to giggle more than this one and I would highly recommend giving it a read. I came into the theatre skeptical over its ability to fully portray the charm of the book, and while it isn’t as moving as the novel, Love, Simon portrayed the quirks of growing up while maintaining its central focus of LGBT themes.

This film does not shy away from the reality of being gay in a southern city, but it’s still lighthearted. While emotional, gut wrenching LGBT narratives are important to showcase, sometimes you want a cute, fluffy film about two gay guys who fall in love over email. You want a lovable friend group that supports the protagonist and supportive parents who are trying their best. It’s serious when it needs to be, but this is as much of a coming of age story as it is a coming out one.

One of my biggest criticisms of the film is that I wish it showed more of the dialogue between Blue and Simon that was in the novel. The book had inside jokes, their interests, how they saw the world - the film only really featured the parts of their conversations that talked about being gay. Perhaps this was to ensure that the film was focused, but as someone who adored these parts of the book, I was disappointed by how little Blue’s personality was shown. I was also perturbed by how over-the-top Martin was; he’s not only annoying but downright clueless, and he came off as too strong to seem realistic.

Despite this, I cannot discount what the film does well: its humor, the fact that it’s 2018 and we need more representation in the media, its acknowledgment of gay stereotypes, and its accurate portrayal of friend groups. The characters do not exist simply to support or bully Simon; they are complex in their own right, with side stories of their own. Simon’s parents are endearingly flawed, and you cannot help but love how much they love Simon. The film doesn’t simplify Simon to his sexuality. He is not only gay – he is funny, a bit awkward, and caring. The film ends with you wanting more of this endearing romance.

Ultimately, Love, Simon is a heartwarming romance that deserves the praise it has been getting. Albertalli has created wonderful characters that you want to be your best friends (except Martin), and they come alive in this film. Support representation. Support art that does it right.

title: Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama: Re-Wrapped – Chance the Rapaper and Jeremih // Album Review
content:
Written by Ela Talu

In the 2016 Christmas season, Chance the Rapper and Jeremih dropped their mixtape Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama but had yet to drop the “Re-Wrapped” version until this holiday season. Chicago’s most talented rapper and R&B hit-maker, respectively, crafted a Christmas mixtape that has a taste of both the present-day hip hop and the traditional tunes to gift the listeners with.

Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama: Rewrapped, composed of a Disc One and Disc Two, has nine tracks in each. Although they are very similar, Disc Two has all the new tracks that are released and Disc One is a reminder for the former mixtape. In both tapes, we hear Jeremih’s tender seductive vocals with Chance’s Chicago referenced and holiday spirited rap verses. The overall sense of the tapes has the typical warmth of gospel and soul with low ends from the artists.

With “Family For,” Chance goes bold with his sincere statements of, “Where they ain’t scared to say the name of the Savior,” through rich vocal harmonies and clean guitar strums to state his perspective on recent political incidents. He also touches on family in tracks like “Held It Down,” again through bold and sincere statements like if anyone touches his family, he won’t hold himself back, and say your “ugly ass family, your great-great grandmammy shoulda used Plan B.” In tracks like “Big Kid Again,” both Chance and Jeremih go festive with the backing up of a children’s choir and state how they try to fulfill their children’s Christmas lists in real life. At parts, some tracks go sentimental, like “One More Cry,” which is dominated with Jeremih’s soulful choruses and Chance’s confessional verses. Within the same track, Chance touches on politics, his family memories, and Biblical influences.

The stand out track is The Jackson Five’s “I Want You Back" influenced “Stranger at the Table,” yet with a piano remix. Chance is again honest with his statements in this track, confessing that “last Christmas was a war zone.” Following the same success is “Shoulda Left You,” in which Chance reminisces on David Bowie and Prince along with Jeremih in the chorus, trying to reject the tearful memories that happened in 2016.

Overall, Merry Christmas Lil’ Mama: Re-Wrapped, with its lyrical and musical attributes, is a reminder of sharing and love throughout the holiday season, brought to you by Chicago’s very own Chance the Rapper and Jeremih.

title: Cory Wong - Cory Wong and The Green Screen Band // Album Review
content:
Written by Sam Celentano 

Cory Wong is a name that should be familiar to any casual Vulfpeck listener, as his name graces the title of the tenth track of their 2016 album The Beautiful Game, and is prominently featured on rhythm guitar in their two most recent releases. However, only referring to Wong as “Vulfpeck’s rhythm guitarist” would be a great disservice to the wonderful library of music and multimedia works he has compiled since 2016. With his new release Cory Wong and The Green Screen Band, Wong lays down an incredible set of musical variety, proving his dominance as a guitarist, songwriter, composer, and videographer.

From the get go we’re confronted with a funky track that not only features Wong’s prowess as a rhythm guitarist, but also enlists the help of a swaggering horn section, and the lush tones of vocalist Antwaun Stanley. As a relatively safe tune that doesn’t extend outside the bounds of 1960s-inspired funk, “Work It Out” seems like the natural choice to start the album off. Though echoes of Curtis Mayfield and James Brown manifest themselves in the beginning of the album, Wong chooses not to pigeonhole himself into the classic funk archetype, and delivers a plethora of varied compositions with their focuses turned to the rhythm section. In the next few songs, we hear a menagerie of tempos and grooves, the inclusion of acoustic instrumentation, and another catchy non-instrumental. This all culminates to distinct break from the rest of the album with the fifth track, “Clouds,” a beautifully rich composition oozing with layers of sound. The band’s lush tone and harmonically complex phrasing helps deliver an intimacy previously unheard in Wong’s music, deepening the range of the album in a manner that both grooves and soothes. The middle of the record seems like the perfect place for this particular brand of tune, an unexpectedly sensitive one that cleanses the auricular palate before diving right back into the funk buffet that is the album’s final five songs.

Cory Wong and The Green Screen Band is a completely cohesive listening experience that engages the listener with its impressive musicianship and inviting jams, appealing to a wide variety of listeners. It is low volume funk so delicious that it will truly make you wonder why Jack Stratton of Vulfpeck has yet to even mention the album anywhere on his many popular social media platforms.
tags: cory wong and the green screen band

title: Red Baraat with The Higgs @ The Satellite (6/29/18) // Show Review
content:
“The South Asian Red Wedding…Celebration is Coming.”

Article by Pam Gwen

Photos and video by Katy Carolyn Ramage

The Earth and The Moon are natural satellites that aren’t easy to miss. THE Satellite, however, is.

“Wait, wait, wait. Siri says we’ve passed it already.”

My best friends and I whip around Silver Lake Boulevard and finally spot the venue through the dim Marquee labeled, “FRI RED BARAAT & THE HIGGS”  The valet driver charges us $5 dollars. Parking, for a bargain? In Los Angeles?! Ahhh, it’s the simple luxuries in life.

I spot a “Dreams of LA: Food and Spirits” sign, but it is an artifact of the past, worn-down and unlit. Today, the Satellite hosts up-and-coming local bands, comedy nights, and eclectic DJ nights from Gay Asstrology (Cancers enter FREE all Cancer season long) to Dance Yourself Clean (EVERY Saturday).

I motion our UCLA Radio giveaway winners to will-call and congratulate them on scoring tickets. On the dance floor, a crowd is swaying in unison to the Orange County cerebral jam band, the Higgs. The 4-piece band: John Lovero on guitar and vocals, Garrett Morris on drums, David Barsky on bass and vocals, and Jesse August Jennings on synth, keyboard, and organ. Named after the Higgs-Boson particle as it unifies a variety of forces. Similarly, the Higgs fuse the forces of progressive and alternative rock, blues, and reggae in their electrifying songs.

Jennings of The Higgs

Jennings is in his own planet, defying gravity with his fingers as he masterfully glides over his set-up. An electric fan blows his hair in an upwards direction towards a retro fluorescent sign labeled “The Higgs” with an astronaut perched on it. The influences of the Grateful Dead, Phish, and Wilco seep through the oscillating sounds of the Satellite. The Higgs grin at each other and bask in the glory of their alluring set.

My friends and I go up the stairs to the second bar and immediately, five of us sardines in the photo booth. After roaring at the comically claustrophobic photos, I peer through the Satellite’s glass wall that reveals the dance floor. I notice the legends of Red Baraat finally piling on stage.

Red Baraat

Sunny Jain, the frontman of Red Baraat, was born of immigrant Punjabi parents. Jain grew up in Rochester, New York which established his framework for music. His mother played Bhajans (in Hindu this means “sharing”), known for their spiritual ideas and melodic ragas (melodic structures for improvisation in Indian music). Sunny’s father constantly banged his Indian banjo and harmonium to classic Bollywood music. His Jainism background was also combined with the Western influence of his sibling’s love for progressive-rock, pop, and hip-hop.

At age 4, Sunny began learning North Indian percussion and rhythm. Sunny played the Indian tabla, but at age 12 he began learning the vocabulary of jazz through idols like Max Roach and Philly Joe Jones. Growing up, Sunny’s teachers encouraged him to drop his Punjabi background and focus on American music theory. Nonetheless, when he began to compose his own music, he knew he wanted to celebrate the inclusivity of his musical backgrounds.

In 2005, Sunny brought his culturally encompassing music to the surface at his own….wedding. He melded North Indian rhythm Bhangra with jazz, rock, hip-hop, and funk along with 30 of his talented musician friends. They performed for Sunny’s baraat. In India and Pakistan, a baraat is a massive marching procession of the groom’s wedding party before they reach the wedding venue. It is a joyous celebration of brass music, singing, stomping, and hand-clapping that can last for 5 hours.

In 2010, Sunny wanted to spread South Asian wedding celebrations to the masses and thus, Red Baraat was born (his mustache, however, was born in 2012). The band name came to fruition because to Sunny, red is a symbol of love, energy, and revolution. They have inspired conservative elderly in walkers in Pennsylvania to get up and dance. Furthermore, they have split their audiences in halves for epic dance battles. The band has cited inspirations from Primus, Miles Davis, Flying Lotus, Gogol Bordello, and Gurdas Maan. NPR has asked Red Baraat to perform for their Tiny Desk Concert series twice and has dubbed them “the best party band in years.” Red Baraat has performed for Obama at the White House, Bonnaroo, the Paraolympics in London, globalFEST, and an exorbitant amount of South Asian weddings.

At the Satellite, Red Baraat begins with chaal rhythm in “Punjabi Wedding Song (Balle Balle)” off of Chaal Baby. The band’s sonic palate is bewitching. The 50-pound gold sousaphone Kenneth Bentley is breathing life and bass into is enchanting. The gigantic sousaphone looks as if it could be its own satellite, its vibrations orbiting the atmosphere of the stage. Unlike Desiigner in his song Panda, Sunny is yelling his version of “rrrrRRAAA” that I find loveable. Full of passion, Sunny freely parades on the stage with a dhol strapped on his shoulder, decorated by white rope and a plethora of black tassels. I have never been privy to a dhol and my initiation to it is mind-blowing. On the double-headed drum, Sunny crafts a tight stampeding pulsation with two uniquely curved sticks.

On June 29th, Red Baraat released their latest album, Sound the People, influenced by the South Asian diaspora. Recorded at Studio G in Brooklyn, New York, the album is Red Baraat’s battle cry – written weeks after Trump’s inauguration. The patient percussion of “Ghadar Machao” produces goosebumps on my arms. Derived from Arabic, Ghadar means “revolution.” I feel as if I’m at a protest, ready and determined to line-up and congregate. My arms vigorously fist pump to Sonny Singh’s beckoning voice as he sings in Punjabi, to English, and even in Spanish. Red Baraat’s candor on the political climate invigorates the crowd to joyously mourn and mindfully release anger. “Ghadar Machao” is a superb folk anthem of immigrant solidarity.

Tears flow down my cheek, but I wipe them away as the dynamic beginning of “Hey Jamalo” off of Sound the People begins. Its cadence is trance-inducing and forces every single person in the room to dance. Hips are surging, feet are stomping, arms are flailing, and there’s headbanging everywhere. The blending of Sonny Singh’s trumpet and Jonathon Haffner’s soprano saxophone is consuming alongside Chris Eddleton’s explosive drumming. The elements of North Indian Bhangra, New Orleans brass, and ska-punk in “Hey Jamalo” obliterates every box Sunny was advised to conform to as a young musician.

Rays of electric blue light gleams on Jonathan Goldberger during his psychedelic rock guitar shredding on “Moray Gari Suno” off of Sound the People. The track is an homage to 1960’s Chutney music from Trinidad with flavors of Indian and Caribbean music. The charismatic synergy and variety of Sunny, Sonny, Jonathan, Kenneth, Jonathon, and Chris’ personalities permeate the raw energy of Red Baraat. Their individual expertise as a cohesive unit cultivates the visceral sonic textures and booming improvisations of their stellar performance.

Red Baraat falls silent and Sunny invites two personalities from the crowd for a dance-battle on stage. The dancers in the center front shy away to the corners, but a courageous fan in a green shirt gets on stage. A minute or two passes and worry falls on Sunny’s face. In that sliver of a moment, I knew it was time for me to put down my notebook and jump into battle. My pulse raced as I stared into the many eyeballs shooting at me from down below.

I closed my eyes and breathed into the present moment, “It’s a Friday night with no homework, work, responsibilities, and worries. You’re on stage with Red Baraat. You. Got. This.” I opened my eyes to all my best friends, partner, and the crowd cheering me on. In a flash, the raucous of “Shruggy Ji” embroiders itself into my veins and overtakes the entirety of my ligaments. I stare into my opponent’s eyes and we both laugh. The members of Red Baraat are smiling and parading around the stage. Accompanied by their presence on stage, I feel as if I’m floating and in a utopian dimension of ecstasy and triumph.

Pam Gwen, a dancing queen, with Red Baraat

As I disembark on stage and reenergize, Red Baraat is instantly revitalized and to the next song. Sunny powerfully grabs the mic and announces, “Now this next track is Punjabi bluegrass. The original track is “Gora Mukra” meaning “fair-skinned face”, but we’ve inverted it to “Kala Mukra” meaning “dark-skinned face.” It is an act of defiance against glamorizations of white skin, subjecting women’s potential to only marriage, and a bunch of other shit like that. Let’s party.” “

Ingrained with a colonial mentality growing up, I was adamant about scrubbing my brown skin off with papaya soap to achieve the fair-skin my Filipino culture idolized. In the past year, I have found that locating myself in my Filipinx heritage has helped me formulate who I can become. “Kala Mukra” is my hymn of postcolonial consciousness. Within each measure, I feel an inner emotional and spiritual catharsis.

“Kala Mukra” features Ali Sethi and is murderous and frenetic. The track’s preamble is Sonny, Jonathon, and Kenneth’s feverish trumpets, the heartbeat is Chris and Sunny’s frantic percussion, and Jonathan’s spiraling Afro-Carribean groove riff is the comedown.

As I look around the variety of beautiful skin colors around me, I find healing. As the bridge of “Apna Punjab Hove” begins, my friend, who hasn’t been dancing much tonight, begins tearing up the dance floor. My friends and I know that he is a professional Indian wedding dancer and we go berserk – we’ve never seen him dance in the flesh before. As we circle around him, a woman in a kurti and another in a blue pin-up dress begin doing classical Indian dance moves. To their left, two men pair up and do Bhangra, a Punjabi-style dance. From beginning to end, Red Baraat puts its crowd into a loving trance, lulling us into hedonistic dancing for what seems like an eternity. Their infectious and magnetizing energy is an experience in itself. A sense of world peace is exposure to Red Baraat’s revolutionary and humanitarian virtuosity.

title: Preoccupations @ The Echo (5/17/18) // Show Review
content:
Photos and article by Tara Kazimi

To attempt to explain the malleable quality and mind shifting abilities Preoccupations, formerly known as Viet Cong (a name abandoned due to fan backlash), possesses does little for their character when compared to the scenes they enact in real life.

On the morning of May 15th Preoccupations woke up in San Francisco to find their van, trailer, and all of their gear/merch stolen. To make matters worse, this was the second time that week that they were robbed, just after re-buying new gear and continuing on the road again. While unfortunate it is to lose almost everything that they were traveling with, to add to the circumstance is the fact that they still had multiple shows lined up. Two of which were set in two days time at The Echo. As heartbroken as fans would be to hear a show cancellation, most would understand given the position that Preoccupations was put in, a position generating a far more broken heart and deflated spirit in the band themselves. However, as dismal as that week was, it didn’t disfigure their character nor detain them from performing two lively sold-out shows at The Echo and whatever came after. No matter how defeating they may have felt internally, they didn’t allow it to take over their persona or work.

On tour for their latest record, New Material, Preoccupations took the stage at The Echo calmly and rather uneventfully. As a group of somewhat middle-aged men who just had all their tour belongings stolen, you could read the past couple of days in their eyes. They started off the set with “Select Your Drone”, slow and steady, but as the song progressed so did they. At least to the onlookers, it was evident how transformative and meditative this night was aligned to become for Preoccupations. They demanded a release and this was going to be it for them. As is, their music already is blissfully and aggressively cathartic, and that night it was more medicinal than ever. Preoccupations are known for their sexy dark post-punk sound, which easily radiated throughout the space everyone was in, almost constructing this consuming tunnel vision mystique over the band.

It was relatively obvious how fatigued they all were, quite often breaking for beer followed by water, as any responsible adult would. However, their ability to push through and still perform at such a taxing level was commendable. They were as engaged as ever not only with themselves but the music as well. Although on tour for New Material they only played “Disarray” and “Decompose”, with most of the set coming from the Preoccupations and Viet Cong records, which produced the most chaos out of the crowd. “Death” in particular, their closing song, brought together the entire venue together in a rigorous entranced episode no matter how divided the older and younger crowds were. Even the frontman of Moaning got himself mixed up in the pit during the repetitive portal portions of it. For the first time in the night, some of the crowd closed their eyes along with the band to also enter the meditative dream daze trance as one, soon to emerge as slightly more level versions of themselves. By the end of the night, everyone in that room that shared that experience felt a little bit lighter, a little bit more whole, and a little bit more connected, all of which could never have been achieved without the metamorphic abilities of Preoccupations.

If you would like to donate to their cause you can use this link: https://www.gofundme.com/preoccupationsgearfund

title: Vagabon @ Bootleg Theater (5/9/18) // Show Review
content:
Photos and article by Jennifer Liaw

Laetitia Tamko, the unique voice behind Vagabon, is an indie rock singer-songwriter from New York who weaves together songs invoke an authenticity and vulnerability which is only amplified in her live performances.

The Main Stage at Bootleg Theater was the perfect setting for this performance. Remnants of a vintage projection theater meant that there were scaffolded theater seats in the back third of the room for those that wanted to relax with a drink and soak in the show, but the option to stand and sway softly to the guitar and see Vagabon’s expressive facials up close was available as well.

Though her stature is short and her frame small, Vagabon holds the center of the stage with a strong and solid stance, guitar firmly in hand. The band starts off with her more rock-heavy songs like “Cold Apartment” and “Minneapolis”, which are backed by her bassist and drummer and build up to powerful chords that convey the emotions behind the simple and raw lyrics. Most of the songs on her LP, Infinite Worlds, are characterized by these extremely personal and poetic but sparse lyrics that span from talking about her identity, to being short, calling herself a “small fish” on “The Embers.”

When she starts to transition into the softer, acoustic songs, she commands the stage with warm, full-bodied voice, which holds a stark contrast to her talking voice. When she talks to the audience, she sounds like a familiar friend, a voice and inflection we’re all used to hearing. But once she starts to sing, there is a new shape to her voice – she opens her mouth wide to allow for more resonance and a huskier but fuller sound emerges to match the rawness of the songs she composes, really embodying her inner punk spirit. “Fear & Force” has me swaying along to the soft acoustic arpeggios of her guitar, while during “The Embers,” the audience shyly sings along to the refrain, “You’re a shark that hates everything,” until she encourages us to join us in the loud and free ending of the song.

Vagabon is a talented instrumentalist, lyricist, producer, and vocalist whose work ranges from bright punk to electronic refrains and emotional ballads. Her work is personal and raw, artistic and expressive, and her stage presence and live performance reflect all of these aspects. Overall a great show to be a part of, and I look forward to her future projects.

title: Interview with City Girl
content:
Interviewed by Jennifer Liaw

album art for Time Falls Like Moonlight, by vickisigh

City Girl is a rising LA-based lo-fi/chillhop producer that incorporates a lot of soft piano and guitar intertwined with electronic beats and vocals. Starting out on Bandcamp and Soundcloud only 10 months ago, they now have three albums out on Spotify, the latest being Time Falls Like Moonlight, released in April.

Tell us a bit about yourself. Where did you grow up? What was growing up in that city like?

I grew up in California close to LA. To be honest once I found music I never really went outside. Before that I was just playing video games and watching cartoons. I guess the internet was more of where I grew up, as opposed to any geographical place.

What music did you listen to a lot growing up? What were your favorite artists back in like middle school, for example?

In middle school it was John Frusciante, all day everyday. Something about his guitar playing really inspired me. It was soulful and beautiful and just felt perfect, like every note was exactly where it should be. In high school my music taste exploded, but John Frusciante was the majority of the first music I learned and played.

Tell us a little about how City Girl first got started.

I uploaded on the train somewhere between my apartment and you 10 months ago on Soundcloud and just emailed a bunch of Youtube channels that were taking submissions. Aurarian music accepted that first release and put it out on Youtube and got the ball rolling so City Girl could get some attention back when it was only 10-20 followers.

How did you come up with the name City Girl?

To be honest, its in honor of “City Girl” by Kevin Shields from the Lost In Translation soundtrack. I’m a huge My Bloody Valentine fan and that song of his is just so amazing.

When did you first start making music? How did you get into it, and how did you first learn how to produce a beat?

I got into guitar playing when I was 12 or so. I just played because my older brother had a guitar. I took it and just Googled how to play guitar and taught myself songs and chords. It was the most fun I’d ever had. It felt so special. I didn’t start producing for like another seven years though. I would just record onto a Tascam tape recorder and jam with friends in garages. I had friends who made lofi beats waay back when it was like CULP and Simo and Onra and john wayne and stuff, but I never got into it, I was more focused on improvising and expanding my musical repertoire in a more performance-focused way.

Are there any instruments that you would like to try out incorporating into your music that you haven’t tried yet?

I want live drums but I live in an apartment. If I could record drums that would be so cool, since I play drums too and I miss it badly.

Where do you usually record your music? Describe your studio space to us.

It’s about five feet no joke from my bed haha. It’s a desk and a midi keyboard and some guitars and other little instruments like the melodica. I have speakers and an old mic. It’s super cozy, my bedroom at my apartment is just covered with vickisigh’s art, like everywhere you look it’s just cute sexy ladies in pastel colors, I love it.

vickisigh’s (Vicki Tsai) artwork, from her instagram

How would you describe the lo-fi/chillhop genre and subculture to someone who’s never been exposed to it?

It’s just a bunch of people who love making music on their computers, and to be honest only one percent is unique and actually worth your time, but the same goes for all genres, 99 percent of it is just not that good. I would be more specific but at this point lofi stands for so so much that you can’t really go much further than that.

What do you think of the lo-fi hip hop/chillhop genre in general? It’s really popular right now what with the YouTube 24hr lo-fi hip hop studying beats stream and the Spotify lo-fi hip hop studying beats playlists as well… There’s literally probably thousands of really similar chillhop producers on SoundCloud… does that ever make you feel swallowed up, in a sense? Or does it feel more like a really large community? How do you try to stand out as an artist among all these other producers?

It’s a tough question to answer, because you can go from quickly, quickly to in love with a ghost and still call it lofi if you want to. These artists share playlists together and Youtube mixes. Who’s to say quickly, quickly isn’t just jazz? Who’s to say in love with a ghost isn’t just electronic music? It’s not so much a genre as it is a movement of instrumental music becoming the focus itself rather than the singer/rapper. Staying unique seems simple to me as I grew up playing and learning music by ear, so I just follow my interests/inspiration and play whatever seems cool.

Which artists would you say are your biggest inspirations or that you’re just blown away by and really admire within your genre? How about outside of your genre?

Well in love with a ghost stands out, like most peeps I found them on Youtube. All the tracks from Let’s Go and Healing by them are amazing. Just super cool textures and melodies, really lovely and creative music. Kupla is amazing too, he’s an amazing piano player, all of his music is great. Outside of my genre I’d say Sheena Ringo, especially her album Kalk Samen Kuri no Hana - it’s pretty much game over, this album does everything better in every regard imaginable than any other music I’ve heard. Don’t know if you can get access to it in US tho, the copyright lawyers are hard at work on this one.

What artist outside of the lo-fi hip hop genre would you really really love to collaborate with? Can you describe the kind of track you’d want to make with them?

With anyone, well shit Beyoncé right? I mean she’s the best vocalist alive next to Frank Ocean. I would just want to make something really beautiful, some In Rainbows type stuff.

Being an artist based out of Bandcamp/Soundcloud in this day means a lot of your career is kind of born out of the internet. What are your favorite and least favorite parts about the internet and spending so much time on the internet/interacting with people on the internet/sharing yourself through the internet?

I love the internet because I can share whatever I want when I want. I don’t feel a lot of pressure because I don’t have any personal accounts on social media and never have, I always just read a lot of books and listened to records and stuff. I’m sure some people think it’s mysterious or whatever that I never cared for social media, instead opting to just read Sartre or watch old movies, but nowadays all I do is make music and play Skyrim so it’s all good. The internet gives me access to all that goodness so I can find it offline.

What are your top five favorite artists right now?

Tom Misch, Swell, quickly quickly, in love with a ghost, and Sam Gellaitry

What are your top five favorite female artists?

Sheena Ringo, Beyoncé, Aivi Tran, MISO (from club eskimo - a collective including Crush, Dean, offonoff, 2xxx!, millic, and more), and tiffi.

Do you have a favorite spot in LA that you wouldn’t want to share with anyone else?

Wherever YAYAYI and JALENTUNA happen to be any given saturday night in k-town is a pretty special vibe that honestly can’t be shared even if I wanted it to be. God there was this $5 flat pho place on Western Ave. that was run by this old couple but it closed like 5 years ago, that was the best place ever and it straight up was ALWAYS empty, no one ate there. I think it was like Pho 36 haha one of those LA pho places that has a random number after it.

What are some things that you really enjoy doing for yourself? When you need to take a day for yourself, what are things that you’ll usually do?

Skyrim is a go-to. It’s usually video games but a lot of times it’s just making music. You gotta understand music is like an addiction to me. I never stop thinking about sounds and I feel uneasy not making music.

So we know you like video games… what are some of your favorite video games of all time? Do you have any funny anecdotes from playing games online with strangers?

Favorite of all time is Psychonauts. Such a creative game and Scott Campbell’s art is the absolute bee’s knees. Right now my favorite is Skyrim as mentioned. I love RPG and adventure games, the immersion gets me good. I loved games growing up, played anything. I have a lot of anecdotes about gaming but I honestly can’t think of just one. Haha well when Xbox Live came out online gaming was brand new and I remember my dad getting on the headset asking people not to cuss (since I was just a kid) and THEY STOPPED. They were like “Oh sorry dude we didn’t know there were kids playing we will keep the cursing to a minimum.” Can you imagine that nowadays? It would never happen. That shit still blows my mind.

Do you play Fortnite? If so, what are your thoughts on it?

I played Fortnite with Chance, thrash, and Maru the other night and I hate it so much lol. The vibe is so terrible, the aesthetic makes me want to barf it’s so ugly. That was the only time I’ve really played it and it hasn’t been on my mind, the itch isn’t there so I guess no hype for me.

What are your favorite K-Pop bands or members?

SNSD was the OG. That old video of Sooyoung going “OP-EHHHH! OP-EH EH EH EH EH” lol that shit is so funny. I don’t follow it much anymore but MISO is the queen right now, she’s the best. I watched all of Jessica and Krystal when it came out too, that’s good stuff.

Ok I also saw on Twitter that you have a cat… tell us about your cat!

Ah yes, Seymour, the Russian Blue. He is a very handsome and beautiful man. He is a shadow in the night. Every part of him is gray except his lil tongue which is pink and his eyes which are green. He lives at my parents house so I don’t see him except at holidays, but he is my good soft boy. I think of him very often.

art from Snow Rose, by vickisigh

What would you say is your favorite track that you’ve produced?

“Anything Like Her” with tiffi is prob my fav. Tiffi is so cool and that song is really different sounding from other City Girl songs so I think it’s cool.

What is your favorite track off of Time Falls Like Moonlight?

“Sunset Lullaby” is probably my favorite. The second half with the acoustic and electric guitar just feels really special.

What was your inspiration for Time Falls Like Moonlight?

I make so much music, the inspiration doesn’t really ever make sense, I am inspired by everything in each moment, I am inspired by my own passion to make music. Not understanding what is going on is really important to how I work, it makes things exciting. I just want the music to make people feel loved and understood for who they are, that there is a purpose for them, a life they can live and be loved in.

When you make songs, are they ever about specific things, people, or events in your life?

Not really, it’s just all my emotions sort of bleeding into the computer. I don’t know if I could write about any particular thing, but I do enjoy imagining lots of people and situations to my music after I made it. Like oh this sounds like Moonlight Hill (from Kingdom Hearts) or this sounds like a tender look from someone or this sounds like a lonely plaza in the middle of some city. It’s all free and open to interpretation.

“Winter Fields” is one of my favorite tracks of yours… mostly because of the lovely violin part by mklachu. It’s so dreamy and kind of reminds me of some of my favorite Ryuichi Sakamoto pieces, too. Can you tell us a little about this track?

It’s random but the track started as a like, flex? I was watching Joji’s Youtube aliases and god they are just awful I mean like him fucking with people and being super lewd and nasty I hate it but I was watching it anyway to like fry my brain and I thought it would be fun to make a nasty trap beat that would fit with his videos and I made “Winter Fields” (I know it doesn’t make sense at all). The song slowly got more romantic as I added piano layers the next day and then mklachu tweeted at me out of nowhere and I asked her to play over it and yeah it’s just what happens when you work on music all the time, everything going on makes it into the song.

Another one of my favorites is “Chateau Fountain.” I love the slow buildup, and then the talking portion that kind of just emerges and goes into like an acoustic drop… ahhhh.. I was wondering where that talking portion is from actually. The guy is like, “Take the flowers,” and the girl is like “I’m all right!” and it sounds like an uncomfortable struggle…a common pattern in society where… men force women to do things regardless of their autonomy or feelings (ha ha). Does it have any significance to the meaning behind the track? What were your reasons for choosing to put that particular snippet in this track? It’s interesting because for me, I think I’m more sensitive than the average person to these kind of power dynamics or like…oppression against women in all aspects of daily interactions or media that I consume, so when I listen to this track it’s like a soft buildup to this point of conflict that is kind of grating, but then evolves back into a calming acoustic melody. That’s personal, of course, but it’s interesting.

DUDE YOU HAVEN’T SEEN ATONEMENT? Omg that movie is so incredible. It’s James McAvoy talking to Kiera Knightley and they have all this tension because they love each other but they can’t be together and ooooooooooooooooooh it’s so good. Their love is so beautiful and honest but it’s injected with all this tension and conflict from society and politics. I felt that snippet fit so perfectly into the emotions of the song, it’s one of the few few times I’ve used movie snippets because I felt it actually added to the track in a creative way.

How do you think you’ve evolved from the first songs you put out on Bandcamp/Soundcloud, and your first album Loveless Shadows, to now?

I know a lot more about mixing, especially with bass and drums. I try to make more upbeat stuff now, but honestly I still end up making a lot of downtempo stuff. I know a lot more jazz piano than I did before so that’s nice too.

What are some artists that you think are really underrated that you’d like to give a shoutout to and encourage people to check out?

frenesi is criminally underrated.

What are your goals for City Girl for the next few years?

Just put out an incredible amount of music and keep building the world of City Girl. I want people to feel relaxed and loved and understood when they listen to City Girl. Honestly I just want to expand the harmonic and melodic depth of City Girl, I want people to head bump and cry in the same track, I want to find that fusion of beautiful and funky that all great music has for me.

I know you just released an album, but besides that, do you have any upcoming events or projects your fans should be looking forward to?

I have another album finished already, but with the way vickisigh (I won’t put out something without her art on it) works it won’t be out until probably another two-three months. So by the time that comes out I’ll have another album done and so on the process repeats. So just look forward to a new album every two-three months for as long as I’m rockin in the free world.

art from Loveless Shadows, by vickisigh

Check out City Girl’s latest album, Time Falls Like Moonlight, out on Spotify, Soundcloud, and Bandcamp! They also have two other albums, Snow Rose from December, and Loveless Shadows from August that are equally as beautiful. Follow them on Soundcloud for all their music updates and on Twitter for all their promo updates!

title: The Garden @ The Regent (3/30/18) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Tara Kazimi

Amidst the surprisingly vacant and relatively quiet back-streets of Main Street in DTLA, the Regent Theater stood out vibrantly given the night that lay ahead. An exuberant cult following was en route to envelope the theater anticipating one of the most stimulating, thrilling lineups The Regent has encountered in a while.

“That’s right kids, plaid suits are back,” affirmed Shattered Faith’s frontman Spencer Bartsch to the crowd far below his years. The night commenced with a first wave So-Cal punk gem, whose drummer also happened to be The Garden twins’ dad, Steve Shears. The younger crowd seemed to thoroughly enjoy their presence and admire their obvious experience even though this was probably their first time hearing them. They performed their notable songs like “I Love America,” “Another Day Passes,” and “Rise & Fall”, generating a mosh pit for most of them. Despite their somewhat lacking in popularity during their prime and inconsistent frequency in the scene, their dark, gritty, melodic, and genuine sound proved eminent that night.

Soon after Cowgirl Clue, formerly known as Wu-Wu, took the stage. Ashley Calhoun never steps on a stage without mesmerizing the audience with not only her carefully constructed songs, but also her dynamic fit. This time she decided that a pair of cherry red go-go boots and a matching patent leather coat would suit the night well. The crowd immediately took to her as she has been a regular with The Garden as of late, not that that has had any effect on how the crowd perceives her. Her music stands for itself and anyone that comes in contact with it can realize its worth and the magic spun within. Her dreamy vibrating persona and electric bubble-gum 90s sound mixed with a lick of gentle dark pop filled the crowd with a warm tingly sensation only she can provide. “Cherry Jubilee” and “Limelite” seemed to strike a considerably inspired and exciting note within the audience as they bounced around in dance. Nothing compares to Calhoun’s own refined and charming dance moves though, completing the unconditional ethereal ambiance that seeps out of her pores.

Following Cowgirl Clue, the classic Tijuana Panthers took the stage. The delicacy lingering in the air was soon replaced by a volatile blast driven by the garage surf rock Tijuana Panthers are known so well for. While the entire set was full of high energy, not only from the performers but also the onlooking crowd, “Creature of The Night” shook the theater in a certain elevated way. Not even the most distracted of fans in that moment could admit that the time-honored bass line didn’t jolt them out of their stream of consciousness.

The night soon began to draw to a close as the final and most anticipated band emerged from backstage, The Garden. The crowd immediately erupted as the intricate and unique twins began their famously intense set. As soon as the phrase, “You want the scoop?” exploded from the speakers, the crowd shot back with as equal a volume, “Yeah I got it baby!” without a second’s delay. It was as if the pulsating fans had practiced day and night for weeks prior just to nail that exchange right on the head. From there on forward the crowd had officially detonated, and was sent into a chaotic frenzy. The Garden has created a name for their own eclectic universe, Vada Vada, and that night not a single person was excluded from that world. While Wyatt pounded his way across the stage and Fletcher jumped off of his drum-kit, all eyes were on them, refusing to miss even a second of their performance. While known for the quick punk roots in which they started, their set mostly consisted of newer songs off their latest records Mirror Might Steal Your Charm and haha. No matter what song they did play, no one was able to stand still, whether they wanted to or not. Songs like “All Smiles Over Here :)” and “Call The Dogs Out” were great examples of how even though The Garden has diverged from their roots a bit, their fans adapt and find new parts of them they never knew they even would like. Even though they chose to leave the jester-esque face paint at home, their fans didn’t care in the slightest, knowing the sporadic atmosphere they created for themselves isn’t defined by a small unusual and unique embellishment of the face. The Garden are authentic in anything they do, and seem to not be physically able to disappoint.

title: Without Warning – 21 Savage, Offset, and Metro Boomin // Album Review
content:
Written by Ela Talu

Dropped over Halloween without any warning, the album Without Warning brings together two of Atlanta’s most wanted rappers, 21 Savage and Offset of Migos, along with the multi-platinum producer Metro Boomin. The trio came together to give the message that this Halloween season, bad guys will be the winners. The lead vocals, 21 Savage and Offset, may seem to be artists of different styles through their different approaches, with 21 Savage sounding almost numb with a hostile and cold-blooded delivery, and Offset with exhilarating and well-measured meters. But their differences somewhat complement each other to create this fierce album.

While 21’s verses are very uniform, concise and direct, without any change in its melodic tone, Offset adds a touch of density to the overall tone of the tracks. They open up the album with “Ghostface Killers,” an homage to Ghostface Killah, a member of the legendary hip hop group Wu-Tang Clan, to start off the album with a bold statement of why nobody should mess with them, along with Travis Scott. This is also the first time that these three rappers are involved on the same track.

The horror of the album is overly exaggerated, with the rappers as goons of a dangerous lifestyle of Ghostface Killers and Mad Stalkers. Offset makes it even more fun with the platinum track “Ric Flair Drip,” named after the WWE Hall of Famer and 16-World Champion Ric Flair, showing off his lavish and wild lifestyle. Throughout the track, Offset uses Ric Flair’s trademark shout “whoo” as an ad-lib. On the other hand, in “My Choppa Hate N****s,” 21 Savage references the violence in the streets and his personal experiences around gang wars, which adds to the horror theme of the album.

To support the rappers, Metro Boomin finds a balance in the beats, supporting the dark tone with ghostly beats and also complementing them with melodies full of adrenaline and hype. In “Rap Saved Me,” Metro Boomin manages highs and lows between Offset and 21 Savage’s verses respectively and uses the drums so powerfully in the transition that they elevate every stanza. In every beat drop, one feels the sudden attack that is approaching them.

Without Warning is overall an album that never loses its intention in the Halloween theme. It seems short with only 10 tracks, but is very concise in its verses and beats to give the listeners both the high spirits and the cold shakes. The surprising collaboration that came very suddenly to our attention definitely brings the satisfaction.

title: Tove Styrke @ The Belasco Theater (10/15/18) // Show Review
content:
article and photographs by Gomi Zhou

The decade of 2010s has been a wild ride for pop music. While the American pop scene is relatively uniform and homogeneous, European pop artists (in my opinions) have definitely experimented with way more different pop elements. Incoming from Sweden, Tove Styrke remains as a breath of fresh air in the global pop swirl.

In her now almost-ten-years-long journey as a pop artist, Styrke has always been experimenting with various sub-branches in pop including Euro-disco, synth-pop, and electro-pop; though, her newest album, Sway, can easily be fit into the branch of dream pop. Based on my understanding of Styrke prior to the show, she is definitely someone who has a clear vision of where she’s heading, and, she’s completely fearless about heading towards it. She has all the potentials to become a global sensation, and her sharp, confident personality definitely shines through from her songs and videos.  

After the illusion-like, cinematic set of the opening artist Au/Ra, the crew brought out a full stage of rose lights. Instantly, the crowd was ignited by the allegory to Sway even before the roses had ever flickered. Shortly after that, Styrke struck onto the stage as the roses started to shine through in all the prettiest pastel colors. Dressed in a shiny black suit, topped with a playful “TOVE STYRKE” logo cowboy hat, “Borderline” somehow actually sounded like a Western cowboy song at that moment. Following the first song, she continued to perform a few more jazzy, upbeat numbers such as “Mistakes”, “Ego” and “On A Level”. Instead of performing songs purely from her latest record, Styrke provided tunes from both Sway and her last album from 2015, Kiddo. By this point, it is clear to me that even though her musical style is always progressing, there are certain consistent elements that would always get preserved. Even though her lyrics are not always sunshine and rainbow, but her music always delivers comfort and encouragement to people who might not be easily understood (introverts, LGBTQ+, etc.).

Throughout the night, Styrke had barely ever stopped interacting with fans. She kept making eye contacts with different people in the front rows while constantly pacing from one side of the stage to another. Her audience on the other hand, responded with enthusiasm by dancing and singing along with the artist. “Wow you guys are singing louder than me!”, she said to her fans with a bright smile on her face during a slower song called “On The Low”. The way Styrke interacted with fans was very casual and genuine, just like many other European pop artists who I had seen before. Perhaps there’s something about a smaller, more intimate crowd in a foreign place that can just warm the hearts of both the artists and the fans to a completely different level.

I gradually realized that even though the whole show had an upbeat energy, it only got more and more intense as it went on. By the time Styrke started singing the last few songs, the crowd was so energetic that everyone seemed to be boiling with happiness. Many fans were holding up signs, while others were now dancing with their new acquaintances. The energy of the venue turned the show into that of a massive teen party, except filled with people from all ages and all backgrounds. And Tove Styrke herself was not just a performer, she was part of the crowd. After the show, many fans stayed after to meet Styrke by the merch stand. Most of them were holding roses that Styrke threw into the crowd during the last song. The meet and greet line lasted for more than an hour, but even so, Styrke greeted every fan with her fairy-like smile. I began to believe that the roses are some sort of symbols. With her humble gratitude and willingness to explore, there is so much more to be expected from Tove Styrke.

title: Interview with Hot Flash Heat Wave
content:
article by Ariana Momnoon

August 14th, 2018 @ The Echoplex

Hot Flash Heat Wave and Summer Salt just played The Echoplex, and it was soooo so sweet. High schoolers dressed in their coolest fits, friendly moshes, and creamy tunes filled The Echoplex last Tuesday. We were lucky enough to chat with some of the members of Hot Flash Heath Wave, check out the lil interview below <3 

photograph by Maly Mann

UCLA Radio: So who are you!? Where are you from?

HFHW: We’re Hot Flash Heat Wave and we’re from Davis, California.


You guys just played Outsidelands, how was that?

We mess with Outsidelands very hard. It was awesome.  


What is your current state of mind?

Stoked / Spicy


If you could do anything else besides making music, what would that be?

Probably doing graphic design. / Farming goats, I love goat milk.


What’s next for yall?

Keep on touring, making more music, trying to create every day. We’re excited.

title: Strong Girl Do Bong Soon // TV Review
content:
by Emily Pitcher

In a Korean culture of abusive relationships, Strong Girl Do Bong Soon aims to flip the power dynamic through empowering female strength. This is the first K-drama I have watched, and it surprised me with its ridiculous humor and giddy romance.

Before watching Strong Girl Do Bong Soon, I dismissed K-dramas as being too soap opera like – I had seen the television screens of my parents who watched Chinese dramas, and the number of tears and people dying seemed absurd. Only, I was proven wrong with how refreshing and lovable the characters were, as well as the way the show handled the responsibilities of power, specifically the pressure to use it for good.

The plot: Our heroine Do Bong-soon has superhuman strength, and she becomes the bodyguard of Min-hyuk, the obnoxious CEO of esteemed video game company Ainsoft. She also works with Guk-Doo, a police officer, to solve a series of kidnapping cases. She has to juggle these two opposing conflicts in her life while working out her feelings for these two men.
