The good: While I cannot deny that simply making a female main character have extreme physical strength isn’t the pinnacle of feminism, I cannot deny that I wasn’t rooting for her while she was proving herself to men who dismissed her. Bong Soon holds all of the power, from navigating crime to her romantic relationships, and I loved seeing such an undeniably strong heroine. Bong Soon is adorable, and you cannot help but fall for her the same way Min Hyuk does, which is giggling and falling to the floor in joy. She may be physically strong, but she also lives her daily life with compassion and a desire to enforce justice.

Min-Hyuk is wonderfully feminine, from crying over comic books to his adoration of Bong Soon. With overly masculine depictions of men in mainstream media, I loved seeing a character the complete opposite, especially as the central love interest. He was fascinated with her confidence and forwardness – he accepts her for who she is, for all of the trouble she brings, and that is a sentiment to admire. Their chemistry is squeal-inducing.

The bad: The show mocks the LGBT community – not overtly, but enough for it to be an issue. Gay characters are a caricature of flamboyancy, as seen in the Team One leader. Furthermore, domestic abuse is treated lightly; Bong Soon’s mother is supposed to be a comedic character in how she mistreats everyone, but her tiger mother nature is too extreme at times. Bong Soon’s father is powerless to her abuse.

As the show progresses, unnecessary side stories pop up and detract from all of the good of the series with how much screen time they take up. The real charm of this show is the changing relationship between the main characters – these minor characters simply cannot attract the same attention.

Going along with my expectations of K-dramas, the sheer cheesiness and overdramatization are too much at times. I had to continually suspend my disbelief at how things occurred simply to further than the plot but made no sense in the grand scheme.

As a whole, Strong Girl Do Bong Soon is a delightful yet occasionally problematic K-drama that I would recommend watching. While certain issues cannot be ignored, this rom-com deserves the praise it has been getting.

title: UCLA Radio’s 2018 NBA Finals Predictions
content:
Members of UCLA Radio’s sports department weigh in on this year’s NBA Finals, answering the tough questions, like…

1. Who’s going to win…Warriors or Cavs? And in how many games?
2. Why do you think they’ll win?
3. What will be the “X-factor” in the series?
4. And who will be the series MVP?

Gabriel Cabrera

1. Warriors in 6
2. Four all-stars on the team vs. one legend on the other side. Like they say, 3 heads (+1) are better than one.
3. Curry
4. Curry

Spencer Weissman

1. Warriors in 4
2. The Warriors have the better players surrounding their main guys. Curry and KD with Klay and Draymond are much better than Lebron and Love (if he is healthy) with Jeff Green and Tristan Thompson. Don’t expect any game to be in single digits. Add in fact Ty Lue is the worst coach to ever win a title and Kerr is the best coming out of half this will not be fun to watch.
3. Iggy and Love if neither is healthy is a wash. For Cavs to stand a chance or get a game need Love to be back and Iggy to be out the whole series.
4. Kevin Durant

Isaiah Benson

1. Warriors in 5
2. Cavs don’t have the defensive or offensive stamina to keep up with Golden Stats high powered offense. The Cavs may get lucky and win one game but the later the series goes on the more worn down LeBron will get and therefore the less effective the Cavs offense will be.
3. Klay Thompson will play his best series ever.
4. Kevin Durant

Sahej Verma

1. Golden State. Wrapped up in 5.
2. Steph will kill the Cavs; LeBron will be double teamed or Money Green will be enough. Kevin Love will miss a few games with an injury.
3. Nick Young secures the games coming off the bench.
4. Steph Curry

Tyler Roope

1. Warriors in 6
2. Lebron can only carry a team so far. Without Love early, they’ll fall back, probably go down two games. After that, it’ll go back and forth with Cavs and warriors wins, with the Warriors taking it in 6. However, Lebron still pulls out two forty point games.
3. Klay Thompson
4. Steph Curry

Tyler Gordon

1. Warriors in 6
2. Don’t get me wrong, I want the Cavs, but the warriors are WAY too stacked for LeBron to carry the Cavs to a Finals win. The Warriors have so many weapons offensively, that I don’t think the Cavs can stop. Lebron needs his help to be playing well because as we all know, as great as Lebron is, this game is a TEAM sport.
3. Curry. I can see Lebron and Durant battling head-to-head, but if Curry is firing on all cylinders, the warriors become very tough to beat.
4. KD. Amidst all the hate, I foresee him shining at the MVP spot.

James Shippy

1. Warriors in 5
2. Let’s be honest there isn’t a human being on this planet that will pick the Cavs to win. I would love nothing more than to see a competitive series but the Cavs (really just LeBron) are outnumbered here. What the Warriors will do to them these next couple of weeks will be nothing short of taking candy from a baby. The most compelling aspect of this series will be where LeBron decides to take his talents to after losing for the 3rd time in 4 years to the Warriors. Unless the Cleveland Cavs become the Cleveland Browns and start tackling the Warriors…nothing to see here folks.
3. An act of God to give the Cavs a fighting chance.  
4. Steph Curry

The NBA Finals begin tomorrow night at 6:00 PM 
Game 2 will be June 3rd at 5:00 PM
Game 3 will be June 6th at 6:00 PM
Game 4 will be June 8th at 6:00 PM
               … and if necessary …
Game 5 will be June 11th at 6:00 PM
Game 6 will be June 14th at 6:00 PM &
Game 7 will be June 17th at 5:00 PM

title: Spring Into Summer With These 5 Sad Songs
content:
Written by Alexa Lee

A playlist for people whose emo angst will not be stopped by the warmer weather and brighter days ahead.

“Not the One” by Mikky Ekko

Most people know Mikky Ekko from his broody verse on Rihanna’s “Stay.” However, Ekko is a musician with a wide range — he not only writes soft ballads about heartbreak, he also writes uptempo indie rock songs about heartbreak! I personally really appreciate the way Ekko unabashedly wails on “Not the One,” as it shows me a different, but equally angsty side of his artistry.

“Stay” by Post Malone

Is Post Malone crusty as hell? Yes. Does he continue to make catchy, melancholy songs that are perfect for those frosty LA nights? Yes, and “Stay” is no exception. If you were that kid in high school who said things like, “Man, I wish Mayday Parade had more slowed down, acoustic tracks,” then you’re gonna love this song.

“‘Til It’s Over” by Anderson .Paak

But Alexa, you protest, isn’t this a happy song? It’s so cheerful and laidback-sounding! What’s it doing on this depressing ass playlist? But that’s where you’re wrong, my friend. Any song can be an emo song if you listen to it in the proper emo state of mind. When .Paak sings, “Say, can’t a young man dream?/Can’t we all live life on a widescreen,” are you smiling? Are you crying? Are you optimistic about your future, or crippled by your past? Who can say?

“Chilly” by NIKI

NIKI references the month of December in this song, but its overarching themes of solitude and bittersweet goodbyes are perfect for angsty listeners year round. I like to listen to this song when I’m putting away laundry or washing dishes, and before I know it my chores have come to a halt and I’m staring out my window wondering if I’ll ever be able to experience a love without selfishness.

“VCR” by The xx

It’s not a new song, but this playlist wouldn’t be complete without a) a song by The xx, a band so broody that sometimes they all wear black turtlenecks at the same time, and b) a painful throwback to the year 2009. Which by the way, was nearly a decade ago. I know, I know. Youth is fleeting and nothing gold can stay.

title: Radimo LA Runway @ Junior High (05/06/18) // Show Review
content:
Photos and article by Gomi Zhou

I am known to be someone who has high expectation for everything, and with that comes frequent disappointments. I woke up stressed out again on the day of the Radimo x Junior High runway show. As usual, I ended up setting inhumanly high expectation for the night.

I also came with worries. I worried that just like many other major queer events nowadays this was going to be another white-washed night. Since some online influencers were also walking and had been promoting the show, I worried that maybe it would once again, inevitably turn out to be a YouTube meet & greet. And mainly, I was worried because I’m still trying to get used to this newly introduced queer lifestyle for myself. It was just a lot of self-doubt, really. After years of calling myself straight and convincing myself that I was straight, I worried that I wouldn’t be able to fit right in with a crowd who had long been comfortable with who they are.

But the runway show still came out (no pun intended) to be everything I could have ever asked for.

7pm on the dot, I arrived at Junior High and a few kids had already got there. Assuming that they were fans of some of the influencers, most of them were surprisingly shy and quiet, contemplating with each other whether they should walk into the venue at such an early time. I also saw some parents, which I was once again surprised by, since mine will never be this supportive when it comes to this particular topic. Walking in, the space itself was lovely. Junior High looked like your typical neighborhood nonprofit organization but just with a lot more teenage angst and a lot more pink–which I found comforting. The pink neon signs, pins that said things like “GENDER IS OVER” felt so comforting to me. This was a space dedicated to the ones who are going through their late teen years and adolescence, the ones who are constantly on the search for an opportunity to speak up and learn but often neglected by the arrogant society who had deemed them as naive.

I had a short chat about the detailed layout for the show with Dan, who was the founder of the brand Radimo and the person behind tonight’s show. I could tell they were in a rush to make sure everything was ready to go, but I also noticed the obvious and genuine excitement behind their voice. Then came the long and slightly daunting wait for the actual show. People were all in small groups: the younger kids were mainly on their phones trying to avoid any awkward eye contact, and the adults were chit-chatting with each other about which bar they should hit together afterward. I myself spent the next hour or so talking to the girls who worked at Junior High and the other photographers. Everyone sounded so cool that they all seemed to be a “somebody” who’s working on some “projects”, a very typical scene you could find anywhere else in Los Angeles. To my surprise and comfort, even though the event was stated explicitly as a queer runway show, not once was there a question asked about sexuality. Maybe this was a given for the other attendees, but for me, a “baby queer” as one of my fellow photographers kindly made up the name for, it felt so foreignly accepting with a good type of intimacy. With all the different personalities I encountered before the show, I found it hard to imagine how would each person act in the audience crowd. Obviously, there were your groups of “stereotypical gays”, who were outgoing and ready for a good time; but the majority of the people looked just as awkward and timid as I was, feeling both excited and slightly nervous for the upcoming fashion show that was deemed to be “revolutionary” for the queer community. As it got closer to showtime, people started piling in. The more people there were in the same room, the more diverse the crowd had become. People in different age groups, ethnicities, occupations were all here for one reason: we were there to see a queer runway show, to support the queer community that we all love.

The runway soundtrack replaced the leftover awkwardness. Almost without warning, the first model walked out. With a loose striped shirt tucked into a knee-length student dress, they walked out with a notepad in their hand. They swayed their hair from side to side, delicately strode down the runway with sass. “YESSSS,” excited voices were as loud as the Beyoncé remix, everyone in the crowd was screaming and cheering now. The crowd was now acting as a whole that everyone was wearing an identical smile and screaming with joy and pride. The same dress and shirt were then worn by several other models who had different heights and different body curves, showcasing the different ways the same design could be worn in different ways by different people. After several outfits being showcased in this way, models started to stop in the middle of the runway and exchange articles of clothing from one person to another. One model would take off their silky flowery cardigan, hand it off to the next model so they could tie it around their waist. The two beautiful models would then walk down the runway hand in hand, showered once again by the overly excited and amazed crowd. The idea of gender was constantly being challenged round after round. All of the pieces were worn by at least two different people in two different ways. Models were presenting these designs in masculine and feminine manners, sometimes both manners at the same time. The gender of the models no longer mattered that everyone was equally as beautiful, proud and most importantly, happy as they strode with the confident smiles on their faces.

When the last set of models walked out, there was a split second of silence. Everyone in the crowd, including me, collectively gasped at the scene in front of us. Then all I could hear were roaring cheers, filling the room with love and love only. Miles, someone who I had been watching on YouTube ever since I was still denying myself, who had been advocating for LGBTQ+ rights since the very first day of his career, who just went through his top surgery, walked out bare-chested with the most muscular model of the night. Hand in hand wearing skirts and high heel boots, they strode slowly down the runway with confidence and pride. Emotions washed through me, not only because Miles had been one of the most important influences for my own journey, but the fact that this representation for the most discriminated against members of the LGBTQ+ community was done with apparent ease and showered by tremendous support in the room. The last time I met Miles, for the first time in my life I came out to a whole room of people despite the fact that it was being recorded from all angles; six months later, I was here sharing this evolutionary night with my beautiful community, for the first time without feeling like I was out of place. Six months ago, Miles was insecure as he kept on getting misgendered even though he had been on testosterone for a few months; and now, he was striding down a queer runway show confidently in front of a whole room of beautiful queer people. It’s crazy what six months can do, it’s crazy how much one can grow in just six months when you are surrounded by support–in this case quite literally.

My favorite thing about meeting new people or people who I look up to is that after you hugged each other, the smell of the other person would get carried by your hair and clothes for the rest of the day. I tried thanking as many people as possible, hugged a few who I had been following on the internet for literally years, and strode out of Junior High with no regard of the concept of gender but filled with love. I still have so much to learn when it comes to being queer and being comfortable with myself, and it can certainly be scary sometimes when you are living with a rather rare sexuality by yourself. But this night gave me so much faith and courage. The show by Radimo at Junior High visually challenged the concept of genders while accepted everyone in the room under the umbrella term “queer”. At the end of the day, love is love, and no one can deny someone for simply being themselves and feeling beautiful.

title: Japanese Breakfast @ The Roxy (4/18/18) // Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Emily Pitcher 

Michelle Zauner, the voice behind the solo project Japanese Breakfast, writes about grief and heartbreak and love in a way that reminds you of all the moments you’ve pushed to the back of your mind. From the death of her mother to the comfort of marriage, she sings with precision, knowing what her sound is and owning it. Coming to the live stage with spirit and the occasional humorous side comment about celebrity sightings, Zauner was a delight to see. 

Portland based And And And and Snail Mail opened. And And And was a pandemonium of strong bass and passionate screaming, heavy and punk rock. Indie-pop Snail Mail sings about the conflict that comes with growing up; at only eighteen years old, her artistry of songwriting is already present. Her songs are cathartic yet nuanced.

Then came Zauner. With her light up shoes and blue eyeshadow, her stage presence was all energy; she jumped around the stage with a giddy smile on her face. From watching her, you can tell how much she loves music, as she is barely able to contain her excitement. Even though her songs are about serious subjects, so much of her music is upbeat, from the dance-inducing “Everybody Wants to Love You” to “Road Head.” Her husband plays on stage with her, and seeing their smirks at each other is endearing. When she introduced “Till Death,” she looked at him, as if describing the song to him and not the audience, and the love between the two was palpable.

“Boyish” is an anthem for self-love, as she criticizes the people in her life who never found her appearance appealing enough. Similar to the music video, she lowered a disco ball to the center of the stage, and she introduced the song as being about “wanting to feel pretty.” It’s a fuck you to the boys who used her but did not value her, to the longing of wanting to be enough. Her performance was biting, a painful but real song of desire.

For the slower tracks - “This House” and “Here Come the Tubular Bells” - she had all but one band member leave. These two songs were her chance to slow the dancing, to get personal. Ultimately, Zauner’s music deals with pain, so not all of her songs can be upbeat. This part of the performance was still engaging, a fitting change of pace.

Asian American women need greater representation in the music industry. Zauner serves as a start to what could be, and she does so unapologetically. Her stage presence is so big and joyous and open – you want to be closer, to know all of the stories that led her to where she is now. Zauner knows how to craft intimate ballads that suck you in, and her delicate voice only captivates you further. She has an unadulterated fascination and talent for her craft, and she does not restrict it. She writes about difficult subjects and the listener can feel the raw emotions behind her words.

Zauner’s performance is one of the most infectious live shows I have seen. She is coming back to Los Angeles in October, and I would recommend seeing her to anyone.

title: Everything Was Beautiful and Nothing Hurt - Moby // Album Review
content:
Written by Anshu Patel

Moby grew tired of listening to Gary Jules’ “Mad World” on repeat and decided to take sorrow-core into his own hands. Kidding, as Moby is certainly no stranger to a sad song –a personal favorite is the aptly titled “When It’s Cold I’d Like to Die” from Play (1995). Moby’s fifteenth studio album, the highly emotional Everything Was Beautiful and Nothing Hurt, was released on March 2 of this year. This record is blanketed in a deep melancholy; it is likely that the album is a reaction to and a reflection of the current political climate. Moby layers anguished spoken-word vocals on several of the tracks, which add to the air of desperation
elicited by the record. The monotone of Moby’s voice works as an effective overlay for the desolate trip-hop beat, while the world is lyrically framed as a barren, hopeless, and depraved place. 

It’s easy to imagine that this album was recorded as a form of catharsis, and I can only hope that some of the misery expressed through the album was alleviated – because this is a troublingly mournful release. The record is past a place of frustration, instead playing as a reluctant acceptance of the inherent malice present in the universe. The guest vocalists also add a beautiful, soulful dimension to the album, allowing a spot of brightness in an otherwise bleak tracklist. Especially notable are Mindy Jones’ soothing vocals on “The Waste of Suns” and “The Last of Goodbyes.” The album artwork, a bull reading to his calf, is an allusion to Moby’s well-known vegan advocacy. The single artwork for “Like a Motherless Child,” a close-up of the young calf, confirms this interpretation. Essential tracks from the album include “This Wild Darkness,” “The Middle Is Gone,” as well as the melodic, futuristic “The Waste of Suns.” Everything Was Beautiful and Nothing Hurts discloses intimate pain and is thus distressing, but
it remains listenable, and enjoyably so.
tags: everything was beautiful and nothing hurts
everything was beautiful and nothing hurts album review

title: Song of the Week: In Your Arms by Sunbeam Sound Machine
content:
Written by Myla Andrews

Australia-based band Sunbeam Sound Machine lives up to their name—each song on their debut album Wonderer evokes the tranquility of lying out in the sun with your eyes closed, free of worry. Comparisons to Tame Impala will certainly be drawn in regard to this contemporary alternative/psychedelic rock band, and not without reason. The dreamy synth, warm, full-feeling timbre, and slow tempo give both groups, to put quite bluntly, a very high feeling. “In Your Arms” by Sunbeam Sound Machine epitomizes this—the gradual ascension and descension of the compressed guitars paired with repetitive lyrics proclaiming a simple need that “all I want to is to feel like the only one in your arms” elicits the simple feeling of just wanting to be with another person. And perhaps that is the genius in the song. It doesn’t try to make complexities out of an uncomplicated feeling—life and love can be as simple as lying in the sun, with someone.

title: CRSSD FEST, Sep 29th -30th // Show Review
content:
article by Jenny Tong

photos provided by CRSSD

The CRSSD festival took place just in the past weekend with a backdrop of mesmerizing sunsets at the Waterfront park of San Diego. Their House x Techno watermark was etched over the three stages: The Palms (house music), City Steps (techno music) and Ocean View Stage (a variety of styles, bigger acts). An event that happens twice a year, once in Spring and once in the Fall, CRSSD’s signature ambiance draws an eclectic crowd. I have heard about the festival from several friends, who noted that the crowd is one of the best they have seen (perhaps partially due to the 21+ age restriction).

Atmosphere and Amenities

Perfect location in downtown San Diego, friendly and invigorating crowd, felt right at home and in my element. The Palms stage was intricately decorated with sunset-colored Kyōwagasa (Chinese oil-paper umbrellas) and, as its name suggests, glowing palms. The stage setup definitely alludes to the dub reggae, Jungle music era that dominated the early UK rave scenes, while also incorporating colors reflecting the sunset, the crowd-favorite time of the festival. How seamless the stage was to its surroundings is unparalleled; further, the sailboats that docked along the coast at sunset further enhanced the visual layers.

What I also thought was interesting to note was that the CRSSD FEST app had a push notification for when selective artists started cruising into the festival through the crowd, such as the duo, Sofi Tukker’s distinctive outfit that caught the eyes of many before their set as they made their way to the stage. It goes to show CRSSD FEST’s attempts to make artists more approachable, as it creates a more interactive and unique atmosphere. I recall the duo also chose a fan to go on stage to dance with them, which brought the crowd to higher spirits.

Crowd and Culture

Definitely one of the most dedicated groups of fans attended CRSSD FEST. There were people who dressed up in shirts with pizza prints just for AntiUp’s “Pizza” song WHILE eating pizza timed right when the duo played it at the set; countless exchanges between fans counting the number of times they have seen Louis the Child live were made; fans of Dillon Nathaniel coming in as early as 12 pm right when the gates opened to catch his set … Such loyalty does not come easy, and CRSSD FEST appears to also draw the most stylish fans (not the people, but the literal fans) around.

Music

I had a handful of acts that I was determined to see on my schedule that I added on the CRSSD FEST app. However, the proximity of the three stages encourages you to walk around and explore between the different artists playing concurrently. My favorite vantage point was on the ledge to the water fountains, although a bit far removed from the stage itself, you would actually be able to listen to both the Palms and City Steps stages’ performances (one on your left side, one on your right), which creates very interesting orchestral crossovers.

Some notable acts included Darius’s live set, Méle (yes to French DJs), John Digweed (his 2-hour sunset set was the best yet, I’ve formerly seen him in a broiler room event in Fabric London but this topped that 100%), Shallou (the barefooted vocalist who jumped off stage to greet audience was an absolute crowd hype), Helena Hauff as well as headliners Duke Dumont and Nina Kraviz. However, the consensual favorite was Anti-Up, the iconic duo (shoutout to another iconic duo UCLA student attendees, Austin Berke, and Aleksandra Vojvodić) at 6:45 pm on Sunday. The reason is that since it was a debut performance, most of the audience did not have a preconceived experience or impression to gauge their expectations off of, so the entire set was a breath of fresh air with many pleasant surprises and twists. I was instantly a converted fan after the set; Chris Lake and Chris Lorenzo are definitely ones to watch.

Shoutout: Oliver (unpictured)

A former UCLA Radio guest interviewee, Oliver (interview mix here), had an absolutely captivating set at the Palms stage. His hidden stature (shades, cap, going in and out of the leaves during his set) added a mysterious aura around him, and the more into the set it progressed, the more entrancing his music became.

Best Visuals: Louis the Child

In particular, the visuals accompanying one of their newest singles, “Dear Sense ft. MAX”, was the most eye-catching.

If you are looking for a festival with a more mature crowd, discovering new house music, with an (optional) APL in one hand overlooking the beautiful waters, look no further - CRSSD FEST will be the best fit for you. I have been absolutely transformed after the festival and cannot wait to attend the coming festival in spring. Till next time!

title:
The Fonda on Wax 
Nightmares on Wax @ The Fonda Theatre (6/11/18) // Show Review
content:
Article by Pam Gwen

Photographs by Katy Ramage

I briskly rise from my seat and proudly walk over to drop my Language Development and Socialization final on the pile of others. I march over to the exit, look up at the moonlit sky, inhale deeply, and exhale my relief. I have officially finished my first year at UCLA. My phone illuminates the dark – 9:15pm, Monday, June 11th. I run across campus to my partner’s car. It’s time to celebrate and witness the elusive creative genius, George Evelyn, known as his alter ego, Nightmares on Wax.

Evelyn’s journey of self-discovery has flourished his expertise as a musician. His enthusiasm of music began with his household engrossed with Afro-Carribean Calypso, the dreamy jazz vibratos of Sarah Vaughn, poetics of Quincy Jones, and the politically conscious soul of Curtis Mayfield. As a teenager in Leeds, England, Evelyn joined and curated mix tapes for the breakdance crew, Solar City Rockers inspired by Rappers Delight and Buffalo Gals. In 1991, Evelyn made a name for himself as a pioneering DJ mixing influences of the 80’s/90’s rave scene of England, hip-hop, and reggae.

For nearly 3 decades, Nightmares on Wax has swooned fans with his experimental discography inspired by his emotionally driven and positive soul. Nightmares on Wax is my go-to artist to truly take a second to breathe and reconfigure. The essence of his music has encouraged me during midterm/final seasons when I have lost motivation and concentration, my meditations to reconnect to nature, and my stellar dance moves that are unearthed only to Evelyn’s signature grooves.

In January 2018, he released the genre-bending masterpiece, Shape the Future. Nightmares on Wax’s creation of his latest record is inspired by the inward and outward journey he has embarked on all over the world. His spiritual, physical, and emotional growth is recognizable in his dub, acid jazz, ska, groove techno, funk-and-soul electronica, and trip-hop mastery found in Shape the Future.

My partner and I smoothly park near Hollywood Boulevard using Pavemint, a community parking mobile app that Nightmares on Wax partnered with to provide stress-free parking for the first 100 of his Los Angeles fans to download Pavemint.

We walk over to the Fonda Theatre and see a line of ecstatic fans getting blue wristbands strapped on their wrists. Katy and I follow suit, but we are also given Goldenvoice purple wristbands for our press passes. As I enter the venue equipped with my yellow notebook, cherry red Dr. Martens, a rainbow beaded necklace made of coconuts, my favorite orange and purple paisley knee-length skirt, and exhilaration –  the tingling feeling of summer finally overcomes me.

The Fonda opened in the 1920’s and this era definitely inspires its interior architecture of Spanish Colonial Revival style. The Fonda is eye-catching with its gorgeous sconces, intricate murals, and peculiar decorations. Aesthetics aside, the Fonda is also perfect for every concert goer. Need a break from the crowd? Need some air? There is a rooftop bar with a view of Hollywood. Not a fan of big crowds? Want a better view? There is a seated balcony with a plethora of comfy seats awaiting you. Itching for a bass thump-fest? Do you love dancing in the pit? Want to be up close and personal with your favorite artist? The Fonda has a first come basis standing pit, just for you! The stage is smaller than most Los Angeles venues, but the quaint intimacy it provides is transcending.

The lights dim, the curtains open, and Nightmares on Wax finally walks on to the stage. He is in a simple black t-shirt, black headphones, a brown baseball cap, cargo shorts, red sneakers, and an intricately multicolored tie made out of beads. He begins smudging (a ceremony of burning sage to bring positive energy to a space) and behind me, a woman whispers to her partner, “Is that a huge joint?” Her partner laughs and replies, “No, that’s sage.” Its scent and excitement fills up his fans. The Fonda is now jam packed with souls of all ages. There are middle-aged women with purple hair, young teens in berets and sailor caps, and OG fans in the very back are hooting and swaying N.O.W’s vinyl records, Smoker’s Delight from 1995 and Carboot Soul from 1999.

The Nightmares on Wax stage is now hazy and forces you to consider whether you’ve stepped into the Fonda or his living room. On stage is a tresillo, in Spain this is a living room set with 2 arm chairs and a 3-seater-sofa. Nightmares on Wax continues to spread the sage with a fan and seats his mind, spirit, and body on the 3-seater-sofa. In front of him is a coffee table laden with his keyboards, synthesizers, computer, and mixers.

A confidence spreads on Nightmares on Wax’s face as he puts the sage out. He has officially cleansed the negative energy of his field and begins his magic. His drummer, Grant Kershaw, in a red shirt, blue jeans, and sneakers then seats himself on the drum kit to N.O.W’s left. Kershaw begins the beat to “Back to Nature.”

The stage behind them has two 50-inch TVs with stands in the back playing his music video for “Back to Nature.” The harmonious and utopian music video is a culmination of magazine cutouts, postcards, and vintage films created by Joao Pombiero. In the middle of the TVs is a banner reminiscent of Shape the Future’s album cover.  A woman next to me with thick white glasses, a striking white mohawk, and the tattooed word “Destiny” taking up her left arm screams, “I love you! Thank you for your existence. Welcome back!” and begins dancing in a circle with all her jubilant friends.

“All humans share one spirit. All humans share a consciousness… All human thought vibrates at a certain frequency. We’re all in communication. When you exhale, I breathe the air you breathe…”

“Back to Nature” is a song of affirmation, mindfulness, and swagger. In the time of 2018’s political fascism, the purity, clarity, and understanding of this tune are healing. “Back to Nature” features Nightmares on Wax’s instrumentation, the voice of spiritual leader Kuauhtli Vasquez, and a hikuru/chant that was recorded at a ceremony in Sacbe, Mexico by the Wixarika Tribe. Together in consciousness and thought, the elixirs of “Back to Nature” curate a poignant beginning to the night.

A champagne bottle behind the armchair on the left is picked up by British and Barbadian singer, Sadie Walker. Walker is striking in red flowy pants, doc martens, and a geometrically cut top. Following Walker, English singer, songwriter, producer, and Rihanna’s brother (!!), Leigh Stephen Kenny/LSK takes a seat on the right armchair. LSK is an ascot cap with a denim jacket that conceals his shirt with only “LIT” emblazoned on the front. LSK is a longtime friend and collaborator of Evelyn’s. LSK has also curated most of Evelyn’s artwork for his albums. Tonight, LSK takes on the role of one of N.O.W’s vocalists.

Walker pours champagne for herself and her bandmates. In succession, I feel as if I’ve somehow walked into a private scene of N.O.W and his best friends hanging and jamming out at his house. As if on cue, fans scream and applaud uproariously. I am reminded that this is a concert - and an intoxicating one at that.

Walker, Kershaw, LSK, and N.O.W’s infectious smiles and ability to vibe as a cerebral unit is mesmerizing. LSK’s solid and thunderous voice accompanies N.O.W and Kershaw’s polished drumming during “Shape the Future”, “Tell my Vision”, and “Play Video.” A woman in a red boat hat that conceals her face is cuddled up with her husband in a red flannel to match. They embrace and smile up at the stage as N.O.W plays his famous hit, “Les Nuits.”

I listened to this track while studying for the final I took just hours ago. I place my hand on my thumping heart to the live bass and it all feels extremely surreal. The crowd becomes electric as individuals proudly dance in their own worlds and jump in rhythm to “You Wish” and “Citizen Kane.” As the crowd settles, Sadie stands from her sofa and her breathtaking vibratos are undeniable during “Deep Shadows.” LSK’s trademark harmonically-rich vocalizations power up “Flip Ya Lid” and everyone begins to bump into each other as the beat takes over our bodies. Kershaw’s begins a percussion-soaked drum solo. All eyes are on him and N.O.W looks proudly at his exceptional drummer.

LSK, Sadie, Kershaw, and N.O.W make moves to exit the stage, but N.O.W snickers and whispers “We’re coming back, don’t worry.” As promised, they assemble themselves back on stage and N.O.W takes center stage with the mic and sings the feel-good lyrics of “Be I Do.” Afterward, the funky and deliciously groovy tempo of “Da Feelin” pulsates the dancefloor.

For all the concerts I have attended, the laid-back yet mind-blowing performance N.O.W has provided proves his genuinity. He does not need costumes, backup dancers, or intricate lights. His virtuosity is supplied by his encapsulating energy and positive soul. George Evelyn is not just a DJ, producer, writer, and spiritual conductor - but, also a humanitarian and activist. N.O.W remarkably comments on his privilege as an artist and beckons his fans to help support change in the lives of others and make a difference, no matter how small.

He begins a speech on  his collaboration with the foundation Last Night a Dj Saved my Life. The foundation creates intiviaties to enable the electronic music industry to make a positive impact on children in crisis. Nightmares on Wax is currently supporting 4,630 people daily with fresh water. The fundraising has already sprouted 3 wells in India and 1 well in Uganda. Documented videos that N.O.W’s team has taken of the children he supports is displayed on the TVs. “Gotta Smile” thunders throughout the Fonda and it is a humble reminder of gratitude and community. You yourself can donate on nightmaresonwax.com/justgive!

Sadie, Grant, and LSK bow and walk off the stage. Evelyn gives his final goodbye, expresses immense appreciativeness to his fans, and departs. Though his presence (and sage) has left the stage, I still feel the lingering feeling of the love, unity, and awakening that he conjured tonight. Nightmares on Wax is traveling with stellar bandmates, equipment, a living room, and is undeniably…Shaping the Future on his tour.

title: Unknown Mortal Orchestra @ Wiltern Theater (5/11/18) // Show Review
content:
Photographs and article by Ethan Lee

On a bustling Friday night in the heart of Los Angeles’ Koreatown, the Wiltern Theater is nearly at its busiest of the week. The art deco, near-turquoise colored theater is an instantly recognizable spot for anyone looking for something to do in LA, accentuated by its towering height and imposing stature and lighting along Wilshire Boulevard. May 11th, 2018 was one of those nights, and Unknown Mortal Orchestra, the psychedelic indie rock band formed by Ruban Nielson, was set to play.  

Unknown Mortal Orchestra is a cultural hybrid of a band, hailing from both Auckland, New Zealand, and Portland, Oregon. They first received significant attention as a band after their first, mysterious Bandcamp release “Ffunny Ffriends,” which would later appear on their debut self-titled LP, received critical and audience praise. Fast forward 8 years later, and the band has seen significant success and growth, topped with the release of their fourth and latest album, Sex & Food, in April and an accompanying tour. The tour kicked off in late April in Northampton, MA, and has finally made its way through California and the heart of Los Angeles at the Wiltern. The sold-out audience was prepared to hear their favorite lo-fi indie rock band perform a trippy set. What they got was a bit more.

Those familiar with the Wiltern already know of its intricately-designed art deco interior. From the general admission, one can admire the geometrical ceiling and the column-like walls that rise up towards it. A swooping balcony looms over the ground level, the latter segmented for optimal audience views. On the stage was Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s setup. White fur rugs covered parts of the temporary platforms built on stage, providing a soft cushion for the electronic keyboards and drum set. A pristine, IKEA-like table sat at the very front; atop it, a white record player with two speakers. Below the table were vinyl records proudly displayed from, perhaps, Ruban’s personal collection, including an unusual Miles Davis record, You’re Under Arrest. Forming the backdrop of the stage was a light fixture with five columns of shelves, each shelf carrying rows of the same leafy plant. Each column was aligned with LED light strings on each side. Between each shelf were spotlights, vertically aligned. At rest, all of these lights emitted a brilliant pink hue, almost as if the audience were looking into a portal that leads to the cover of Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s album art for Multi-Love, but we’ll get into that later.

By the time I reached the show, Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s opener, Makeness, had already begun. A one-man act, Makeness took multiple duties as instrumentalist, programmer, and vocalist for his opening act. His performances more or less involved stacking multiple layers to establish a groove, creating programmable drum patterns on repetitive synth patterns to sonically support his higher register vocals. Makeness produced dance-pop sentiments on stage and maintained a DIY-like attitude with the one-man act setup, complimenting Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s pop-indie-psychedelia hybrid sound and lo-fi background that are well known to the audience.

45 minutes and a couple of soundchecks later, Unknown Mortal Orchestra took the stage, and, as if making a poetic gesture reflecting on the band’s career, started off the show with “Ffunny Ffriends,” the song that started it all. The roars from the audience alone indicated that they knew what was to come. Unknown Mortal Orchestra delivered an outstanding career-spanning set, surprisingly playing a decent distribution of songs from each of their four albums. Some rare surprises were a performance of the self-titled LP’s “Nerve Damage!”, to which Ruban introduced, “This next song is so old, you guys probably won’t even know it.” A significant number of songs from II were performed, including the fan-favorite for singalongs “So Good At Being In Trouble” as well as “Swim and Sleep Like A Shark.” Given the band had just released Sex & Food a month before, it was apparent Unknown Mortal Orchestra would perform almost the entire album live, performing fan favorites like the groovy “Hunnybee” and seamless transitions between “Major League Chemicals” and the fiery “American Guilt.” One particular moment I liked was the fact that they added precise detail to the show by playing a recording (albeit, a distorted, skipped version of a recording) of “A God Called Hubris” while introducing the band’s stage crew before transitioning right into a live rendition of “Major League Chemicals”. Hell, even “Chronos Feasts On His Children” got a performance in the encore!

The setlist is just one aspect of the show; Unknown Mortal Orchestra has proven that they’ve refined the art of the performance. Many of the songs were open to improvisation, from long-running guitar solos at the end of “From the Sun” to even occasional saxophone textures in the more psychedelic renditions. One highlight of the performance was, during the extended solo in the outro of “From The Sun,” Ruban ran off stage, gracing his guitar still plugged into a “wireless” amp. For a good minute, he was off stage while still soloing, until cheers grew louder and louder from the balcony; he had run up to the balcony all while continuing his improvised guitar solo. He teetered over the edge of the balcony, overlooking the general admission crowd who turned around when they realized where he was, as hoards of fans on the balcony roared and took selfies with him at the bottom of the balcony.  

The band played every beat and note that has existed in their respective recordings but added even more on top of it in improvisation. Fans of Unknown Mortal Orchestra may also note that seeing a live performance of theirs is much “cleaner” than their recordings; while Ruban stays true in using the appropriate effects on the guitar to replicate the sounds fans have come to love in his records, Ruban doesn’t use any filters on his voice to maintain the lo-fi aesthetic in live shows, leaving his raw voice out in the mix, which can arguably make the show a bit more unique and appealing for fans. Visually, the lighting effects on stage, mentioned earlier, deviated from its constant pink hue at resting state, using rotating beams, vibrant strobe lights, and saturated colors across the spectrum to transform the stage into Unknown Mortal Orchestra’s personal kaleidoscope, perfectly in sync with their music. The sound and visual setup complemented each other in the show’s psychedelic yet laid-back attitude, and the audience of dedicated fans seemed to enjoy every second of it, calling out the next tracks and dancing the night away.

title: Echosmith with Jena Rose @ The Fonda Theater (5/12/18) // Show Review
content:
Review and photos by Mark McGreal

Echosmith finished off a United States tour at The Fonda Theater in Hollywood, and it was lively. The show, basically a homecoming for the group that originated in Chino, California, was an eclectic celebration of music, and it highlighted all of the things that make us fall in love with music.

When I finally entered The Fonda, I looked around and noticed how tiny and claustrophobic The Fonda Theater happened to be. The pit isn’t very large, it only goes back about 10-15 rows, so most of the seating is in the balcony above the floor. The outside of the theater has an old marquee that reminds me more of a community theater for children than a concert venue. The theater looks like a relic of a time long gone, and it reminded me that time can be ever so fleeting. That thought prompted me to stay in the moment for as long as I could.

There were two opening acts for Echosmith. Seventeen-year-old starlet Jena Rose and indie pop band The Score traveled with Echosmith throughout the country over the last six weeks. Rose recently released a new EP, which I would highly recommend. She may only be seventeen, but her voice is that of a much older, much more mature artist. The Score’s new album Atlas is the perfect soundtrack to a riot. Needless to say, even before Echosmith went out to perform, I was incredibly amped up and ready for a brilliant show.  

But Echosmith’s performance was more than just a show. It was an experience. The show began with one member of the group going up on stage in basically complete darkness with only a little backlighting to give the audience even the smallest idea of what was about to happen. The man started banging a large standalone bass drum in rhythm, almost like a tribal beat. This beat grew as more members of the band joined their compatriot on stage until finally, the lead singer strode out. She was wearing a knee length blue and red dress and began singing. After the first song ended, confetti cannons exploded, and we were drenched in a torrential downpour of colorful paper.

Throughout the night there were moments, both big and small, that made the show particularly memorable. The Score, Jena Rose, and Echosmith were all on stage together at one point, shooting confetti and getting the audience excited during an Echosmith song. The three groups looked like genuine friends, enjoying one last incredible moment together before the tour ended, and they would all have to go their separate ways. Echosmith covered the Killers’ “When You Were Young” and part of the hit Death Cab For Cutie song “I Will Follow You Into the Dark”. These covers, while small moments overall, showed Echosmith’s obvious love for music, and their appreciation for the art form to which they add. Sydney, being the talented band member that she is, even played the drums for a couple of minutes in order to give her tired drummer a well-deserved break. She also threw in a costume change mid-show in order to show the mood shift from pop hits to something slightly more angsty.

An exceptionally important moment of the night came when the lead singer, Sydney Sierota, asked for a volunteer to come up on stage. I didn’t think much of it. I had seen this trope done before at concerts. Bring up a loyal fan, dance around with them a little, make them feel special so more people will buy your album or your t-shirt, et cetera et cetera. So imagine my shock when Sierota said the name “Zoey” and called an audience member from the front row on stage.

Zoey ran on stage with all of the excitement of a child who has finally woken up on Christmas morning. She got on stage and hugged Sierota after which, Sierota explained to all of us that she knew Zoey’s name because “She has been with us since the beginning”. All of a sudden, I gained a greater appreciation for the band I was watching. Although I had enjoyed their music up to that point, this simple action added a layer of emotion to the show that I wasn’t expecting. Here is how I understand the relationship between Zoey and the band. Zoey had presumably been to see the band early on in their development, back at a time that all artists go through, the time where the band has maybe six dedicated fans who they know by name. Zoey was one of those dedicated fans. And Sydney remembered her. At that moment, the tiny, claustrophobic theater suddenly felt small and intimate. This band, that, nine years later, has gone double platinum and tours all over the country, still remembers the people who were there since day one.

During their song “Goodbye”, giant balloons filled with confetti were thrown into the audience in order for us to simply play and have fun. This added to the mystique of losing oneself in an event rather than a simple show. After “Goodbye”, the show had its obligatory false ending, before the group came back out for its encore and finished things off with “Cool Kids”, their most well-known song, which ended with another tornado of confetti being shot out at the audience.

Echosmith will remind you why you love music. They play an interesting, energized, and, most importantly, fun show. They don’t play for the fame or the money. They play for the fans.

title: Interview with CJ Harvey
content:
Interview and photos by Megan Hullander

We caught up with photographer CJ Harvey on tour with Ron Gallo, The Nude Party, and Twen.

You can check out her work via her Instagram and her website.

You seem to be very close with everyone you tour with. I’m sure it did not start off that way, so how has touring with people who are also your friends changed your work?

It has influenced me so much. I am kind of one of those people who mostly just listens to whatever my friends are making. I think it’s more fulfilling to listen to because if I am sad or bummed out I can just put on my friend’s music and it’s like my friend is just singing to me, and I am very lucky to be surrounded by such talented musicians where I can kind of do that and get by with only listening to my friends’ projects which is so awesome. And I’m definitely most inspired by my friends who are, you know, making art and touring and playing shows, and I would always rather watch my friends play than, you know, someone else.

I have kind of reached a level of success with tour photography at the point where I can be more selective with who I’m touring with, where it’s not like, oh, this is the only band willing to take me out like this year, so I’m going to do it because I want the experience and I want a tour. I can kind of pick and choose who I’m working with and, you know, my best friends are going on tour, I want to go with them and I’m now experienced enough so they want to go with me, and I’m learning a lot by being so close with my subjects because there’s just kind of a level of trust that wouldn’t have happened had it just been like a random band that hired me. And that is not to say that there is anything wrong with touring with bands that I am less close with but it takes a long time to develop that kind of trust. It will take like two weeks into the tour for you to actually feel like you’re comfortable with each other and you’re not being like a burden. Everyone is so busy on tour, everyone is exhausted, everyone is doing everything at once, nobody wants to go out and go on a photo adventure, but when it is just your best friends, its like hey, if you don’t have time to do this right now, you tell me, if you do, let’s do it. It’s so easy and a lot more exciting because it’s more involved and it’s more personal and it’s people I care a lot about.

I always get spooked out when I use flash, it just feels so invasive.

Yeah, it can feel so scary! But like with Ron I am just like in his face, I’m on stage, I’m walking around, I don’t feel like I need to hide behind a curtain where if anyone sees me I am doing it wrong. There is a lot more creative freedom in that situation which is awesome.

Going off of that, it seems like you feel a connection between artists and their art, which kind of goes into people disowning music when allegations come out about artists. Where do you see the line being between separating art from the artist and is it okay to continue to have a relationship with their art?

So, obviously, everyone feels very differently about this subject and I would never judge someone for continuing to support someone. Say their friend fucked up and it was an honest mistake and they apologized and they are genuinely trying to get help, like that’s awesome, everyone fucks up and everyone deserves a second chance and everyone you know deserves love and respect in their healing process, but I just get so turned off as soon as something sour comes out about someone. Especially if it’s someone that you respected or looked up to or like supported in any way, it just feels like such a personal attack, like I can’t believe someone that I know did this or like this happen to like my friend, like fuck you forever.

I am pretty unforgiving in terms of actually listening to music. For example, if there was someone who did something kind of shitty and they kind of handled it as best they could and they’re like I take full accountability and I’m so sorry this is me, genuinely apologizing, and here are the steps I’m taking to get better, I got sober, I’m in therapy, I like contacted this person that I’ve hurt. If they are going about it the right way of course they deserve a second chance and of course they deserve to keep making art, but I just won’t want to listen to anything that they made because for me I see it as they made this at a time when they are doing the shitty thing and I don’t trust them and I don’t respect this version of that person therefore I want nothing to do with this and it’s going to turn me off and it’s not going to be fun to listen to.

With that being said there is nothing wrong with having important emotions and memories, all of the emotions and memories you have to certain artists and memories that is totally valid. Those memories should not have to change, but I just can’t do it. I can’t pity someone enough to be like, oh its okay, its still a good album, it makes me feel so good.

Yeah, it is tough, because there is just so much out there that it is pretty easy to replace it.

You can easily replace any artist, everyone sounds the same, nothing is original. That’s actually kind of funny, there should be a website, like oh you found out about this person, here is like five other bands you might like that sound exactly the same. Here are much better humans who make very similar music.

You have posted quite a few times about just being considerate of other people at shows, and women specifically. Where do you see this boundary being between being in the moment when experiencing live music and being conscious and considerate and respectful of other people and their boundaries?

I think especially for people it shows who identifies as a woman, like it’s so easy to just be the victim of everyone around you. It takes just one shitty person at a show to make you feel like you don’t belong there and you aren’t welcome and nobody cares about your safety and well being. Especially at a show, especially if it is a band who is so progressive and welcoming and kind. I tour with really great people, and that is not always the case of course, but at least for the people I am touring with, if anyone was in the crowd and someone was dancing on them in a way that made them feel uncomfortable or someone was touching them inappropriately, if they got someone on the stage’s attention, that would be it. That person would get kicked out, get sent to the other side of the room, or have security called on them. My friends don’t tolerate that.

As someone who has been the victim of weird things happening to them at shows, I am a lot more aware of my personal space. I feel like it is not hard at all to have fun and dance and have a good time, and even if you are someone who enjoys moshing, that is awesome and there are definitely other people who want to mosh with you and it is so easy to slowly start a mosh pit. You just start slowly, feel it out, test the waters a little bit. If there are people who look uncomfortable, help them get out before you start the pit. Just mosh with the people who want to mosh. People make such a big deal about it and are like, “I just wanna have a good time at the show,” but it’s so easy to also not violate other people’s space.

I feel like the people who mosh with people who clearly don’t want to are also the people who mosh during the wrong songs too.

Yeah! And I hate moshing 99.9 percent of the time because I always have a camera on me, and I have broken a bone at a show before, I have been slammed to the ground and trampled. I have been through all of that shit and I am kind of claustrophobic too. I am usually at the front because I am taking pictures and not paying attention to what is going on behind me, so if you come crashing into me, you are going to smash me to the ground. As I am falling I am gonna protect my camera over my body and end up getting really hurt because you are an insensitive asshole.

I always get scared of people with drinks, and they start to like lean into you a bit.

And you’re like, I hate that you are ruining this! And then you can’t pay attention to the show at all, you are just looking through you peripheral vision hoping this person won’t crash into you and spill their drink and vomit all over your stuff. It sucks not trusting the people around you at shows. There is a mosh etiquette that most people just don’t understand.

We need to add to our website with the artist redirection -  like how to mosh, how to not spill your drink on someone at a show.

Maybe just don’t have a drink on you while you’re moshing. If you are gonna be thrashing around, don’t hold liquids. Easy. There should be mosh cups that are paper, or no, use like a camelback. That would be awesome.

Another easy add to our website. Lets add moshing camelbacks.

What other business endeavors should we start? As a result of shitty people in music.

You’ve been around for a bit within the music scene, do you feel the dynamic has changed at all since you first started?

Women have always existed in the music industry, but within the last year especially, there has been this huge boom. I work with a lot of bands who are all straight, white dudes, like zero diversity, but that’s not to say they are uninteresting or bad people. They are so lovely and welcoming and kind and they have really gone out of their way from what I have observed to get women on their shows and trying so hard to work with the female agent instead of the other agent who was recommended to them, or bringing me out not because they feel like they have to but because they want to support me as a female and my work and give me a safe space where they will look out for me. The bands I tour with are also really good at picking up on social cues and I am definitely really vocal about stuff that makes me uncomfortable and I am gonna call them out. Even this tour, all of the guys in Ron Gallo and The Nude Party and Twen have all gone out of their way to check in with me. There was this guy who was super drunk and close to me and talking in my ear and it was totally fine, but I can see how it might look like it was maybe a sketchy situation and Dylan while drumming was looking at me like mouthing, “Are you okay? Is everything good?” He is like looking out for me mid-song! All of the guys I surround myself with have my back. I can’t speak for other touring women, but you can educate your friends and get them on the same page. Like you may have not have had this experience but I have and this is why it’s not okay, and even if you didn’t know before, now you do and you know how to look out for that.

It is crazy to see how quickly people’s mindsets will change, like as soon as they become aware of this kind of stuff. Even with social media platforms, just the number of people you can reach.

Exactly, I have even had men DM me on Instagram and be like, I had no idea that was happening or still is happening. Thank you for sharing this and now as a guy I can look out for it and help out my female friends. Its really cool to see that -

*** CJ was then interrupted by a man who approaches and asks if we need tickets, and when I reply no, he says, “Just send your girlfriends on over to me.” ***

Love the timing. I was just starting to feel warm about everything.

That’s the thing! I know this is still on the record, but I am just gonna shit talk someone at the show in Santa Cruz. You think you are surrounded by such loyal, loving men who are there to look out for you and it’s awesome and you feel invincible. This tour specifically is full of so many good people and you get in this head space where you are like everything is fine, this is a safe space and you forget that there are external people who come into that group.

There was this one man who comes up to me at the merch table and is like, “Oh, is that your boyfriend?” And I get that question all of the time and I hate it. I’m like, no it’s not, you see me here selling the merch, why would you not assume that it’s my job to sell merch? He just found it really hard to believe instead of being apologetic. And I said no, but why would you assume that I simply must be dating someone on stage? And he said, “I am not assuming that you have to be dating someone.” But like he did! That is the very first thing he said to me, he didn’t even introduce himself! There were people in line and I didn’t have time to talk to him too much and Ron was still doing the encore so it’s kind of hard to hear. And he said, ”Well, so you aren’t dating anyone in the band, what are you doing?” And I am like, let me tell you how many hats I wear on tour and how I work my ass off for these bands and pour my entire heart and soul into this. Let me tell you about all of the jobs I am doing right now.

Really everything except dating them.

Yeah that’s exactly it. This man was like, “Sure, well for your sake I hope you are being important and helpful and creative. For your sake I hope one day you can be one tenth the creative genius as that guy on stage.” I just was so mad, I had other people to sell to, I was just done, I can’t be upset right now, and I tried to brush it off. I am usually pretty good at doing that, but I saw him talking to Ron after the set and I was like I need to say something, not to make him feel bad or put him on the spot, but I just needed to tell him that it is not okay to say that to people. So I go up to him and I say, “Hey, man. Next time you see a woman identifying person at a show, don’t assume they are there to sleep with someone in the band. Don’t assume that is their job. If you see someone working a show, assume they are working.” And he was like, “Look, sorry you have some problems you are projecting on me. I am a lot older than you are. I have been to way more shows than you have and scientifically speaking, women at shows are usually dating someone in the band.” And I was like interesting because let me tell you how many shows I have been to in the last five years alone and how few of the women I have interacted with are sleeping with someone in the band and I told him that that is bullshit. He said, “I am a realist, I speak the truth, I am not gonna lie to you to protect your feelings.” I had kind of complained about this guy earlier and in that moment Pat from The Nude Party noticed that I was clearly upset by this guy and he asked me to come help pack stuff up so I had an excuse to get out of it, but I was like, “You’re an asshole!” And he was like, “No I’m not!” I was just shaking I was so mad. Usually someone is close minded and then you explain it to them and they apologize, but he just would not have it. I started crying and it’s so frustrating because people like that are never going to change. They don’t want to change.

I just never even understand the intention behind it, like what are they getting out of asking you that in the first place, even if you were dating someone?

Like what satisfaction would that give you if one of the guys was my husband of twenty years? Now that I have started tour managing too, I love having that say because you’re at the top of the touring crew, so if something like that happens, you can get them kicked out. I like knowing that I can do that to help people out. But that night I just could not handle it and then The Nude Party came to pack up their merch and I am sobbing and they are like, “What happened?” And Alec is like, “What is he wearing, is he still here? I need to talk to him.” And I was like no, no, no, no, no. He just ran outside to try and find him, but he had already left.They are just very good boys. I cannot speak highly enough of them. There are good boys in music.

Catch the good boys and sweet gals of Ron Gallo, The Nude Party, and Twen on tour now with CJ.

title: Milk & Bone @ The Bootleg Theatre (3/20/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Jennifer Liaw

The Bootleg Theatre is unidentifiable from the outside. Google lets me know that I’ve arrived and I park in a narrow alley that Angelenos have to call two-way streets, then make my way to the small line formed outside of the warehouse building that otherwise has no indications of housing a venue inside.

The opener, Dizzy, is a four-person band consisting of a female lead singer, two guitarists, and a drummer that also has a pad in front of him and does backup vocals. They’re from Canada, like Milk & Bone, and their sound is reminiscent of an indie pop genre similar to the other band. Katie Munshaw’s voice brightly stands out against a background of mellow guitar tones and steady beats that remind you a little bit of the freedom of adolescence, and a little bit of the stuffiness of suburbia.

Munshaw’s stage presence completely captures me. As she sings lightly and effortlessly, she has the most mischievous smile perched on her face and accompanies every tune with almost signature hand motions, cute in a way only she could pull off. The drummer, however, stands out to me. He vocalizes in the background of one of the songs and it enchants me how he can sing like that in the flesh before my eyes…all the while driving the beat on his drum set.

Finally, Milk & Bone comes out. The female duo from Montreal, Canada is dressed in sporty matching jumpsuits that are both stylish and unique, and they stand behind a large reflective counter that houses their pads and mixing equipment. It was a setup you’d expect to see from any of the hundreds of male EDM duos in existence, a pleasant surprise I hadn’t quite anticipated from them.

They open with one of their hits, “Coconut Water,” but they do a cool live remix of it that has me singing along but also grooving, like, “Damn, I hope they release this sometime,” and, “Are they the female ODESZA?” Between one of their songs, Camille Poliquin tells us that since they play their hit tracks at every show, it gets repetitive for them and so they’ve remixed versions that they now only play live. “Natalie” and “Pressure” are given equally exciting EDM-geared remixes, and they even sample an actual ODESZA song, “Boy,” in the remix of “Pressure.” “Natalie,” on the other hand, is given interjections of beats that make you dance, which turns the darker emotional aspects of the track into a carefree pop tune. If no other DJ does a remix of your songs that actually does it justice, why not just remix it yourself, right? But actually, this really showed me their versatility as a band and musicians. I’m still hoping they’ll release official versions of it sometime so I can bump it in my car and at my next kickback.

I personally knew Milk & Bone best from their EP Little Mourning, but this tour was off their newly released album, Deception Bay. I had given it a listen when it first came out and then revisited it before the show, but in general my first impressions of the album was that their sound had changed and become more similar to other indie pop that bordered a general pop sound with effervescent female vocals, which was not as unique as the sound they boasted in Little Mourning. However, hearing these tracks live totally changed everything…which is honestly something that I love to have happen at live shows. “KIDS” was such a fun track live, with cute lyrics to go along with a bright melody that just put you in a good mood and reminded you of summer and youth. The dreamy, viscous intro to “Set in Stone” captured me immediately and the vulnerability in the lyrics kept me enraptured until the last chord. “Faded” was a darker tune with strong electronic beats that I really enjoyed, reminding me of the mood that BANKS, Kelela, or FKA Twigs give off in their music. “BBBLUE,” which was the one track that caught my ear on my solo listens before the show, was such a fun track to dance to live and definitely didn’t disappoint - a great electro-pop anthem. The Canadian duo’s live performance definitely highlighted the nuances of the non-title tracks of their new album, and gave me a newfound appreciation all of them.

Throughout the show, Poliquin would apologize for her voice because she was recovering from a cough, but honestly, I was astounded that she was sick and still sounded the way that she did. Her voice was beautiful and clear, filled with strength and emotion, and she only faltered or coughed when she was speaking. It was truly impressive, and I wonder what she sounds like when her voice is in full power. Especially at the end of “New York,” she just vocalizes a haunting cry, and it was completely flawless and bone chilling. That entire song gave me chills live. The discord in the harmony the two create when they repeat the line “I/made love/to another one,” kept me spellbound throughout. So much talent, not only vocally, but with their electronic production skills too!

Overall, this show exceeded my expectations and grew my appreciation for Milk & Bone as an artist and Deception Bay as an album. I’d highly recommend seeing them live if you ever get the chance!

title: Interview with Elephante
content:
Elephante in the UCLA Radio Station, 2016. 

Interviewed by Alexis Chung 

I recently got to sit down with Tim Wu, better known as Elephante, at Beyond Wonderland 2018 to talk about his experience with college, being an Asian American, and finding his passion for EDM. Wu, who attended Harvard University and worked at a corporate job post graduation, eventually took the leap to pursue music full time. He will be making his EDC Las Vegas debut
this upcoming May.

Is there anything you would want to say to your college self?

It’s really hard for me to regret any of the decisions that I made because I’ve been incredibly lucky. Growing up as a young Asian boy, being a musician’s not like a thing. That’s not an option, it’s not even in the realm of possibility, right? I’ve loved music growing up and I’ve been writing songs since I was in middle school and so it was something I loved doing, but it was like, “Alright well, now you’ve gotta get a real job and go to school.” I’ve been very lucky but finally
making the leap and being like, “You know who knows what’s going to happen but I gotta give this a shot and if I don’t I’ll never forgive myself.” I had that realization relatively later on in my life but once you go for it, you kind of realize like, “Oh, the world isn’t going to end. You can figure it out, you can make things happen for yourself.” So honestly, it might sound cheesy but you know man, you’re young, go for it. Honestly it’s worth it to give it a shot. 

And for your timeline of events, do you think you had to go through the three years of working at a corporate job for you to realize that this is what you wanted to do? Do you ever wish you found EDM earlier?

I mean literally everyday I see a new eighteen year old headlining Tomorrowland and I’m like, “God.” I will say the one thing it makes me know for sure is that any time I have a bad day or I’m stressed out, or I’m like “Why am i doing this?” I already know what the other option is, right? I already tried to have a normal life and sit at a desk and I know the worst day I have making music is better than the best day I had at that job. So for me it’s like a constant reminder of like,
“Oh no you gotta make this work.” It’s like, “Alright well you’re jumping off without a parachute and you better start flapping your wings because you’re not going back.”

So if you were to ever change something in the past it would basically change who you are as a person today?

Yeah I think it’s like a slippery slope to go down, right? Because I really like my life and I’m very thankful and fortunate for what I get to do. But at the same time, you can’t help but think like, “Hey, maybe if I went to music school I’d be hanging out with Martin Garrix right now.” In music you draw on your life experience, right? And it’s all part of what I do but I will say that for anyone who’s thinking about stuff like that or scared to try something new: you can do it. The fear of
doing it is often greater than the actual challenges that you end up facing.

Have you ever cried to your own song?

I’ve cried because I’ve spent so long on it. When I work on a song I’ve listened to it so many times that you become numb to it, right? It’s like if you say the same word over and over again it kind of loses its meaning in your head. So when you listen to the same eight bars for literally a thousand times in a row it’s really hard to examine it as a first time listener. I look at songs when they’re done very differently than someone listening to it for the first time. And for a long time, every time I’d be done with a song it was when I hated it so much that I couldn’t work on it anymore. So it took me a long time for my first EP. I think it happened like, two or three months ago when I finally sat down and listened through the whole thing and I was like, “Okay this is pretty good.” There are things that I would still change and there are things where I was like, “Ugh, I can’t believe that made it through.” In general, I kind of forgot that nitty gritty of like, “Should the snares be like this?” where I would literally go back and forth like a hundred times and then forget what the whole point of it was in the first place. So going back and just being able to take it in as a whole piece of art, I was like “Okay, this is pretty good.”

Do you ever get nervous performing?

That’s funny, you should ask because I was just telling my friends that I literally had like a panic attack halfway through my set. It was short and I was like, “It’s going to be okay,” but it definitely comes and goes. I mean I’ve played so many shows at this point but there’s always that fear that you’re gonna get up there and they’re going to hate what you do. Maybe it’s an irrational fear but it’s part of not taking anything for granted and not assuming that you’re just gonna go
up there and spin gold every time you’re on stage. There have been disasters before for sure so sometimes you’re just trying to get through it. I try and just like step back and try to enjoy the moment and be like, “This is really cool.” I mean I guess it’s also like I hope I don’t mess things up. Same thing when I’m releasing music it’s like, “I hope people like this.” I think it’s probably from being kind of a control freak. Because when I’m in the studio it’s like, “Okay, everything is
on me.” I work with other people but at the end of the day the final decisions are all mine and so it’s like same thing when I’m on stage. There’s no one else responsible for this and at the end of the day I’m the one making the final cut. Look, at the beginning of my career I put out a new remix every three weeks, so every three weeks I was making a certain remix or making a song and I would put everything I had into it. It was the best thing that I could do and I would finish
and I would be like, “I will never make anything better than this,” and I would release it and no one would care.

Did you know that you wanted to make music from the start or was it a passion that you cultivated over the years? Do you think passion is predestined or something you constantly have to rediscover?

So to the first part: I’ve always loved music ever since I was a kid. I took piano lessons, I was playing guitar in middle school, that was sort of the thing I loved. I recently found out that when I was a baby if I was crying or whatever my mom would put Fantasia on and sit me in front and by
the time I was four or five I must’ve watched Fantasia a hundred times. Instead of watching Blues Clues or whatever I was just watching Fantasia and I would think that would probably have something to do with it as a young boy with my brain developing and just listening to music. So, it’s always been the thing that has excited me and interested me and I wanted to learn how to make this. To the second part, I think that you’re passionate about the things that you are getting better at and the things that you excel at. That can be your passion too so I think
it’s a combination. I’ve been passionate about music ever since I was a kid but the way that I express myself in that music has changed. So before I was playing guitar and singing and now I’m producing music or producing EDM and then I will spend like a week learning songs on piano again. The exciting part to me is that at the end of the day when you’re making something, you’ve made something that you’ve never made before and to me there’s so much to learn about it and there’s such a world that even now I still don’t understand. I’ll listen to a song and be like, “How did they do that?” and then down the rabbit hole I go and that part of it has stayed the same.

Not a lot of Asian Americans have made it as far as you have in the EDM industry. Is the lack of Asian representation something you have noticed or is it something that doesn’t really matter among you and your peers?

I’ve found the EDM community to be very accepting of minorities and I think that’s one of the amazing things about dance music, is that it started out as outcast culture you know? So it’s very accepting and embracing of people from different walks of life and so I think there are a lot of young Asian American artists who are doing great things. In broader culture I try not to think
about it too much but it is true, name one male, non-comedy, non-kung fu actor, it’s like John Cho, but that’s it. Bringing it full circle, it’s not an option to be a musician or to be an artist really and for a lot of my Asian American friends it’s the same way. From a young age it’s like okay, you’re gonna go to school and you’re going to become a doctor or a lawyer and that’s great, there’s no shame in that but I think that there are people out there where that’s not that biggest
contribution that they can have to society, they could be making amazing things and it doesn’t have to fit into one of those pre-prescribed sort of stereotypes of what an Asian should do.

Were you parents pretty accepting when you wanted to quit your job?
