My mom was extremely accepting. She knew how miserable I was and she was like, “Well you’re not going to kill yourself if you do this so that’s good.” I think they were definitely worried, they didn’t quite understand and I think it was like well, “I hope he gets through this phase and doesn’t get addicted to heroin,” and then once they saw that things were going pretty well and that I hadn’t asked therm for money in the entire first three years that I was doing it they were
like, “Oh I guess he can do it.” I think they still worry everyday but what are you going to do.

title: Huncho Jack, Jack Huncho - Travis Scott & Quavo // Album Review
content:
Written by Ela Talu

Following the trend of surprising collaborative albums, Travis Scott teamed up with Migos’ Quavo to create the album with the same names aka Huncho Jack, Jack Huncho. The two had already worked together in multiple tracks, starting with Scott’s sophomore mixtape Days Before Rodeo (2014) and freshman album Rodeo (2015). The combination of Scott’s sound effects with Quavo’s playful auto-tune mastery creates a solid blueprint for this album. The confidence they have established through their successes in the last few years allows for well-crafted lyrics as well.

Throughout the album, the two experienced rappers do not seem like a rap duo totally compatible with each other, yet they show off their unique styles in the most independent ways possible without compromising each other’s vocal formulas. The album starts off with “Modern Slavery” that parallels slavery in America hundreds of years ago with how they are enslaved to their life of luxury with that particular independence. Buddah Bless makes the track even more special by chopping some Otis Redding vocals into the production of the track. “Eye 2 Eye” continues with a feature from the spotlight rapper on Culture II, the junior album of Migos, Takeoff. While Quavo handles the chorus, saying, “We see eye to eye,” to underscore that him and his crew are the only real ones to another, Scott supports it with throwing echoes and ad-libs.

Towards the middle of the album, we come across tracks like “Huncho Jack,” produced by the Canadian producer Murda Beatz who also has had his touch on Scott’s albums Rodeo and Birds in the Trap Sing McKnight, that have more startling keys to create an emotional depth, which has the touch of hip hop’s legendary producer Mike Dean. For the hit track “Dubai Shit,” featuring Migos’ Offset who went platinum with his solo track “Ric Flair Drip” by Metro Boomin’s production, Scott puts himself behind the boards and creates a track that parallels the rappers’ lavish lifestyle with the modern city. Later in “Saint Laurent Mask,” which was named Quavo’s favorite track on the album, we see Dean and Buddah Bless come together to create an instrumental track designed with synthesized reverb and the rappers’ auto-tuned vocals that acts as complimentary melody for the collection of bells, bringing a richer texture.

Overall, Scott and Quavo bring a collective piece with Huncho Jack, Jack Huncho by not only taking part in the vocals but also taking on roles as producers, as well as mastering the tracks in every aspect. They bring in familiar producers to work with so that their powerful and unique sounds can come out as their own instruments accompanying the melodies. This may not be each of the rapper’s best works compared with their previous platinum albums, however it definitely makes a name for itself and give us hope that there is more coming from these artists that we have not experienced the top level of yet.

title: STRFKR @ the Teragram Ballroom (2/4/18) // Show Review
content:
Written by Miranda Montenegro 

A majority of the crowd seemed to have the same expectations going in for STRFKR’s performanceL they wanted to sing and dance along to their famous hit, “Rawnald Gregory Erickson the Second.” Don’t think you’re familiar with this song? Fear not. If you had a television set in your possession or in close enough proximity in 2009, you definitely did. “Rawnald Gregory” appeared in a popular Target commercial that promoted their nationwide pharmaceutical services. This song has gone on over the years to be featured in television shows such as 2012’s Weeds and 2014’s The Blacklist and the 2014 feature film Two Night Stand. Regardless of whether you have heard the song or not (I’m still convinced that a majority of you guys have), this was the song that all the STRFKR fans were excited to hear live. Five minutes into the concert, this was not the case at all.

When STRFKR’s Josh Hodges confidently stepped foot on stage donning a hot pink wig and turtleneck long-sleeved dress alongside the rest of his band, a silence came over the audience for a brief five seconds before they erupted into clapping and cheering. A lot of concertgoers had no idea what to expect from the band. Many of them really did just want to hear “that one famous hit.” Then, without any introduction of some sorts, the band went straight into “Hungry Ghost,” going on to play songs from earlier albums like 2016’s Being No One, Going Nowhere.

While these were STRFKR’s less well-known tracks, everybody appreciated the band’s instrumental-heavy style. As I was listening, I turned back to see how the people directly behind me were taking all of this in. They were shuffling their feet back in forth, nodding their heads. As a wise friend once told me, “You know a band is failing to grab an audience’s attention when some of them have their phones out.” No phones whatsoever. If anything, people were digging these tracks and filming the band for their Instagram and Snapchat stories. As the band began playing some of their more mainstream hits, I began realizing how a majority of their songs covered the anxieties or simply just the concept of death and mortality. Due to the fact that their music generally tends to be on the upbeat and lively side, it could easily be dismissed that the songs’ actual subject matters are based on such topics. However, I was able to notice the trend through bassist and vocalist Keil Corcoran’s emotions throughout the show. Whether he was the one that took over the vocals during the show or gravitated towards the back when playing the drums, his emotions throughout the show were undeviating. Corcoran seemed to be conscious of what subject matter the songs tackled, channeling expressions of agony, pain and melancholy. This was what ultimately made me appreciate the band even more. In general, their songs take such an abstract concept and convert it into something accessible and enjoyable for everyone through cheerful sounds and beats.

By the time the group began playing “Rawnald Gregory,” they absolutely had the audience in the palm of their hands. Once “that one famous hit” was being played, everybody was pleasantly taken aback, realizing that they were truly enjoying the other previous songs. However, that did not stop everybody from singing along and basically taking over the song. At one point, Hodges stopped singing, letting the audience sing for what seemed like the entire song. The audience was in sync, singing to the song as if they had practiced it all together before the concert. Nobody missed a beat. It demonstrated to me how brilliant the song was. While the song lyrics themselves are simple due to the fact that they are only five repeated lines with a slight variation, the song itself deals once again with a gloomy topic – people slipping away. However, you couldn’t tell based on how excited people were to sing this song together. To say the least, I was even more in awe after they wrapped up the song. And to think that “Rawnald Gregory” would signify the concert’s peak… boy, was I wrong.

Immediately after STRFKR wrapped up their famous hit, a dance party was unleashed. While playing songs like “Lazer Fight,” “Interspace,” and “Helium Muffin,” the band brought out dancers dressed in spacesuits and rabbit costumes. These dancers were killing it, interacting with both the performers and fans. People were snapping pictures left and right, going crazy and even getting up on stage to crowd surf with the dancers. Everybody, including myself, was banging on the stage and jumping like there was no tomorrow. When the band began playing their cover of Cyndi Lauper’s 1983 hit, “Girls Just Wanna Have Fun,” people were living. At that point, the audience was going crazy alongside the band and dancers. People were screaming the lyrics while hugging one another. As somebody who attends concerts frequently, I had never seen anything like it. Strangers were going up to one another, encouraging one another to go up on stage and jump into the arms of their fellow concertgoers. It was absolutely incredible.

When the band performed their last song, “Being No One, Going Nowhere,” everybody was still having the time of their lives, singing along and embracing one another. When the performers took their last bow with one another, they left the stage with a resounding “Encore” in back of them. The audience did not have enough of the band and vice versa. That’s why STRFKR came on stage for the last time and performed “Leave It All Behind” and “Maps” with their former bandmate, Patrick Morris. The audience was hyped to see an appearance from Morris, walking out of the show impressed out of their minds. Everybody came in wanting to hear “that one famous hit.” Everybody left wanting to hear every single song over and over again. Sunday, February 4, 2018 was a night to remember.

P.S. Here’s “Rawnald Gregory Erickson the Second” in case you don’t know which song I am referencing (I’m pretty sure you do though.)

title: Business Casual @ The Improv Space // Comedy Review
content:
article by Moses Mascuch

Business Casual is a three man improv team. And Business Casual gets sweaty. After their recent show at the Improv Space, as this writer approached the members Business Casual for congratulatory (and masculinity-affirming) back pats, I detected with each clap between the shoulders a telltale wetness. But this is not the sweat of just any comedian under hot lights. This is the sweat of a group of performers who pile into the family car, throw a brick on the gas pedal, and steer onto the freeway. Their show at the Improv Space was Business Casual in top form, a riotously funny mix of sketch and improv comedy propelled by high-energy performances and an ironic and raunchy sense of humor.

Sweat wasn’t the only fluid on display at their show. Members were spat on, bled from wounds, and several characters masturbated on stage, at least one to completion, leaving a tangible and impressively large load on stage, which was later sheepishly cleaned up. This is all to say that a lot of comedic ground was covered in the Business Casual forty-five minute performance. The show opened with a musical number set to “All That Jazz,” complete with enthusiastically performed choreography. An immediate transition saw the members now being arrested, interrogated about what they did last summer, and put on trial. How does Business Casual get out of this jam? A plea from Jeremy Elder to the invisible judge: “Can we start the show please?” From there, the audience was treated to a suite of sketches, most under a minute. These sketches shared a structure: the title or subject matter of a sketch would be announced, and then a brief scene would take place, typically subverting expectations. For example, a sketch announced as “zipping up your fly,” is, in fact, a father zipping up the backpack of his half-human, half-fly son. 

The sketches were arranged skillfully, with jokes reappearing, often with a slight twist, between multiple sketches. Structurally, most sketches, given their interactions with their titles, had some element of wordplay, so occasionally punchlines could be guessed at from titles. But even when one might anticipate the punchline of a sketch, what’s undeniable is the gusto with which these punchlines are delivered. Even the most jaded comedy snob wouldn’t be able to resist laughing at Hunter Saling’s (as the man-fly) pitch-perfect delivery of the sketch’s final line: “Nyeah, I’m a fly!” One other note on Business Casual’s sense of humor: those who enjoy jokes about buttholes, jerking off, or, shall we say, the physical act of love, will certainly find their interests represented in the sketches of Business Casual. But these raunchy elements are always well incorporated into sketches, they’re never taken to be funny simply by existing. When Corey Lane jerks off at the Thanksgiving table, it’s not just the action itself that’s funny, but rather how he has played on expectations of what unbuckling one’s belt after a meal might be. Perhaps Business Casual can be seen to be within a certain lineage a comedy, where bawdy material is done smartly; comedy that may be vulgar, but isn’t crude.

From sketches, the show then segued into improv. In this section, it was clear just how tight-knit Business Casual is as a group. The three have been performing together since their Freshman years, and it shows. Each member of the group seemed to be both performing an individually realized character, and yet remained in tandem with his two co-performers. I write this as a relative improv novice, who perhaps hasn’t entirely shed the wide-eyed yokel attitude of “Ya really don’t write any o’ that stuff down beforehand?” and as such, I may not be attuned to the subtleties of what makes truly masterful improv. But in my view, I witnessed some an impressive performance. Characters and storylines were spun out and developed with grace, and comedic premises seemed to blossom naturally out of the dialogue, a testament to the comfort these performers have with each other. What struck me about the improv, as with the sketches, was the pure energy behind the performances. Even when the improv felt a little directionless, or seemed to lack a premise, the energy of the performers kept the audience engaged until the hilarity started. There was never a sagging moment where an audience member would be able to disengage from the comedy and perhaps execute a covert phone-check. Business Casual was truly captivating.

Perhaps the best review of Business Casual doesn’t come from my own experience of their recent show, but from the friend who accompanied me to it. He knew, having a hard commitment at 9 pm, that he would not be able to see the whole show. And yet, when the time came for him to leave, my friend was extremely reticent. So engaged was he in Business Casual’s comedy that the act of getting up from his seat seemed to cause him physical pain. If Business Casual is looking for a promotional slogan, feel free to steal this one: comedy so good it hurts to say goodbye.

title: Surf Curse @ The Hi Hat (6/6/2018) // Show Review
content:
Article and photographs by Noelani del Rosario-Sabet

Buds was the album that stole my heart. My eighteen-year-old self listened to it on repeat as I waited to leave the meth-infested small town I lived in. I wanted to be a goth babe in LA. When I heard that Surf Curse would be performing the entirety of Buds, I not only decided to go, but to take my twelve-year-old sister as well. You’re never too young to fall in love with punk, right?

Usually, I arrive late to skip the first act. At the tender age of twenty, I already feel as if I have the stamina of a seventy-year-old. There’s no way I can last through openers and headliners and still be able to drive home. This time, however, I let myself be persuaded by my boyfriend who was adamant about seeing the opener: Brutus VIII.

Brutus VIII was like listening to the punk embodiment of a horror movie. The singer was a character. Not just any character; he was a badass motherfucker. He’s the kind of guy who will make you swoon and rip your heart out…with his bare hands.

Unlike other openers I’ve seen, Brutus VIII really knew how to draw a crowd. Everyone moshed and danced until the singer demanded that they stop. The obedient crowd listened (for the most part) until he ended the set by diving into the sweaty bodies of moshers.

Next up was Surf Curse and I was able to edge my sister and me to the front. The show started with someone flipping off the stage, just barely missing the top of my sister’s head. That’s when the crowd starting churning and bouncing and mushing and mashing.

It should also be noted that about 50 of these people started lining up at 5pm in the blistering heat wave. They should definitely be given props for their dedication to melt in the sun for hours and still have the energy to mosh.

For this show, it was just Nick and Jacob performing. The original duo, just like “the good old days.” They would play a song, stop if they didn’t feel it was right, joke around a little, and tell stories from when they lived in Las Vegas. It all felt very intimate.

Before each song, they would give a little anecdote about how it came to fruition. One that particularly resonated with me was the story of “Ponyboy”. Nick told a story about a night he spent with his ex playing with an Ouija board in a cemetery. It reminded me of the kinds of things my friends and I would do in my hometown. Jacob’s story about going to The Smell for the first time was also heartwarming for any punk kid who grew up outside of Los Angeles.

That’s what Nick and Jacob were really good at. They can relate to you. They can sing about an experience and make you feel like you were right there with them.

title: Iceage @ The Regent (6/6/18) // Show Review
content:
Photographs and article by Tara Kazimi

As of late Iceage has pared themselves down to the extreme, they’ve departed any sort of rhythmic existence and have been cruising through a simultaneously temporary evanescent persona and evermore state of being. 

This has been achieved through the transmutation they are now known for. For early die-hard fans of Iceage this may come as a disappointment as the early sounds of New Brigade have long been set aside (as far as anyone knows, currently at least) to make room for this fast-fusion love child called Beyondless. On one hand you can ask, “what band has ever kept the same exact sound throughout their career?” but on the other, what band has ever matured, slicked-back, cleaned up, and progressed their sound this soon and this quick throughout their career? 

Iceage’s recent show at The Regent, in support of their latest record Beyondless, is a good testament to that. While the crowd seemed to echo frontman Elias Rønnenfelt’s drunken but classy theatrics, the punks there that bled New Brigade could easily be picked out. You could see the frustration in their eyes when coming to the realization that early Iceage would never take control in the way they wanted. Instead this uncompromising rugged but forever chic gothic-pop drone enveloped the space. Their latest record was mainly on display, songs like “Thieves like us”, “Pain Killer”, Catch it”, and “Hurrah” caught extra commotion. They did dip into “Plowing Into the Field of Love” a bit to the relief of some. 

While the music has grown, at least Rønnenfelt’s appearance has seemed to plateau to the satisfaction of his punk idolizers. He still emerges sharp and lustrous, tipsy and drowsy, unforgivable and unforgiving. While he longs to transcend, it is always in hopes his crowd stays the same with as high of energy as ever, and he makes sure of it. While performing he absent-mindedly kicks himself into the front row, constantly throwing the mic’s wire into the faces of those that stood out earliest to see him up front. A couple knees to the face but not a care in the world. He longs to interact and create chaos, even if it has its expenses. Nonetheless, it seems as if he and the band are on such a pedestal that it was a pleasure to endure, the aggression was welcome, and disorder was urged. 

Throughout the show, the artist Roger Ballen’s Boarding House series kept continuously coming to mind. The Boarding House is a transient place in the human psyche, a strange place where people come and go for elementary existence and immediate survival. The body or the home can constitute as a boarding house in certain situations, it just matters how they are confronted and used as a means for continuance. In a way Iceage felt to be a boarding house, this required an anomalous form of relief that everyone longs for when in a rut. That’s why no matter where Iceage goes, whether in demeanor or sound, they’ll be a Need no matter what.

title: Interview with Stonefield
content:
Interviewed by Carla Rowley & Ashley Hoffmann, article and photos by Ashley Hoffmann

If a lava lamp was transformed into music, it would sound like the band Stonefield. Their third album, Far From Earth, was just released a few weeks ago on this latest Friday the 13th if that gives any clue to their aesthetic. Since their first recorded album all the way back in 2011, they’ve developed a thunderous groovy sound and drifted to the forefront of the neo-psychedelic rock scene, touring with everyone from King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizards to Fleetwood Mac. Their songs drip with heavy psychedelic guitars, reverb, echoing harmonies, and distinctive wailing female vocals. I’ve truly never seen a mouth open as wide and passionately as the lead singer’s does as she belts over her drum kit — that’s right, their lead singer drums too.

I insist on first emphasizing their musical prowess for fear you’ll get distracted by what every other profile opens with: Stonefield is an all-girl band of four beautiful sisters, ages 20 to 28. I urge you not to overlook their talent for their charm.

The band just finished their April residency at the Bootleg Theater, and we got a chance to talk to them at their last show before they returned to their native Australia.

You just came out with a new album, how would you describe the evolution of your sound? How would you describe the differences, especially from your second to third album?

Amy: It’s definitely matured… like a fine wine. I think we’ve just gotten better at songwriting and better at expanding away from a typical song structure, or idea of writing a song.
Hannah: And also kind of realizing how to create something that we want to listen to or that we’re envisioning. I think we’ve probably improved a lot on that front.
Amy: Broadening influences as well. I think that probably for this last record, we listened to a lot more newer bands than other records, which probably affected the sound.
Hannah: And also, I suppose the biggest part was that we kind of just went and wrote it without telling anybody. So we weren’t thinking about anyone else.
Amy: We weren’t hearing other opinions during the writing process.
Hannah: Which, as much as you try not to let that affect you, it’s always going to somehow affect you a little bit. So it was nice to not worry about that and just do it for ourselves.

You said you were listening to newer music, do you guys listen to music together? Do you spend a lot of time together? Do you spend ALL your time together?

Amy: *laughing* We spent four days in a van, listening to music, nonstop.
Holly: I feel like we’re very similar in the sense that we like the same clothes, we’re into the same music, into the same movies, we like everything that each other likes.

How does being sisters affect your band?

Holly: I feel like being in a band is such a different experience with sisters. Like if I played in a band with friends it’d be so different.
Hannah: We definitely probably wouldn’t have lasted as long as we have if we weren’t sisters.
Holly: Well it depends on the people that you’re playing with.
Amy: I reckon maybe we don’t push each other as much as… maybe sometimes because we’re too comfortable. I reckon being too comfortable with each other could stop us from pushing each other musically. But at the same time, we do work really hard and do tell each other to work really hard.

We were listening to a bunch of interviews, and every interviewer really emphasizes that you are young women, sisters, and we were wondering if that’s annoying to you, if it discounts you, or if you appreciate the recognition in that way.

Holly: It’s annoying.
Amy: It’s really annoying.
Sarah: ‘Young, young’… yeah, it’s so annoying.
Hannah: It shouldn’t be about that, it should be about the music.
Holly: Like it’s okay but at the same time it’s like, you should recognize us for being in a band, not just because we’re women, that makes us good, you know?

What do you think about the state of women in music, in the industry?

Amy: Well I think that it’s crazy that it still is the way that it is.
Hannah: And that it still has to be a talking point, that “is it harder for women.” It should just be the same, it should just be equal. It is actually just insane that it’s still a thing.
Holly: Like Amy was saying the other day that music festivals in Australia are putting this thing forward where it’s like, by 2020 the lineups of festivals are going to be 50-50 male-female ratios, but like Amy was saying, why does it have to be by 2020? Just do it now. There are plenty of female artists that could be put up on the lineup that are just as good if not better than other male bands.
Amy: Even someone here the other night, that works in the industry, was like, “You can really play! You can really play. You’ve got a story, it’s very marketable. You’re sisters.”
Holly: “You’ve got the looks.”
Hannah: Right, he said “You’re four young good-looking girls… and you can play.”
Amy: So like, it’s annoying. Pretty much.

Did you have a night in your Bootleg residency that was your favorite?

Hannah: Every week is sooo different.
Amy: It has actually been interesting that literally every night feels like a totally different thing. Like, even though we’re playing pretty much the same set, same place, same time… every week has had this –
Holly: Completely different vibe,
Amy: – completely different energy, a different audience. Like, the audience gives off a different energy which makes you give off a different energy. Last week was my favorite, I think.
Holly: For us playing, that was my favorite.
Amy: I don’t know, we just had this angsty kind of aggression!
Holly: It just felt really good. It felt like we were really letting it out, frustration at just, everything.

Are there any bands that you played with that you think you’ll move forward with? Not that you don’t like all the bands you played with! But any in particular?

Holly: There’s one that definitely stands out.
In unison: Hoover III.

Among much conversation they also highlighted Automatic and Church of Sun. Amy also clued us into farm rock – as she explained, “They sing about their tractors… which sounds really weird but it’s really cool. It’s really punk and awesome.”

Amy: Everyone’s been… amazing!
Holly: Which is good because we haven’t had much time to go to gigs whilst we’ve been here. So every residency’s been really good to see bands.

You’ve also toured with Foo Fighters, Fleetwood Mac, Meat Puppets, King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard… It’s hard but did you have a favorite one of those?

In unison: Fleetwood Mac. *laughing*
Amy: We met Mick Fleetwood, which is pretty cool.
Sarah: He was such a god.
Holly: I was saying, he smells so good, and his beard was like silk. *laughter* No I’m not even kidding you, he kissed us on the cheek and his beard was – just you know how it’s always prickly? – it was like velvet. I was like… wow.
Hannah: Imagine if he listened to this and he was like, “uhh… okay who are these girls?”
Amy: He smelled like herbal tea. He smelled really nice.
Holly: We probably sound so strange.
Sarah: We sound like really obsessive fans, but he was just…

How does being in a band affect your sisterhood? Has that developed your relationship in a unique way that you think wouldn’t happen if you weren’t in a band together?

Holly: I reckon that we wouldn’t be as close if we didn’t play in a band together. Because I’m the youngest, she’s the oldest, there’s eight years between us, so like, there’s quite an age gap really, and I reckon that we wouldn’t hang out as much as what we do.
Amy: But then Hannah and I live in the city, and Sarah and Holly live at home in the country. So we go home to the country to practice and write and stuff, so we see each other all the time, and Mom and Dad. We probably wouldn’t even see Mom and Dad as much as we do because they’re there when we practice. Yeah, I think we definitely are closer because of it. We always have been close, before this.
Holly: Sometimes it’s like, maybe not a good thing! ‘Cause we hang out with each other all the time.
Amy: We’d probably be nicer to each other if we didn’t see each other all the time.

Do you have a favorite song you like to play together?

Amy: I like playing “Love” because it’s a real groovy kind of song, it’s a song where you really can lock into each other really well, I think.
Sarah: I like the heavy ones. It’s like, *headbang*. *laughter*
Amy: Yeah, like you can let your frustrations out?
Holly: They’re pretty fun. Like, the other night we were feeling really angsty, so then when we played the heavy songs, I feel like we were all playing really…. it was a good outlet.
Sarah: I feel like it works together for some reason.

How have you liked living in LA for the past month?

Sarah: Honestly it’s really hard to adjust. It’s so, so different here.
Hannah: I do think the main reason that we do find it so hard to adjust is because…I think it’s really important to surround yourself with people that make you feel comfortable, and that you’re kind of used to hanging out with.
Holly: It really makes me laugh because whenever we see anything that’s comforting we’re like, “man that’s comforting,” like anything that reminds us of home. It’s just really funny. Well not even just reminds us of home but just… like the other night we were at that burger place, Sonic, *laughter* and this car of dudes were next to us and they were just being so rowdy and they were like “where are you girls from?” and all that stuff, and it was like late at night and we’d been driving for ages and we were feeling homesick and we were like “ugh this is gross,” and then this car just pulled up to us of these two guys and they were just like laughing at how ridiculous this place was as well and we were like, that’s so comforting. I don’t know what the point of that story was, *laughing* but just that we find things really random comforting.
Amy: It’s just a totally totally different city to Melbourne, so it is hard to adjust. In saying that, we do adjust pretty well, considering, because we’re used to traveling all the time and sleeping in a different bed every night and whatever. But the music scene here is so cool! Like we’ve played with so many amazing bands, people come out and support music. People do at home as well but it seems like such a bigger thing over here which is really exciting, and definitely a bigger audience for our type of music in particular, which is amazing.
Holly: I feel like the more time we spend here, the better it gets, because you find the spots.
Amy: It’s been good spending a month here because it does allow you the time to be like, ‘that place is good,’ ‘the coffee here is really good,’ which is cool to actually have the time to discover things so it’s been really fun.

What are your personalities like, in relation to each other?

Holly: Well Amy, who is the oldest, and me, I’m the youngest, clash reeeaaally badly, because we’re so similar.
Sarah: They’re very alpha personalities, I would say.
Holly: Like, we both have very strong opinions and it has to be our way. And don’t like being told what to do.
Amy: (in a comedic tone) Does anyone?
Hannah: I feel like I’m pretty open to constructive criticism.
Amy: I don’t know, but like, yeah, we clash, like, so much. Like, it’ll just be really passive-aggressive comments back and forth.
Hannah: I don’t even think it’s passive aggressive, I would just say aggressive.

What kind of things set you off?

Holly: Clothes, food…

Food?

Holly: I’m actually not kidding, generally chips, like, I swear to god.

Oh, yeah, like sharing chips?

Amy: Yes, because whenever we get food, this one, Holly, is like, *imitates ravenously shoveling chips into mouth*, so like, no one can get chips.
Holly: No, it’s because we’ll set out a plan at the start of the dinner, like, Hannah and I will go halves on the chips.
Sarah: Here we go.
Holly: And then they’ll just get in there, and it’s just like, that wasn’t the deal. So then I’m like…
Amy: Chips are actually fries, by the way.
Holly: I take my chips very seriously. It’s annoying.

(If you needed any more insight into their personalities, Holly’s a Capricorn, Sarah’s a Gemini, and Amy and Hannah are Aquarius. ;~) )

Do you have any other creative outlets besides music?

Sarah: I like taking photos.
Amy & Hannah in unison: Sarah’s a really good photographer.
Amy: Jinx.
Holly: I really like fashion, I love going shopping. It’s actually an addiction, it’s ridiculous. Every time I get a parcel I have to hide it because I’ll get harassed in the house. Like I’ll walk in and Sarah will be like “What’s that? Open it here!” and I’ll be like… leave me alone!
Hannah: I would say music is my main creative outlet.
Amy: I like crafty things.
Sarah: And baking.
Holly: And she’s good at cooking.
Amy: And gardening, I really like too.
Holly: Oh yeah, we’re all into gardening as well. I love going to movies as well.
Sarah: *laughing* …That’s not creative.
Holly: I was actually thinking, like, maybe I should be a director! I’ve just been, like, what would I do if I didn’t do music? I’ve been thinking about that a lot lately, just random things. Maybe I’ll do psychology, maybe I’ll be a director!
Amy: I think I’d like to be a florist.

Where do you see yourself in 5 years, where do you want to be?

Amy: Ideally to be able to live solely off of music, and be able to tour internationally and not be spending money to do it, that is the ultimate dream. Because at the moment we’re still so fresh over here, it’s like an investment, pretty much, for us. We love coming over here and touring and it would be amazing to keep doing that and keep doing that all over the world …and be able to live comfortably.
Hannah: To record and tour and live comfortably whilst doing it would be the ultimate goal.

How are you feeling about leaving, since tonight is your last show?

Amy: We’re sad to be going home. Excited, but sad.
Holly: It’s sad but I’m also kind of really excited to go home, to see my dog.

The only interview question that we didn’t get to ask was: So, do you need any more sisters?

Stonefield will be playing with King Gizzard & The Lizard Wizzard at the Hollywood Palladium, Friday May 31st.

title: of Montreal with Locate S,1 @ Teragram Ballroom (5/04/18) // Show Review
content:
Imagine yourself at a concert: hands in pockets (or awkwardly dangling by your sides if you’ve made the unfortunate choice of a pocket-less outfit), head bobbing to the beat, shuffling anxiously to maintain footing as people shove by you to get an inch closer to the front. Imagine the stuffy air, sharp elbows, and sticky floors. Now hold onto that image, and imagine the complete opposite—that’s what it was like to be part of the crowd at the Of Montreal show on May 4th at the Teragram. 

of Montreal frontman, Kevin Barnes

Before the band ever graced the stage, I knew the show was going to be something special. The normal pre-show anxiety and mindless chit chat was entirely absent, replaced instead with smiling faces, genuine compliments, and complete and total inclusivity. Fans basked in the warmth of self-expression—donning everything from neon safety vests to vibrant makeup loaded with glitter, every gender, race, sexuality joined together under the power of music.

Locate S,1 – the opener for of Montreal

There couldn’t have been a more perfect opener for of Montreal than Locate S,1. Her psychedelic riffs and dreamy voice slowly but surely amped up the audience for what was going to be the ride of their lives. From the moment they stepped foot on stage—of Montreal gave the fans everything they came for and so much more. Frontman Kevin Barnes’ revealing outfits and glamorous hair and makeup showed fans just how beautiful it was to feel comfortable in your own skin. He didn’t hold anything back, using the stage as a place to express himself fully and freely, an attitude which translated to the audience as they let loose and danced without inhibition. 

Another shot of of Montreal’s colorful getup

title: Ho99o9 @ 1720 (4/27/18)// Show Review
content:
Written/Photos by Tara Kazimi

For a collective that has only been around for a few years, Ho99o9 has challenged the status quo and surpassed basic benchmarks beyond imagine. Their latest tour, Lights Out America, is a more than sufficient testimony to that. After a month of gut wrenching, aggression provoking, and stimulative, basically back to back shows, Ho99o9 finished the final leg of the tour in Los Angeles at 1720 on April 27. Located in downtown Los Angeles, 1720 is the warehouse no one thought they needed. It was spacious yet intimate, had a modern industrial feel, and was surrounded by free parking. It captured and executed a tangible presence that encapsulated Ho99o9 quite well.

Upon approaching the venue, the crowd seemed to mainly consist of white metalheads that were obviously there for 3TEETH. To make the situation even more pressing, when entering the venue, the bouncer had to ask me if I was at the right show. Other than the fact that I was dressed in red head to toe, it was easy to tell that I definitely didn’t stand out from their fan demographic. Surprisingly enough, that momentum never terminated as the night drew on. However, something about that divided crowd revealed a deeper submerged aspect to Ho99o9 that I believe even they didn’t realize was being transmitted.

Eaddy and theOGM thought that the most fitting entrance would be one filled with obscurity. Following through, they came onto a blacked out stage for their first song, continuing with certain frame points only lit by the single light coming from the motorcycle helmet theOGM wore. While known for the theatrics intertwined within their live show, the motorcycle helmet portal sucking light was as theatrical as they got that night. Which I don’t mean to bring up in a bad way, but in a way of freedom and obstruction from an overblown presence that is thought to only be present to make up for a deficit. Of course, Ho99o9 is blood, they are twisted gore, melodramatic visual chaos that seeps through everyone’s pores. But that in no way is to say that their identity is dependent on it; in fact Ho99o9 is in such a transformative and advanced artistic zone that their semblance seemed to come across even more vibrantly when on hiatus and completely naked from all the stagecraft.

In a past Vibe interview, theOGM stated that that “those [3TEETH] ni**as are tight, they’re straight industrial. They’re music is dark and sexy. I’m trying to make dark and sexy music. All we’re making is angry music, two black men.” Ho99o9 survives and thrives within a unique state of limbo, a pulsating world between sensuality and anarchy, something much more than just angry music by two black men. They hold the ability to in one instance play “Street Power,” mechanically oscillating and angering the blood, and in the next play “Splash,” electrifying an erotic susceptibility. Despite their rigid exterior, seductive connotations withstood the pressure and were prevalent everywhere. 

Every spit of genius that comes out of Ho99o9 seems to come from within, never intentionally, which is a test of their subconscious and currently unmaterialized talent. Some time into their set, Sinatra’s “My Way” blasted through the speakers. Eaddy then admitted that he just wanted to take a break, that there was “too much running around, too much horror,” really completing the circle. Even the crowd was able to feel this softer dimension never thought to be associated with them, as throughout the rest of the night couples could be seen grinding up on each other and making out within the pit. It’s a truly strange and enlightening experience to realize that rap-punk isn’t as one-note as you may believe, that even a concept this raw and diabolical can still be layered. Ho99o9 was able to constrict and refract, transform and reform that night. There is a lot more complexities than meets the eye, they are innovative and metamorphic and will not spare the opportunity to rip through any intestine in sight. It’s hard to describe a night or a presence where transmogrification encapsulates everything that it touched, all at the hands of two mutants born to elude.  For when you bleed the devil it evens the odds, no matter where you go you losing your mind…Welcome to the deathkult. Pledge allegiance to the triple nines.

title: 10 Classical Songs Everyone Knows but No One Can Name
content:
Written by Rio Hayashi 

“Earworm” most commonly happens to me with classical music. This is the worst time of earworm because there is no way to search it online. There’s no lyrics. Dadada dada dadada is not going to tell you what the song is called. Even when you sing the melody to somebody, the title of the song is most likely too complicated for anyone to suggest it out of the blue. Personally, this tortures me endlessly.

So I hope this article inevitably gives you a sense of Oh! Oh! Oh! and will provide a name to some of those internal soundtracks in your life.

1. Sabre Dance - Aram Khachaturian (1942)

When the uber gets here faster than you expected and you’re not ready yet.

2. Also Sprach Zarathustra - Richard Strauss (1896)

The legendary opening scene of 2001 - A Space Odyssey <3 <3 <3

3. La Primavera (La Quattro Stagioni) - Antonio Vivaldi (1725)

*sips English Breakfast tea with your antique china whilst listening to the birds chirp*

4. Hungarian Dance No. 5 - Johannes Brahms (1869)

Personally, this is what I call a banger.

5. Rondo Alla Turca - Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1784)

I have no idea why I know this song. Do you?

6. William Tell Overture - Gioachino Rossini (1829)

If your mind is thinking “horses,” me too! It’s the theme of Lone Ranger.

7. Entry of the Gladiators - Julius Fučík (1897)

A song that gives me major anxiety because my mind immediately associates it with circus clowns.

8. Étude Op. 10, No. 12 “Revolutionary Etude” - Frédéric Chopin (1831)

If you can play this song on the piano, that’s the highest you’re going to get.

9. In the Hall of the Mountain King - Edvard Grieg (1875)

A theme song for the quarter system.

10. A Midsummer Night’s Dream - Felix Mendelssohn (1826)

I still have never heard this at an actual wedding :(

BONUS: “The Blue Danube” - Johannes Strauss (1866)

Everyone will have a different movie reference to this song. As of mine, it will always be once again, 2001 - A Space Odyssey.

If you reached the end of this, are you thinking ……where have I heard all of this?

Me too.

I have no idea.

The truth is whether you like it or not, most of what we hear in our daily lives are not in our control, and these songs can be traced in our world everywhere: commercials, movies, TV shows, YouTube videos, etc.

But hey, at least you know the name of it now!

title: Beyond Wonderland 2018 // Show Review
content:
Photo courtesy of Jake West for Insomniac Events

Written by Alexis Chung

The eighth annual Beyond Wonderland ‘18 took place this past March at the NOS Events Center in San Bernardino. With over 70,000 attendees, 60 musical artists, and a decked out events center, Beyond Wonderland was certainly a night to remember. From the captivating decor to the stacked lineup, Beyond
was a wonderful way to spend a weekend with friends and music lovers.

Ambiance

Attendees were greeted with neon lights and art installations as soon as they entered, where many were taking photos with their friends. The flaming lily cups in the middle of the lake gave the festival an Alice in Wonderland vibe, with other colored LED lights and decorations adding to the atmosphere. There was even a caterpillar on a totem going through the crowd, with beautiful lights pulsing through it. Festival goers were mesmerized by the strobe lights coming from different stages, as well as the unique outfits of other attendees. Although the air was chilly, music lovers generated heat by dancing their hearts out at five unique areas.

Stages

Queen’s Domain, a mega structure decorated with lasers, LED panels, and confetti was graced by the likes of Dash Berlin, Tiësto, Alesso, and more. The Mad Hatter’s Castle was hosted by Insomniac’s own renowned bass music brand, Bassrush. In addition, performers such as Kayzo and Kill the Noise helped head-banging fans live out their wildest dreams. Caterpillar’s Garden featured performances by Claptone and Chris Lake, where people could dance to techno and house tunes. The Cheshire Woods Stage, hosted by Insomniac Records, featured Champagne Drip and Discovery Project. No matter what genre, Beyond Wonderland was able to deliver. Trap lovers, bass heads, and ambient fanatics were able to find their stage.

Photo courtesy of Jake West for Insomniac Events

Food

After hours of dancing, attendees feasted on food trucks from around Southern California, including Kogi, Shake Ramen, and Leno’s Tacos. The trendy and insta-worthy food items were a hit among festival goers, and the sustenance was very much needed after the countless hours of dancing.

VIP Experience

The VIP experience at Insomniac Events is always worth the extra price. Being able to enter through the dedicated festival entrance, make Kandi bracelets, and visit the beauty and glitter bar makes the festival that much more enjoyable. In addition, the countless photo opportunities in the VIP area is sure to make

all your friends wish they were there too. Happy Toast served rainbow grilled cheese and glitter tater tots for VIP guests to enjoy. While digging into delicious food, VIPs were also able to gain access to a sectioned off area at the front of the stages to enjoy the music in a less crowded setting. While being in the main crowd is an experience, it was also nice to be able to enjoy your space and spread out while in the VIP area. VIPs could also rest their feet and recharge at multiple seating areas, all while enjoying a refreshing beverage and being surrounded by immersive decorations.

Courtesy of Ivan Meneses for Insomniac Events

Final Verdict

Personally, Beyond Wonderland was one of the best experiences I have had at an EDM festival in a while. I spent most of my time at Queen’s Domain, where I first saw Elephante put down some bangers and remixes. K?d was also another favorite performer of mine, his presence brought a new type of energy to the festival. Although it did rain towards the end of Day 1, attendees pushed through the cold and kept dancing. I was able to expose myself to new artists, new friends, and new memories. Beyond Wonderland is an event I will never forget. Insomniac will always have a special place in my heart, and hopefully it willfor you, too.

title: A Different Age - Current Joys // Album Review
content:
Written by Alexandra Shambayate 

Nick Rattigan, sole member of Current Joys (formally known as TELE/VISIONS), has recently come out with his latest album titled A Different Age. This masterful album blends into the typical Current Joys sounds, while incorporating strong elements of nostalgia and melancholy. While the album retains the standard garage sound, the overall constant slow tempo throughout makes the album stand out from past projects. The album is very honest and sad. A feeling of coming-of-age, but also a sense of stagnancy overwhelms the album. Lyrics of painful truths are sung by a broken voice and paired with sounds of wistful guitar loops. The album describes feelings of frustration and stagnation in a current life situation, distance from one’s self mind and being, wanting to be in love while having empty feelings of love. To me, this album is being alone in a cold car on a rainy day. I think the feeling of being stuck and depressed while wanting something else but not knowing is what’s really captured in the slow and steady
sounds of this project. 

A Different Age is hauntingly and realistically beautiful. Some of my favorite lyrics include, “ Like a life without love God, that’s just insane, but a love without a life well, that just happens everyday and I wish I could change, but I’ll probably just stay the same,” off of “A Different Age,” and, “Cause I’m too young to be part of a dying breed and I’m too young to see that it’s the breed that’s killing me,” off of “My Nights Are More Beautiful Than Your Days.” Although these lines are emotional, the gorgeous instrumentation at times throughout the album breaks my heart a bit more than the lyrics. I highly recommend this album if you need a good cry or are in need of a relatable life perspective. I am in love with this album and hope Current Joys continues making masterpieces such as these in times to come.
tags: my nights are more beautiful than your days

title: 3 Comedy Podcasts to Listen to Before You Die
content:
Written By: Courtney Burness, UCLA Radio Comedy DJ (02/17/16)

1. How Did This Get Made? 

This podcast takes the worst of the worst movies (a la Jupiter Ascending and Sharknado) and asks the real question: How Did This Get Made? Paul Scheer, Jason Mantzoukas, and June Diane Raphael watch and dissect these terrible movies, poking holes in plotlines and harcore judging every aspect of the movies. This hilarious trio makes something enjoyable out of movies that make your brain implode.

2. Gilmore Guys

This podcast goes deep into the realm of Stars Hollow, discussing and analyzing every aspect (of every episode) of Gilmore Girls. From the plethora of pop culture references to the (sometimes questionable) fashion, Gilmore Guys Kevin and Demi are sure to cover it. Never seen Gilmore Girls? Not a problem! Neither has Demi. Follow along episode by episode, and if you’re lucky enough, catch one of their live shows at the Upright Citizens Brigade (Sunset.)

3. Call Chelsea Peretti

Ever-hilarious Chelsea Peretti (Brooklyn Nine-Nine) takes calls from across the nation and chats (/plays mind games with) her eccentric callers. While every episode is filled with gems, perhaps my favorite sound byte is when Chelsea discusses her utter hatred for silverfish (Episode 33: Silverfish Dementia). I’m with you there, Chelsea. I’m with you.

title: Months After Rodeo: Reflecting On Travis Scott // Album Reflection
content:
Written By: Connor Warnick, UCLA Radio DJ (02/09/16)

I cannot say with confidence that an album has given me as much joy as Rodeo has in a long time. No album penetrated my consciousness as deeply as Rodeo did this year. It has now been months after Rodeo, and this album has only gotten better for me. The explosive and gothic production carries listeners on a cinematic adventure through Travis’s life of drugs, sex, fame, and the dark repercussions of such a lifestyle. The expectations following his breakthrough 2014 mixtape, Days Before Rodeo, that I placed upon this album did not seem possible to surmount, yet Rodeo was somehow the youthful Yeezus that I wanted it to be and more. Critics and “serious hip-hop heads” are still caught up with accusing Travis of biting his role models’ ideas, hiding behind bigger names and features, and lacking tangible substance in his music and they continue to ignore his incredible talents and potential. They fail to hear that Travis’s music is possessed in a way that neither Kanye nor Cudi have ever been able to accomplish (“Pornography, “Oh My Dis Side”, and “Never Catch Me” are strong examples of this evil sound that only Travis can really pull off). He does a little bit of everything on this album. He showcases his ever-improving vocal abilities in the forms of his signature autotuned harmonizing, his fiery crooning and wailing, his infectious ad-libs, and his raspy voice as a rapper (the second half of “Ok Alright” is utterly gorgeous). Most of all, it is his amazing ears and eyes that are on display on Rodeo. The album’s all-star cast of features and producers includes Kanye West, Metro Boomin, Mike Dean, Young Thug, Quavo, The Weeknd, Chief Keef, Swae Lee, Future, 2 Chainz, T.I., Wondagurl, Pharell, Toro y Moi, Justin Bieber, SZA, and Schoolboy Q, and to me that is an amazing strength of the album, not a shortcoming. His ability to curate and engineer the sounds and talents of his friends and peers towards his own aesthetic is displayed throughout the album via a absolutely masterfully produced collection of instrumentals. “3500”, “Pray 4 Love”, and “Piss On Your Grave” all have massive industry names and features (Future, Metro Boomin, The Weeknd, and Kanye), yet they are all clearly catered to Travis and only Travis which is something that Travis deserves a lot of credit for. “90210”, “Nightcrawler”, “Antidote”, “Impossible”, and “Maria I’m Drunk” cohere into an incredibly vibrant depiction of the duality between the endless rage and the dark underbelly of Travis’s nightlife. When listened to in the proper setting (with quality headphones or speakers, and maybe with a little Henny in your system), this album is nothing short of phenomenal. It is a livid and visual experience that no other hip-hop album came close to touching this year from a synesthetic perspective.

Travis has never been great at expressing himself verbally. As he himself has said in interviews as well as on “Apple Pie”, he is not a rapper. Thus, he should not be considered under such terms and expectations. I feel guilty placing him in the same category as artists like Kendrick Lamar, Earl Sweatshirt, or even Future because I feel like he is trying to accomplish such a different goal than they are with his art. He wants his music to be a supplemental experience to the multimedia experience that his arresting videos, his exhilarating concerts, his icy merchandise, and his glowing single/album artwork amount to. As he explained in his interview with Complex, his album was supposed to be released with a bonus USB that theoretically would’ve had additional visuals and material on it.

Since he is not a rapper, how should one think of his sound? Travis’s musical genre would be infinitely better described to someone who’s never heard it as something closer to trap-rock, metal/hip-hop, futuristic punk rap, or some hybrid like that, than rap. To me, stylistically, his music and visuals more closely resemble 80’s punk and hair metal bands like The Sex Pistols, Motley Crüe, Metallica, and Guns N’ Roses than Kid Cudi, Kanye, Future, or Drake or any other contemporary artists that I’ve heard him accused of copying. With Future, Cudi, Kanye, and Drake, you can hear their pain and their sadness in their music in different and original ways. But Travis’s sound is evil in a way that theirs has never been (“Skyfall” and “Nothing But Net” are good earlier examples of this). Rodeo reminds me more of Guns ’N’ Roses’s debut album Appetite For Destruction or my favorite horror movie scores than of 808’s and Heartbreak or either of Cudi’s Man on The Moon albums. He has shown over and over in his career that what he lacks in lyrical substance, he more than makes up for in sonic and visual expression and Rodeo displays that extremely clearly and strongly. So I don’t understand why people expect and demand him to change his method of expression right now if he’s clearly shown that that is not who he is or ever intends to be as an artist.

My love for this album is ultimately a result of personal taste, but I’ve been trying to dive deeper into both why I adore the dark theatrics of Travis’s music and why most critics and “real” hip-hop fans are so reluctant to like him. I have followed Travis’s career since his first appearance on “Sin City” on Kanye West’s G.O.O.D. Music compilation album, Cruel Summer. Since then, I have traced and stalked his music all the way back to early YouTube treasures like “Lights (Lovesick)” and “That B!tch Crazy”. If you listen to early songs like “Low” and “Analogue”, then his poppier sounding club-bangers like “Antidote”, “Wonderful”, and “Nightcrawler” make more sense. I think people who accuse Travis of biting, faking, and lying misunderstand and marginalize Travis greatly as an artist. I see the cohesiveness between those early unreleased tracks, Owl Pharaoh, Days Before Rodeo, and Rodeo. It’s clear to me that he is a gifted producer and art director with a taste for dark ’80’s synthesizers, metal guitar riffs, trap drums, and autotune. He has an ephemeral, tortured-soul persona that is hard to grab onto. He lives a turbulent life and his impassioned music and performances reflect that beautifully. He is a new-age “rapper”–a commercialized term that is far more synonymous with “rockstar” than with “storyteller” or “bard” or “poet” in 2016, and I am more than okay with that.

His ceiling is so high. Who else in hip-hop has had such a mastery of unique sounds and visuals at such a young age? Only A$AP Rocky, Tyler, The Creator, and Young Thug come to mind for me. I’m not sure what the future holds for him though. It could certainly go in many directions. It’s interesting that Complex named him “The Man of Next Year” for 2016, when I feel like I would’ve called him the man of next year last year. 2015 was supposed to be his big breakthrough, and in some ways it was, but he must be both frustrated with Epic Records for messing up Rodeo’s release as well as disappointed by Rodeo’s relatively underwhelming success. His two newest singles, “Wonderful feat. The Weeknd” and “A-Team”, and his EDM-club banger collaboration with DJ Mustard “Whole Lotta Luvin’”, are more upbeat and less dark than Rodeo. I’m a big fan of “A-Team” and I enjoy dancing to the other two songs, but they feel less like the Travis that I’ve come to love. He claims he has another new album on the way and frankly I hope it does not continue in this poppy direction even if he is frustrated at the critical and commercial response to Rodeo. The other leaks I’ve heard (“Tourist”, “Left Cheek, Right Cheek”) are more encouraging. Regardless of what critics might say, I don’t view Travis as a trend-follower musically. I’ve always believed Trav’s sound has been very progressive and ahead of its time, and I hope that he does not succumb to conformity in order to improve his image and reputation.

What I want more than anything as a genuine die-hard fan and believer in Travis Scott as an artist is for him to simply ignore his haters and continue to hone in on his individual talents as a producer, curator, director, and vocalist and continue to produce the amazing work that I know he’s capable of. Most people like Days Before Rodeo more than Rodeo (I don’t personally) because it’s slimmer, more measured, more efficient, and more lyrical. It’s a seemingly more mature project despite preceding Rodeo chronologically. Travis is limited as a lyricist because it doesn’t seem like he has much that he’s ever dying to tell us, and that is fine with me. In fact, my least favorite moments on Rodeo are his two attempts at social commentary on “Pray For Love” when he raps unconvincingly, “I’m tired of seeing black kids on the face of Fox” and “Fuck CNN, they don’t wanna see us win”. I am all for promoting social justice, but I don’t think that’s what “Pray For Love” is about and I definitely don’t think that’s who Travis is as an artist.  

He always manages to show me sounds and images that convey his story more powerfully than his words can, and I just want him to keep blowing me away with that.

Another take that I have on Travis is that people hate him because he is essentially the ultimate fan boy who made it. He is living out the hypebeast dreams of many of his fans, haters, and critics. However, while a lot of people dislike him for that reason, I feel like that is a reason why I relate to him and his music so much. Listen to the kids! Travis is the favorite artist of almost every kid between the ages of 14-19. He idolized Cudi and Kanye so much that he decided to follow that dream, and then drew inspiration from them on his own terms until he grew into his own identity enough to gain serious attention. Do you realize how inspiring that is for kids of this generation? A Travis Scott concert is not just a thrilling place to mosh, it is a place to be truly inspired and uplifted, and perhaps that is something only the members of today’s youth culture can fully appreciate because their dreams have not died yet.
