title: The Case For Listening to Gov. Martin O’Malley // UCLA Radio News Op-Ed
content:
Written By: Zach Seidl, UCLA Radio General Manager (02/03/16)

First of all, before you get upset or confused or you laugh so hard your head rolls away and you are unable to reunite it with your body to continue reading this article, I would like to insert the premise that this is not any form of endorsement for the Democrat polling at most 4% in a three candidate race. I will not be voting for Martin O’Malley. It is important though, that he is running and that the viewers of the Democratic debates listen to what he says instead of talking over him, decrying his irrelevance. Is Martin O’Malley going to win the Democratic nomination? No. Is he going to win one state in primary? I’d be willing to bet that he won’t and willing to bet my life that he won’t win more than two. Despite this, when I see the Governor on the stage of the debate, a sense of relief washes over me. He makes me feel that anyone can run for president if you have good ideas, a positive track record, millions of dollars (of course) and a following of at least 2% of polled Democrats. As Gov. O’Malley speaks, I know he knows that he is not going to win and the fact that he is still up there is admirable to me. The fact that he will not win is not reason enough to ignore him. We must be more mature than that. I implore fellow democrats to at least listen to the man during the debates and take note on what he has to say because he might be our best shot at dethroning President Rubio in 2020.

title: Show Review // Club Time 2 (1/23/16)
content:
Review By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio DJ 1/31/16

Photos by: Michael Melwani, courtesy of Fine Time

Late Saturday night as we drove past the neon pink sign for Déjà Vu and into downtown the anticipation for Club Time’s show with the label Lovers Rock was palpable. The fact that Earthen Sea and Aurora Halal were to play live sets in conjunction with the distinguished reputation of the label Lovers Rock and promotion company Fine Time set expectations high.

Without an RSVP to the event you would have been wildly lost. From the street we pushed past a nondescript metal screen door, which even a savvy partygoer could have easily missed. As we walked up the two flights of dimly lit stairs, the music grew gradually louder until finally we emerged into a white room decorated with a centerpiece of leafy plants. Shawn Merz, an alumnus of UCLA, had created two installations of flora and wire for the event. This room opened up to another space, flanked on either side by beige patterned couches. After moving through the space, we finally came upon the room where the music was coming from. This room was a bit small considering the undeniable allure of the Lovers Rock artists, but the sound was loud enough that attendees could still hear the music quite well from any of the other rooms, which encouraged socializing in the entirety of the space.

In the main room, atmosphere was created by a smoke machine paired with a single laser projector to the right of the DJ booth. The light machine was projecting trippy visuals across the crowd and onto the opposite corner of the opposite wall. The bass was so heavy that the entire wood floor was reacting dramatically, which in conjunction with the hyper-crowded room of people, gave the illusion that we could’ve fallen through the floor at any moment.


Damon Eliza Palermo opened the night. Palermo is a Los Angeles based dance music producer. Late last year he released Clouds of David for 1080p, but his jams Saturday night were much more ready for the dance floor than his ambient release.

Up next was a live set from San Francisco native Jacob Long, who goes by Earthen Sea. His set was made up of sublime drones and dub textures, layered with a light house pulse. This segment was an ideal transition between Damon Eliza Palermo and Aurora. It was integrated seamlessly with its preceding set it while leaving the audience with a taste of what was to come by preparing them for something harder. Earthen Sea created Lovers Rock’s first full-length LP, Ink, which was released late last year and enjoyed favorable reviews for its washed-out melodies and trippy immersive qualities.

Aurora Halal was a sorceress on top of her game, as per usual. Her broken beat kicks with massive synth stabs sent the entire room into oblivion. She did a great job of building the energy the entire time she played, and never let up. In addition to being a DJ, Aurora is a visual artist, musician, and promoter based in Brooklyn, New York – who founded the label Mutual Dreaming and co-founded Sustain-Release. It was a gift to be able to see Aurora perform live after what Resident Advisor dubbed “her biggest year yet,” marked by an EP on Mutual Dreaming and touring across the US and Europe.

Ital closed with diverse and eclectic selections – both in terms of genre and in his fresh versus old school material. Despite a few rough transitions, his selections were on point and he kept the vibe going strong into the late night, accomplishing what he set out to do. Daniel Martin-McCormick, based in Brooklyn, founded the label Lovers Rock in 2008 and has explored a wide range of genres over his career, finally arriving at dance music.

At 5AM the lights came on in the smoky room and the small crowd left standing filed out over the sticky floors. The leafy floor centerpiece was spread across the room in a way that illustrated the interactivity of the piece and made it even more beautiful. As we were birthed into the industrial night, the magnitude of the talented musicians that we had just witnessed sunk in and continued to astound me.

Catch the next Club Time show on February 5th to see performances by Soichi Terada, Olin, Guillaume, and Tahl K.

title: David Bowie’s Blackstar // Album Review
content:
Review By: Doug Gil, UCLA Radio DJ 1/18/2016

David Bowie made his career as a polished musical chameleon: Yes, he adapted to the styles of the era, but he was also fundamentally shaping “genre” as we know it.  Even today, accepting that the same man arranged both “Space Oddity” and “Fame” is still a difficult feat for me.  However, one can’t help but give Bowie credit for approaching each new musical identity with such fervor and tenacity. Blackstar, Bowie’s 26th and final studio album is yet another change of pace, exploring a brooding and often eerie side of art rock that’s only fitting given the subject of this record: Bowie’s own mortality.

Admittedly, reviewing an album posthumously is a daunting task.  To avoid the kind of effect John Lennon’s death had on the reception of Double Fantasy, I foolishly attempted to separate Bowie’s passing from the music on this record during my first listen.  But by the time the lyrics hit, one realizes that context is pivotal to interpreting this particular LP.  For the next forty minutes, Bowie stares into the face of death and competes with its voraciousness.

The title track opens the album with spacious chords and percussive attacks while Bowie’s ghastly vocals blanket the rest of the instrumentation.  The result is a sinister, and appropriately dreary opening.  “Blackstar” hits a shift at around the four-minute mark where Bowie’s more familiar, melodic sensibilities come into play.  It isn’t long before this all melds together with the aberrant aspects of the first half of the track, which effectively sets the stage for the rest of the album in the process.

Blackstar is distinctly David Bowie from start to finish, but something always feels a little “off” about every moment in this LP.  Whether it’s the occasional abrasive vocal effect, an unexpected saxophone wail, or the profundity of the lyrics, Blackstar keeps finding ways to be inventive and unpredictable. David Bowie cited Kendrick Lamar as being an influence on the experimental routes this album takes, but I think the finished product joins the likes of Swans in terms of a raw and unhinged rock performance. The fact that this man has provided a soundtrack to his death is unsettling on its own, but the added experimentation and overall freakish tone make each track more exhilarating than the last.  The final two tracks, “Dollar Days” and “I Can’t Give Everything Away” pursue a more ballad-like approach, however.  These songs provide a refreshing contrast to the aggression present on the bulk of this album, but remain somber enough to fit within the larger picture.

The self-awareness of Blackstar really works to its advantage.  Not only does Bowie come to terms with his impending death during the course of this LP, he also embraces his age and the weakening of his voice in a way that, ironically, makes it sound very impactful.  The song “Girl Loves Me” comes to mind as Bowie sings with an exasperated, and equally desperate infliction that is sure to grasp the listener’s attention.

My only complaint about this LP is that the instrumentation struggles to keep up with the vocals on many occasions.  When someone like James Murphy isn’t providing live drumming on tracks like “Sue” and “Girl Loves Me” for example, the instruments begin to sound a little too mechanistic for my taste. There can be advantages to tightly controlled instrumentation, but an album like Blackstar might have benefitted from more unrestrained performances on that front.

Blackstar is undoubtedly one of the braver records I’ve heard in quite some time.  Not just as far as experimentation and risk-taking, but also in the manner that David Bowie handles his own impending mortality.  The subject of death is explored tirelessly in modern music yet it’s an entirely different experience to hear a record from someone at the cusp of it.  It’s rare that someone will get to say goodbye before his passing, and even more rare that he’ll treat his death as an opportunity for an art project.  An album like this is exemplary of the man’s insanity, but also his devotion to music and showmanship until very end.

title: Show Review // Club Time: White Material w/ Galcher Lustwerk, DJ Richard, Young Male, and Alvin Aronson (1/8/16)
content:
Words By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio DJ 1/14/16

Club Time’s White Material night was a flawlessly curated and executed event that showcased both the talent of the performers and the skill of Fine Time as a promotion company. Fine Time gave birth to a wonderful microcosm that transcended the physical and manifested on some ethereal level that epitomized how electronic music and the unadulterated bliss of the dance floor is a universal lubricant for connection.

The event was a creation of Fine Time, the brainchild of Kate Stimac and Tahl Klainman, who met in their time at UCLA. Their website defines themselves as “a live-music promotion company based in Los Angeles that programs concerts in different locales throughout the city.” Fine Time provides a pedestal for emerging and overlooked artists spanning all genres. Among other genre-specific nights, the company puts on Club Time, a house and techno affair focusing on both established and rising artists.

Fine Time’s assembly of show-specific environments was showcased here in the minimal production, which coupled harmoniously with the house and techno. Fog machines worked the whole night as projectors beamed brilliant light work into the crowd. The conjunction of these two elements created the perfect atmosphere in a way that was not overbearing or contrived and perfectly suited the space and the music.

The night was an assortment of artists working under the label White Material. This New York and Berlin based label was founded by DJ Richard and Young Male in 2012 as they emerged from Rhode Island School of Design. The tight-knit nature of the group was tangible in the DJs’ seamless transitions from set to set. White Material prides themselves in making “working man’s techno,” which was evident this Friday night in the group’s skill at producing A1 music, while keeping it accessible to a large population.

We arrived early, as the event page and location e-mail suggested. On a poorly lit row of predominantly unmarked warehouses, our Über driver slowed down and announced that we had arrived. Standing in the middle of an industrial street somewhere in Boyle Heights, we could hear techno ghostly emanating from one warehouse, and the smell of food wafted out along with it. It was chilly – by Los Angeles standards near freezing – outside, which made entering the warehouse feel like coming in from the cold that much more inviting.

When we entered Tahl greeted us with hugs, radiating positive and welcoming energy. I got the chance to speak with him about the venue, the universal appeal of White Material, and how clutch it is to have food at a show. He fondly rehashed how in his time at UCLA, he was a member of Student Committee for the Arts and a DJ for UCLA Radio. He asked me how I had heard about the event and followed by saying he was always curious as to how people had wound up there. Since the location is secretive, announced three hours before the event via e-mail only to those that had RSVP’d, nobody in the crowd was there by accident.

The expansive entry room had refreshments and a food stand serving up kimchi and pulled pork quesadillas on the opposite end of the room, which made me feel like I could’ve lived my entire life there. Past a plastic curtain was the room with the DJ booth which, when we arrived fifteen minutes after the doors had opened, was inundated with smoke from two fog machines and holding only about six other attendees – generating a post-apocalyptic vibe that Alvin Aronson’s pulsating opening set certainly helped to reinforce. Aronson is newer to the label, and his work on WM007 certainly informed what he opened the night with: a special brand of drone techno.

Galcher Lustwerk went after him. A native of Ohio, Galcher Lustwerk graduated from RISD the same year as DJ Richard. His trademark is spoken words and rapping over deep house, a technique that has earned him a large fan base and is especially evident in his seminal mix 100% Galcher. The prolific artist has done work under Ghostly International, White Material, and his own label Lustwerk Music, among others. The inclusion of tracks featuring his vocals – most memorably the banger “Put On” – in the set was enthusiastically lapped up by the crowd.

Next up came DJ Richard, who played a rad acid-soaked set. His set was a blend of the subdued house, ventures into drone, and serene looping heard on his 2015 album Grind and the noise and house that he was previously known for. This was perhaps as a result of his relocation to Berlin, the hub of techno. Richard seemingly haphazardly intentionally stopped his set twice to wait for applause, so when he was interrupted a third time by the power going out for about two minutes it was difficult to tell if it was for effect or whether it was a genuine power outage.

Quinn Taylor, who goes by Young Male, closed with a precise and energizing techno set with a drop of house. His intermittent fist pumping mirrored the crowd’s. Among some of techno-whistle-inducing jams he played was “Zombie Machine” by Gesloten Cirkle, which was an unreal conjunction with a Kraftwerk track that had cats on the dance floor losing their minds. He played the tightest set of the night, but when someone screamed “he’s the headliner!” in my ear with regards to Taylor I couldn’t help but think how co-dependent and complementary the four sets had been and how each of the skilled artists had brought something completely different to the table.

The unifying power of the music and the space really struck me. A sea of 20-somethings dressed in monochrome and baseball caps/beanies has the potential to be an intimidating environment but manifested as accessible and welcoming. The crowd was racially and sexually diverse but music was connecting. The minimal use of smartphones was impressive considering the median age of the crowd was smack-dab in the middle of the millennial generation. The few cultural outliers, like the one douchey-looking guy in a fitted gray suit and man bun, weren’t paid much attention to, as everyone’s focus was so wholly devoted to enjoying the music.

Don’t miss Club Time’s upcoming night featuring Ital, Aurora Halal, Damon Eliza Palermo, and Earthen Sea representing the label Lovers Rock on January 23rd. Fine Time plans to open a venue in East LA later this year.

title: Connan Mockasin at Center for the Arts Eagle Rock // Concert Review
content:
Words By: Gabrielle Sheerer, UCLA Radio DJ

Connan Mockasin’s show December 7th at Center for the Arts Eagle Rock was a refreshing live musical experience. A unique venue, a fluid set list, and an organic chemistry between the audience and the band allowed for a mellow Monday night.

The Center for the Arts in Eagle Rock is formerly a library, which gives it a historic feel. Culture seeps through the walls. Metallic brown chandeliers frame the room, and the remnants of the librarian’s desk function as a bar for refreshments. Connan and his gang came on stage in their goofy outfits- Connan himself and his bass player rocked low braided pigtails. Connan wore a captain’s hat, all setting the tone for the show ahead.

The set was fluid and improvisational. Transitions from song to song either happened where it was just the band’s way of grooving, as if a song was a sentence and they were unable to find a place to end the thought. Or it was the complete opposite, they would end a song and have a little pause where neither them or the audience knew what to do. However, it was ok. Even the awkward pauses were genuine. Connan Mockasin was uncomfortable in their uncomfortableness, being authentic to themselves. It never seemed like they were pushing for a certain aesthetic, rather they rolled with their essence as a psychedelic rock band from New Zealand. Their set had a wonderful mix of ups and downs, as they did a great job of holding and releasing tension. Further, they did not stay at the same volume for the set. It went up and down adding fuel to the songs that deserved the push. During Forever Dolphin Love, the band went off bringing spirits up super high and letting them flow when the song allowed. The show felt intimate and was the furthest from a show where you feel that you’re just listening to a band’ record in a big room. Rather, this show felt more like a jam session, one where you were homies with Connan Mockasin and they called you up to hang around.

The dialogue during song breaks was quirky. Some of the stuff Connan would say was basically incomprehensible due to his accent, soft voice, and some drugs or a lot of beer I’m sure. People from the audience would yell out song suggestions, and he would blatantly curve them. Personally, I find it obnoxious for peeps to do that, but to each his own. The worst part was when someone called out “Caramel” and his response was “yo we already played that one.” There was still a comfortable connection between band and audience, and I felt that the people around me were engaged and enjoying it.

Connan Mockasin’s show at Center for the Arts Eagle Rock was the most rad way to spend a Monday night during finals week. I’m super happy I got to have the experience and I hope he comes around again soon.

Check out his current project with Dev Hynes from Blood Orange titled Myths 001. It’s a three song project and my personal favorite is Feelin’ Lovely.

title: Film Review: More Uncomfortable: Reviewing Entertainment
content:
“What’s the difference between Courtney Love and the American Flag? It’s wrong to piss on the American flag.” The joke told by Entertainment’s unnamed comedian protagonist opens the film and hurls the audience into a two hour Discomfort Simulator. Rick Alverson forces the feelings of the washed-up comedian on tour through Meth Valley (read: the Mojave Desert) onto an unassuming audience. The film lowers us into the murky psyche of the comedian (an homage to actor Gregg Turkington’s Neil Hamburger character) holding out to find something worth living for. The film stands as a masterpiece of ‘cinematic functionalism’ as the cinematic form of the film effectively recreates an existential crisis for the audience. 

A work of ‘entertainment’ fastens the audience in for a high-speed chase down PCH, but Entertainment moves with the sangfroid of a debilitated elevator. Each shot is (intentionally) too long in duration. For example, at a particularly pathetic point in the comedian’s tour he blows a raspberry for well over a minute—the audience in the movie, as well as the real-life audience, are forced to wait out the uncomfortableness. 

The film is comprised of wide angle shots with negative spaces taking up most of the screen, and the general emptiness makes for underwhelming views. With nothing else to see on the screen, a single focal point quickly draws the eye in. As each shot drags on, the viewer’s eye starts to wander. The shot continues to drag on and the eye of the viewer becomes restless. We continue waiting, our expectation bubbling; the silence still builds, and: nothing happens. We, too, have fallen into the existential pitfall. And with each scene, there comes another glimmer of hope—another chance for meaning to take place. 

When the time finally comes that action is taking place, we start to try to make meaning of out of our desperate situations. At a motel we are introduced to a beautiful presenter leading a seminar on the healing nature of various shades of color. As each color is presented along with a host of the flaws it treats, the audience internally scrambles to make something from this seminar. But though instances of colored lights are present throughout the remainder of the film, these instances are disjunctive, a faux motif. Like a man with nothing left to live for, we start to create something out of the steady-stream-of-nothing that life throws at us. We try to rationalize entropy, but looking for purpose in chaos is as futile as finding solitude in a wood chipper. 

The pitfall the protagonist finds himself in is far from inescapable. His cousin and his coperformer open themselves up to the comedian, offering a helping hand to pull him away from himself—but true to his fatalistic character, the comedian refuses to be helped. Even the angelic hostess from the seminar cleanses the comedian in showers of color, but while our Dante continues to circle through the Circles of Hell he refuses salvation from this Beatrice. Similarly, the pitfall we find ourselves in is far from inescapable. This trapping is self-imposed, for we, the audience, in fact paid for a ticket to see the movie. We have the agency to leave the theater thus ending this suffering, but we want our money’s worth; so we sit in anxious anticipation waiting for something to happen.

Words By: Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ

title: UCLA Radio’s Show of the Month: “Fantasy Archive” w/ Jimmy Bazzy
content:
Greetings reptilians. Jimmy Bazzy is the host of the almighty internet music show “Fantasy Archive” on UCLA Radio. This month, UCLA Radio has chosen the show as its “Show of the Month” for not only spreading memes and flourescent color gradient charms webwide, but knowing how to. “Fantasy Archive” showcases only the deepest cuts in the (no love) deep web and goes beyond the world we know as “C++” (or “Earth” for short) to make it all happen. From today’s prominent electronic music such as that from label/collective PC Music to old, underrated SNES video game tunes, Jimmy sure knows how to provide a mean internet-centric type music playlist each week. It really goes to show how much a music genre thrives off a certain aesthetic to truly understand and what a better way to get educated than by tuning into Jimmy’s show.

Want a little background of Fantasy Archive’s aesthetic and learn a little more about Jimmy? Check out this mini-documentary and listen to Fantasy Archive this Tuesday and next Tuesday from 7pm - 8pm (time subject to change once Winter Quarter begins)

title: Interview // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 13 with Naked Giants
content:
Written By: Megan Hullander, UCLA Radio Intern

Photos Courtesy of Red Bull Sound Select

A collection of handmade maj paj lighters lay on the merch table. Composed of cartoon cutouts, each lighter featured a message written by the band.

“Those will sell out quickly,” their manager, dressed entirely in jean, tells me. “I can negotiate with you, if you want to buy them all.”

I settle on one, and ask him if I could chat with the band before the show. He graciously complies, bringing me drummer Henry LaVallee.

Naked Giants is a three-piece lo-fi garage rock band out of Seattle, most easily characterized by their vivacious energy and groovy aesthetic.

“I got dressed up today,” Henry explained, gesturing toward his patterned button down shirt, loose fitting vest, and signature bandana. “I picked my own clothes, but they were like, ‘You’re getting sponsored so you’ve got to wear fancy clothes.’”

He continued, describing how playing house shows has provided the band with experience in channeling their energy and dealing with broken equipment.

“People get moshy and break stuff, and cymbals fall. I almost had a cymbal chop me in half one time because someone jumped into Gianni, he jumped into my cymbal, and the cymbal popped off and landed and sliced me. But it was okay.”

They band recently released their first album, R.I.P., and are currently on tour with Car Seat Headrest. Midway through the interview, guitarist Grant Mullen joined us. He cited his favorite stop on tour as Hot Springs, Arkansas.

“There were natural hot springs. We went in them. They rejuvenated us.” Henry elaborated; “There’s a big mountain that has a lot of water stocked up in it, so there’s a little tourist town where they have bath houses, that are just natural mountain water that is just naturally heated by the whatever science tectonic plates and shit. So they would harness that, but we would just soak for like three hours.”

I leave them there, hoping to squeeze my way to the front for their set. I slipped through the crowd, grabbing a spot near the front on the right side of the stage.

“Are you guys Naked Giants?” a CSH fan asked as she leaned into the stage. Bassist Gianni Aiello smiled and nodded as he fumbled with the chords on stage. The crowd watched intently as the band began to set up, trying to distinguish the band members from the stage crew while they quickly search “Naked Giants” on their phones. As with most opening bands, few in the audience had heard of Naked Giants, but within the first few seconds of the opening song, the crowd became chaotic, aggressively banging their heads and thrashing their bodies around in a fashion that somewhat resembled dancing.

Gianni demanded the attention of the audience, frantically moving his hips to the beat of the music and dropping to the floor in fits of passion. Opposite Gianni, Grant shook his head as he sang, feverently flipping his straggly blonde hair across his face. Refusing to be overlooked, Henry used his entire body in playing the drums, losing his vest and bandana in the process.

Their set left the audience both exhausted and exhilarated. Before the show, Henry explained that, “I really like playing shows where I’m playing on the ground level, with the people. Which if I want to be a big, famous drummer probably isn’t going to last that long. They connect better with me, and I connect better with them when I’m like right there.”

Though the Teragram Ballroom is a relatively small venue, it is large enough for for the divide between those onstage and the audience to be felt, but the passion and indulgence that Naked Giants put into their set made it feel intimate. So to Henry, I say that the connection between the band and the audience is not dictated by the size of the venue. I imagine that whether they’re playing a house show or a festival, the energy that Naked Giants puts in is not lost in effect.

title: Festival Review // Beach Goth 2016
content:
Written By : Elizabeth Hsieh, UCLA Radio Digital Press Intern 

Post Date : 11/4/16

Last weekend, attending the Beach Goth organized by the California home-grown band The Growlers left me feeling far closer to surf-rock music scene than I have ever before. Amidst the array of backlash and angry festival-goers demanding refunds, I can’t help but stand in support with the nightmarish festival experience—if you can even call it that. Throughout the years, the scene has never been a glowing archetype of how a festival should operate. It’s always been a logistical nightmare with its overcrowded claustrophobic feel, unbearable sound quality, and unorganized set times. In fact, the punkish attitudes of the artists inside their lo-fi bubble and the contributors born into the Burger scene seem to perpetuate this type of indie, psychedelic grittiness.

While the first day unfolded without a kink, I couldn’t comfortably say the same about the second day. As the rain came in waves, dampening the festival-goers in body and spirit, the chaos began to ensue as artists changed and even cancelled their scheduled sets. For most of day two, I was huddled in the green room above the Observatory waiting for the rain to subside and for the crowds to disperse from their usual cattle herd formation. I couldn’t help but laugh at the scene of the fuming mom jean clad crowd attempting to break their way through the chain of pink shirted security guards.

But still, the remaining acts (besides Grimes), rallied. Even amidst the wreckage of flooding, overflowing toilets, and electrical issues, the bands continued to press on once the rain ceased.

While concertgoers still urge the Growlers to refund their tickets, I am satisfied with my experience at Beach Goth. To me, these hometown boys cease to seem like kids who simply bit off more than they could chew. Like a band with wild dreams to host a concert that catered to the music tastes of their fans. Like guys just trying to share their music and hope others do the same. Beach Goth’s extreme chaos is not met with anger or disdain, but instead sympathy for this band who tried the best they could.

title: Kubo And The Two Strings // Film Review
content:
Written By : Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date: 11/01/16


I was a little miffed with the movie industry this summer.  It was disheartening.  I began the season pounding through a series of personal and academic projects, one of which was a commitment to check out at least a few tentpole releases in theaters on opening weekend.   Old-fashioned as it may seem, there is something special about turning out to see a summer release on its first Saturday night.  If it’s hot outside, it’s always cool inside the venue.  These days you can even walk up to the bar inside the Arclight and pick up a glass of wine before you head in.  There’s real butter on the popcorn.  You can reserve the best seat in the house if you get your ticket a little ahead of time.  It’s kind of like a movie-goer’s paradise, right?  

Wrong.  All the amenities that I didn’t have as a kid and am blessed to have now don’t mean a thing if the movie sucks.  I can’t afford to down a whole bottle of Riesling at Arclight prices, so drinking away the pain of a bad movie isn’t an option; and unless that’s cocaine instead of salt in those little packets that I put on my buttery popcorn, the new Bourne movie is still going to suck.  And don’t forget the ongoing pain of a spouse who gets dragged out on the one free night of the week to see a bad movie and who glowers until well after brunch on Sunday. Quality-wise, it was kind of a train wreck.  Weekend after weekend I went. Movie after movie:  Bourne, Magnificent Seven, you name it - they were unbelievably bad. After a few hundred dollars spent, many weekends wasted and wondering if my marriage was going to hold up until school started in the fall, I gave up and watched the new seasons of Transparent, Ballers and Mr. Robot rather than go to the theater again.  I’ve loved going to the movies ever since my first one, so many years ago that there were still ashtrays in the armrests and nobody cared if an 8-year snuck into an R-rated movie.  But with this kind of quality at these kinds of prices, I couldn’t do it anymore.  I gave up the ghost. I stayed home.

But just when it seemed over, I began to hear whispers. It’s how word-of-mouth amongst movie fans really works.  At a job interview, on the train, in line at the supermarket, I heard people mentioning this one release – and everything I heard made me want to know more. It was an animated movie.  A hero’s journey type thing that should have been ordinary except for the fact that everyone kept talking about how extraordinary it was. I had to see it.  Without telling a soul, I finally headed to the theater for a midweek, mid-summer matinee on my own – and that’s how I discovered the best release of the summer – Kubo and the Two Strings (2016 – D. Travis Knight).

“If you must blink, do it now.” is the very first line of this breathtaking stop-motion animated film.  From the first moment until the very last frame, the film delivers on visual style, sharp screenwriting and crisp, clear characterization that would put any live-action release of the summer to shame.  From his first moment onscreen, young Kubo faces a world filled with grim realities and vivid dreams that live in the waking world.  Facing a series of challenges placed upon him at birth, he navigates an increasingly treacherous landscape with ingenuity and the assistance of a surrogate family comprised of a talking snow gorilla and a large insect/man hybrid.  While this may sound clunky, the film and narrative are executed with seamless and lyric grace in the vein of Kurosawa with a touch of Tim Burton.  The animation is spellbinding and the performances by an array of star talent voicing the lead characters are excellent. Storytelling is the foundation of magic in Kubo’s world, and that same magic is what he needs to survive it.  The ending will surprise you in such an elegant and heart-wrenching way that I can promise you will never be able to anticipate it.  Do yourself a favor, don’t try.  Let this movie wash over you, move through you, and change you.  Kubo and the Two Strings is water for the soul that thirsts for beautiful storytelling.  Deeply resonant and fiercely committed, this movie saved me from my summer blockbuster cynicism.  It might do something interesting for you too.

So that’s how Kubo and the Two Strings saved me from my own bitterness and restored my faith in the movie business, more or less.  I did myself a favor after I saw it and haven’t been back to the theaters since.  It was an experience I want to keep close to my heart which means I can’t let just any other movie muscle in on the space I’ve given it there.  I won’t lie – for me, the summer blockbuster is a thing of the past.  If Doug Liman ever comes back to direct another Bourne movie I might be tempted, but he’s never going to do it and so I don’t have to make that decision.  Until then, I’ll keep my eyes peeled for more by Laika, the animation house that produced this lovely and compelling tribute to the art of storytelling.  For those who must continue to go, a glass of Chardonnay at the Pasadena Arclight costs 9 bucks – bring your own special salt.

title: Show Review: LUSH @ The Fonda
content:
Written By: Derek Khaothong, Digital Press Manager

Post Date: 10/14/16


Reformed after ages and ages, Lush’s reunion tour was not only a reward for the alternative teenagers and adults of the 90’s, but also an interesting sight to behold for the new wave shoegazers of the millennial generation. Opening with Tamaryn, they followed the essential shoegaze starterpack: long bangs covering their faces, heavily distorted guitars with an extravagant amount of reverb, and great dreamy music. They were a surprise that I was happy to discover, their set consisted of songs like “Cranekiss”, which rattled the floor of The Fonda with banging drums from what sounded like a vintage 90’s drum machine.

Lush opened up with “De-Luxe” and in the beginning of the set, singer and guitarist Miki Berenyi told the crowd to “put their fucking phones away” in a cheeky voice that had the crowd applaud and cheer. Because of the lack of iPhones being waved around in the crowd, I felt like I had transformed back to the early 90’s. For the most part, Lush played their shoegaze classics from the album “Split” and “Spooky”, but also managed to slip in a new song of theirs titled “Out of Control” which sounded nearly identical to their songs prior to their breakup. “Ladykillers” was played somewhat near the end of their set, which changed the atmosphere of the show from dreamy shoegaze to their more Britpop high-thumping catalog. Lush played two separate encores, one with “Lost Boy” and “Leaves Me Cold”, while their second encore consisted of only the song “Monochrome”.

The crowd was an odd mixture of young adult shoegaze enthusiasts, parents seeking nostalgic memories of the early 90’s, and oddly enough a grandpa who could reach the height requirement for a basketball player who wore a fanny-pack. In a similar vein, Lush have lived quite normal lives involving regular day jobs, marriages, and having kids during their hiatus, but in the instant that the music begins playing, they become Lush again, despite Miki Berenyi’s lack of spunky red hair.


Their great comebacks amongst all comebacks of other legendary shoegaze artists of the early 90’s gives extraordinary hope to a revival of an underappreciated genre that continues to thrive and inspire the noisy, vocally-quiet artists of this generation.

title: Show Review + Interview: Jack Garratt @ The Observatory (09/19/16)
content:
Written By : Brianna Klipp, UCLA Radio DJ

This isn’t about you. We’ve grown up thinking everything is about us. Jack Garratt makes it about us.

In a dimly lit room of the depths of the Observatory, an epiphany is about to happen. These fleeting moments awaken us from the stillness of daily ritual, allowing the existential crisis we once had to cease for a moment as we appreciate the vulnerability of British superstar Jack Garratt. The power of a good-live performance is enough to bring a smile, but the power of the Jack Garratt Show is enough to make humans romantic again.

Jack Garratt, best known for his boyish smirk and impressive red beard, brings a British charm last seen when the Beatles were around. He’s ready for this “Phase” in his life, where he’s toured internationally at music festivals to debut his latest album- “Phase.” Performing at Outside Lands and ACL, just to name a few, the audience at the Observatory are close enough to see the sweat drip on the Brit’s forehead. Normally we’d be bothered. This time, we welcome it.

Couples on their first dates begin to hold hands, a birthday girl cries for recognition. The set begins suddenly, and Jack immediately jumps into his first song of the Phase album, “Coalesce”, beginning the percussion and multitasking as he sings into his mic. He doesn’t stop at percussion, as his guitar anxiously waits for its turn. Jumping from instrument to instrument, Jack appears calm and frantic all at once, as he searches for the right sounds to evoke emotion. It works. His voice sounds as melancholic as heard through headphones, as he gracefully displays the range of the highs and lows of an acapella tone. Without waiting for a transition or taking a breath, as soon as the song ends, “Breathe Life” and “Far Cry” keep the crowd on their feet. Throughout all three songs, Jack’s genuinely smiling, and it makes us wonder if he’s singing the song to someone particular. His energy remains consistent and happy throughout the entire show, and for that hour, time stands still as we experience Jack Garratt.

Halfway through the set, Jack admits a confession- he’s exhausted, and with a laugh, he asks if he could do a cover. Covering the now infamous rendition of “Fresh Prince”, Jack lures in the YG crowd next door. Mid song, he notices them. “Don’t be shy! Come on in.” Midway through song, as the crowd in the back pauses to enter the room, Jack jumps in to humming “elevator music”, resembling the sound of a jazzy kazoo through the microphone. “We can wait” he jokes, as the theater feels like an elevator with hundreds of people. Suddenly, he jumps in to a cover of Justin Timberlake’s “Seniorita”, and the intimacy grew closer with each strumming motion of the guitar.

Even for a red bearded brit who’s been touring for the past several months across the globe, the show has just begun. Jack Garratt, better known as the Jack of all trades, has built his show so that he can legally, in public, “play with himself in front of people.” That’s the point of it, he says. “This shouldn’t be a show where I come for an hour to play a song and that’s it. The audience should be left feeling just as physically and mentally exhausted as I am, otherwise I haven’t done my job.”

Jack’s been playing music his whole life, and knew this would always be a part of his career. Finding the bravery to leave college where he was originally going to become a music teacher, he found himself doing music full time. “I am the least important person in the room. I walk out on stage, and I have to give and share a moment with whoever else is in the room. I have to take myself out of the equation. I know nothing that will happen on stage, its up to the crowd as to what happens on that point. But I have to help them.” Jack’s performances are unique to each show, even though his set list remains the same. Like different colors, the energy remains the same, we just experience it differently.

Jack references a conversation with (UCLA Radio’s) Jack Black, who said “We are one person on a planet of billions of people. We must remember we are so small, so it makes it fun to walk on stage and remember that we are still so small…The reason I can say I am the least important person when I’m stage, is because I know I’m the most important person in my life.”

If Jack Garratt wasn’t a performer, he’d be a philosopher. The Millennials’ Descartes, we can say with absolute certainty that as Jack multi tasks through his live performances, sacrificing himself for the sake of other people, we look forward to the next phases in his life.

title: Floral Talk UK Tour @ ArcTanGent Festival 2016
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 09/18/16

I managed to catch Floral on three separate occasions during their UK tour, thanks to some serendipitous and totally unplanned overlaps in the scheduling of my family vacation with their tour. As someone who’s been following the band for a while, it was pretty exciting to see them catching fire overseas especially since the California-native band has yet to tour within the United States. When listening to high volumes of math rock, I’ve found that there are many bands whose sounds may blend together and start to sound more or less the same. Floral has never been one of those bands. Their music is easily recognizable, which comes in large part as a result of Nate Sherman’s rapidly virtuosic and highly melodic style of guitar playing. These qualities are very prominent on the band’s two EPs and their live shows have the added bonus of highlighting both the tightness of the band’s musical chemistry and the high levels of complexity that both guys make seem so effortless. I sat down with Nate and drummer Ty Mayer just hours before the last show of their tour, which was also the largest show they’d ever played. For more about their festival set, check out my “Top 5 Most Anticipated Acts at ArcTanGent” list here. For videos from Floral’s UK tour, including their ArcTanGent set, check out the 2 Stones + 1 Bird page here.

August 19, 2016 - Fernhill Farm, Bristol, UK

Layla: This is your first ever tour and UK tour. How has it been for you guys?
Nate: Unprecedented.
Ty: Really really fun. Especially because you were at a few of the shows.
Layla: I was at many of the shows. I was even at some shows you didn’t see me at. I just decided to stop by in disguises.
Ty: Oh wow. Is that true? That’s not true.
Layla: No, it’s not true.
Ty: I could almost see that.
Layla: No, I had plans.

L: How have the UK audiences compared to the American ones?
N: They’re better. I mean, we’ve had great shows in the US, of course. But I don’t think we expected to feel this good about coming to another country and feeling as welcomed as we were by not just the people watching our shows but the other bands we were playing with and people we’re staying with and promoters. They’re all really stoked to have us and really stoked to be here so it feels really good.
L: Yeah, I feel like the math rock scene in the UK tends to be, if not bigger then just more connected than in the US. Would you guys agree with that?
T: We only have a small amount of data points to go on so it’s hard to say but that’s what it seems like to us, yeah.

L: In your time in the UK, have you picked up any British slang that you’re bringing back to the US with you?
N: I would say wanking. That’s a big one. I mean, I always refer to wanking as playing guitar really weirdly but now we have another use for it. I’ve started referring to things as half-two and half-three instead of two-thirty or three-thirty. Ty accidentally said uni at one point.
T: I did. Someone had just said it to me twenty seconds before so that then became the word for that minute for college. But it’s called college.
N: After a few beers you start to have the same mannerism and phrasing as the people around you, just completely unconsciously. I’ll try to sound American but it just doesn’t work sometimes.

L: I know you guys don’t have any touring plans in the future. But if you could choose another country to tour which one would you choose next?
T: We were hearing good things about Germany last night, so probably that one.
N: Yeah, Malik from Town Portal was saying, “Go to Germany”. They put you up and apparently they just really appreciate artists over there. And honestly, compared to the US, this has been pretty good too. But people have said very high things about Germany and just mainland Europe in general. It seems to be the place to be.
T: I think if we did Germany, we’d bring my mom and she’d be our translator.
L: Oh, does your mom speak German?
T: She does. She was a German teacher. We have no German heritage but she accidentally wound up in a German class once and basically it became her major. So we would bring her along.
N: How do you think your mom would hold up on tour, Ty?
T: Better than me, for sure. She knows how to camp. She can rough it.

L: Getting more into gear stuff. Nate, I know you’re not technically endorsed by Daisy Rock yet.
N: No, it’s sort of a joke that the hashtag #daisyrockpleaseendorsenate has found its way into various posts. And I don’t know, I hope they’ll [see] this interview and listen to my music and think “This guy would do pretty well with the Daisy Rock endorsement”. You know, just send me a few free guitars. I already have 3 Daisy Rocks and I want more to keep them in all sorts of tunings.
L: Can you talk about why you chose Daisy Rock? Because I don’t think I’ll see any others at this festival.
N: Well, my mom bought one. I think because she thought it was cute. But I always liked having different guitars to keep in different tunings. I was experimenting with trying to find a tuning for this project that is now Floral and I took it from my mom without asking because she wasn’t really playing it and I restrung it and it just sort of stuck. I guess I really liked how light they are. I’m really not a fan of heavy guitars And they were short, which was a big deal actually because my high string is tuned so high and I actually tried doing the same tuning that I do on a different guitar and I kept on snapping the high string. Which meant that I probably should have gotten a thinner string. But it worked on this guitar. It’s the Daisy Rock Rock Candy Special. It’s like a custom. I haven’t been able to find the same model online for a while. But yeah [they’re] just light, short, they look cool. That’s a big one, that they look really cool.
L: Yeah, they do. They’re fun.
N: They are fun. They’re fun guitars. And they sound great. Honestly, people come up to me and they’re like “Ah man, your tone is so good. What kind of pickups do you use?” And they’re expecting me to say “EMG Bare Knuckles” or something like that. And I’m like “No, these are just the stock pickups that came in my Daisy Rock”. They’re Seymour Duncans. They have a coil tap and everything so sometimes if I’m feeling it I’ll just pull the coil tap and play single coil for some songs. But yeah, that’s why I like them.

L: Awesome. So, I happen to know that you guys have been playing music together for many years. But at what point did you decide to make the switch to math rock and give birth to what is now Floral?
T: Three years ago, I think. We were in another band where we played different instruments and we had a drummer. And at one point the drummer’s schedule just conflicted too much and we had to stop playing with him. I think I had already started living with Nate at the time, or at least I was going over everyday. So he just pulled out “Climbing a Wall”, the riff from that, and so we started working on that.
N: And we wrote other songs.
L: And now you have two EPs together.
N: Yeah. Pretty much all the songs for both EPs were written around the same time, like within the same year. But we recorded them a year apart. So it was cool to have all that backlog. And when we played, after releasing the first EP, it was cool to be able to play songs that weren’t on that. Then eventually they all got released. Hopefully we’ll write new songs soon too.

L: Did the songs that were on the 2nd EP grow at all in playing live or were they pretty much the same as when you first wrote them?
N: Ooh, that’s actually a good question. Because we had the songs down and they weren’t recorded. We would just jam them out and we remembered how to play them every time. So maybe not consciously, but I can definitely think of some things –
T: What was the question? I missed the question.
L: The question was did the songs from the 2nd EP that you hadn’t recorded yet evolve while you were playing them live or were they pretty much the same?
T: Well, Nate had the structures down but we just got better at them while playing them live. I probably finalized certain things while playing them live but Nate’s part probably didn’t change too much.
N: I mean, I‘ve found sometimes when you write something, you’re not playing it the most efficient way possible. At first [you’re] just trying to figure out what the best sounding way to play the same part is. But there’s definitely little things that did shift around. The structures all stayed the same pretty much from the very beginning. But there definitely are little things, very little things.
T: I guess “Climbing a Wall” was just half of that song for the first few months and then after we’d written some other ones, we combined two songs into one.
N: Yeah, speaking of the first EP. That was definitely an example of that.

L: What were the early bands you guys were listening to when you decided to – Were you consciously thinking “let’s do a math rock band” or was that just the sound that came out?
N: It was kinda conscious, I think. Parent Guardian, our old band, had some math stuff in it. We experimented with not playing in 4/4 and 6/8 all the time. I was listening to a lot of Town Portal at the time, I found them online and jammed their songs all the time. And then Ty started showing me some bands too, like Three Trapped Tigers and Daughters. He showed me Piglet as well, I think. And Invalids, another huge one obviously. So it was just hearing those bands and thinking “Oh man, people can make music like this” and then I realized I could do it too.
T: I think the first two songs that we wrote, especially because “Climbing a Wall” didn’t have the second part, they weren’t really math rock. It was just that he was finger-tapping, which people call math rock. But it was really straightforward time signature. I think it wasn’t until the third or fourth song that we had anything like that in there.

L: I want to know what do you guys think about the term “math rock”? How would you define it and do you think it’s accurate to your own music? Because it seems like a pretty vague term for some people.
T: I actually think as a genre term, it’s one of those things that it now means a specific kind of music to a lot of people. But the idea of calling rock with odd time signatures math rock makes a lot of sense. It’s one of the more sensible genre names that exist.
N: It does definitely make sense but I feel as though a lot of math rock isn’t necessarily any more complicated than a Frank Sinatra tune. A lot of older music had plenty of short bars and stuff like that and I feel like that’s slowly made its way back into rock-like music. And now we have math rock. Maybe if I’d invented the genre I might have called it something different but I feel as though it’s definitely appropriate. I definitely don’t mind labeling things as a person, I think it’s pretty natural for people to do that. So as a blanket term it definitely makes sense.

L: So, later today you guys have the biggest show you’ve ever played. Do you have any special additions to your regular set or any surprises you’re willing to divulge?
N: We’re playing longer. We’re usually pretty concise with our set but we have a time slot to fill. It’s cool to do that every once in a while. I’m not mad about playing a long set today. Also Dominique, who is doing a juggling set during Gulfers’ set today is going to run over and do a song with us as well. She’s going to do a pretty sweet hat juggling act so that’ll be cool.
T: Also, violent nudity by the end of the show. But that is a surprise.
L: Is the beginning of the show going to be more subdued nudity and then get more violent as the set goes on?
T: You’ll have to wait and see.
L: I will be very excited for that.

title: Taran Killam Interview // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Interview Conducted by: Kim & Aliya, UCLA Radio Comedy Managers (02/18/16)

Taran Killam is an actor, comedian, and, coolest of all, a UCLA drop-out. He is currently a cast member on Saturday Night Live. We recently talked to him about comedy, fame, fortune, and UCLA.

Is anything more important than fame and fortune? If so, what?
Yes. There’s actually 17 things more important than fame and fortune. They are (in exact order): Flossing, Flossin’!, Flotsam (the eel), Flop Sweat, Fetty Wap Sweat, Flambé, Queen Bey, Bebe’s kids, Bebe the clothing store, Investing, Intricate High Fiving, In Room Dining, Vin Diesel, Randy Diesel (Vin’s brother), Bio Diesel, The Movie Bio Dome And Those shoes w/ wheels in the heel.

Do friends and family call you Mr. Hollywood even though you live and work in New York?
Only if they don’t want to be cut off. 


At what point should we give up and just do tech?
May 14th, 2032 at 5:47pm MST

What is the worst advice anyone gave you regarding this crazy industry we call “THE industry”?
Listen to your heart. 

Best advice?
Listen to “Listen to Your Heart” by Roxette. It’s my power anthem.

Why should we hire you when we rise to the top of the entertainment world?
Because by then I’ll be tragically but endearingly nostalgic to you. Kinda like “Fuller House.”

Did your brief time at UCLA help, like, at all? Should we drop out?

(Shakes face loosely and drops the “character” he’s been doing to answer sincerely) The friends I made at UCLA were and are the best friends I’ve ever had. They support me, they are my family and have shaped the man I am today. (Back into “character”) And Twiiiiiiiins!!!! (what?)

Where did you spend most of your time on campus?

Hitch Suites, baby! I was desperate to make my freshman experience as similar to “Saved by the Bell: The College Years” as possible.

Did you know about UCLA Radio while you were at UCLA? If so, what was your opinion of it?
Nope. I was too busy partying! Do not research that. DO NOT RESEARCH THAT!!

Do you listen to podcasts? If so, what are your favorites?

Yes. Many. WTF, Comedy Bang Bang, The Indoor Kids, I Was There Too, This American Life, Serial, The Moment, Here’s the Thing, You Must Remember This and (in my opinion) the funniest podcast ever: Norm Macdonald Live

Anything else you want to say to your adoring fans?
Thanks mom.

title: Night Beats - Who Stole My Generation // Album Review
content:
Written By: Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ (02/16/16)

Who Sold My Generation solidifies the common phrase “third time’s the charm” - Night Beats is making a triumphant return in 2016 with their best album yet. In many ways their second album Sonic Bloom seemed just like part two of their self titled debut studio album Night Beats, but the new album manages to distinguish itself. Who Sold My Generation retains the band’s signature mixture of blues and psychedelic rock but takes a step further. It’s as if the adolescent garage rock they also take influence from grew up a little and grew more confident in their own shoes. Night Beats, now comfortable with their old sound, dives deeper with even more new inspirations - track “Porque Mañana” is sung all in Spanish, “Egypt Berry” adds Middle Eastern influences, and “Bad Love” pays homage to 60’s surf rock. It’s also easy to hear the impact of Robert Levon Been of Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, who guitarist and singer Lee Blackwell cited as important to the production of the album. For those new to Night Beats, the band is akin to if the early Black Keys, B.B. King, and Ty Segall all got together in a garage, dropped acid, and made some music. It’s interesting to see how the musicians have shaped their sound around their local music scene. The band members grew up in Austin and are now based out of Seattle, and the distorted sound of the Seattle grunge scene puts a unique spin on Texas rock and blues. Overall, Who Sold My Generation finally grasps the idea Sonic Bloom and Night Beats were hinting at and pulls in new creative influences, creating an original and catchy album. I’m already looking forward to what Night Beats is going to do next.

title: Entertainment Networking Night Overview // UCLA Radio Comedy News
content:
Written By: Asmita Paranjape, UCLA Radio Comedy DJ (02/08/16)

Here at UCLA Radio, and especially in comedy, we all have a passion for entertainment and the people in it! In my few times at Student Alumni Association’s Entertainment Networking Night over the years, I have amassed some insider tricks-of-the-trade. ENN 2016 killed it just as hard with alumni as amazing as the lines were long. Keep these in mind for networking nights to come.

  • Google “How to Network”
  • Just start talking to yourself, there are so many people they truly won’t notice.
  • Start to well up.
  • Start clearing your throat.
  • Fake an allergic reaction.
  • Throw all normal conversational convention out the window. These people are old.
  • Make the alumni feel old.
  • Ask them about their race.
  • Tell them what gender and/or race you assumed they were by their name.
  • Don’t be afraid of silence. Forbes says it’s a power move!

And the most important thing, above all:

  • Ask for a job.

title: Possible Hidden Member of our Solar Family // UCLA Radio News Report
content:
Written By: James DePaola, UCLA Radio DJ (02/07/16)

In early 1800s, only 7 planets in our solar system were known. By that time, physics had progressed well enough that most orbits and positions of planets could be predicted many decades if not centuries into the future. However, some astronomers noticed that for Uranus, the farthest then-known planet, wasn’t following the physics equations as nicely as hoped. It seemed like something was tugging on it, disturbing its orbit. From these observations, it was hypothesized that another planet, too far to see with the naked eye, was out there waiting to be found. And in 1846 it was found, just where it was predicted. It was a testament to the accuracy of physics.

Today, history may be repeating itself as astrophysicists have noticed similar perturbations in orbits of trans-Neptunian objects. Those objects are the small, icy bodies whose orbits can be tens or even hundreds of times farther away from the sun than our Earth. It’s quite cold and dark there, and it’s hard to spot even large objects. But using the same techniques that led to the discovery of Neptune, researches at Caltech are hypothesizing that a ninth planet is indeed out there waiting to be discovered.

While not officially confirmed, the researchers can use the data from disturbed orbits to estimate things about the mysterious body. They estimate it is 20 times farther from the sun than Earth (or about 186 million miles) and would weigh about 10 times more than Earth (or about 5 thousand billion billion tons). And that is still only half the size of Neptune; Jupiter is still thirty times bigger than the proposed planet. Our solar system is a HUGE place. And it is amazing to know that we can still discover such massive and distant parts of it.

title: Six Movies You May Have Missed in 2015 // 2015 Film Recap
content:
Written By: Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio DJ (02/03/2016)

If you’re exhausted by this year’s award season, which has been dominated by The Revenant and the Oscar’s apparent inability to recognize actors of color, then be prepared to renew your faith in film - there were several overlooked yet extraordinary movies from the past year that deserve a second glance. I’ll admit, I saw Star Wars: The Force Awakens not once but twice in theaters, and reveled in Tarantino’s glorious 70mm, but there were many filmmakers who made much riskier and, in my opinion, much more exciting movies than many of the current award nominees. The next six lesser known films are in much need of due recognition.

1. ‘71

Watch if you like: Cook from Skins, historical action dramas

Jack O’Connell is astounding as British soldier Gary Hook, who is abandoned in the neighborhoods of Northern Ireland after his unit is attacked in an IRA riot. With both the rebel army and his fellow soldiers desperate to find him, Hook is stuck in a game of cat and mouse that keeps you at the edge of your seat until the very end. In an era of action movies where people are constantly shot, stabbed, and blown up without the blink of an eye, director Yann Demange (in his full length feature debut) reverse’s Hollywood’s approach to violence and makes the small number of deaths that occur in the film as shocking and point blank as if the viewer is witnessing them in real life. Managing to provide empathy for both sides, the film allows us to view the tension of Britain and Northern Ireland that occurred in the 1970s from both perspectives, and see the losses both suffered.

2. The Stanford Prison Experiment

Watch if you like: raw, unflinching thrillers

The cast of new up and coming actors in this film is to die for: Ezra Miller, Thomas Mann, Tye Sheridan, Keir Gilchrist, Michael Angarano, Jack Kilmer, and Olivia Thirby (and trust me, the list goes on) make the movie adaptation of the events of the infamous Stanford Prison Experiment absolutely electric. The movie quickly dismisses any possibility of a melodramatic or sensational interpretation and goes straight for the heart - the movie is relentless and expresses just how easily the young participants get swept up into a simulation of the prison environment and the abuses of power. Billy Crudup is fantastic as a professor who struggles to figure out where to draw the line in his fascinating yet terrifying experiment, which was stopped after just six days. The interactions of “inmate” and “guard” are so shocking it’s hard to believe the film is based on actual events.

3. The End of the Tour

Watch if you like: Jesse Eisenberg being Jesse Eisenberg, honest, unedited dialogue

The End of the Tour is based on the Rolling Stone interview that occurred between author David Foster Wallace and journalist David Lipsky, and features little more than the two characters talking and driving along the last leg of Wallace’s book tour for Infinite Jest. Yet the lack of action is made up by fascinating, authentic dialogue that lets us see into the life of Wallace, a troubled, quiet, yet brilliant writer who would later commit suicide. Jesse Eisenberg is quick-witted and arrogant as Lipsky, and Jason Segel is absolutely wonderful as Wallace. Segel’s role as a more serious character will have you questioning why he hasn’t been doing these roles for a long time - it’s truly a shame he was overlooked this awards season.

4. Me and Earl and the Dying Girl

Watch if you like: quirky teen stories, crying your eyes out

Although Me and Earl and the Dying Girl received moderately widespread attention, its inability to shake the pervasive teenage coming-of-age label made some underestimate one of the best films of the year. Based on the novel of the same name, the fantastic script was adapted by author Jesse Andrews himself, keeping the story authentic and free of Hollywood meddling. If you’re convinced this is just another teen cancer narrative similar to The Fault in Our Stars, STOP IN YOUR TRACKS - the film is truly so much more. Awkward, eccentric, creative, and heartbreaking, this movie swept Sundance and won both the Audience Award and Grand Jury Prize. Be warned, however - as a person who very rarely cries during movies, the tears were streaming both times I saw this film in theatres (yes, I liked it so much I went to see it again.)

5. Girlhood

Watch if you like: coming of age foreign cinema, silence as much as dialogue

In another film helping to redefine the dreaded coming of age movie genre, Girlhood takes away the tremendous overload of hormones and drama and lets the viewer appreciate and observe the small, significant events of a teenage girl’s life. Director Celine Sciamma previously explored gender in her film Tomboy, which features a young transgender character, and she is back again to look at the complexities of womanhood as expressed through teenage protagonist Vic. The film is so subtle in capturing the rich details of Vic’s ever changing world you won’t even mind having to read the subtitles.

6. Appropriate Behavior

Watch if you like: Girls and Jenny Slate

Desiree Akhavan shot to the top of my queer crush list when she burst into the Hollywood scene with Appropriate Behavior, which she wrote, directed, and starred in. She adds to the new branch of romantic comedy where female protagonists fuck, fuck up, and (surprise!) don’t end up with Prince Charming, and don’t really need him either. Akhavan follows in Lena Dunham’s footsteps but ditches the white feminism for more interesting commentary on the intersection of her queer and Iranian identities. Combine Appropriate Behavior with Obvious Child (a similar gem from 2014) for a  movie night that celebrates the long awaited combination cinema and the modern woman.

Honorable Mentions: It Follows, Tangerine, Grandma, Mistress America

title: Album Review // Ty Segall’s Emotional Mugger
content:
Review By: Abe Zuckerman, UCLA Radio DJ (1/27/16)

Ty Segall has been releasing vast amounts of music under various names for years, and for years his ability as a guitar player / singer-songwriter has been undisputed.  Since his garage-punk, self-titled, debut album, Ty Segall, released in 2008, Ty has been consistently dropping music that reaffirms his abilities as a shredder and his knack for matching powerful, virtuosic guitar playing with pop-oriented, singer-songwriter style writing.  While both of those two of his defining characteristics are ever-present in the new release, Emotional Mugger also represents a bit of a descent from his dependable formula.  His straightforward punk turns a little more complicated, as seen right off the bat in heavily syncopated “Squealer”, and his investigation into more experimental instrumentation (as first seen in 2015 release, Manipulator) becomes more complex as he plays with a synthesizer on a few tracks.

Emotional Mugger is riddled with the idea of juxtaposition.  There are several instances on the album where Segall places things together that don’t necessarily belong.  In the beginning of “Squealer” different combinations of instruments take turns introducing a Segall-style riff.  In “Californian Hills”, a mellow jam is periodically interrupted by bursts of fast guitars.  Throughout the album, Ty juxtaposes his standard vocal style with that of an alter ego — one with a deep, gravelly voice.  This theme of juxtaposition keeps listeners on their toes and gives the album an uneasiness that mirrors the picture on its cover.


Ty Segall’s Emotional Mugger seems to be a transitional piece.  Ty makes it clear he hasn’t forgotten how to shred or how to write a poppy melody, but he also starts to define a new direction.  The man is obviously not just looking to put out another album.  He is definitely beginning to undergo a sort of transition and whatever happens next is going to be exciting!

title: Indigenous Soul Interview
content:
Interview conducted by: Kelsee Thomas, UCLA Radio DJ

KT: So when did you first fall in love with Hip Hop?

Indigenous Soul: I fell in love with Hip Hop because of my older sister, who was 11 years older than me. So she was a teenager during the 90s while I was like, you know born in ‘95, so like '97 when you can remember things. '98, I was three, 'ya know so (laughs) basic math. I was watching “Supa Dupa Fly” video by Missy and I just wanted to be in this green pasture she was in in the video. I’m not sure why, I just…liked looking at that video…it was the aesthetics of hip hop at the time and the music videos they were a lot different. I did love “Back Dat Azz Up”. (pauses) I shouldn’t have been watching that video, but none of us should’ve-

KT: Well we didn’t even really know what we were talking about. (laughs)
IS: We didn’t, but it wasn’t the ass shaking, although that was fun to do or try to do. It was the weird, cool “afro-futuristic” aesthetics that I saw in Hip Hop. It was watching “Hot Boyz” with Eve, you know a lot of women drew me into Hip Hop. Eve, Missy, it was “no matta what people say…”, you know these videos and these songs. Then Lauryn Hill just sealed the deal, and I was like, “Yo, I can mess with this. I’m not even sure if I can do this, but I can listen to this all day.” And then my music skills kicked in, and it was a wrap after that. It was really a wrap.
KT: That’s dope though.
IS: Yeah, it was BET, it was VH1…
KT: 106 & Park (laughs)
IS: MTV Jams. It was all that.


KT: So what would you define as an artist? You’re talking about Missy, and Lauryn Hill, and back in the day and how Hip Hop used to make you feel and everything. To second that, would you say that some of those people are more artists or considered more of an artist than some of the mainstream Hip Hop artists of today?
IS: The only reason I would say yes is because I feel that art is about originality, in my opinion. Anything can be art, but what makes it special is originality and being innovative and I feel like right now we are in a real “cookie cutter” age where everything, even the videos have to look the same. Where everyone’s trying to have this flow, you know, “I want a Drake flow. I want a Future flow. I want to sound like this person.” When before everyone was like, “Nah, I wanna sound like who we are and whoever’s going to like it is going to take to it.” It wasn’t really so much about being liked, it wasn’t so much about pleasing anyone. I really just think it’s a change in mainstream Hip Hop. At one time, Mainstream Hip Hop to me was very… It was still underground in the sense that it wasn’t the popular thing to do, but it was, for our culture, it was still a “norm”, but the “norm” was to be different. Now the “norm” is to be the same. And that’s my only thing, but there are still plenty of artists today that are trying to, I’m one of them, who’s trying to make their own sound. Chance the Rapper does a great job. Of course we are all influenced by someone. Hip Hop stems from so many different genres, so we all have a root from music of different sorts. Chance the Rapper is new to me, like his sound. Noname Gypsy. Even J. Cole. Kendrick! Like they have influences of other giants. My thing is if you’re trying to make your money, trying to feed your family, do what you gotta do. But that love in Hip Hop stemmed from being so creative and so different.
KT: You’re talking about originality and creativity, especially in music. How do you think you do that within your own music?
IS: I’m talking about things that happen to girls in real life and my message is not exploited by anyone. There’s no one behind my music telling me how to write or telling me, “make this more sexy”. It’s just for anyone who wants to listen. I’m not going to say it’s just for women, it’s for everybody. But I’m really the master behind what I’m saying. I think that makes me different than everybody because I feel like a lot of people are being told what to talk about. Also with my vocals. I have a raspy voice, and incorporate different harmonies because of my choir background. It’s got a bit of an old 90’s, hip hop sound sometimes. There’s reggae, there’s Afrobeat in there. Just whatever I’m feeling.
KT: So it’s you.
IS: It’s me. I had a slight obsession with Afro-Latino culture when I was younger so sometimes I’ll speak in Spanish. It’s really just how I’m feeling. (laughs)
KT: Do you feel like anyone pigeonholes you? Because I know a lot of people say that you have an India.Arie type of feel, an Erykah type of thing, and while those are completely good compliments, do you ever feel like that may pigeonhole you into a genre? While you feel like, “I don’t really do a genre, it’s really just me and how I feel”?
IS: Yes, I do feel like people do that in general just on a daily basis with everything. People can be lazy in their thinking so we always like to categorize what we may not understand or think we understand. So I do think I’m pigeonholed, and right now I think it has to do with my name. “Indigenous Soul, what does that mean? Sounds like you’re walking through the Cameroonian rainforest.” You know?
KT: But you wanted that didn’t you? I mean where did the name Indigenous Soul come from?
IS: I was on the bus (laughs) I was trying to get to Slauson and Sepulveda, right by the Fox Hills Mall. I had been brainstorming different names for a minute but they all made me feel like, “nah, that’s too much” or “that’s just not enough”. Nothing made me go, “Okay! That’s the one!” And then one day on the bus, I was just like, “What about Indigenous Soul?” People always say the cliche, “A voice came into my head” story, but that’s basically what happened. It came to me, and I just kept it. It has several meanings to me. If you break down the word “indigenous”, it means “native to a place or native to a certain area”. On the literal sense, I am an indigenous African, because my parents are from Bamenda, Cameroon. But that’s not really even the reason for my name. I feel like I’m from – actually I don’t know where I’m from. I’m just a native soul. I don’t know how I got here, but I just feel like I’m a child of the universe. That’s where my name comes from.
KT: I think I like your name better now that I know that. (laughs) So talking about not wanting to be pigeonholed and that this is a reflection of you, what’s the biggest thing that you want people to take away from your music?
IS: There’s a few things, but one of the things is to not be afraid to try new things. Not be afraid to talk about things that other people are afraid to talk about and to really be yourself. Because I am neither hot nor cold, I listen to Blackstar and then I’ll go twerk at the club. My intention is not to be different. It’s not to be, “I must be zen”. I mean thanks to Bryson Tiller, we have Trapsoul, I might make a soulful trap song one day and be cool with that. It’s really just about – I just want people to believe in themselves more once they listen to it. I want them to listen to my music and whatever topic I’m talking about and for them to be like, “I can go and do, whatever the heck I want to do because I have the capability”. Because that’s really how I started. I had no training. My parents came here on a very school-related tip, “I got here on scholarship, education was my way out of poverty in an African country.” That was the move. They had a child singing, and were like, “Okay, I’ll let her sing in the corner but she still needs to get these A’s in school.” I wasn’t trained, so I think my music is to say that it’s just whatever raw talent you have, harness it and whatever comes your way take advantage of it. Just do well in life, in whatever way you want to. I want you to be empowered in the way you want to be empowered. Whatever I say is how I think, but I’m not pushing that on you – Scratch that, I want your spirit to lifted after listening. That’s really it. Let me also clarify, it’s feel good as well as – I just want you to feel what I’m feeling too. If I’m mad about corruption, I want you to take from that song, “Damn, some shit’s really going on wherever she’s talking about.” I think sometimes we’re caught in this mindless turn up music, which is okay because I love it, but at the same time let’s have a balance and  let’s feel sometimes. Let’s not always be, “I don’t give a fuck, I don’t give a fuck.” Let’s give fucks about certain things.
KT: So with that being said, you wanting to a be an inspirational artist, “I want your soul to be uplifted when you listen to me”, and that’s what you like in music you listen to yourself, what artists are you listening to – and not just music artists, but artists in all forms of the word – are you listening to, watching, looking at, and are inspiring you right now?
IS: What I’m watching is Cecile Emeke, she has a series on YouTube called “Strolling”. It documents and gives people Bamenda, Cameroon. But that’s not really even the reason for my name. I feel like I’m from – actually I don’t know where I’m from. I’m just a native soul. I don’t know how I got here, but I just feel like I’m a child of the universe. That’s where my name comes from.

Just do well in life, in whatever way you want to. I want you to be empowered in the way you want to be empowered. Let’s not always be, “I don’t give a fuck, I don’t give a fuck.” Let’s give fucks about certain things.
KT: So with that being said, you wanting to a be an inspirational artist, “I want your soul to be uplifted when you listen to me”, and that’s what you like in music you listen to yourself, what artists are you listening to – and not just music artists, but artists in all forms of the word – are you listening to, watching, looking at, and are inspiring you right now?
IS: What I’m watching is Cecile Emeke, she has a series on YouTube called “Strolling”. It documents and gives people a platform to speak about their experiences as members of the black diaspora. It started out in the UK, they have about 10 episodes of young black people from the UK of all different ethnicities – Caribbean, Afro-British – just all kinds from all over the globe. Then they went to France and they interviewed some Afro-French people.
