It really just gives you an understanding of situations of black people that’s not just happening in America, and they have 4 episodes where they went to the Netherlands, they have 2 episodes about Afro-Italians. People that I didn’t even – of course I knew they existed, but I wasn’t familiar with their experiences, and what they go through, their struggle. I like that because it’s so real that it reminds me of my art. I just like truth. I don’t even have to relate to it, as long as it feels real. That’s in no way scripted, everyone just talks about what they want to talk about – struggles, joys, things that piss them off. I like the rawness of it. To me, the interviews are just very artistic. J Dilla samples in the background of every single one or most of them. Music, Iisten to Blackstar, “King Kunta” by k. dot, Choquibtown, an Afro-Columbian group. I like Buika, she’s an Afro-Spanish singer. Shoutout to Mr. Faverly from the 11th grade for putting me on that. (laugh) A lot of Afrobeat, I just go on any soundcloud link and see what comes up, but it really just depends on my mood. If I want to dance I’ll turn on some Afrobeat. Cry, some India.Arie and to let somethings flow. Not just cry, if I want to be into my spirit. When I want to be funky, Erykah. If I want to be conscious, Iman Omari, Moruf. I feel your music, bruh. (laughs) Whatever I can walk to and feel really good. Sometimes I listen to angry rap, it just depends, but it’s definitely global. Majority of the time conscious. Sometimes very unconscious, I really like Kodak Black’s “SKRT”. It’s a really good song.
KT: With you saying whatever you’re feeling, that’s what you’re listening to, you don’t like to just listen to one artist, is that what you love most about the artists that you listen to? That whatever they’re making, their emotion is put into it?
IS: Definitely. Sometimes the emotion is just in the beat! And that’s okay because I can appreciate production. But yeah, I listen to these artists because they share who they are through their music. Honestly, that’s a really hard question.
KT: When you’re creating your art, when you’re making your music or when you’re drawing or painting or dancing or whatever, what’s your process? Or are do you even have one?
IS: A lot of times words just come to me with melodies already attached to them. Sometimes I hear beats, it’s usually a soulful beat or a funky beat. I’ll just start singing, like a character will just come out of nowhere within me and put lyrics to it. It may even be some stuff that I’m not experiencing, but just like Tupac said in Kendrick’s “Mortal Man”, “It’s really just the dead homies speaking through whoever that vessel is.” Things just come to me. My dancing process is really just how I feel, literally vibing with whatever sound I’m hearing and putting those vibes into my movements. Sometimes I’ll make a song and leave it alone and be done. Sometimes I have to wait 2 months, it just depends. There is some type of format because I usually need a beat first, but if I’m in nature and God puts something in my head, I’ll just sing it out loud and record it on my phone, then come back to it. It’s very scattered, but it works for me.
KT: What is your…I shouldn’t say end goal, but what are you working towards with your art?
IS: That’s a wonderful question. College has me wondering.
KT: Because I know this is one thing that I’m struggling with right now.
IS: Yeah, I think because we’re also not just wondering what we’re working towards in our art, but in life. That can be very conflicting because sometimes thinking too deeply into the future makes me forget about my art a little bit. But to be honest, I want to empower myself with my art so I can empower others. I’m working towards making little black girls feel like they can do anything, which is a way that Jilly from Philly, the glorious Jill Scott, made me feel. That’s how Erykah Badu made me feel. Lauryn…just…empowering little black girls and also black boys. That’s one of my goals, but on a very global level because I know a lot of the oppression that we face is global, it’s not just in one place for black people or anybody. I just want to empower anyone who feels like they can’t do something or if anything is holding them back or any inferiority complex. I want my music to be a reminder, even if it’s just “I look good right now”. If that’s a reminder that you need, I’ll bring you that. I want to leave room for more creativity. Erykah did so many things that made me like, “If Erykah can do that, well shoot I can do! I like the fact that we’ve had so many people be pioneers for us. We’ve already been given the okay for things that may seem out of the "norm”, because those people did it. So I want to further push those boundaries.
KT: I know that’s kind of hard to do because we’re in 2015 and we’re coming so late in the game, that it’s hard to push boundaries. I actually was listening to an interview the other day and they were saying that it’s not the point that you go into it saying, “Okay I’m going to make something new. You need to look at the things that inspire you, take that, and then say, 'How is this me?’ Because that’s when you’re making something new. Because nobody can be you.
IS: If the only thing I do is inspire, then that’ll be okay with me. I want people to dance. I want people to laugh. I’m not really a serious person, I’m a soulful person, but I’m a goofball. The end goal should be me being completely comfortable with my artistry, whether I’m in front of one person or 10,000 people, so that that energy can transfer to everyone in my presence. I want them to feel comfortable with themselves. I want it to be that type of exchange – you give me your ears and I give you some comfort.
KT: So you’re talking about stadiums, do you want to be that type of artist? Career wise now. Is the end goal as far as your career, to pack out stadiums or do you want to fill out a coffee house or two?
IS: I definitely want to pack out festivals more than stadiums. Festivals for sure. (laughs) If everyone’s okay with me being me, me being things that you may not understand – on your stage – then I’ll pack out tons of stadiums, but I’ll never water myself down for what mainstream America wants me to be. If everyone’s cool with me being myself and my art, I will pack out the world. But it really just depends on who rocks with me. I rather have 100 people in the room really rocking with me, then a stadium full of people who are like, "Who is this girl?” People who are not open to understanding that which seems unfamiliar. You’re going to have to have an open mind if you’re going to listen to me. As long as the recording labels don’t come to me indirectly saying, “We want you to be a female bojangles”, then I’ll pack their stadiums. But if that’s what it sounds like they’re looking for, then I’ll stick to my 100 people.

You can find Indigenous Soul’s music at:

https://soundcloud.com/indigenoussoul

Check her out for a truly uplifting sound.You can reach her for a collab at theindisoul@gmail.com

title: UCLA Radio’s Top 10 Albums of 2015
content:
First and foremost, this year was jampacked with music coming from all directions. “Album Mixtapes” from artists who decided to make an appearance more than once this year to tide us over until their highly anticipated albums actually sees a release, such as Drake (Views from the 6) and Lil Wayne (Tha Carter V). Unfortunately, there were also those who we still haven’t seen a highly anticipated appearance from, *cough cough* Frankie Ocean where you at!! *cough cough*, hardly even a peep (he did release a gem of a cover earlier this year, gotta give him that). Surprise releases were a hit this year as well, from Earl bringing us I Don’t Like Shit, I Don’t Go Outside earlier this year to Willow Smith’s Ardipithecus just last week.

From the beautiful selection of albums given to us this year that UCLA Radio’s staff chose from, we bring you our top 10 albums of the year!


10. D’Angelo and the Vanguard - “Black Messiah”

- “Waited 15 years for it and it was better than I ever imagined it would be” – Anastasia Gershman


9. Travis Scott - “Rodeo”



8. Oneohtrix Point Never - “Garden of Delete”



7. Drake - “If You’re Reading This, It’s Too Late”


- “One of the best records of the year was released considered as a “mixtape.” However, this was available for purchase on iTunes and caused a bit of controversy because that just simply defeats the purpose of a mixtape. Fortunately, this “album mixtape” features some of Drake’s more sophisticated and egotistical rhymes and themes about being at the top of the game and yadda yadda yadda. That’s not necessarily a bad thing in this case because Drake definitely does it well. Tracks like “Wednesday Night Interlude” and “6PM In New York” are just two out of this selection of bangers that are included and fit very well in the context of the record but are quite special (the former technically being a PARTYNEXTDOOR song and the latter being considered as a “bonus track” to the record). There are quite a lot of surprises, but the biggest one is that when this surprise dropped back in February, it blew up everywhere and it is a damn good mixtape. Whatever Drake did, and whatever he is doing to tide us over for “Views from the 6″, I’m all for it.” – Eddie Hernandez

6. Future - “DS2″



5. Tame Impala - “Currents”

- “The perfect mix of psychadelia, groove, and R and B for my ache breaky heart. In any other year this would be my number 1 (and is currently number 1 in plays for this year), but Kendrick made an all time great album. That being said, there is no better production down to every last snap and synth sound that Kevin Parker creates. I’m a sucker for the polished sound and he lays it on fat here for me. Also, “Let it Happen” is my favorite song of the year, and the dances I’ve had to way too loud listens of it will always make me nostalgic.” – Scott Gee



4. Father John Misty - “I Love You, Honeybear”

- “I’ll be honest, I’m all for that lumbersexual craze an Father John Misty’s aesthetic is a 10/10. But that doesn’t change the fact that his new album ‘I Love You, Honeybear’ is fantastic. It’s not like any of the indie folk rock that I listen to today, and it isn’t as odd and eccentric as Devendra Banhart’s music. There’s still an earthy element to his album but there’s also threads of electronica that give it such a distinct sound. His music is like a collage of music.” – Alison Chi


3. Sufjan Stevens - “Carrie and Lowell”

- “This record hit me hard.” – Nicolo Scolieri

2. Jamie xx - “In Colour”

- “Do you really need a blurb for this album? “In Colour” would represent the best of the year just for the amount of radio coverage it’s gotten, even without having become a personal favorite (which it did)” – Chris Laganiere


1. Kendrick Lamar - “To Pimp a Butterfly”

- “Obvious choice, but one of the most creative important albums of this generation.” – Esther Robinsun-Abrams

title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 15 with HAIM
content:
Written By: Elizabeth Hseih 

Post Date: 12/10/16

Photos Courtesy of Red Bull Sound Select Content Pool 

There’s no doubt that HAIM has become the definition of what it means to be a girl band in the modern age. Fronting two guitars and a bass, The HAIM sisters—Este, Danielle, and Alana—are the girls that broke through the proverbial glass ceiling of a male dominated industry. This power trio headlined for Red Bull’s 30 Days in LA on November 15. With their last album Days Are Gone released in 2013, the crowd bubbled with excitement for the sisters to bang out their newest tunes. For anyone who is unfamiliar with HAIM’s music, their sound is displayed as a kinetic amalgam of many different musical influences—namely rock and synth pop. Undoubtedly, the band is acclimated to playing high energy shows accompanied by a highly engaged audience that raises their hands when ordered to and acts as a backing chorus when a microphone is pointed their way. Easily, the band showcased their undeniable musical talent with their first song “Forever,” that was complimented with a plethora of stank faces and synchronized dance moves.

With their impressive performance prowess, I couldn’t help but notice that almost every person in the crowd failed to participate in an organic concert experience. At the start of the show, with Steven A. Clark and Charlotte Day Wilson as the openers, the crowd seemed disengaged from the obvious emotional catharsis occurring on stage. As Wilson poured her soul on stage, the audience seemed more interested in conversing about Saturday brunch and how-to articles on BuzzFeed. Even as HAIM made their way on stage, arms in the audience quickly shot up, iPhone in hand, in order to snap the best picture for Instagram—a platform so engaged in pleasing, pandering, and pretension.  

The audience’s blatant disinterest in the talented musicians right in front of them had me thinking about the ingenuity of emotion and personal style. As the bands began to play new songs, the battle of voices between conversation of the audience and the singers made itself obvious to me. This sentiment, specifically in 2016, poses the dilemma of how the public is devouring music in the modern age. It seems as if populists are more interested in going to shows purely for their ‘live value’ rather than attending for the pure, unadulterated musical talent. Thus, bands are forced to resort to playing well-known, well-loved tunes that are familiar to the audience’s ears.

With the like-obsessed audience in mind, it seemed to me that HAIM’s ‘cool girl’ persona was at best pandering to the popular notion of what an all-girl band should be. Their array of stank faces, moody glances, and nonchalant attitude initially translated into a way to feed into what the general population wanted them to be. With HAIM’s backing on high-end magazines, A-list friendships, and sold out shows, their trendsetting and “original” persona has been glued directly into their image as a band, leaving them no choice to adhere to what the public wants. We’ve seen this before. Call it selling out. Call it the reality of the music industry.

title: What Now? Review // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By : Rohnie Williams, UCLA Radio Comedy

Post Date : 10/14/2016

Kevin Hart returns to the big screen and releases his third theatrical stand-up special, What Now? I had the pleasure of catching the advanced screening of the film in Hollywood at the World Famous TCL Chinese Theatre. Before the film began, Hart, who right before had an engagement unveiling his star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame, told the audience that this film was his “baby”, his magnum opus.

I can say, without a doubt, this may have been one of the greatest stand-up specials of all time. The stand-up features a frame story in which Kevin Hart lives out his secret agent fantasy with Halle Berry as his “Bond Girl” only hours before he is due on stage. The stage, by the way, is none other than Lincoln Financial Field, the football stadium in his hometown of Philadelphia. For even daring to pack this many people in one space, Hart broke a few records and began the most successful comedy tour of all time with Billboard clocking in so far at $35 million after only selling 600,000 tickets back in March 2015.

I’ve seen Kevin Hart’s previous specials and have finished each hour with tears in my eyes and a pain at my side, What Now?doesn’t disappoint. Kevin Hart touches on his relationship with his then-fiancée, children and father and hanging out with his older friends and getting older himself. Hart, as a seasoned veteran at this point in career, expertly weaves what feels like a continuous story rather than simply telling jokes, starting with a hood ass raccoon and ending with his own inability to make sense of Starbucks.

What really took the film to the next level was how prepared he was for this one to be his biggest and best show yet. Giant monitors supported Hart’s jokes with visuals and sounds that aided in his storytelling. An amazing feat of the design of this show is during Hart’s segment on using the airport bathroom when his “stomach told [his] ass” that he needed to get to a restroom immediately. Hart positioned his stool and with the camera trained on him it looked as if he was sitting on a toilet complete with the sounds of the restroom. The entire show featured other moments of Hart seamlessly playing God and turning all the lights on in the stadium with simply a wave of his hand.

Ultimately, the film was a reminder that Kevin Hart can still kill it with stand-up and everything (except for Soul Plane) Kevin Hart touches will leave you in stitches.

title: Show Review: Chrome Sparks @ The Echoplex (09/27/16)
content:
Written By : Kyle Frankhuizen, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date:  10/04/2016

Brooklyn-based electronic artist, Jeremy Malvin, better known as Chrome Sparks headlined The Echoplex last Tuesday night in a spectacularly hypnotic performance. Malvin, who was educated in classical percussion began performing as Chrome Sparks while studying at the University of Michigan. His musical career took off with the release of the 2013 stoner anthem “Marijuana” which was later sampled by Jamie XX on “Loud Places”. The performance at The Echoplex was characterized by loud, pulsing bass drums and heavy synthesizers which brought unique elements to the electronic genre.

The night’s opener was the Australian producer Roland Tings, whose set list was deeply rooted in the early UK rave and club music of the 1990’s. His music featured long buildups filled with retro-sounding synths and classic club drum beats. While his music was well arranged and mixed, it lacked in tonal variety. Much of the set felt like a buildup for the audience who was eagerly awaiting Chrome Sparks to appear.

Chrome Sparks took the stage with percussionist Bill DeLelles, both clad in all white, a stark contrast to the near pitch darkness of the venue. Malvin surrounded himself with synthesizers and samplers, all connected to his laptop and Ableton Live. DeLelles sat on a drum kit that was also fitted with electronic pads to add depth to the beats. The duo was well rehearsed and the music took new life with live drumming and keyboard performances by Chrome Sparks. After a long introduction, the duo performed “The Meaning of Love” which highlighted Malvin’s heavy usage of the vocoder and “the octagon”, a custom made octagon-shaped light that flashed different colors and three-dimensional patterns with the beat. The octagon captured the audience’s attention and helped transport them into a state of intense musical nirvana.

Malvin and DeLelles performance was unlike most other producers. The two used their musical training to improvise and take the music to new progressive sounds. The overall tone of the show was different than his recorded material; it sounded heavy and psychedelic, as if Malvin had met El-P and Trent Reznor while on an acid trip. The intense synths were welcomed by the audience, who danced along to a hypnotic take of “Send the Pain On”. Chrome Sparks played some newer tracks such as “All or Nothing” which was added to by DeLelle’s drum fills. Malvin closed off the night with a lively rendition of “Marijuana”, during which a smoky haze filled the room. The duo quickly walked off stage only to shortly return, understanding that the audience demanded more. Chrome Sparks played some new material during the encore and made use of the seizure-inducing lighting from the stage, which flashed on and off with the rhythm of each song. At the end of the show, DeLelle walked off stage and left Malvin alone with his synthesizers, where he continued to play along to a sustained chord before thanking the audience and exiting the stage. The set flowed continuously from its onset, as if Chrome Sparks knew that the audience did not want the performance to end.

title: TTNG “Disappointment Island“ // Album Review
content:
Written By: Sanjay Pawar, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 07/31/16

                     “Insight inside an introverted hurt”

          So sings Hank Tremain on the second track, entitled A Chase of Sorts, of TTNG’s latest release, at once an appreciation for the growth that pain so often provides and and a frustration toward the necessity of the hard times in life. TTNG (formerly known as This Town Needs Guns), while existing since 2004, have truly come into their own with their most recent release, Disappointment Island.  This is something I’ve said about every record they’ve released since I first heard 2008’s Animals, so take it with a grain of salt, but I stand by it. The current incarnation of the band, consisting of brothers Chris and Tim Collis, as well as Henry Tremain (who joined the band before their 2013 release, 13.0.0.0.0) conveniently came along with the transition in band names. And with Disappointment Island, they’ve shown that not only are they far beyond talented as musicians, but that the talent is merely a channel for expression of their human existence. Because while they do things with their instruments that seem completely inhuman at times to the ears of a fellow musician, as a person you can’t help but to be overwhelmed with both empathy for the struggles presented in the lyrics and the beauty in those struggles, framed impeccably by instrumentation that is at once intricate and mathematic, yet at the same time vulnerable and elegant. On the newest album, it feels like we’re seeing Hank’s lyricism grow into something even more honest and vivid, and while there is no shortage of odd time signatures and impossible guitar riffs, the music works cohesively to serve the emotion. The opening track, Consoling Ghosts, is a motivational speech to oneself through the process of writing music, as Hank sings: “Option paralysis stole your time, if you don’t decide you’ll fall behind, do you realize this is bigger than you?” and “The worlds likely have less merit than the timbre of their sound, so say anything you feel like, and don’t let it get you down.” The song is a signal of Hank’s struggle to break down the walls separating his emotional self and the music shared by fans around the world. And by the end of this first track, he’s effectively convinced himself that, for better or worse, it’s best to let the words and feelings fall out, and so ensues the rest of the album.

           Through ponderings of life events as heavy as the suicide of a loved one to frustrations with thinking patterns and unconditional loneliness, he maintains a forward progress, not shying away from questions that only raise more questions and inquiring into those brought up by the ones he asks.  Investigating the biology at the root of the emotions he feels, and making peace with the human condition is the drive that pushes this album forward. Tremain searches for the evolutionary roots of depression and the roots of the search for happiness on songs like Bliss Quest. A few times on the album, the band builds and then breaks into powerful distorted guitars, something that hasn’t been seen as much since songs like It’s not true rufus, don’t listen to the hat from the band’s self-titled album, providing an intense emotional release from lyrical topics as draining as existential confusion on Sponkulus Nodge, or the frustration of falling in and out of depression on Whatever, Whenever, where the cathartic resolve at the end of the song exchanges showing emotion through lyricism for an intense, purely instrumental build-up followed by an explosion of wide, overdriven guitars. TTNG experiments with a multitude of sounds on this record that are somewhat new to them, yet they employ them masterfully, such as the tremolo guitar break on In Praise of Idlenesss, proof that you can get down on a grove in a song that is entirely emotionally vunerable. The band puts the rhythm section in the forefront on the song Destroy the Tabernacle!, showcasing a gritty bass tone that we’ve gotten glimpses of on songs like 13.0.0.0.0’s Left Aligned, but never quite to this extent, where the band channels the sounds of bands like The Mars Volta, bursting into a 5/4 breakdown that is nothing short of badass. On Empty Palms, the album’s closing track, where Hank sings “Two holding hands now halved, two empty palms apart. It’s best we part, I am broken and no good for you,” before dropping out and letting the resolve of the sparkling guitar riff leading into the full band playing in unison at a tempo that carries the listener and the band forward, allowing us to reflect on the never-ending nature of the questions asked by the album, and also to be aware of the beauty in being able to ask the questions themselves.

           I was fortunate enough to be able to see TTNG play the Teragram Ballroom on July 22, and the songs played from the new album translated seemingly effortlessly to a live setting. The band’s often bleak lyrics were in no way indicative of their demeanor between songs, as they were constantly cheery, bringing a necessary sense of lightness to the atmosphere. While they were sure to play plenty of songs from the newest record, which were received by the audience as if they had been songs known for years, they were also sure to play favorites from each of their releases. Highlights included tracks like Baboon, I’ll Take The Minute Snake, and Want to come back to my room and listen to some Belle and Sebastian, but the true climax of the show came with the encore, when the band played the leading track from their self-titled debut, 26 is dancier than 4. Hank warned the crowd before that “this song is very hard to play, so we apologize if we mess up,” before breaking into a near-flawless performance of the song, which is not only one of the band’s most technically impressive, but one that is sure to wet every eye that was still dry in the venue. With their latest release and tour, TTNG has shown that they are at the top of their game, and are showing no signs of letting up any time soon.

title: Album Review // Kanye West’s The Life of Pablo
content:
Written By: Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff (02/18/16)

In a followup to his polarizing 2013 effort and a long, contentious series of Tweets, Kanye West finally releases his 8th studio LP: The Life of Pablo.

Just days after this LP’s release, The Life of Pablo is already proving itself to be even more divisive than 2013’s Yeezus, but I have to give West credit for the accidental genius of this album’s marketing campaign.  Emerging almost exclusively via Twitter, the buildup surrounding The Life of Pablo is owed to Kanye’s erratic, ongoing monologue in which he released multiple versions of the album’s “final” track listing, and repeatedly changed the album’s name, cover art, and release date.  The result was an unexpected series of memes involving anyone from casual fans, to big name corporations like Burger King and even Nintendo mimicking West’s baffling social media behavior.

When the album was finally released, the final track list boasted an 18 song set as opposed to the original 10 that West promised with his first handwritten track listings.  Even if West hadn’t made every single edit public knowledge, this sudden dumping of tracks would have been easily apparent, especially given the lack of cohesion that ultimately characterizes the final product.  Many Kanye stans have, and will continue to argue that this album’s blatant “messiness” is purposeful given the project’s namesake, but unlike a Picasso painting, this LP isn’t actually greater than the sum of its parts.

The parts themselves are a mixed bag: Clashing sound changes, underutilized features, and the occasional ill-placed transitional piece make this a difficult record to predict, or really define under any singular concept.  The Life of Pablo opens incredibly strong, however.  The sound on “Ultralight Beam” is distinctively Kanye in its grandiose aesthetic while also delivering on his promise on this album being a bit of a gospel record.  There’s also a Kelly Price feature on this song that goes over remarkably well, and by the end the reigns are dropped into Chance the Rapper’s lap, who, delivers a fantastic and altogether comforting performance to round the song out.

The first part of “Father Stretch My Hands” begins inoffensively enough as a followup, but quickly plummets into this lousy juxtaposition between avant-garde and immaturity that fails to come together in any meaningful sense.  This track is also known for containing the now infamous “bleached asshole” line which is only more cringeworthy in execution than it is on paper.  

“Famous” is actually fairly decent track, even if all the credit goes to the dynamic production propping it up.  The climbing chords and satisfying vocal samples near the end almost make me forgive the bizarre line implicating that Taylor Swift owes Kanye sex for making her famous.  From very early on, it’s apparent that Kanye’s new brand of verisimilitude will only appeal to fans that find Kanye West fascinating outside of the context of this album.  The Life of Pablo after all, is just as mixed and flawed as the persona West has been perpetuating ever since My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy.  There’s no sin in pushing an over-the-top personality, but the problem this album suffers from is that it demands to be taken seriously while simultaneously insulting you for looking too deep into lyrics about having a GoPro for a penis.  It’s easy to be obnoxious, and wholly acceptable to be profound—The real challenge is being both, and it’s a challenge The Life of Pablo doesn’t particularly succeed in.

A track like “Low Lights” for example, is evidence that this album takes itself a lot more seriously than it objectively is.  It’s a dramatic two minute transition in a series of tracks that don’t carry much of a tangible narrative or theme to begin with.  But despite this mostly dissatisfying first half, the album hits a bit of a positive streak beginning with "FML.”  The progression between this track, “Real Friends,” and “Wolves" is seamless and actually pretty refreshing to listen to.  I can’t say I’m totally in love with “FML,” but the Weeknd feature feels very natural, and for the first time in several minutes, we’re getting a cohesive track from beginning to end.  “Real Friends” is definitely one of the highlights of this project, featuring a very spacious beat, and well-written verses detailing everything from disingenuous relationships to having an overall askance approach to everyday life.  The track closes and immediately gives way to “Wolves,” which is eerily strung along by a vocal sample that sits somewhere between a wail and somber howl.  This is a decent track overall, even if the Biblical parallels and lyric about a stolen sandwich warrant a bit of an eye roll at first.  Despite this, you can’t help but appreciate that you’re finally getting the most earnest and serious version of Kanye possible, even if it’s just for a few fleeting moments. 

Unfortunately, this hot streak of tracks hits an abrupt end with the meandering “30 Hours.”  The song begins solid enough—adopting a very casual autobiographical approach, kind of sounding like Mark Kozelek if he took up rapping.  But by the two and half minute mark, “30 Hours” has no business existing.  Kanye insists that all the best songs ride out this way, but all he accomplishes here is accentuating the fact that his best tracks are the ones that have a cohesive plan behind them. 

I definitely don’t have a problem with experimentation in rap music, but unless experimental hip hop begins and ends with abrasive sounds and auto tune, then it’s apparent that Kanye West still hasn’t figured out how to do it very well.  I do think the sounds are more varied and even a little more challenging than they were on Yeezus, but the end result is only "cutting edge” in that it appeals to a very surface level of alternative sounds.  At times I feel like the music is still so self obsessed that it finds more interest in the act of experimenting than in actually making a quality song.  The closing track, “Fade,” is a perfect example of this.  Kanye hardly has any meaningful presence in it whatsoever, and he has certain sounds and samples popping in and out of the track without any tact or particular reason.  Ultimately it’s a pretty lackluster closer, while simultaneously serving as a frank reminder of the mess you just experienced.

Even if it fails to be especially compelling by the eighteenth track, I can give the album credit for holding the listener’s attention through and through.  There’s something uniquely fascinating about listening to Kanye when he’s left to his own devices.  Unfortunately the results aren’t always as interesting as West thinks they are—The concept of making a messy album just isn’t revolutionary.  More important still is the fact that the rewarding moments on this LP don’t magically elevate the lazier ones just because we’re getting a mixed bag.  The Life of Pablo simply plays like a rough mixtape, and not the concept album its being marketed as.  

As of writing this review, fans are currently hard at work rearranging the track last into more digestible, or even sensible pieces—hoping a masterful album lies underneath.  I will not attest to The Life of Pablo being the Blade Runner of rap albums, but I will admit my sympathy for those desperately clinging to the waning brilliance of the “Old Kanye™.“

title: Eaux Claire Festival Preview -- August 12th/13th, 2016
content:
Review By: Alison Chi, UCLA Radio DJ (02/15/16)

I used to obsessively wait for music festivals lineup to be released, only to realize that every major music festival recycles the same artists over and over again. At some point, I was completely numb to music festivals: they were all the same. Just copy and paste Coachella’s lineup to Lollapalooza, change Indio, CA to Chicago, IL.

Sure there would be a handful of music festivals that were somewhat different: Sasquatch and Lightning in a Bottle — but in the end, these music festivals were trying to make money. There was no real heart in curation.

But last year, my excitement for music festivals was reignited when I found out that Bon Iver’s Justin Vernon was teaming up with The National’s Aaron Dessner to create Eaux Claires, a music festival in Vernon’s hometown Eau Claire, Wisconsin. It was so evident that the festival wasn’t some ploy to get money, to sell some sort of teenage fantasy of girls is daisy dukes and flower crowns. Eaux Claires transcended the basic stereotypes of music festivals with a wholesome intent.

I had extensively found out everything I could about this festival, mostly because my love for Justin Vernon grows and grows. Back in 2015, Vernon had stated that he didn’t have any definite plans in releasing music under Bon Iver anymore and that Eaux Claires might be the only place he’d perform under that name. However, Vernon recently did an interview with Billboard stating that he’s been writing new music and will soon embark on a mini-Asia tour. Festival attendees can definitely expect Vernon to be playing some new music as Bon Iver, just as he did last year when he played two unreleased songs.

What struck me the most about this festival was it’s clear intent: to foster a community. While the lineup is indeed centered around folk artists, Vernon also tries to cultivate the Wisconsin and Minneapolis music scene. I’ve personally been a fan of the Minneapolis music scene for a while — and hopefully I’ll see Night Moves and Hippo Campus on the Eaux Claires lineup one day. Another aspect of the lineup that makes it so special is that it is curated by Vernon: he utilizes his resources to invite artists that he loves to listen to, like Senyawa, an Indonesian hardcore metal band.

Additionally, the whole Eaux Claires experience is different from other music fesitvals: Eaux Claires focuses on accentuating their location of rural Wisconsin. It’s everything the little folk lover inside of me could want — a weekend out in the wilderness filled with music and love. Vernon even commented how last year’s Eaux Claires was so heartwarming because the attendees were so enthusiastic and loving: “It felt like I was getting married and everyone was there and everyone was getting married to each other.”

Going through the 2016 lineup, I found some new artists that I’m excited to explore. I’ve mentioned a few that caught my attention but I’ve created a small sampler playlist that highlights only a portion of the talent Eaux Claires will be showcasing this year.

Eaux Claires 2016 includes: James Blake, Bon Iver, S. Carey, Lisa Hannigan, Aaron Dessner, The Staves, Unknown Mortal Orchestra, Vince Staples, My Brightest Diamond, Nathaniel Rateliff & The Night Sweats, Phil Cook, and Phosphorescent.

Alison’s To-Watch List:

Har Mar Superstar

Jenny Lewis

Kill The Vultures

Little Scream

Lucius

Tenement

Tickle Torture

Tuskha

William Tyler

————————–

Spotify Playlist of Associated Artists:

http://bit.ly/1SruB6x

title: Birthday Recap // UCLA Radio Comedy Piece
content:
Written By: Annie Rimmon, UCLA Radio Comedy DJ (02/09/16)

February 3, 2016

8:00 AM Wake Up

8:11 AM Roommate wakes up, sleepily says “Happy Birthday”

8:27 AM walk to class, expect everyone to know it’s my birthday and greet me with cake and party hats

8:38 AM no one knows it’s my birthday

8:39 AM realize I really don’t know that many people

8:40 PM slip into vortex of self-esteem problems

9:01 AM sit next to that one friend who always forgets its my birthday in lecture

9:09 AM said friend asks what the date is today

9:10 AM “February 3” I say out loud

9:11 AM “My birthday, you bitch” I say under my breath

11:14 AM receive text from said friend “lol is it your birthday”

11:47 AM accidentally tell person in office hours it’s my birthday, and professor overhears

12:03 PM professor forces class to sing “Happy Birthday” to me

12:04 PM  seven people that sit in the front row sing as rest of class, mostly international students from Asia, sits apathetically in silence

12:05 PM that one girl who I don’t really know that well, but is really excited about it being my birthday interjects the singing of “Happy Birthday” with “Cha Cha Chicken”

12:05-6:00 PM go to class, eat food, question life so far, have existential crisis, etc.

6:02 PM have dinner with people from office hours and math professor at BPlate because they invited me and I don’t know the next time I’ll get swiped in

6:17 PM stuff face with 7 Grain bread and almond cashew butter because there’s no birthday cake in sight

6:22 PM professor prompts everyone again to sing “Happy Birthday” when I return back to the table

6:23 PM people at surrounding tables kinda sing along but also kinda annoyed

6:46 PM the professor asks what I’m doing that night, expects me to talk about crazy plans

6:47 PM respond “Going out with friends”

8:38 PM Actually go out with my mom, that’s cool now though right? Gilmore Girls makes it ok that my mom is my best friend right?

11:46 PM Go to sleep because all my friends have midterms

Twenty Fun amiright?

title: A Punchable Face // UCLA Radio News Op-ed
content:
Written By: Madeleine McComb, UCLA Radio DJ (02/07/16)

A candidate’s likeability is a wholly subjective metric, the answer depending on whom you ask. Not so with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. Craig Maizin, the Senator’s roommate at Princeton, describes him as an “asshole” and a “cyborg” on Twitter, also claiming that the year they spent rooming together should earn him “reparations”. My (very liberal) mother likes to say he has a “punchable face”. The Senator’s colleagues in Washington are slightly more gracious; former House Speaker John Boehner publically refers to him as an “asshole”, and notoriously mum former President George W. Bush once told donors that he “just doesn’t like” his fellow Texan. Even conservative New York Times columnist David Brooks, a center right guy who typically waxes poetic about morality and civil discourse, took to his wildly popular column on January 12th to declare, “Cruz is a stranger to most of what would generally be considered the Christian virtues: humility, mercy, compassion and grace”.

So why does everyone hate Ted Cruz? And, perhaps more importantly, why is he still polling so well in the national Republican primary?

The Senator’s likeability – or lack thereof – is perhaps one major driving factor for his early support. According to an August poll conducted by the Associated Press, 77% of registered Republicans reported preferring a “Washington outsider” to someone with experience inside the beltway. Furthermore, in a field of true outsiders, people like Donald Trump, Ben Carson, and Carly Fiorina who have never held any elected office, Senator Cruz is familiar enough with the Washington bureaucracy to understand it, but distant enough – and disliked enough – to still appear unsullied. In a country where the approval rating of Congress is somewhere between cockroaches and traffic jams, being an outsider is nothing but upside.

Furthermore, his legislative record while in Washington is that of disruption and disarray. Senator Cruz proudly takes credit for shutting down the government in 2013 in an attempt to defund the Affordable Care Act, and came close to a similar scenario earlier this year over Planned Parenthood funding. His style of governance is puritanical, and thus aligns nicely with the far-right wing of the Republican Party, for whom compromise is a synonym for weakness. As Candidate Cruz attempts to appeal to the Tea Party and other members of the new Freedom Caucus coalition, his balance of elitist East Coast credos with unapologetic conservatism plays nicely among primary voters.

That isn’t to say that likeability is no longer a factor in this or any other race. Any Republican candidate going against the Bush family, David Brooks, and other prominent components of the GOP establishment have an uphill battle to fight. Likeability might be a non-factor right now, as candidates crisscross a frigid Iowa, kissing babies and begging for votes. But anyone with such a face as “punchable” as Ted Cruz’s will likely have to address these problems eventually – after all, it was one sweaty brow that killed Nixon in 1960. In the age of television, addressing one’s likeability problems is an inevitability. But maybe Senator Cruz will have the last laugh; he himself said that he has a “face for radio” – and, really, how bad could that be?

title: Film Review // A Perfect Day
content:
Review By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff Writer 02/02/2016

I wanted to love this movie, but I didn’t.  A Perfect Day takes on a place, space and war that very few would ever define as funny, and misses its chance to show us how wrong that definition might be.

Directed by Fernando León de Aranoa,  A Perfect Day starts out as a ragtag group of international aid workers somewhere in the mountains of Bosnia-Herzegovina in 1995 face down the troublesome problem of a body in a well.  If the body doesn’t come out of the well, regional inhabitants will be deprived of water.  What appears to be a simple problem with a simple solution proves to be anything but, and therein lies the rub.

I wanted to love A Perfect Day.  It seems pointless to beat around the bush and write that I went into this movie without preset expectations.  With a stellar cast and an interesting premise, I imagined that this small movie might bring something interesting to the table as far as film in 2016.  Featuring Benicio del Toro and Tim Robbins as two jaded aid workers attempting to bring sanity to the madness of the Yugoslavian conflict, the film draws deeply from the “war is hell” school of filmmaking.   Stellar examples of this genre would include M.A.S.H., Catch-22, maybe a shade of Apocalypse Now,  and less known pics such as Buffalo Soldiers and a personal favorite, Mediterraneo.  Still, given that these examples all include protagonists who are part of the military war machine, the reimagining of the main protagonists as civilian volunteers seemed to hold promise.   The absurdities of life on the ground in a war zone don’t always translate into war-as-comedy – but when it works, it’s breathtaking.   But as much as I would like to say otherwise, it didn’t work here.

The film finds its best moments in those aforementioned absurdities.  Two aid workers contemplate a dead cow on the road ahead, knowing that likely it was placed there to force cars around and over planted land mines.   They struggle with the decision in front of them: right, left or straight through the cow? – and it’s funny in the worst kind of way.  A search for rope turns into a Balkan Alice-In-Wonderland – children brandish handguns, goat herders face down UN peacekeepers and men bite dogs rather than the other way around.   But it’s not enough.  The hindrances of bureaucracy and an inserted love story weigh the story down in periodic intervals that preclude the ability of the narrative to transport the viewer.   The story never gets a chance to really take wing, and it feels clunky in the spaces where it should be mercilessly funny.   

The cast does what it can.  Tim Robbins and Benicio del Toro both create raspy and authentic characters that beg for more to do and a little more madness to throw themselves into.   The supporting characters aren’t fleshed out as more than props for the two central ones.  The exception would be the lovely star turn by Fedja Stukan as Damir, who conveys the complexity and vulnerability of the place, the war and his position in one riveting and heartbreaking moment.

title: Show Preview // FROM BERLIN TO LA - Feb. 5th - 6th
content:
Written by: Aaron Peretz, UCLA Radio DJ (1/25/16)

We are excited to announce FROM BERLIN TO LA, a weekend-long festival hosted by Your Mom’s Agency that celebrates the exchange of music culture between the sister cities of Berlin and LA. The festival includes workshops and panels on production and DJing in the afternoon. At night, head to any of the five venues sprawled throughout LA to hear electronic music ranging from house to techno to experimental and everything in between.

The best part: all events are free. All that’s required of you to dance like a Berliner with the city’s biggest up-and-coming DJs is to RSVP on Your Mom’s Agency and the Facebook event. Complete info on performances, panels and workshops can be found at the RSVP link for Your Mom’s Agency.

title: UCLA Radio’s Show of the Month: “Rad Womxn Radio” w/ Regina
content:
UCLA Radio is very honored to announce that ‘Rad Womxn Radio’ with host Regina Napolitano is our show of the month for January!!!

Rad Womxn Radio on UCLA Radio is one of the most important shows on the airwaves today. Regina designs each week’s playlist and discussion grounded on ideas and topics about female musicians. It is also some of the most fun you can have tuning into a UCLA Radio show as some of the tracks that you hear are beautifully hand-picked gems that Regina throws into weekly sets that leave you dancing in your living room, headbanging in the shower, spacing out and/or crying to melancholic and heartbreaking lyrics, and much much more.

In addition to having a very thoughtful, eclectic playlist of songs made by female musicians (and non-binary musicians on occasion), there are a lot of very interesting and important talk that happens in between sets of songs from reading off quotes from great feminists and activists such as Roxane Gay and Angela Davis to fun facts about the female artists she plays during her show. It’s rad as hell.

Now, we might be a little into January already, but as the station has been gearing up for Winter Applications which are due on January 11th at 11:59pm (this upcoming Monday), we wanted to remind everyone via our social media that applications are still being accepted until then! If you want to learn how to become a UCLA Radio DJ and hopefully be Regina’s next intern (which is a pretty high honor, if we do say so ourselves), apply here now!

title: Album Breakdown: Erykah Badu’s “But You Caint Use My Phone”
content:
This Black Friday we were given more to be thankful for with the drop of 2 new songs from J. Cole and Kendrick Lamar. (anticipating their new album in February possibly?) But just as important, if not more, Ms. Badu dropped her anticipated mixtape, “But You Caint Use My Phone” at exactly 12 o'clockthat Friday morning. I’m going to be honest and say that I haven’t digitally bought an album in YEARS. With new free music streaming on Soundcloud constantly, streaming apps like Spotify and Apple Music, and radio apps like Songza and Pandora, buying music isn’t really necessary anymore. That might be changing though, with artists not releasing on any streaming sites, or even waiting to release til they hit a certain number of pre-orders (Jay Rock’s “90059”). That’s another post though. Regardless, I bought my godmomma’s mixtape today and I’m going to break down and review her gift right here. 

1. “Caint Use My Phone (Suite)”
Badu stays true to theme and makes sure you’re not confused on the subject of the album with ringtones and communication methods throughout the first track. (You betta use telepathy/Put a message in a bottle/You betta use Morse code/Get a towel and some smoke…) She also makes sure that you recognize the source of the name of the album, with sampling of her infamous ‘97 track “Tyrone”, which is not only self-produced, but has the help of Zach Witness. He hails from the same stomping grounds as Badu, Dallas, TX, but also did an amazing remix of “Bag Lady” earlier this year. He pops up again helping on tracks like, “Phone Down”, “I’ll Call U Back”, “Dial'Afreaq”, and “Medley”. (Basically half the album)

2. “Hi”
The next track works as an interlude into “Cel U Lar Device” (or the “Hotline Bling Remix” as we know it) clocking in at only 36 secs, but it also introduces the sounds of the ending track with Andre 3k, “Hello”. Once again, some self-production with the help of T. RUNDGREN, an instrumentalist from the 80’s.


3. “Cel U Lar Device”
Not much review on this one considering its the track we all fell in love with and what started this whole album, the “Hotling Bling Remix”. Drake apparently helped her with the production on this one, which isn’t surprising, but was D.R.A.M. asked too? (Educate yourself on the “Cha-Cha”/“Hotline Bling” sampling issue.)


4. “Phone Down”
Another single off the album, in my top 3, “Phone Down” I actually feel has the exact amount of Badu’s trademark sound while weaving this generation’s “wavey rap” perfectly. Sounds like an OVO sound without the crying, partying, and heartbreak dripped lyrics. (On the topic of lyrics, every bit of this I want to sing to every guy I’m ever involved with. Haha.)


5. “U Use to Call Me feat. Drake”
The first physical appearance of Drake on the album. He gets a full interlude to himself, except for the background sampling of the earlier song, “Cel U Lar Device”. Nice minute interlude though.


6. “Mr. Telephone Man”
In case you missed it, we’re all about education on this blog so if you don’t recognize the song title or sampling, you didn’t listen closely enough to your mama when she was playing her oldies. The song references and samples are almost word for word, New Edition’s “Mr. Telephone Man”. Even better, the original producer for the single, Ray Parker Jr., produced this as well. Doesn’t do much lyrically for the album, but it’s still a smooth song. They all should be though, Erykah used every tool possible to make sure the frequencies on this album were as comforting as she could make it. Science, people. Science. 


7. “U Don’t Have to Call”
I don’t know what it is about Usher’s “U Don’t Have to Call”, but everyone wants to remake it. Last year it was Childish Gambino’s on “STN MTN”. Domo Genesis recently sung it at Camp Flog Gnaw this year. Now Erykah wants a turn at it, at least she adds her own verse though. (What planet did you come from boy/I know that we just met homeboy/comin’ for my lovin’ oh boy) This is the first reference to her using the word “squirrel” as a pet name too, she does it again in “Hello” while talking to Andre. She also makes it her own with the amazing production of Pharrell at hand on the track.


8. “Medley: What’s Yo Phone Number / Telephone (Ghost of Screw Mix) feat. Drake”
The second longest song on the album, another one of my favorites, and one of the most surprising when looking at the producers of the track. (Artists start making liner notes somewhere on your albums again!) Turns out that her oldest, Seven Benjamin, does the production for this one. Keep in mind that this son is the offspring of Erykah Badu and Andre 3000, which explains the talent. Drake does another feature, as well as there being a subtle remix to her track “Telephone” to end the song. Once again, my favorite. Five minutes isn’t long enough.


9. “Dial'Afreaq”
Okayyyy, here’s the explanation to all the bees on the cover. (More education, I told ya’ll we’re about that here.) So apparently, bees use the Earth’s magnetic field as a compass to fly. Since cell phones’ signals and frequencies are messing that force up, the bees fly erratically or as “Badu-Tron” puts it “making it impossible for them hoes to find their way back to the hive”. This results in the huge decline in the bee population ever since the popularity in cell phones has risen. Without bees there’s no pollination. No pollination, means things can’t grow. Things can’t grow, then it’s all around bad for us. So be nice to a bee today, they have it hard. Lesson over. This one’s the funniest off the album, I don’t think Badu meant for this one to be a favorite on the work. It has tons of early Funkadelic on it for sure though.  

10. “I’ll Call U Back”
This one starts off with the same intro as her “Hotline Bling Remix”, “Cel U Lar Device”, but is way more R&B influenced. Not only that, but Erykah has definitely been paying attention to Hip Hop lately with a major flow sampling from Post Malone’s “White Iverson”. One of the smoothest tracks on the album as she reminds ya’ll, business is first and I’ll call you after.


11. “Hello feat. Andre 3000”
Yes, I know you all have been waiting for this one since I mentioned 3000’s appearance on the album period. We all know Andre allows us one fire feature a year and then slips back into whatever other universe he actually lives in for another 3k-less year. This time the infamous couple/not-a-couple team up for the unanimous best song on the piece. Proving that they always should’ve gotten married and been #RelationshipGoals for all of us Carefree People of Color looking for more than bae in this world.

Nonetheless, the song is nothing but a dream throughout, mostly with a lot Andre leading the lyrics. He challenges us to walk out of the room with our phones unlocked, and right side up (which we all know is the biggest trust exercise there is). As well as, thinking out loud on his insecurities, waiting to see if his woman will answer his call. The pet name, “squirrel”, comes up again, but no explanation as to why. Nothing, but love and positive frequencies to end the album though. Sorry, I can’t give you more without ruining the effect for you all when you listen.

Final thoughts? Go out and get the album! Best $7.99 I ever spent. I regret nothing. If it comes out on vinyl, I’ll buy that too. But she’s my godmomma so it would be wrong if I didn’t anyway…

Words By: Kelsee Thomas

title: "Whimsiclassic Christmas” Playlist by Shane Emeis
content:
Hark! What’s that you hear ring-ting-tingling?Well ho ho ho, all you prancers and vixens. You better watch out, you better not cry, cuz we’re dashing through the snow to make the yuletide gay with this WHIMSICLASSIC CHRISTMAS Playlist. There must have been some magic in these Christmas carolers’ mistletoe cuz these jingles will make you want to frolic and play the eskimo way. So don’t be a grinch, hurry down the chimney and join in our reindeer games with these merry melodies. Pour some eggnog, grab that corn-cobbed pipe, and give these tinsle-y tracks a mix and a mingle. Kick back in your sleigh, you jolly happy souls, and let visions of sugar-plums dance in your head. May your days be merry and bright and a partridge in a pear tree. Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night.

Playlist, Caption, and Picture by: Shane Emeis

title: Film Review // Doctor Strange
content:
Written By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date: 12/10/16

A film that is based upon a magical universe inside of a the actual one is bound to be complex.  But still, the cinematic storytelling tradition happens in three acts. As complex as it is or needs to be, for a story to work in this format, it must comfortably and sensibly fit into this model.  There are other conventions in filmmaking that we respect because they work.  For example, if you want your audience to sympathize with your protagonist, you beat the shit out of him for most of the first act.  Think the first episode of Breaking Bad or the first act of The Bourne Identity. Very few characters are as stripped of power and masculinity as Walter White, and poor Jason Bourne is literally adrift alone in the cold ocean. There are other practices that are followed because they make narrative or business sense.  Stories are abridged, characters are omitted or added, and narratives that might need two or three hours to tell effectively are shortened to 98 minutes to address short attention spans. None of this is news, and the story of a magical universe set inside of the actual one is bound to be complex.  But in the case of Doctor Strange, it isn’t, and the film suffers for it.  

The story of a genius young neurosurgeon with an ego of Trump-like proportions, Strange begins his journey as a decidedly unlikeable guy. Forced into introspection by tragedy, he wanders the Earth (and other realms) on a quest to be restored and ultimately finds redemption.  It’s the kind of thing that presents almost unlimited opportunity for rich and innovative storytelling. Instead, the one-dimensional take on a decidedly multi-dimensional character ends up making things feel formulaic. There are too many compromises and too much insincerity when the story calls for authenticity. Questions are asked and answered in the same breath, and the viewer doesn’t get a chance to think about what any specific action, word, or event means. It feels canned. Even when Strange experiences a paradigm shift and becomes a somewhat nicer person, it’s hard to buy it. At its heart, Doctor Strange is the story of a complex man navigating infinitely complex and sensitive situations.  Unfortunately, the filmmakers seem to think we aren’t up to that. Like a packet of saccharin instead of real sugar, they built a world of simple neat story lines instead of something deep, dark, meaty, and satisfying.  It made an interesting story boring, and it kind of hurts to be spoken down to.

The visual effects are pretty, but fail to live up to the hoopla. Shortcuts and bows to convention make Doctor Strange feel like a lot of other films – contrived. Whitewashing one of the most important characters from an Asian man to the talented but decidedly white Tilda Swinton doesn’t help matters.  She does what she can with the role, but her casting is one of those nods to the formula that make the film feel like a color-by-numbers experience. Major transitions happen in the blink of an eye – such as Strange accepting and becoming adept in magic. This is a man who is forced to change his ideas about everything he knows or thought he knew. The problem here is that the transformation happens lickety-split. That happens a lot in this movie. With a run time of just under two hours, an extra 20-30 minutes of screen time dedicated to fleshing out the Doctor’s physical and spiritual journey would have gone a long way towards making things actually feel magical.

It’s not all bad. Doctor Strange has a freshness and energy that hasn’t touched Marvel in years (Guardians of the Galaxy is a lovely exception.) As far as film music goes, the score is exceptional. The cast sparkles with talent and charm.  Of special note are supporting characters Christine and Pangborn, beautifully played by Rachel McAdams and Benjamin Bratt, respectively. Mads Mikkelsen does his thing and knocks it out of the park as the very angry and tragic villain Kaecilius. It would have been great to have a better understanding of what drove him to madness.  But even with the insufficient backstory, he is 100 percent effective as the guy whose appearance makes your blood run cold.  Benedict Cumberbatch has the makings of a star, and it’s easy to see why he was chosen to helm this project.  If he’d been given more to work with, he would have been up to it.  If we had been given more story, we might have been too.

title: Album Review // Warmth Equation - Infinity Crush
content:
Written By: Alana Enriquez, UCLA Radio Music

Post Date: 12/4/16

2013 was marked by an onslaught of releases from Infinity Crush, the North Carolina-based solo project of Caroline White. A majority of these releases were demos - soft acoustic tracks defined by expressions of love, loss, and memory. However, following the release of Sometimes Even in My Dreams I Am in June of 2013, releases from Infinity Crush came to a halt. During this period, White worked on projects such as Julia Brown, began the ambient duo High Bloom, and, for the past two years, wrote and produced Infinity Crush’s first full-length album with friend Derrick Brandon. That album, Warmth Equation, is a twelve track exploration of various forms of coping with grief. It features the vocals and lyrics of White paired with the subtle guitar of Brandon, along with the keys and vocals of Sam Ray, from Ricky Eat Acid, Julia Brown, and Teen Suicide.

Warmth Equation opens with the demo turned full-fledged track “Drowning Here with All My Friends,” a testament to that prolific year of 2013 as well as a display of meticulous and well-thought-out efforts to develop a clean, mature sound. What follows is a combination of ambient reverberations centered on loss and twinkly nods to lovers past and present, all presented by White’s ringing, unearthly voice. Still tracks such as “Spoil” and “Over You” provide more light-hearted pictures of modern romance and unwanted advances, returning back to the sugary-sweetness of White’s final release of 2013. Yet despite the varied atmospheres, the sound always returns to its base elements: simple guitar riffs, dainty vocals, and the refined poetic verses of Caroline White.

The album finishes with “Heaven,” a collective piece largely centered on understanding deep grief through the concept of a flower-filled afterlife, where we can meet again with those we have lost. Its slow pace, soft harmonies, and abrupt stop call back to the previous works of Infinity Crush, combining to represent the culmination of its past scratchy bedroom recordings and its present warm, developed sound.

The entirety of Warmth Equation is a collective of White’s memories of love and loss, along with her ties to her most active year of musical production. She employs the help of friends, along with her own incredible talent in poetry, to submerge us in delicate moments of affection and sorrow on our thirty-minute walk home. She produces tracks of the near spiritual variety, yet always returns us to reality - that is, the inevitability of our passing, and how we learn to cope with it.

title: Show Review // Saint Pablo: Kanye’s Best Live Show Ever?
content:
Written By : Brian Suruki, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date : 11/03/16

Kanye West is undoubtedly one of the most influential artists of our time. Aside from his influences in music, fashion, art (among other things), West is notorious for his live performances and stage productions. His last tour was the Yeezus Tour (in 2013-2014), which included ballet dancers, a 50-foot tall Mountain, and even “Jesus” himself.  This marks my third time seeing Kanye West live and it is apparent each time why he remains considered one of the greatest artists of our time.



The night starts as I was waiting to gain entry into the photo section. As I was sitting on my stool (that I was asked to bring) with my camera hanging around my neck, I noticed a group of people walking up behind me. I realized that I was blocking the pathway so I moved my stuff to the side while realizing it was 2 Chainz making his way into the arena along with his dog.



After waiting a bit, I made my way into the arena as well. The energy inside of the Forum Arena was pure excitement as everyone was waiting for the show to begin. The crowd went into a roar as the lights shut off and orange lights lit up a stage on the other side of the arena. Without an opener, Kanye West stood on the stage as a slightly altered version of “Father Stretch My Hands,” began playing.  



The floating stage started moving towards the center of the arena as the audience below him raised their arms in the air. Kanye West continued playing songs from The Life of Pablo along with other selections from his discography as the crowd looked up at him in awe. Is Saint Pablo Kanye’s best live show ever? Probably not, but it is without a doubt a spectacle to see.

title: Big Baby Dram // D.R.A.M. Album Review
content:
Written By : Harold Gonzalez, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : (10/25/16)


Favorite Track: “Cute” / Least Favorite Track: “WiFi”

D.R.A.M. might hang in the back of most’s minds as the guy who made that one song that “inspired” Drake to make a latin-flavored dance banger. If you keep a keen eye to hip-hop, then you would instead see D.R.A.M. as the drunk, sloppy crooner that scored that #1 single, “Broccoli”, alongside Lil Yachty. It’s clear now that Big Baby is both no stranger to success and has found his own flavor. While the flavor is unique, it can be a bit overdone, possibly oversaturated, but it stands slightly above most in the bucket of mimics that the mumble rap genre has produced.

The record kicks off with a kick to disbelief’s face on the track “Get It Myself”; where D.R.A.M. laughably refrains that he had to stop depending on others, or waiting on others, to reach his success. He takes the off the wall sounds of ODB with the off-key hilarity of Biz Markie to sculpt together a feel-good atmosphere on almost all of his tracks. It’s as if D.R.A.M. is not taking himself in the slightest way seriously. “Misunderstood” is a guitar driven banger that sees Young Thug join Big Baby on more serious topics regarding police and self-identity. Despite these sincere undertones on the intro tracks, D.R.A.M. quickly displays quirky, melodic off-key singing and rapping on the tracks “In a Minute/In House” and “Monticello Ave”. They are both songs about personal backgrounds and relationships: “In a Minute” pokes fun at sexual tones as he mutters references to celebrating celibacy by having sex; while “Monticello Ave” is a sincere display of affection to his significant other while on the road. Up to this point, the instrumentation on the record has been bouncy and mixed relatively well (the percussion for a fact has been a bit more dynamic than one might come to expect from hip hop records).

Big Baby sees fit to later clump the singles into the midsection of the record where an avid listener might be most prone to falling asleep. “WiFi”, “Cash Machine”, and “Broccoli” are fun bangers but can feel extremely boxed in and flaccid at around their respective 2/3rd marks. “WiFi” is one of the most underwhelming tracks on the record, with D.R.A.M. attempting to croon over a very polished RnB instrumental and as a result the track feels very disheveled. Fortunately, the same cannot be said for “Cash Machine” and “Broccoli”. These are two tracks that rely heavily on 808 bass hits and straightforward production that provides more than enough freedom for D.R.A.M. and his guest to play with summery references and the typical rap topics of weed, wealth, and women.

It’s important to note that D.R.A.M. can get away with a lot of things that many other rappers can’t, such as the corny lines on the track “Cute”. He shows a lot of diversity on the tracks that round off the record: “Change My #” and “Password” are all technology-referencing tracks that deal with sour relationships and rocky endings. However, even with the more sappy topics, Big Baby gets away with being sugary, even to the point of being oversaturated. His voice riddles each track with a different emotion displayed in the lyrical content. At the same time, these beats are not too flashy or attention seeking but rather they are fit for D.R.A.M. to doodle over.

The record is then rounded out with a sweetly tinged weed-praising track, “Sweet VA Breeze” and an apparently generic struggle rap song disguised as a pop rap jingle “Workaholic”. The record might not have listeners absolutely begging for new material from the new age Biz Markie anytime soon, but it will for sure be in the back catalog of anybody looking to pop a feel good record during the upcoming winter.

6/10

title: The Cooties + Reggie Watts “Trumpy Trump” -- NEW MUSIC VIDEO // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By: UCLA Radio Comedy

Post Date : 10/12/16

Today, The Cooties and Reggie Watts release their brand new music video entitled “Trumpy Trump”!!

More than good tunes and vibes, this song is a hilarious take our current political climate. If you don’t know who to vote for yet, maybe this video will help make up your mind!

The Cooties are an L.A. based musical comedy group with band members Ethan Edenburg, Eric Jackowitz, and Jacob Jeffries. They became close with Reggie, music and comedy legend,  after opening for him at El Cid.

If you like The Cooties, you can find out more about them at their website http://thecooties.sex (yes that is their real website).

title: Talking Tangents and Fond Farewells with Dan Wild-Beesly of Cleft @ ArcTanGent Festival 2016
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 09/27/16

When Cleft announced the band’s breakup last year, I never could have imagined that I would somehow be there to witness their final show. It was already consolation enough that the Manchester-based duo, made up of Dan Wild-Beesly on guitar and John Simm on drums, would be recording and releasing a final album before walking away. When it was announced, several months after I’d gotten my ArcTanGent ticket, that they’d be playing one last show at the festival (a fitting farewell since they had played every ArcTanGent since the festival’s inception in 2013), my already high level of excitement was multiplied tenfold. So while I was still sad that the band was ending, being able to fly from California to England to see their last ever performance was the best possible silver lining.

I spoke with Dan as he was changing his guitar strings in preparation for the band’s last ever gig later that afternoon. We discussed ArcTanGent, the band’s first and last shows, and their process for writing “stupid music”. For more about the show itself, check out my “Top 5 Most Anticipated Acts at ArcTanGent” list here.

August 19, 2016 - Fernhill Farm, Bristol, UK

Layla: You’ve actually played every year of ArcTanGent, haven’t you?
Dan: Guiltily, yes I have.
Layla: How do you think the festival has grown or changed since the first time you played?
Dan: It’s definitely grown quite a bit. It’s always been a 5,000 capacity festival but I think this year they’re very close to have selling it out. The first year, it was still busy but it wasn’t like it is now. It’s got a real community hinged around it. I’m sure you might have already worked that out just being here for a day.
Layla: Yeah definitely.
Dan: Everyone knows each other, just really friendly and it’s unlike any festival I’ve ever been to, apart from 2000trees which is like a slightly bigger version of this and run by the same people. But yeah, it’s incredible.

L: Do you have a favorite memory from this year or any year?
D: The very first year we played was mad because we were a totally unknown entity and we were both super nervous. It was probably by twice the amount the most people we’d ever played to and we were shitting ourselves before we got onstage. There’s one picture John [Simm, drummer] managed to get of the crowd that’s really blurry because he was shaking with nerves. So that was pretty great but I think the 2nd year we were on the same stage, the same stage we’re playing today actually, we did a medley of Rage Against the Machine tunes with Tom [Peters] from Alpha Male Tea Party. It’s the first one we did and it’s become a bit of a tradition. That’s probably my favorite time here so far. Although, every year I’ve had a blast actually. I can’t really tell you what the best year was. I’ll come off stage today and be like “That was the best one, definitely” (Editor’s Note: I spoke with Dan after the show and he confirmed that it had in fact been the best show they’d played) and then if I ever play again in another band I’ll probably say the same again. It’s just the best place to play. Basically our entire fan base comes to ArcTanGent so every time we play we’re playing to everyone that’s ever heard of our band. And everyone’s just really friendly. This is a beautiful place and I love coming here and even if I’m not in a band this time next year I will be here as a human being to watch bands.

L: Because this is my first of hopefully many ArcTanGents, do you have any advice for newcomers in your veteran experience?
D: I suppose I am a veteran. I’d say just go and see all the bands because they don’t book bad bands. From the very first band to the very last band of every day on every stage, they’re all fucking great. If you’re a fan of math rock and anything a bit weird and guitar-based, this is the only place to be. It’s fantastic. So go and see bands, don’t sit in your tent and be an asshole. And talk to people as well. Everyone here is more friendly than almost anywhere else you can go. We don’t have much of a reputation, us Brits, as being friendly but once a year everyone gets together in a field just outside of Bristol and we talk to each other and it’s nice.

L: Talking about how many great bands there are, are there any bands you’ve seen so far that have really blown you away or anyone you’re still looking forward to seeing?
D: I’m really looking forward to seeing Mutoid Man tomorrow. They are so fucking fun and heavy as hell but still quite cheesy in places. They’ve got the balance perfectly right. I saw Three Trapped Tigers yesterday. I’ve seen them tons of times but I’m a massive fan. That was great. We had a little mosh pit and I pretended I was 18 again. Axes were absolutely fucking awesome. We’ve toured with Axes quite a few times and they were exceptional last night. They’re the ultimate festival band. They’re just so much fun and everyone’s dancing and having a wicked time.

L: I want to ask you about the term “math rock” because I know there’s a variety of opinions on it. How would you describe it and do you think it’s actually accurate to your music?
D: Every single style of music needs a title and it annoys me when people get really pissed off about it. You need a name. How are you going to say “I just play widdly guitar stuff, has some weird time changes, very little vocals” which you could say in two syllables if you say “I play in a math rock band”. I wouldn’t say that Cleft is necessarily that much of a math rock band. The only problem I have with the term “math” rock is twofold: One is that I’m shit at math so that just frustrates me and secondly, people when they hear the term “math rock” if they know a bit about it assume that you’re sat there picking time signatures before you’re writing riffs and thinking of melodies and chord structures and writing a song, which is completely the opposite of our writing process. We just jam and then come up with something that makes one of us laugh and then extend that. Quite often, we’ll record something on - we’ve both got those Zoom Handy Recorders which are perfect. Anyone in a band, I’d highly recommend you get a Zoom Recorder and record everything you ever do if you think it’s any good. Then go back to it and you’ll realize that you’ve got more material than you realize. All of our stuff comes from bits and pieces of jams where it’s like, “Oh that little tiny bit, that was good” and quite regularly we won’t come back to it for two years and then “Do you remember that riff we had? I reckon that might sit in well with these chords”. It’s just a really good way of documenting your process and it’s quite easy to amass a load of shit that’s rubbish but eventually you’ll find there was one bit in there that you really liked.

L: What bands were you listening to early on in the formation of Cleft that influenced your sound?
D: One band that I could think of is Faraquet with Devin Ocampo on lead guitar but not playing solos. His playing really changed the way I thought about guitar. My first proper band when I was 16 was a three-guitar band so I was one of three. So my thought process with that was always finding my place in the song and often not playing for half a song or I also played a bit of keys in that band as well. But it was very much knowing my place whereas I started Cleft having heard Faraquet because Devin Ocampo is just the most insanely tasteful but brilliant guitar player. No solos, really. But really nice chords and fast little riffs and mostly not even double-tracked on the recordings. They’re quite stripped back recordings which, again I was very guilty of layering up tons and tons of guitar tracks all the time.

L: You announced the band’s breakup back in December and I do want to say I’m very happy that you decided to release another album and do more shows before splitting up. Does it feel weird that this is finally the last show when you guys have been building up to it for a while?
D: Yeah, I fully agree with you. I’m very glad we decided to do it this way. We sat and had a chat in my kitchen in November last year and we were just saying “I don’t know what it is, but I’m not enjoying being in this band anymore. There’s something that doesn’t have the same kind of buzz that it used to” and we said even before we wrote our first track that if we get to that point, just knock it on the head straight away but not just fizzle out. Actually say goodbye because we’ve done quite a lot together in the last four years. So we didn’t want to do it a disservice to just go, “Alright, we’re done. Cheers.” and not do anything more. And we already had basically an album written and studio time booked. So it’s like, alright let’s do this last album, let’s do a final tour, go back to the places that we’ve played before and just put it to bed properly rather than just letting it die out like a forgotten fart.
L: That’s an excellent way of putting it.

L: I know there’s probably going to be some emotions surrounding it but what is something you’re definitely not going to miss about the band?
D: Ooh, tough question. I won’t miss traveling through Birmingham Town Centre at 3:00 in the morning having been paid about £12 to play a gig to six people on a Sunday evening and then having to get up for work at 9:00 in the morning the next day. I will not miss that.
L: Yeah, that does sound miserable.
D: Yeah, it’s pretty shit.
L: To any people who want to start bands and think it’s glamorous.
