D: Yeah, it’s really not. I won’t miss that but for the majority of the time it’s been awesome. I’ve had a blast and I’ve met most of current best friends through being in this band. Like Tom [Peters] was the best man at my wedding.
L: Aww wow! That’s nice! And you just met through being in bands?
D: Yeah. We happened to support [Alpha Male Tea Party] in Manchester at the Bay Horse. Tiny little gig to probably about 10-12 people. Got on really well, they liked my guitar so decided to speak to me and we’ve been best mates ever since.
L: That’s wonderful.
D: He’s been sick in my house many times.
L: That’s the mark of true friendship right there.
D: Yeah, it really is, like “You can vomit in my house. Mi casa es su casa”.
L: That’s great. That’s the new thing I need to base all my friendships on.
D: “Have we vomited in each other’s houses? Well, we’re not proper friends then. Sorry”
L: Just walk up to someone and ask, “If I vomit at your house tonight, would it be okay” and if they say “no” just walk away. Don’t even bother.
D: “You’re dead to me”

L: So, you guys do have your last ever show tonight. Do you have any surprises or secrets you’re willing to divulge?
D: We’re gonna be doing what’s become an ArcTanGent tradition for Cleft, a little medley at the end of our set. We’re getting up two guest vocalists from two bands, one being Nick Duke from Trojan Horse and one being Ben Forrester from a band called Bad Grammar, who are no longer together either. But Ben’s also started a new project called Peaks. The medley consists of recently departed musicians’ tunes so it’s got Motörhead, Prince, and two Bowie tunes.
L: Oh my god.
D: It’s gonna be pretty emotional.
L: I might cry.
D: I think probably a few people will. I’ll probably be there with them, not being able to play anymore.
L: Yeah, I think the show will end when the entire stage is just a puddle of tears like an electricity hazard.
D: No one else will ever be able to use that stage again.
L: That’s how you do it. It’s your last show. Just burn the stage down when you’re done.
D: “Thank you and good night!” (explosion sound) Release the bees.
L: That would be the way to end it.

L: I want to talk about the new album, although some of the tracks like “Me, Sugar” and “Onan’s Boulder”, those have been around for years now.
D: Yeah, we did live kind-of demos of those for… last year’s ArcTanGent? No, the year before actually.
L: I think it was two years ago.
D: Yeah, thank you. We did that because we hadn’t released anything for a little while and we had those two tunes. And you can’t really call two songs a demo or an EP. We’d been experimenting with live recordings for ages anyway and done quite a few gigs where we’ve kept the audio. In fact, our very first ever gig is on YouTube, like the first two tunes from there anyway. And in fact, oddly enough that very first gig - I’m going to go off on a tangent so you might need to poke me back in the right direction.
L: No, by all means. It’s ArcTanGent.
D: There should be lots of tangents at ArcTanGent.
L: Exactly, we encourage tangents.
D: So yeah, our very first ever gig was at a venue called the Yorkshire House in Lancaster, where John went to uni. We were supporting a band called Dohnut (formerly known as eating disorder), which is their full name. And I thought “I wonder why they were called Eating Disorder” but they were always called Dohnut (formerly known as eating disorder).
L: That is brilliant.
D: Yeah, but their whole shtick is to play to a film that they’ve put together for it. Basically that meant that they have to have a screen in front of a stage for the whole gig. So our first gig, we actually had to play behind a screen. It was very strange. You can’t really get that nervous if you can’t see the crowd. Luckily it was, again, all these stories end with “There’s only 6 people there” so it doesn’t matter anyway. Anyway, I was talking about them because I saw their sticker on a coffee machine at one of the cafes this morning.
L: That’s funny.
D: Yeah. What was the question? I think I lost it.
L: I think it was about you guys recorded two songs but it’s all connected.
D: Yeah yeah, it’s all connected eventually. I’ll get there. So yeah, we put them out and we felt like we needed to do them properly. It was a really nice way to start an album. We’ve already got two tunes that really we should record properly because we’ve kind of done a bit of a disservice to them by only releasing them as live recordings. So that’s what we did and I’m still pretty chuffed with them.

L: Also talking about that, were most of the songs on [Wrong, the new album] part of your backlog or did you record them specifically for the album?
D: We wrote 80% of the album new. We just happened to have those two tracks already going and we figured we should really do them again. Well, I say new but like I was saying, our process is [to] record lots of live jams, pick it apart, find one good bit and then reconstruct again. So a few of them have been around for a long time but in no actual guise we’ve played in front of people or anything.

L: I’ve noticed that when a lot of two-piece bands go into the studio, they tend to overcompensate with lots of overdubs and very heavy production whereas you seem to take the opposite approach. Your albums always sound very live. Is that intentional?
D: Totally, yeah. Again, going back to Faraquet and Devin Ocampo, all of their tunes especially the earlier ones sound like a band in a room and I’ve always loved that idea. So for this last album we wanted to make it as close to what we sound like in the flesh as possible. But we also decided to go quite far out in terms of budget and studios. Initially the plan was to do a different track per different studio per day all on the trot and do a little documentary about it. But we quickly realized that that was a stupid idea and probably impossible and that, especially if we wanted to play live, it was never going to happen. So we did a version of it, we went to about 5 different studios.
L: And you posted small videos about each one to get the feel.
D: Yeah, but it wasn’t this big documentary. I wanted to do a math rock shit version of “Sonic Highways” but it didn’t work out in the end. And I’m still proud of the album. I think it sounds pretty cool. It was a huge effort that we put in. There was loads of driving and it was pretty intense but I think it’s turned out alright.
L: I think it’s fantastic.

L: So, a more technical question. Because you have a pretty elaborate pedal board.
D: That is true.
L: When you’re writing, do you have a riff in mind and then see what pedals work with it or do you already have the pedals in mind as you’re writing?
D: Most of our tunes come out of us dicking about in the practice room so a lot of the time I’ll just be playing on a clean sound but usually with a POG (Polyphonic Octave Generator) on just because it fattens everything up. That’s on 95% of the time, really. But I don’t really think “I’ve got this new pedal, I want to write a song for this pedal”. I’ve tried to do that. Don’t get me wrong, I am a massive nerd. But I’ve generally never gotten anywhere with that. So I just try to write something that I like to dance to or I think is funny or pull a stink face. If I look like I’ve just smelled a big pile of dung, then it must be onto something.

L: How do you come up with names for instrumental songs? Because your names are quite… noticeable.
D: (laughter) That’s very diplomatic. Usually whoever has hold of the recordings, like I’ve said, we record everything very roughly. We’ve got a shared Dropbox folder full of stuff. Well, it’s now actually very organized because John is the most organized person on the planet Earth. It’s incredible. Keep your receipts. But yeah, the names come from whoever puts it up. You can’t have “Untitled 3075” so we just pick a stupid name and if it’s funny enough, it sticks and if it’s not funny enough I’ll think of something else.
L: Yeah, the stupider the better, really.
D: Yeah basically. But we try to keep just shy of wacky.
L: Nice. Because when you’re going wacky then you’re just going too far.
D: Yeah exactly.
L: It’s a very fine balance. I don’t think people realize that it’s both an art and a science in naming instrumental tracks.
D: Absolutely.
L: It can completely change the entire song.
D: Totally. Like, I don’t like this anymore. Why do we have to call it “Shit Stick”?
L: (laughter) Shit Stick is actually the name of my band.
D: Is it?
L: It is now.
D: Shit Stick dot com.
L: Dot org.
D: Oh okay, you must be organized.

L: You can speak for John on this too, but what’s next for you guys? How can people keep tabs on you?
D: Well, I’ve already been writing other bits and pieces. John is in general in at least ten bands. We’ve had this discussion and I’m gonna be posting stuff up on the Cleft page if I do something new, which I will because it’s very hard to stop being in bands once you’ve done it for as long as I have. My first band I was 15 and I’m now 31 in two weeks. So it’s been a long time and I don’t know what I would do if I wasn’t in a band, even if it was just a pub-rock band. I have this need and I get very depressed if I’m not playing music so I’ll do it forever or until I physically can’t anymore and then I’ll be really depressed.

L: You’ve touched on this earlier. I’m not sure if it’s just me because I have a very strange sense of humor but I feel like there is a lot of humor and not taking itself too seriously within math rock. Do you agree with that?
D: Oh yeah. I don’t actually like that many bands that take themselves seriously. It might be something to do with mainly enjoying instrumental music where you can’t say “Oh, this song is about so and so” if there’s no lyrics. You can try and impart some kind of emotional feeling but ultimately we’re just two dickheads that like doing stupid music and other people seem to like that so that’s fine. Well that’s not fine, it’s fucking brilliant actually.
L: It’s certainly convenient if nothing else.
D: Oh, it’s great! We’re still shocked when people are really big fans of ours. Like, are you sure? You haven’t got a different Cleft in mind, have you?
L: Like those crazy people who’ll come all the way from California.
D: Yeah, exactly. I mean, who the fuck would do that?
L: It’s weird.
D: That’s a mad thing to do.
L: Very strange. Might be a little bit disturbed.
D: (laughter) Aren’t we all?
L: I think that’s why everyone’s here. We’ve all just wandered here in a daze.
D: Exactly. We’re all on the same page at this festival and that’s one of the nicest things about the festival in itself is everyone’s a bit weird. You can just do whatever you want, like “Hey! We’re all the same, aren’t we?”
L: That’s very true.

title: Show Review: TTNG @ Thee Parkside - San Francisco, CA (7/21/2016)
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 07/28/16

Math rock heavyweights TTNG kicked off their US tour in a packed, sweaty room at Thee Parkside surrounded by 100 eager fans who had come ready to rock and count along. It was the UK-by-way-of-Blompton-based band’s first show since the release of their third studio album, Disappointment Island on July 8th. The album also marked their second release as a trio, with the departure of two members and the addition of Henry Tremain to brothers Tim and Chris Collis in 2011. 

The night began with Bay Area natives Covet, an immensely talented trio that in their short tenure has already produced a standout EP which successfully fuses impeccable math technique with rich atmospheric soundscapes. Unlike many bands whose complexly layered studio recordings can’t help but fall flat when placed in a live setting, Covet’s performance somehow managed to heighten the listening experience, especially during more dramatic tunes like “Sea Dragon”.

Taking the stage at just past 11:30, it only took a couple of seconds into “Sponkulus Nodge” for TTNG to prove what many had previously suspected: It’s not easy to dance to songs in 14.5 meter. That said, this crowd was certainly up to the challenge.

Although it may not have been the band’s original intention when first forming in 2004, the current lineup is one of the strongest live power trios I’ve come across in recent years. Individually, each part seems infinitely intricate and precise yet when played together they meld seamlessly as a singular cohesive piece of music. While Tim Collis’ flowing ornamented guitar lines carry the songs beyond the territory of conventional counting methods, Henry Tremain’s bass playing is the counterweight with decisive rhythm and punches of melodic counterpoint. Paired with his bright vocals and falsetto, Tremain’s custom Squier 6-string bass is an excellent anchor for the trio’s low end. His style is as unique as the instrument itself, refusing to conform to the standard roles of a baritone guitar or a 4-string bass. At the core of every song is Chris Collis’ asymmetrical yet organic drumming, which serves as the thread that ties all the other musical elements together.

It was this strength as a trio that made for such an interesting dynamic when the band was joined onstage by their tour manager and fellow Sargent House labelmate Henry Kohen, who is best known for making his own brand of one-man math rock under the name Mylets. Being a longtime friend of the band and having contributed bass to a track on the new album, Kohen’s presence onstage seemed effortless as the two Henrys split bass and rhythm guitar duties throughout the night.

TTNG’s dedication to their fans was evidenced in how they constructed their setlist. With this being their 5th visit to San Francisco since the release of their previous album in 2013, it was clear that they were making an effort to keep their shows fresh and exciting. In addition to playing several tracks off their new album, the band also reached deep into their back catalog with songs like “Want to Come Back to My Room and Listen to Some Belle and Sebastian” off of their 2008 self-titled EP. Their set was also littered with fan favorites such as “Gibbon” off the band’s first album Animals, which had every member of the audience singing along in a raucous chorus, as well as the live debut of their virtuosic jam “+3 Awesomeness Repels Water”.

Many years ago, this band was my inauguration into the world of math rock and no matter how deeply I explore the genre I still feel that their execution of the style is one of the purest I’ve ever heard. Their songs are highly technical and precise without ever feeling mechanical. Their newest album demonstrates their ongoing commitment to pushing rhythmic and harmonic boundaries without slipping into self-indulgence. Each instrumental line has its own complexities, just as each musician has their own personality, yet they still come together in a way where no instrument overshadows or detracts from another. Listening to a TTNG album, you can hit replay as many times as you’d like to try and soak up every last note. But when experiencing them in a live setting, one can do nothing more than smile, nod along and enjoy the ride.

title: Album Review // Chimurenga Renaissance - Girlz With Gunz
content:
Written By: Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio Digital Press DJ (02/18/16)

Tendai “Baba” Maraire, a multi-instrumentalist and rapper known for his involvement in Shabazz Palaces, and Congolese guitarist Hussein Kalonji comprise the experimental trans-African group Chimurenga Renaissance. Their newest project is titled Girlz With Gunz, an exploration of the African music tradition’s past and future. The name “Chimurenga” refers to the Zimbabwe War of Liberation that ended the white minority rule in what was then Rhodesia, a British colonial territory. The word translates to “struggle.”

Girlz With Gunz is fraught with references not just to the struggle of a nation’s liberation, but also the struggle of a single woman: Grace Maseva, a Zimbabwean resistance fighter who eventually died of AIDS. The album’s release comes with an essay by writer Charles Tonderai Mudede, tying the album’s themes with the history of Maseva. Chimurenga Renaissance is an effort of community. They recruited members of the art collective Black Constellation, using vocals from Sassy Black of future-R&B group THEESatisfaction, and singer JusMoni. Thematically, Girlz With Gunz is an indictment of the pernicious effects of colonization and an ode to the power of womanhood.

Though Girlz With Gunz is a tapestry of musical influence, its sensibilities lie in the synthesis of African musical tradition with contemporary rap production. Maraire’s beat production follows the frenetic and jumbled rhythms of Zimbabwe’s Shona music, and momentary glints of the traditional Mbira instrument are present in the mix. Kalonji fills in with Congolese guitar melodies, adding texture to the ballistic clash of bass and drums.

In songs “Our Purpose Is Forever” and “Everything Comes Off Tonight” the vocal lines tread the line between the croon of soul/gospel music and the vocal projections of Shona tradition. The 27-minute project comes to its conclusion with the song “Girlz With Gunz.” The synthesis of influence seems to work best here, as Kalonji’s shining guitar bleeds over a swelling bassline and trap beats, spotted with tribal drums. Just as the music is informed by the spirit of fluidity in national identity, it frees itself from the bounds of genre. Chimurenga Renaissance seeks and finds a cohesive sound that celebrates black music’s roots, its contemporary moment, and its future liberation. Girlz With Gunz can be streamed in full with accompanying visuals directed by Daniel Kaufman.

title: Breakbot’s “Still Waters” // Album Review
content:
Written By: Doug Gil, UCLA Radio Digital Press Staff (02/11/16)

After a four-year lull, Ed Banger Records finally relieve their stagnancy on full-length releases with Breakbot’s Still Waters. 

Since 2012, we haven’t heard much from Mr. Thibaut Berland aside from a few remixes dispersed here and there, enhancing songs by fellow French acts such as Phoenix and the DJ Busy P.  However, its been almost four years since French house fans ecstatically received Breakbot’s first studio LP, By Your Side.  In one of the best funk records of 2012, the French DJ lined up track after track of smooth, dynamic, and often stellar dance tracks aided by a handful of thoughtfully placed vocal features.  With this record, Breakbot had created a sound that many fans described as kind of a Michael Jackson/Daft Punk lovechild.  And while realistically it may not have reached the heights of its influences, By Your Side was inarguably a pleasure to listen to and certainly the backbone of many summer playlists.

Still Waters on the other hand, suffers from more or less of a sophomore slump.  While listening to this LP, you can tell Breakbot is trying really hard to recreate some of the sounds and styles that made his previous effort so great, except he just doesn’t have the means and enthusiasm to pull it off.  For one, there’s a lot less variety here when it comes to the vocal features: Ruckazoid and Pacific! are nowhere to be found, leaving longtime collaborator Irfane to occupy almost the entirety of this LP.  Consequentially, Still Watersmakes Breakbot feel much more like a duo than a standalone DJ.  While vocal features certainly flesh out songs for many DJs itching to get their work out into the mainstream, they can inadvertently blur the line between the artist and the collaborator in many cases.  The mixing on Still Waters certainly highlights Berland’s production quips, but Irfane’s prominent and often nasally vocals still come out as the more dominant element each time.  There’s a possibility that Breakbot isn’t confident enough to carry an album on his own, but that theory doesn’t make much sense given how organized and tightly produced his solo tracks have been.

“2Good4Me” for example, features some of Breakbot’s smoothest and most modern sounding production to date.  But when you have Irfane at the forefront of this track, the listener’s attention is diverted over to his romantic, albeit cheesy lyrics.  We get the same kind of issue with songs like “My Toy,” which isn’t a bad song on the whole, but the simplicity and staleness of this sound highlights the occasional lack of an authentic Breakbot personality throughout this record.  Most of this album just feels like a survey of Berland’s trademark funk and French house tricks.  These sounds are totally lovable on the surface, but I think fans are antsy to hear what he can actually add to the genre instead of just recall from it.  The end result is unmistakably Breakbot, it’s just that his efforts often fall short of making a real impact on our understandings of French disco.

Despite my various complaints, Still Waters is still very easy on the ears as a whole and won’t be much of a letdown for fans who thoroughly enjoyed his 2012 release.  Much like By Your Side, this album opens and closes with long and almost anthemic-sounding instrumental pieces.  Structuring his album this way, Breakbot succeeds at developing another soundscape for the classic nostalgia-induced summer drive along the coastline.  It’s a pleasant and inoffensive trek, but one demands much more of the artist that planned it out for you.

title: Does Whiteness Month belong in College?  // UCLA Radio News Op-Ed
content:
Written By: Nicole Jewell, UCLA Radio DJ (02/08/16)

“White privilege” is a hot topic throughout colleges, especially with recent political and social movements such as Black Lives Matter; redirecting our attention to how we currently treat racial issues. A community college in Portland, Oregon, has implemented a unique way to teach about the social structures of white privilege.

Faculty and staff at PCC have devised to make April a “Whiteness History Month,” attempting to “change [the] campus climate,” by breaking down the “racial power structure” derived from white privilege. Of course this has caused a lot of controversy, with an interpretation that this is simply a “white-shaming month,” and if will have a positive result on the student body. According to the school’s website, PCC has “90,000 students…making it Oregon’s largest college,” providing some insight as to why they would choose this college to represent such a significant social statement.

A subcommittee of diversity at the school were discussing changes that the campus could make, but during this last MLK monday, the “discussion went viral.” Some questions thrown around were: “‘Who benefits from the consequences of whiteness? Who loses from whiteness? How?“ or "In what ways does whiteness emerge from a legacy of imperialism, conquest, colonialism and the American enterprise?’” Those that support the cause are grateful for the school’s innovative take, and feel as though it will make an important contribution to the subject of racism on the campus. It makes one wonder if UCLA could benefit from an event like this, given this past year’s social, racial movements that have flooded the campus.

UCLA’s recent sparks of racial awareness and movement makes it difficult to predict what reactions would occur, if the campus was to have a “White History Month.”According to UCLA admissions, UCLA undergraduate acceptance demographics are: 4% African American, .5% American Indian, 33.5% Asian/Pacific Islander, 19.1% Hispanic, 27.1% White, 3.1% Domestic, 12.6% International. Based on these percentages, who’s to say that a “White History Month” is justifiable? Is it the awareness that UCLA would be getting across, or the isolation of one racial group? Granted, the reasoning for movements like this is because of violence happening in our world, or one race being singled out from admissions, or just a general over or underexposure of one race. But is it really necessary to dedicate an entire month to teach about white privilege, or is it a serious issue that needs to be addressed? Do students really not understand white privilege, or do they abuse it?

The attempts for PCC is to “change the climate,” and to really get to expose the social structure of whiteness is. Implying that students aren’t actually aware, and that this dramatic of an event will properly educate them goes a bit too far. True, maybe not all students consider their white privilege for what it is, is it not safe to assume that at least a majority of the student body does? If  UCLA needs a “White History Month,” then there is still a lot of work the student body needs to do. Is “white privilege” overlooked on UCLA’s campus, or is it an issue that can be left alone?

Source: “White History Month” Stirs Up Controversy at Oregon College

Author: Michael McLaughlin, Huffington Post

title: Panic! at the Disco - Death of a Bachelor // Album Review
content:
Review By: Casey McNamara, UCLA Radio DJ (02/03/16)

When the original members of Panic! At The Disco were barely out of high school, they wrote an unusual song about a wedding gone awry (“I Write Sins Not Tragedies”) that reached number 7 on the Billboard 100 and made them as famous as their peers My Chemical Romance and Fall Out Boy. Ten years later, Panic! At the Disco has gone through some changes—vocalist Brendon Urie is the only member left and the exclamation point is back—but their frantic, baroque approach to pop punk remains, and, for the most part, still sounds fresh on their fifth record, Death of A Bachelor.

Promotion for Death of a Bachelor has focused on the new Frank Sinatra influence on Panic!’s sound. This is most evident on the title track, where Brandon Urie croons about his recent marriage. Its hard to resist that falsetto when he sings, “How could I ask for more?/ A lifetime of laughter/ At the expense of the death of a bachelor.” The range and charisma in Urie’s voice is Panic!’s secret weapon and the reason they can adopt styles from the Beatles, Queen and Sinatra without sounding put on. Unfortunately, there are points on the record where Panic! strays too far from their usual style to sound genuine, like on the lead single “Victorious”, where they give in to the recent trend of former emo bands making songs you can pregame to. “Don’t Threaten Me With A Good Time” is another misguided attempt at a club song.

If you’ve been a Panic! fan in the past, there are definitely some real gems/jams here. Check out “Impossible Year”, “Death of a Bachelor”,  “Hallelujah”, “The Good, The Bad and The Dirty” and “Golden Days”. Even with a couple of clear misses, Death of a Bachelor will make your inner mall kid happy.

title: Transgender Athletes Can Finally Take Part in the Olympics - Without the Fine Print // UCLA Radio News Op-ed
content:
Written By: Brittany Hewitt, UCLA Radio News DJ (02/01/2016)

In the schema of a world in which feminism is a trendy word, gay marriage is no longer a shocker and taboo topics are in the press, progress is being made globally for those outside of the “norm.”

This past week, the International Olympic Committee ruled that transgender athletes can compete in the Olympics, without the necessary sex reassignment surgery. Namely, female to male athletes can compete “without restriction.” Male to female athletes must have their testosterone levels below 10 nanomols per liter for at least a year.

This is a big change to the previous 2003 rules that required not only reassignment surgery, but also two full years of hormone therapy before becoming eligible. These new rules have been overturned and replaced, just in time for 2016 Rio Olympics.

The IOC released a document to their website, detailing the rationale behind these changes:

“It is necessary to ensure insofar as possible that trans athletes are not excluded from the opportunity to participate in sporting competition. The overriding sporting objective is and remains the guarantee of fair competition… To require surgical anatomical changes as a precondition to participation is not necessary to preserve fair competition and may be inconsistent with developing legislation and notions of human rights.”

This is an effort to adapt with the changing public image of transgender issues. As social, legal and scientific attitudes change, regarding the heteronormative norms, large institutions are taking the hint. This comes after recent scenarios of the finest athletes turned away from competing : including Olympic decathalon champion Caitlyn Jenner, Indian sprinter Dutee Chand and South African runner Caster Semenya.

Taking an intersectional approach to modern issues such as the destigmatizaton of transgender peoples is successfully manifesting itself in typically mainstream hetero-genres, such as the Olympics.

Former IOC medical commission chairman Arne Ljungqvist told the Associated Press:

“It has become much more of a social issue than in the past. We had to review and look into this from a new angle. We needed to adapt to the modern legislation around the world. We felt we cannot impose a surgery if that is no longer a legal requirement… Those cases are very few, but we had to answer the question. It is an adaptation to a human rights issue. This is an important matter. It’s a trend of being more flexible and more liberal.”

Indeed, one can hope that the IOC will set a new precedent in sports and the transgender community will continue to feel the support of the world in their plight to achieve normalcy.

title: The Revenant // Film Review
content:
Film Review By: Anastasia Gershman, UCLA Radio DJ 1/19/16

In the early 19th century a frontiersman named Hugh Glass became known as The Angriest Man in America and achieved a meager celebrity status in the press of the time.  With his trapping company in the wilderness, he survived unbelievable trauma only to be left for dead by the men trusted to care for him.  Rather than die as expected, the horrifically injured man used an astonishing array of wilderness survival skills and began a thousand mile trek in search of the men who had betrayed him.  News of a man so bent on revenge that he refused to die spread made its way into the papers back east, and thus an American fable was born.  In the end, Glass chased the men to the point of exhaustion and once he found them, was too tired to do much more.  
In The Revenant (2015) director Alejandro G. Iñárritu creates a fictional representation of Hugh Glass that honors the myth as its foundation while still taking license with creativity and narrative.  Stories of the film shoot itself have drifted through and around Hollywood all year as the budget ballooned and delays set back delivery and release dates more than once.  While it may not be the Apocalypse Now of its generation it wouldn’t be entirely inaccurate to say that the film came to represent a bit of a mythical white whale – its legend grew bigger over time but no one had actually seen it.   When it finally hit theaters early this month in wide release, I didn’t know what to expect but I was hoping for a lot. 


The review: The Revenant delivers natural vistas on a scale that you probably won’t see again for a long time. Shot on digital using an Alex Arria 65 and lenses between 12 and 21mm – it has a visual crispness and scope within frames that creates a sense of being in the scene with the actors, in the forest, under the snow, plunging over cliffs, facing down a bear.  The immediacy of the environment becomes the lead actor, and you can’t take your eyes off of it.  The beauty of the land and its role in the story as it evolves makes the visual aspect of this film primary in a way that is more that it would be in another.  It deserves to be seen as a film that changes how we understand film itself. As an expression of what is possible, this movie makes full use of every advantage that technology and the accumulated experience of Hollywood offers.
The Revenant is a serious movie.  It doesn’t go for laughs and it doesn’t present you with any inside jokes. Hugh Glass is a man wronged and conflicted, living between two worlds and tragically deprived of the one person who anchored him in the land of the living. The narrative draws deeply from elemental symbolism and mythologies that invoke a sense of Hugh Glass as a man who has died more than once, and who is honor bound to stay on the earthly plane in pursuit of revenge.  At times it feels larger than it needs to be, often balanced out by moments of deafening stillness and quiet.  The heartbreak of the man’s situation and indeed of the all of the men around whom the film revolves is apparent and plainly articulated, yet moving from scene to scene more often than not it was the visual aspects that compelled my eye to follow.  
When I did feel compelled to give my attention to the characters it was always attached to the American fascination with the wilderness man.  Hugh Glass’ scramble for survival would put Bear Grylls to shame, and it stands as a testament to research  and commitment to authenticity that certain scenes unfold the way that they do.  The fear of the white trappers attacked by Native Americans on the frontier is palpable and offers what might be the most original and authentic interpretation to date of what this type of fight would have looked and sounded like. Leonardo DiCaprio gives so much of himself it’s a wonder there is anything left after a performance as wrenching and visibly exhausting as any that have ever been put to film.  

After all is said and done while still determined to not reveal too much, I can say that The Revenant  delivers.  If you’re squeamish it’s not for you. If you abhor violence its not for you. If you want a sense of an America long gone but whose beauty refuses to quit our imagination or our storytelling tradition, check it out.

title: Show Review Throwback // Beach House Show Review (12/10/15)
content:
Words By: Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio DJ 1/15/16

When it was announced that Beach House would be playing four shows in Los Angeles, all at the Fonda Theater, one could imagine the much-loved Baltimore group to be in high demand. Having four nights to fill, the release of Depression Cherry and the surprise follow-up Thank Your Lucky Stars provided double the amount of new material to be expected.

Starting the night off, the band began with “Levitation,” the first track off Depression Cherry, a predictable choice that pleased everyone nonetheless. Next, the recognizable drum machine lilting of Teen Dream’s “Walk in the Park” greeted the audience to what was to be the first of many songs from their past discography. Victoria Legrand first spoke in her sultry voice, saying: “Welcome to soirée número dos.” To address the night as a soirée was especially apt, considering the waltzing sway of songs like “PPP” and “Astronaut” entreating the audience to join in the movement. On occasion with the flick of Victoria’s wrist a backlit screen of stars would illuminate, adding to the centralized ambience and romanticism of the night.

Victoria Legrand and Alex Scally always have a taste for filling their shows with drama and mystery; the subdued movements of the band throughout the night maintained a sort of still-life image of a moment at a cabaret bar, the moment of emotional clarity. It was clear they were not to present the best of their new work, with the occasional throwback thrown in, but rather to show the depth of their oeuvre’s thematic and sonic capabilities. Perhaps each of the four nights were completely unique in style and selection, but I would bet that each directed the audience toward the same unifying feeling. As expressed in “Levitation,” their goal is clear: “there’s a place I want to take you / when the unknown will surround you.”

title: Munir Griffin of Westwood Village Ent. Interview
content:
Interview Conducted by: Kelsee Thomas, UCLA Radio DJ

KT: So when did you first fall in love with Hip Hop?
Munir Griffin: I first fell in love with hip hop, I’d say when I was 3 or 4 years old, and I was listening to a Rakim record. (laughs) My dad was listening to Rakim non-stop and from there I just started listening to a lot of neo-soul: Jill Scott, Jaguar Wright, Kindred the Family Soul and it kind of enlightened my ears to see it and pursue doing music which I started at the age of 5.
KT: So at the age of 5 you were like, “Yeah, I want to do music.” You did it yourself? Because I know growing up they tried to get me to play piano. (laughs) I mean now I wish I had kept going with it, but at the time it was just really hard. But were you like, “Yeah, I want to play this?”


MG: Yeah, I mean I did want to do that, but growing up where I lived we had a community center that had a New Orleans style brass band. They kind of had other kids playing instruments and since they had other kids there, then I wanted to do it. They would kind of restrict me from doing it because I had never had an instrument, I wasn’t in school playing music…I was 5 years old, they were just like, “No, you’re not playing.” I remember I came in to a gig one time with a recorder and they started laughing at me because I had a recorder and everyone else had actual instruments: trumpets, trombones…So I kind of felt out of place, but as soon as I got a horn, I was so happy and fell in love with it. I just loved playing it.
KT: I’ve spoken with you before and you’re always talking about this community center that you grew up in. Were you always in it? Did your parents always put you in this community center? What’s up with that?
MG: Growing up in Camden, when I was younger you always wanted to do stuff because you would always just see bad things happening and you just wanted to be a kid and have fun all the time. So I kept riding by a little community center, at night there were always people there. They had tons of trophies in the window. So one day I just said to my mom, “Hey I want to do karate.” She was like, “ You want to do karate?” (laughs) It started as a karate school when I went, and as soon as I got information and started doing karate, I started seeing the other options and outlets that they had to offer. From karate, to the brass band, to African dancing and drumming classes, they were basically a scheduled thing. But once you went to the classes there were also performances you had to go to for those classes.
KT: So how long were you in karate though? Like do you have a black belt or something? (laughs)
MG: Yeah, I actually have a first degree black belt. (laughs)
KT: You said that you were introduced to music instrumentally through New Orleans Brass Band. You play the sax now and everything, do you think the elements of the New Orleans Brass Band is apparent in your music now?
MG: Yeah. (laughs) It’s just that a lot of the things from New Orleans band music is instrumental, but even now with their contemporary type of music, that’s on the radio…You won’t know, but it’ll be a instrumental song, but with a hip hop feel or they’ll kind of make a remake of a song like “Let’s Get It On” by Marvin Gaye and make it more into a contemporary style of music. If you’re listening to that style, it’ll really help because you’ll be able to bring instrumentation along with rap and vocal lyrics and bring them together as much as possible. So when I do do that, it’s me bringing a new feel of hip hop, that people don’t really know of. That’s all I’m really trying to do. Just hearing what I know.
KT: With a lot of people, especially musicians, I like to ask, “What would you define as an artist?” A lot of answers I usually get are following your own way and making work for you. With you saying, “I like to take the brass band sound and infuse it into hip hop and do what I want to do”, would you define that as what an artist is? How would you define what an artist is?
MG: I would say, you’re focusing on yourself, but at the same time, you’re focusing on someone who’s listening because you’re taking an aspect now of, “Oh, that sounds good!”, you have to know how to relate to that person. As much as possible. Me being a male, I should know how to relate to man, female, boy, girl, anybody that can know a message. If you’re able to do that, the best artists should be able to do that. Just relate to somebody who is hearing what you make. Through your story, they can hear a similar story of their own. So they can say, “Yeah, I relate.” For instance, somebody like Drake or Erykah Badu doing “Hotline Bling”, doing those lyrics might really mean something for them, but for someone listening it might mean something deep to them too. Like you start singing the lyrics, like you’re the one who made the lyrics! (laughs) That’s how it’s really supposed to be. The listener is really in tune and engaged, “Oh yeah, this is me all the way. I want to mess with this person, because there’s a part of me that I hear or see in you.” Energies and vibes, music kind of enhances all of that too, so when you bring all of that together it shapes a great artist.
KT: Who are you listening to right now, or it doesn’t even have to be a musician, but artist wise who are you listening to, who are you watching, who are you looking at, who represents…Who’s kind of an inspiration to you? As far as this whole idea of an artist is concerned?
MG: There’s different aspects. You have people like J. Cole or Kendrick Lamar that are more conscious and they’re hip hop artists or poets basically, telling a story. But then you have new artists as far D.R.A.M. or Goldlink. Goldlink is a great artist because you hear what he has through his music a lot, especially when he’s writing. Different people. I just listen to a lot of different things. SZA, Iman Omari, even producers like Sango or KAYTRANADA, the music is more of an energy that they have. When you feel that or what their brand is or what they’re trying to show, that has a lot of importance as an artist. You know, the more you push your brand and what your brand is showing is what can bring an artist out more.
KT: When somebody asks you what type of music are you into or who you’re listening to right now, it’s such a hard question.
MG: Yeah, especially if you’re trying to create new music. It’s really ambiguous. I mean with me, majority of the time we’re listening to the same people so I’m always trying to put someone on to different or new people. For someone to be like, “Oh! I’ve never heard of them before. You’re listening to them? Let me see who that is.” Because I know when other people do that for me, it broadens my horizons to see new people. My manager, Amanda, listens to so many different people and reggae like Buju Banton, all these different people that are crazy. She really helps me listen to different things. I’ve been listening to a lot of Diplo and Major Lazer stuff and looking at how he’s, in my opinion, an all around artist. His visuals and music aren’t really in relation to him, it relates to emotions and feelings and problems people go through.
KT: Yeah, actually one thing I love about Major Lazer or Diplo was the fact that he’s so creative. I don’t know if it comes on anymore, but he had this cartoon on Fox that revolved around his character, Major Lazer. Every episode was something different…
MG: Yeah! I remember there was one where they were trying to legalize marijuana. (laughs)
KT: Yeah! Then there was another one where there was this Professor that stole the beat drop in all of music and concentrated it into one Beat Drop. (laughs)
MG: A good thing too, is that he displays his music in the cartoon, either throughout or at the end and there’s always a message at the end of those shows. People like that are always going to make money because they can basically appeal to anyone and not just one demographic of people. The whole world can get something out of watching Major Lazer, either from knowing exactly who he is or who Diplo is. That’s something I would really want for my music, to have anything that can relate to people because then you know you’re doing something good in the world. Getting paid for it too is the best thing. (laughs)
KT: You actually went into my next question which is, what do you want people to take away from your music? At the end of the day?
MG: Right now, with me playing different types of music, from Trap to Wavy R&B and Soul music to Commercialized Pop music, I just want people to hear what it can do for them. Since music can heal the soul, I know that some people have heard me play and it brings a warmness to their soul basically. I want it to be very moving or heartfelt or touching. I want that through all realms whether producing, performing, music video, anywhere you hear me, you’ll be like, “Yeah, this is going to keep me right where I need to be.”
KT: What is your end goal with your music? Whether that’s career wise or your end goal in life with your art. Where do you find the progression in your art?
MG: Mostly, for right now, through the brand. In the future, I think more personally. Me not only portraying good music and making touching music, but telling my story. Where it becomes personal, that’s where the relation comes from and will transpire through my music. Like Erykah Badu who tells her story, whereas Beyonce makes feel good music, there’s a difference. Letting people know my journey.
KT: I know this is different for every artist, as far as the question of fame and everything, but would you be happy selling out stadiums…
MG: Of course. Of course. I would want to do that because I’ve been performing in stages and stadiums since I was younger, so me doing my own thing like that would be…I mean if I told you all the things I did and performed in when I was younger you’d be like, “Wow, why are you even standing here right now.” I did things such as performing at the Million Man March, I went to West Africa, Guinea, and performed for their cultural festival where we performed with Les Ballets Africains, performed at Brooklyn Academy of Music so many times, just did…So many things I’ve done, put with fame can inspire somebody else. Tupac said, “I don’t want to be the one who does it, but be the one who sparks the brain that does.” I want to do that, but more consciously. I want to be an intellectual black man from the hood that does this. Kendrick Lamar kind of did it, but he’s not college educated. J. Cole kind of did it. 2 Chainz actually graduated as valedictorian, but doesn’t portray it on where he’s at right now. I’m trying to do that being at one of the best universities in the world and still trying to get it out there.
KT: You’re speaking of making sure your intelligence is apparent in your work and your brand and everything, what’s your process as far as making art is concerned? You sound like you have a lot loaded in your work. How do you make sure you get this all in your work?
MG: First off, how do I feel? Then after how I feel, the intent comes along. Like why would I feel like this or why I would think somebody would feel like this? I’m always thinking about that one person who might be feeling that song or who might this song be for. Then once I start writing, it becomes more personal, but other than that it’s feelings first, intentions second. I just apply what I do from the intention.
KT: That’s interesting because I know a lot of people that work that backwards. (laughs) The intention is first, then my feelings, what do I intend for this to say and then my feelings involved in that.
MG: Well I mean, Joey Bada$$, who’s another person too as the main inspiration. Maybe because we’re both Aquariuses, which is crazy (laughs), but he sums it up the best, “If it don’t hit my spirit, then I don’t get near it.” So if I don’t feel it then I’m not even going to want to be near it or do it. I have to feel it first. If I don’t feel it then I know somebody else isn’t going to do feel it. Then once I feel it, the intentions automatically start coming. Feeling is really key.
KT: A little bit off topic, but mentioning Joey Bada$$, you actually remind me a lot of him and even your group puts off the same vibe that his does. With that being said, you are in a group, Westwood Village Ent., that’s full of different people from everywhere, so how’d ya’ll meet?
MG: It really started when I started hanging out with Ace Mack, who’s a fourth year rapper who goes here, and one day he was just saying, “My dad used to engineer for Tupac,” and he was from out of Sacramento so I was just thinking, “Ayee we gotta link.” I linked up with him and he introduced me to Lyon. Lyon was in another group called Wild Tribe, which was Pro Era-ish a little bit, but it was more so that they were all rappers. When I got closer to him and Lyon though, it became more of us making music. We then found out that Lyon’s a Gemini, I’m an Aquarius, we really started clicking more and making music. So from there he was supposed to be making a mixtape called Westwood Village, and I was like, “Wow, this should be a group.” (laughs) Plus, that was when Ani came (Indigenous Soul) and we started doing more stuff together. I started paying more attention to a lot of the artists who were around me and realizing that we should do a collective. Knowing that Ani sings and that Lyon raps, we came together and made a song called “So High”. We haven’t recorded it, but we play it live all the time. From there, the flame was lit.
When me and Lyon moved in together, we met Bashir, and came to find out that he was also from New Jersey, North New Jersey, making it an East Coast connection. So, that’s when Sky Season came about too. Right now, Westwood Village is like the overhead, since it’s more of the business of everything, but everything else is more independent. Like our independent artists such as Indigenous Soul, Lyon, Chris Winston, Munir Griffin, Alec Be, Christopher Pree, we have so many people that want to be a part of what we’re doing which is making good music. I mean we  even have amazing musicians such as Rameen Abrahams, who’s a dope bass player. Him and his brother just got finished doing something for Red Bull, the soccer team’s half time show in New York, he did something for the Clippers playing the National Anthem. He’s really dope. We just have so many different outlets of people, who want to use their talents.
But mainly I want there to be a music culture or artistic culture that people after us can come here and get into, even after I graduate. Like, “I can be stable if I want to do this artist thing, or this entertainment thing, or anything.”
KT: I think with all off that that you all are really creating a family as well. I mean especially with the fact that you all come from different places all over, you all kind of say, “Hey, you’re dope. We’re here for you.”
MG: I mean, yeah, we’re definitely working towards that. We’re also working towards people saying, “Hey I grew with ya’ll. I remember ya’ll when you weren’t big yet,” and sharing that with other people. That’s why us being involved with ASU (Afrikan Student Union) or campus events, let’s people feel like, “Yeah, that’s our house band. We see them a lot.” (laughs) We’re trying to make it where Westwood becomes a place for artists and good vibes. Something like Westwood Village is meant for diversity and it’s to impact and empower the masses. That’s why I’ve made songs like “We Dem College Kids” because at the end of the day we’re not just one race, we’re the human race.

You can find Munir Griffin/Westwood Village’s music at https://soundcloud.com/munirgriffin orhttps://soundcloud.com/westwoodvillageentCheck their diversity in genre and vibes as you listen.You can reach them on their soundclouds linked above.​

title: Show Review: Seoul & We Were Promised Jetpacks @ Teragram Ballroom (11/20/15)
content:
Scottish Indie Rock mixed with Canadian Indie/Electronic equals a fantastic Friday night. We Were Promised Jetpacks performed at the Teragram Ballroom on November 20th, touring for their new album Unraveling, released October 3rd, 2015, and Seoul, who recently just finished their first U.S. tour, opened for them.

Seoul kicked off the show and from the get-go I could immediately tell that my friend and I were just about the only two people in the crowd who knew who they were—I don’t expect a WWPJ fan to know Seoul at all. But looking around, I could see the crowd dancing to the synth infused indie/electronic sounds. During “Stay With Us” from their debut album I Become A Shade (2015) people were dancing in place, rocking to the reverb and lo-fi sounds emanating from their instruments. My favorite part of their set is when Julian, the front man of the band, talked about Los Angeles winters. “We’re very confused about your weather since we’re from Canada. November in Ontario is full of slush, not snow or rain, but a wet mixture of both and it’s freezing.” But regardless, he said, this weather reminded him of drinking red wine while cuddling with your lover.

After their set I actually got a chance to chat with Julian. I told him that my friend and I were able to catch their show at the Echo in September—he was very happy to know that we attended the only two shows they played in Los Angeles—and I asked him what his least favorite city from that tour was. He laughed, not expecting the question, and answered “Chapel Hill, North Carolina. There were like 4 people there and it was just awful”. He also talked about his experience when they stayed at his grandma’s house after having a show somewhere in Florida. “I hadn’t been in a very long time and so it was nice to see her. For some reason everyone in Ontario always has a house in Florida. Anyways, when I saw her she said, ‘Julian! Can you play that song that says ‘fuck’ in it for my friends’ (referring to “Silencer” from their debut album)? It was really embarrassing but funny”.

My friend also asked him what their album art represents and where it was taken. “That was taken at the Olympic stadium in Ontario. You know when a city hosts an Olympic games and build massive stadiums, only to be abandoned once they are over? This is what was left of those Olympics. My friend and I were taking pictures there and the picture on our cover is of me swinging my backpack in a circle. It kind of looks like I’m either entering the photo or dissipating from it, kind of like I myself am becoming a shade. That’s why we used it”. After our conversation he signed both of our vinyls!

We Were Promised Jetpacks started and the serene ambience that Seoul brought to the Teragram immediately changed to raw emotions mixed with nostalgia. They played “Ships With Holes Will Sink” from their debut album These Four Walls (2009) and the crowd became alive with energy. Everyone was reciting the lyrics almost as if the song had helped each member of the crowd in some different way—the emotion was indescribable really. The energy continued as the band played “A Part of It” from Unraveling (2015) and “Keeping Warm” from These Four Walls (2009). During the five-minute instrumental introduction of the song, the crowd began chanting the melody and the collective effervescence was contagious: euphoric. Another moment like this was when they played “Sore Thumb” from their sophomore album “In The Pit of the Stomach” (2011). The song itself is very somber but hearing it live was breathtaking. Adam Thompson, the lead singer, puts the microphone to his diaphragm and begins passionately singing. As soon as he is finished, the breakdown begins and the crowd just goes into this synchronized head banging. The song is so powerful, drawing the same emotions as an Explosions in the Sky song.

My overall favorite part of the night was when the band played “Quiet Little Voices” from These Four Walls. A mosh pit broke out in the crowd and the funniest thing about it was I saw what appeared to be two 50-year-old men in the middle of it; the unity that this band brought was awesome. Every person in the crowd put their phones down completely entranced by the band. Hearing this song live for the first time in my life was such a pleasure. I have been a big fan of this band since I was a freshman in high school so it was almost as if I marked it off my bucket list. They finished their set with “Its Thunder and Its Lightning” from These Four Walls (2009), thus concluding probably one of my top 5 favorite concerts of 2015. It probably would have been in my top 3 had I not gotten a $73 parking ticket.

WWPJ Setlist:

When I Know[new]

Ships With Holes Will Sink

A Part of It

Moving Clocks Run Slow

Safety In Numbers

Peaks and Troughs

Keeping Warm

Repeating Pats[new]

Roll Up Your Sleeves

I Keep It Composed

Sore Thumb

Quiet Little Voices

Boy in the Backseat

Pear Tree

It’s Thunder and It’s Lightning

Seoul Set:

I Become A Shade

The Line

Stay with Us

Silencer

Fields
White Morning

Haunt/A Light

Real June

Carry Home Food In Winter

I Negate

Words By: Bryan Villalpando

Photos By: Bryan Villalpando

title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 13 With Car Seat Headrest
content:
Written By : Amy Cummings, UCLA Radio Intern

Photos Courtesy of Red Bull Sound Select Content Pool

Post Date: 11/30/16

Considering how easy it is to listen to Car Seat Headrest in daily life, it never would have occurred to me to label them as a “rock” band. Accordingly, I didn’t fully consider just how loud their live performance would be, or how much screaming would be involved. Tickets to the show sold out in just over an hour, and I mourned for weeks that I hadn’t gotten tickets before miraculously getting my hands on a press pass.

As soon as Will Toledo walked on stage, soon joined by the rest of the band, I could feel the energy in the room rising. After acknowledging the recent presidential election and citing the death of Leonard Cohen this week, as well as the year’s earlier loss of David Bowie, the band opened with covers of Cohen’s “Field Commander Cohen” and Bowie’s “Five Years” to start the show. All four members of the band were giving it their all, evidenced by the blasting guitars and drums radiating over the crowd. But the moment I knew we were in for a great ride was when we heard the opening notes of “Fill in the Blank,” the first track from CSH’s highly-anticipated Teens of Denial album, which came out earlier this year. After a roar of approving applause and cheers, the crowd began singing along: “I’m so sick of… (fill in the blank)…” As the instruments all briefly cut out for the start of the chorus, the crowd started to not just sing but scream along with the chorus: “‘You have no right to be depressed!’ ‘You haven’t tried hard enough to like it’… it hurts, it hurts, it hurts, it hurts…” Although the band’s faces remained stoic, the crowd’s energy built throughout the set to match the intensity of the music pouring off the stage. The crowd continued alternatively singing and screaming along, even to some of the band’s older songs.

The show, of course, was incredible. It was almost hard to believe that such a strong musical performance was coming from this relatively calm-looking group of musicians. Unlike performers who throw their whole bodies into their act, the band’s faces reflected a placid state of concentration. Will, the poster child of CSH, barely moved for most of the show, besides picking up and putting down his guitar. The ultimate of art boys, he was clad in a gray dress shirt, shiny black dress shoes, and a dark tie and jacket as if he had just escaped from some oppressive prep school. I wondered how he was able to play without sweating through all those clothes. Nonetheless, his vocals were surprisingly powerful, to say nothing of the frequent screaming that broke through sporadically. The band’s outward low-energy stage presence, contrasted with the intensity of their performance, seemed to represent something often reflected in their lyrics: you might look calm on the outside, but inside you can still be filled with rage, power, and pain.

Pictured above: UCLA Radio interns before having their minds completely blown by Car Seat Headrest

After an impressive hour-long set that went by in what seemed like a few moments, Will stepped to the mic and announced, “We were going to end this with a sad song, but I don’t want to do that anymore ‘cause I’m actually feeling pretty good right now.” We saw his elusive smile for maybe the first time as he turned to his bandmates and they banged out “Destroyed by Hippie Powers” to close out the set. Then they disappeared off stage, and the crowd screamed for an encore like our lives depended on it. After an excruciating minute or two that almost made us believe that the walk-off was for real, they re-emerged and told us they hadn’t been able to decide between “the sad encore” or “the happy encore,” so they would do both. The sad factors were obvious, but “the happy thing is that life goes on, and we still go to rock shows, and we still fall in love and all the other good shit,” Will told us. The band played two more songs. I didn’t want it to end and neither did anybody else.

It would do no good to try to further put into words exactly how the show was or how euphoric it was to be among all the other angsty people dancing, jumping, and singing along as we dumped our hearts all over the Teragram Ballroom. There were no hecklers, there was no moshing, only people reacting in earnest to music that really touched them. After the show I spent fully 24 hours thinking about how perfect it all was and hearing in my mind the echo of the crowd. I’m not one for concert videos, but I combed YouTube for a live recording of “Fill In the Blank,” and no one was singing along in any of them. Red Bull Sound Select, if you’re reading, please release live footage of Day 13 so we can see a band and a concert crowd together at their finest. For now, I’ll be clinging to the memories and waiting for the next tour.

title: Show Review // Day Wave @ The Troubadour (11/3/16)
content:
Written By : Andy Talajkowski, UCLA Radio Digital Press Manager

Photos By : Jonathan Hays, UCLA Radio Photo/Video 

Post Date: 11/07/16

It’s 10 p.m. on a Wednesday, and at the Troubadour, the night has just begun. The small floor space is packed, and people are pressed against the stage, laughing at the bar, and leaning over the balcony. The two openers have left everyone restless. Local alternative rock band Future Feats animated the crowd with their boyish energy and excitement, as an opener whose music sounds much better live because of the pure enjoyment they emulate during their performance. Clean Spill had continued with their slurred, angsty vocals against surf rock streaked guitar and steady drums. While the crowd a little slow to catch onto the mood after the more mainstream energy of Future Feats, by the end many were moving and cheering, and even managed to form a small pit by the last song. Now buzzing with anticipation, fans peek up every once and awhile at the glass booth on the upper level, where Day Wave and his touring band are waiting to take to stage.

It’s an impressive sight for a musician who, just a little over a year ago, was playing only small local gigs in the Bay Area. I’d first met Day Wave when they were performing at happy hour in the quad of Phoenix Hotel in San Francisco, with a modest crowd made up mostly of patrons enjoying a cocktail by the pool. Back then they were getting paid in free booze and hotel rooms, and they were fun - talking to them after their set, they were energetic, excited, and just a bit cocky. In the subsequent months they’ve burst onto the indie music scene, performing in Europe, Australia, and across the United States at festivals like Lollapalooza and Treasure Island. Yet after seeing their features on Noisey and Urban Outfitters, the washed out pastel portraits of Jackson Phillips, the musician behind Day Wave, and the EPs released on limited edition pink vinyl, part of me became worried that what was really propelling the band was its ability to fit inside the current alternative aesthetic. Indeed, when I had investigated their merch table earlier that night I found minimalist white pocket tees and stacks of dreamy polaroids taken by one of the touring musicians during their previous tour. Sifting through the photos, I wondered if the band’s selling point that night was their music, or their look.


For a brief moment, as Phillips stepped out on stage in black jeans, white high top Converse, and an appropriately ironic D.A.R.E. t-shirt, my fears seemed to be confirmed. Yet the minute the group launched into their new single “Wasting Time,” I experienced a complete reversal of all I had expected. The band’s live performance chose to favor their rock influence over the more dreamy electronic aspects of the music, while still keeping the perfect hint of synth and slightly ethereal delivery. The musicians forwent the indie stereotype of barely moving on stage with eyes closed and instead moved around to jam out together, bending low over their instruments, and keeping spirits high. The first song, one of Day Wave’s more upbeat and breezy releases, set a perfect tone for the night. The set was nearly entirely music, with very brief interludes of Phillips thanking the crowd, and almost bashfully admitting the band wasn’t used to performing for such a sizeable group of people. The arrangement of the venue, with the floor pushed close up to the low stage, also created a shared atmosphere between the performers and attendees, and helped immensely with both groups trading excitement and good vibes. The crowd bounced and swayed along as Day Wave played tracks from EP’s Headcase and Hard to Read. “Deadbeat Girl” especially brought cheers as the familiar synth and upbeat guitar led into Phillip’s whimsical vocals. Even when the band brought down the tempo with quieter, daydreamy “You,” Phillips smiled softly, bringing a sweet nostalgia to his lyrics, “I don’t know how to feel about you,” in one of the best songs of the night. The performance concluded with a masterful three piece ending, starting with the band’s stellar cover of “Ceremony.” Much of Day Wave’s music is already influenced by New Order, making the rendition a good fit within the set. When they flowed into their most popular track, “Drag,” no one could help but to sing along. Finally, after the band promised to come back to LA soon, the night concluded with a raucous version of one of Day Wave’s first songs, “We Try But We Don’t Fit In,” which had the crowd shouting and even head banging as the band applied a garage band energy and rowdiness to their sound. After the set, Phillips and the touring members hung around the floor, talking and drinking with the crowd in a comfortable sense of familiarity and casualness. When I asked one of the musicians how things had changed since the Phoenix back last summer, he shrugged and said it wasn’t that much different. And I believed him. When it came down to the question of whether Day Wave would become neatly packaged within their pastel polaroids, their performance showed they most certainly didn’t. They hadn’t even really been there in the first place.

title: November’s Show of the Month // Reporting For Booty
content:
Post Date : 07/01/16 

How did you first get into mixing and live djing?

Officer Gavin: DJing was something that had always peaked my interest, even to the point of purchasing some equipment during high school. However, I never really began to learn how to use it or mix until I was approached by a member of SCA (student committee for the arts) who asked to open for esta. I was actually referred to that person by other members of UCLA Radio that are also a part of SCA. It’s hard because anyone that has a show is really allowed to call themselves a DJ, even though they aren’t necessarily live mixing. I’m fairly certain I was approached because some people were under the impression that I actually knew how to mix, but being presented with the opportunity to open for esta. provided me with more than enough motivation to learn.

Who or what inspires your musical/djing style?

 Office Gavin: I started taking dance classes when I was 2 years old. Although dance was not something I chose to pursue professionally, it has manifested itself somehow in almost every part of my life and was integral to my developing such a deep connection to music. I’m inspired by anything that makes me want to dance and that’s a vibe I try to maintain throughout my entire set.

Say you’re hosting Reporting For Booty: The Live Music Festival Edition. Who is invited to perform? Who is banned?

Officer Gavin: DAMN that would be so sick I really hope this is a real event one day! Artist wise I’m thinking Luca Lush, Porter Robinson, James Blake, Sean Paul, Dillon Francis, Missy Elliot, Disclosure, T-Pain, Zebra Katz, Kid Cudi, Stooki Sound, OutKast (wishful thinking), and Fergie. Donald Trump is banned.

 What advice would you give to someone who is just getting started in the mixing and live performance scene?

Officer Gavin:

a.     Everyone started somewhere, I’m sure Diplo’s first show was small and lame af.

b.     Your mixing skills correlate SO heavily with the amount you practice so put the time in!!!

c.     No one will ever know if you mess up while performing (except for you) so just have a fucking awesome time!

 And finally, what is one thing people need to know about you and your show?

Officer Gavin: I need people to know that every week, without fail, there is not one second of reporting for booty where I am not dancing in the studio. I hope that you feel the need to report your booty to the dance floor as much as I do, however you may choose to do that.

title: 22, A Million - Bon Iver // Album Review (Release Date : 09/30/16)
content:
Written By : Alexa Lee, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 10/18/16

Bon Iver press release statement regarding 22, A Million:

“22, A Million is part love letter, part final resting place of two decades of searching for self-understanding like a religion. And the inner-resolution of maybe never finding that understanding. The album’s 10 poly-fi recordings are a collection of sacred moments, love’s torment and salvation, contexts of intense memories, signs that you can pin meaning onto or disregard as coincidence. If Bon Iver, Bon Iver built a habitat rooted in physical spaces, then 22, A Million is the letting go of that attachment to a place.”

There is music that is beautiful because it reminds us of something else, for example when The Killers evoke New Wave nostalgia or how Adele never lets us forget the beauty of a classic piano ballad. And then there is music that is beautiful because it feels so different and innovative it reminds us of nothing else. Bon Iver’s newest album, 22, A Million, falls into the latter category.

In this album, Bon Iver experiments sonically with computer-affected vocals and arrangements, as well as instruments such as the saxophone that not typically used by this indie folk, Wisconsin-based band. However, despite being a distinct departure from previous bodies of work, 22, A Million still maintains an innate yet intangible “Bon Iver” quality to its sound, which I can only describe as a clarity of emotional expression so embedded into the heart of Bon Iver’s music that it feels not only deeply personal, but also vulnerable.

What separates 22, A Million from past albums is that before, this, for lack of a more apt name, “Bon Iver” quality was firmly anchored in the music’s connection to physical places. The very titles of songs from Bon Iver and For Emma, Forever Ago are largely names of places such as “Perth” or “Lisbon, OH.” In 22, A Million, the “Bon Iver” quality disconnects from physical places, which is reflected both in the lyrics and the disembodied, slightly electronically altered sounds of the album. The song “33 “God”” states plainly, “These will just be places to me now,” concisely summarizing the shift from expressing oneself through physical locations to suspending freely in a more ethereal understanding of existence in the world. Like the unfamiliar yet intimate musical sounds of 22, A Million, the lyrics of the album depart from attaching emotional significance to places and transcend onto a level of self-understanding and emotional reflection that is beyond one’s immediate physical surroundings.

My only criticism for 22, A Million is a superficial one. I think the song titles needlessly use excessive symbols and letter capitalization. Because of this, it becomes inconvenient to reference the specific song titles in verbal conversation (“Hey what do you think about 715 – CRΣΣKS? You know what my favorite track is? ____45_____”), which is a shame because I want to talk about the album with people! However, I am willing to concede that perhaps this is an artistic choice singer-songwriter Justin Vernon makes for reasons that go over my uncreative head.

Favorite tracks of the album: 29 #Strafford APTS and 715 – CRΣΣKS

title: Interview: Getting Geeky with TTNG @ ArcTanGent Festival 2016
content:
Written By : Layla Moheimani, UCLA Radio DJ

Post Date: 09/21/16


Among the many distinctions TTNG holds in my musical development, they will always be part of my fateful “first math rock concert” several years ago that helped pave the way for the deep love and appreciation for the genre that I have today. Maybe that’s why it felt so fitting for them to be one of the first bands I saw at my first ArcTanGent. Last time I saw the trio, it was their first show following the release of their third album, Disappointment Island. (You can read a review of the show here.) This time around, they had toured the album all across the United States and as a result, many of the tracks definitely felt more settled. It was also clear that the fans had fully embraced the new album as well. From an audience perspective, it was perhaps the most electrifying set I’ve seen them play and it really set the tone for the whole festival and all the exciting bands I’d be witnessing over the next three days. I sat down with guitarist Tim Collis and drummer Chris Collis to discuss the band’s evolution, their new album, and geekiness in the math rock scene.

August 19, 2016 - Fernhill Farm, Bristol, UK

Layla: This is your third time playing ArcTanGent. How do you think the festival has grown since the first time you played it?
Tim: There’s a few more people. It seemed pretty popular the first year but I guess they’ve sold more tickets since the years have gone on.
Chris: Yeah, it’s cool that the kind of lineups are obviously changing. I mean, they still have bands back on the Thursday but they seem to get really big popular acts that haven’t played before as well. So I hope they keep finding enough bands to keep it interesting, which they seem to be doing at the moment.

L: Do you have a favorite memory from ArcTanGent, either from this year or any of the previous years?
C: I think playing last night was probably the highlight of all of them. That was awesome.
T: I like the first year but purely for the weather because it was really sunny. That was nice for that reason but yeah as Chris said, this one was pretty cool performance-wise.

L: This is my first year [at ArcTanGent] so do you guys have any advice for a first-timer? How to navigate or any do’s or don’ts?
T: Don’t camp (laughter)
C: Bring a jacket. We’re pretty wussy when it comes to camping because we don’t live too far so we tend to drive home and come back. But we might camp tonight. It’s pretty fun so we’ll see.

L: Have you guys been seeing a lot of the other bands around? Are there any who’ve surprised you or any you really enjoyed?
C: I watched Three Trapped Tigers. They’re awesome so I always like watching them. I look forward to seeing toe, obviously.

L: What bands were you listening to when you first started this band and were trying to figure out your sound?
C: (to Tim) Well you first started it, didn’t you?
T: I guess when the band first started it sounded really different. It sounded more like Biffy Clyro’s early stuff and I was listening to bands like Incubus. So this was a long time ago. It didn’t actually sound anything like it does now. It was completely different.
C: I think American Football, Owls, Make Believe were quite influential in the movement towards mathy indie stuff.

L: Henry [Tremain, bassist and vocalist] isn’t here so I can’t ask him about vocals, but as a band that has a vocalist when a lot of math rock bands are instrumental, do you think it’s harder for vocals to fit into math rock? Why do you think that it’s less common?
T: I think it is harder. I think it depends how you want the vocals to sit. We have it as quite a predominant thing. The lyrical aspect is at the forefront in a traditional sense of what a vocalist would do. They’re delivering the most obvious message to the audience in terms of lyrics and meaning that you can take directly. But yeah, I do think it’s harder for vocalists to write math rock music because it tends to be more technical. There’s less space. But I think Henry likes that. It’s more of a challenge to fit things in and perhaps not just consider lyrics, but syllables and rhythms of how he’s singing and how it’s gonna fit or where to leave space. So yeah, I think it’s more difficult but I don’t think it’s necessarily a bad thing.
C: I think a lot of instrumental math rock bands could benefit from having vocals. Because I personally find it gets very boring and samey without them. But that’s just what I like from music. I definitely like some vocals on them.

L: You guys became a 3-piece band over three years ago, but Disappointment Island was your first album actually recording as one. Do you think that playing live as a 3-piece for so many years influenced the writing and recording process? Did it make you feel more comfortable?
C: When we became a 3-piece we had to make a lot of amendments to the [early] music to try and be able to play it as the three of us. So it’s been nice to have finally written an album where it’s the three of us from the start and it’s very comfortable playing it because that’s how we wrote it, whereas before we were always trying to figure out quite how to do it and never quite sounding as full. But yeah, they’ve certainly brought us closer in tightness, just being three and playing together for so long now so it does come across in that new album.

L: So, this most recent album. You guys recorded it to tape and with very little overdubs. What was your reasoning behind doing that?
C: We just wanted to have a stripped down production to it so it was just the sound of the two guitars and the drums in a nice room. Recording it live to tape seemed to be the way that we could play the music together and get a nice energy to it and keep it simple and just play through the songs as we normally would do.

L: You guys toured the new album in the United States and now you’re playing it here. Have there been any songs that have been the most exciting for you to play live?
T: It’s always fun to play newer stuff, but what’s been nice is it doesn’t seem like there’s a standout track that people like. It seems like people’s favorite track varies. So the few new songs we’ve played, like yesterday’s, had a really good reception and it seemed like hopefully there wasn’t a duff one amongst them. So yeah, it’s been cool to play new stuff and have it received pretty well.

L: Continuing with your live shows, you guys always seem to tour with really fantastic bands. I’ve seen you guys play with Tera Melos, EV Kain, Mylets, And So I Watch You From Afar, and most recently Covet. Even just on your past US tour you also had LITE and Giraffes? Giraffes!. Have any of those touring lineups, those or others, been particularly special?
