C: Yeah, they all are in their own way. You always get very close to the people you’re touring with and they become your friends. It’s always great to watch other bands who, like in the case of Tera Melos, always blow me away, like when I watch John [Clardy] drumming. We’ve been very lucky with who we’ve been able to tour with and we’ve always got on really well with all of them. So they’ve all been good in their own way.
T: I guess going back a little bit, one of - maybe all of ours - but one of my favorite tours was with Nate [Kinsella] from Birthmark, who we asked if he wanted to hop on a European tour with us and luckily he said yeah and it was super fun. It had a lot of challenges on that tour but he was just such a great guy to have on the road and his music is pretty special to us. So yeah, we’ve been pretty lucky to have the chance to play with such good bands over the years.

L: Are there any bands who you would love to tour with that the opportunity hasn’t come about yet?
C: I would love to tour with Deerhoof just because I think they would be a lot of fun to hang out with.
T: I’d love to tour with Make Believe, who’s another one of Nate’s bands but I don’t know if those guys are particularly active at the moment. But that would be great. I’d literally be front row every night just loving it.

L: I want to ask you guys this because I feel like this might just be me but I feel like math rock, more than other kinds of music, doesn’t take itself as seriously and there’s more fun or humor to it. Do you guys agree with that?
T: I think so. I think it’s probably overall a smaller genre anyway so I don’t know if there ever will be, or maybe I’m completely wrong, there’s ever gonna be a math rock band that, as such, is huge. So maybe the fact that you exist in a bubble of smaller shows where it is more intimate makes it easier -
C: Yeah, everyone’s sort of weird and geeky in the math rock world so I think it lends itself to people not being that serious.
T: Yeah, it’s very much about the musicianship and I would say that the vast majority of most audiences that go to math rock shows are in math rock bands or other bands. And they‘ll all come and talk to you about gear and stuff. I don’t know, I couldn’t imagine being in a band that doesn’t want to go and talk to people who come to shows because there’s so much in common and it’s such a positive environment. It seems weird that there is ever pretentiousness in music and that people are built up into something that is lauded as being better than anyone who’s there when those dudes are pretty much the exact same as you. So, maybe that’s a reason. Who knows. Maybe the math rock dudes who are geeky are just nice people, I don’t know.

L: Because you did mention gear, I have a more technical question. Tim, you use some pretty unique tunings in your songs. How do you come up with those tunings? Do you think of a riff and then find a tuning that works with it or do you just say “I wonder how this tuning would work” and then find something that comes out of it?
T: Yeah, it’s always just an experiment. I guess both Henry and myself, our approach to guitar has always been pretty much self-taught. So it’s just noodling around like, okay someone might show you a few chords but then it’s off on your own. I think experimenting with open tunings and going from tuning first then just finding a way around it is really interesting. I always remember this, I can’t remember what band it was, but I read this interview and the guy had specifically said that he felt open tunings were like cheat codes to a game. And I just really disagreed with it. I know I personally didn’t feel like it’s a cheat code or it’s a way to make it easier. I thought it was a bigger leap into something unknown and you’re finding a way around it, especially if you’re not from a background of theory or analyzing music in that way where it is just “Okay, I’m gonna try this out”. For me, I just thought it was really fun to come up with a chord shape that I perhaps knew and it sounds totally different or kind of invent chord shapes that, sorry not that don’t exist (laughter). Yeah, with six fingers or anything. That unknown keeps it interesting because we’ve been playing our instruments for quite a long time now and there are days where I say “I clearly don’t feel as excited about it as ten years ago” but I think with things like that, maybe for other bands new effects or whatever, it’s quite a good way to keep it personally interesting and that can develop into your songwriting and keep that fun as well.

L: So Chris, when you hear a riff that Tim comes up with that’s in some really strange meters or timing, do you find that you have to try to dissect it and count it out or do you just go by feel when constructing drum parts?
C: Yeah, for [TTNG’s first album] Animals I did split it up into sections and count them out. Then as the riffs got more and more complicated on the later stuff where there was more half beats and things, it’s almost impossible to count and play so then that’s detrimental. So I just listen to his riff and get it in my head and then just try and play along with that or against it or something rather than splitting it up. I think it sounds a bit more flowing when I’m not like “Here’s a bar of 4, then 5, then 3”. It’s more musical to try and just pick out bits to emphasize or disagree with in certain cases. It’s easy just to feel it.

title: Show Review: Silversun Pickups @ The Hollywood Palladium - Los Angeles CA (8/13/16)
content:
(Photo Credit: Susan Koh)

Written by: Bryan Villalpando, Promotions Manager

August 16th, 2016

Los Angeles natives Silversun Pickups rocked the Hollywood Palladium this past Saturday in support of their most recent release Better Nature (September 25th, 2015). Touring around the world since 2015 they made one final stop in their hometown before they embark on the European leg come October.

9:30pm: the room goes dark. A xylophonic melody of Cradle (Better Nature), (Better Nature) begins to play softly; anticipating an unforgettable night, the restless crowd begins to cheer. The soft audio track mutates into a heavily distorted guitar and shrill synth, juxtaposed with Brian Aubert’s–the lead singer–eerily raspy, yet powerful voice as the band emerges from the shadows. Their energy was electric and inviting from the moment they stepped on stage. We rocked out, they jammed: this was only the beginning.

One of the more lighthearted moments of the set was during their performance of Circadian Rhythm (Last Dance), (Better Nature). Before playing the second single of the album, Brian Aubert (lead singer/guitarist), stopped and showed his appreciation for us because of how supportive and welcoming his hometown was to the band.“I’m a 4th generation Angelino, my kid was born here, and I hope that their kids are born in the best city in America. It’s wild because as a band we have been to so many shows here at the Palladium. We saw Bjork here, and now to be on this stage playing for you is extremely humbling. So thank you for welcoming us back home.”

Hit after hit is played, until we reach arguably one of their most popular songs, Panic Switch (Swoons). The heavily distorted guitar riff rips through the room, Nikki Monninger (bassist) shreds, that iconic bass riff: the duo cradles each other’s sound. The crowd breaks out into a wild, nostalgic frenzy. Released in 2009, this song embodies the teen angst of my generation. To scream “I’m fading and waiting and floating away” 7 years later was, for a lack of a better term, awesome!

The best part of the night. They begin playing an A capella snippet of Growing Old is Getting Old, (Swoons). Silence. The G# notes on the guitar rings. The crowd roars as Lazy Eye, (Carnavas), commences. We sing the melody as Brian and Nikki effortlessly play the beautiful beginning riffs. This song is so unique because of the different textures each guitar solo has, transforming the sound throughout the song. I had to mentally step away for a moment just to make sure who I was seeing was real: what I was experiencing was real. Hearing “I’ve been waiting for this moment all my life” has never meant more until then. They step off the stage and the crowd begs for more.

A few minutes later they returned with a fire unseen from the first part of the set. They come back to play Kissing Families, from their first album Pikul–an oldie, but a goodie. After, they play Dots and Dashes (Enough Already) from Neck of the Woods and they finish the unforgettable night with The Wild Kind (Better Nature). Silversun Pickups rocked the night away and did their hometown proud.

“I hope you do something nefarious tonight, ya know, do something weird!” - Brian Aubert

Setlist:

Cradle (Better Nature)

We Thought Out Twinkles

The Royal We

Nightlight

Circadian Rhythm (Last Dance)

The Pit

Little Lover’s So Polite

Friendly Fires

Panic Switch

Ragamuffin

Lazy Eye (Began w/ snippet of Growing Old is Getting Old)

Kissing Families

Dots and Dashes (Enough Already)

The Wild Kind

title: TacoCat Interview
content:
Written By : Brianna Klipp, UCLA Radio DJ

July 11, 2016

Somewhere in Ashland Oregon, a van full of Seattle feminist-punk band members are making their way to Chico for the first time to fulfill their Summer ’16 tour. TacoCat isn’t new to the grind of touring though, as they’ve been performing all over the US with likeminded artists for almost an entire decade. As best friends, the adventurers of TacoCat have seen it all, and their story continues to become more interesting. Prior to their stop in Los Angeles where they will play at The Echo on July 19 with The Regrettes and French Vanilla, singer & bassist, Bree, found time to reminisce on the past, discussing nostalgia infused embarrassing moments, and what the future holds for TacoCat.

DJBree: You’re all over the states for your summer tour. How do you like the experience of performing in LA?

BREE:The big thing in Seattle is fostering younger communities.. This is our first time playing with The Regrettes, who are all only 15 or 16. It’s great that we can be a part of this with them. One of the band members Dad’s messaged me on Facebook and we were discussing the tour.

DjBree: Did you have a mentor when you first started?

BREE: Not even taking people under your wing but just being like, a nice peer. When you’re in music in Seattle, you’re in a Seattle DIY atmosphere… they make you feel that ‘you can do this too.’ I like having a community with these ladies… anything related to art, like music or radio, it feels good. For my own experience, it felt really intimidating being a fem playing music, so it feels good to have a non-binary, feminist audience.

DJBree: Do you think you expanded your fan base just on the virtue of being feminist?

BREE:I think it expanded because its been male dominated for most of my life, so having songs and topics that we can relate to… Like, we just started writing songs about our songs and our experiences and that’s feminist centric because its our values. I think when we get fans that feel the same way where they haven’t been touched on as much, it feels cool that they end up liking our music because they end up being similar as us. You end up really loving your fans.

DJBree: You just reminded me of your song, “Crimson Wave”, where you write about being on your period. This topic is kind of a unicorn because we know it exists but no one wants to talk about it, but you unleash this stigma to make it a natural, funny thing.

BREE: YEAH! Half the population goes through this every month or has to deal with it. Its like.. what? How has this not been talked about? Its such a big deal. Theres 3 ladies in the band and we talk about it pretty comfortably. Why do we have to hide it? Its so stupid. If men went through this, there would be so many songs about it.

DJBree:  Talking about your tour, do you have any embarrassing moments that have happened when you performed?

BREE: Oh yeah, all the time. We have many embarrassing stories that have happened over the years… But 2 days ago in Portland we got stuck in traffic and we were playing at a record store, and we were late. We missed load in, so we had to be super sweaty and gross in front of this crowd of people and unload and immediately perform. It was a lot of work, but we pulled it off.

DjBree: Im sure you have all your own habits and quirks about you. What’s a quirk that you have that may bother other people on the road? Do you make smoothies at 5 am?

BREE: We’re just 4 people that live in a van for months and months, so eventually the smallest thing will get to us.. like, how I chew my food really loud, or crazy things like that. Normally we’re pretty laid back people, but there are things that start to get to people. We have a funny relationship where we know our routines are understood, like we know Eric needs to pee before bed or Emily needs a certain kind of tea, we all know to take care of each other. There’s habits that are just unspoken. I know these people better than I know anyone.

DjBree: So to talk about your writing process, when you go to write a song or coming up with a concept, is there ever a clash when you develop them or is it go with the flow?

BREE: Its usually go with the flow. It starts with me and Erick who comes up with rifts ourselves and we try to mesh it together with Lila. Sometimes its hard to change things that someone wrote, but we can navigate it. We come up with song topics based on what we’re talking about. Emily is the master of melody and weaves it together, like the last piece of the puzzle. Its really fun.

DjBree: No fist fights over the process?

BREE: Not yet! Maybe today! The thing about it, is we’re all libras, so it takes a while.

DjBree: Oh really! Do you buy in to astrology? Do you check your moons? You must have a really fun birthday.

BREE: Oh yeah, we’re way in to being libras. Actually, our drummer is the only non libra, so she complains about October being the break the bank month where she spends all her money going out with us.. we’re just like, sorry Lila.

DjBree: Any plans for this October?

BREE: we were talking about going to mexico because we would have just gotten from tour, but we might just want to stay home and veg out. I just finished Jane the Virgin, Game of Thrones, and I rewatched Sex and the City.

DjBree: Okay, then the question becomes- are you team BIG, or team AYDEN?

BREE: I keep getting in to this fight, this is so funny. I think Ayden is a good guy! (laughs) He’s like such a good person, but my friend Julia from “Chastity Belt is” very team Big and says Ayden is a clingy monster.

DjBree: It’s funny how the human mind works- we always want what we can’t have. In terms of your latest album, “Lost Time.” How did this album come to fruition?

BREE: It came from songs we wanted to do… the “leisure bee concept” vs “worker bees.” We’re sort of in an alternate lifestyle. For the most part we wrote all of them in a 2 month period. We had gotten back from a tour had had the whole summer to write.. We had never worked with a producer up until this point, but everything that he had technically speaking- how we should record drums, double vocals, is really awesome. Sometimes when you play the same song over and over, you get stuck in your own head.

DJBree: Any songs you love playing?

BREE: weekend and internet, which are about internet trolls. Its just like a fun, dancy song vibe. So its just fun to play too.

DJBree: While on tour, what are 3 things you wish you could bring on the road?

BREE: I miss vegging out and ordering Indian food in my pjs all day on Netflix, which is a big one… the person we’re dating, which is a hard one. We try to hangout every 3 weeks for a few days which is really important to us. I’ve gone through this a lot, and it seems like a good solution.

DJBree: This might be a basic question, but our audience needs to know, how did you come up with the name, TacoCat?

BREE: Me and my friend scotty were just writing out a bunch of palindromes, like, racecar, and we were playing around with them on a napkin at his work.. And TacoCat came up, we said it would be a good girl’s band. And here we are.

DjBree: You consider your genre to be feminist sci fi.. Can you explain with this means?

BREE: Did you come across the drawing of the cat with the antennas? There was this short-lived book club in Seattle and the genre came up… it was so appealing to me. So much sci fi has a feminist slant, but I never considered it as a drama. We have some songs like “alien girl” and it’s just fun to think of music through this lens.  There are so many intersections of feminism, and that’s important to us.

DjBree: Feminism has been given a bad rep lately because people think feminists just want to destroy all men and burn beards. Why is this happening?

BREE: its such a weird flashback. Theres such a weird reaction to it. We enjoy pants and the right to vote, and to walk around without being scared of rape.. There are so many important benefits that you would have to be crazy to be against it.

DjBree: your thoughts on menninism?

BREE: it’s a really pathetic flashback against feminism. I went to this standup comic, and I had never heard the term before, and he asked if there are any menninists in the room. It was me and my 6 friends in the front row and gave him a “WTF” look, and he kind of dropped it.

DjBree: Do you have an album that you would embarrassed for your friends to find?

BREE: I think since we’re in a band all the time, my friends know everything about me already.. but Blind Melon and Eve 6, any 90’s one hit wonders are still good.

DjBree: if you were to get arrested, what would it  be for?

Bree: probably drinking in public.

DJBree: Youre going to on tour July 19 at the Echo. Is there anything you want to tell our listeners?

Bree: this show is going to be super fun, I’m looking forward to it! Unfortunately the bar I usually go to after the show, smogcutter, is shut down.  

DjBree: Thanks so much for talking with me today, UCLA Radio is happy to have you on. We’ll see you at the Echo!

title: Weekly Recommendations // UCLA Radio Comedy
content:
Written By: UCLA Radio Comedy Department (02/17/16)

1. HBO’s new animated show, Animals.Produced by the Duplass Brothers and featuring over 70 voice actors from all areas of comedy.

2. VEEP. Okay, we know Veep is incredibly critically acclaimed and has been on for a while but seriously if you haven’t watched it, START. Great dialogue, great cast, no negatives.

3. Jane The Virgin. It’s clever, and we think you’ll enjoy it.

4. Lauren Lapkus. Great at podcasting, improv, sketch, characters. We especially recommend checking out her improv team Wild Horses which also consists of other UCLA Radio favorites Erin Whitehead, Stephanie Allynne, and Mary Holland.

5. JASH. A comedy network made up of the world’s top comedians: Sarah Silverman, Michael Cera, Tim and Eric, and Reggie Watts.

6. Adult Swim Infomercials. Most notably, For Profit Online University.

title: Fine Time :: Club Time // Show Review (02/05/16)
content:
Written By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio DJ (02/12/16)

Photos By: Olivia Lim, UCLA Radio DJ

Considering that they only started throwing shows in the first half of last year, Fine Time is quickly becoming a key player in Los Angeles nightlife. Vice’s Guide to Los Angeles recently shouted it out as what it’d be like to party in a Basquiat painting. Their most recent Club Time was no exception in what has been a string of incredible events.

The venue was a few blocks down South Central from the Coca Cola Bottling Company, past a weathered glass apartment door, and at the end of a tall flight of stairs. The venue was a contrast to the more typical underground venues in how polished it was – think if the Ace Hotel threw a warehouse show. The windows overlooked an industrial yard with wooden palettes stacked so high they were reminiscent of something straight from a Dr. Seuss book. There were funny little indications that the space was somebody’s apartment, like the rack of clothing that had been left out, the couches and chairs that created intimate spaces for socializing, and kitchenette. These details quietly demanded a respect for the space most evident in how smokers self-relegated to a smaller room off the main space the whole night.

Philip Rugo, Babyyruth, and Blvckmxtr, all three of whom rep UCLA’s Design Media Arts program, created the night’s visual installations. The works interacted with their space by using projection mapping to most fully and psychedelically take advantage of the three dimensional surfaces available. Blvckmxtr’s work was projected onto several figures secured to the wall above the DJ booth. Babyyruth and Philip Rugo’s collaboration “Architectural Mapping Experiments” explored sound through color, motion, and experimental imagery in a beautiful fusion of the technological and human.


Tahl K warmed up the night with an hour-long set of laid back jams including a Chrissy Edit of Hypnotic Tango by My Mine, which the crowd lapped up.

The crowd was a very literal embodiment of Fine Time’s doctrine to not cater to just one subset but rather to unite diverse groups of people through music. The monochrome-wearing dance music enthusiasts that habitually frequent Club Time shows clocked in excited to hear the legendary Soichi Terada perform alongside a lineup of other incredible artists. A large part of the crowd, however, variegated the space by not fitting this archetype. This variance is fun when people – like the middle-aged man I saw getting down in a sparkly fedora – still hold respect for the music, space, and other people attending.

Olin started off with funkier house and proceeded to bust out a versatile set that covered a large swath of house sub-genres with a few brief forays into deep techno. He seemed to navigate the crowd well, transitioning effortlessly between genres and playing something for everyone that had come out. He bumped The Underground by Celeda into the mix, which went over insanely well. As a resident of Chicago institution Smart Bar, Olin is known for such diversified sets. After a wild two and a half hours he eventually ceded to Soichi around 2:40AM.


Soichi Terada crafted a live performance that felt very romantic and nostalgic. His exceptionally youthful energy and excitement radiated through his music and presence. Instead of feeding off of the audience, he seemed to be breathing his own life and freshness into us. Towards the end of his set, he stood up on a chair and danced, waving his arms above his head and smiling with carefree serenity. This was the first stop on his North American tour and his first visit to Los Angeles. Terada has been a mainstay of house music coming out of Japan since the 1980s thanks to his emotionally evocative and soulful sound.

In contrast to the emotional warmth and very human sound from Soichi, Guillaume’s set sounded hard and mechanical, especially in his incorporation of a bit of acid. Olin stepped up in the mix with him a few times and helped diversify. The beats eased up towards 5AM when he played the Florian Kupfer edit of Couldn’t Love You More by Sade, which carried a soothing release as it washed over the room. He closed with Heroes by David Bowie at close to 6AM, when there was still a healthy crowd of partyers going strong.

Fine Time will be partnering with Acid Camp for their next event, taking it outdoors to present Dwig, Steve Mizek, Savile, Tahl K & Aaron Davis.

title: Pro Bowl or No Bowl? // UCLA Radio Sports Op-ed
content:
Written By: JT Osborn, UCLA Radio DJ (02/09/16)

This past Sunday, the annual carnival where the ‘Best of the Best’ in the NFL play against one another occurred and fewer people than ever before can claim to have watched it.

According to Austin Karp of SportsBusiness Daily, the Pro Bowl game garnered a 5.0 overnight rating which is a drop from last year’s 5.6 rating and a huge decline from 2014’s 6.7.

In defense of the NFL, a 5.0 rating is still a damn good rating in this day and age with television becoming more diffused than ever and other outlets like Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime, etc. stealing possible ratings from traditional cable outlets.

But the real question here is, should the Pro Bowl still exist? I mean, according to ESPN.com’s Kevin Seifert more players than ever made the Pro Bowl because a good number of players voted in declined to play.

Rumors are swirling that some of these players are using this as leverage to get the game completely removed according to a BleacherReport article by Mike Freeman.

Ok, so it’s clear that audiences are less inclined to watch than ever and players are less inclined to play than ever, so the game should be removed, right?

As my favorite Jim Carrey character, The Grinch, would say, “Wrong-o”. This league is a business, and even though Roger Goodell claims to remove the Pro Bowl if the quality of play isn’t sufficient, he’s lying. He’ll remove the game when it no longer turns a profit.

And I’m sure the game still does with all of it’s promotions and commercial advertisements—granted, I SWEAR I saw that Alec Baldwin and Dan Marino commercial like 30 times.

And yes, players are turning the game now more than ever before, but a lot of great young talent still came out to play to the game. There are still a majority of players that view this as a reward for their season, or simple competitive fun.

And yeah, audiences are choosing less and less to watch the Pro Bowl against other captivating TV shows like My Diet is Better Than Yours or Kocktails with Khloé. But, the Pro Bowl still gets people like me that will take any kind of football over no football.

So for God’s sake keep the Pro Bowl. It’s not perfect, but what the hell is? Besides, I could watch Richard Sherman try to RKO Clay Matthews all damn day.

title: Young Marco // Show Review (1/16/2016)
content:
Review By: Greta Langenberg, UCLA Radio DJ (02/04/16)

The RSVP e-mail for Young Marco’s six hour set gave an address in an industrial area of downtown which indicated that attendees to look for a U-Haul for further instructions. Upon arrival, we opened the door of our Über and were met by a menacing man wearing all black who asked in a booming voice what we were looking for.

“Uhh, the U-Haul?” I tried.

“No, what are you looking for,” he retaliated.

When I responded “Young Marco,” he gave me a new address and we got back in the Über and drove to the actual warehouse 10 minutes away. Another Über was pulling up at the same time so we followed the other partygoers down an alley and past a large black tarp into the warehouse. The DJ booth had two potted palm plants on either side of it and sported a textured white cloth hanging over the front. White fabric was draped from the ceiling culminating in one central point, under which was hung a disco ball. They had set up a minimal projection out into the crowd and a few lasers pointed at the disco ball. When we arrived around 11:15, Young Marco was just starting to spin.

Marco Sterk, who DJs and produces music under the moniker Young Marco, hails from Amsterdam. He was the only artist to play all night. He has been on the forefront for underground disco and house music for almost a decade. He took us through a sonic journey for an astounding six hours alternating between CDJs and vinyl.

Marco eased the night off with some approachable disco tracks as the room began to fill, which got heads nodding as we eagerly anticipated what was to come. After midnight he set the tone for the evening with his infamous Libyan disco tunes. This era featured slower tempos with vocals bordering on RnB and featuring tribal flutes and Latin Percussion. This progressed into a deep rabbit hole of education from the man, leading the night into a dance filled frenzy of heavy synth, disco influenced, eclectic house with some borderline techno-sounding tracks. Once he had permeated that world, he brought in some crowd favorites including I:CUBE’s Oblivion and St. Elmo’s Theme by Fantastic Man.

The sound system for the night was a Funktion-One setup from the Los Angeles sound system warriors Funkworks. It was an interesting choice to have such an incredible sound system but not have it flexing on a level representative of even half of what it was capable of. For the first three hours of the night there was little to no low end, to the point where I held a conversation with someone two feet away from me at a regular speaking level. At one point all of the tracks were buzzing and highly distorted, but Young Marco’s incredible tune selection kept the audience engaged.

Around 2AM they got a street vendor making food outside which had a constant line of five people deep. Since the venue was relatively small for a warehouse, the outdoor smoking area was packed, which was an ideal environment for socializing with the somewhat bizarre assortment of people who had been drawn to the show. There was a Seth-Rogen looking dude clad in flip flops, basketball shorts, and a grey tee who looked like he’s just rolled out of his dorm room into this underground electronic scene. There was a gay cat donning a leather vest with zippers, tight leans, and flashy monochrome sneakers. A lot of the girls there looked like they had just finished shopping at Melrose trading post. Perhaps the most intriguing character, however, was the large African-american man dressed in all black with flo$$y jewelry posted up in a fold-up chair in the smoking area all night who would occasionally get up to buy more beers to keep underneath his seat.

The lights came on around 5AM and people poured onto the industrial streets, waiting for rides home as the sun came up.

Far Away throws underground parties in Los Angeles and has a monthly radio show on  Gr in addition to being a touring agency, mix series, tape label, and DJ crew. Catch their next event with Mark Sven on February 26th.

title: My Fears // UCLA Radio News Op-ed
content:
Written By: Conner Lund, UCLA Radio News DJ (02/02/16)

During President Obama’s State of the Union address, Obama hinted at the current primary politics of the nation, as the new political atmosphere becomes clearer on who’s in line for the position of President. It seems apparent from pop culture how big of a deal the election cycle is, which will culminate in 2016 yet has been popularized now by candidates such as Donald Trump and the quick surge of Bernie Sanders. In his speech, Obama made comments about certain issues in the election cycle, with undertones that dealt with specific topics Donald Trump said in recent news, specifically regarding an anti-Muslim stance Trump has taken up. Although Obama did a good job at shying away from confronting this issue, Representative Paul Ryan was more than frustrated at the tone Obama used when confronting the issue, claiming that it’s “not what presidents ought to be talking about in State of the Union addresses.“ But why can’t the president discuss the current state of the US political system, if it is such an integral part of not only our reputation domestically but our reputation abroad? How do these issues reflect on the US?

In a world where the US has not only the strongest military but also the strongest cultural influence in the world, how can we justify such statements when our big reputation is on the line? Our culture and society spreads to all reaches of the globe as a leader in creating the cultural climate. In his speech, Obama discussed the entirety of the current state of the world, ranging from climate change to health care. This comment that has been condemned by Paul Ryan, however, holds massive weight in not only affecting the political system here with Donald Trump and the Republican race, but massive weight abroad. How can we claim such cultural superiority when we have a business tycoon making national headlines, claiming absurd things that don’t represent our country accurately? It frightens me that somehow Donald Trump has had a huge effect on our international image, but all for the wrong reasons. Instead of promoting the ideas of honest democracy and open dialogue, a message the US continually tries to spread throughout the world, Trump has systematically destroyed the image of American politics. He has claimed politically incorrect things, has slandered other candidates, and has promoted xenophobia against Muslims, which is one of the leading international issues today with the turmoil in the Middle East. Obama’s speech was, in my mind, meant to discuss where we are in a realist view, not only the good, but also much of the bad and the places to improve. When I see where the US is going, it scares me. It scares me that people like Trump have so much weight in this world. It scares me that we let him have so much weight in this world. It scares me that Paul Ryan didn’t want to address the issue. It scares me more that the world wants this issue addressed. Since the Arab Spring, the US has played an instrumental role, whether for better or worse, in establishing and promoting Democracy and American ideals. But what happens when these core pillars, for which we have tried to build the world on, collapses? What happens when Democracy becomes dependent on money and business? What happens when the ideals and values of candidates degrades; yet the poles reflect the opposite? What worries me is that these issues that all seem to be domestic really have an outward effect on the world. That other countries turn to America for cultural norms and values. All of these issues Obama brought up scare me, and yet what scares me more is that other politicians were scared by his message, not for the sake of the world reputation, but for the sake of their own.

title: Show Review // Cage The Elephant @ The Observatory (1/19/2016)
content:
Review By: Brittany Hewitt, UCLA Radio DJ (1/25/2016)

Photos By: Olivia Lim, UCLA Radio DJ

Sweat beads hit the muddy floor in between swinging bodies as a swell of the latter half of the millennium generation sang along to utterly every word of a 12-set show, including a double encore.

The Observatory – a monumental gem for Orange locals and die-hard fans in L.A. who venture out of the scene to listen to great live shows, hosted Cage the Elephant for a weeknight rowdy shebang #onatuesday.

Lead vocalist Matt Shultz charismatically engaged the audience, giving shout outs to David Bowie and throwing beer into the crowd occasionally to refresh them.

For most of the show, the stage was decked in red: the ambiance, the lighting and the lightning passion in presence.

All of the members were pretty sweaty, looking like they had all won a wet t-shirt contest of beer. This was contrasted by the song “Ain’t No Rest For the Wicked.” The ambiance changed to blue and as the music halted, an acapella rendition was carried out by the audience. Some leaned against walls, and those who were dragged there by their girlfriends even got up for this number.

Cage the Elephant shows are marked by a surreal mosh pit hype, interlaced with angelic moments of harmony.

Monochromatic minimal lighting cocooned the band for the climax of the show when the band payed homage to their older records. Blue lighting formed a grünge opium den, where Matt became the caterpillar from Alice in Wonderland, except instead of puffing Os, he belted uplifting notes up at the sky.

As the set began to close off, the razor sharp white light bars behind Matt set him up for a crashing wave entrance of jumping off the drum set elevation into the crowd. Matt exuberated energy as he whipped his hair back and forth. Organized chaos ensued as Matt ripped off his shirt, threw beer into the audience, and Keyboardist Brad Shultz even began to shake maracas at one point.

“Come a Little Closer” was a communal closing chant. It was a protest. The chant gained momentum as the mosh pit became more and more real, and suddenly everyone was in sync. Psychedelic overlays caressed an audience practically playing a Garage Band set into the purple mood. As Matt stood center stage, hair slick back and shirt off, Cage the Elephant apocalyptically all stood in a line jamming out. This closing number was an invitation to go nuts in reciprocated energy.

Once the music abruptly ended, they all walked off, in sync, like a curtain drop.

The encore chant immediately began and within 90 seconds, the band was back, refreshed and ready to end the night with a snapchat-worthy moment.

The stage lit up in blue and Cage the Elephant ascended as they, in cohoots with the audience, belted “Cigarette Daydreams” and “Shake Me Down.”

It took several minutes for the audience to dehype before exiting the smokey, sticky venue, into the dimly raining and wildly refreshing outdoors – only to rush to their cars and listen to OG Cage the Elephant all the way down the 405.

title: UCLA Radio Sports // “Lou Williams Embraces New Role With Lakers”
content:
Lakers guard Lou Williams has certainly gotten around in his 11-year NBA career.  Ever since being drafted into the league by the Philadelphia 76ers in 2005, Williams has played for four different teams, come back from a stint in the D-League, been a team-leading scorer, seen the playoffs in three different cities, torn an ACL, been referenced in a Drake song, and won a Sixth Man of the Year Award.  And yet somehow, none of Williams’ diverse basketball experiences quite prepared him for the unique venture of being a Los Angeles Laker in 2015-16.

Williams, the second unit extraordinaire, signed a 3-year, $21 million deal over the summer to come to Tinseltown.  Since then, he’s averaged 12.3 points per game, 2.4 rebounds per game, and 2.4 assists per game in 24.9 minutes per game over 14 regular season appearances for the Lakers.  

“We’ve had some ups and downs so far,” said the former McDonald’s All-American after Lakers practice on Thursday, November 19th.  “Obviously we’d like to win more than we have.  But I think we’ve made some positive strides.  For myself, I’m starting to find a rhythm, sort of a pocket for to play in that will work for me.”

The change of scenery has not come with its growing pains, however.  Williams has struggled shooting the basketball with his new team so far, connecting on just 34.8 percent of his attempts from the field and 23.6 percent from three-point range.  Still, he has maintained his confidence and composure and is finding other ways to contribute to the team on nights when his shot isn’t falling, most notably by getting to the line at a high rate (his 5.8 free throw attempts per game with the Lakers mark a career-high).

“I haven’t shot the ball well,” Williams said bluntly. “I was probably just trying to catch the ball and do too much, trying to play outside of my comfort zone. But in Phoenix [a 120-101 loss to the Suns on November 17th in which Williams put up 16 points], I was able to play within my bounds and make shots and find a good rhythm.

“Just gotta continue to be aggressive,” he continued.  “Sometimes, if you’re around this league long enough, during the season, sometimes you’re gonna have stretches where shots aren’t gonna fall and you gotta find other ways to make a positive impact on the court. And getting fouled and being able to get to the line has been one of those outlets for me.

“I’ve shot way worse than I have now. It just comes with the territory when you’re a scorer, you have good runs and you have bad runs.”

Also part of Williams’ learning curve as a new Laker is that he’s being tasked with heavier ball-handling/playmaking duties this season than he’s been used to.  After logging 89 percent of his minutes at the shooting guard position for the Raptors last year, Williams is seeing 59 percent of his minutes for the Lakers at point guard (per Basketball Reference) and is often being relied upon as a primary creator for the second unit.

“It’s been years,” said Williams about his increased handling responsibilities.  “The most ballhandling I do is when I get a rebound or an outlet and just running drag pick-and-rolls but as far as initiating the offense, bringing the ball down, it’s probably been at least five or six years since I’ve done that.

“I’d definitely say it’s been an adjustment with the way our offense is set up,” he went on. “You have scoring opportunities from all five spots on the court with the open style of play that we have so my job is to initiate the offense and at the end of the day, just make plays.”

Another piece of new territory for the 29-year-old Williams with the Lakers this season: he’s being relied on as a mentor for some of the Lakers’ young guards such as D’Angelo Russell, Jordan Clarkson, and Anthony Brown.

“It’s been different,” Williams said.  “It reminds me of my experience when I was in Philadelphia when we had four or five young guys come in at the same time and try to put everything on the fly. It took us about three or four years to kind of start seeing the fruits of our labor.”

But this year’s Lakers have presented a unique challenge for Williams.

“We’re rushing the process here with these guys because we’re like, ‘We need to do it right now. We need to go right now.’ And so it’s been a very different role for me, just trying to get those guys to have the knowledge that I have about the game and just trying to help as much as I can.”

Williams opened up on some of the tidbits of wisdom he’s trying to impart on the team’s youngbloods as well saying, “Just how to come in and compete every day and just understand that this is not a hobby. It’s not something that you do on the weekends. It’s your job and you have to come in and have a professional attitude and that requires to carry yourself in a certain manner and to come in and compete every day in practice and the game.”

The former Naismith Prep Player of the Year went on to praise the young talent that the Lakers have, while also admitting that they still have a lot of work to do.

“I’ve been very impressed with these young guys and how they approach every day,” Williams said. “I think the biggest challenge for us is gonna be to make some of these great practices that we have with them translate into having great games. You come into practice, we have a ton of energy with these guys, they talk they communicate, they’re getting after it, and then in the games, we kinda take a step back because we’re playing against somebody different than the guys that you’re comfortable with. So I think that we have to translate that onto the game floor.”

Williams singled out Russell in particular, who has been under the public microscope for his lackluster rookie season thus far as well as his slow development.  

“[D’Angelo’s] just gotta understand that it’s nine guys on the floor that has the same talent level, if not better, that he has,” said Williams. “In college, you’ll probably have two or three guys on the floor that can really play and you have six or seven guys that are just decent. And up here, it’s gonna be ten guys on the floor that can play, that’s gonna be able to sniff out the no-look passes, that’s gonna be able to sniff out some of the fancy things that you want to do, and you just gotta get adjusted to that.”

Lakers head coach Byron Scott understands that the unfamiliar role he is tasking his new veteran guard with is a difficult one, and appreciates what Williams has brought to the team in the early going.

“He’s the same Lou that I thought we would get,” said Scott also after Thursday’s practice. “Somebody who’s aggressive on the offensive end, who’s done a lot better as a leader than I thought. Been very adamant in the locker room with the younger players and does a pretty good job defensively. And I didn’t think that was the Lou that we were getting.”

Scott acknowledged Williams’ struggles from the field early on though, but recognizes that it comes with the territory of coming to a new team .  

“He hasn’t shot the ball well and that’s something that he’s been real upset about with himself. He’s coming out for the last four, five days getting extra shots, trying to find that rhythm. But I don’t worry about Lou that much. I think any time you go to a new system, it takes time for that to kick in and I think that’s where he is right now.”

Scott also praised Williams’ competitive fire as a vocal leader for the young guards as well as his ability to draw fouls.

“He’s pretty fiery. That’s the one thing I don’t think we all thought about him when he got here. He has a lot of fire. A very competitive guy too. He spoke to the guys when we were in Miami [a 101-88 loss to the Heat on November 10th] and he wasn’t happy about the way we were playing at that time and I think guys responded to it. But that’s the one thing I didn’t think we were getting is a leader. And that’s exactly what I see in him. One of those guys that walks the walk well.

“He doesn’t necessarily have to shoot 45, 50 percent for him to be effective because he does get to the free throw line,” Scott continued.  “He gets there six, seven times a game. And at times, when he’s playing 24, 25 minutes, he can get there in double-digits. He’s one of those guys that knows how to create opportunities for himself and if he’s not shooting well, he can still get numbers up for you.

“That’s an art, the way he draws it as an art form, he draws more fouls from the three-point line than I’ve seen from anybody.”

It’s on Scott however to balance his rotation between the veterans like Williams and the youngsters like Russell and how to deploy them when they do see the court, which are aspects that he is still trying to figure out early in the season.  

“I think the fact that [Lou’s] out there on the court is what he wants to be. It doesn’t matter if he’s handling the ball or if he’s off the ball. But like I said, I’ve made some changes with putting him at that point guard position, especially with the emergence of Metta [World Peace], having him at the 3, and then Nick [Young] at the 2, instead of having Marcelo [Huertas], then him, then Nick. That’s probably why I made the change.

“As a player, you want to play when the game’s on the line. If you got any competitive nature in you at all, you want to play when the game’s on the line,” Scott continued when pressed about his fourth-quarter playing time decisions.  “I know Lou has that and I think D'Angelo has that as well. It’s just a matter of a young guy still learning and understanding what he has to do when he’s out there on a day-to-day basis. So he’s got a couple opportunities, a little further in the season, he’s gonna get a lot more. For me, in the fourth quarter in the last six, seven minutes, it’s whoever is playing the best, that’s who I’m gonna go with.”

For Williams, who largely HAS been getting that nod from Scott in the fourth quarter, his new role with the Lakers is an unfamiliar one, but a welcome one.  He’ll only get better and grow more comfortable as the season goes on and he logs more reps with his new teammates, and hopefully Williams has finally found the home he’s been looking for throughout his NBA career in Los Angeles.  

Words By: Darryn Albert

Photo By: Darryn Albert

title: Album Review // Forth Wanderers - Slop
content:
Written By: Alana Enriquez, UCLA Radio Music 

Post Date: 11/30/16

Forth Wanderers is a New Jersey based five-piece indie rock outfit characterized by its melodic, melancholic reflections on unrequited love, delivered through the smooth vocals of Ms. Ava Trilling. The band formed when the members were in high school and has received national acclaim from various independent media outlets since the release of their debut album Tough Love in 2014. Forth Wanderers has now returned with Slop, a four track EP that sticks to their woeful yet dynamic sound filled with adolescent musings and addictive melodies, but with a newfound confidence and self-awareness that was less present in their initial releases.

The EP’s opening track “Know Better” immediately shifts from its lone catchy guitar riff to the rich voice of Trilling. It’s a fitting start, with musings over the band’s central focus: being caught in a space between adolescence and adulthood, knowing you may not be very great at either. The theme follows into the title track. The same simplistic, yet enthralling instrumentals keep in time with Trilling’s soft, forlorn confessions of instability and naivety - “I love too much to hurt this bad / I laugh too much to be this sad.” The third track “Nerves” introduces itself with a gentle guitar riff, followed by lyrics filled with a sense of defeat reserved for our moments of juvenile turmoil. The EP concludes with “Unfold,” a slow-paced song whose slightly optimistic, accepting attitude contrasts the previous track. Slop ends with a confession of love and reverberations that brings it to a close.

Forth Wanderer’s return to music brings with it not only the angst-filled and poetic troubles of being mature yet naive, but also a fully developed sound that is aware of the message the band hopes to convey. Slop is hopelessly romantic, justifiably dramatic, and painfully relatable, and that’s what makes it so lovely to listen to.

title: Show Review // Red Bull Sound Select: Day 2 With Sunflower Bean
content:
Written By : Casey McNamara, UCLA Radio DJ

Photos By: Carlo Cruz, Red Bull Sound Select Content Pool

Post Date : 11/10/16

Sunflower Bean played to an eager crowd at the Roxy on Day Two of the Red Bull Sound Select 30 Days in LA music festival. The Brooklyn psych rock outfit returned to the Sunset Strip almost a year to the day after they opened for DIIV on a string of fall tour dates. These days, Sunflower Bean are headlining a national tour and basking in the critical adoration garnered by their debut record for Fat Possum, Human Ceremony. In the relatively intimate space of the Roxy, the audience was palpably transfixed by their unique blend of classic rock bombast and modern indie, listening intently and only starting to move towards the end of the show, when lead guitarist Nick Kivlen hopped off the stage and into the crowd. 

The trio have a formidable sound live, managing to give off a more muscular vibe than one might expect from their record. In fact, almost everything about the band is magnified in person. Lead singer and bass guitarist Julia Cummings’ voice is unusually dynamic. In her higher register, she sounds ethereal and detached, and in her lower register, raw and emotive. Guitarist Nick Kivlen occasionally sings too, in a punk-rock tone that matches Cummings’ intensity. They opened with the mid-tempo title track from their album, “Human Ceremony,” which had lyrics that echoed the stage dynamic, with Kivlen interjecting from the other side of the stage, “In your right hand, theres a potion…” Dressed in bell bottoms and a button-up shirt with ruffles, he resembled a young Bob Dylan in person, and played an intricate solo on closing song, “Space Exploration Disaster”. Cummings kept the stage banter to a minimum, but she expressed how grateful they were to be there and also spoke from the heart about her love of Red Bull™, which was brought out on the stage during the performance and thrown into the crowd. 

The set was comprised mostly of songs from their debut, but “Tame Impala” and “Somebody Call A Doctor” were highlights from their 2015 EP Show Me Your Seven Seasons. For the encore, the band played lead single, “Easier Said”, which has jangly guitar lines and lovelorn lyrics that remind me of the Cranberries in the best way possible. Before leaving the stage, Kivlen reminded the crowd that on the following day, the band would be the first live concert streamed on MTV in over ten years. Sunflower Bean are the perfect example of the reason why live rock music is just as popular as ever. Even if they weren’t breaking new ground, they gave the audience a blissed out break from the real world.

title: Album Review // Nicolas Jaar - Sirens
content:
Written By : Dylan Karlsson, UCLA Radio Digital Press

Post Date : 11/02/16

Nicolas Jaar was just 21 when he released his debut album Space Is Only Noise, showing he had an impressive ability to cohere a host of influences without sounding singular. The haunted voices which worked in tandem with a minimal house style seemed to change with each track, as if never coming from a single source.

Since Space Is Only Noise, Jaar has worked through the use of networks and fragmentary bouts of output. He’s worked with Dave Harrington on the collaborative project Darkside, created a score for the avant-garde, Soviet film The Colour of Pomegranates, and dropped intermittent tracks which now assemble the proper Nymphs LP. On top of all this, Jaar’s assembled a collective of artists through his label Other People, and debuted Sirens through their own online radio system with a series of streams to choose from.

Now, Sirens comes to us through this context of network-building, as the third in a series of records after Pomegranates and Nymphs. One can see Sirens as a culmination of Jaar’s recent releases, as each becomes increasingly structured and rigorous in terms of craft. Jaar presents 5 wholly fleshed out songs (with the exception of “Leaves” which works as an ambient interlude), which effortlessly code-switch between genre, language and sonic palette. 

“Killing Time” bursts with fluid, piano glissandos and breaking glass, simultaneously evoking violence and beauty. The song segues into a contemplative exploration of racial prejudice, using the story of Ahmed Mohamed, who in 2015 was arrested for bringing a self-made clock to school, because authorities erroneously thought it was a bomb. Jaar presents Ahmed’s creation as an act of self-preservation: “He was just building his own sense of time.”

What follows are songs that span genres, dipping into the histories of rock’n’roll, R&B and punk. In “No,” Jaar sings in Spanish over a lilting reggaeton beat, recalling the 1988 Chilean referendum which asked citizens if US-backed dictator Augusto Pinochet should return to power for the next 8 years. The response was a simple and effective no, from the people to the government. Jaar carries this message of resistance and reclamation throughout Sirens.

The final track, “History Lesson,” tenderly and honestly addresses the western, imperialist narrative of history, and revises it in the form of a history book’s table of contents. “Chapter one: we fucked up.” In a similar mode of revision, the cover of Sirens features an image a billboard in Times Square which shows geographical USA with the words “This Is Not America.” This image comes from A Logo for America, an installation created by Chilean-born artist Alfredo Jaar, Nicolas’ father. The use of his father’s artwork ties together the networks of genre, history and community Jaar is crafting and re-crafting. Sirens shows Jaar’s ability to look beyond the dominating narrative, and instead carves out space for a new narrative through genre.

Nicolas Jaar recently played at the Fonda Theatre on October 26th and 27th.

title: Show Review: The Head and the Heart @ The Greek (10/7/16)
content:
Written By : Annie Rimmon, Comedy Director

Post Date: 10/20/16

For me, The Head and the Heart has always meant one song. Rivers and Roads. The acoustic anthem perfectly encapsulates that feeling you get whenever you move on from a place that you call home. I sang my heart out to it driving home from camp last summer which was my last year as a counselor. I played it as the wheels of a plane lifted off the ground in Florence as I left to come back to L.A. after studying abroad there for four months. It’s nostalgic. It pinpoints that pain and inevitable feeling of moving on. I expected this vibe of remembrance and hurting going into The Greek last Friday for The Head and the Heart’s concert, but yet got something completely different.
The band has come a long way since their self-titled album and their more recent 2013 album, Let’s Be Still. After the tour for that album, in 2014, the band decided to take a break. Each of the band members went in their own direction. Kenny Hensley (pianist) took kung-fu lessons in China. Chris Zasche (bassist) camped in the Canadian Rockies. Tyler Williams (drummer) lived in Richmond, Virginia to engage in the music scene there. Charity Rose Thielen (vocalist) spent a lot of time writing songs. And main vocalist Jonathan Russell worked with the non-profit Artists for Peace and Justice in Haiti.

They all came back together bursting with different life experiences and thoughts about the world and put together their newest album, Signs of Light which is also the title of the tour. The songs off this album and their words in between songs during the concert clearly demonstrate that they’ve moved on from Rivers and Roads. They are no longer nostalgic, but rather excited about the present moment and where their lives have brought them today. They are fully accepting and relishing in their new lives in a place that may not be their original home, but a place they’ve learned to call home, Los Angeles. Jonathan Russell expressed this in his opening monologue. He said it was so great to be back in Los Angeles which they now consider to be like a “second home” which perfectly lead into their new song “City of Angels”. The lyrics “I know where my heart should be” show that there’s a confidence in their new place. This is very different from their song “Down in the Valley” which lyrics say “California, Oklahoma, and all those places I’ve never been to”.

The concert proved that The Head and the Heart is transitioning from a little indie band to a major record label L.A. group. This could even be seen in Russell’s clothing. The band usually dresses pretty casually, but this evening Russell sported a fancy leather jacket and an ascot, which he thanked the crowd for giving him a pass for wearing.

While the band has moved leaps forward, they still recognized that maybe their audience hasn’t been moving as fast to keep up with them. So as the show was coming to a close, people began shouting for the song which I had come to see them for. Russell smiled and coyly said “Fear not Los Angeles, you will have your Rivers and Roads.” And for the last song of the evening, the audience of the Greek sang and cried in unison “rivers and roads, rivers and roads, rivers till I reach you” as the neon sign which read “Signs of Light” glowed on stage, reminding us that you can be nostalgic about the past while being optimistic about the present day.
